NEW DELHI, India, May 10 (AP) -- A commu: WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Power of the Federal Communications Commission to regulate the major broadcasting chains in the public interest was upheld by the Supreme Court today in a five-to-two decision ending a five-year battle by the National Broadcasting Company and Columbia Broadcasting System against commission rules.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Exports from the United States in March reached a value of $931,000,000, the highest monthly total in history, the Department of Commerce reported today. It compared with the previous high of $928,000,000 in June, 1919, and represents an increase of 33 per cent over the February total.

The State of Minnesota announces that it will offer for sale on June 2 a new issue of $2,700,000 of rural credit deficiency fund certificates of indebtedness. The issue will be dated July 1, 1943, and will mature semi-annually from July 1, 1951, to Jan. 1, 1953, but will become callable on July 1, 1946.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 11 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler, moving frantically to bolster the defenses of Axis Europe on the heels of the collapse of his Tunisian armies, has picked two of his highest lieutenants to take over the defense of Italy, the Russian radio reported today.

The Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad Company reduced its funded debt and equipment last year by $20,812,619, according to Ralph Budd, president, in the company's pamphlet report for 1942. At the year-end the road's long-term debt outstanding in the hands of the public amounted to $217,401,000.

An utter disregard for precious shoe leather was shown by the big majority of the 13,972 turf fans who trekked through the Belmont Park track gates yesterday for the inaugural program of the Westchester Racing Association's twenty-four-day Spring meeting.

Fur manufacturers would be justified in going on a buyers' strike against high prices on raw furs and may have to do so for their own self-preservation, Edward Fillmore, counsel of the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Administration forces mapped strategy to head off 100 per cent abatement of a year's taxes today when the Senate Finance Committee reported out the Ruml-Carlson pay-as-you-go bill by a vote of 13 to 8.

The procedure which cotton goods converters must follow before releasing their civilian inventories of eighty-square four-yard printcloths, which were "frozen" by the WPB as of May 6, was made known yesterday by the priorities section of the agency's regional office.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first i three months of this year, released yesterday by A: N. Wfiliams, president, shows a net income of $1,233,465 after all expenses and charges, compared with a net of 151,313,570 in the March quarter a year ago.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -The indicated yield of Winter wheat is nearly 8 per cent less than was forecast a month ago, the Department of Agriculture said today in a report showing crop prospects generally were not so promising as those of 1942.

The most interesting point about the trial peace balloon that General Franco sent up yesterday is its incidental revelation that the Spanish dictator has considerably modified his views about the way the war is going. He is now convinced that it has reached a deadlock in which neither side has the power to destroy the other.

"We can prove we are not just a luxury organization," Mrs. Lee Laird, delegate to the twenty-third annual meeting of the Association of the Junior Leagues of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, said yesterday in an interview.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 11 -- Russian planes carried their biggest aerial offensive of the war into the second day yesterday by blasting eleven more key rail centers behind Nazi lines, and Moscow announced that anti-aircraft defenses had shot down forty-three of 200 German planes that attempted an assault on the Rostov-Bataisk gateway to the Caucasus.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 10 -- Willie Klein, veteran Wheatley Hills pro who has many links laurels to his credit, today teamed successfully with Ed New, Hempstead amateur, to win the first one-day tournament of the Long Island P.G.A., producing a 71 on his own ball over the Garden City Country Club course.

Lord Halifax probably will not mind our saying that after he had sent out advance copies of the speech he delivered in Chicago last night he had to follow with corrections. The news in a few hours had outrun his expectations, as indeed it did every one's.

ALGIERS, May 10 (AP) -- General Henri Giraud, opening a French war loan drive, offered the French in North Africa today an opportunity to stake their money on the future of France. The bonds will pay 3 per cent and mature in three years. They are in denominations of 1,000 francs upward.

LONDON, May 10 -- America's heaviest single-motored fighter, the Republic Thunderbolt, or P-47, is now in action against the Nazis, it was officially announced today, after a rather puzzling delay while several operational "bugs" seriously concerned the Fighter Command of the United States Eighth Air Force, headed by Brig. Gen. Frank O. Hunter.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- A Congressional committee recommended today that the War Production Board take steps to prevent "waste and non-essential use" of paper by the Federal Government and that the War Manpower Commission designate the paper production industry as an essential war industry.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that a grand total of $18,533,000,000 in securities was sold in the second war loan drive, $5,533,000,000 more than was originally sought in the greatest government financing campaign in history.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Grocers' profit margins on cabbage, onions, some poultry and salt codfish were reduced today by the Office of Price Administration, which at the same time fixed a top limit of twenty-five pounds of sugar per person for home canning and freezing of this year's crops. This is higher than last year's allowance.

Although business of the Packard Motor Car Company in the March quarter this year was nearly two and a half times the volume of the first three months of last year, earnings were only about 7 per cent better because of increased taxes, according to the company's statement issued for release today.

Several changes in the executive organization of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., were announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of the store. Wheelock H. Bingham, executive vice president in charge of men's wear, children's wear, domestics and fabrics, has received a military leave of absence to accept a commission in the United States Navy.
Directors of the United Aircraft Corporation declared a dividend yesterday of $1.50 a share on the common stock. Last year stockholders received $1 in June and $2 in December.

The prospects of the domestic Winter wheat crop deteriorated rather sharply in April. The United States Department of Agriculture forecast yesterday the yield from this year's Winter wheat crop, based on May 1 conditions, at 515,159,000 bushels, compared with 558,551,000 as of April 1 and a harvest of 703,253,000 from the 1942 crop.

ONCE upon a time a brilliant race of logicians lived in the middle of a continent. The brightest of the logicians decided that it would be logical to enslave the world -- for then the logicians would demonstrably have everybody working for them. Accordingly, the master logician created a party to monopolize the government of Logiciana.

Determined to keep their sales organizations intact for the postwar period, four large furniture manufacturers have arranged to maintain all salesmen who were employed prior to Pearl Harbor, it was announced yesterday by the National Wholesale Furniture Salesmen's Association.

Mrs. Payne Whitney, mistress of the Greentree Stable and known as the "first lady of the American turf," captured the fiftieth running of the Toboggan Handicap with Devil Diver as Belmont Park opened its Spring meeting yesterday under the exigencies of war and the transportation stringency.
"They Came to Blow Up America." the Twentieth Century-Fox film originally scheduled to open at the Globe on Thursday, will open instead on Friday, the management reported yesterday. . . . "

ONCE upon a time a brilliant race of logicians lived in the middle of a continent. The brightest of the logicians decided that it would be logical to enslave the world -- for then the logicians would demonstrably have everybody working for them. Accordingly, the master logician created a party to monopolize the government of Logiciana.

Horse racing and its relation to the war will be discussed during the two-day session of the National Association of State Racing Commissioners opening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel today, The Associated Press reports.

Ernst Levy, Swiss pianist, composer, musicologist, pedagogue and historian, played a formidable program last night in Town Hall. No doubt it was in part his seriousness as a scholar that dictated Mr. Levy's choice of compositions. Did he, perhaps, also cherish the pleasing conviction that he could make even such a program engrossing and exciting through the exercise of peculiar musical powers?

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 10 -- Jack Benny has been signed by Warners for the lead in the comedy-fantasy, "The Horn Blows at Midnight," to be produced by Mark Hellinger. The story deals with the comic experiences in New York of a cornet player from a celestial orchestra.
MOSCOW, May 10 -- Yesterday's All-Slav Committee meeting at the Trade Union Hall was the first big Moscow gathering that correspondents attended where one felt real good-will toward the Allies.

MONTREAL, May 10 (Canadian Press) -- Hugh East, veteran right-hander of the Jersey City Little Giants, shut out the Montreal Royals today as his team won, 1 -- 0. East allowed five scattered hits and did not give a base on balls. He struck out nine.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- The grain trade got a surprise today in a Department of Agriculture report suggesting the smallest Winter wheat yield since 1935 and rye since 1936. The figures were well below private estimates, and brokers said the returns suggested that drought conditions that prevailed during the latter half of April were more severe than had been expected.

I agree in toto with the letter signed "Warden" concerning the indifference of the general public to the practice air raid drill on the night of May 4. These wardens, fortunately for us, take their work seriously. A zone warden in my neighborhood works hard all day at his own office and gives hours of his time at night in trying to make this particular zone safe for us in the event of a raid.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) -- Representative Manasco of Alabama, said today that sponsors of the anti-poll tax bill "have as their purpose the destruction of the Democratic party in the South.

Although reports from New Brunswick and Maine are apt to add to the fisherman's wanderlust, nevertheless metropolitan salt water fishermen are taking advantage of every opportunity to try their luck in neighboring bays these days, as well as in Long Island Sound.

As the local Office of Price Administration pressed its drive against price ceiling violators, Magistrate Samuel Orr in Yorkville Court continued until tomorrow disposition of three cases brought before him under the new amendment to the State War Emergency Act.

CHICAGO, May 10 -- Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, asserted here today that the war had passed a turning point and that this time the United Nations could not allow the spirit of cooperation, the unity of effort and sacrifice and the comradeship they had achieved on the battlefields of war to wither and die with the coming peace.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Administration supporters attempted today to throw up an impenetrable line of defense against anticipated attempts to restrict the reciprocal trade agreements program to the extent that in their opinion it would be worthless.

Opposition to the proposed change to a point-rationing system for shoes was voiced here yesterday by A.B. Cohen, vice president and general manager of the United States Shoe Corporation of Cincinnati, who declared it would be unfair to abandon the present coupon method, in effect since Feb. 10, until it had received a fair trial.

The two twelve-story apartment houses at 310 and 320 West Eighty-sixth Street, beween Riverside Drive and West End Avenue, have been purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from the Greenwich Savings Bank.

Culmination and odyssey are, both of them, susceptible of shades of meaning. President Roosevelt's congratulations on the Tunisian victory were naturally addressed to General Eisenhower, but overlooked none of his chief lieutenants.

No question in law is more important or more stimulating than that of the limits of constitutional rights. If any one of such rights is indefinitely expanded it sooner or later results in trespass on some other right. To take a familiar example, the man who cries fire in a crowded theatre has carried the right of free speech beyond its proper boundaries.

CHUNGKING, China, May 10 (AP) -- At least sixteen Japanese planes were destroyed by American airmen in a fifteen-minute running battle during the shattering raid on Canton Saturday, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 10 -- It is now possible to outline in some detail the dispositions of the Allied troops for the final stages of the Tunisian campaign, which were entered when four divisions of the Eighth Army hit the hills north of Enfidaville along a thirty-three mile line on April 20.

There is something which I do not understand about accounts of a great shortage of physicians throughout our country, nor do I understand the objections voiced by some of your correspondents regarding restrictive measures and proposals.

POTSDAM, N.Y., May 10 -- The last of the famous floating islands in the Racquette River in the Northern Adirondack foothills near Colton today went over the Higley Falls power dam of the Central New York Power Corporation.

TUNIS, May 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- Liberated Tunis is a hysterically happy city today and none here are happier than American soldiers who, as prisoners of war, were ready to be transported to Italy when British armored forces burst into the capital and Axis troops fled.

Never was a Congressional Medal more nobly earned than that given after his death to Commander Howard W. Gilmore. He was experienced and successful in undersea warfare. He had won the Gold Star and the Navy Cross, but the day of his final discharge was his most glorious.

The outlook for Peconic Bay fishing has been considerably changed with the OPA gasoline ration which puts the guiding of fishing parties or the chartering of boats for fishing in the non-occupational class and makes no provision for such craft to obtain gasoline.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Roosevelt refused to accept today the resignation of Abe Fortas, Under-Secretary of the Interior, who is of draft age, on the ground that he could serve the country better in his present post.

A nation-wide investment banking group will offer today to the public 242,664 shares of common stock of the Houston Lighting and Power Company at $54 each. Smith, Barney Co., Lazard Freres Co. and Blyth Co., Inc., will head sixty-nine investment banking firms in the offering, which will divest completely the Houston property from the Electric Bond and Share Company system.

An interesting observation on the operation of the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act is afforded in the deal which today will separate the Houston Lighting and Power Company from the National Power and Light Company system.
LONDON, Wednesdy, May 12 -- German planes, striking at East Anglia for the second time in twenty-four hours, dropped incendiary bombs on a coastal town early today.

George A. Eastwood, president of Armour Co. of Delaware, said in a letter to stockholders yesterday that the company's registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed issue of $35,000,000 of thirty-five-year 7 per cent income debentures was expected to become effective about May 19.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At Loew's Criterion the new attraction will be "The Desperadoes," a Columbia Western drama starring Randolph Scott, Glenn Ford, Claire Trevor, Evelyn Keyes and Edgar Buchanan.

A declaration by the Right Rev. William T. Manning opposing the proposal to unite the Protestant Episcopal Church "with one of the several separate Presbyterian churches in the United States" was greeted with applause and cries of "Hear! Hear!"

The formal opening tonight of the Garden of the Ambassador for its late Spring and Summer season will be the occasion for many dinners and supper parties given by persons actively interested in the work of Dogs for Defense, Inc., the organization which will benefit from the opening fete.

Drivers of cars from out-of-town who park near amusement places will be called upon to explain to New York City police how they are able to do so much traveling on the gasoline rations issued to them by the Office of Price Administration, it was disclosed yesterday when the text of instructions sent to all police commands by Commissioner Valentine were made public.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The first of twenty-three new short wave radio transmitters, which are expected to place the United States "in the same league" with Germany in broadcasting power, will be delivered this Summer for use by the stations leased by the government last Autumn and used by the Office of War Information.

Sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended with January were the largest in the history of the Allied Stores Corporation, which operates the largest department store chain in the country, according to the annual report of B. Earl Puckett, president, released for publication today.

LONDON, May 11 -- This country, usually regarded as that most addicted to tradition, lived up to one of its more recent ones tonight when it opened at Bristol the first State Theatre in British history and thereby maintained the wartime tradition that precedents are made to be broken.

Postmaster Albert Goldman, in accordance with instructions issued last week by Postmaster General Frank C. Walker, placed the New York Postoffice area yesterday on the new key number system of addressing mail. This system, while seemingly complicated, merely adds a numeral after the name of the community and before the name of the State to indicate the delivery district of the addressee.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill arrived in Washington late today for conferences with President Roosevelt relative to preparations for a second front in Europe and other offensive actions against the Axis around the world.

FORT KNOX, Ky., May 11 -- Convinced of the correctness of their tactical doctrines and the excellence of their equipment -- "now as good as the best" -- officers of the hard-hitting armored force headquartered here are driving themselves consciously to removing the obstacles which they freely admit have hitherto prevented the fullest adaptation of this theory and equipment in battle.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The power of the Axis has been finally broken in North Africa American and British chiefs of staff are discussing the strategical stroke that will follow. Nobody can foretell which European area or areas they will select. But this, at least, can be said: The Italian people now feel that Italy lies exposed to air attacks on a scale not yet witnessed in the present war, except perhaps in Malta.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Bank debits as reported by banks in 274 leading centers for the month of April aggregated 70,137 million dollars. During the past three months total debits for the same centers amounted to $184,238,000,000, or 34 per cent above the total reported for the corresponding period a year ago.

The greatest concern of Frank Wright, 35-year-old blind man, of 46 West 120th Street, after he was struck and injured yesterday by a taxicab, seemed to be for Lassie, his dog, which he had trained to guide him.

New issues of temporary loan notes, aggregating $9,243,000, will be offered for sale on May 26 by fifteen local Housing Authorities in various parts of the country. All of the issues will be dated June 16, 1943. The issues, which range in size from $1,360,000 to $100,000, are to be bid for separately.

DENVER, May 11 -- Streets of Cody and Powell in Wyoming, towns nearest to the Heart Mountain Japanese relocation center, were empty of Japanese today for the first time in months, the result of petitions by the town councils to Guy Robertson, camp director, to forbid their appearance in the towns unless accompanied by military escort.

CHUCK DRESSEN had singled and was parked on first base, not watching Walter Christensen, the next hitter, but peering with his sharp eyes at John McGraw in the Giant dugout. The Little Napoleon gave his wrist an almost imperceptible twist. Dressen signaled to his Cincinnati teammate that a curve was on its way and the forewarned Christensen hit solidly to right for the run which won the game.

Because of the war, camp life this Summer for vacationing youngsters will include training in the pioneer virtues of simplicity and do-it-yourself. But, far from discouraging young holiday makers, this hardy state of affairs is attracting them in numbers that camp directors estimate as record-breaking.

The twelve-story and penthouse apartment building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street, known as 1070 Fifth Avenue and 1 East Eighty-eighth Street, has been sold by the Bankers Trust Company to an investing client of Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers, who will continue to manage the property.

Walter Hoving, chairman of the Executive Committee to Balance the Budget Through Sensible Economies, is flogging the wrong culprit. He predicts the bankruptcy of the city's business if Mayor La Guardia's realty tax of 2.94 is adopted. If a 15-point increase in the tax rate is fraught with such dire consequences, then a 100-point increase in mortgage payments at this critical time is a far greater cause for alarm.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Senators and Puerto Rican witnesses exchanged angry words today in a six-hour hearing on the Tydings bill for Puerto Rican independence, during which the measure was both condemned and compared to the Magna Carta and Bill of Rights.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Democratic House leaders, seeking to beat down a drive to place restrictions on further extension of the administration's reciprocal trade treaty program, viewed their chances as improved after disclosure today of the "personal" belief of Harrison E. Spangler, Republican National Chairman, that the treaties should not be interfered with "during the war and for some time thereafter."

CHUNGKING, China, May 11 (U.P.)-- Japanese columns attacking Chinese units along the shores of Lake Tungting are preparing to use poison gas to overcome strong Chinese resistance, a Chinese military spokesman said today. He said the Japanese forces in China had used gas "more than 800 times that we know of."

LONDON, May 11 -- The French Radical Socialist party, a middle-of-the-road peasant group whose support has often been crucial in the turbulent history of French Cabinets, has emerged and now shares resistent and de Gaullist tendencies with the more Leftist parties whose supporters are largely urban, according to Henri Queuille.

The possibility that the City Council would ask Governor Thomas E. Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature to vote additional taxing powers for the city to meet the $753,071,123 executive budget for the coming year was dimmed yesterday when the Council adjourned until May 21, the last day on which it can act on the fiscal program.

A farmer's wife who Friday night sold fourteen chickens from her parked car at Eighty-sixth Street and Second Avenue received a suspended sentence from Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran in Yorkville Court yesterday, after he had noted that she was "selling not at black market prices but at white market prices."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 11 -- Oscar Wilde's story, "The Canterville Ghost," which has been on and off the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer production schedule several times in the last four years, has again been revived and, according to the studio, will go before cameras this Summer with Charles Laughton starred.
Hundreds of New York City food merchants are refusing to handle poultry and fish under conditions established by Office of Price Administration regulations, it was learned yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, May 11 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 11 -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare has rejected all schemes for supplying food to Europe, with the exception of Greece, Dingle M. Foot, the Ministry's Parliamentary secretary, said in London today.

A group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., won yesterday the award of $5,300,000 of one-to-ten-year equipment trust certificates of the New York Central Railroad on a bid of 99.279 for a 2 per cent coupon rate.

TUNIS, May 9 (Delayed) (AP) -- French troops of General Henri Honore Giraud marched into Tunis today and received an enthusiastic welcome from civilians who only two days ago were under German oppression.

BRITISH FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Tunisia, May 10 (Delayed)--Strong tank and infantry formations of the British First Army cut down behind the Axis forces facing the British Eighth Army and continued to mop up the enemy positions at the base of the Cap Bon Peninsula today as the campaign in Tunisia moved rapidly toward its close.

"Speedometeritis," which an official of the enforcement division of the OPA described here yesterday as turning back automobile mileage readings or disconnecting the speedometer to conceal excess mileage when applying for supplemental rations, has become almost epidemic in this section.
The many friends of Tony the cab driver, whose full name was Antonio Vedella, mourned yesterday on hearing of his death.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- The Yankees' first appearance of 1943 in the Middle West ran against a snag today. Unfavorable weather prevented a scheduled exhibition against the Milwaukee club of the American Association in Milwaukee.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Office of War Information likes blondes but doesn't need any of their hair. An avalanche of parcels containing everything from single strands to sizable hanks followed a report that OWI wanted long blonde tresses for war production purposes.

A sound national program of public works, which might provide half of the annual $15,000,000,000 outlay for public and private building and construction necessary for the industry to maintain full post-war employment, was advocated yesterday by Major Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, in an address before the weekly luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

With virtually all old potatoes going to the armed service, dehydrators and institutional users, and with their over-all supplies cut to one-third of normal for this season, New York distributors indicated yesterday that metropolitan housewives might wisely plan to continue using noodles and spaghetti as menu items until around June 1 at the earliest, with supplies after that depending on breaks in the weather over southern producing areas.
STOCKHOLM, May 11 -- Gunder Haegg, the Swedish distance star, sailed from Goteborg today aboard the tanker Saturnus en route to the United States and a series of races with American distance runners.

HEADQUARTERS, ARMY AIR FORCES SCHOOL OF APPLIED TACTICS, Orlando, Fla., May 11 -- The Army Air Forces lifted the lid today on AAFSAT, a completed, advanced school for air combat leaders, said to be the only establishment of its kind in the world.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- The Tokyo radio reported today that Japanese forces in Western Burma had advanced to a point twelve miles from the Indian border and were "mopping up enemy remnants still on the eastern side of the frontier."
In spite of repeated warnings in the newspapers about the fire danger due to smoking in motion picture houses, more and more men and women insist on smoking in all parts of the theatres.

More shortcomings in Japan's military aviation program, already the cause of a major shake-up in the Japanese Army air department, were reported yesterday in a Tokyo radio address by a high Army official, who said that the Japanese air force was "inferior in technical knowledge" to Allied air units.

Widening the scope of religious education for greater benefits to the individual and community was advocated yesterday by leaders in this field at a meeting held under the auspices of the Religious Education Association at Riverside Church.

OTTAWA, May 11 -- Canada has allocated to Britain $689,000,000 worth of munitions and $311,000,000 worth of foodstuffs and raw materials under the "gift to Britain" arrangement made last year, but actual shipments have reached $1,440,000,000, Finance Minister J.L. Ilsley told the House of Commons today.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,724, as against 1,428 in the preceding week and 604 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 896, which compared with 740 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Brushing aside the protests of organized labor and holding that the Senate-adopted Connally bill was inadequate for strike control in time of war, the House Military Affairs Committee, in executive session, completely rewrote that legislation today, converting it into a measure directed more at punishment for strikers, their leaders and their unions than at government seizures of property.

After developing moderate strength in early dealings, cotton prices on the New York Cotton Exchange eased yesterday on hedge selling and a limited volume of liquidation to close at net losses of 2 to 4 points. A tendency on the part of the trade to await further developments in the cotton price control program continues to dominate the market.

Latin-American countries have recently been accumulating dollar credits at such a rate that, if the trend continues and no artificial trade barriers are erected, they may be able to support a gold standard in the post-war period and finance their own developments without borrowing from the United States, James S. Carson, chairman of the foreign trade education committee of the National Foreign Trade Council, declared yesterday.

Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt visited yesterday the Andrew Fureseth Club of the United Seamen's Service, 30 East Thirty-seventh Street, and saw a request of hers amply fulfilled. A large canteen, in the club basement, was going full swing under the auspices of the American Women's Voluntary Services, to whom Mrs. Roosevelt had appealed for just such a service.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (U.P.) -- The War Production Board said today that conversion of prison industries to war work has reaped a harvest of essential supplies.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 11 -- Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel appeared in Crete in mid-April to confer with General Harter, commanding the German division there, according to reports reaching Cairo. This tallies with other reports that Marshal Rommel has assumed command of Axis defenses in the Balkans.

The Brooklyn Federal Grand Jury handed up an indictment yesterday charging two borough baking companies, two officials of the companies, and two officers of an American Federation of Labor local of conspiring to deprive employes of the companies of their rights under the Fair Labor Standards Act (the Wages and Hours Law). If convicted, the defendants may receive a ten-year prison term and fines of $5,000.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) -- Award of cash prizes totaling $1,100 to three artists was announced today on the eve of the opening of the twenty-second international exhibition of water-colors at the Art Institute of Chicago.

BOSTON, May 11 -- A.F. Plock's Woodford Lad, claimed for $3,250 last December in Florida, returned his second winning dividend today as he took the Swampscott Purse, a $1,500 allowance mile race at Suffolk Downs.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The President said today he had instructed the War Shipping Administration and the Navy Department to arrive at some uniform method of reckoning marine tonnage for public announcements of construction, sinkings, etc.

More fuel oil and gasoline will be available for home owners and motorists in the East next Winter because of improved regulation of the flow of petroleum products through pipelines, it was reported yesterday at a convention of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he would take a hand in settling the dispute over his "hold the line" executive order of April 8.
The "poor" breeder, who only produces the horses that run the races that make the money for race tracks, finally is getting some attention, The Associated Press reports.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 11 -- A communiqu published by the German High Command tonight said that Field Marshal General Erwin Rommel, commander of the defeated African troops, had been on leave in Germany for the past two months because of ill health.

Prospect of an agreement between the United Mine Workers and anthracite operators before expiration of the fifteen-day truce under which the entire coal industry is now operating appeared yesterday, together with a possibility that the threatened resumption of the recent coal stoppage upon expiration of the truce may be averted in both the anthracite and bituminous fields.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Income payments to individuals totaled $11,211,000,000 in March, compared with $10,443,000,000 in February and $8,796,000,000 in March, 1942, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, reported today.

Salesmanship that brought close to $2,000,000 for war bonds and stamps postponed yesterday the scheduled closing today of a shop at 333 Seventh Avenue operated under the auspices of the War Emergency Board of the Fur Industry for workers in the fur district.

Sales of leading chains and mail-order companies increased 5.4 per cent in April, according to a compilation made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The percentage gain, reflecting the Easter trade rise, was larger than that reported for March, but was less than half of the increase noted for February.

The executive council of the New York State Federation of Labor reported yesterday that it had named Thomas Murray, for the last seven years head of the Building and Construction Trades Council, to fill the presidency of the federation, vacated by the death of Thomas J. Lyons last Thursday.

The four houses at 4031-33-35-37 Eighteenth Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company, as trustee, to Andrew N. Miller through Samuel Hurwitz, broker. They are two-story buildings, each containing two apartments, with a combined assessed value of $30,000.

WASHINGTON, May 11--President Roosevelt announced today that production of airplanes by the United States now exceeded that of all other nations combined, with emphasis being placed on the four-engined bomber to carry out plans for greater offensives against the Axis.

DETROIT, May 11 -- A shake-up among the higher officers at Selfridge Field was announced today by Julius H. Amberg special assistant to Secretary of War Henry Stimson, who arrived to take charge of the investigation to alleged irregularities at the field.

Sven Wellmer and Arnold R. Hanson, securities brokers, and John W. Hession, former financial columnist, were placed on trial in Federal court yesterday under thirty counts of mail fraud, violation of the Securities Exchange Act and conspiracy.

LONDON, May 11 -- Taking cognizance of the recurrent complaint that Britain is letting post-war civil aviation control pass to the United States by default, Sir Stafford Cripps assured the House of Commons today that the government would do all that it could to expedite the production of all types of commercial planes, but not at the expense of the war effort.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- High-speed passenger travel across the Atlantic by air would be made safer and more practical by the building of three man-made islands in mid-ocean, the Pennsylvania-Central Airlines said today in proposing to establish the first "seadrome" route between this country and Great Britain.

A report urging the re-nomination and re-election of six judges on a non-partisan basis was submitted to the annual meeting of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its headquarters, 42 West Forty-fourth Street, last night, by its committee on the judiciary, of which Alfred A. Cook is chairman.

The City Council voted yesterday to meet on May 25 at 11 A.M. to organize for the task of drawing Assembly district lines within the city under the reapportionment bill enacted at the last session in the State Legislature.

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Bullish enthusiasm in the grain markets evaporated soon after the opening today on the Board of Trade. An early bulge due to a bullish construction placed on a Department of Agriculture estimate of the Winter wheat and rye crop, issued late yesterday, lifted wheat around 1 cent and rye 1 1/2 cents, but heavy profit-taking and considerable professional selling developed immediately, and late in the session stop-loss orders were uncovered.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The Bristol-Myers Company of Hillside, N.J., may represent its product Sal Hepatica as a "competent laxative" but not as an "effective treatment for colds," the Federal Trade Commission has ruled.
GUTTENBERG, N.J., May 11 (AP) -- Theodore Engelhardt, president of the Jersey City-Lyndhurst Bus Company, said tonight a strike by the company's bus drivers had halted service on its three lines.

The British radio announced last night that a British West Indian detachment had embarked for little Dominica Island, a British possession that lies between Martinique and Guadeloupe in the French West Indies.

Although supplies of pepper now in this country are enough to meet the estimated requirements for the next three years, the movement of stocks into normal trade channels has been "frozen" because of the inadequacy of present price ceilings on the commodity, it was charged yesterday by speakers at the opening sessions of the two-day convention of the American Spice Trade Association at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Reversing a previous decision, the National Labor Relations Board, by a two-to-one vote, excluded today foremen and supervisory employes from the protection of the National Labor Relations Act. John M. Houston, recently appointed member, cast the deciding vote, joining Gerard Reilly, who dissented in the Union Collieries case on June 15.

At last the Legislature of New Jersey has passed a bill giving the people the right to decide at the November election whether or not they want a revised State Constitution. Last year the politicians of both parties burked mention of the subject in their party platforms.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- Major Margaret D. Craighill, M. D., former dean of the Women's Medical College in Philadelphia, who is the first woman physician to be commissioned directly in the Army under recently enacted legislation, will report for duty in two or three weeks in the Surgeon General's office.

LONDON, May 11 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in congratulatory messages to General Dwight D. Eisenhower and General Sir Harold Alexander, said today that the simultaneous advance of British and American armies into Tunis and Bizerte "is an augury full of hope for the future of the world."

Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange last month rose to the largest aggregate since the end of June, 1938, according to a compilation released yesterday. The figure was 882,376 shares, against 774,871 at the end of March, neither figure including short positions in the odd-lot accounts of odd-lot dealers.

Dr. Louis G. Small, the notorious abortionist, who fled to Eastman, Ga., last month, forfeiting $12,000 bail, just before the Appellate Division affirmed his conviction in General Sessions on an abortion indictment and three-year sentence to Sing Sing, lost his application yesterday to appeal the Appellate Division's action.

Following the annual ceremonial today in the auditorium of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and the National Institute of Arts and Letters, 632 West 156th Street, an exhibition featuring sculpture by Carl Milles and containing work in various media by other artists will open with a private view in the adjacent gallery.

In order yesterday at Belmont Park, the pay-offs on the first five winners were as follows: $38.70, $13.20, $41.90, $72.10 and $70.70, providing the longest one-day sequence of such big figures that many a veteran could remember. And the daily double returned $666.50 for $2.

Bernard F. Gimbel, president of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., informed stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday that sales for the first three months of the current fiscal year rose 22 per cent over the volume of the corresponding period last year and that earnings showed a decided improvement.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 11 -- British armored forces and troops were advancing far up the coast roads on either side of the Cap Bon Peninsula today after having closed its mouth. Thus far they have taken about 20,000 new prisoners, who are being concentrated near Beni Aichoun, on the south coast.
LONDON, May 11--A feeling that important war developments are imminent checked buying in most sections of the stock markets today and induced profit-taking, notably in home rails and diamond shares.

LONDON, May 11 -- The belief is strongly held in political circles here that Russia figures more prominently in the discussions of the Anglo-American conferees at the White House tonight than any last-minute thoughts about what is to be done with the Tunisian victory.

DETROIT, May 11 -- The hitherto unpublished story of a mental and physical super-hell on Guadalcanal in which our marines fought and lived and hoped and despaired in the days following Aug. 7, 1942, was told today at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 11 (AP) -- A House majority approved today a bill setting up State regulations of labor unions and their membership fees and prohibiting work-permit charges.
The Italian Tuesday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Senate will take up the pay-as-you-go tax problem tomorrow in an atmosphere of uncertainty whether the Finance Committee's bill, following the Ruml plan principle of 100 per cent cancellation of a year's taxes, or an alternative proposal to cancel only 75 per cent of 1942 taxes, will prevail

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 11 -- The notorious pro-Nazi collaborator Pierre Pucheu has arrived in North Africa and General Henri Honore Giraud has ordered him placed under house arrest, it was revealed tonight.

Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and Attorney General Francis Biddle, addressing the Textile Workers Union of America in Carnegie Hall yesterday, deplored labor tactics that hindered war work. Miss Perkins called on labor to be "punctilious" and Mr. Biddle warned that unions should not permit their organizations to be used for "outside and subversive purposes."

At the annual meeting of the Beatrice Creamery Company on June 1 stockholders will be asked to approve an amendment to its certificate of incorporation authorizing issue of 91,317 shares of $4.25 cumulative preferred stock of no par value to effect the retirement of all outstanding 91,317 shares of $5 cumulative preferred stock.
NEW DELHI, India, May 11 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 11 -- Confirmation of recent attempts in France against German and Italian troops of occupation is now available. On the night of April 27-28 two Italian officers were seriously wounded in Nice by unknown assailants.

The Canadian Government has leased space for offices for a consulate general on the fourth and fifth floors in 620 Fifth Avenue, Rockefeller Center. This is understood to be the first consulate general opened by Canada in a foreign country. Its jurisdiction will include New York, Connecticut and part of New Jersey.

Civilians, for the first time, may earn the right to wear an official service bar much like the campaign bars of the armed services, James M. Landis, Civilian Defense Director, announced yesterday. The award will be given to civilian defense volunteers with 500 or more hours of service wherever defense councils adopt the plan.

WITH THE UNITED STATES ARMY IN THE ALEUTIANS, April 29 (Delayed) -- How the commanding general of the Alaskan military theatre was almost caught by the Japanese on American soil at Kiska last June was told today by the most vitally concerned person -- Lieut. Gen. Simon B. Buckner Jr., himself.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The victory of the United Nations in Tunisia will open the Mediterranean to the Allies and the German air force will be unable to keep American and British ships from using that sea, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox said today in noting that this route will reduce the distance for Allied shipping to the Arabian Gulf area by about 5,000 miles.
WASHINGTON, May 11 -- The Office of price Administration today ordered discontinued its policy of providing for adjustable pricing on sales of meat to war procurement agencies, effective May 17.
The City College track team defeated Brooklyn College, 101 -- 25, yesterday at the loser's field in Brooklyn.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 11 -- In a written protest to Premier Vidkun Quisling, the Norwegian Church acted today against the conscription of Norwegian laborers for work on German fortifications.

James J. Hines, former powerful Tammany district leader, failed to win parole yesterday from Sing Sing Prison, where he has been serving a four-to-eight-year term for protecting the policy racket of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer.

BAYONNE, N.J., Wednesday, May 12 -- Early this morning, with sixty-five out of seventy-four election districts in Bayonne counted, following the City Commission election yesterday, it appeared that the forces of Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, Democratic boss of Hudson County, had won a clear-cut victory.

THERE'S something about a novel three or four times as long as the average work of fiction that intimidates, browbeats and impresses. The heavy weight in the hand, the mere sight of all that formidable type, the painful awareness of the author's furious industry, toilsome days and sleepless nights, the evidence of a publisher's confidence -- all these demand respectful consideration.

Though individual German units continue resistance in Tunisia, the outstanding feature of the Allied victory is the quick collapse of German fighting morale once the odds turned and hope of victory was gone. The last smashing blows in Tunis and Bizerte, which clearly demonstrated Allied superiority in men and material, precipitated a process of German dissolution.

Mrs. Elsa Nilsson Foster, widow of Dr. Allyn King Foster Jr., whose death in Bellevue Hospital on Jan. 17, 1942, resulted in an investigation by the District Attorney's office, the Medical Examiner's office and the police, filed an application in Surrogate's Court yesterday for permission to discontinue a suit for damages for alleged negligence and malpractice against officials and employes of the hospital.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 12 -- The Red Army captured a German fortified key position in the violent battle of Novorossiisk yesterday and pounded the Nazi foe in the Caucasus with infantry, artillery and aerial power on a day marked by a continuation of heavy air battles and vigorous activity along the entire front.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- In occupying Tunisia the Allies assume control for the first time of a large Axis population, the Italians living in that French protectorate, the Office of War Information pointed out today in issuing a survey of the numbers and status of Italians there, who retain their nationality.

BERNE, Switzerland, Wednesday, May 12-- Back in Paris after a two-day inspection tour of his "Atlantic wall" defenses, Adolf Hitler late yesterday ousted Col. Gen. Ernst von Schaumburg as commander of the occupation forces in the Paris region and appointed 52-year-old General von Beulenburg-Wehrfeldt as commander of all forces in the "northwestern region," according to a Berlin announcement received here early today.

A handsome new shop and a lot of new ideas were revealed with the opening yesterday afternoon of Henry a la Pensee at 9 East Fifty-fifth Street. For several years this accessory house from Paris has been across the street from its present address.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- More than 1,500,000 holders of T gasoline ration books will be called in by the Office of Defense Transportation starting next week and required to justify the mileage allotments granted to them under their certificates of war necessity.
A number of Park Avenue rentals were among the contracts for residental space reported by brokers yesterday. Other leases were spread from Greenwich Village to Washington Heights.

With less than 100 working days left in which to produce next Winter's civilian requirements in protective underwear, distributors declared yesterday that quick action is needed by those charged with the duty of safeguarding essential homefront output to assure sufficient supply of warm undergarments for infants, children, the infirm and for outdoor war workers during the coming Fall and Winter season.

LONDON, May 11 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews and thirteen others who were killed in a plane crash in Iceland were memorialized today by what probably has been the biggest single assemblage of high-ranking United Nations officers since the war started at services in the handsome Royal Chapel of Wellington Barracks.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 11 -- As remnants of the German Africa Corps are being pounded to smithereens in Tunisia -- "Remember Dunkerque!" -- attention in Europe continues riveted on the next phase of the operations, and the general feeling among competent observers is that the time is fast approaching when the bluff is about to be called as regards "Fortress Europe."
The German Tuesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Wednesday, May 12 (U.P.) -- With German police patrols in the Netherlands shooting on sight whenever they encounter a group of more than five persons, Netherland circles here reported today that the Nazis had established a state of siege in the country to meet a wave of sabotage in opposition to German decrees ordering the re-internment of former Netherland army and navy men.

Joseph Freeman, author of "Never Call Retreat," published this Spring by Farrar Rinehart, will be the guest of Bennett Cerf on the "Books Are Bullets" program over WQXR tomorrow at 5 P.M. The program is under the sponsorship of the Council on Books in Wartime.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 11 -- A year-round program of pre-election work for the New York State League of Women Voters was adopted as a meeting project at this afternoon's session of the board of managers. Taxation, revision of State aid and child care are to have secondary consideration.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, May 12 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers, battling through a tropical storm, bombed the Japanese Vunakanau airdrome at Rabaul, New Britain, before dawn yesterday, setting fires visible for sixty miles and starting many small blazes in dispersal areas.

With the sixty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships crowded into a single day this year, it will be interesting to follow the fortunes of Dartmouth's Don Burnham Saturday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. Burnham, winner of the 880 and mile races at Franklin Field last week-end, will attempt to repeat the double.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- The complaint of soft coal miners that their wages cannot buy enough food at present prices brought a reply from operators today that weekly earnings of the miners increased almost 60 per cent from Jan. 1, 1941, to February, 1943, while living expenses rose only 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, May 11 -- A schedule setting specific prices for all types of whiskies, gins and other hard liquors is in the making at the OPA and will be announced late this month or early next, it was learned tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 11 (U.P.) -- Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu said today he was very happy at the favorable reaction abroad and in Argentina to his May Day speech denouncing totalitarianism, the bluntest anti-Axis statement made to date by any member of the national administration.

A bundle cocktail party will be serve tomorrow afternoon in the Ambassador Garden for the benefit of Everybody's Thrift Shop. Officers of the shop who have made reservations include Mrs. Lovett Sturgis, president; Mrs. Harold Mixsell, Mrs. J. Wideman Lee, Mrs. Willard C. Rappleye and Mrs. Thatcher M. Brown, vice presidents; Mrs. Murray Sargent, secretary, and Mrs. John G. M Stone, treasurer.

Every little while a person finds himself coming back to the thought that it is not only college freshmen in the field of American history who ought to know more names, dates and places. There are Americans who were freshmen as much as twenty-five years ago who ought to brush up on some of their Russian dates, names and places.

For the last seven years Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof has been an active member of the Board of Education. A kindergarten teacher for thirty-five years, she was the first representative of her profession to serve on the board. She has probably put in more working hours at board headquarters than any other appointee and she has an impressive list of accomplishments to her credit.
LONDON, Wednesday, May 12 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 11 (AP) -- A communique:

Lacking in balance and without leadership from key stocks, the stock market exhibited yesterday signs of fatigue. Losses on the Stock Exchange which ran to a point in the morning hours were recovered partially in the afternoon, and as an entirety the list closed irregularly lower.

Twelve hundred pupils of the High School of Music and Art yesterday forenoon heard Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, coach a student conductor in the leading of the school's senior orchestra in Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" overture.

A new issue of $7,500,000 of John Morrell Co. fifteen-year 3 per cent debentures priced at 99 will be offered today by an underwriting group headed by A.G. Becker Co., Inc. This is the first public financing for the Ottumwa, Iowa, meat-packing concern, which was established in England in 1827 and extended its operations to the United States in 1865.

The sponsorship of that spectacular musical comedy, "Miss Underground," which will employ a family of twenty-six circus riders, the Christianis, finally has been settled after an unusual series of pre-production throes.

The North African campaign, now ending after six months of bitter, see-saw fighting, has been a campaign of missed opportunities, great gambles and considerable defeats, of frustrations and improvisations, of hard-won victories and heavy losses for both sides, of final well-earned triumph.

Advertisers are beginning to line up the arguments which they will present to the House Committee to Investigate Restrictions on Brand Names and Newsprint, which will start to hold public hearings on May 24, it was indicated yesterday. The committee will study various OPA orders on labeling and standardization affecting such items as hosiery, underwear, work clothing and food.
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 -- Connie Mack confirmed today that his second son and heir apparent, former minor leaguer Earle Mack, will succeed him as manager of the Athletics "when I retire" -- if ever.

The prosaic trolley car -- its death knell seemingly sounded by the subway, the bus and the automobile -- is getting a new wartime lease on life with women motormen as a practical solution to local transportation problems arising from manpower shortages.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 11 -- The United States Army Air Force continued the destruction of Sicily's airfields, harbors and installations today by attacking Marsala on the west coast, leaving fires the smoke of which was visible over the African coast. Almost 200 bombers and more than 100 fighters took part in this all-American raid.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Leaves of absence to permit industrial workers having small farms to plant and harvest crops were advocated by Paul V. McNutt, manpower chief, and Chester Davis, food administrator, in a joint statement issued today.

By unanimous vote the Board of Education re-elected Ellsworth B. Buck, Staten Island member, as its president yesterday, thus ignoring the recent warning of Mayor La Guardia that he would "fire" Mr. Buck the first chance he got.

Price ceilings recently put into effect by the Office of Price Administration for second-hand trucks have almost destroyed the local market and are an invitation to a growing "black market" outside the regulated industry, officials of dealers' associations charged yesterday.
Sterling Drug, Inc., and its subsidiary companies had a net income of $2,405,095 in the quarter ended on March 31, according to the report issued for publication today.

Back from Baltimore, Cliff Melton lost no time yesterday spreading the glad news he had learned at Johns Hopkins. The lanky southpaw ace of the Giants informed Manager Mel Ott that Dr. George E. Bennett had given his ailing arm a thorough going over and could find nothing wrong.

The Waves are only supposed to release sailors for combat duty, but the other day Apprentice Seaman Audrey Pearl Roberts decided to go on combat duty herself while stationed at the Naval Training School for Women's Reserves in the Bronx.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 11 (AP) -- Allied light bombers and fighter-bombers maintained a round-the-clock strafing of roads and a few small boats today. Night-flying Hurricanes caught motor traffic in the path of their flares and other airmen fiercely bombed the airfields at Korba, Menzel-Temime and Rass Addar [Cap Bon], at the extreme northern tip of the peninsula, where a number of Junkers transports were wrecked.

A pound of hamburger will serve six or seven persons when it is blended with a mix that is made by a Chicago company. Guaranteed to extend meat and to enhance its flavor, this preparation recently arrived in town in four-ounce packets that sell for a dime apiece.

BUFFALO, May 11 (AP) -- Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, said tonight that labor's grievances "must and will be solved without a strike movement" and declared that "the war is first of all labor's war."

CHICAGO, May 11 -- Developments which, if they materialize, will place people who have been using coal for heating in about the same predicament as those who use fuel oil were outlined here today by Merrill F. Blankin of Philadelphia, at the annual meeting of the Illinois chapter of the American Society of Heating and Ventilating Engineers.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 11 -- Dropping secrecy regarding the seriousness of the situation following the latest developments in North Africa, the Italian Government tonight decreed a "state or emergency" for the Calabrian Peninsula -- the southern tip of Italy, forming the toe of the boot.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 11 (U.P.) -- Georges Andre, one of the greatest French athletes, was killed in action while fighting beside the Americans in the assault on Mateur, it was revealed today.
MOSCOW, May 11 (AP) -- The noon communique:

LONDON, May 11 -- The House of Commons got its government statement on the victorious Tunisian campaign when Clement R. Attlee's speech was delivered today after a brief secret session. His addresses seldom are delivered in a manner calculated to bring the M. P.'s to their feet, but today his subject matter was of such a nature that his words were interrupted frequently with lusty cheers and shouts of "Hear!" "Hear!"

A PRISON CAMP, Northern Tunisia, May 11 (AP) -- The German Empire in Northern Tunisia today consists of two prison camps in a wheatfield in which the Germans still living are penned behind barbed wire and of a number of military cemeteries where the German dead are buried.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- Flint Garrison of New York City, special consultant to the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, today urged adoption of a price control scheme based on historic margins instead of arbitrary technical standards for manufactured goods.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -- All forty-three governments invited to participate in the United Nations Food Conference opening at Hot Springs. Va., next Tuesday have now accepted, it was learned at the State Department today.

General Enrique Penaranda, President of the Republic of Bolivia, who went to Washington on an official visit last week and is now on a tour of war production centers, will arrive at Pennsylvania Station from Montreal tomorrow morning at 8:30 o'clock, it was announced yesterday by Theodore Hartmann, Bolivian Consul General, who is in charge of the arrangements for the President's stay in New York.
The Second Service Command under Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry tested a large area of Southern New York last night for patience. Reports seemed to show it lacking.

By his "Mornings in Florence" John Ruskin increased enjoyment of the lovely Italian city for many visitors. But his gift, as shown in that series of essays, for disclosing the charm of what might otherwise have escaped notice as "trifles" would surely not have failed him could he have written of "Spring Mornings in Manhattan."

Arnold Constable put on yesterday a display of Summer fashions on the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The airy and bright setting, coupled with attractive Summer togs in good taste and nice fabrics, made spectators overlook, and even forget, the drenching rain that pelted against the roof.
MOSCOW, May 12 -- The Union of Polish Patriots in the U.S.S.R. today published in their organ Wolna Polska a declaration of its aims, together with the organization's statutes.

DURING the Nineteen Thirties individualist liberals used to complain that the only books on political economy to get a hearing were collectivist or Marxist. Aside from a few rare exceptions such as Walter Lippmann's "The Good Society," Herbert Agar's "Land of the Free" and Albert Jay Nock's "Our Enemy the State," the collectivist books seemed to blanket the market.
LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

Our nation is faced with many shortages, but one of the most critical is the shortage of foster homes for temporarily homeless children, declared Marshall Field, chairman of the New York City Committee on Child Welfare of the State Charities Aid Association, at a luncheon conference of New York child care workers at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Mrs. William A. Hastings of Madison, Wis., gained two new distinctions today when it was announced she had been elected president of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers. She also is the organization's first leader to be elected in a mail ballot which replaced the congress' national convention, now discontinued for the war's duration.

The activities of the Army Air Forces will be incorporated into a play to be written, directed and produced by Moss Hart for the benefit of the Army Emergency Relief Fund, it became known yesterday. Broadway will see it in October with a cast recruited from the Air Forces personnel.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- "Flare Path," Terence Rattigan's London success dealing with the Royal Air Force, will be presented by the United Nations Club at three performances in the Wardman Park Little Theatre, May 28-30. Squadron leader John Bown of the Royal Air Force will direct the production in association with Miss Margaret Webster.
The German Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 12 -- Col. Gen. Dietloff von Arnim, the commander of all German troops in North Africa for several months, has been captured, it was officially announced tonight.
LONDON, Thursday, May 13 (U.P.) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 12 (AP) -- The Gazette de Lausanne reported here today that 150 Frenchmen, many of them government officials, had been arrested in Vichy on a charge of plotting to overthrow Pierre Laval, Chief of the French Government.

Vivian Rivkin began her piano recital at Town Hall last night with some exquisitely chiseled playing of Beethoven and Schubert. She gave the opening Rondo in C major, Opus 51, No. 1, of Beethoven with a fine, full tone, excellent phrasing and articulation and a true feeling for Beethoven.

LONDON, May 12 -- The stock markets here were quiet again today. The business was small and some additional profit-taking was responsible for a further easing of prices in several groups. Home rails continued to give way, mostly in the junior stock section, losses of 1/3 to 1 point being recorded.

LONDON, May 12 -- The extent to which concern over post-war dollar imperialism has replaced the Bolshevist bogey was indicated again today in the House of Commons when members opened a debate on the relative merits of the plans of Baron Keynes and Harry White for the stabilization of postwar currency.

Ralph E. Samuel has been appointed chairman of the Business Men's Council of the merged New York and Brooklyn Federations of Jewish Charities, it was announced yesterday by George Z. Medalie, president of the organization. He succeeds Captain Paul Felix Warburg, now on active duty with the Army overseas.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 12 -- Various changes in officers of the Glens Falls group of insurance companies marked their annual meetings today. Frank M. Smalley retired as president of the Glens Falls Insurance Company and the Commerce Insurance Company and as vice president of the Glens Falls Indemnity Company, and E.W. West retired as president of Glens Falls Indemnity and the Glens Falls Investing Corporation.
LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
Governor Dewey has signed some forty bills pertaining to conservation, according to an outline issued by the New York State Conservation Department relating to the changes in existing laws.

Albert Stoessel, noted conductor and violinist, collapsed and died a few minutes later on the auditorium stage of the American Academy of Arts and Letters yesterday afternoon as he was conducting an orchestra at the annual ceremonial of the academy and the National Institute of Arts and Letters.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 12 (AP) -- Newark pounced on Jack Tising to start a spurt good for seven runs in the fifth inning tonight and stowed away a subsequent 13-to-1 victory over Buffalo.

The strike of 150 employes of Press Wireless, Inc., begun last Friday in a dispute over the suspension of nine employes and the dismissal of one because of alleged absenteeism, was ended early yesterday morning after an all-night conference between representatives of the company and of the Independent Communications Guild, which directed the strike.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Amid protests that government payment of commissions on war contracts appears to be "a plain fraud," the Senate Naval Committee approved legislation today to compel refund of excessive fees paid to war brokers.

Retail jewelry sales thus far this year are running 20 per cent or more ahead of the record 1942 volume, which had shown a rise of about 30 per cent over 1941. Comment in the trade yesterday indicated this meant that many retailers were turning into cash much inventory that cannot be replaced under wartime conditions.

Reactionary tendencies, but of a mild nature, ruled yesterday at the close of trading in the stock market although the morning hours had held out promise for a revival of the previous forward movement. The list slipped easily in the late trading without any pressing prodding from sellers, chiefly because the rails reversed their strong position despite some bullish news.

LONDON, Thursday, May 13 (U.P.) -- Russian planes, in their mass offensive against enemy communications, heavily bombed more than twelve key German railroad junctions and stations Tuesday night and attacked airdromes in the enemy rear, a Moscow broadcast said today.

From the cocoanut groves of Tahita to the palm-fringed shores of Miami is a mighty long haul and one that is frightfully boring in the picture called "Tahita Honey," which came yesterday to the Palace as the companion piece to the second-run "Air Force."

The garden of the Ambassador was formally opened last night for the new season with a dinner and dance given in aid of Dogs for Defense, Inc., a non-profit agency assisting the War Department in procuring dogs to serve in various capacities with our armed forces.
Herbert Bayard Swope, chairman of the New York State Racing Commission, last night predicted the appointment of a national sports coordinator, The Associated Press reports.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Baseball in general, and off-hour contests in particular, received a strong plug today from Paul V. McNutt, the nation's manpower boss.

A print of the forthcoming film, "Stage Door Canteen," will be presented to the American Theatre Wing War Service, Inc., by Sol Lesser, producer of the picture, this afternoon. Rachel Crothers, president of the Theatre Wing, will receive the film at the organization's offices, 730 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, May 12 -- Allied escort ships and planes fighting a fierce, eight-day running battle against a pack of as many as twenty-five Axis submarines attacking an Atlantic convoy recently sank four and perhaps ten of the U-boats, the Admiralty announced today.

A mystery in which two babies were found abandoned yesterday afternoon in St. Simon Stock Roman Catholic Church, Ryer Avenue and 152d Street, the Bronx, was solved last night, detectives said, by the statement of a 21-year-old mother that she had been unable to care for the children.

DETROIT, May 12 -- Ned Harris looped a single to center field with two out in the fifteenth inning today, scoring a pinch runner, Charley Metro, from third base, to give the Tigers a 3-to-2 decision over the Athletics in the opener of a three-game series.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 12 (AP) -- The Middle East took on the aspects of a theatre of likely war action today with the arrival of the veteran Sixth South African Armored Division and the announcement that British military and government leaders of the area are conferring here.

CLEVELAND, May 12 (AP) -- The Indians beat the Senators, 8 to 2, in the first night game of the local season and moved within a game of the league-leading Yankees tonight. The Tribe supported Chubby Dean's six-hit hurling effort with a barrage of thirteen blows.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 12 (AP) -- A special communique declared tonight that isolated pockets of enemy resistance were still active, but the battle was officially considered ended.

TUNIS, May 11 (Delayed) -- Moving with a speed that surpassed that of the Germans in Belgium three years ago today, British tanks and infantry penetrated to the northern tip of Cap Bon and to the Gulf of Hammamet and, with the help of the Royal Navy and Allied Air Forces, completely cut off the remaining Axis forces in Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- By a vote of 196 to 153 the House tentatively decided today to limit extension of the Administration's reciprocal trade agreements program to two years instead of the three years for which it has twice been extended since its original adoption in June, 1934.
BERNE, May 12 -- Through Axis channels, it is revealed today that M. Laval once more has been worsted in horse trading with the Germans, whom he professes to surpass in bargaining.
WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A total of 285 companies owned by German, Japanese or Italian nationals are to be sold by the Alien Property Custodian at public auction, it was learned today.

At an organization meeting of the directors of the International Paper Company here yesterday a new executive office, "chairman of the corporation," was created and Richard J. Cullen, president of the concern and its predecessors for the last seven years, was elected to the new office.

The T.J. Oakley Rhinelander 2d, Post No. 6 of the American Legion, having outgrown its old office, has leased larger space in 248 West Fourteenth Street through the Georlia Realty Corporation. John A. Kennedy acted as attorney for the lessee and J. F. Cahill Co. represented the owner.

American journalism will play an important role in post-war world affairs, David Hinshaw, vice president of the Institute of Public Relations, declared yesterday in an Oscar S. Straus Memorial Association address at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

R.J. Wysor, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, told stockholders at their annual meeting yesterday at Flemington, N.J., that operations were at the rate of 102 per cent of capacity during the first four months of 1943 by forcing every facility to the utmost.

WHEN last seen, the Chicago Cubs were actually bursting with health. They had come over from French Lick to Bloomington to play an exhibition game with the Reds. "We're really in the pink," said Jimmy Wilson enthusiastically as he went on to declare that his Indiana training site was even superior to anything he'd seen in California or Florida.
The Italian Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Thursday, May 13 (AP) -- Allied patrols in the New Guinea jungles near Mubo clashed with small Japanese units yesterday at three points, in one case killing five of the enemy, it was reported today.

Growing scarcity of denims and other utility fabrics used in work clothing threatens to block the reported project of the Agriculture Department to clothe a Women's Land Army of 50,000 farm workers this year, Worth Street suppliers reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Walter Reed General Hospital at the Army Medical Center averages almost 400 physiotherapy patients a day and has only seven graduate physiotherapists, nine apprentices and twenty-six students to treat them.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, preserved the judicial character of the National War Labor Board today and saved it from threatened dissolution by restoring its authority to make wage adjustments "to aid in the prosecution of the war or correct gross inequities," provided such adjustments did not increase prices or increase production costs.

ALBANY, May 12 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of Thomas D. Thacher, former Solicitor General of the United States and at present Corporation Counsel of New York City, as an associate judge of the Court of Appeals. He will succeed Judge Edward R. Finch, who retired April 30.

As the aftermath of the knifing to death last Saturday of Hubert Alexander, a 23-year-old chief cook in the Navy, three youths were booked on a charge of homicide yesterday at the Gates Avenue Precinct in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Lamenting the "hatred of the Germans" and the "ramparts of bitterness and enmity" being created in German-occupied countries, the Catholic Bishops of Germany denounced the Nazi persecution of religion in the strongest terms they have yet used in a memorial sent to the Minister of Church Affairs, Dr. Bernhard Rust, on Dec. 18, last, and made public today by the Office of War Information.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 12 (AP) -- Allied communique 187:

Cotton prices lost further ground yesterday on increased liquidation influenced in part by the favorable weekly weather report and the war news. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed at net losses of 4 to 12 points, with the greatest decline in the new crop months.

Elmer S. Prather, known here as a lecturer on telepathy and astrology under the name of "Professor Knowles" until he went to France in 1922 after the American postal authorities halted his business, left a net estate of $530,744 when he died in France on April 27, 1939, it was disclosed yesterday in the estate tax appraisal filed here.

The projected rollback on coffee prices, scheduled to become effective on June 1, will be a straight 3 cents a pound on roasted coffee and not 10 per cent as previously reported, the National Coffee Association announced yesterday, following a conference with the Office of Price Administration.

The new pricing order for the liquor industry now under consideration by the Office of Price Administration is not likely to produce any general reduction in prices to consumers in this area. On the contrary, it is likely to lift current levels in many instances, liquor trade observers here asserted yesterday.

HEADQUARTERS, ARMY AIR FORCE SCHOOL OF APPLIED TACTICS, Orlando, Fla., May 12 -- Today the Army Air Forces demonstrated to visiting correspondents how a fighter plane field should be attacked and defended. The Germans, theoretically, had invaded Florida and had cut the State in half.

The announcement of the installation of the key number system for mail in this city brought a flood of telephone calls and personal inquiries yesterday to the General Postoffice and all its branch offices. Postmaster Albert Goldman reported that 1,000 calls had been received in the first hour after opening the General Postoffice.
Morris Hadley, New York lawyer, was elected president of the board of trustees of the New York Public Library yesterday afternoon to succeed the late Frank L. Polk.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- A resumption of scattered liquidation carried wheat prices off about 1/2 cent a bushel in the early trading today on the Board of Trade, but mills took the buying side on the break, and later there were general buying and short covering based on reports of floods in some areas in the Central West and prices rallied 1 to 1 5/8 cents from the bottom, May leading.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12 -- Civilian protection officials of Westchester County and its six cities met here this afternoon and voted to ask permission from the State and the Army to announce air raid alarm all-clears to the public by sounding the air raid sirens and whistles for ten seconds.
