DETROIT, May 12 (AP) -- Theodore Donay, a naturalized citizen of German birth, was convicted by a jury in United States District Court today of misprision of treason in concealing knowledge of aid given last year to an escaped Nazi flier.

FORT BLISS, Texas, May 12 -- Tests carried out in the last few weeks by officers and men of the anti-aircraft artillery training center at Fort Bliss have convinced them that the United States is on the way to developing, if it has not already developed, the most effective automatic anti-aircraft artillery controls in the world.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 12 -- On the eve of the government's taking over the American Railroad of Puerto Rico on account of an unsettled three-months strike of members of the Union of Railway Workers, Governor Rexford Guy Tugwell issued a proclamation at noon today immobilizing traffic on the railroad for forty-eight hours.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The President was host at a stag dinner in honor of Dr. Eduard Benes, President of Czechoslovakia, after a day spent in conference with Prime Minister Churchill, interspersed with talks with Roane Waring, American Legion commander, Mayor Edward Kelly of Chicago and a C.I.O. delegation of New York.

New York's potato appetite normally demands eighty carloads a day, or roughly 3,000,000 pounds. Assuming that part of New York's potato shipment goes beyond city limits it means one-third of a pound of potatoes a person.

The issue in the coal case squarely before the American people is whether "one man is big enough to defy the President of the United States and get away with it," Cyrus S. Ching, industrial and public relations director of the United States Rubber Company, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 (AP) -The United States Circuit Court of Appeals has upheld the dismissal of a stockholder's suit asking that the Pennroad Corporation and sixteen officers and directors be held liable for an alleged loss of $9,000,000 in connection with purchases of Boston Maine Railroad stocks.

In order to put an end to inequities that have grown out of the Controlled Materials Plan, especially in the textile fields, the War Production Board is giving serious consideration to an amendment which would modify or even eliminate that section which permits civilian goods manufacturers covered by the plan to extend priority ratings to themselves on non-CMP materials required, it was learned yesterday.
LONDON, May 12 (Reuter) -General yon _ was England's bitter opponent commanding German forces in Northern Tunisia while Field arshal Rommel was fighting the British Eighth Army.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Appended is the text of the German Catholic Bishops' Memorial to the German Government, copies of which were sent on Dec. 18, 1942, to the German Minister for Church Affairs, the German Minister for the Interior and the Chief of the Chancellery, as released here by the Office of War Information:

Using posters, pennants, animated charts and brief dramatic sketches broadcast over public address systems to imbue plant workers with the idea that they are "production soldiers" upon whom fighting men in the front lines depend, the airplane division of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation has sharply reduced voluntary absenteeism among the men and women who are producing planes for the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia was received by President Roosevelt at the White House this afternoon for an official visit, during which he plans to discuss post-war problems of Central Europe, as well as current questions concerning Russia and Poland.

New issues of notes totaling $12,364,000 were awarded yesterday through competitive bidding by fourteen housing authorities in various parts of the country. A total of $4,500,000 was awarded to Salomon Bros. Hutzler; $3,502,000 to the Girard Trust Company of Philadelphia; $3,000,000 to F.S. Moseley Co.; $862,000 to the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, and $500,000 to Harriman Ripley Co., Inc.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 12 -- Almost 400 Allied planes hammered Sicily yesterday for the third straight day, leaving a trail of fiery destruction in the ports of Marsala and Catania, while other aerial forces smashed at the Island of Pantelleria.

Stark Young, author of "So Red the Rose," "River House" and "Heaven Trees," will exhibit his paintings, executed in the past two years, at a benefit preview to be held Tuesday at headquarters of the Friends of Greece, 52 East Fifty-seventh Street. The proceeds of the showing, which will be open to the public after the preview, will be used to send vaccines and cod liver oil to the children of Greece.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Following is the text of the directive authorizing the War Labor Board to make certain wage adjustments, issued today by James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, together with a summary made public by Mr. Byrnes:

LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- The Netherlands' 400,000 former service men were instructed in unprecedented action by the Netherland Government in London tonight to defy a new German registration order and to "defend" themselves against any resulting Nazi attempts to arrest them.
Two future double-headers blossomed from yesterday's wet weather, which washed out the Cubs-Giants game at the Polo Grounds and the twilight contest between the Dodgers and Pirates at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- After less than five minutes of deliberation following a stormy public hearing this afternoon, the House Rules Committee cleared the way for floor action on the completely redrafted Connally anti-strike bill.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- Declaring that mobilization for war production was confronted by a crisis, with aircraft, tank, ordinance and other quotas undergoing cutbacks, a special Military Affairs subcommittee of the Senate recommended as "urgently necessary" today the establishment by Congressional action of an overall authority with centralized powers to determine policies and enforce them.
The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which opens an engagement of eleven days at the Broadway Theatre next Wednesday, announces the following repertory for the first six performances:

PITTSBURGH, May 12 (AP) -- An announcement by the South Penn Oil Company, largest supplier of Pennsylvania grade crude oil, that deliveries would be cut 15 per cent on June 1 and 20 per cent on July 1, based upon May deliveries, brought today an immediate charge from oil men that the "nearsighted policy of the OPA" was responsible for the decreased output.

LONDON, May 12 -- While German transport has deteriorated under the stress of wear and tear as well as Allied bombing, the Ministry of Economic Warfare reminded Britons today that the project of bringing it entirely to a halt by air attack was extremely ambitious and it would be some time before "decisive results" could be expected.

Final figures on the results of the Second War Loan drive in the Second Federal Reserve District were announced yesterday by Allan Sproul, chairman of the New York War Finance Committee. The total for this district, which includes New York State, Northern New Jersey and Fairfield County, Conn., was $7,051,765,000, of which sales to non-bank investors amounted to $5,167,557,500.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- With the Mediterranean soon to be opened to use by the United Nations, Allied armies in Tunisia will be free to draw on a substantial supplementary supply source for the oil required for their mechanized forces and aircraft.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill began today their intensive global war conferences, both separately and with their key military, naval and air leaders. The scant circumstantial evidence available in the capital was interpreted as indicating that considerable attention was being given to new offensive moves against the Japanese.

Man-made steel islands stretching across the Atlantic, each complete with a hotel, repair shop, radio station, fuel tanks, storage rooms and other necessaries of aerial transport -- newspaper readers must have rubbed their eyes and asked questions when they read the advertisement yesterday in which Edward R. Armstrong's seadrome was described.

ON THE TUNISIAN FRONT, May 10 (Delayed) -- This is the story of the British First Army -- a force neither spectacular nor glamorous, but long-suffering, patient and, in the end, gloriously victorious.

NEW DELHI, India, May 12 (AP) -- American heavy bombers dropped thirty tons of bombs yesterday on an oil factory at Syriam, southeast of Rangoon, in an intensification of the Allied campaign to deprive the Japanese of Burma's natural resources.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- A major shift in the petroleum-carrying program from wooden to steel barges, with an increase of 50 per cent in capacity, was announced today by the Office of Defense Transportation.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS NORTH AFRICA, May 12 -- The war in Africa is over, it was officially announced tonight.

The Textile Workers Union of America, one of the largest affiliates of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged yesterday scrapping of the Little Steel formula, now governing pay rises in the nation. The change was requested in a resolution adopted unanimously by 1,100 delegates at a convention in Carnegie Hall.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., May 12 -- State Senator Frank S. Farley was linked here today with strenuous efforts to aid the resort's gambling fraternity in forestalling discontinuance of telephone service to the horse race information service of George L. Goodman, in Atlantic City's gambling heydays of 1939.

Third in the Kentucky Derby, W.E. Boeing's Slide Rule, 3-year-old son of Snark, a noted mud runner, yesterday won the $7,425 Swift Stakes at Belmont Park. Perhaps the liking for mud runs in the family, for it was needed over the deepest track Belmont had seen in many a day.

Hospitals throughout the metropolitan area celebrated National Hospital Day yesterday by intensifying their drive to recruit student nurses to help meet the needs of the armed forces. Many hospitals opened their doors to young women interested in nursing careers, while exhibits in department stores and the opening of a school for nursing at Wagner College on Staten Island also commemorated the day which marked Florence Nightingale's birthday.

It was a game strictly out of the leaoJes. Bunts became doubles when the ball Foiled past the pitch[er's pretty legs. Texas Leaguers went for triples. Batters reached high for the ball, then knelt low, practically praying, as it bounced past them.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The Senate ended its first day of debate on pay-as-you-go taxation tonight with the prospect of a vote on three choices. These are cancellation of a full year's taxes and 75 or 50 per cent of a full year's taxes.

By a happy coincidence Washington and the United States are able to welcome, along with Winston Churchill, another outstanding European statesman who played a big role in the past and will play a big role in the future -- Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile and one of the first victims of Hitler's craze for world conquest.

The Grand Duchess Charlotte of Luxembourg, accompanied by her military aide, Captain Guillaume Konsbruck, and Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, chairman of the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, was the guest yesterday of the New York Air Defense Wing and inspected an aircraft warning center in a Manhattan skyscraper.

Sergeant Robert Duff Bijur, Royal Canadian Air Force, 22 years old, of 160 West Seventy-fifth Street, who was listed yesterday as presumably dead, was lost mysteriously on a bombing raid over Nazi Europe last August, his mother, Mrs. Harry Bijur, wife of a lawyer, said yesterday at the Hotel Delmonico, where she is staying temporarily.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The large and important group, inside and outside the government, which for many reasons is anxious for the public to have more details of the submarine warfare is very hopeful that a new and more liberal agreement as to this will be reached between the President and the British Prime Minister during Mr. Churchill's stay in this country.

Reversing a previous decision, the National Labor Relations Board, by a two-to-one vote, has excluded foremen and supervisory employes from the protection of the Wagner Act. The reason given for the new decision is that recognition of unions of supervisory employes would impede "the processes of collective bargaining, disrupt established managerial and production techniques and militate against effectuation of the policies of the act."

Declaring that the interpretations placed on his re-election as president of the Board of Education were "wholly erroneous," Ellsworth B. Buck asserted yesterday that Mayor La Guardia had favored the board's action.

The Moreland commissioners conducting an inquiry into the workmen's compensation law administration will seek a Supreme Court order to require James F. Schlesinger, secretary-treasurer of Bendiner Schlesinger X-ray Laboratories, Inc., to produce his company's books showing cash disbursements which he told the commissioners yesterday he was "unable" to produce.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- A price schedule setting quotations for all packaged drugs at all levels of distribution from manufacturer to retailer was announced today by the Office of Price Administration and will go into effect on May 26. The new regulation continues in effect the March. 1942, prices in most instances and carries a provision requiring the manufacturer to print the retail ceiling price on the label of all proprietary medicines.

Here's a plan for a dinner party wartime-style: Serve wine rather than cocktails -- it's sometimes cheaper, and certainly simpler Eliminate canapes, which are fussy to make, and bring a casserole or chafing dish into the living-room filled with something that can take the place of the first course.

After several months of study the New York Clearing House announced yesterday the clearing procedure it would follow in handling ration coupon banking checks. Immediately effective, certain of these checks will be cleared through the City Department of the Clearing House, instead of by the former method of including such items in envelopes with the regular check exchanges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 12 -- Andrew Stone, who is producing and directing "Hi Diddle, Diddle" for United Artists, has been signed to make two more pictures for the company this season. The first will be a musical in technicolor to be titled "Petticoat Lane," the screen play for which is being written by Frederick Jackson.

The toilet goods industry was warned yesterday to be on the alert for moves to eliminate trademark names and weaken fair trade laws under the cloak of the war effort by H.L. Brooks, head of Coty, Inc., and president of the Toilet Goods Association.
ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) -- Unable to match the Browns' hitting power, the Red Sox were defeated today, 6 to 4, in the opening game of their first Western trip of the season.

The Koussevitzky Music Foundation, established last year in memory of Natalie Koussevitzky, wife of Serge Koussevitzky, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, has approved grants of money for symphonic works to be written by Igor Stravinsky, Bela Bartok and William Schuman, it was announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 12 -- A pitched battle in the center of Sofia occurred early today when troops and police besieged what Axis newspaper men described as an "important center of terrorist activities." The fight lasted a half hour, during which the "terrorists" -- described elsewhere as members of the "patriotic front" -- held the militia at bay with automatic rifles and grenades.

LONDON, May 12 (AP) -- Whistling in the dark over their vaunted coastal ramparts, the Axis war lords stood wholly on the defensive today for the first time in more than three and one-half years of war, awaiting the inevitable onslaught at places and times to be set, London observers believed, by the conferees in Washington.

LONDON, May 12 -- The first contingent of non-commissioned Waacs to be stationed here permanently arrived today and caused most interest among the enlisted men, who are very much aware that the girls are not permitted to date officers.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Resentment which Senator Clark said he had nursed against Major Gen. Ben Lear since the publicized "Yoo Hoo" incident of two years lago, resulted today in postponement of the officer's promotion to lieutenant general.
A call to civilian defense workers to keep themselves in a state of preparedness was is sued yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the Office of Civilian Defense.

Lassie, 4-year-old lead dog, was joyfully reunited yesterday in Bellevue Hospital with her blind master. Frank Wright, 35 years old, of 46 West 120th Street, who is suffering from injuries received when he was struck by a taxicab on Tuesday.

DAKAR, French West Africa, May 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- The 7,500-ton French cruiser Georges Leygales, based at Dakar, has brilliantly signaled her return to action against Germany by sending a large submarine supply ship to the bottom and returning to port with ninety prisoners.

As wave after wave of cosmetic hosiery breaks upon the market it provokes a flood of frantic questions from a puzzled and bespattered feminine public. What can be expected of this new and revolutionary form of make-up?

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The United States now has all the plant and machine tools it needs to beat the Axis, and as a result $5,000,000,000 to $5,500,000,000 worth of contracts for the construction of new war facilities will be re-examined by the War Production Board with a view to their cancellation.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC NAVAL BASE, April 14 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Many American warships and cargo vessels that were sunk in seventeen months of naval warfare in the Pacific are being salvaged and reclaimed, it was disclosed today.

Reductions of one cent a pound in the prices of viscose rayon staple fiber were announced yesterday by American Viscose Corporation. The standard bright type, lowered from 25 to 24 cents a pound, had not been changed since September, 1937, when it was reduced from 28 to 25 cents.

A recently appointed Internal Revenue agent was indicted here yesterday in the first criminal action to grow out of an Army investigation of the fitness of a citizen to remain in the East Coast defense area. The defendant and the subject of the investigation, Wilhelm A.G. Meyer, a naturalized citizen of German birth, was said to have made false statements concerning his acquaintance with a convicted German spy.

It was a real pleasure to pick up your paper the other day and read on the editorial page of the exploits of Captain Dick Harris. I was closely acquainted with Captain Harris at Georgetown University. While there, he was universally known and loved.

The Tunisian campaign, which ended yesterday with the crumbling of the last organized enemy resistance, has been a difficult testing ground for men and materiel of American, British and French armies.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 12 -- Charles H. Griffiths of New Rochelle resigned today as chairman of the Westchester County Republican Committee, a position he had held nine years. He explained that the step was taken because of his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Surrogate of the county.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 10 (Delayed) -- It was June, 1940. In a railroad car on the fringe of the forest of Compiegne Reichsfuehrer Hitler, being particularly nasty, was dictating armistice terms. Only General Charles de Gaulle was upholding French traditions to the world.

First mortgage Series E 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Public Service Company of Indiana, due on May 1, 1973, in the amount of $38,000,000, will be offered today to the public at 102 3/8 and interest from May 1.

First mortgage Series E 3 1/4 per cent bonds of the Public Service Company of Indiana, due on May 1, 1973, in the amount of $38,000,000, will be offered today to the public at 102 3/8 and interest from May 1.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (U.P.) -- The House Naval Affairs Committee, in the first of a series of reports on Navy personnel policies, revealed tonight that the department's draft-deferment policy for civilian employes had been sharply revised following disclosure of large-scale abuses and laxity.
I cannot understand why one of the most important morale builders should be ignored while every one is racking his brain for new stunts to keep up the morale of our men in the service.

OTTAWA, May 12 -- Marking the increasing cordiality of relations between Canada and the South American republics, President Enrique Penaranda of Bolivia arrived in Ottawa today for a short visit. He is the first head of a Latin-American State to visit the country.

Frederick R. Lack has been elected a vice president of the Western Electric Company, the company announced yesterday. Mr. Lack, who resigned as an officer of the company on Nov. 1, 1942, to become director of the Army and Navy Electronics Procurement Agency with offices in Washington, will now resume the direction of Western Electric's radio division in New York.

LONDON, May 12 -- The perplexing problem of solving Europe's refugee problem will be debated in Parliament soon, when the British delegates report on the work of the Bermuda conference. It is almost certain that the government will be assailed for not doing enough.

Federal grand juries are being convened in Brooklyn and Manhattan to investigate price-gouging in poultry and other foods, it was disclosed yesterday after six wholesale poultry concerns and thirteen of their officers had been arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay in Brooklyn and held in $1,000 bail each for grand jury action.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce today reported favorably the Bolton nursing bill to encourage more women to join the nursing profession by subsidizing the training of those who pledge their services to a proposed student war nursing reserve.

WASHINGTON, May 12 -- The governments of Norway, Belgium and the Netherlands have addressed notes of protest to the State Department against the issuing of royalty-free licenses to American companies to exploit patents owned by the nationals of these occupied countries.

Albert Stoessel was widely known as a violinist and conductor and was especially associated with the Juilliard Graduate School, the Chautauqua Institution and the Oratorio Society of New York. He was director of the opera and orchestra at the Juilliard School, musical director of the Chautauqua Symphony Orchestra and conductor of the Oratorio Society.

Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Colket entertained with a dinner yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for Major and Mrs. Walter V. Cotchett of Chateau St. Hilaire, Louviers, France. The other guests included Lieutenant and Mrs. Holstein De Haven Fox of Philadelphia, Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Harrah and Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana.

LONDON, May 12 -- Broadcasting to the people of France over the British Broadcasting Company tonight, General Charles de Gaulle dwelt upon the vital role of the Fighting French in the battle for Africa that has just ended victoriously for Allied arms.

PHILADELPHIA, May 12 -- Morgan S. Kaufman, Scranton lawyer and former Eastern Pennsylvania bankruptcy referee, was disbarred today by the unanimous vote of five judges of the United States District Court here for unethical financial relations with J. Warren Davis, retired judge of the Third Circuit Court of Appeals.

Twenty-one months have passed between Prime Minister Churchill's first conference with President Roosevelt and his present one, the fifth. Some very young persons may live to see more exciting months. We don't know about that. None will see more decisive ones.
Several investments in business buildings in Manhattan were reported yesterday by brokers.

I am much interested in the recent letters from "Warden" and Miss Martha L. Kobbe about the air-raid drills. To answer "Warden," we have been most patient in permitting the public to become familiarized with the new signals and now we shall answer by issuing summonses.

A total of 91.3 per cent of the weekly newspaper publishers of this country believes that the Federal Government should pay at least a part of the cost of war advertising, according to a nation-wide survey by the American Press Association.

MOSCOW, May 12 -- Two young Russian girls, Maya Lokshina and Raissa Liberson, have just returned from the central front, where for a fortnight they traveled in trucks and jeeps and on horseback, but mostly on foot, distributing American cigarettes and chocolate sent by the Russian War Relief.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in its report for the three months ended on March 31, issued yesterday by Robert C. Stanley, chairman and president, shows a net profit of $8,075,238 after depreciation, special amortization, $6,167,665 provision for taxes and all charges.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 12 (AP) -- Leslie Combs's Hometown took command from the start today to win the Central Park Purse at Churchill Downs.

Last Fall, Wall Street payrolls were at rock bottom. From 1937 they had been cut for reasons of retrenchment. When selective service came along, there was general indisposition to replace the men taken. Since November, however, there have been increasingly active markets and brokerage houses have been forced to add new help.

Track and field addicts more or less agree in their selections of the probable winners in eight of the nine races to be contested Saturday at the sixty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor championships at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

LONDON, May 12 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio said today that Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Commissar for Foreign Affairs, had turned over to foreign diplomats in Moscow a note charging that new documents revealed how the German Government had sponsored the systematic deportation of hundreds of thousands of Soviet civilians into slavery in Germany last Winter.

DETROIT, May 12 -- Studies of brain waves indicating their possible use in the early detection of arteriosclerosis (hardening of the arteries), one of the major diseases of civilization and the greatest single cause of death in the United States, were described here today before the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

Supplies of major oil products along the Atlantic Coast declined last week to another new low level, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index, covering gasoline and light and heavy fuel oil, stood at 25.5 at the close of last week, compared with 26.3 a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 7, last, when the current down trend started.

CHICAGO, May 12 -- Yankee expectations were shattered at Comiskey Park today. The 1943 Western debut of Joe McCarthy's men was spoiled by a ten-inning 2-1 setback as Tiny Bonham's three-game winning streak came to an end against the seventh-place White Sox.

Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran yesterday opened a new field of employment to women here when he appointed two as uniformed court attendants. They were Henrietta V. Law of 140 Waverly Place and Lillian Halperin Wolfe of 141 East Twenty-first Street, Brooklyn, who were first and second respectively on a civil service list after physical and mental tests last year. Three other women recently were appointed to clerical jobs in the same court.

Mayor La Guardia's executive budget of $753,071,123 for 1943-44, as approved by the Board of Estimate and transmitted to the City Council, is "neither sound nor honest" and the Mayor's "threat" of a 15-point rise in the basic tax rate is "politically motivated and quite unnecessary," according to a statement issued yesterday by Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs, Manhattan Fusionist and former Borough President.
LONDON, May 13 -- With the fall of Tunisia to Allied arms there has come some further enlightenment about Allied plans for the administration of a liberated Europe.
MEXICO CITY, May 13 -- The creation of an Economic Emergency Board which will cope with the various problems originated by the war was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration announced specific retail ceiling prices today for kosher cuts of beef, veal, lamb and mutton to take effect Monday, when similar ceilings will be imposed on non-kosher cuts.

MIAMI, Fla., May 13 (AP) -- Red signal lights attached to their lifejackets were credited today by four members of a Navy gun crew with the speedy rescue of ninety-five men who took to the lifeboats and rafts when their United States merchant ship was torpedoed late in April in mid-Atlantic by a hit-and-run Axis submarine.
NEW DELHI, India, May 13 (AP) -- A Tenth Air Force communique:

The large majority by which the House of Representatives voted yesterday to renew the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act is a fine victory for Secretary Hull and for the broad point of view in international affairs of which he has been a stalwart champion.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- "Such frills as oyster forks, bouillon spoons and butter knives will be scarce for the duration," the War Production Board said today, admonishing brides that they would not find available the pre-war variety of silverware patterns.

NEW DELHI, India, May 13 (AP) -- United States heavy bombers continued their attacks against Japanese communications and installations in Burma yesterday, dropping thirty tons of bombs on a railroad bridge between Mandalay and Rangoon and blasting the river port of Bassein, about ninety miles west of Rangoon.

General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, arrived in New York yesterday morning and spent the first of five days lunching and dining with business leaders, receiving a degree of Doctor of Laws at Columbia University, and confronting a press conference in which twenty-five reporters kept him busy more than an hour with questions on a dozen delicate subjects.

Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, disclosed yesterday in a report to Mayor La Guardia that more than $500,000,000 in contracts had been placed in New York City by the armed forces during the first quarter of 1943.
Beginning June 2 the schedule of the "Ziegfeld Follies" will include Wednesday night performances, which have been omitted because of Milton Berle's radio commitment.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Representatives of the steel industry asked the War Manpower Commission today to grant further time before enforcing its recent order that a 48-hour week be established in the industry after July 1 and that no new workers be hired after June 1 where the 48-hour week had not been put into effect.
Several apartments in the Riverside Drive and West End Avenue sections of Manhattan were included in the rentals reported by brokers yesterday.

Directors of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation at its twenty-first annual meeting at 8 West Fortieth Street called yesterday for a pronouncement by the United States Government that America would not again turn her back on the problem of maintaining peace.

Hesitation continued yesterday in the stock markets and prices remained on the easier side. Offerings were not heavy, but they were sufficient on the Stock Exchange to impair values fractionally. Again it was a case of potential bidders being passive until a better picture of the global war strategy can be observed, while the tax situation also hampered any return to the previous tempo of trading.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The award of 513 decorations for valor and exceptional performance in action to officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Eighth Air Force in England was announced today by the War Department.

Today's events: Harcum College Glee Club, Hotel Barclay, 4 P.M.; Composers Press concert, the Wyoming, 853 Seventh Avenue, 8:30; Alexander Kipnis, bass, International Study Center, 1010 Park Avenue, 8:30; Spring concert, Music Department of New York University School of Education, 37 West Fourth Street, 8:30.
MOSCOW, May 13 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Heavy rains throughout the country, particularly in drought areas, have improved crops considerably during the last week, according to a government report. Farms in the Northeastern States are still behind schedule, however, and are definitely in need of warmer weather and more sunshine.

WASHINGTON, Lay 13 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 387 United States soldiers held prisoners of war, divided as follows: By Germany, 14; by Italy, 262; by Japan, 111.

Blue skies and a friendly sun took away some of the terrors of overland hiking for racing followers yesterday and 13,376 -- only 712 fewer than on the chilly opening day -- trekked to the huge plant in Nassau County for the fourth day of the Belmont Park meeting.
LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The cosmetics industry has gone a long way in adjusting itself to war conditions and it does not appear that another order calling for a horizontal cut in production is likely, C.A. Willard, deputy director of the drug and cosmetics section of the chemicals division, War Production Board, said yesterday.

DETROIT, May 13 -- A resolution attacking legislation permitting the appointment of a layman as Commissioner of Mental Hygiene for the State of New York as "reactionary and prejudicial to the effective operation and further development of the Mental Hygiene Department" was passed unanimously today by the American Psychiatric Association on the final day of its annual meeting.

With interest centering in properties along the West Side as far north as Washington Heights, several apartment buildings and a dwelling in Manhattan passed to new control in deals reported yesterday. Most of the selling was done by savings banks.

A licensed representative of claimants, deriving his clients from labor unions, appeared in 2,000 compensation cases in 1942 and grossed between $50,000 and $60,000 annually during the past four or five years, according to testimony yesterday at the inquiry before Moreland Commissioners William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman in the Bar Association Building.

The text of the note that Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff, Soviet Commissar for Foreign Affairs, addressed to the ambassadors and ministers of nations represented in Moscow on the mass abduction of Soviet citizens and their enforced enslavement in Germany was made available here yesterday by The Associated Press, to which it was supplied by Tass, the Russian news agency.

William Vessie, Columbia sophomore high jumper, ranks as the athlete having the best chance to register a record-breaking performance in the sixty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships tomorrow at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

The thick suspense that pervades the Bronx Zoo this morning is caused by Annie the penguin, who either is or is not about to become a mother. For thirty-eight days Annie has had an egg, tenderly deposited in a nest officially described as consisting of "short sticks laid crosswise and tumbled up with crackerjack boxes, old fish heads, peanut shells, match covers and cellophane cigarette wrappers."

Summer weather along with the Pirates came to Ebbets Field yesterday, but the temperature was far below that developed by Manager Frankie Frisch as his Buccos lost to the Dodgers, 5 -- 4, in a bitterly argumentative contest.

LONDON, May 13 -- Although the collapse of resistance by the Axis forces in Tunisia gave a cheerful tone to today's stock markets, business failed to expand. One restricting influence was a desire to await news regarding present most important discussions in Washington.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- In the belief that one of the main attacks on "Fortress Europe" will be on French soil, the German and Italian High Commands have told Pierre Laval, Vichy Chief of Government, what they expect of him.

BRITISH FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, May 12 (Delayed) -- Col. Gen. Dietloff von Arnim, Commander in Chief of the Axis forces in Tunisia, his sallow face drawn and lines of exhaustion etched beneath his eyes, surrendered himself but not the tattered remnants of his army to Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson here this evening.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia, who is here for an official visit, predicted at a press conference this afternoon that Germany would collapse suddenly, just as her army did in Tunisia.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, May 14 (U.P.) -- Allied ground forces inflicted more than ninety-five casualties on the Japanese yesterday in the spreading jungle warfare around Mubo in New Guinea. Allied aircraft attacked Gasmata and other enemy bases on New Britain island.

A fund of more than $400,000, to promote the performance of opera and to help in the musical training of young men and women of talent, was left by Mrs. Joseph B. Long, vice chairman of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, it was disclosed yesterday in a nonresident estate tax appraisal filed here.
Five notable urban gardens were opened to lovers of horticultural beauty yesterday afternoon on the annual pilgrimage of the City Gardens Club.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The long-discussed merger of the Western Union and Postal Telegraph companies neared reality when George H. Payne, one of the Federal Communications Commissioners, announced today that the companies had signed such an agreement and would file application with the FCC to have the pact approved.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 13 (U.P.) -Alfred M. Landon, 1936 Republican Presidential nominee, asserted tonight that his party always had been internationalist in policy and outlined a five-point post-war program calling for an "interim world council."

Roman Catholics in the United States, Alaska and the Hawaiian Islands number 22,945,247, according to the Official Catholic Directory for 1943, to be issued today by P.J. Kenedy Sons, publishers here, who annually compile this sectarian census.

The present subway system, particularly under the pressure of wartime patronage, is responsible for unnecessary accidents resulting in loss of time, temper and jobs. A month ago my friend's leg was crushed between the subway platform and a car when, as she was coming out of the car, one of the maniac mob seeking to enter at the same time knocked her down. She now faces an operation.
While many an angler is necessarily stalled by limitation of travel, Frank Tuma of Montauk demonstrated that the fish-for-food campaign was highly successful as far as he was concerned on Wednesday.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, May 13 (AP) -- A new phase in the war of the Pacific was envisioned by military observers today as a result of the first conference between Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., and General Douglas MacArthur.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown stated today that the cancellation of the 6 per cent increase in railroad freight rates brought about by the intervention of the Office of Price Administration would save more than $350,000,000 a year and that in most cases the savings would be reflected automatically in reduced prices to the consumer.

TRENTON, N.J., May 13 -- Governor Charles Edison's latest effort to obtain confirmation or rejection of nominations to numerous State and county offices proved fruitless today when the Senate reconvened in special session at his call and adjourned within twenty minutes without taking any action.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, May 14 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Senate ended its second day of debate on pay-as-you-go taxation in a muddle reminiscent of the confusion which characterized House consideration of the same legislation. Instead of the three proposals discussed yesterday, five choices, not including the Forand bill passed by the House, were before the Senate as recess was taken until 11 A.M. tomorrow, an hour earlier than usual.

Governor Dewey's appointment of Thomas D. Thacher as an Associate Judge of the Court of Appeals is sure of unanimous approval by the bar and by the public. Mr. Thacher has made his mark in his profession and on the bench. He was well trained for a great career.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 13 -- Troops of the Fourth Indian Division captured General von Arnim and sent him exhausted to General Anderson's First Army headquarters.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Administration leadership appeared today to have effected a postponement of House consideration of drastic anti-strike legislation until after the fifteen-day truce with the coal miners has expired next Tuesday midnight.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Re-employment and cash bonuses for women who enlist in the Waves, Waacs, Spars or Marines, equal to those given to men for military service, are being announced by business firms and industries throughout the Chicago area, Rush Butler, a volunteer member of the Army Council, reported today.

BRITISH FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, May 12 (Delayed) -- Lieut. Gen. Kenneth A.N. Anderson, commander of the British First Army, said today that the Second Corps had done "danmed well" in recent battles and predicted it would do "better and better as the war progresses, for it is a magnificent fighting machine at present" He said Allied casualties had been amazingly small.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 13 -- Walter C. Coffey, president of the University of Minnesota today based his cap and gown honors day address on the implications of THE NEW YORK TIMES examination of the American student's knowledge of his country's history. He called the results appalling, saying:

Although the current group show at the Kleemann Gallery, 65 East Fifty-seventh Street, is called "The Artist and War," a visitor, entering, is not likely to be bowled over by scenes implicit in the title.
LONDON, Friday, May 14 (U.P.) -- The Russian Thursday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded in London:

Pocket Books announce publication of four new titles: "Topper Takes a Trip," by Thorne Smith; "The Pocket Book of Crossword Puzzles"; "The Human Body," by Logan Clendenning, and Dashiell Hammett's "The Glass Key."

Consolidation of the nation's largest telegraph systems -- the Western Union Telegraph Company and Postal Telegraph, Inc. -- to form the largest single telegraph combination in the world was agreed upon yesterday when the top executives of both companies executed an agreement calling for the outright purchase of the Postal system by Western Union.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 13 (AP) -- The captive toll of Germans and Italians neared 175,000, including seventeen be-medaled generals, today in a Tunisian triumph that put Allied airmen only a few minutes' unchallenged flight from Italian Sicily's already devastated ports and military installations.

Finding the National League cellar a cold and lonely spot, the Giants yesterday made certain that company, in the form of the Cubs, would drop in to share their unenviable quarters, and therein lies a story.

The discussion of what to do with Germany after the defeat of Hitler is frequently hampered by widespread confusion about the role of Prussianism as the determining force in German aggression. An instance is the letter of Emil Ludwig which appeared in the May 11 issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES in which he proposes a modified form of geographical division plus Allied occupation to cure German aggressiveness.

The Rev. Dr. Loyd F. Worley of Stamford, Conn., was appointed by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area yesterday to represent the New York East Methodist Conference at coming public hearings before the House Committee on Immigration and Naturalization in Washington on proposed bills to change immigration and naturalization laws.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Secretary Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator, told a press conference today that another interruption of work when the fifteen-day coal truce expired Tuesday midnight was "unthinkable."
ST. LOUIS, May 13 (AP) -- There couldn't be a tougher setting for a relief pitcher -- the score tied, the bases loaded and no one out in the final half of the ninth inning.

Advertising linage in May issues of monthly magazines continued to soar, widening the increase over the 1942 period to more than 22 per cent, according to a compilation yesterday. In April the increase was only about 12 per cent over the like month of last year.

NORTH AFRICA, May 13 (U.P.) -General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Supreme Commander of the Allied Forces in North Africa, revealed today that General Sir Harold R.L.G. Alexander had fooled the German High Command by delivery the knockout blow in Tunisia with the British First Army instead of the Eighth Army, which the Axis had expected to finish the job it started back at El Alamein.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- By a nonpartisan vote of 342 to 65 the House approved today extension of the Administration's reciprocal trade treaty program for two years, instead of the usual three years twice approved by Congress.

Appointments to parishes of the priests who were ordained in St. Patrick's Cathedral a fortnight ago and many transfers of assistants in parishes were announced yesterday at the chancery office of the Archdiocese of New York, 477 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The drafting of fathers for military service in the immediate future appeared likely today as the Army extended the furlough period given to newly inducted men from seven to fourteen days.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Production of piece goods on the worsted and the woolen systems must be stepped up at least 6 per cent for the balance of this year, members of the woolen and worsted industry advisory committee were told here yesterday at a meeting with officials of the textile, clothing and leather division of the War Production Board.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 13 (AP) -- Three of Germany's best and oldest armored divisions and every Italian armored division that ever existed are among the five Axis armies wiped out in the African campaign ended in Tunisia.

VERONA, N.J., May 13 -- A Civil Air Patrol plane crashed this afternoon into a house at 258 Linden Avenue, killing the pilot, tearing a hole in the roof and setting fire to the rear of the structure as it fell to the ground and exploded. The flier was Second Lieutenant Roy G. Paite of 913 North Sixteenth Street, Philadelphia.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 13 (AP) -- Word of the death of their son, Second Lieutenant John P. Burke, nationally prominent golfer, in the Central African area, was received today from the War Department by Mr. and Mrs. David Burke.

For the first time since it began the weekly issuance of statistics on brokers' loans more than a quarter century ago, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York revealed yesterday what part of the total figure represented borrowing on government securities and how much was borrowing for stock market purposes.

Rapid increases in fur-trimming prices are "seriously complicating" the preparation of fur-trimmed coats and suits for Fall despite the good outlook for a strong demand for this merchandise, members of the legal and legislative committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board asserted yesterday at a conference with H. Stanley Ford Jr., head of the women's apparel section of the New York regional office of the OPA.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Further advances in primary market prices for farm products and foods, largely fresh fruits, vegetables and eggs, brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics index up 0.2 per cent during the week ended on May 8.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- It was far better to have beaten the Germans "to their knees" in Africa at the present time and spread this lesson through the German Reich than to have won the race to Tunis in November, Henrly L. Stimson, the Secretary of War, stated today.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- Amid the crumbling ruins of his twenty-one-year-old Fascist regime, Premier Mussolini stood alone today before a bewildered populace and announced that he had ordered the cessation of hostilities in Tunisia "early this morning."

Politically, economically and psychologically French North Africa has presented problems that are in some sense a cross-section of those that we shall encounter when the Allies invade Europe. It has been a political as well as a military testing ground.

TORONTO, May 13 (Canadian Press) -- The Maple Leafs ran their streak to eight straight when they defeated Newark, 2 -- 1, tonight. Jimmy Ripple was responsible for all Toronto's runs as he poled the first pitch over the rightfield fence in the fourth inning, scoring Al Rubeling ahead of him.

Reflecting heavier traffic, the March quarter net income of the United Air Lines Transport Corporation increased to $982,779, or 65 cents a share, from $143,002, or 9 cents a share, in the first three months of 1942, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, discussed plans today to hire 1,400 more investigators to help roll back the cost of living, and said the OPA's new subsidy program would be strictly experimental.

The High School of Music and Art presented its fifteenth annual concert and art exhibition yesterday afternoon at the school. Participants in the concert included the Senior Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Alexander Richter; the Senior Choral Ensemble, under Helen Clarke Moore, and Rhoda Shapiro, pianist.

James F. Byrnes, Director of Economic Stabilization, did not "go far enough" in his order restoring to the War Labor Board certain of the wage powers of which it had been stripped, Emil Rieve, president of the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O., told members of his union yesterday in convention at Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- President Roosevelt asked Congress today to increase the authorization for war housing by $400,000,000 to help shelter an estimated 1,100,000 workers who are expected to migrate to war jobs in the next fiscal year, which begins July 1.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- The Navy Department made public today the names of 1,044 United States Navy personnel held prisoners of war by the Japanese, mostly in the Philippine Islands.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Drawing attention to the first anniversary of the Waac, to be celebrated on Sunday, Secretary Stimson said today at his press conference that be could not overemphasize "the devoted, capable work" of the women's corps, and "the debt of gratietude" toward it owed by the Army as well as the people of this country."

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- With-standing pressure from both Congress and members of the trade, Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, today ruled that the rayon hosiery regulation, setting dollars-and-cents ceiling prices for this type of women's stockings at all sales levels, will go into effect, as a wartime measure, on Saturday.

Though the net effect of Director Byrnes's latest directive is obscured by some ambiguities and apparent contradictions, it seems reasonably clear that it will now permit the War Labor Board majority to continue to grant wage increases. The new directive speaks of permitting wage "adjustments" (in plainer language, increases) provided these "do not increase prices or increase production costs."

BRITISH FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, May 12 (Delayed) -- Long lines of trucks and cars bearing German prisoners passed along a near-by road today. Many officers were driving their own staff cars to the cages and almost all prisoners, Germans and Italians alike, had bed rolls while some bore musical instruments, boxes and books.
WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Captain Charles E. Rosendahl, the naval expert on lighter-than-air aircraft, was nominated today by President Roosevelt to be a rear admiral.

New York University lengthened its lead in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday with an 11-4 victory over Columbia at Baker Field. It was the ninth victory in ten Conference starts for the Violet.

LONDON, Friday, May 14 (U.P.) -- The Moscow radio reported today that the Germans had struck back, in their first retort to Russia's giant air offensive against enemy communication centers, by bombing Liski, south of Voronezh on the main Moscow-Rostov railroad.

Mrs. David Rumsey gave a luncheon yesterday at Sherry's for Mrs. John Hubbard and her house guest, Miss Uecke of Honolulu. The other guests included Mrs. Ernest Fahenstock, Mrs. Edward L. Tinker, Mrs. Willis H. Booth, Miss Janet Coleman, Mrs. J. Herbert Lawson, Miss Margaret Lawson, Mrs. Clark Williams, Mrs. John Adams Mayer, Mrs. J. Ramsay Hunt, Mrs. Harris Fahnestock, Mrs. Henry Merwin Shrady and Miss Mary Rutherfurd Jay.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Growers and distributors differed sharply on the subject of price ceilings for fruits at a hearing before the Office of Price Administration here today. At the same time, Geoffrey Baker, price executive of the agency's fresh fruit and vegetables division, heatedly denied statements by growers that its regulations were stifling production.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 13 (AP) -- Shipping losses in moving the enormous number of men and supplies into North Africa for the Allied campaign have amounted to 2.16 per cent of the total traffic, it was announced officially today.

A little after 10 o'clock yesterday morning a thin, rather tall sailor in United States Navy uniform appeared on a two-foot ledge atop the thirteen-story loft building at 315 Fifth Avenue at the southeast corner of Thirty-second Street.

The United States Army is finding a place for the mentally retarded and "marginally useful" soldier, just as institutions for persons of similar limitations are training them for occupations related to the war, leaders in this field declared yesterday at the sixty-seventh annual meeting of the American Association on Mental Deficiency.

" Lady of Burlesque" has received a "Class C" or "condemned" rating, from the National Legion of Decency, it was announced yesterday coincident with the Broadway opening of the film at the Capitol Theatre. Barbara Stanwyck and Michael O'Shea are starred in the picture produced by Hunt Stromberg for release by United Artists.

In the presence of 2,000 pupils from the city's public and parochial schools, assembled yesterday in City Hall Plaza, Mayor La Guardia presented War Bonds and honor scrolls to the winners and runners-up in a city-wide essay contest conducted as a preliminary to the "I Am An American Day" exercises to be held Sunday on Central Park Mall.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 13 -- The German High Command today added its official "finis" to the fighting in Tunisia. Its last communique to bear a North African dateline said:

LONDON, Friday, May 14 -- The Netherlands was reported on the verge of open revolt against her German conquerors today, and a Stockholm dispatch said rioting had occurred in Berlin among relatives of German troops overwhelmed by the Allies in Tunisia. The Berlin episode, said by a Swedish newspaper to have occurred in the heart of the Nazi capital Wednesday, was not confirmed elsewhere.

Three new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Globe the attraction will be "They Came to Blow Up America," a Twentieth Century-Fox drama starring George Sanders. In supporting roles are Ward Bond, Anna Sten, Dennis Hoey, Sig Rumann and Ludwig Stossel. . . .

Last week serious disturbances broke out in Guadeloupe. The local police suppressed them but it must have been a pretty hard job since four men were killed. That fact evidences the population's growing impatience with the totalitarian rule of Admiral Georges Robert and his subordinates.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- A significant move toward closer coordination of Army, Air and Navy High Commands was announced today by Secretary Stimson in disclosing the establishment of a joint Army and Navy Staff College.

Dr. Camille Dreyfus, president of the Celanese Corporation of America, reported yesterday to stockholders in an interim statement of operations for the first quarter of 1943 consolidated net profit of $1,985,848 after provision of $3,392,316 for Federal taxes on income.

It is plain, from experience in this and other areas, that the present air-raid-warning system is not working well. This is not because it baffles the public intelligence. Any one can understand it. It is because the American temperament, or perhaps plain human nature, does not like to operate in a twilight zone.

A red, white and blue ribbon, guarding $13.35 worth of food, was cut yesterday morning by Commissioner of Markets Daniel P. Woolley to open a point rationing and menu planning information service for Harlem residents. The food, representing an adequate week's diet for a family of five, was displayed in Booth 301, Building 3, of the Park Avenue Market at 113th Street.

Edwin T. Gibson, vice president of the General Foods Corporation, announced that the corporation had signed an agreement here yesterday with Snider Packing Corporation for the acquisition of all assets and business of the latter company, subject to the approval of Snider stockholders.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., May 13 -- Fifty officers and enlisted men of the Army Air Forces were cited here today, one of them posthumously, for "extraordinary achievements." All received air medals and one, the posthumous recipient, a purple heart decoration in addition.
BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- The Cardinals turned five hits into five runs in the seventh inning today to shut out the Braves, 5 to 0.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 8 were 12 per cent above the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This gain followed a loss of 5 per cent for the week ended May 1 compared with the like week of 1942.

The letter in a recent issue of THE TIMES, "On Jobs for Older Women" and signed "Clubwoman," is, according to my experience, entirely mistaken. For the first time in my life I am working in a factory, doing war work. I am sure there are not a few other women like me, over 50 years old, who accomplish a forty-eight-hour week with no sense of doing anything very unusual.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- When the revenue bill of 1942 was before the Finance Committee of the Senate, the Secretary of the Treasury recommended a spendings tax, to provide the Treasury with funds and to reduce consumer spending. It was explained that the levy was designed to reach the low income groups and to put penalty rates on luxury purchases.

Diederich H. Ward was nominated president of the Life Underwriters Association of the City of New York, Inc., Beatrice Jones, chairman of the association's committee on nominations and elections, announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Fowler McCormick, president of the International Harvester Company, said at the annual meeting of stockholders at Hoboken, N.J., yesterday that the sharp reduction in civilian volume handled by the company has resulted in a drop of 19 per cent in net sales for the six months ended April 30, the first half of its fiscal year.
CLEVELAND, May 13 -- Washington racked up two runs in the twelfth inning and then staved off a last-minute flurry by the Indians to earn a 3-to-2 triumph in League Park today.

On the one hand, we have the airplane and plastics. On the other hand, there is Thomas Jefferson. We look to the airplane, after it has helped us win a global war, to help us build a global civilization in which everybody will be next-door neighbors.

Brooklyn Technical and Haaren High Schools set national records in naval aviation cadet examinations which were conducted throughout the country last week, and five other city high schools, including three Catholic schools, won high recognition in the tests, it was revealed yesterday by the Naval Aviation Cadet Selection Board, 120 Broadway.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 13 (AP) -- Bill Voiselle, youthful Jersey City right-hander, hurled his third shutout of the season and his second over Rochester when the Little Giants shaded the Red Wings today, 1 -- 0, in ten innings.

LONDON, May 13 (AP) -- The Bank of England in its weekly condition statement issued today, disclosed a decrease of 2,347,000 in notes in circulation, the first decline reported since the latter part of January.

The Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot is especially anxious to have as many capable shirt manufacturers as possible bid on its procurement involving 19,000,000 Army shirts, bids for which will be opened May 25, according to Clayton D. Quaw, quartermaster liaison specialist in the WPB.

LONDON, May 13 -- Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister, announced to a cheering House of Commons today that with the conclusion of fighting in North Africa that theatre of war had ceased to be a "vulnerable area to be defended" but had become an advanced base for a final assault upon the fortress of Europe to force Hitler to surrender unconditionally as his generals did in Tunisia.

Because the Stock Clearing Corporation no longer clears but only settles transactions, the heavy volume of March, April and May has caused strain but no breakdown in its operations. Only once this Spring has overtime carried beyond midnight, compared with December of 1941, when the staff staggered to hotel beds at 5 A.M. day after day.

ALBANY, May 13 (AP) -- A request that harness racing be permitted this Summer at New York State's three trotting centers -- Goshen, Westbury and the Saratoga Raceway -- was presented to Governor Dewey today by Frank L. Wiswall, secretary of the United States Trotting Association.

ALBANY, May 13 -- Plans to halt the departure of high school students from classrooms to war plants and for the part-time instruction of thousands who already have left were tentatively agreed on today at a conference attended by local school superintendents, officials of the State Education Department and a representative of the War Manpower Commission.

Figures which post-war planners toss casually into their remarks are, to speak conservatively, impressive. We have been told that our potential unemployment at the close of hostilities will be 15,000,000 persons. Yesterday Holgar J. Johnson, president of the Institute of Life Insurance estimated that the war's end will see us with a backlog of needed housing which may reach $15,000,000,000 or $20,000,000,000.
Ernest Gordon (Blimp) Phelps, 35-year-old catcher, yesterday was purchased by the Phillies from the Pirates for an unannounced sum and will don a Philly uniform on Monday.

Author, Mountbatten's Aide, Says England Is Careful to Keep People Informed "Complete and unfailing help" from the nationals of the occupied countries in Europe has been encountered by British raiding, parties on any landings or operations undertaken on the Continent, according to Hilary St. George Saunders, official British recorder on the staff of Lord Louis Mountbatten's Combined Operations command, here to confer with British Information Service officials in America.

About 50,000 square feet of space on the fourth, fifth and sixth floors of the Broad Exchange Building, at 25 Broad Street, has been leased by the War Department from the Prudential Insurance Company of America through the Abex Realty Company, Inc., brokers.

W. Warder Norton, chairman of the Council on Books in Wartime, yesterday described as "wholly inaccurate" statements involving the council's name which appeared in an Associated Press story from Washington dated May 12. The story concerned a contract for the purchase of books, to be cheaply printed for distribution to American forces overseas, arranged through the Council on Books in Wartime.

YOU can see George Jessel in person at the Capitol Theatre today (advt.). You can see a stage show with other expert entertainers and a Barbara Stanwyck movie, too, and probably a news reel and an advertisement of the next attraction. And the amount of time passed more or less pleasantly will be only a little less than it would take to read a book called "So Help Me."*

A Reconstruction Finance Corporation official and a group of insurance company executives took the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday to deny all knowledge of a supposed meeting at which the price of certain railroad bonds was reported to have been discussed.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that he would begin tomorrow a three-day conference with Marriner S. Eccles, governor of the Federal Reserve Board, and the presidents of the Federal Reserve Banks on the government's borrowing policy.

Postmaster Albert Goldman made public yesterday an outline map showing the key numbers for New York residents showing the stations of the New York Postoffice and the key numbers of the delivery units. A study of the map, Mr. Goldman explained, will help the public to familiarize itself in the use of the key-number system.

There has been a widespread popular belief that many wartime aircraft, notably the big bombers, will be suitable for conversion to cargo-carrying when the war is over and the world is once more at peace. Those experts in the industry, however, who have given most thought to the subject hold that cargo planes will be specifically designed for the job.
Sixteen-year-old Rosemary Glimm -- who would rather "be a math teacher than a poet" -- is this year's poet laureate for the city's high schools.

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- For the 221st time since March 1 American airmen last Tuesday heavily bombed the Japanese submarine base and airfield at Kiska, enemy position in the Aleutians, the Navy Department announced today. It was the first onslaught against Kiska since May 6, when our forces attacked the island five times.
CHUNGKING, China, May 13 (AP) -- The Japanese have again attacked Chinese lines west of Tungting Lake. Both sides suffered numerous casualties.

LONDON, Friday, May 14 -- American Flying Fortresses, following up history's greatest air raid which rocked Duisburg, Germany, before dawn yesterday, made their own heaviest attack of the war on Europe a few hours later.

The owner and placement managers of the Accurate Personnel Service of 2 John Street testified yesterday, in the State investigation into discriminatory employment practices, that such conditions were widespread in this city, but their agency, far from abetting such law violations, actually combated them.

The alumnae of the Gardner School of New York and Tuxedo Park will give a luncheon today at the Junior League clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. Proceeds will augment the Louise Elting Memorial Fund, which provides student scholarships.

LONDON, May 13 -- For three months after the Allied landing in North Africa the shipping tonnage available to the Food Ministry was barely sufficient to feed the population of this island nation, it was disclosed today in the House of Commons by William Mabane, Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry.

After the war American housewives are promised curtains, draperies and upholstery in true, bright colors that will not fade. Mrs. Harry Linkletter, a chemist of the Aridye Corporation, described a new pigment-printing process, developed by her concern, at the final session of the Decorator's Club annual institute yesterday at the Parsons School of Design, 136 East Fifty-seventh Street.

DETROIT, May 13 (AP) -- The Tigers, those overtime specialists, dropped a thirteen-inning game today to the Athletics, 2 to 1, when Dick Siebert singled home the winning run to give Jesse Flores, rookie Mexican right-hander, his fourth successive pitching triumph.
The German Thursday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Loft properties in Manhattan continued yesterday to prove attractive to investors and operators.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, May 13 -- General Douglas MacArthur and Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., commanders in the Southwest and South Pacific, respectively, have met to effect the closest cooperation between their forces, it was announced today, and a headquarters spokesman said that General MacArthur would command any joint operations that might result.

CHICAGO, May 13 -- Reports that liberal deliveries of Canadian oats would be made on May contracts started liquidation in all grains today on the Board of Trade, and wheat, oats and rye declined about 1 1/2 cents a bushel before short covering and some commission house support were able to check the break
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 13 (AP) -- A communique:
I don't intend to deal with Emil Ludwig, the politician. However, I was astonished to read in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 11 the following sentence written by Emil Ludwig, the historian:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 13 -- A new type of savings account known as the "citizens' budget account,'' designed to assist patrons in systematically budgeting their money to take care of certain basic responsibilities, was announced today by T. Philip Reitinger, president of the Montclair Savings Bank.

Although bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday were 8.7 per cent below the preceding week's twelve-year record volume, the total of $9,215,528,000 for the twenty-three major cities of the nation showed the substantial gain of 45.7 per cent over the $6,326,942,000 recorded in the corresponding week last year, according to yesterday's report by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

BOSTON, May 13 (AP) -- Ask Aunt Ada, owned by Captain Henry H. Hecht of Baltimore, scored her third victory in five starts today as she won by two and a half lengths in the Marblehead Purse at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 11,500.

More than one-third of the $4,500,000 minimus goal set for the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund has been raised in the first ten days of the drive, according to W. Randolph Burgess, general chairman of the fund, who reported a total of $1,561,628 at the first report luncheon held yesterday in the Hotel Commodore.

Eight hundred tulips, along with other Spring flowers, rose arbors and trailing ivy, were featured in the Dutch Garden of Holland House at its official opening yesterday afternoon in commemoration of the third anniversary of the invasion of Holland by the Nazis.

Cotton prices were irregularly lower yesterday under the continuance of hedging operations and scattered liquidation. On the New York Cotton Exchange final prices of active contracts were unchanged to 5 points lower with the exception of October, which was up 1 point.
CHUNGKING, China, May 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Along thousands of miles of Atlantic and Mediterranean beaches the German patrols today move restlessly and there is the clang of metal as Hitler strengthens what he calls his "Fortress Europe." Though he cannot in this way make invasion impossible, he can make it hard.
WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- Navy communique 375:

WASHINGTON, May 13 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, who braved the German submarine menace in making his trip here by sea for global war conferences with President Roosevelt, will address a joint session of Congress next Wednesday at 12:30 P.M. (Eastern war time), it was announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13 (AP) -- The Phillies moved into fourth place in the National League today by splitting a double-header with the Reds before a ladies' day crowd of 7,541. This was one of the largest weekday turnouts in years for the Phillies, who gained a 2-to-1 victory in the opener, but dropped the second game, 3 to 1.
New York University succeeded Fordham as champion of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference when the Violets defeated St. John's, 11-1 at Ohio Field yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 14 -- Allied planes, participating in the sweeping victory in Tunisia gained "complete air supremacy" not only over the Axis lines, but over airfields, shipping lanes and bases in Sicily, Sardinia and Italy, it was disclosed yesterday when the United States Army's African Air Force and the Royal Air Force made a joint report of operations during the North African campaign.

BOSTON, May 14 (AP) -- After taking two consecutive strikes, Charlie Workman lashed the third pitch for a hit to right field with two out and the bases loaded in the tenth inning to give the Braves a 4-3 victory over the Cardinals today.

With the exception of the black markets in foods, few wartime frauds are flourishing, according to the twenty-first annual report of the Better Business Bureau of New York, made yesterday at the board of directors' meeting. The report disclosed that more than 1,000 complaints and inquiries have been acted upon in protecting consumers from deceptive advertising and selling practices in cooperation with business and government bureaus.

Though the public has paid little attention to Senator Kilgore's bill which would set up an Office of Scientific and Technological Mobilization, few recent proposals have been the subject of more controversy. Senator Kilgore wants his proposed office not only to draft all research scientists but to develop science and technology, encourage inventors and guide the President and Congress in scientific matters.

MEXICO CITY, May 14 -Rear Admiral Arthur W. Johnson, head of the Mexico-United States Joint ! Defense Committee, and other I United States members arrived here today to confer with Mexican I military leaders and with FranI cisco CastiUo NAjera, Mexican Ambassador to Washington, on I questions of defense. Several meetings have been scheduled.

Abraham Straus, Inc. in its statement of operations for the twelve months ended on Jan. 31, last, disclosed yesterday an increase in net sales to $28,676,974 from $27,216,444 for the twelve months ended with January, 1942.

A reappraisal of labor policies and practices leading to better employment relationships through the elimination of "middle men," whom he described as labor leaders, politicians and bureaucrats, was suggested last night by C. Donald Dallas, president of Revere Copper and Brass, Inc., at the opening session of the National Council of Foremen's Clubs, at William Sloan House, 356 West Thirty-fourth Street.

Walter Vincent was re-elected president of the Actors Fund of America at the organization's sixty-first annual meeting yesterday at the Lyceum Theatre. Other officers elected without opposition were Harry G. Sommers, first vice president; Katharine Cornell, second vice president; Vinton Freedley, treasurer; Robert Campbell, secretary, and Charles Dow Clark, J. Herbert Mack, Warren P. Munsell, James O'Neill, Jacob I. Goodstein and Alfred Lunt, trustees for three years.

SWEDESBORO, N.J., May 14 -- The Duke of Windsor learned to cut asparagus and mistook a juke box for a stove today during a flying visit to 214 of his constituents, Bahaman Negroes who were brought to this Southern New Jersey area to help relieve the farm labor shortage.
Although Manhattan collected only six hits in its game with Fordham yesterday, the Jaspers won the Metropolitan College Baseball Conference contest on Rose Hill by 9 to 8.

The apartment house at 143 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn, on a plot 75 by 257.6 feet has been sold by the Sourad Realty Corporation to the Framox Holding Corporation, subject to a mortgage of $108,675. A purchase money mortgage of $39,000 was executed.

WASHINGTON, May 14--The National Labor Relations Board offered today to dismiss its long-fought proceedings against two West Coast companies of Henry J. Kaiser if he would agree with the American Federation of Labor to make "open shops" of three shipbuilding yards at Portland and Vancouver. The A.F.L. declined the offer.

Doris Fleeson, for nine years a Washington reporter for The New York Daily News, and Gertrude Bailey, women's editor of The New York World-Telegram, received last night the seventh annual awards of the New York Newspaper Women's Club for outstanding stories by women journalists during 1942.

The Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. track and field championships, compressed into one day in line with the hurry-up policy associated with most college activities but retaining, nevertheless, a full sixteen-event program, will be held today at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

Asserting that present trends indicate that increased Federal control of finance may be exerted in the post-war period, thus endangering the present powers of the State-chartered banking system and State government institutions, Eugene E. Agger, New Jersey Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, told members of the New Jersey Bankers Association at the fortieth annual convention yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania that prevention lies in the ability to "modernize" State operations.
Ralph R. Browning, vice president of the Union Carbide Company, has leased a large apartment in 320 Park Avenue through Pease Elliman, brokers. Douglas L. Elliman Co., agents.

The annual awards and citations of the National Association for American Composers and Conductors were announced last night at a reception and musicale at the Waldorf-Astoria. The Henry Hadley Medal "for the greatest service to American music during the past year" was awarded to Deems Taylor, "primarily for his broadcasts over the Columbia network in connection with the Sunday concerts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society."

NEW HAVEN, Cleveland, May 14 -- The first formal meeting in the academic history of the United States to study the consequences of alcohol will be held in a six-week session of a School of Alcohol Studies at Yale University this Summer.

BOMBAY, India, May 14 (U.P.) -- Kan Bahadur Allah Baksh, ousted Prime Minister of turbulent Sind Province and president of the All-India Azad (Independent) Moslem Conference, was shot and killed by gunmen today at Shikarpur, near the Baluchistan frontier.
LONDON, May 14 -- Two separate pronouncements on the Battle of the Atlantic were made in London today, and both of them struck a highly encouraging note.

GOOSE AIRPORT, Labrador, May 14 -- One of the vital links in the chain of airfields that provide short-jump passage between the New World and the Old is a tiny piece of land in the wastes of Labrador. It is regarded by many as the most important transport airfield in the world today.

DETROIT, May 14 (AP) -- Pete Suder, refusing to become discouraged, squeezed home Johnny Welaj with a run off the veteran Tommy Bridges in the twelfth inning today to give the Athletics a 7-to-6 victory over the Tigers and a 2-to-1 series edge.

Lilacs from Southern Jersey, both lavendar and white, waft a delicate Spring fragrance through Manhattan flower stalls this week. With more and more outdoor-grown flowers appearing, the New York Department of Agriculture and Markets revealed yesterday that city dwellers unable to drive to the country may easily bring Maytime blossoms into their homes.

LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- Adolf Hitler's strong-arm specialist, Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler, was reported hurrying to Sofia tonight at the urgent call of King Boris to help keep the Bulgarians in line while German military experts strengthen defenses there against the possibility of an Allied blow in the Balkans.
