A simplified plan of price regulation for the fur industry, designed to eliminate many of the difficulties encountered under the present ceilings, was discussed yesterday at a joint meeting of the ready-to-wear and governmental regulations committees of the Association of Buying Offices, held in the offices of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

NEW DELHI, India, May 14 (AP) -- The British command announced today that British and Indian troops had fallen back again in Western Burma, this time withdrawing northward from Maungdaw, only a few miles from the frontier of India.

Final responsibility for relations between academic and military portions of the Navy's College V-12 Training Program, which will start at 150 colleges on July 1, must rest with the educators and naval officers immediately in charge of each college, Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, Chief of Naval Personnel, declared yesterday at the conference of 600 college and Navy officials in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University.
Harvard's action in dropping intercollegiate football for the duration of the war is deplorable. It is simply pathetic to see a big fellow take that attitude when the going gets a little difficult.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 14 (AP) -- A communique:
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 14 (AP) -- Jersey City won on two hits today, rallying in the ninth inning to score three runs and defeat Rochester, 3 -- 2.

About 3,000 children, ranging in age from two weeks through adolescence, are in danger of becoming war casualties here in New York, Miss Sophie van S. Theis, secretary of the New York City Committee on Child Welfare said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The combined air power of the United States and Britain destroyed 2,000 Axis planes, while losing only 770 of United Nations aircraft, during the six months and three days of the African campaign, through Nov. 8 to May 11, the War Department revealed today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 14--Allied bombers and warships pounded Italy's island outposts in Sardinia and Pantelleria yesterday.
The Dodgers and Freddy Fitzsimmons tried a noble experiment of their own yesterday at Ebbets Field, and the results were sad.
CHUNGKING, China, May 14 (U.P.) -- A. Communique:

HEADQUARTERS, ARMY AIR FORCES SCHOOL OF APPLIED TACTICS, ORLANDO, Fla., May 14 -- "Brooklyn-in-the-jungle was shown to visiting correspondents today. Cleverly camouflaged and hidden in the swamps and brush near Leesburg, it was only an hour and a half's ride from school headquarters by bus, and about thirty minutes back by transport plane.

More than a generation ago President Theodore Roosevelt established Superior National Forest, in the Rainy Lake country, forming part of the boundary between Minnesota and Ontario. On the Canadian side the Quetico Provincial Park was set up at the same time.
LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The elimination of lay representatives of claimants in workmen's compensation cases and their replacement by a panel of lawyers who would give free advice to injured employes was indicated yesterday at the Moreland inquiry into the job law at the Bar Association Building.

Leaders in the architectural and community planning fields hailed Edward M. Bassett as the "father of zoning and the best-known authority on this subject in America" yesterday when they presented him with their Medal of Honor for City Planning.

Postmaster Albert Goldman reported yesterday continued progress in the city's assimilation of the new key number plan for mailing. He said the response of business organizations and the public has been little short of sensational, and that this type of cooperation would soon iron out any difficulties that might arise from the adoption of the new system.
Arthur Daley's article in THE TIMES last Sunday concerning Pat McDonald was grand and undoubtedly was appreciated especially by the old-timers who followed athletic events in the old days.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor, with 15,000 other circus fans, attended the Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus at Madison Square Garden last night, and to the Duke, as to few other devotees of the big top, came the moment of a lifetime.
The International Game Fish Association has announced that a new world's record has been established, an unusual achievement because of current wartime restrictions.

These last few days the postmasters of New York and Brooklyn have been trying to teach their somewhat too large classes a new style of addressing local letters. Our days have long been numbered; now our letters must be. Addressing an envelope to be delivered in this town, you put after the name of its urban destination the number of the district, the not at all mystic but "key" number.

LONDON, May 14 -- General Charles de Gaulle announced tonight that he had appointed a "Monsieur X," described officially as one of the leaders of the French underground movement, as a member of the French National Committee.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (Science Service) -- With faulty welding alleged as cause of failures in recently constructed Liberty ships, particular interest will attach to an X-ray method for testing new welds, just patented here by William A. Bruce of Tulsa, Okla.

DAVIS-MONTHAN FIELD, Tucson, Ariz., May 14 -- High above the hot sands, cactus and mesquite of Southern Arizona thousands of young Americans, already trained as pilots, navigators, aerial engineers, gunners and radio operators, are being molded into combat teams to take giant Liberator bombers on their egg-laying missions over enemy territory wherever in the world it may be found.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during April totaled 938,989 bales of lint and 105,475 bales of linters, compared with 999,749 bales of lint and 130,1929 bales of linters in April last year.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The reciprocal trade agreements program was held up tonight by Secretary Hull as a cornerstone of policy which will determine whether the United States is to cooperate for peace, security and prosperity in the post-war world.

CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) -- Frederick C. Crawford, president of Thompson Products, Inc., reported today first-quarter earnings of $448,952 for the company and all subsidiaries, except Thompson Aircraft Products Company, equal to $1.41 a share of common stock.

CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) -- For a few moments today the Indians thought Jim Bagby had his fourth straight victory but the scrappy Senators pushed over three runs in the ninth inning for a 3-to-1 triumph which gave them the series, two games to one.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 14 -- The great round-up of Axis prisoners and booty continued in Tunisia yesterday. The war in Africa, which began on June 10, 1940, when Italy entered the war, was concluded at 11:45 A.M. yesterday when the few remaining Axis troops holding out against the tightening Allied ring of steel surrendered.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A measure authorizing construction of 1,000,000 tons of small naval craft for amphibious warfare was passed swiftly by the House today after it had heard the boats would be used "to open new fronts on foreign soil wherever necessary."

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The largest Navy Department appropriation bill ever offered in the country's history, carrying a total of $29,463,687,198 for the fiscal year beginning July 1, was reported to the House today by the Appropriations Committee. The next largest was last year's appropriation measure of $23,738,000,000.

" Masquerade," a Soviet importation, will have its local premiere today at the Stanley Theatre. The picture, based on the poetic drama by Mikhail Lermontov, nineteenth-century Russian writer, was produced by the Lenfilm Studios, Leningrad, U.S.S.R. Featured players are Nikolai Mordvinov and Tamara Markarova.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) -- The appointment of Palmer Hoyt, publisher of the Morning Oregonion of Portland, as domestic director of the Office of War Information, succeeding Gardner Cowles Jr., was announced by the OWI director, Elmer Davis, today.

ALBANY, May 14 -- Most of the major industrial groups in the State increased payrolls from March to April, the Department of Labor announced today. This was due mainly to increased payrolls and hours in war plants. Some losses were reported by factories making civilian goods.

Convicted of maintaining a place for gambling, Mrs. Sarah Shanoff, 37-year-old widow and mother of two children, was fined $100, with an alternative of thirty days in jail, yesterday by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney in Bronx Magistrates Court. She said she had no money to pay the fine and it appeared likely that she also would lose her $74 monthly widow's pension.

FONTANA, Calif., May 14 -- The first steel made on the West Coast from Western iron ore was tapped here late this afternoon, when an open-hearth furnace poured out a 150-ton stream of molten metal at Henry J. Kaiser's integrated iron and steel mill, the first to be put in operation west of the Rockies.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Prices at which well-known brands of soap may be retailed to the public were set today by the Office of Price Administration in a regulation, effective May 24, which also fixed wholesale and manufacturing ceilings.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 14 -- The political innocence of United States troops in Northern Ireland let the British military chiefs in for an embarrassing moment, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- American troops have landed on Attu, westernmost link in the Aleutian chain, and a violent battle is progressing for possession of this strategic volcanic isle, held by the Japanese since last June.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- A delegation of monetary experts representing the Philippine Government stated today that it agreed in essentials with the United States plan for world currency stabilization and would be willing to participate in formal conferences with the Treasury on that basis.

Many of the commodities in the so-called "nonessential lists" of Latin-American countries drawn up under the decentralization plan of the Board of Economic Warfare have been included at the behest of the United States Government and not on the basis of the needs of the countries of destination, it was charged yesterday by exporters.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Barring of labor representatives, officials of the Office of Civilian Supply, representatives of the War Production Board's own information division and other "observers" from closed meetings of WPB's industry advisory committees appeared to have collapsed here tonight under concerted protests.

LONDON, May 14 -- All Jews in Warsaw's ghetto have been "liquidated," according to Poles' reports to Rabbi Irving Miller of Far Rockaway, Queens, who is here as secretary general of the World Jewish Congress.

WASHINGTON, May 14--New blows to aid "heroic Russia," and "long-tormented China" were promised today by Prime Minister Churchill as a result of his global war conferences with President Roosevelt at the White House.

As Magistrates Courts throughout New York City meted out punishment to violators of price ceilings on food items under authorization of the State War Council yesterday, the demand for jail sentences grew more insistent.

As the first step in an attempt to wrest control of the American Labor party in the city and State from its right wing, the New York County executive committee of the party, controlled by its left wing, issued a statement last night attacking "those who seek to disrupt the United Nations through slander of our great fighting ally, the Soviet Union."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Iay 14 (U.P.)-Organized resistance on the enemy's lost African bridgehead ceased at 7:52 P. i. Wednesday, an official announcement said, but it was not until some sixteen hours later that the last exhausted Germans straggled down from the l hills and surrendered.

LONDON, May 14 -- The stock markets again were cheerful today. The chief interest was in a continuation of speculative buying of foreign bonds encouraged by favorable war news. South American securities continued to attract speculators.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Prime Minister Wintson Churchill, who used to be First Lord of the Admiralty, finds a voyage across the Atlantic restful despite the menace of German submarines, for whom he would be a prize bag, it was disclosed today.

In a leading editorial on May 10, you take up the cudgels against subsidies. As the Director of the Export-Import Price Control Office in the Office of Price Administration, I have spent much time studying the subsidy problem.
WASHINGTON, May 14--The House under unanimous consent passed today the Bolton bill providing Federal aid for nurses' training.

British and Indian officials paid tribute yesterday to the part being played in the war by Indian volunteers at the formal opening of the British Indian Merchant Navy Club for seamen at 100 West Thirty-eighth Street.

And so the curtain goes down on the northern rim of Africa, which is the southern edge of the Mediterranean. The scene shifts back to the sea itself and its northern shores. Exit the African desert across which for nearly three years the combatants shuttled back and forth.

With eighteen named for the $10,000 added Metropolitan Handicap, Belmont Park will stage its first Saturday program of the Spring meeting today, and transportation worries or no a crowd of at least 25,000 is expected.

The A.E. Gallatin Collection, which formerly constituted the Museum of Living Art at New York University, is now settled in its ne home, the Philadelphia Museum, where, after a preview luncheon, it was opened to the public yesterday afternoon.

John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, would not comment last night on the action of the War Labor Board ordering resumption of negotiations in the bituminous wage dispute, with the request that the conferees report back to the board within ten days.

The issues raised by MPR 339, which becomes effective today for manufacturers of women's rayon hosiery, "will not down until they are given a sound solution," Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, declared yesterday in commenting on the decision of OPA Administrator Prentiss M. Brown not to defer the effective date as requested by the producers.
The historic Parmly estate known as "Bingham Hill" at Rumson, N.J., has been purchased by Mike Jacobs, sports promoter, through William H. Hintelmann, broker.

A feature of the cotton futures market yesterday was the squeeze in the May position, trading in which ceased at noon with the close 46 to 51 points above that on Thursday. Other active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were easier throughout the session, mainly on hedging operations, and closed at net losses of 13 to 18 points.

The most outstanding feature of the 1942 operations of the Ford Motor Company of Canada, Ltd., was the volume of products shipped, the total value of which was $177,418,446, W.R. Campbell, president, said in his address to stockholders, made public yesterday.

Newspaper advertising linage last month spurted 17.0 per cent over the corresponding 1942 period, the largest year-to-year gain chalked up in many years, according to a Media Records compilation of newspaper advertising in fifty-two cities.

In this time of gas rationing horses are more important than ever. But, just as motor vehicles cannot operate without gas, horses cannot work without water to drink. The New York Women's League for Animals makes a special plea this Spring for aid to carry on the free watering stations which it maintains in traffic districts of the city.

It is hard to tot up a political balance sheet of North Africa without referring to the basic assumption of the Anglo-American plans for that operation -- an assumption that, it may be argued, was wrong but one on which the whole campaign was predicated.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The National War Labor Board late today unanimously directed officials of the United Mine Workers of America and Appalachian bituminous coal operators to resume negotiations, with an implied promise of higher pay per week for mine workers if coal production continued uninterrupted after expiration of the current "truce" at midnight Tuesday.

LONDON, Saturday, May 15 (AP) -- The Red Air Force, attacking in the East as the Allied aerial offensive swelled in the West, destroyed seventy-two German planes, 300 freight cars, 200 supply trucks and other enemy war equipment in widespread raids along the huge Russian front, it was announced in Moscow early today.

Joseph Stalin said in a 1926 interview that Russia would not hesitate to give financial aid to American Communists "if we thought it might accomplish something of value," Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury.

LONDON, May 14 (U.P.) -- Violence, sabotage and mass strikes spread through the Netherlands tonight despite the execution of more than seventy patriots in the last twenty-four hours and a German warning that "every attempt to cause unrest will be drowned in blood."

EVERY one wonders how the Chinese, beaten back into the western hills and deprived of their richest factory and farming regions, derive the strength to fight on. And every one wonders how Chinese coolies, sleeping bunk above bunk in the warrens of port cities, maintain an essential dignity and pleasantness amid squalor that would change other people into snarling beasts.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 14 -- Ann Sheridan will be starred by Warners in the film version of Sinclair Lewis's "Hand Book for Jealousy," a current magazine serial, film rights to which were acquired while the novel was in galley-proof form.
LONDON, May 14 -- In connection with its third anniversary celebration, which will come to a climax Sunday, the British Home Guard today took over the historic job of guarding Buckingham Palace.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The wheat policy of the Roosevelt Administration. which has included subsidizing of farmers to "plow under" wheat lands and subsidizing of farmers to grow other crops in the face of what seemed a surplus of farinaceous foods, is on the point of reversal.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 15 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:

Keeping a promise he had made before he came to Washington on his present journey, Mr. Churchill broadcast yesterday a message of gratitude and good cheer to the Home Guards of Britain. The third anniversary of their "faithful, unwearying and absolutely indispensable work" will be celebrated by their countrymen tomorrow.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 14 -- Marking the ascendancy of the Army over the Fascist party in the direction of Italian affairs now that the question of defense has become a crisis, the quadrumvirate of new marshals -- Enrico Caviglia, Rodolfo Graziani, Ugo Cavallero and Emilio de Bono -- who assumed responsibility from the party directorate for the defense of the peninsula, got down to work early this morning.

Leon Greanin former director-producer of the Jooss Ballet, is planning an "up-to-date" version of "Chauve-Souris" for Broadway presentation sometime this Summer. Mr. Greanin reports that arrangements for the production have been completed with Mrs. Morris Gest and Mme.

Saying that he intended to support President Roosevelt in all measures necessary for victory in the war but to oppose domestic policies that did not contribute to the war program and tended to undermine our democratic form of government by autocracy and waste, Senator Harry F. Byrd attacked the Roosevelt Administration last night for its handling of the labor problem, for extravagance in spending and for ineptness of a growing bureaucracy.

Dr. Ira S. Wile, child psychologist, has sold the four-story building which has been his home and office for many years at 264 West Seventy-third Street to M.C. Berg, realty operator. The property is assessed at $25,000, of which $22, 000 is land value, and was purchased subject to a first mortgage of $8,750. It was in one ownership for about twenty-three years and was sold through the Wood, Dolson Company.
WASHINGTON, May 14--The House Appropriations Committee carried to the floor today its fight to remove from government payrolls three officials it called unfit to hold a public position of trust.

" I am an American Day" will be observed tomorrow in the churches and today in the synagogues. Clergymen will preach sermons on the duty of every citizen to make sacrifices at home for the war effort in some degree commensurate with those of our men in the armed forces, especially those giving their lives.

PHILADELPHIA, May 14 -- Armour Co., a Delaware corporation, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amendment naming ninety underwriters to handle their proposed issue of $35,000,00 of 7 per cent cumulative income debentures due in 1978, which will be offered to the public about May 19.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 14 -- Asserting that the OPA's coupon system of shoe rationing has so dislocated normal consumer demand that lower-priced shoes are not selling, I.M. Kay, chairman of the Midwest Volume Shoe Retailers Committee, declared that it should be replaced with "a new and equitable rationing plan."
Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's broadcast to Britain yesterday on the occasion of the third anniversary of the British Home Guard, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:
WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Roosevelt held his press conference; Prime Minister Churchill and he conferred with United Nations leaders.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 15 -- The Japanese made a costly raid yesterday morning on the Allied base at Oro Bay in New Guinea's Buna sector, sending over twenty bombers with twenty-five fighters and losing sixteen to twenty-two planes.

Retail trade here improved this week in comparison with a year ago, with weather conditions a stimulating factor toward the end of the period. Considerable variations between stores in percentages of increases were noted, however.

The May issue of the New York Public Library's monthly publication, "Branch Library Book News," is devoted to the post-war world. Called "Tomorrow's World," the booklet contains an annotated list of books on present and past plans for world peace and reconstruction and a list of books for discussion leaders.
The Department of Nutrition at Teachers College, Columbia University, opened a nutrition exhibit yesterday that shows how well the average American fares compared with the subjugated peoples.

LONDON, May 14 -- American bombers, roaring out over Europe again, struck their heaviest blow of the war today with four separate, closely coordinated attacks on enemy naval, airfield and factory targets in Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, Reich Propaganda Minister, grimly acknowledged yesterday in his weekly newspaper, the Reich, that "never before in history have [the German] people in a generation been called upon to assume such great risks as the present one."

Once again the shadow of waste and exploitation stalks the border lakeland between Minnesota and Ontario. The guardianship of Superior National Forest is in jeopardy, and with it the wilderness policy of the United States Forest Service.

For reasons that need no explanation the menus for next week are potatoless. They are planned to include rice, toast, corn bread, macaroni, noodles and hominy grits, that coarse Southern version of corn meal. Nutritionally speaking, these things are not, of course, complete substitutes for potatoes.

TORONTO, May 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Bears brought Toronto's winning streak to an end at eight games tonight with a 7-6 victory. Newark used four pitchers, two in the ninth inning, to stop a Leaf rally which produced two runs and fell short of tying the game when Tom Ananicz struck out Crompton with the bases full.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Breaking through the secrecy that had hitherto surrounded the United Nations conference on food and agriculture, which will begin next Tuesday, Richard K. Law, chairman of the United Kingdom delegation, today held the first press conference in which any delegation,

Twenty-five years ago today a young United States Army lieutenant named Torrey H. Webb stood on the fringe of a small crowd at Belmont Park and listened to a speaker predict that one day mail would be flown from the United States to Europe.

CLEVELAND, May 14 -- A special meeting of the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations called upon President Roosevelt today to withdraw the authority of James F. Byrnes, director of economic stabilization, to review War Labor Board wage adjustments "necessary to eliminate gross inequities or to aid in the effective prosecution of the war."

Chief City Magistrate Henry H. Curran yesterday took issue with the action of Magistrate J. Roland Sala in the Queens Traffic Court Thursday in increasing the customary $4 fine on nineteen motorists who parked their cars near the Belmont Park Race Track to $15 each.

New issues of municipal bonds up for award next week amount to only $1,539,614, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's total of $15,963,500, which included $12,364,000 of local housing-authority notes. The weekly average of new municipal financing for the year to date now stands at $16,951,691.

Dr. Seth Bingham, organist and choir master of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, will be honored there tomorrow, the thirtieth anniversary of his service in those offices. At 7:30 P.M. there will be a special service with a sermon of tribute to Dr. Bingham by the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, the pastor.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- President Roosevelt today directed Joseph B. Eastman, defense transportation director, to take possession of the American Railroad Company of Puerto Rico, whose employes have been on strike since Wednesday demanding a wage increase of 25 per cent.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 14 -- General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, and nineteen members of his party visited the United States Military Academy this afternoon. The party was met at Washington Gate and received by Major. Gen. Francis B. Wilby, superintendent of the academy.
CHICAGO, May 14 -- The Yankees suffered their first shut-out of the year at Comiskey Park today as Lee (Buck) Ross was deprived of a no-hit pitching distinction on a single of questionable validity.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- The Senate passed its Finance Committee's version of the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan by 49 to 30 tonight after a hectic day of voting and debate in which five other proposals were voted down.
As a keen racing fan who enjoyed Daniel Harwood's letter in THE TIMES last Saturday, I would like to supplement his remarks on the daggers which are being tossed at the lifeline of the turf sport.

The stock market backed down again yesterday for the fourth consecutive session and the cuts in values were the widest in a week. Whereas volume had tended to lighten in the three previous retreats, early selling yesterday invited enlarged offerings, which put prices back fractions to a point on the average and even further among some of the high-priced issues.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- Despite the elimination of cuffs from trousers and other limitations, Donald Nelson, war production chief, warns that rationing of clothing and textiles may come unless all facilities are used to the utmost.

A threat that labor would resort to "independent political action" should there be a "continuation of the ever-deepening trend toward reaction in the present major political parties" was sounded by the Textile Workers Union of America, C.I.O., yesterday shortly before the close of its biennial convention at Carnegie Hall.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 14 -- The latest Allied air bombardments of Germany have caused a reduction of the Reich war effort of 8 or 9 per cent, according to a careful survey of the situation made in initiated quarters in Berlin and received here today through private channels.

OTTAWA, Ont., May 14 -- Demand was made in the House of Commons today by M.J. Coldwell, leader of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation party, for a royal commission to investigate "the aluminum deal and its implications to Canada and the United States."

A third star for the Army-Navy "E" flag for excellence in production was presented yesterday to the Ford Instrument Company in ceremonies at its plant, 32-36 Forty-seventh Avenue, Long Island City, Queens. Colonel Robert C. Patterson, chairman of the State War Savings Staff, also presented to the company and its employes the Treasury Department "Minute Man" flag, indicating 100 per cent enrollment in the weekly war bond purchase plan.

Aided during the early rounds by a pair of imposing home runs, the first of the season for Master Melvin Ott and Maestro Ernesto Lombardi, the Giants yesterday decided to sit back in the ninth inning of their battle with the Cubs at the Polo Grounds and await developments.
LONDON, Saturday, May 15 (AP) -- The Russian Friday midnight communique, as broadcast .from Moscow and recorded here by the the Soviet monitor :

ALGIERS, May 14 (AP) -- French authorities announced tonight that no general measures would be taken against the 100,000 Italian nationals in Tunisia. They will be permitted to resume normal life and accusations alleging some of them aided the enemy forces during the occupation will be examined individually.

MOSCOW, March 14 -- Large, well-armed German concentrations in the region of Belgorod, northeast of Kharkov, have been frequent targets of the Red Air Force. Every effort is being made to impede the enemy's preparations for an offensive.

WASHINGTON, May 14 -- General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, and President Roosevelt agreed during their conversations here last week on the desirability of intensifying the cooperation of the two countries with respect to the supply of their products and raw materials.

Important corporate financing was resumed here this week after light offerings for a month, new bonds for $50,985,000 being offered for public subscription in four flotations. It was the largest amount since the week that ended on April 2.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 14 -- The thirty-sixth Bach festival of the Bethlehem Bach Choir opened here this afternoon in Packer Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University. Despite transportation difficulties due to the war, all of the 1,200 seats in the chapel were sold out in advance.

The attack on Attu in the Aleutians, revealed by the Japanese and confirmed by the Navy Department, is one of those operations whose importance is out of all proportion to the numbers engaged. Neither side could ever get many men there, nor find room for them if it got them there, nor supply them if it could find room for them.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 14 -- Although Clarence Doser, pro at the Scarsdale Golf Club, was the only individual to better par over the wind-swept Westchester Hills course today, half of the twenty teams competing in the Westchester Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur event blended their scores into sub-par figures.

ALBANY, May 14 -- Attacks on the New Deal and predictions that public resentment against the conduct of the war on the home front would result in a Republican victory in the 1944 Presidential election, featured the opening of the annual convention of the State Association of Young Republican Clubs today.
LONDON, May 14 (AP) -- The Russian communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor here:
THE skipper of an American destroyer sunk in the fighting around the Solomons was sitting on the edge of his hospital bunk telling of the night naval engagement off Savo Island.

In Washington last week the President of the United States and the Prime Minister of Great Britain were in conference. It was the fifth meeting between the two men who direct the grand strategy of the Western democracies, the fourth since the United States entered the struggle.

HEADQUARTERS ARMY AIR FORCE OF APPLIED TACTICS, Orlando, Fla., May 15 -- After nearly a year of sparring, the American landing at Attu Island on Tuesday finally elevated the North Pacific theatre from the side-show category and raised the curtain on a great forthcoming battle.
One of the most popular phases of salt water fishing will be officially welcomed today at Peconic Bay, still among the famed fishing grounds of our Eastern seaboard.

Federal authorities in Manhattan and Brooklyn announced last night that through the arrest of a man who carried $37,000 in cash they had uncovered a black market ring that is believed to have sold 40,000,000 pounds of beef alone and collected more than $200,000 of tribute here this year. Investigation of the ring is continuing.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Intimations in radio reports from Tokyo of Japanese reverses on the island of Attu in the Western Aleutians buoyed hopes here today, but official word of developments was lacking. The Navy adhered to its policy of not announcing details until the situation is clarified.

A DINNER will be given Friday in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to mark the merging of the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery and the Spence Adoption Nursery and to celebrate the christening of the combined agencies as the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service.

MRS. JENKINS folded the list of food ceiling prices that she had clipped out of her newspaper, tucked it in her ration-book holder, and started for the door. "Now," she said, "I'll shop like an executive."

Mayor La Guardia paid a thirty-five-minute visit to Central Park Mall yesterday morning to inspect the facilities provided by the city to accommodate a huge crowd at today's exercises to celebrate "I Am an American Day." He found everything in good order and pronounced the arrangements "very good."

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- A semi-rigid embargo was clamped today on the movement of virtually all workers into or out of any town in the Middle Atlantic States or the city of Washington to take jobs with new employers.
BOSTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Braves gained a 1-to-0 victory over the Reds today as Nate Andrews and Johnny Vander Meer waged a tight duel on the mound.

Could it be that Winston Churchill came to Washington chiefly for the trip? No doubt he will be talking over a good many things at the White House and participating in decisions. They will discuss the next move from Tunisia.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Marie Evans's one-time marathon champion of the American turf, Shot Put, today raced to a stirring victory in the twenty-fifth Kentucky Handicap as the twenty-nine-day Spring racing season at Churchill Doyens came to a close.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15 -- Prefaced by chorales by the Moravian Trombone Choir from the church tower, a performance of the Mass in B Minor brought the Bach Festival of the Bethlehem Bach Choir to a close here today in Packer Memorial Chapel of Lehigh University.

ANY dog who has a sense of publicity will insist that his master read "The Fireside Book of Dog Stories," for thereafter said dog may drool on the best carpets, chew up fur coats, bring fleas into the nursery and mud onto the newly upholstered divan without a word of reproof.
John Desmond's delightful fable about the Gremlins in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine really caught my fancy. But do Gremlins really exist?

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 15 -- Why did the German and Italian troops in Africa suddenly collapse after six months of sturdy battling against the Allied forces? In the answer to this question one can find many lessons of prime importance for the future.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- With assurances from military heads in this area that no drastic restrictions are contemplated which would affect civilian activities in this section, bathing beaches, bath clubs, Boardwalk shops and amusements are reopening for the Summer season, ready to receive the first sizable influx of visitors expected for the Memorial Day week-end.

Plans for the complete participation of all branches of the entertainment world in the war program will be formulated at a two-day conference beginning June 3 at the Hotel Edison, it was announced yesterday by the Associated Actors and Artistes of America, parent body of all A.F. of L. entertainer unions.

Anticipating a growing need from now for salvaging Army uniforms and other combat equipment from overseas, the Quartermaster Corps has begun to set up a new sub-depot for such repairs at 125 West End Avenue, with Major William H. Lee in charge, it was learned yesterday.

The hundredth anniversary of the birth of the late Dr. Kaufman Kohler, leader of Reform Judaism in the United States, was commemorated yesterday at Temple Emanu-El with a speech by Dr. Julian Morgenstern, head of the Hebrew Theological Seminary.

ANTHOLOGIES of ghost -- and horror -- stories do tread upon one another's heels, so fast they come. Mr. Stern himself made one of the best. "The Midnight Reader," only a year ago. And I should be the last to say a word against the poorest. But the "tales of fantasy and imagination" -- this is a comparatively virgin field.

Small pieces of what goes on in Martinique and Guadeloupe -- the two French islands in the Western Hemisphere that are now an international problem -- were told here yesterday as thirty-four Frenchmen, most of them sailors, who recently "escaped" from these unsettled island passed through on their way to join the Fighting French of General de Gaulle.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor were guests of honor yesterday at a tea dance in the Women's Military Services Club, 451 Madison Avenue. More than 1,000 Waves, Waacs, Spars and women Marines as well as Army nurses were introduced to the couple.

WOMEN volunteers at the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue, have to be up on the Dodgers, Yankees and Giants these days. According to Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler, co-chairman of its entertainment committee, 367,500 free tickets have been distributed by the three major ball teams so that the men and women in the armed services may see the games free of charge.
More than 200 from Queens and Kings attended the girls' athletic rally sponsored by the Catholic Youth Organization at St. Monica's Hall in Jamaica recently.

INCLUDED among the many signs of the imminent approach of Summer are the opening of the hotel roofs and the presentation of the hot-weather after-dark entertainment. This week, tomorrow evening to be specific, the Hotel Astor begins operating its Roof Garden and no less a person than Harry James, whose swing band was the cause for the recent disturbances along West Forty-third Street and Broadway, will be the featured attraction.
LONDON, May 15 -- Secret plans by Pierre Laval's Vichy government to help the Germans thwart any Allied attempt to invade France were disclosed tonight by Fighting French Headquarters.

Why does the skin "burn" under the sun? That the ultra-violet rays are the cause has long been known. But the action is chemical. What is it? Dr. Stephen Rothman and Jack Rubin (University of Chicago) give the answer in The Journal of Investigative Dermatology.

HARRY HANSEN once called Jim Tully the best interviewer in America, and to date this declaration has not been challenged. In his new book, "A Dozen and One," Tully examines a baker's dozen of prominent men with penetrating skill that warrants close attention.

LONDON, May 15 -- The first phase, but only the first phase, of the battle for the Mediterranean has ended. But already with naval bombardment of Pantelleria and the bombing of Sicily the second stage is blending in with the first. For the Axis still holds some of the strategic keys that control that sea, the domination of which is vital to the success of Allied strategy in this global war.

FORT BENNING, Ga., May 15 -- In spacious, modern buildings, looking like factories, thousands of men are spending hour after hour learning how to take a motor apart or how to send a coded message over the air. For twelve concentrated weeks the soldiers -- privates and officers alike -- go to school to learn one of the many special trades needed by the Army.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill were understood today to be devoting the week-end to intensive conversations on over-all strategy of the war. It is the first opportunity they have had to concentrate exclusively on the subject since the arrival of Mr. Churchill.

TODAY, even the freshman victim of a history quiz probably could identify Elmer Davis. Readers of these pages will remember him as a scholarly reviewer and a top-drawer political commentator. Some will even recall that he wrote several light novels back in the Nineteen Twenties and at least one serious novel called "Giant Killer."

When wartime restrictions are eased better quality eggs and omelets may come from the average kitchen as the result of research conducted by P.J. Schaible and C.G. Card, two Michigan State College men. They have perfected a process for freezing eggs in a form easily handled in the retail trade and the home.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The estimated private debt in the United States at the end of 1942 was more than $113,000,000,000, a decline of $3,000,000,000 from 1941, while the net public debt had risen to more than $110,000,000,000, an increase of $45,000,000,000, the Department of Commerce announced today.

MOSCOW, May 15 -- German counter-attacks in the Lisichansk sector of the Donets front and attempts to filter through the Russian lines northeast of Novorossiisk with the aim of interrupting the incessant Soviet artillery bar rage were reported today to have been the main features of last night's fighting.
TODAY is "I Am an American Day." What does that mean to us, falling on this May Sunday in the midst of a global war? Why, by proclamation of the President, do we mark this day?

AS American educators have sown, the country must now reap. Higher education for women in this country in the last generation has definitely tended not to produce experts in the scientific, engineering and other professional fields.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- The Navy is using more than 4,000 physically fit men in Washington clerical positions, a House Naval Affairs subcommittee reported today in demanding their replacement so they can go to sea.

IF some Sunday night, about 10:30, you drop in at one of the bustling cafeterias on Forty-second Street, just west of Broadway, and overhear a group of men babbling in a language that is pig-Latin with buzz-saw accompaniment, don't bother to call the F.B.I. The men are not fifth columnists, just sidewalk florists talking in their own tongue.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 15 (AP) -- Anticipating a scarcity of manpower needed to maintain 1943 football schedules, expanded to include games with service teams, the Western Conference today made certain that its available players will be well conditioned at the start of the season.

Bruno Walter, conductor, will direct the first two "sponsored" Summer broadcasts of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's fifty-two-week series from Carnegie Hall, and Fredric March, film and stage actor, first intermission guest, will recite Abraham Lincoln's farewell address to his fellow-townsmen at Springfield Ill., it was announced here yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 15 (AP) -- A communique:

Having rejected by a vote of 50 to 32 Senator George's amendment for a 75 per cent abatement of 1942 taxes, it became obvious that the Senate strongly favored either the Ruml pay-as-you-go tax plan, without amendment, or a compromise measure such as the Senate Finance Committee's redrafted version of H.R. 2570, passed by the House on May 4 as the Robertson-Forand bill.

A MEDICAL research man, W.W. Greulich, has figured that the chances of quintuplets surviving are 57,287,761 to 1. Quadruplets have occurred fifty times in recorded medical history, but only two of the fifty sets survived.

LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- As Germany watched Turkey for a turn of events that might bring her newly equipped army into the war, the Turkish Ambassador to London, Rauf Orbay, has gone to Ankara for consultations.

An unprecedented performance by A. Richmond (Boo) Morcom, New Hampshire pole vaulting, high jumping and broad jumping star, constituted the individual feature as favored New York University regained the team crown in the sixty-seventh annual Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. outdoor track and field championships at Randalls Island yesterday.
American equipment has stood the test of battle in Tunisia with satisfactory results, but our ground forces have had to learn bitter lessons in a bloody school.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 15 (U.P.) -- The Ministry of the Interior announced today that a special amnesty affecting an estimated 5,000 persons was now being prepared which would free all political prisoners in North Africa.

Martin Kastengren, Swedish Consul General in New York, and Mrs. Kastengren and G. Hilmer Lundbeck, who recently returned from a trip to Sweden and Finland, will be guests of honor at the supper dance to be given Friday in the Wedgwood Room of the Waldorf-Astoria, under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the American-Scandinavian Foundation.

The fate of the public utility holding company industry under the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act will not be known until late this year, or perhaps early 1944, in view of developments in the Supreme Court of the United States last week.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Administration's hand is clearly discernible in the tiresome history of pay-as-you-go tax legislation on Capitol Hill. Equally in evidence has been the Republican party. Over it all, as a kind of mirage, have been flickers of the 1944 election.

WALKS of paved blocks or flagstones, interplanted with low-growing carpeters, have a special advantage in the small garden, for they not only increase the area to be planted but offer natural growing conditions for a distinct class of plants.

WITH the watchful eye of the government on every move along the Atlantic shore, small-craft sailors this year will do well to turn to our oldest and most historic inland waterway, running from the upper Hudson past Lake George, through Lake Champlain and forming a chain to the far green St. Lawrence.

A choral-ballet, "Fight for Freedom," featured a concert given last night at Carnegie Hall by the Workmen's Circle Chorus, under the direction of Lazar Weiner, conductor, for the benefit of the Veterans Fund of the Jewish Labor Committee. Mr. Weiner wrote the music for the work and the libretto was by M. Osherowitch.
Drew Middleton's Sunday Magazine article on the attitude of the American soldiers in Europe concerning the future world was very interesting to me.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration tonight imposed dollars and cents ceilings on prices of canned fruits and vegetables sold in all retail stores in 130 metropolitan centers.
THREE demonstration Victory gardens are on display at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, comprising a model kitchen garden, city kitchen garden and collection of vegetables.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Housewives will be able to obtain at least a substantial part of the sugar they need for home canning without having to go to local ration boards to obtain "sugar allowance coupons," the Office of Price Administration announced today. They will instead be able to use sugar stamps in War Ration Book One to obtain part of their canning allotment.

THE annual "Round-Up" -- a diversified entertainment and dance in aid of the Madison Square Boys' Club -- will be held on the night of May 25 at the Park Lane. As in the past many noted entertainers will appear on the evenings program, to which several members of the club will contribute special features.

Robert W. Wolcott, president of the Lukens Steel Company, announced yesterday record sales of $24,851,530 for the company and its subsidiaries, The By-Products Steel Corporation and Lukenweld, Inc., for the first six periods of the company's fiscal year which ends on Oct. 15, compared with the previous high total of $19,920,168 for the same periods of 1942.

Jimmy Wilson's Cubs, so-called dark horses of the National League, were turned to a dim gray when they tangled with the league-leading Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, and today their cellar-pallor is even more pronounced.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This seashore resort approaches its official "unlocking of the beach" ceremonies late this month with expectations of a banner war season of vacationers. The chief basis for this optimism is an early season record of exceptionally large crowds of week-enders.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (U.P.) -- Early ousting of Japanese forces from Attu, westernmost of the Aleutian Islands, seemed assured tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- An additional force of 1,400 investigators will be sent into the field in the next few months by the Office of Price Administration to augment that agency's current complement of 2,400 agents. The additional aid is necessary, Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, conceded here this week, if the price and rationing regulations of the OPA are to be properly policed.
A method of making a fresh solution of arsenoxide, long known as a potent killer of spirochetes (the germs that cause syphilis) is now being tested at the Falk Clinic of the University of Pittsburgh.

LONDON, May 15 -- When the British Home Guard marks the climax of its third anniversary tomorrow with a parade, the leading unit will be the First American Squadron, which about Independence Day will celebrate its own third anniversary.

LONDON, Sunday, May 16 -- Soviet planes, maintaining their heavy offensive against bases for probable German offensives, have battered the enemy-held strong points of Gomel and Orel, the Moscow radio reported today, while Axis sources indicated that the Red Army had made a successful landing at Novorossiisk in the Caucasus.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 15 (AP) -- With Hugh East pitching a 3-0 shutout, his second in six days, the Jersey City Giants made a sweep of the three-game series with the Red Wings today.

TODAY most home gardeners are concentrating on growing vegetables. For those of us who do not want to give up flower growing entirely it is important to choose perennials that combine all-season attractiveness with minimum requirements of cultivation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 16 (AP) -- The Japanese hurled more than 100 planes against Allied troop positions in New Guinea Saturday, attacking American and Australian forces five miles south of Salamaua with one of the heaviest dive bomber forces yet employed.

THE reader of a 1943 book on contract bridge bidding will find it little different in substance from books published in 1934 and 1935. If the same reader were to observe an expert game in 1943 and compare it with an expert game of 1935, he would find marked differences in the methods employed.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Prices of grains were on the upgrade today on the Board of Trade, more because of lack of selling pressure than because of aggressive buying. There was, however, some buying in wheat, which brokers regarded as removal of hedges against sales of cash grain to Mexico.

THE author explains in a foreword that his purpose in writing this book was to "acquaint the American public for the first time with the complete, over-all inside machinations of German spies and saboteurs in this country from 1939 up to 1943."

FRITZ LANG once told this writer that a thing he would dearly love to do would be to direct a "realistic" Western, straight from the shoulder and no holds barred. His notion was that our Westerns have been so grossly romanticized that they have thoroughly deceived the public as to the real and sordid nature of the West.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- To provide farmers with what they most urgently need to produce more food, the new Office of Civilian Requirements acted today to make some fifty items of farm equipment and machinery available at once.

ANOTHER "scare" statement on clothes rationing, issued this time by Chairman Nelson of the War Production Board, who was deploring such incitement not so long ago, may touch off another buying rush, it was predicted in trade quarters at the week-end.

THE battle for Sevastopol was probably the turning point of the Russo-German war. The Germans expected to capture this great Black Sea naval base on the southern tip of the Crimea in a few weeks, then push on to Stalingrad and Baku in the Summer of 1942. But Sevastopol did not fall in a few weeks.

LONDON, May 15 -- The greatest American heavy bomber fleet ever put into the air over Germany showered incendiaries and explosives today on the naval base of Emden and vicinity. The Flying Fortresses attacked through a novel smudge-pot smokescreen defense that only served to outline the target for the widespread firebombing throughout the harbor city.

THE farmers went to their fields; the women went to the streams to wash garments. Men moved in the streets, and travelers started over the roads. The light increased, and as it increased the earth and the heavens became greater in size.

THE newly organized collection committee of the New York City Chapter of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will meet Tuesday afternoon at the Stork Club to discuss plans for their incorporation on June 1 into the roster of welfare organizations in whose interests Everybody's Thrift Shop is maintained at 922 Third Avenue.
ON the night of Sept. 24, 1942, Mrs. Ellen Lawson was feeling none too well in her Washington, D.C., apartment.

LONDON, May 15 -- In a speech from his accustomed croaking place on the balcony of the Palazza Venezia, the bullfrog of the Pontine Marshes recently declared that millions and millions of Italians were suffering from "Africa sickness."

Summer institutes are no news, but a conference which has by tradition and intention convened to discuss social problems with definite representation of groups which are a cross-section of the community is unique. Rare indeed are the occasions when teachers, business men, labor leaders, ministers, college students, government workers and housewives can meet each other face to face for ten days and discuss common problems of public urgency.

TORONTO, May 15 (AP) -- Newark pitchers tossed a couple of three-hit games at the league-leading Maple Leafs today, but the teams divided a light-hitting double-header. Toronto won the first game, 4 -- 1, and Newark came through, 5 -- 4, in a scheduled seven-inning afterpiece which went nine innings.

AMERICANS talk a good deal about Asia without knowing very much about this most populous of the world's continents. It is one of the interesting paradoxes of our time that many far corners of the globe have become less accessible politically just when modern inventions and means of transportation have made them more accessible physically.

CLEVELAND, May 15 -- Bespectacled Jack Salveson, salvaged from the major leagues' pitching scrap heap, threw nine consecutive goose-eggs at the Athletics today to give the Indians a 2-0 decision in the series opener.

Retail trade here continued active last week, with sales rising in accord with favorable weather. Some establishments, staging sales which were held earlier last year, had increases ranging up to 20 per cent. Estimates indicated the average for the city will range well under that figure.
Housewives of the nation approve of rationing, according to the Office of Price Administration's "Housewife No. 1."

IT was two years ago this month that the world of radio trembled in the balance, as the orators say, the Federal Communications Commission having just then issued its startling regulations designed to curb alleged monopoly in the field of chain broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt in a statement issued from the White House today congratulated the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps on its first anniversary and expressed the gratitude of the country for the services of its members, declaring "they have justified magnificently the trust that was placed in them."

Top-ranking war agency officials, including Donald M. Nelson and Arthur D. Whiteside, will be featured speakers at the twenty-eighth annual convention of the National Association of Purchasing Agents to be held from May 24 to 26 at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the association announced yesterday.

ASCOT, England, May 15 -- Thousands on bicycles, in horse-drawn carts and on foot made their way to Ascot in uniform and in utility clothes today for the first race meeting to be held on the Royal course since the war began.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Senator George, chairman of the Finance Committee of the Senate, predicted today that the upper chamber would approve legislation continuing the President's power to make reciprocal trade agreements, but conceded that controversy might develop over suggested amendments to the House-approved bill.

General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, accompanied by members of his party now visiting the United States, inspected military facilities on Governors Island yesterday and talked with Lieut. Gen. Hugh A. Drum, commanding general, Eastern Defense Command and First Army.

ETHEL SMITH'S success saga in radio bears a pretty startling resemblance to that of the brash Oscar Levant. Like the irrepressible Oscar, Miss Smith comes from Pittsburgh, the city which generously offered George S. Kaufman, and Adolphe Menjou, as well, to the entertainment field.

Housewives who think a Molotoff cocktail is an alcoholic beverage, as well as feminine ordnance workers who know it isn't, are invited to get a close-up of the weapons of modern war during Women's Ordnance Week, opening tomorrow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 15 -- In a brief address to the Danish people tonight King Christian X of Denmark warned them from continuing widespread sabotage to avoid suffering "serious consequences." This was King Christian's first public address since his recent illness and after his resumption of government duties today.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 12 (Delayed) -- The warring world, which leaves no corner inviolate, has at last broken through the mountain fastnesses of Afghanistan and now this ancient country of Central Asia must make its bow on the stage, where it, too, has an important role to play.

ALTHOUGH thousands of photographs of America's military airplanes have been reproduced in the public prints there remain many citizens who unashamedly admit they can't tell a Flying Fortress from a fireplug.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Because the Tunisian campaign took "oceans of oil" and it is requiring still other "oceans" to prepare for "a vastly greater offensive to come," Petroleum Administrator Ickes warned the motoring public today that gasoline consumption in the Eastern States could not continue at its present rate without a transportation breakdown.

FIRST AID FOR FAITHFUL SERVANTS -- The family tool chest, which has probably been knocking about the cellar or storeroom for the past decade, suddenly becomes a significant and almost glamorous part of the household equipment.

UNDER the auspices of the Generosity Thrift Shop, Inc., at 1237 Third Avenue, a cocktail party and dance will be given Thursday afternoon on the Pierre Roof to raise funds for the several welfare agencies to which the thrift mart contributes its support through the sale of a wide variety of donated articles.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 16 (AP) The Noon communique:

EVERY year at about this time the American Academy of Arts and Letters and its affiliate, the National Institute of Arts and Letters, emerge into public view, always with dignity, never with plangent fanfare.

IN a deal perhaps unique in film history, Andre Maurois has turned over the screen rights to all of his novels and biographies of famous personages to a French film producer who shortly plans to set up business for himself in Hollywood.

The private social agency is helping to solve the manpower problem through guidance and vocational programs based on individual approach, Walter A. Miller, president of the Federation Employment Service of the New York Federation of Jewish Charities, declared yesterday.

IT seems hard to believe that a large symphonic work of Tchaikovsky's has gone unrecorded until now, but there is no indication of any previous recording of the Manfred Symphony, Op. 58, here or abroad.

In the quietest Saturday trading since mid-April, stocks on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday recovered most of their Friday losses. Volume was 640,210 shares, against 1,063,210 for the preceding Saturday. Of the 757 issues traded, 413 rose, 145 fell and 199 were unchanged.

OMAHA, Neb., May 15 -- Talk about the farm manpower situation has been a lot more cheerful of late. It sounds more optimistic than at any time since the size of the production job expected of farmers was first realized. The feeling is not a result of any sudden appearance of a corps of skilled farm workers to fill the labor void, but rather discovery of a hitherto unconsidered reserve of farm strength.

The Giants' recently developed penchant for winning ball games with a spectacular late-inning flare-up was balked twice at the Polo Grounds yesterday while a gathering of 6,856 looked on with bated breath. It failed in the ninth inning and again in the tenth. But in the eleventh it was not to be denied.

In line with the statement by the War Production Board last week that "this country now has enough plants and machine tools to beat the Axis," Herbert I. Segal, executive chairman of the Machinery Dealers Institute, reported yesterday that the supply of used equipment on the market has been increasing at an accelerated rate over the last two months.

There is little likelihood that the coming battles in Europe will be fought as the campaigns in Poland and France were fought. Blitz tactics based on speeding tanks and screaming dive-bombers gave Germany those overwhelming victories. But the technique of warfare has changed since then.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 15 -- American heavy and medium bombers thundered across the Mediterranean yesterday to blast Civitavecchia, forty miles northwest of Rome, and Olbia, the Sardinian terminus of the supply line from Italy to Sardinia. [Olbia, according to Baedeker, is the ancient name for Terranova Pausania.]

WASHINGTON, May 15 (U.P.) -- The Vatican radio's disclosure that Pope Pius longs for peace, "but not for peace at any price," was looked on tonight as strengthening the hands of President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill against possible Axis peace offensives.

One big inning, the fourth, at Baker Field yesterday brought victory to Columbia's baseball team and considerable satisfaction to about 1,200 returning old grads, who spent a long afternoon at various activities arranged for Columbia's annual Spring Alumni day. The score was 3 -- 1.

HERE is a trumpet summoning Americans to their great opportunity, the consummation of all their pioneering and past preparation. Now is the moment to lay the foundations of the postwar world, at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Waac officers' uniforms will be available for distribution through regular retail channels, as has been the case with male officers, as a result of the assignment today to manufacturers of such uniforms of A-1-i rating for procurement of fabrics and other material used in their production.

THE stillness of the gray dawn is shattered by a shout of "Feuer." A volley of shots rings out, a body falls. People still asleep in the neighborhood shiver and draw their blankets closer as if they had just seen something evil in their dreams.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 15 -- Army shut out Fordham's nine by 5 -- 0 on Doubleday Field today. In sharp contrast to previous Cadet-Maroon diamond contests, the game was witnessed by a strictly home crowd. Only the dugout held Fordhamites today.

IT'S getting so, in Hollywood, that if any other company wants to make a picture with a Washington, D.C. background, it sends over to Columbia for the loan of, say the Capitol, or the Lincoln Memorial, like a housewife running next door to borrow a cup of sugar -- in the days when sugar was a borrowable commodity.

Loving and consistent home authority -- dependable authority -- is one of children's needs, Dr. Alexander Reid Martin told this reporter recently apropos of a survey compiled by the Children's Aid Society.

LONDON, May 15 (Canadian Press) -- Blackpool, Northern League Cup winner, won the unofficial football championship of England today by defeating Arsenal, Southern League Cup holder, 4 -- 2, at Stamford Bridge. More than 55,000, including Dominions Secretary Clement Attlee and First Lord of the Admiralty A.V. Alexander, watched.
Setting: A cattle station in Queensland, Australia.

An unheralded rush of shows in this late period of the season continued last week, my share of the new attractions being paced by the lively exhibition of the Associated Artists of New Jersey, at the Riverside Museum.

WITH THE ROYAL NAVY IN TUNISIAN WATERS, May 12 (Delayed) -- The British Navy, used to the drudgery of convoying ships over roundabout routes, sweeping mines from the seas and counteracting the submarine menace, has long been waiting for the day that has now come, when the Mediterranean may serve again as a highway.

WHO was Lao Tse? He was an obscure man who voluntarily led an obscure life. Little is known abort this strange person who dedicated his time to mountains and hills. What tales of him remain are mostly legendary.

FOR recruits itching to earn their wings the Navy has prepared a welcome as warm as Walt Disney's saludos to our Southern amigos. In a "Hi, friends," tone some anonymous but competent authors, restricting the degree of difficulty of their vocabularies to "empirical," have finished the first of twelve volumes "to make it easier for you to be a topnotch pilot."

All fourteen divisions of New York University will function on a continuous twelve-month basis for the rest of the war, it was disclosed yesterday, with the announcement that a series of six-week pre-Summer sessions will begin tomorrow in the schools whose regular sessions have ended.

Because the Navy cannot take funds appropriated by Congress for the war to preserve institutions of higher education, colleges contracting for the Navy College V-12 Program must meet local inadequacies at their own expense, J.A. Fowler Jr., counsel for the Bureau of Naval Personnel, told 600 college and Navy officials yesterday at the final session of the naval training conference at the McMillin Academic Theatre, Columbia University.

Sidi Mohammed al Mounsaf is a member of a dynasty going back to 1691, when a military revolution overthrew the sovereignty of Turkey. He succeeded to the title only a few years ago and, before the war, ruled under a French protectorate, established by the Treaty of Le Bardo in 1881.

SWEET corn is not generally recommended for small gardens because it requires considerable space in which to develop. The smaller size gardens are best suited to the more intensive vegetable crops, such as beans, beets, carrots, tomatoes and lettuce, or to the greens crops which lend themselves readily to intensive planting and where succession and companion cropping may be practiced.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- When President Roosevelt receives the pay-as-you-go tax bill, which should reach him some time next week unless unforeseen circumstances develop, it is expected that in either accepting or rejecting it he will produce reasons in the form of a Federal fiscal program for the year starting July 1.

EVANSTON, Ill., May 15 -- Michigan regained track supremacy in the Western Conference today, beating off Illinois' challenge, 53 3/4 to 47 1/4, but the Wolverines had to wait four hours after the apparent end of the meet before facts and figures of the forty-third annual games became official.

FORT RILEY, Kan., May 15 (AP) -- About 200 men were injured, five seriously, in a tornado which whipped through this cavalry replacement center today, destroying or damaging forty-one frame buildings valued at $175,000.

THE philatelic record of Poland since the Nazi invasion in September, 1939, is told in postage stamps and postmarks in the collection of Dr. A. Hartman of Glasgow, Scotland, and is reviewed in the most recent number of the weekly magazine Stamp Collecting to arrive here from London.

Sir William Beveridge, author of the British "cradle to the grave" social security plan, disclosed yesterday that he was at work on another program dealing with the problem of providing maximum employment after the war.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 -- The Yankees arrived today to open their first series of the year with the Browns, but ran into a postponement. The game scheduled for today will be played when next the Yanks visit the city July 5 to 7.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 15 -- New Jersey's two leading golf champions fared poorly today when Johnny Kinder and Sergeant Charley Whitehead failed to pass muster in the qualifying test of the State's eighth annual amateur-pro best ball championship at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

LONDON in the Spring -- the fourth Spring of war -- is a city of hope. The blank and staring windows of its shattered buildings are its badge of pride and courage; it has been bowed but unbroken by the bombs. It is a city facing toward tomorrow, forever changed yet forever unchangeable.

Commander Charles S. Bookwalter, U.S.N.R., assistant naval Port Director, who will receive the annual merchant marine achievement trophy on National Maritime Day this week, is one of the venerated figures in shipping and naval circles in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The National War Labor Board has just attained a new lease of life. James F. Byrnes, Economic Stabilization Director, has handed back to it some of the authority which President Roosevelt's "hold the line" order of April 8, 1943, withdrew from the board.

The arrest of 144 selective service delinquents here, as part of a nation-wide round-up of 638 violators of the draft law during the week-end, was announced by E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from, Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Even though Federal regulations on yacht fuels this season will confine power boating mainly to those craft in the Coast Guard Auxiliary or in other forms of war activity, the clubs are proceeding bravely with their plans to follow all the traditional programs of boating etiquette.

ALGIERS, May 15 -- The Bey of Tunis has been deposed by General Henri Honore Giraud for compromising the internal and external security of the regency by remaining in Tunis during the Axis occupation, according to a communique issued by the Resident General of Tunis today.

You know that a French Republican Committee has just been founded in New York. It is composed of a group of the most representative Frenchmen who are animated by the traditional French Republican spirit. Among them are Philippe Barres, Emile Bure, Gilbert Chinard, Andre Geraud (Pertinax), Jacques Hadamard, B. Mirkine-Guetzevitch, Henri Laugier, Francis Perrin and Paul Rivet.

IT is hardly necessary to stress the pre-eminent place that music holds in our world today -- not alone in the world of culture, not alone in the art history of mankind, but also in the daily life of the average man.

AFTER months of comparative calm during which practically every player of note in Hollywood was either happy or satisfied with the roles assigned him or her by the various studios, a wave of actor-dissatisfaction has spread over the town resulting in numerous contract-player walkouts.
PHILADELPHIA, May 15 (AP) -- The Cardinals said it with extra base hits today as they came from behind to beat the Phillies, 6 to 3.
PRESENTING a question-and-answer session in which three prevalent beauty questions are answered by three prominent beauty specialists.

Seeing an apple tree in bloom makes it easier to understand Johnny Apple-seed's passion for planting orchards in the wilderness. A well-ordered orchard is a magnificent sight at this time of year, but even more breath taking must have been the beauty of the trees the old wanderer planted all up and down the Ohio Country when most of it was still Indian Land.

In the commerce section of the Manhattan committee of the Greater New York Fund sixty-five chairmen and co-chairmen are now enrolled, according to a report yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. IV[acy Co., and commerce section chairman.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Winston Churchill has talked with several of the chiefs of the civilian departments of the war government of the United States since he arrived in Washington. But the occasions have been social; the Prime Minister of Great Britain has no pressing business to transact at them. His pressing business is war, and war is what the President and he have been talking about.

Professor Shapley, director of the Harvard Observatory, puts mankind in his debt when he reports the discovery of 75,000 new galaxies to add to the 325,000 already known. He tells us the galaxy spotters will probably run the total to a million within a few years, and that the average galaxy contains more than 1,000,000,000 suns, plus, no doubt, planets, moons, comets and other minor accessories.

Cornell University will be one of the leading centers of Russian instruction in the United States this Summer, following the announcement by President Edmund E. Day that an intensive study of contemporary Russian civilization will be undertaken during the sixteen-week period from July 5 to Oct. 23.

AFTER nearly three years of exile the 4,000 British children evacuated to this country for the duration show no weakening of the "thumbs up" spirit they brought with them across the Atlantic. Recent Allied victories abroad have sharpened their hopes of an early return to England, but they still await the war's end with the fortitude which characterized their arrival.

C.S. FORESTER, famed creator of Captain Horatio Hornblower, adventurous hero of the Napoleonic wars, has abandoned historical fiction for a while and has turned his attention to the war now in progress in the Mediterranean.

MEXICO CITY, May 15 -- Energetic measures to control the rise in prices and smash the ring of speculators who have been partially responsible for the present high cost of living were announced today by President Manuel Avila Camacho.

THIS little book contains rarely lovely pictures of growing things, drawn with the beauty that the artist's eye sees in blossom and plant and leaf and stem, and the accuracy that comes from careful observation. The text gives brief information about what goes on in the earth; how rock becomes soil; how sand and silt, gravel, loam and clay differ, and why most plants grow best in loam.

PUBLIC relations as a career and a force in present-day life is here discussed with some thoroughness by an authority of practical experience. As he defines it, no one will be likely to deny its right to be classed as a profession; but except in a very comparative sense or as a composite of publicity, propaganda, advertising and liaison activities, there is reason to doubt that it is new.

THE Pied Piper of Gotham has been in town lately and New York youngsters, like those of Hamelin town centuries ago, have flocked after him. For hours they stood in long lines outside the Paramount Theatre waiting for a chance to hear the brazen notes, at times staccato and shrill, then coaxing and seductive, which tall, thin, loose-jointed Harry James toots from his shiny trumpet.
Setting: A sports arena and other places in an unidentified city.

FIFTY years in show business is nothing to sniff at Lionel Barrymore did not sniff when this hoary milestone was called to his attention. He snorted. Using a cane to emphasize his grumpy retorts with a staccato rat-a-tat-tat, he said in effect, but in much more pungently colorful language, "To h -- l with the good old days!"

PRIOR to Jerome Weidman's latest book, the only novel of his which I have read is "I Can Get It for You Wholesale." That was well representative of the hard-boiled fiction which has flourished in America in recent years, but which is now becoming a casualty of the war.

IN this book, which bears no resemblance to the usual handsomely illustrated discussion of "The City of the Future," a distinguished architect and teacher, Finnish by birth and education, now fortunately American by adoption, digs deeply into the causes of the "disorder and decay" which are eating at the hearts of so many cities.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The general who is responsible for teaching soldiers to keep down, out of the line of fire, forgot himself and a piece of shrapnel found its mark.

ST. LOUIS, May 15 (AP) -- Army engineers disclosed today that Axis prisoners of war had been used for emergency flood control work along the Mississippi River in the St. Genevieve, Mo., levee district.
ALGIERS, May 15 (AP) -- Sidi Mohammed al Mounsaf has been sent to the French island of Madagascar in the Indian Ocean, it was reported today. [Madagascar is under Fighting French control.]

BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 15 -- Dr. William L. Estes Jr., chief surgeon at St. Luke's Hospital, was re-elected president of the Bethlehem Bach Choir this afternoon at the annual business meeting between the two sessions of the Mass in B minor.

THE gray stones of St. Patrick's Cathedral facade will form a setting for a garden gay with vari-colored Spring flowers in a background of green shrubbery at the annual flower mart to be held by the Outdoor Cleanliness Association from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Tuesday.
LONDON, May 15 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

New York A.C. members won all four of the men's metropolitan A.A.U. senior swimming championships that were at stake in the meet at the Winged Foot pool last night. Those who came through were Eugene Rogers in the 440-yard free style, Jack Smith in the high-board dive and the 300-yard medley and 400-yard free-style relay teams.

THE sweet potato is a tropical plant and is easly injured or killed by light freezing. However, it will grow and produce tubers successfully in Northern sections if it is planted in warm, well-drained, sandy soil and if it can have about four and a half months of warm weather.

ALBANY, May 15 -- Governor Dewey, addressing the State Association of Young Republican Clubs here tonight, pictured the concentration of power in Washington as "cracking to a collapse" and stressed, as an alternative, return of power to "the people."

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- President Roosevelt "saluted" the nation's millions of civilian defense volunteers on the second anniversary of the Office of Civilian Defense in a letter today to James M.
