Landis, director, in which he praised their efforts "in protecting our bulwarks at home" and declared "their efforts must continue unceasing until the day of victory is attained."

An official guide showing how industry can tie in with the national wartime nutrition program has been released by the Nutrition and Food Conservation branch, Food Distribution Administration, in cooperation with the OWI and the Advertising Council.

UNTIL he became active in a Children's Court, Clifford A. Strauss never took seriously those threadbare jokes about mothers-in-law. He takes them seriously now. In an article, "Grandma Made Johnny Delinquent," in the April issue of The American Journal of Orthopsychiatry, he writes: "I believe that the presence of grandparents in the home has caused delinquency in a considerable number of cases."

The United Seamen's Service announced last week that it would broaden its entire medical program and establish new centers where seamen may convalesce after injuries or illness and where those unable to return to their old duties may be instructed in new work and given new interests.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Hundreds of thousands of pounds of food fish will be added during the next few weeks to rapidly diminishing American supplies under the terms of an agreement between the United States and the British Government of the Bahamas, effective last Monday, permitting for the first time the taking and buying of fish in Bahaman waters.

THESE two books should be read by everybody interested in post-war planning, because they carry the stamp of high authority; so much so that they offer a unique opportunity to gain an insight into the policy of the United Nations.

POULTRY feed is scarce and every poultry raiser, large or small, must this year pay special attention to the feeding of his flock. No feed must be wasted by improper rations or by using a wasteful feeding method. Every pound of feed is needed for production.
WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) -- Bad weather may be hampering the American drive to wipe out Japanese positions on Attu Island, authorities familiar with conditions in the Aleutians suggested today,

GREENWICH, Conn., May 15 (AP) -- The Philadelphia first team, a strong favorite to win its tenth women's national lacrosse tournament championship in eleven years, all but did so today with a 10-0 victory over New York and a 7-5 triumph over Westchester.

HERE is sheer beauty in writing. This little volume of short pieces will give me reader a clearer conception of the combat's thinking, fighting, living, than anything that has come before. The little tales are gems cut from purest carbon, handed down so that they spit cold fire.

Your page of George Shellhase's humorous pictures of Victory gardening in last Sunday's Magazine omits one scene that is all too common in back yards this Spring. Perhaps it is too grim for humor. I refer to the discovery by thousands of wartime gardeners that their soil is utterly unfit for vegetables or for plants of any sort, including lawn grass, and that it was deliberately made so by short-sighted house-builders.

Rejoicing over the victory of the United Nations in North Africa rabbis in sermons here yesterday nevertheless warned against an let-down in our war drive. Other sermon subjects were "I Am an American Day" and the centenary of the B'nai B'rith Order.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 15 -- In the late afternoon chill of this Spring day, spectators at the forty-first annual show of the Long Island Kennel Club applauded the victory of the sleek whippet, Champion Flornell Glamorous, owned by the Mardormere Kennels of Mrs. George A. Anderson of Glen Head and handled in the ring by Percy Roberts.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association has made a tabulation of the number of performances given last season by the principal singers in the company, excluding Sunday night concert appearances. Thelma Votipka heads the list with fifty performances, with Norman Cordon a close second with forty-seven.

American business men and their trade organizations should immediately begin to give attention to matters of post-war international commercial policy, Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared yesterday on the eve of Wartime National Foreign Trade Week, which will be observed nationally beginning today.

Teacher and student ranks in the graduate schools of the nation's universities are being severely depleted by war demands, Dean George B. Pegram of the Faculties of Political Science, Philosophy, and Pure Science of Columbia University, warned in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, made public yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, May 14 (Delayed) -- John D. Nichols of Montclair, N.J., director of the American Red Cross in China, returning from a three weeks' inspection tour of Kweichow Province to check up on the distribution and allocation of supplies, declared he "saw no evidence of commercial diversion of medical supplies."

A UNITED STATES ARMY REPLACEMENT DEPOT Somewhere in England, May 15 -- A Hungarian whose father is fighting with Germany against Russia and a Finn who thinks his homeland should chase the Nazis out and a Pole who won the Purple Heart decoration in the United States Army in World War I were among the 231 soldiers and nurses naturalized here today at a mass ceremony.

While bituminous operators of the Appalachian region have announced readiness to comply with the interim order of the National War Labor Board in the coal dispute that direct negotiations between owners and miners be resumed in an effort to reach an agreement, the United Mine Workers yesterday delayed action on the board's directive, pending study and clarification of the order.

GOLDIE, the 600-pound matron of Bear Mountain, who still poses as a glamour girl, has again produced a couple of healthy and frisky young cubs. That makes the opening of the warm weather season up here official.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Removal of Dr. Robert Morss Lovett from his post as Government Secretary of the Virgin Islands, as proposed in a House Appropriations subcommittee amendment to be offered next week, would not only be an unconstitutional action but "the type of liquidation that is enforced in European countries," Secretary Ickes asserted today.

The Battle of Africa has ended in a spectacular Allied victory and an equally spectacular Axis collapse. American forces are attacking in the Aleutians. Winston Churchill is in Washington conferring with President Roosevelt on the next steps to follow. So is Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Republic.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 15 -- The Tunisian defeat has staggered the Nazi propaganda department of Dr. Joseph Goebbels into vague mumbling that Germany still retains the initiative. This is true in the eyes of qualified observers up here only in regard to one sector of the front surrounding the Axis countries -- the Bulgarian-Turkish border, and that, too, might be a gamble.

A record volume of early Fall and Winter business was placed in the wholesale markets last week, with the number of buyers in the markets larger than for the like period during the past twenty-five years, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

Production is the best known anti-inflation force and it is highly desirable that this country enter the post-war era with a production and distribution system for consumer goods of the highest possible efficiency and effectiveness, it was emphasized last week in the annual report of the Allied Stores Corporation, operating the largest chain of department stores in the country.
Setting: Somewhere near Los Angeles.

Eddie Mack, Boston promoter, announced yesterday that Willie Pep of Hartford, Conn., would defend his claim to the featherweight championship against Sal Bartolo of Boston in a fifteen-round bout at Braves Field, Boston, June 8, The Associated Press reports.

New York City's acute shortage of meats and poultry is unlikely to be relieved for two months, if then, it was predicted by Federal Government and food trade experts yesterday as supplies were reported shrinking almost to the vanishing point.

The battle for a greater consideration of the civilian needs in the production program broadened last week when the Senate passed and sent to the House the Maloney-Taft-Scrugham bill, which would establish a powerful independent civilian supply administration to succeed the Office of Civilian Requirements, now part of the War Production Board set-up.

WHAT with all the trouble we are having in real life lately, fewer novelists have felt impelled to write "strong" books in which all the characters hang around, knee deep in squalor, pulling the wings off flies.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, May 15 (U.P.) -- How twenty white persons, including six Allied airmen and four young women who were teachers or nurses in an Anglican mission, were murdered or betrayed to the Japanese by renegade natives was revealed today with the announcement that twelve natives had been condemned to be hanged and that others were awaiting trial.

THE civilian radio maintenance problem is growing more acute. There is no ready means of knowing just how many home receivers are now feeling the pinch of radio-tube and serviceman shortages, but one thing is certain -- the number of sets out of commission or in serious trouble is mounting.

LAST WEEK brought official confirmation of the news published in these columns on Feb. 28 to the effect that the Postoffice Department was planning to issue postal paper which would honor European countries now subjugated by the Axis.

Cancellation of war contracts by the armed forces has become so serious on some products that many plants are rapidly reaching the distressed stage and are making frantic appeals to the procurement agencies, the War Production Board and the Smaller War Plants Corporation, it was learned here last week.

TWO considerations have dominated American policy toward Latin America -- "national security and the idealism of the American people. Of these * * * national security has always been uppermost." So writes Mr. Bemis in this formidable study of our dealings with our Southern neighbors.

Demonstrations and ceremonies in the metropolitan area and elsewhere throughout the nation are being planned by Federal and local organizations for next Saturday in observance of National Maritime Day on a scale unprecedented since the first celebration of the day on May 22, 1933.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- How the German banking system has reached out to grasp the economic resources of Europe in an octopus-like clutch designed to hold fast despite any change of political leadership in Germany was described today by the Office of War Information.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 15 -- Under a decree drawn up four days ago by Premier Mussolini, but announced only today by his Under-Secretary of Interior, all Fascist hierarchs have been mobilized on a twenty-four-hour basis for "emergency service of any kind" deemed necessary by the party headquarters in Rome.

THE SPRING crop of antique shows has been more plentiful than usual this year, which augurs well for both the antiquarian and the dealer, because it indicates that antiques are taking the place of new furnishings, in many cases compensating for the wartime shortages.

DETROIT, May 15 (AP) -- The Tigers regained third place in the American League race today by defeating the Senators, 8 to 1, behind the five-hit pitching of Paul (Dizzy) Trout who notched hit third successive triumph after one defeat.

ALBANY, May 15 -- All that Northeastern farmers ask of Federal Government agencies concerned with food production and prices is that when they undertake to solve the growers' multiplying problems they start from sound premises and do their figuring correctly.

DRAMATIZED versions of the achievements of Britain's three arms, distilled from the prosy official records of the departments concerned, are a popular form of literature nowadays. The latest, "Enemy in Sight," is the tale of the Battle of the Seven Seas.

WARTIME curtailment of travel and the scarcity of hotel space have changed the normal convention routines of two State federations of women's clubs, scheduled to meet this week. The New Jersey group will convene Wednesday afternoon at the Hotel Commodore in New York and adjourn at noon Friday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 15 -- The selection by President Vargas of J.C. Muniz, Ambassador to Cuba, and Enrico Penteado, Brazilian financial representative at Washington, to represent Brazil at the Hot Springs food convention, has been well received in American circles here. Senhor Muniz will head the commission.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- American Red Cross volunteers have produced the "staggering total of 3,102,072 articles for the use of the United States Army and Navy hospitals and the able-bodied men in the armed forces within the last eight months," that agency said today.

An experiment unprecedented in the history of labor and management is being conducted at Yale. Five labor leaders, studying on fellowships granted by the university, meet with five representatives of management in a course on the economics of collective bargaining.

Justin R. Whiting, president of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, declared yesterday in his annual report for 1942 to stockholders that the present system of corporate taxation in this country should be changed completely, "as it now throttles business enterprise and unfairly taxes small stockholders on the same basis as large stockholders."

RESERVATIONS at Summer resorts along the Eastern seaboard are being made unusually early this year, according to travel bureaus. One agency said it had already booked several people at a near-by mountain lake for August and September, and that other inquiries indicated a trend among vacationists not only to plan for a definite period but to settle down in one spot for that period.

An editorial in THE TIMES of May 10 very properly commends our forces for their successful creation of an advanced air base on Amchitka Island, in the Western Aleutians. But in an effort to explain the very great difficulties that had to be overcome the editorial adds more than a little misinformation to that which is already widespread about the Aleutians.

A "redesign" of American educational purposes and methods was advocated by Dean William F. Russell of Teachers College, Columbia University, in his interim report to the trustees of the college, made public yesterday.
THREE new exhibitions, all of them small in scope, became current last week at the Museum of Modern Art.

IN the organizational set-up of the Army, headquarters furnishes the brain; reconnaissance elements, the eyes; and the Signal Corps, the nerves. The growth and development of these nerves are found in "What You Should Know About the Signal Corps."

A noble experiment that failed for Manhattan College brought the Brooklyn College nine its first victory in the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference yesterday as the Jaspers and Kingsmen split a double-header at Brooklyn College field.
NEW DELHI, India, May 15 (AP) -- A Tenth United State Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The eight-story building on the fringe of Washington's financial district which is the United Mine Workers' headquarters has been somewhat lonesome for the last two months -- "tomblike," said one attendant. For "the boss," as John L. Lewis is known to those who work there, has been out of town.

HERE is as gentle and unpretentious a prize-winning novel as one will find in many a moon -- a love story written with restraint and taste. Joyce Horner's quietly paced story of an English girl growing to maturity in the decades between two world wars was selected as the winner of the Doubleday, Doran-Curtis Brown Writers' Conference prize in 1942.

To win the peace, the United States must participate in world affairs and not return to an era of isolationism, Dr. John W. Studebaker. United States Commissioner of Education, declared yesterday in an address before 1,700 students and educators attending the fourth annual luncheon sponsored by the Evening Adult Students Association.

Charging a plot to embarrass those seeking to oust Michael J. Kennedy as leader of Tammany by delaying announcement of the number of members of the Democratic County Committee to be elected in each election district, Eugene J. McManus sent yesterday a telegram to David H. Knott, chairman of the New York County Demo cratic Committee, demanding that he file such a statement immediately with the Board of Elections.

The Ringling Brothers and Barnum Bailey Circus, with its personnel of 1,600, left Madison Square Garden last night, after breaking circus records by entertaining 987,000 persons in its seventy-five performances here.

Three English physicians, Drs. Brian Maegraith, G.M. Findley and N.H. Martin, all now in the army, announce in Nature the discovery of a hitherto unknown chemical which destroys red blood corpuscles, the presence of which in excessive amounts may be the cause of anemia.
LONDON, Sunday, May 16 (U.P.) -- The Russian Saturday midnight communique's broadcast from Moscow:

IN the fifty years that have elapsed since the discovery of X-rays by the German physicist Roentgen great progress has been made in their application, not only in medicine but in industry and the arts. Dr. Hart gives the layman an insight into what is being accomplished today by roentgenologists, chiefly in the medical field.

ALTHOUGH cryptography as a science is older than the pyramids, it has been shrouded in mystery for centuries. When the first World War began we were sadly lacking in "cipher brains," and at the outbreak of the present conflict no shortage was more acute -- or less publicized -- as Mr. Smith points out, than that of qualified cryptographers.

Drs. C.C. Gordon and J.H. Sang of Aberdeen University announce that nicotinic acid, the anti-pellagra vitamin, can correct hereditary defects. Presumably with the aid of X-rays, they developed a race of fruit flies without antennae or feelers, that is, a race which invariably passed its defect on to its progeny.

CHICAGO, May 15 -- Although the technology of food dehydration has improved since the last war, much remains to be learned -- and chemists are working to that end now -- to make the fighting man's dried rations more appetizing, the American Institute of Chemists was told today at its annual meeting in the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

IN his foreword to this collection of our Under-Secretary of State's speeches between September, 1939, and February, 1943, Dr. Butler reminds us that nearly thirty-three years ago Congress unanimously "called upon the President to invite the nations of the world to organize for the establishment of international peace, this organization to be protected by an international police force made up of the combined navies of the world." Nothing happened.

DESERT TRAINING CENTER, Calif., May 15 -- Scattered out over 30,000 square miles of desert in Southeastern California and Western Arizona, more than 100,000 soldiers are completing their "college course" for war. Their postgraduate course will come in battle.

THIS week will see a kind of ballet competition without precedent hereabouts when the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo returns for its Spring season at the Broadway Theatre on Wednesday, while the Ballet Theatre is still finishing up its engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House with an intensive weekend beginning on Friday.

WHY should any one want to educate the Germans? It is not a thing usually done after a war, to provide for the education of the enemy. No doubt the Christians in the Dark Ages and the Moslems later sometimes gave the pagans or infidels a choice between being massacred or converted, but we have outgrown that form of propaganda. Our position is much simpler.
CHICAGO, May 15 -- Some 32,000 Chicagoans who live in hotels will have to make their own beds tomorrow.

Extracted from an unwilling Judiciary Committee by a petition signed by 218 members, a bill forbidding the poll tax requirement "as a prerequisite to voting in a primary or other election for national officers" will come before the House of Representatives on Monday, May 24.

ONCE upon a time there was a little red hen and she lived on a big farm that was owned lock, stock and barrel by a smart and industrious farmer named McGregor. One day Farmer McGregor was looking around in his barn and he found ten bushels of excellent wheat seed.

A second Army-Navy "E" award was presented to the Kollmorgen Optical Corporation of 2 Franklin Avenue, Brooklyn, at ceremonies held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn, last night.

NO matter what individual idealistic thoughts each soldier in the armies of the United Nations may have on the subject of this war and just exactly why he personally is fighting, they are all, more or less, agreed in focusing their special speculations on one burning question: When will it be over?

YOU may remember that from time to time we have casually mentioned a gentleman named Jed Harris on these pages. The other day we thought it high time to make a recapitulation of his endeavors in the theatre.

EVER since Pearl Harbor the Broadway theatre and its people have been in a ferment as to what it and they should be and do in wartime. What they should do as citizens they have had no difficulty in solving and brilliantly accomplishing. What the theatre should be in wartime, however, has been decidedly more of a debatable matter.

C'EST LA GUERRE: Transportation difficulties didn't keep true racing fans from the opening of the Belmont meeting last week. One woman who wore an orchid on the lapel of her smart tweed suit hitched a ride to the track on a coal truck.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 15 -- Oregon will become the tenth State to apply the Community Property Law when a bill passed by the 1943 Legislative Assembly goes into effect on June 9. The bill will enable the wealthier residents of Oregon, who pay high Federal income taxes, to save approximately $9,000,000 annually.

The petitions of two Germans, former naturalized United States citizens, for release from Ellis Island, where they had been interned for eleven months as dangerous enemy aliens, were dismissed yesterday by Judge John W. Clancy in the Federal Court here, and as a result they will be detained for the duration of the war.

AN enormous number of works on psychoanalysis have appeared here and in other English-speaking countries since 1909, following this reviewer's publication of the first translation of Freud's papers on the neuroses.

IT has been said in certain quarters, thoughtlessly, I think, that the years of the present World War have failed to produce memorable poetry, and it has been implied that poetry in some mysterious way has failed to live up to great occasions.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- Postmaster General Walker announced tonight that within two months the Army would release six cargo planes to the commercial airlines to relieve the shortage of airmail carriers, and that more ships would be made available later in the year.

Despite the total conversion of distilleries to the production of industrial alcohol for war needs, supplies of liquor in New York City are relatively plentiful and will probably continue so for some time. In other areas, however, supplies have been drastically reduced and in many States liquor is being rationed.

MOSCOW, May 15 -- At the beginning of the 100th week of their struggle with Germany the Russians from all appearance are in higher fighting fettle than ever before. "Unconditional surrender," the cry of their warrior leader, to which President Kalinin has added his authority during the week, has more real weight behind it than it could have had at an earlier period of the war.

THE Reference Shelf's "Independence for India?" compiled by Julia E. Johnsen, has been issued (H.W. Wilson Company, $1.25). This is a particularly useful and suitable book about the peninsular subcontinent of Asia -- the key to a long or short war.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 15 (AP) -- A surprising Louisiana State track team came from behind today with an advance of points to outscore the co-favorites, Georgia Tech and Auburn, and win its sixth successive Southeastern Conference track and field championship.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 15 -- The first official party, except for a small advance group, arrived here tonight for the United Nations conference on food and agriculture which will open next Tuesday with delegations from forty-three countries in attendance.

Retail trade was active in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey last week for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Main floor departments were busy, particularly those handling neckwear, blouses, millinery, gloves, handbags and jewelry.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 15 -- The Cornell varsity crew, defeated by Navy by three lengths in the Adams Cup race on May 1, came back today to defeat the midshipmen by a deck length over a mile-and-three-quarter course on the Severn River.

FACED with a scarcity of nearly all other commodities and with a curtailment of the customary amusements, the Swedish public hungers for books more than ever. This explains why one of the oldest publishing houses in Stockholm has just announced the highest sales volume in its existence of more than a hundred years.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 15 -- The Mediterranean Sea is now open because the enemy air forces have been knocked out, Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur William Tedder said today in an interview reviewing the course of the air war in the Mediterranean.

CHUNGKING, China, May 15 -- China's leading independent newspaper, Ta Kung Pao, today reiterates the thesis that Formosa must be returned unconditionally to China after the war in an editorial on an article by John K. Jessup, post-war planner for Time and Fortune magazines.

AYN RAND is a writer of great power. She has a subtle and ingenious mind and the capacity of writing brilliantly, beautifully, bitterly. "The Fountainhead," her second novel, has been more than five years in preparation; it is a long but absorbing story of man's enduring battle with evil.

A RADIOGRAM received from Moscow last week by J. H. Stolow brings the information that the U.S.S.R. is issuing three stamps to mark the bicentenary of the finding of the Bering Strait by Vitus Johanssen Bering (1681-1741). Bering was a Danish navigator and Denmark in 1941 released postal paper to commemorate his death, hut his discovery of the water passage bearing his name was made while he was serving in Russia's Navy.

Cotton futures prices fluctuated irregularly in dull trading in yesterday's short session. At the close of trading active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 5 points to off 2 points, with the strength in the distant positions.

The "Portrait of an Old Man" by Rembrandt, is one of the masterpieces in the collection to be placed on sale in the new Macy Gallery of Fine Arts, the store announced yesterday. There are 281 other paintings, with a total value estimated at $130,000, in the collection that will go on display tomorrow.

Harry W. Eberlin, a teacher at Public School 109, Queens, has been nominated to succeed Henry Ludwig Jr., former principal of Junior High School 223, Brooklyn, as president of the Protestant Teachers Association, which covers the five boroughs.
WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 261 United States soldiers held prisoners of war by Japan, twelve by Italy and one by Germany.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 15 -- Following conversations in Vichy between Pierre Laval, French Chief of Government, and German and Italian generals representing the occupying authority, the French male population generally is being reminded that in case of an Allied landing it must conform immediately with military instructions under penalty of summary execution as francs-tireurs.

Confidence that the voters of the American Labor party will support the present State organization at the coming primary election was expressed yesterday by Alex Rose, State secretary, in reply to a statement by Representative Vito Marcantonio and Eugene P. Connolly, respectively chairman and secretary of the New York County Committee and leaders of the party's so-called left wing.

Dr. Charles Frederick Bolduan, a leading public health worker for thirty-nine years, will retire on June 1 as director of the Bureau of Health Education of the municipal Department of Health, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 15 -- The successful completion of the Tunisian campaign and the inception of what might be called the armistice and planning period in the Arab world raise the first specific problems of the United Nations in their proposed application of the Atlantic Charter on the ruins of Axis ambitions.
The German Saturday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 15 -- Scoring all of their runs in the first two innings, New York University defeated Hofstra, 4 -- 2, in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game today.

BOSTON, May 15 -- Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Kingfisher, shipped from New York for the event, defeated Robert Robertson's K. Dorko by a neck today to win the ninth running of the $5,000 added Governor's Handicap at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 25,000.

WASHINGTON, May 15 -- The Nazi version of the Axis defeat in Tunisia, as offered to Germans and the outside world this week by the Nazi press and radio, is that in an unequal fight the Axis scored a historic strategic success by holding off numerically superior Allied forces for six months, during which the fortification of Europe against an invasion was completed.

Even the name of this wartime development remained on the deeply secret list until the War Department recently disclosed some of its capabilities, although, of course, none of its technical detail. The name Radar stands for "radio detecting and ranging."

The report of the Senatorial subcommittee on war mobilization does not make good reading. That there is still no unified policy has long been common knowledge. The controversy over the relative need of rubber, 100-octane gasoline and naval escort vessels has not yet subsided.

THE whole question of men in uniform appearing regularly on sponsored radio shows has been raised anew by the abandonment last week of the proposed commercial presentation of "This Is The Army," originally scheduled to start this Tuesday over CBS.

CLEVELAND, May 15 -- The executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations charged today that John L. Lewis "has jeopardized the just demands of the United Mine Workers of America by exploiting the injustice of the mining industry in furtherance of his personal and political vendetta against the President of the United States, our Commander in Chief."

IT will be interesting to see how Dr. Koussevitzky's proposal, printed in a neighboring column, will be received by the leaders and the rank and file of his fellow-musicians. His conception of a new deal for the composer is a highly provocative one.

THIS timely and humorous autobiography might have been called "The Americanization of Frank Kingdon" but for one fact. Its Cockney-born author never really had to be Americanized. Legally, he became an American in 1918, and the book closes with that event. Spiritually, however, Frank Kingdon had been an American through all the days of his youth.

Confidence that the voters of the American Labor party will support the present State organization at the coming primary election was expressed yesterday by Alex Rose, State secretary, in reply to a statement by Representative Vito Marcantonio and Eugene P. Connolly, respectively chairman and secretary of the New York County Committee and leaders of the party's so-called left wing.

Dr. Charles Frederick Bolduan, a leading public health worker for thirty-nine years, will retire on June 1 as director of the Bureau of Health Education of the municipal Department of Health, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, Health Commissioner, announced yesterday.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 15 -- The successful completion of the Tunisian campaign and the inception of what might be called the armistice and planning period in the Arab world raise the first specific problems of the United Nations in their proposed application of the Atlantic Charter on the ruins of Axis ambitions.
The German Saturday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- If the United States chooses the path of permanent deficit spending, as a strong faction within the present Administration believes it should, disastrous inflation can be avoided only by regulation and control amounting to complete regimentation of our economic life, according to Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Joseph W. Martin Jr., House Republican leader, forecast tonight that the Senate's Ruml-type 100 per cent pay-as-you-go bill would win House acceptance by a narrow margin Tuesday.

LONDON, May 16 -- The stock markets's response last week to the brilliant victory in Tunisia could not have been more surprising or more disappointing. There was no expansion in business such as had been confidently expected, and prices barely held their ground in the first half of the week.
LONDON, May 16 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Tax and other uncertainties have been hindering the progress of a stock market which is beginning to wonder if it has not gone too far too quickly. There is little evidence that this is true, but the feeling in investment circles cannot be ignored and has resulted in a pausing and a taking of stock.
TUNIS, May 16 (U.P.) -- The Italians of Tunis have gone to absurd extremes in their efforts to hide until the time when they will be accepted as loyal to the French protectorate of Tunisia.

All back and current interest on the general mortgage 5 per cent cumulative bonds of the Brown Company, New Hampshire producer of pulp and paper products, will be paid on June 1, according to an announcement by Henry P. Kendall, chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The progress of American Army troops on fog-shrouded Attu Island remained a naval secret today, the sixth day they have been there. While the Navy maintained silence for the second day since announcing merely that American forces had landed on the Aleutian isle and had engaged the Japanese, Axis broadcasts reported by the Office of War Information confined themselves to a repetition of previous statements that "hard" fighting was going on.

ATLANTA, May 16 -- The seven Southeastern States that constitute Region 4 of the WPB jurisdiction received almost $6,000,000,000 in war contracts from June, 1940, through February, it was made known this week by Harry G. Thornton, regional director of the War Production Board.

The tide has turned against Hitler and the Tunisian victory was merely a dress rehearsal for the many other surrenders that soon will be forced on other fronts in his European fortress, Senator James E. Murray of Montana told 2,500 persons last night at a rally of District Grand Lodge No. 1 of B'nai B'rith at Carnegie Hall.

PHILADELPHIA, May 16 -- The rejuvenated Phillies and the Cardinals -- world champions -- split a pair of fine pitching duels today before a crowd of 30,823 at Shibe Park, the biggest major league attendance of the day and the second largest National League turnout in Philadelphia history.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- More than a score of saboteurs are being trained by the German high command at its highly organized sabotage school to be sent to all parts of the world to obstruct the war effort of the United Nations, J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said tonight.

CASABLANCA, Morocco, May 13 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The feeding of the people of Tunisia liberated from the Axis will be facilitated by an expected bumper crop of wheat and cereals in French Morocco, officials said today. Harvesting of the crop has started and it will reach a peak in mid-June.

Eight years ago Patrolman Joseph Pappace was so badly beaten by gangsters that he spent twenty-one days in the hospital. Since then he has carried with him a Rogues Gallery photograph of one of the gang. Last night he got his man.
CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) -- The Indians salvaged the nightcap of a doubleheader with the Athletics today to remain one game behind the pace-setting Yankees.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 16 -- Cecil B. DeMille will borrow Laraine Day and Signe Hasso from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for his Paramount production, "The Story of Dr. Wassell." The actresses will play two of the four principal feminine roles in the picture.

NEW DELHI, India, May 16 (AP) -- American heavy bombers pounded the railhead of the Burma Road at Lashio yesterday while other Allied air units swept over Burma to hammer Japanese-held positions in attacks that continued into the night.

A French Army, 300,000 strong, trained in the traditions of St. Cyr, proud of the memories of Verdun, is rising from the ashes of defeat in North Africa and may soon be marching shoulder to shoulder with the 90,000 veterans of General Charles de Gaulle in a crusade to free France.

At least 1 important government and private agencies in the United States are engaged in research or public education on a national scale on the problems that will confront this country when the war ends. More than a third of these agencies are devoting major attention to problems involv/ng international relations.

The Committee of Fifteen, headed by Paul Windels, formerly Corporation Counsel in the La Guardia administration, reiterated yesterday its plea for a higher subway fare and the creation of a Transit Authority to operate the city's unified lines.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -American ground troops, perhaps without air and sea support because of heavy weather, presumably are battling furiously against the Japanese on Attu.

Three prizes to seniors who have been chosen by their classmates as outstanding members of the Class of 1943 will be presented at the annual Columbia College Class Day ceremonies on May 31 at Brander Matthews Hall, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- A tight situation in cash corn that started several months ago showed no evidence of changing last week. Leading cash handlers continued to believe that they could sell millions of bushels if they were able to remove hedges against corn in elevators or if the country sold on a large scale.

LONDON, May 16 -- Some United States fliers, who prefer to keep their names to themselves, have brought from North Africa just what the doctor ordered for a 10-year-old boy who is being treated for a rare abdominal ailment in a hospital at Newbury, Berkshire: lemons.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 16 -- With the aid of the Gestapo, Chief of Government Pierre Laval is curbing in France all opposition to his personal rule. Most opponents disappear, to be whisked off to Germany.

LONDON, May 16 -- For the first time since the end of January, the Bank of England was able to report last week a decline in note circulation. The decrease was 2,340,000 in contrast to an increase of 3,200,000 at the same time last year and has encouraged the belief in some quarters that currency requirements are at last definitely slackening.

Lieutenant Hugh M. Robinson, 27 years old, son of Lieut. Comdr. Hugh B. Robinson, assistant port director in New York, has received the Silver Star for conspicuous gallantry in the Solomon Islands waters, it was disclosed yesterday by the Navy Department. Lieutenant Robinson's brother, Frank M. Robinson, was killed in action last year aboard the aircraft carrier Yorktown.

MEXICO CITY, May 16 -- The newspaper Excelsior announced yesterday that the United States and Mexico had agreed to erect the largest refinery for high-octane gasoline in Latin America. The plan, it said, was submitted in Washington by Efrain Buenrostro, general manager of Petroleos Mexicanos, which has the oil monopoly in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Secretary Ickes declined to comment tonight on John L. Lewis's refusal to meet with representatives of the War Labor Board tomorrow morning to work out arrangements for resumption of negotiations between the coal operators and the U.M.W.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Outlook for the new domestic wheat crop is slowly coming to the fore as a price-making influence, although lack of outside interest at present prevents the market from making a full response to the developments.

The Rev. Dr. John Van Ess, missionary in Arabia and Iraq for forty years, was the guest preacher yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

LONDON, Monday, May 17 -- Red Army planes have blasted the railroad centers of Bryansk, at the junction of the central and southern fronts, and Kremenchug and Dniepropetrovsk on the Dnieper River, a special Russian communique announced today.
Turkey merits the attention and interest of the Western peoples to a far greater degree than she is now receiving, largely because we do not know enough about her.

Vice President Henry A. Wallace told a crowd estimated by the police at more than 1,000,000 persons at the "I Am an American Day" demonstration in Central Park yesterday afternoon that Americanism in its deepest meaning stood for "the freedom and the welfare and the brotherhood of the plain people of the world, wherever they are."
A New York team won the Eastern States contract bridge championship for mixed teams of four here last night at the Park Central Hotel, after leading the way in the two sessions of play.

The second annual benefit concert for the Deborah Tuberculosis Sanatorium was presented last night in Town Hall before an enthusiastic audience of good size. Participants includes Jan Peerce, the Metropolitan tenor; Dorothy Kirsten, soprano; Suzanne Sten, mezzo soprano, and Max Pollikoff, violin.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 16 -- Germany, seized now by the Maginot Line complex that three years ago proved disastrous for France, is showing slight signs promising the future crack-up among the German people and economy. This is the view of many persons one can talk with in Sweden who have chances of communicating with Germany, now confronted with the prospect of an Allied thrust into Europe.

A peace settlement without a spiritual basis cannot last, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway at 120th Street. The services opened the 107th annual commencement exercises of the Seminary.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Increased receipts of hogs and sharply lower prices have eased the position of packers to some extent, but prices of lard and other products have been little affected, and trading has been mainly at ceiling prices.

With liquidation and hedge selling outweighing supporting factors, the cotton market last week lost ground sharply. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were 25 to 40 points net lower.

Victory gardens throughout the city need have no fear of trampling feet or predatory hands if Mayor La Guardia has his way. In his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday the Mayor gave warning that he would be merciless in prosecuting trespassers on or pilferers from these war-dedicated plots.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 16 -- From the sidewalks of New York and the main streets of mid-America, from the halls of Harvard and Princeton and the tenant farms of the South and ranches west of the Divide American men by the thousands are pouring through this port to Pacific areas.

The Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele Jr., for seven years vicar of the Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, at Broadway and 155th Street, has accepted a call to the rectorship of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Germantown, Philadelphia.

"By Jupiter" now will end its run on June 12, after 426 Broadway performances over a period of just one year and nine days, the longest run ever chalked up by a Rodgers and Hart musical. The nearest R. H. competitor was "A Connecticut Yankee," which ran for 421 performances.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The American Red Cross announced today that seventy-five scholarships in medical and psychiatric social work will be made available by it to eligible candidates between next July 1 and June 30, 1944.

LONDON, May 16 (U.P.) -- Occupation by Allied armies and air forces and the establishment of an inter-Allied council for the control of defeated Germany for several years after the armistice were recommended today in a post-war program drafted by a committee of thirty Conservative members of the House of Commons and six peers.

The shortage of physicians in the rural and the booming industrial areas has focused attention on the lopsided distribution of medical care. As a result reforms may be expected after the conclusion of peace. All this means not only more doctors where there have always been too few but also more nurses.

BOSTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Braves extended their victory streak to four straight today as they swept a double-header with the Reds, 3 -- 1 and 6 -- 1, and moved into a tie for second place in the National League.
CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) -- The magazine Steel reported today "some iron ore" from North Africa is being received at Atlantic ports.

Subsidized housing as a social reform went out with the war, but subsidized housing for war workers has taken its place. The President has just asked Congress for an additional $400,000,000 for this purpose, making, if appropriated, a total of $1,600,000,000 authorized under the Lanham Act since October, 1940.

Three scholarships in classical studies with stipends totaling $2,500 have been awarded by the American Academy in Rome, 101 Park Avenue, as a result of its annual competition. The scholarships are for advanced study and research at an American university, instead of the fellowships awarded annually before the war for study and travel abroad. No fine arts awards were made this year.

While Allied air armadas are softening up Hitler's European fortress for the invasion and the first thunders of coming Spring offensives begin to reverberate along the Russian front, important events appear to be brewing on the political front which may change the whole picture of the war with dramatic suddenness.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 16 -- The Allied supply services -- a dusty, sweaty array of truck drivers, quartermasters, railroad workers, stevedores and road menders -- won a signal victory in the North African campaign by feeding, housing and transporting the Allied forces through the six-month campaign, building them up to such strength that they fired 38,000,000 rounds of ammunition in the last forty-six days of the campaign.

Mayor La Guardia announced in his regular Sunday broadcast from City Hall yesterday that the City Department of Markets was prepared to authorize food dealers to reduce ration points to move quantities of cheddar cheese "in imminent danger of spoilage" if Office of Price Administration authorities in Washington delayed action beyound the middle of the week.

WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) -- The Navy announced today its eighth Merchant Marine casualty list, containing the names of eleven killed and 321 missing in action during April. The list includes one dead and seventy-five missing men having next of kin in New York, one dead and twelve missing men with next of kin in New Jersey and six missing men with next of kin in Connecticut, as follows:

General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, and an official party of twenty including Luis Fernando Guachalla, Bolivian Ambassador to the United States, and Tomas M. Blio, Minister of Foreign Affairs, attended the 12:35 P.M. mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday.

The Administration cannot hope to win the battle against inflation unless it does three things. It must frame a basic, well-considered anti-inflation policy. To know whether that policy is or is not being put into effect it must at all times keep informed on the actual statistical position of affairs, the incidence of its policies on different income groups.
MEMPHIS, May 16 (AP) -- Of all the wartime baseball comebacks none is quite so amazing as that of Mickey O'Neil, Old Indestructible, now catching for the Memphis Chicks in the Southern Association.

MEDFORD, Mass., May 16 -- Asserting that America is not yet under the domination of a dictator, Dr. Claude M. Fuess, headmaster of Phillips Andover Academy, urged the graduates of Tufts College today to make "your votes and voices count" because social and political changes could be accomplished "only by the people with their consent and approval."

Anticipating early Congressional action on the proposed constitutional amendment granting equal rights to men and women, Mrs. Nora Stanton Barney announced yesterday the formation of an advisory council to the National Woman's Party which will press for passage of the amendment.

The Giants' flair for spectacular late-inning victories finally failed them at the Polo Grounds yesterday, with the result that 18,056 on- lookers, hopeful to the last, had to settle for an even break in a long double-header.

The glow of the first-of-the-season sunburn is already reflected on various countenances. It probably won't be long before every face in town is wearing a healthy tan from week-ends of sun-worshipping on rooftops and beaches.

LONDON, May 16 (U.P.) -- Allied radio stations intensified their propaganda campaign against Italy tonight with warnings that the time had come for the Italian people to choose between a separate peace and destruction.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP) -- The White Sox scored four runs in one inning today to beat the Red Sox, 4 to 2, but lost the second game of the double-header, 4 to 2, when Luke Appling's wild throw let in two runs.

Private Eric Rosenblith, violinist, came to New York from Camp Pickett, Va., to appear last night at the "Frolics" of the Jewish National Fund at the New York Times Hall, taking a train back immediately after he had played. The young violinist brought cheers from the large audience at the conclusion of his first number, "Poeme," by Chausson.

LONDON, May 16 -- Credited by a Flying Fortress pilot with a heroism that, "by the will of God alone, did not cost him his life," Sergeant Maynard H. Smith of Cairo, Ill., was reported today to be a likely candidate for the highest decoration that the government can award.

TIJUANA, Mexico, May 16 (AP) -- An estimated 7,000 persons crossed the international border today to watch resumption of horse racing at the Agua Caliente track, closed since last October. The crowd was above the average for Sunday. Automobiles were lined up for a mile on the American side two hours before post time, and at the same hour a three-block line of pedestrians awaited inspection to cross into Mexico.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The War Food Administration and the Office of Price Administration announced jointly tonight the establishment of a War Meat Board, to increase effectiveness of the government's meat-management program by developing more rigid safeguards against black markets.

Formation of a war production committee of the Pulpwood Consuming Industries to conduct a campaign in conjunction with the effort of the War Production Board and the Department of Agriculture to increase the production and cutting of pulp wood on farm lands will be announced today.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- Still "on edge" because of the possibility of subsequent mine shutdowns which would affect steel production, the steel industry last week pushed output up one-half of a point to 99.5 per cent of rated capacity.
ST. LOUIS, May 16 -- A crack in the Yankees' first line of defense at Sportsman's Park today robbed the American League champions of a twin triumph over the Browns before 20,425 fans.

LONDON, Monday, May 17 -- Swift Royal Air Force Mosquito bombers attacked Berlin over Saturday night and Allied fighters, including American high-altitude Thunderbolts, raked Adolf Hitler's Atlantic Wall positions yesterday in the rolling air offensive.

BERNE, Switzerland, Monday, May 17 -- Immobilized under the threat of a long air raid alarm which lasted until about one o'clock this morning, Rome discussed an unconfirmed rumor that popular King Victor Emmanuel had abdicated.

LONDON, May 16 -- Norwegian airmen have dropped a greater tonnage of bombs on Germany than the Nazis let loose on Norway during fighting there in 1940, according to a brief summary of the Norwegian war effort issued here today in connection with the observance of Norway's Independence Day, which occurs tomorrow.

In the first of two "Spanish Festivals" at the Metropolitan Opera House the always admirable Argentinita Saturday night gave what was undoubtedly her most sumptuous performance hereabouts, but not by the same token her most brilliantly successful one.

Bloomingdale Bros., Inc., reported yesterday for the six months ended on Jan. 31, last, a consolidated net income of $522,986 after taxes and charges, equal after preferred dividend requirements to $1.48 each on the 300,000 common shares outstanding.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that WNYC, the municipal radio station, had saved the city $148,500, in addition to valuable manpower and critical materials, by constructing for the Police Department, at a cost of only $7,500, an auxiliary transmitter to supplement and strengthen the existing short-wave alarm system.

The West Branch of the Croton River is furnishing good dry fly fishing these evenings to most of the veterans who know the stream. Conditions have been regarded as more or less perfect recently and Putnam County residents have overcome the first flourish of the opening of the season and settled down to the job of taking nice-sized brown trout, that may be a bit too wary on occasions.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 17 (AP) -- Ten Japanese planes, four fighters and six bombers, were machine-gunned on the ground at Lae Saturday, and numerous fires were started, the Allied High Command reported today.

Although twelve chefs work in shifts from midnight on at the Pierre Pastry Shop, 55 West Fifty-sixth Street, they often have difficulty in keeping up with the demand. This is particularly true on cool days, the manager informs us, for then appetites for the bakery's rich cakes, tarts and French pastries seem to be at their peak.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 16 -- Khaki-clad soldiers from Fort Jay, Governors Island, with side arms and M.P. bands, took up positions around the Homestead today, barring press and public for the duration of the United Nations conference on food and agriculture, which is to begin Tuesday.

CHICAGO, May 16 -- Soaking rains blanketed parts of the Winter Wheat Belt last week, greatly improving the outlook for the new crop, especially in the Southwest, but heavy losses in acreage are feared in some States as low lands were flooded.
CHUNGKING, China, May 16 (U.P.) -- A communque:

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Office of War Information reported tonight that war plants seeking and remedying the causes of absenteeism have only half as high a rate of job absences as plants without systematic plans to solve the problem.

Defeating the Kearny Celtics by 2-0 in the second game of their home-and-home soccer series before 3,500 at Starlight Park, the Philadelphia Americans, former national champions, yesterday captured the Lewis Cup. Added to the 6-1 score of the first match in Philadelphia, the Americans' margin was 8-1.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., May 16 -- Sergeant Vic Ghezzi, former holder of the P.G.A. title, and his partner, Sergeant Pat Mucci, put Army golf in the spotlight today, when they won the Albion C. Buckley Trophy, emblematic of the New Jersey State pro-amateur best-ball championship.

The need for united action by the nations to maintain peace in the post-war world was stressed by John J. Bennett, former State Attorney General, in his address to the ninety-first graduating class of Manhattan College at exercises yesterday afternoon on the college quadrangle in the Bronx.

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that 4,000,000 application cards for War Ration Book 3 would be distributed throughout the State on Thursday by the Post Office Department. One card will go to each family in the State, he said, and when they are returned to the Office of Price Administration the information they contain will be used for the issuance of the new ration books, which will be distributed by letter carriers.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Washington Post says a "black market in potatoes is operating here on an unbelievable scale, in utter contempt for price ceilings and rationing -- and right under the noses of OPA enforcement officials."

EVANSTON, Ill., May 16 (AP) -- Naval Aviation Cadet Roger Downs of Northwestern defeated top-seeded Bob Wasserman of Ohio State today for the Big Ten tennis singles championship, but the Buckeyes captured the doubles crown and banked points in two other singles divisions to win the team title with 13 points.

American war casualties in dead, wounded and captured are now at the rate of 5,000 a month, it was disclosed yesterday by Colonel A. Robert Ginsburgh of the Industrial Services Division of the War Department. He disclosed also there were now seventy American Expeditionary Forces scattered over the world war theatres.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 16 (AP) -- Philadelphia's first team today defeated the Etceteras, a squad composed of college girls, 12 to 2, and clinched its tenth National Women's Lacrosse Association tournament title at the Greenwich Academy field.

Last week the Irving Fisher Index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 111.8. The raw materials index declined 0.1 per cent as decreases in cotton, oats, wheat, cows and hogs more than offset increases in eggs and steers.

LONDON, May 16 -- Throughout Britain and Northern Ireland church bells pealed today in celebration of the big Allied victory in Tunisia, but there was at least one man whose heart was not gladdened by their joyful sound, Col. Gen. Jurgen von Arnim.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 16 -- Police have found no trace of Miss Lillian Hynes, 17-year-old daughter of Professor and Mrs. Walter A. Hynes of 714 Yonkers Avenue, who has not been seen by any member of her family since she got on a trolley car near her home Thursday morning.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 16 (AP) -- The Chiefs swept a double-header with Jersey City today, 5 to 4 and 9 to 0.

PITTSBURGH, May 16 -- To the coal miners of the nation, an estimated 60 per cent of whom are of Slavic descent, the national committee of the American Slav Congress addressed today an appeal to "place their case before the government agencies" and to stay on the job "to beat the Axis."

Graduate nurses and nurses from hospitals and training schools filled the Cathedral of St. John the Divine last night to hear Bishop William T. Manning, and the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of the Christ Church, Methodist, at the nineteenth annual Florence Nightingale Service for Nurses.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 16 -- Anti-Personalist radicals who, together with President Ramon Castillo's own National Democrats, form the pro-government alliance known as the "Concordancia," held a party convention in the city of Santa Fe this morning.

Jobs for all who want to work, it is reasonably certain, will be available after the war, George A. Eastwood, president of Armour Co., predicted yesterday in a special address to fighting forces overseas. The talk was short-waved over station WBOS as one of a weekly series presented by the National Broadcasting Company in cooperation with the National Association of Manufacturers.
WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 8 to 14 are given in the appended tabulation:

AT U.S. AIR GROUND SUPPORT HEADQUARTERS, England, May 16 (AP) -- The implied threat to the Germans in the appointment of a tank expert, Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, as commander of the United States forces in the European theatre has been underscored by a demonstration of what the Eighth United States Air Force could do in reinforcing a land invasion.

Displays in the retail stores throughout the country range from patriotic to glamorous to usher in the beginning today of the thirteenth annual Cotton Week. This truly American fabric is fighting on all fronts this year, for it is used not only for uniforms in all branches of the service and other war supplies, but also for factory garments and victory garden clothes.

IT has been a long time in coming but it is better late than never. Emil Von Elling, the modest little fellow who has been coaching the N.Y.U. track team for twenty-eight seasons, will be honored by the Track Writers Association tomorrow for "distinguished service to the sport over a span of years." It is a singularly happy choice.

The threat of another nationwide coal stoppage became acute yesterday as John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, again defied the War Labor Board and announced that the union would ignore the board's order to appear before it in Washington this morning to make arrangements jointly with the soft coal operators for resumption of negotiations in their wage dispute.
LONDON, Monday, May 17 (AP) -- Two London dailies reported this morning that Adolf Hitler was preparing to abandon Italy to her fate, leaving her to face the threat of Allied invasion unaided.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 15 (Delayed) -- Americans, I was told by Mohammed Hashim Khan, Prime Minister of Afghanistan, are considered by Afghan tribesmen and village folk as "useful," and that is as high a compliment as these simple people can pay. By that they mean the opposite of "harmful," which is their other characterization of outsiders.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- The Office of Price Administration warned today that dealers who require new car purchasers to agree to turn in used cars as part payment or to purchase unwanted accessories are violating provisions or the price schedule on new automobiles.

They jeered when Leo Durocher allowed Bobo Newsom to hit for himself in the seventh inning of the second game of yesterday's double- header between the Dodgers and Cubs at Ebbets Field. The score was tied, two were out and Billy Herman was on second.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 -- When an Army plane is forced down at sea and its crew takes to a rubber raft a small balloon is sent aloft, a shipwrecked flier turns a crank and an SOS signal crackles over 100,000 square miles of ocean. Days, perhaps weeks, of often futile searching is saved and the prompt action of the "grounded" airmen may mean the difference between life and death for the whole crew.
DETROIT, May 16 (AP) -- The Senators defeated the Tigers twice today before 23,309 spectators, 7 to 1 and 10 to 6, to win their second straight series and regain the American League's third place.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 16 (AP) -- Outfielder Leon Culberson of the Louisville Colonels has been swapped to the parent Red Sox for Outfielder Tommy McBride, Manager Bill Burwell of the American Association team said today.
LONDON, May 16 -- Britain's Home Guard may not have captured Tunis and Bizerte, but today it went a long way toward capturing London.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 16 -- Arthur Davis, with his International sloop Patricia, today led in the second tune-up contest for the Summer racing on Long Island Sound, as he did a week ago. Against the wind from the Larchmont Yacht Club buoy to Parsonage Point, Rye, and back for six miles, the Patricia paced Joseph Merrill's Feather by 19 seconds.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- Republican women are organizing committees throughout the country "to spot and curb the misuse of government propaganda to further the Roosevelt fourth-term campaign and New Deal radical schemes," it was announced today by Miss Marion Martin, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee and Director of Women's Activities.

In the necessary preparation for the peace after this war, there is one subject on which there is a general agreement in this country -- that there must be speedy and effective punishment of those guilty of shocking and flagrant violations of hitherto accepted methods of warfare among civilized nations, and a punishment that will tend to discourage future leaders of any country from again indulging in such crimes against civilization.
LONDON, May 16 (U.P.) -- The Russian noon communique as broadcast from Moscow:
LONDON, Monday, May 17 -- In a weak retaliation for the R.A.F. raid on Berlin Saturday night, the Germans sent a small number of their planes over London at long-drawn-out intervals early today.
The German Sunday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

Italy soon will be out of the war, abandoned by the Nazis and deserted by Premier Mussolini, after all available war materials have been shipped to Germany, Mayor La Guardia predicted yesterday in his radio broadcast from City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 16 -- A pontifical high mass of thanksgiving in the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception at Catholic University this morning opened the commemoration here of the silver jubilee of the Code of Canon Law promulgated by the late Pope Benedict XV on May 27, 1917.

Expansion of the American Labor party of New York State into a nation-wide third party to protect the social and labor gains made under the New Deal was urged last night by Mayor La Guardia in a speech at the dinner of its State executive committee at the Hotel Commodore.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 17 (AP) -- The noon communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 16 (AP) -- A lull in aerial activity has settled on the Mediterranean and its shores as Allied fliers and soldiers ease up in the interval between the violent battle of Tunisia and the next phase of the war.
The text of the address of Vice President Wallace at the American Day exercises here follows:...

The thoughtless may have assumed that problems of etiquette are held in abeyance in wartime, but this is not the case, of course. One question keeps rearing its ugly head, according to a recent syndicated column by Emily Post.

The local season of the Negro National Baseball League started yesterday when the New York Cubans and the New York Black Yankees clashed in a double-header at the Yankee Stadium. The Cubans took the first game, 10 -- 2, and were held to a 5-5 tie in the second game, which was called because of darkness at the end of the tenth.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 16 (AP) -- A lull in aerial activity has settled on the Mediterranean and its shores as Allied fliers and soldiers ease up in the interval between the violent battle of Tunisia and the next phase of the war.

The local season of the Negro National Baseball League started yesterday when the New York Cubans and the New York Black Yankees clashed in a double-header at the Yankee Stadium. The Cubans took the first game, 10 -- 2, and were held to a 5-5 tie in the second game, which was called because of darkness at the end of the tenth.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- That old jinx of the Cubs, Johnny Podgajny, aided by a five-run uprising in the first inning, pitched the Phillies to an 8-to-4 victory over the Bruins at Shibe Park today. As a result the Phillies moved into fifth place.

BOSTON, May 17 -- In her sixth try of the year Mrs. Sam Orr's Us finally found the winning circle today at Suffolk Downs when she scored by a nose in the Salem, $1,500 sprint for $3,500-$3,000 platers, feature offering of an all-claiming program.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 18 (AP) -- The Germans flung infantrymen and tanks into "several attacks" northeast of Novorossiisk Monday in a new outburst of fighting in the Caucasus, the Russians announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a radio station whose operating license would be affected has a right to intervene in proceedings before the Federal Communications Commission to determine whether the facilities of another station should be increased.

Improved trade buying in the wake of dminished hedge selling brought moderate gains to the cotton futures market yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts, with the exception of the new May delivery, ended 3 to 8 points above Saturdays final quotations.

OTTAWA, May 17 -- The fourth Victory Loan of $1,100,000,000 has been oversubscribed by $100,000,000, it was revealed today. This represents an average of $100 from every man, woman and child in the Dominion lent to the government after the national purse had previously been dipped into three times since 1941.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Opposing legislation to prohibit the induction of fathers until all other manpower is exhausted, Major Gen. Lewis B. Hershey testified today that "we may run out" of other draft registrants about Aug. 1.

BOSTON, May 17 -- Secretary Knox said tonight that the United Nations are acquiring "greater and greater" domination of Axis lines of communication and that the hour draws near when they will strike a powerful blow at its main fortifications in Europe and Asia.

An exhibition of paintings, icons and other objects of art from private collections will open today at the Gould House Galleries, 579 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of Russian War Relief. Admission to the opening today (from 4:30 to 7 P.M.) will be by invitation only.

Coming from behind in a hard fought match, Linton Baldwin of Poly Prep reached the final round of the Athletic Association of Private Schools tennis championship by defeating Herbert Gruber of Dwight, 4 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 0, at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.
Another wartime occupation has opened for women, on an experimental basis. They are being used by R.H. Macy Co. as helpers on delivery trucks.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- To distribute the war services of military, government and civilian nurses equitably, the War Manpower Commission has set up a Nursing Supply and Distribution Unit, similar to its Procurement and Assignment Service for medical personnel, Paul V. McNutt, chairman, said today.

MOSCOW, May 17 -- Pravda today reprints extensive extracts from an article about General Wladislaw Anders's Polish Army published by Wolna Polska, organ of the Union of Patriotic Poles in the Soviet Union, on May 1. The author was Colonel Zigmund Berling, former Chief of Staff of the Fifth Polish Division in the Anders Army and now commander of the Polish division in formation in Prussia.

Eighty-eight pieces of sculpture and pottery, made by blind women members of the Lighthouse Recreation Department, will be shown at the Lighthouse, 111 East Fifty-ninth Street, beginning this afternoon at 3. The exhibition will be open every afternoon from 3 to 5 through Saturday.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The text of President Roosevelt's identical letters to Senator George and Representative Doughton, chairmen of the Congressional tax committees, follows:

The cold, late Spring and continuing rains have aggravated New York and New Jersey's No. 1 farm problem -- manpower -- already made acute by the many war plants that have skyrocketed farm wage scales and drained off experienced hands, according to the men trying to solve the problem.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Interior Department's money supply for next fiscal year was cut 60 per cent below the current year's funds in a joint economy drive today by Secretary Ickes, the Budget Bureau and the House Appropriations Committee.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Wright Rumbough gave a dinner last night in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Their guests included Colonel John W. Downer, U.S.A., and Mrs. Downer, Miss Grace Rumbough, and Lieutenant J. Platt Downer, U.S.A.

The threatened new stoppage of coal production at midnight tonight was averted yesterday through the intervention of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Fuels Coordinator for War, who, in a telegram, asked the miners to remain at work upon expiration of the fifteen-day truce under which the industry has been operating and expressed the hope that this would open the way "for immediate collective bargaining conferences" with the soft coal operators.
Calling all volunteers; calling student nurses; calling nurse's aides!

For divers reasons, I apprehend that the term "treason" will soon be discussed by our citizenry generally, as never before since the Civil War period. It is therefore proper for all of us to understand just what acts constitute this offense, which Sir William Blackstone, in his "Commentaries," calls the most heinous of crimes.
The Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office issued a call yesterday for additional vol unteers to donate their blood.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 17 -- The wild ducks and Canadian geese that the Westchester County Park Commission has lured to its bird sanctuary along the Bronx River Parkway in Scarsdale, Crestwood and Bronxville are devouring the young tomato plants and bean sprouts in victory gardens of the area, residents complained today to the commission.

Consumption of silver in the United States last year for all purposes amounted to 193,933,000 ounces, a record, compared with 135,064,000 in 1941 and 62,239,000 in 1940, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. Of the total, 78,933,000 ounces were used for coinage purposes, against 55,064,000 in 1941 and 21,239,000 in 1940.

WASHINGTON, May l7 -- Interpreting the Fifth Amendment to the Constitution, which bars taking private property for public use without just compensation, the Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 decision said today that the amendment "allows the owner only the fair market value of his property; it does not guarantee him a return of his investment."

An alliance between the left wing of the American Labor party and the leadership of Tammany Hall was charged yesterday by State Senator James G. Donovan, chairman of the committee seeking to oust Michael J. Kennedy from the Tammany leadership.

The promotion of increased international cooperation and international trade is now a "matter of supreme foreign policy" for the United States, Francis B. Sayre, special assistant to the Secretary of State, declared yesterday in an address read for him at a luncheon inaugurating Foreign Trade Week, attended by about 1,000 foreign traders at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Retailers of shoes are not required to surrender ration currency at the time they place orders for merchandise for Fall delivery, the Office of Price Administration emphasized today. Surrender of ration currency is not called for until just before shipments of the shoes are actually made.

Stranding thirteen base runners, the Giants deserved no better fate than befell them at the Polo Grounds yesterday. They filled the sacks with none down in the sixth but failed to score, and go the Reds, happy to escape alive from Boston, where they dropped three in a row, won by 3 -- 1 behind Ray Starr.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The Senate, which has been leaving the strategy of the war to the Commander in Chief and the military and naval high commands, was plunged into a three-hour debate marked by blunt criticisms and allegations today as Senator Chandler of Kentucky, addressing his demands and appeals direct to the present conferences between President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, urged a turning of full-scale battle, now, upon Japan.

DETROIT, May 17 -- The Yankees arrived this morning for their first visit of the year to Briggs Stadium and ran into a day of idleness, as the scheduled opener of a four-game series with the Tigers was postponed. The conflict will be played on the champions' next visit here, the exact date to be set later.
Mr. and Mrs. Lincoln Isham of the Carlyle will leave today for their country home in Dorset, Vt., where they will spend the Summer.

One of the major horrors of the German invasion of France, the separation of families, could have been lessened by an agency such as the central registration bureau set up in New York City after Pearl Harbor, it was said yesterday by Miss Jacqueline Seligmann and Mrs. Edmee Chapelle, who drove trucks used in evacuating French children from the enemy's path.

The fanatical scream, "Hell Hitler!" ripped through the air in Rockefeller Center. It took startled crowds some time to realize that the cry and the bark of Hitler's voice came from some captured German sound films. The official opening of the exhibit, "The Nature of the Enemy," sponsored by the Office of War Information, was under way in the promenade from Fifth Avenue, between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets.
LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- The American Red Cross is going in for a bit of glamor to offset the realities of war.

LONDON, May 17 -- The King, Crown Prince and Prime Minister of Norway joined today in assuring the people of their homeland that the day of liberation was nearing. They spoke in connection with the observance of the 129th anniversary of Norwegian Independence Day.

LONDON, May 17 (U.P.) -- Reports from Italy today said that Premier Mussolini had appealed to Pope Pius for counsel in the face of a German warning against any attempt to "sell out" to the threatening Allied might massed across the Mediterranean.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Congress was urged today by Representative Springer of Indiana to do what it could to curb the circulation of "My Part In This War," a privately-distributed pamphlet prepared with the aid of government employes which, he maintained, sought to indoctrinate school pupils with controversial ecenomic philosophies following Administration pattern.

The United States Treasury will now seek to sell $600,000,000 of war savings bonds each month under payroll deduction plans, instead of the present $400,000,000 by this method, Ralph G. Engelsman, associate field director of the Treasury's payroll savings division, told 300 volunteer members of the New York War Savings Staff at a meeting yesterday morning at the Hotel Abbey, Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue.

BERNE, Switzerland, Tuesday, May 18 -- Reports from Germany reaching here early today through private channels indicated at least 4,000 persons killed and 120,000 made homeless in the Upper Ruhr and Weser Valley regions as a result of the wrecking of the Moehne and Eder dams over Sunday night by the Royal Air Force.

CHICAGO, May 17 (AP) -- The Big Ten golf tournament ran according to the familiar pattern of the 1942 event today as Jim McCarthy of Illinois, defending individual title holder, and Michigan's team champions took the lead in the first day of play over the soggy Westmoreland Country Club course.

Alex. Brown Sons won the award yesterday of a new issue of $150,000 Cumberland, Md., airport bonds, due serially from June 1, 1954 to 1965, on a bid of 102.539 for the bonds as 1 3/4 per cents. Re-offering is being made at prices to yield 1.30 to 1.60 per cent.

CHICAGO, May 17 -- Favorable crop comments fell flat as a price-making influence in wheat, except for a brief period in the early trading today on the Board of Trade.
