Selling at the opening was light and the market quickly turned upward, due more to lack of pressure than to aggressive buying, and closing sales were 1/4 to 5/8 cent a bushel higher than Saturday's close.

PHILADELPHIA, May 17 (AP) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company of New York, paid Walter S. Gifford, president and director of the company, $210,250 for his services during the 1942 fiscal year, the company revealed to day in its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Bolivia is making "a real contribution to the prosecution and winning of the war." Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday at City Hall in extending the city's official greetings to General Enrique Penaranda, President of the South American republic.

Billy Southworth's world champion Cardinals faced the Dodgers for the first time this year in a twilight game at Ebbets Field yesterday and today the Redbirds are in third place, with the league-leading Durocher boys four games in front of them.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Lieut. Col. J.T. Taylor, deputy War Food Administrator, today issued a statement acknowledging that one of the two vessels on which Jamaican farm workers were imported to this country was crowded and without adequate sanitary facilities, that a "disturbance" occurred, and that one of the workers accidentally fell overboard and was lost at sea.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Hope that the Allied victory in North Africa will be followed by further successes in Eastern and Western Europe and by offensive actions in Asia "in the near future" has been expressed by President Roosevelt in personal messages to Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia and Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of China, it was disclosed today.

The San Carlo Opera Company will open its Spring season here on Wednesday night, May 26; with a performance of "Aida" at the Center Theatre. The season of sixteen performances will continue there for twelve days with matinees on Saturdays and Sundays, and will end on Sunday night, June 6.

Up here at the front those of us who are fortunate enough to have a radio in our organization follow the world news with close interest. Our primary interest is ending the war, and we get most of our cheer in these lonely parts from any information that leads us to think that end is being accomplished.
NEW DELHI, India, May 17 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

CAPTAIN LIDDELL HART, the British advocate of a war policy of limited liability, is in disfavor at the moment. Yet it remains true that little Britain, with its 45,000,000 inhabitants, could not possibly hope to defeat 80,000,000 Germans by relying on a mass army. Britain's hope for survival has always rested on superior weapons in the hands of small, picked bands of firstrate fighting individuals.

A little over three years ago the Nazis were dropping bombs on Norway in an avowed effort to "protect" that country from the horrors of war. This week it was announced that Norwegian airmen have deposited more than an equivalent weight of bombs on German soil.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A group of top-ranking government officials registered opposition to the pending Connally-Smith anti-strike and labor restrictive bill in letters to Speaker Rayburn today.
MONTREAL, May 17 (AP) -- Behind the three-hit-pitching of Tom Ananicz the Newark Bears scored a handy 3-1 victory over the Montreal Royals today.

Selection of a blue-ribbon jury to try Milton Solomon, former deputy city controller, on an indictment charging attempted grand larceny was completed yesterday in General Sessions before Judge James Garrett Wallace.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 17 -- Registering a 65, Lew Carson of the home club and Jack Mallon, professional at the Garden City Country Club, captured top honors in the Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball tourney held on the No. 4 course of the Salisbury Country Club today.

The General Motors Corporation now is the nation's biggest producer of ordnance, having turned out in one recent month 118,000 guns ranging in size from carbines to cannons, according to a survey appearing in the current issue of GM Folks, a monthly employe publication.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- United States fishermen caught 300,000,000 pounds of sport fish last year, says Dr. Ira N. Gabrielson, director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

An English-language broadcast from Tokyo radio beamed to North America said yesterday that "Mr. McCormick's plan for the absorption by America of all the British countries may perhaps be the best plan to safeguard American interests," the Columbia Broadcasting System short-wave listening station reported.
I disagree with the Mayor in his repeated pleading for a costly and unnecessary special session of the Legislature so that he can increase the city sales tax.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 17 -- The recent Royal Air Force raiding of Baltic waters achieved its biggest known result when one of the largest German merchantmen, the 18,160-ton North German Lloyd steamer Gneisenau, was beached after having run into a mine in the Southern Baltic.

Wall Street is commencing to discuss what appears to be a country-wide slow-up in the non-essential businesses and services and to wonder whether action from Washington might not counteract it. As financial leaders see it, the retort of "Don't you know there's a war on?" is being used to excuse sloppiness and inattention in almost every business.

The Book of the Month Club announces a dual selection for August. Chosen are "Thirty Seconds Over Tokyo," by Captain Ted Lawson, to be published by Random House, and "Origins of the American Revolution," by John C. Miller, an Atlantic Monthly Press book from Little, Brown.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 17 -- Plans for the establishment of a graduate school of Christian education were announced today by the board of trustees of the Princeton Theological Seminary at its annual meeting. The session was held in connection with the seminary's one hundred and thirty-first commencement exercises, which took place this afternoon in the Princeton University Chapel.

LONDON, May 17 -- The great Moehne and Eder Dams are key factors in Germany's war potential. It was with knowledge of their vital importance that a famous German-Jewish medical specialist exiled from Berlin and now practicing in London asked me why the R.A.F. had not bombed them.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Roosevelt recommended today that American women study post-war problems and possibilities rather than partisan questions, so that they would not be "as unprepared in their thinking" as they were following the First World War.

The synthesis of biotin, nature's most powerful vitamin and one of its rarest and costliest substances, is announced in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- President Roosevelt, acting on the eve of a House vote on the Ruml pay-as-you-go plan, served notice late today that he could not "acquiesce in the elimination of a whole year's tax burden on the upper income groups during a war period when I must call for an increase in taxes and savings from the mass of our people."

ALBANY, May 17 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore estimated today that New York City would receive $40,332,260 as its share of State-collected taxes during its present fiscal year, ending June 30. He said that $38,916,679 had already been turned over to the city treasury.
WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The armed forces of the United States have lost more than 80,000 men in battle casualties in seventeen months of war.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Navy announced that a small United States merchant vessel was torpedoed and sunk by an enemy submarine early in March in the North Atlantic. Survivors have been landed at New York.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 10 per cent for the week ended May 15, in comparison with the same week a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
BILLY SOUTHWORTH was discovered yesterday in a suite on the fortieth floor of his hotel, which was a pretty lofty spot for any manager to be.

Making a front race of it all the way, Mrs. R.E. McIlvain's Bright Willie lasted to take yesterday's feature race at Belmont Park as the biggest weekday crowd of the meeting, 15,436, made the trek to the Long Island racing plant.

Some of the "dream" products of the post-war period now being pictured both editorially and in ads in publications were discounted yesterday by R.C. Cosgrove, vice president and general manager of the manufacturing division of the Crosley Corporation.

TORONTO, May 17 (Canadian Press) -- Premier Gordon D. Conant, presiding at a meeting of the Ontario Cabinet this afternoon, informed the Ministers that he would resign tomorrow and would recommend to the Lieutenant Governor that Harry Nixon be called on to form a government, it was learned tonight from reliable sources.

Mark Woods, president of the Blue Network, announced at a party given yesterday afternoon at the Waldorf-Astoria for Dr. Serge Koussevitzky and Dr. Roy Harris that he had commissioned Mr. Harris to compose a Sixth symphony to be played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Dr. Koussevitzky's direction.

The problem of distributing the State's quota of new pressure cookers released by the War Production Board to encourage home canning will be one step nearer solution this week as advisory committees are formed to pass on applications from groups seeking to buy them.
The world premiere of Stanley Bate's suite of three pieces for two pianos featured the two-piano recital last night at Town Hall by Dorothea Freitag and George Bauer, seaman first class.

Thirty-five million copies of current American books will be shipped abroad to the armed forces of the United States in the coming year, under a plan announced yesterday by the Council on Books in Wartime.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 18 -- Large formations of United States Eighth Air Force bombers made heavy attacks on targets in Nazi-occupied territory by daylight yesterday, it was announced officially last night. The largest attacks were made against harbor installations at Lorient and the adjacent U-boat base at Keroman, while the ports and docks of Bordeaux were bombed effectively.

A vast throng crowded Carnegie Hall last night for Vladimir Horowitz's second recital of the season, postponed from an earlier date because of the death of Rachmaninoff. Hundreds of service men and some service ladies were seated on the stage.

ST. LOUIS, May 17 (AP) -- Manager Luke Sewell has been invited to a preview of his Browns after Uncle Sam puts the finger on Shortstop Vern Stephens -- and this is one show Luke would just as soon not see.

A banking group headed by Lehman Brothers will offer today a new issue of $3,000,000 Flintkote Company fifteen-year 3 per cent debentures, priced at 102. This issue will constitute the only funded debt of the company, which is engaged principally in the production of building materials, paper board products and industrial, marine and railroad products.

A Federal public works program to insure against unemployment in the post-war period was proposed yesterday by Mayor La Guardia. The project calls for appropriation of $300,000,000 for working plans immediately and grants to States, counties and municipalities after the conflict.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 17 -- Allied bombs smashed the seaplane base at Lido di Roma, only fifteen miles southwest of Rome, last night. British Wellingtons flew over the moonlit capital in a striking demonstration of the ease with which Allied air power could strike at the heart of the Italian State.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, May 18 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The addition of two-year junior colleges to New York, City's system of free higher education was proposed in a report to a meeting of the Board of Higher Education last night at Hunter College by its chairman, Dr. Ordway Tead.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (U.P.) -- Navy Communique 379:

Even if the war makes new toys scarce, New York will have a well-rounded stock of antique playthings in the reproduction of an old toy shop that will be opened today at the Museum of the City off New York, Fifth Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- A long and uninterrupted line of Supreme Court decisions is challenged by the anti-poll tax bill which has been petitioned out of the House Judiciary Committee and is about to become once more a focus of controversy. If the measure should become law and is upheld on a test of its constitutionality, the present Supreme Court will be obliged to reverse John Marshall and other eminent justices.

LONDON, May 17 -- The stock markets here began the week on a very quiet note, due, probably, to forthcoming events in the war. Prices were lower in several sections. There was further profit-taking in South African mines and prices fell sharply.

LONDON, May 17 (Reuter) -- The Moehne dam, one of the two German dams broken by the R.A.F. last night, is near the town of Soest in Westphalia. It is the biggest source of water supply for industrial and domestic purposes in the Ruhr. It also supplies electricity for many large factories.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 12, the Federal Reserve Board announced: increases of $396,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills $973,000,000 in holdings of United States Government bonds, $523,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $846,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Hotel operators must maintain sales promotion to build good-will in the same manner that other industries are doing, Allan G. Hurst, vice president and general manager of the Hotel Knickerbocker, Chicago, declared yesterday in an address at the sixteenth annual convention of the National Hotel Sales Managers Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Coach Jackson Browne's New Utrecht High School squad, taking eight of the fifteen first places, retained its team title with 70 points in the fifth annual Brooklyn P.S.A.L. track and field championships at Brooklyn College Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- To relax mileage rationing to allow to motorists extra travel for vacations would be a "luxury which we cannot afford in total war," Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, said today.
Both in the Mediterranean area and in Western Europe German air power is a declining air power.

Every human being in the United Nations, not to speak of those in the neutral and enemy lands, has a concern in the food conference which begins today at Hot Springs, Va. The questions, when do we eat, and what, have a universal application. Moreover, whatever food program is adopted will depend for its success on popular understanding and consent.

TORONTO, May 17 (Canadian Press) -- Al Jarlett came up with a four-hit performance to join the fraternity of winning pitchers for the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight. Adding nine strike-outs to the four-hitter, Jarlett led the Leafs to an 8-2 decision over the Jersey City Giants.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has accepted the chairmanship of the planning committee of the New York Dress Institute, which will formulate a post-war program to promote New York as the fashion center of the world, it was learned yesterday. The institute, it was estimated, has in excess of $1,000,000 in accumulated funds for the promotional work.
Ellsworth B. Buck, who was re-elected president of the Board of Education on May 11, announced yesterday the following committee appointments for the ensuing year:

The stock market was stunted yesterday by a drastic reduction in business and prices milled about in a narrow range. Minor gains showed in a few of the most heavily traded issues on the Stock Exchange and the common and preferred of New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) were a center of activity, with additions of more than 3 points.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 17 -- Crops in Southern Europe are threatened with catastrophe if rain does not fall within fourteen days, it was reported here today. Rumania and Hungary have both experienced a drought worse than any they have had during the last fifty years, it was added.

CHUNGKING, China, May 17 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have thrown parachute troops into action in the fighting west of Lake Tungting in northern Hunan Province, hoping to occupy important county seats in that rich rice-growing area, a Chinese communigue revealed tonight.
CHUNGKING, China, May 17 (U.P.) -- A communique:

NEW DELHI, India, May 17 (U.P.) -- American fliers, concentrating on Japanese supply lines in Central Burma, yesterday dropped more than ten tons of bombs on railroad installations between Mandalay and Shwebo and an even greater weight of explosives on Zigon, twenty-seven miles northwest of Shwebo, the Tenth United States Air Force announced today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 17 -- The second wartime conference of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, was told today by John D. Kemper, board chairman of the division, that Regulation W was not proved an anti-inflationary measure beyond dispute.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A Republican proposal to keep a Congressional string attached to the reciprocal trade agreements aroused prompt opposition today from Secretary Hull.

Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury that as president of the group he had received a letter on Jan. 11, 1939, from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, asking him to take "decisive action against the communistic influences" reported in the Teachers Union, Local 5, in New York.

Our correspondent Herbert L. Matthews has found another country to observe and enjoy. American visitors to Afghanistan have been few. Only a handful of American temporary residents is there, mostly members of the United States Legation. Our fathers and grandfathers heard now and then of a royal expulsion or assassination, or of invasion by a foreign Power to punish the murder of some of its citizens.

Formal announcement of the decision of all mutual savings banks in New York State to insure their deposits with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation instead of through the New York Mutual Savings Bank Fund, was made jointly yesterday by Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, and Myron S. Short, president of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The War Labor Board declared today that John L. Lewis's defiance of the board "challenges the sovereignty of the United States in time of war and gives aid and comfort to our enemies." The board staked its future on its demand that Mr. Lewis recognize its jurisdiction.

Local draft boards were advised yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Director of Selective Service, to classify in 1-A all pre-medical and pre-dental students who are not already in a college reserve corps, or who have not completed the first year of their school's Army Specialized Training Program.

" Behind Prison Walls," starring Ann Baxter and Gertrude Michael, and a Western, "Carson City Cyclone," compose the week's new double feature program, starting today, at the New York Theatre. . . . The Irving Place Theatre will revive, today and tomorrow, the French film, "The Mayor's Dilemma," and the Russian picture, "Baltic Deputy."

LONDON, May 17 (U.P.) -- British cruisers, one commanded by a first cousin of Queen Elizabeth, intercepted two German blockade runners carrying valuable cargo from the Japanese-occupied Far East and forced their panicky crews to scuttle them, the Admiralty announced tonight.

Only a year ago he was a 35-cent-an-hour worker. He was the junior high school boy who came in on his bicycle after school on weekdays and longer hours on Saturday to help cut the grass, rake leaves and stack the firewood.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to review a decision holding that Japanese born in this country are American citizens and hence entitled to vote.

The war manpower problem is now one of allocation and distribution, since there are no more reserves, Lawrence A. Appley, executive director of the War Manpower Commission, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Council of Industrial Editors' Associations, which is holding a wartime conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A sudden cast change of major importance has been made in the musical comedy "Early to Bed," which is scheduled to begin its try-out next Monday in Boston and is slated to arrive at the Broadhurst on June 10. Carl Brisson, who had the leading role, that of a broken-down bull fighter, is no longer in the company, it was acknowledged yesterday by his representative, Henry Wiese.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- A "drastic shake-up" in the Office of Price Administration was recommended today by a House Naval Affairs subcommittee as two other House committees planned to investigate the agency's regulations and rent-control practices.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 17 -- Apart from official notices, the French press these days is filled with so-called dispatches all written in Vichy, publication of which is imperative under pain of suspension.

KNOXVILE, Tenn., May 17 (U.P.) -- The Federal Government's gigantic economic experiment, the Tennessee Valley Authority -- which will be ten years old tomorrow -- has sold nearly thirty billion kilowatt-hours of electricity and saved Southern power consumers an estimated $100,000,000, it was reported yesterday.
LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

MOSCOW, May 17 -- The population of the island of Stampalia, one of the Aegean Islands, recently revolted, against Italian authorities and set up its own government, according to a report in the Turkish newspaper Yeni Sabah quoted by the Soviet News Agency.

Minority stockholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York made a concerted but unsuccessful attempt yesterday to pass resolutions calling for curbs on management salaries and to question the qualifications of several of the candidates for election to the company's board of trustees.

Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, declared yesterday in an answer to the Mayor's statement in his Sunday broadcast about a bear market in city real estate, that "if any such group exists outside the Mayor's imagination it is undoubtedly receiving the utmost in aid and comfort from the city administration."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, May 18 -- Two hundred and eighty-eight persons in the Australian and British medical service and eleven women nurses perished when a Japanese submarine torpedoed the Australian hospital ship Centaur a few miles off the Queensland coast in the darkness of last Friday morning, it was announced today.

LANSING, Mich., May 17 -- First steps toward rationing of bottled liquor in Michigan will begin Thursday with the registration of adults throughout the State, it was announced here today by the Michigan Liquor Control Commission.

Sales of the National Department Stores Corporation for its fiscal year ended on Jan. 31, 1943, increased 10.9 per cent, to $55,821,228, from $50,316,295 for the preceding year, according to the report of Harry H. Schwartz, president.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The names, with next of kin, of 1,057 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas were made public today by the War Department. Of these casualties, 832 occurred in North Africa.

LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- The Air Ministry said tonight that the break in the Eder Dam alone flooded Kassel, industrial city on the Weser, and towns beyond it; disrupted hydro-electric stations throughout the area, and seriously affected traffic on the Mittelland Canal, main east-west water artery that links all main navigable rivers west of Berlin.

LONDON, May 17 -- British bombers struck a crippling blow at German water power last night. Flying over the ramparts of Hitler's fortress Europe, big Lancasters of the Royal Air Force penetrated deep into the Reich and dropped mines from an altitude of 100 feet and less against the Eder and Moehne dams, two of the biggest in Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today refused to review a decision enjoining a labor union from picketing two cafeterias operated by a group of persons who maintained they were all partners and did not employ any outside help.

As local Office of Price Administration authorities cited the law, obviously for the benefit of Mayor La Guardia, showing food retailers the necessary steps to take to cut points and prices to sell Cheddar cheese "in imminent danger of spoilage," the War Food Administration of the United States Department of Agriculture moved yesterday to force millions of cases of eggs out of speculators' hoards.

Mr. Lewis's agreement to prolong his "truce" and give the Government another two weeks in which to meet his terms does not change the fundamentals of the present situation. "The issue now confronting the nation in this dispute," declares the War Labor Board, "is whether Mr. Lewis is above and beyond the laws which apply to all other citizens of the United States.
If the law of supply and demand continues to function, the Peconic Bay boat captains believe they will enjoy one of the best seasons since weakfishing became a popular pastime.

Several furniture manufacturers, many of them from the South, will "boycott" any furniture show that is held in Chicago next month, it was learned yesterday. Although the New York event has been canceled at the request of the Office of Defense Transportation, no word of plans to cancel the Chicago show had been received here up to last night.

Disposition of the affairs of the twenty-eight nurseries that had been operating in the city on Work Projects Administration funds until the abolition of that agency was revealed yesterday by Miss Helen Harris, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on the Wartime Care of Children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 17 -- Universal is preparing a musical under the title, "Hip, Hip, Hooray," with a background of show business from the days of the concert hall on through to the present swing band craze. This will be produced by John Grant, who recently was elevated to producer status on that lot from his former berth as writer for the Abbott and Costello pictures.

Reporting yesterday on operations for the six months ended on March 31, E.R. Breech, president of the Bendix Aviation Corporation, informed stockholders that net sales and other operating income, totaling $417,812,579, rose 145 per cent over the $170,420,270 volume in the corresponding period of the preceding year.
CHUNGKING, China, May 17 -- During this period of stalemate in the war a number of things disturb Chungking savants. Here are a few topics commonly discussed by Chinese with Westerners over teacups:
LONDON, May 17 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:
The German Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
BOSTON, May 17 -- Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said today that "generally the picture is improving" for the United Nations in submarine warfare, although it is "subject to ups and downs."
As the war moves into the long-awaited offensive stage, victory has brought to the surface a new problem, more important than most people imagine. It is the problem of prisoners.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- The manufacture of rubber tires for civilian use must be resumed this year so that the industry will be in a position to produce the 30,000,000 new tires which must be fabricated in 1944 to keep the country rolling, it was reported today by William M. Jeffers, Rubber Director.

Degrees were conferred last night upon ninety-four students, representing fifteen denominations, at the annual commencement exercises of the Union Theological Seminary at Broadway and 120th Street. The degrees were presented by Thatcher M. Brown, president of the board of directors.

If you happen to be in the vicinity of the Medical Center, you might visit the Washington Heights-Riverside Health Center, Broadway and 168th Street, where a special program is in progress this week under the direction of the center's nutrition committee. There is no charge for admission.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- In one of the briefest communiques on record, the Navy Department today broke its silence on the battle of the Aleutians and said: "Operations against the Japanese on Attu Island are continuing."

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Continuing their destructive toll against Japanese shipping in the Pacific and Far East, United States submarines operating in these waters have sunk six more vessels, including one enemy destroyer, and damaged a seventh, a Navy communique reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 17 -- Continuing their destructive toll against Japanese shipping in the Pacific and Far East, United States submarines operating in these waters have sunk six more vessels, including one enemy destroyer, and damaged a seventh, a Navy communique reported today.

Although contradictions crop up from time to time to nullify in a measure the complete success of the fish-for-food campaign, the leaflet which the New York Conservation Department is distributing on this topic is in line with the principles set forth by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- One length separated the first three finishers in the $1,500 Roslindale Purse, allowance feature over a mile and seventy yards, at Suffolk Downs today, with H.M. Babylon's Abbe Pierre, imported 6-year-old, the winner. L.B. Sheppard's Kansas ran second, with Charlie Rufi's Dense Path third.

BOSTON, May 18 (AP) -- Scoring all their runs in a fourth-inning splurge which included home runs by Charlie Workman and Johnny McCarthy, the Braves blanked the Pirates, 4 -- 0, today for their fifth straight victory. Al Javery pitched the shut-out for his third triumph against one defeat.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate debate yesterday on post-Tunisian strategy, of which Senator A.B. Chandler of Kentucky was the central figure, was the projection of dispute among some of the highest officers of the armed forces.

LONDON, May 18 -- How British submarines are ranging the length of the Mediterranean and plaguing enemy shipping was emphasized today by a communique listing the sinking of one Italian destroyer and five supply ships and the damaging of several others.

John J. Raskob won yesterday from Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein the dismissal, as against him, of a suit brought by two stockholders of the General Motors Corporation for recovery of losses allegedly suffered by the corporation in 1930 as a result of an exchange of stock with Mr. Raskob in connection with the institution of a new bonus plan.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Eighteen prominent airlines have put themselves on record unqualifiedly against government participation in their management or ownership of their companies in the development of foreign air commerce, it was announced today.

Caleb Milne 4th, who engineered a "hoax kidnapping" of himself in December, 1935, to obtain money and publicity so he could get a job on the stage or in motion pictures, was killed in Tunisia on May 11 while tending two wounded men, it was revealed yesterday by the American Field Service, 60 Beaver Street.

After having escaped unhurt when his destroyer, the Aaron Ward, was struck by three fourteen-inch shells, one eight-inch shell and a five-inch shell during the Battle of Savo Island last November, Chief Machinist's Mate John J. MacDonald was killed when the destroyer was sunk by ninety-eight Japanese planes on April 7, his widow, Mrs. Frances D. MacDonald, said yesterday.

BOSTON, May 18 -- The tail and luminosity of the recently discovered Whipple Comet are acting in a normal comet manner, that is, unpredictably, Dr. Fred L. Whipple, Harvard University astronomer, its discoverer, declared today.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Pullman, Inc., Chicago, reported today that although first quarter traffic volume and armament shipments lifted the company's total gross income to the highest amount for any quarter in Pullman's history, provision for Federal taxes absorbed nearly 82 per cent of net income, restricting earnings to 2 cents on each dollar of gross against 4 cents in the first quarter of last year.

Price-fixing against recent government orders, along with continued fixations against purchases of cotton by Spain, strengthened the cotton futures market in late dealings yesterday. The list of active contracts showed final net gains of 12 to 15 points, the highest closing levels in a week.
LONDON, May 18 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, May 18 -- By German order, at the instigation of Chief of Government Pierre Laval, several members of Marshal Henri Philippe Petain's entourage in Vichy have been relieved of their posts under the pretext that they were opposed to the regime.

Breaking with tradition, the Board of Education will issue high school diplomas to students who complete the four-year general course regardless of their ratings on the Regents examination, it was disclosed yesterday. In the past only those who had passing grades in the Regents tests received diplomas.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Navy communique 381:

" Flying Fortresses" -- and eventually planes of far larger size -- roaring above the cities and towns of Western Europe in greater and greater number will herald the eventual inevitable end -- even though that end may be delayed -- of Hitler's Reich.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 18 -- The latest methods of foods preservation and the technique of teaching them to other women is the two-fold purpose of a foods preservation school being attended by forty-seven lay leaders and home makers from all parts of the State today, tomorrow and Thursday at the College of Home Economics, Cornell University.

The Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad Company reported yesterday that the road's net income last year was $11,306,965 after taxes and charges, in contrast to a net deficit of $2,301,913 in 1941. Gross revenues were $54,475,495, compared with $31,572,624.

If complete government control of business is to be avoided in the post-war period, organized labor and industry will have to cooperate extensively to preserve small business, William Sheperdson, chief of the small business unit of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, declared last night at a meeting of the New York Credit Men's Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

An increasing shortage of paper later in the year was forecast yesterday at the wartime conference of the National Council of Industrial Editors Association at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. Efforts to curtail the consumption of paper were related by government speakers.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Representative Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, today proposed a national service teams' football championship for the 1943 season.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 18 -- A race between Christianity and communism to control the world after the war was forecast here today by the Rev. Dr. John Homer Miller, minister of the Hope Congregational Church at Springfied, Mass., in a keynote address at the 110th annual meeting of the New York Congregational Christian Conference.

LONDON, May 18 -- Fernand Grenier, former French Communist member of the Chamber of Deputies, who arrived here from France in January to join the forces of General Charles de Gaulle, said in an interview today that the French underground movement hopes to raise an army of 50,000 men for a nation-wide revolt against the man invaders to coincide with the Allied invasion of the European Continent.

Louis Schlefer, 49 years old, a lawyer, of 545 Fifth Avenue, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to seven and one-half to fifteen years in State prison on his recent conviction of defrauding an aged paralytic of $1,500. Schlefer told the victim, Moses Solomon, 74, of 145 Nagle Avenue, that the money was to be turned over to a mysterious income tax investigator.

This year's crop of carrots, at least from the important producing States of Arizona and California, is expected to be about twice as large as that of 1942, according to estimates made by the United States Department of Agriculture. As might be expected, shipments to the city have been sizable in recent months, with the result that the vegetable remains, at an average of 9 cents a bunch, one of the cheapest varieties available.

NEW DELHI, India, May 18 (AP) -- British troops made a successful commando-type raid on a jetty at the Japanese-occupied port of Maungdaw in Western Burma Sunday night and inflicted casualties on the enemy in fierce hand- to-hand fighting, a British communique announced today.

Work by Mrs. Irving T. Bush will be shown, beginning with an invitation preview this afternoon, in the Hotel Gotham branch of the Grand Central Galleries. Her exhibition opens to the public tomorrow and will continue through June 2.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 18 (AP) -- A British communique issued today told of attacks from Malta on shipping, railways and roads last night in Southern Italy, and the strafing of a tank-landing boat filled with troops at Augusta, in Eastern Sicily. Porto Empedocle, in Southern Sicily was pounded Monday night by naval squadrons that set fire to a power station and bombed a railway and near-by buildings.

Thousands of pedestrians were attracted yesterday by the display and sale of Spring flowers on the steps of St. Patrick's Cathedral, conducted under the auspices of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association for the promotion of its program "in the cause of a clean city."

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 18 -- The United Nations conference on food and agriculture, attended by representatives of forty-five nations, opened tonight with a message of welcome from President Roosevelt.

MONTREAL, May 18 (AP) -- Jack Graham's sixth-inning home run with two on broke up the ball game today as Montreal downed Newark, 7 to 4. Up to the time of Graham's pay-off wallop, it was a seesaw struggle. Each team used three pitchers.

Differences of opinion between Chief Magistrate Henry H. Curran and Magistrate J. Roland Sala, growing out of the latter's heavy fines against twenty-one motorists who parked last week near Belmont Park race track, flared up yesterday when Magistrate Sala assailed the chief magistrate's conduct as "discourteous and unethical."

In spite of the heavy demand for cotton for war purposes, the statistical position and the price of the staple are not much changed from a year ago. According to the New York Cotton Exchange, the stock of cotton in the United States at the end of April was 13,940,000 bales, compared with 13,911,000 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Senate Education and Labor Committee today approved the House-approved Bolton bill to provide more nurses by subsidizing their training in wartime. The committee added an amendment designed to protect the government from paying the hospitals' share of nurses' expenses.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The President presented the Congressional Medal of Honor to Captain Joseph Foss, Marine ace; held a press conference, and received a number of visitors, including Dr. T.V. Soong, Chinese Foreign Minister; Herbert H. Lehman, Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Director, and Daniel J. Tobin, president of the Teamsters Union.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- A French central authority at Algiers, from which General Henri Honore Giraud, as French Civil and Military Commander in Chief in North Africa, would be excluded, has been proposed by General Charles de Gaulle, Fighting French leader.

LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- The latest thing in American Red Cross millinery is appearing on London streets as the remainder of the second largest arrival here of Red Cross women workers from the United States checked in at headquarters.

The current motion picture "Mission to Moscow" has been the target of "a subversive influence" which is attempting to suppress it, Victor E. Devereaux, director of the National Department of Americanism of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, charged yesterday in criticizing "renegade Communists" and others who have expressed their opposition to the film.

LONDON, May 18 -- Discussing the British and American plans for post-war monetary stabilization, Lord Keynes, making his maiden speech in the House of Lords today, declared there was no foundation whatever for the belief held in some American quarters that the purpose of his proposals was to make the United States the "milch cow" of the world in general and of Great Britain in particular.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Food Administrator Chester Davis asked Congress today to continue the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation with an additional $1,000,000,000 borrowing power, amid indications of a brewing fight over the subsidy program.

Mayor La Guardia went on a potato hunt yesterday and succeeded in locating between 15,000 and 17,000 pounds stored in the back room of a barber shop on upper Sixth Avenue, opposite the Center Theatre, after he had become involved in a controversy with the Food Distribution Administration concerning the condition of another 438,000 pounds stored in Brooklyn for use of the Federal Government.

Despondent over low marks in school, 14-year-old Paulina Silva shot herself through the head with a .22 caliber rifle yesterday evening in her home at 31-44 Seventieth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. She was taken to St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, where she died at 8:30 o'clock.

Wendell L. Willkie was re-elected chairman of the board of directors and Spyros Skouras was reelected president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation at the organization meeting of the board following the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday threw a wrench into the machinery of the featherweight bout between Willie Pep and Sal Bartolo on June 8 in Boston by refusing to accord it championship recognition.

Allied preparations for an invasion of the European Continent make the Bank for International Settlements at Basle, Switzerland, look still more incongruous than it ever looked since the outbreak of the war in September, 1939. In the seclusion of a Swiss city American, German, French and Italian bankers, not to mention Belgian, Swedish, Swiss and Netherland representatives, are still at work side by side and attend to a common business.

LONDON, May 18 (U.P.) -- Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister, revealed in the House of Commons today that German and Italian casualties in almost three years of African fighting had been almost four times those of British and Empire forces.

On Monday Andrew Fleming West, Professor of Latin at Princeton for forty-five years, Dean of its Graduate School for seven years, was 90. No man among us has done more to keep alive the flame of classic studies; and he is as familiar with medieval as with Roman Latin. The Graduate School at Princeton is his child.

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced that the delivery of notices about mail district numbers had been started yesterday in nine of the districts of the New York postoffice. He said carriers had left 200,000 slips in letter boxes, business offices, apartment houses and hotels.

CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (U.P.) -- Heavy fighting is raging in the suburbs of the strategic Yangtze River port of Chihkiang in Central China where Chinese troops are battling to outflank a Japanese offensive in the bitterly contested Lake Tungting region, a communique reported today.

LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau took official cognizance today of the effects that British air attacks are having upon Germany, declaring that increasingly frequent raids on industrial centers are "causing the enemy considerable loss" and creating panic among the population.

Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, admitted yesterday under cross-examination before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury that as president he had taken no action on charges that some locals of the federation were dominated by Communists.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 18 -- Germans living outside the afflicted areas had yet to learn today details of the blasting of the key dams in the vulnerable Ruhr district by British air attack. In Berlin it was stated that military considerations made it imperative to avoid discussian of the scope of the Ruhr disaster.

ABOARD AN ESCORT CARPIER, At a Northern British Port (Delayed: via London, May 18) (U.P.) -- The Admiralty revealed to war correspondents today one of the outstanding contributions to the coming Allied victory in the Battle of the Atlantic -- the American-conceived escort aircraft carrier, as typified by H.M.S. Battler.

The infant mortality rate in New York City climbed last week to 39.9 per 1,000 live births, the highest rate for any week since April 17, 1942, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday. But despite the high birth rate, infant deaths for this year so far amount to only 30.9, compared with 31.5 at this time last year and 34.3 in 1941.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission has asked the Baltimore Ohio Railroad Company for further information regarding the $3,500,000 equipment trust certificates recently sold at 100 1/8 per cent of par to Halsey. Stuart Co. and associates, subject to Interstate Commerce Commission approval and which are now being offered to the public.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Mandatory grade labeling of this year's output of canned fruits and vegetables and their juices was eliminated today in a revision of the OPA's regulation governning the pricing and labeling of canned goods which it issued last January.

Consumers who pay less than $1 a pair for women's full-fashioned rayon stockings will have to pay an additional $16,000,000 yearly as a result of increases for unbranded hosiery permitted by the Office of Price Administration's regulation MPR 339, which became effective Saturday.

Five teams of policewomen and detectives operating under the direction of District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens visited yesterday several sections of Queens in search of violators of OPA ceiling prices.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House again defeated the Ruml plan today, voting 202 to 194 against instructing its conferees to accept the Senate pay-as-you-go bill which contains the Ruml proposal to abate a full year's tax liability as the quickest way to put the most taxpayers on a current basis.

Communist influence in the four city colleges is now extremely small, members of the Board of Higher Education declared yesterday, adding that the resolution adopted Monday by the board calling for an investigation of Communist activities on the campuses was to see if such radical organizations as did exist were adhering strictly to the rules and by-laws of the board and the colleges.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Roosevelt brushed aside today the press corps controversy over restrictions on the reporting of the United Nations food conference at Hot Springs, with the suggestion that reporters might like front-row seats at Cabinet meetings and secret conferences in his office.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA (AP) -- Eighteen members of two bomber crews who sank two large Japanese cargo ships and damaged a transport in Rabaul Harbor, New Britain, last Dec. 20, have received the Air Medal from Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney, commander of Allied Air Forces in the Southwest Pacific area, it was announced today.

Mme. Ivy Litvinoff, wife of Maxim Litvinoff, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, opened the exhibition "Five Hundred Years of Russian Art" for the benefit of Russian War Relief yesterday afternoon at the Gould House Galleries of Gimbel Brothers, 579 Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- An increase of 18 per cent in sales of independent retailers in April over April, 1942, was reported today by J.C. Capt, Director of the Census. April dollar sales were 7 per cent over those of the preceding month. These estimates are based upon reports from 14,655 independent stores in thirty-four States.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 18 -- A one-hit pitching effort by Rudy Imarata enabled Fordham to gain an easy 6-0 victory over Hofstra in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game today. The victory put the Rams ahead of the Flying Dutchmen into third place in the standings, with a record of 5 -- 4. Hofstra now has 5 -- 5.
The Reynolds Metals Company, in its annual statement for 1942, reports net sales of $86,068,181, an increase of 77 per cent over the $48,602,557 total for 1941.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, May 19 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The "rollbacks and squeezes" policy of the Office of Price Administration as an alternative to subsidies "will ruinously threaten food production and paralyze food processing and distribution," the National American Wholesale Grocers' Association asserted yesterday in a special bulletin to its members.

Maurice Holt, sales manager of the Triangle Appliance Corporation, which was alleged to have a virtual monopoly of stirrup pump sales under the war defense law passed by the City Council, was called yesterday as the State's principal witness at the opening of the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, a lawyer.

Householders who recently have converted from oil to coal burning heaters face a problem in obtaining fuel to fill their bins for the Winter, it was disclosed yesterday. Most dealers were said to desire to take care of old customers from present limited supplies before taking on new customers.

A new issue of $13,815,000 of refunding bonds was announced yesterday by the Imperial Irrigation District in California. The bonds, to be sold on June 31, will be dated June 21, 1943, and will mature on Jan. 1, 1983. The interest rate is to be named by the bidders and is not to exceed 3 1/2 per cent. The district, organized in 1911, is in Imperial County.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 18 -- French Army officers, often disguised in civilian clothes, outwitted the Axis armistice commissions in North Africa and hid at least one-third more arms and ammunition than authorized by the commission, it was disclosed tonight.

The Parents Magazine Medal, presented annually to the author of an outstanding book for parents, will be given to Mrs. Anna W.M. Wolf, author of "Our Children Face War," published by Houghton Mifflin, and Dr. Dorothy W. Baruch, author of "You, Your Children and the War," published by Appleton-Century, at a luncheon today at the Roosevelt Hotel.

BOSTON, May 18 -- In a statement released here today Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Committee on Small Business, currently engaged in an investigation of the Office of Price Administration, charged that the OPA "has evaded and circumvented" what he characterized as a "direct mandate that the powers of that agency shall not be used to compel changes in the practices of business in any industry."

RICHMOND, Va., May 18 (AP) -- Railroads in the United States are hauling 150 per cent more passengers than they were a year ago and the peak will not be reached until midsummer, Ernest E. Norris, president of the Southern Railway Company, told stockholders at their annual meeting today.

Large-scale campaigns in newspapers on straw hats for men are due to start breaking on Friday, according to retail executives yesterday. The hot spell of the last two days caught stores unprepared and few of them have their windows trimmed as yet, but unless there is an adverse break in the weather before Friday, retail copy will appear on that day.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Opening its hearings on alleged departures by government officials from the intents of Congress in administering laws and regulations, the Special House (Smith) Investigating Committee heard charges today from the National Association of Real Estate Boards that the Office of Price Administration had operated widely beyond statutory prescription.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 18 (U.P.) -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower, Allied Commander in Chief in North Africa, revealed tonight that Axis prisoners in Tunisia totaled "well over 200,000."

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Wednesday, May 19 (U.P.) -- Japanese planes raided Allied positions at Wau, thirty miles south of Salamaua in the Huon Gulf battle area of the New Guinea coast yesterday for the third time in four days, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique disclosed today.

Asserting that the elimination of mass unemployment was the "first requirement" of the post-war Period, Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, proposed yesterday a reorganization of the Federal fiscal and monetary policy to complement and supplement the activities of private enterprise in the maintenance of "high production and high employment."

A reduction of from 10 to 12 per cent in outstanding B and C gasoline ration books in the seventeen Eastern States and "substantially more than 12 per cent" in T books allotted to fleet truck operators in the area was forecast yesterday by Charles Phillips, director of the automotive supply rationing division of the Office of Price Administration, here to line up local boards in an intensified review of these ration books.

A general boycott by all organized labor groups of food dealers charging above ceiling prices was urged yesterday by the Joint Board of Hotel and Restaurant Workers, American Federation of Labor, in an appeal to its 50,000 members in this city to take a "holiday" in buying at present abnormal prices as the most effective instrument for smashing the black market.
The German Tuesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Leading representatives of the nation's food industry warned yesterday that legitimate distribution of food throughout the country was threatened with "complete demoralization," if not by "annihilation," as a result of the Office of Price Administration's new community dollars-and-cents ceilings and roll-back of prices.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 19 -- The Royal Air Force hammered German airfields in Northern France yesterday while the deadly new American Thunderbolts battled enemy fighters over occupied Belgium, carrying the furious Allied air offensive through its sixth successive day.

The Chungking radio, in a broadcast to North America, recorded yesterday by the Federal Communications Commission and reported to the Office of War Information, told of the organization of the Association of Foreign Correspondents in China with Brooks Atkinson of THE NEW YORK TIMES as its first president.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 18 -- Following discussion of possible Swedish participation in the liberation of Norway, the Germans have recently mined all the bridges along the Swedish border. This is only one of many measures taken in Norway in preparation for the expected invasion.

Citizens of this city have before them the challenge of fighting for an "independent, resolute Board of Education," Mrs. Sam A. Lewisohn, director of the Public Education Association, declared yesterday in presenting her report at the annual meeting of the association, held at the Hotel Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a deficiency appropriation bill of $134,000,000, with two amendments. One, by a vote of 155 to 101, prohibited the President from using any part of any war emergency funds, of which about $89,000,000 were carried in the measure, to support the Farm Security Administration or the National Resources Planning Board.

The National Power and Light Company, undergoing dissolution in compliance with the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, is finding compliance with the act a "difficult process" from the point of view of preservation of values, P.B. Sawyer, president, declared yesterday in his 1942 report to stockholders.

A nation-wide series of track meets is being arranged for Gunder Haegg, invading Swedish record-breaker, with tentative events already planned for Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Boston, Cleveland and Pittsburgh, it was disclosed yesterday, according to The United Press.

The Tokyo radio yesterday said that the United States was "continually" landing reinforcements on Attu after a Tokyo broadcast to Japanese areas had suggested that Attu might become another Guadalcanal, with the Japanese fighting "to the last man."

Former Magistrate Jeanette G. Brill, named to a $3,500-a-year post as assistant corporation counsel last Friday, will qualify for a pension in thirty days, it was learned yesterday after Mayor La Guardia had confirmed the fact of her appointment.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 18 (AP) -- A plan for the "lending" of industrial workers to farmers to relieve a "desperate" regional planting crisis met today with a favorable action from the Syracuse Manufacturers Association and possibly will receive State-wide application.

SEVENTH ARMY AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Hickham Field, Hawaii, May 17 (Delayed) -- United States Army Liberator bombers did "considerable damage" in an attack on Wake Island Saturday, May 15 (United States time), and shot down two and possibly three of twenty-two Japanese Zero fighter planes, Colonel Clarence F. Hegy, 36, of Hartford, Wis., said here tonight.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Rialto the attraction will be "The Leopard Man," an RKO horror drama featuring Dennis O'Keefe and Margo, with supporting roles played by Jean Brooks, Isabel Jewel and James Bell. . . .

DETROIT, May 18 -- The weather bugaboo which has dogged the footsteps of the Yankees since their first swing through the West started, presented itself again today to keep the champions and Tigers idle.

AT A NEW GUINEA BASE, May 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- On armed reconnaissance today over Gas-mata, New Britain, Lieutenant William Crawford Jr. of Niles, Ohio, spotted six enemy planes sitting on the airdrome -- and gave them top priority on his bomb load.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP) -- The Phillies climbed into a tie with Cincinnati for fourth place in the National League by coming from behind to beat the Cubs, 5 to 4, before 20,820 fans at Shibe Park tonight. It was the third straight victory for the Phils and the seventh straight loss for Chicago.

American drug exports in the post-war period will be affected by the trend toward localized industry in Latin America and parts of the British Empire, T.W. Delehanty, chief of the drugs and pharmaceuticals unit of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, said yesterday.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 16 (Delayed) -- Wise and cruel Amir Abdur Rahman, who ruled this country in the last two decades of the nineteenth century, wrote in his autobiography: "This poo goat, Afghanistan, is a victim at which a lion on one side and a terrible bear from the other side are staring and ready to swallow at he first opportunity afforded to them."

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- American troops fighting on Attu Island are closing a pincers on the Japanese between Holtz Bay and Massacre Bay and, despite "stubborn enemy resistance from numerous machine-gun nests," have captured an important rocky ridge on which the enemy gunners were entrenched, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, announced today.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, May 18 (AP) -- The initiative of a courageous young Iowa marine sergeant, whose leg was severed below the knee as he bailed out of his dive-bomber, may lead to flight training for rear-seat men in Navy planes -- a training program designed to save combat aircraft and the lives of wounded pilots.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 18 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's letter, read to the United Nations Food Conference tonight by Judge Marvin Jones, chairman of the American delegation:

General Enrique Penaranda, President of Bolivia, visited Fordham University yesterday and received the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws. It was conferred by Mgr. Joseph P. Donahue, vicar general of the Archdiocese of New York, in the absence of Archbishop Francis J. Spellman.
NEW DELHI, India, May 18 (AP) -- A communique:

" Uncle Harry," the Thomas Job mystery melodrama, will end its first year on Broadway tonight. Since the opening last May 20 there has been but one minor change in the cast, which is headed by Eva Le Gallienne and Joseph Schildkrauh.

Mrs. Anna H. Paton, widow of Morton S. Paton, attorney, whose will was contested because of her bequests to the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, left an estate of $1,089,827 net, according to the estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Roosevelt said today he probably would appoint a committee of three to consider problems of carrying on organized sports in wartime and make recommendations to him.

The thing has been said before, but there is no harm in saying it again. History does have its lessons after all, except that the process works the other way about. We rarely learn from the past how to deal with the present, but we often find the present a great help in clarifying the past.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- In a new challenge to the Price Administration, the Senate Agriculture Committee approved today a bill to fix a floor of 23 1/2 cents a pound on government-held cotton while prohibiting any ceilings on this commodity at below 25 cents.

The Delia Austrian Medal given annually by the Drama League of New York for the best performance of the season was awarded yesterday to Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne for their work in S.N. Behrman's "The Pirate." In the absence of the winners, who were unable to attend, Theresa Helburn received the medal from Judith Evelyn at a luncheon held in the ballroom of the Hotel Pierre.

First Grade Detective Charles A. Barts of the Harlem District was arrested in Newark yesterday on charges of extortion and receiving stolen money. Bail of $2,500 was set on each of the charges by Justice of the Peace Samuel Verniero in Newark and, lacking bail, the detective was sent to the local jail.

Guided by stronger leadership from the industrials, the stock market made a substantial upturn yesterday to within striking distance of the highs of the recent bullish movement. A return of activity to key issues and a lessening of business among the "dollar" stocks attracted sufficient buying to push values forward on an average of a point.

Hearings on legislation to repeal sixty-one-year-old discriminations against the Chinese are announced to open in Washington today before the House Immigration and Naturalization Committee. What is asked by friends of the Chinese is more than reasonable. It is simply the repeal of long-standing laws specifically prohibiting Chinese immigration and singling out the Chinese as ineligible for citizenship.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- President Roosevelt pointedly rejected today the advice of Senator Albert B. Chandler, Kentucky Democrat, that the United States change its war strategy and insist upon the defeat of Japan before disposing of Germany.

The President's eleventh-hour letter to Senator George and Representative Doughton had its desired effect. Enough votes were apparently influenced by the belief that the President would veto the Senate bill to cause the House to reject the full pay-as-you-go plan. The whole question of wartime taxation is once more thrown into uncertainty.

Aany luncheon parties were given yesterday at the formal opening for this season of the outdoor Garden of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Robert Aorris Pbi]lips had as i her guests lVLrs. Wright Barclay, Airs. Ambrose N. DieD] of Pittsburgh and San Francisco, 1Vrs !Gustave Porges, ATrs. Charles H. Goddard, Mrs. Theodore Schu-! reacher, Lady Aiontague and A_rs. Imre de Josika Herczeg.

On a hot Spring afternoon it is pleasant to recall the cool-looking garments designed for just such days that Saks Fifth Avenue assembled for a Summer showing of play clothes yesterday morning. A white seersucker suit made of men's suiting with squared shoulders and flap pockets, worn with a big hat trimmed with mint green and white striped chintz ruffling the upper edge of its shade-giving brim, was especially cooling to remember.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your Stockholm correspondent, George Axelsson, certainly misreads Norwegian ideas when he, in his telegram in your edition of May 2, ventures to state that, after this war, Norwegians will be glad to have Sweden say the decisive words about their alliances, and that they would be willing to enter a union with Sweden with the first, last and perpetual aim of forming a bulwark against Russian aggression.

The charge by James G. Donovan, head of the committee seeking the ouster of Michael J. Kennedy as leader of Tammany Hall, that Tammany and the left wing of the American Labor party had made a political deal last Fall produced two opposite reactions from the groups concerned yesterday.

After an ownership of three weeks the thirteen-story apartment house with stores at 174-76 West Eighty-seventh Street, southeast corner of Amsterdam Avenue, has been sold by a client of O'Connell Butler, attorneys, to a client of Newman Bisco, attorneys.

A new challenger moved forward yesterday at Belmont Park for consideration as a front-rank steeplechaser when M.A. Cushman's Rouge Dragon captured the twenty-second running of the Charles L. Appleton Memorial Steeplechase, which had a value to the winner of $2,870 in addition to the handsome trophy presented by Mrs. Payne Whitney.
An audience of 17,500, including many service men of the United Nations, thronged Madison Square Garden last night for a benefit in behalf of Greek war relief.

OTTAWA, May 18 (AP) -- New selective service regulations aimed at combing all coal miners out of other employment and putting them back into the production of fuel were announced today in the House of Commons by Labor Minister Humphrey Mitchell.

ALBANY, May 18 -- Democratic participation in the formulation of State policy was further reduced today when Governor Dewey announced ten appointments to legislative commissions, all to succeed members named by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Wake Island, where a gallant little band of Marine defenders finally was overwhelmed on Dec. 24, 1941, after resisting the Japanese for fourteen days, was attacked four days ago by Army heavy bombers, a Navy communique disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- For attempting to save fifteen men adrift on a raft under enemy shell fire by swimming and towing the raft out of danger, Charles Jackson French, a Negro mess attendant, has been commended by Admiral William F. Halsey Jr., Commander in the South Pacific.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- All contracts in corn futures for delivery in May, July and September, 1943, which are outstanding and mature during the last seven business days of each of the three delivery months, may be settled hereafter either by the delivery of cash corn or at a settlement price of $1.07 a bushel.
LONDON, May 18 (AP) -- A joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 18 -- British Wellingtons pounded the airfield and port of Alghero, in Western Sardinia, last night in another of the series of short, fierce raids against Italian strongholds in the Mediterranean.
LONDON, May 18 -- Stock market conditions today again were quiet, with gilt edge issues recording losses from a sixteenth to an eighth.

LONDON, May 18 -- Down the valleys of the Ruhr and Weser today swept pent-up waters released by Royal Air Force mines that over Sunday night breached the Moehne and Sorpe and the Eder dams in the heart of industrial Germany.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,814, which compared with 1,724 in the preceding week and 594 in the like period of last year, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The twenty-eight-family apartment house on a plot 50 by 137 feet at 116-18 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was sold by the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company, in liquidation, to Meyer Cohen of Baltimore. This structure is assessed for $63,200 and was sold for $52,000.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 18 -- While the race for the Republican Presidential nomination gives evidence of being a sharp and lively contest, with no one candidate favored by a clear majority of the rank and file at the present time, the situation within the Democratic party is remarkably different.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) -- Paul E. Hadlick, counsel for the Senate Agriculture subcommittee investigating the alcohol and synthetic rubber program, announced today his resignation, effective June 1, asserting that accomplishments of the inquiry have reached the point where "I feel my services no longer are needed."

Mayor La Guardia's $753,071,123 executive budget "can and will be cut," leaders of the Democratic majority in the City Council declared yesterday in ruling out the possibility that the Council would ask Governor Thomas E. Dewey to call a special session of the State Legislature to consider city finances.
James Salmon of Xavier won the twenty-eighth tennis tournament of the Athletic Association of Private Schools at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, yesterday.

Since July of last year subcontracting of war contracts by large manufacturers to smaller independent plants has reached "tremendous proportions," George A. Sloan, chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, reported yesterday.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 19 (U.P.) -- Forty-nine German defense positions have been knocked out by Russian guns in a day of heavy artillery activity on the Leningrad front, the midnight Soviet communique reported today, and four German planes attempting to reconnoitre Russian positions have been shot down.

Committee members arranging the cocktail party and dance to be given tomorrow afternoon on the Pierre Roof in aid of the Generosity Thrift Shop were qlests yesterday afternoon at a tea given in the foyer of the Cotillion Room of the hotel by Airs. Arthur C. Patterson, vice president of the thrift mart.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who has been appointed head of a special committee of the New York Dress Institute to plan the future of the women's clothing industry in this city after the war, said yesterday he would name the other members of his committee about June 1.

Since July of last year subcontracting of war contracts by large manufacturers to smaller independent plants has reached "tremendous proportions," George A. Sloan, chairman of the Mayor's Business Advisory Committee, reported yesterday.

Yesterday the Museum of the City of New York, that thoughtful provider of public pleasure, opened its show of old playthings. Those of us who remember engravings of Dolls' Houses of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, with their charming display of antique diminutive furniture, will be eager to visit The Old Toy Shop.

Voodoo music, Harlem "blues" and the harmonica found their way into Town Hall last night in "An Evening of Music" intended to show the influence of popular or folk music on "art" music. The unusual entertainment was presented by The Little Red School House to raise funds for needed scientific equipment and to aid the Elisabeth Irwin High School.

Hitting and running once more in their 1942 form, the Cardinals yesterday trampled the Dodgers, 7 -- 1, and cut the Brooklyn first place lead to two and one-half games. The Braves, however, are in second place, half a length in front of the Redbirds.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 18 -- Veering around from its bombastic claims of the past few days that "invasion is impossible," the Italian press, led by Virginio Gayda, adopted today a "realistic" view of the situation in examining Italy's international situation.

CHICAGO, May 18 -- Montgomery, Ward Co. today reported net earnings were $3,588,554 for the three months ended April 30, the first quarter of its fiscal year, and restated its profit for the corresponding quarter of 1942 in a reallocation of provisions for Federal taxes as finally enacted for last year.

In order to save valuable time after the war that would otherwise be wasted in nonproductive effort, the machine tool industry should be encouraged to begin reconversion for post-war products a year or more before the war ends, Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, declared yesterday at the meeting of the Textile Distributors Institute in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, May 18 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin said today that the Japanese, again ignoring the rules of civilized warfare, torpedoed the Australian hospital skip Centaur last Friday despite the fact that Australia informed all Axis powers in February that the vessel was to be used for that purpose.

For three hours on Monday the Senate listened to a debate on the grand strategy of the war in which Senator Chandler of Kentucky spoke for a sharp reversal of present plans and a shift of the main emphasis of the American effort from Europe to the Pacific. The arguments he made have been used by many others who favor the same move.

CLEVELAND, May 18 (AP) -- The Chesapeake Ohio Railway's net income for April was $2,681,789, or 34 cents a share, against $1,996,132, or 25 cents a share in the same month of 1942. Gross income was $17,405,983, against $15,318,455, and net income for the first four months has climbed to $10,408,919, or $1.33 a share, from $7,809,295, or 99 cents a share in the same period of last year.
CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Magistrate Abner C. Surpless refused yesterday in Flatbush Court in Brooklyn to compel Gaston Koch of 1430 Ocean Avenue, a deputy sector commander in the air warden service in the Parkville precinct, to give up his air warden credentials and equipment.

In the face of growing reports in film trade circles that the public is becoming bored with war pictures, Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., yesterday urged the nation's theatre owners not to be "intimidated or coerced" into not showing films treating with the war by "persons who are not wholeheartedly behind our war effort" or who are trying "to keep the truth from your audiences."

WASHINGTON, May 18 -- Secretary Ickes, as Solid Fuels Coordinator for War, told John L. Lewis today that he had no power to negotiate a contract with the United Mine Workers of America, nor to institute collective bargaining negotiations between miners and operators.

The Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York in the first year of its existence carried out important investigations in the fields of influenza, whooping, cough, nutrition, venereal disease, blood transfusion, rabies and research of a confidential nature that will save lives on the battlefield and at home in case of emergency, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, City Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday to Mayor La Guardia.

WHEN is a triple play not a triple play? Here's what happened. The Reds had two men on base with none out when the batter hit the ball. Before another pitch was delivered the side had been retired, but it was officially ruled a double play, although three outs were made. This is not quite as silly as it sounds, either.

LONDON, May 18 -- The first major athletic event with a genuine Olympic touch since United Nations officials here projected an informal Olympic program to last all year will be held on June 10 when British and American Army boxers meet in Albert Hall.

CHUNGKING, China, May 18 (AP) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek praised the Christian church and its missionaries in China today and said that the "abolition of unequal treaties had freed the Christian church from all association with foreign imperialism or aggression."

As the result of a survey of twenty-five war plants, the National Association of Manufacturers reported yesterday that absenteeism in industry had gone up 56 per cent, or from an average of 3.48 per cent of workers absent every day before the War, to 5.42 per cent at present.

The board of directors of the National Public Housing Conference issued a statement yesterday following its semi-annual meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania endorsing President Roosevelt's request for an additional $400,000,000 to house 1,100,000 migrant war workers.

In baseball circles, a rock is a high-sounding term for a bonehead play. Every once in a while the best of them are guilty and yesterday, at the Polo Grounds, the party of the first part was Bill Jurges, captain and sparkplug of the Giants.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 18 -- A Social Democratic campaign in Finland to remove the party leader, V.A. Tanner, from the Cabinet and from his party post appears to be under way, according to information from Helsinki.

An evening of music largely in three-quarter time, music of Vienna of the nineteenth century and of the twentieth before Hitler, was presented at Carnegie Hall last night. Robert Stolz, himself a composer and conductor of Vienna, directed sixty-five members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphonic in a program that was called a "gala festival of Viennese music."

One of the worst floods in a decade rolled southward through Illinois and Indiana last night, according to a United Press survey, leaving millions of dollars damage in its wake as waters of a half-dozen rivers spread over half-grown crops.

TORONTO, May 19 (Canadian Press) -- Nick Strincevich racked up his fifth straight pitching victory for the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight by turning back Jersey City, 6 -- 3, in the floodlight part of a twilight-night double-header after the Little Giants had taken the seven-inning curtain raiser by the same score.

The relation of religion and democracy was discussed yesterday by Dr. Everett R. Clinchy, president of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, and Rabbi William F. Rosenblum of Temple Israel at a forum of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations in the community house of Congregation Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

A six-story loft building and two connecting nine-story loft buildings at 1 to 11 West Fourth Street have been sold by the Manhattan Savings Bank to Aaron Kahan. They occupy the blockfront on the north side of the street, from Broadway to Mercer Street and were sold for cash over a purchase money mortgage.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 19 -- Total war became total destruction for the Axis armies in Tunisia, where they suffered approximately 324,000 casualties, according to figures released today by Allied Headquarters.

New York district and county gasoline rationing officials, expressing the belief that there had been little chiseling in the obtaining of supplemental rations, indicated yesterday that C-book holders would be the first to feel the pinch in the general tightening up ordered by Washington officials of the Office of Price Administration.
