KABUL, Afghanistan, May 12 (Delayed) -- Fate and geography have linked the destinies of Afghanistan and India so closely that neither Britain nor the United Nations can think of a peace settlement in the Middle East without taking Kabul into account. The racial, social and economic ties are such that anything that happens in India reacts sympathetically in Afghanistan.

Warning of a condition which would seriously hamper the cotton textile industrials war effort, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants, yesterday flatly contradicted statements made before the Senate Agriculture Committee on Tuesday to the effect that materially higher raw cotton prices without proportionate increases in present OPA ceilings on cotton fabrics would leave "a fair margin of profit" for cotton textile producers.

TRENTON, May 19 -- Governo Charles Edison announced today he had ordered investigations of the State Civil Service Commission, the State Board of Shell Fisheries and the office of the Hudson County Superintendent of Election headed by William E. Sewell.
BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- The unconditional release of Vernon (Lefty) Gomez by the Braves tonight reduced the roster to twenty-six players, one above tomorrow's major league limit.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Congress received Prime Minister Churchill's address today with general, unstinted acclaim and found it "encouraging" and reassuring," particularly the Prime Minister's pledge that Britain would fight to the end for the defeat of Japan.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- An order banning all pleasure driving in twelve Eastern States, including New York, where an acute gasoline shortage exists, was completed by the Office of Price Administration tonight and will be put into force tomorrow.

Earnings of the Consolidated Oil Corporation this year have been running at about the same rate as in the corresponding period of 1942, H.F. Sinclair, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday. For the first six months of 1942 the company had reported after charges, taxes and reserves a net income of $8,423,448, equal to 65 cents a share on the capital stock.

The hopes Warren Wright once had that his flashing Nellie Flag would win the Kentucky Derby were doomed to disappointment, but that mare's daughter, Nellie L., captured one of the most desirable filly fixtures on the calendar at Belmont Park yesterday.

One of the newest of the towering buildings in the financial district figured in the realty activity yesterday when it was announced that the City Investing Company, Robert W. Dowling, president, has purchased the Continental Bank Building, a forty-eight-story skyscraper at 30 Broad Street.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- Russian guns were reported today to be laying down a heavy barrage in the Sievsk sector, between Kursk and Orel, while other reports from various parts of the front pointed to intensive preparations for battle.

Mrs. Carol Sierck, in 47 E 64th St through Samuel A. Herzog. Alan Jay Lerner, in 205 E 78th St through Pease Elliman; James Fonda, in 425 E 51st St through Braislin, Porter Baldwin -- Warren Marks Associates, brokers.

LONDON, May 19 -- The restoration of normal relations between Russia and the Polish Government in Exile remains one of the outstanding diplomatic problems confronting the British and American governments.

Vice President Wallace said in the course of his American Day speech in Central Park that here in the United States we have no monopoly on the name American. Obviously. He went on to say: "I have just come back from visiting Americans in seven different countries -- in Costa Rica, Panama, Chile, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador and Colombia.

George B. Salisbury gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois. His guests included Mrs. William K. Grimm, Miss Vivian Thorbecker and Cadet Willem K. Thorbecker of the Royal Netherlands Air Force. Another party at La Salle du Bois was given by Mrs. Frederick E. Greene of Westport, Conn., for Mrs. William Mills of Stamford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The questions regarding the terms of Italy's surrender, which were raised for the first time by writers in the Italian press yesterday, were regarded here today as significant of the growing realization by Italians of the doom facing their country and its regime, but not as signs of an immediate collapse of Italian resistance.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Congressional tax conferees will hold their first meeting tomorrow in a race against time to agree upon a compromise acceptable to the President. Final action deferred beyond the end of next week would probably make setting up the withholding system impossible by the proposed date, July 1, in the opinion of Senator George, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

The dividing of responsibility between Albany and City Hall constitutes a threat to government, City Council President Newbold Morris told the annual convention of the New York City League of Women Voters yesterday at the New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

Asserting that if "creative capitalism" does not solve the problem of mass unemployment after the war, "the governments of the world will do it for us extravagantly," Eric A. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, told members of the Bond Club of New York at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Bankers Club that he believes the answer lies in expanding many old industries and in developing new ones.

City College teachers have agreed to a plan under which 128 members of the faculties of the Schools of Liberal Arts, Business and Education will teach throughout the Summer without receiving additional pay, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Noble Wright, president of the college.

Wispy columbines mingled with stately tulips of varied hues, standing row upon row like proud soldiers on parade, at a special one-day Spring flower show yesterday in the headquarters of the Horticultural Society of New York, 598 Madison Avenue.

Consolidated net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on March 31 amounted to $9,085,359 after taxes and all charges but before depletion of metal mines, according to the preliminary statement issued yesterday.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- Describing himself as "only a messenger boy," former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies arrived at the Moscow airport this afternoon and was met in a swirl of Soviet and United States flags by Soviet Foreign Office officials and William H. Standley, the United States Ambassador, and members of his staff.
Referring to the editorial "Apple Blossoms" in THE TIMES of May 16, it is true that Johnny Appleseed had a good idea, but he lacked knowledge. Hence, in my youth, he was damned by many farmers.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (AP) -- With 10,000 persons homeless and uncounted crop and property damage, Indiana struggled tonight against widening flood waters as turbulent streams threatened additional levees.

LONDON, May 19 -- The tone of the stock market today was cheerful but business was small with a further recovery in diamonds the outstanding interest. Consolidated rose 1 1/8 to 35 5/8 shillings, Anglo-American Investment 1 1/4 to 61 1/4 shillings and De Beers deferred 1/8 to 19.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- A tight ring of armed guards was stationed around the Capitol for Prime Minister Churchill's visit. Helmeted troops, armed with rifles, were posted at twenty-foot intervals to form an outer circle, while others did sentinel duty at the entrances. District of Columbia and Capitol policemen, along with a big detail of secret service men, augmented the soldier guard.

"Books Across the Sea" will give its third informal book-reception in the members' lounge of the English Speaking Union, 30 Rockefeller Plaza, this evening at 8:15. Guests of honor will be Walter Harrap, G. Wren Howard and Geoffrey Faber, visiting British publishers here under the auspices of the Book Publishers Bureau.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to keep the National Resources Planning Board alive, but on a highly restricted basis. At the same time it acted to permit the Home Owners Loan Corporation to be liquidated gradually, instead of during the coming fiscal year and in what das described as "an orderly manner."
LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by The Associated Press:

With a brilliance and an eloquence characteristic of his greatest moments, Prime Minister Churchill laid before the Congress of the United States yesterday a balanced account of the war which was full of pride of achievement, but which also contained a solemn warning and an equally solemn pledge.

Professor Oscar R. Lange of the University of Chicago announced yesterday that he was withdrawing as a speaker at an Allied Unity Rally in Carnegie Hall tonight because efforts had been made to represent the meeting as "an attack upon the memory" of Henryk Ehrlich and Victor Alter, Polish labor leaders executed by the Soviet Government.
A fly-tyer is usually a calm, cool and reserved person. Jim Deren falls into that category in the best manner of his profession.

The purchase by Jack Dempsey's Restaurant Corporation of the Hotel Great Northern, a twelve-story building containing 400 rooms at 118 West Fifty-seventh Street through to 109-21 West Fifty-sixth Street, was announced yesterday.
Leases of loft space in buildings in the city were announced yesterday by renting agents.

In addition to devoting more consumer ads to post-war planning and products, manufacturers are now beginning to aim their trade advertising in this direction, with emphasis on distribution, according to agency men. For instance, one radio company, which is preparing to add a line of electrical appliances, has started a series in trade papers, pointing out to dealers that it will go in for selective distribution in the post-war period.

The recent report of the National Resources Planning Board "gives lip service to private enterprise, but the measures they propose would bring it to an untimely end," Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared last night at a dinner of the National Society of the Sons of the American Revolution at the Hotel Plaza.

One of the latest intended victims of the new Congressional device of attaching attainder clauses to appropriation bills is Dr. Robert Morss Lovett, secretary of the Virgin Islands government. Dr. Lovett is a distinguished teacher, author and critic, serving his country in a tough job at the age of 72.

An exhibition of building materials each afternoon through May 24 from 2 to 4 P.M. in Room 1415 of the Municipal Building, under the direction of Major Irving V.A. Huie, Public Works Commissioner, is offered as an aid to architects, engineers and contractors serving the city and planning post-war public and private building activity.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, May 8 (AP by Mail) -- News censorship has erupted in neighboring Argentina in acute form. Like most censorships, the Argentine variety is baffling to those compelled to deal with it.

The assumption that the United States should undertake the re-education of Germany after a United Nations victory was branded last night as "childish arrogance," by Dr. Alexander Meiklejohn, retiring president of the American Association for Adult Education.

ALBANY, May 19 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of C. Chester Dumond, Ulster County fruit farmer, as State Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets to succeed Holton V. Noyes, Democrat, who has occupied the office since 1938.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 19 -- The Norwegian amnesty of May 17, announced by Nazi puppet Premier Vidkun Quisling, has been of a wider extent than at first presumed, and so far 142 persons have been released from Grini, according to a report tonight from the S.T.B. news agency.

A new issue of $3,100,00 of secured 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund bonds, of Mercantile Properties, Inc., due May 1, 1963, will be offered today at 100 and accrued interest. The offering group is headed by Laird, Bissell Meeds and Spencer Trask Co.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 19 -- Strong forces of American bombers swept across the Mediterranean narrows yesterday to hammer the Axis at Pantelleria and at Trapani in Sicily. In the thunderous resumption of the daylight offensive almost 100 tons of bombs were dropped on Pantelleria, and Flying Fortresses inflicted extensive damage on the port of Trapani.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- Navy communique 383:

NEWARK, N.J., May 19 (AP) -- Counsel for an indicted meat-packing firm, in a brief asking dismissal of the indictment, told Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney today that pressure from the farm block up familiarity with the meat industry or sheer incompetence prevented the Office of Price Administration from eliminating a black market in meat.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The results of the recent Anglo-American exploratory conference on refugees at Bermuda were described in a general way by the State Department today which announced that the delegates had now terminated their discussions and had submitted a joint report to their governments which were now engaged in carrying out the recommendations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP) -- The armed services beckoned to big Babe Dahlgren today. The 30-year-old shortstop-first baseman, who is married, has a 6-month-old child, and is one of the best reasons why the Phillies are looking like a ball club, took a preliminary physical examination on the order of his San Francisco draft board and the induction move started new talk of player deals and sighs of "Jinx!"

The audience at Carnegie Hall last night for Alejandro Vilalta's recital of Spanish piano music, although not small, was by no means as large as it should have been. For Mr. Vilalta made of this concert, "in homage to Enrique Granados," one of the really top-flight musical treats of the season.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Forward units of American forces advancing from Massacre Bay and Holtz Bay on Attu Island have closed their pincers on the Japanese and the enemy now is withdrawing into a pocket at Chichagof Harbor, from which, authorities predicted today, there can be only surrender or annihilation.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 19 -Fascist organizations and the Italian police during the past few days have intensified their measures against "certain elements considered lacking in the dignity of the Italian nation," according to a semi-official reports received here today.
Two records were set at the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. There were four special offerings, the largest number ever completed in a single day.

Extension of specific dollar and cents maximum prices for drug and cosmetic products within the next few months was predicted yesterday by Robert Deupree of the drug, cosmetics and soap section of the Office of Price Administration. Mr. Deupree was a speaker at the annual convention of the Proprietary Association of America at the Hotel Biltmore.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- After meeting the heaviest tax bill in history, individuals in the United States in the first quarter of the year still were able to add $4,300,000,000 to their cash on hand and checking accounts, or more than eight times the amount of such savings during the comparable period of last year, it was disclosed today in a quarterly analysis prepared by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Some years ago I was able to ask readers who were closing their houses or apartments for the Summer to send any unwanted books and magazines to the Hospital Reading Society, 105 East Twenty-second Street, where they would be sorted and distributed among local hospitals and prisons and needy schools in the South.

When the war is over British Overseas Airways and the national airlines of the other United Nations should each be permitted to obtain from the United States, on equitable terms, all the ocean transport planes they will need to restore the balance for fair competition, Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, urged last night.

LINDEN, N.J., May 19 -- A water shortage, resulting from a break in a main of the Elizabethtown Water Company at Bound Brook, caused a suspension of work this afternoon at the Eastern Aircraft plant of General Motors Corporation here.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The United Mine Workers of America has applied for reaffiliation with the American Federation of Labor five years after it was expelled, William Green, president of the federation, announced today.

Two brothers on trial in Bronx County Court with six other youths charged with the rape of a 17-year- old girl in the Bronx Opera House on March 11 pleaded guilty yesterday to rape in the first degree after Assistant District Attorney Lawrence Peltin had blasted their alibi and had proved that five alibi witnesses, including the boys' father, had committed perjury.

The directors of the American Telephone Telegraph Company authorized at a meeting held yesterday, the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share on the common stock, continuing the rate that has been in effect since 1922. More than 635,000 stockholders will receive some $42,000,000 by the payment on July 15 to holders of record of June 15.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, May 20 (U.P.) -- Long-range Allied bombers destroyed or damaged nine enemy aircraft yesterday at the Penfui airdrome at Kupang in Netherland Timor. In this and other operations they ran their toll of enemy aircraft for the week to at least sixty-two, it was disclosed today.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., May 19 (AP) -- Sales of the F.W. Woolworth Company for 1942, reported at the annual stockholders' meeting today, were a record $423,220,598, compared with $377,148,059 in 1941. Last year's net income was $23,538,739, equivalent to $2.43 each on 9,703,608 shares of capital stock, of which there is only one class.

JOHNSTOWN, Pa., May 19 (AP) -- Organizers of the United Mine Workers were directed tonight to halt a spreading walkout of miners in Central Pennsylvania, as three more mines were shut down, bringing to more than 4,000 the number out.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- A wage contract which has two more years to run barred New York motion picture operators today from the benefits of the War Labor Board's "Little Steel" formula.

LONDON, May 19 -- To provoke the Germans to further bloody reprisals against the Serbs, bodies of German soldiers killed in fighting against Yugoslav patriots are being mutilated by Bulgarians, who also attach to the bodies the Chetniks' motto, "Freedom or death," according to reports reaching Yugoslav circles in London.

Zinaida Alvers, Russian mezzo-soprano, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. The program, which began with early Italian classics by Caldara and Vivaldi, contained a group of German lieder by Wolf, but otherwise was devoted to Russian items by Mussorgsky, Taneieff, Borodin, Rimsky-Korsakoff, Rachmaninoff and Strimer.
Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's address to Congress as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LONDON, Thursday, May 20 -- Newly reinforced American Flying Fortress units smashed through a heavy German fighter screen yesterday to set consuming fires in the Kiel and Flensburg submarine yards in Northwestern Germany. Flying 1,000 miles unescorted, the big bombers knocked down many of the challenging fighters during a two-hour running battle, from which six bombers failed to return.

Annual reports as of Dec. 31 last are still coming in and probably will continue to do so for some time, due to the pronounced shortage of accountants. Yesterday the New York Stock Exchange issued its monthly tabulation of reacquired shares.

Approval of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's plan for a $50,000,000 post-war housing project on the East Side, to be known as Stuyvesant Town, will mean the creation of a privately owned "walled city" with no public schools, day nurseries, libraries or other community facilities within its borders, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday at a public hearing at City Hall.

A war program for sculptors, in relation to military, industrial and civilian life, has been prepared by the Sculptors Guild, Inc., a society of American sculptors, 96 Fifth Avenue. The organization believes this to be "the first real effort to demonstrate the need for sculptors' talents in the war period."

BERNE, Switzerland, May 19 -German official reticence in the blasting of two major Ruhr dams by the Anglo-American Air Forces relaxed only slightly today when a statement by the official news agency, D.N.B., acknowledged that 370 Germans had been killed and thirty-six were missing.

"THE LIGHTS AROUND THE SHORE"* is advertised as Jerome Weidman's first "non-hardboiled" novel. The distinction is not very descriptive, for Mr. Weidman's talent will never cause him to be mistaken for James Barrie, Robert Nathan or Barry Benefield. Yet "The Lights Around the Shore" is a relatively "soft" piece of work.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Full cooperation of retailers with the War Production Board and with that agency's Office of Civilian Requirements was offered here today by an informal committee of retailers headed by Lew Hahn, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

HOT SPRINGS, May 19 -- The text of the statement submitted by Judge Marvin Jones, president, to the executive committee of the United Nations food conference relating to press coverage of the parley follows:

LONDON, May 19 -- When Archbishop Francis Spellman of New York was in London last month he told the heads of exiled governments that he was convinced Italy wanted to get out of the war but that she did not know how to accomplish it, it was learned here today.
The People's Chorus, L. Camilieri conductor, will give a concert at 8:45 o'clock tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the American Flying Service Foundation.

Jack Wallace, former prize fighter from Newark, N.J., and a henchman of Joseph Fay, surrendered yesterday at the Court House in Newburgh, N.Y., in answer to a secret indictment handed up on April 14, containing two counts of grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Living costs of city workers in the month ending March 15, 1943, were 21.8 per cent above the level of January, 1941, according to Secretary Perkins, who announced today that living costs for such workers had advanced 1.5 per cent in the thirty-day period up to March 15.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo is back in town, unmindful of the generous season of ballet we have already seen hereabouts, and got off to a lively and promising start last night at the Broadway Theatre. The company is no longer the star-studded aggregation it once was, but it still has plenty of "names" and in general seemed stronger last night than it has on some other occasions.

BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Boxing Commission today announced it would recognize the winner of the Willie Pep-Sal Bartolo fight here at Braves Field on June 8 as the featherweight champion of the world. Pep is now regarded as such by the New York commission.

LONDON, May 19 -- Out of a long debate in the House of Commons today on the perplexing question of refugees in the light of the Bermuda conference came only one entirely clear declaration and that was to the effect that the only real solution of the refugee problem lay in complete victory over the Axis.

John W. Hession, financial trader and former columnist, denied from the witness stand in Federal court yesterday charges of fraud on which he is being tried with two co-defendants, Arnold R. and Sven Wellmer Hanson, over-the-market securities dealers.

With inventory control for most large retailers effective on May 1, the merchandise stocks of New York and Brooklyn department stores at the end of April were 36 per cent under those of the same month a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Decreases in stocks on hand had been previously reported for February and March, but the April drop was the largest thus far.

In the first Axis reaction to Prime Minister Churchill's speech to Congress, the diplomatic correspondent of the German D.N.B. agency complained last night that "Churchill's declaration that this war must be waged to the very end, whatever the cost, is typical for him and for his attitude to all problems."

CHICAGO, May 19 -- A 920-page book, entitled "The Principles of Peace from Leo XIII to Pius XII," assembled under the direction of Archbishop Samuel A. Stritch of Chicago, is scheduled for publication here on or about June 15.
The Tammany Policy Committee, with Senator Robert F. Wagner as spokesman, endorsed last night the leadership of Michael J. Kennedy, after a dinner conference at the National Democratic Club.

Germany has probably suffered between 2,000,000 and 3,000,000 casualties -- dead, permanently disabled, prisoners and missing. The Luftwaffe has been weakened. German military and civilian morale has been impaired and bombardment and blockade have greatly intensified the basic shortage for which Germany can find no substitute -- the shortage of manpower.
HARRISBURG, May 19 -- The Pennsylvania Federation of Women's Clubs declined today to approve two peace resolutions at the closing session of the annual convention.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Either newspaper publishers must curtail their consumption of newsprint or the War Production Board will have to do it for them, W.G. Chandler, director, and H.N. Bitner, deputy director, of WPB's Printing and Publishing Division, announced today.

"Three Hearts for Julia," a romantic comedy starring Ann Sothern and Melvyn Douglas, will have its local premiere at Loew's State this morning. The Metro production, directed by Richard Thorpe, features Lee Bowman, Richard Ainley, Felix Bressart, Reginald Owen, Martz Linden and Jacqueline White.

There is a good deal of nonsense written and spoken about the psychological influence of feminine embellishments. Yet even the most disabused psychiatrists admit that beautiful surroundings and a consciousness of personal charm can do a great deal to restore a shaken self-confidence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 19 -- Arrangements were made today for all cities, towns and villages in Westchester County to sound ten-second all-clear signals on sirens and whistles at the termination of air raid alarms after midnight Saturday, but Captain Rossiter Holbrook, Deputy County Director of Civilian Protection, disclaimed all responsibility for the decision and said he believed it would jeopardize life and property.

Training preparations for their world lightweight championship bout tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden virtually were concluded yesterday by Beau Jack, holder of the title, and Bob Montgomery, highly-regarded Philadelphia contender for the crown.

Juan T. Trippe has been honored this week by two outstanding awards for public service. On Monday the president of Pan American Airways System received the Captain Robert Dollar Memorial Award, given each year to an American citizen who has made "distinguished contribution to the advancement of American foreign trade."

For the first time in several weeks, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday a slight improvement in oil supplies along the Atlantic Coast. At the close of last week the index of the institute stood at 27.1, compared with 25.5, the low point, a week earlier and 58.3 on Nov. 7, last, when the downward trend started.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 19 -Army, in its final game before meeting the Navy here a week from Saturday, was downed by New York University today, 7 to 2. It was the second defeat for the cadets this season.

LONDON, May 19 -- Surging resistlessly through valleys better defended against attack by bombs than against floods, the torrents released by the Royal Air Force's mine attack on the Moehne, Eder and Sorpe dams continued today to spread through the heart of the industrial Ruhr Valley.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- May oats advanced 7/8 cent a bushel in the early trading today and for a time threatened to go to a new seasonal high, but later it was reported that 1,000,000 bushels of Canadian oats had been purchased to come here for delivery on May contracts and the price dropped 1 cent from the high and closed at the bottom.

Carl A. Carlson, 30-year-old machinist's, mate in the Coast Guard who has served in the South Pacific and piloted a landing barge at Guadalcanal, was designated yesterday as the millionth service man to visit lounges maintained in the Grand Central Terminal and Pennsylvania Station by the Travelers Aid Society.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A reduction of $1,320,000 annually in charges for telegraph messages between the United States and South America, Central America and the West Indies was proposed in a report released by the Federal Communications Commission today.

LONDON, May 19 -- The impression here tonight was that Prime Minister Churchill, in his address to the American Congress today, was using all his powers of eloquence and oratory to win American popular support for the decision, already made by him and President Roosevelt, to finish with Reichsfuehrer Hitler first.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced today that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had sold $21,635,000 Lower Colorado River Authority 4 per cent revenue bonds to Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., R.A. Underwood Co., Inc., Smallwood Co., and W.A. Jackson Investments at 105 and interest.

The application filed yesterday by John L. Lewis with the executive council of the American Federation of Labor for reaffiliation of his United Mine Workers with the A.F. of L. was hailed by labor leaders here as a constructive move for organized labor.

It appears that a bill forbidding the requirement of payment of a poll tax by persons voting in elections for national officials will come before the House of Representatives on May 24, having been demanded by petition of a majority of the members.

The Committee on Latin-American Affairs of the Congress of Industrial Organizations demanded yesterday that the Board of Economic Warfare and other government agencies incorporate fair wage and working conditions, abolition of child labor and social security clauses in contracts now being negotiated for the purchase of Bolivian tin.
CHUNGKING, China, May 19 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Application blanks for Ration Book 3, which is to be a replacement for Books 1 and 2, will be distributed to every household in the State through the postal system beginning today, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

Sixty-three buildings, mostly temporary structures of sheet rock standing on foundations a foot off the ground, intended to house 1,700 builders of Chance-Vought shipboard fighters and Sikorsky helicopters, are rising on Main Street, Stratford, Conn., just outside Bridgeport, on land so fertile that for three to four decades it has been double and triple cropped in vegetables to supply near-by families from June to November.
Dr. Eduard Benes, president of Czechoslovakia, reaffirmed last night the intention of his government to seek a Central European confederation of states, with the approval of the Soviet Union.

The new OPA ban on pleasure driving was described last night by Sol Herzog, counsel for the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Conference, as "a shame and a disgrace," imposed to cover "the mistakes of the OPA."
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- More than 97 per cent of the Navy men and marines wounded at Pearl Harbor have survived, the Office of War Information reported today.

LONDON, May 19 (AP) -- For the hardy troops of his victorious Eighth Army, General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery still wishes "good hunting in the battles yet to come" -- the phrase with which he sparked the epochal African rout of the Axis.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The Senate's Truman committee reported today there "was no question but that some defective parts" were furnished for use in Army and Navy planes by the Wright Aeronautical Corporation from its plants at Lockland, Ohio, near Cincinnati.

Miss Virginia Pope, fashion editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, last night was elected president of the New York Newspaper Women's Club at the annual meeting at headquarters in the Hotel Biltmore. Miss Pope succeeds Miss Sonia Tomara of The New York Herald Tribune, now a war correspondent in India and China.

Because of disappointing response by debenture holders to a modified exchange plan announced by the Childs Company on May 5, the directors met yesterday at the end of the acceptance period and directed return of bonds deposited during the two weeks.

LONDON, May 19 (U.P.) -- Col. Gen. Jurgen von Arnim, captured Axis commander in chief in North Africa, will draw only $64 a month in pay while he is a prisoner of war in Great Britain, a War Office spokesman said in the House of Commons today in reply to a barrage of questions by Labor members.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The House today ended consideration of the Navy Department appropriation bill for next year, carrying record-breaking appropriations and contract authorizations of $29,463,687,198. Final approval was put over until tomorrow because Representative Hoffman said there was no quorum.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee reported favorably today a resolution extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Law for two years, but with an amendment which Senator George, chairman, declared would "emasculate" the act if adopted by Congress.

To contrast to the early days of the war, American airplane pilots are being trained now by the tens of thousands and in sufficient numbers to meet the ever-expanding production of our fighting aircraft, Brig. Gen. Thomas J. Hanley disclosed last night.

The future regulation of aviation in this country should be in the hands of a single Federal jurisdiction in order to insure the proper development of commercial air traffic, according to Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America.

PHILADELPHIA, May 19 -- Gunner was born at sea. Two ships have gone down under him as the result of torpedoes. Now he is in training for the United States Coast Guard Beach Patrol, although he is only seven months old. But Gunner is a German shepherd dog.

Professor Philip O. Badger of New York University, president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, expressed the hope yesterday that college sports would be represented on any committee appointed to guide the wartime conduct of athletics, The United Press reported.

LONDON, May 19 (U.P.) -- Naval cadets of the Italian Annapolis at Leghorn were reported today to have clashed with Fascisti in a royalist demonstration following new Allied warnings to Italy to get out of the war or suffer the devastating consequences.

JERSEY CITY, May 19 -- Leo Rosenblum, president of the Hudson County Tax Board, was arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today on a charge of failing to obey an order by Draft Board 26 to appear for a physical examination before Medical Advisory Board 8 on May 6.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- About 30,000,000 cases of the 1943 canned pack of vegetables, fruits and fruit juices which originally had been earmarked for government purchase will be released for civilian consumption as the result of an order today by the War Food Administration.

Ilona Massey's successor in the "Ziegfeld Follies" was signed yesterday. She is Sara Ann McCabe, the singer (not chanteuse), who was seen in "Show Time" for a while and is now appearing on the variety portion of the Capitol program. Miss McCabe will enter the "Follies" on June 2, according to the Shubert office.

Joseph S. Fay and James Bove, two of the most prominent and powerful leaders of the American Federation of Labor in this State and New Jersey, were held in $25,000 bail each yesterday in General Sessions after their indictment on a conspiracy count alleging that they had extorted $703,000 from nine syndicates of contractors.

Maurice Holt, so-called sales manager of the Triangle Appliance Corporation, continued yesterday his testimony as the State's principal witness in the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, lawyer and former Democratic Deputy City Controller, on an attempted grand larceny indictment
BOSTON, May 19 -- The surging Braves extended their winning streak to seven games with a double triumph today over the Pirates, 2 -- 1 in eleven innings and 5 -- 3.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 143 United States soldiers killed and 163 missing in action in the European, Ibero-American, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas. It also listed 167 held as prisoners of war by Italy.

We greatly appreciate your favorable editorial of May 7 relating to the achievement of the Library of Congress in restoring to the screen the long "lost" films which constitute the beginnings of the motion-picture art.

Cotton prices improved slightly yesterday for the fourth successive day. On the New York Cotton Exchange price-fixing pushed the list of six active contracts to midday gains of 6 to 11 points, but liquidation on the bulge and a switch by New Orleans operators to the selling side pared the advances.
NEW DELHI, India, May 19 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

Streamlined is a word that is frequently used these days when life's pace is swift. It applies to the clothes exhibited yesterday noon on the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. It was Russeks Fifth Avenue that elected to endorse sleek styles.

Archbishop Spellman left us in February. Yesterday we heard of him taking a train for Syria from Ankara, where he had just "spent several hours" with President Ismet Inonu. Traveling by train must seem almost like a hardship to him, he has rushed through the air so much. He used to have his own air car and took great pleasure in running it. His observation with extensive view covers a wide range of geography.

AMERICA'S oldest sport is being pretty generally by-passed by the Army and Navy as a physical conditioner, although if the authorities took the trouble to examine it they would find that it has just the qualities they require. The Great American Game in this instance is not baseball but lacrosse.

A solid basis for post-war labor-management relations has been established through widespread adoption of employe suggestion systems to stimulate war production, E.S. Taylor, president of the National Association of Suggestion Systems, declared yesterday at the opening of the group's two-day conference in the Hotel Shelton.

LONDON, Thursday, May 20 -- Berlin reported today that the Red Army had opened major attacks in four areas along a 1,100-mile front and indicated a belief that the Russians might develop their operations into a general offensive in one or more sectors.

Mrs. Anna W.M. Wolf, author of "Our Children Face War," published by Houghton, Mifflin, and Dr. Dorothy W. Baruch, author of "You, Your Children and the War," published by Appleton-Century, received Parents Magazine medals for 1942 yesterday at a luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Faced with the prospect that the salvage of kitchen fats will show a drop this month, for the first time since the fat collections started last Summer, War Production Board officials announced yesterday that 8,000 posters would be placed in the city's transit system in the next few days to spur housewives to greater conservation efforts.

East New York Vocational High of Brooklyn scored 42 1/2 points to capture the city P.S.A.L. Vocational track and field team championship at the annual outdoor games conducted at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium yesterday. Brooklyn Automotive finished second with 36 1/2, while Bronx Vocational was third with 16.

James G. Blaine, president of the Marine Midland Trust Company and a past chairman of the Greater New York Fund, received yesterday the award given annually by the Kiwanis Club of New York City to the city's "most outstanding citizen for 1943."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, May 20 (AP) -- Noon communique:
The favorites experienced little trouble in working their way into the quarter-finals of the William Taft High school singles championship on the courts of the Concourse Tennis Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- A striking aspect of Prime Minister Churchill's address to the joint session of Congress today was that a British statesman gave to the national legislature of the United States war information it either did not possess or had not received clearly enough to realize.

The first Charles L. Mayer Award of $2,000, administered by the National Science Fund of the National Academy of Sciences, was presented last night at the annual dinner meeting of the Fund, held at the University Club, to Dr. Charles B. Huggins, Professor of Surgery at the University of Chicago, "for the most outstanding contribution during 1942 to present-day knowledge of factors affecting the growth of animal cells, with particular references to human cancer."
BOSTON, May 19 (AP) -- Coming on in the stretch, Cape Cod, owned by Grover C. Greer of Baltimore, today won the Jamaica Handicap, a $1,500 sprint, by half a length at Suffolk Downs.

Testimony was introduced yesterday at the Moreland investigation into the Workmen's Compensation Law that Bart J. O'Rourke, licensed representative of claimants, paid an agent of a labor union $500 a year "as a matter of protection" against complaints among union members.

MILWAUKEE, May 19 (AP) -- Another step in the program to give eventual control of The Milwaukee Journal to its employes was taken today with announcement that the board of directors would be enlarged by six members chosen by employe stockholders.

Mrs. Lytle Hull, Mrs. William H. Osborn and Mrs. Courtlandt D. Barnes jointly gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cottage of Hampshire House for Mrs. Douglas Gibbons, chairman of promotion of the women's division of the New York War Savings Staff, and for Mrs. Thomas P. Durell, chairman of the booth committee, who are retiring after sixteen months of service and through whose efforts $1,000,000,000 in war bonds has been sold.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Matthew Woll, president of America's Wage Earners Protective Conference and member of the A.F. of L. executive council, advocated today ratification by the Senate of future reciprocal trade agreements and supported extension of the administration-sponsored Trade Agreements Act provided that all treaties are to be suspended within six months after hostilities end.

Basic factors to be used in determining the eligibility of agencies for participation in the city-State day care program, were listed yesterday by Miss Helen Harris, executive director of the Mayor's Committee on Wartime Care of Children.

WASHINGTON, May 19 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill today gave a cheering, applauding joint session of Congress a generalized preview of plans for American-British aerial attacks that will lay the great cities and munitions centers of Japan in ashes, and other British-American military moves designed to "take more of the weight off Russia in 1943."

Within the last two days a noticeable improvement in the potato supply has taken place here and further improvement can be expected daily, leading wholesalers agreed yesterday. Except for a Food Distribution Administration order requiring shippers in Alabama and California to set aside one-half and one-third, respectively, of their holdings for government use the improvement would be even more rapid and marked, it was said.

LONDON, May 19 -- In a bomber doomed by an accident during the take-off, Captain Derrol W. Rogers of New Britain, Conn., shuttled back and forth from a landing field to the sea to save the lives of the members of his crew and to jettison the plane's bombs, only to lose his own life.

CHICAGO, May 19 -- An open hearth furnace used for making armor plate was kept cold and idle for the fifth consecutive day today by C.I.O. strikers at the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation's works in Gary, Ind. The strike continued despite pleas by officers of the Ninth Naval District and the Army's Sixth Service Command.

As Allied planes swarm ceaselessly across Germany's frontiers the German people, whose battles for more than a hundred years have been fought in other lands, are now learning at first hand what war actually means. Their armies are helpless to protect them. The Luftwaffe seems almost impotent. They themselves are being tried by air, fire and flood.

Because 150,000 New York City defense workers have dropped their volunteer activities since the North African victories, and because military authorities still regard New York City as the enemy's "Target No. 1" in this country, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will open on June 2 a ten-day recruiting campaign on a scale unprecedented in this country.
NEW DELHI, India, May 19 (AP) -- A communique:

PATERSON, N.J., May 19 -- Robert Gainesmiller, 35 years old, a truck driver of 44 Rowland Street, Newark, was questioned tonight by Paterson police in connection with the death of Mrs. Elizabeth Czarneski of 47 Second Avenue, Newark, a war plant worker.

Liberal Judaism, a new illustrated monthly journal of opinion and letters, has been issued by The Union of Hebrew Congregations, it was announced yesterday. The cover of the first, or May, issue, published last Saturday, is dedicated to the memory of Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, founder of Reform Judaism in the United States.

The pressure of wartime housing has brought together many public and private interests which previously had been constantly at odds with each other and if this condition can be maintained after the war it will be possible to provide millions of new homes and jobs, John B. Blandford Jr., Administrator of the National Housing Agency, declared yesterday.

Employment and wages have generally increased in New York City during the last four years, as shown by government statistics and by the fact that relief rolls are only a third as large as they were before war was declared in Europe in 1939.

As this war turns from a defensive to an offensive operation, as territory is regained and as peoples are liberated, the United Nations are brought face to face with grave problems that will imperil their unity. Already we see that threat.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 19 -Without taking a vote, the executive committee of the United Nations conference on food and agriculture has silently approved this government's arrangements under which armed soldiers keep reporters from entering the Homestead Hotel to interview delegates, it was revealed today by Judge Marvin Jones.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 19 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer announced today that Spencer Tracy will be starred in the screen version of William L. White's best seller, "They Were Expendable," the story of the exploits of Lieutenant John B. Bulkeley's motor torpedo-boat squadron.
1V[r. and Mrs. Oliver H. P. Champlin have arrived from Towson, 1E[d., and are at the Biltmore.

The yells and screams of children rang through the rooms of the West Side Center of the Children's Aid Society, 419 West Thirty-eighth Street, yesterday afternoon. Dozens of the youngsters ran about the building dressed in nineteenth century costumes, their faces smudged.

Political figures of the State and nation who were associates of former United States Senator James A. O'Gorman during his career in Congress and in the Supreme Court of this State paid him tribute yesterday by their presence at his funeral.

The death in Rome of Prince Francesco Giuseppe Rospigliosi, member of one of the best known families among the Roman nobility, was reported last night by the Berlin radio, which quoted a dispatch from Rome.

Supplies of salt-water fish are moderate to liberal, reports a spokesman for the Fishery Council. He adds that 75,000 pounds of haddock arrived yesterday, as well as good-sized hauls of whiting and porgies. Bluefish and cod, croakers and weakfish are also represented in the market.

Mr. and Mrs. William Hubbard of Holyoke, Mass., entertained with a dinner last night on the St. Regis Roof for their son-in-law and daughter, Lieutenant Walter I. Tibbetts, U.S.A., and Mrs. Tibbetts. Others in the party were Mr. and Mrs. R. Stewart Kilborne Jr., Mr. and Mrs. William S. Kilborne, Mrs. Raymond S. Clark, Mrs. Allen S. Hubbard Jr. and Miss Elizabeth Skinner.

BOSTON, May 20 (AP) -- Saving ground on the rail all the way, George R. Watkins's Gondalina, second choice in the field of five, registered a five-length victory in the Roxbury Purse at Suffolk Downs today. Navy, the 8-5 favorite, ran second, four lengths in front of Tamil.

The Brooklyn Trust Company has sold the two five-story apartment and store buildings at 307-313 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, to Arthur Cutler, builder, through Benjamin Weintraub, broker. The sale was for cash above a purchase-money mortgage.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Powerful as Prime Minister Winston Churchill is in the affairs of war and peace, his utterances can be edited by an anonymous British official, it developed today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Office of Price Administration tonight denied charges of grocery retailers and wholesalers that its price regulations, particularly the newly introduced community-wide ceilings on processed foods, were stifling trade for the distributors.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Major Gen. Edmund B. Gregory, quartermaster general, disclosed today that illegal markets in some districts continue to hinder army food procurement. He advocated more strict enforcement by the Office of Price Administration of rationing and price ceiling regulations as the best means of correcting the situation.

LONDON, May 20 -- Fighting French Headquarters here, obviously, though unofficially, disheartened by Prime Minister Winston Churchill's mention of General Henri Honore Giraud and his failure to mention General Charles de Gaulle in his address to the United States Congress yesterday was substantially cheered up today by the receipt of a reply from General Giraud to General de Gaulle's note of May 1 proposing that their meeting take place at Algiers.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- With the approach of a German collapse, which some who know Germany predict for next Winter, German groups in this country have been stirred by reports that the United States Government favors drastic decentralization of the Reich, even to the point of its political dismemberment.

William H. Coverdale, president of the American Export Lines, Inc., said at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday that he expected 1943 earnings to be "whittled down sharply," under the War Shipping Administration's policy of low-rate charters making all subsidized steamship companies work entirely for government account.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A program by which War Production Board officials believe they can circumvent rationing of clothing has been worked out and will be applied during the coming months, it was learned tonight.

In his great report to Congress, Mr. Churchill compared the present phase of the war to the period in the Civil War that followed Gettysburg. Although the fate of the Union was decided in that battle, and nobody on either side thereafter doubted the outcome, more blood was shed to consolidate the victory than in all the fighting that went before.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Luther M. Walter and Helen W. Munsert, attorneys for the Chicago North Western Railway Company, announced today that they had filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission a petition asking for re-opening, further hearing and modification of the road's reorganization plan.
LONDON, Friday, May 21 -- Swedish dispatches indicated today that Allied planes may have bombed Berlin for the second time in little more than twelve hours.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Secretary Hull prepared today to assert vigorously his opposition to the threat in Congress to vitiate his reciprocal trade agreements program.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Except for further increases in prices for farm products and foods, largely fresh fruits and vegetables, commodity markets were steady during the week ended May 15. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of prices in primary markets advanced 0.1 per cent to a new peak, 103.8 per cent of the 1926 average.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Hope for a break in the pay-as-you-go income tax deadlock was revived tonight, and it was disclosed that the Treasury had ordered 120 carloads of paper to prepare forms for putting a current tax system into effect July 1.

More than 900 British residents of the metropolitan area have signed up to give a pint of blood each for the armed forces of the United States at the blood donor center of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross next Monday, it was disclosed yesterday by Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, director of the New York Chapter.

BOSTON, May 20 -- Although he has been released by the Braves without throwing a single pitch for them in National League competition, the affable Vernon (Lefty) Gomez, an illustrious Yankee pitcher for thirteen seasons, was without rancor today as he started planning his future at the nowadays tender age of 32.
Several inquiries during the last few days have been received concerning the fishing at Peconic and Shinnecock Bays. The rumor department had it that weakfishing had been stopped.

The American people have undergone a most noticeable change from intense isolationism to a keen interest in their neighbors and the rest of the world, it was agreed yesterday by ten Latin-American newspaper men from Chile, Cuba and Paraguay, who are now on the last stretch of a seventeen-week tour of United States war industries under the auspices of the National Press Club of Washington and the Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

Bank clearings of the principal cities of the country for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $9,116,979,000, a decline of 1 per cent from the preceding week, but 25.5 per cent above the $7,262,252,000 volume recorded in the 1942 week, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

HAMIILTON, Bermuda, May 20 -- Bermuda's first civilian Governor, Viscount Knollys, who has just returned from a visit to England, is leaving his post here within a few weeks to become chairman of the British Overseas Airways Corporation, it was announced at the Government House today.

The Reliance Manufacturing Company of Illinois announced yesterday in its report of operations covering the quarter ended on March 31 net profit of $279,070, after providing $1,100,000 for Federal income and excess profits taxes based on tentative estimates of final liability.

The citizen of tomorrow will be trading in his house every three or four years like the citizen of yesterday did his automobile, Dr. Harvey N. Davis, president of Stevens Institute of Technology, predicted yesterday. What's more, the new house model will be delivered at his prospective front door in packages on a truck, he surmised.

John Desiderio, a 28-year-old bookmaker suspect, who was alleged to have paid off horse-race bets with bogus gasoline coupons, was held in $5,000 bail yesterday afternoon when arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward Fay in Brooklyn Federal Court on a charge of possession and sale of counterfeit T gasoline rationing coupons.

TRENTON, N.J., May 20 -- Leonard Dreyfuss, State Civilian Defense Director, is meeting with all kinds of trouble in the line of duty. He told today of correspondence he has been having with a Mountain Lakes man for several months.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The gasoline famine along the Eastern seaboard has immobilized thousands of tractors and other gasoline-driven farm equipment, thereby creating a crisis in food production, the Department of Agriculture stated today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor declared today that some labor-restricting laws adopted in Arkansas, Kansas, South Dakota, Idaho, Texas and Colorado, were "part of a sinister and underhand attempt by Fascist influences in America to tear the trade union movement apart and to smash the economic and political strength of America's workers."

Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the Phoenix Securities Corporation, announced yesterday that the company was calling for redemption on June 30 all outstanding shares of its $3 convertible preferred stock, Series A, at the redemption price of $55.75 a share, including an accrued dividend of 75 cents a share.

A BRITISH BASE, on the Indo-Burmese Frontier, May 18 (Delayed) -- A super-raid by British and Empire troops that for three months swept through Burma on a 300-mile front, wrecking railroads and bridges and generally harassing Japanese occupation forces, drew near its close today as the weary raiders, many of them disease-ridden, struggled out of the jungle.

The Highland Folk School Fourth Annual Writers' Workshop will he held this year from July 12 to 26 on the school campus at Monteagle, Tenn. Director of the workshop will be Harold Preece, and the sponsors include Babette Deutsch, George Seldes, Millen Brand and Mary Lapsley.

NEWARK, N.J., May 20 (AP) -- Roland Van Slate, 27-year-old Baltimore right-hander, checked the Bears with three hits in a twilight game tonight and hung up an 8-to-0 victory for the Orioles. It was Van Slate's fourth decision of the season and came after he had suffered three straight setbacks.

The prosecution yesterday, in the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, the lawyer, on the attempted grand larceny indictment growing out of the so-called war-defense stirrup-pump monopoly in this city, sought to introduce fourteen dictograph records of a "drinking party" in the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn on the night of last Nov. 23.

The Atlantic Coast Line Company of Connecticut, a holding company, announced yesterday the declaration of a $1.50 dividend. The previous payment, $2.50 last December, was the only disbursement made in 1942.

BEAU JACK is a quiet little fellow who lets his fists do all the talking for him, and a very elegant language they speak, too. When it comes to polysyllabic conversation, however, the Beau Jack camp has a champion of its own, the very effervescent Charles Hercules Wergeles, his manager. Chick is the Great Mouthpiece, in capital letters.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 20 (U.P.) -- Important research progress in determining the cause of infantile paralysis has been made by a group of Swedish scientists, who have isolated and photographed the virus believed responsible for the disease.

A statement that the Navy Department would facilitate the proposed settlement of the $5,000,000 suit brought by the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation and a group of its minority stockholders against its former foreign sales agents was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein at a hearing on the fairness and adequacy of the proposed settlement agreement.

The Metropolitan Opera Guild held its annual meeting yesterday afternoon at Louis Sherry's and made its yearly contribution to the Metropolitan Opera Association. A check for $15,000, derived from the guild's membership dues, was presented to Edward Johnson, the Metropolitan's general manager, by Lucrezia Bori, chairman of the guild.

Asking whether the Senate is limited to passing legislation approved by the State Department, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, announced yesterday that he had addressed that body to call its attention to Senator George's statement that the State Department was "unwilling to accept" changes in the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Despite John L. Lewis's application to reaffiliate the United Mine Workers of America with the American Federation of Labor, it was reported today that some of the "middle of the road" unions associated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations may have an opportunity to rejoin the federation at the same tame, if they act promptly.

The mission fund of the church school of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L.I., will be the beneficiary of a dance to be given this evening at the Cathedral House under the auspices of the junior vestry.

"What are they bringing all those prisoners over here for? They will eat up our food. We have a hard enough time as it is. And then they will all stay here after the war and take Jobs from good Americans."
An exodus from a stretch of territory along the menacing Mississippi was under way last night as fresh forces were rushed into the fight to hold levee lines against the pressure of rising rivers.
NEW DELHI, India, May 20 (AP) -- A United States communique:
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Navy Communique 384:

Patrolman James L. Drew of the Liberty Avenue precinct in Brooklyn, seventeen years on the force, was suspended from duty by Police Commissioner Valentine at 1:45 P.M. yesterday pending departmental trial.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 20 -- A great campaign for air supremacy over the approaches to Southern Europe began yesterday with a convincing American victory in which United States Army Air Force bombers and fighters destroyed twenty-eight Axis fighters while delivering smashing blows upon targets, especially air fields, in Sardinia and Sicily.

Despite the fact that the advertising field is making valuable contributions to the war effort, there is no justification for including its workers in the "essential" category, particularly when men are being taken from war plants, Brig. Gen. William C. Rose, chief of the executive services, War Manpower Commission, told the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

The Essleve Hotel Corporation, a syndicate headed by M. Essenfeld, has purchased the Hotel Colonial, a twelve-story apartment hotel containing 200 apartments at the northeast corner of Columbus Avenue and West Eighty-first Street.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- A Consolidated Liberator bomber, an Army B24, crashed into a high gas storage tank today, killing the entire l crew. The tank, two and one-half miles southeast of the Chicago airport, was virtually demolished and its 18,000,000 cubic feet of gas was set ablaze.
MOSCOW, May 20 (AP) -- Today's communique:

Captain Gerald J. Crosson, New York's former flying policeman and holder of six war medals for outstanding achievements in the Pacific, is back at his home, 5540 Amboy Road, Huguenot Park, S.I., preparing for another engagement but, as he puts it, with a real case of stage fright for the first time in his life.

In modern war the queen of battles is not the infantry. It is gasoline. This is one stern fact that every motorist who is inclined to growl at OPA's renewed order against pleasure driving should write down and memorize.

War Loan Operations Settled -- Changes in Holdings of Government Securities For the first time in seven weeks the earning assets of the sixteen regularly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City showed a sharp decline in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the figures for the week released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- The voluntary plan filed by the Ogden Corporation, successor in reorganization to the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, providing for divestment of all interest in subsidiaries which are holding companies or public utility companies, received qualified approval today from the Securities and Exchange Commission.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- National Maritime Day, Saturday, will be celebrated by awards of eight Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medals.

More than 1,000 persons gathered yesterday afternoon around the statue of Lafayette in Union Square to hear tribute paid to the Revolutionary War hero on the 109th anniversary of his death. The ceremonies were held under the auspices of the Comite Francais du Souvenir de Lafayette.

According to THE TIMES of May 19, the OPA, the Mayor, the Commissioner of Markets, the Housing Commissioner and several details of policemen and firemen descended upon a little barber shop on Sixth Avenue into which a man named Caplan had unloaded 15,000 pounds of potatoes.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 20 -- A Bulls press service dispatch from Berlin said tonight that German submarines had "recently been on a vain hunt for Allied shipping." The conclusion reached by the Berlin writer is that the Allies are assembling shipping for an invasion.

LONDON, May 20 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill's speech yesterday to the United States Congress cheered the stock markets here today, but most sections remained quiet. Diamonds showed further rises; De Beers deferred to 19 1/4, Consolidated to 36s 3d and Anglo-American Investment to 62s 6d.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Large numbers of German and Italian prisoners captured in Tunisia will be transported to the United States, Secretary of War Stimson disclosed today in announcing that camps have been set up for their accommodation and plans made to use them on farms and at other types of permissible work.

New York City's volunteer civilian defense army used to number half a million. For some reason, perhaps because many persons illogically decided that the United Nations victory in North Africa had ended the danger of an air attack here, it has dropped to 350,000.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on May 15 were 848, 522 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 31,971 cars, or 3.9 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 9,468 ears, or 1.1 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 12,280 cars, or 1.4 per cent, fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A message of commendation by President Roosevelt and the naming of J. Edgar Hoover, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, as a national hero of American boyhood, were features of the thirty-third annual meeting of the National Council, Boy Scouts of America, yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

A meeting to pay tribute last night to Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, who served for seven years as a member of the Board of Education, turned into one of protest against the failure of Mayor La Guardia to reappoint her on the expiration of her term two weeks ago.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a decrease of $134,764,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

THE Amazon flows to the sea across most of Northern South America. Its source in tiny Lake Lauricocha, high in the Andean uplands of Peru, is only some eighty miles from the Pacific Ocean. To its gaping mouth in the Atlantic is more than 3,000 miles. While still in Peru the world's greatest river is already two miles wide; while near the end of its mighty course it is fifty miles wide.

The Tokyo radio broadcast yesterday a Domei agency reporter's delayed account of the Battle of Attu, which acknowledged that United States planes and warships had blasted Japanese troops out of their ridge positions and killed more than two-thirds of one Japanese force.

LONDON, Friday, May 21 -- Up to 12,000 German troops, attacking the Russian offensive line east of Novorossiisk, have been thrown back with heavy losses after a fierce fight, the midnight Soviet communique reported today.

"After sharp showers right sweet is the sun." Wednesday the Londoners heard the bells of St. Paul's, once more daring to peal on a weekday. Thanksgiving for the victory in Africa was given in the great cathedral, itself wounded by the air raids that have destroyed so many famous London churches.

American leadership in the post-war period must be of the type which the public will support and other nations will welcome, "the type of leadership which private enterprise is eminently fitted to provide," Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, declared last night at the closing session of the first Western Hemisphere conference and dinner of the Inter-American Commercial Arbitration Commission at the Hotel Astor.
Rules clarifying the driving permitted and prohibited under the ban on so-called "pleasure driving" were announced here as follows:...

Just as New York seemed about to emerge from its long potato famine, it found its receipts cut short abruptly yesterday by the disclosure that an upward revision in the OPA ceiling prices to Southern growers would be put into effect soon.

Increased advertising linage on all types of men's and women's clothing was responsible for a gain in New York department store linage last month, according to a breakdown by Media Records. While linage totaled 3,176,093 last month, as against 2,883,366 in April, 1942, only seventeen out of thirty departments showed increases and the majority was in clothing.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- "Absenteeism" among Senators and Representatives prevented members of the New York City Consumer Council, with representatives of the New Jersey Consumer Council, from interviewing as many as they hoped, but they reported today after canvassing the Capitol that they believed little opposition existed to Senator Wagner's amendment to the Agriculture Department Supply Bill restoring the school luncheon and penny milk program.

"Sons and Soldiers" will give its twenty-second and final performance at the Morosco tomorrow night Financed by Metro, the Irwin Shaw play opened May 4 with a cast headed by Geraldine Fitzgerald, Gregory Peck, Stella Adler, Millard Mitchell, Herbert Rudley and Leonard Sues.

LONDON, May 20 -- The ancient ceremony of drinking from a loving cup was performed today at a luncheon in the Mansion House when the United States Ambassador to Great Britain, John G. Winant, and Sir Samuel Joseph, the Lord Mayor of London, drank together as a symbol of Anglo-American friendship.
DETROIT, May 20 (AP) -- As one Texan to two others, Pinky Higgins's answer, underscored with a plentitude of base hits, is definitely no to a possible shift from third base to the outfield.

CLEVELAND, May 20 (AP) -- The Red Sox took a double-header from the Indians today, winning the ten-inning opener, 2 to 1, and topping it with a 7-to-4 triumph in a finale that saw ten pitchers in action.

LONDON, May 20 -- Saboteurs have fired the big Spanish naval base at Ferrol, on the north-western tip of Spain, destroying or damaging a large part of the Spanish Fleet there and docks and harbor installations, a usually reliable American source said today.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -- Those rambunctious, "new deal" Phillies ran their winning streak to five straight games by shutting out the Cubs, 3 to 0 and 2 to 0, in a double-header before 3,429 at Shibe Park today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Distress among small business as a result of war conditions is not so general as had been rumored, according to a report made today by the Office of War Information at the request of the fighting services, Maritime Commission and the War Production Board.
Colonel and Mrs. Sosthenes Behn will be dinner hosts tonight in the Persian Room of the Plaza.
The Germa Thursday communi-I qud, a.s broadcast from BcrZin and recorded by The Associated Pres:

Aubrey Williams, administrator of the National Youth Administration, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury that he had refused an appointment to Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, because of an article in The Saturday Evening Post that portrayed Mr. Davis as a "Communist and a Stalinist."

President Roosevelt still maintains a tenuous control of Congress "even though he has lost almost every battle on minor fronts," Representative Will Rogers Jr. of California told the Win-the-War rally of the New York Newspaper Guild last night at Manhattan Center in urging a heavy labor vote in the 1944 Congressional elections.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 20 -- Cedric Hardwicke, whose contract with Twentieth Century-Fox has been extended another year, will play the lead in "The Empty Room," Charles Morgan's novel of wartime England, which was bought two years ago for Henry Fonda.

The Charles Frederick Chandler Medal for distinguished achievement in chemistry was presented last night at a large gathering of scientists at Horace Mann Auditorium to Willard H. Dow of Midland, Mich., president of the Dow Chemical Company, pioneer in the extraction of bromine and magnesium from sea water.

CHICAGO, May 20 (AP) -- Wheat, oats and rye are making fairly good progress in most sections of the producing belt, the Weather Bureau's summary of crop conditions said today, but corn planting is considerably behind schedule because of wet weather.

LONDON, May 20 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden today summed up six months of global war in terms as unqualifiedly satisfying to fellow Britons and their allies as they must have been painful and ominous throughout the Axis world.

With the continued improvement in revenues, there are indications that much dissatisfaction is developing among junior security holders of the nation's railroads which are in process of being reorganized. In some instances securities have been held to be worthless, but earnings on them are now running at the highest rate since they were issued.

CHUNGKING, May 20 (U.P.) -- Sixty thousand Japanese, supported by planes, tanks, paratroops and heavy artillery, are pushing westward in Central China toward Enshih, war-time capital of Hupeh Province, only 180 miles east of Chungking, a Chinese military spokesman said today.
LONDON, Friday, May 21 (AP) -Th Soviet midnight communique, broadcast by Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

New and far-reaching housing problems have been caused by the fact that about 60 per cent of the hundreds of thousands of men living in war production areas who expected to be drafted within the next year are married, Coleman Woodbury, Assistant Commissioner of the National Housing Agency, revealed yesterday.

A strong suggestion that neither the health commissioner nor heads of subsidiary divisions in the Health Department should be full-time city employes was made last night by Dr. Charles F. Bolduan at a dinner marking his retirement as director of the municipal health education bureau.
NEW DELHI, India, May 20 (Reuter) -- A special British communique:

By no means the least interesting feature of the current season of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre is its use of new dancers in old roles. Last night's bill found the Nijinska "Snow Maiden," a fairly recent addition to the repertoire, with both its leading feminine roles in new hands, and Massine's old and ever popular "Gaite Parisienne" quite transformed by young blood.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Major Gen. Ben Lear, Acting Commanding General of the Army Ground Forces, was confirmed by the Senate today for elevation to the rank of lieutenant general after Senator Clark of Missouri fought alone for an hour and a half to have him disqualified for promotion on two counts.

To meet a potential shortage of teachers in 1943-44, estimated by the National Education Association at 75,000, Teachers College, Columbia University, has organized a wartime Summer session refresher service for instructors and other educational workers, it was announced yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 20 -- A blanket invitation was extended today to members of Congress to come down to this fashionable pleasure and health resort in the Allegheny Mountains, stay overnight in the luxurious Homestead Hotel and even attend executive sessions of the United Nations conference on food and agriculture.

The twenty-family apartment house with two stores at 505 Jefferson Street, Hoboken, N.J., has been sold by the Hoboken Bank for Savings to the Alamar Corporation through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Winston Churchill discussed global war strategy with members of the Pacific War Council for ninety minutes today and Dr. Alexander Loudon, Netherland Ambassador, told reporters later that they had given an "optimistic" over-all picture of the conflict.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 20 (AP) -- Tom De La Cruz scored his fourth triumph of the season and his second in a row over Jersey City when he squeezed out a 3-to-2 victory for Syracuse tonight.

NORFOLK, Va., May 20 (AP) -- The Yankees and Dodgers got the nod as pennant winners from most of the former big leaguers now on Uncle Sam's payroll here -- five on the Norfolk Naval Training Station nine and five on the Norfolk Naval Air Station team.

While reinstatement of the pleasure-driving ban on the East Coast made sizable cuts yesterday in passenger-car traffic, Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, said in Washington that still further reductions in gasoline use would have to be made in the East and that new restrictions might be extended to the Midwest "before the present crisis is over."

Plans for the establishment of a world fashion center in New York as a post-war project, first conceived in 1940, received impetus yesterday when Grover A. Whalen made public a letter to Mayor La Guardia asking him to appoint a research, study and planning committee of twenty-five business men and women to consider the matter.

Lanky Rube Melton, who shut out the Cardinals in the opener of the four-game series last Monday, brought the Dodgers back on an even keel by hurling them to a 5-2 triumph over the world champions at Ebbets Field yesterday and gaining an even break in their four-game series.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, May 21 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Trading in cotton futures failed yesterday to produce any feature as continued uncertainty over political and legislative issues retained values near the previous close in a small market. Business was strictly routine, with price-fixing sustaining the near months on the New York Cotton Exchange and hedge-selling and liquidation weakening the distant positions.
The following story is symbolic of the French problem.

The People's Chorus of New York, under Lorenzo Camilieri, held its eighteenth annual Spring Song Festival last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. The concert was given for the benefit of the American Flying Services Foundation.

The City Planning Commission approved yesterday by a vote of 5 to 1 the $50,000,000 Stuyvesant Town medium-rental housing project of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, to be located on the tract bounded by Avenue C, First Avenue, East Fourteenth Street and East Twentieth Street.

NEW DELHI, May 20 (AP) -Heavy and medium bombers of the United States Tenth Army Air Force dropped more than 125 tons of bombs on Japanese installations in Burma yesterday, marking the second day in succession that it had broken its record for weight of bombs showered there.

A drying up of buying power in the late trading yesterday produced an easier note at the close in the stock market, but only after prices had pushed forward to new high marks. On balance, however, the share list did not get out of hand, for at the finish of trading the number of issues that had advanced just about equaled the number that had receded.

Dr. Eduard Benes, president of Czechoslovakia, had a busy day in New York yesterday. He visited an exhibition of war caricatures at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street; had lunch at the Union Club as the guest of Thomas J.
