Watson, stood at the head of a receiving line in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel that lasted two hours late in the afternoon and then did the same thing again in the evening.

Checks representing about 10 per cent of all salaries paid since Jan. 1 will be delivered next week to 900-odd employes of the New York Stock Exchange as a result of a War Labor Board decision announced yesterday. The settlement ends a labor relations tangle that has embarrassed the trading institution since last Autumn.

Responsibility for a successful employe suggestion system rests with management, W.A. Patterson, president of United Air Lines, declared last night at the dinner which concluded the two-day conference of the National Association of Suggestion Systems in the Shelton Hotel.

War work in factories and shipyards for mothers of children under 14 years of age was condemned yesterday by Mrs. Alfred J. Mathebat, president of the American Legion Auxiliary, at the season's final meeting of the Business Women's Forum of the Women's National Republican Club, as a form of "adult delinquency," hurtful to the growing generation.

ALBANY, May 20 -- Governor Dewey appointed today Charles Harvey Sells, former Westchester County Commissioner of Public Works, to the $12,000-a-year office of State Superintendent of Public Works. He succeeds Captain Arthur W. Brandt.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that its program to bring used and reconditioned furniture and other used consumer durable goods under a new over-all regulation, which will make their ceilings specified percentages of their prices when new, had been approved at a trade meeting attended by twenty-three industry representatives.

The lightweight championship of the world, or the New York State Athletic Commission version thereof, will be the prize tonight when Sidney Walker, Augusta, Ga., battler, known to the boxing world as Beau Jack, faces Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia in a fifteen-round fight at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- That the money to be realized from the post-war sale of the $15,050,000,000 of government-financed war plants will be less important than the policy under which the properties are sold, because these could "make or break foreign relations and stimulate or severely handicap free competition," is the essence of a memorandum prepared by the program analysis section of the War Production Board.

We believe a map would explain to Senator Chandler much of the mystery which he finds in the failure thus far of the British armies in India to drive Japan out of Burma and so open a broad highway into China. Senator Chandler counts "60,000 Japanese" in Burma.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, May 21 (AP) -- The Japanese air force kept up its offensive against New Guinea over Wednesday night and yesterday by sending twenty-one planes against four Allied bases, bringing to nearly 250 the number of enemy sorties in raids within a week's period.

Mussolini's earliest title to fame is being pulverized by Allied bombings from the air and occasional bombardments from surface ships. Italian train schedules are becoming more and more sadly disrupted.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- An effort to limit future Presidential terms to two of four years each, which more than a majority of the members of the United States Senate have been discussing for several weeks, was taken out of the cloak room today into the public prints.

DETROIT, May 20 -- More than 28,000 workers, members of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., were idle tonight and five major war production plants were closed as the result of a flurry of wildcat strikes, the most serious work stoppage in Detroit since Pearl Harbor.

PERNAMBUCO, Brazil, May 20 (AP) -- The sinking of the 9,300-ton Greek ship Edifots became known today and reports were current that her captain probably perished as a manacled prisoner aboard a subsequently disabled U-boat which was scuttled when overtaken by a British destroyer.

CHUNGKING, China, May 20 -- Not everything is beer and skittles in Japan, according to a Japanese anti-Fascist known here as Mr. Aoyama, who has been living under the protection of the Chinese Government. He prints Japanese language publications here and still has several sources of information from Japan.

The appointment of the Very Rev. Francis X. Shea, vicar for religious of the archdiocese and member of the staff of St. Patrick's Cathedral, as secretary to the Archbishop, was announced by Archbishop Spellman yesterday in a cablegram received at his office.

WINNIPEG, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- A reduction in the wheat acreage of the prairie provinces by slightly more than 17 per cent was forecast today by The Winnipeg Free Press in its first crop report of 1943.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- American forces on Attu Island now have captured a second strategic pass leading toward the area where the Japanese are trapped, and the "partially completed" airfield that the enemy was building now is in our hands, the Navy and War Departments revealed today.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- The tight-fitting American League baseball schedule virtually became a noose on four Western clubs' series with Eastern rivals today as the result of a record number of postponements.
MOSCOW, Friday, May 21 -- The secret message of President Roosevelt was presented to Premier Joseph Stalin by Joseph E. Davies in the Kremlin last night at a meeting likely to become historic.

Three well-dressed young Brooklyn girls were arrested yesterday afternoon by Staten Island detectives, charged with committing a series of burglaries on the north shore of the island during the past two weeks. The trio, who, according to Deputy Chief Inspector Michael F. McDermott, have admitted robbing five homes and making attempts on at least five others, were taken into custody on the porch of a home at 59 Cortelyou Place, New Brighton.

Miss Elizabeth Wood, executive secretary of the Chicago Housing Authority, often called "Chicago's Largest Landlord" in connection with the supervision she maintains over the rental of low-cost apartments to 6,000 Chicago families, was elected treasurer of the National Association of Housing Officials yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A business associate and even the family of an important witness who has been sought since March 25 by the Moreland Commission investigating the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law have no knowledge of the man's whereabouts, Thomas A. Quinn, the business associate, testified yesterday at the Moreland inquiry in the Bar Association Building.

In reply to the Tammany policy committee's praise of Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, voiced Wednesday night by Senator Robert F. Wagner, State Senator James G. Donovan, chairman of the committee to reorganize the Democratic party in New York County, declared yesterday that the purpose of his committee was to get rid of the name of Tammany.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 20 -- Carrying accounts of the depreciation of the Italian lira in Tripolitania and Tunisia with figures comparing its value inside Italy and in territory occupied by the Allies, the Italian press today complained bitterly against treatment allegedly accorded by the Americans to Axis-friendly inhabitants of North Africa.

TORONTO, May 20 (Canadian Press) -- Miss Judy Johnson, 29-year-old New York woman who recently received a jockey's license in Maryland, would like to get permission to ride and train horses in Ontario, she said in an interview today.
The board of trustees of Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, yesterday elected Frederick H. Wood, Manhattan attorney, as board chairman to succeed Dr. Arthur E. Bestor, who served eight years.

Laurie Henderson, 32 years old; Marle Revell, 36, and Robert Mattlin, 39, members of a Washington gang of blackmailers, all with criminal records, were sentenced to Sing Sing for terms of five to six years each yesterday in General Sessions by Judge Jonah J. Goldstein.

PITTSBURGH, May 20 -- United Mine Workers officials moved tonight to end wildcat strikes in the bituminous district of Western Pennsylvania,, West Virginia and Ohio. More than 2,200 of about 6,700 strikers voted to end their walkout in the Johnstown area.

PEARL HARBOR, May 20 -- The operations on Attu are believed to be an attempt to pinch off permanently Japan's Aleutians salient, while at the same time we are extending the front on which the enemy is being annoyed throughout the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Eighty delegates representing unions affiliated with the Congress of Industrial Organizations called on government officials today and requested "action" on wage, price and labor policies affecting about 500,000 of their constituents in Indiana, Illinois, Wisconsin, Minnesota and Iowa.
LOS ANGELES, May 20 (AP) -- The Cubs and their sixty-one-day holdout, Lou Novikoff, are about to shake hands and make up.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 15 were 16 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

More than a hundred representatives of the American Red Cross, Civilian Defense Voluntary Organization and other volunteer organizations playing a leading role in the war yesterday welcomed the Borough of Manhattan members of the American Women's Voluntary Services at the opening of their new headquarters, 39 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Thirty-one new canine members were inducted into the Army K-9 Corps yesterday at the Teevan Riding Academy, East Eighth Street and Caton Place, Brooklyn, by Dogs for Defense, Inc.

Ernest C. Oberholtzer's splendid letter published in THE TIMES May 15, regarding preservation of the Quetico-Superior wilderness region, and your editorial comment thereon are timely. Emergency and other conditions resulting from the war have invited indiscriminate and in some cases senseless and unwarranted exploitation and denudation of our few remaining wilderness areas.

Four hundred color-phase foxes were offered yesterday at the beginning of a silver fox sale by the New York Auction Company. The offering included platinum-type, white face, pearl platinum and ring neck foxes. The top was $190 for a platinum-type.

Serious strikes in principal Italian industries, including a flare-up at the Ilva navy yard near Naples, as a result of Allied bombings and the African victory were reported yesterday by the Italian American Labor Council on the basis of information from underground sources in Italy.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., May 20 -- Honorary degrees were conferred on Dr. Wu Yi-fang, president of Ginling College in China, and Sigrid Undset, Norwegian novelist, at Smith College's sixty-fifth commencement exercises today. A doctorate of law was conferred on Dr. Wu and a doctorate of literature upon Miss Undset.

Dr. Corliss Lamont, chairman of the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, awarded a certificate of appreciation for the film "Mission to Moscow" to Warner Brothers Pictures, Ambassador Joseph E. Davies, and Walter Huston at a rally held under the auspices of the council in Carnegie Hall last night to build Allied unity and protest against anti-Soviet propaganda.

PHILADELPHIA, May 20 -Terming the capital structures of the American Power and Light Corporation and the Electric Power and Light Corporation "abominable" and "a mess from any point of view," the Securities and Exchange Commission asked the First Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston today to affirm an order requiring dissolution of the two concerns, both of which are intermediate holding companies in the Electric Bond and Share system.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. At the Strand "Action in the North Atlantic" will have its local premiere. Humphrey Bogart, Alan Hale and Raymond Massey are starred in the topical drama of the merchant marine.

Four Long Island golf clubs, Wheatley Hills, Cherry Valley, Garden City Country and Hempstead, will engage in a series of quadrangular matches on their respective links this season, it was announced yesterday.
Germany is probably weaker economically and psychologically than she is militarily, but military defeat must probably precede internal breakdown.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- As the House unanimously approved a record-setting Navy Department appropriation bill of $29,463,687,198, President Roosevelt asked Congress today to appropriate new funds and reappropriate unobligated balances for a total of $71,898,499,700 to operate the War Department during the 1944 fiscal year.

Acting on the recommendation of Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry of the Second Service Command, Mayor La Guardia announced last night that the all-clear signal in the city's air raid alarms would be a siren note of less than ten seconds duration. Under the present system, which has caused confusion in some quarters, the all-clear has been given by radio announcements and wardens' whistles.

CHICAGO, May 20 -- Trading in May grain contracts will cease at the close of business tomorrow, and evening-up operations today resulted in somewhat nervous price movements on the Board of Trade. Buying of May against sales of the deferred deliveries of wheat strengthened the former and it close 1 1/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday, while the deferred months were up 1/2 to 5/8 cent.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Accusing the War Labor Board of failing to comply with a Senate resolution requesting data upon which a clear understanding of the effect of its wage-increase decisions might be had, Senator Byrd of Virginia called upon the board today to file a supplemental report providing "omitted" information promptly.

Praise for the administration of the State civil service by the State Civil Service Commission in the past decade was coupled yesterday with a plea for more aggressive action in insisting on modern personnel management, in the annual report of the Civil Service Reform Association.

The Town Talk Foods Corporation has taken a seven-year lease on the street floor in 104 West Forty-third Street for a "Town Talk" restaurant under the direction of Cy Cooper who has several other restaurants in New England. This is the first to be opened in this area.

A seven-point plan for conserving fabrics in the new lines of Fall millinery, anticipating the expected WPB conservation order, was put before the industry yesterday by Lilly Dache, Sally Victor and John-Frederics, Inc., comprising Millinery Fashion Inspiration, Inc., at a breakfast at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Miss Bernice M. Wilbur, who nursed Lieut. Gen. Lesley J. McNair and was flown with him from North Africa to the United States, has been promoted from a first lieutenant to a lieutenant colonel, the War Department announced today.

"Fighting begins responsibility, not ends it," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt told two thousand students yesterday at City College's School of Business and Civic Administration. She urged them to begin "planning and building" now the kind of world they wanted to live in after the war.

LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- The Bank of England's weekly report today disclosed a drop of 4,285,000 in notes in circulation. Government securities decreased more than 8,000,000, private deposits were off 2,508,000, public deposits, 2,366,000, and other securities were more than 1,000,000 lower.

The regular twenty-eight-week season of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall will open Thursday night, Oct. 7, and close Sunday afternoon, April 6. In a general summary of the orchestra's plans for next season, released yesterday, it was announced that in March Bruno Walter, guest conductor, will celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of his career as batonist.

A plan setting up new hiring controls in the New York City area to replace the limited measures now in effect, will become effective next Thursday, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, Regional Director of the War Manpower Commission, announced yesterday.
CHUNGKING, China, May 20 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Bill Sickle, considered only a sprinter by most racegoers, ran a dashing mile and a sixteenth through Belmont Park's mud yesterday to humble Vincentive, Maryland's erstwhile hope for the Preakness who went to the post a 3-to-5 favorite with the crowd of 11,105.

In yesterday's issue of this newspaper appeared a full-page advertisement by the United Automobile, Aircraft and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (UAW-CIO) in which that union presented its own plan "for practical, common sense economic stabilization."

A $70,000 jewel robbery at 40 John Street in the heart of the downtown jewelry district just before 5 o'clock last night caused considerable excitement among the homegoing thousands as police threw a cordon around the block. Despite swift action by the police, the thieves escaped.

Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, Commander in Chief of the combined Japanese Fleet, who reportedly boasted he would dictate peace terms to the United States from a seat in the White House, was killed during April "while engaged in combat with the enemy" aboard a warplane, Japanese Imperial Headquarters announced in a communique broadcast domestically this morning by the Tokyo radio.

Black market operations in cattle slaughtering have brought about a definite deterioration in the quality of hides appearing on the market and may also have reduced the quantity available, speakers declared yesterday at the Spring business meeting of the Tanners Council of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Total taxes charged to electric operations of the larger privately owned electric utilities in the United States in the first quarter of 1943 were reported to be $178,465,000, compared to $164,132,000 in the first quarter of 1942, an increase of 8.7 per cent, according to a statement issued today by the Federal Power Commission.

A new form of "ticket" for motorists made its appearance yesterday to strengthen enforcement of the ban on pleasure driving as the gravity of the East Coast gasoline shortage increased and Federal agencies prepared for further curtailment of home deliveries by large stores, laundries and other business establishments.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Retail prices of food continued to advance sharply last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Advances were recorded in the latter part of March and the early part of April, the board said, and its indices showed increases of 6 per cent, as compared with January.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Senate Finance Committee faced today a choice between suppressing information which already has been printed and distributed as a public Congressional document, or running afoul of a law which permits executive departments and agencies to classify data as "confidential" and protects its secrecy.

NEWARK, N.J., May 21 -- Indictments charging that three live-poultry wholesalers, all of this city, had violated price ceilings set by the Office of Price Administration and had failed to keep accurate and complete records were handed up here today by the Federal grand jury. The true bills represented the first criminal action by the OPA against poultry wholesalers in New Jersey.

BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Wools bought from the West under free marketing and supplies from abroad are moving along to mills on purchases made some time ago. Probably 80 per cent of the contracted domestic wools were sold after acquisition by dealers from the growers.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Preliminary decisions on future Anglo-American military moves in every theatre of combat, agreed upon by the joint staffs, were forwarded tonight to President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill, who are expected to make final plans in the next week.

The three-story dwelling and store at 356 Park Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Rocco Marino to Berdie Morris. The size of the plot is 25 by 90 feet, and the assessed valuation of the property is $11,000. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- While a Navy communique reported that the Japanese on Attu Island had established positions on high ground east of Attu village two days ago, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said at his press conference today that the campaign now could be considered "a mopping-up process."

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today denied the application for registration as an over-the-counter broker-dealer of George Lewis Ohrstrom, doing business as G.L. Ohrstrom Co. at 40 Wall Street, New York.

After absorbing a first-round beating that threatened to blast him into quick submission, Bob Montgomery of Philadelphia struck back against Beau Jack so effectively as to win the decision in the fifteen-round bout that featured the card at Madison Square Garden last night.

ONE swallow does not make a Spring, nor does one horse make a race. But casual followers of the Sport of Kings know only one name in so far as the turf is concerned, Count Fleet. The Hertz Hurricane, winner of the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, will take a whirl at the Withers over the Belmont Park strip today, thus stirring into frantic betting activity those who love to wager on a sure thing.

Will some one please explain what is the official salute to the flag? Ever since the old salute was tinkered with about six years ago Americans have been groping around awkwardly for a place to put their right arms every time they are called upon to pledge allegiance.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- The Office of War Information and the Office of Price Administration joined hands today to explain the meanings on price tags of stockings for women -- words like "gauge," "circular knit," "irregulars'' and "seconds."

LOS ANGELES, May 21 (U.P.) --Grinning, cocky and certain he is just the boy to pull the Cubs up by their bootstraps, Lou Novikoff left by train today for Chicago with a signed contract in his pocket and a chuckle up his sleeve.

The all-time, all-star baseball squad named by Sam Geschwint in his recent letter and containing one ace from each of the sixteen major league clubs was a fine team. It gave me the idea of picking the following all-time, all-star combination of players who also served or are serving now as managers of those clubs.
MEXICO CITY, May 21 -- Leaders of the Senate and of the Chamber of Deputies today urged the dissolution of the Sinarquist Union as a threat to Mexico's national security.

Charges that the so-called decentralization plan controlling exports to Latin-American countries is unworkable and unnecessarily hampering to United States commerce with those nations were made by foreign traders yesterday. The Export Managers Club, in a special bulletin, listed a series of such criticisms received from its members, including the assertion that the program, in effect, vitiates the Reciprocal Trade Agreements.

Count Fleet and five others have been named for the historic Withers Stakes, $15,000 added feature at Belmont Park today, that will serve as a test of the champion's ability to come down to a mile from the longer routes he has been running.

" Svenskt I Och Omkring New York" ("Sweden in and Around New York") will have its local premiere at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre today. The feature-length documentary produced by Ernest Mattson for Scandia Films, Inc., covers the activities of the Swedish community in the Greater New York area and environs.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Elimination of the cartons made up for the convenience of consumers carrying bottles of carbonated beverages from retail stores is under consideration by the War Production Board as a measure to conserve paperboard for military purposes.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt paid tribute today to the men of the Merchant Marine for braving the perils of submarines, dive bombers and surface raiders in order to deliver the goods and declared that "their skill and determination will keep open the highway to victory and unconditional surrender."

A dozen breaks in levees along the Mississippi, Illinois and Wabash Rivers sent flood waters over thousands of acres of fertile Midwestern farm land yesterday but saved several cities from the threat of immediate inundation.

Arguments for an increased subway fare do not make good reading for subway patrons going to or from work during the rush hours. Yet the regular subway rider is the very person who ought to listen carefully to what the unofficial Committee of Fifteen, under the chairmanship of Paul Windels, said on this subject two years ago and now reiterates and underlines.

The Ballet Theatre returned last night to the Metropolitan Opera House for a final week-end of five performances and found another sizable audience awaiting it, in spite of the fact that for the first time in local history a second major ballet company was also playing on Broadway.

A mock air attack on Chinatown in which the antiquated building of New York's Chinese Overseas School, Hwa Chiao Han Wen H'sir Hsiao, at 64 Mott Street, was sprayed with "incendiary bombs" by "enemy planes" was staged yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, May 21 -- The stock markets here were cheerful today, but the turnover was small and the week closed quietly apart from diamond-mining shares, which saw fresh buying on hopes of increased dividends. De Beers went to 20, the preference shares improved to 15 3/8, Consolidated Diamonds rose 9d to 37s and Anglo-American Trust, 6d to 63 3/4s.
Fishing captains and party boatmen in New Jersey and Long Island centers were trying to find a silver lining yesterday.
BOSTON, May 21 (AP) -- Two noses separated the first three finishers in the Highlands Purse, six-furlong sprint at Suffolk Downs today.

Two major meets will command the attention of New York City's outstanding scholastic track and field athletes today. They are the fortieth annual city P.S.A.L. senior high championships slated for Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island and the twenty-sixth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools title games at Baker Field.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21 -- After several months of indecision the executive committee of the Westchester County Republican Committee met here this afternoon and chose its candidates for the November election.

LONDON, Saturday, May 22 (AP) -- Heavy Russian artillery barrages along hundreds of miles of the eastern front were announced early today in a Moscow communique that ignored German reports that the Red Army already had lashed out in a prelude to offensives in the Caucasus and Orel sectors.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 21 -- The Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung has launched a campaign for restoration of the eight-hour working day, it was revealed here today.

The eleventh annual observance of National Maritime Day will be marked today in New York and elsewhere in the nation by parades, awards to seamen, inspections of maritime training facilities and ceremonies in memory of men who have died at sere

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21 -- Alfred Rado, elderly white-haired principal of Public School 89 in the Bronx, N.Y., was accused here today in Supreme Court of having practiced fraud and deceit in inducing Miss Ruth Paynter, the second of three teachers he has married, to become his wife in 1933.

Closer cooperation between government agencies and nursing councils in local communities was suggested as a solution for community nursing needs on the home front at the New York State Nursing Council for War Service meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Two versions of the death of Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, said by Tokyo radio to have been killed in action while directing a naval operation from an airplane, were advanced in the United States yesterday.

W. Alton Jones, president of the War Emergency Pipelines, Inc. -- the "big inch" pipeline which is carrying oil from the Texas fields to the Eastern Seaboard -- announced last night that construction of a temporary eight-mile loop in the line is being rushed so that oil may again be flowing to the East by the end of the month.

LONDON, May 21 -- The first American-built air base, somewhere in Britain, was opened officially today. It was named Andrews Field in memory of Lieut. Gen. Frank M. Andrews, who was killed in an airplane accident in Iceland recently.
LONDON, May 20 (AP) -- The Soviet noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor here:

MOSCOW, May 21 -- Joseph E. Davies indicated tonight that President Roosevelt's personal letter to Joseph Stalin, which he delivered in the Kremlin last night, would be answered by the Soviet Premier within the next few days.

The National Gallery of Art in Washington has announced the acceptance of the gift of sixty-three American portraits from the A.W. Mellon Educational and Charitable Fund; a group of eight paintings from the Chester Dale collection and two portraits presented by Clarence Van Dyck Tiers.

THE TIMES states that the Board of Education will issue high-school diplomas to students who complete the four-year general course, regardless of their ratings in the Regents examinations. This means that a high-school diploma may be obtained without satisfying any officially defined standards; diplomas will be issued merely for a four-year attendance.

The next ten days will prove critical in crop harvesting, and if the gasoline shortage holds up the work a good portion of the harvest will be lost, Morse Salisbury, director of the office of information of the Department of Agriculture, declared yesterday at the closing session of the annual meeting of the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Improvement of modest and a highly irregular character set in yesterday in the stock market after the list had weakened further in the early hours. There was nothing decisive about the session on the Stock Exchange, nor any hint as to the immediate trend for prices, although the rails perked up and, in so doing, gave partial confirmation to the new highs set by the industrials earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The three-man panel of the National War Labor Board reported tonight to the board its fact-finding data covering the dispute between the United Mine Workers of America and the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian region.
The annual report of the Brown Sharpe Manufacturing Company, machine tool manufacturers, disclosed yesterday 1942 net sales of $60,144,699, in contrast to the 1941 volume of $43,605,746.

The proposals to have a sports coordinator or a three-man committee guide the wartime conduct of athletics in this country have a dangerous tinge and I hope they will be rejected quickly. There's enough centralization of power now.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 22 (AP) -- The noon communique:

After more than four months of discussion and wrangling, Congress has still to pass a withholding tax or adopt a pay-as-you-go plan. The House and Senate conferees apparently have been unable to agree because they do not know precisely what plan would be acceptable to the President.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:
DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- The Tigers, playing their seventh extra-inning contest of the season, pushed home a run in the 13th today to defeat the Red Sox, 2 to 1, in the opener of a four-game series.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 21 -- Declaring that he had been informed by "America's No. 2 statesman" that our chances of winning the peace are but one in three, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of Boston, told the New England Methodist conference today that the Methodist Church this year will promote a crusade to influence United States participation in world government.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP) -- It took Johnny Humphries just 1 hour and twenty-nine minutes to pitch a three-hitter tonight while the White Sox beat the Senators, 1 to 0, before a crowd of 8,567.

New securities offered for public subscription this week amounted to $10,436,000, representing five bond issues, compared with $50,985,000 for four loans last week and with $4,439,000 for three offerings in this week of 1942.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 21 -- The extent to which Australians are looking to the United States for armed support after the war as well as at present is revealed in a public opinion survey completed this week throughout Australia.
Today's events: Commencement concert, Manhattan School of Music, 4:30 P.M.; George Boyle, composer-pianist, and Samuel Lifschey, viola, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30.

LONDON, May 21 -- Between thirty and forty Axis warships, supply ships and auxiliaries were sunk or severely damaged by mines laid across the enemy's supply lines to Tunisia, according to an Admiralty communique issued today.
CINCINNATI, May 21 -- A United States Marine who fought and helped beat the Japanese on Guadalcanal failed today to convince a group of striking war workers that they should get back on the job.

Golf is not only slipping now, but it has been slipping for years and years, maybe twenty-five or more. If something isn't done, it will revert to the rich who monopolized the sport in its early days, or will fade away to just a few hundred clubs.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 21 -- The German Foreign Office has announced that a series of White Books dealing with the origins of the war will be published soon.

Mayor La Guardia has blocked the appointment of Norman M. Stone as director of education in the Department of Correction at $2,400 a year because he is a brother of Lester B. Stone, the Mayor's executive secretary and the choice might be open to criticism, since Mr. Stone is not No. 1 on the civil service list of eligibles.

A profusion of lilacs continues to be the only bright spot in an otherwise depressing picture of the current flower marts presented yesterday by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets. Flourishing mostly in stalls set up on sidewalks, they bloom with an air of Spring freshness.

Inclement weather affected retail trade here to some extent this week, but despite this handicap some stores here had substantial sales increases over the comparative 1942 week. These gains ranged up to 20 per cent, but the average for the department stores here was estimated as well under that figure.

With the approach of Memorial Day week-end New York shops are experiencing a rush of requests for smart and practical wardrobes by women planning to visit their husbands at camp. The prospect of heavier traffic than ever this year on buses and trains makes it expedient to travel with everything in one light bag or week-end case.
CHUNGKING, China, May 21 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Definite limitation or allocation orders will increasingly govern each commodity so that the applicability and field of use for priorities will become more restricted, Randolph P. Butler, chief of the WPB leather section, declared yesterday at the Spring business meeting of the Tanners Council at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

New issues of municipal securities announced for award next week aggregate $16,131,000, of which $9,243,000 comprises note issues of various local housing authorities. Next week's total compared with $6,420,614 this week, according to the Daily Bond Buyer, and with the weekly average for the year, thus far, of $16,425,137.

The City Council slashed $10,864,905 last night from the 1943-44 city budget of $753,071,123, proposed by Mayor La Guardia and recently approved by the Board of Estimate. It effected this drastic cut by a vote of 18 to 8, approving a majority report by its finance committee and adopting a revised budget totaling $742,216,118.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 117 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas. It also gave out a list of eighty-seven men held prisoners of war by Japan, twenty-six by Italy and seventeen by Germany.

DETROIT, May 21 -- A back-to-work movement, headed by a War Labor Board directive and backed by leaders of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., was aimed tonight at getting 27,500 idle Chrysler Corporation workers back at their jobs tomorrow.

ALBANY, May 21 -- Nursery facilities in structures under the control of any religious group cannot be financed from the $2,500,000 appropriated by the Legislature for establishment of childcare centers, according to a formal opinion to the State War Council by Attorney General Goldstein.
A cab driver with a retentive memory and tenacity of purpose enabled the police to recover $18,000 worth of jewelry lost by a Navy lieutenant's wife and led yesterday to the arrest of the finder.

Voicing the belief that all hold-up killers should be put to death on conviction rather than get prison terms on which they usually obtain their freedom on parole, Judge James Garrett Wallace yesterday in General Sessions accepted a plea of guilty to second degree murder from William F. Flynn, 24 years old, in a Harlem bar hold-up with the understanding that he would send Flynn to prison for "the rest of his life."

CHUNGKING, China, May 21 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, gaining new ground in their powerful drive westward in Central China, have captured a village less than 280 miles from Chungking, but the rejuvenated Chinese Air Force has made a damaging attack on Ichang, important enemy supply base on the north bank of the Yangtze River, it was announced tonight.

Your editorial of May 14 on the air raid signals raises one point which has been raised many times and answered many times, but apparently still lacks understanding. It is: Why do the British use only two air raid signals -- a "Red" and an "All Clear"?

Why do the British have only two air raid signals -- a "Red" and an "All Clear" -- while civilian defense authorities in this country insist on an additional "Blue" signal? OCD Director Landis answers this in a letter published on this page today.
LONDON, May 21 (AP) -- An Admiralty communique:

The desserts suggested in the menus for next week -- baked rhubarb, quick-frozen peaches, baked apples, strawberries and so forth -- are on the simple side with one exception. This is the peanut butter coffee roll that tops off Tuesday's dinner, a meatless meal that might seem insubstantial without a fairly filling conclusion.

HARRISBUHG, Pa., May 21 (AP) -- A work stoppage at the nearby Steelton plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company spread from a rolling mill to several other departments tonight. George Medrick, district chairman of the United Steel Workers, C.I.O., described the walkout as "a wildcat strike."

While Mr. Churchill, Mr. Roosevelt and military advisers representing all the fighting theatres continue their long-drawn-out conferences, while Mr. Stalin ponders over the contents of the letter delivered to the Kremlin by former Ambassador Davies, Fortress Europe is the target of the heaviest and most widespread bombardment in the history of war.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 21 -- The principal shipping, shipbuilding and naval executives of Australia have just met under the chairmanship of Prime Minister John Curtin to discuss the revision of the shipbuilding and ship-repair program.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- For sustaining the basic economy of the conquered territories in Africa, textiles constitute the "most important" supplies the Lend-Lease Administration now ships, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., administrator, said today.

The establishment of the Frank G. Brewer Trophy, valued at $10,000 and awarded annually for the outstanding contribution in the field of air-youth education, was announced yesterday at a special meeting of the trophy committee at the Wings Club of the Yale Club, Vanderbilt Avenue and Forty-fourth Street.

Hedge selling and liquidation in the cotton futures market yesterday ended a six-day advance. The list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the session's low levels at net losses of 1 to 10 points, with the distant positions incurring the widest declines.
NEW DELHI, India, May 21 (AP) -- A United States Tenth Air Force communique:
The Finnish Friday communique, as broadcast from Helsinki and recorded by The Associated press:

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Housewives will be able to get sugar for home canning by using Stamps 15 and 16 in Ration Book One, the Office of Price Administration said today. The revised program wipes out a plan of applying to local ration boards for coupons, as previously announced.
The end of the Tunisian campaign, coinciding with the approach of Summer and the intensification of bombing raids upon Germany, presages the beginning of the Allied assault upon Hitlerian Europe.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- President Roosevelt made public today the reports of three fact-finding boards in the railroad industry, the chief one covering a dispute over the manning and the rate of pay of employes on Diesel electric locomotives.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 -- RKO has new plans for Pearl S. Buck's novel, "China Sky," which was shelved last August when Claudette Colbert was relieved, at her request, of her commitment to star in it. The picture will be produced this Summer by Emmet Lavery and directed by Edward Dmytryk, who together made "Hitler's Children" and are now filming "Behind the Rising Sun."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Heavy bombers are being produced in the United States at a rate of more than 500 a month and schedules call for a production of at least 1,000 a month by April, 1944, Charles E. Wilson, executive vice chairman of the War Production Board, said today.

The proxy statement for the annual meeting of stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., to be held in New York on June 15, describes four resolutions to be acted on that were submitted by James Fuller, a stockholder. The management of the company advises stockholders that it opposes all four resolutions in the form presented by Mr. Fuller.

Bogged down in a mass of administrative difficulties, the Army's Specialized Training Program, scheduled to begin sending men to the nation's colleges and universities March 1, is still struggling to get under way, it was learned yesterday. As a result, only a fraction of the 150,000 men originally designated for this program has been selected and sent to the campuses.

Eric A. Johnston, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, criticized yesterday the Office of Price Administration for its failure "to inject enterprise" into the national economy in an address in which he predicted that "creative capitalism" will be the future means of raising the standard of living in this country.

Miss Helen Hall, who has been lent to the Red Cross by the Henry Street Settlement, has recently arrived here from Australia with two main thoughts on the local consumer picture. One -- on the lighter side -- keeps her wishing at mealtime that she was back in a Red Cross service club in Australia, where a steak dinner costs only one shilling, or sixteen cents.

Asserting that Clarence H. Neal Jr., leader of the Twentieth Assembly District, was the real leader of Tammany instead of Michael J. Kennedy, former Sheriff Daniel E. Finn Jr. announced yesterday that he was a candidate for re-election as Democratic leader of the western part of the First Assembly District.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- There are two schools of thought in responsible quarters in Washington about Italy and the attitude the Allies should take toward the peace feelers that have come in the form of questions about possible terms.

Several thousand girls and boys are expected to attend the annual service for the presentation of the Lenten Missionary Offerings of the Sunday Schools of the parishes in the Episcopal Diocese of New York at 2 P.M. today in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street.

NEW DELHI, India, May 21 (AP) -- United States heavy and medium bombers dropped more than 100 tons of bombs on Japanese supply lines and installations in Central Burma yesterday, the third day in succession of such heavy raids, and three R.A.F. formations maintained the pounding in other areas, it was announced today.

Otis L. Guernsey, president of Abercrombie Fitch, has leased an apartment in 975 Park Avenue through Edgar Ellinger, Inc., Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, agents. Other rentals reported yesterday included:

MOSCOW, May 21 -- Softening of German defenses by artillery fire and bombing was reported today from sectors of the front as far apart as Leningrad and the Sea of Azov. Only in the Donets Valley and in the Kuban was infantry fighting on any considerable scale reported.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 21 -- Dean Acheson, Assistant Secretary of State, announced here today that a separate international conference would be held very soon on relief for the occupied nations as they are liberated from Axis control.

Counsel for Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, rested his case late yesterday in Supreme Court in his $150,000 libel suit against the Curtis Publishing Company and Benjamin Stolberg, writer, for allegedly portraying him falsely as a "Communist and Stalinist," The trial began May 13 before Justice John F. Carew and a jury.

Two Manhattan child welfare services, the Alice Chapin Adoption Nursery and the Spence Adoption Nursery, celebrated their merging into the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service with a large dinner last night in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Construction of the "big inch" pipe line -- the war-emergency project designed to carry oil from the Texas fields to the Eastern seaboard -- met its first major disaster from the elements this week when the flooding waters of the Arkansas River caused a break in the line at Little Rock, Ark.

Over the signature of Dr. Seymour E. Harris, Director of Export-Import Price Control, Office of Price Administration, Washington, D.C., THE NEW YORK TIMES published a letter on subsidies under date of May 15.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Evening-up operations in May wheat, trading in which ceased at the close of business, sent that future today to 2 7/8 cents a bushel over July at one time on the Board of Trade. Shorts covered freely and there was also buying of May against sales of July which was attributed to cash interests.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 21 -- The Axis air forces suffered a second smashing defeat yesterday when wave upon wave of American bombers and fighters blasted airfields, communications and docks throughout the Central Mediterranean area from Grosseto, Italy, ninety miles northwest of Rome, to tiny bomb-wrecked Pantelleria Island, off Cap Bon, Tunisia.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- A 309-4 vote of the House passed and sent to the Senate late today a supplemental lend-lease appropriation of $6,273,629,000 to carry forward the program which debate and records showed to be working reciprocally to the direct and immediate benefit of hundreds of thousands of our own troops on many battlefronts.

LONDON, May 21 -- After the success of the Royal Air Force's smashing of the Moehne and Eder Dams, the Nazis were reported today rushing anti-aircraft protection and protecting nets for their remaining big dams, particularly Bleiloch Dam and power station, which feeds the Leuna nitrogen and fertilizer works and other industries of Central Germany.
LONDON, May 21 -- Nearly 1,000 Germans were killed or wounded in the battle in the Warsaw ghetto in the last two weeks when the Nazis undertook the final liquidation of the ghetto.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- The Transit companies of American cities, which maintain high standards of skill and physical fitness among employes, are combing the rapidly dwindling labor markets for women to operate street cars and motor buses and fill maintenance jobs.

In his column in THE TIMES on Monday, Arthur Daley stated that "New York apparently supports track very well as an indoor sport but refuses to give it the same cooperative enthusiasm in the great outdoors.

HENRY J. TAYLOR'S "Men in Motion"* is the work of a business man, a traveler, an informed journalist and a philosopher. The surprising thing about it is the way it all hangs together. The business man is articulate; the philosopher perceives the relationships between the abstract and the concrete, and the traveler takes the journalist to where the news is breaking.

After an ownership of ten days Frederick Brown, the operator, has resold the twin twelve-story apartment houses at 310 and 320 West Eighty-sixth Street, between Riverside Drive and West End Avenue, to an investing client of Kramer Kaprow, attorneys.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 21 -- Although the weather forced a cancellation of the main part of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association one-day tournament at the Knollwood Club today, enough members of the celebrated Turnesa family were present to hold a sweepstakes event in which first honors went to Doug, one of the famous golfing brothers, and Charley DeLucca of Orienta.

Eight executives of the Lumbermen's Mutual Casualty Company were promoted at the thirty-first annual meeting of the directors and advisory boards hold in Chicago last Wednesday, according to the announcement yesterday by James S. Kemper, president of Lumbermen's and the affiliated Kemper companies.

Emphasis on the new global geography as against the old-style thinking in flat maps may have one paradoxical result. It may do away with the use of globes altogether. After all, it was not just perversity on the part of Mr. Mercator that brought into favor flat maps printed in books.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron Levy, in the Bronx, yesterday not only denied a motion for a temporary injunction to restrain Mayor La Guardia and the city from issuing summonses to egg dealers who were accused of price ceiling violations, but asserted the Mayor should "receive unstinted commendation and approval" for his attempt to enforce the OPA regulations.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 21 (AP) -- A communique:

Ida Halpern, Marion Vuzzo and Ida Zuckerman, the three young Brooklyn girls who, according to the police, confessed to committing five daylight burglaries in Staten Island during the last two weeks, were held in $1,000 bail each by City Magistrate Charles Keutgen for the action of the Richmond County grand jury when arraigned yesterday in Felony Court at Stapleton. Unable to furnish bail, they were committed to the House of Detention in Manhattan.

Contracts for printing unfinished cotton textiles for lend-lease distribution in foreign lands are being placed with various American facilities, W.G. Galliher of the Treasury Department's procurement division announced here yesterday.

CANAAN, Vt., May 21 (AP) -- After wandering for fifty-six hours in the dense Northern Vermont woodlands, Mrs. Carol Downer, 33, of Kingston, N.Y., walked into a fire warden's station tonight, tired but otherwise in good physical condition.

ST. LOUIS, May 21 (AP) -- Veteran Johnny Niggeling's two-hit hurling against the Mackmen went for naught tonight as the Athletics capitalized on an error in the ninth inning to defeat the Browns, 2 to 1, in the first nocturnal game of the season at Sportsman's Park.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 21 -- Any change in conditions prevailing in Germany's notorious Dachau concentration camp during the past eighteen months has been for the worse, according to an informant of a Swiss religious publication, it was disclosed today.

Stockholders of the United States Lines Company of Nevada yesterday approved the plan to merge the company with International Mercantile Marine Company, which owns all of the common stock and 85 per cent of the preferred stock of the Nevada company.

LONDON, May 21 -- The Battle of Germany has already begun, thanks to Allied aerial warfare against Nazi war power, Sir Archibald Sinclair, British Air Secretary, told an audience in Edinburgh tonight.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 21 -- A pitched battle inside a Nazi submarine between members of the crew and the officers was one of the astounding revelations disclosed today when Allied officers in Pernambuco questioned the commander and crew of the Nazi submarine which surrendered three days ago to Allied warships off the coast of Alagoas.

As a result of a survey of daytime radio listening habits which revealed that only 53 per cent of housewives listen to daytime serials, while 79 per cent of the total network commercial daytime hours is devoted to such serials, the Blue Network will tailor its daytime programs to new and varied types of entertainment sought by listeners, Edgar Kobak, executive vice president, announced yesterday at a luncheon to the press at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The possibility that the city might increase its livestock slaughter pool to provide sufficient meat for the 115 voluntary hospitals was indicated yesterday by Mayor La Guardia in an address before the annual meeting of the Greater New York Hospital Association at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Curtailment of all "frills" and of many services which heretofore have been considered an integral part of retailing is the price such enterprises must pay for WMC ratings of "essentiality" in their communities, according to recommendations made to WMC by the Office of Civilian Requirements.

CLEVELAND, May 21 -- The most disappointing trip a Yankee club has made in years entered another chapter in a different locale when the scheduled first night game of the season was postponed late today because of the weather. The Yanks and Indians thereupon scheduled a nocturnal clash for tomorrow, leaving the postponed contest to fill in an open date or make a double-header on the New Yorkers' next visit.

There will be celebrated today the 124th anniversary of the departure of the steamship Savannah from Savannah on the first successful transatlantic voyage under steam. Never before in its history has national Maritime Day had so deep a significance. The "Bridge of Ships" is essential to victory.

ALGIERS, Algeria, May 21 -- General Georges Catroux, Fighting French National Commissioner on Missions and liaison officer to General Henri Honore Giraud, has left Algiers for London with a memorandum for General Charles de Gaulle from General Giraud inviting the Fighting French leader to meet him in Algiers or any other place in North Africa he desires under certain conditions, according to French political sources.

PITTSBURGH, May 21 -- As the back-to-work movement of striking soft coal miners gained impetus today, appeals of United Mine Workers officials to that end received reinforcement from Leo Krzycki, president of the American Slav Congress and a vice president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers. C.I.O.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Following is the text of the sections of the War Labor Board panel report dealing with the questions of wage adjustments, and portal-to-portal pay in soft coal mines:

LONDON, Saturday, May 22 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortresses battered the U-boat yards at Emden and naval workshops at Wilhelmshaven in Northwest Germany by daylight yesterday on the heels of the Royal Air Force's fifth night attack on Berlin in eight nights.

Seven hundred members of the bar and judges of the higher courts of New York honored Edward Ridley Finch at a dinner last night in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, marking his retirement from the Court of Appeals and his resumption of private practice. Governor Thomas E. Dewey praised Judge Finch's "loyal service to the State" and wished him success in his new undertaking.

The four-story building at 654 Elm Street, Kearny, N.J., containing thirty-three apartments, has been sold by Harry Lowy, trustee, to the Acme Realty Corporation. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker and the New Jersey Realty Company arranged the mortgage financing with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

Six Bronx youths were found guilty of rape in the second degree at 6:50 o'clock last night in the case of a mass assault upon Theresa O'Brien, 17 years old. Two others previously had pleaded guilty to the same charge.

RICHMOND, Va., May 21 -- Among the 579 patents issued during the last week, as listed in The Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office, a significant number went to chemical investigators, who received patents on various hydrocarbon processes having to do with oil chemistry.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Congressional conference on pay-as-you-go taxation ended its second day of discussion today apparently in an unbreakable deadlock.

Continued perversity of the weather, which earlier in the week raised havoc with the American League clubs sloshing through the West, struck the National League's current scene of operations in the East yesterday, when all four games were postponed.

Jose Ferrer, the actor, has acquired a play in verse which he plans to produce on Broadway next Fall. Entitled "Night Song," it is the work of Howard D. Richardson, an Army Air Forces cadet now stationed at Maxwell Field, Ala. The play, which will have music by Douglas Moore, is based on "a North Carolina version of the Barbara Allen legend."
LONDON, Saturday, May 22 (U.P.) -- The Soviet Friday midnight communique as broadcast from Moscow:

The Dutch Treat Club, an informal association of writers, artists, statesmen and editors, held its thirty-eighth annual dinner last night in the ballroom of the Park Lane Hotel. The traditional "show," lampooning current topics and contemporary business, political and professional leaders was not presented because of the war.
VALLETTA, Malta, May 21 (AP) -- A communique:

A four-point program to protect the entire food industry from "oppressive" regulations of the Office of Price Administration was proposed tentatively at a meeting of the New York Retail Grocers Conference yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Secretary Hull declared his opposition to the amendment of the Senate Finance Committee to the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Bill in a vigorous statement today. The amendment, sponsored by Senator John A. Danaher, Republican, of Connecticut, would make trade agreements revocable by Congress or by Presidential proclamation.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Attorney General Biddle announced today a Federal indictment at Denver charging that two bureaus, seven concerns and twenty individuals conspired in violation of the anti-trust laws to prevent independent rate making by motor carriers through "intimidation, boycott and other coercive practices," and thus deprived the shipping public of low cost freight transportation by truck in fourteen States.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 22 (AP) -- The pace of the air war all over the Southwest Pacific was stepped up sharply yesterday with good success for Allied fighters and bombers in combat with Japanese Zeros.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- A separate training program will be set up for officers and enlisted personnel of the Women's Reserve of the Coast Guard.
EARLY tomato plants go out into the open garden now, if they have not already been placed in their permanent quarters.
Mrs. Andre de Limur and her daughter, Miss Mary de Limur, have arrived from Washington and are at the St. Regis.

SHORTLY after we entered the war the spotlight was thrown upon a serious condition of fascist activity in America, stimulated and nurtured by German funds. Working on their principle of dividing and conquering, the Nazis in this country had endeavored to organize the Negroes in Northern metropolitan centers against the domination of the whites.

Retail trade here continued active last week despite inclement weather. Some stores had increases ranging up to 20 per cent over the comparative 1942 week. The department store average, however, according to estimates, will run well below that figure.

Recognition of home-keeping mothers as "war workers of the highest rank" is urged by the United States Children's Bureau in its new bulletin, "Community Action for Children." (Publication No. 295, 5 cents, from United States Government Printing Office.) The bureau holds that "Mothers who work at home, building buoyant health and spirits in their children, are doing essential war work, just as surely as mothers who take jobs outside the home."

MONTICELLO -- One principal activity of Sullivan County resorts this year will be the sale of war bonds, in furtherance of a campaign begun last Summer. It is estimated that five to ten million dollars in bonds will be disposed of by Labor Day.

Medical services at nominal rates will be made possible for persons of low incomes if recommendations proposed by the Committee on Medical Economics of the Medical Society of the County of New York are accepted by representatives of the city government and citizens interested in the plan.

MASSACRE BAY, Attu, May 17 (Delayed) -- American troops are in possession of the west arm, Holtz Bay, after seven days of fighting and are now on the ridge looking into the east arm, Holtz Bay, according to reports from Navy Catalina fliers and from front-line firing positions.

A BOLD and stinging statement was issued the other day by Harry M. Warner, president of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc. Completely out of patience with a growing agitation in some parts to persuade the picture industry that the public is fed up with war films, Mr. Warner landed with both feet on what he termed "that small group of entertainment appeasers * * * who are trying to keep the truth from audiences."

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Approximately 600,000 tons of medical supplies, food, fuel, clothing and other necessities of life required by the civilian population of French North Africa have been shipped from the United States and Great Britain, the Office of War Information said today.

ALBANY, May 22 -- The executive committee of the New York State Bar Association, in a telegram today to Senator Walter F. George, chairman of the Conference Committee of Congress, urged swift adoption of a reasonable pay-as-you-go income tax plan which wil lexclude "the injustice of double taxation."

SOAPWORT is a rather common roadside plant growing in the poorest gravelly soil. But it may be used very successfully in a rock garden and its many names suggest its homely virtues -- Bouncing Bet, Boston pink, chimney pink, hedge pink, crow pink, Fuller's herb, wood phlox and Wild Sweet William. The correct botanical name is Saponaria.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Congressional tax conferees were still deadlocked when they finished their deliberations today, but resolved to confer again on Monday in a last effort to end the four-month impasse on a pay-as-you-go tax bill.

MODERN art, the art of our own century -- and in particular art that was produced within the once so fertile and prolific Ecole de Paris -- has of late been leaving New York in considerable abundance. The suspicious or superstitious might ask: Can there be some sort of conspiracy at work?

THIS reviewer believes that mathematics as taught in our schools and colleges carries an excess of ballast, by which it is unnecessarily and undesirably weighted down and complicated, and hopes that in the course of time there will be an attractive reform.

Sixty divisional heads representing forty-three industrial fields are working with Medley G.B. Whelpley chairman of the industry section of the Greater New York Fund in its current drive, he announced yesterday.

WAR'S lexicon has been enriched by a new and meaningful word -- "radar." Its definition is not to be found in any published dictionary. Until very recently the word itself was under military restriction. But now that radar has been successfully employed against the enemy for many months and in many theatres of operation, some of the basic facts about it can be told.

Eugene Hinck Remmer of Oakdale, L.I., has been named salutatorian and Gilbert Meredith Turner of Fair Haven, N.J., has been chosen valedictorian of the Columbia College senior class, which will be graduated June 1, the office of the dean announced yesterday.

Jacob Pomer makes a fine distinction, according to the Office of Price Administration, between the sale of genuine gasoline ration coupons, which is illegal, and the sale of counterfeit coupons, which is doubly illegal.
CHUNGKING, China, May 22 (U.P.) -- Outnumbered poorly equipped Chinese troops battled savagely today to stop an accelerating Japanese offensive supported by planes and artillery in Central China.

NOW that we are going the V-V way, our new education food will be made easy by Mrs. Harris's new book. For the inveterate vitamin hunter, for a basic daily food list for a normal healthy adult with a variety of 400 recipes to choose from, this book should take first place on the cook-book shelf.

Although by now most war contractors have learned that the Treasury's decisions govern the subject of adequate financial reserves to be allowed for post-war reconversion, renegotiation officials reported yesterday that they were still encountering instances where contractors try to justify their attempts to set aside arbitrary amounts of current profits to cover anticipated reconversion costs.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- Roman Catholic High of Philadelphia won its first junior eight-oared shell championship in the ninth annual regatta of the Schoolboy Rowing Association of America on the Schuylkill River today, finishing one length ahead of St. Andrew's School of Middletown, Del.

THE thirteenth annual American Folksong Festival will be held Sunday, 13, at Traipsin' Woman cabin, near Ashland, Ky. The festival, devoted to the type of music presented at the singing gatherings of the Kentucky mountain folk, will be directed by Jean Thomas.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- Aggressive short covering and general commission-house buying today lifted rye futures 1 5/8 to 2 cents a bushel over yesterday's close, and while there was considerable profit-taking, closing sales on the Board of Trade were at the top.

Main floor departments continued to draw heavy crowds in active retail trade last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer-Both Reports.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- The veteran Johnny Adams guided J.H. Rouse's 5-year-old gelding, Three Percent, to a four-length victory today in the opening-day feature of the seventy-three-day Detroit race meeting, but Jockey Paul Keiper seized riding honors before an overflow crowd of 20,848 at the State Fair Grounds.
Attendance at some minor league baseball games definitely has been hurt by the weather this season, but the nine circuits are doing right well at the turnstiles.
In an exhibition match at Livingston, Staten Island, yesterday, the Brooklyn Cricket Club triumphed over a British Navy eleven by a margin of 68 runs, with one wicket to spare.

MEXICO CITY -- Conditions brought about by the war have hit Mexico's tourist trade just as they have hit that of other countries in the Western Hemisphere. Yet Mexico, because of its proximity to the United States, beautiful scenery, picturesque towns and customs, pleasant climate and hospitable, courteous people, has continued to draw a respectable number of foreigners.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Secretary Morgenthau reported today that the Second War Loan campaign which raised more than $18, 000,000,000, was supported by 73, 938 newspaper advertisements worth $4,564,270.

JERUSALEM, May 22 -- Zionism today faces its most acute and baffling deadlock since the contemporary political Zionist movement began fifty years ago. The recent Anglo-American Conference on Refugees, held in Bermuda, brought about that deadlock.

LONDON, May 22 (U.P.) -- Danish patriots, ignoring King Christian's appeal to cease sabotage lest existing relations with Germany be severed because of it, have dynamited two German-controlled shipyards at Svendborg and Aalbord, Danish quarters reported tonight.

CARLOS ARROYO DEL RIO, Ecuador's President, plans to come to the United States soon to return the visit of Vice President Wallace to Quito last month. The General Stamp Company is informed that Ecuador will issue special stamps to commemorate Dr. Arroyo del Rio's journey.

THOSE who are curious about the post-war future, here and elsewhere, will find material for reflection in these two books. Mr. Motherwell's, which deals mostly with Europe, contains a prognosis and a prescription.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 22 -- Reporters won a partial victory today when in their fight for free conference at reasonable hours with the delegates at the United Nations conference on food and agriculture in the Homestead Hotel.

ONE looked forward to the concerts of Yehudi Menuhin with pleasure and also, if the truth be told, with some little anxiety. In his London visits the exceptionally gifted violinist had shown such a singular mixture of styles that one wondered what the now full-fledged artist had to show us.

Special Maritime Day memorial services were held at 10 A.M. yesterday at the Fort Schuyler Armory, the Bronx, in commemoration of twenty graduates of the New York State Maritime Academy and the Naval Training School who have lost their lives in the present war.

ROBERT GREENWOOD'S first fictional venture, "Mr. Bunting in Peace and War," though sound, good stuff, did not prepare one for the full measure of beauty, dramatic force and artistic rightness of his second, now published less than eighteen months later. "The Squad Goes Out" is alive with both maturity and youth -- a tested maturity and a burgeoning Springtide youthfulness.

The Grace Line this year celebrates the fiftieth anniversary of the establishment of its regularly scheduled steamship service between New York and the West Coast of South America. The company at the same time also marks the fiftieth anniversary of its first large fleet of specially constructed steamships which replaced the sailing ships used on that route in the first decades of its history.

OTTAWA, May 22 -- Prime Minister Churchill's commendation, in his speech to Congress, of the "massive and invaluable contribution'' that Canada has made to the war was heard throughout this country with satisfaction. But it has not served to quiet that growing criticism of the administration that rises daily from the press and the opposition parties in the House of Commons.

IN the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow afternoon a cocktail dance will be given in the interests of underprivileged children of Manhattan, many of whose parents are engaged in war-production activities. Proceeds from the fete will be directed to the New York Kindergarten Association for the advancement of its work.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 22 -- East Hampton will have many newcomers in its Summer colony this year, and while there will be little in the way of social activity there will be many war-relief projects to keep every one busy during the season.

WORKING girls become "taxi dance" hostesses on Monday evenings, when the New York City Defense Recreation Committee holds a service men's dance at Broadway's Arcadia ballroom. Instead of ticket strips at "ten cents a dance," free tickets are distributed at the committee's headquarters, 99 Park Avenue.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 -- Reelection of President Roosevelt as a patriotic necessity if the war is not over by Summer of next year was called for today by Dean Alfange, former American Labor party nominee for Governor of New York, in a speech at the constitutional convention of the United Labor Committee of Philadelphia in Town Hall here.

LIKE the Great Wall of China, the walls of American isolation have crumbled forever. Throughout America -- North, South, East, West and Middle West -- the people are determined to drive through to complete victory in this war -- victory for our arms and for our principles, cost what it may.

LONDON, Sunday, May 23 (AP) -- Russian airmen and gunners destroyed sixty-five German planes out of a large formation that attacked Kursk, a main base supplying Red Army troops threatening Axis-held Orel, eighty miles to the north, Moscow announced early today.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- Now that the unique "dimout curtain," the mile-long canvas screen which is lowered along the Boardwalk at night to prevent the glare of lights being seen to seaward, has been completed, the Summer season will officially open here with the Memorial Day week-end.

The record number of buyers who have been actively placing orders for women's Fall apparel during the last three weeks still face the major problem of obtaining deliveries on their commitments. An intensive follow-up job remains to be done and indications are that many buyers will return here during the latter part of June and early in July to see how their orders are coming along.

THE American Revolution is well served by a general story such as this. The novel follows its course from the Williamsburg reverberations of the Boston Tea Party to the surrender at Yorktown a few miles away.

THEY were marching to mess, these jubilant Waves at the Hunter College training school. To the tune of "This Is the Army" the long line of blue-clad women fitted words that applied to them. Heads high, voices true and clear, they breezed along. The rhythm of the tune punctuated every step of their way.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- While others have concentrated on broader aspects of post-war planning the Fine Arts Commission has been hard at work on a blueprint for making Washington a suitable world capital in the era of peace to come.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- The War Labor Board today ordered a three-cents-an-hour wage increase for "Big Four" rubber workers. Learning of the strikes at Akron, it called on the workers to return to their jobs at once.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 22 (AP) -- Liberators of the Ninth United States Air Force rained some 150 tons of high-explosive and incendiary bombs on the Italian ports of San Giovanni and Reggio Calabria yesterday and shot down ten enemy fighters and damaged others, it was announced today.

BOSTON, May 22 -- Coming from far back in the stretch, Henry H. Haag's Devalue, an 8-1 shot in the mutuels, scored a half-length triumph today in the $5,000 added Paul Revere Handicap at Suffolk Downs before 17,960 persons.

WALDO FRANK'S "America Hispana," published in 1931, was as popular in Latin America as his classic book, "Virgin Spain," had been in Spain itself. Therefore, he recently went among our southern neighbors as an old friend who had earned the right to be critical as well as appreciative, to be candid and truthful, instead of cagily diplomatic.

Sicily is now under such heavy bombardment that it can no longer supply Italy and Germany with sulphur, and without sulphur the chemical and metallurgical industries of both countries will find it hard to make sulphuric acid, fertizers, pulp, explosives, insecticides, fungicides and several thousand other essentials.

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine yesterday notified members of his department of an amendment to the Police Department Rules and Regulations wherein the identity of juvenile delinquents, neglected children and victims of sex crimes are not to be revealed to the press henceforth.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill received leading members of Congress at a cocktail party at the British Embassy this afternoon.

FOR THE COMING WEEK: Last call to get the lawn into good condition to go through the Summer -- reseed bare spots, remove perennial weeds, and apply compost or manure if it is available. . . . . Succession plantings of early sown crops -- lettuce, beets, carrots -- go in now, if not already seeded.

RAGNAR SVEDJE, a poor Swedish farmer, was once unjustly condemned to death. About 300 years later, in our own time, a native writer dug him up again from the dust of archives. Novels from archives often smell of dust, but this one does not.

A protest against a War Labor Board wage award closed the plants of Akron's three chief rubber companies yesterday and workers in some other plants walked out in sympathy. About 40,000 C.I.O. workers went on strike and 12,000 more workers were made idle.

WELLINGTON, N.Z., May 22 -- British-born Anthony M. Singer and Peter I. Singer, 24-year-old twins, topped their strangely parallel careers in New Zealand's air force today by appearing in the same honor list as having won Distinguished Flying Crosses for bombing operations over Europe.

The Giants hurled theselves into the path of the world champions at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but all it got them was a double thrashing for the price of a single admission, a performance scarcely appreciated by 9,950 onlookers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 22 -- The dissolution of the Comintern came today as one of the greatest surprises to German political circles. Their stupefaction is exemplified by vain attempts to explain Moscow's latest move.

DETROIT, May 22 -- The Ford Willow Run bomber plant, which has been the problem child of war production, "no longer is the No. 1 manpower headache," according to a report issued this week by the Detroit district of the War Manpower Commission.
DODGE CITY, Kan., May 22 -- Governor Andrew Schoeppel and his Farm Labor Commission conducted a survey of Kansas farm areas this week to mobilize men, women and children for food production.
ROASTER PEANUTS lend distinction to your favorite muffin recipe. Add a half-cup of chopped nuts to the batter, pour into tins and place a whole nut on top of each muffin.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The Navy Department today announced that the battle for the island of Attu in the Aleutians had "entered the final phase," and almost simultaneously the Tokyo radio reported that American forces had reached a point only a quarter of a mile from the last Japanese resistance and were "being constantly reinforced by new landings."

CAMDEN, N.J., May 22 -- Another small aircraft carrier, the second to bear the name Langley, converted from a cruiser during hull construction, was launched today at the yards of the New York Ship Building Corporation here.

" ARKANSAW." says Mr. Masterson, in a suggestive preface to an interesting and valuable book, "is a mirage hovering over the soil of Arkansas." By that he means that, like the shadow of a substance, an emanation compounded of slow trains, hound dogs, fiddle tunes, moonshine, chawin' terbaccer and such, rises like an exhalation from the swamps and mountains of Arkansaw.

Members of the executive and transportation committees of the New York State Public High School Athletic Association met here yesterday and saw "bright hopes" for continuation of school sports next year.
LONDON, May 22 -- Each Axis partner in Europe seems to be doing its own worrying about where the Allied invasion will take place. That it will occur they seem no longer to doubt.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 22 -- Eighty-six Axis planes were destroyed in the latest twenty-four-hour period of the continuing Allied offensive to drive the enemy from the advanced air bases that guard the Mediterranean Narrows and Southern Europe, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The unpredictable John L. Lewis has done it again. As a creator of public surprises that set tongues wagging, the president of the United Mine Workers of America achieved a major effect when he applied for readmission to the American Federation of Labor.
