While American bombers rained blows on the vast perimeter of Nipponese conquests in the South and Central Pacific, American ground forces struck at the enemy in the far North. In a smashing attack Army ground forces, aided by the Navy, pinched off one of two Japanese spearheads that had menaced Alaska from the fog-bound Aleutians.

The broad lines of Allied global strategy were laid down within the month that followed Pearl Harbor. Germany, counted the most powerful foe of the United Nations, was marked for defeat first. A harassing war upon Japan was planned until the full weight of Allied might could be brought to bear following the defeat of Germany.

A plan for increasing the amount of meat available and effecting a more equitable distribution by means of subsidies to farmers and the creation of national and local allocation boards under the WPB has been developed by the OPA New York District Labor Advisory Council and forwarded to the proper OPA officials, Russell H. Potter, acting OPA district director announced yesterday.

CAPTAIN FREDERICK WAY is well on the way to getting himself called the Mark Twain of the Ohio River. Like Mark, he is a good pilot, a very likable fella both in and out of his books; and, like Mark again, he brings to writing the interest in people, the rich colloquial style, and the perception of the humors of living which distinguish both the Western waters and the Western lands.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A Presidential Executive Order to protect export and import statistics from giving aid to the enemy, but which is said to have been so interpreted and administered as to deny the American public information even on the number of cantaloupes shipped to Canada since Pearl Harbor, faced Senate consideration today along with the legislation extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Program.

AFRICAN Daisies (Gerbera jamesoni), hybrids, have attained in the last few years great popularity as cut flowers. The classic beauty of the long, graceful stems bearing the delicately curved petals of the daisy heads, their long-lasting cualities and their magnificent colors, ranging from white and cream through gorgeous pastel shades to orange and red, have caused many amateurs to wonder whether they can be grown in the open garden.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Definite prospect was held out by the State Department today for the return of approximately 1,500 more American civilians held by the Japanese in return for the exchange of an equal number of Japanese civilians from this country.

THE Japanese on Kiska Island call it "the cesspool of information," but to United States troops on remote, cold assignments it is the last connecting link with civilization, being their primary source of news and entertainment. Such is the wartime role of one of America's more interesting and important stations, KFAR, in Fairbanks, Alaska, whose enterprising manager, Wilson (Bud) Foster, was a visitor here last week.

THE Spring spraying program for fruit trees is all important. A thorough job done early in the season is much more than half the Spring battle. Unfortunately there are many gardeners to whom the mere mention of spraying brings immediate discouragement.
LONDON, May 22 -- The text of the resolution of the Presidium of the Executive Committee of the Communist International, as broadcast by Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

IT has been pretty well established by psychiatrists that what happens to us in the first critical years of our childhood is a prime determining factor in the kind of men and women we turn out to be. This is true of plays as well as human beings.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The names, with next of kin, of 409 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwestern Pacific areas were made public today by the War Department.

ANDOVER, Mass., May 22 -- Dick Hall, Exeter Academy undefeated miler, and Jim Burnham and Steve McKee of Andover, fashioned record-breaking performances as Exeter took over Andover's New England preparatory school track and field championship by 89 points to 81 1/2 in the fourth annual sectional meet today.

THE berries or fruits which are formed on roses after flowering have come into prominence for their valuable vitamin C content, and are proving to be extremely useful in many ways. Correctly called "hips," these small red globes are well worth gathering and utilizing.

THE young child's pride in being considered "big" and "grown-up" can be an asset when the new baby arrives, and reminders to let the older child help in caring for the infant are not new. But as in so much counsel on bringing up children, it's not so much what you do as how you do it.

DETROIT, May 22 -- The Four Freedoms "are a reaffirmation of the Christmas messages of Pope Pius XII since 1939," it is declared in a monograph, "Quest of the Centuries: Peace," published today by Marygrove College.

Merchant ships constitute an earth-girdling "lifeline upon which the future of the world depends," Captain Edward Macauley, U.S.N., retired, deputy war shipping administrator, declared last night in an address before the Propeller Club of the United States, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) -- A Congressional investigation into the activities at the big red house at 2101 R Street and of John P. Monroe, host there to many of the capital's prominent persons, ended today with Chairman May of the House Military Committee declaring that "we found no criminal conduct."

At the end of the first full year Of academic instruction under the accelerated war program, colleges and universities throughout the country report that they have become adjusted to the changed campus conditions brought about by the war emergency.

YOU cannot enter a bookstore nowadays without noting the unusual number of pamphlets displayed on its counters. There is more than one explanation of this revival of a form of publication which until recently had gone out of fashion.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- Henry Armstrong, still stepping briskly up the come-back trail, took from his mouth the pipe that he never smokes, and said a few kind words about the new king of the lightweights.

The subway passenger is carrying a box as big as a suitcase, holding it flat and looking uncomfortable. Out of the box come sounds audible even in the roar of the train; sounds of something alive, saying, "Peep! peep!"

Maritime Day was observed yesterday at the Maritime Service Training Station, Sheepshead Bay, with a review of the station personnel and a series of events in which the apprentice seamen demonstrated their ability.

LETTERS of Washington and other founding fathers, as well as documents concerning governmental matters of a century and a half ago, will go on sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Monday and Tuesday evenings.
The annual report of the Phillips Packing Company and its subsidiaries disclosed yesterday a net profit of $770,780 for its fiscal year ended on March 31.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) -- With Schoolboy Rowe hurling a four-hit shut-out, the Phillies swamped the Pirates, 10 to 0, before 11,692 fans at Shibe Park tonight for their sixth straight victory.

With Mayor La Guardia describing it as another expression of the cordiality and helpfulness that the city feels for all men in uniform, the new service men's dormitory, a project of the Masonic war chest committee of the Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York, was dedicated yesterday at Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Economists, including quite a few who are sane -- it has been quite a trick for an economist to remain sane in the years since 1932 -- are discussing the plan of Lord Keynes for a post-war world. A sample of their arguments was presented on this page on May 9 in the report of a debate at the New School for Social Research.

SMALL sculpture and drawings by Herbert Ferber are on view at the Midtown. Ferber's work has impact but seems to me to possess an overplus of stress which -- combined with grimness of subject as in "Marsyas Flayed" and one or two others -- threatens to break away from certain implicit plastic obligations of inner repose, "Conspirators," a bronze group of sinister aspect, is one of Ferber's best pieces.

With two major ballet companies in town, yesterday's performances in that medium numbered four. The particular novelty of the day at the Broadway Theatre, where the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo is in residence, was the first of two appearances by Agrees de Mille as guest star in her own ballet, "Rodeo."

BUENOS AIRES, May 22 (AP) -- Workers' representatives in Buenos Aires and elsewhere tended to agree that dissolution of the Com-intern would contribute to the consolidation of Leftist elements that have been divided in the past over the Communists' presumed subservience to Moscow.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An estimate that the lowest paid Army private receives the equivalent of $1,700 a year came tonight from the Office of War Information, which said that the estimate was made by Representative Patman of Texas, assisted by the War and Navy Departments and the Veterans Administration.

LONDON, May 22 -- The British Labor party's national executive committee has informed all organizations within the party that the maintenance of the electoral truce -- in other words, the support of the national government under Prime Minister Churchill -- is imperative both for the prosecution of the war and for planning for peace.

ALBANY, May 22 -- The first major Republican appointments to the State Labor Department were announced today by Paul E. Lockwood, secretary to Governor Dewey. They included a deputy commissioner industrial and two assistant commissioners.

BOSTON, May 22 -- Boston baseball fans threw two fast strikes at Eddie Joost even before he hit town but today they're hailing him -- and rightfully so -- as the sparkplug of the early season surge of the Braves.

NEVER again should it be bandied about that the Hollywood heart is hard. Believe it or not, the story goes that when Cheryl Walker was chosen as the unknown actress who would play the part of Eileen in the forthcoming "Stage Door Canteen," Producer Sol Lesser cried.

VALLEY COTTAGE, N.Y., May 22 -- Howard McElroy, who was the despair of truant officers in his boyhood, is being sought again in the Rockland County hills in which he used to take refuge when school became boring, which was often.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The National War Labor Board began considering the report of its panel on the bituminous coal controversy today amid reports that a substantial wage increase would be recommended by next Wednesday, if not sooner.

THE Island may have the usual Hollywood backdrop of a languorous tropic moon, the gentle caress of ocean waves on its shores and the lavish splash of lush vegetation. But for Lieut. Comdr. James H. Crowley it is merely a place where he is working hard and doing his bit to win the war as rapidly as possible.

JASPER, Texas, May 22 -- Representative Martin Dies, informed of the Moscow action to dissolve the Communist International, said tonight the move would probably result in the dissolution of his Congressional Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- Despite travel restrictions, Litchfield County, heart of Connecticut's vacation area, is looking forward to one of its busiest Summers in many years. Its proximity to New York makes this section ideal for those who have only a short time to stay, yet there is much to hold the interest of those who come for an extended visit.

DEHYDRATION, which is one way to preserve the crops from Victory Gardens, may be carried through successfully without the scarce materials that most canning entails -- pressure cookers, sugar, rubber.

MASSACRE BAY, Attu Island, May 14 (Delayed) (AP) -- Reinforced American invasion forces continued to push toward the high passes of Attu today against stubborn Japanese opposition which was selling each foot of soggy ground at the highest possible price.

Baseball has been a sport at New York University since 1873, but no Violet nine ever achieved as fine a record as did the current outfit, which concluded its season at Ohio Field yesterday with a 3-0 victory over Brooklyn College.

Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday, after a public hearing in his office at City Hall, that he would sign a local law designating as McCarthy Square the triangle at Seventh Avenue, Charles Street and Waverly Place in Greenwich Village, to commemorate the heroism of Private Bernard McCarthy of the Marine Corps, who was killed in action on Guadalcanal.

WITH "Saludos Amigos" currently making the rounds of the nation's theatres and "Surprise Package" practically ready for inspection, Walt Disney is planning to salute cinematically another of our Latin-American neighbors.

PLYMOUTH, Wis., May 22 (AP) -- The Wisconsin Cheese Makers Association will join with the State Agriculture Department's dairy division in appealing for revision of ration point values on cheese, it was announced today.

AMONG the many books about Japan that have appeared since Pearl Harbor this is one of the few that could fairly be called indispensable for its high informational content. The author has learned about as much as any foreigner could learn about the organization and psychology and training and general make-up of the Japanese Army.

VERY different in appearance from the housewife as traditionally pictured is Mrs. Leone Crowlie, lately appointed the American housewives' consultant at the Office of Price Administration. In the dark tailored suit, white shirtwaist and low-heeled tan calf shoes she usually wears at OPA, she might be a successful professional woman or an executive of big business.

A CONCERT in memory of Sergei Rachmaninoff will be presented by the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, Tuesday night, June 1, in Carnegie Hall. The program will be devoted to compositions by Rachmaninoff, who was an ASCAP member.

The Jewish Welfare Board's ministry to men and women in the armed forces was hailed by rabbis here yesterday, market in the synagogue as "Jewish Welfare Board Sabbath." Prime Minister Churchill's speech to Congress was another sermon topic.

Garnering places in fifteen of the sixteen events figuring in the team score, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's well-balanced squad regained the senior division laurels in the twenty-sixth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools outdoor track and field championships at Baker Field yesterday.

The new 1943 schedule of the Metropolitan Golf Association lists thirty-six tournaments for the coming season. The first of the fixtures is slated on Wednesday when a one-day tournament will be held at the Cherry Valley Club, Garden City, L.I.

DETROIT, May 22 (AP) -- Paul (Dizzy) Trout and Jimmy Bloodworth combined today to give the Tigers their second straight victory over the Red Sox, 4 to 0, with Trout pitching a two-hitter for his fourth successive triumph, and Bloodworth driving in all four runs.

MR. SONNICHSEN uses graphic strokes in portraying the rascality and rowdiness of Tombstone, Ariz., during the last two decades of the nineteenth century. The legend started, says Sonnichsen, with Ed Schieffelin's discovery of silver in 1877 where skeptics had predicted he would find nothing but his tombstone.

LONDON, May 22 -- Oliver Lyttelton, Minister of Production, cited impressive but guarded statistics today showing that British plane production was making huge strides and that it had not even yet reached its peak.

A TRANSATLANTIC cover, flown by the late Italian Marshal Italo Balbo from Rome to Rio de Janeiro in 1931, is one of 150 donations of stamps, covers and other philatelic material thus far received from collectors and dealers in all parts of the country for auctioning for the benefit of the United Service Organizations.

CHUNGKING, China, May 22 -- According to Shao Yu-lin of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Japan has made considerable progress in the past year organizing and developing plunder from occupied territories. Although unwilling to put the government's imprimatur on estimated annual totals he has figures indicating that large quantities of rice, salt, coal, iron, rubber, oil, tin and wolfram are being taken from China, French Indo-China, Thailand, Burma, Malaya and the Netherlands Indies.
MOST of us are already acquainted with Mrs. Paterson's brilliant Olympianisms on current questions. Here at last is an ordered statement of her political and economic opinions.

Starting on Saturday, the yacht racing season on Long Island Sound will open for the Summer session, and from then on through September a total of thirty-nine regattas will be held by the various clubs in the Sound Association, the fleets of all being combined in each.

WE are heading eastward -- toward war. It was midnight when the destroyer slipped her lines from the bollards at the navy yard pier and stood down river. The captain conned her through the harbor traffic with an order to the wheel now and again; and now she lifts and falls -- the gray shapes of the convoy behind her -- to the surge of the open sea.

IF Milton could read our twentieth century books about him he would surely conclude that he must have been at least what Topsy and Eva like to call "twinsies." We have been told that he was a great moral hero and a monster.

The Silver Screen Canteen, opened three weeks ago in the old Friars Club, 110 West Forty-eighth Street, as a recreation center for enlisted men already is proving inadequate for handling the large number of visiting service men, officials of the canteen said yesterday.

The Morgan Strassers of Pittsburgh will meet the Brooklyn Hispanos, Eastern champions, in the final of the National Challenge Cup soccer competition at Starlight Park, the Bronx, today. The game will follow a preliminary between the Richelieu Marines and the Royal Netherlands Navy, scheduled for 1:30 P.M.

Interest appeared to be lacking on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Stock prices drifted narrowly and closed mixed. Trading was dull, with volume of 433,380 shares, the smallest since Jan. 23, against 640,210 on May 15. Only 670 issues were traded. Of these 278 rose, 191 fell and 201 were unchanged.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- There has been the same uncertainty about the military news available here this week as about the weather. The days known throughout the Slav world as the Three Kings -- windy, wet days alarming to farmers -- have fallen within the week.

PAINTINGS by Forain, in a small but valuable collection representing the first one-man show of that artist's paintings to be held here, will be placed on exhibition from Wednesday through June 12 to formally open the exhibition rooms in the new headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies at 457 Madison Avenue -- the former Fahnestock mansion.

The four top-seeded players in the William Howard Taft Eastern interscholastic tennis tournament advanced to the semi-finals yesterday at the Concourse Tennis Club, close by the Yankee Stadium.

THE St. Nicholas Club for Service Men, situated at 16 West Forty-eighth Street in the heart of Rockefeller Center, will celebrate its first anniversary next Saturday with an afternoon reception for its many friends and supporters and a dance in the evening for its junior hostesses and men in the armed forces of the United Nations.

THIS book by Mrs. Adams, who added to culinary history as food editor of the newspaper PM at one time, is in two parts. The first part deals with seasoned menus and the second with the recipes. All the recipes are measured to serve four people.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 22 -- Politically, no doubt, Italy is seething as much as any country in Europe -- the more so, perhaps, because internal developments there run true to type, Machiavellian and subtle, calling for expert knowledge for correct appraisal.

DETROIT, May 22 -- Less than 2,000 of 29,000 striking Chrysler Corporation workers returned to their jobs today and an additional 2,900 employes of the Chrysler tank arsenal were sent home for lack of parts from strike-bound supply plants, company officials said.

" MAKE mine a frosted." That used to be the way to order a drink at the corner drug store. It is now the request for a permanent wave -- a new and cold and utterly painless wave that takes place in half the former time, and is almost a relief from the heat of the Summer.
IMAGINATION and an adventurous spirit are the very essence of good cooking. This much underrated art can be the greatest fun in the world if approached with verve.

An end to factional strife and the beginning of an era of domestic peace within Bolivia are indicated in an interchange of correspondence between General Enrique Penaranda, President of the country, who is now in Mexico City, and his former political opponent, Dr. Jose Antonio Arze, chairman of the Left Revolutionary party in Bloivia.

TO distinguish American-made antique furniture from British pieces takes an experienced eye, as an exhibition of English Sources of American Designs at the gallery of Ginsburg Levy, 36 East Fifty-seventh Street, suggests.

Formation of an Austrian Freedom Front by the underground anti-Nazi movement in Austria to maintain a state of war between the conquered Austrian people and "the Nazi-Prussians" was reported yesterday in a document made public by the American Federation of Austrian Democrats, 1819 Broadway.

GEORGE JESSEL is indulging in the autobiographical at the age of 44. He has entitled his book "So Help Me," but the obvious ends there. His is no routine stage biography cooked to order by a comical ghost writer but a singularly personal work that is both fascinating and irritating, not alone for what it tells of the show business but also for its revelations of one of the more complex publicized figures of today.

WHILE Memorial Day falls on Sunday this year the following day will be generally observed as a legal holiday. Schools, banks and many offices will be closed, giving many workers a three-day leave. Some near-by hotels are already pretty well booked for the holiday.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- An announcement by the Office of Price Administration that it would issue tomorrow dollars-and-cents community-wide pricing for general grocery commodities in all stores in more than 130 metropolitan centers, and another that red stamp "J," worth 16 points of rationed meats and fats, would be valid throughout June to prevent a last-minute rush on retailers, were two of today's developments on the food front.
This is the first of a series of ten articles on recent developments in expert bidding methods.

PEOPLE did considerable running around in Johnsonian circles, picking up the great man's epigrams as he dropped them, slipping out of the room to jot them down for posterity or the next social gathering, and hurrying back to catch his newest observation.

IT is about a quarter of a century since the Sitwells first sprang their works and themselves on London. There were Edith and Osbert; then there came along the youugest brother, Sacheverel, ten years Edith's junior. They were an exciting trio; they admired themselves tremendously and also their ancestors, and were given to public and printed expression of both admirations.

ANY one trying to learn about the armed services will find a wealth of information in this book, written by two newspaper men with long experience in the reporting of government news, one serving in the Army, the other, far removed, at his desk in New York.

With the colorful background of 1,000 choristers, wearing gowns of many hues in a procession at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the annual service for the presentation of missionary offerings by the children throughout the Episcopal Diocese was held yesterday under the sponsorship of the Diocesan Board of Religious Education.

It is perhaps too early to judge what effect the drastic gasoline curtailment win have on the general picture of recreational sport fishing in the East at a time when so many contemplated spending some of their leisure in the highly recommended outdoors.

NOW comes another "reader" about wars and battles. Ben Ames Williams, a weaver of spells and a practiced teller of tales, draws down from musty shelves, and from shelves not so musty, thirty-four accounts of American fighting men in action.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Rarely has there been a more striking demonstration of the vitality of democracy, or of what some would call its recklessness, than was given on Wednesday at the Capitol when the Prime Minister of Great Britain virtually took part in a Congressional debate by discussing publicly the military strategy of the Allies, while much of the world, including the enemies of the Allies, listened by radio.

Announcement was made yesterday by the Huntington Yacht Club that it will hold a distance race next Sunday during the daylight hours. It is the first scheduled event of that sort for the season. Unfortunately, it will come on the opening day of the Long Island Sound championship season

THE two most remarkable kinds of books on fact and theory in this country today are probably those about the world in the making and those about the American past. Apart from the publisher's desire to share the market, the only good reason for putting out a new book on American history is that it contains new materials or a fresh interpretation.

THE owners of small gardens often hesitate to plant squashes, both because of the general opinion that they require an immense space and because there seems little chance for variety in cooking. Just fried or boiled and mashed, they grow monotonous.
WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Protocol, the code of international politeness, is meeting some of the toughest handling of its history these days in Washington.

AFTER a period of innocuous activity the Broadway night club impresarios are once again making an earnest effort to please the local nocturnal prowlers. Specifically, they are offering this week one new night spot and three Summer productions.

PHILAJDELPHIA, May 22 -- Although Roy Talcott and Johnny Eide allowed only five hits, Princeton was beaten by Pennsylvania in the latter's final game of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League today, 3 to 2.

It took Fordham's hitters four innings to find the range at Fordham Field yesterday, but from that point on they shelled the Naval Receiving Station team with steady power and added one more victory to their season's list. The score was 15 to 1.

Strong hope for a better relationship between the United States and Russia as a result of the dissolution of the Communist Third International was the predominant reaction among leaders of labor, civic and industrial organizations here yesterday.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Food production is being stressed in all the Berkshire Summer resort colonies. Where flowers formerly grew there will be potatoes this year, and Victory Gardens are everywhere. Mrs. William Ellery Sedgwick of Boston has had a large tract of meadow near the Sedgwick Mansion, Stockbridge, plowed and it will be laid out in plots for use by her neighbors.

AS any faithful reader of these pages should recall, our London scout, Mr. W.A. Darlington, was telling just the other day about Noel Coward's latest London activities, i.e., the presentation there of "Present Laughter" and "This Happy Breed."

Garnering points in all except three events, New Utrecht High of Brooklyn captured its third important track and field championship this year when the Green and White athletes annexed the city P.S.A.L. senior high crown in the fortieth annual games at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
CLEVELAND, May 22 -- Playing for the first time since last Sunday, the Yankees tonight suffered their most decisive setback of the season when they lost to the Indians, 9 to 2.

PAST wars have each produced one or more men whose heroism has been stuff for legend's and for story's looms. An El Cid remains for centuries in men's minds, embalmed in verse and on canvas. A Black Douglas stands sharp and clear against Time's horizon with the light of glory forever on his rugged features.

IN the past three or four years there have been produced -- not in the major opera houses but, as it were, on the fringe of the centers of operatic activity -- two American operas that seem to stand out in this reviewer's memory for their concern with American themes and for their frequently original and indigenous treatment.

WASHINGTON, May -- With the Aleutians campaign developing satisfactorily and with the Japanese apparently relapsing into a strategy of tough defense throughout the entire Pacific theatre, the time appears to be approaching when the United States and its allies, at any time they consider the possible gains worth the cost in men, materiel and effort, may make the next move in the battle of the Pacific.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- President Roosevelt's letters to Capitol Hill this week, indicating the possibility of a veto of the Senate's full-abatement tax bill if it passed in the House, won sufficient votes to defeat the measure by a slim margin, but at the cost of further upsetting the fiscal side of his anti-inflation program if the conferees fail to reach an agreement quickly.

It may be fairly said that prior to the enactment of the 1942 Revenue Act, the excess profits tax law was seriously inadequate in the matter of providing relief for cases presenting various forms of abnormalities. Whereas the 1941 act recognized as the basis of a claim for relief only certain objective situations, the 1942 act takes into account abnormalities in earnings and in the financial position of the taxpayer as well.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., May 22 -- "The ideal of the government in China is to make sure of the welfare of the people and freedom of expression of public opinion," said Dr. Bang Nee A. Liu at the convention of Business and Professional Women at the Lake Placid Club today.

CHICAGO, May 22 -- The respect and the maintenance of the independence of the small European nations and States "is now and will be in the future vital to the peace of Europe and the world," Dr. Eduard Benes, president of the Czechoslovak Republic in Exile, declared here today after receiving an official welcome to the city from Mayor Edward J. Kelly and a large delegation of Czech citizens.

NO contemporary American printer is more willing to experiment or spend time in attaining perfection than the Grabhorn Brothers of San Francisco, and none have a more fanatical regard for the details indispensable to outstanding excellence -- a fanaticism that is medieval in spirit -- impressing their originality and personality upon the materials with which they work.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 22 (AP) -- Bunching hits in the late innings and running wild on the bases, the Syracuse Chiefs swept their two-game series with Jersey City by taking tonight's contest, 6 -- 0, behind Red Bartleson's seven-hit pitching.

MISS BRITTAIN, an Englishwoman has seen fit to offer for publication a series of letters to her 15-year-old son in America which can have interest only to herself, her son and those among us who still have the strength and will to examine the position and arguments of pacifists in a time when more space must be found for casualty lists.
BEHIND the scenes at the Brooklyn Museum, in a workroom suggesting wholesale mayhem, forty-five soignee wax manikins are being converted to war work.

WILLIAM DEAN HOWELLS once remarked that the smiling aspects of life were the more American. This has never been quite true, in any period of our history, though there have been times -- Howells's was one of them when it seemed more nearly true than it does today.

THE second annual program of orchestral scores by American composers, heard for the first time in New York during the season and selected for a rehearing by the Music Critics Circle of this city, draws near.

A recommendation that the traditional college and university entrance requirements be discarded for returning veterans of the armed forces, and that aptitude and achievement tests be adopted in their place, was made yesterday in a report prepared by the Commission on Liberal Education of the Association of American Colleges.

Big Bobo Newsom, leading citizen of Hartsville, S.C., also became the leading citizen of Flatbush yesterday when he pitched the Dodgers to a 5-2 triumph over the Reds before 6,461 refrigerated fans at Ebbets Field.

NOW that the youth of the world grows day by day more air-minded and since girls of high school age are as keenly interested as their brothers in the progress of aviation and the feats of individual fliers, "Heroines of the Sky" is a timely and valuable book.

The Mississippi River, swelled by flood waters from its rising tributaries, crashed through weakened barriers in Southern Illinois and Eastern Missouri late yesterday, inundating one of the country's largest railroad yards and trapping some 1,000 civilians who appealed to the Coast Guard for rescue boats.

TORONTO, May 22 -- Paolita, sleek black filly owned by Charles Hemstead of Markham, Ont., won the eighty-fourth running of the King's Plate at Woodbine Park today, the first member of her sex to turn the trick since 1935.

THE development of American landscape painting for nearly two centuries is illustrated in the current exhibition at the Knoedler Galleries, through some fifty canvases, beginning with wall panels of the 1750 period and concluding with paintings by Preston Dickinson, Man Ray, William Zorach, Marsden Hartley and Dean Fausett.

THE simpler pleasures of life are being made interesting again in some of the new English novels. For they are no longer commonplace, no longer dull and part of habit. Habit grinds the life and excitement out of so much.

ALTHOUGH its editor has gone off to the wars, The Matrimonial Post and Fashionable Marriage Advertiser is still published monthly from its Dickensian office on Charing Cross Road, and Miss Violet Stockton, editor and general manager pro tem, is pleased to report business is better than ever.

Golf links, trout streams and bridle paths are among the amenities it offered its peacetime patrons.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 22 -- As the first of a series of contemplated international conferences to lay the economic foundation for lasting peace, the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture represents a tentative and cautious first step toward global planning.

A new servicemen's center, which will provide recreation and dormitory facilities for men in the armed forces and the merchant marine, was dedicated yesterday afternoon at 71 West Twenty-third Street. The ceremony was attended by Mayor La Guardia, representatives of the Army and Navy and 200 members of the Grand Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons, which donated and will maintain the center.

It was the first stake of the Chicago season and the first of half a dozen on the Lincoln Fields program. Eddie Anderson's Burnt Cork was third.

Most interesting of the dog show combinations arranged for the double purpose of carrying on the customary exhibitions and at the same time conserving tires and gas as far as possible will be carried through the coming week-end. Eisenhower, associate director of the Office of War Information, declared here today:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 23 (AP) -- Allied bombers struck at four Japanese bases on New Guinea and New Britain yesterday, the High Command announced. A 500-ton Japanese ship was sunk by air bombing off Kaimana, Netherland New Guinea.

AT the age of 69 Harold L. Ickes has gone into the coal mining business. He by-passed the pick and shovel route and started at the top. By Presidential edict he is boss of all the country's mines and the men who go down in them to dig coal.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- The Third International, which in effect ceased to exist with the Comintern declaration announced today, was formed as a result of an appeal made in January, 1919, by a group of organizations headed by the Russian Communist party.

Earnings of the steel and allied industries for the first quarter of this year were about 24 per cent less than in the initial three months of last year, based on the published statements of sixty-six companies. From the final quarter of last year the decline was 27 per cent.

YONKERS, N.Y., May 22 -- The New York Central Railroad has posted notices that service on the Getty Square branch of the Putnam division will be abandoned next Saturday. The two-mile spur, linking Getty Square here with the main line of the Putnam division at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, was built more than sixty years ago.

THE dream world of Dr. J. Kenneth Galbraith, formerly assistant professor of economics and now deputy administrator of OPA, will meet up with some of the facts of business life at a series of hearings which start tomorrow in Washington.

P.G. DOWNES is an American school teacher whose a favorite extracurricular activity for years has been summering in the Canadian sub-Arctic. "Sleeping Island" constitutes his refreshing record of a one-man expedition to Canada's Great Barrens, the huge area north of the 60th parallel, in which "the endless spruce forest at last grudgingly gives way to dwarfed clumps and then to a vast land of rolling treeless moss and sedge -- the tundra."

THE neighbors have gone in for chickens, and during several week-ends the clack of hammers and swish of whitewash brushes have kept the world informed that these budding poultry farmers and their volunteer foremen were hard at it.

MOSCOW, May 22 -- The Presidium of the Executive Committee of the Communist International [the Comintern], meeting in Moscow on May 15, reached a decision to propose to all sections of the organization its own dissolution, thus freeing the separate Communist parties from their duties and obligations and enabling them to adapt their formations, programs and political activities to the conditions prevailing in the various countries where they exist.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 22 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point marked National Maritime Day this morning with a program that included the award of two Merchant Marine Distinguished Service Medals and a review of more than 2,000 cadets by officers of the Naval Reserve.

Four hundred white-clad apprentice seamen from the government training station on Hoffman Island marched up lower Broadway first before noon yesterday, opening the city's observance of National Maritime Day.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- The White House was reported today to have checkmated an attempt by John L. Lewis to obtain immediate re-entrance into the American Federation of Labor for the United Mine Workers of America.

A TWO-DAY course in "Disease and Pest Control" will be given at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park on June 1 and 2. The instruction, which deals with the fundamentals of disease and pest control, will be given from 10:30 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. each day.

TO stimulate the composition of works for women's voices the Philadelphia Art Alliance offers the Eurydice Chorus Award of $100, to be made in October for a work by an American for women's voices of three or more parts, a cappella or accompanied. Entries should be sent to the Eurydice Chorus Award Committee, care of The Philadelphia Art Alliance, 251 South Eighteenth Street, Philadelphia.

A POST-WAR radio world of the brightest luster and greatest public service is envisioned in a plan offered here last week by the Institute of Radio Engineers. The institute's views on how this may be accomplished have been set forth in a "charter" or proposal for a country-wide "radio technical planning association" designed to cover every phase of the radio art -- broadcasting, television, facsimile general communication and kindred electronics.

A 38-year-old executive of a Queens utility company yesterday scaled the steep roof of the Holy Trinity Church at 316 East Eighty- eighth Street, between First and Second Avenues, and stayed there for nearly an hour, shouting at the crowd below, before his wife's pleas persuaded him to abandon the dangerous perch.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22 -- Disclosing that from Jan. 1 to the end of May the country's shipyards would have delivered 700 new ships, a figure closely approaching the production for all of last year, Rear Admiral Emory S. Land today asserted that "we are getting on top of the submarine threat."

PORTLAND, Me. -- Maine tourist interests face the approaching season with Yankee calm despite restrictions and shortages. " BAREFOOT BOY WITH CHEEK" might easily become a best seller. It is the first work of a 23-year-old cadet in the Army Air Corps; it has some very amusing drawings, and it is written with that particular brand of American humor which relishes the ridicule of trifles.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 22 -- Under a gray and forbidding sky, the International sloops today held their first race of their annual Spring pre-championship series for the James D. Sparkman Trophy, and Corny Shields sailed his Arleen to a fifteen-second victory over Joseph Merrill's Feather.

On three previous occasions, Mrs. Filomena Mauro of 2525 Cruger Avenue, the Bronx, had seen her sons go off to war, but yesterday when she had to say good-bye to her eldest, Vincent Paul, 30 years old, the strain proved too much for her weakened heart.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- A preliminary blueprint of 1944 food production plans, obtained from official sources, revealed tonight that the government plans removal of all acreage restrictions and wider use of contract farming.

LONDON, May 22 -- The chief achievements of Allied air warfare over Western Europe -- principally Germany -- have been the hastening of Axis defeat in North Africa, the weakening of Germany's campaign in Russia and the laying of the groundwork for the invasion of Festung Europa.

AS a result of a few talks with Dickens and Ainsworth, George Cruikshank claimed credit for the invention of "Oliver Twist," "Pickwick Papers" and at least three of Ainsworth's novels. After a brief period of training with a volunteer regiment that never saw a battle, he considered himself capable of leading an army.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- A 40 per cent cut in truck, bus and taxicab mileage in thirteen States of the Eastern gasoline shortage area and the drastic curtailment of deliveries of such commodities as beer, liquor, soft drinks, ice cream and flowers were decreed today by the Office of Defense Transportation to meet the gasoline shortage caused by military demands and the washout of pipelines and railroad beds by Western floods.
THE Caribbean tourist of happier days touched at the bustling port cities, visited Caracas with its delightful country club, and happily recorded in his travel diary that he had "done Venezuela."
THE Caribbean tourist of happier days touched at the bustling port cities, visited Caracas with its delightful country club, and happily recorded in his travel diary that he had "done Venezuela."

LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- While the devastating power of the Royal Air Force's home - based heavy bombers still was being withheld in advance of what might be a sustained knockout aerial attack against Europe, British Mosquito planes stung Berlin last night for the third consecutive night and the sixth time since May 13.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 22 -- As the war progresses the dateline on this dispatch -- Stockholm -- is becoming increasingly common in the world press. Information from the Swedish capital is read in all belligerent countries in the hope of finding out something about the adversary.

IT is just fifty years ago -- the precise date was May 18, 1893 -- that Thomas Huxley delivered at Oxford his Romanes Lecture. "Evolution and Ethics." That lecture was a milestone in late nineteenth-century thought, pointing a straight way to a better order of human life, though no small part of the world's traffic has taken, alas, a wrong turning since that time.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP) -- Russ Christopher of the Athletics did about everything that could be expected of a pitcher in earning a 2-to-1 victory over the Browns today, moving Philadelphia into fifth place in the American League.

The cotton futures market yesterday ended a listless week on a note of strength with increased short-covering and price-fixing in the July position by trade sources, supplemented by New Orleans and commission-house support in the distant contracts.

OF THE three great captains discussed in this book Winston Churchill's ancestor, Marlborough, is clearly the author's favorite. He calls him inimitably great as a soldier. Marlborough was almost fanatical in his adherence to the offensive.

DURING the eight different Summers which the author, who is a biologist for the United States Government, spent in Alaska among the Eskimos, studying waterfowl and animal life, he heard through an interpreter many of the tales with which the Eskimo men and boys entertain one another during the long, monotonous Arctic days.

ALTHOUGH this story is complete in itself the many readers who enjoyed "The Littlest House" will be charmed to find that "Twelve Months Make a Year" continues the adventures of Jean and Lydia and Mark, the latter still too young always to take an understanding part in the enterprises of his older sisters, but making, because of his decided personality, a very definite contribution to the life of the family.

LONDON, May 22 -- The announcement in Moscow of the liquidation of the Third International was welcomed here today as a step toward eliminating suspicions of Russia's post-war intentions in international affairs.

Following its long-established precedent, the South Shore Y.C. at Freeport, L.I., will hold its traditional going-into-commission flag ceremonies on Memorial Day. There will be a slight modification of the usual time schedule. The annual commodore's breakfast will be combined with the next meal as a "brunch" and has been set for 11:50 A.M. The club colors will be hauled aloft at noon.
MEALS that have the "just right" touch, even in this day of special planning with our economies and shortages, is the aim of this new menu book.
LONDON, May 22 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

ON BOARD U.S. SUBMARINE WAHOO, at a Pacific Base, May 22 -- Eight submarine warriors stood on the black steel planking of this vessel today and received decorations from Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, commander in chief of the Pacific Fleet.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 22 -- Italian editorials go out of their way today to bring home to the people that, "far from having ended with the conclusion of the fighting in Tunisia, the Battle of the Mediterranean is only beginning."
WASHINGTON, May 22 (U.P.) -- Navy communique 386:

A considerable number of buyers were in the wholesale markets again this week, consisting of new arrivals as well as many who prolonged their stay, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

Bob Montgomery experienced another thrill yesterday, one almost comparable with the one he felt Friday night when he won the lightweight championship of the world from Beau Jack at Madison Square Garden. The new titleholder received a check for $14,033.68, largest sum he ever has obtained in his seven years of ring campaigning, and he was a pleased fighter as he entrained for his home in Philadelphia.

THE name of Jeanette Seletz is unfamiliar to the reading public, but that will soon be remedied. This big first novel of hers should make headline news. It is also a pretty fair guess that there are more where this one came from.

A request that there should be no use of Federal patronage to support Michael J. Kennedy, leader of Tammany, in the fight against him was made yesterday by State Senator James G. Donovan, chairman of the Committee to Reorganize the Democratic Party in New York County, in telegrams to United States Senators Robert F. Wagner and James M. Mead.

DESPITE predictions by studio executives that fewer pictures than usual will be made this coming season, there is yet no tangible evidence supporting the prophesies. This week there were fifty films before cameras at the various studios, an unusual seasonal high, with every indication being that this level will be maintained, perhaps exceeded, during the next few weeks.

In a climax to nation-wide resentment against the autocratic methods of war agencies, Congress and industry will unite this week to protect nationally advertised brands from further government attacks and to preserve established patterns of distribution.

The skies were overcast but the alleys and streets of Washington Square were ablaze with color yesterday as landscapes, marines and flower paintings lined the fences and building walls. It was the twenty-third semi-annual Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibition.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Some 5,000,000 tires will be manufactured from synthetic rubber this year for distribution to civilians, Rubber Director William M. Jeffers revealed this week in making public the third of his "progress reports" on the synthetic rubber program.

THE All-American Highway, though it still has gaps in its projected majestic sweep from the Arctic Circle to the region of Cape Horn, is already serving in the war -- and one link, that built by the Army in Alaska was built specifically for war.

Of the 1,300,000 boys in American high schools between the ages of 16 and 18, it is estimated that about 80 per cent are headed directly for the armed forces. Some 40 per cent will be in the air forces, 32 per cent in the land forces and 8 per cent in the naval forces.

THIS is a witty picture of what is probably a typical American small town. It is more than merely clever, for it cuts through the polite front maintained by the self-conscious "old families" of Guilford to the family feuds and the deep rivalries that are so deadly serious to the participants and so amusing to the onlooker.

THE well-known radio commentator, Ida Bailey Allen, has written an excellent book for wartime needs, on how to cook familiar foods in double- quick time. Here, indeed, is something to interest the woman who works part time or full time, or to the woman who has no maid and rushes home after a day at the Red Cross to see that the family will be adequately fed.

The labor stabilization plan which becomes effective in this area on Thursday is not intended to freeze employes in their jobs, but on the contrary is designed in part to overcome the voluntary agreements among some employers not to raid one another's personnel, Lillian L. Poses, regional attorney of the War Manpower Commission, declared in an interview yesterday.
The imminent collapse of Office of Price Administration regulations was forecast here yesterday by leading spokesmen for the nation's food industry.

Defying their union's warning that a walkout was barred by their contract and that any member taking part "does so at his own risk," 200 of 600 welders working on war jobs at Robins Drydock at Dwight Street, Erie Basin, Brooklyn, staged a wildcat strike at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
Seven new films will open at Broadway theatres during the week. The program follows:

Price-fixing by the trade, though only of moderate volume, last week recovered most of the previous week's losses in the cotton futures market. With strength vested in the near positions, the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange registered net gains of 8 to 35 points, or 40 cents to $1.75 a bale.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- The speed with which women hang up their kitchen aprons and don overalls may determine whether a national service act is necessary to meet manpower problems, the Office of War Information reported today.
LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- The Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Two American naval vessels supporting our operations on Attu Island in the Aleutians were attacked yesterday by about fifteen twin-engined bombers, which came from what may be the Japanese counterpart of "Shangri-la." The attack was a failure, the Navy said.

In perhaps the longest National Challenge Cup championship final on record the Morgan Strassers of Pittsburgh and the Brooklyn Hispano soccer team battled to a 2-all draw before 6,000 at Starlight Park, the Bronx, yesterday.

LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- A spokesman of the Netherland Government-in-Exile said today that 100,000 Netherland soldiers were in hiding in their Nazi-occupied homeland, waiting to spring into action when the Allies invade continental Europe.

The nation-wide observance of Cotton Week, which ended Saturday, included promotional support which, in the face of wartime merchandising difficulties, made it clearly evident that the event "has a secure place on the retail merchandising calendar," according to a report by the Cotton-Textile Institute and National Cotton Council following a preliminary survey of results.

A program for the extension of the benefits of democracy to under-privileged groups in the United States in the post-war period was advanced last night by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in an address at a meeting of the city-wide Citizens Committee on Harlem held at the home of Lieutenant Edward A. Norman, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Norman at 124 East Seventieth Street.
MOSCOW, Monday, May 24 -- Premier Stalin entertained Joseph E. Davies at a state dinner in the Kremlin last night and afterward saw the motion picture "Mission to Moscow" in the Kremlin theatre.

CHUNGKING, Monday, May 24 (U.P.) -- An official Chinese source said today that the Japanese were rushing heavy reinforcements and great quantities of material into Central China in preparation for a major offensive against the key Chinese positions in that area.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 15 to 21 are given in the appended tabulation:

Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo" with her in the central role was the principal event of a full day of ballet hereabout yesterday. Appearing with the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway theatre as guest artist, she succeeded in bringing back to her delightful, homey little piece about cowboys and girls all its warmth and essential truthfulness.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Proposals by British and American commissions on post-war education which were published today by the American Council on Public Affairs revealed that the British commission favors a compulsory control of education in post-war Germany by a high commissioner appointed by the United Nations, while the American commission does not favor such a step.

The magnitude of the employment problem that will arise with demobilization of the armed forces was stressed by the National Industrial Conference Board in a report published yesterday. It declared that the problem would be greater than the task of finding jobs for all men employed in manufacturing in 1939.
The Daily Worker, New York Communist newspaper, says today in an editorial commenting on the decision in Russia to discontinue the Communist International:
Mrs. J. Breckinridge Bayne will come today to the Weylin from Washington.

DETROIT, May 23 -- The last-place Red Sox pushed home a run on Tony Lupien's single in the tenth inning of the nightcap today to defeat the Tigers, 3 to 2, for a split of a double-header before 28,899 spectators, largest 1943 crowd at Briggs Stadium.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 23 -- In the first of a series of experiments to test the popular strength of various possible 1944 Presidential candidates the institute has just completed a Presidential "trial heat," matching a Democratic ticket of President Roosevelt and Vice President Henry A. Wallace against a Republican ticket of Governor Dewey of New York for President and General Douglas MacArthur for Vice President.

LONDON, May 23 -- The stock markets have pulled themselves together in the last few days after the dismal display that followed the Allies' victory in Tunisia. The change, however, has been principally in sentiment. Business has been even quieter and the daily total of officially recorded transactions has fallen to the lowest levels of this year.
May I refer to the interesting editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 15 on the problems of post-war aviation?
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The text, in translation, of General Henri Honore Giraud's letter of May 17 to General Charles de Gaulle follows:

The West Side Taxpayers Association made public yesterday a letter to Mayor La Guardia, asking him to order members of the Police and Fire Departments to refrain from soliciting, on city time and at city expense, signatures for their petitions asking a referendum vote on a "war bonus" of $450 a year.

Property loss in the Middle West's worst flood in recent years mounted last night as muddy waters of four swollen rivers burst new levees in three States, swirled over thousands of more acres of rich farm lands and isolated hundreds of inhabitants.

LONDON, May 23 -- General Georges Catroux is back from North Africa again and it is reasonably safe to guess that, when he starts for Algiers the next time, it will be with General Charles de Gaulle and a third Fighting French leader.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- Scenes reminiscent of a world series were enacted at Shibe Park today as the up-and-coming Phillies, "miracle" club of the National League, split a double-header with Pittsburgh before 37,176 -- the largest attendance in National League history in Philadelphia.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 23 -- After scraping the keel of his International Class sloop Aileen over a rock at Execution Lighthouse, Corny Shields kept on today to win the James D. Sparkman Trophy by a single point.

ST. LOUIS, May 23 (AP) -- Joyner White's two doubles had a lot to do with the Athletics' 3-to-2 victory over the Browns in the second game of a double-header today after the Browns had turned on the power to win the opener, 9 to 1.

ALGIERS, May 23 -- It appears reasonably certain that General Henri Honore Giraud and General Charles de Gaulle are ready to meet in Algiers soon to compose their differences and achieve that union of Frenchmen outside Metropolitan France that is necessary if the military victory in Tunisia is to be accompanied by political success.

The main responsibility for the inexcusable delay in the pay-as-you-go and withholding tax plan, and particularly for the failure of the House and Senate conferees so far to agree on a compromise measure, now rests upon the President. By his letter to the chairmen of the two Congressional tax committees, with its implied threat of a veto, he has blocked the enactment of a full pay-as-you-go plan.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The Consolidated Electric and Gas Company has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposal to sell 4,950 shares or all of the common stock of its subsidiary, Peoples Gas Company, for $1,246,000 to the Texas Public Service Company.

In your issue of May 16 Arthur Upham Pope, attacking our criticism of the film "Mission to Moscow" in your issue of May 9, impugns our integrity and that of the Commission of Inquiry of which we were, respectively, chairman and secretary.

Fishing pressure in most of Westchester County has not been reduced this year, according to estimates made by wardens and close observers of the likely spots. With bus service and railroad facilities at hand, the back-yard fishing area of the metropolitan district has been attracting anglers by the score.
CHUNGKING, China, May 23 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Sixty-three special awards of miniature gold basketballs, footballs, baseballs, track shoes and fencing charms have been presented to members of New York University's major sports teams, it has been announced by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Reports of a marked improvement in the outlook for the Winter wheat crop are being received from parts of the West and Southwest, which temper to some extent the claims of losses by floods in the Central West and parts of the Southwest, and by near drought conditions in Southwestern Kansas and sections of the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles, as well as South Dakota.

THE Cincinnati Reds' board of strategy was sitting around, awaiting the final games of the Eastern jaunt with the Dodgers. Deacon Bill McKechnie, General Manager Warren Giles and Traveling Secretary Gabe Paul were batting the conversational ball back and forth, as baseball men always will in every waking moment.
ATTU ISLAND, May 13 (Delayed) (AP) -- Americans today have had an opportunity for the first time to find out a few things about the equipment the Japanese have provided their troops in the Aleutians.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 23 -- Striking a balance from the Italian communiques of the past ten days, since the end of the fighting in Tunisia, reveals that Rome has officially announced that 285 civilians have been killed and 625 seriously injured during Allied air raids over the peninsula and the islands.
JERSEY CITY, May 23 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark divided a double-header before 6,285 fans today, the Little Giants winning the nightcap, 3 to 1, after the Bears had captured the opener, 2 to 0.

Attu and Kiska were the only gains Japan got out of her ambitious but disastrous attempt to capture Midway and Dutch Harbor. Attu and Kiska remained in her hands as relics or tokens of that plan. Holding the islands as a barrier against any American advance on the Japanese home islands, the enemy never relinquished his original purpose to use them for a thrust of his own.

Declaring that an important source of manpower as yet largely untapped is available to this country in the refugees who have come here, the National Refugee Service of 139 Centre Street made public yesterday a detailed survey of 2,250 refugees, all of whom are specialists in science, medicine, social science or commerce.

Senator Byrd is fully justified in declaring that the information furnished by the War Labor Board, in response to the unanimous resolution of the Senate, was neither adequate in amount nor clear in form. The board's report failed to list each decision in such a way that the reader could check back on the general summary.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 -- Warner Brothers have bought the screen rights to Donald Culross Peattie's "Singing in the Wilderness," a novel based on the life of John James Audubon, the naturalist. The picture will be produced in technicolor by Jesse L. Lasky with Errol Flynn most likely in the lead.

A PACIFIC BASE, April 25 -- Up from the coral beach, through the scarred cocoanut groves of Guadalcanal, past the Marine cemetery, across the bomb and shell marked brown and green of Henderson Field, a battalion of an Army regiment slogged through the mud and rain and darkness the early morning of Oct. 24, 1942.

PHILADELPHIA, May 23 -- The United Labor Committee, representing more than 130,000 members of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations in the Philadelphia area, adopted today a constitution after heated debate on a clause barring from office any one "affiliated with any organization that believes in the philosophy of a totalitarian government."

CHUNGKING, China, May 22 (Delayed) -- This is how an air raid alert affects Chungking. At 6:30 in the morning the house boys in the rookery where the correspondents live hurried excitedly from door to door. "Ching pao [alarm]" they shout as they make the rounds.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 23 -- Strengthening of our democracy "so that never again can we fall prey to international confidence men and gangsters" was urged here today by J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Hoover's remedy was the development of leadership.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 23 (U.P.) -- A communique:

LONDON, Monday, May 24 -- German aircraft followed up their heaviest daylight raids in several weeks against Britain with forays over the northeast coast early this morning, dropping bombs at one point, it was learned today. In daylight yesterday the German raiders strafed and bombed two resorts on the south and southeast coasts, and heavy death tolls were feared.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The next ration of coffee will be the largest since the inauguration of official apportioning.
CHICAGO, May 23 -- In spite of efforts of the trade to prevent it, it appears more than likely that allocations or rationing will be ordered in the paper box industry.

CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- The White Sox defense fell apart in the first inning today while the Senators scored seven runs eventually to overwhelm the Comiskey team, 11 to 0, in the first contest of a scheduled double-header. The second game was postponed because of weather, disappointing a crowd of 14,883.

Delving to the roots of the nation's industrial war-production program, coal is playing an important role, not alone for its productive qualities on the industrial front but also for the numerous functions which it performs, through by-products, in advancing successful prosecution of the war.

DELAIR, N.J., Monday, May 24 -- State police reported this morning that eighteen persons were killed and scores of others injured in the wreck of a passenger train of the Pennsylvania Railroad late last night. However, railroad authorities said at 1 A.M. that they knew of only six dead.
DELAIR, N.J., May 23 -- A partial list of the injured in the train wreck here tonight follows:

BETHANY, W. Va., May 23 (U.P.) -- Secretary Frank Knox warned today that any disorderly clamor to have the fighting men returned home when peace came would bring chaotic demobilization and possible loss of "the very democratic principles for which we fight."

The American people are substantially agreed on what they want after victory is won, according to the report of a survey on changes in the nation's economy and of probable post-war problems in eleven major fields of the nation's life, made public yesterday by the Twentieth Century Fund.

The prediction that the action of the State Legislature in naming a commission to study chiropractic laws and procedures in other States would eventually result in the licensing of chiropractors in New York State was made last night by H.E. Bernhardt, president of the Federation of Chiropractors, of New York, Inc., at that organization's annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

Many memorial services in honor of Americans who gave their lives in the present and past wars were held throughout the city yesterday, with thousands gathering to pay tribute to their deeds of heroism. The exercises included parades, tree plantings, the reading of messages from numerous government officials, and addresses in praise of the nation's war veterans.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., May 23 -- Revitalization of the teaching of United States history in universities and colleges of the Western Hemisphere as a step for insuring the preservation of democratic liberties was urged today by the Rev. Dr. Joseph F. Thorning, Professor of Sociology at Mount St. Mary's College, Emmitsburg, Md., preaching the baccalaureate sermon at Nazareth College here.

BOSTON, May 23 -- The Cubs wound up an otherwise disastrous road trip today by winning both ends of a double-header from the surging Braves, capturing the opener, 2 -- 1, and taking the nightcap, 1 -- 0, in a pair of pitching battles after losing nine straight games. The double setback dropped the Braves from second to third place in the league standing.

"Leadership, fortitude and discipline," the qualities that must be developed by the Army, according to a correspondent with our forces in Africa, are the same qualities that must be developed by every citizen of a democracy and by every Christian who wishes to save his soul, Mgr. Bryan J. McEntegart, national secretary of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- British Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden, in a message to the Mexican Foreign Minister on the first anniversary of Mexico's entry into the war, said tonight that "shattering blows have been dealt the enemy in the past year."

AKRON, Ohio, May 23 -- C.I.O. United Rubber Workers voted to return to work tonight at the plants of General Tire and Rubber Company, one of four Akron rubber concerns hit by a week-end work stoppage of 40,000 employes who objected to a wage ruling by the War Labor Board.

Floods of water have flowed under the bridges of the Moscow River since the March day in 1919 when the representatives of revolutionary movements in thirty countries assembled in the Soviet capital and founded the Third International. It was a revolutionary time.

Captain James J. Hayes, 24-year-old pilot of a Flying Fortress who won the Distinguished Flying Cross for heroism during the Battle of the Bismarck Sea in March, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday afternoon. He was greeted by his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Hayes of 1926 Fowler Avenue, the Bronx; his fiancee, Miss Margaret Williams of 350 Marine Avenue, Brooklyn, and other members of the family.

LONDON, May 23 -- The British Board of Trade's index of commodity prices for April, based on 1930 as 100, was 162.8, a new wartime high, compared to 162.2 for March and 159.6 for April, 1942. Since Aug. 31, 1939, there has been a rise of 66 per cent, food and tobacco being 78 and industrial materials 60 higher.
MEXICO CITY, May 22 (AP) -- The widow of Leon Trotsky, slain Communist leader, tonight called the dissolution of the Comintern "the final rite in the slow death of a once revolutionary party."

Despite continued skepticism regarding its practical effects, which must still be demonstrated by events, the dissolution of the Third or Communist International is none the less one of the most momentous developments of this war. It is momentous from the standpoint of the historic evolution of the Bolshevist revolution as well as from the standpoint of the practical realities of the present war situation.

New York City taxpayers can look forward to a lowered tax rate or to substantially reduced assessed valuations only if debt service charges are reduced or the city's rapid transit, docks and airport, markets and ferries are put on a self-sustaining basis, according to a study of the city's debt made public yesterday by the Institute of Public Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -Destruction of a German submarine in the Caribbean was disclosed by the Navy today in announcing award of the Distinguished Flying Cross to Lieuteni ant Gordon R. Fiss of Virginia ]Beach, Va.

LONDON, Monday, Army 24 (U.P.) -- Russia announced today that its air force had destroyed 313 German planes last week, to bring a four-week toll of enemy aircraft to 1,894 for the air force alone. Many others were reported shot down by anti-aircraft gunners.

LONDON, May 23 -- A committee of British business men has called on the government to formulate a post-war commercial air policy at once and has urged immediate negotiations with the United States concerning future international air commerce, according to a report published today.

LONDON, May 23 -- Lieut. Gen. Jacob L. Devers, commanding the United States forces in the European theatre, told a radio audience tonight that far-reaching decisions being made in Washington should not be confused with the carrying out of them, explaining that "plans made with vision months ago covered many eventualities."

NEW DELHI, India, May 23 (AP) -- Nearly half of a Japanese force of twenty bombers and eleven fighters that attacked the Chittagong airfield in India yesterday morning were destroyed or damaged by R.A.F. Hurricanes, a British communique said today.

The Union Securities Corporation, a New York investment banking firm, announced yesterday that it has completed the purchase of substantially all of the common stock of the Colorado Milling and Elevator Company, and that Guy A. Thomas of Minneapolis has been elected as the new president of the company.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- About 2,000,000 bushels of Canadian oats and 1,000,000 bushels of rye have been received here since the opening of lake navigation. Liberal deliveries on oats on May contracts had a depressing effect and caused a sharp break after prices had advanced rather sharply.

Favorable war reports, a reaffirmation of Britain's military support by Prime Minister Winston Churchill and the continuance of coal-mining operations influenced the stock market favorably last week. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange advanced moderately to their best levels since November, 1940, with industrial issues featuring the improvement.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 23 -- Increasing guerrilla warfare is sweeping Crete, Yugoslavia, Greece, Albania and Western Bulgaria, menacing the German rear in Southeastern Europe, according to reports to Turkey.

Mrs. Elizabeth Bird is probably the only woman in New York with the privilege of telling fastidious men which wines to drink. It is her job. She is the sommeliere of the Hotel Algonquin, which makes her the mistress of the wine cellar and adviser to the gourmets.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 23 -- Seventeen more Axis aircraft were destroyed in the air and on the ground yesterday as the Allied air forces continued their round-the- clock onslaught against enemy airports in the Central Mediterranean. The day's toll brought the enemy's losses for the past four days to 289 machines.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 24 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Immediate enactment of a definite Federal labor relations policy, with the Smith-Connally bill as a beginning, was urged yesterday by the National Association of Manufacturers in its weekly news letter to its members.

The twentieth anniversary of the national radio pulpit was celebrated yesterday with the dedication of a new radio chapel by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of the radio pulpit. During the last twenty years, he said, the national radio pulpit has come to be the oldest continuous radio program in the world.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Ten million tons of coal had to be shifted to the railroads during the 1942-43 fuel year as a result of the dislocation of New England coal shipping routes by enemy submarine activity and diversion of colliers to other services, the Office of Defense Transportation has reported.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 23 -- Following is the text of a declaration of principles submitted tonight by Chairman Richard K. Law of the United Kingdom delegation to the International Food Conference:

Declaring that "the Jew must have the right to live where he is born," Representative Sol Bloom, chairman of time House Foreign Relations Committee and one of the three members of the United States delegation to the recent refugee conference in Bermuda, reported yesterday afternoon that he was "perfectly satisfied" with the results of the conference.

In wartime we must brace ourselves for many disappointments. There is the matter of whale meat. Some talk has been heard of late about the possibility of adding it to our diet. The mere word meat stirs the appetite these days, even when it is on the fishy side.
NEW DELHI, India, May 23 (U.P.) -- A communique:

The huge parking spaces at Jones Beach, which accommodate 15,000 automobiles and are usually black with cars on a nice Sunday in late May, were used yesterday by ten cars. Most of the cars were driven by men in the uniforms of the armed services.

For an outfit that once was the best Sunday team in baseball the Reds certainly have done an about face. In the presence of 32,732 persons, the biggest Ebbets Field attendance of 1943, Bill MicKechnie's men dropped two decisions, 3 -- 0 and 3 -- 1, to the Dodgers yesterday.

GRAHAM GREENE is a young Englishman blessed with a murky, lurid, undisciplined writing talent that has won him extravagant recognition. By a strange grafting of the abnormal psychology he learned from the pages of Sigmund Freud upon the violently melodramatic plots he took over almost unchanged from that old master, Edgar Wallace, he has evolved a literary formula of his own, which might be called the psychological mystery.

Fall buying continued heavy in all markets, particularly in the coat and suit division, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. On many items commitments were placed to cover requirements to the end of the year, but most of the selling was on the allotment basis.

A special service of thanksgiving to commemorate the fall of Bizerte and Tunis to the United Nations was held at noon yesterday at the Hellenic Cathedral, 319 East Seventy-fourth Street, Archbishop Athenagoras of the Greek Orthodox Church in North and South America officiated and was assisted by the Most Rev. Basil Efthimiou, dean of the cathedral Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick represented the city.

A scene reminiscent of the Gay Nineties occurred in Queens yesterday morning when a runaway horse hitched to a buggy scattered groups of churchgoers and caused injuries to three persons before it was halted by policemen in a radio car.

Ceremonies rededicating the Rabbi Jacob Joseph School, the oldest Hebrew parochial school in the country, to the four freedoms and a memorial tribute to the founder's grandson, a marine captain killed on Guadalcanal, were held yesterday at the Seward Park High School, Grand and Ludlow Streets.

LONDON, May 23 (U.P.) -- Marshal Enrico Caviglia, Italy's 81-year-old World War I hero, may succeed to power in the event of an upheaval forcing the ouster of Premier Mussolini, it was suggested today in reports on Italy's internal situation received through usually reliable neutral channels.
Present-day American education will never regenerate Germany, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, asserted in his sermon yesterday.

The Women's National Book Association will hold its annual business meeting tomorrow evening at the New Weston Hotel. Josephine von Miklos, author of "I Took a War Job," to be published July 8 by Simon Schuster, will speak, her topic being "Women in War Work."

Your mild approval of Senator Kilgore's bill to mobilize science and technology leads me to point out some of its striking deficiencies. Aside from the futility of attempting to mobilize science and coordinate technological facilities and personnel, there are specific objections to details of the bill.

A reception in honor of Bishop Paul Yu Pin, Vicar Apostolic of Nanking, China, was held yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral High School, 111 East Fiftieth Street, by the Catholic women of the Archdiocese of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The Office of Price Administration replied today to criticisms from retailers that they had not been consulted or given advance notice prior to the issuance of a regulation setting ceiling prices on officers' Summer cotton uniforms by producing information showing the extent to which they had been consulted or advised.
CHICAGO, May 23 (AP) -- President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia declared today that the United Nations must stand together until Japan, as well as Germany and Italy, had been defeated.
