In the pre-war days owners of such silken luxuries as two-thread sheers had a special trick to make them appear even more elegant than they were. They would flick them inside out and wear them with the frosty, dull-mat finish on the outside.

Three men were believed to have drowned in the swirling waters of Hell Gate and four others were rescued yesterday when a tugboat collided with a cargo ship in the East River 100 yards off Seventy-ninth Street.

DETROIT, May 23 -- Striking members of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.) voted today to end unauthorized work stoppages which have crippled war production at seven plants of the Chrysler Corporation since Thursday.

In order to give Helen Hayes and the cast of "Harriet" a five-week vacation that play will recess at Henry Miller's after the performance of Saturday night, June 26. The engagement will be resumed at the same theatre on Monday evening, Aug. 2.

Flanked by a sympathetic gathering of 37,135, the Giants fired two more barrels into the world champions at the Polo Grounds yesterday. But for the second successive afternoon the recoil floored Mel Ott's team as the Cardinals again bagged a double-header to sweep the four-game series, hurdle over the Braves into second place from third and remain two and a half lengths behind the pace-setting Dodgers.

With the pleasure-driving ban obviously successful, on the first Sunday since its renewal, in cutting passenger car travel to a minimum, residents of the Eastern gasoline crisis area looked anxiously yesterday to the government for word as to how it would apply the 40 per cent over-all reduction in mileage ordered for buses, trucks and taxicabs.

FORT DEVENS, Mass., May 23 -- Ten carloads of wounded veterans of the war-toughened United States First Armored Division have arrived at Fort Devens -- only a few weeks after they were struck in battle, the Army made known tonight.

Warning that the supply of young lawyers is "rapidly approaching the vanishing point," Dean Young B. Smith of the Columbia University School of Law suggest yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, that military authorities select a number of limited service men and send them to law schools to be trained for legal positions with the government.

In any test for able-bodied workers the handicapped would be low on the list, but war plant employers today rate them as highly useful and are asking for more. In fact, for some groups, such as the hard of hearing, the demand is now greater than the supply, the local office of the United States Employment Service reported yesterday.

The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, who has just returned from a two-and-a-half-month visit to Great Britain, said yesterday that he had found everywhere in Britain the profound conviction that the destinies of our two countries are definitely joined.

Though the canning season is still a couple of months in the offing, interest in the art of food preservation is already apparent. In Westchester County, for instance, women are enthusiastically attending all-day "institutes," at which experts demonstrate ways of conserving the harvests from Victory Gardens.

CLEVELAND, May 23 -- Two explosive innings submerged the Yankees in both ends of a doubleheader at Municipal Stadium today before 29,245 fans and catapulted the Indians into the American League lead. The circuit champions of 1942 fell to second place, one game behind Cleveland and a half length ahead of the third-place Senators.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Excessive rains in parts of the Central West slowed the movement of hogs to market last week and prices showed a tendency to advance after dipping early to the lowest level of the year.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Extension of the operations of the Daily Newspaper Printing and Publishing Panel, pending a review of the panel's work to determine whether it will be established permanently, was announced today by the National War Labor Board.

In the unsettlement of swiftly moving events the distinction between right and wrong is often overlooked, and today one of the most serious problems facing us is the blurring of moral issues and the lowering of moral standards, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, stressed in his sermon yesterday.

Employes themselves may play a significant part in advancing the multiplicity of new products now on drawing boards for post-war output, through utilization of warspurred employe suggestion systems, E.S. Taylor, president of the National Association of Suggestion Systems, said in an interview here last week.

The ashes of Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, Japan's leading naval hero, who died in the South Pacific last month, arrived in Tokyo yesterday and were placed in state at the Navy Club in suburban Shiba while Japanese press and radio propagandists capitalized on his death to key up the war effort on the home front.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Prime Minister Churchill, during a weekend recess of his conferences with President Roosevelt, devoted today to independent talks with American and British war planners.

CHICAGO, May 23 -- Planting of corn in the Central West has been delayed further by excessive rains, floods and relatively low temperatures, and brokers who have canvassed the situation estimate that planting will be completed about two weeks later than normal, even under the most favorable conditions.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 23 -- Dissolution of the Comintern -- the Third International will not affect the anti-bolshevist policies of Germany and her allies and the fundamental implications of the anti-Comintern pact retain full validity, it was announced in Berlin today, according to German broadcasts.

PITTSBURGH, May 23 -- The continued threat of a coal stoppage, an unchanged steel operating rate, a heavy influx of new business and the possibility of a bottleneck later this year in coke supplies featured news in the steel industry last week.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed in his regular Sunday broadcast yesterday that he had appealed to Federal authorities to set up a meat "coordinator or score-keeper" to check raids on local civilian meat supplies by the armed forces and war shipping agencies.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Forty-five billion dollars more must be raised this year to finance the war, through new taxes and increased purchases of war bonds, Secretary Morgenthau announced today while thanking the nation for its record-breaking participation in the recent $18,500,000,000 war loan drive.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 23 -- A comprehensive declaration of policy on post-war problems was made public tonight by Richard K. Law, chairman of the British delegation to the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture, after copies had been distributed to all the delegates from the forty-four nations represented here.

Full concentration by the American people on the task of winning the war can shorten its length by a year, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, declared yesterday. But he warned against overconfidence, selfishness and distrust, urging management, labor and the people to work as "if this were a never-ending war."
Louis Rosenberg of 595 West End Avenue, a middle-aged advertising and merchandising counsel is one of those fortunate people who finds things.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Attempts to break the Senate-House conference's deadlock over pay-as-you-go taxation failed twice again today when the four House Democratic members of the committee refused to listen to any compromise proposal that would result in cancellation of more than 50 per cent of a year's income taxes.

In THE TIMES of May 21 Harold Callender gives a very informative survey of German attitudes in this country toward plans of decentralizing or dismembering the Reich after the war. His factual enumeration, however, could easily make many of your readers believe that all those who oppose Germany's dismemberment act, by and large, out of the same basic reason -- that they resent any harsh treatment of their homeland.

A heavier volume of price-fixing by the trade yesterday overcame increased hedge selling and liquidation in the cotton futures market, raising prices to the highest levels in two weeks. Volume, nevertheless, remaining below 100,000 bales for the twenty-fifth consecutive session.

The newly organized Pressed Metal Institute, comprising some sixty representatives of sheet and strip metal fabricators, rolling mills and metal press manufacturers serving the industry, will cooperate closely with appropriate government departments to speed up and increase mass production of war materials, George E. Whitlock, president of the group, announced yesterday.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 24 -- An Army Air Force private testified here today in Hudson County Quarter Sessions Court that before he was inducted he had paid $500 for a job as a skilled worker in a machine shop, although he had never had experience in such work.

NEW DELHI, India, May 23 (Delayed) -- The scarcity of food, the high price of cloth and the general price and monetary inflation have reached a point where they throw political activities far into the background today.

The Columbus (Ohio) Boy Choir School laid a rare feast before lovers of early ecclesiastical music at the Town Hall last night, making up the entire first half of its program from works by three masters.

"The press is a barometer of freedom. The greater the degree of freedom of the press, the greater the democracy," declared Thomas W. Palmer, vice president of the Pan-American Society, at a luncheon of the society yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria in honor of ten Latin-American journalists from Cuba, Chile and Paraguay.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 111.8 to 112.2. The 0.4 per cent rise was due entirely to advances in the agricultural indexes. A sharp rise in the price of potatoes was primarily responsible for the 1.5 per cent increase in the farm products index and the 1.3 per cent increase in the foodstuffs index.

A special committee has been appointed by the Retail Fur Council to study and act upon the proposed simplified price-control plan developed by the National Federation of the Fur Industry, it was learned here yesterday.

Moving to encourage increased unit output of women's and children's clothing from available rayon, wool and cotton fabrics, the War Production Board yesterday issued its first general revision of Order L-85, which made its original appearance more than a year ago.

A PACIFIC BASE, April 26 -- The first impression of Guadalcanal most of the 164th remember was the beauty of the green hills and blue mountains in the early morning light and the heavy odor, sweet as a Maine clover field at cutting time, that blew off the eastward end of the island where meadow grasses and wild flowers carpet the swampy lowlands and receding hills.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 24 -- Soviet Russia is very much interested in the United Nations' conference on food and nutrition and its program for long-term, post-war reconstruction, but is chiefly concerned with getting more lend-lease food right now for the Russian Army and its civilian populations of areas liberated from Nazi rule.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- A procession of movie executives started toward the witness stand today as six alleged former associates of Al Capone began a legal battle against removal to New York for trial on charges of extorting more than $1,000,000 from motion picture companies.

A four-day music festival will be held in this city next week from Tuesday through Friday under the auspices of the Headquarters Chapter of the American Guild of Organists. The programs will be open to the public.

Net sales and profit of Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., in the six months ended March 31 were more than double those in the same period of the preceding year, according to a report by Ward M. Canaday, chairman, and Joseph W. Frazer, president, who said that increasing production of jeeps, shells, bullet cores, gun parts, aircraft subassemblies and many other war supplies accounted for the gains.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 (AP) -- That old master of infighting -- Hammerin' Henry Armstrong of Los Angeles -- displayed his talent unusually well tonight and scored a technical knockout over Maxie Shapiro of New York before 8,842 at Convention Hall.
SOMEWHERE IN IRAN, May 23 (Delayed) -- Here are more excerpts from your correspondent's diary:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Abolition of the National Youth Administration on June 30, thirty-six days hence, was recommended to the Senate today by a majority of the joint Congressional-Departmental committee on reduction of non-essential federal expenditures.

While the district Office of Price Administration was cracking down yesterday by suspending A books of violators of the renewed pleasure-driving ban, continued operation of city-owned vehicles under reduced allotments of gasoline for commercial users was becoming a source of extreme worry to Mayor La Guardia and city department heads.

The annual report of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies is both a summary of civilian problems that continue, and even intensify, in time of war, and a reminder of the tremendous task that must be done when the war is over. The Federation was organized in 1920, in a time of post-war problems; its leaders know, from experience, the magnitude of the tasks that lie ahead.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Marine Corps headquarters announced today that two officers and ten enlisted men had received letters of commendation for heroic actions during the initial assault upon Gavatu Island in the Solomons area last Aug. 7.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, May 24 -- New Zealand's shift to an offensive role in The Pacific war was stressed by Lieut. Gen. Edward Puttick, Commander in Chief of the Army, today.

The Nazi-controlled Paris radio broadcast a comment by one of its leading speakers yesterday, a Dr. Friedrich, in which he accused the Catholic Church of "a crushing responsibility in unleashing the present war."

Volume on the stock market slumped yesterday to the smallest in more than a month and prices continued to follow a mixed course, with only a few issues altered more than fractions. The sharp contraction in business appeared despite cheering war bulletins.

LONDON, May 24 (U.P.) -- Allied naval circles, discounting Axis complaints that the Atlantic was "empty" of shipping, said todayI that there was every indicationI that 1ay would be the war's most successful month of campaigning against the U-boat menace.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Office of Defense Transportation tonight ordered restriction of wholesale and retail deliveries in the Northeastern gasoline shortage area and entirely prohibited retail delivery of fifteen commodities -- including ice cream, soft drinks, alcoholic beverages, magazines and radios.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The reciprocal trade agreements extension resolution was taken to the Senate floor today with a warning from Senator George, in charge of the measure, that its adoption as amended by the finance committee, of which he is chairman, would constitute a refusal to commit the United States to economic collaboration with our Allies in the post-war period.
CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Lou Novikoff today signed baseball's most ballyhooed piece of paper this season -- his contract.

Considerable activity in the one and two-family home market in Brooklyn is evidenced by the reports received from brokers in that borough yesterday. The Home Owners Loan Corporation, alone, disposed of five properties.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 24 -- Pantelleria Island, Italy's rocky outpost in the Sicilian Strait, was hammered in three separate attacks by American Mitchells, Marauders and Warhawks yesterday and then bombed again last night by Wellingtons of the Royal Air Force, which pounded the harbor and airfield with two-ton block busters.

One effect of the war has been to make the housewife more receptive to personal interviews required in market research, S.W. Sheetz, director of research of the Ross Federal Research organization, reported yesterday at a meeting of the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.

MOSCOW, May 24 (AP) -- Joseph E. Davies, honored at a long state dinner given by Premier Joseph Stalin last night in the Kremlin, proposed that the Russians not rebuild Stalingrad on its present site, but leave the gallant Volga city as a memorial and a lesson to people yet unborn.

HONDO, Texas, May 24 (AP) -- E.F. Woodward, an oil-field roustabout who developed a fortune in that industry and then retired to develop one of its largest and most famous racing stables, died today of injuries received in an automobile-train collision.

As part of a six weeks' period of mourning and prayer proclaimed by the Synagogue Council of America 300 rabbis gathered yesterday morning in the Kehillath Jeshurun Synagogue, 117 West Eighty-fifth Street, to discuss intercession for Jewish and non-Jewish victims of Nazi persecution.

LONDON, May 24 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill, in a special appeal sent from Washington to all British coal miners, said today that coal production was dropping off "just as we are massing our strength in this year of vigorous assault" and called for greater output
BOSTON, May 24 (AP) -- Boston University conferred the honorary degree of doctor of laws on Wendell L. Willkie today.

The Yankees were back at the Stadium yesterday, but it was only for badly needed practice. Under the direction of Coach Art Fletcher, the squad went through a brisk two-hour drill. The club had returned in the morning from one of its most disastrous trips in the thirteen-year regime of Manager Joe McCarthy.

CHUNGKING, China, May 24 -- Although the dissolution of the Third International will not have any specific bearing in the relationship between the Chinese and Russian Governments, it will make their association easier during the war and particularly in the years of peace, according to a competent authority today.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- The war in Europe is in its final phases, with the fall of Germany and Italy expected within a year, to be followed by the military and political collapse of Japan, Dr. Eduard Benes, former President of Czechoslovakia and head of that nation's government in exile, said in a speech in Mandel Hall, University of Chicago, tonight.

Another property in Flushing, Queens, has been bought by the office of Commander Vincent Astor, it was learned yesterday. It is the two-story taxpayer at 136-27 to 136-35 Roosevelt Avenue, running through to Thirty-ninth Avenue, which was purchased from Maurice Levin and is directly opposite the bus terminal acquired by the same purchaser in the Fall of last year.

Last week this column pointed out the tremendous rise in the cost of food since 1939 and its effect on low-income families in New York City. Today we report on how such families are being aided by social welfare agencies in the city, among them the Department of Welfare, the Community Service Society, the Jewish Social Service Association and the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TLfS: AS the news from the flooded Western areas brings daily reports of the terrific loss, would it not be a good time to seriously consider means of averting similar catastrophes?
CAMDEN, N.J., May 24 -- A list of the dead in the wreck of the Pennsylvania Railroad Express near Delair, N.J., last night, and of the injured who are still in hospitals, follows:

LONDON, May 24 (U.P.) -- Gestapo Chief Heinrich Himmler has ordered thousands of workers from the Netherlands and other occupied countries to help on reconstruction in the areas flooded by the R.A.F.'s balsting of the Moehne and Eder dams, Aneta, the Netherlands news agency, said tonight.

CHUNGKING, China, May 24 (U.P.) -- The Japanese have driven deeper into Chinese defenses south of the Yangtze River in Western Hupeh Province and are pressing their advance westward toward Chungking, now less than 260 miles from the enemy's forward units, it was announced tonight.

Next Tuesday night's premiere of "Kicked Upstairs" at the Windsor having been canceled, according to the management of the theatre, Broadway will be without an opening for the fourth consecutive week. "Three's a Family" was the last entry, on May 5 at the Longacre; the next will be "The Student Prince," on June 8 at the Broadway.

Dortmund, already half flooded by the breaching of the Ruhr dams, has now been blasted by 2,000 tons of airborne explosive. Raids of this kind, undertaken in a relentless effort to destroy enemy war production and disrupt enemy transport, will certainly continue and increase in power.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 19, the Federal Reserve Board announced today: increases of $240,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, and $601,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and a decrease of $481,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

One by one the barriers set up against the press at Hot Springs have been let down until now the newspaper men can do their work there almost as freely as in Washington. The Government, which in this case means the President, has shown a commendable willingness to rectify its mistake, though not admitting that it actually was a mistake.

Before the war is over most of us may have learned by heart the difference between logistics and logic, but one cannot be too sure. The difficulty is by no means one-sided. Logistics is a new word and a very technical word, whereas men have talked about logic probably ever since men began to speak at all.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Gerald M.F. McLaughlin, a prominent lawyer of Newark, N.J., was nominated by President Roosevelt today for a judgeship on the Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
LONDON, Tuesday, May 25 (U.P.) -- A special Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a new challenge of the constitutionality of a penalty tax imposed on wheat produced in excess of quotas set by the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Representative Herter of Massachusetts, chairman of a Republican food subcommittee, told the House today that the nation's food distribution machinery was in complete breakdown approaching a "major catastrophe."

LONDON, May 24 -- Five hundred British Girl Guides, all of them volunteers over 21 years of age, are now being trained to follow the liberating armies into Europe and help in the administration of relief to the hungry, weakened populations of the enemy-occupied countries.

The ascendancy of national patriotism over ideology as a basis of unity among and within the United Nations, inspired by the war and so dramatically exemplified by the dissolution of the Third International, now promises to produce an equally gratifying result -- the unification of France.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 24 -- Black market suppliers are likely to destroy the legitimate marketing agencies, especially the auctions that New Jersey farmers have built for themselves during the last fifteen years as a low-cost means of getting their foodstuffs to Metropolitan New York and North Jersey outlets, according to a group of farmer spokesmen who gathered today to discuss the problem at the State College of Agriculture here tonight.

An unprecedented demand for teachers, one third of them in the field of science, was reported yesterday by the teaching division of the Columbia University Appointments Office, which has been called upon to fill a thousand jobs in the last year.
NEW DELHI, India, May 24 (AP) -- A communique:
Mrs. James M. Cox, wife of the former Governor of Ohio, and her daughter, Mrs. Bradford Ripley 2d, have arrived from Trailsend, their home in Dayton, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.
NEW DELHI, India, May 24 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Discussion of major aspects of the bituminous coal controversy approached completion today at the War Labor Board and it was indicated that recommendations to the United Mine Workers and the coal operators of the Appalachian area may be ready by Wednesday.

WHEN the Pirates were playing the Dodgers at Ebbets Field, Frank Frisch decided to give his ancient muscles some exercise. So he planted himself at third base for the final stages of the infield drill. Jake Flowers batted a sizzler at him, and the Flash missed it with great neatness and dispatch. Again Flowers drilled one down and again Frisch completely missed coming up with the ball.

Dr. Charles Dewey Crandall, dismissed deputy medical examiner of Bellevue Hospital, received the option yesterday in Special Sessions of paying a $100 fine or going to the workhouse for thirty days on his recent conviction of possessing a pistol in his penthouse apartment at the hospital.

An increase in the coffee ration to one pound a person every three weeks was urged by the principal spokesmen for the coffee trade yesterday on the basis of increasing stocks of coffee. On Sunday, Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown announced the ration would be increased to a pound a person every four weeks instead of every five under Stamp 24, valid May 31.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A 2,000-mile Army Signal Corps telephone line from Edmonton, Alberta, to Fairbanks, Alaska, capable of simultaneously carrying vocal, telegraphic and radio messages, is "nearing completion," the War Department disclosed today.

Until we get a law making greed a crime, punishable by some drastic method, warfare will never be eliminated. Self-preservation, with its concomitant development of greed, superinduced by the economic methods of the word, will engender conditions which have brought and will continue to bring on warfare.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 24 -- Comment in official circles in Rome on the dissolution of the Third International today recognizes in the move an "unquestionable success" for the Allies, not only on the international front but also on their home fronts where there has been opposition to collaboration with the International.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 24 -- There is growing gloom in quarters here that know what is going on over the possibility that neutral Sweden may be facing the war's most difficult time, with more complete commercial and communications isolation from the Western world.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- President Roosevelt and Prime Minister Churchill conferred together and with United Nations military leaders; Mr. Roosevelt's visitors included George Harrison and Marriner Eccles; he nominated Rear Admirals William A. Glassford and Raymond A. Spruance to be vice admirals, and Captain Wilder Baker to be a rear admiral; he proclaimed effective the treaty by which the United States relinquishes extraterritorial rights in China.

President Roosevelt, in a message read last night in Carnegie Hall at the celebration of the 400th anniversary of the death of Copernicus, declared that liberty was not the exclusive right of great men and great nations but "must be made progressively available to small states, to communities and to the individual himself if humanity is to march forward into light and life."

Add to the list of films opening this week, "That Nazty Nuisance," a Hal Roach comedy, which will arrive at the Laffmovie, Broadway and Forty-sixth Street, on Friday. Bobby Watson, Joe Devlin and Johnny Arthur are featured in the picture which was produced and directed by Glenn Tryon.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Spokesmen of the knitted underwear industry expressed vigorous opposition today to proposed standardization and grade labeling, contending it would wipe out brand names as an integral part of American life, as a House subcommittee opened hearings on grade labeling.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 25 -- Beating down the world's thickest anti-aircraft defenses guarding the primary source of Germany's war power, the Royal Air Force dumped more than 2,000 tons of bombs on the industrial city of Dortmund in the Ruhr on Sunday night in the heaviest and most concentrated air attack in history.

PHILADELPHIA, May 24 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of two amendments to a rule dealing with the qualifications of accountants who certify financial statements, in order to avoid what the commission said was misunderstanding resulting from use of the more particularized language of the original rule.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- A joint announcement by the War and Navy Departments today said that the Army-Navy Production Award pennant had been granted to twenty-nine more plants engaged on war contracts. Their names and addresses are:
The Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office said yesterday that the danger of the city being bombed grows each day, and yet essential CDVO services are still short of 376,768 volunteers.

LONDON, May 24 -- Despite near-starvation conditions and the relentless requirements of the forced labor system, Belgium's resistance to the Nazis is increasing and morale remains high, it was asserted today by a count, a countess and a baron who had escaped from their homeland.

The late Dr. Henry R. Linville, a leader of the group that left the Teachers Union to form the Teachers Guild, considered Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, one of the "Communist or Communist fellow-traveler" group in the national organization, Benjamin Stolberg, writer, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury.
The German Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
BALDWIN, L.I., May 24 -- Bob Odom and Willie Klein today outscored opposing combinations in the weekly one-day amateur-pro golf play at the Milburn Club sponsored by the Long Island P.G.A.

Thirty-one air raid sirens in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn were sounded by mistake at 11:25 A.M. yesterday as 1,250,000 school children in this city had a practice air raid drill and as all of New York State outside of New York City had its first State-wide daytime practice alert.
TULELAKE, Calif., May 24 -- Seven young Japanese-Americans, dressed in their best outfits, shook hands with tearful well-wishers today, climbed into a station wagon and started on a great adventure.

Recessions upstream narrowed the Midwestern flood zone, but torrents of water poured through and over dikes and forced hundreds of families to join the homeless multitudes, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

In this newspaper yesterday were notes by C.L. Sulzberger of a hitch-hiking trip over the rough road that carries supplies through Iran to the Russians. The route is a sort of cemetery of trucks. The Iranian truck drivers make Jehu look like a slowpoke.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The resignation of several key officials of the Food Price Division of the Office of Price Administration and the reported withdrawal of still others -- in all, more than a dozen -- were linked today to growing policy differences despite denials by Administrator Prentiss M. Brown of rumors of a "mass" crack-up of his organization.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday opened a drive to be conducted by the city's grade and high school students throughout the week for used clothing to send to Soviet civilians through the Russian War Relief. He accepted 150 bundles of clothing from two young representatives of the 600 pupils at Public School 11, 314 West Twenty-first Street, who were assembled in the school's auditorium.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Aaron L. Jacoby, former Kings County Sheriff and later Register, was named yesterday as chief clerk of the Kings County Surrogate's Court by Surrogate Francis D. McGarey. Mr. Jacoby will get $12,000 anunually in the post formerly held by Percy T. Stapleton, who retired recently.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- Aggressive buying of rye futures, headed by houses with Eastern connections, carried the price of that grain up around 1 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade and to within 1/2 cent of the seasonal high before liberal profit-taking developed and caused a reaction.

Vanya Oakes, author of "White Man's Folly," published last January by Houghton, Mifflin, will speak to the members of the New York branch of the English Speaking Union at P.M. today in their clubrooms, 30 Rockefeller Plaza.

Synthetic flavors developed to meet wartime shortages of the natural products have proved so satisfactory that they are likely to be continued in use permanently, it was brought out yesterday at the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Ballet and opera will be given at the Stadium Concerts this Summer according to an announcement made yesterday by the management. Additional conductors and soloists were listed.

Now that the National Power and Light Company, a unit in the Electric Bond and Share Company system, has sold its remaining common stock holdings in the Houston Lighting and Power Company, the next step in its program of corporate simplification and eventual liquidation is the retirement of substantially all of its outstanding preferred stock now in the hands of the public.

LONDON, Tuesday, May 25 (AP) -- Still sparring in preliminaries to an expected great Summer offensive, Red Army troops made a feeler thrust Monday into German positions on the Western front and smashed a strong German battle reconnaissance group near Rostov, the Russians reported early today.

AKRON, Ohio, May 24 -- Sporadic fisticuffs broke out and the number of idle Akron rubber workers rose to 44,000 today as pickets formed a shoulder-to-shoulder barricade at gates of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's largest plant, turning away afternoon shift employes.

An appeal to the American Women's Voluntary Services to "go after the gal that's sitting out this war" was made yesterday by Grover Whalen, director of the Greater New York Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.
Another big weekday crowd, 14,377 fans, found a way to Belmont Park yesterday without the use of automobiles and watched an afternoon of racing that had several out of the ordinary trimmings.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (U.P.) -- The top-flight Norfolk Naval Training Station baseball team beat the Senators tonight, 4 to 3, barely riding out a ninth-inning rally by the American Leaguers that topped off a brilliant $2,000,000 war bond exhibition game.

The ire of a Red Cross worker's husband was aroused yesterday when four of her Period Six A gasoline coupons were canceled by an Office of Price Administration hearing board. Mrs. Cecilia Robbins of 25 Lefferts Avenue, Brooklyn, appeared at the Empire State Building in her Red Cross uniform with her husband to answer a charge of nonessential driving after an OPA inspector saw her car Sunday in Millbrook, N.Y.

JERSEY CITY, May 24 (AP) -- Newark made it two out of three in its series with Jersey City by capturing the third and final game today 2 to 0, behind the brilliant four-hit pitching of Walter Dubiel, rookie right-hander.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Over almost solid Southern opposition and amid threats of a Senate filibuster and political reprisals against the New Deal, the House indicated today it was in favor of abolition of poll taxes as a prerequisite to voting in any election involving a Federal office.

NORFOLK, Va., May 24 (AP) -- While a United States patrol plane circled directly overhead, an Axis submarine torpedoed and sank a medium-size Panamanian merchant ship in a daylight attack off the United States East Coast early in May, survivors of the lost vessel related on arrival here.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- With the National Resources Planning Board's future threatened by lack of funds, President Roosevelt asked Congress today for authority to spend up to $85,000,000 to stimulate a post-war public works program in cooperation with State and local authorities.

LONDON, May 24 -- The stock markets here opened the week quietly, with a generally firm tone. Diamond shares attracted attention today as buying shifted to London, due to the closing of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange in celebration of Empire Day.

HOLLYWOOD, May 24 -- Franchot Tone was signed today by Universal for the romantic lead opposite Deanna Durbin in "My Girl Godfrey," formerly titled "His Butler's Sister," which with Pat O'Brien playing the third role will follow Miss Durbin's current "Hers to Hold."

Misapprehension still exists in the minds of both draft board members and registrants regarding the difference between essential war work and listed non-deferrable occupations, it was admitted yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, New York City Selective Service Director, who made public a memorandum he had just dictated in the hope of clearing up the situation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, May 25 (AP) -- Two formations of Allied heavy bombers yesterday attacked Japanese airdromes at Rabaul, New Britain, where a large concentration of enemy aircraft had been reported.

The report of the War Labor Board panel on soft-coal wages shows every effort to be fair to the claims of the miners union. Indeed, the panel seems to lean backward in an effort to find a formula for giving Mr. Lewis an increase. It begins by declaring that it was asked for a "purely factual report."
A number of leases in buildings on Park Avenue and in structures on the East Side were among the contracts for residential quarters reported by brokers yesterday.

The General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, the former Democratic Deputy City Controller, on the charge that he tried to obtain $8,000 last November from the Triangle Appliance Corporation to kill a bill before the City Council affecting the concern's reputed stirrup-pump monopoly, was devoted exclusively yesterday to the running off of police dictograph records for the blue-ribbon jurors.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores had an increase of 17 per cent in sales last week over the comparative 1942 week, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. For the preceding week the bank had reported a rise of 17 per cent in sales volume.

Politics in Britain have been suspended during the war by reason of a "truce" between the Conservative party, which has a substantial majority in the House of Commons, and the Labor party, which forms the Opposition. Whenever a vacancy has occurred in the House a candidate has been nominated to fill this vacancy only by the party that held the seat in question.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Sixteen twin-engined Japanese bombers appeared over Attu yesterday but six of the Army's swift twin-tailed Lightning fighters tore into them and shot down five of the enemy. This stroke at the United States land forces on Attu followed the surprising but unsuccessful Japanese attack the day before by fifteen twin-engined bombers on two American vessels supporting the United States Army operations on the small Aleutian island.

ALBANY, May 24 (AP) -- Parker Corning, while in Congress, fought attempted continuation of the National Recovery and Agricultural Adjustment Administrations and the Guffey Coal Act before their invalidation by the United States Supreme Court.

Recommending that commercial banks in this State that maintain thrift accounts adopt a uniform method of computing interest on these accounts, the New York State Bankers Association, through its committee on bank management and research, states that at present these banks now use no less than eighty different ways of reckoning interest.

ALGIERS, May 24 -- Colonel Francois de Linares, spokesman of the French Provisional Government, said today: "General de Gaulle, having accepted the laws of the republic and democratic ideas in the same spirit as General Giraud, as far as we are concerned unity has been achieved."
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 24 -- The text of the statement by A.D. Krutikov, chairman of the Russian delegation, to the food conference, follows :

Patrons of motion-picture theatres donated $2,100,000 to the fund collection campaign for the National Foundation of Infantile Paralysis, it was announced yesterday by Nicholas M. Schenck, National Foundation for Infantile the film industry.
WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Although the War Production Board in no way sought to create or curb fashions by its clothing order today, the result will be to keep extremes of fashion "out" for the duration.

A group exhibition of oils, watercolors, drawings and sculpture by American, British and Mexican artists, is being held at the American British Art Center, 44 West Fifty-sixth Street. It will continue through this week.
LONDON, May 24 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Before boarding a train for Chicago, the Giants dropped in at the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, blood bank yesterday. Led by Manager Mel Ott, all but three members of the squad donated a pint and said they were happy to do so.

Figures indicating a sharp shrinkage in the milk supply for New York and other cities of the State were made public yesterday by Fred H. Sexauer, president of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, with a statement that "the nation is about to pay in terms of inadequate milk, butter and cheese supplies for unsound price and regulatory policies applied by the government against the dairy industry."

ABILENE, Kan., May 24 -- What makes the wheels go 'round is no mystery to ten Kansas Wows. They spend forty-eight hours a week around and beneath Army trucks and Jeeps, on maintenance jobs. These girls, all members of the Woman Ordnance Workers, are graduates of the first Civilian Automotive Technicians' School for Women at Fort Crook, Annex No. 2, near Plattsmouth, Neb.

LONDON, May 24 -- Because of the disbanding of the Communist International some executive committee members of the British Labor party are pressing for a special meeting to reconsider the issue of Communist affiliation. If they fail the issue will be fought out at the next convention.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo introduced several novelties in matters of personnel and casting at its performance last night at the Broadway Theatre. For one thing, Alexandra Danilova, who has been out of the bill for two performances, returned to make her first appearance in the "Pas de Deux Classique" from "The Magic Swan," and won as always the enthusiastic plaudits of the spectators.

Unless governmental agencies charged with administering the food program quickly straighten out the "muddled situation," 2,000 "panicky" restaurants are seriously considering closing for the duration, it was reported last night by Paul Henkel, president of the Society of Restaurateurs.

Japanese Imperial Headquarters asserted yesterday that Japanese aircraft and submarines had sunk a destroyer and damaged six other United States warships, including a battleship, in the Attu area, and other Axis broadcast asserted that 5,000 United States Army and Navy men had been "lost" in the fighting.
Peconic Bay weakfishing on Sunday found all available craft chartered largely by veterans who have been accustomed to making the trip to the east end of Long Island each Spring.

In an editorial in your issue of May 21 you attribute the drop of civilian defense workers to signs of overconfidence. I have the feeling that this loss of membership, as far as air raid wardens are concerned, is due to two causes: First, the lack of effort on the part of existing posts to canvass for new members.

MIAMI, Fla., May 24 (U.P.) -- Poon Lim told in detail here tonight how he got that "Chinaman's chance" and lived in nakedness 132 days on a life raft in the South Atlantic after being the only survivor of fifty-five men aboard a torpedoed English merchantman.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- Norman T. Bolles, vice president and general manager of the Narragansett Machine Company, Pawtucket, R.I., told a House Military subcommittee today that John P. Monroe had connived with Albert Fey "to blacken our name with this committee."

Three-year-old Charles Rosich Jr. was promised an identification tag by his father, who lives at 751 East 155th Street, the Bronx, last night when Mr. Rosich claimed his son at the Bronx Children's Shetler at 6 o'clock last night. The boy was found wandering shortly after 4:30 A.M yesterday by a policeman at Wales and Westchester Avenues, an isolated section of the Bronx.

The thirteen-story Hotel Wentworth at 59-61 West Forty-sixth Street, together with the adjoining five-story structure at 56 West Forty-seventh Street, has been purchased by a new corporation, headed by Benjamin Winter as president and Walter A. Baron as secretary-treasurer.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The War Department made public today an additional list of American civilians, with next of kin or emergency addresses, interned by the Japanese in the Philippine Islands. The number of items on this list is 526, but the number of internees is considerably larger, because in some cases one entry represents several members of a family.

DELAIR, N.J., May 24 -- The blame for the derailment of a Pennsylvania Railroad Atlantic City-New York express that cost the lives of fourteen persons, including a baby born during the accident, and injured more than a hundred was placed today on the engineer by an official of the line, who said a preliminary investigation indicated the train was traveling at an excessive speed for the section of track where the accident occurred.

CHICAGO, May 24 (AP) -- Producers unloaded today the largest number of salable offerings in three months on the hog market and prices promptly broke 10 to 15 cents to new lows for the year. Top was $14.40 and average price was estimated at $14.25.

ALBANY, May 24 -- The epidemic of amoebic dysentery that raged at Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens during the early months of the year "has been brought to an end," Moreland Act Commissioner Archie O. Dawson informed Governor Dewey today in a report recommending sweeping changes in policy and administration, not only at the institution but in the entire Department of Mental Hygiene.

LONDON, May 24 -- There is sufficient tangible evidence to hand now to justify the statement that those strategists who believe the wide use of air power against Germany can save the lives of thousands of American and British soldiers when the time comes to invade Europe have won the day.

The adoption of an extensive social security system to meet the needs of "the common man" and returning soldiers will not infringe on individual initiative and independence, Dr. Herman Finer, special consultant on post-war reconstruction problems at the International Labor Office in Montreal, told the annual meeting of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities yesterday at the Hotel Bossert.

ANKARA, Turkey, May 23 (Delayed) (AP) -- Reports of a Turkish move to appoint an Ambassador to the Greek Government in Exile were regarded in informed quarters today as an indication of open Turkish acceptance of the Allied belief that the exiled government ultimately would resume the control of Greece.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The long-awaited test of the Federal Rent Control Law was thrown out by the Supreme Court today because the tribunal ruled that the case was collusive, with the lawyers on both sides chosen and paid by one of the participants.

A resolution condemning "the undemocratic attitude and established policy of the American Bar Association, whereby it discriminates in the admission to its membership of Negro attorneys," was adopted yesterday by members of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut at a meeting ill the United States Court House in Foley Square.

Loew's, Inc., in a statement of operations for the twenty-eight weeks ended on March 18 reveals a net profit of $6,376,228 after $2,600,000 reserve for contingencies, $1,793,512 for depreciation and $8,862,771 provision for Federal taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The Office of Price Administration today authorized manufacturers to set their own prices under the General Maximum Price Regulation for new products not sold by them or by competitors during March, 1942, instead of asking the Washington office of OPA to set them as has hitherto been required.

WASHINGTON. May 24 -- "If you've followed recipes exactly in making cake, you can learn to load shells," the Women's Bureau of the Labor Department told housewives today in a bulletin describing war industrial jobs for which their household skills have fitted them. It adds:
A program designed to solve wartime nursing problems in this State was adopted here yesterday by the New York State Nursing Council, of which Miss Alta E. Dines is chairman.

LONDON, May 24 -- One of the longest, most complex political battles of World War II seemed to have entered a new and hopeful phase tonight with the announcement that General Charles de Gaulle had accepted General Henri Honore Giraud's proposal for the meeting of a nine-man committee in Algiers and would probably go to North Africa with two aides within a week.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The current activity of the director of Economic Stabilization, Mr. Byrnes, as liaison between the President and the Congressional conferees of the tax payment-method bill highlights an administrative procedure to which some students of the war program attribute many of its conflicts, confusions and delays.

A special meeting of stockholders of the Celotex Corporation has been called for June 18 to vote on proposals to change each share of $100 par value 5 per cent preferred stock into five shares of $20 par preferred stock and to authorize the issuance and sale of 134,067 shares of common stock at $10.50 each.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- While steps were being announced today for the resumption of unity conferences between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations the International Association of Machinists, A.F.L., authorized its executive board to withdraw from the Federation if, in its discretion, it deemed it necessary to do so.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- The War Department gave out today the names, with next of kin, of 252 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

In a hurried effort to untangle the bottleneck in supplies of part-wool yarns for Army socks that has been developing for several months, the War Production Board will hold an emergency meeting today in Washington, it was learned yesterday in the local textile market.
I was greatly pleased to read your editorial in which you bring together in one paragraph the names of Commander Howard W. Gilmore and Captain James Lawrence of "Don't give up the ship" fame.

A few contrasting messages are to be found in the mailbag today, one of them coming from J. Hammond Brown, president of the Outdoor Writers Association of America, who forwards a few items about Alaska.

Arthur O. Dietz, president of the Universal C.I.T. Credit Corporation, announced yesterday that owners of automobiles may now trade them in for new cars, for post-war delivery, while war workers can obtain good used cars for essential transportation, under a plan to be operated by the company, sales financing subsidiary of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Two years of self-regulation by securities dealers through the National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., is bearing fruit, as evidenced by a large decline in the number of complaints against brokers in the last seven or eight months, Wallace H. Fulton, executive director of the association, said today at a meeting of its board of governors.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., May 25 (AP) -- Gloria Baker Topping received a divorce today from Henry J. Topping Jr. on the ground of mental cruelty. She received the custody of two young children, Sandra Emerson Topping, 4, and Henry J. Topping 3d, 3.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 25 -- Flying Fortresses, Mitchells and Marauders were used in yesterday's smashing attacks on Sardinia. In addition, formations of Lightnings carrying bombs roamed over the island, attacking whatever targets were sighted.

BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP) -- Baltimore Transit Company workers voted today to go out on strike at 4 o'clock tomorrow morning. Union leaders said the strike would tie up at least 80 per cent of the city's transportation system, already strained by the gasoline shortage.

THE baseball teams shift their scene of operations today with the Eastern clubs of the National League out where the West begins and the Western combinations of the American League opening a new front along the Atlantic seaboard.

Wartime retailing demands an "extra something" from the store controller in terms of flexibility, speed and imagination and this requirement will be still more emphasized in the post-war period, Sidney Reisman, vice president and general merchandise manager of Bloomingdale Brothers, said last night at the dinner meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Hotel Martinique.

The celebration of the fiftieth anniversary of the Henry Street Visiting Nursing Service brings to mind another institution which was founded about the same time and which has worked in close cooperation with the Settlement. I refer to Gouverneur Hospital, located on the lower East Side, a stone's throw from the original Henry Street Settlement House.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- As long as the OPA retains in responsible positions within its organization "persons or a group of persons who maintain an ignorant prejudice against business," its path is bound to continue to be rocky, Earl Constantine, president of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers, told the House committee investigating government restrictions on brand names and newsprint.

Since 1933 the Government has issued some 500,000 visas to persons in countries dominated by the Axis Powers. Only about 250,000 have succeeded in escaping to our shores. Among these exiles are 2,250 who are not only a desirable acquisition at any time but a source of intellectual war-power which we have not yet tapped.

Charged by the State Constitution with the duty of redrawing assembly district lines within the city in accordance with the reapportionment enacted by the Legislature this year, the City Council adopted a resolution by unanimous vote yesterday setting up a committee of ten authorized to spend $25,000 on the job.

Laying the nation's "alarming" food situation to the fundamental unsoundness of the OPA approach to food price control, Paul S. Willis, president of the Grocery Manufacturers of America, proposed yesterday a study to determine the practicability of placing food controls at the source instead of at the retail level.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 (AP) -- American Liberators dropped 150 tons of bombs before noon yesterday on the Southern Italian harbors of San Giovanni and Reggio Calabria, where exploded ammunition dumps shot sheets of flame and debris more than 1,000 feet into the air.

Five New York experimental theatres have been placed on a blacklist for failing to meet craft union conditions, Actors Equity Association was informed yesterday. The council of the actors' union endorsed the stand of the other unions, it was announced by Alfred Harding, Equity spokesman.

WITH A FLEET TASK FORCE IN SOUTH PACIFIC (Delayed) (AP) -- This task force scouted almost under the noses of the Japanese Shortland and Bougainville island strongholds in the farthest penetration yet made by such a major fleet unit up the Solomons Islands "slot" from Guadalcanal.

Albert Spalding, violinist, gave a brilliant recital in Town Hall last night before an enthusiastic audience that overflowed to the stage. He had contrived a program both popular and at the same time musically important.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Petroleum Administration for War announced today that fourteen depots will be established in oil-producing areas by July to meet emergency needs for materials by wildcat operators, those prospecting in new fields.
The text of the government's motion for summary judgment against The Associated Press follows:
WASHINGTON, May 25 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board today voiced

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- By 265 to 110 the House adopted the Marcantonio Anti-Poll Tax Bill today. The measure would abolish poll taxes as a prerequisite for voting for Federal candidates in primaries and final elections in the seven Southern States which impose this levy. Three members of the House merely voted present.

The British radio, in a broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System, said yesterday that Crown Prince Humbert of Italy, in a special order of the day, had warned Italians that they were short of arms and called on his troops to throw into the struggle all their "spiritual and physical strength."

In a move unprecedented in anti-trust cases, the Department of Justice yesterday demanded summary judgment, without trial or further presentation of evidence, in its suit against The Associated Press. The motion was presented to the three-judge expediting court that will decide the case and was made on the basis of a government contention that sufficient facts were already on file to warrant a verdict for the plaintiff and against the cooperative news-gathering agency.

BOSTON, May 25 (U.P.) -- Forty-two sailors perished when a medium-size Netherland merchant vessel was torpedoed and sunk by a submarine in the North Atlantic early last month, thirty-eight survivors reported today on their arrival here.

LONDON, May 25 -- Lord Perry, chairman of the British-controlled Ford Motor Company Limited and one of the first men in the automotive industry in this country, urged that the United States after the war "eliminate exports of motor vehicles in an interview published in the weekly magazine Great Britain and the East."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 25 (U.P.) -- Blood donated by American civilians saved thousands of lives during the Tunisian campaign, British Major Gen. Ernest Cowell, director of the Medical Services of the Allied Armies in North Africa, said today.

Miss Belle Calloun, 29-year-old chief wire machine operator at the Lincoln Wire Company, 47 Walker Street, has been selected as "Miss Negro War Worker," it was announced yesterday. Miss Calloun, who was chosen in a nation-wide contest, will receive a $25 War Bond at the Negro Freedom Rally show at Madison Square Garden on June 7.
MOBILE, Ala., May 25 -- Mobile was heavily patroled tonight following a racial disorder in a shipyard which resulted in upward of 7,000 Negro workers being called from their jobs throughout the city.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 -- Asserting that "transportation will be the basic commodity of which the world will have most need" in the post-war period, Edward G. Budd, president of the manufacturing company bearing his name, disclosed today that the concern has a backlog of $164,000,000 of war orders and that prospects were that the transportation field would be kept busy for "years" after the war.

Henry C. Taylor, Dr. Arpad Lux, in 21 E 79th St; A.J. Cordier, in 130 E 67th St; Mrs. Lillian B. Ballin, in 49 E 86th St; James E. Gray, in 230 E 50th St; Capt. Vlaho Bruer, Walter W. Hess, Edna E. Donnell, in 40 Central Park South -- Culver, Hollyday Co, brokers.

Henry Armstrong, fresh from his seven-round knockout of Maxie Shapiro at Philadelphia last Monday night, yesterday was signed to meet Sammy Angott, the former lightweight champion, in a 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, June 11.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A cotton weavers' industry advisory committee, national in scope and intended to establish a means for more direct consultation between the Office of Price Administration and the industry, is in the process of formation, the OPA announced today.

Remington Rand, Inc., and its subsidiaries, in a preliminary statement of operations for the fiscal year ended March 31 released today, reports net profits of $4,318,478 after depreciation, interest, United States and foreign income and excess profits taxes.

DANBURY, Conn., May 25 -- A controversy over the appearance of a decoration on Danbury's honor roll, identified as the fasces of ancient Rome, also currently the symbol of the Italian Fascisti -- but also, however, engraved on one side of the American dime -- was raging here tonight.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 25 -- A Camden County grand jury will be requested to fix the responsibility for the derailment of the Pennsylvania Railroad Atlantic City-New York express in which fourteen persons were killed and more than 100 injured, County Prosecutor Gene R. Mariano said today. The wreck occurred Sunday night at Delair, N.J., two miles from here.
CHUNGKING, China, May 25 (U.P.) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it had set up a "roll-back" averaging 7 per cent in ceiling prices of potatoes to consumers, while increasing the price paid to growers by 30 cents a hundredweight on the early 1943 crop.

There is no doubt in the minds of most Americans as to the importance of food production in the war effort. But few fully realize the problems of the farmers trying to maintain a maximum output. I am not discussing here the labor or the economic problems of agriculture, with which we are already somewhat familiar.

A "marriage" between the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office and the American Women's Voluntary Services to carry out more effectively the common war aims of both groups was proposed last night by Grover Whalen, president of the CDVO here.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 26 (U.P.) -- Planes of the Russian Black Sea Fleet have sunk seven of a fleet of eleven German landing boats, motor-torpedo boats and transports along the forty-five-mile stretch of the coast between Anapa and Kerch, northwest of Novorossiisk, and have set fire to two more, the Moscow radio said today.

At least eight champions will be on hand to defend their national A.A.U. crowns in the fifty-fifth annual track and field title meet at Triboro Stadium on Randalls Island June 19 and 20, it was announced yesterday by Dan Ferris, national secretary-treasurer.

Charles Oliver of Perth Amboy, N.J., became the new champion as the William Howard Taft High School interscholastic tennis championship was concluded at the Concourse Tennis Club yesterday. In a close and exciting match, Oliver defeated the defending champion, Alan Watson of Milburn (N.J.) High, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 25 -- Trial began here today before J. Addison Young, Supreme Court referee, of three marital suits brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey, lieutenant commander in the Coast Guard and former champion heavyweight pugilist, and Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey, former actress whom he married ten years ago in Nevada.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 25 -- Following is the text of the United States delegation's proposal that the United Nations Food Conference set up an interim commission to carry on the conference's work:
Fashion designers of the city, asked for their opinion of the latest action taken by the War Production Board in ruling out fashion frills, agreed yesterday that the new regulations were not extreme.

For the first time this year, the general death rate in New York City fell below 11 per 1,000 estimated population, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins said yesterday in his weekly report. The death rate last week was 10.7, still .06 above the "predicted" rate for the season.

It will be Home, Sweet, Home, so far as the Yankees are concerned, today at the Stadium, where the American League champions -- they didn't act or look the part in recent starts -- launch a home stand against the Western clubs, engaging the strength of the circuit until June 6, on which date they take to the road again.
The German Tuesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALBANY, May 25 -- Transfer of the August racing dates from Saratoga to either Belmont Park or Aqueduct was assured today when Federal representatives concurred in a decision by James C. Hagerty, executive assistant to Governor Dewey, that racing at the up-State track could not be conducted without the use of automobiles.

Although empowered by Congress to extend financial aid, the Smaller War Plants Corporation prefers that local banks assume such functions, Henry M. Brundage, regional director of the agency, declared yesterday at the forum on "Helping Distressed Plants" at the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (U.P.) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said today that the only way to wipe out black markets was for consumers to refuse to patronize them. She asserted that the patrons were equally responsible for the illegal establishments.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- The War Labor Board said today that it denied a panel's recommendation for 8 cents an hour wage increase for Akron rubber workers because granting it would have "seriously unstabilized wage relationships in the industry."

The Allied air war is being carried in full force to Italy's islands. Pantelleria, bombed eight times in nine days, can no longer send up fighter planes to defend itself. Every port of Sicily has been pounded hard. Cagliari, capital of Sardinia, has been abandoned by its civilian population, while American Flying Fortresses and Warhawks range over the island 300 at a time.
The reconquest of Attu, still incomplete last night, is a small part of the difficult pattern of Pacific strategy.

An exhibition of paintings by Jean-Louis Forain will be opened to the public today, inaugurating the new exhibition rooms at the headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 457 Madison Avenue. A preview tea was held on Monday afternoon.

An American B-24 Liberator bomber known to its crew of ten as Tidewater Tillie was back in the news last night, The United Press reported, this time with a thrilling story of how it caught a German submarine on the surface and blew it to pieces with depth charges.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 25 -- Paramount has bought "Ready, Willing and 4-F," an original screen story by Brian Marlow, as the basis for an Army camp comedy for Eddie Bracken, William Bendix and Gil Lamb. It will be filmed this Summer with E.D. Leshin producing.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Their exhibition game at the Great Lakes Naval Training Station postponed until a later visit, Mel Ott and his Giants' board of strategy spent most of today striving desperately to devise ways and means of snapping the Polo Grounders out of a slump that threatens soon to deposit them in last place unless something drastic is done.

The nine-family apartment house at 1619 Palisade Avenue, Union City, N.J., was sold by the Hoboken Bank for Savings to the Sirab Realty Company, Inc. Pierson Brand were the attorneys for the bank. Wilbur Rose represented the buyer. J.I. Kislak, Inc., were the brokers.

Eighty-seven cents out of each dollar spent for education in New York City goes directly for instruction of the children, according to the Board of Education's annual financial and statistical report, made public yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools.

Not only the war plans being hammered out in Washington by British and American strategists but post-war plans as well will be appreciably affected by the results of the systematic bombing of German industry. The numerous official and unofficial groups engaged in studying the problems of peace have given a great deal of thought to the question of destroying the war potential of the Reich.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- A Senate appropriations subcommittee deleted from the $134,141,279 urgent funds bill today the House-approved restrictions designed to remove Robert Morse Lovett, Secretary to the Government of the Virgin Islands, and Goodwin B. Watson and William E. Dodd Jr., F.C.C. employes, from the Federal payroll for alleged past or present "subversive" affiliations.

Directors of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $3 a share on the utility's outstanding $6 preferred stock, subject specifically, however, to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 25 -- The United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture will adopt a resolution calling for the establishment of a United Nations interim commission on food and agriculture, to be set up not later than July 15 and probably in Washington, if a project submitted by the United States delegation today is approved.

CHUNGKING, China, May 25 (AP) -- Japanese forces driving west-ward through Western Hupeh Province, south of the Yangtze River, have made new progress, the Chinese High Command announced tonight, and belief grew in Chinese quarters that this might be the initial stage of a drive on Chungking itself.

Bus operations in New York City will be pared to the bone, milk deliveries put on an every-other-day basis starting tomorrow, if possible, trucking curtailed drastically and taxi mileage cut about 40 per cent here as part of the Office of Defense Transportation's program for coping with the gasoline shortage crisis in the Northeastern States, it was disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, May 25 (AP) -- Poland will continue her effort to organize a central European confederation, despite the antagonism of Soviet Russia, Count Edward Raczynski Foreign Minister of the Polish Government in exile, told the Polish National Council today.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill was the embodiment of calmness and ease when he answered the questions of 151 Washington newspaper correspondents for half an hour at President Roosevelt's press conference in the Executive Office of the White House this afternoon.

MOSCOW, May 25 -- The Anglo-Soviet treaty of alliance, described by the British Ambassador in Moscow, Sir Archibald Clark Kerr, as "the sheet anchor of Anglo-Russian relations," will be one year old tomorrow. Russian appreciation of the United States' close association with the treaty's ideals is shown by the fact that both the American and the British Ambassadors have been invited to Foreign Commissar Vyachisloff M Molotoff's anniversary luncheon party.

The pamphlet report for 1942 of the Southern Pacific Company disclosed yesterday that certain amounts of income that might be held subject to land grant deductions were withheld from revenues last year and in 1941 and credited to "other unadjusted credits."

The apartment house with twenty suites at 602 East 140th Street, the Bronx, was sold by Esther Bloch to Rose Roberts through Abraham Roberts, broker. This structure is on a plot 38 by 100 feet and is assessed for $32,000. Title was insured by the City Title Insurance Company.

LONDON, May 25 -- The ceaseless Allied bombing of Cagliari, the capital of Sardinia, has caused "city districts proper to be abandoned," the Rome radio said today. The broadcast added that an emergency decree had placed all workers in war factories and military works in Sardinia and Sicily under military control.

A host of soldiers and townsmen fought last night to hold levees still standing against the devastating waters sweeping down the Mississippi and Illinois River Valleys, according to The Associated Press.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 25 -- After months of cryptic references by German Propaganda Minister Dr. Joseph Goebbels to a new "super-bomb" that would slaughter wholesale the populations of Great Britain and "other Allied Nations strongholds," the Italian Propaganda Ministry today released for publication "some details" of a new super-explosive "city buster."

Michel Fokine's amusing little trifle, 'Igroushki,' was revived last night by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre with Alexandra Danilova and Alexander Goudovitch as its principal figures. This is the miniature in Chauve-Souris style which Fokine created a number of years ago for Gilda Gray to do in a night club, and which he resurrected in 1939 for presentation by this company.

WASHIGTON, May 25 -- Lend-lease aid through April 30 totaled $11,102,000,000, of which about $7,805,000,000 worth had been exported by the end of March, President Roosevelt told Congress today. He said that factories of this country now were "outbuilding the aggressors in every category of arms" and that we were "delivering them in the amounts necessary to build up the striking power for offensives that will end only in Berlin and Tokio."

Variety's annual poll of the drama critics will be published today. It will show that the critics voted Alfred Lunt's performance in "The Pirate" and Tallulah Bankhead's performance in "The Skin of Our Teeth," the best seen in Broadway theatres this season.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Reports that Russia would need larger amounts of food started a buying movement in rye that carried all before it and prices advanced today to a new high since 1937, with the finish about the top at gains on the Board of Trade of 2 1/8 to 3 cents a bushel.

A banking group comprising the Chase National Bank, Salomon Brothers Hutzler and R.W. Pressprich Co., won the award yesterday of a new issue of $5,000,000 Boston notes. The bankers bid an 0.53 per cent basis, plus a premium of $5 for the issue, which is dated May 28 and is payable on Nov. 5.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, May 26 (AP) -- Single Allied bombers raided four Japanese bases yesterday in adverse weather that limited operations in the Southwest Pacific, the Allied Command announced. The only deviation from the use of single planes was in attacks by small formations of bombers on New Guinea villages on the Huon Peninsula.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 25 -- More than 300 American planes smashed at the harbors, airfields and communications of Sardinia yesterday. Formations of American fighter-bombers slashed at Pantelleria again and the Royal Air Force continued its heavy bomber operations and intruder sweeps against other Italian defenses.

Pictures and figures of the enormous storage and transport economies in dehydrated foods never lose their wonder. You look at a healthy serving of beef or of cabbage in their natural state, and then at the modest little heap of nourishment which is the same amount of food with the water taken out.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 26 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers attacked Germany again during the night, it was announced today, striking at the Reich after a one-night lull following their record breaking assault on Dortmund Sunday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Judge Thurman W. Arnold, former Assistant Attorney General, told the Senate Interstate Commerce Commitee today that a Chicago grand jury would have indicted carrier rate-fixing bureaus early this year had not the proceedings been ended as a result of letters written by the War and Navy Departments and the Office of Defense Transportation, which expressed the hope that nothing would be done which would impede the war effort.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Paramount the attraction will be "Five Graves to Cairo," a topical drama with Erich von Stroheim as Field Marshal Rommel and Franchot Tone, Anne Baxter and Akim Tamiroff in the principal roles.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Participation in post-war arrangements of the United Nations, particularly as regards counteracting Nazi "poison," was asked today by the Educational Policies Commission, descibed as the policy-framing body of the National Education Assocation and the American Association of School Administrators.

Claude F. Garesche, vice president of Patino Mines and Enterprises Consolidated, Inc., told stockholders at their annual meeting here yesterday that the company would produce between 14,000 and 15,000 long tons of fine tin this year despite manpower problems.

Reports received yesterday by the Greater New York Fund from committee chairmen representing the 35,000 volunteer workers in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens indicated that the drive would exceed its original goal of $4,500,000 necessary to maintain the 406 institutions depending upon it.

Axis broadcasts claimed last night that long-range Italian planes had made a "long, difficult'' flight from the Eastern Mediterranean to bomb Sudan, Red Sea port of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan, and Gura, in the former Italian East Africa, but British sources dismissed the story simply as a "morale booster.''

CINCINNATI, May 25 -- The construction and building supply industries can and must be kept at a high level of production and employment after the war as the keystone of orderly readjustment to a peacetime economy, members of the Producers Council, National Association of Manufacturers of Building Material and Equipment, were told here today at the opening of their annual meeting.

With loin lamb chops selling for eight points a pound many persons are suddenly developing an interest in fresh fish. Fortunately supplies have been increasing recently, and although prices are not nearly as low as they were a year or so ago they are still relatively reasonable.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 (U.P.) -- War prisoners assigned to work in German factories loaf so much and make so many "mistakes" that the Nazis have begun sending them back to prison camps, a well-informed source reported today.

JERUSALEM, May 25 -- Presaging a considerable saving in shipping space from the United States and Great Britain, it was announced today that Palestine's growing industries would soon engage in the manufacture of a variety of essential articles for export to other Middle Eastern countries.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Even with repairs completed to the "Big Inch" pipeline, which is capable of supplying 300,000 barrels of petroleum products a day to points close to the Eastern gasoline famine area, it will take three weeks to a month, to bring supplies up to the minimum of 356,000 barrels a day necessary for civilian use, Federal rationing and oil supply officials estimated today.

Leaving thoughts of long red fingernails and lacy dresses behind, women gathered yesterday at the B. Altman store to enlist in the newly-created Women's Land Army, a part of the United States Crop Corps.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,414, as against 1,814 in the preceding week and 498 in the similar period a year ago, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 623, which compared with 843 last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has sold $9,768,000 of Arkansas State highway refunding bonds to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at 104 and accrued interest, this price representing a premium to RFC of $390,720, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, announced today.

Intercollegiate athletics will lose one of its strongest advocates in the retirement next month of Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics and head of the Department of Physical Education at Columbia University.
