CINCINNATI, Ohio, May 25 -- Designers of the country's towering skyscrapers and vast industrial plants may look forward in the future to more adequate recognition of outstanding skill in their work, members of the American Institute of Architects learned as they assembled here today for the organization's seventy-fifth annual convention.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill suggested to the Italian people today that they would be wise to get out of the war now, and declared the resources of the United Nations were expanding to a point where the war ultimately could be waged with equal force on the European and Asiatic fronts.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Owners of small homes, the Office of Price Administration said today, will get increases in their fuel oil rations for next season automatically.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 (AP) -- The German High Command was reported today to have shifted unusually strong troop reinforcements to Danish Jutland and strengthened coastal fortifications in Norway, apparently in the fear that the Allies might strike at Northern Germany as the shortest route to Berlin.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The proposed issue of $3,500,000 of equipment trust certificates by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, recently sold to Halsey Stuart Co., Inc., and associates, at 100.125 with a 3 per cent interest rate, represents "a definite step in advance in railroad financing," R.L. Snodgrass, vice president of the B. O., told the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday.
LONDON, May 25 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

LONDON, May 25 -- A collapsible stretcher which the bearer wears like a gas mask and can be used in sixteen different ways has been invented by Sidney Hedley Bingham, veteran Interborough Rapid Transit technical expert, who is in charge of military railways in the European theatre of operations and who was recently promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel.

Victory or even "the imminence of victory" for the United Nations will change the attitude of the leaders of the Argentine Government toward the nations who have opposed the Axis, Dr. Nicolas Repetto, Socialist deputy to the National Congress from Buenos Aires, declared here yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP) -- Receipts of salable hogs here today were 16,000 head, 3,000 above expectations, and receipts at twelve leading Western markets were 99,300 head, compared with 85,929 a week ago. Nevertheless, prices here were steady, with a top of $14.40 a hundredweight. Today's report by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Prize-winners in connection with the Contemporary American Masters exhibition, held in the clubhouse of the New York Junior League for the benefit of the league's welfare fund have been announced. The show has just terminated.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Committees representing the life insurance companies and mutual savings banks today petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission to deny the request of the Chicago North Western Railroad to reopen the reorganization proceedings for further hearing and modification.

The new regulations establishing a tax differential on alcohol will result in an annual saving of $43,000,000 to users of non-beverage alcohol, it was pointed out yesterday at the closing sessions of the thirty-fourth annual meeting of the Flavoring Extract Manufacturers Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, May 25 (U.P.) -- Civilian populations are being evacuated rapidly from Calabria, the "toe" province of Italy; from the islands of Sardinia and Sicily and from coastal towns on the Italian peninsula as a precaution against an early Allied invasion, the Morocco radio reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 25 -- An admission by German officers captured on a submarine off Brazil that they had received information of ship movements from German spies in Argentina again focuses attention on three memoranda on German activities in Argentina delivered by Ambassador Norman Armour to Foreign Minister Enrique Ruiz Guinazu last November.

Writings of Earl Browder, American Communist leader, a letter from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and documents dealing with the 1935 split in the Teachers Union in New York were introduced yesterday by the defense in the $150,000 libel suit by Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, against the Curtis Publishing Company and Benjamin Stolberg, writer.

In a smashing trial for next Monday's Suburban Handicap, Market Wise yesterday captured the Ballot Handicap before 12,760 at Belmont Park in a manner that probably will establish him as the favorite for the famous $30,000 added mile and a quarter run.

The twelve-story loft building on a plot 28.6 by 92 feet at 9 West Twentieth Street, near Fifth Avenue, was sold by a client of Goodman Mable, attorneys, to Henry Goelet, operator, for cash subject to a first mortgage of $52,000.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Congressional farm groups, having apparently blocked direct appropriations for government price control subsidies programs, turned attention today to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which will finance the recently ordered subsidization of meats, butter and coffee, and gave signs of fight on that front also.

BUFFALO, N.Y., May 25 (AP) -- The Lower Lakes Grain Commitmittee was created today at a meeting of Eastern and Midwestern grain men to formulate a plan for equitable allocation of vessel space to transport various types of grain from Lake Superior to ports on the lower Great Lakes this season.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (U.P.) -- The Navy Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 952 United States Marines held prisoners of war by the Japanese, mostly in the Philippine Islands. The list included fifty-nine officers and 893 enlisted men.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) -- Navy communique 389:

Featured by covering, price-fixing and liquidation of the July position in a volume that was estimated to exceed 50,000 bales in that contract alone, the cotton futures market yesterday extended its gains moderately and the spot markets rose to within 4 points of 21.38 cents a pound, the figure at which the government has announced it intends to stabilize the commodity's prices.
LONDON, May 25 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Sir Kingsley Wood asked the House of Commons today for an additional credit of 1,000,000,000 to cover the period until August.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, who withdrew as a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination at the last convention, has taken a strong stand against the war aims of President Roosevelt, striking out at "the Four Freedoms" as not what "we went to war for."

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 25 -- Unidentified thugs assaulted an American citizen, Julius Strupp, last Friday, it was learned today, inflicting painful injuries that still oblige him to remain in a hospital Mr. Strupp is of German origin.

Government officials issued a strong warning to industry yesterday that America's two major fuels, oil and coal, were in dangerously tight supply and that plant conversion from the former and the accumulation of stockpiles of the latter were vital to avert shutdowns.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Announcing a successful test of the ability of helicopters to land and take off from the deck of a merchant ship, the War Department said today "a new anti-submarine weapon is available."
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- An order of the Bureau of the Budget today prohibited the purchase by government agencies for the duration of the war of twenty-eight items of office supplies and equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Revealing additional details of the ill-fated Japanese attempt to raid Attu Island, the Navy disclosed today that, in addition to the five enemy bombers previously announced as shot down, seven others were "probably destroyed," while the remaining four of the sixteen that came over "fled to the West."

Representatives of fifteen major factors in producing and handling metropolitan New York's supply of fresh fruits and vegetables, meeting yesterday with spokesmen for the War Food Administration at 204 Franklin Street, took steps to launch an industry advisory committee to work with government agencies to solve any problem impeding the movement of the area's supply of these foods.

Four hundred Columbia University graduates will hear Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, deliver his annual address at the alumni luncheon, the principal event of the alumni program during the 189th Commencement Exercises next Tuesday, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- The five-day deadlock of the conference on pay-as-you-go tax legislation was broken tonight when an agreement was reached on abatement of 75 per cent of a year's taxes for each taxpayer whose tax exceeds $50, and complete cancellation of the liability of those whose tax is $50 or less.

Dr. Margaret Mead, author of "And Keep Your Powder Dry," published by Morrow, will be the guest of Bennett Cerf today at 5 P.M. on the "Books and Bullets program over WQXR. The program, a weekly feature, is sponsored by the Council on Books in Wartime.

The hundreds of varieties of plastics developed for war purposes, with their many thousands of uses, will ultimately lead to a great many new industries in the post-war era which will offer serious competition to the present types of textiles, Dr. Gerald D. Wendt, science editor of Time magazine, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executives Club in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Although the new decentralization plan for the control of exports to Latin America has been criticized by many foreign traders here, "the vast majority of the merchants in South America look hopefully and with favor on the plan," Franklin Johnston, publisher of The American Exporter, declared yesterday at a meeting of the Export Managers Club at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

District leaders representing fewer than five full votes on Tammany's executive committee attended the meeting of the committee to reorganize the Democratic party in New York County yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Murray Hill.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 25 (AP) -- A communique:

AKRON, Ohio, May 25 -- Approximately 3,000 workers at the General Tire and Rubber Company rejoined 49,000 strikers at three other principal rubber companies here tonight on the eve of a special meeting of their union's executive board, which may put an end to the three-day work stoppage.

Food must be sent now to the starving children of France, Holland, Belgium and Norway, Dr. Howard E. Kershner, former director of Quaker Relief in Europe, asserted yesterday, warning that even though the United Nations may win the war they will lose the peace if they permit the people in the occupied countries of Europe to starve while the German people eat.
DETROIT, Wednesday, May 26 -- Edsel Ford, 49-year-old president of the Ford Motor Company, died this morning at his home at Grosse Pointe Shores following an illness of six weeks.
LONDON, May 25 -- A British woman who has spent twenty years in India charged today that her countrywomen in that land were doing more to create enmity between races than any other factor.

Supreme Court Justice Bernard L. Shientag granted yesterday a motion by defendants to dismiss the complaint in a suit by minority stockholders of the General Gas and Electric Corporation to compel restoration to the corporation of controlling blocks of stock in four operating utilities.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (AP) -- Benjamin F. Fairless, president of the United States Steel Corporation, New York City, received $154,800 for his services during 1942, the company's annual report to the Sceurities and Exchange Commission disclosed today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 25 -- In a speech in Mannheim today Gauleiter Robert Wagner thundered that "lukewarm Nazis will be kicked out of the party," which "has a right to expect that each of its members be an example of courage, valor, will to sacrifice and idealism."

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 25 (U.P.) -- The Japanese who wreaked vengeance on Chinese and missionaries for aiding Major Gen. James H. Doolittle's American fliers after the Tokyo raid stopped only at cannibalism, the Rev. George Yager, an American missionary, said today.

Yesterday's House vote to outlaw the poll tax as a requirement for voting in national elections was foreshadowed when sufficient signatures were obtained to bring the bills out of committee. The debate on the subject brought forth nothing new, unless it was an outburst from a young sailor in the gallery, who wanted to know why one had to pay to vote when one didn't have to pay to fight.
LONDON, May 25 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Several newspaper advertising classifications came close to new high records last month, according to Media Records figures. Department store linage, for example, at 30,440,036 for fifty-two cities, was the second highest for April on record, being exceeded only by the figures for April, 1930.

CHICAGO, May 25 -- Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's, Inc., told United States Commissioner Edwin K. Walker today that Willie Bioff, former West Coast leader of the International Alliance of Theatre and Stage Employes, who is under a ten-year prison sentence for extortion, demanded $2,000,000 from the motion-picture industry in April, 1936, and boasted that he could "close every theatre in the United States in twenty-four hours."

CRANBURY, N.J., May 25 -War price and rationing boards in Norfolk, Va., and Miami Beach, Fla., were notified today by Police Recorder Walter Harris of the arrest by State police of two women drivers who he said displayed full ration books they asserted were issued by Southern boards to permit vacation trips.

While a camp for homeless men ordinarily may not be the most appropriate place for a college professor, it is if he wants to study vagrancy, according to Dr. Sieg fried Kraus, instructor in the Department of Sociology at City College.

LONDON, May 25 -- The stock markets here maintained a bright tone today. Gilt-edge issues attracted fresh attention. War Loan 3 1/2 per cents, Consols 2 1/2 per cent, and British Fund 4 per cents were among those to improve.

DETROIT, May 25 (AP) -- Sales of the Fruehauf Trailer Company for the three-month period ended March 31 were $15,475,501, President Harvey C. Fruehauf reported today. They compared with $6,633,208 for the like 1942 period.

From a system planned soon after Pearl Harbor to function in New York City during an air raid or similar emergency, a network of coordinated protective and communications services has now evolved. According to the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, which issued a call for volunteers from its headquarters at 707 Fifth Avenue yesterday, three types of communications service branches need workers to handle telephone calls and highly confidential reports.

Chalky Wright, 130 1/2, former featherweight champion from Los Angeles, knocked out Billy Pinti, 126, Rome, N.Y., in the fourth round of the scheduled eight-round feature bout at the Broadway Arena last night.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell entered an order yesterday designed to ease the Federal tax problems of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and its top subsidiary, the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation. The order authorized the trustees of both concerns to make a joint offer of $750,000 to the Collector of Internal Revenue in settlement of claims aggregating $8,465,777 for the years 1934 through 1939.

The strike of 49,000 rubber workers in Akron is perhaps the most shocking spectacle on the home front since the war started. These men are not only striking themselves; they are not only holding up war production of the most vital kind by their own inaction, but they are forcibly preventing those who want to work from doing so.

The Japanese still learn from others, as they have through all their history. They are adapting to the war in China something of the higher strategy of the war in Europe. They are acting on the principle that in modern warfare to strike at the economic underpinning of a country is the surest way to bring the country to collapse.
CAIRO, Egypt, May 25 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

Furniture store sales in the Second Federal Reserve District during April were off 5 per cent from the corresponding month last year, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The report, which does not include department store sales, showed a gain of 1 per cent for this city over the same period.

Adding its protest against MPR 339, the new hosiery pricing order, to those made by other trade groups, the National Retail Furniture Association, in a brief filed with the Select Committee on Small Business of the House of Representatives, has recommended the freezing of retailers in their business practices as of a given base period, it was learned yesterday.

Coupon-conscious customers have been rushing the white shoe season. Shoe salons report that women shoppers have adopted the "early bird catches the shoe" principle in such force that complete stocks of especially attractive models disappear from a store within twenty-four hours.
The six-story apartment house at 9524 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, was purchased by A.B. and B.B. Block from an out-of-town insurance company through the Farber-Wittman Company, brokers.

WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Announcement that collective bargaining negotiations between the United Mine Workers and bituminous operators of the Appalachian region would be resumed here tomorrow followed by several hours the recommendations of the War Labor Board today disposing of some of the points at issue but remanding the union demands for "portal-to-portal pay" and for universal adoption of the six-day work week back to the parties for direct negotiations.

According to an account in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 24 the British Joint Commission of the Council for Education in World Citizenship, even though it recognizes that "there has been enough burning of books," recommends that after the war "all copies of 'Mein Kampf' and other Nazi works (to) be made into pulp for new paper to be used to reprint books destroyed by the Nazis in the countries they have occupied."

A four-day upturn in the cotton futures market was stopped yesterday. Demand decreased owing to lack of new developments in agricultural legislation and the War Labor Board's denial of a wage raise to coal miners, which was taken to indicate that the Administration similarly would countenance no rises in commodity prices.

EASTON, Pa., May 26 (AP) -- John W. Farquhar, 82, retired New York lawyer and prominent alumnus of Lafayette College, plunged to his death from a seventh-floor washroom in the Northampton National Bank Building a little before noon today.

James A. Hamilton, president of the American Hospital Association and director of the New Haven Hospital, warned 350 delegates attending the war-time joint conference of the Hospital Association of the State of New York and the New Jersey Hospital Association that the voluntary hospital "must be redefined in the light of new responsibilities in community relationship" in order to live up to its public trust.

Rejection of a contract under which the city would permit the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to construct a $50,000,000 Stuyvesant Town housing project on the East Side was urged on Mayor La Guardia and the Board of Estimate yesterday by the Greater New York Industrial Union Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

LONDON, May 26 -- Germany is being compelled to disperse her war industries more and more to southeastern Europe as a result of the growing weight of Allied air attacks, and the United States Army Air Force's day attacks are greatly accelerating this process, particularly with regard to the airplane and motor industries, it was stated at the Ministry of Economic Warfare today.

The United States Golf Association is in a state of suspended animation so far as tournaments are concerned, but it is still very much alive in guiding the sport through the pitfalls of the war years, The Associated Press reports.

The increased interest in the opposite sex shown in these war times by the adolescent girl is primarily an imitation of her older sister who is marrying earlier and having more babies, Dr. Caroline B. Zachry, director of the Bureau of Child Guidance of the Board of Education, declared yesterday.

Before they troop back to school in the Fall, 60,000 to 70,000 high school and college students of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will have lent a hand in relieving the farm labor shortage in this region, a survey disclosed yesterday.

An appeal to members of the Communist party to leave it and join the ranks of the Fourth International, founded by Leon Trotzky, was issued here yesterday by the national committee of the Socialist Workers party, which charged that the dissolution of the Communist International "has provided official recognition of the fact that the Comintern has long been dead as a revolutionary international."

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A survey of Senate sentiment indicated today that half a dozen Republicans might decide the fate of an amendment which Senator George of Georgia, has charged would hamstring the reciprocal trade agreements program.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 26 (AP) -- A communique:
CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (U.P.) -- An abridged communique:

A children's circus in the gymnasium of the Union Settlement, 237 East 104th Street, brought to a climax yesterday afternoon the settlement's fortnight of open house. Many of the performers, who ranged in age from 4 to 14, had gone to the real circus when it was in town, and yesterday they put on their own version.

LONDON, May 26 -- A force of British and Canadian planes approaching in numbers the fleet that blasted Dortmund Sunday night in history's greatest raid battered the German arms center of Duesseldorf last night with more than five two-ton block-busters a minute, the Air Ministry announced today.

While New York City industries have not shared as widely as other large centers in the wartime economy, it will have the advantage of less dislocation of employment and business after the war, Edgar J. Nathan Jr., Manhattan Borough President declared yesterday.
Two prizes awarded to outstanding members of the class will be presented to Columbia College seniors at class day ceremonies next Monday, the faculty announced yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 26 -- Coinciding with the closer relations between Generals Charles de Gaulle and Henri Honore Giraud, confirmation comes from France that "groups of resistance" there are coordinating their efforts in preparation for an Allied landing.

LONDON, May 26 -- Britain observed today with wartime simplicity, but with feelings unquestionably enhanced by memories of another war, the seventy-sixth birthday of Queen Mary, mother of King George VI.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- John L. Lewis was reported today to have offered to settle the vexing "portal to portal" wage demand issue on the basis of a wage increase of $2 a day for all 450,000 bituminous coal miners, above and underground.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- The national executive committee of the Labor party, Great Britain's second largest, advocated today the post-war "establishment of a world-political-authority which should be not only the armed guardian of international peace, but also the agency of consultation and decision upon all great political issues arising among nations.''

The decision of the War Labor Board on soft-coal wages succeeds in paying lip service to the "Little Steel" formula and to the President's "hold the line" order. The Board has denied union demands for a general wage increase of $2 a day. It also denied double time for Sunday work, and a guaranteed fifty-two weeks of work a year.

PITTSBURGH, May 26 -- Enveloped in a smoke of base hits, bases on balls and incomprehensible managerial strategy, the Dodgers today opened their hinterland invasion by suffering a 17-to-4 walloping from Frankie Frisch's Pirates before a jeering Forbes Field crowd of 2,130.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Six Chicago leaders of the Capone syndicate, accused of participating in the $1,000,000 shakedown of the motion picture industry, abandoned their fight today against removal to New York to face the charges. The unexpected move came after the noon recess of the hearing before Edwin K. Walker, United States commissioner.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, May 27 (AP) -- Two-thousand-pound bombs were dropped on Madang, New Guinea, yesterday by raiding Liberators, the High Command announced. Madang, 350 miles northwest of the Allied-held Port Moresby, is an enemy feeder base for menaced positions at Salamaua.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Two Navy patrol planes sank an enemy submarine in the South Atlantic several weeks ago, the Navy reported today, and as the craft finally disappeared beneath the surface with its guns firing it left thirty or forty survivors afloat.

DETROIT, May 26 (AP) -- The death of Edsel B. Ford today placed back upon the shoulders of the almost 80-year-old Henry Ford executive direction of the far-flung industrial empire the elder Ford started forty years ago with a paid-in capital of $28,000.

LONDON, Thursday, May 27 (AP) -- Sixty-seven German planes were destroyed in huge air battles north-east of Novorossiisk and an attack by 1,600 enemy troops was shattered northwest of the city yesterday in a violent eruption of fighting in the Caucasus, Moscow reported early today.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Roosevelt tonight ordered the 52,000 striking Akron rubber workers to return to their jobs by noon tomorrow.

DUBLIN, May 26 -- During tonight's Dail sitting, James Dillon, the sole deputy who would like to make neutrality an issue in the coming election, asked Premier Eamonn de Valera to tell the House the circumstances in which the Irish ship, Irish Oak, was recently sunk in daylight by a submarine in the Atlantic.

Fortune Gallo's San Carlo Opera Company opened its annual twelve-day Spring season at the Center Theatre last night with a performance of Verdi's "Aida." The work, which was heard by a large and demonstrative gathering, was directed by George Schick, Czech conductor, who made his New York debut.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- As leader of Congress' "three friends of football," Representative Weiss, Democrat, of Pennsylvania, today asked Brig. Gen. Millard G. White, Assistant Chief of Staff, to alter present regulations and permit participation in intercollegiate athletic competitions by soldiers attending colleges.

The Security Traders Association of New York will launch today a month's drive for funds with which to supply twenty ambulances to the armed forces of the United States. The drive is under the chairmanship of Walter F. Saunders, of the Dominion Securities Corporation.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Opposition of the meat-packing industry to the Office of Price Administration's subsidy program, scheduled to go into effect June 1. was reported today by the American Meat Institute. It said that packers faced a loss of more than $25,000,000 if prices were rolled back on meats in inventory and process.

LONDON, May 26 (U.P.) -- Greek 'sea guerrillas," carrying forward in the Aegean Sea the tactics followed by their compatriots on land, have seized a fleet of small Axis vessels, including at least two of Italy's E-boats, and are using them to harass enemy coastwise shipping, a Greek Government spokesman said today.

Mayor La Guardia assured New Yorkers yesterday that the reduction in bus service made necessary by the gasoline crisis would not be enforced according to any arbitrary formula from Washington but would be worked out locally to meet "actual needs."

Representative Ward Johnson of California maintains that the proposal to repeal the Chinese exclusion acts is "right in line with utopian attempts * * * to assist the downtrodden races in foreign countries by permitting them to come to the United States."

In the untimely death of Edsel Ford at 49 the nation has suffered a serious loss. Self-effacing and instinctively avoiding the limelight which could have been expected to play upon the titular head of the world's most remarkable industrial empire, he had been for more than two decades in every sense a full partner of his father.

Back in New York after an extensive trip raising funds for the Red Cross and playing exhibitions in Army camps in Arizona, Miss Mary Hardwick made known yesterday that she is organizing a series of tennis matches for camps and training stations in the East.

In a vigorous defense of the Office of Price Administration against the barrage of criticism leveled at it in recent weeks, Clair Wilcox, director of the industrial materials division, yesterday labeled as "sheer fantasy" the reports that the agency was "verging on collapse" or was going "to be torn limb from limb."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 26 -- A body attachment for the apprehension of Miss Yvette Colbert as a witness for Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey in her marital litigation with William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey was issued here this afternoon by J. Addison Young, Supreme Court referee, when attorneys for Mrs. Dempsey said Miss Colbert was ignoring a subpoena.

The Yankees, who, more than anything else, need work and lots of it, especially the pitchers, were idle again yesterday. Impatient to get going again, the Bombers spent the afternoon counting the raindrops after their contest with the Tigers, the opening game of the Westerners' invasion, was postponed, but hope to start the ball rolling at the Stadium this afternoon.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized for listing but will not admit to dealings until further notice 600,000 shares of common stock, $1 par value, of United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc. It has also authorized for listing 55,906 additional shares of the Pan American Airways Corporation.

Robert and Gaby Casadesus, French pianists, gave a recital for one and two pianos at Carnegie Hall last night for the benefit of Russian War Relief, under the auspices of the Bronx division. The first number was the Mozart Sonata in D major, Koechel 448, for two pianos, and the fourth and last consisted of "Danse Russe" by Mr. Casadesus, "Deuxieme Valse Romantique" by Chabrier and "Gracia" by Infante.

AKRON, Ohio, May 26 (AP) -- The C.I.O. United Rubber Workers International Executive Board today called on "all its members now engaging in a stoppage of work in Akron and elsewhere to return to their war production jobs without delay."

A loan exhibit of Chinese paintings, entitled "Court Yards and Flowers," will open today at the American Institute of Decorators, 595 Madison Avenue. Malvina Hoffman's portrait of Dr. Hu Shih is included, together with paintings lent by the Metropolitan Museum and others from the collections of C.T. Loo, Giovanni Del Drago, Dikran G. Kelekian, S.R. Hoo and Mrs. Kenneth Torrance.

Cecil Roberts, author of "One Small Candle," published by Macmillan, will be one of the guest speakers at the War Bond Rally to be held Saturday in New Bedford, Mass. Other authors speaking are Ilka Chase, who wrote "Past Imperfect," a Doubleday, Doran book, and Walter Graebner, whose "Round Trip to Russia," was published this Spring by Lippincott.

LONDON, May 26 -- Although business on the stock markets here today was small, gilt-edge stocks improved. The 2 1/2 per cent Consols rose 3/8 to 81 3-16, local loans were up 1/8 to 95 9-16 and the 4 per cent British Funding Loan gained 1/8 to 113 1/2.

One of these days -- perhaps today -- it is going to stop raining and the weather will behave as it is supposed to at this time of year. It will be warm and clear and bright, and contingents of sun-worshippers will appear on lawns and roofs and near-by beaches.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 26 -- The Wilhelmstrasse is countering the Moscow move of dissolving the Comintern by featuring General Andrei A. Vlassoff, the Russian Quisling whom they captured in Kiev in 1941 and have kept in reserve while waiting for a convenient time to produce him.

New York City teachers, living longer than they have a statistical right to do, will now be forced to pay higher rates to keep the pension system on a sound basis, it became known yesterday. A new set of mortality tables has been prepared by George B. Buck, actuary for the Teachers Retirement Board.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Further hearings of complaints against the OPA's scheduled rollback of consumer prices of meats, butter and coffee developed today into plans by a Senate Agricultural subcommittee to support a bill to prohibit the payment of government subsidies on farm products.

CHICAGO, May 26 (AP) -- The tenth All-Star football game, which annually opens the nation's gridiron season, will be played by the Washington Redskins, champions of the National Football League, and a squad of selected college headliners at Dyche Stadium, in suburban Evanston, on the night of Aug. 25.

In a room banked with flowers and crowded with several hundred public officers and active Republicans, Abraham H. Goodman, Republican leader of the Eighteenth Assembly District of Brooklyn, was inducted yesterday as Deputy State Industrial Commissioner at the State Office Building, 80 Centre Street.

Retail credit collections in April showed an increase of 11.01 per cent, according to the twenty local store index, issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The average collection percentage last month was 57.96 against 46.95 for April, 1942.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., May 26 -- Four hundred butcher shops in Hudson County will close on Mondays under a manpower conservation plan approved by the Hudson County Retail Meat Dealers Association, it was announced today by Herman Ehrhardt, president of the association.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Some of those in closest touch with Russian relations believe that the dissolution of the Communist International may be followed by some gesture in the religious field calculated to allay suspicion of Moscow abroad.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 26 -Military operations on the Eastern Front remain hidden behind the smoke screen of official secretiveness and reports from Berlin are to the effect that both belligerents are camouflaging their movements.

MOSCOW, May 24 (Associated Press) -- The elaborate state dinner given at the Kremlin last night in honor of Joseph E. Davies included caviar, back of dried sturgeon, herring with dressing, back of sturgeon in sauce, English-style roast beef, cold ham, gelatine, olives and Spring salads, radishes, cucumbers and a variety of cheeses.

Schemes thus far advanced to stabilize post-war world trade and currencies by means of an international fund or clearing union are unsound and foredoomed to failure, the Guaranty Trust Company asserts in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

A clarification of the new authority of the War Labor Board under the "hold-the-line" directive order was presented yesterday by Theodore W. Kheel, chairman of the regional board, which has jurisdiction in New York and Northern New Jersey.

Two United States Maritime Service officers, one of whom won distinction for heroic behavior when the steamship Morro Castle burned in 1934, have been arrested on charges of stealing meats, dairy products and pastry. The case was disclosed yesterday by E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local Federal Bureau of Investigation offices.

TEHERAN, Iran, May 24 (Delayed) -- "Now you," says Major Gen. Donald D. Connolly addressing himself to a United States Army Major acting as an interpreter, "tell the Colonel exactly what I say and not what you think I ought to say."

LONDON, May 26 (Reuter) -- The Rome radio officially denied today what it called a rumor that large Allied forces were crossing the Sicilian Strait. [No similar rumor has hitherto been reported from any source.]

American Machine Metals, Inc. announced yesterday declaration of a 25-cent dividend on the common stock, the same as the previous payment on March 30. Last year one dividend, a year-end disbursement of 50 cents on Dec. 1 and the first since 1937, was distributed to common shareholders.

ALGIERS, May 26 -- The two principal problem facing the executive committee that General Henri Honor Giraud and General Charles de Gaulle hope to form here are first, the relationship between the commander of the North African army and the committee, and, second the status of Resident General Charles Nogues of French Morocco, Governor General Pierre Boisson of French West Africa and Governor General Marcel Peyrouton of Algeria.

Objections to terms of the proposed merger of Universal Pictures, Inc., with its parent company, the Universal Corporation, were heard yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins. A group of dissenting minority stockholders of the pictures company objected to the ratio of exchange provided for their stock in connection with the merger.

Let me thank you for your recent editorial, "Thanksgiving in St. Paul's," in which you quote the beautiful "Prayer of Thanksgiving," which expresses the yearning of the people for "a lasting peace" -- in the words of Paul "simplicity and godly sincerity."

Investment funds poured back yesterday into the stock market, and, on gains of from 1 to 2 points, prices pushed through their previous highs into new ground since November, 1940. The session produced the widest additions since early April, while volume on the Stock Exchange reverted to its former tempo in the heaviest trading in a week.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- An emergency board appointed from the National Railway Labor Panel recommended today to President Roosevelt a general wage increase of 8 cents an hour for more than 1,000,000 non-operating railroad employes on the ground that such increases were "the minimum, non-inflationary adjustments necessary to correct gross inequities and to aid in the effective prosecution of the war."

Too Timely, a filly bred in far-off Texas, won yesterday at Belmont Park, with her owner, Congressman Robert J. Kleberg, among the 6,452 persons in the stands who were rain-swept and fog-bound by turn. The King Ranch bred the three-year-old chestnut that finished first in the twenty-seventh Coaching Club American Oaks, which grossed $18,500, of which $13,250 was the winner's portion.

Major Gen. Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Red Cross Chapter, presented citations yesterday to representatives of three training schools for nurses at the War Nurse Recruitment Center, 139 East Thirty-sixth Street.

Although the Blackfriars Guild, 316 West Fifty-seventh Street, is one of the five experimental houses blacklisted by six craft unions on Tuesday, there will be no interference with the guild's presentation of "Moment Musical," opening next Monday.

A problem that has concerned many a woman is how she is going to fasten her skirt or slacks when zippers are no more. No longer need she worry. An ingenious way of closing a garment has been developed that does not call for zippers or any device using metal that must now be conserved for war uses.

A PACIFIC BASE, April 27 -The first unit of the 164th Infantry to come to actual grips with the Japanese on Guadalcanal was the First Platoon of Company G of the Second Battalion, which was sent up early the night of Oct. 23 to reinforce the Seventh Marines at the start of the "Battle of Coffin Corner."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 26 (AP) -- With Big Ed Levy powerhousing the attack with three singles and a double, Southpaw Tom Ananicz chalked up his third triumph as Newark turned back the Syracuse Chiefs, 6 to 1, tonight. The victory sent the Bears into a tie for second place with Montreal.

Czechoslovakia's sacrifice in 1938 -- her submission to Nazi Germany without a fight after the pact of Munich -- has earned her the right to be once again independent in the post-war world, Dr. Eduard Benes, president of the Czechoslovak Republic, declared yesterday.

Testimony that the reputation of Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, was "that of a Communist" in 1939, and that in the affairs of the federation he "followed the Communist party line," was offered yesterday by the defense in Dr. Davis's $150,000 libel suit against the Curtis Publishing Company and Benjamin Stolberg, writer.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Means of expanding war production through better utilization of manpower were discussed at the annual convention today of the National Metal Trades Association. The 600 industrialists in attendance were told by speakers that it is necessary now to give shop foremen better training and sufficient authority to adjust grievances of those under them and that incentives can increase production more than added facilities.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 315 United States soldiers missing in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern and North African areas and of 159 prisoners of war, of whom 144 are held by Japan and fifteen by Italy.

PHILADELPHIA, May 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the payment by the North American Company of the first dividend to be paid in common stock of its subsidiary, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.

Officials of the United Parcel Service, which handles retail package deliveries for most of the large retail establishments in this city, indicated yesterday a temporary stay of the ODT order cutting deliveries to two per week may be requested. A conference with local ODT officials will be sought today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Accusing government departments and agencies of continued "extravagances" in travel and communications expenses and estimating that such costs would rise to $100,000,000, excluding the War and Navy Departments, for the fiscal year ending June 30, the Joint (BYrd) Economy Committee demanded immediate and drastic retrenchments today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA (AP) -- A bombardier who crippled a Japanese convoy so badly that other bombers were able later to attack it effectively is among twenty-three American war heroes newly decorated.
The Italian Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The administrative committees of the State and Kings County committees of the American Labor party yesterday unanimously endorsed Lieut. Col. William O'Dwyer for re-election as District Attorney of Kings County and recommended his nomination by the Labor party. The committees met at the Labor party headquarters in the Hotel Claridge.

J.K. Galbraith, deputy administrator of the OPA, has been asked by the National Retail Dry Goods Association to take steps to remedy "intolerable" price conditions in the fur industry which are "destroying the retail fur business," it was learned here yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 26 -- The methodical destruction of military defenses, industry and communications in Italy's chain of island strongholds continued with increased ferocity yesterday. Almost 400 American bombers and fighter-bombers blasted docks, shipping, factories and airfields in Sardinia, Sicily and Pantelleria.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 26 -- Twenty-eight pilots of the Fifty-seventh Pursuit Group are going home after nine months of brilliant campaigning with the British Eighth Army from El Alamein to Tunisia. In announcing their departure today Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, commanding the United States Ninth Air Force, said:

MOSCOW, May 26 -- The first anniversary of the Anglo-Soviet treaty of alliance was hailed in Moscow today not only as an instrument whose proved worth would facilitate the achievement of complete victory, but as the cornerstone of the righteous peace to succeed it.

CHUNGKING, China, May 26 (AP) -- Chinese troops have recaptured an important strategic point and killed 600 Japanese in a battle on the outer ring of Ichang in Central China, a High Command communique reported tonight. Ichang is the center of menacing Japanese thrusts along the Yangtze River, in Southwestern Hupeh Province, in the direction of Chungking.

Captain James J. Hayes, 24-year-old Flying Fortress pilot who distinguished himself in air battles in the South Pacific, received yesterday from Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx a scroll of appreciation.

The commercial aspects of Father's Day will be subordinated for the duration and the annual promotion will be devoted to the war effort, it was revealed yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Pennsylvania sponsored by the National Council for the Promotion of Father's Day, which launched a $1,000,000,000 war bond drive in cooperation with the United States Treasury.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- President Edwin Barclay of Liberia, returning a call made by President Roosevelt in January, was welcomed to the White House today by the President and Mrs. Roosevelt and other high government officials.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Exceptional efforts at recruiting new workers for the food canning and processing industry will be required this year if wastage of food crops and consequent reductions in the supply of processed and canned foods is to be avoided, the Office of War Information reported yesterday.
CALCUTTA, India, May 25 (Delayed) -- Monsoons re beginning in the south of Burma, and in a matter of days they will have the whole of Eastern India in their sodden grip.

LONDON, May 26 -- Signal honors have been conferred on Generals Dwight D. Eisenhower and Douglas MacArthur, according to an announcement by the British War Office tonight. Both generals, who have captured the imagination of the British public, which holds them in the same high esteem as it does General Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, have been made members of the Order of the Bath on instructions from King George.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Dutch Leonard, veteran knuckle baller, blanked St. Louis with four hits as Washington defeated the Browns, 1 to 0, before 13,500 fans tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Members of the armed services on furlough will find it much easier to get food ration certificates than they have in the past as a result of an order by the office of Price Administration effective June 2. The order is aimed at cutting the red tape which soldiers, sailors and others have had to follow to get food ration certificate processed.

LONDON, Thursday, May 27 (AP) -- Joseph E. Davies, who delivered the secret letter of President Roosevelt to Premier Joseph Stalin a week ago, visited the Russian leader a second time last night after having indicated he was ready to return to the United States immediately.

CALCUTTA, India, May 26 -With the formation of a Ministry under Moslem League auspices in the Northwest Frontier Province, which was announced yesterday, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, the league's president, can now claim five provinces.

After nearly five months of wrangling, Congress has arrived at a compromise pay-as-you-go measure. The compromise is a relatively simple one that could have been passed months ago if it had not been for the obstructive attitude of the Administration. The compromise bill is not as good as the Senate bill and is even inferior in several respects to the House bill.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 26 -- President Anastasio Somoza requested today that Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs and High Commissioner, as trustee and fiscal agent of Nicaragua's guaranteed 5 per cent Cordoba bonds of 1918, redeem before June 30 all bonds of this issue outstanding in the hands of American holders.

Four midtown theatres will present new films today. At the Rivoli, "This Land Is Mine," a topical drama set in a Nazi occupied town, will have its local premiere. Charles Laughton and Maureen O'Hara are starred in the production, written by Dudley Nichols and directed by Jean Renoir for RKO.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- A Korean leader, who said that he had predicted the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor two months before it occurred, told the House Immigration Committee today that the Japanese planned to offer China a separate peace not later than September.

The Regional War Labor Board announced yesterday that it would approve "as a general policy" incentive bonus plans that result in lower unit labor costs because, though such plans allow a greater "take home" for the employes, they are "in keeping with the purpose of the wage-stabilization program."

WASHINGTON, May 6 -- Army troops battling the Japanese on Attu Island have cleaned out the enemy pocket in Chichagof valley and now are making an assault in force, with air fighter and bomber support, on a ridge north of the valley, where one of the two remaining centers of resistance is situated, a Navy communique reported today.

Trade opposition to the government's roll back subsidy program for coffee, butter and meats became more pronounced yesterday as dealers sought to liquidate their stocks as rapidly as possible to avoid being squeezed if it goes into effect June 1, as scheduled.

Offering will be made today of an issue of $16,848,000 of Lower Colorado River Authority, Texas, 2 3/4 and 3 per cent revenue bonds, due serially from May 1, 1954 to 1970, and 2 1/2 per cent term bonds due May 1, 1975, by a nation-wide banking group headed by the First Boston Corporation and Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc.

Fifteen local housing authorities in various parts of the country awarded yesterday a total of $9,243,000 of temporary loan notes through competitive bidding. The Chemical Bank and Trust Company obtained the award of $5,660,000, and the remaining $3,583,000 went to Salmon Brothers Hutzler.

TRENTON, May 26 -- William E. Sewell, Superintendent of Elections and Commissioner of Registration in Hudson County, told Governor Edison in a report made public today that the enforcement of the election laws in the stronghold of Mayor Frank Hague had been made difficult by lack of cooperation from grand and petit juries.

Business men and industrialists must start planning now, boldly and intelligently, to meet the problems of post-war employment if the system of free economic enterprise is to be preserved in this country, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, an organization set up by industry to help plan for reconstruction after victory, told the National Industrial Conference Board last night.
CINCINNATI, May 26 (AP) -- Eddie Miller singled Bucky Walters home with two out in the ninth tonight to give the Reds a 1-0 victory over the Phillies.
The war has doubled the work of the Young Men's Christian Association of the City of New York, Richard W. Lawrence, its president, declared yesterday in a letter sent to friends of the association.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The compromise pay-as-you-go plan agreed upon yesterday by tax conferees appeared today to be headed for Congressional approval as executive draftsmen worked to have the new bill ready tomorrow. The measure will come up in the House Tuesday.

Yesterday Queen Mother Mary was 76. Princess in her own right, she is descended from that Duke of Cambridge who was a son of George III. She was a cousin of the then Duke of York, whom she married in 1893 and who became King in 1910. George V described her publicly as "a constant helpmate in every endeavor for our people's good."

DUBLIN, May 26 -- The Dail Eireann adjourned tonight to allow Eire to hold its first general election since the war began. Normally the Dail should be dissolved, but under special emergency provisions it will remain nominally in existence until a new Dail is elected on June 22.
Although June 1 had been set as the date for mailing applications for War Ration Book 3, the Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that it was prepared to receive them immediately.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Fear that recent Office of Price Administration price and quality regulations threaten freedom of the press through abolition of much advertising was voiced by spokesmen for the work clothing and hosiery industries today before a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee investigating restrictions on brand names and newsprint.

With all the unions involved giving their nod of approval, "Tomorrow the World" will offer a special matinee on Monday, June 7, for high school students only at an admission price of 10 cents. This was announced yesterday by Alfred Harding, chairman of the Central Control Board of the New York City School Theatre Program.

Charging manipulation by a few individuals for the purpose of gaining control of all lumber distribution after the war, more than 400 retailers and wholesalers called upon Congress yesterday to abolish the Central Procuring Agency of the Corps of Engineers, U.S. Army, and demanded an investigation of that agency's present activities.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- J.A. Krug, program vice chairman of the War Production Board, announced today that details of the internal organization distribution bureau in WPB had been completed. The division has been divided into five units -- the office of the director, John W. Logan; the controller division, the Canadian division, the priorities control division and the compliance division.

ALBANY, May 26 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of a five-member Moreland Act Commission, charged with the task of formulating a long-range program for the improvement of the State's mental hygiene hospitals.

The volume of business transacted by the Todd Shipyards Corporation in its fiscal year ended on March 31 rose to $137,443,964 from $91,757,650 for the previous fiscal year, according to the annual report of John D. Reilly, president, issued for publication today.

CAIRO, Egypt, May 26 (AP) -American Liberators from the Middle East dropped 175 tons of high explosives and incendiaries on the Sicilian port of Messina in daylight yesterday, it was disclosed officially today.

WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- Navy communique 390: South Pacific 1. On May 23 the small United States auxiliary vessel Niagara was attacked by Japanese planes east of Cape Surville, San Cristobal Island.

Cheering news comes from the OWI to the effect that 97 per cent of the sailors and marines who were wounded at Pearl Harbor have survived, that 53 per cent returned to duty by March 31 of this year, that 43.5 per cent are still in hospitals, and that only 1 per cent have been invalided from service.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Army-Navy production award has been given to the following companies:

Tokyo yesterday officially announced the appointment as Minister of State without portfolio in the Tojo Cabinet of Fumio Goto, who shortly afterward issued a formal statement warning the people of Japan that they "are now facing an unprecedentedly grave situation" that requires an even greater effort on the home front.

The struggle between the dictatorial and democratic philosophies of life will continue to confront the world though the Nazis and Japanese are conquered, Dr. John Milton Potter, president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Geneva, N.Y., declared in the annual commencement address yesterday morning at General Episcopal Theological Seminary, Ninth Avenue and Twentieth Street.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Familiar sounds, faintly borne on the Spring breezes of the last few days and growing in volume, have lifted the ears of veteran observers in the capital. The sounds are very similar to those which in the past were heard when the New Deal doghouse was being made ready for a new occupant.

BALTIMORE, May 26 (AP) -- Ed Klieman pitched a 2-hit shut-out against Jersey City tonight as the Baltimore Orioles pounded out 17 hits to win, 10 to 0. Infielder Steve Shemo garnered both hits off Klieman, one a scratchy pop back of third base.

In the seventeen months since Pearl Harbor the once simple business of getting in the family groceries has become an involved transaction, on Park Avenue or on Pearl Street, from Avenue A to the Hudson. Yet New York housewives can testify to the sterling service of that harassed citizen, the corner grocer, as a tour of various sectors readily reveals.

NEWARK, N.J., May 26 -- Joseph Williams of 126 Bowden Road, Cedar Grove, the owner of seven houses there, was deprived today of the use of fuel oil until Dec. 31, 1944, under an order issued by the Newark District OPA.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo has extended its Spring season at the Broadway Theatre for an additional week, with its final performance scheduled for June 5. Extra matinees will be played on both Sunday and Monday in celebration of the holiday.

May I comment briefly on Harold Callender's interesting article, "United States Germans Fear Splitting of Reich," published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 21? In this article my name was mentioned among those "who oppose the reduced unity of Germany that a federated Reich would bring."

BOSTON, Ma., 26 (AP) -- L.B. Sheppard's Kansas took the top and never looked back today as he won the Suffolk Purse at Suffolk Downs and kept intact his record of not having been out of the money this season in five starts.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Lend-lease supplies worth about $60,000,000 were transferred to the forces of General Henri Honore Giraud in French North and West Africa during April, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator, stated today.

DETROIT, May 26 -- Henry Ford owned 58 per cent of the corporate stock of the Ford organization. Edsel Ford was said to have had 40 per cent and Mrs. Henry Ford 2 per cent since the family acquired all holdings more than twenty years ago.
LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 26 -- The resolution of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture for the appointment of an interim commission was approved by the Russian delegation tonight as "a basis for a joint discussion in the conference."

ST. LOUIS, May 26 (AP) -- Mort Cooper picked the wrong man to pitch to in the eleventh inning tonight, and the Braves clipped the Cardinals, 4 to 3, on Charley Workman's single. Al Javery held the Cards to six hits.

Howard L. Aller, president of the American Power and Light Company, attacked yesterday what he termed discriminatory taxation policies of the Federal Government against the utilities. Declaring that heavy increases in Federal taxes pose a "particularly serious" problem for public utilities, he urged that some remedy be found for the industry's difficulties arising from the present formula used for the computation of such taxes.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The War Department, by renegotiating its contracts, has saved $1,866,000,000, or a little more than 10 per cent, in excessive profits, according to a statement issued today by Maurice Karker, chairman of the department's Price Adjustment Board.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Navy Department disclosed tonight that the "first several" of a new type of patrol craft, specifically designed for "heavy convoy duty in northern waters," have been launched and that contracts have been placed for construction of nearly 100.

LONDON, May 26 -- The sweeping powers given to the British Government as a war-time measure whereby the central authorities control the destinies and personal affairs of virtually every man, woman and child living in this country were debated again in the House of Commons today.

Charles N. Abbey of the United States Employment Service, who is farm placement supervisor for New York, stressed yesterday the need for volunteer farm labor at a meeting sponsored by the Welfare Council of New York City in the Theodore Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

The recommendation yesterday of an increase of 8 cents an hour in the rate of pay for all non-operating railroad employes by the Emergency Board of the National Railway Labor panel, if put into effect, will mean an increase of $204,000,000 annually.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- Paced by Dick Bartell and Billy Jurges, two figures who doubtless will ever remain eyesores to a Chicago baseball gathering, the Giants made a wreck of Lou Novikoff's Homecoming Day today by defeating the Cubs, 4 to 2, in the opening clash of a three-game series.

There was a moderate set-back last week in the already depleted oil supplies along the Atlantic Coast, following upon an improvement the week before. On Saturday, the American Petroleum Institute index for East Coast stocks was 26.8, against 27.1 the week before and 25.5, the low point, two weeks before. It compares with 58.3 on Nov. 7, when the downtrend started.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 26 -- The evacution of 25,000 Jews from the ghettos of Sofia, scheduled for today, was reported postponed, following wide outbreaks in the Bulgarian capital during which large crowds of non-Jews, referred to in official communications tonight as "anti-nationalists" or "Communists," demonstrated against the "cruel, inhuman measures" the government was about to adopt.

NEV BRUNSWICK, 1. $., 1V[ay 26 -- College women entering the armed forces or essential civilian effort on the home front will find the experience paying dividends when peace returns, Lieut Comdr. Mildred H. McAfee, director of the Waves, declared today at the twenty-second Annual commencement of the New Jersey College for Women.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Moving to prevent the Executive Department from giving money to projects and functions for which Congress has refused to appropriate, the Senate Appropriations Committee wrote into the $143,639,591 urgent deficiency bill today a specific prohibition against the use of any of the President's emergency fund for such purposes.
Connecticut is attempting to give resident as well as non-resident anglers a better idea of how to reach the various ponds and streams withing its borders.

LONDON, May 26 (AP) -- Italy's reaction today to the Allied air attacks was a mixture of taunts that the "victory in Tunis is two weeks old and is still unexploited," and a threat of retaliation -- by her more powerful partner, Germany. However, there was frank admission that damage had been serious.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, and an aide revealed yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, the lawyer accused of attempting an $8,000 shakedown, that it was Mayor La Guardia who ordered the dictograph entrapment of the defendant last Nov. 23 in the "double scotch," highball party in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, and an aide revealed yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, the lawyer accused of attempting an $8,000 shakedown, that it was Mayor La Guardia who ordered the dictograph entrapment of the defendant last Nov. 23 in the "double scotch," highball party in the Hotel St. George, Brooklyn.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 26 -- One hundred years ago today startled cows and panicky hens noisily expressed their fright with loud bawling or throaty notes, each according to its kind, as the first railroad train entered this hamlet.

LONDON, May 26 -- Robert S. Hudson, Minister of Agriculture, has warned British farmers who are doing their utmost to cultivate as much soil as possible that the demands being made on them are not likely to ease before 1947, even if victory has been won in Europe before then.

Evidently Mr. Churchill does not share the view that Italy has become a negligible factor in the war. The highlight in his remarks at the President's press conference was his advice to the Italian people to get rid of the leaders that had brought them to disaster and throw themselves on the justice of the United Nations.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., May 26 -The arts of hog-calling, tending chickens and growing vegetables are rapidly supplanting the dignified extracurricular activities of English tradition at the Hackley Preparatory School here.

CHICAGO, May 26 -- With employers in doubt whether to observe Memorial Day Sunday, the date on which it falls, or Monday and whether employes are entitled to premium pay, the Illinois Manufacturers Association asked the Department of Labor in Washington for an interpretation of its order governing overtime pay.

America is now in the midst of an industrial revolution which will produce the greatest era of development ever known, provided that monopoly seeking to protect present invested capital does not dominate after the war, Thurman W. Arnold, former "trust-buster" and now associate judge of the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, told the New York Rotary Club at its weekly luncheon at the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

After five successive postponements of games with Detroit, four in the West, the Yankees caught up with the Tigers -- or vice versa -- yesterday at the Stadium, and the result was another bitter dose for the McCarthymen. In losing by 3-2, the Yanks suffered their fifth straight setback and blew a fine chance to regain first place.

Mrs. Vincent Astor and her sister, Mrs. John Hay Whitney, gave a cocktail party yesterday afternoon in the St. Regis Penthouse to start the ticket selling campaign for "The Army Play-by-play," a group of five prize-winning, one-act plays written by soldiers in a nationwide contest, which will be presented on June 14 at the Fortysixth Street Theatre for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club.

Staying at home over the Memorial Day week-end appeared yesterday to be the most comfortable way of marking the holiday. The New York district office of the Office of Price Administration banned driving to Memorial Day parades and sharply restricted driving to cemeteries.

CHUNGKING, May 24 (Delayed) -- The daily spectacle of Jacques Fischbacher of the Fighting French mission gaily jogging through the streets here in a jeep is a pleasant reminder of the fact that the Gallic complications in Chungking are amusing.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Roosevelt presented to Mr. and Mrs. James Munro the Congressional Medal of Honor, which was awarded posthumously to their son, Douglas Albert Munro; he announced that British and American military leaders were in complete agreement on future operations in all war theatres; his visitors included George Harrison, Anna Rosenberg, David B. Robertson and Philip Murray.

The enactment by Congress of the Anti-Poll Tax Bill would create a far greater and more lasting evil than the one it seeks to cure. For the sake of an immediate end to the poll tax, which has been disappearing anyhow over a period of decades, the proponents of the measure would create the precedent of Congressional control over the right to vote.

It is a harrowing tale that has been brought back by Father George Yager, American missionary in the part of Kiangsi Province in China in which General Doolittle's fliers landed after the bombing of Tokyo. The Japanese swept in after the fliers had left and in revenge on the Chinese inhabitants of the district systematically and deliberately slaughtered, tortured, pillaged, destroyed.

Mayor La Guardia, recently designated by the war cartoons committee of the American Society of Magazine Cartoonists as "Never-Take-a-Furlough-Fiorello," accommodated the society yesterday by posing for fifteen of its members in his office at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The International Association of Machinists advised the American Federation of Labor today that it would withdraw its 565,000 members from affiliation with the parent organization on Monday because the federation's executive council had "protected" several unions which had "raided" the machinists' jurisdiction "in defiance of A. F. of L. decisions."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Indicating a trend toward slower and more intensive training, the course of instruction at Officer Candidate Schools will be lengthened from three months to a minimum of four months, Secretary Stimson said at his press conference today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 27 (AP) -A communique:
Harrison Knapp, in 160 E 48th St; Murray Keesten, in 205 E 78th St; John H. Schluffer, in 115 E 92d St; Mrs. Joan Herbert, in 135 1/2 E 62d St -- Pease Elliman, brokers.

The Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo last night revived its production of "Coppelia" in the three-act form at the Broadway Theatre, with Alexandra Danilova in the role of Swanilda. With its charming score by Delibes, it is a nice old ballet, eminently worth keeping alive, and in the main this is a good version.

The five-story apartment house at 854 East 175th Street, the Bronx, has been resold by Henry Goelet, operator, after a short ownership to an investing client of Norman Siegel, attorney. The building is on a plot 50 by 147 feet and contains twenty-nine apartments.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 27 (AP) -- Hedy Lamarr, film actress, was married to John Loder, screen actor, tonight in a ceremony performed here by Judge Cecil D. Holland and witnessed only by five other persons. The Vienna-born actress and Loder, whose father was a British Army officer, invited no guests.

Urging the steel industry to begin consideration of the role which it will have to play in domestic and world markets at the close of the war, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, paid a tribute to the war production records already accomplished and still to come at the fifty-second general meeting of the institute at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.

Six one-family houses have been sold in New Jersey through Albert M. Greenfield Co., brokers, as follows: 66 Floral Terrace, Tenafly, sold to George J. Brenner; 126 Stephenson Road, Middlesex Borough, to William Gallagher; a house on Fairmount Avenue, Chatham, to William Kent; 266 Franklin Road, Englewood, to Mildred Buchunsky; 253 Kent Place Boulevard, Summit, to Arthur Westenberger, and 12 Rockland Terrace, Verona, to C. DeSantis.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Top-ranking British and American military leaders in land, sea and air warfare have reached "complete agreement on future operations in all theatres of the world," it was announced today by President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A proud mother accepted from President Roosevelt today the Congressional Medal of Honor, awarded posthumously to her Coast Guardsman son, killed eight months ago on Guadalcanal, and then joined the Coast Guard as a lieutenant (junior grade) in the Spars.

As tight a mile run as the meeting has seen was dashed off at Belmont Park yesterday when Lochinvar, bred as well as owned by J.M. Roebling of New Jersey, eked out a nose decision in the $2,500 Pontiac Purse. This colt was a mild sensation last season but hadn't shown much of anything in 1943.

ALGIERS, May 27 -- The decision of General Henri Honore Giraud and Charles de Gaulle to leave the reconstitution of the French Government to the people of France is the outstanding development of the week here and one which, in the eyes of Allied diplomats, will have considerable effect not only upon France but upon other European countries now suffering under the German yoke.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Price control over raw furs and finished fur garments will continue to be exercised by the Office of Price Administration, that agency announced today in denying reports that the items, were to be removed from regulation because they represent luxury goods.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation and four officials of the metallurgical department at its Irvin Works were recommended for indictment today as the Federal grand jury investigating sale of the alleged sub-standard plates to war agencies completed the first phase of its inquiry.

CINCINNATI, May 27 -- Convinced that slum clearance and rebuilding of American cities must be one of the foremost objectives to stabilize the national economy in the readjustment period following the war, members of the American Institute of Architects voted today to broaden its advance planning activities to promote this type of work.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- As the result of the increasing number of women being employed in industry, many more women counselors and personnel officers are at work in factories, Miss Mary Anderson, Women's Bureau Director of the Labor Department, said today. She added:

What is the difference between a wisecrack on the one hand and a witty remark or a flash of humor on the other? One of our NEW YORK TIMES men at the press interview with Winston Churchill drew a vivid little pen picture of the Prime Minister's manner and spirit.

CHUNGKING, China, May 27 (U.P.) -- The Chinese High Command reported tonight that more than 1,000 Japanese had been wiped out south of Ichang and that two of the three enemy columns driving westward up the Yangtze valley had been checked.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Congressional tax conferees made final changes today in their compromise pay-as-you-go bill preparatory to reporting to both houses tomorrow.

Three simple and effective methods of canning and food preservation were demonstrated yesterday afternoon to a capacity crowd in The New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street. The theatre, with a scattering of men among the 500 attending, was turned into a classroom where questions were profuse throughout the demonstrations.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -Navy communique 391:

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 27 -- Secretary Ickes exonerated today Dr. Jose M. Gallardo, Insular Commissioner of Education, of charges of alleged failure to increase instruction of English. He said that "at my request" Dr. Gallardo had withdrawn his previously offered resignation.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau announced today that the sale of War Bonds to the commercial banks would in future be handled by the Federal Reserve Board and separated from their disposal to the general public.

Dr. Eduard Benes, president of Czechoslovakia, ended his series of speeches to the people of America during his visit here before a packed house at Carnegie Hall last night. Declaring that his country had been a liberal, socially highly developed democracy differing profoundly from the Soviet Union, he asserted as the belief of his countrymen that "collaboration with the Soviet Union in war will bring the United Nations into a peaceful and democratic post-war collaboration."

BOSTON, May 27 (UP) -- A bad spill in the fourth race, from which Jockey Charlie Wahler of Philadelphia and Patrol Judge Willie Doyle of Upper Marlboro, Md., escaped with comparatively minor hurts, and a surprise victory in the six-furlong feature by James C. Braswell's Begda, a 9-1 shot, featured today's card at Suffolk Downs, witnessed by a crowd of 9,712.

Mayor La Guardia appeared as the prosecution's last witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, lawyer and former Democratic Deputy City Controller, on the charge that the defendant, last November, tried to "shake down" a concern for $8,000 under misrepresentation he could use influence to defeat an amendment to a city ordinance that would have destroyed the concern's virtual monopoly in stirrup pump sales.
The New York Chamber Orchestra, under Dean Dixon, will give a concert tonight at 8:45 in Town Hall with Rosalyn Tureck, piano, as soloist.

Even "some of the Communists" believed that Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, was one for their number, according to testimony given yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury by Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 -- Four bankers in this city were permitted today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to solicit authorizations to represent other holders of preferred stock of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation to give such shareholders a voice in the management's plan to reduce the holding company's capital structure to a single class of common stock as directed by the commission.

LONDON, May 27 (U.P.) -- United States Flying Fortresses destroyed at least seventy-four enemy aircraft during last Friday's smashing attack on German naval installations at Wilhelmshaven and Emden, establishing a record, United States Army Eighth Air Force Headquarters announced today.

At a time when there is pressure for the largest revenues that we can raise, and when increased taxes are being laid on every one else, Congress would hardly approve a direct proposal to raise exemptions, narrow the income tax base, and bring in fewer taxpayers. This would rightly be regarded as purely political.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 27 -- Strong formations of American bombers and fighter bombers battered three key airports in Sicily, and shipping, industry and defensive positions in Sardinia and Pantelleria yesterday, the ninth day of the Allied aerial offensive against the south-ernmost bastions of Adolf Hitler's European fortress.

An advertising and promotion plant designed "to keep the vitamin business in the drug stores" has been developed by McKesson Robbins, Inc. A portfolio detailing the program declares that a leading authority estimates the annual vitamin potential sales soon to be reached at $496,881,000, or $9,034 a year for the average drug store.
CHUNGKING, China, May 27 (AP) -- A communique:

Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo, sitting in Brooklyn, yesterday fined twenty-two corporations and individuals a total of $119,500 after they had pleaded nolo contendere to an indictment charging them with conspiracy to defraud the Federal Government on asphalt supplies for WPA paving contracts in Queens, Staten Island and Rockland County.

MOSCOW, May 27 -- Joseph E. Davies concluded his second mission to Moscow today and prepared to return to Washington almost immediately, bearing with him a large wax-sealed envelope containing a letter from Premier Joseph Stalin, addressed to the Commander in Chief of the United States Armed Forces, President Roosevelt.

Correspondence between the City-wide Citizens Committee on Harlem and the Secretary of the Navy, showing the failure of the group to effect the entrance of Negro women into either the Waves or the Spars, was made public by the committee yesterday.
From the west and from the south the attack upon the "Fortress of Europe" and its outposts continued yesterday.
BALTIMORE, May 27 (AP) -- Jersey City defeated the Orioles, 6 -- 3, tonight with a four-run rally in the ninth after Baltimore had tied the score with two runs in the eighth.

More than eight weeks have passed since the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations created a special subcommittee to study and report on a number of pending resolutions relating to the part to be played by the United States in the post-war world. This subcommittee held its first meeting on March 31.
Dr. Eduard Benes, President of the Czechoslovak Government-in-Exile, will be 59 years old on May 28.

NEWARK, N.J., May 27 (AP) -- Eight men, including the former supervisor of the State Finance Commission's Trenton warehouse, were found not guilty today by a Federal jury of charges of conspiracy to possess articles for distilling alcohol in violation of the Internal Revenue Law.
MOSCOW, May 27 -- Little more than curt hints of the fighting to come were available from official reports in Moscow today.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, May 27 (AP) -- The greatest sprinter in Texas schoolboy history is going to run in the national A.A.U. meet and he doesn't want to make any stops this side of the best competition the country has to offer.
