LOUISVILLE, May 27 -- The Office of Price Administration filed in Federal District Court here today two suits for about $7,000,000 against forty-eight former officers and stockholders of the dissolved Cummins Distilleries Corporation, charging them with violating price ceilings on whisky sales and asking triple the amount of the alleged overcharges.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN USTRALIA, Friday, May 28 (AP) -The noon communique:

The Greater New York Fund has collected more than half of its $4,500,000 minimum goal, W. Randolph Burgess, general chairman, announced at the second report luncheon yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. So far $2,501,207 has been collected, he said.
LONDON Friday, May 28 (U.P.) -- The Soviet midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Senators defeated the Browns, 4 to 2, tonight to take sole held of first place in the American League. A crowd of 13,600 saw the Senators reach the top.

LONDON, May 27 -- Gilt-edge stocks continued today their upward trend on the stock markets. War Loan 3 1/2 per cents at 103 11/15, Consols 2 1/2 per cents at 81 1/4 and local loans at 95 5/8 were each 1/16 better. In the foreign bond market, German issues eased. Home rails remained steady.
Edwin F. Coffin and Walter H. Eisenhut will manage the new branch office of R.M. Horner Co. in Albany.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 27 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Donald W. Richardson of Union Theological Seminary, Richmond, Va., tonight was elected Moderator of the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, succeeding Charles G. Rose of Fayetteville, N.C.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed an increase of $142,895,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

CHICAGO, May 27 -- Liberal profit-taking sales halted today an upturn in rye that started about a week ago, and although professional traders and the Northwest were good buyers at times, prices receded and the close on the Board of Trade was at net losses of 3/8 to 3/4 cent a bushel, July showing the most strength.

ALBANY, May 27 -- Richard C. Persons, Republican Controller of Erie County, was appointed by Governor Dewey today as State Commissioner of Standards and Purchase at $10,000 a year, succeeding John T. Higgins of Cohoes, who returns to his former civil service status as deputy commissioner.

James J. Lyons, Bronx Borough President, suggested yesterday in a letter to Mayor La Guardia that the subways could be used as a means of alleviating the gasoline shortage by transporting materials in the early morning hours.

Louis and Murray Gordon, operators of a chain of linen supply and laundry companies, have leased from the Moore Estate for thirteen years to May, 1956, the industrial building at 527-41 West Twenty-third Street, in the Chelsea district.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 27 -- In a radio broadcast tonight Richard K. Law, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs and chairman of the British delegation at the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture, said that if the conference goal of "freedom from want" is realized the world a generation or two from now will not suffer from surpluses as in the Nineteen Twenties and Nineteen Thirties, but from scarcities.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- Representative Frank L. Sundstrom, New Jersey Republican, in a House speech today termed appointment of a committee to advise. President Roosevelt on organized sports "unnecessary and uncalled for."
LONDON, May 27 -- A blueprint for the occupation of a conquered Germany has been drawn up by the United States Army's Civil Affairs Section in this theatre.

The Boys Club of New York held its annual pet show on the roof of the Jefferson Park Building, 321 East 111th Street, late yesterday afternoon -- an event that was not without some anxious moments, what with dogs snapping at cats and the judges having difficulty deciding what constituted the "finest dog" and the "cleanest and best groomed dog."

The progressive retirement of industries upon their completion of war production to a peacetime program was advocated yesterday by Walter D. Fuller, president of the Curtis Publishing Company, as the best means of preventing mass unemployment in the transition from "war to post-war conditions."

LONDON, May 27 -- The recently formed British-American Legion, whose aim is to foster a more friendly and cooperative spirit between the nations, held its inaugural dinner tonight in the American Red Cross quarters, Rainbow Corner, in London.
A PACIFIC BASE, April 28 -- Major Gen. A.A. Vandegrift, commanding the Marines and Army on Guadalcanal, issued the following division bulletin late in October:

John E. Prendergast, Tammany leader of the Third Assembly District, Middle, one of seven district leaders who on Tuesday attended a meeting of the committee to reorganize the Democratic party in New York County, called at Tammany Hall yesterday and pledged his support to Michael J. Kennedy, Tammany leader.

Coxswain Eulace Peacock of the Manhattan Beach Coast Guard and Ensign Hugh S. Cannon of the Staten Island Navy Base, who made successful comebacks in winning their specialties at the Penn Relays last month, have entered the metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships on Saturday, June 5, at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.

The weekly Federal Reserve figures issued yesterday, covering the week ended on Wednesday, disclosed that excess reserves of member banks in New York City dropped $35,000,000 in the week to only $10,000,000. Three weeks ago these banks showed a deficiency of $10,000,000 in reserves.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- During the week ended May 22 the Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices in primary markets remained unchanged at 103.8 per cent of the 1926 average.

A student club affiliated with the Young Communist League has been chartered officially at City College's School of Business and Civic Administration, it was learned yesterday. The charter was given by a unanimous vote of the school's Faculty Committee on Student Activities.

Welcoming the step taken by John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers for reaffiliation with the American Federation of Labor, the International Ladies' Garment Workers, representing a membership of nearly 300,000, yesterday characterized as "unadulterated bunk" the assertion "in some circles'' that Mr. Lewis will seek to transform the A.F.L. into a weapon for the Republican party in 1944 and into an instrument against President Roosevelt.

It is too bad that the general public does not attend hospital meetings, at least at present, when the proposals of the Social Security Board threaten serious damage if not destruction to both the voluntary hospitals and the hospital service plans.

PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- Directors of Baldwin Locomotive Works today declared a dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock, payable June 30 to holders of record June 15. A dividend of $1 a share was paid last December, the first on the common since reorganization.
MOSCOW, May 27 (AP) -The mid-day communique:

The Canadian Government has placed before Parliament a national health measure which should have a profound influence on our thinking. Insured medical care is to be available to all, the cost to be shared by the beneficiaries, by employers and by the Provincial and National Governments. Actually there are two bills, one to be taken up by Parliament, the other by Provincial legislatures.

John W. Hession, securities analyst and former financial columnist, was convicted in Federal court yesterday of mail fraud and violation of the Securities Act of 1933. Arnold R. and Sven Wellmer Hanson, brothers and partners in Hanson Hanson, over-the-counter brokers, were acquitted of the same charges and of conspiracy, on which Hession likewise was cleared.

Earnings of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., in the first four months of this year approximated $9,500,000 based on tax rates effective in the Revenue Act of 1942, John A. Brown, president, told stockholders at their annual meeting held here yesterday. The profit is equivalent to about 30 cents each on the 31,178,323 capital shares outstanding.

LONDON, Friday, May 28 -- The Red Army hurled 150,000 men and hundreds of guns, planes and tanks against Germany's Kuban lines yesterday, temporarily cracking them in a swaying battle that still is going on, the Berlin radio announced early today.

Despite the misgivings of many observers in the men's shoe trade that men would be willing to part with ration coupons for sports shoes, the demand this week for this type of footwear has taken a spurt, according to the National Shoe Retailers Association and several local buyers.

Like the factories that have converted peacetime equipment into tools for making the instruments of war, eight women artists in the metropolitan area have turned their talents to emergency production. Instead of paintings, fashion designs and drawings, these artists are doing poster work for New York's Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization.

A vast amount of confusion is developing in connection with the return of applications for War Ration Book No. 3, officials disclosed yesterday. In Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island large quantities of early application forms are being handed back to the senders by the Post Office Department for lack of proper postage.

LONDON, May 27 -- In the midst of the Axis rage over the fierce American and British bombing raids and the frequent suggestions by the neutral press -- principally Spain, where some newspapers are shot through with German propaganda -- that the warring countries should agree to cease their bombing attacks, Britain served notice today that she had no intention of giving the enemy any let-up.

"Busless Sundays" for Manhattan, where the motor lines are privately operated, and a reduction today in service in Brooklyn, where the city runs the buses, were projected yesterday as the Office of Defense Transportation ordered an immediate 20 per cent cut in bus and taxicab service as a step toward the 40 per cent over-all mileage reduction previously ordered because of the gasoline crisis from Maine to Virginia.

BOBO NEWSOM was about to leave for Pittsburgh the other day and paused for a moment to say hello -- or maybe it was good-bye. But once Bobo starts to talk there is no stopping him and the Great Man was soon off on a conversational marathon.

Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, customers flock to the Swap Shop maintained by the Henry Street Settlement in the basement of 334 Madison Street, one of the Vladeek houses. Yesterday, instead of prospective swappers, the shop entertained three women visitors at an inspection tea.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 27 -- A reverse for the Germans in their U-boat war is acknowledged for the first time indirectly in an article in today's Berlin Lokal-Anzeiger by the German submarine expert Heinz Bongartz. He is quoted as saying:
HONOLULU, H.I., May 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Delos C. Emmons Will be transferred from command of the Army's Hawaiian Department on June 1 and his place will be taken by Major Gen. Robert C. Richardson Jr.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Edwin Barclay of Liberia, who is here on an official visit, addressed the Senate and the House today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 27 (AP) -- Tom De La Cruz scored his sixth victory of the season when he earned a 2-to-1 decision over Newark tonight. The Chiefs' curver, beaten twice on the road, has won all six starts at home.

It is good news that the War Department has found, upon test, that a new anti-submarine weapon is available in the helicopter. Experiments made on Long Island Sound this month from a deck space only 78 by 48 feet have now "sufficiently proved" the feasibility of operating helicopters from the decks of tankers.

ALBANY, May 27 -- Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, and Irving V.A. Huie, Commissioner of Public Works, of New York City, may continue to hold office on the City Planning Commission, the Court of Appeals held today when it affirmed the dismissal of a complaint by Robert S. Childs, president of The Citizens Union, who sought to restrain payment of salaries to the incumbents.

ST. LOUIS, May 27 (AP) -- Howie Pollet outpitched Jim Tobin today as the Cardinals clung to second place with a 3-to-2 victory over the Braves, but it was a fielding error, not poor mound work, that let in the winning run.

CINCINNATI, May 27 (AP) -- The Reds came to life with a bang today. Backed by Elmer Riddle's four-hit hurling, they pounded two pitchers for fifteen safeties and a 7-0 victory over the Phillies. It was Cincinnati's second straight shut-out.

Plans for a five-year program of cooperative industrial research in the textile industry, involving a $2,000,000 fund-raising project, were announced yesterday by Fessenden S. Blanchard, president of the Textile Research Institute, Inc., following approval by the group's directors at a meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 27 -- Semi-official Vatican sources today did not confirm insistent rumors of the past two days that Moscow and the Vatican might be on the eve of concluding a concordat, negotiations for which, according to some usually reliable sources, have Been under way for the past month in Ankara, Turkey, under the guidance of British and American representations there.

WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -In its first award of a wage increase to correct "substandards of living" since President Roosevelt's "hold the line" order, of April 8, the War Labor Board today ordered an average rise of ten cents an hour for sixty-eight employes of the Everbest Engineering Corporation, of New York.

CLEVELAND, May 27 -- The Cleveland Ordnance District of the War Department has distributed 45 per cent of prime contracts for war material to industrial companies employing less than 200 persons, according to a report issued by the district.

Current delay by the WPB in promulgation of its conservation order for the millinery industry will not prevent an early start on the Fall wholesale season and lines will be officially opened during the week of June 28, it was announced yesterday by Walter K. Marks, president of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association.

LONDON, May 27 (U.P.) -- King Peter II, 19-year-old exiled ruler of Yugoslavia, has precipitated a crisis in the Yugoslav Cabinet in London by asking to be allowed to marry Princess Alexandra of Greece immediately, reliable informants said today.

A new issue of $2,000,000 Commonwealth of Massachusetts notes, dated June 11, 1943, and due June 9,1944, was awarded yesterday to the Merchants National Bank of Boston. The bank bid an 0.37 per cent basis.
LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- The Bank or England's condition statement for the week ended May 26 reported a decrease of 2,335,000 in note circulation.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Total American losses in the North African campaign, beginning with landing operations on Nov. 8 and extending through the end of the fighting on May 15, amounted to 2,184 killed, 9,437 wounded and 6,937 missing, the latter figure including prisoners of war, making a total of 18,558, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson announced today.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, May 28 (U.P.) -- Liberator and Mitchell bombers with a Beaufighter escort delivered the heaviest Allied aerial attack to date on the Japanese New Guinea coastal base at Lae yesterday, dropping twenty-eight tons of explosives and incendiaries and setting fires visible for seventy-five miles, it was announced today.

The Walt Whitman Society of America has announced as a joint award for 1942-43, Wendell L. Willkie's "One World," and Eve Curie's "Journey Among Warriors." Both were voted the "most conducive to world understanding." "The Making of Tomorrow" by the late Raoul de Roussy de Sales won a second award because of its "lucid analysis of paramount ideological problems of the present."
The German Thursday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The first Georgia peaches arrived here this week, the United States Department of Agriculture reports, but only a few stores have them and prices are high. A quart costs $1 in one Madison Avenue shop, and though the fruit is ripe, it is very small. Other expensive newcomers are fresh California apricots, at about 60 cents a dozen. They also are small.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company sold the twelve-story apartment house at 515 Park Avenue, southeast corner of Sixtieth Street, to an investor. Assessed at $630, 000, the property is 100.5 by 60 feet and contains apartments of six and eight rooms.
WASHINGTON, May 27 (AP) -- The accent is on cheerful news the Office of War Information indicated today in outlining the kind of letters our soldiers like to receive from home.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., May 27 (AP) -- Recapitalization of the Guantanamo Sugar Company was favored in a vote by 76 per cent of the company's stockholders today, David M. Keiser, president, announced, but court action promised to delay consummation of the plan, advanced by directors of the company.

Bank clearings for the current week held the substantial margin of increase over the corresponding 1942 period that has been recorded during recent weeks, but showed the moderate decline of 4.7 per cent from the total of the previous week, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Production at two New Jersey war-work plants, the Ford Motor Company's plant in Edgewater and the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's plant in Newark, was retarded yesterday by unauthorized work stoppages. An estimated 3,500 Ford employes left their jobs in the afternoon, two hours before they normally would have, and 1,200 of the 1,500 on the Brewster firm's day shift remained idle about two hours.

BOSTON, May 27 (AP) -- The Red Sox, back for an extended home stand, defeated the Indians twice today, taking a morning encounter, 2 -- 0, and scoring a 4-3 decision over Cleveland in the afternoon game.

Combined sales of the Dresser Manufacturing Company, maker of pipe fittings, and its subsidiaries for the six months ended on April 30 exceeded those of the entire 1942 fiscal year, H.N. Mallon, president, reported in a quarterly statement mailed to shareholders yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 27 -- Twentieth Century-Fox is planning to do a film biography of the late President Woodrow Wilson, with particular stress on his efforts toward world peace. The picture will deal principally with his life from the time he was president of Princeton to the Versailles Treaty.

Major Granville Stokes Carrel of the Army Air Corps, who was "Granny" Carrel on the University of Pennsylvania football team some years ago, became rooted in his tracks in Edinburgh, Scotland, a few weeks ago, as he came to Princes Street Gardens.

The change announced yesterday by the Treasury in its war bond program is the second in fairly quick succession. When the first War Loan Drive was held last December, the long established War Savings Staffs in each State handled war savings bonds, and the Victory Fund Committees in each of the twelve Federal Reserve Districts handled all other new issues of government securities.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Office of Price Administration is stronger today than it has been in months and is doing a better job of price regulation than it was when he took office, Prentiss M. Brown, administrator, told an impromptu press conference here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 27 -- Departing from its custom of previous years, the National Headliners' Club has admitted newspaper women to its ranks of journalists cited for outstanding achievements in their fields of activities during the past year, it was announced today by Mall Dodson, president of the club.

PITTSBURGH, May 27 -- In a battle under the lights tonight that almost literally was a knock-down-and-drag-out affair, 14,724 fervid Pittsburgh fans saw the Pirates stage a four-run attack in the eighth inning to trounce the Dodgers, 9 -- 5, for their second straight victory in the series and cut the Brooklyn first-place lead over the Cardinals to a game and a half.

DETROIT, May 27 -- The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin of New York, president of Union Theological Seminary, was named Moderator today of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America at the General Assembly.

Joint action designed to assist in the orderly and equitable distribution of furniture in this area was mapped out yesterday at a meeting of retailers with the trade relations committee of the Furniture Manufacturers Representatives of New York.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- After "hard fighting" by ground troops who cleared their way with bayonets and hand grenades, American forces on Attu, supported by naval bombardment and aerial attack, have won a foothold on lofty peaks south of Chichagof Harbor and are making "steady progress" in the destruction of the remaining Japanese forces, War and Navy Department spokesmen disclosed today.

The establishment of PX's, Army Post Exchange Stores, as close as possible to the front lines of the war theatres, enabling soldiers to obtain "little extras," has proved a great contributing factor in the building of morale among American soldiers, Brig. Gen. Joseph W. Byron, chief of the Army Exchange Service, said yesterday.

A gas explosion, caused by the suicide of a 50-year-old woman early yesterday morning, demolished the interior of the woman's apartment on the thirteenth floor of 5 Riverside Drive, partly wrecked two other apartments and routed residents of the fifteen-story building from their beds.

The discovery that the blood of individuals in a state of anxiety secretes a chemical that modifies the rhythmic contractions of a rabbit intestine, offering a possible explanation of one of the mechanisms by which certain changes in the body are produced during an acute emotional experience, was reported last night at the clinical research meeting at the New York Academy of Medicine, arranged by the academy's committee on medical education.

The end of the Roosevelt-Churchill conference is announced in a one-sentence communique, which states only that full agreement has been reached on action in all theatres of the war. Without attempting to speculate on the specific decisions that have been taken, there is every reason to believe that the long-drawn-out discussions have in fact covered every fighting front.

LONDON, May 27 (AP) -- Award of the Victoria Cross to Acting Wing Commander Guy P. Gibson, 25-year-old leader on the raid on the Moehne and Eder dams in Germany's Ruhr Valley on the night of May 16, was announced here today.

The Vatican radio, in a German-language broadcast reported yesterday to the Office of War Information in Washington, denounced as "propaganda" an assertion by the Nazi-controlled Paris radio that the Catholic Church had "a crushing responsibility in unleashing the present war."

AKRON, Ohio, May 27 -- War production climbed toward normal at Akron's four largest rubber companies tonight as C.I.O. strikers streamed back to their jobs, heeding a Presidential ultimatum to end a five-day stoppage which made more than 50,000 workers idle.
Paul E. Flato, a jeweler with lavish offices here and in Hollywood, was accused yesterday of pawning more than $100,000 worth of merchandise entrusted to him on memorandum.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Department store sales in the week ended May 22 were 20 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 16 per cent for the week ended May 15 compared with the like week of 1942.

LONDON, Friday, May 28 -- Speedy Mosquito bombers of the Royal Air Force darted 500 miles from England last evening and penetrated heavy Nazi defenses to bomb the world-famed Carl Zeiss instrument works and other targets in the Central German city of Jena, the Air Ministry announced early today.

In THE TIMES of May 22, I have read the article "Army's Program Is Reported Bogged Down." It happens that I have had opportunity to keep in rather close touch with the development of this program since its inception and would like to comment briefly on your article.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 130 United States soldiers missing in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Senate bill making the Waac (Women's Army Auxiliary Corps) a part of the Army as "Wac" -- minus the "a" for Auxiliary -- was passed today by the House and returned to the upper chamber with amendments made by the House Military Affairs Committee.

With New Orleans operators increasing their selling pressure in late dealings, the cotton futures market yesterday closed 2 to 5 points under Wednesday's final quotations after a dull session of narrow price movement.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 27 -- With Army and Navy uniforms largely replacing the flowing academic gowns and tasseled caps of peacetime graduations, Harvard conferred today 1,115 academic degrees at its commencement, while certificates were awarded by Army and naval officers to 4,000 officers at the ten Harvard service schools.

"That Nazty Nuisance," which arrives at the Laffmovie at Broadway and Forty-sixth Street, is this morning's sole film newcomer. The Hal Roach comedy features Bobby Watson, Joe Devlin, Johnny Arthur, Jean Porter and Ian Keith. It was produced and directed by Glenn Tryon.

Signing of the first industry-wide agreement under which an industry as such assumes responsibility for old age pensions for its employes was announced yesterday by Israel Feinberg, general manager of the Cloakmakers Union, an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, affecting 35,000 workers.

Further confirmation of the break through to new high territory was given yesterday by the stock market, although profit-taking in the afternoon, induced by the sharp run-up, reduced prices on the Stock Exchange to a mixed closing. Constructive interpretation continued to be placed on the domestic economic developments with the better-type issues once again out in front.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- President Roosevelt was reported today as being interested in an early resumption of labor unity conferences between spokesmen for the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
A few salt-water entries are beginning to trickle into the Trenton headquarters for the New Jersey Governor's fishing contest after a considerable lull.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A vigorous criticism of restrictive transportation policies which the Anti-Trust Division of the Justice Department alleges have almost suppressed air freight transport, severely hampered trucking operations, blocked the development of strategic waterways and obstructed the completion of pipe lines, has been added to the record of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee.

Additional food and fuel restrictions were predicted by government spokesmen yesterday before the joint conference of the Hospital Association of the States of New York and New Jersey in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The War Department confirmed tonight that Lieut. Gen. Emmons had been succeeded in Hawaii by Major Gen. Richardson and would go to a new post.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, May 27 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, arrived this morning by plane from California for a private visit. American circles explained that his trip related purely to problems concerning his office and connected with the over-all picture of American information activities in Mexico.
PHILADELPHIA, May 27 (AP) -- The Athletics got to Johnny Humphries for a four-run outburst in the sixth inning tonight and defeated the White Sox, 7 to 5, before 14,894 fans at Shibe Park.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- The Office of Price Administration must oust Dr. J.K. Galbraith, deputy administrator, and the rest of his policy-making "hierarchy" and rewrite price-control regulations in a simple form not designed to change the business structure of the nation under the guise of war necessity, if price control is to succeed, a House investigating committee was told today.

"Early to Bed" will have its premiere at the Broadhurst on Thursday night, June 17, a week later than previously announced. Last Monday the new musical comedy, described by the management as "a fairy tale for grown-ups," had its first performance in Boston, where it will continue for a third week through June 12.

After completion of new hearings ordered by the Appellate Division, Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin upheld yesterday the valuation of $12,500,000 put on the Sixth Avenue Elevated Railroad when the city purchased the structure, and held that this was a fair value for purposes of condemnation proceedings and assessment of damages against property owners benefiting from demolition of the line.

An inquiry into the conduct of a Federal court jury during the twenty-seven hours it deliberated on a verdict last month will be conducted personally next Tuesday by Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston, it was disclosed yesterday. Meanwhile, Judge Galston deferred action to quash the verdict, brought on a motion by attorneys for several defendants who were convicted.
CHICAGO, May 27 -- The Cubs were still serving the Giants well today, dropping their second successive game to Mel Ott's suddenly revivified Polo Grounders. The score was 3 to 2.

IDENTIFY the following and state what common tie connects them: Alton B. Parker, Winfield Scott Hancock, Samuel J. Tilden, Lewis Cass, Horatio Seymour. If the questions in the recent NEW YORK TIMES history questionnaire had been as difficult as this one there would have been less surprise and consternation over the ignorance of young Americans about the history of their country.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 27 -- Judge Marvin Jones, president of the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture and chairman of the United States delegation, issued a statement today emphasizing the importance of yesterday's action by the Russian delegation when it joined the rest of the forty-four participating governments in publicly stating approval in principle of the plan for a permanent international organization to deal with post-war problems of food and agriculture.

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- Employing the power of appropriations, the Senate voted, 44 to 31, late today, to shrink the National Resources Planning Board, headed by Frederic A. Delano, the President's uncle, down to a mere skeleton organization with functions restricted to cooperation with State and local agencies in their war and post-war planning, and with only $200,000 allowed of the $1,400,000 the agency sought to finance its operations through the coming fiscal year.

UNITED STATES BOMBER BASE SOMEWHERE IN BRITAIN, Friday, May 28 -- King George and Queen Elizabeth informally discussed the problems American Flying Fortresses face in blasting Axis cities in daylight raids in talks with American flying officers at this bomber base and met America's new sky terror, the Thunderbolt fighter, in their first visit to a United States fighter station.

ORLANDO, Fla., May 27 -- In the jungles near here there is a bit of transplanted New York where recruits from Flatbush, the Bronx and Broadway are taught the tricks of jungle warfare in an Army Air Forces School of Applied Tactics.

LONDON, May 27 -- General Charles de Gaulle, whose scheduled meeting with General Henri Honore Giraud in Algiers is only a matter of days, predicted confidently in a radio broadcast tonight that French empire unity would be accomplished.

Accusing the American Red Cross of "intimidation," Bernard Segall, president of the left-wing-controlled Social Service Employes Union, reaffirmed yesterday its determination to unionize employes of the Red Cross regardless of the latter's policy not to bargain within any union for reasons made known by high officials of the organization.

The government will pay for the continuance after the war of the education of soldiers who have had theirs interrupted, in the opinion of Mayor La Guardia. Speaking yesterday at the dedication of City College's Army Hall, used as barracks for cadets assigned to the college under the Army Specialized Training Program, the Mayor said that it would be "the only decent thing to do."

WASHINGTON, May 27 -- A "feeler" on a possible basis for disposing of the vexing "portal to portal" wage issue in the joint wage conferences of Appalachian operators and the United Mine Workers of America was extended by the spokesman for the Southern group of bituminous operators today, it was reported following the meeting.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The Senate approved today without debate a provision which would prohibit President Roosevelt from using any of the money in his special emergency fund to finance projects or functions for which Congress had refused to appropriate in accordance with budget estimates.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- The question whether the Central Railroad of New Jersey must pay the State of New Jersey $10,101,520 was back today in the jurisdiction of the United States District Court, which had its choice of awaiting an opinion of the New Jersey Chancery Court on the constitutionality of the State's railroad tax settlement acts or holding a hearing itself on their constitutionality.

Post-war reforms for higher education in America are proposed in the challenging report prepared after seven months of considered study by the Commission on Liberal Education. Recognizing that the war will change many traditional campus and classroom concepts, the Commission calls for the inauguration of new measures.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The House-approved Kilday bill, designed to give rigid statutory draft deferment status to fathers, was tabled by a unanimous vote of the Senate Military Affairs Committee today. This action, Chairman Reynolds said, was tantamount to killing the measure.

NEWARK, N.J., May 28 -- A practice air raid drill, described as a "holiday quicky," was called in New Jersey late tonight to test the response of householders and travelers to signals received on a holiday week-end.
Today this column presents menus for next week designed for a model household of three, a moderately active man and woman and a school-age child.

Despite the system of price controls of the Office of Price Administration and the efforts of other governmental agencies, the cost of living continues to rise at the rate of about 0.6 per cent a month, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the June issue of its monthly review of business and credit conditions.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 28 (AP) -- A single by Dutch Mele with two out in the ninth drove in the winning run at Syracuse scored a 3-to-2 victory over Newark in the series finale tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Cutting deeply into the Japanese-held area on Attu Island, United States Army troops have moved past Lake Cories and are beating their way along a ridge commanding the area between Lake Cories and Lake Canirca, a Navy communique reported tonight.

May I comment on one aspect of your editorial "Dissolving the Comintern," May 24. Skepticism is your first and last note on this historic act, which has been widely hailed as a body blow against the Axis. That is the same note with which Berlin attempted to parry the blow.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- William G. Chandler has resigned as director of the Printing and Publishing Division of the War Production Board and has been succeeded by Harry M. Bitner, who was a deputy director.

With the public disregarding the Federal Government's appeal to stay home, the rising tide of holiday travel threatened yesterday to engulf Grand Central Terminal and the Pennsylvania Station as Memorial Day approached one day nearer.

EAST FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 28 -- State police with four bloodhounds were searching the woods near here tonight for David R. Cox, 28 years old, of Milville, who is reported to have fled from the home of Valentine Glaab, 53, after Mr. Glaab had died of strangulation.

A national conference on the Scientific Spirit and Democratic Faith will be held today and tomorrow at the meeting house of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street. Dr. John Dewey is honorary chairman.

Reorganization of the management and board of directors of the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation will take place in Dover, Del., next Wednesday to reflect the passing of sole control of the company into the hands of the Atlas Corporation by liquidation of the large equity holdings of the Radio Corporation of America and Rockefeller Center, Inc.

LONDON, May 28 (U.P.) -- Six policemen and two members of the Liberty Front were killed Wednesday at Ruschuk in northwestern Bulgaria when authorities attempted to round up suspected Communists, reports from Istanbul said today.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Admiral William H. Standley has signified to President Roosevelt his desire to resign at once as Ambassador to the Soviet Union, according to well-informed circles.
The New York Conservation Department has announced that public camp sites under the department's jurisdiction in the Adirondacks and Catskills will not be open over the Memorial Day weekend.

The first step toward bringing seventeen nurseries formerly operated under WPA funds here into the State program for the care of children of mothers working in war industry was taken by the New York City War Council yesterday in certifying to the need for these facilities.

New issues of State and municipal bonds totalling $7,347,438 will come up for award next week, compared with this week's total of $24,531,989, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new financing now stands at $16,811,178.

LONDON, May 28 -- Speaking at a luncheon today in Portsmouth's drive for funds for the construction of more planes for Britain, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden declared that Britain would bomb the Italian and German military machine wherever it was to be found.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 29 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The imposing of any new taxes for collection this year after Congress passes the pay-as-you-go bill is regarded by several leaders on Capitol Hill as highly unlikely. Their only qualification was that a breakdown of price control might require quick and drastic fiscal action.
It is interesting to note that the results of four early-season major league baseball games this year were vitally affected by balks. In two instances the balks directly decided the issue.
LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

An involuntary petition in bankruptcy was filed in Federal court yesterday against Paul E. Flato, 42 years old, a jeweler, of 1 East Fifty-seventh Street. Flato, who was arrested Thursday on charges of pawning $100,000 worth of jewelry that had been entrusted to him, said in an affidavit accompanying the petition that he was willing to be adjudged a bankrupt.

ALBANY, May 28 -- Mayor Erastus Corning welcomed 500 delegates of the 247 councils of Knights Of Columbus in the State to Albany this afternoon, after they had marched to the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, where the Most Rev. Edmund F. Gibbons, Bishop of Albany, presided at a pontifical mass.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Roosevelt issued an executive order today setting up a new Committee on Fair Employment Practice, with additional powers to prevent discrimination in war industry employment, and appointed Mgr. Francis J. Haas of Catholic University as chairman.

The annual report of the Pitney-Bowes Postage Meter Company for the year ended March 31, issued yesterday, showed a net profit of $515,578 after $1,080,000 provision for renegotiation of war contracts. The profit is equivalent to 57 cents a share.

Price-fixing in the near months steadied the cotton futures market in late dealings yesterday, erasing earlier losses up to 5 points that had resulted from pre-holiday liquidation. The list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange ended the dull session unchanged to 3 points above Thursday's last quotations.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- In a sharp attack on the reciprocal trade agreements program, Senator Langer, North Dakota Republican, demanded today that pending legislation to renew the authority be amended to provide for Congressional approval of agreements before they become effective.

Memorial Day will be observed in churches tomorrow with services for those who have died in this world war as well as in the Civil, the Spanish American and World War I. The day will be observed this morning in the synagogues. There will be special services tomorrow in parks, on college campuses and at Army and Navy bases.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 28 -- Allied and Japanese hostilities in the Southwest Pacific came to a focus in the new flare-up of activity at Lae and Salamaua. Heavy American and Australian air attack on Lae and near-by Japanese positions made yesterday and announced in today's communique is indicative of the intensification of the conflict in the Lae-Salamaua area.

COLUMBIA, Mo., May 28 -- Edwin L. James, managing editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, received today the award of a medal as a distinguished editor and foreign correspondent from the School of Journalism of the University of Missouri at the annual Medalists' Day ceremonies here.
As an old baseball fan who played left field on his college team, I confess to a sense of puzzlement over the manpower problem as related to the national sport.

The six-story apartment house at 518 West 111th Street was sold by the Dry Dock Savings Bank to an investing client of Howard C. Forbes, Inc., co-broker in the deal with Harry S. Proctor. This structure is on a plot 108 by 100 feet.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Six citations were announced today by the War Department for award of the Silver Star and one for the award of the Legion of Merit.

The New York Chamber Orchestra, under Dean Dixon, gave a concert last night at Town Hall, with Rosalyn Tureck, pianist, as soloist. An unusual program was presented, which with the exception of the scherzo from Mendelssohn's "Midsummer Night's Dream" and the rarely played piano concerto in B flat of Beethoven was devoted to unfamiliar music and works performed for the first time.

The bombs dropped by the R.A.F. on Dortmund and Duesseldorf constitute the heaviest loads of explosive ever delivered by air in the history of warfare. In each case they amounted to more than five times the explosive that London received on its worst night of bombing.

In a letter sent out to its affiliated stations yesterday, the Mutual Broadcasing System announced the release of the periods from 8 to 8:30 P.M. and 10:30 to 11 P.M. New York time on Sunday evenings from the option-time provisions in Mutual contracts.

The movement of Canadian grain to this country is proceeding at a steadily increasing pace. The Chicago Board of Trade reported yesterday that 795,000 bushels of oats, on which duty was paid, had been received at that port. This brings the amount received in Chicago since the opening of navigation on the Great Lakes to almost 3,000, 000 bushels.

BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- Ken Keltner recovered from his sinus attack to return to third base and spark the Indians to a 5-2 verdict over the Red Sox today, salvaging one decision for his team in the three-game series. The victory sent Cleveland into a first-place tie with the idle Senators.
Only six months remain before snow flies to provide an additional route for bringing fuel oil and gasoline to the East, where it will be sorely needed next Winter.

MOSCOW, May 28 -- This afternoon the German radio reported a Russian break-through in the Krymsk region of the Caucasus above Novorossiisk. While this news is not yet confirmable here, it is evident that the stalemate recently prevailing on the Taman Peninsula now has been definitely broken.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 28 -- Young persons must believe earnestly in democracy if it is to be preserved, Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress, said this afternoon at the fifteenth annual commencement exercises of Sarah Lawrence College here.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28 -- Despite the role which American forces played in the victory in Tunisia, the British people consider that America's contribution so far toward winning the war is far less than that of Russia or Britain or even China.

VINCENT RICHARDS was back in the news recently when he promoted a tennis tournament for the Eighth Regiment of the New York State Guard at the huge Kingsbridge Armory. What is even more noteworthy is the fact that he played as well as promoted, thus marking his twenty-eighth year of activity in the sport.
The Broadway impresarios are promising seven attractions for next month, against the six that were offered in June of last year. The list for the moment, subject to change, is as follows:
Three emotions characterize most of the interest which is taken by the public in the part that the Vatican may or may not be expected to play in the rumored peace tentatives.

BERNE, May 28 (UP) -- A Lyon, France, dispatch to the Tribune de Geneve reported that the resistance of France to the German occupation troops had increased since the Allied victories in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Grade labeling of canned goods is a reform which may have some advantages, but not enough to justify its imposition on merchandisers and consumers in the midst of a war which already has created may confusing new situations for them, a House committee was told today by Julian J. Verst, publisher of grocery trade magazines.

Business and industrial executives who already know that their dependency deferment may soon end, with the imminent, induction into military Service of fathers under 38 years old, were advised yesterday by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, city Selective Service director, not to count on occupational deferment "just because they may consider themselves irreplaceable key men."

Red, white and blue flowers bloom in abundance just in time to express the sentiments of Memorial Day, yesterdays report from the New York State Department of Markets and Agriculture disclosed. After revealing an unusually poor showing last week, cheery tidings emanated from the department, accompanied by the news that no runaway prices are anticipated over the holiday week-end.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 28 -- Abbreviated because of the war, Princeton University's 197th commencement program got under way today with the induction of new members into Phi Beta Kappa in the morning and a review of the Reserve Officers Training Corps unit and class ceremonies in the afternoon.

Two new films will open in midtown theatres this morning. At the Rialto, the new attraction will be Paramount's "Night Plane From Chungking," a topical melodrama with Robert Preston, Ellen Drew, Stephen Geray, Otto Kruger and Tamara Geva . . . At the Abbey, the newcomer will be "Murder in Times Square," a Columbia mystery melodrama featuring Edmund Lowe, Marguerite Chapman and John Litel.
Mrs. F. Baird Cole, in 410 Park Ave; Mrs. Pearl R. Chapman, in 67 Park Ave -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, brokers.

Henry Modell, sports goods dealer, proved a voluble defense witness yesterday in the trial of Milton Solomon, lawyer and former Democratic deputy city controller. The latter is charged with attempting to shake down a concern for $8,000 on misrepresentations that he would kill unfavorable legislation before the City Council that would have affected the company's monopoly of stirrup pump distribution in this city.

By adopting new underwear and hosiery specifications designed to speed procurement, the Philadelphia Quartermaster Depot may be able to break the bottlenecks in yarn spinning and cloth weaving that have created serious delay in completing current programs, Worth Street suppliers reported yesterday.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, May 28 (AP) -- Appointment of Lieut. Comdr. Harvey J. Harman as athletic director and football coach at the Navy Pre-Flight Training School here was announced today by Captain David C. Hanrahan, commanding officer.

LONDON, Saturday, May 29 -- In "great strength," Royal Air Force bombers slugged Essen, that "most bombed city in the world," Thursday night in a newly devised wave-bombing pattern of attack, carrying out the third massive bombardment of Germany in five nights, the Air Ministry reported yesterday.

Under the guidance of a young, married assistant hotel manager, four young women last night made the rounds of dinner, theatre, night club and supper as guests of three American Army fliers who are stationed "somewhere in the South Pacific."
LONDON, Saturday, May 29 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- On the eve of a meeting of the policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America tomorrow, John L. Lewis, president of the union, refused today to budge from his demand that the Appalachian bituminous coal operators make an allowance of $2 a day for "portalto-portal" pay for 450,000 miners.

Dressed in new seersucker uniforms, a Red Cross gleaming on breast-pocket and cap against the hyacinth blue of the costume, twenty young women completed yesterday the new forty-hour dietitian's aide course under the auspices of the Brooklyn chapter.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Replacement was announced today of the War Production Board's facilities program division, construction division and facilities division by a new facilities bureau charged with obtaining maximum utilization of the nation's existing plant facilities and making plans for the minimum amount of new construction to be permitted.

Those of us who live beyond the city's walls awake these May mornings to the friendly reveille of the robins. Busy jays are prattling to each other in the oak tops as we make a quick inspection (station bound) of that row of beets so hopefully breaking through the new-worked soil and the onions which, come evening, we definitely must thin.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION IN ENGLAND, May 28 -- A Flying Fortress renamed "F.D.R." for President Roosevelt on his last birthday was one of eleven that failed to return from the heavy raid on Kiel on May 14, the Eighth Air Force disclosed today.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 -- The Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation was indicted today by the Federal grand jury investigating the sale of sub-standard steel plates to war agencies, but the jury refused to indict four officials of the metallurgical division of the corporation's Irvin Works as recommended yesterday in a presentment.

Traders in securities became a little hesitant yesterday with the approach of the extended weekend, caused by the Memorial Day holiday on Monday, although prices on the stock market edged a bit higher toward the close of the session.

Dominick Taddio, 38-year-old Staten Island war worker, was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair during the week of July 12 for the killing of Mary Rycoitch, 19-year-old war worker of 16 Catherine Place, Mariners Harbor, on last Dec. 28.

MONTREAT, N.C., May 28 (AP) -- A proposal for eventual reunion of the two branches of the Presbyterian Church, divided since Civil War days, stirred members of the Southern branch's general assembly today as they heard that the Northern general assembly had approved the proposal.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 28 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general of the Public Health Service and member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture, said today that the nutrition section has agreed on recommending an international nutrition office as part of the permanent world food organization which the conference has virtually decided upon.

CAROLINE SLADE'S "The Triumph of Willy Pond" was likened to "The Grapes of Wrath," and her second novel, "Lilly Crackell,"* merits the same sort of comparison. There is, in "Lilly Crackell," an easy power, a sure knowledge of the meaner conditions of life, and an emotional pity that gives the book a lyric glow even when the subject-matter is a monster.

While reading Timothy Bennett's letter in THE TIMES recently, I got the impression that he doesn't like to walk. Neither do I, especially when the hike is so unnecessary and is attributable to such poor causes as mentioned by him.

New York's 30,000 public school teachers are a fine body of women and men -- putting them in numerical order. They have been doing splendid work over and above their regular school-room duties, ever since we entered on the period of war emergency.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 28 -- "The greatest mystery of all time," Lew Andreas, Syracuse University athletic director, said today, is the absence of a uniform athletic program for the armed services, as indicated by Army and Navy attitudes toward college football.

DETROIT, May 28 -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America took steps today to raise the standards of its ministry by adopting a report on theological education.

Unless the War Production Board takes action to supply manufacturers of men's clothing with enough rayon and cotton linings and trimmings, they will be unable to produce more than 25 per cent of the Fall apparel they did a year ago, Walter Cohen, vice president of Brand Oppenheimer, Inc., textile converters, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 28 (AP) -- Navy communique 392:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, May 29 (AP) -- Defying extremely bad weather, Allied bombers followed up Thursday's heavy raid on Lae, New Guinea, by dropping nearly nineteen tons of bombs yesterday on airdromes in the area of Wewak, a supply base for Lae further up the coast.

Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer signed an order yesterday requiring the city to show cause on Tuesday why the Board of Estimate should not be restrained from taking action on plans for a post-war razing of the "gas house district" between Fourteenth and Twentieth Streets, First Avenue and Avenue C. to make way for the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's housing project.

BOSTON, May 28 (AP) -- The commercial bulletin will say tomorrow: "Buying of wool needed promptly by mills has kept the market here going on a restricted scale. Medium grades, both domestic and foreign, continue to predominate in demand.
BALTIMORE, May 28 (AP) -- Del Jones's ninth-inning fly, enabling Hal Sieling to score from third, gave Baltimore a 5-to-4 decision over Jersey City tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 28 -- American bombers struck two more heavy blows at Axis air power in the Mediterranean yesterday when strong formations of Marauders and Mitchells pounded airfields at Decimomannu and Villacidro in Sardinia.

While the war will give great impetus to industrial research, this growth may be accompanied by rising costs of doing research, possibly beyond the resources of private industry, according to Dr. Robert W. King, assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Roosevelt created today an Office of War Mobilization, headed by James F. Byrnes, as the top Federal agency for conduct of the war on the home front.
For some years past the American Foundation for the Blind has provided sightless people with watches, on the dials of which raised dots indicate the numerals.
CHUNGKING, China, May 28 (AP) -- A communique:

On paper the reorganization just announced by the President represents a step forward of the first importance. It could mark the inauguration of the kind of war cabinet that has been advocated so often in the press and by Congressional committees. The President himself emphasizes this possibility by declaring that the new committee will meet in the Cabinet room.

Two of the nation's major utility holding companies yesterday accused the Securities and Exchange Commission of engaging in "loose talk" and of presenting arguments "completely false" in its attempt to defend the "death sentence" provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

Declaring that the new mark-ups are "actually ruinous," the New York Wholesale Grocers Association disclosed yesterday that it had asked Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown for a hearing with representatives of wholesale grocery distribution in this State.

Burton Charles Bernard of Granite City, Ill., winner of a nationwide oratorical contest for high school students, sponsored by the National Association of Manufacturers, received a $4,000 check yesterday to be used for his education.

Stressing the increased needs of philanthropy on "the military front, the United Nations front and the home front," directors of community fund-raising organizations from many States met yesterday to prepare for the Fall campaign for $125,000,000 under the auspices of the National War Fund, Inc., to meet these needs.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Liberal profit-taking developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade, wheat and rye declining 1 cent a bushel before the break was checked. Aggressive professional buying of rye developed on the break and a strong rally followed and the finish in that commodity was around the top for the day with the close 1/8 cent lower to 1/8 cent higher than yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 -- Ford Frick fined Johnny Allen $200 today and suspended the Dodger righthander for thirty days. The punishment, heaviest meted out by Frick since he became president of the National League, was for Allen's attempted assault on Umpire George Barr in the eighth inning of last night's Dodger-Pirate game.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Oklahoma City and Jacksonville, Fla., shared leadership over other cities in the sales gain of department stores in April as compared with April of 1942, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The gain recorded by each was 57 per cent.

Hank Borowy and the Yankees snapped out of their slumps yesterday at the Stadium at the expense of the Tigers. The American League champions beat Steve O'Neill's club, 2 to 1, after having dropped five games in a row. The victory was Borow's in first in five starts and his second of the year.

LONDON, May 28 -- Increased prosperity of the diamond trade was reflected in today's announcement that De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., will pay an interim dividend of 15s a share on account of 1943. No interim was paid last year but 1 a share, equal to 40 per cent, was declared at the end of 1942.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company and three other companies which operate 80 per cent of all the buses in Manhattan announced last night that none of their vehicles would run tomorrow or on other Sundays as long as the emergency transport regulations caused by the Eastern gasoline crisis remain in effect.
CINCINNATI, May 28 (AP) -- The Reds unleashed their batting power today, winning from Philadelphia, 11 -- 8, in an 11 A.M. game for swing-shift war workers.

OTTAWA, May 28 -- Seed, agricultural implements, locomotives and rolling stock of all kinds will be the first needs after the immediate food relief of the Netherlands and the other occupied countries when they are liberated, Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Foreign Minister of the Netherland Government, stated here today.

It was a big night for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre last night. There was no particular reason why it should have been for the program contained no more of a novelty than the first performance this season of the tried and true "Bluebird" pas de deux from "The Sleeping Beauty."

This city is adequately prepared to treat civilian casualties as the result of possible enemy action or any other war disaster, Major Randolph A. Wyman, deputy chief, Emergency Medical Service, New York City, declared yesterday at the closing session of the joint wartime convention of the Hospital Associations of New York and New Jersey at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, May 28 -- Although it is not likely that the present Giant team will leave lasting footprints in the sands of time, Mel Ott's Polo Grounders did leave some heelmarks on the necks of the Cubs today as they beat Jimmy Wilson's hapless tailenders 3 to 1.

ALGIERS, May 28 -- General Georges Catroux, Fighting French liaison officer, arrived here this afternoon as the cast for the formal union of General Henri Honore Giraud and General Charles de Gaulle in the French executive committee began to assemble. General de Gaulle is expected to arrive soon.

Lieut. Comdr. Harold E. Stassen who resigned last month as Governor of Minnesota, entered the Naval Training School at Fort Schuyler yesterday for a two- month indoctrination course. At the completion of the course, the 36-year-old former Governor will be assigned to an advanced base outside the United States.

Retail trade continued active here this week, with estimates indicating the average sales gain for department stores will probably exceed 25 per cent over the comparative 1942 week. This week, however, contains six business days, against five last year, because of the shift of Memorial Day.

The Edward G. Barrow Trophy, emblematic of the Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference championship, was given to Coach William V. McCarthy and his New York University team at a luncheon yesterday in the press room at the Yankee Stadium.

CINCINNATI, May 28 -- In the belief that concerted action is important in meeting the problems of the uncertain days ahead, the American Institute of Architects moved today to bring all groups and members of the profession into one national organization.

The Rev. John Bartle Everts has taken up his duties as pastor of Grace Methodist Church, 135 West 104th Street, between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, to which he was recently appointed by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist Area.

The seventeen outdoor swimming pools and five beaches operated by the city Department of Parks will be opened to the public for the new season this morning. Until June 20, however, the pools and the bathhouses at the beaches will be open on week-ends only, in addition to Memorial Day, celebrated Monday.

The Mississippi and Arkansas Rivers both reached all-time record heights yesterday in their destructive rampages, with the Mississippi circling Cairo, Ill., to form a second junction with the Ohio River, The Associated Press reported.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Rumors, believed to originate in Switzerland, that Count Dino Grandi, former Fascist Ambassador in London, has come to this country and that through him or other channels the Italian Government or the Italian Royal House has made direct peace overtures to Washington, were denied in responsible quarters here today.

With nine entered in the $7,500 added Peter Pan Handicap and ten in the $5,000 added Roseben Handicap, Belmont Park will stage its third Saturday program of the current meeting today with the same transportation that in recent weeks has made pedestrians of a good many horse-minded persons.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Roosevelt's immediate purpose in setting up the new over-all War Mobilization Board, and the Office of War Mobilization under Justice James F. Byrnes, was undoubtedly to strike wholesale at the controversies which have lately grown to explosive intensity within and among agencies dealing with the home front of the war.

Opposition to terms of the proposed settlement of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation's $5,000, 000 suit against its former sales agents was expressed yesterday in a brief filed with Supreme Court Justice J. Sidney Bernstein by Weinstein and Levinson, attorneys for a stockholder owning 500 shares of Brewster stock, one of a group of minority stockholders who brought the suit originally before the corporation joined as plaintiff after a change of management.
Bryan Field's story on the Withers Stakes in THE TIMES last Sunday sheds some light on just how much the worst of it a racegoer gets in the pari-mutuels when betting on an odds-on favorite.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Reports that black-market operations in gasoline are depriving the armed services of needed supplies of high-octane and commercial grades of gasoline circulated here today, but found little backing among officials of the Office of Price Administration, Petroleum Administrator for War and other agencies concerned with the movement and distribution of gasoline to the East Coast and elsewhere.

LONDON, Saturday, May 29 -- Berlin continued today to give lurid accounts of a terrific Russian offensive in the Kuban and to claim big Red Army losses, but the Russian midnight communique said only that "battles continued northeast of Novorossiisk."

CHUNGKING, China, May 28 (AP) -- While Chinese troops fought to check Japanese advances toward this capital, thirteen enemy planes today dropped delayed-action bombs on Enshih, 200 miles northeast of Chungking, Chinese dispatches reported.

Only a few neutral governments now remain in Europe. None of them, except General Franco's, has ever hoped the Axis would win this war. But all of them, as the Nazi hordes spread like a flood across the Continent, believed that it might. The developments of the last seven months, however, have brought about a notable change in this respect.

BOSTON, May 28 -- A front ride by Willie Turnbull brought Mrs. Wallace Renard's Anonymous back to the winner's circle after the feature race today at Suffolk Downs. The Identify colt scored by two lengths over Jerome H. Louchheim's Alhalon, with W.W.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- President Roosevelt created the Office of War Mobilization headed by James F. Byrnes as the top agency for conduct of the war on the home front.

The four-story apartment house on the corner of East Twenty-fifth Street and Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold to an investing client of William Scheinberg, attorney, by the Bedkirk Realty Corporation. A first mortgage in the amount of $136,500 is held on the property by the Manufacturers Trust Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 28 -- On the French Riviera people are becoming jumpy in the expectation of an Allied landing there. Yesterday rumors of impending military operations provoked a general exodus to the hills from Monte Carlo and the principality of Monaco generally.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- Picturing the Allies' situation in the Battle of the Atlantic as the "most encouraging" since the start of the war, informed quarters said today that new methods of fighting submarines were enabling the Allies to smash the undersea offensive that Germany launched in a desperate effort to stave off invasion.

Norman Dello Joio, 30-year-old New York composer, won the Town Hall Composition Award for 1943 with his "Magnificat" for chamber orchestra, it was announced yesterday by Walter W. Naumburg, chairman of the Town Hall Music Committee.

The time-worn formula of "live and let live" must be abandoned by the nations of the world in favor of the new one of "live and help live" in the new era after the World War, Dr. Eduard Benes, president of the Czechoslovak Republic, declared yesterday in an address acknowledging the city's official welcome at ceremonies held in City Hall Plaza before an audience of 3,000 persons.
PHILADELPHIA, May 28 (AP) -- Athletics moved to within a game and a half of first place in the American League today When they defeated the White Sex, 5 to 2.
The sixteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 114-16 West Eighty-sixth Street was sold by Paul S. Hitlin, builder and operator, to an investing client of E.L. Gothelf, attorney.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 28 -- Italians were warned indirectly tonight that an Allied invasion attempt, "if not against the mainland, at least against Italian island possessions, might be a matter of days at the most," and a military commentator on the Rome radio drew attention to a passage in today's communique referring to Italian aerial activity against "mezzi di sbarco" -- ramp or landing boats -- concentrated at Bizerte and Sousse.

SEATTLE, May 28 (AP) -- Attu Island's first casualties came out of the fog-wrapped North to a Pacific Northwest Army hospital today, agreed that fighting the Japanese in the Aleutians would not be bad if you could see them.

A joint Memorial Day service in honor of the fighting men of both World Wars was held yesterday afternoon by the American Legionnaires of Metropolitan Post No. 385 and Nylic Post No. 503 in Madison Square. Charles G. Taylor Jr., vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, said in an address:

More than 750 children of service men attended a party yesterday given by Bundles for America at its national distribution depot, 42 East Thirty-third Street. The celebration, for which the toy industry donated 1,000 toys, marked the depot's first anniversary.

With Nazi hatred mounting high against the United States because of our successful air onslaught against Germany and the Reich's submarine campaign losing its effectiveness, Hitler is very likely to start air raids against this country regardless of the cost, Major Gen. Ralph Royce, commanding the First Air Force, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The following are the text of the statement by President Roosevelt accompanying his executive order creating the office of War Mobilization and the text of the executive order:

BOSTON, May 28 -- Dr. John W.M. Bunker, dean of Massachusetts Institute of Technology Graduate School, at commencement exercises, warned American scientists and engineers tonight against professional isolationism and overspecialization.

LONDON, May 28 (AP) -- The German news agency D.N.B. reported that an earthquake shook a large area in Southwestern Germany early today, causing slight injuries to a number of persons near Stuttgart. The D.N.B. report was broadcast by the Berlin radio and recorded by The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, May 28 (U.P.) -- J. Edgar Hoover, head of the F. B. I. announced today that John Roy Horton, a ship's radio operator, had been arrested at Savannah, Ga., on charges of illegal possession of confidential information concerning convoy schedules.

PITTSBURGH, May 28 -- Going about the business calmly and efficiently, the Dodger today scored their only victory in the three-game series here by topping the Pirates, 6 -- 2, and departed for Cincinnati tonight in a much better mood than when they had walked off Forbes field after last night's embroilment.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- The War Food Administration started today on a nation-wide search for idle farm machinery, saying it would be requisitioned by the government and distributed where it is needed most to increase food production.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A greatly simplified, light-weight air-conditioning system for small homes, which can be installed in existing buildings, is an outstanding item among the 558 inventions on which patents were granted by the Patent Office this week.

The exhibition of paintings by Stark Young, novelist, current at Friends of Greece, Inc., 52 East Fifty-seventh Street, has created such interest that it has been extended for another week, through June 5. Proceeds of the sale of pictures will be donated to Greek war relief.

PHILADELPHIA, May 28 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today the broker-dealer registration of William K. Archer and Edward G. Mader of Kansas City, on the ground that Archer's past record did not justify his re-entry into business.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Fred M. Vinson, 53, of Kentucky, a lawyer, tax expert and Federal judge -- in that order, is the new Economic Stabilization Director and a member of the War Mobilization Committee.

The Appellate Division, in a unanimous ruling yesterday, upheld as "sufficient to comply with the statute" the language used in the "loan statement" that accompanies loans made by the Household Finance Corporation. The court reversed a Supreme Court decision, which had found technical legal deficiency in the language used and on that technical ground had canceled the note and chattel mortgage given by a borrower.

WASHINGTON, May 28 -- A further decline in pulp inventories to a point where the typical non-integrated consuming mill -- with the exception of news-grade unbleached sulphite and ground wood -- now has an inventory of only about thirty days pulp, was reported today by the pulp and paper division of the War Production Board.

The Stadium Concerts, which afforded free admission to soldiers and sailors last season, is expanding its efforts to provide recreation for men and women in the services of the United Nations. Its Defense Recreation Committee has worked out the following plan for the organization's forthcoming season:...

ST. LOUIS, May 28 (AP) -- LouKlein not only hit safely in his eighteenth consecutive game today but his tenth-inning triple drove Pitcher Max Lanier home from first with the winning run in the Cardinals' 2-to-1 triumph over the Braves.

Every-other-day delivery of milk ordered by the Office of Defense Transportation as a gasoline conservation measure, hit a snag yesterday with the announcement by officials of the Milk Wagon Drivers Union, A.F. of L., that its 14,000 members in metropolitan New York, Northern New Jersey and Westchester County had been instructed to refuse to take double loads at platforms of the various milk companies this morning.
The German Friday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
WASHINGTON, May 28 -- Following is the text of President Roosevelt's executive order estabing a new Committee on Fair Employment Practices:

In another column on this page we publish a letter from Earl Browder, General Secretary of the Communist party of the United States, in which he offers that organization's aid in a "cooperative effort to lay the 'specter of communism.'" This seems to us to be a curious offer to come from Mr. Browder.

NEW DELHI, India, May 28 (AP) -- A British communique: With the exception of a few patrols, there has been no Japanese activity north of their positions in the Maungdaw-Buthedaung area during the past week and there is no change in the Arakan situation generally.

DUMONT, N. J., May 28 -- Four 'teen-age youths, three of whom are members of the local Defense Council Auxiliary Fire Department, were arrested today on charges of setting five fires that caused approximately $16,000 damages in this town in recent months.
Spinach has begun to glut the metropolitan markets. Housewives show little or no enthusiasm, although the price has dropped in ten days from $1.50 to between 50 and 60 cents a bushel.

Mayor La Guardia said last night that he saw no impropriety in the assignment of employes of the Department of Sanitation to work on the improvement of Sanita Hills, the department's Summer camp in Dutchess County. The property, the Mayor added, is owned by the city and the department's welfare honor relief fund would reimburse the city for labor and equipment used on the job.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 28 -- Travers Island, the forty-acre country home here of the New York Athletic Club since 1904, will be occupied after next Tuesday by Norwegian sailors, Albert F. Jenkins, commodore of the yachting department of the club, said this evening.

The third community rally of the Book and Author War Bond Committee was held Thursday at New Bedford, Mass., with a larger total sale of war bonds and a larger per capita sale than in either of the committee's two previous successful rallies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 28 -- Anne Baxter, now in the romantic lead of Samuel Goldwyn's "The North Star, on loan from Twentieth Century-Fox, will return to her home lot to start in "Paris, Tenn." She will have the Army officer's wife role, previously scheduled for Ida Lupino.

An appeal for 1,500 women with high-school diplomas, to aid in the war -- and at the same time get into interesting work -- by enrolling as volunteer health assistants in this city, was broadcast yesterday by Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins.

Activity in the market here for new investments was limited this week entirely to the tax-exempt field, with offerings in that category the largest for any week in almost three months. Four issues of State and municipal bonds aggregating $17,977,000 were offered for public subscription, compared with $10,436,000, representing a diversified list of five offerings, last week.

LONDON, May 28 -- Any hopes that might have been raised for the affiliation of the British Communist party with the British Labor party as a result of Soviet Russia's recent action in dissolving the Comintern appeared to be nipped in the bud today when the Executive Committee of the Labor party remained adamant in its opposition to such a step.

CHUNGKING, China, May 28 -- Despite the seriousness of the military and economic situation the fact that repeal of the Chinese Exclusion Act is being opposed by certain groups in the United States has not gone unnoticed in Chungking.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 28 -- From dawn through noon today strange combinations of ancient and modern vehicles wound their way toward Middletown through the Catskill foothills in Orange County to take part in the Erie Day parade.

Lucien O. Hooper, statistician for W.E. Hutton Co., was elected yesterday president of the New York Society of Security Analysts, succeeding William Hamilton Swartz of Goodbody Co. Oscar Miller of General American Investors, Inc., was made secretary.

AT AN ADVANCED PACIFIC BASE, May 28 -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, recently presented a Presidential unit citation "for outstanding performance in action" to the Enterprise, the first aircraft carrier so honored.

Two fine blasts at the proposals to have a sports coordinator or a three-man committee guide the wartime control of athletics were published in your pages last Saturday and I am sure hundreds of thousands of fans rejoiced over them.

The outstanding theatrical collection of the New York Public Library received a valuable addition yesterday from The Players, 16 Gramercy Park. Since this organization was started in 1889 it has been assembling portfolios of clippings, play bills, criticisms and other memorabilia of actors and actresses in America.

Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse of 1040 Fifth Avenue entertained at dinner last evening on the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mr. and Mrs. John P. Armstrong of Guatemala, Miss Martha Armstrong, Miss Sylvia Whitehouse and George B. Whitehouse.

THE Symphony Orchestra of Mexico, under Carlos Chavez, opens its sixteenth season Friday night at the Palace of Fine Arts, Mexico City. In addition to a fourteen-week subscription series on Fridays and Sundays, the season will include a popular-priced series and a Festival of Contemporary Music, consisting of three programs on Oct. 22, 26 and 29.

SALLY GIBBS has chosen an interesting situation for her new novel. In the days before the United States entered the war Alix Michon, a lonely, sensitive Belgian girl, became engaged to an American flier, Renny Fanstock, who died of pneumonia before he had an opportunity to get into action in the war.
