DETROIT, May 29 -- Johnny Adams, 28-year-old wizard of the saddle from Iola, Kan., who topped the nation's riders last year, booted home five successive winners today before 11,619 fans at the Detroit Fair Grounds and picked up an estimated $1,000 in salary and bonuses.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., May 29 -- Wartime exigencies have wrought striking changes in life in Southampton, which for more than fifty years has been the setting for many brilliant public fetes in behalf of various important charitable organizations, noted tennis and golf tournaments and many private entertainments, as well as one of the outstanding gathering places in the country for members of the social, financial and diplomatic worlds.

What appeared to be a Memorial Day week-end travel record continued in the making yesterday and last night. Disregarding the appeal of the Federal Government to stay at home and the plea of transportation services "to take it easy," the general public, augmented by vast numbers of service men on furlough, jammed trains, buses and airlines, bound both for and out of New York.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 -- Steady and stingy in yielding hits after the opening frame, Southpaw John Eide commendably closed his collegiate baseball career today by pitching Princeton to a 3-to-1 victory over Fordham on University Field.

The relocation, training and orienting of hill-country farm laborers, shifted from Kentucky and West Virginia to the Northeast to head off the serious agricultural labor shortage, has been a task replete with sociological and educational problems.

NEWARK, May 29 (AP) -- Lefty Tom Sunkel checked a ninth-inning rally and chalked up a 3-to-2 victory for Jersey City over the Bears today for his second decision since being transferred by the parent Giants.

AN ever-popular pastime with American movie fans is that of matching selections of their all-time favorite films. Rub two or more screen enthusiasts together for even a brief length of time and soon you will see the inevitable smoke of contention rise. For Americans have an odd way of cataloguing their experiences by grades.

President Roosevelt, in a letter to Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, made public yesterday, emphasized that nothing must interfere with the movement of American ships. The President praised the spirit of American seamen and pointed out that their services in the movement of American troops and cargo to the main theatres of war were important to victory.

WITH the approach of Summer, two large-scale military productions are being rushed ahead by British studios. Both films demand good visibility, the manoeuvres of large bodies of men and a considerable amount of elbow-room

More than 400 members of Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc., representing 107 cities from Maine to Washington, D.C., attended the fifteenth annual meeting at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, yesterday.

QUEBEC, May 29 (U.P.) -- Viscount Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, asserted tonight that the war was caused largely by "the continuous erosion" of Christianity, which reached its culmination in nazism.

" -- BUT WITH DIGNITY": .i roundup of the Marriage License Bureaus of the city's five boroughs last week showed that licenses are being issued at the rate of about 300 a day. The pace will accelerate, officials say, and a record crop of June brides may be expected.

Diamonds not only have become essential to the production of war equipment; they now are actually going to the front. It is estimated that about 15 per cent of the Army personnel wear glasses -- and glasses break! The American Optical Company has developed a mobile lens-grinding unit for Army use, which is equipped with diamond tools.

ANY one, old or young, who has even a passing acquaintance with the rich land of the Pennsylvania Dutch will succumb at once to the charms of this book, the fifth in Mr. De Witt's brilliant series of pictorial geographies about American regions.

Charges that distribution of lumber is being manipulated by a few individuals who have designs on post-war control of the industry will be investigated by the anti-trust division of the Department of Justice, it was learned yesterday.

The curse of the century is "the clever but socially irresponsible technician, whether he be a shyster lawyer or a time-serving engineer or a Nazi gauleiter," Dr. Harold A. Larrabee, Professor of Philosophy at Union College, declared last night at the opening of the Conference on the Scientific Spirit and Democratic Faith at the Ethical Culture Building, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

THE Kniphofia or Tritoma, as it is commonly called, is one of the most spectacular of our Summer and Fall blooming perennials. Authorities describe them as herbs with long spikes of red and yellow flowers and an abundance of radical foliage.
LONDON, May 29 -- Norwegians have sabotaged the German labor-conscription plan to the extent of cutting the 35,000 workers that the Axis wanted to 3,500, it was indicated today.

HERE is the absorbing story of the great Far Eastern empire that Japan has conquered, as it was in the frenzied year before Tojo's troops stormed down from the north and swept the Americans and British and Dutch out of the lands of the Far Pacific and Southeastern Asia.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 29 -- The holiday week-end has given added impetus to the influx of visitors here, many of whom will spend the Summer. Members of society long identified with the resort are returning to their cottages and to the various hostelries and already are making plans for the season ahead.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 29 -- Wesleyan University announced today that it had discontinued intercollegiate athletic competition for the duration of the war.

An appeal for funds to send 765 boys and girls to the three Summer camps of the Union Settlement Association will be launched on Tuesday when Mrs. Harold Ruckman Mixsell, chairman of the camp committee of the organization's women's auxiliary, will give a luncheon at La Salle du Bois for Mrs. George C. Barclay, executive secretary of the association.

DIVERS and interesting rejoinders to the letter of Dr. Serge Koussevitzky, printed in these columns two weeks ago, concerning the lot of the serious composer in America, and suggesting that the performing musicians themselves contribute in one way or another to the straightening of his position in the community, nave been received.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- Ordered home because of illness, Lieut. Col. James Roosevelt, eldest son of the President, wept when he turned over command of a battalion of marines to his successor at a South Pacific island base, a letter from one of his men has revealed.

There was no let-up in wholesale market activity last week, and in addition to the large number of buyers already reported a new group is expected after the weekend holiday, according to the report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

DEVOTEES of fencing hold -- and probably with justice -- that it is the best of all exercises, making for harmonious development of all the muscles of the body and for perfect coordination of hand and eye and brain.

IN her story of the Crackells who lived on Sand Hill and had a bad name, Caroline Slade has written a case history of the destitute. At the same time she has presented a case history of the case-historians, the well-meaning futile and sometimes corrupted social workers who "live off the poor" and have a good name.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Although the stubborn fighting still dragged out on the frozen, fog-shrouded wastes of Attu this week, military and naval observers here confidently regarded the campaign as an all but closed issue. Informed circles also felt that, even if reconquered Attu never became the springboard for an active offensive in the North Pacific, the campaign still would be a sound investment, because of the bleak island's strategic potentialities.

Interesting comments upon the impression made upon the people of occupied France by the landing of Anglo-American forces in North Africa, and by the institution last Winter of compulsory recruitment of French workers for German war plants are found in a letter written in Paris by a competent observer, and recently received here.

SUPERFICIAL observers who consider that the Jew is suited only to commercial pursuits should read this able presentation of what has been accomplished by the Jewish Agricultural Society in diverting the flow of immigrants from the large cities into the country districts.

DEVON, Pa., May 29 -- That remarkable Welsh terrier Champion Flornell Rare-Bit of Twin Ponds this afternoon scored his eighteenth best-in-show victory. Rare-Bit, a natural showman, is owned by Mrs. Edward P. Alker of Great Neck, L.I., and is handled by John Goudie in the ring.

AMERICANS who have just discovered the fact that Alaska lies mainly in the North Temperate Zone, not in the Arctic, with plenty of warmth and sunshine, may obtain further information through a reincarnated Mr. Pepys in Ales Hrdlicka's "Alaska Diary."

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Claude Passeau held the Braves to eight hits today and drove home the winning run in the thirteenth inning to give the Cubs a 4-to-3 victory and end their three-game losing streak.

The latest notice of shipments made by the Geneva offices of the War Prisoners Aid of the Y.M.C.A. shows that during the month of November, 3,750 different packages were delivered to pris on camps in Germany.

More fuel oil and gasoline will be available for the furnace and automobile next Winter as the result of an investigation recently completed and announced by Professor George Granger Brown (University of Michigan) and Frank C. Fowler (Phillips Petroleum Company) before the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Alorter, a juvenile colt owned by A.C. Ernst of Cleveland, closed with a tremendous rush to beat Mrs. Albert Sabath's Civil Liberty, the 4-5 favorite, in Lincoln Fields' 5,000 added Joliet Stakes at Hawthorne today.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Grove Park Inn, which has been in government service for the past fifteen months, will be reopened for guests and visitors on June 1. The inn, which has been used by the State Department and the Navy, will be renovated and the entire lobby will be completely redecorated and refurnished.

The just-released amendment to the government's L-85 regulation of women's and children's clothing broadens the existing control by establishing maximum measurements for the "body basic," or the untrimmed dress. The body basic includes the front and back of the waist, the skirt, sleeves, inside shoulder pads, belt or sash, hem, normal facings and a 2-inch lap on an open front top.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Navy communique 394:

THE mounting interest displayed in the growing of hardy asters is reflected in the large number of varieties that can now be obtained. Until a few years ago the culture of these beautiful plants was centered largely in Europe, where, singularly enough, the varieties having the most popular appeal were largely derived from our American species, the most notable being the New England aster (Aster novaeangliae), and the New York aster (Aster novibelgi).

OLD time wrought iron weather vanes, andirons, hinges and other homely articles have a practical as well as sentimental appeal. Recalling the village blacksmith, that country craftsman who made the most of these iron accessories, they may be put to every-day use once more and, unlike more fragile antiques, be none the worse for it.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 -- The St. Louis area had a flood in May, 1844, which set a record of 41.39 feet, or 11 feet above flood stage. This ninety-nine-year-old mark was almost equaled during the last two weeks, when the Missouri and its tributaries and then the Mississippi went on a rampage as the result of fifteen successive days of rainfall.

A year ago the Memorial Day week-end was one of the best of the local salt water fishing years. There were several choices to be made by the curious angler. He could still decide whether or not he would go off-shore and try his luck for mackerel, if nothing else, or he could hie down to the east end of Long Island and go weak fishing.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Those who believe this war will put an end to Soviet Russia's twenty-five years of isolation and bring her into closer contact and cooperation with the Western democracies -- and they include some of the highest officials of this government -- found encouragement in two events in the last week.

LONDON, May 29 -- Led by Ambassador John G. Winant and United States Army Navy chiefs, American service men and civilians and many Britons will hold solemn Memorial Day services tomorrow and Monday. They will pay tribute to those who, in defending the Stars and Stripes, fell in four wars -- the Civil War, the Spanish-American War, the First World War and this war.

CINCINNATI, May 29 -- With the bases filled and none out in the eleventh inning, Lonnie Frey rifled a first pitch from Max Macon over Dixie Walker's head in right field to score Eric Tipton and give the Reds a 5-4 triumph over the Dodgers today.

A LITTLE to the right is the statistician's view of the departing season of 1942-43, and since the theatre is a bit like horseracing in that both pay off on the winners, it is quite possible the statistician's view of the success of the season is the only correct one.

THE People's Book Club, a gigantic countrywide project of Simon Schuster, Sears, Roebuck and Consolidated Book Publishers of Chicago, on the fire for months, will be launched shortly. Object of the club is to tap the hitherto unsounded book market in the hinterland by making books of current popular appeal available at popular prices to large groups of people who are not now book buyers or readers.

LONDON, May 29 -- Jeering at the Germans for shedding crocodile tears and putting out propaganda against aerial bombing, Air Chief Marshal Sir Arthur T. Harris, chief of the R.A.F. Bomber Command, today made the grim announcement that the recent big British-American blows on the Germans and Italians were "chicken feed" compared to what was in store for them.

THERE was nothing "little people" could do to change their "fate," some fathers and mothers thought at the outset of a series of discussion groups about which this reporter hears from Mrs. Jean Schick Grossman. But that was some ten weeks ago. As the series of evening meetings dosed, Mrs. Grossman reports.

American war workers are chiefly concerned at present with their post-war employment status, according to Walter E. Poor, president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. A poll of the company's workers just completed showed the question: "Will I have a job when the war is over?" was asked four times more often than any other, he reported.

One of the Power Squadron's best known members, Marshall Van Winkle Jr. of Little Silver, N.J., has been elected commander of the Shrewsbury Squadron for 1943. He heads an entirely new slate of officers of this busy unit that draws its members from along both branches of the Shrewsbury and down the Jersey coast as far as Asbury Park.
CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
The Yankees went in for hits and runs on a mass production basis yesterday at the Stadium and enjoyed partial revenge for the discomfiture they suffered on their recent trip to Cleveland.

A REWARDING exhibition of work by the German artist Lovis Corinth opened last week at the Galerie St. Etienne. Corinth belongs to the nineteenth century, but also to the twentieth (he died in 1925). This robust expressionist is by no means as well known here as he deserves to be.

Restrictions on production, rationing of consumption and control of prices, as well as the increasing cost of operations, are affecting in varying degrees earnings of companies in the chemical, oil, mining and paper industries. With few exceptions, companies in these fields were among those which had the largest increase in the first World War.

HERE is Private Hargrove in skirts. What the sergeant (present status) did for the United States Army, Auxiliary Elizabeth R. Polock does for the Waces. In "Yes, Ma'am! the Personal Papers of a Waac Private," a woman relates play-by-play her experiences as a member of the armed services.

FREEDOM of speech on the radio has long ranked near the top of controversial issues in broadcasting and at the moment perhaps no one is more directly involved than Mark Woods, president of the Blue Network.
BERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -- News comes from Paris of arrests of "Communists" and "Jews" in connection with the "interning of dangerous spies."

LONDON, May 29 (U.P.) -- Lord Sherwood, Under-Secretary for Air, speaking at a Wings for Victory celebration at Dumfries, Scotland, disclosed that 12,000 fliers participated in the raids on Dortmund, Duesseldorf and Essen.
LONDON, Sunday, May 30 (AP) -- A joint British Air Ministry and European Theatre of Operations, United States Army, communique:

IN addition to all its other surprises Mexico holds two shocks for the American tourist that stick in his mind long after he comes home. One is the pervasive presence of that almost palpable entity called "the revolution."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- In spite of attacks in and out of Congress on Administration plans to subsidize some food producers in an effort to check inflation, the Office of Price Administration announced today that butter producers would be subsidized sufficiently to enable them to "roll back" prices by about 6 cents a pound, effective June 10.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, May 29 (U.P.) -- Rear Admiral Theodore S. Wilkinson, deputy commander of the United States South Pacific Fleet, said today that the Allies were on the offensive in that area and hinted strongly at new blows against the Japanese, possibly north of the Solomon Islands.

Last October a group of biochemists headed by Dr. Vincent du Vigneaud succeeded in picturing the structure of the complex biotin molecule -- a performance akin to but far more difficult than drawing the plans of a house. With the blueprint of Dr. du Vigneaud to aid them, chemists of the Merck laboratories have now built the molecular house called biotin.

AT midnight tomorrow what is commonly known as the theatrical season will end, thanks to the peculiar set-up of Equity contracts. And that gives all of us a good reason for indulging mildly in retrospection. Once a day or a month, or especially a theatrical season, has passed, it becomes history.
WASHIGTON, May 29 -- Strikes in war industries have been on the increase in the last three months and the number of workers idle and man-days lost have also increased.

BROADWAY'S pants presser and valet extraordinary is Misch. For twoscore years or more he has been putting the crease in the breeches of the famed gentlemen of the entertainment world and cleansing the gowns of the ladies everything from the several yards in which Lillian Russell was encased to the square centimeter or two which screens the fillies of today.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 29 -- Some of the young men of the service academies paused on their way out to the wars today to stage another Army-Navy Sport Day before hundreds of visitors and much gold braid and rank.

A STRIDENT voice from Tokyo recently boasted that bombing of the American Continent will "bring America to her knees." The speaker was Lieut. Gen. Ashinari Uchida, director of the Japanese Army's aeronautical affairs section. It recalled a statement by the German Propaganda Minister, Goebbels, last month assuring his people that an "appropriate reply" would be made to British and American air attacks.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, May 28 (Delayed) -- Japanese naval and military experts, accompanied by technicians specially trained in the construction of island defenses in the Asiatic theatre, have been flown to the German-occupied islands in the Mediterranean and the Aegean, it was learned tonight from foreign military intelligence and naval sources.

The report of the Snider Packing Corporation for the fiscal year ended March 31 shows a net profit of $472,781, after a deduction of $1, 030,630 for Federal income taxes and excess profits taxes. This is equal to $2.25 a share, and compares with a net income of $449,237, or $2.14 a share, in the year to March 31, 1942, when taxes amounted to $486,815.

The late Ralph Adams Cram was more than an architect. To him, technical architecture meant nothing unless it formed, with music, painting and poetry, what he called "a dynamic unit." His own temperament was dynamic enough, and yet harmonious. His interests were boundless; nothing that was human was alien to him.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 29 -- Herve Alphand, chairman of the French delegation, said today that he had urged the United Nations conference on food and agriculture to recognize that the "real problem" of achieving freedom from want in the post-war world was that of "the equilibrium of the balance of payment."

A city-wide drive for the collection of discarded clothing and resalable articles will be made this week on behalf of the Bundles for Britain national "Save and Sew Campaign." The workroom, Gift Shop and Thrift Shop divisions of the organization will conduct the drive with the special events committee, of which Mrs. Eliot Tuckerman is chairman.

For thirteen successive months stocks on the New York Stock Exchange have been rising. Yesterday they closed another month with industrial prices the best in two and a half years and rails at the top for six years.

IN commissioning Roy Harris to write a Sixth symphony, Mark Woods, president of the Blue Network, declared he made no demands on the composer, only hoping that the new work would be an expression of the nation's war effort.

RACEGOERS have found a new hero -- Count Fleet. Is the Count another Man o' War in the making? That is the question many will be asking at Belmont Park next Saturday when Mrs. John D. Hertz's speedy 3-year-old goes to the post for the Belmont Stakes. Count Fleet has already chalked up the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness to his credit; the Belmont is the third link in the coveted turf triple.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission's Legislative Committee, headed by Chairman Walter M.W. Splawn, in a letter addressed to Burton K. Wheeler, chairman of the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee, has recommended that the bill introduced by Senator Stewart of Tennessee to amend Section 20 of the Interstate Commerce Act be passed with certain amendments or modifications, it was learned today.

LONDON, May 29 (AP) -- Advocates of closer cooperation with Soviet Russia today urged that the Allies begin building immediately upon a new foundation of inter-allied understanding, which they said Joseph Stalin had provided in a letter explaining the dissolution of the Comintern.

DETROIT, May 29 -- Close friends of Henry Ford said today that he would resume the presidency of the Ford Motor Company on Monday, taking the place left vacant by the death of his son, Edsel. A meeting of company executives has been called for Monday.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The American Red Cross announced today the receipt of cabled thanks for aid to Greek refugees from King George of Greece, who recently completed a tour of the Middle East camps where refugees are being aided by British authorities with Red Cross cooperation.

A clash between two rival "clubs" -- the "Flashes" and the "Sabers" -- on Lenox Avenue between 139th Street, where the fighting began, and 142d Street, where it ended, sent our Harlem boys to Harlem Hospital in serious condition about 5 P.M. yesterday.

FOR three thousand years or more, a Hebrew shepherd, poet, musician, soldier, outlaw and monarch has been known admired and even revered by one-half at least of this still mainly illiterate human race. He is patron of Wales.

NEW programs for the Summer continue to come forth. One of the more formidable finds Paul Whiteman and his orchestra and Dinah Shore, the songstress, combining their talents for a show which will replace Edgar Bergen in the 8 to 8:30 period Sunday evenings over NBC (WEAF).

To provide for either complete or partial termination of war contracts when hostilities cease, the War Production Board's procurement policy board which has been studying this complex problem for nearly a year has set up tentatively two proposed methods and is now in active consultation with industry representatives to iron out differences, it was learned here yesterday.

"MOSCOW DATELINE" is the honest-to-goodness account of two momentous years in Moscow written by a first-class reporter. What I mean is that Henry Cassidy has not given us a subjective account of himself and his emotions. This is a reporter's book, written by a reporter, the correspondent of The Associated Press, who tells his story simply, in clear objective terms.

Roy Talcott of Princeton, Don Clay and Ed Bell of Cornell led the statistical parade in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League for the recent season, according to figures announced yesterday by the Central Office for Eastern Intercollegiate Athletics.

DETROIT, May 29 -- Maxon, Inc., the advertising agency owned by Lou R. Maxon, deputy administrator of the OPA, has received a sufficient number of extra food ration points for a Summer lodge, where Maxon entertains friends and customers, to serve three meals a day to eighty persons in May and June, it was charged here today by R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O.

LONDON, May 29 (U.P.) -- A strategic air reserve of probably 400 crack planes on camouflaged airdromes is believed to be Adolf Hitler's ace card against the coming Allied invasion of Europe. Axis invasion jitters are mounting and there is an avalanche of speculation.
A German naval officer, Lieut. Comdr. Rudolf Krohne, acknowledged improved Allied defenses against U-boats in an article reported to occupied Europe yesterday by the Nazi DNB agency.

NEWARK, N.J., May 29 -- An executive committee representing employes of the Newark, Long Island City and Hatboro, Pa., plants of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation announced tonight after a meeting here that employes at the three plants would limit their working week to forty hours "until such times as the Navy stops interfering with the contract" between the Newark local of the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and the company.

The United States Lines received word last week of the death of Captain Henry A.T. Candy, well known shipmaster, on May 1, in Southampton, England, where he had made his home since his retirement in 1932 after forty-five years' service at sea.

MILWAUKEE, May 29 -- Clarence Dunn furnished the top individual mark of the program and his team-mates produced ample power and balance to give Illinois its first Central Collegiate Conference track and field championship tonight in Marquette Stadium.
The German Saturday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- C.E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation, made public today the text of a telegram he has sent to members of the House Military Affairs Committee further emphasizing his support of legislation which would make illegal the unionization of foremen for the purpose of collective bargaining.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 29 (AP) -- The text of General Eisenhower's speech follows:

President Roosevelt reports to Congress that the United States is "outbuilding the aggressors in every category of modern arms" and is "delivering them in the amounts necessary to build up the striking power for offensives that will end only in Berlin and Tokyo."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Administration program to pay "wholesale subsidies" to farm producers, farm processors and food-products handlers in an effort to check inflationary trends is "strong medicine" which is inflationary in itself, Senator Byrd, Democrat of Virginia, asserted in a statement today.

IT will take more than statesmen alone and alone the governments of victorious States to set up the new World Order in behalf of which the present terrible war is being fought. It will take all of us -- working each in his own fashion, according to his own capacity and bent, yet working in a fundamental concert of desire -- to achieve that end.

IN his first book, "A Judge Comes of Age," John C. Knox emerged from the necessary aloofness and seclusion of a judge of the United States District Court here to write about his court and himself. Readers of that book found some one they would have valued as a friend in the tall, slim jurist.
ST. LOUIS, May 29 -- For a few fleeting moments today the Giants appeared to have more lives than a sackful of cats as they strove to gain their first victory of the season over the Cardinals.

A PACIFIC BASE, April 29 -- When the threat of major Japanese reinforcements on Guadalcanal had passed with destruction or dispersal of the Japanese armada moving down from Bougainville and the Shortland Islands the 164th Infantry moved out across the Matanikau River to retake the gorund voluntarily surrendered the week before.
A RECENTLY discovered cover mailed longer than a year ago in Lisbon. Portugal, and addressed to Brunn, Protectorate of Moravia, now occupied by the Nazis, is causing considerable speculation.

The Brooklyn Hispano soccer team will oppose the Morgan Strassers of Pittsburgh in the replay of the National Challenge Cup final at Starlight Park this afternoon. Two preliminary games will precede the main encounter, the Sada aggregation opposing the Richelieu Marines at noon and the Uhrik Truckers tackling the Local 32B team at 1:30.

Along the graveled paths of The Homestead at Hot Springs, Va., last week two white-clad South Americans strolled in deep conversation. On the tennis courts a turbaned Indian and a Briton in shorts played an expert game. A uniformed colonel of the Red Army talked on the broad terrace with compatriots in civilian clothes.

IN the Eighteen Forties the Lloyd-Joneses -- a fervid, Bible-preaching, long-lived clan -- came to Wisconsin from Wales. In the Eighteen Sixties Anna, aged 29, married William Wright, aged 46, from Hartford. Their first and only boy.

Suspension of Sunday service on all but seven of the thirty bus routes in Manhattan and drastic reductions in other boroughs became effective last midnight to meet the emergency transport regulations caused by the Eastern gasoline crisis.

CHUNGKING, China, May 29 (AP) -- Japanese troops with aerial support have renewed their attack in Central Hupeh Province and "severe fighting is proceeding along the entire line," a Chinese communique announced today.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -- Addressing a meeting of the Government party in Budapest today, Premier Nicholas von Kallay served warning that Hungary's future lay with other small States -- completely independent of interference from larger States, wherever they may be. He also issued a vague invitation to Balkan States to recognize that they have "more in common to defend than they have in opposition."

The nation's great department stores since the beginning of the war have had to trim the ruffles off their service, and make swift changes. Last week, another complication arose. With the gasoline shortage acute and deliveries of merchandise curtailed, store executives were busy figuring the best ways to meet the new crisis.

The deadline for renewing three-year commercial chauffeurs' licenses expired at noon yesterday, with indications that the number of men engaged in that activity in New York City has declined 30 per cent from the 1940 total.

PITTSBURGH, May 29 (AP) -- Every man in the Pittsburgh lineup made at least one hit today as the Pirates bombarded Al Gerheauser and Waiter Beck for sixteen to wallop the Phillies, 12 to 4, in the inaugural of a three-game series.

THE Lace Verbena (Zaluzianskya) is an attractive little plant, especially recommended to gardeners who like night-blooming and fragrant flowers. It is an annual, grows easily and the flowers are pretty. In its native South Africa it is known as Star Balsam and Night Balsam, but it resembles rather a verbena or phlox, and its common name here is thus more appropriate.

FOR six months after September, 1939, there was in Europe what was called a "phony war." It became a real war, the most deadly perhaps in man's bloody annals. For eighteen months there has been in Asia and over the broad reaches of the Pacific a war that cannot be characterized by an adjective, that does not fit into any classification drawn from historical experience.

The re-election of Bert Lytell as president of Actors Equity Association for another three years was announced yesterday. Ballots, cast Friday at the association's annual meeting, which was held at the Hotel Astor, were tabulated yesterday at the headquarters of the union, 45 West Forty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- The National Football League's second meeting of the year has been called for June 19 and 20, primarily to approve the new schedule and draft an additional 200 collegians, but there's an outside chance one or more petitions for club franchises will be presented then, too.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 251 United States soldiers wounded, and of 179 missing, in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

REPORTS of a "black market" in Pullman reservations continue to circulate and stories are told about how this and that agency or individual can "fix up" the worried and impatient passenger who must have a lower or a bedroom on a certain day.

ALBANY, May 29 -- The dissolution of 6,395 stock corporations last year was not owing to stringent laws of New York State but to "the drains to which they were subjected by direct and indirect taxation primarily Federal in character," according to the Division of Corporations reporting to the Secretary of State. This report is now on Governor Dewey's desk.

ALBANY, May 29 -- A resolution urging "gasless Sundays" throughout the nation as a substitute for the present prohibition against pleasure driving was sent to Washington today by New York State automobile dealers. The resolution, adopted at a joint meeting of the dealer's associations in Albany, was directed to President Roosevelt, Petroleum Administrator Ickes and members of Congress from this State.

That members of the legal profession in all countries of the United Nations act as "a directive force" for justice in behalf of the victims of the Axis powers was proposed yesterday by the executive board of the National Lawyers Guild.

Human beings are for the first time revealing the body's needs for amino acids -- little known food elements essential to life and as important as vitamins, Professor William C. Rose of the University of Illinois Chemistry Department told the Nutrition Foundation in New York last week.

EMIL LUDWIG regards himself as the originator of "the new art form of modern biography." On the first page of his preface to his new book on Beethoven, he observes that his Life of Goethe, issued in 1919, "became the basis for all the books which, appearing in many languages, varied this form."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Office of Price Administration today extended for another two months the provision allowing retailers to make emergency reductions in the point values of rationed meats and fats which are in imminent danger of spoiling. This lengthens the period until July 31.

IT is hardly likely, transportation problems being what they are, that a new attendance record will be set at Belmont Park tomorrow afternoon. That will be a day when even the most vehement critic of the turf would want to see those turnstiles spin merrily, because all of the net proceeds of the park's traditionally biggest day will go to war relief and local charities.

"SEEMS like the ocean's sloshed right up to the door and we're all in it, just like so many fish." Thus spoke one of the neighbors after big Cap'n John Bennington breezed back to his little New England port.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 30 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur, who has said that the range of his bombers constituted the Allies' margin of safety in the Southwest Pacific, extended that margin yesterday by sending Liberators more than 1,000 miles from Australia during attacks on enemy shipping and air bases.

LONDON, May 29 (U.P.) -- While Britain's biggest bombers were grounded Friday night after their week of raids on Dortmund, Duesseldorf and Essen in the Ruhr, a force of Albacore torpedo planes of the Fleet Air Arm destroyed or damaged nine of twelve German R-boats in an engagement off the Cherbourg peninsula.

CHUNGKING, China, Sunday, May 30 -- Emergency legal arrangements were completed early today for Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek automatically to become acting President of the Chinese Republic if President Lin Sen, who is gravely ill, should become "incapacitated."
HILARY ALDEN ST. GEORGE SAUNDERS has a manner of almost chirping good cheer, and is an exceptionally serious and competent man He is now the world's best-selling living author.

The pitcher plant and Venus' flytrap are about the only carnivorous plants known to the well-read. This department learns from Dr. F.E. Lloyd's "Carnivorous Plants" now issued by the Chronica Botanica Company, Waltham, Mass., that there are about 450 species of such plants.

Suspension proceedings against eighteen pork retailers in Harlem have been initiated by the District Office of Price Administration, it was announced yesterday by Edward L. Coffey, chief attorney, who explained that the storekeepers were accused of charging more than ceiling prices for bacon.

DURING the last thirty years in the United States, soybeans have risen from a non-recognizable bean to a crop of about 150,000,000 bushels per annum in 1942 -- second only to the gigantic production in China (217,000,000 bushels).

The Trade Agreements Act, commonly referred to as the reciprocal trade treaties, will expire by limitation next month unless it is renewed by Congress. At the present time the House has agreed to an extension of the act for two years as against the previous extensions of three years, but in the Senate it appears that amendments may be adopted which will completely destroy the effectiveness of the act.

Floods, thunderbolts and earthquakes used to be "acts of God." Now man is producing them, sending deluges to devastate populous valleys, blasting cities to rubble, causing such temblors in the earth's crust that anti-aircraft batteries are thrown off their positions.

PHILADELPHIA, May 29 -- The scoreboard of U-boat destruction within the last four weeks has shown that the Atlantic menace will be eliminated within four to six months, James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, declared today at the christening of six potential subkillers, known officially as destroyer escorts, at the Navy Yard here.

Now that the so-called Decentralization Plan is at last established and apparently functioning as intended, there is a strong possibility that its effect will be to nullify much of the recent improvement in the shipping situation and that vessels may soon be leaving for Latin-American ports underloaded because of the lack of available cargoes, foreign traders asserted yesterday.

It was usually called Decoration Day, out in the Midwest, with the simple directness of country speech. It was hot with the breath of approaching Summer, the first touch of "corn weather," and it was fragrant with late lilacs and early roses. Small yellow roses, and simple pink ones, which bloomed in generous sprays along the picket fences, and huge lilac clusters from the untrimmed bushes in the dooryards.

OF all the "inside" pictures that have come along recently -- and by "inside" pictures we mean those that imagine the way things are in Nazi-occupied countries -- the most respectable, intellectually, has been Jean Renoir's and Dudley Nichols' current "This Land Is Mine."

AT A CAPTURED JAPANESE OUTPOST, Attu, May 17 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese left perfumed soap, small hand grenades, patent medicines, a freshly caught string of eight cod, red and white surveying flags, saki, cigarettes and a little portable steam bath at this five-building outpost.

IN this interesting and well-told story of vigorous Amercans and life in out-of-the-way places, Hugh Kent of the United States Forest Service is the hero. His wife also, through whose words the narrative is unfolded, holds much of the reader's interest, and her variegated experiences often call to mind both text and title of "No Life for a Lady."

Any occupation of Martinique by the American nations would be "nothing more than an abuse of force," and each inhabitant of the French Antilles "is ready to shed his blood to show his love of France and of liberty," Admiral Georges Robert, Vichy-appointed Commissioner, said in a letter to The United Press received yesterday.

ON several occasions I have advocated a middle-of-the-road approach to peace by Americans, and defined generally its implications. Critics have apparently found it difficult to quarrel with this approach, except to counter that recent events show the average American is keener on the parliament of man and federation of the world and readier to go into them than some tough-minded observers admit.
The first Boys Club to be operated by the Salvation Army in New York was officially opened yesterday afternoon at Gates and Bushwick Avenues, Brooklyn, in an edifice where Nazi bundists formerly met.

LONDON, Sunday, May 30 (AP) -- The German radio announced early today that a Soviet battering ram had forced the German Kuban troops to "adopt a particularly elastic warfare" -- the term used during last Winter's Axis retreat in Russia.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 29 (AP) -- A communique:
THIS is the story of an American soldier. He was killed in Tunisia this month as the tide of victory rolled forward. Of all the deaths we mourn today his is one of the most recent.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 29 -- Raising farm income is one aim of the United Nations conference on food and agriculture, according to a radio address tonight by Paul H. Appleby, Under Secretary of Agriculture and vice chairman of the United States delegation.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 29 -- Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, told the 251 members of the graduating class at the university's 197th commencement this morning that the universal desire for peace through the reign of law must be incorporated in an international political organization if peace were to prevail.

LONDON, Sunday, May 30 -- The largest force of heavy bombers yet employed by the United States Eighth Air Force made a three-way attack on targets in France late yesterday afternoon, United States Headquarters and the British Air Ministry announced early today.

THE conquistadores were past their first youth when they planted the Spanish King's flag in California: the dream of El Dorado had tarnished considerably, when Mr. Shaftel opens his colorful and always interesting novel.

METHODS of responding to opening bids have changed considerably since, in 1930, the principle of "keeping the bidding open light" was generally adopted. There has been discernible change even since 1935, when what may be called modern bidding practices came into vogue.

LONDON, May 29 -- Declaring that Allied teamwork in North Africa was based on "indestructible devotion to a common cause," General Dwight D. Eisenhower said tonight that he and the American, British and French Armies under his command were now "ready to undertake any further task our countries may choose to assign us."

Something new has been added to European warfare. Greek sailors, following the tactics of their compatriots on land, have seized a fleet of small Axis vessels and harass enemy shipping in the Aegean Sea with a flotilla of some 20 to 30 ships which the Germans and Italians had previously captured from the Greeks.

Expenditures by the Federal Government now are at the rate of about $100,000,000,000 annually, with consequent rises in employment, in money in circulation and in bank deposits. Only about one-third of these expenditures is being financed through taxation.

The complement of the Brooklyn Naval Receiving Station, Flushing and Vanderbilt Avenues, assembled yesterday morning to listen to their commander, Captain R.W. Wuest, read individual citations granted to twin brothers, Rolla J. and John R. Cordell, 29-year-old first-class machinist mates, for their heroic conduct during the battle of the Coral Sea as members of the U.S.S. Lexington.

According to a reporter, listening to a broadcast by Mr. Churchill, the latter has "no public school accent." This is correct in a sense, though Mr. Churchill went to Harrow. His pronunciation is substantially that of the educated classes; of the public schools, of the universities at none of which he was a student; of the law courts and Parliament.

The Propeller Club of the Port of New York, at its annual meeting last week in the Downtown Athletic Club, voted unanimously to invite its parent body, the Propeller Club of the United States, to hold its 1943 convention in New York.

TRADITION is in bad repute today in certain quarters. There is an obvious distrust of "tradition" on the part of those who feel that the times move, that novelty is the watchword, that we must cut loose from "old hat."

THIS is a handbook that any one wishing to get beyond the obvious poetry, drama and controversy of TVA will want to read. The author is assistant professor of political science at the University of Chicago.

The finance section of the Greater New York Fund's current campaign has raised $670,031, or 70 per cent of its $966,996 goal, it was reported yesterday by Pierpont V. Davis, chairman. Daniel A. Freeman Jr. is associate chairman of the section.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, the little island off Cape Cod, is beginning to gather in its Summer "regulars" and make ready for newcomers who annually seek out the spot colonizers found "so fair" 300 years ago.

EXCEPT for the food lines where all is confusion and complaint, retail trade is going ahead in orderly and mounting volume. Shortages grow more numerous, but shifts are possible, and the trend toward higher priced merchandise more than makes up for sales lost through scarcities.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Office of Price Administration announced tonight that its subsidy on butter would go into effect Tuesday at the rate of 5 cents a pound.

IF a poll were to be held to determine which vegetables have made the biggest gain in popularity in the last decade, Zucchini squash would undoubtedly be near the top of the list. Home gardeners have discovered that this tender, palatable, easy to grow vegetable well repays those who give it a try.

CABRIDGE, Mass., May 29 -- Sometimes we must wait twenty years to observe a stellar eclipse to learn the secrets of stars like VV Cephei, which appears as a single sixth magnitude star just visible to the naked eye, but is really a double star whose main body is a red giant thought to exceed in size any other known star.

BOSTON, May 29 -- Coming with a rush through the final quarter mile, Mrs. Hazel M. Babylon's Abbe Pierre scored by a length today at Suffolk Downs before 20,000 racegoers in the $5,000 added Puritan Handicap of a mile and a furlong.

AMERICANS are amateurs at war; but this may be an advantage. The weakness of the career soldier, bred in the military tradition and trained in his duties through years of service, is that he knows when he is whipped. He is a professional, wiser than the amateur and with the professional's mental attitude.

It is somewhat surprising to find Emil Ludwig, in THE TIMES of May 11, suggesting that "the only way to safeguard the world against new German aggressions consists not merely in disarmament but in a guardianship.

IN the heart of Manhattan are the offices of the fastest-growing business in the nation. It has more than a million customers, but no cash register. It deals in dozens of commodities, yet has no stock, or even shelves. Its employes are mostly volunteers, yet they take considerably more abuse than the paid salesgirls of department stores.

SHE has chestnut hair and big gray eyes and she's just learning to walk. On the sunny roof of the children's shelter the other day she braced herself against the play pen, started out gamely and then tumbled.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The pay-as-you-go tax conferees filed their report today and there was every indication that the compromise would be accepted by the House on Tuesday and possibly by the Senate the same day.

Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind yesterday denied a claim for $1,050,000 by the United States Government as assignee of the Russian Government growing out of an alleged breach of contract by the Curtiss Airplane Company and others in connection with the sale of airplanes to the Imperial Russian Government in 1915.

Since the defeat of the Senate's pay-as-you-go tax bill, the Conference Committee of the Senate and the House has made an intensive joint effort to reach a compromise basis which will be deemed acceptable to the Administration.

CHICAGO, May 29 -- Prices of rye soared today as much as 2 7/8 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade, reaching the highest level since 1937, on buying induced by reports that a government loan of 75 cents a bushel on the 1943 crop would be announced over the weekend.

A GOOD many perfectly levelheaded and fair-minded people are disgusted with certain practices of our great radio industry. They think that it is being ruined by the amount and quality of the advertising it dispenses to the millions of helpless listeners, and that commercialism is running riot in this field.

THE highlight of this week's activities in the bistro belt is the formal reopening of the Monte Carlo Beach. Under the direction of Dick Flanagan the Summer spot opens its doors next Tuesday evening with an intimate type of entertainment featuring Mary Howard, stage and screen actress.

A FEW days ago Mrs. Nadine Bandler -- native Texan, New Yorker by adoption -- was awaiting her dinner in a Park Avenue restaurant. Service was slow. The manager apologized -- it was due, he said, to the scarcity of trained help.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Hope for a "break" by Monday in the negotiations for a new agreement to replace the present contract covering 450,000 bituminous miners in the Appalachian fields was expressed here today by government sources following an abortive conference of spokesmen for the operators and the United Mine Workers.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Warrenton Community League has made plans for two canning projects this season, one for the benefit of the school lunch room, the other open to the public. In the first, members of the league put up food for the lunch room, using the Red Cross Canteen kitchen lent them for the purpose, and Thomas Leiter gives the produce of his garden.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 29 -- One week after British tanks rumbled into Tunis a special emergency supply of approximately 7,500 tons of food, clothing and medical supplies had been delivered to the people of Tunisia, the North African Economic Board announced yesterday.

Thousands of gallons of skimmed and whole milk are being dumped by receiving plants throughout New York State, it was learned yesterday. The annual "milk flush," starting last Thursday, has overloaded virtually all receiving plants Manufacturing facilities are described as "loaded up to the hilt."
MEXICO CITY, May 29 -- President Manuel Avila Camacho declared in a speech broadcast to the nation late last night that if necessary Mexico was ready to send troops to fight overseas.

An end to "misleading" estimates of retailer mortality which ignore favorable factors in the distribution picture and serve to bolster unjustified demands for further controls on business was urged in retail circles here last week.

LONDON, May 29 (U.P.) -- Netherland judges, aroused by brutalities in German prison camps, in one of which 280 persons died within five months, have threatened a criminal courts "strike," it was reported tonight as German occupation authorities battled new guerrilla outbreaks, sabotage and passive resistance throughout Europe.

ANOTHER artist who loved and served France has been recalled from the shades, through his paintings, to serve France again. This time it is Jean-Louis Forain, who is represented by some twenty canvases from public and private collections, in the current exhibition at the headquarters of the Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, 457 Madison Avenue.

Some biologists think that the human species is doomed because of the overspecialization of the brain. Dr. Alfred J. Lotka, an internationally known authority on population, holds that the human species is sick in the sense that any species is sick when "it is afflicted with an assortment of propensities that impede it in the struggle for survival."

BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 14 (Delayed) -- As Arab leaders discuss the proposal emanating from various Moslem countries for the eventual establishment -- they hope -- of some sort of federative State embracing the Arab world, they are puzzled not only about resolving their differences with Zionism in Palestine but also about the future of the Levantine States originally mandated to France and including Syria, the keystone of the proposed Arab arch.

THE Philadelphia Orchestra, which has probably made more recordings than any other symphonic ensemble in the country and perhaps in the world, has shifted its allegiance from Victor to Columbia. It has signed a long-term contract with the latter company and will make recordings, under its conductor, Eugene Ormandy, for Columbia as soon as the ban on new records is lifted by the Musicians Union.

A TINY girl in New York was turned down by the Women's Army Corps because she fell short of the required height. With womanly persistence, she dashed to a chiropractor to get stretched out. Even then she couldn't quit make the inch.

ALCOHOL SCHOOL -- Where is to be a six-week Summer session at a School of Alcohol Studies in Yale University, the first formal school of its kind in the academic history of the United States. "The prevention of alcoholism and its ill effects are hampered by the lack of community leaders who have a broad scientific understanding of the problem of alcohol," the school prospectus states.
BOSTON, May 29 (AP) -- The Tigers won the opening game of their series with the Red Sox, 6 to 4, today, making five runs in the first three innings off Yank Terry.

Slide Rule and Some Chance won the two stake races at Belmont Park yesterday before 26,041 persons who wagered $2,106,022, marking the fourth day in New York this season that more than $2,000,000 passed through the totalizator.

City College will enroll an entering class in June instead of the Fall for the first time in its history, it was announced yesterday by Robert L. Taylor, registrar. Freshmen who would have ordinarily started their studies in October will be allowed to begin with the twelve-week Summer term, from June 28 to Sept. 17.

The surest methods of curing neurosis ("nervousness" in the extreme form) are those in which the patient participates in his own recovery. So holds Dr. Jules H. Masserman of the University of Chicago, on the basis of research conducted with artificially induced neurosis in cats.

Mayor La Guardia declared yesterday that he had received thou sands of protests.agnln-t the action of the City Council on May 21 in cutting $10,864,905 from his executive budget of $753,071,123 as approved by the Board of Esti-. mate. The Mayor, in letters to war veterans' organizations in all of the city's boroughs, hinted strongly that he would exercise his veto power.

Six rulings or reminders of rulings are contained in a circular issued yesterday by the department of member firms of the New York Stock Exchange. They cover margin requirements on securities selling below 5, margin on reorganization rail arbitrage, special offerings, minimum commission charges and confidential reports to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

ALBANY, May 29 -- Two appointments to the New York State Bridge Authority were announced today by Governor Dewey, who named Dr. John A. Edwards of Hudson, president of the First National Bank of that city, to succeed the late Raymond D. Kennedy of Hudson, and reappointed Robert Hoe, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of Poughkeepsie.
LONDON, May 29 -- Now at last, after more than six months of hard bargaining, the prospects of agreement and cooperation between General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud are bright.

CONSTANCE JORDAN HENLEY is authentically a grandmother; nearing, as she admits without flinching, her sixtieth birthday. Her age and status are thus frankly stated for a very good reason -- to convince the world that motor travel over the new Pan-American Highway is feasible and rewarding.
GENERAL LANDRUM'S HEADQUARTERS, Massacre Pass, Attu, May 18 (Delayed) (AP) -- "The Japanese force will be given no time to recoup. Continued pressure will be exerted to capture or destroy him."

THE Diocese of Hippo in North Africa, over which St. Augustine presided as the most illustrious Bishop of a remote antiquity, is today the scene of a victory won by the civilization in which he believed over the forces of paganism that, in his day as in our own, raged over the Mediterranean and humbled the city of Rome herself.

The resignation of Mark Anton as East Coast chief of the fuel section of the Petroleum Administration for War was announced yesterday by H.W. Dodge, district director of the PAW. Mr. Anton, a resident of West Orange, N.J., has been with PAW since last June, having served in Washington and Chicago before coming to the district office in this city.

WAYNESVILLE, N.C. -- The thrill of that first green carrot top in the Victory garden this season is giving a definite impetus toward farm vacationing. North Carolina guest farms and ranches report that they are expecting visitors to the extent of their capacity.

CHICAGO, May 29 (AP) -- An official of the American Butter Institute asserted tonight that virtually the entire American butter industry had liquidated its holdings to the government at pre-rollback prices and that for the next three weeks "butter supplies for the civilian consumer will be practically non-existent."

Five producers of steel have the responsibility of providing 75 per cent of the War Production Board's steel expansion program, according to figures given last week to members of the American Iron and Steel Institute by J.A. Kinney, assistant to the vice president of the Bethlehem Steel Company.

HOLLYWOOD, at present feverishly engaged in preparing musical and other so-called escapist entertainment for the country's screens, nevertheless is generally in accord with Harry M. Warner's defense of intelligently produced war pictures.

AFTER the fanfare and glitter of the Ballet Theatre's recent tenantry of the Metropolitan Opera House, the modest and unpretentious "season of favorite ballets" by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre seems pleasant and restful and definitely homey.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., May 29 -- The Naval Academy lacrosse team defeated the West Point cadets, 12 to 5, today and became a contender with the University of Maryland for the national title.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, May 30 (AP) -- The noon communique:

LONDON, May 29 -- The first act in the Allied offensive against Adolf Hitler's Fortress Europe was concluded with the capitulation of the Axis forces in Tunisia. This is an intermission before the next act of the grim drama that is being unfolded, and the scene shifters are busy behind a curtain of secrecy to insure the suspense and surprise that are so essential to success.

There will be tennis, despite gasoline restrictions. According to Holcomb Ward, United States Lawn Tennis Association president, the sport will be boosted especially among the younger groups, in grade and high schools.

A simulated enemy raid on the city from the skies will be staged in Madison Square Garden on the night of Thursday, June 10, in which a combination of live participants, motion pictures and sound effects will be used to demonstrate with graphic realism the work of civilian defense volunteer workers under air raid.

CHUNGKING, May 29 -- "If the Japanese take Chungking they have no one but themselves to blame," an American soldier sardonically remarked one morning after contemplating the wretched climate and the barren, wartime life of Free China's capital. But the offhand gibe of the Yankee doughboy hardly conveys the mood of this anxious city.

LONDON, May 29 -- London newspapers speculated today on the prospects of a European invasion, with one saying that "the greatest naval operation in history is imminent," while the Rome radio declared, "Now the enemy has chosen Pantelleria, Sicily and Sardinia as his objectives."

INSTITUTE, W. Va., May 29 -- Evidence of the country's ability to become self-contained so far as its rubber requirements are concerned was unveiled to newspaper men here this week on a conducted tour of the largest integrated synthetic rubber plant to come into production.

ALGIERS, May 29 (AP) -- General Henri Honore Giraud placed his own Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor on General Dwight D. Eisenhower today. The American Commander in Chief of the Allied forces declared that he would emulate the French leader's example in wearing no decoration until France had been liberated.
OTTAWA, May 29 -- The Provinces of Ontario and Quebec are heading toward elections, although war and internal conditions combine to make the date still uncertain.

STOCKHOLM, May 29 -- One afternoon in the latter part of November, 1941, just a few weeks before Reichsfuehrer Adolf Hitler declared war on the United States, I visited the Luftwaffe training school at Plane on the River Havel in Brandenburg Province.

I HAVE just a returned from a tour under the auspices of the USO Camp Shows. Our small concert group consisted of two violinists, 'cello and saxophone, Spanish dancer, pianist and myself, the vocalist. In twenty-seven weeks we traveled 21,000 miles, from the Atlantic to the Pacific and back, and gave 240 concerts in 154 camps.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- One hundred and three additional colleges and universities have been selected to participate in the Army Specialized Training Program, bringing the total number in the project to 145, the War Department said today.

THE graveyard shift in an airplane plant makes the background of Glendon Swarthout's novel, "Willow Run." Against it he builds the incidents of conflict and violence which end with the night's work. When the morning signal sounds for quitting, a bomber has been built, mad several lives have been distorted or destroyed.

Captain John L. Beebe, U.S.N.R., ship master in the transatlantic and other trades, took up yesterday the duties of Superintendent of the United States Maritime Service Training Station at Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Captain Beebe, formerly superintendent of the U.S.M.S. training station at Avalon, Calif., succeeds Captain George Wauchope, recently ordered to sea duty, at the Sheepshead Bay post.

A GRAY-HAIRED woman with a worried expression stood silently studying the nose of the giant B-26 Martin Marauder bomber on display in the Ordnance Department War Exhibit in the Chrysler Building. She bit her lip and clenched her fists tensely.

For eighteen months America has been pouring men and munitions toward the battlefronts in ever-increasing quantities The strain on the home front, where all this strength must originate, has grown heavier every day. Sharp disputes between executives in charge of vital war production programs have been frequent.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senators turned back the White Sox, 7 to 4, tonight to regain undisputed possession of the American League leadership.

AN ordinary serving of muskmelon supplies 40 per cent of the daily requirement of Vitamin A and of Vitamin C, according to nutritionists, so that for growing this delicacy there is good argument aside from delectable flavor and cooling juiciness.

THREE years ago the five-volume "Dictionary of American History," designed to make readily available the facts and trends of the nation's past, came from the press in brave blue binding. It filled a definite and obvious need.
ALGIERS, May 29 (U.P.) -- General Henri Honore Giraud removed all Vichy-imposed restrictions on North African newspapers today.
In celebration of 100 years in the book-publishing business, the Macmillan Company of 60 Fifth Avenue will conduct its first general prize contest, "An Opportunity for Those in the Armed Forces."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- James F. Byrnes took the oath today as Director of the Office of War Mobilization and prepared to move energetically in carrying out his new duties as over-all director of the home front in the war. He is to make a speech at his home town of Spartanburg, S.C., Monday night, and an outline of his plans is expected.

The athletes of Mount St. Michael made their superiority felt with emphasis yesterday by taking both ends of the annual C.H.S. A.A. Bronx-Manhattan-Westchester track and field championship meet at Van Cortlandt Park Stadium.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 29 -- Long Island Sound's Summer racing season was opened today with a special regatta of the Echo Bay Yacht Club. The leading craft were Joseph L. Merrill's International sloop Feather, handled for the first time by Sherman Hoyt, and Charles Vanderlaan's Atlantic Class boat Minkie II.

THE seasonal sun-madness (which never fails to produce its annual crop of anguished itchings, of lobster-red complexions and of evil dispositions) is upon us once more. Summer has come upon us suddenly and every one is apparently determined to acquire a tan in one hectic week-end.

SENATOR BARKLEY and Representative McCormack introduced the Lend-Lease Bill in the two houses of Congress and the front pages of the following day's newspapers were curdled with the sour dissents of Herbert Hoover, Alfred M. Landon and Thomas E. Dewey.

OUTDOOR sports, in this year of global warfare, are showing a distinct tendency to run to the practical. Next in popularity to the newly rediscovered art of vegetable gardening is the art of -- yes -- chicken-raising.

Irony could not go much further than in the note of congratulation which Emperor Hirohito sent last week to President Castillo on the occasion of the 133d anniversary of Argentina's independence. The government of Argentina is the only one in this hemisphere, except, possibly, that of Admiral Robert in Martinique, which Hirohito would wish to felicitate or which would wish to be felicitated by him.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 29 -- Almost 100 Flying Fortresses, making their longest flight since they were based in North Africa, blasted the important port and oil-refining center of Leghorn [Livorno], 200 miles north of Rome, yesterday.
The Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor reports that there were 7.5 per cent more delinquent boys in 1942 than in 1941 and 31 per cent more delinquent girls.

MOSCOW, May 29 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's statement on the dissolution of the Comintern, contained in a letter delivered this morning to Harold King, Reuter correspondent in Moscow, puts an end once and for all to several conjectures by Axis propagandists.

EARLY in the war it was said that the alcoholic content of the war correspondents' books was pretty high. The boys had a tendency, it was charged, to write a great deal about their highjinks in the Adlon and Savoy Hotel bars, partly because this was the pattern established by another generation of war correspondents in the last war and partly because a little whisky is a comforting thing when the buildings begin to shake.

A BREATHLESS courier, who must have negotiated at top speed the seventy-five odd yards which separate this office from the Paramount Building in Times Square, bounded into this department the other day with the announcement that "For Whom the Bell Tolls" had been completed and all that remained now was the processing of the Technicolor prints.

MR. HARLOW has done a homely book on Bret Harte. It has some of the peculiar literary flavor of a Horatio Alger story except that the ending is not happy. Quite in the Alger vein is an early chapter in which Francis Bret Harte runs away from home -- the family lived in Abingdon Square in Greenwich Village then -- at the age of 6, to make his way in the world.

In Washington, last week was a week of long-range planning. In England it was a week of long-range bombing, aimed at the industrial heart of Germany and carried out on an unprecedented scale. In North Africa it was a week of chipping and blasting at the southern wall of Hitler's fortress.

NOT the least odd of the radio's phenomena, it may have occurred to you, is the seeming casualness with which a daytime serial is launched, although history has proved that it is apt to be a momentous event indeed. Whereas a play, a book or a film is publicized long before its appearance, with many a deft touch designed to woo the expectancy of the public, a serial sneaks up on you, so to speak.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- Representative Clare Booth Luce of Connecticut said tonight that Washington observers were "more hopeful than enthusiastic" about the new Office of War Mobilization created by the President.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, May 29 -- With "More Rubber for Victory" as their slogan, all Brazilians will swing into step during June to collect the rubber vitally needed to win the war. President Getulio Vargas has decreed June as "the rubber month."

THE Men's Garden Club of New York meets on Thursday at 12:15 P.M. in the Hotel Lexington. Following luncheon, Allen K. White will show motion pictures in color depicting the complete life cycle of growing plants.
"THE JUNGLES OF DUTCH GULANA," by Nicol Smith, originally called "Bush Master," has been made available for the first time at a popular price ($1, Garden City Publishing Company).

The Italian-American Labor Council, representing 300,000 Italian-American workers adopted a resolution yesterday warning the United Nations against making a deal with any "diluted or perfumed monarchist-Fascist set-up" in Italy.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- While the mopping-up operations on Attu have lasted longer by a few days than some observers had first thought likely, it appeared that the conquest of the island might be over within three weeks of its beginning. Next Tuesday will mark the opening of the fourth week.

THE patriotic gardener who is growing food by the sweat of his face, makes the most of every foot of arable land. Yet even he cannot live by bread alone. Near his vegetables he must be encouraged by the gleam and color of the flowers that he loves. Well may he give the preference in his Victory Garden to the sword lily of the ancients which we call gladiolus or "little sword."

While the city's entire police force and an augmented staff of Office of Price Administration inspectors hunted yesterday for pleasure drivers -- who were few and far between -- the Office of War Information reported that the farm gasoline crisis on Long Island and up-State had passed.
THERE is in this rhythmic tale of two Kerry Blue terriers a fine feeling of experience gauged just right for the age which considers a walk down the street to be the height of adventure.

DETROIT, May 29 -- An outline for world peace, based on the principles of Christianity and embodying moral standards separate from economic and political considerations, was adopted here today by the 155th General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America.

Columbia University's 189th commencement program, its first "full-dress" wartime one, which will culminate Tuesday evening with the conferring of 3,867 degrees in course and seventy certificates, will open today at 4 P.M. when prospective graduates from seven colleges and schools march to the annual Baccalaureate Service at St. Paul's Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 117th Street.

THE authority of experience and a brisk style of writing are found in this manual by the Education Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES. Mr. Fine's book is explicit and practical in its aid to publicity directors and writers for schools, colleges and other educational organizations.

. memorial service for 'Inomas Moore, the Irish poet, was held yesterday afternoon, on the 164th anniversary of his birth, at the Moore Monument near the East Fifty-ninth Street entrance to Central Park. The program included the singing of several of Moore's melodies and a talk on the life of the poet by Professor James O'Brien of the Romance Language Department at Fordham University.

HOLTZ BAY BATTLEGROUND, Attu, May 19 (Delayed) -- Two hundred and ten men, without food for three days, most of them with frozen feet, attacked the Japanese at Holtz Bay, withstood vicious counter-attacks and finally helped dislodge them from dug-in entrenchments.

IN every election democracy runs for office, and here, at the moment of dissolution and renewal, the strains and strength of a democratic order are felt most sharply. "They Also Ran," the story of the men who were defeated for the Presidency, is based on a quite brilliant idea, and is often brilliantly executed.
To aid in the selection of qualified men for the specialized training program, the Army has established twenty-two colleges and universities which will serve as screening centers for all candidates.

Adrian Gips, chairman of the Netherland Shipping Committee, revealed yesterday that the training center at 65 Pondfield Road, Bronxville, now has twenty-five men studying for various licenses to qualify them for promotion under the requirements of Netherlands maritime law.

As an American student at McGill University, I have had ample opportunity, for the past two years, to observe the effects of American films on a "foreign" audience. In this case Canada, our nearest neighbor, may be called foreign because it is politically distinct from the United States, though not economically or culturally so.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 29 -- Official Rome is "indignant" over the refusal of the British to listen to "the humanitarian pleas of the the Spanish press in favor of Italian civilian populations, which today are suffering more heavily from aerial bombardment than the armed forces themselves."

On buying support of a speculative nature furnished chiefly by New Orleans operators, the cotton futures market extended its gains moderately yesterday in fairly active pre-holiday trading. Net gains of 2 to 5 points were posted at the close for the six active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.

Current discussion emphasizes the fact that in any real post-war settlement the problem arising from the position of the small nations will be one of utmost difficulty. Self-determination and equality of the states are phrases which require elucidation and definition.

THE past week's arrivals of new stamps include two series issued in January and February by the U.S.S.R. "in connection with the splendid victories of our glorious Red Army on the fronts of the Great Patriotic War."

RICHMOND, Va., May 29 -- The House has passed the bill repealing the poll tax as a prerequisite to voting in Federal elections, and much of the South doesn't like the measure. Yet many Southerners who object to this form of Federal intervention in what they regard as the affairs of the States do not wish their Senators to filibuster against the bill in the middle of a war for survival, when every day counts.

Japan's blueprint for expansion was made clear after Pearl Harbor. It called first for the conquest of East Asia, source of vital raw materials and home of half the human race. The task was to be accomplished while America and Britain were busy in Europe. After Asia was consolidated Dai Nippon would be invincible and could press on to other adventures, perhaps to world domination.

ATLANTA, May 29 -- Joseph P. Kennedy, former Ambassador to the Court of St. James, was the recipient tonight of the President's Medal bestowed by Oglethorpe University immediately after he had delivered an address to graduates and guests.

Aware of an approaching food shortage, members of the agricultural faculty of Southern University (La.) are giving their spare time in aiding farmers of this and adjacent parishes to increase their food crops through growing gardens, producing chickens, hogs, and milk and butter from cows.
Mrs. Benjamin R.B. Townsend will come today to the Plaza from Sewickley, Pa.

Only two new films are slated to open on Broadway this week. These are "Bataan," a Metro picturization of the American stand in the Philippines, with Robert Taylor, George Murphy, Thomas Mitchell, Lloyd Nolan, Lee Bowman, Robert Walker and Desi Arnaz in the lead roles, Thursday at the Capitol; "He Hired the Boss," a comedy starring Stuart Erwin, Thursday at the Palace along with the second-run "Forever and a Day."
PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (U.P.) -- The 1943 "dream game" appropriately will be a night contest.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 30 -- Princeton University this morning honored its 6,000 alumni and undergraduates in the armed forces and paid tribute to the forty-eight Princeton men who have died in service.

DETROIT, May 30 -- The Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin of New York, newly elected Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, called upon his followers today to end racial discrimination and promote inter-denominational unity.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 -- Steel output for the country was unchanged last week at 99 per cent of rated capacity. Since holidays like Memorial Day never have been recognized in the primary steel departments, steel-ingot production this week probably will equal or exceed last week's.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -- The facility with which the German High Command is camouflaging its preparations for a Summer offensive on the Eastern Front is responsible for a crop of rumors that obscures reasonable conjectures.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 (AP) -- With a rookie, Don Black, pitching a one-hitter in the opener and Jess Flores chalking up his seventh consecutive victory in the second game, the Athletics swept a double-header with the Browns, 3 to 0 and 4 to 1, before 21,254 at Shibe Park today. Philadelphia thus advanced from fifth place to third in the American League standing.
ALGIERS, May 30 (AP) -- From Bizerte to Casablanca, near battlefields where American soldiers died in the cause of Allied victory, their graves were decorated today by comrades in arms.

Mr. Ringrose says in his letter which you published on May 18 that he expects soon to hear much public discussion of what is treasonable. This seems implicit with the suggestion that the conduct of some has become treasonable or close to it.

CINCINNATI, May 30 -- Mild Will McKechnie, the deacon of Wilkinsburg, Pa., must be about ready to vote for abolition of Sunday baseball.
