The Dodgers walloped his Reds twice today, 6 -- 0 and 10 -- 6, and that marked the fifth twin bill and a total of eleven Sunday games Cincinnati has lost this year without winning one.

ALGIERS, May 30 -- General Charles de Gaulle landed at a tiny makeshift airfield in Algeria at noon today to take his place with General Henri Honore Giraud at the head of the executive committee that will govern Frenchmen outside the motherland until victory has been won. Tonight General de Gaulle announced that the committee would hold its first meeting at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 30 -- One-third of the government's rubber program has been completed, one-half of the aviation gasoline plants to meet expected eventual needs are in operation and the naval escort ship program is proceeding at a high rate.

Some unions are seeking to promote the notion that the wages of industrial workers have failed to keep abreast of living costs. They have demanded that living costs be rolled back to the levels of May, 1942. These have risen, according to the calculations of the National Industrial Conference Board, 5.7 per cent from that month to March of this year.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Office of Defense Transportation outlined today a priority system under which the more essential truck, bus and taxicab services would receive preferred treatment in allotment of gasoline in the Eastern shortage area.

The annual appeal for funds by the Brooklyn Catholic Charities was opened yesterday at a meeting attended by the clergy, laity and members of the special gifts committee at St. Gregory's auditorium, Brooklyn Avenue and St. John's Place.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The White Sox knocked Washington out of the American League lead and into second place with a double victory over the Senators, 5 -- 2 and 5 -- 1, before 22,000 fans today.

To usher in its final week at the Broadway Theatre, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo decided to revive "Les Sylphides" yesterday afternoon. With Mia Slavenska, Milada Mladova, Anna Istomina and Igor Youskevitch in the solo roles, it succeeded in presenting a very good performance, though one which lacked the requisite magic to make it an outstanding one.

The annual report of the New York Community Trust, custodian of sixty trust funds, shows total resources of $10,036,486 at the close of 1942. Appropriations made last year amounted to $547,261, comparing with $398,504 in 1941. The trust has paid out more than $3,500,000 since 1925, it announces.

The chief Memorial Day observance here today will be the parade of 26,000 persons up Riverside Drive from Seventy-second to Ninety-fifth Street. The parade will begin at 9 A. M. Grand Marshal George W. Collier, 99-year-old Grand Army of the Republic member, will be the only Civil War veteran in line.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 30 -- A torpedo boat battle with Japanese destroyers at night was described yesterday by a naval officer recuperating here from injures suffered when his PT boat was destroyed Feb. 2 in the Guadalcanal area.

LONDON, May 30 -- Sufficient time has elapsed since publication of the Keynes post-war currency plan here and the White plan in Washington for the City to have formed fairly definite opinions concerning their respective merits. Both plans, it is generally agreed, must be looked at together because they form the basis, but only the basis, of post-war international policy.

A steady volume of price-fixing orders by the trade sustained the cotton futures market at slight gains last week, despite continuing liquidation and hedge selling. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts registered net gains of 11 to 15 points for the week, following increases of 8 to 35 points in the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- A general slash in civilian beef rations appeared imminent today as the Office of Price Administration prepared its monthly revision of red stamp point values.
A Japanese communique, as broadcast from Tokyo Sunday:

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Seldom has such a shortage of cash corn prevailed at leading markets as at present. Unfavorable weather and a consequent delay in planting, plus farmers' resistance to ceiling prices, have resulted in an unusually small movement from the country.
" Delinquent" parents were scored yesterday by Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The only opening of the week will take place tonight at the Blackfriars' Guild, 320 West Fifty-seventh Street, when that semiprofessional organization presents "Moment Musical," a new play by Charles Angoff. Directed by Dennis Gurney, the cast includes Joan Croydon, Dayton Lummis, Catherine Bradford, ack Woods, Eileen Heckert and Gene Lyons.

LONDON, Monday, May 31 -- More than 1,500 tons of screaming steel were dropped Saturday night by the Royal Air Force on Wuppertal, another key point in Adolf Hitler's Ruhr arsenal, in what was described as one of the heaviest bombing attacks ever made.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, May 30 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur has made another visit to troops in the field.

Calling for a new order based on international humanism and the cooperative spirit of science, Sir Richard Gregory, president of the British Association for the Advancement of Science, pictured yesterday a world in which applied science will make all mankind, regardless of the natural resources within any one nation's geographical boundaries, self-sufficient.
CHICAGO, May 30 (AP) -- The Cubs defeated the Braves by 5 to 1 today before weather caused postponement of the second game of a double-header with the Cubs leading, 4 to 3, after three innings.

Baseball's largest crowd of the year flocked to the Stadium yesterday to see the Yankees scalp the Indians in a double-header and vault to the American League lead, a game and a half ahead of the second-place Senators.

A PACIFIC BASE, April 30 -- When the 164th Infantry sailed for Guadalcanal from New Caledonia on Oct. 9 it left back in the hills, on a training mission, a newly formed reconnaissance platoon, which was to follow on a later ship and carry through one of the outstanding patrol assignments given any Army unit on Guadalcanal -- a complete reconnaissance of the Cape Esperance area to learn the enemy strength there.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- There is so much uncertainty in regard to possible developments in wheat that market interest in this grain has fallen off materially. Sales of futures on the Board of Trade last month were estimated at about 100,000,000 bushels, or 40,000,000 less than the trade in rye and 63,000,000 less than in the trade in wheat in May, 1942.

Tomorrow begins the month of June, which promises to become a fateful month for a world at war. For it now appears inevitable that this month will see the beginning of the Allied offensive for which we have been preparing so long. The goal of this offensive is an attack on the strongholds of Axis power in the fortress of Europe.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Better weather prevailed last week in the Central West and a continuation of dry weather is expected to result in planting of corn becoming general within a day or so, except in the flooded areas, where little or no field work is expected until late in June.

A NINTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE BOMBER BASE, Somewhere in Libya, May 29 (Delayed) -- Lieutenant Robert H. Austin of Campbell, N.Y., a Liberator bombardier, recently saved his ship, himself and other members of the crew by sheer nerve and heroism in defusing a 1,000-pound bomb that had jammed in the racks over an Italian target.
LONDON, May 30 -- French warships at Alexandria have come under the Allied banner after having lain immobilized since the fall of France three years ago, the Berlin radio declared tonight.

LONDON, May 30 -- The surge of confidence here that followed complete Axis collapse in Tunisia is becoming a tidal wave of optimism, in which wishful thinking plays an increasing large part. It has reached a sort of climax this week end with the publishing of reports both here and in the United States implying that the long-awaited opening of a second front in Europe was a matter of only hours.
CHUNGKING, May 30 (AP) -- A communique:

LONDON, May 30 -- Royal Air Force Coastal Command planes, operating over Iceland waters, the Bay of Biscay and waters north of Britain, destroyed five enemy submarines with depth charges and damaged several others in a ten-day period recently, the Air Ministry announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The Japanese force annihilated yesterday in the Chichagof Valley, naval men said, presumably constituted the last large unit of the enemy garrison on Attu. One spokesman added that definite information on the final stages of the Attu battle may be available tomorrow.

The heads of many of the national labor unions, particularly in the A.F. of L. group, are, I believe, making sincere efforts to establish discipline among their membership in the war effort. That these efforts are meeting with only partial success is demonstrated by the recent withdrawal of the International Association of Machinists from the A.F. of L. over a jurisdictional difficulty and the recurrence of wildcat strikes contrary to the no-strike pledge.

Housewives shopping to replenish the family market basket have begun to complain of rising prices of food and other household commodities under the Office of Price Administration's ceilings. Women shoppers report that prices are moving up to meet the new dollars-and-cents ceilings not only on kitchen but bathroom necessities.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 112.2. The only major index to change was the finished goods index, which rose 0.1 per cent as a result of increases in the prices of brick and gas.

The American Labor Conference on International Affairs, organized by leaders of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations to promote study of foreign affairs and constructive American cooperation in the building and maintenance of the future peace, will hold its first annual meeting in the Hotel Commodore on June 12.

LONDON, Monday, May 31 (AP) -- Russian airmen and gunners destroyed 456 German planes last week for a month's total of 2,069, Moscow disclosed early today amid reports of sharp air and land engagements in the widely separated Kuban and Leningrad sectors.
ARLINGTON NATIONAL CEMETERY, Va., May 30 (AP) -- The Unknown Soldier and his legions of sleeping comrades were honored anew in this national cemetery today -- with fresh flowers and a solemn promise.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 140 United States soldiers wounded in action in North Africa. Included were the following in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

CHUNKING, China, May 30 (AP) -- Chinese troops in a smashing attack have recaptured Yuyangkwan, prize by the Japanese as the "gateway to Chungking," inflicting 2,000 casualties on the enemy and sending the survivors reeling in retreat, Chinese headquarters announced today.

PITTSBURGH, May 30 (AP) -- The Pirates shot into fourth place in the National League today by sweeping both ends of a double-header from the skidding Phillies, 4 to 3 and 2 to 1, before 7,297 fans. The nightcap went ten innings, with Vince DiMaggio's single sending home the winning run.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -- After bluffing for months, Vichy today made a grave concession of failure. It admits by implication that French farmers have paid as little heed to its appeals as to its fines, and that the bread ration will have to be curtailed even though medical authorities declare it is already insufficient.
The war has now entered a stage where political, rather than strategic, factors are determining its course.

If America should revert to spiritual and political isolationism at the end of the war, every memorial erected to the memory of those fighting for America's freedom will be an accusing reminder of a betrays of the cause for which they fought, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, said yesterday in his sermon on "Democracy in a Free World."

The task of prevailing upon the people of Italy to make peace with the United Nations cannot be achieved by mere appeals to revolt against the Mussolini government, James Battistoni, newly elected president of the Mazzini Society, declared here yesterday.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 30 -- Eighteen craft sailed today in the initial regatta of the season conducted for cruising auxiliaries by the Huntington Yacht Club. Three handicap races were staged for Class A, B and C boats.
It is estimated by scientists that 75 per cent of man's everyday activities depend upon the use of his eyes. (Only 10 per cent demand a sense of hearing, 8 per cent a sense of touch.)

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 31 (AP) -- Flying Fortresses scattered thirteen tons of bombs on two Japanese airdromes in the Wewak area of New Guinea, causing numerous explosions and fires.

A program calling for higher taxes, based on ability to pay, and the rationing of all essential scarce goods as the best methods of curbing inflation was adopted yesterday by the delegates to the fifteenth annual meeting of the Eastern Cooperative Wholesale, Inc.

SPARTA, Wis., May 30 -- Beaver Creek, usually placid, inundated the business district of Sparta in a "flash" flood today, its sixteen-foot crest causing damage estimated tentatively by Chief of Police Carl Lehman at "between a half and three-quarters of a million dollars."

WHEN the firing ceased in France three years ago Hitler refused to make peace; he refused even to discuss terms for an armistice. For days, while traitors struck down the French Government and its hope of continued resistance, the people and the soldiers remained ignorant of their fate. It was during that anomalous interval that the Nazi Wehrmacht went on the biggest man hunt in history.

The city observed Memorial Day yesterday with parades, dinners, religious services and addresses praising the American dead of this and past wars. Ceremonies were held in each borough and thousands of persons, including many visitors from out of town, participated.

Parades and other ceremonies in commemoration of the war dead were held in many suburban communities yesterday. In several places the attendance was off sharply from that of former years, the result of the curb on the use of automobiles and buses.

Three weeks ago tomorrow American troops began swarming up the fog-wrapped shores of Attu. From that moment the conquest of the island was a foregone conclusion. Japan could neither relieve nor remove her surprised and outnumbered garrison. Now Tokyo admits they have "perished."

CHICAGO, May 30 -- Rye came last week to the front as the leader in the grain markets. Speculative interest was unusually large, and official reports indicate that the volume of business in May on the Board of Trade was about 140,000, 000 bushels, or 23,000,000 bushels more than the previous record of 117,000,000, established in December, 1942.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Japanese military expenditures for the fiscal year ending next March 31 were estimated by the Board of Economic Warfare today at about $9,000,000,000, compared with anticipated United States war costs of $100,000,000,000 for the corresponding fiscal year ending next June 30.

RENO, Nev., May 30 -- Sir Yeshwant Rao Holkar, Maharajah of Indore, India, who arrived at Palamino Guest Ranch seven days ago, tonight confirmed that he was establishing residence prior to seeking a divorce from his American wife, the former Mrs. Marguerite Lawler Branyen of California.
The German Sunday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

A penthouse apartment at 17 East Ninety-sixth Street has been leased by Ray Heatherton, the orchestra leader, from the East River Savings Bank. Howard C. Forbes, Inc., arranged the lease as broker through William A. White Sons.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Department of Agriculture, in connection with the Office of Price Administration, has been studying the milk shortage that exsits in some Southern cities and threatens to become more general in the Autumn, with a view to adding milk to the rationed foods if and when that should be considered necessary.

CHUNGKING, China, May 30 (AP) -- Medicines flown to Chungking from India by the American Red Cross were reported tonight to have brought a slight improvement in the condition of Lin Sen, 81-year-old President of China, whom physicians earlier had given only a "fifty-fifty" chance of recovering from a critical illness.

DENISON, Texas, May 30 -- Former members of Hitler's crack Africa Corps, captured in North Africa, have substituted crosscut saws for rifles and an axeman's swing for the goosestep as they help clear lands for the Denison Dam Reservoir in this country's first war-prisoner project of its type.

In spite of wartime restrictions on travel which made it impossible to transport racing shells, oarsmen of New York, Pennsylvania and New Jersey managed to stage five events in the annual Memorial Day regatta of the New York Rowing Association on the Harlem yesterday.

The necessity of teaching American history in the schools was urged by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church, Methodist, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, in his sermon yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- A sharp decline in lumber consumption during the first quarter of 1943 has been reported to the Commerce Department by the Lumber Survey Committee.

A new technique for the international transmission and distribution of radio news photographs and facsimiles has been developed in recent months by the overseas branch of the Office of War Information with such success that the flow of pictures of American victories and accomplishments to the neutral and warring countries of the world has been greatly increased.

The campaign of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office for 500,000 volunteers to man the city's protective services will begin on Wednesday with a parade from the Battery to City Hall, with former Governor Alfred E. Smith riding in a military jeep as grand marshal, Mayor La Guardia announced yesterday in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall.

There was a lull yesterday in the record movement of travelers in and out of New York City that reached its peak on Saturday, with holiday week-enders disregarding Government importunities that they "stay at home," as they fought for space on buses, planes and railroad coaches.

LONDON, May 30 -- Ambassador John G. Winant, high United States Army and Navy officers and representatives of Britain and the British Dominions paid tribute to the American dead today at an impressive Memorial Day service in Brookwood Cemetery in Surrey, where lie buried men who gave their lives for Old Glory in this war and the last.

DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- A superb mahogany sable collie dog went through a long day of competition to capture the highest honors this afternoon in the fourteenth annual show of the Delaware County Kennel Club, held on the grounds of the Devon horse show in this town.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 30 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer have announced the acquisition of the screen rights to Irwin Shaw's "Sons and Soldiers," recently seen at the Morosco Theatre in New York. Norman Reilly Raine will write the film adaptation and Everett Riskin will produce it.

LONDON, May 30 (U.P.) -- The growing warmth of the British press to Russia since dissolution of the Comintern resulted today in a proposal in The Sunday Observer for organization of the peace on the basis of a "power group" of Britain, Russia and the United States rather than on the basis of the League of Nations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 30 -- Two submarines and two floating workshops were launched within thirty-two minutes today in a mass launching at yards of the Cramp Shipbuilding Company as a collective Memorial Day tribute by its thousands of employes.
Charles Driscoll, author of "Kansas Irish," published recently by Macmillan, will be interviewed by Warren Bower on the "Reader's Almanac" program this afternoon at 4:30 over WNYC.

Deploring the tendency of many persons to think democracy a legacy and religion irrelevant to modern culture, the Right Rev. Karl Morgan Block, Bishop of California, declared yesterday that unless we give primacy to the Christian way of life, a military victory will not win the peace.

A novel chapter in soccer history was written at Starlight Park in the Bronx yesterday as the Brooklyn Hispano eleven, holder of the American League title, shaded the Morgan Strassers of Pittsburgh, 3 to 2, to capture the United States open championship and become the first club ever to take both crowns in the same season.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- The arrival of June and traditional fighting weather, with long, sunny days and a firm terrain, finds an estimated one hundred and ninety German and twenty-eight satellite nation divisions disposed along the tremendous Russian front that extends from the Arctic Circle to the Kuban Valley in the Caucasus.
LONDON, Monday, May 31 (U.P.) -- A special Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Sunday bus service became just another memory yesterday to thousands of New Yorkers, but Mayor La Guardia, expressing displeasure that 80 per cent of Manhattan's buses had come to a sudden halt, promised that some of them would be running again next Sunday, especially on the crosstown routes.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- Thirteen men and women war plant workers in the New York-New Jersey region were among 141 throughout the country cited today by the War Production Drive Headquarters of the War Production Board in Washington for contributing useful production ideas.

A round-the-conservation-clock survey of other States brings several items, some serious, some humorous. For example, "fawn-napping" is the phrase the California Division of Fish and Game now uses to describe the action of "kind people who pick up fawns erroneously supposed to be lost.
LONDON, May 30 (AP) -- The Russian noon communigue, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

BALTIMORE, May 30 -- The threat of a general American Federation of Labor "holiday" hung over Baltimore tonight as leaders of that organization considered action to aid one of their affiliated unions in a strike against the Baltimore Transit Company.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 30 -- Leghorn, the seat of the Italian Naval Academy and one of the more important naval centers of the Mediterranean, is described today as a "smoking heap of ruins" after Friday's attack on the city by American planes.

DETROIT, May 30 (U.P.) -- Wendell Willkie was picketed today by a small group of Gerald L.K. Smith's America First party workers who carried placards denouncing the 1940 Republican Presidential candidate as a "New Deal stooge," "Communist bootlicker," and hired spokesman of "Hollywood, Wall Street and the Whisky Trust.

Marching by fours in cap and gown, seniors from seven colleges and schools of Columbia University entered St. Paul's Chapel yesterday afternoon as the chapel bell tolled for the annual baccalaureate service and the official opening of the university's 189th commencement program.

Forty-three members of the Columbia College class of '43 will be graduated with honors tomorrow, it was announced yesterday. It was also disclosed that Martin Klein of 333 West Eighty-sixth Street has been awarded the Albert Green Memorial Prize, bestowed annually upon the senior with the highest scholastic record.

Highway fatalities and accidents continue to show a high rate in several reporting States, despite all restrictions on pleasure driving and the constant pressure for slower speeds in the interest of fuel and rubber conservation. Motor Vehicle Commissioner Magee in New Jersey, for example, reports fifty fatalities in his State during the month of April.

Detailed regulations covering special pre-induction physical examinations for men classified as 1-A under the draft law who might undergo hardship by winding up their affairs only to be subsequently rejected by the Army were sent last night to local draft boards by Colonel Arthur V. McDermott, Selective Service director.

On only three days last week did trading exceed a million shares, as against the first week of May, when transactions passed the million-share mark on every day and the full five-day average reached 2,370,000. In last week's closing days, the market became irregular, but only after prices had touched new high levels for the year, both in stocks and bonds.

CHICAGO, May 30 -- The Chicago Stock Exchange had an operating loss of $66,746 in the fiscal year ended April 30, compared with the loss of $86,701 in the preceding year, Kenneth L. Smith, president, says in his annual report.

BOSTON, May 30 (AP) -- The Red Sox got back into the winning groove today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Tigers, winning the first, 3 -- 0, behind Dick Newsome's six-hit pitching, and taking the nightcap, 5 -- 1, on six blows off two Bengal hurlers.

LONDON, May 30 -- To bobbies who have had to cope with them for years London's beggars are always "glimmers." But to countless American soldiers in whom handout seekers have found good pickings they are still panhandlers.

Haven for hounded foreign scholars, the New School for Social Research has now assumed an important role in the intellectual life of this nation. Since the formation of the "University in Exile" with the advent of Hitler ten years ago hundreds of Europe's foremost thinkers have found a new home here.
The importance of religious training for the young was stressed by the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick in his sermon yesterday in The Riverside Church.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 30 -- American bombers and fighter-bombers pounded the tiny, crater-marked island of Pantelleria yesterday, causing explosions and fires. Other fighter-bombers attacked docks and military supply depots at Porto Ponte di Romano in Southwest Sardinia.
All the women in the armed services who want to serve overseas may soon get the opportunity, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt predicted yesterday.

Dr. Robert C. Clothier in his letter published May 28 regarding the program of the Army Specialized Training Division calls for constructive criticism. There is one point in the plan for training engineers which appears to require some elucidation in order to escape the conclusion that the work of the planners is not all bogged down in red-tape, indecision and general confusion.
MOSCOW, May 30 -- Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador to Russia, refused today to comment on reports in Washington that he was contemplating resigning.
A tour of city stores reveals some interesting innovations in the way of groceries. Here is a resume of our findings, most of them well able to "perk up" wartime menus:

Mrs. Pauline Gershow, 49 years old, of 1 Parkside Court, Brooklyn, and her daughter, Leonore, 9, were killed yesterday when they plunged from the roof of a six-story building at 55 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that from a group of twenty-eight men and women telephone workers who were selected for individual outstanding "acts of noteworthy public service" in 1942, four persons had been chosen for special honors, receiving silver medals plus cash awards of $500 each.

NEWARK, N.J., May 30 (AP) -- The Bears ended a three-game losing streak today by taking a pair of one-run decisions from Jersey City before a crowd of 5,568. Newark won the opener with a three-run rally in the eighth, 7 to 6, and bagged a 3-to-2 decision in the seven-inning nightcap.

Fashion insists upon carrying on, priorities notwithstanding. Take one material away from a designer and he will find another. Leathers and metals are no longer feasible for the making of bags. "So what!" exclaim those responsible for styles in bags.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 30 -- Crew shortage, made worse by transportation difficulties, cut down the fleet in the opening regatta of the championship series on Long Island Sound, which was held today by the Echo Bay Yacht Club.

The estate of Louis Sachs has sold the twelve-story store and loft building at 38 to 44 West Twenty-first Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, to Taylor Properties, Inc., Milton Barkin, president. Assessed at $180,000, the property is 67 by 92 feet and is fully rented, according to Walter Samuels, the brokers in the sale.

Louis Tufano's Market Wise, the "Cinderella horse," who holds two victories over the mighty Whirlaway, rules the favorite for the fifty-seventh running of the Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park today, The United Press reports.

The conflict between milk dealers and the Milk Drivers Union over the question of every-other-day deliveries arising from the order of the Office of Defense Transportation to curtail service in an effort to save gasoline continued yesterday as members of the Milk Dealers Association of Greater New York were unable to make wholesale deliveries to hotels, restaurants and stores.

LOU BOUDREAU is half the age of most major league managers, but the Boy Leader of the Cleveland Indians hews to the same party line which all of them have been following. The American League pennant race, they all say, will be as tight as a pack of cards and there will be plenty of shuffling before it is over.
A golden wedding party, honoring fifty-two couples who have been married fifty years or more, was held yesterday afternoon in the Grand Street Boys Association clubhouse, 106 West Fifty-fifth Street.

By the scant margin of a half point, the New York Pioneer Club captured the team honors in the junior track and field championships of the Metropolitan Association of the Amateur Athletic Union at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday. The Pioneer athletes garnered 42 1/2 points to earn the title over the Grand Street Boys Association, which was second with 42.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, May 31 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The consumer will get along better next year than he has this year, an authority of the War Production Board said today. This authority also predicted that wholesalers and retailers would do "slightly less" business in 1944.

ST. LOUIS, May 30 -- The Giants, still deep in the second division, managed to make their presence felt in the upper levels of the National League flag race when they held the Cardinals even in a double-header today before 7,611 fans.

The Bay of Naples and the golden coasts of Sicily lie under a pall blacker and more deadly than the flaming cones of Vesuvius and Etna ever emitted in their worst eruptions. The lava that buried Pompeii and Herculaneum cut a narrow path of destruction compared to the smoking ruins of Palermo and the wreckage that remains of the curving moles of Naples, Genoa and a dozen other ports from Cagliari to Livorno.

MEXICO CITY, May 30 (AP) -- Step By, black gelding from the barn of W.A. Osborne, overcame the handicap of a poor start today to win the 100,000 pesos Handicap of the Americas by two and a half lengths.
LONDON, May 30 (U.P.) -- An Admiralty communique:

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The next-to-last organized enemy force on Attu has been exterminated, the Navy indicated today, and Japanese Imperial Headquarters reported that the entire defending garrison on the barren but strategic Aleutian island had "perished."

Verdi's "La Traviata" was performed by the San Carlo Opera Company yesterday afternoon at the Center Theatre. Topping the cast were Lucille Meusel as Violetta and James Gerard as Alfredo, artists whose accomplishments in this work always evoke enthusiastic response.

While protesting against Allied bombings in Axis territory, German planes mercilessly razed four towns in Montenegro without excuse, according to a broadcast yesterday from Berne, Switzerland, by a correspondent of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 30 (AP) -- Berlin broadcasts of Rome reports said today that six-story houses had been leveled in Leghorn and that Count Ciano, former Italian Foreign Minister, and Zenone Benini, Italian Public Works Minister, as well as King Victor Emmanuel and Queen Elena, had visited the city.

Among the pleasures of the commuter one that has not been adequately dwelt upon, perhaps, is the small-town newspaper. This is usually read under the most favorable circumstances, after a good, sound dinner, in a mood of quiet relaxation while seated in the master's lounging chair.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) -- Congressional groups hostile to the Administration's food subsidy program made it plain today that their fight against the program will continue despite OPA's announcement that the first phase of the plan, a butter subsidy, becomes operative Tuesday.

The British radio, in a French-language broadcast to the Continent yesterday, read the text of a letter addressed by the Belgian Supreme Court of Appeals to Nazi occupation authorities in Belgium, vigorously protesting the "unjust horrors" perpetrated on the Belgian population by the Germans in their drive for slave labor.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 31 -- Livestock herds in general in Europe have decreased so much that five or six years will be required to restore them to pre-war levels, Herbert H. Lehman, director of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations, declared today in an address at Swarthmore College's commencement exercises.

GLADSTONE, N.J., May 31 -- A converted $600,000 carriage house was the scene of a visit paid today by the Duke and Duchess of Windsor. Thirty-two merchant seamen, victims of enemy fire, were the occupants visited in the Merchant Marine Rest Center at Hamilton Farms, the estate of Major and Mrs. C. Suydam Cutting.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -- The 110th Bulgarian political functionary and outspoken supporter of pro-Axis foreign policy to fall from "terrorists' bullets" died en route to a hospital early this mornning at Kostievo. He was Sapria Klevkoff, member of the Sobranje, adherent of the government party, member of the parliamentary commission of the Ministry of War and a rabid anti-Communist.
CHUNGKING, China, May 31 (AP) -- communique:

A PACIFIC BASE, May 1 -- When the 164th Infantry was relieved west of the Matanikau on Dec. 11 and returned to the reserve area near Henderson airfield, it was a tough fighting unit. As Major Gem A.A. Vandegrift of the Marine Corps had said in his farewell message, the 164th had faced without flinching the worst the enemy could do to it and had thrown back the best that he could send.

LONDON, May 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, who has been much more closely identified with the war on the other side of the world than in the European theatre of operations, is here on his way back to China, it was disclosed today, and has already engaged in the first sessions of what he described as "just one big military conference all the way home."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission, said today that he had signed regulations governing granting of exemptions from his earlier order decreeing a forty-eight-hour work week for the steel industry on a countrywide basis.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 31 -- Following yesterday's production report, which urged an expanding world economy to make effective the "freedom from want" clause of the Atlantic Charter, the consumption and distribution sections of the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture made their reports today, recommending that the forty-four participating governments take "action in concert" after the war to establish "freedom from fear" as a world policy.

TARRYTOWN, May 31 -- Bishop Stephen J. Donahue presided today at the annual commencement exercises of Marymount College, at which fifty-nine young women received degrees. Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff, the commencement speaker, urged the graduates to make sincerity the keynote of their lives.

It's tough to be stranded in New York without funds, but it's just as bad to have $1,000 in cash, especially when the $1,000 consists of two $500 bills, and no banks are open, Police Lieutenant Frederick Wendel of the West Fifty-fourth Street station, discovered yesterday.

A SOUTHWEST ENGLISH TOWN, May 31 (AP) -- A six-foot cross still hung over the pile of rubble that was the parish church of this popular peacetime resort until German raiders wrecked it yesterday, killing at least eighteen children and three Sunday school teachers.

LONDON, May 31 (U.P.) -- The sharp-shooting crew of an American Flying Fortress set a new record during the United States raid on Wilhelmshaven and Emden on May 21, by destroying at least eleven German fighter planes, and probably several more, before their ship was damaged and forced down in the North Sea, it was announced officially today.

MEXICO CITY, May 31 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, left today by plane for Washington, leaving behind him a chorus of praise and undoubtedly a much better atmosphere of United States Industrial relations than he found when he arrived here last week.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board tonight announced a nation-wide wage increase of 12 1/2 cents an hour for 12,000 non-messenger employes of the Postal Telegraph Company to correct "substandard" pay scales. Also, the board granted a 10 per cent increase for messengers and a 7 1/2-cent an hour rise to workers who are classified as "route aides."

Japan's propagandists yesterday used the defeat at Attu Island as the basis for a barrage of emotional domestic broadcasts in which the nation's workers were implored to increase production in memory of the Aleutian "heroes."
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Navy's lowering of physical standards for draftees may slow up slightly the induction of fathers, Manpower Chief McNutt said today.

LONDON, May 31 -- What the world has been witnessing these past few days is the specific application to a given region of enemy territory of the theory that the war can he won from the air. This hapless region is the part of the Ruhr district some sixty by forty miles in area that before the war produced some 70 per cent of Germany's heavy armament.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- One of the country's most "air-minded" Roman Catholic nuns -- Sister Mary Aquinas of the Franciscan Order -- has found cloistered life no detriment to learning to fly.
The Yankees went from the ridiculous to the sublime yesterday in their twin bill with the White Sox before a gathering of 33,274 at the Stadium.

American cooperatives are supplying one-third of all lend-lease food shipments and with the coming of peace will play a major role, in conjunction with European cooperatives, in solving the international food problem, Howard A. Cowden, president of the Consumers Cooperative Association and vice president of the Cooperative League, declared yesterday in an address over radio Station WABC.

Thousands of New Yorkers unable to obtain transportation home from their three-day holiday weekend in the country were reported left stranded last night, while out-of-towners leaving the city jammed every outgoing plane, bus and railroad coach, with standing room, even, at a premium.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A warning that the child population of the United States is shrinking so rapidly that the smaller group of adolescents may not offset the mounting casualties of war, was sounded here today by the National Resources Planning Board in a report released by the White House.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Treasury today announced a new campaign to begin June 15 to boost national payroll savings for war bonds. Wages, salaries and other income of the American people are now at the rate of $140,000,000,000 a year, the Treasury said in announcing the new drive.

DURHAM, N.C., May 31 (U.P.) -- Under-Secretary Sumner Welles said today that a world court to settle disputes among nations and an international-police force to keep the peace must be established at the end of the war if humanity is to be spared a repetition of the conflict.

TUNISIA, May 17 (By Mail) -- Easel set up on a Cap Bon roadside facing a poppy-sprinkled wheat field strewn with wrecked cars and dead horses. Artist George Biddle, brother of Attorney General Francis E. Biddle, was calmly sketching the scene of death and devastation the other day.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, May 30 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Australian and American troops joined today in ceremonies among the white crosses in a green New Guinea valley, honoring their war dead on the second overseas Memorial Day services for United States troops in the Southwest Pacific area.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Moving openly, though still cautiously, toward the issue of the post-war world, the Republican National Committee, through Chairman Harrison E. Spangler, announced today the appointment of a post-war advisory council of forty-nine members to develop "a realistic peacetime program for American progress."

Consumers in the metropolitan area will be without their usual quota of delivered milk tomorrow because of the continued refusal of the various locals of the Milk Wagon Drivers Union, an affiliate of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., to respect the order of the Office of Defense Transportation limiting retail deliveries to a "skip-a-day" basis to save gasoline.

DETROIT, May 31 -- Executives of the Ford Motor Company held a series of conferences today at the administration offices in the Rouge plant, but officials declined to say whether a successor to the late Edsel B. Ford, president, was chosen.

MOSCOW, May 31 -- The distinction of employing the only American-born United States citizen now engaged in private capitalistic ventures on a "business as usual" basis in all Russia belongs to the firm of Papert-Strasburg of 251 West Thirtieth Street, New York. Its representative, Sidney Hollander, the well-known fur broker of Omsk, has just arrived in this capital after seventeen months of fairly arduous duties in the center of Siberia.

SOMEWHERE IN SOUTHERN ENGLAND, May 31 -- A young second lieutenant from New Jersey and an M.P. from Virginia, who used to be a plumber, shared honors with a battalion of Rangers and "bazooka" Americans who manned the new tank-bursting rocket gun at the first large-scale competitive manoeuvres between American and British troops held in Britain during this war.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The pay-as-you-go income tax compromise of the Senate and House conference, exempting 1942 liabilities for lowest brackets and abating 75 per cent for other levels, was advanced tonight on the eve of its voting test in the House as a "this-or-nothing" current payment program.

BOSTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Red Sox took two overtime games from the Browns, 2 -- 1 in thirteen innings and 7 -- 6 in ten, to move into the American League's sixth berth today before a crowd of 15,658.

About a week or ten days ago a letter by Albert A. Volk was published and it deserves attention. The real estate tax problem involves the mortgage lending institutions and their handling of their mortgage situations largely to the extent the heavy tax burdens aggravate the difficulties between mortgagee and mortgagor.

Those of us living in the West Eighties who have been a trifle timid about protesting to the authorities that so far as the air raid sirens are concerned we live in what seems to be a "dead area" received unexpected and welcome support from the article in THE TIMES of May 29 about the previous night's raid drill in New Jersey.

Captain Denman Fowler, an infantry officer, who formerly practiced law here, was killed in action in Africa on April 23, the day after his thirty-first birthday, his father, Dr. Edmund Prince Fowler of 319 East Fiftieth Street, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Senators and Indians divided a double-header today. Washington won the first game, 8 to 7, and the Indians took the second, 7 to 6, in thirteen innings.
NEWARK, May 31 (AP) -- The Bears stretched their winning streak to four games today by winning an exciting twin bill with Jersey City. The scores were 2 -- 0 and 6 -- 5.

Three years after the great defeat France has a capital again -- not Paris, not Vichy, but Algiers. The committee which has emerged from the meeting of General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud is not a government, but it is a trustee for the French liberty and the French unity which were abandoned at Paris, betrayed at Bordeaux and turned into a dreadful mockery at Vichy.

The soldier team of Lieut. Col. E.O. Keller, Sergeants Phil Abramsohn and Morrie Elis, with Waldemar von Zedtwitz as its fourth member, won the open team-of-four bridge championship of the American Bridge League South Shore tournament early this morning, defeating Charles H. Goren, Harry J. Fishbein, Mrs. A.M. Sobel and Miss Ruth Sherman by 1,410 points in the final round.

With an eye to the Victory gardeners and housekeepers who plan to do considerable fruit canning this year, the United States Department of Agriculture offers pointers on how to accomplish the feat under the rigors of sugar rationing.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Large numbers of big landing boats and power barges are on hand in North Africa, two Army generals reported today and troops there are being trained in the use of a new amphibious truck.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- An appeal to all Americans to curb their use of gasoline to the absolute minimum in the interests of the armed services abroad was broadcast tonight by Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and head of the Office of Petroleum Administration for War.
Four alumni of New York University will be honored tonight for "distinguished service to the university" at a dinner in the Washington Square Faculty Club. Those to be cited include:

Selected for medal awards for heroic and meritorious actions during the last year, eighteen officers and men of the New York Fire Department will be honored by Mayor La Guardia in a joint ceremony with Police Department medal winners in City Hall Plaza at noon on Tuesday, June 15, it was announced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh.

LONDON, May 31 -- Diamond shares provided the chief point of interest in the stock markets today but profit-taking sales caused reactions from the initial levels. Sir Ernest Oppenheimer's optimistic speech on the future of the industry caused a jump in Debeers to 22s 3d, a new high since 1937 but later the price eased to 21s 5d.

Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, holder of the Distinguished Service Medal for his part in the occupation of French Morocco, will assume command of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn tomorrow, succeeding Rear Admiral E.J. Marquart, who has held that post as well as being commandant of the Third Naval District for the last fourteen months.

Prices, wages and the cost of living have been kept "pretty well under control" in Great Britain as a result of subsidies, rationing, price regulation and labor arbitration, according to Sir William Beveridge, British economist and author of the "cradle to the grave" social security plan.

Vital contributions to the war are being made by many refugees, it was said yesterday in the annual report of the National Refugee Service. The report revealed that thousands of refugees were serving in the armed forces, working in war industries and helping to maintain civilian health and morale.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 31 -- Paramount will deal with post-war problems of returning soldiers, in a picture, "The Time Is Now," based on an original story by Stanley Paley. Walter MacEwen will produce the film, with Susan Hayward and James Brown in the leads.

RAOUL AGLION'S "The Fighting French"* tells one of the supremely great stories of the war. It is a story of men who had faith. It is also one of the best auguries for the future integrity of the French Republic, for it manages to exalt General Charles de Gaulle without in any way belittling General Henri Giraud. M. Aglion is a de Gaullist, and proud of it.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., May 31 -- In a speech bristling with the hard figures of overwhelming armament production, James F. Byrnes declared tonight that "many attacks on many fronts lie ahead" as the time had come for this country to assume a major part in all-out military operations against the enemy.
CHUNGKING, China, Tuesday, June 1 (AP) -- A zpeciaZ communi-[ qud:

The Netherlands news agency reported yesterday that Netherlanders again were setting fire to town halls containing records that might be used by the Germans in conscripting men for their compulsory labor service, The United Press said.

Mentioning the company as an illustration of the extent to which corporations have departed from their customary production programs to participate in the war, Theodore G. Montague, president of the Borden Company, in a letter to stockholders, reveals that it has entered diversified food lines, modifying equipment or installing new machinery, to produce dehydrated soups, concentrated coffee extracts, canned fish, powdered fruit juices, vitamins and processed eggs.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 31 -- Four hundred persons marched four miles from the American Legion Building here to the grave of President Theodore Roosevelt, where Legionnaires and British war veterans placed a wreath.

Investment bankers, freed from their efforts in the Second War Loan Drive, marketed a large volume of new securities here in May. Bond offerings reached the largest total for any month since January and stock flotations were the greatest since February, 1942.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended May 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: Decreases of $120,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $567,000,000 in United States Government deposits and $195,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and an increase of $533,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, May 31 -- It seemed probable today that the Japanese had succeeded again in strengthening their position along the north coast of New Guinea.

Don Bingo, a horse from the Argentine, and Paul Ames, a man from Wall Street, combined to make yesterday's fifty-seventh running of the $38,100 Suburban Handicap perhaps the most memorable renewal of that mile-and-a-quarter stake in the history of Belmont Park.

Among the sights which New York offers her sightseeing visitors there are four exhibits that have traditionally stood out above all others. Two of these are now war casualties, though fortunately not the two finest ones in the estimation of many of us.
Major crime and traffic accidents decreased in New York City during 1942, the first war year, according to the Police Department's annual report, released yesterday.

WITH THE UNITED STATES FIFTH ARMY, in North Africa, May 31 -- Lieut. Gen. Mark W. Clark, commander of the United States Fifth Army, hinting at the invasion of Europe, predicted today that a year from now "we shall celebrate Memorial Day in another land with victories behind us."

In his address yesterday at Durham Under-Secretary of State Welles outlined certain "cardinal principles" which he believes must be the basis of action by the United Nations if this war is to be followed by an enduring peace. The principles are stated in broad terms, and rightly so.

ALGIERS, May 31 -- Seven men became the rulers of the resurgent French Empire today when General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud set up the executive committee that will govern the empire and represent the people of metropolitan France until the motherland has been freed.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 31 -- Naples, the chief supply port for Italy's island outposts in the Mediterranean and a center of war industry in Southern Italy, was heavily bombed yesterday without loss by more than 100 Flying Fortresses in the biggest daylight raid yet directed against the city. Widespread damage was inflicted in the course of the attack on objectives in Naples and the immediate vicinity.

Yesterday's novelty by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre was the season's only presentation of "L' Apresmidi d'un Faune" with Igor Youskevitch in the title role and Lubov Rostova as the principal nymph. There is little to be said about the performance except that the audience enjoyed it, for the contemporary version of this work is scarcely even an echo of the Nijinsky original and has small claim to attention.

NEW DELHI, India, May 31 (U.P.) -- American fighter planes, continuing their almost daily attacks on Japanese objectives in the Hukawng Valley area of Northern Burma, yesterday started fires in four enemy settlements and destroyed two motor vehicles, the Tenth United States Air Force reported today.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 1 (AP) -- British medium bombers and escorting Spitfires made two long sweeps over Northern France and the Low Countries yesterday. The four-motored heavyweights of the R.A.F. remained in their hangars Sunday night after their busiest week of the war last week.

Add to the films opening this week, "Captive Wild Woman," a Universal melodrama, which will arrive at the Rialto on Saturday. Acquanetta, John Carradine, Evelyn Ankers, Vince Barnett and Lloyd Corrigan head the cast of the picture, which was directed by Edward Dmytryk.
WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Thirty-three additional plants have received the Army-Navy production award pennant for outstanding performance on war work, it was announced today.

Despite such drawbacks as traveling restrictions, weather and competition from outdoor events, yesterday afternoon's holiday performances in the Broadway theatres fared much better than had been anticipated. Of the two dozen shows, thirteen gave matinees.

JERUSALEM, May 31 -- Recent excavations in the Jordan River valley by Dr. Nelson Glueck, director of the American School of Oriental Research of Jerusalem, resulted in the discovery of the ruins of seventy villages that existed between 3500 B.C. and the twelfth century A.D.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 31 -- Before a large gathering of relatives and friends of the June class of 1943, Alumni Day festivities got under way at the United States Military Academy this morning with traditional exercises at the monument of Colonel Sylvanus Thayer, "the father of the Military Academy" and its first superintendent.
LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
A penthouse apartment at 40 Central Park South has been leased to Robert Gabriel, restaurant owner, through Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers, and Culver, Hollyday Co., agents.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 31 -- Following is the text of a summary of recommendations of Section III of United Nations Food Conference on ways of improving the distribution of food under a post-war economy of abundance:
PITTSBURGH, May 31 (AP) -- The Pirates and Braves split a double-header today, with Boston taking the first game, 6 to 1, and Pittsburgh the second, 4 to 0.

Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange in May continued at an active pace in the second largest trading of any month in more than a year and the largest in three years for a corresponding month. Sales, for the year to date, exceed the total for all of 1942, and are the heaviest for any similar period in six years or since 1937.

The arrest last week of sixty-five alleged violators of the Selective Service Act, including a 28-year-old man who "just couldn't seem to get up in time to go to the induction center," was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the New York office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
It was just the type of day for an "old-time boat fisherman who likes to sit in the sun and dangle a line."

Columbia University will end a three-day celebration of its 189th commencement at 5 P.M. today when 3,867 degrees in course are conferred at traditional outdoor exercises in South Court. Ten honorary degrees, four university medals for excellence and seventy certificates and diplomas also will be awarded.

DETROIT, May 31 -- Wendell L. Willkie, in a speech here tonight, said that America must retain its "leadership among the people," a principle which has gained for this country much good-will on the part of other nations. This goodwill, he said, is the country's best insurance against becoming involved in post-war chaos.

The apartment house containing twenty-eight suites at 36 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank, N.J., was sold to the 36 Riverside Corporation through Harry T. Jenkin, broker, for $125,000. William J. O'Hagan was the attorney for the purchaser. J.L.R. Lafferty was the attorney for the seller.
Copies of a booklet listing the new postal numbers for all streets in Manhattan and the Bronx will be available today at the carrier station, Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (U.P.) -- Awards of decorations to United States officers and enlisted men of the Northwest African Air Force for exceptional aerial performance in the Tunisian campaign were announced today by the War Department. Included were:

MIAMI, Fla., May 31 (AP) -- A Nazi submarine torpedoed the Swedish motor ship Industria in the South Atlantic on March 25 and took aboard as prisoners the three ranking officers of the neutral vessel, survivors reported here today.

DEVON, Pa., May 31 -- That new favorite of the dog-show public, the beautiful black cocker spaniel, Try Cob's Favorite Girl, bred and owned by Mrs. R. Kenneth Cobb of Huntington, L.I., and shown in the ring by Mr. Cobb, this evening gained her second best-in-show victory.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Investigators for the Dies Committee reported today that the approximately 85,000 Japanese who are being held in ten relocation centers in this country probably are among the best fed civilians in the world.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS in Australia, Tuesday, June 1 (U.P.) -- Allied heavy bombers dropped thirty-six tons of bombs yesterday on enemy targets at Lae, Japanese coastal base in New Guinea, a communique said today. An official spokesman said that it was the heaviest bomb load ever dumped on Lae.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System announced today that consumer credit outstanding at the end of April was estimated at $5,216,000,000, representing a decrease of about $135,000,000 during the month.

Higher temperatures and sunnier days have set New Yorkers to poking about the city's shops in search of the newest versions of swimming togs. Already it is apparent that Miss Atlantic Beach of 1943 will appear this Summer, as sirenish as ever, for despite the fact that rubber has virtually disappeared from beach fashions, her sartorial snap survives.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 31 -- The German radio suggested today that "der Tag" for the Allied invasion of the Continent was June 22, attributing its information today to "confidential and well-informed quarters in London."

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Federal Government made funds available today, first to give emergency food, shelter and medical attention to homeless families in the Midwestern flood area and then to rebuild roads and bring crop lands back into war food production.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that an increase of 900,000 in total employment during the last month was caused mainly by the movement of students and housewives into farm work.

Detective work, coupled with good luck, has enabled sixteen women volunteers for the home service department of the Red Cross to render a valuable service. It is their job to locate many persons and deliver to them incompletely or incorrectly addressed messages of hope or of tragedy, from enemy-held territory.

Britain was cited as a living example for the hard-pressed Italian people by a fascist spokesman who urged them not to heed Allied "appeals" to surrender or rebel against Premier Mussolini's regime, the Rome radio reported yesterday, according to the Federal Communications Commission.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Dr. J.K. Galbraith, target of concentrated criticism from the food, textile and other industries as well as from members of Congress, tendered his resignation today as a deputy administrator in charge of the Price Department of the Office of Price Administration.

Echoes of war pervaded Brander Matthews Hall yesterday afternoon as a third of Columbia College's graduating class heard Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university, and Associate Dean Nicholas McD. McKnight, as well as the salutatorian and the valedictorian, counsel them in class day addresses to assume their roles in shaping the post-war world.
Captain Roger Welles, U.S.A., and Mrs. Welles have come to the Weylin from Alexandria, Va.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The aircraft carrier Enterprise -- "lovingly known to her men as the Old Lady" -- helped protect the U.S.S. Hornet on the famous Tokyo raid, and participated in the Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands, which proved so disastrous to Japanese air power, the Navy Department revealed today in telling the story behind the Presidential unit citation of the gallant ship.
WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices received by farmers for agricultural commodities advanced two points between April 15 and May 15.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- A special committee meeting of directors of the National Canners Association will be held here Friday and Saturday of this week to re-examine the industry's relationship with the Office of Price Administration and to develop public relations policies for the remainder of the year, it was learned here today.
The Finnish Monday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

CHUNGKING, China, May 31 -- If the Battle of Hupeh-Hunan ever was an actual threat to Chungking the danger seems now to be diminishing. By recovering Yuyangkwan, which is described as "the gateway to Chungking," the Chinese Army recovered one of its major strategic defenses in that area.

In its first change of ownership in many years, the six-story apartment building at 2001 Grand Concourse, in the Bronx, was sold by the Max Luria Realty Corporation to the Forty-seven Holding Corporation, a client of Gerard Bloomfield, attorney.

LONDON, May 31 (AP) -- The May total of German fighters destroyed by bombers of the United States Eighth Air Force brought to 768 the number the Flying Fortresses and Liberators have shot down this year. The previously announced figure for May was 297, but this did not include those shot down in the three-pronged attack May 29 on St. Nazaire, La Pallice and Rennes.

Mrs. William S. Gill, described by] Ithe police as the former Janet] Snowden of New York, was killedI a little after last midnight when/ she jumped or fell from a suite on] Ithe sixteenth floor of the Hotel Sa-' roy Plaza to the roof of a fourstory extension on the Fifth Avenue side of the building.

Hard on the heels of the Japanese defeat on Attu Island the Chinese announce another Japanese defeat which may prove of importance to the whole war in the Far East. After a 36-hour battle the Chinese forces, aided by the American air corps, succeeded in breaking the spearhead of the Japanese offensive started along the Yangtze River in the direction of Chungking, and in an "all-front" counter offensive have routed five enemy divisions.
FOR a man whose team had just swept a double-header from the Washington Senators the day before, Jimmy Dykes did not seem in a particularly happy frame of mind.

ST. LOUIS, May 31 -- The first-place Dodgers and second-place Cardinals divided shut-outs in their doubleheader today before 26,248 fans, with the result that Lippy Leo Durocher's boys still are a game and a half in the van.

Sixty-one American Women's Voluntary Services headquarters throughout the city will remain open from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. as recruitment centers during the city's ten-day drive for 500,000 volunteers that starts tomorrow under the general direction of Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office here.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 240 United States soldiers killed in action in various theatres of operations. All those from the New York metropolitan area, however, gave their lives in the African fighting.
With 3,000 recruiting centers established throughout the city, the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office will begin an intensive campaign to enroll additional volunteers.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 1 (AP) -- The Germans claimed to have driven a wedge into Russian lines above Smolensk yesterday, and both sides reported thrusts and parries of scouting raids as June brought the traditional month of best fighting weather to the long Russian front today.

Miss Harriet S. Wright, superintendent of extension work at the New York Library, will retire today after having served the institution twenty-eight years. Since 1926 she has been associated with the extension division, of which she has been superintendent since 1937. She will be succeeded by lVLrs. Anne S. I-Iutchins, formerly librarian of the High Bridge Branch Library in the Bronx.

Pointing out that only about 5 per cent of the radio audience really knows what frequency modulation is, Arthur Freed, vice president and general manager of the Freed-Eiseman organization, in a letter to dealers, has called upon them to education the consumer through newspaper and direct mail advertising.

New York observed its second Memorial Day of the present war yesterday with parades and patriotic observances and with a vast flow of travel that left thousands of residents unable to obtain transportation home after a three-day week-end in the country.

As the tempo of the air warfare in the European and Pacific theatres increases, uninformed and for the most part fruitless comparisons between our aircraft and those of the enemy continue to appear. Confusion reaches its height with regard particularly to the fighter category.

PHILADELPHIA, May 31 (AP) -- Coming back to win the second game, 4 -- 3, after Detroit had taken the first, 7 -- 0, the Athletics divided a double-header with the Tigers before 23,833 at Shibe Park today.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Although the Battle of Attu has been conceded to the American attackers by the Japanese Imperial Headquarters, the Navy Department reported today that Army troops, as late as Sunday, still were combating "bushwhacking" tactics by remnants of the enemy forces.
SPARTANBURG, S.C., May 31 -- The text of the address prepared for delivery here tonight by James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, follows:

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The United States Rubber Company and the Hood Rubber Company, the leading manufacturers of rubber and canvas footwear in the United States, were charged by the Federal Trade Commission today with price discrimination between purchasers of their products.

Five issues of Treasury discount bills amounting to about $900,000,000 each were awarded in May, four maturing in ninety-two days and one in ninety-one days, at prices showing yields of about three-eighths of 1 per cent. A year ago in the same month, four ninety-one-day issues, one for $150,000,000 and three for $250,000,000 each, were sold at prices averaging from 0.358 to 0.368 per cent.

BATON ROUGE, La., May 31 -- From new plants recently completed along the bayous of Louisiana, synthetic rubber now is moving to the country's war industries at a rate in excess of 75,000 long tons a year. In peace time, this would be sufficient to meet one-eighth of the country's rubber requirements.

The volume of gasoline available for civilian use in the Northeast will be smaller this month than it was last, spokesmen for the petroleum industry and the Petroleum Administration for War agreed yesterday. They explained that this was due to the fact that some reserves were available to augment. May receipts while conservation measures were being mapped, but that the reserves were all but exhausted now.

The destruction by cruising British planes of five enemy submarines within ten days emphasizes the increasing effectiveness of one of the chief Allied weapons against the U-boat and strengthens current optimistic reports from both sides of the ocean on the Battle of the Atlantic.

Women doctors, none of whom was in Britain's armed forces before the war, have joined them in considerable numbers in administrative jobs, in hospitals at home and in a few cases hospitals overseas, said a statement issued in New York yesterday by the British Information Service.

Time's gunners have not cut down all of Grant's and Lee's young men. One of them, George W. Collier, a G.A.R. veteran, was still young enough at 99 to be grand marshal of yesterday's parade in Manhattan. In the whole country there are still about 500 G.A.R. members and perhaps somewhat fewer Confederate veterans.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Official Washington, which has seen the births and deaths of several successive home front "controls," spent the Memorial Day week-end in discussing the newest infant Hercules, the Office of War Mobilization. Largely because there have been several before which never came to effective maturity, the discussion has developed two schools of opinion.

MARTINS FERRY, Ohio, May 31 -- An official of the Blaw-Knox Company's war plant here today ordered the Amy-Navy E pennant, awarded May 19 for excellent production, hauled down because twelve chippers failed to report for work.

Fearing further tightening of inventory restrictions, many retailers sought last week to take in immediately as much scarce goods as possible, especially in textiles, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. With shortages becoming more acute, buyers offered little resistance to the marking of orders "for delivery when ready."

Recruiting a writer outside the ranks of professional authors, Scribner lists for publication early next month, "The Spirit of Enterprise," by Edgar Monsanto Queeny, chairman of the board of the Monsanto Chemical Company. The book tells of a business man's attempt to reorientate himself in a war world and expresses the belief that the best interests of the people will be served by a free enterprise economy as opposed to a strong centralized bureaucracy.

Women doctors, none of whom was in Britain's armed forces before the war, have joined them in considerable numbers in administrative jobs, in hospitals at home and in a few cases hospitals overseas, said a statement issued in New York yesterday by the British Information Service.

Time's gunners have not cut down all of Grant's and Lee's young men. One of them, George W. Collier, a G.A.R. veteran, was still young enough at 99 to be grand marshal of yesterday's parade in Manhattan. In the whole country there are still about 500 G.A.R. members and perhaps somewhat fewer Confederate veterans.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- Official Washington, which has seen the births and deaths of several successive home front "controls," spent the Memorial Day week-end in discussing the newest infant Hercules, the Office of War Mobilization. Largely because there have been several before which never came to effective maturity, the discussion has developed two schools of opinion.

MARTINS FERRY, Ohio, May 31 -- An official of the Blaw-Knox Company's war plant here today ordered the Amy-Navy E pennant, awarded May 19 for excellent production, hauled down because twelve chippers failed to report for work.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, May 31 (AP) -- A Communique:

CHICAGO, May 31 -- Total meat production in May was 15 per cent greater than in the preceding month, the American Meat Institute, trade organization for the packing industry, reported today. Coincidentally, military demands have become more pressing, civilian appetites have become whetted by harder work and pocketbooks have expanded and lend-lease purchases have been stepped up.

Fearing further tightening of inventory restrictions, many retailers sought last week to take in immediately as much scarce goods as possible, especially in textiles, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. With shortages becoming more acute, buyers offered little resistance to the marking of orders "for delivery when ready."

Recruiting a writer outside the ranks of professional authors, Scribner lists for publication early next month, "The Spirit of Enterprise," by Edgar Monsanto Queeny, chairman of the board of the Monsanto Chemical Company. The book tells of a business man's attempt to reorientate himself in a war world and expresses the belief that the best interests of the people will be served by a free enterprise economy as opposed to a strong centralized bureaucracy.

BERNE, Switzerland, May 31 -- That there is a measure of bluff in Axis assertions of the impregnability of the "European Fortress," at least on its western side, seems confirmed by events in France and reports from there.

George S. Van Schaick, regional director of the Office of Civilian Defense, announced yesterday establishment of the Fire Guards, a protective force to be trained to man pump tank extinguishers. Mr. Van Schaick said formation of the new group had been recommended by James M Landis, national director of the OCD.
LONDON, May 31 (U.P.) -- King Peter of Yugoslavia announced "regretfully" today that his marriage to 22-year-old Princess Alexandra of Greece would have to wait until after the war.

Henry D. Sayer, general manager of the Compensation Insurance Rating Board, announced yesterday that a complete revision of compensation insurance rates had been issued with the approval of the State Superintendent of Insurance, to be effective for the year beginning July 1, on new and renewal business only.
BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, May 31 -- The pro-government alliance known as Concordancia published its platform for next September's presidential election today.

Federal and municipal authorities intervened yesterday to halt the dumping of thousands of gallons of milk that manufacturing plants in New York and New England were unable to convert into cheese, butter and powdered milk because of labor and transportation shortages.

The Blue Cross Hospital Service Plan of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, providing for increased benefits which will mean an estimated saving of at least $500,000 a year to subscribers without any increase in subscription rates, will be put in effect today, it was announced yesterday by Louis H. Pink, president of the service.

Assailing John L. Lewis as "the intriguing mine workers' union leader" who "set out to wage his one-man war on the United States" in the dispute between the United Mine Workers and operators, Sidney Hillman's Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O., through its official organ, The Advance, called yesterday for immediate unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Wartime shortages of labor and material made it necessary this year to reduce the tonnage of newsprint used by American publishers. Fortunately for the public and the newspapers themselves the War Production Board placed this reduction program in the capable hands of working newspaper men who knew what they were doing and understood the needs of the business in which they had grown up.
WASHINGTON, Tuesday, June 1 -- Bituminous miners in twenty-five States stopped work when their contract expired at midnight last night without being extended and 450,000 are expected to be idle.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 31 -- Protesting against the closing of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation yards for the day, thousands of employes appeared at the gates this morning but were turned away because of what the management described as a temporary shortage of critical material.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 1 (U.P.) -- The Russian Monday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by The United Press:

LONDON, May 31 -- The French naval squadron of nine warships immobilized at Alexandria since July, 1940, has voluntarily joined the Allies and will be ready for battle service within six months or less, it was officially announced today.

After a brief ownership, the ten-story loft building on a plot 50 by 92 feet at 15 and 17 West Eighteenth Street was resold by a syndicate of operators headed by Alexander Hirsch, attorney. The building has a rent roll of $18,400 and was disposed of through Dwight, Voorhis Helmsley, brokers.
Little encouragement has been found in official circles regarding the nation's food outlook, according to the Guaranty Survey monthly publication of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York.

LONDON, May 31 -- The French naval squadron of nine warships immobilized at Alexandria since July, 1940, has voluntarily joined the Allies and will be ready for battle service within six months or less, it was officially announced today.

Their game with the White Sox washed out yesterday, the Yankees added another double-header to their already overcrowded schedule. Aside from the regularly listed twin bills, the McCarthymen now are down for an even ten double-barreled attractions, seven of which will be contested on the road.

After the flaring excitement of Monday's record-breaking war charity day, Belmont Park seemed like a lighthouse on a foggy coast yesterday as only 6,331 journeyed through the mists to the huge Nassau County plant, in contrast to the previous day's 47,083, to wager $608,705 in the mutuel machines, as opposed to the holiday handle of $2,699,153.

ATLANTA, Ga., June 1 -- Paul Robeson, who once said he never again would cross the Mason and Dixon line into the South, declared here today that he saw the greatest hope of his people in the colored youth of the South.

The National Committee of the Communist party issued a statement yesterday assailing John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, as "setting himself up above the labor movement and above the country" in calling a second stoppage in the coal industry.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, June 1 (U.P.) -- Australian Air Minister Arthur S. Drakeford said tonight that the United Nations had wrested air supremacy from the Japanese in the Southwest Pacific and that the Allies were steadily encircling Japan "with a ring of steel."

CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- Bill Cox, owner of the Phillies, announced today a player transaction whereby outfielders Danny Litwhiler and Earl Naylor go to the Cardinals for outfielders Coaker Triplett, Dain Clay and Buster Adams. Clay will report to the Phillies from Rochester of the International League, a Cardinal farm.

Predicting that Italy would free herself from her Fascist masters more easily and quickly than Germany would rid herself of the Nazis, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday at alumni luncheon held in connection with the 189th annual commencement of the institution that "the military struggle may be over sooner than you think."

PRINCETON. N.J., June 1 -- Princeton University has bought the home of its oldest living alumnus, Dr. William H. Vail, 97 years old, of Newark, thus ending the threat of his eviction under a mortgage foreclosure.
