WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The War Dejartment made public today the names, with next of kin, of 287 United States soldiers wounded in action in North Africa.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The House adopted the compromise pay-as-you-go tax bill today, 256 to 114, and favorable action was expected in the Senate tomorrow. President Roosevelt informed Speaker Rayburn that he would sign the bill.

Federal judges Learned Hand, John C. Knox and Murray Hulbert, sitting as a statutory court, began consideration yesterday of a plan of the Delaware Hudson Company and the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation to adjust the payment of a bond issue that fell due May 1.

The Republican National Committee has announced the appointment of an advisory council of forty-nine members to develop "a realistic peacetime program" for the United States in the post-war world. Notably absent from the list of forty-nine are the last three Presidential candidates of the Republican party -- Mr. Willkie, Mr. Hoover and Mr. Landon.

BOSTON, June 1 (AP) -- The outcome of today's feature at Suffolk Downs, the $1,800 Somerville Purse, must have served as a tonic to Charlie Rufi of Brady Lake, Ohio, owner of the winner, Dense Path, who led a field of seven to the wire by a length.

Columbia's commencement yesterday, the 189th, reminds us that she will be 200 soon. She is an old citizen and friend. The names of some of her graduates are blown about the world. New Yorkers are thick upon her catalogues. The last commencement of King's College, her predecessor, was held in Trinity Church.
Peconic Bay boat captains were advised yesterday that the Coast Guard was ready to carry out instructions from the OPA and stop "gasoline-propelled vessels for pleasure purposes."

There had been some vague talk and a couple of premature announcements, but the continued presence of the gentleman with the endless supply of superlatives was enough testimony that something was brewing.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The death sentences against Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, Emanuel (Mendy) Weiss and Louis Capone were unanimously upheld when the Supreme Court today announced that their trial in the Kings County, New York, court had been fair.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, June 2 (AP) -- The noon communique:

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 1 -- "We have the initiative, and we shall push from here and from New Guinea and push the sons-of-guns back home if we can," Rear Admiral Theodore S. Wilkinson, deputy commander of the United States South Pacific Fleet, said here in expounding American offensive strategy in the Southern Pacific.

Two more films have joined the list of new arrivals coming to midtown theatres this week. They are "Jitterbugs," a Twentieth CenturyFox comedy starring Laurel and Hardy, which opens at the Globe on Friday, and "Soy Puro Mexicano," a Mexican production with David Silva, Raquel Rojas and Pedro Armendariz, also due on Friday at the Belmont Theatre.

HOLTZ BAY, Attu, May 19 (Delayed) (AP) -- One of the mysteries of Attu was solved today when American troops had their first opportunity to examine, without danger of enemy fire, the airfield the Japanese had been building here for months and months.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Asserting that the conservation aims of the "cuffs-on-trousers" ban for men and boys had been accomplished, the War Production Board relaxed today its regulations to permit simulated cuffs.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Wearing the new khaki Army Nurse Corps uniform for the first time, Lieut. Col. Florence A. Blanchfield, acting superintendent, took oath as colonel and superintendent in a brief ceremony in the office of the Army Surgeon General.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 1 -- Several cases of active resistance were reported tonight from Grenoble, in the part of France occupied by the Italians. The most serious damage was caused by several bombs in a hotel occupied by the Italian staff. Six persons were injured, three of them seriously.

There is no need at this late date to expand upon the grave injury that a coal strike can work upon the American war effort. To suspend the production of coal is to suspend the production of steel, of power, of the basic raw materials without which war production becomes impossible.

Caution prevailed in the cotton futures market yesterday as traders awaited the outcome of the coal miners' strike and revisions in the Office of Price Administration. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts held within a narrow price range and closed at the session's low levels, 2 to 10 points under Saturday's final quotations.

The Broadway Theatre, which had been leased by Prudence Bonds Corporation to Michael Todd for a year, starting Aug. 1, will continue to be operated by its present lessees, the Shuberts, it was announced yesterday by the Shubert office.
WASHINGTON, June 1 -- American shipyards broke all records in May by turning out 175 merchant ships totaling 1,782,000 deadweight tons.

Substantial orders for Fall dresses were placed yesterday as arriving buyers began to fill manufacturers' showrooms. Additional showings of new lines, including sportswear, will be made during the next few days. This week for most producers will correspond to the period immediately after July 4 last year, the earlier current showings allowing some five to six weeks of additional time for production.

Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston upheld yesterday a jury verdict that had been attacked on allegations that one of the jurors had been drinking and left his hotel room while the jury was locked up. In doing so, the court sustained the conviction of three men and two corporations, and exonerated the accused juror.

Consolidated net profit of the Richfield Oil Corporation and its subsidiaries in the March quarter amounted to $654,596 after all charges, according to the report issued for publication today. The profit is equal to 16 cents a share on the 4,010,000 shares of capital stock and compares with $539,394, or 13 cents a share, for the first three months of 1942.

NORTHFIELD, Vt., June 1 -- Recalling the part played in the Philippines by a graduate of Norwich University, Admiral Dewey, hero of Manila Bay in the Spanish-Amrican War, Lord Halifax, British Ambassador to the United States, speaking today to the Army aviation students in training in Norwich, pledged the cooperation of Great Britain in restoring those islands to this country
DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -- Henry Ford, who will be 80 years old next July 30, came back today to the presidency of the Ford Motor Company after a lapse of twenty-four years

MONTREAT, N.C., June 1 (AP) -- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States, saying that Roman Catholic Church leaders had represented to the State Department that Protestant missions in predominantly Catholic Latin-American countries were a hindrance to the "Good Neighbor" policy and ought to be discontinued, voted today to file a vigorous protest with the department.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- After hearing officials of the War, Navy, and Labor Departments, Maritime Commission and the National Labor Relations Board protest today against various provisions of the Smith-Connally strike and labor control bill, the House Military Affairs Committee decided to go into executive session at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow to consider amendments to the measure, which is scheduled to go before the House at noon.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Navy Department confirmed today the previously reported lowering of physical requirements for men inducted through Selective Service, which had led Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Director, to predict yesterday that induction of fathers would be slightly delayed next Fall as a result of the new source of recruits.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Senator Wagner is expected to introduce a bill tomorrow to provide for a new national social insurance system, it was learned today. The measure will be supported by the American Federation of Labor. Representative John T. Dingell of Michigan will sponsor it in the House.

DETROIT, June 1 (AP) -- Lou R. Maxon, director of OPA information and aide to Administrator Prentiss M. Brown, denied today charges made by R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (CIO), that he had received special food rations for his cottage at Onaway, Mich.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Two college professors, both with a background of specialization in economics, today were named to succeed J.K. Galbraith, Harvard Professor of Economics, who resigned from the OPA supposedly as the result of a demand for the elimination of "professors and theorists" from the price control agency.

CINCINNATI, June 1 -- Mel Ott's revised battlefront looked excellent on paper late this afternoon as the Giants squared away at the Reds in a twilight game, but inside of one hour and twenty-nine minutes Master Melvin was to learn that it still contained a few flaws.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The greatly diminished effectiveness of German submarine warfare in the last two months and the spiritless performances of the Luftwaffe in the same period have led some officials here to the belief that a fundamental weakness has developed at last in the Nazi war machine.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, May 31 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Japanese apparently are persisting in an attempt to develop a German-style submarine offensive against the long Allied shipping routes to the South and Southwest Pacific war theatres, informed sources here believe.

Apropos of the $10,000 award for the best novel submitted to Harper by July 1, the publishers received a singular suggestion from one prospective author in New Mexico. She wrote: "Will you make me an advanced payment of about $200 so I can hire a hand to keep the irrigating going while set under a tree and write the book'?

ALBANY, June 1 -- State Commissioner of Agriculture Chester Dumond today charged the New York Regional Office of War Information with disseminating "totally false information" concerning the farm gasoline crisis in this State.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 2 (U.P.) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Four New York University alumni who will receive alumni meritorious service awards a week from today at the university's 111th commencement were honored last night at a dinner at the Washington Square Faculty Club.

The four-story garage building at 527-51 West Thirty-third Street, running through to 528-56 West Thirty-fourth Street, occupied under lease by the Federal Government for the storage of Post Office trucks, was bought in at foreclosure sale yesterday by the plaintiff, the Empire Trust Company, as temporary trustee, on a bid of $1,352,312.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Vice Admiral Raymond A. Fenard, chief of the French Naval Mission to the United States, said today that, contrary to the general impression here, there were "thousands" of experienced regular members of the French Navy already in North Africa who could quickly supply the crews for the French warships under Admiral Rene Emile Godfroy at Alexandria, which have just joined the Allied forces.

What is a good breakfast? This was the question recently put to seven authorities in the food field by the Cereal Institute, a research organization to which leading cereal manufacturers belong. Here are the answers -- interesting, informative and even, in a few instances, somewhat bewildering:

PERHAPS it is not very discreet in time of war to look askance at an Army policy, but the Army appears to be pursuing a very shortsighted and stiff-necked procedure in refusing to permit soldiers in the colleges to engage in intercollegiate athletics.

LONDON, June 1 -- Barely four years after he had installed his brother, the Duke of Kent, as Grand Master of the United Grand Lodge of England, King George VI officiated at Freemasons' Hall today at the installation in the same office of the Earl of Harewood, his brother-in-law.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -- The Senators scored a run in the tenth inning to defeat the Indians, 3 to 2, before 10,309 spectators tonight. The victory brought second-place Washington within a game of the league-leading Yankees, who were idle.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Sales of all retail stores increased 2 per cent in April, as compared with March, and totaled $5,194,000,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. The increase, however, was regarded as less than usual, considering the late Easter this year, and tile department's seasonally adjusted index declined from 160 to 157, based on the 1935-1939 average.
NEW DELHI, India, June 1 (AP) -- A Tenth United State Air Force communique:

LONDON, June 1 (U.P.) -- A lengthy oral protest by the British Consul General at Tangier against Spanish authorities' arrest of 300 Jews and Arabs of pro-Allied sympathies was regarded today as showing a sharp stiffening in British policy.

Last night's program by the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre was a "Fokine Festival" consisting of two more than familiar works by the great Russian master and two considerably less familiar ones. In the former category were "Scheherazade" and "Prince Igor," and in the latter, "Igroushki" and "Les Elfes."
The month of June, always significant in the history of European warfare, opened yesterday as signs of new operations multiplied.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 1 -The Nieman Foundation at Harvard University announced today that Nieman fellowships for newspaper men would be restricted this year to men outside the draft in age or military availability, whose intention for study is to equip themselves to deal with post-war problems.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- For most taxpayers the tax collection bill adopted by the House will mean that they will remit more in income taxes during war years than they would have under the present law. The abatement will not show in the taxpaying history of the average person until his income falls off, he loses his job, or at death.

Three years of war, according to announcements made in Parliament yesterday, cost the British Empire forces 92,089 killed, 226,719 missing, 88,294 wounded and 107,891 taken prisoner, or a total of 514,993. The toll of prisoners was swollen by Indian troops taken at Hong Kong and Singapore.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 1 -- Despite a near record of civilian goods output last year, the furniture industry, with 13 per cent of its facilities converted, turned out about $100,000,000 worth of war items, Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants serving the industry, reported here today.

THE BRITISH MEDITERRANEAN FLEET, June 1 (UP) -- The famous "gentlemen's agreeznent" that nmobilized the French bttto squadron t AJex2Ildria 'after the collapse of France has come tots logical conclusion with Admiral Godfroy% decision to bring his nine warships to the side of the Allies.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A Navy communique today told of further progress of Army troops in mopping up the Japanese remnants on Attu Island in the Aleutians. Three Army spearheads beat down ''weak resistance" Sunday and effected a junction on the shores of Chichagof Harbor, killing more than 400 Japanese during the advance.

LONDON, June 1 -- The House of Commons devoted its whole session today to the many problems confronting British civil aviation's approach to the post-war era. Then, it is feared, this country, which has been devoting itself to the production of war planes, will be outclassed in the field of commercial carriers by the United States.

When the Board of Estimate takes up the plans for the Stuyvesant Town housing project at its regular meeting tomorrow it will be confronted with a question profoundly affecting the future of this city. The question is how far the municipality can afford to go to induce private enterprise to provide medium-income housing.
I am merely another student at on of New York City's public high schools. But I have noticed a pretty important thing.

LONDON, June 1 -- Venereal infection among United States troops here is at least 25 per cent higher than at home. In the first four months of this year 2,060 soldiers have been temporarily out of action because of it, not counting those who took their problem to civilian doctors.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Evaporated and condensed milk were added to the list of rationed canned goods today in an order intended by the Office of Price Administration to insure adequate supplies for infants.

Serious war work is fun for 200 city high school girls. As junior service groups in child care courses wind up in seven different centers, the girls are now receiving Civilian Defense Volunteer Office certificates attesting their preparation as volunteers.

DAVID, son of Jesse and King of Israel, lived some three thousand years ago. He was a poet, a musician, a soldier, a great ruler, a lover of women and a devout worshiper of his God. So long ago did he live, so far back behind the obliterating mists of time, that what kind of a man he was is a matter for each man's own imagining.

Eugene Lyons, former Moscow correspondent, now editor of the American Mercury, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury that a book on Soviet Russia by Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, showed "a type of Soviet propaganda" by its omission of certain data in the presentation of Russian conditions.

As a result of the public's experience with rationing and conservation, post-war demand for consumer goods will be based on value and not necessarily on price, J.N. Bauman, vice president in charge of sales for White Motor Company, Cleveland, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Sales Executives Clubs in the Hotel Roosevelt.

New York City retailers are virtually on strike against the purchase of butter while wholesalers are trying desperately to unload large stocks on which prices will be rolled back about 5 cents a pound on June 10, it was learned in the trade last night.

LONDON, June 1 (U.P.) -- The British, who thought it rather silly that some Americans became excited over sweater girls in war plants, were all worked up today over whether London shop girls must wear stockings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 -None of the Rodgers and Hart score of the stage musical, "Higher and Higher," will be used by RKO in its film version, which, with Tim Whelan producing and directing, will get under way next month. A set of seven new musical numbers is being written for the picture by Jimmy McHugh and Harold Adamson.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 (AP) -- A thrilling steal of home in the fourteenth inning by shortstop Huck Geary, after the bases had been loaded with one man out, gave the surging Pirates a 5-4 victory over the Braves today.

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Trading in rye futures today on the Board of Trade was at a slower pace than late last week, and the market showed an easier undertone. July opened fractionally higher and went to a new seasonal peak, but broke sharply on profit-taking and at one time prices were off 1 1/2 cents a bushel from the early top.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 1 -- The shattering weight of the great American air offensive was directed against the Italian mainland again yesterday, when strong formations of Flying Fortresses wrecked the airdrome and freight yards at Foggia, eighty miles northwest of Naples and 440 miles from Tunis.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 2 (AP) -- British light bombers and fighters carried the Allied air offensive to Western Europe by daylight yesterday after the Royal Air Force's heavy bombers had remained inactive for a second night.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- Detailed regulations designed to extend the 48-hour week to all branches of the steel industry by Aug. 1 with a consequent addition of the equivalent of 50,000 workers to the labor market were issued today by Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Commission chairman.

WEST POINT, N.Y., June 1 -The Axis powers "see the handwriting on the wall" in ceaseless aerial bombing by Allied planes, General Henry H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Force, told the largest graduating class in the history of the United States Military Academy at commencement here today.

The use of occupational therapy in restoring both civilians and soldiers to physical and mental health is illustrated in an exhibition to be opened today at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 1 -- Axis efforts to crush the Greek patriot forces have met with new and unabated resistance. Appeals issued jointly by the German occupying authorities and the Quisling Athens government for Greek man and woman power to enlist for work in German factories have had no voluntary response whatever.

NEW DELHI, India, June 1 (U.P.) British and Indian troops have inflicted considerable casualties on the Japanese in a series of localized engagements during the past ten days, with enemy units attempting to drive toward the Indian border from the Myittha Valley area of Western Burma, a British communique disclosed today.

Harding C. Woodall, Walter V. Millette, David L. Skinner and Franklin T. McClintock have been elected vice presidents of Harriman Ripley Co. They are, respectively, manager of the buying department, New York sales control manager, syndicate manager and manager of the buying department.
Leighton McCarthy, Canadian Minister to the United States, has come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Washington.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 1 -- The United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture made public tonight a 500-word declaration of principles, in which the delegations from the forty-four participating nations stated their belief that its goal of freedom from want could be achieved.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 36 per cent last week in comparison with a year ago, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The week, however, contained six business days, against five last year, in as much as Memorial Day fell on a Saturday in 1942.

Lieut. Col. William O'Dwyer, on leave from his office of Kings County District Attorney while serving in the Army was endorsed last night for re-election in the Fall by the executive committee of the Kings County committee of the American Labor Party.

The Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors will open its third annual exhibition with a preview at 4 o'clock this afternoon. This show, held at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street, opens to the public tomorrow and will continue through June 26.

Beginning with Memorial Day it is a satisfaction to think that our holidays for a period of four and a half months will be impersonal holidays, and not some eminent American's birthday or bicentennial.

CHUNGKING, China, June 1 (AP) -- The Chinese, expanding one of their greatest victories of the war, were thrusting forward tonight over a great Central China front, enveloping Japanese troops falling back in north Hunan Province and annihilating a Japanese regiment and additional mixed cavalry and engineering forces that had sought to cover the enemy's retreat in southern Hupeh Province.

LONDON, June 1 (U.P.) -- Naval observers noted today that the Allies might be "over the hump" in the Battle of the Atlantic and that the power of the submarine might continue to decline because of new and secret Allied weapons.

The dispute between the Milk Wagon Drivers Union and milk dealers in the metropolitan area involving the refusal of the drivers to comply with the order of the Office of Defense Transportation for "skip-a-day" deliveries to save gasoline was submitted yesterday to the National War Labor Board by Ralph T. Seward, impartial chairman of the Metropolitan Milk Distributors Commission.

Edward W. Scheer, president of the Reading Company, said at the annual meeting held at Philadelphia yesterday that the board of directors several years ago had agreed upon a policy of debt reduction rather than increase the common dividend, which has been at the rate of $1 a year for several years.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The first day of the second nation-wide coal strike in a month ended today with bituminous operators and the United Mine Workers of America belligerently attacking each other in public but at a stage of greater progress toward a settlement of their dispute than at any time since the Appalachian joint wage conference opened in New York March 10.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A gain of 16 per cent in sales of independent retail stores in April as compared with April, 1942, was reported today by J.C. Capt, director of the census, based on reports from 19,968 stores, not including department stores.

LONDON, June 1 -- Andrew Michalapoulos, who has just resigned as Minister of Information in the Greek Government in exile, said in a speech at a meeting of the Anglo-Greek Parliamentary Committee tonight that more than 100,000 persons had died of starvation in Athens, whose population was formerly just under 1,000,000.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 2 (AP) -- Thrusts by air, artillery and ground troops spurred action on the Russian front yesterday, bringing death to nearly 1,000 Germans, the midnight Soviet communique reported today, while a news broadcast told of sharp engagements in the Caucasus in which Nazi counter-attacks were beaten back.
CHUNGKING, China, June 1 (AP) -- A communique:
A large apartment in 580 Park Avenue has been rented by Luis Tamayo, consul general of Collombia, South America. Reba E. Minford, broker, arranged the lease.

LONDON, June 1 -- United States Army nurses in the European theatre of operations are receiving a new type of training to prepare them for front-line duty. They are learning how to detect booby traps and hidden mines, how to distinguish poison gases and counteract their effects, and how to fight fires in case they are caught in incendiary raids.

MOSCOW, June 1 -- The eve of what is expected to be Germany's third effort at a crushing offensive against the Soviet Union finds Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's vaunted Luftwaffe gradually changing from an offensive to a defensive force in its essentials.
NEW DELHI, India, June 1 (AP) -- A communiqie:

Barnard College Class Day exercises were held yesterday at Barnard Hall, preceding the formal Columbia University graduation ceremonies. Margaret Jackson, president of the senior class, made the salutatory address, and Denise Donegan presented the class gift, an American flag and a Barnard College flag, to the college.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- United States submarines, adding to the unrelenting toll of Japanese shipping that has been taken since Pearl Harbor, have sunk seven more Japanese vessels, including one destroyer, and have probably sunk another ship, the Navy Department announced in a communique tonight.
CHICAGO, June 1 (AP) -- The Phillies beat the Cubs for the sixth time in seven games this season when they walloped 12 hits today to win, 7 to 2.
No drama, no detail will be omitted today when the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office hurls itself into its "I Am Serving" recruiting campaign for 500,000 workers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (AP) -- An annual saving of more than $310,000 is possible through combined operation of the St. Louis County Gas Company and the Union Electric Company of Missouri, subsidiaries of the North American Company, Dudley Sanford, treasurer of St. Louis Gas and assistant treasurer of Union Electric, testified at a Securities and Exchange Commission hearing today.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

LONDON. June 1 (U.P.) -- Stockholm dispatches based on information from Berlin expressed doubt today that Germany would he able to essay its promised decisive offensive on the Russian front this Summer and suggested that instead the German command would engage in one or more powerful local offensives in small sectors such as Leningrad.
American cartoonists attacked the problem of absenteeism yesterday afternoon by opening an exhibition of 200 cartoons at 535 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON. June 1 (U.P.) -- Stockholm dispatches based on information from Berlin expressed doubt today that Germany would he able to essay its promised decisive offensive on the Russian front this Summer and suggested that instead the German command would engage in one or more powerful local offensives in small sectors such as Leningrad.
American cartoonists attacked the problem of absenteeism yesterday afternoon by opening an exhibition of 200 cartoons at 535 Fifth Avenue.

LONDON, June 1 -- With Britain and the United States now about ready virtually to bomb Germany and Italy out of the war, Home Security Minister Herbert Morrison delved today into not so ancient history to refute Reich Minister Joseph Goebbels's latest propaganda line that it was Britain and not Germany who initiated warfare on civilians from the air.

ST. LOUIS, June 1 -- Harry Walker walloped a first pitch from Rube Melton atop the pavilion roof in Sportsman's Park today for a two-run homer that gave the Cardinals a twelfth-inning, 11-9 triumph over the Dodgers and cut Brooklyn's first-place lead over St. Louis to only half a game.

THE TIMES of May 30 reports Senator Byrd as criticizing farm subsidies because these do not prevent inflation but actually are inflationary of themselves. The Senator says, "It (subsidies) will be ineffective unless linked with a strong anti-inflationary policy in the control of wages," and adding that with such a policy "these subsidies are not necessary."

A major overhauling of the Japanese industrial structure is about to be carried out because "the war situation is extremely grave and the demands for increased production of vital war materials have become extremely urgent and important,'' the Tokyo radio declared yesterday in broadcasts to Japanese areas, according to the Office of War Information.

SEATTLE, June 1 (AP) -- Joseph E. Davies, President Roosevelt's emissary to Joseph Stalin, arrived here today en route to report to the President in Washington, it was announced by Major Frank E. Williamson, commanding the Air Transport and Control Detachsent.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) -Navy communique 397:

ALGIERS, June 1 -- Marcel Peyrouton, Governor General of Algeria, resigned his post to General Charles de Gaulle tonight and became a captain of the colonial infantry. The startling shift in politics symbolized General de Gaulle's mastery of the political situation here.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- A Great Lakes shipyard, a Gulf Coast ship repair yard, a leading naval architect, and twelve manufacturing companies have received for the first time the Maritime Commission's "M" pennant, the Maritime victory flag and labor merit badges for the workers for excellence in production.

LONDON, June 1 -- The stock markets here were quiet today. Diamond shares reacted further on profit-taking following resumption of interim dividends. De Beers deferred fell to 20 1/2 and Anglo-America Investment to 66s, but Consolidated Diamonds was 3d better at 39s.

OBERLIN, Ohio, June 1 -- Wendell L. Willkie said here today he had not decided whether to enter Ohio's Republican Presidential primary and declared he might get the party's 1944 nomination "in spite of myself."

The Clergy Conference on Negro Welfare, in a resolution announced yesterday, called on President Roosevelt, the Secretary of War and the Secretary of the Navy to take steps to "insure to all Negroes in the services the actual elimination of all forms of racial discrimination from all branches of the service."

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The Senate, in its first major tests of What the State Department views as the real American attitude toward United Nations post-war collaboration, gave two resounding votes of confidence today to the Reciprocal Trade Agreements program and indicated approval of its extension for two more years without congressional interference or restrictions.

Part of the current profits of American industry should be used for advertising in Latin America, even though lack of shipping space and product shortages make it difficult to accommodate new business at this time, according to Irwin Vladimir, who will leave on June 6 for an extensive trip to South America.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- To conserve an additional 30,000 barrels of gasoline daily in twelve Northeastern States Prentiss M. Brown, Price Administrator, today ordered a one-half gallon cut in the unit value of "B" and "C" coupons issued to motorists who use their cars for occupational driving. The cut, from the present three gallons each to two and one-half gallons, takes effect at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

The resignation of J. Kenneth Galbraith, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration, probably will result in an early adjustment of the food industry's pricing problems, trade observers predicted yesterday. While explaining that the development provided only grounds for hope, the food men pointed out that they had held Dr. Galbraith primarily responsible for the pricing regulations which have "strangled" their operations.

Women in war jobs in various areas are beginning to show signs of fatigue and emotional strain, according to Miss Florence Williams, director of health and recreation for the United Service Organizations division of the National Young Women's Christian Association, who returned yesterday from a six-month field trip through centers in the East, South and Midwest.

LONDON, June 1 -- High and low officers in the Royal Air Force and the air forces of the British Dominions figure prominently in the King's birthday honors list to be published tomorrow, the thirteenth list of its kind since George's reign began.

A new issue of $3,000,000 of municipal light and power revenue bonds was announced yesterday by Tacoma, Wash., for award on July 2. The issue will be dated July 1, 1943, and will mature each Jan. 1 and July 1 from 1944 to 1963, with the interest rate to be named by the bidders, at not to exceed 4 per cent.

LONDON, June 1 -- Casualties among all ranks of the British Empire fighting forces in the three war years between Sept. 3, 1939, and Sept. 3, 1942, totaled 514,993 and over half of that number were from the United Kingdom, according to figures given to the House of Commons today by Clement R. Attlee, Deputy Prime Minister.

The resignation of J. Kenneth Galbraith, deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration, probably will result in an early adjustment of the food industry's pricing problems, trade observers predicted yesterday. While explaining that the development provided only grounds for hope, the food men pointed out that they had held Dr. Galbraith primarily responsible for the pricing regulations which have "strangled" their operations.

Women in war jobs in various areas are beginning to show signs of fatigue and emotional strain, according to Miss Florence Williams, director of health and recreation for the United Service Organizations division of the National Young Women's Christian Association, who returned yesterday from a six-month field trip through centers in the East, South and Midwest.

Mayor La Guardia's rejection of budget economies worked out by the City Council with the assistance of the Citizens Budget Commission, the Commerce and Industry Association and other civic and business groups, whose stake in the welfare of the city at least equals that of the Mayor, fails utterly to point the way to easing the burden of the taxpayer.

Appointment of a panel of five auditors to serve in insolvencies in the fur industry was announced last night by J.D. Silberman, president of the American Fur Merchants Association, at the meeting of that organization. Heretofore, the practice has been to have one auditor, whereas under the new plan selection will be made from the panel.

CHUNGKING, China, June 2 (AP) -- After the gloom and anxiety of last week the elation in Chungking over the current Hupeh fighting is wonderfully refreshing. Although the Japanese are still in control of the rich Tungting Lake rice bowl and still may show some economic and strategical profit on the May operations, the Chinese counter-offensive proves two things that encourage everyone:

LONDON, June 2 -- Deputy Prime Minister Clement R. Attlee assured questioners in the House of Commons today that Britain did not intend to meddle in the relations between Poland and Czechoslovakia. He said that the Polish claim to parts of Silesia and Slovakia, annexed at the time of the Munich agreement, was "a matter which concerns the two Allied countries" and declined to intervene as suggested.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Senators blasted out a 13-1 victory over the Indians before 14,000 fans tonight. The victory advanced Washington within 8 points of the pace-setting Yankees.

Right at home in the slow footing, William Ziegler Jr.'s homebred colt, Breezing Home, captured the Cheops Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday to complete a long-shot riding double for Johnny Gilbert, who previously had won on Assailant. Breezing Home returned $25.10 after he had dashed six furlongs in 1:12 3-5 before 11,902 persons who wagered $1,038,401 on the eight races.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 2 -- Fritz, the 5-year-old German shepherd dog owned by Clifford H. Lee of 33 South Virginia Avenue, was in his own backyard again today after flunking the Army's K-9 Corps training course at Gulfport, Miss.

CINCINNATI, June 2 -- For a few fleeting moments today the Giants put on a gaudy show as they blasted the redoubtable Bucky Walters from the mound inside of two innings roll up an imposing total of five runs.

ST. LOUIS, June 2 -- The largest crowd ever to see a game under the Sportsman's Park lights turned out for the Dodgers-Cardinals finale tonight and was rewarded in reverse by a 3-2 Brooklyn triumph, which restored Libby Leo Durocher's crew to a game and a half lead over the second-place Redbirds.

An investment in a tall loft building in the midtown area featured realty activity in Manhattan yesterday when the twenty-one-story store and loft property at 264-66-68 Wset Fortieth Street was sold by the New York Insurance Company to Kenlene, Inc., a client of Omnia Properties, Inc.
Details of the sales of two large properties on the west side of Manhattan -- an apartment building in Twenty-ninth Street and a commercial structure in Columbus Circle -- were revealed yesterday.

After months of wearying negotiations, French unity seemed at last to have been achieved when Generals Giraud and de Gaulle met in Algiers a few days ago with the avowed purpose of establishing a central executive committee under their joint leadership. But the first product of their meeting is one of those political crises which plagued France before the war and wrecked her during the war.
MURDER POINT, Attu Island, May 20 (Delayed) (AP) -- Whatever else the Japanese have been doing on Attu for the last year they must have spent most of their time digging in the mushy tundra.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 2 -- To all practical intents and purposes the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture completed its work tonight when it made public the recommendations of the fourth and last section to report, that an permanent organization.

Frank C. Russell, a coffee importer and vice president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, was appointed yesterday as director of the New York District for the Office of Price Administration at a salary of $6,500 a year.
With buildings on Park and Madison Avenues attracting several tenants, apartment leasing yesterday centered on the East Side.

Rudy Simms of De Witt Clinton was awarded the George F. Pigott Jr. Trophy as the outstanding performer for the second year and five track records were broken in the fifth annual Brooklyn Automotive High Schools track and field meet held yesterday at McCarren Park, Brooklyn. Seven open high school events also were staged.
CHUNGKING, China, June 2 (U.P.) -- A. communique:

Under devastating air assault since the fall of Tunisia, the Italian outpost island of Pantelleria has now been attacked twice within forty-eight hours by Allied warships. Bombardment from the sea is almost invariably the final phase of the preparatory process that leads to invasion.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 2 -- Reichsfuehrer Hitler's Fortress Europe needs a calm 1943 in which to recover from bomb raids and the crippling Russian and North African defeats, according to the Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm Tidningen, in a dispatch on talks with "initiated German circles."

MINNEAPOLIS, June 2 (AP) -Joseph E. Davies, President Roosevelt's emissary to Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union, arrived here late today by plane en route to Washington. 1VIr. Davies came here from Seattle on an Army bomber and was taken to a downtown hotel, where he planned to spend the night_ He declined to make any statement to newspapermen. T-y.j. journey will be resumed tomorrow.

MOSCOW, June 2 -- Because of the exigencies of war a substantial measure of decentralization has occurred in Soviet administration, increasing the responsibilities and authority of town and city governments and regional councils. Central authorities are now urging responsible provincial organs to go even further and show initiative without asking themselves too frequently "What would Moscow say ?"

OLD LUKE is not very old at all. However, Luke Appling always referred to himself as Old Luke from as far back as he can remember. The Chicago White Sox shortstop was almost beaned at the Stadium the other day, but he came up with his ever-present grin and the remark, "Shucks, they can't hurt Old Luke."
Humphrey O. Clarke, third secretary of the British Embassy, and Mrs. Clarke have come to the Pierre from Washington.

The 20 per cent cut in bus service has caused such difficulties in Queens that a direct appeal will be made to Washington to exempt that borough from the Office of Defense Transportation's order because of the special nature of its transportation problem, Mayor La Guardia said yesterday after conferring at City Hall with Borough President James A. Burke.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Consolidated gross operating revenues of subsidiary companies of the Standard Gas and Electric Company for the twelve months ended on March 31 were $108,493,045, an increase of $6,751,681, or 6.64 per cent, compared with the preceding twelve months, it was announced today.
The German Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
Ascension Day will be celebrated today and special prayers will be offered for our armed forces in churches of many denominations. For Roman Catholics today is a holy day of obligation.

Emil Cooper and Jose Iturbi have been added to the list of conductors previously announced for the forthcoming Stadium concerts season. Mr. Cooper will direct four concerts on the nights of Aug. 5 to 8, and Mr. Iturbi will conduct a Dance Festival for Argentinita, Monday, July 12.
JERSEY CITY, June 2 (AP) -- Baltimore handed Jersey City its fifth straight defeat, 1-0, tonight, winning behind the superb four-hit pitching of Ed (Specs) Klieman, who registered his eighth victory.

While raw fur prices continue firm, increasing resistance to further advances was reported yesterday pending the completion of current efforts to develop a price ceiling plan satisfactory to all branches of the industry, including retailers. Buyers in the coat and suit industry in particular were showing greater opposition to increases on trimming furs.

YOUNG BILL WHITE went to Harvard, where he presumably had the advantage of contact with Copeland, Kittredge and other great teachers of the written word. But the sonorous utterance and the lofty Johnsonian period bored the daylights out of this son of a great shirt-sleeve editor of the Kansas plains. Ever since he left college he has been entranced with the short, broken, casual rhythms of common speech.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2 -- The First National Bank of Pleasantville will be consolidated soon with the Pleasantville branch of the County Trust Company of White Plains, subject to formal approval by stockholders and States and Federal banking authorities, according to an announcement this afternoon by Arthur C. Hoyt, president of the First National, and Andrew Wilson Jr., president of the County Trust.

One man was killed and four small shacks were destroyed in an explosion followed by fire at 9 A.M. yesterday at the Staten Island plant of the Unexcelled Manufacturing Company, in peacetime manufacturers of fireworks, but at present under war contract with the government.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 2 -- Addressing the members of the Sacred College of Cardinals, gathered in his private study to present their wishes on the occasion of his name day, Pope Pius XII this morning again appealed to the belligerents on both sides to retrain from the blind furies of total war, including aerial reprisals, and to return immediately to the path of Christ before it was too late.

Rationing of child care services was suggested yesterday by Mrs. Juan T. Trippe, chairman of the child care section of the Welfare Council of New York City, as a possible solution for the "maldistribution" of existing facilities. Examples were given in Mrs. Trippe's report at the annual meeting of the section held in the Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The statement on the soft-coal dispute, unanimously adopted by the War Labor Board, was as follows:

One of the outstanding style trends of this wartime season is the rolled-up sleeve -- of Navy nurses in Guadalcanal, of welders in Connecticut, of Waacs in Washington. In some cases this is only a figurative fashion, but in many more it is an actuality -- and the feminine arms that emerge from these sleeves are plunged deep into the grimy work of winning a war.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, June 1 (Delayed) (AP) -- Again a B-17 came home, beat up and shot up, and the crew said, "When we stopped rolling, all of us, with shaking knees, just sat on the ground and thanked God."

The National Conference of Entertainment for War Activities will open a two-day session this afternoon at The New York Times Hall. The object of the conference is to bring about a greater mobilization of the entertainment industry to further the war effort.

NEWARK, June 2 (AP) -- The Bears and Syracuse battled to a 3 -- 3 draw in a ten-inning twilight game tonight that was called because of dimout regulations. But for more than an hour after play had ceased no one knew whether or not the game was complete.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The War Department gave out today the names, with next of kin, of 107 United States soldiers missing in action and of 124 held prisoners of war. The missing men were in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American and Southwest Pacific l areas.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 2 -- Seven broad food groups necessary to maintain good health and vitality, based on standards of nutrition approved by the most modern scientific knowledge, were listed today in a report of the consumption section of the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture.

A sixteen-man team was named yesterday to represent the United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia in the annual metropolitan A.A.U. senior track and field championships scheduled for Saturday at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

BOSTON, June 2 (AP) -- The Red Sox and Browns made their, four-game series an all-overtime affair today by splitting a double-header, the visitors taking the opener, 7 -- 4, in twelve innings and the home forces the 3-2 nightcap in ten frames.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 2 -- The mightiest sea and air weapons in the Mediterranean theatre -- the British fleet and American Air Force -- combined their forces to batter Italy's tiny island fortress of Pantelleria with hundreds of tons of bombs and shells yesterday.

Oil supplies on the East Coast declined sharply in the week ended on May 29, partly as a reflection of the breaking of the "big inch" pipeline in the floods. Measured in terms of stocks available in 1940 and 1941, adjusted for seasonal variations, the index for East Coast supplies was 25.7 on May 29, according to the American Petroleum Institute, comparing with 26.8 the week before and 27.1 two weeks before.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Having defeated five moves to impose wartime and post-war restrictions on the reciprocal trade agreements' program, the Senate, by a vote of 59 to 23 today passed the House-adopted resolution to extend it for two more years without Congressional interference.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Because beef slaughter during the last month was 10 per cent less than expectations, preferred cuts of beef, such as steaks and roasts, will call for surrender by the housewife of from 2 to 3 points a pound more after this Saturday, but many kinds of lamb, veal and variety meats will be rated at 1 point less, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

The fashion show that scored yesterday noon on the Starlight Roof at the Waldorf-Astoria was an all-American team. The featured fabric was cotton; the star, the military beau. The "home run" was made by the girl he loves. The diamond -- well, it was the one she wore on her finger.
There weren't many salt-water fishing captains that were smiling yesterday, but at least a few had not entirely lost their sense of humor.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Senator Byrd of Virginia said today that millions of Americans are asking the question: "Who is the boss of the United States of America; is it John L. Lewis or President Roosevelt?"

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- When the President created the Office of War Mobilization in the form he did, with James E. Byrnes at its head, he chose one from a number of diagrams. Whether his choice was the best from the standpoint of organization will probably never be demonstrated unless this design is unsuccessful and is successfully replaced by one of those that Mr. Roosevelt rejected.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Virtual paralysis of the war production program will follow any serious curtailment of coal supplies to the steel, synthetic rubber, aviation gasoline and numerous other war industries, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, asserted today.

MADRID, June 2 (U.P.) -- Reliable reports from the French Riviera said tonight that the Italian garrisons on Pantelleria had been ordered to action stations to meet an imminent Allied invasion attempt.

NEW DELHI, India, June 2 (AP) -- The story of a Japanese attack on American airmen who parachuted from a crippled bomber was told here today in an official dispatch following an account given by the only known survivor, Sergeant Marvin W. Beckman of Inglewood, Calif.
LONDON, June 2 -- From the Admiralty came an encouraging report today on the progress of the war at sea.

Paul Mifsud, 28 years old, an ex-convict native of Malta, was sentenced by Judge John J. Sullivan in General Sessions yesterday to a State-prison term of fifteen to thirty years. The judge, noted for his urbanity, scathingly denounced Mifsud as "the lowest, most vicious criminal" ever brought before him.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 2 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., lend-lease administrator, reported today that lend-lease exports of food in the first four months of 1943 totaled 2,700,400,000 pounds, but in most commodities represented only a small proportion of total suply.

A parade pulsing with color and spirit brought out ticker tape and confetti to remind the city of days of peace. The Mayor hurled insults at men deferred from military service who are not active in the city's protective services. So opened the dramatic "I Am Serving" recruting campaign for 500,000 volunteers, launched yesterday by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -The prevailing view in official circles here today was that the arrival of [General Charles de Gaulle in Algiers, instead of representing the consummation of French unity, as some had expected, was only the beginning of a probably prolonged negotiation.

Sixty years ago this morning, to the day, Edward H. Holland, a little damp from the late Spring warmth, reported for work in Solon Palmer's perfume factory at 376 Pearl Street, in the shadow of the new Brooklyn Bridge.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- The War Production Board has completed plans to dim the lights on a moment's notice if the coal strikes make such action necessary, it was stated today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 3 (AP) -- The noon communique:

General compliance with the order of the Office of Defense Transporation for skip-a-day milk deliveries was reported yesterday for most of the metropolitan area by William J. Clark, ODT regional manager in charge of motor transport, as milk dealers carried out their program of no doorstep deliveries for the day.

Minnesota awarded yesterday $2,700,000 of rural credit deficiency fund certificates of indebtedness to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and including Stone Webster and Blodget, Inc.; Eastman, Dillon Co., Hemphill Noyes Co., B.J. Van Ingen Co., Inc.; Beacon, Stevenson Co. and Edward Lowber Stockes Co.

ALGIERS, June 2 -- The seven Frenchmen who form the executive committee of the French Empire will meet at 10 A.M. tomorrow to try once more to fuse the warring de Gaulle-Giraud movements into a united French regime.

CHUNGKING, China, June 2 (U.P.) -- Japan's unsuccessful offensive in Central China has cost the invaders more than 30,000 casualties in the past two weeks, a Chinese spokesman said today, adding that Chinese forces "continued to inflict staggering losses on trapped enemy remnants in the middle Yangtze Valley."

LONDON, June 2 -- Sir Wilson Jameson, chief medical officer of the Health Ministry, said in an interview today that the general health of this country continued to show an improvement despite nearly four years of war. One important factor in this improvement, he said, was the simple but excellent diet imposed by the exigencies of war.

Discussions are in progress to increase from $35,000,000 to $55,000,000 the amount of a Regulation V loan to the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation and extend the period over which the funds will be available for borrowing by the company, it was learned yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 2 -- J. Addison Young, Supreme Court referee, ordered the continuance this afternoon of the trial of divorce suits brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey and Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey when physicians agreed that no purpose would be served by adjourning the trial for a month as Mrs. Dempsey's "complete nervous collapse" probably would reoccur on the adjourned date.

Miss Margery P. Stoddard gave a luncheon yesterday at Trouville for Mrs. William K. Procter of Harrison, N.Y., who will leave next week with her husband for England, where Mr. Procter will enter the British Army and Mrs. Procter will join the Motor Transport Corps.

Felicia Sorel, who has not danced hereabouts for several seasons, gave the first of two recitals last night at the Labor Stage Theatre, assisted by Riccardo Sarroga, a young Negro from Colombia; Wallace House. folk singer and guitarist, and Frank Green, blues singer and pianist.

BEAUMONT, Texas, June 1 -- Some time yesterday the nation started the production of the second 100,000 airplanes since it began re-arming in 1940, Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, said here tonight as he and other Federal officials ended the third day of their tour of war industries of the Gulf Coast.

Alternating periods of strength and weakness studded the stock market yesterday, and, while "peace" issues managed to hold a firm line, the general tendency elsewhere was to admit small inroads in values. Activity in lower-priced stocks, but not necessarily in the speculative fold, kept volume above the million-share line on the New York Stock Exchange and accounted for the broadness of the session.
LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

King George's list of birthday honors reflects the momentousness of the air service. To it goes the largest share. Sir Hugh Dowding, Air Marshal in the perilous and finally triumphant days of 1940, is made a Baron. He was retired last year at his own wish. No distinction would be too great for his service.

LONDON, June 2 -- A British Overseas Airways transport plane, with the actor Leslie Howard reported among its thirteen passengers, was officially declared overdue and presumed lost today after reporting in a final message at 11 A.M. yesterday that it was being attacked by an enemy aircraft while en route from Lisbon to England.

Sharp reductions in bus service in New Jersey and Westchester were announced yesterday as the lines moved to comply with the order of the Office of Defense Transportation for a 20 per cent curtailment of mileage.

Harper will issue on July 7 Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's "Resistance and Reconstruction," the story of his people's heroic struggle against Japan. The publication date is the anniversary of the Marco Polo Bridge incident in 1937 when the Japanese began their armed invasion.

Holding the terms fair to all concerned, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins approved yesterday a plan to terminate litigation by minority stockholders of the Universal Pictures Company, Inc., by merging the company into its parent holding concern, the Universal Corporation.

An effort will be made to override Mayor La Guardia's veto of virtually all of the $10,864,905 cuts made by the City Council in the city's $753,071,123 budget, Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the Council, promised yesterday as a flood of protests against the Mayor's action poured in.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- By a vote of 211 to 163, the House of Representatives today adopted a rule calling for immediate consideration of the Smith-Connally strike and labor control bill. Consideration of amendments to the measure will begin tomorrow, with a possibility of a final vote at the day's end.
LONDON, Thursday, June 3 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
The Wednesday Finnish communique, as broadcast from Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

NEWARK, N.J., June 2 -- By the end of this year the average American family should be putting into war bonds 25 per cent of its net income after taxes. Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. asserted here today at a press conference, during which he denied reports that serious friction had developed between Treasury officials and the Federal Reserve System over a recently set up plan placing bond sales on a State basis.

Language is becoming more sinewy and spare under the war strain, as we should expect it to do. The headlines in recent weeks have taken on a sturdy grass-root face. They speak of the roll-back of prices, of the President's hold-the-line order, of withholding and forgiving.

Milton Solomon, former Deputy City Controller, took the General Sessions witness stand yesterday in his trial on the charge of trying to "shake down" the Triangle Appliance Corporation for $8,000 on the promise to kill an amendment before the City Council that would have ended the concern's virtual monopoly of the sale of stirrup pumps.

Two new films will arrive in Broadway theatres this morning. At the Capitol, the attraction will be "Bataan," a topical Metro production dealing with the American stand in the Philippines. Heading the film's all-male cast are Robert Taylor, George Murphy, Thomas Mitchell, Lloyd Nolan, Lee Bowman, Robert Walker, Desi Arnaz, Barry Nelson, Phillip Terry and Kenneth Spencer.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) -- Spokesmen for the canning industry told a Congressional committee today that OPA regulations affecting their operations had been drafted without consulting them and had proved unfair and unworkable.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- Grains had a heavy undertone early today on the Board of Trade, but turned strong late in the session. Rye was up around 1 cent a bushel from the bottom and closed at the top with net gains of 1/8 to 1/4 cent. Wheat and oats finished unchanged to 3/8 cent up, the July deliveries showing the most strength.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 2 -- Columbia is planning a picture under the title "Lebensraum," which will deal in a prophetic vein with the international tribunal that may be set up at the peace to punish those responsible for war atrocities.

The culinary art is undergoing a renaissance, what with the shortage of servants as well as the increase in the number of brides. Even the New Yorkers who used to "eat out of a tin" are learning to cook -- some of them in the experience-is-the-best-teacher manner, some of them by enrolling in a school and systematically attending classes.

Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, "accepts the ultimate objective of communism and belongs psychologically and morally to the group that advocates it," but is short of 100 per cent in his advocacy, the Rev. Dr. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of Georgetown University, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury.

PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP) -- Scoring three runs in the ninth, on a home run by Elbie Fletcher with a mate on base, Al Lopez's triple, two walks and Frank Colman's single, the Pirates scored a 3-to-2 triumph tonight over the Braves before 10,000 fans.

For a fellow who only a year ago was pleading for work as a free agent, the left-handed Jack Wade is faring right handsomely, thank you. At the Stadium yesterday, before 5,042 fans, the 30-year-old hurler set down the Yankees with five hits as the White Sox came from behind to beat the home forces, 2-1, counting one run each in the eighth and ninth innings.

ALBANY, June 2 -- Transfer of Empire City's Summer race meeting, June 28 to July 24, from the Yonkers track to Jamaica was asked today by Judge William F. Bleakley, counsel for the Empire City Racing Association. He said the request was caused by the drastic curtailment of gasoline allotted to commercial vehicles used to van horses from the Long Island tracks to Empire.

CHICAGO, June 2 -- The candy industry will be able to hold its ground during the coming year in spite of government restrictions if manufacturers will use their ingenuity in adapting substitute materials to their products. This appeared to be the consensus of opinion at the opening session of the National Confectioners Association wartime conference here today.

MOSCOW, June 2 -- Some indication of the improved aerial situation on the Eastern Front, as compared with the last two years, can be given by the recent series of bombings of German lines of communication by the Red Army's Tactical Air Force, which apparently has been concentrating considerable attention on sorties behind the Smolensk, Bryansk and Orel sectors of late and nibbling away at the Wehrmacht's lines of communication from the rear.

PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) -- Rookie Southpaw Frank Overmire held the Athletics to five hits today while his Tiger team-mates blasted fourteen for a 7-to-2 triumph. It was Detroit's third victory in the four-game series and tightened the Tigers' hold on third place.

The Home Owners Loan Corporation sold the three-family house at 1141 Forest Avenue, in the Bronx, to John Nicholas through Samuel Cowen, Inc., and George James, co-broker. The one-family house at 374 East 142 Street was purchased by John Dorsay through Samuel Cowen, Inc., and Maude Beebe, co-broker.

The 8,000,000 prisoners who have been thrown into German industry and agriculture are "the greatest of all fifth columns" and a "nucleus of resistance standing at Germany's throat, ready to join the invading armies of freedom," Constantin Joffe, author of "We Were Free," a documentary volume of French prisoners in German prison camps, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Overseas Press Club, at the Lotus Club, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street.

When the bill for renewal of the reciprocal trade program came before Congress this Spring Secretary Hull expressed the hope that there would be "strong nonpartisan support for this nonpartisan legislation." There was. The measure passed the House on April 13 with the approval of 145 Republicans, or two-thirds of the party representation in that chamber.
CHICAGO, June 2 (AP) -- With three hits each, Babe Dahlgren and Danny Murtaugh paced the Phillies to a 6-to-5 victory over the Cubs today to conclude the four-game series.

Reorganization of the direction of the war program, through the establishment of the Office of War Mobilization under the leadership of James F. Byrnes, came none too soon, according to the National City Bank of New York in the current issue of its monthly bank letter.

WESTFIELD, N.J., June 2 -- The body of Rollin C. Dean, formerly director of the purchasing department of the Rockefeller foundation in New York, was recovered this morning from the Connecticut River at Suffield, Conn., according to word received here today by Chief of Police John R. Schreiber from the Connecticut State Police at Hartford.

LONDON, June 2 (AP) -- Spitfires, Typhoons and Mustangs shot up eleven locomotives and ten barges and destroyed an armed trawler, and damaged three others in daylight sweeps today over Northern France and off the Netherland coast, the Air Ministry announced.

LONDON, June 2 -- Despite the "whines from Germans all over the world" the Allies must exact restitution in kind from Germany for the unprecedented economic looting in occupied countries, Viscount Maugham told the House of Lords today.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin F. Schreiber reserved decision yesterday on an application by Moreland Commissioners William F. Bleakley and Herman T. Stichman to compel James F. Schlesinger, secretary and treasurer of the Bendiner Schlesinger X-ray Laboratories, to produce books of the company showing cash disbursements from Jan. 1, 1940, to May 4, 1943.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 3 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers yesterday gave the Japanese airbase at Wewak its third heavy raid in a week of air assaults against enemy strong-points along the Northeast New Guinea coast, dropping twenty-four tons of bombs that started fires indicating destroyed or damaged aircraft and ammunition dumps, it was announced today.

As another step in assuring essential supplies for civilian economy, local War Production Board officials are pressing for exemption from CMP regulation No. 5 of a variety of items, such as flashlight batteries and bulbs, twine, small electric motors, staplers and similar products, it was learned here yesterday.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 2 -- The report of the consumption section of the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture, made public today, stated that better nutrition was a primary concern of every government in the world.

Although the production of whisky was discontinued in October to permit conversion of distilling plants to the manufacture of alcohol for war purposes, supplies of whisky in bonded warehouses are adequate for three to four years on a rationed basis, Allied Liquor Industries, Inc., a nation-wide liquor trade association, reported yesterday.

The most immediate and principal concern of Latin-American business men with regard to the post-war period is whether exporters here will then offer credit terms equally attractive with those of British and German traders Franklin Johnston, publisher of the American Exporter, declared yesterday.

In announcing a change in name of the Advertising Council yesterday, Chester J. LaRoche, chairman, said the goal set for this year was to double the $250,000,000 contributed by advertisers and media during 1942 to explain the war to the people.

A tight supply situation in both book paper and newsprint was described yesterday by George S. McMillan, secretary of the Association of National Advertisers, at the organization's wartime conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. The ink situation is satisfactory but the typesetting field has been plagued by the manpower and transportation problems common to all industry today, he said.

Pledging an endeavor to maintain standards set by the New York Navy Yard in Brooklyn, Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly yesterday became its commandant at a noontime ceremony in the yard, attended by American and United Nations naval officers.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- A "paper-skinned" Coast Guard cutter, commanded by a skipper from New York City, recently shepherding a large and important convoy across the North Atlantic, out-manoeuvred, out-shot and sank a German submarine, then plucked from the water forty Nazi seamen who were screaming "Halp!" and "Wasserbombs!" the Navy Department disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Following is an analysis of the tax bill as agreed upon by Senate-House conferees and sent by Congress to the President for his signature:

The fifth annual Churchman Award, given by that religious magazine for "the promotion of good-will and better understanding among all peoples" was presented last night to Mme. Chiang Kaishek at a dinner at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Chalky Wright of Los Angeles, former world featherweight champion, boxed four fast rounds with Tommy Mills yesterday in completing his training for his fifteen-round clash with Phil Terranova of the Bronx tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.
The Italian Wednesday communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The American Rolling Mill Company and most of its subsidiaries did a record volume of business in 1942 with net sales of $180,978,867, an increase of $11,800,628 from the $169,178,239 volume for 1941, Charles R. Hook, president, reported in the forty-second annual statement to stockholders issued for release today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- All persons subject to the jurisdiction of the United States, including American citizens in foreign countries, who had an interest in any property in a foreign country on May 31 were required today by the Treasury to file a report on Form TFR-500.

The recent order of the Office of Defense Transportation suspending private bus service for apartment house dwellers has affected almost 20,000 families in the Bronx. Because many of the tenants now are forced to take public buses to subway lines they have demanded a reduction in their rent, and some landlords voluntarily have reduced rentals to offset the added transportation cost, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- Women's hosiery will be less plentiful, less varied and shorter in 1943, the Office of War Information stated today. But there will be "enough to meet clothing needs."

As an actor, motion picture director and producer here and in England for more than a generation, Leslie Howard was equally successful on the stage and screen and equally popular on both sides of the Atlantic. Especially noted for his romantic roles, he divided his time between this country and England until 1939, when he returned to England to make a series of war pictures for the British Government.
WASHINGTON, June 2 -- At least 1,500 Japanese have been killed on Attu Island by United States Army troops, but only four were captured alive, a Navy communique reported today.

DETROIT, June 2 (AP) -- A War Labor Board panel, with the industry member dissenting on all major issues, recommended to the national board today the appointment of a permanent impartial umpire to act in disputes between Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers, C.I.O., and urged that the check-off of union dues and "a standard maintenance of membership clause" be included in a working contract.
LONDON, June 2 -- The stock markets here remained quiet today.

LONDON, June 2 -- Labor disputes cost wartime industry in Britain and Northern Ireland 1,527,000 working days last year, an increase of 448,000 over 1941, when the total working days lost through strikes numbered 1,079,000, according to statistics issued by the Ministry of Labor today.

LONDON, Thursday, June 3 -- The Germans hurled 500 planes against the big central Russian base of Kursk yesterday in five attacks and lost 123 of them, Moscow announced early today. The Russians reported losing thirty defending fighters in the series of battles.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 2 -- The lessons of Buna and Guadalcanal emphasized for American military leaders in this area the importance of the individual soldier of the platoon and squad in the jungle-amphibious warfare that is demanded by conditions in the tropical Pacific.
LONDON, June 2 -- The stock markets here remained quiet today.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- While she desires close and friendly ties with the other Scandinavian countries, Norway "alone among the northern countries fights actively on the side of freedom" and it is inconceivable that she should adopany foreign policy not in accordance with her continued friendship with her Allies "not only to the west but also to the east," said Wilhelm Munthe de Morgenstierne, the Norwegian Ambassador, in a statement today.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- The entire Russian aircraft industry has just undergone drastic reorganization, and all warplane factories have been readjusted to the assembly line and conveyor belt system of production. This represents the first time that the assembly line has been used in Soviet aircraft plants.

Consent decrees barring ten laundries in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Mount Vernon from charging more than ceiling prices were signed yesterday by Judge John Bright in Federal Court at the request of the Office of Price Administration.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- Navy communique 400:

A new issue of $180,000 of water and sewer revenue-refunding bonds was scheduled yesterday by Dearborn Township, Mich., for award on June 15. The bonds will be dated May 1, 1943, and will mature serially from May 1, 1945 to 1972, with the interest rate to be named by the bidders at not to exceed 4 per cent.

Application for an appropriation of $534,000 to care for 7,500 children of working mothers in the Buffalo area is now on its way to Washington for ratification after approval by the regional office of the Federal Works Administration and the State War Council, Miss Elsie Bond, chairman of the committee on child care for the council, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics' comprehensive index of prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent during the week ended May 29. The all-commodity index stood at 104.0 per cent of the 1926 average, 5.3 per cent above a year ago.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, June 3 (AP) -- Admiral William F. Halsey today dispatched a message of tribute to the U.S.S. Enterprise, the aircraft carrier cited by President Roosevelt earlier this week for a year of effective fighting against the Japanese.

One of the tragedies of city life, especially for children, is the fact that city dwellers are deprived of the beauty and inspiration which come from association with wild creatures. But one bird of rare beauty has the courage to come and live in New York. The duck hawk from time to time makes its nest within city limits.

Potato shipments have increased considerably during the week -- 357 cars arrived between Saturday and Wednesday -- and authorities believe that most families will be able to buy at least a pound or two of this highly prized vegetable. Supplies are still not adequate to meet demand, however.
Large coal consumers in the New York City area are not facing any immediate danger of a shortage because of the coal strike, according to a survey by The Associated Press yesterday.

One of these days Herr Goebbels may suddenly find himself wondering about his favorite propaganda crack. It concerns the England which is prepared to fight to the last American. That is for American consumption.

The motorist who drives to work when he could use the subway is more than an irritant to his patriotic neighbors, it developed yesterday -- he is also a wrinkle in the brow of the Office of Price Administration.

The rocky little Italian island of Pantelleria again felt the weight of Allied bombs yesterday as American and British air and naval forces continued the "softening-up process" which is an essential preliminary to any invasion.

The Milk Wagon Drivers Union has contributed generously to all community drives. Its members have 10 per cent of their pay deducted for bond purchases. As a body it donated thousands of pints of blood to the blood bank. The patriotism of its members is amply demonstrated by the record.

The Four Freedoms Show, in the International Building of Rockefeller Center, 630 Fifth Avenue, run in connection with the War Bond Drive, will be opened to the public today. It will continue until June 13 and will be free of charge.
HOT SPINGS, Va., June 3 -- Following is the text of a summary of the results of the United Nations Food Conference as prepared by the parley's secretary general:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 3 -- Six men of the R.A.F. missed their breakfast Tuesday morning, but won the honor of taking the last German prisoners in North Africa, nearly three weeks after the Tunisian campaign had ended.

Seventy-five volunteer nurses' aides were capped last night at special ceremonies at St. Vincent's Hospital School of Nursing. They heard the Rev. John J. Curry, assistant director of the division of health of New York Catholic Charities, emphasize that "yours is a contribution that the nation acknowledges with reverence and gratitude."

In a featureless session yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange prices of cotton held within a 5-point range as small buying orders by the trade and commission houses were about balanced by slight hedge selling. Five of the six active contracts ended with a net loss of 1 point each and the May closed unchanged from Wednesday's final quotation.

The annual bazaar of the Junior Congregation of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, arranged for this season as a Latin-American Fiesta, will be held this afternoon and evening at the community house of the church in East Fiftieth Street. Tea will be served during the afternoon and Mexican dishes will be features of the evening refreshments.

BOSTON, June 3 -- A government plan to allocate among wholesalers and retailers the entire production of anthracite coal was decribed here today by speakers at the annual convention of the New England Coal Dealers Association.

The country will stand solidly behind the President's uncompromising order to the miners to return to work. It is hard to believe that the strike can continue in the face of this order. As the President reminds the miners, they are engaged in essential war work. It is their duty no less than that of their sons and brothers in the armed forces to fulfill their war duties.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 3 -- International control of mineral resources after this war is the key to lasting peace in the world, Dr. Charles Kenneth Leith, head of the metals and minerals branch of the Office of Production Research and Development of the War Production Board, declared here tonight.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- Except for one wholly unconfirmed Axis radio report of rescue, hope waned today for possible survivors of the missing Lisbon-to-London airliner that was attacked by a Nazi sky raider Tuesday over the Bay of Biscay.
