Consolidated net income of the Greyhound Corporation for the first three months of 1943, according to the report to be released today, amounted to $1,941,405 after Federal taxes and all charges. This is equivalent, after preferred dividends, to 68 cents a share on an average of 2,784,353 shares of common stock outstanding in the period.

DETROIT, June 3 -- Edsel Bryant Ford, only son of Henry Ford, left the major part of his stock holdings in the Ford Motor Company to a foundation for educational and charitable purposes, and thus the total of inheritance, transfer and other taxes to be assessed against the estate will be reduced to about $12,000,000.

The fifty-four family apartment house at 2680 Heath Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by E. Matthews to Betti Grossman through Snyder Co., brokers. The property was conveyed subject to a first mortage of $146,000. Stanley Ide LaCov represented the seller.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Bureau of Standards said today that experiments indicated that alcohol and other substitutes for gasoline might find a limited use, at least in the Eastern gasoline shortage area. They will be a good deal more expensive than gasoline but, with engine adjustment, could be expected to give as good performance, it said.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Secretary Hull hailed today Congressional renewal of the Trade Agreements Act as "a splendid manifestation of national unity in favor of practical international collaboration now and for the future."

Mar-Kell from the Calumet Farm was able to carry top weight of 122 pounds for a mile and a sixteenth and that's all there was to the running of the $6,450 Top Fight Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

While the emphasis in the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office drive for 500,000 additional volunteers shifted yesterday to the need for aircraft spotters and workers in the filter stations, the Army announced that some time during next week there would be a drill and test blackout with three Army bombers participating.
DETROIT, June 3 (AP) -- A walkout which has virtually halted production of Rolls-Royce aircraft engines and Packard marine engines at Packard Motor Company here continued tonight.

With mounting strength in the motors, a resumption of the rally in the rails and fresh recovery among the sugars, the stock market pierced yesterday its previous high points by a slight margin. The upturn was not general, however, for there were several faltering spots, so that on balance the share list closed only irregularly higher.

Being a visiting British aviator, I wish to express my appreciation of the wonderful hospitality which Mayor La Guardia, the citizens and the civic organizations of New York are extending to the Allied personnel of the services within your gateway.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 3 -- The reactions of a former world's heavyweight boxing champion to finding his wife in a darkened bedroom with a barefooted prizefight promoter were related here today before Supreme Court Referee J. Addison Young at the trial of divorce suits brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey and Hannah Williams Dempsey, former actress.

Ethel Barrymore's repeat engagement in "The Corn Is Green" will end at the Martin Beck on Saturday night, June 19, after a run of fifty-six performances over a period of seven weeks. Next Autumn Miss Barrymore will again take the Emlyn Williams play on tour, which will start Sept. 20 at Worcester, Mass., and end May 27 at Schenectady.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 -- The distribution of stolen and counterfeit ration stamps in this area was dealt a hard blow by the police here today when they uncovered a huge cache of gasoline, fuel-oil, and sugar coupons in the tailor shop and the home of a local man.
The new senior tennis season will have its start today in the holding of the annual Sears Cup matches for women at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills.

Sharply attacking the existing custodial set-up in the New York City public schools, the Rapp-Coudert committee's survey staff, headed by Dr. George D. Strayer, is recommending in a 700-page report to be published soon, the abolition of the present system of paying custodians lump sums from which they can hire their own helpers and over which the Board of Education has no control.

Russell H. Potter, who was displaced on Wednesday as acting district director of the Office of Price Administration, announced last night that he was resigning all connections with the OPA because of "political machinations designed to create a political patronage machine" there.
CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The American victory on Attu Island puts the Army "within striking distance of Japanese territory," Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson pointed out at his press conference today. He observed, however, that it was a "pretty long distance" and warned that "no inferences on my part" should be drawn.

With only one classification registering a loss, advertising linage in eight New York newspapers rose 14.3 per cent last month over the corresponding 1942 period, according to a compilation yesterday based on Media Records figures. Six of the eight newspapers experienced increases.

Because of the substantial volume of government priority orders placed recently with American Woolen Company, civilian deliveries of men's Fall worsted fabrics will not be completed until December or even later, instead of during the third quarter, Charles H. Silver, general sales manager of the company, announced yesterday.
The audacity of the manager of a small movie theatre in flouting Major La Guardia's ban on bingo has brought him scores of nonpaying patrons and six summonses, it was learned yesterday.

Albert (Chalky) Wright, ageless campaigner from Los Angeles, will make his bid for another chance at the featherweight championship that he once held when he tackles Phil Terranova of the Bronx in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. The New York State Athletic Commission recognizes the clash as an elimination battle and the winner will be paired with Willie Pep, who now holds the 126-pound title.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -Told that important negotiations with Russia hung on prompt action, the Senate today amended and returned to the House a $6,273,629,000 lend-lease appropriation bill which would bring direct appropriations for that purpose to nearly $25,000,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 3 -- Ann Sheridan, Dennis Morgan, Jane Wyman and Jack Carson, the four principal members of the cast of Warners' "The Animal Kingdom," production of which was halted last week after a Hays office warning of censorship, have been switched to "Shine On Harvest Moon," the forthcoming film biography of the late Nora Bayes, which has been advanced on the schedule to start June 21 with David Butler directing.

While the Office of Price Administration in Washington yesterday ordered a reduction of one-half cent a quart in the maximum price of milk delivered to homes in the New York metropolitan area, officials of the milk drivers union indicated that milk deliveries, wholesale and retail, may be halted altogether as a consequence of the dispute between the union and milk dealers over enforcement of the skip-a-day schedule.

A joint program of fifty-two "war information" shorts, which will be furnished free of charge to 16,500 theatres at weekly intervals, was announced yesterday by Lowell Mellett, chief of the motion picture bureau of the Office of War Information, and Francis Harmon, executive vice chairman of the motion picture industry's war activities committee.

The Rev. Dr. Halford E. Luccock, Professor of Homiletics at Yale Divinity School, testified yesterday before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury that Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, had the reputation of being a liberal and not a Communist.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- "The end of the war may be much closer than some of us imagine," the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare, told a civic meeting at East Sheen today. The war hinged on four issues that might be decided in the next four months, he said, and "if we do well in all of them" the war might end rapidly.
LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- The mid-day Soviet communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

May a foreigner with widespread knowledge of European peoples -- both Axis and United Nations -- draw the attention of your readers to the fact that the damage done by the coal strike -- as measured in dollars or tons of lost production -- is only a minor item compared to the major defeat in the psychological warfare involved.

The first word from Washington by the Coordinator of Fisheries, Harold L. Ickes, regarding the possibility of obtaining extra gasoline rations for sports fishermen was contained in a dispatch yesterday.

CHUNGKING, China, June 3 (AP) -- Supported by an American-Chinese air force that dominated the Central China skies and was shooting Japanese planes down at the rate of fourteen to one, the Chinese armies swept tonight to the west bank of the Yangtze and were separated only by that great river from the main Japanese base of Ichang in Hupeh Province.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 3 -- An Allied destroyer force broke up an enemy convoy off Cape Spartivento on the southeastern coast of the toe of the Italian boot Tuesday night and sank a merchant vessel and a torpedo boat.

A Swedish correspondent in Berlin reports to his paper that Germans in high places are saying that Germany needs "a calm year." A breathing space is what they want, they remark plaintively, to repair the damage done by bombing, to redistribute their dwindling stock of war material, to train new pilots, soldiers and laborers to fill the gaps caused by four years of fighting.

ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- The last-place Browns got some help today -- in the front office -- with the signing of affable Jimmy Conzelman as assistant to President Donald L. Barnes and public relations director of the American League Club.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 3 -- Senator Jose A. Balseiro, member of the minority Union Republican party, attacked the administration of Governor Tugwell for three hours today in testifying before four members of the House Insular Affairs Committee investigating conditions here.

Post-war planning is keynoting the activities of the electric power and light industry and such plans are being formulated on the definite assumption that governmental policies will permit the continuance of the American system of free competitive enterprise, 500 members of the Edison Electric Institute were informed yesterday at their annual meeting, shortened this year to a one-day affair to conform with wartime restrictions.

CALCUTTA, June 3 -- If the coal miners and other strikers could hear what Americans in the Army here are saying about them they might not be on strike today. The language used is unprintable, but it is a simple fact that there is bitterness and anger among the soldiers which bodes ill for the American trade union movement after the war.
LONDON, June 3 -- The stock markets here were not supported today by the expected war developments and activity was restrained. However, the general tone was steady.

AT UNITED STATES FIFTH ARMY HEADGUARTERS, North Africa, June 3 (U.P.) -- General Luis M. Orgaz, High Commissioner of Spanish Morocco, visited the Fifth Army Headquarters today and saw a troop demonstration that made it perfectly clear, headquarters press relations said, that the war will be carried to the Axis until it surrenders unconditionally.

Nearly every letter that arrives from the fighting front underlines one effect of the coal strike that is as important in its way as the effect on production. We cannot afford to forget this is a war, the first in history, in which soldiers at the front, by means of the radio, know everything that goes on at home as soon as it happens.

Justice Thomas J. Whalen of the Municipal Court has been elected president of the New York University Alumni Federation, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the federation's board of directors at alumni headquarters, 22 Washington Square North.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Friday, June 4 (U.P.) -- Allied aircraft attacked Japanese shipping at Lauten on the north coast of Timor for the second consecutive day yesterday, General Douglas MacArthur's noon communique revealed today, but only two Liberator bombers were in the raiding force and bad weather generally restricted the movements of aircraft in the Southwest Pacific.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Tigers exploded for seven runs in the seventh inning to defeat Washington, 8 to 2, before 14,000 spectators tonight. Rudy York blasted his third home run of the season into the left field stands in the fifth.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 3 -- William M. Jeffers, rubber director, at the conclusion of a four-day trip through the war plants of the Gulf Coast area, said today that he expected all the synthetic rubber plants to be completed and in production by late in October and that all would be producing at rated capacities by the first of next year.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 3 (AP) -- The Arkansas-Louisiana Gas Company, Shreveport, La., and Gus B. Walton of Little Rock, a dealer in bonds, announced today their intention to purchase four operating utilities at Hot Springs, Ark., for $4,600,000.

In a five-day course with fourteen New York University students, Mrs. E. George Payne, wife of the dean of the university's School of Education, has been studying "the scientific way to do it" before she goes to her Summer home in Maine to can the harvest from the Victory garden her husband has planted there.

Denying Mayor La Guardia's statements that reductions made by the City Council in the city's $753,071,123 budget would curtail essential city services or cut jobs, Joseph T. Sharkey, Council vice chairman, invited editors of city newspapers yesterday to send accountants to check the Council's work sheets.

PITTSBURGH, June 3 (AP) -- The three-day-old walkout of coal miners is causing a daily tonnage loss of more than 2,000,000 tons, unofficial reports from eighteen coal-producing States disclosed today as industrial supplies diminished and curtailment of production appeared probable in steel, the foremost war metal.

In an interview yesterday, George T. Christopher, president of the Packard Motor Car Company, declared that, if the war was not to be followed by a period of disastrous production tie-ups and unemployment, government and business must begin now to plan the change-back to production for civilian consumption.

PLANDOME, L.I., June 3 -- It was a case of last being first in the Long Island Golf Association's best-ball tournament at the Plandome Golf Club today for Frank Graven, club champion, and Bob Buggeln, last pair to tee off, topped the fifteen other teams that played on one of the most oppressive days of this or any other season.
Mrs. Henry Iselin and Miss Patricia Iselin have come to the Plaza from Hewlett.
PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) -- Ripping into Joe Heving and their ex-team-mate, Chubby Dean, for 18 hits, the Athletics forced the Indians into sixth place today by taking a 10-to-4 victory.

LONDON, June 3 -- Virtually all phases of civilian wartime activity -- test flying, railroad and highway transportation, air raid protection work, hospital services and war savings drives -- receive recognition in the second section of the King's birthday honors list to be announced tomorrow.
CHUNGKING, China, June 3 (AP) -- A communique:

President Edwin Barclay of the Republic of Liberia will be received by Mayor La Guardia and a reception committee when he and his official party arrive at Pennsylvania Station this morning at 9 o'clock.

An annual world consumption of natural and synthetic rubber of 2,000,000 tons after the war, twice the yearly pre-war total, was predicted yesterday by John L. Collyer, president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, in an address before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at its monthly meeting, 65 Liberty Street.
ST. LOUIS, June 3 (AP) -- Murry Dickson came out of the bullpen today to pitch his first complete victory of the season for the Cardinals with an 8-to-2 triumph over the Phillies.

WASHINGTON, Friday, June 4 -- Pope Pius has created a new Catholic diocese at Youngstown, Ohio, and has named the Most Rev. James A. McFadden, now Auxiliary Bishop and Chancellor of the Diocese of Cleveland, to be the first Bishop of Youngstown.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Treasury has revised its proposal of last year for a spending tax as the principal feature of its program to raise an additional $16,000,000,000 in taxes or borrowings.

At its final revival of the season, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway last night brought back Fokine's "Carnaval" to the local scene after an absence of two years. Time was when it was probably the most overdanced little piece in the repertoire, but after its extended rest it should rightly be restored to active service, for it is inherently a charming bit of thistledown fantasy.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- An investigation into the methods by which distillers and other distributors of whisky have been pricing their merchandise in recent months was started by the Office of Price Administration today with an order to "all owners of brands of domestic distilled spirits" to file information on their pricing within the coming thirty days.

Three thousand bus drivers on lines in Manhattan, the Bronx, Queens, Staten Island and Nassau County were reported last night to be on the verge of striking unless the Office of Defense Transportation modified its order for a 20 per cent cut in bus service.

I noticed the letter of John L. Bogert, suggesting a route for an oil pipe line from Carrabelle, Fla., to Jacksonville. Mr. Bogert is evidently not familiar with the fact that this pipe line has already been completed and is now in operation.

In Maria Pass, where the Great Northern Railway crosses the Rockies in Montana, stands a heroic statue of John F. Stevens, a tribute to a trailblazer who was at once a pioneer and a civil engineer. In the Cascade Mountains another pass bears his name. With him the country loses the last of those remarkable men who gave us our continental transportation system.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Joseph E. Davies delivered to President Roosevelt today a personal letter from Premier Joseph Stalin. Well-informed Washington sources speculated that the basis for a face-to-face war strategy conference between Mr. Roosevelt, Mr. Stalin and Prime Minister Winston Churchill now has been laid.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., June 3 -- Delegations from forty-four governments unanimously adopted a "final act," comprising a declaration of principles, a resolution calling for a permanent international organization and recommendations of the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture for creating a new world order based on lasting peace and freedom from want, at the closing plenary session in the Homestead today.

Two midtown theatres will present new film attractions this morning. At the Globe the new offering is "Jitterbugs," a Twentieth Century-Fox comedy starring Laurel and Hardy. Bob Bailey, Vivian Blaine, Douglas Fowley and Lee Patrick appear in supporting roles.

PERTH AMBOY, N.J., June 3 -- How molecules of synthetic wood alcohol are mixed with molecules of ammonia to form the basic ingredient for a secret new explosive used in the "blockbusters" that are daily blasting Axis industrial plants was demonstrated here today at the du Pont Electrochemical plant.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Official reports disclose that 17,083 American soldiers are prisoners of war held by the Axis, with the large majority in Japanese hands, the War Department said today.

MOSCOW, June 3 -- Denuded as it is of overwhelming areial protection, the Wehrmacht might be expected to bring forth some effective substitute weapon as it tries for the third successive Summer to knock the Red Army out of the war.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The War Production Board's steel industry advisory committee noted today that the War Manpower Commission regulation requires consultation with WMC regional directors and unions on new employes and the forty-eight-hour week, and declared it "will have the effect of setting up a vast, unworkable bureaucracy which must inevitably seriously interfere with steel production."

CHICAGO, June 3 (AP) -- A plan of reorganization of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad Company under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act was disapproved today by Judge Michael L. Igoe. The court announced that it would, on motion of interested parties, order the plan referred back to the Interstate Commerce Commission for reconsideration.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 3 -- Hungary wants none of the Reich's war industries, if a semi-official statement from Budapest is to be believed. A statement from authorized quarters in the Hungarian capital has been issued to the effect that no changes have been made during the past eighteen months in the Hungarian industrial plants, and adds that none are contemplated.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission reported today that the nation's 136 Class 1 railroads had a net operating income of $127,059,362 for April, an increase of 25.1 per cent over the same month last year.

CHALKY WRIGHT is a refreshingly frank citizen whom the Jacobs Beach sunbathers would describe as a "character." He likes classical music and Shakespeare and he doesn't like fighting. He has made several hundred thousand dollars out of the art of fisticuffing and expects to wind up without a cent in his jeans.

Practical post-war planning will be individual planning in which each person, each small company and each corporation will plan for itself, Lammot du Pont, chairman of the board of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., declared yesterday in an address at the annual meeting of the Manufacturing Chemists Association in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

" RUSSIA is the Great Fact, perhaps the greatest of our time." In this fateful June of 1943 that marks two years of Russia's magnificent defiance of the mechanized might of Hitler's superlative military machine, supported by the industrial resources of most of Europe, few would care to dispute this truth. Russia is undoubtedly a portentous, crucial, mysterious fact, whose share in shaping the ultimate destiny of the world may be decisive.

Sixty business and professional women, who for the last year have been giving up part of their leisure time to guide service men on sightseeing tours around the city, will meet in Sloane House of the Young Men's Christian Association, 356 West Thirty-fourth Street, next Thursday at 6:30 P.M.
LONDON, June 3 (U.P.) -- Pressure on Spain's Generalissimo Francisco Franco for a friendlier and more pro-Allied attitude is believed to be increasing steadily.

NEWARK, N.J., June 3 (AP) -- Superb relief pitching for two and two-third innings by Ed Marleau enabled Newark to beat Syracuse, 3 to 2, in the second game of a twilight twin bill tonight after the Chiefs had won the opener, 4 to 2.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 3 -- Governor Prentice Cooper took steps for immediate induction of striking Tennessee coal miners today after members of the draft board in Robertson County told him that they would send no more men into the Army "until our government has taken adequate steps to meet this (strike) situation."

MINEOLA, L.I., June 3 -- Within four hours this afternoon, four military planes crashed on Long Island, causing injuries to two of the pilots and a civilian that required hospitalization. Two other pilots, one of whom parachuted into a tree, were unhurt.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A new "American Beveridge plan" in legislative form, designed to provide post-war social security from the cradle to the grave, was presented to both houses of Congress today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Renewal today of the 1941 stabilization agreement between the United States and Mexico was made the occasion by the Mexican delegation for a proposal that the United States world stabilization plan be adopted even before the end of the war as a preventive rather than a cure of monetary chaos.
The Thursday German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

The Federal Government is about to launch its gigantic attack to wipe out black markets in meat. To that end it is completing plans to set up local agents in virtually every one of the 3,073 counties of the nation.

More than 1,000,000 letters have been received from all parts of the United States by the Russian War Relief, Inc., at 11 East Thirty-fifth Street, in response to the campaign sponsored by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Wendell L. Willkie, Bishop William T. Manning and Thomas W. Lamont, to have Americans correspond with citizens of the Soviet Republic.

Milton Solomon, under cross-examination of the prosecutor yesterday in his General Sessions trial in the alleged attempted $8,000 "shakedown" to suppress the anti-stirrup-pump amendment to the city's war defense ordinance last November, told Judge James Garrett Wallace and the jury he has only a "hazy" recollection of that "double-scotch" highball party in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn that is a vital part of the evidence.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- After a day of debate on amendments to the Smith-Connally strike and labor control bill, the House adjourned today without action on any of them after one veteran member complained that no one knew what he was being asked to vote on and another asserted bluntly that "the House is in no condition to vote on anything," and delay until Monday would give members "a chance to cool off."

Liabilities totaling $696,000 were charged yesterday to Paul E. Flato, Jeweler of 1 East Fifty-seventh Street, in schedules filed in Federal court, where Flato has been adjudged a bankrupt. The Jeweler was indicted on Wednesday and pleaded not guilty, in General Sessions, in connection with the alleged larceny of jewelry valued at $125,000.

The wistful, middle-aged young man of "Berkeley Square," "The Petrified Forest" and, not so happily, "Hamlet," took with him as his plane plunged into the Bay of Biscay Tuesday morning some of the atmosphere of the forever-lost Nineteen Thirties. Leslie Howard typified a certain aspect of the between-the-war period -- not its despair, not its bitterness but its gently cynical withdrawal.

Sir William Beveridge, British economist and author of the postwar social security plan bearing his name, told 1,500 health and welfare workers yesterday that the proposed program was not a device to permit permanent retirement on an insurance income or to induce idleness and illness.

President Roosevelt thanked the amusement world yesterday in a telegram to the National Conference of Entertainment Industry for War Activities. The President's message, read by Lawrence Tibbett at the conference's first session yesterday in the New York Times Hall, said:

MOSCOW, June 3 -- The extent of the aerial warfare now taking place above the Russian front, with daily totals of plane destruction approaching the levels attained during the 1940 Battle of Britain, gives rise to considerable speculation here about the possibility that the long-awaited German offensive may materialize soon.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Lean Lon Warneke, the old Arkansas humming bird, sang a six-hit tune to the Dodgers today and made them dance to his music -- but they didn't like it. The cellar-dwelling Cubs (a designation long considered copyrighted by the Phillies) walloped Lippy Leo Durocher's league leaders, 8 -- 1, collecting thirteen hits off three pitchers.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Senator Bailey of North Carolina introduced in the Senate today a joint resolution to amend the Constitution to prohibit a President from running for a third term.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Dr. Frederick MacCurdy, 55, director of the Vanderbilt Clinic of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and Professor of Hospital Administration of Columbia University, was appointed by Governor Dewey today as State Commissioner of Mental Hygiene at $12,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Representative Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, today introduced in the House a bill to allow Waves to go overseas, to raise their highest commission to that of captain and to give them allowances and benefits similar to those granted Navy men with dependents.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- An easing of pressure against the Office of Price Administration, in Congress and among representatives of the food industry, was predicted here tonight by observers in close touch with developments both on Capitol Hill and in business circles.

Mrs. John Jay Hopkins gave a luncheon yesterday in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre for Mrs. Herbert Paul Grimm of Los Angeles. Among the other guests were Mrs. David G. Ashton, Mrs. Clarence Ross, Mrs. Esdras L. Gruver, Mrs. Robert F. Hogue, Mrs. Dorothy Hull and Miss Ethelwynne Hinckley.

Oliver Clandorf, 62 years old; his son, Frank, 36, and his son-in-law, Lyle Wilson, 35, were sentenced yesterday in Special Sessions on their recent conviction for operating two midtown hotels as houses of prostitution until the police raided them last Winter.

For many years it has been the custom of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in its weekly consolidated statement covering the sixteen regularly reporting member banks in New York City, to list commercial loans and open market paper separately.

Check transactions at the twenty-three leading cities of the country for the five-day week ended on Wednesday rose 23.4 per cent to $7,768,797,000 from $6,293,664,000 for the similar five-day week of the previous year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Father Divine soon will be obliged to find a new butcher to provide the meat served in various Harlem restaurant "heavens," it developed yesterday when Harry B. Chambers, Chief Regional Office of Price Administration hearing commissioner, enjoined Samuel Miller of 1150 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, from dealing in meats for three months beginning July 1.

LONDON, June 3 (U.P.) -- The Ministry of Economic Warfare, asserting that Germany and Japan were losing their desperate gamble to exchange vital war supplies, today disclosed that eleven Axis blockade runners had been sunk between November and the middle of May.
BOSTON, June 3 (AP) -- The White Sox ousted the Red Sox from sixth place today by opening a five-game series with a 6-4 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- White Laboratories, Inc., Newark, N.J., manufacturers of Feenamint, and its advertising agency, William Esty Co., New York, have filed a joint answer to a Federal Trade Commission complaint alleging misrepresentation.

For the last three days thousands of New Yorkers have swarmed into the Office of Price Administration workrooms at 330 Fifth Avenue, next door to the Empire State Building, to tackle the job of handling applications for War Ration Book 3.

On June 24 Simon Schuster will publish Louise Randall Pierson's eventful life story, "Roughly Speaking," a book that never would have been written were it not for a series of private letters. The letters came to light one day in January, 1941, as Max Schuster had luncheon with Arthur Krock, head of THE NEW YORK TIMES Washington Bureau.
LONDON, Friday, June 4 (AP) -- The midnight Soviet communique, as broadcast from Moscow radio and heard here by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations asked President Roosevelt today to set up a $2,000,000,000 subsidy program designed to roll back prices to the level of May 15, 1942, the date on which cost of living adjustments for labor are based.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 3 -- Appointment of Harry A. Mahnken as coach of football at Princeton University and of Richard F. Vaughan as his assistant was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, acting director of athletics. Mahnken has coached the Princeton 150-pound football team since 1937, while Vaughan is hockey coach, junior varsity football mentor and assistant baseball coach.

The discovery of an increased incidence of tuberculosis through physical examinations for the armed services and in industry shows the need for redoubled efforts in the prevention and treatment of this disease, leaders in this field declared yesterday.

When peace comes after this war, the world is not going to be automatically changed for the better because the order has been given to cease firing, the Rev. Dr. S. Tagart Steele Jr., vicar of the Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, declared in an Ascension Day sermon yesterday morning at Trinity Church, Broadway at the head of Wall Street.

Whether or not Gunder Haegg, sensational Swedish distance runner en route to this country, will compete in the national A.A.U. senior championships here June 19 and 20 is the big topic of discussion in track and field circles.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- President Roosevelt late this afternoon ordered 530,000 bituminous and anthracite miners now on strike to return to work on Monday, reminding them that they were working "for the government on essential war work and it is their duty no less than that of their sons and brothers in the armed forces to fulfill their war duties."

An improved plan for price control of furs has been submitted to the OPA by the Retail Furriers' Emergency Committee, organized by the Retail Manufacturing Furriers of America, Inc., it was announced yesterday by Charles Gold, counsel to the committee.

The Wistarians, a new Negro organization composed of Hunter College graduates, adopted a threefold program designed to promote better understanding among racial groups at their inaugural meeting yesterday. One hundred and fifty members of the group attended a reception in honor of Miss Adelaide Cromwell, first Negro instructor appointed to the college faculty, at the Hotel Woodward.

LONDON, June 3 -- Sir Frank Newsam, Deputy Under-Secretary of the British Home Office, declined today to be interviewed regarding vice conditions in Piccadilly, to which one-third to one-half of all venereal infections among the American forces in the European Theatre of Operations have been traced.

Tropical weather arrived in New York yesterday in earnest for the first time this year, the official temperature soaring to 89 degrees at 4:30 P.M. Although not a record for the date, the heat, accompanied by a high humidity, was enough to induce a state of general discomfort.

Between the government lawyers and economists who work out programs and the politicians who operate them is the hazard that occurs between the cup and the lip. The fact that a sound set of principles animates and is laid down by civil servants in formulating a plan or a policy does not necessarily mean that these principles will be a full-time guide for the political administrators.

ALBANY, June 3 -- Justice Pierce H. Russell of the Supreme Court ruled today that New York State's new legislative reapportionment law, first such statute enacted in twenty years, is invalid and unconstitutional.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 3 -- The German commandants of all strategically vital defense areas in the Balkans are hastening formation, training and provisioning of special units of shock troops designed to fight independently from a central command when cut off from supplies and communication in the course of an expected Allied invasion, according to information reaching foreign military intelligence circles and Istanbul sources in Southeastern Europe.
JERSEY CITY, June 3 (AP) -- Jersey City and Baltimore battled ten innings to a 3 -- 3 tie tonight in a game halted in the eleventh by dimout restrictions.

Asserting that Congress has not conferred such authority upon the Federal Trade Commission, the Celanese Corporation of America yesterday challenged the constitutional authority of the commission to compel the company to classify its synthetic textile products, sold under the registered trademark "Celanese," as "rayon."
CINCINNATI, June 3 (AP) -- A four-run uprising in the eighth inning saved a ball game for Johnny Vander Meer tonight as the Reds downed the Braves, 7 to 4.
LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- The condition statement of the Bank of England for the week ended on June 2, issued today, showed an increase of 1,464,000 in note circulation.
ALGIERS, June 3 -- A united government for the French Empire became a reality this morning when, after three days of bickering, the French Committee of National Liberation was formed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 3 -- A caravan, a Brazilian version of that of Lewis and Clark to settle Washington and Oregon, this one led by Colonel Flaviano Vanique, already conversant with the secrets of the Brazilian jungle, will leave for Matto Grosso July 15, self-supporting and carrying such modern appliances as radio and other up-to-date equipment.

After a distressing and disquieting interval of political manoeuvring, the two French factions in North Africa have come together again and have created a National Committee of Liberation to represent France in the grand alliance of the United Nations and to direct her energies in the common struggle against the common foe.

The functions of the advertising manager and the established techniques of advertising have been broadened as a result of the war to include a variety of tasks never previously handled by advertising departments, speakers declared yesterday at the wartime conference of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 3 -- The British people are to have the opportunity of seeing the Royal Air Force's damage to Germany through the "magic eye" used by Air Ministry experts. This stereoscopic equipment, in a small cabinet nine inches wide and eighteen inches high, enables Air Ministry experts to "read" the results of Allied air attacks on Adolf Hitler's ports and war centers.

Following is the text of the Algiers communique announcing the formation of the French Committee of National Liberation, as broadcast yesterday by the British Broadcasting Corporation in the French language to Europe and recorded by the United States Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Department store sales for the week ended May 29 were 42 per cent above the same period a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 21 per cent in the week ended May 22 compared with the same week of last year.

The form of contract and plans for the $50,000,000 Stuyvesant Town housing project to be constructed by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company on Manhattan's East Side were approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate by a vote of 11 to 5 after a three-and-a-half hour hearing brought out many heated pros and cons on the proposal.

CHICAGO, June 3 -- Grain traders placed a bullish construction today on a crop report issued by C.M. Galvin and James E. Bennett Co. suggesting that the aggregate yield of wheat, rye and oats this year would be 475,000,000 bushels less than last year's harvest.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The informal discussions between the United and Associated Nations started by the Treasury early in April are approaching a point at which all will sit around a table together to discuss "a general area of agreement," according to United States participants.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The OPA today announced that red stamp point values of some of the more popular kosher beef items would be increased June 6, brought industrial container sizes of frozen fruits and vegetables under rationing, reduced the retail prices of delivered milk in the New York metropolitan area and made other announcements of interest to consumers of food throughout the nation.

LONDON, Friday, June 4 -- The Red Army has sprung a new offensive near Temryuk on the Sea of Azov in an effort "to split German forces" clinging to the swampy Kuban bridgehead, but has not achieved any "lasting success," the Berlin radio said last night.

Representatives of American exporters who have been working on the problem of funds blocked in Spain have made considerable progress and a settlement is likely to be announced in the near future, it was reported in foreign trade circles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 214 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.
PITTSBURGH, June 3 -- The end of a painful trail still being nowhere near in sight the battered Giants moved into this Pirate lair today to find it anything but a haven of refuge.

Probably the most striking disclosure in this week's figures of the Federal Reserve System, released yesterday and covering the week ended on Wednesday, was the fact that money in circulation in the nation jumped $194,000,000 to a new high record of $17,196,000,000.

LONDON, June 4 -- Most sections of the stock markets here were inactive today before the week-end closing. Kaffirs again were the feature on Cape buying, Blyvoor rising another 5/8 to 69 3/8s, while West Wit gained 1 1-16 to 7 3/4 and Western Holdings jumped 1 1/4 to 25 3/4s.

With conservation of materials forming the main theme, early Fall millinery trends were indicated yesterday when Lilly Dache, John Frederics and Sally Victor, comprising Millinery Fashion Inspiration, Inc., presented their lines in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- Russian forces on the Donets front were reported today to hold dominating positions near Lisichansk on the right bank of the river, from which they are able to observe German troop movements. The Red Army artillery is said to be giving the enemy no respite.

A decision of interest to thousands of buyers of war bonds was handed down yesterday by Surrogate James A. Foley in the case of the estate of William J. Deyo, who died Dec. 25, 1940. The decision involves millions of dollars.

Henry (Heinzie) Teitelbaum, "court jester" of the old Lepke-Gurrah gang of racketeers that terrorized the garment and other industries in this city ten years ago, was sentenced to one year in the penitentiary yesterday by Judge John A. Mullen in General Sessions after Teitelbaum had pleaded guilty to a charge of having conspired in the gang's extortions, a misdemeanor.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 29 were 852,518 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 9,184 cars, or 1.1 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 56,897 cars, or 7.2 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 50,735 cars, or 6.3 per cent, more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, June 4 (AP) -- Axis troops attempting to wipe out General Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav guerrillas have been driven back toward Croatia and Slovenia and forced to yield 1,200 square miles of territory and twenty-one railway stations, the Yugoslav government in exile said today.

New financing here this week declined to the smallest total for any week in a month, offerings consisting of two issues of tax-exempt securities and one of industrial bonds. The three issues aggregated $8,650,000, compared with $17,977,000 for four State and municipal issues marketed in the preceding week and with $70,472,000 for a diversified list of eight issues floated in this week a year ago.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 4 -- Puerto Rico will abandon its insular agencies for land settlement, agricultural development and building up local industry if and when they are proved to be failures, Senate President Luis Munoz Marin, leader of the Popular Democratic party, told the Bell Congressional committee today.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 4 -- If a group of conscientious reporters were to travel around England gathering the views of the common people concerning an international police force, then cross the Atlantic and talk to a cross-section of the American people from Maine to California, they would find that exactly the same proportion in each country -- seventy-four persons out of every 100 -- favor participation in a world police force after the war.

OMAHA, June 4 (AP) -- Ensign Nile C. Kinnick Jr., former Iowa football star, has been killed in action. Parents of the 24-year-old flier, who was attached to an aircraft carrier, said today they received word from the Navy Department that Ensign Kinnick had been killed in action and that his body had not been recovered.

CHICAGO, June 4 (AP) -- That milk bottle at the first tee on most of the nation's golf courses this Summer will be a reminder to players to deposit a dime before each round, a procedure that may bring $5,000,000 a year into various war relief coffers.
LONDON, Saturday, June 5 (U.P.) An air raid alarm sounded in London early today.
CHICAGO, June 4 -- Blasting twenty-three hits for a total of thirty bases, the Dodgers today more than wiped out yesterday's setback by beating the last-place Cubs, 18-5.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A joint conference between railroad managements and brotherhood representatives to settle differences over the manning of Diesel locomotives and the basis of pay for enginemen working on them has been proposed by President Roosevelt.

The public inattention that has been paid to the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture should satisfy those who desired to treat the meeting at Hot Springs as a military secret. Except for the loud protests of the press against the peculiar policy of non-publicity adopted for the assembly in the first instance, its sessions aroused little general interest.

Retail trade continued active here this week, with strong consumer demand on hot-weather lines. The week, however, has only five business days against six last year because of the Memorial Day holiday on Monday. Accordingly, estimates indicated department store volume would either be about even with or slightly under the comparative 1942 week.
CHUNGKING, China, June 4 (AP) -- A communique:

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 4 (AP) -- Viscount Halifax, the British Ambassador, said here today, in commenting on the Pope's plea for humane air warfare, that the Allied aerial attack upon the Axis has become inescapable, was being directed with the greatest possible precision against military targets exclusively and was accomplishing more damage to the enemy's war potential than we probably know.
PHILADELPHIA June 4 (AP) -- Ray Mack's triple with Otto Denning on base gave the Indians a run in the eighth inning tonight and a 3-2 victory over the Athletics before 18,894 fans in Shibe Park.

Results of Operations Given by Other Concerns, With Comparative Data Net earnings of Transcontinental and Western Air, Inc., for the first three months of this year were $313,327, or 33 cents a share, after provision for Federal income taxes and other charges, in contrast to a net deficit of $310,651 reported for the corresponding period of 1942, according to a statement issued yesterday by Jack Frye, president.

TONAWANDA, N.Y., June 4 -- Joseph P. Molony, district director of the United Steelworkers of America, C.I.O., said that striking workers at Wickwire Spencer Steel Corporation's Tonawanda plant voted tonight to return to their jobs tomorrow.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 4 -- Allied warships and bombers continued the methodical destruction of Axis defensive positions on the island of Pantelleria yesterday. A British naval squadron shelled the island at dawn, while during the day relays of Mitchells, Marauders, Lightnings, Warhawks and Bostons pounded the last Italian toehold off the African coast.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- It probably will not be possible to pass another tax bill until very late in the year because it could not be considered until early Fall after the Summer Congressional recess.
LONDON, Saturday, June 5 (AP) -- The Russian Friday midnight communique, as broadcast by Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine amended the city's taxi regulations yesterday to legalize the refusal of drivers to carry passengers more than five miles, but made five exceptions to the new rule that goes into effect for a trial period of thirty days as part of the gasoline-conservation program.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A revolution in American eating habits appears in prospect.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 4 -- A long-cherished dream of schoolboy days to prepare examinations has come true for the students of the Photo Intelligence Section of the First Air Force stationed here. The catch is, however, that everybody in the class takes the examination except the student who prepared it.

Magistrate Abner C. Surpless in Queens traffic court yesterday expressed the opinion that much juvenile delinquency is the result of the statements to young people by Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt that they should develop their personality.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The bill allowing Waves to go overseas, establishing the rank of captain and granting allowances for dependents other than husbands was approved by the House Naval Affairs Committee today. The only woman member of the committee, Representative Margaret Chase Smith, Republican of Maine, author of the legislation, presided.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (U.P.) -- Senator Reynolds, chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, demanded today that the small nations of Europe and the former British and Dutch possessions in the Far East receive immediate guarantee of post-war independence.

Fishing and hunting guides can prove to be excellent companions. Game protectors and wardens can be of great service, yet the average sportsman does not have more than a casual acquaintance with many.

Furniture made in the days of Queen Victoria has been rescued from attics and storerooms to stage a spirited revival at B. Altman Co. As far removed from the parlor atmosphere of our grandmothers' days as the art of modern designing can make it, a simple collection of these pieces and model rooms are opening this week-end in the Young Homemakers Shop.

ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP) -- Mort Cooper permitted the Phillies only one hit tonight, while the Cardinals protected a two-run lead from the third inning on and hammered Charlie Fuchs for three more in the eighth to win, 5 to 0. Ken O'Dea's homer scored Ray Sanders ahead of him.

The cotton futures market held yesterday to its recent pattern of light trading and slight price movement, while awaiting settlement of legislative and political issues. Active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed with net losses of 2 to 5 points.
JERSEY CITY, June 4 (AP) -- Jim Konstanty, big Syracuse right-hander, hurled a one-hitter against last-place Jersey City here tonight, but dropped a 1-to-0 decision to Hugh East.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Dr. Horacio B. Oyhanarte, former Argentine Foreign Minister, declared tonight that he would return to Buenos Aires "as soon as possible" at the request of the Radical party to become its Presidential candidate in the forthcoming elections.

The chief importance of the United Nations Food Conference, just concluded, was symbolic. It was a demonstration to the world that representatives of the United Nations could assemble and act as a cooperative group for the purposes of peace as well as for the purposes of war.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Opponents of the McKellar bill to require Senate confirmation of the appointment of government employes who receive more than $4,500 a year, resorted to preliminary manoeuvres today to delay a vote on the measure and thus run it into a log jam of appropriations which must be passed by the end of this month.

The stock market gave up yesterday an attempt at further improvement and eased in late trading to close with fractional losses on the day. Developments in the coal controversy, which came with rapidity and suddenness, were not present during the active hours of business on the Stock Exchange, and, as a result, the list did not have the benefit of the new turn of events.
ALGIERS, June 4 (Reuter) -- General Henri Honore Giraud and General Charles de Gaulle broadcast tonight from Algiers. General Giraud said in part:

The arguments on the subject of wages as propounded by leading spokesmen, including President Roosevelt and William Green, are brought together in "Wage Stabilization and Inflation," the latest Reference Shelf Book published by W.H. Wilson Company.

"Captive Wild Woman," a Universal melodrama, will have its local premiere this morning at the Rialto. The film, directed by Edward Dmytryk, has Acquanetta, John Carradine, Evelyn Ankers, Vince Barnett and Lloyd Corrigan in the cast.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- The Giants went skidding down to another defeat tonight when Frankie Frisch's high-flying Pirates tripped them, 9 to 8, but, for the comfort of the folks along Broadway's home front, this time Mel Ott's men went down fighting.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The War Department disclosed today that 36,688 Axis prisoners-of-war 22,110 Germans, 14,516 Italians and sixty-two Japanese, were at twenty-one prison camps in continental United States.

PITTSBURGH, June 4 -- Eager to be again on the job, now that President Roosevelt's "back to work Monday" order has been backed up by John L. Lewis, this district's 36,000 bituminous miners "will answer promptly when the whistle blows," William Hargest, secretary-treasurer of District 5, United Mine Workers of America, declared tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Total income payments to individuals rose again in April, if allowance is made for seasonal influences, but the rise was less than in any month since September of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.
MOSCOW, June 4 (AP) -- The noon communique:

After observing for years the master-minding tactics of various baseball managers, both sandlot and big league, I now wish to nominate Leo Durocher of the Brooklyn Dodgers as my choice for the title of worst manager in the majors.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- With the establishment of the new United States air bases in the South and Southwest Pacific theatres, together with the development of longer-range planes, the time is approaching when air power will play an increasingly more decisive role in those areas, Artemus L. Gates, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air, predicted today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The policy committee of the United Mine Workers of America directed today that the 530,000 striking bituminous and anthracite workers go back to work on Monday.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 4 (AP) -- The executive board of the Progressive Mine Workers of America formally petitioned the American Federation of Labor executive council today to reject the petition of John L. Lewis for re-entry of the United Mine Workers of America into the A.F. of L.

CHUNGKING, China, Saturday, June 5 -- The Chinese armies, beating forward fast on both wings on the Central China front, have thrown substantially the last of the Japanese invaders out of the area north of Tungting Lake by reaching the river port of Owchihkow and have swept into Yangchi on the Yangtze to the north, the High Command announced today.
Arthur Daley deserves a word of praise for his constructive comments in THE TIMES on Wednesday concerning the Army's policy on athletic competition for its soldier-students in the various colleges.

Just see how ideas are the most useful things in the world, but also the most dangerous. Toss a new idea into the open and there's no telling how far some enthusiastic minds, not to say undisciplined minds, will carry it.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The Middle States Securities Corporation, Mutual Funds, Inc., and the Mutual Funds Trust were declared today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to have ceased to be investment companies within the meaning of the Investment Company Act of 1940.

ALGIERS, June 4 -- General Henri Honore Giraud's retention of command of the powerful North African Army was the chief point of discussion in the second meeting of the French Empire's Committee of Liberation this morning.
BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The White Sox took their second game in a row from the Red Sox today, 4 to 3, chalking up all their runs and two of their four hits in the first inning against Louis Lucier.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox expressed "fears" at his press conference today that recent encouraging reports from London on favorable results in combating submarines might be highly misleading to the public.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- By "militant presentation of the food requirements of American civilians," Dr. Russell M. Wilder, chief of the Civilian Food Requirements branch, "has obtained a larger allocation for civilians than they otherwise would have received," Roy F. Hendrickson, Deputy Administrator of the War Food Administrator and director of its Food Distribution Administration, said today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 4 -- Vichy announced tonight that Pierre Laval would broadcast to the French nation tomorrow night. The announcement caused no sensation, but rather a feeling of suspense because, since he returned to power more than a year ago, his announcements have invariably related to more concessions to German demands.

The Broadway engagement of "Blithe Spirit" will come to a temporary halt tonight at the Booth Theatre, where it will have given 650 performances. Except for a week's vacation last August, the Noel Coward comedy has played continuously since its opening on Nov. 5, 1941.

A towering homer that came to rest in the deep reaches of the lower leftfield stand was exploded by Joe Gordon yesterday at the Stadium to give the Yankees a ten-inning victory over the Browns. The count was 6 to 4. Charley Keller was on first after having nicked George Caster for a single when Gordon connected.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked formally today the registration as a broker-dealer of H. Vaughan Clarke of Philadelphia, who was sentenced in April by a Federal court in New York to ninety days in prison and fined $1,000 on charges of mail fraud and conspiracy to violate the Securities Act of 1933.

AT UNITED NATIONS HEADQUARTERS, Australia, Saturday, June 5 (U.P.) -- Allied aircraft attacked five Japanese air bases in the islands north of Australia on Thursday and yesterday, a communique disclosed today, striking their heaviest blow at Wewak, on the Northeast New Guinea coast, where eighteen tons of bombs were dropped in the third raid in a week.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 4 (AP) -- General Manager John C. Stiglmeier of the Buffalo International League Baseball Club today filed a complaint against umpire Butch Henline with league President Frank J. Shaughnessy.

AN ADVANCED AMERICAN BASE IN CHINA, June 3 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- The Fourteenth United States Air Force threw wave after wave of fighter planes yesterday against Japanese units retreating across the Yangtze River near Ichang, and Mitchell medium bombers made a destructive attack on Yochow, important enemy base in Northern Hunan Province.

While Frank C. Russell denied that he had been asked by Frank V. Kelly, Kings County Democratic leader, to take the post of district OPA manager, he disclosed yesterday that he had conferred with Mr. Kelly before accepting the appointment.
AN AMERICAN BOMBER BASE IN BENGAL, May 29 (Delayed) -- Nature has done her stuff and the rains have come and life is at its dullest in the bomber bases this correspondent has just been visiting.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Only vegetable juices are subject to point change in the new table of point values for processed foods effective Sunday, June 6, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

S.C. Stackhouse, president of the Utilities Employees Securities Company; Stanley Clarke, trustee of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and Denis J. Driscoll and Willard L. Thorp, trustees of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, announced jointly last night that they had reached an agreement with other interested parties "settling various complicated litigations and controversies" in connection with the reorganization proceedings of the Associated Gas and Electric system.

Visitors to the International Building in Rockefeller Center yesterday found an added attraction in the program of the Four Freedoms War Bond show held under the auspices of the Treasury Department and The Saturday Evening Post. The Fifth Avenue Association was the local sponsor.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The War Labor Board stated today that adjustments to equalize the pay of men and women for comparable work still may be made by employers without prior approval of the board regardless of President Roosevelt's "hold-the-line" order of April 8 by which the board's General Order No. 16, authorizing "equal pay for equal work" was in no way "impaired."

An amendment filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Gulf Oil Corporation relating to the forthcoming offering of 764,500 shares of capital stock at a price to be set within the next few days gives a complete list of the 150 investment banking firms which will be in the nationwide underwriting syndicate, headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation.

The Chinese are much like the English in one respect. Only when all hope seems to be gone is there any real hope for them. Then they turn and save themselves, but only then. The last two weeks offer another illustration.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange were asked yesterday to approve an amendment to the constitution of the Exchange that would continue the present "transaction tax of 1 per cent" in order to establish the finances of the Exchange on a sound basis.
Since you consider my offer of cooperative effort to lay the "specter of communism" a "curious" one, I trust that your curiosity will welcome a continuation of the discussion.

Another defeat in the long fight to reapportion the State Legislature comes with the decision of Supreme Court Justice Pierce H. Russell of Albany that the Legislature violated the State Constitution in laying out fifty- six Senatorial districts. The proper number, Justice Russell said, was fifty- two.

Dissatisfaction inside Argentina with the policies of President Ramon S. Castillo had existed since the conference of American Foreign Ministers at Rio de Janeira, Brazil, soon after the bombing of Pearl Harbor had pushed the United States into the war.

Despite wartime restrictions on the brewing industry, beer sales, although off sharply from normal seasonal gains, showed an increase during April of 13 per cent over the 5,030,070 barrels sold during the similar month last year, according to the latest figures of the United States Treasury Department.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 4 -- There seems to be no doubt that Pennsylvania's anthracite miners will go back to work Monday, but many expressed bitter feelings about being "used as a political football." Others thought the action by John L. Lewis was the only sensible one and that further negotiations would result in a concrete settlement.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., June 4 -- With farmers of Nassau and Suffolk Counties calling for help, the plan of Federal and State agricultural agencies to bring 250 Bahamans to their rescue has struck an obstacle in the refusal of the Huntington Town Board to permit the quartering of the alien laborers on the unused eighty-acre farm owned by Squadron C Inc. of Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Wheat became today the leader in the grain markets on the Board of Trade after a period of relative inactivity. It advanced 1 1/2 cents a bushel at one time to the highest mark in more than two months on heavy professional buying, coupled with less favorable comment on the crop in Kansas.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 4 -- Getting as much golf as he can into his remaining days in mufti, Kenneth Porter Jr. of Rockville, former Lehigh player, today won another war bond when he carried off first honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Cherry Valley Club.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Roosevelt indicated today that he favored a forty-eight-hour week with time and one-half pay after forty hours of work for 1,100,000 non-operating railway employes to bring them in line with workers in other industries.

EARLIER in the week Master James J. Dykes had warned: "Wait until Luke Sewell catches up with you. He'll be moaning plenty!" But Luke was not moaning even a little itsy bit. The manager of the Browns, perhaps reconciled to impending disaster by the departure of Verne Stephens, was strictly on the philosophical side, with no pretensions and no false hopes.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Tigers produced a score on l two singles and a pair of infield i rollers in the ninth inning to topple Washington, 2 to 1, before 14,800 fans tonight. The victory sent Detroit into second place in the tight American League race.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Roosevelt said at his press conference today that the understanding and accord between Premier Joseph Stalin of the Soviet Union and himself was excellent.

While two of his four wives smiled gleefully and another wept softly, John von Vorst, a 67-year-old stamp dealer, who formerly lived at 5 East Eighty-second Street, was sentenced in General Sessions yesterday to an indeterminate penitentiary term up to three years on his guilty plea to unlawfully obtaining a license to marry one of them, a misdemeanor.
Chalky Wright had little more than a gymnasium workout in his clash with Phil Terranova of the Bronx at Madison Square Garden last night.

LONDON, Saturday, June 5 -- The Soviet Air Force, answering the air challenge made by Germany in Wednesday's raid on Kursk, sent a fleet of 520 planes to pound Orel, enemy base eighty miles north of the Russian strong point, Thursday night, the Moscow radio reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The revolt in Argentina produced strong hopes here today that she would now align herself with the United Nations.

The average temperature in the city yesterday was 85 degrees, the highest average ever established on June 4, exceeding by one degree the average of 84 reached in 1925. Yesterday's highest temperature, 92 degrees at 1:50 P.M., was three degrees short of the 1925 record, however.

The total gross bonded debt of 343 cities in the United States with populations of 30,000 or more amounted to $8,492,000,000 on Dec. 31,1942, a decline of 3 per cent during the year, according to the annual compilation of Rosina Mohaupt of the Detroit Bureau of Governmental Research.

Reuben Greenspan, 39 years old, a merchant seaman, who was alleged to have obtained money while representing himself as a lieutenant commander in the United States Navy, was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a charge of having violated the impersonation statute, E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the New York F.B.I. office, announced.

Readership of grocery advertising has returned to normal, it was indicated by the Advertising Research Foundation yesterday in issuing its study of The Evansville Courier, sixtieth in the Continuing Study of Newspaper Reading. As the novelty of rationing wears off and housewives become more accustomed to manipulating "points," their interest in point-value data declines, according to the committee in charge.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- After two years of unremitting warfare with the most powerful military force the Axis could muster in its effort to crush the Soviet Union, the Russians today are preparing for what is generally expected, to be probably the last critical campaign of the eastern war, in which it is believed a final decision will be forced.

Outstanding track and field performers in this district will compete in the fifty-third annual metropolitan A.A.U. senior championships today at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island. Twenty-one crowns will be at stake in the meet, slated to start at 1:30.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 4 (AP) -- There will be no varsity football at Vanderbilt University this Fall, Chancellor O.C. Carmichael disclosed today.

Major Gen. Marie Emile Bethouart, the principal representative of General Henri Honore Giraud here, arrived in Algiers Wednesday. He left Washington by plane last Saturday on what was understod to be an important political errand.

LONDON, June 4 (U.P.) -- Axis forces, extending their operations against guerrilla troops in Yugoslavia, claimed without Allied confirmation tonight to have captured the partisan general staff after a bloody battle high in the snow-covered Montenegrin Mountains.

There was a tense morning during the battle of Ousseltia late last January when Captain Quentin Roosevelt won the Silver Star and the Croix de Guerre. And another tense morning one month later at Kasserine when he got the Purple Heart.

BUFFALO, June 4 (AP) -- The Federal Government alleged today that the South Buffalo Railway Company "has failed to conform its standards of operation, management and service to the requirements of the law applicable to common carriers engaged in interstate commerce."

KEARNY, N.J., June 4 -- A 14-year-old girl's week of practice with an empty ginger ale bottle and an old sock in the backyard of her home bore fruit today when the combat cargo vessel Virgo, latest addition to the nation's merchant marine fleet, was launched at the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Gasoline available for civilians in the East Coast gasoline shortage area decreased further during the week ended May 29 despite the repair of pipelines and of roadbeds washed out by the recent Western floods, the Petroleum Administrator's office reported today.
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 4 -- Joseph C. Grew, once the Ambassador to Tokyo, declared tonight that while the Japanese would be hard to defeat, it would be easy to make "a real peace" with them.

A Federal statutory court which is considering a plan for easing the payment of a $50,000,000 bond issue of the Delaware Hudson Railroad tentatively closed its hearings yesterday after listening to testimony offered by minority opponents of the plan.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 4 -- Testimony against Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey in the divorce suit brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey was completed today after more descriptions had been given of a raid conducted last Nov. 22 at a Los Angeles apartment in which Mr. Dempsey found his wife with Benny Woodall, prizefight promoter.

With both Count Fleet and Whirlaway scheduled to run, but in different races, the Belmont Park meeting will end today. Mrs. John D. Hertz's 3-year-old champion, who already has won the Kentuck Derby and the Preakness Stakes, is considered the surest kind of sure shot to take the Belmont Stakes and the mythical triple crown, as only two are entered against him and they not of the front rank.

"Continued warm." On a day when all the devils of heat and humidity were dancing their wildest corroboree, such was the oracle of our local weather gods. So in Gilbert Land a philosophic observer might ask a sufferer from lingering and humorous punishment if the oil was warm enough.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Reports that George J. Burke, general counsel to the Office of Price Administration, will be named first assistant to Prentiss M. Brown, Administrator, and that Lou R. Maxon will be made second assistant circulated here today.

The difference between a "racing tip" and a "racing selection" was judicially established yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Peter Schmuck. While the difference may "at first blush seem a microscopic distinction," Justice Schmuck ruled, it is in reality so great as to create a "bridgeless gulf" between a "tipster sheet" and a racing sheet that bases its selections on a study of all probabilities.

A new issue of $22,775,000 of electric plant refunding revenue bonds was announced yesterday by the Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power for sale through competitive bidding on June 15. The issue will be dated June 1, 1943, and will mature serially from June 1, 1944 to 1976, and will be callable on various dates to be made known subsequently.

The Appellate Division reversed yesterday the conviction of Nat Smilen, president of a retail fruit and vegetable chain-store corporation, who was sentenced to one year in the penitentiary after his conviction in Special Sessions on a charge of committing perjury before the grand jury in December, 1939, in its investigation of racketeering in that business.

RICHMOND, Va., June 4 -- Two new developments in the field of radio detection, just made public, stand out among the 650 patents issued this week, as listed in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 4 -- Revolting Argentine Army leaders drove isolationist President Ramon S. Castillo and his Cabinet into exile today and invoked martial law throughout the country after their quick seizure of power.

The millworking industry should seek to use types of lumber which are in relatively easy supply for storm doors and windows instead of continuing to insist on scarce grades, local WPB officials said yesterday in answer to complaints that the agency was restricting lumber for such products.

After two days of deliberation, the National Conference of Entertainment Industry for War Activities approved yesterday an over-all plan expected to provide for the entire entertainment needs of our civilian population and the armed forces.

The world-wide opportunities available to nurses after the war were stressed last night by Major Julia C. Stimson, former superintendent of the Army Nurse Corps, at graduation exercises for twenty members of the Nursing School of the New York Medical College, Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Though the official statement in Algiers indicating a union of both French factions bore an air of finality, it was regarded by well-informed observers here today as representing merely the current stage in what seemed likely to prove a long-drawn-out and very French drama.

From the letter of Mr. Browder, published in another column on this page, it might be supposed that this newspaper had proposed the legal extinction of the Communist party or the adoption of some other "exceptional laws to control political opinion." We made no such proposal.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 -- Ronald Colman has signed a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract to star in "Kismet," portraying the role of the Baghdad Beggar which Otis Skinner created on the stage and played in the two previous screen versions of the Edward Knoblaugh play.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5 -- That Argentina will draw closer to the democracies and possibly break off diplomatic relations with the Axis at an early date is the impression of the majority of Chileans, who tried today to piece together the truth out of fragmentary reports pouring in from Buenos Aires on the revolution that started this morning.

Sir William Beveridge, British economist and author of the cradle-to-the-grave social security plan, outlined a three-point program last night on which he said rested the main conditions for world security after the war. He spoke at a dinner in his honor in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel sponsored by the English Speaking Union of the United States.

CLEVELAND, June 4 (AP) -- First Baseman Otto Denning and utility Infielder Eddie Turchin of the Indians were traded today for First Baseman Michael Rocco of the Buffalo International League club, Cleveland Vice President Roger Peckinpaugh announced.

Eight national organizations of the United States and eleven of Canada will send delegations to a meeting to be held in Toronto beginning tomorrow and continuing through Wednesday "for joint discussion of post-war problems arising from a United Nations victory" under the auspices of the national councils on both sides of the border of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches.

The sentiments expressed on Memorial Day are very fine, and in wartime especially this day has added significance. To some this is a holiday and a day of rest. But as for us defense workers: our way of remembering the heroes of this and other wars was to go to work today and to do our bit to get this thing over with.

CHICAGO, June 4 -- Unpredictable shortages of certain other materials may force the WPB to throw out its highly controversial wool blending order of last June before many weeks are past, according to information received from well informed sources.

BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP) -- Newark took the opening game of the series, 5 to 1, from Baltimore tonight. Emerson Roser toyed with the Orioles, allowing four hits and striking out six. The Bears got eight hits, Gene Corbett leading the attack with a triple and two singles.

Axis reaction to the Argentine revolt was marked last night by extreme caution, coupled with efforts to minimize its effect by disseminating misinformation about the day's events, the Office of War Information reported on the basis of enemy press transmissions recorded by the Federal Communications Commission.

WOLVERHAMPTON, England, June 4 (Reuter) -- "I hold strongly to the view that to bomb Rome would be a crime against civilization and a betrayal of the very things for which we are fighting," Dr. E.S. Woods, Bishop of Lichfield, declared today at the Lichfield Diocesan Conference here.

FOR a generation we have been gradually forgetting that such abstractions as "social forces" and "society," being composed of individuals, naturally derive their behavior from individual characteristics. We have pursued something vaguely called "social studies" and abolished ethics and moral philosophy from the curriculum.

Mayor La Guardia made a case in point out of a letter from a Queens Village civic organization yesterday to emphasize the need for more members in the City Patrol Corps as part of the current drive of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office for 500,000 more men and women.

Unless far-sighted legislation aimed at the post-war expansion of commercial aviation is enacted by the United States "our present great aeronautical effort will be scattered to the four winds of heaven, and our national security will again be jeopardized," Colonel Edgar S. Gorrell, president of the Air Transport Association of America, told the eighth annual meeting of the association yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria, Hotel.

Peonies, now at the peak of their season, according to the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets, are available in abundant supplies for home bouquets and decorative arrangements this week-end. Florists report plentiful stocks of these beautiful big flowers in colors ranging from palest pink to richer rose and deep, velvety red.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Major Gen. Omar N. Bradley, who succeeded Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton in command of the United States Second Army Corps, which captured Bizerte, was among fourteen Army officers nominated for promotion today by President Roosevelt.
MEXICO CITY, Mexico, June 4 -- The coup d'etat in Buenos Aires created a sensation in Mexico City. Newspaper editions were sold out as soon as the news spread.

The Army recently announced that 100 more colleges have been annexed as war training centers. Unable to cope with the situation the schools have disbanded most of their major teams. Indignation has arisen everywhere and many persons are demanding to know the reason competitive sports have been dropped without a substantial effort being made to retain them.
