For its second presentation of Fokine's "Carnaval," the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo at the Broadway Theatre last night brought a bit of different casting into the picture and accomplished considerably brighter results.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The "Coronation Scot," de luxe British passenger train which was exhibited at the New York World's Fair, was presented to the United States today to provide temporary living quarters for Army officers.
Mrs. John H.P. Gould and Misses Jenifer and Josephine Gould have arrived from Lenox, Mass., and are at the Madison.
BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

Clifford Milton Markle of 64 Sagamore Road, Bronxville N.Y., a field director of the American Red Cross on duty with the Army in Africa, was killed in a motor accident in Tunisia on May 25, according to word received here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The names, with next of kin, of 650 United States soldiers wounded in action in North Africa and of 189 held prisoners of war by Japan were made public today by the War Department.

Your editorial "Educational Reforms," calling attention to the necessity of revising college admission requirements in order to conform with the needs of returned soldiers and more mature students who will seek higher education in the post-war period, points to only a minor reform need.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Giving the lie to extravagant Tokyo claims of great losses inflicted on the United States Navy during our victorious Attu campaign, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox reported today that not a single American warship was sunk or damaged during the operation.

TRENTON, June 4 -- The report on the inquiry into the State Highway Department was submitted by Governor Edison today to the Senate, Assembly and Attorney General David T. Wilentz for such action as they might "want to take in the premises under the laws and constitution of New Jersey."

Premier Hideki Tojo, addressing a Tokyo gathering, warned the Japanese people that the "present situation is increasingly serious" and urged renewed effort until the United States and Great Britain are "destroyed," the Tokyo radio said in a domestic broadcast reported yesterday by United States Government monitors.

A steadily increasing belief on the part of the American people that industry is doing a good job for the most part in helping to win the war was reported yesterday at the concluding session of the wartime conference of the Association of National Advertisers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- By a vote of 231 to 141, the House adopted and returned to the Senate today a far more stringent version of that body's Connally strike and labor control bill. Hopes of Administration forces to obtain adoption of the Senate draft were blocked by the strategy of a coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats.

The Office of Price Administration is working out a procedure, it was learned yesterday, to limit the issuance of gasoline ration coupons to a monthly quota in given areas in an effort to end the unbalance between outstanding coupons and available supply that has been a contributing factor in sporadic crises.

Payrolls of the steel industry in April set a new record of $133,275,000 for a thirty-day month. The previous record for any month was $136,813,000, made in March, 1943, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute.

A federal system of government for Europe which would be designed to guarantee peace, the demilitarization of Germany and the protection of individual rights within every country, was described yesterday in a declaration by the board of the Pan-European Conference.

With both sides presenting make-shift line-ups in the absence of ranking players, the women's team of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association defeated the Middle States representatives, 8 to 1, to retain the Sears Cup yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills.

BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- General Arturo Rawson, partner with General Pedro Ramirez in Argentina's military coup d'etat, took possession of the Government House, the Casa Rosada, while President Ramon Castillo was making a futile plea for assistance from his First Field Artillery Regiment, it was learned tonight.

Today's events: "La Traviata," afternoon, and "Carmen," evening, San Carlo Opera Company, Center Theatre; Rosalyn Tureck, piano, in Victory concert, Public Library, 5:30; Arvid Samuelson A Cappella Singers, Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, 8:30.

NEWARK, N.J., June 4 -- As a result of a series of street fights here last night between groups of white and Negro schoolboys, a 15-year-old Negro youth died today of a gunshot wound in the back while another alleged participant in the brawls was in a serious condition from stab wounds and two others were suffering head injuries.

I was among the forty-odd thousands who traveled by train to Queens Vilage on Memorial Day and then hoofed it over to Belmont Park. The trip was a revelation, for it certainly demonstrated what a mess can develop from rulings which have no flexibility.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- President Roosevelt gave every evidence of pleasure today over the reply Premier Joseph Stalin sent to his recent letter, but he still kept secret the nature of their exchange.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 4 -- The full weight of German vengeance has fallen on Lithuania over that country's steadfast refusal to contribute a so-called volunteer legion to the "Nazi crusade against Bolshevism," according to advices received here today from Kaunas through private channels.

The announcement of John L. Lewis that he will recommend the return of his miners to work on Monday closes what threatened to be the most serious crisis on the home front since our entrance into the war. The announcement also illustrates the effects of a governmental policy of firmness as compared with a policy of appeasement.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The largest daily double of the New England racing season was registered today when Allen T. Simmons' Smart Lookin and Mrs. Pete Christenson's Night Pennant returned $1,023.40 on twenty $2 tickets at Suffolk Downs. Smart Lookin was a 42-1 shot and Night Pennant paid $29.40.

BOSTON, June 4 (AP) -- The largest daily double of the New England racing season was registered today when Allen T. Simmons' Smart Lookin and Mrs. Pete Christenson's Night Pennant returned $1,023.40 on twenty $2 tickets at Suffolk Downs. Smart Lookin was a 42-1 shot and Night Pennant paid $29.40.
The editorial comments on birds which have inspired letters from your readers have interested thousands of us.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A bill extending the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation two more years and increasing its borrowing power by $1,000,000,000 was approved by the Senate Banking Committee today after it wrote in a restriction against use of any of the funds to pay subsidies in the food price roll-back program.
DETROIT, June 4 -- The National War Labor Board called upon striking Packard Motor Car Company workers today to "resume production of vitally needed war material at once."

LOS ANGELS, June 4 (U.P.) -- Lieutenant Louis Zamperini, former University of Southern California track star, was reported today missing in the South Pacific war theatre. His mother, Mrs. Anthony Zamperini, was notified.

Prices of cotton declined moderately yesterday for the fourth successive session. In dull trading, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated narrowly and closed at the day's low levels, 3 to 7 points below Friday's final quotations.

Possible changes in retail promotional methods that would eliminate "over exploitation" of merchandise are being quietly considered in conversations between retailers and government agency spokesmen, it was learned here last week.

JAMES FRANCIS BYRNES has covered the span of the three coordinate branches of government faster and more completely than any other man in the nation's history. Two years ago Mr. Byrnes was a Senator from South Carolina. One year ago Mr. Byrnes was an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

CLEVELAND, June 5 (AP) -- Steel mills in Ohio, Michigan and Kentucky were ordered today by the War Manpower Commission's regional director, Robert C. Goodwin, to arrange to go on the forty-eight-hour week immediately.
Charley Keller unfurled his eighth home run of the campaign in the ninth inning of the Yankees' game with the Browns at the Stadium yesterday, but the blow was struck in a losing cause.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 5 -- Dr. Albert Speer, Reich Minister for Armaments and Munitions, declared at a rally of war industry workers at the Sportpalast in Berlin today that the German front was being supplied with new weapons, new tanks, new bombers and new U-boats in quantities that would enable German soldiers to see the war through to a victorious end.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 5 -- Despite their inability to master the two short holes on the No. 4 nine of the Montclair Golf Club course L.A. Seton and Drake Delanoy today annexed the medal in the club's member-guest tourney, first of its kind played in this district this season.

FOR many years Soviet Russia has been developing from an International Revolutionary Society into a nationally-patriotic progressively-minded community of peoples. Economic and social progress have been concurrent with the modification of the revolutionary social ideas of the original founders of the Soviet regime.

GRANDMA has stepped out of the quiet obscurity of her kitchen onto the production line. In hundreds of defense plants all over the country she and thousands of other women well past middle age are welding, cutting steel plates, running drill presses and lathes, testing guns, standing guard against sabotage and performing other tough jobs that two years ago were largely reserved for young men.

INDICATIONS that the local season is in process of folding up abound. Helping China to help herself to a better life will be one of this country's "greatest opportunities" in the post-war world, Senator Elbert D. Thomas of Utah declared last night on the first program of a series entitled "For This We Fight" over the NBC network.

The recently organized Association of American Ship Owners has no intention of competing with any similar type organization, but was formed for the specific task of representing privately owned, non-subsidized steamship companies that heretofore have had no group representation of their own, according to a statement made here yesterday by a spokesman for the association.

ALGIERS, June 5 (AP) -- General Giraud and General de Gaulle are scheduled this evening to address a "symbolic" session of the French Chamber of Deputies, to be attended by almost fifty members of that body who are in North Africa.

VIRGINIA, BEACH, Va. -- Wartime restrictions that have touched almost every aspect of America's normal life have not affected the opportunities for recreation and old-fashioned fun-in-the-sun for which this resort town is known.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt renewed today his recommendation that contributions to the social security system be increased as a means of combating inflation.

The obstacles to immediate drafting of a European federal constitution do not apply to the Bill of Rights that must be included in such a constitution, Fernando de Los Rios, former Spanish Ambassador to the United States and chairman of the legal committee of the Pan-European Conference, declared yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 5 (U.P) -- Diplomatic and military observers here reacted cautiously tonight to the Argentine revolution, discounting first inclinations to regard the overthrow of President Ramon S. Castillo as meaning that Argentina will throw in its lot 100 per cent with the United Nations.

LIKE every one else who has gone there, this writer found "Oklahoma" a delightful show. First because of a number of especially good tunes by Richard Rodgers and excellent lyrics by Oscar Hammerstein 2d, and tasteful and suggestive decor on Americanesque motives, and, above all, because of the dancing that is so original and so expressive of genuine things that lie deep in the people and the soil.

FOR the past quarter of a century and longer, Robert M. Yerkes of Yale University has been the foremost organizer of scientific studies of ape behavior and a leading contributor to that field of knowledge.

William J. Connor, retiring president of the New Jersey State Bar Association, declared yesterday that States should not be required to respect the divorce laws of other States. Retailers are now ready to agree that earlier fears about the influence of income tax payments and war bond buying were unfounded.

CHUNGKING, China, June 5 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, turning the big Japanese offensive in Central China into a virtual rout, have seized the important enemy base of Kungan smashed into the outskirts of Ichang and cleared the invaders from a 135-mile stretch along the south bank of the Yangtze River, the Chinese High Command triumphantly announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America today confronted the country with another strike threat as of June 20 if an agreement is not reached in the meantime with the Appalachian bituminous operators and the anthracite operators.

AN afternoon spent with Lawrence Langner brought forth a variety of items about the Theatre Guild reasonably identifiable as news, which are hereby passed along. With $100,000 or so in advance sales for "Oklahoma!" the Guild is not anxious about selling the picture rights and is even giving serious thought of making its own movie version.

The Argentine revolution seems to have been about as democratic as a military revolution can be. It had to be military, for the Castillo Government held power only by the support of the army and police. When this support was withdrawn the regime collapsed.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 5 -- How does Italian morale stand today? The question is germane, since wars are won by morale as much as by materiel, and since Italy is certainly the weakest partner in the Axis. Some even conceive that she might be detached from her allegiance under the combined effects of mass bombings and threats of invasion.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 -- Carl Hubbell turned back the years with a majestice sweep of his bent and aging left arm today as in an inspired performance the Giants' veteran screwball maestro tossed a brilliant one-hitter to set back the Pirates, 5 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- President Roosevelt has received the pay-as-you-go Tax Bill finally passed by the Senate on Wednesday and has referred it to the Treasury and Bureau of the Budget for their reports and recommendations, it was stated today by Stephen T. Early, secretary to the President.

Oh, to be in Bismarck, now that June is here! In Bismarck, says the morning paper's weather report, it was just 43, while New Yorkers were watching the mercury blithely glide up to 89 and cling there. Duluth wouldn't be bad, either. Duluth, that day, had a high of 47 and a low of 44.

In Hot Springs, Va., last week there came to a formal end the first full-scale international conference in the history of the United Nations. Earlier there had been an Anglo-American conference in Bermuda on refugee problems, and there are discussions of international monetary matters yet to come.

IN time of war the Coast Guard becomes a part of the United States Navy. As such it takes part in the fighting in all parts of the world. Since this is the case, it becomes necessary to take men from civilian life and train them for the duties they are to perform, and it is with the training of these men that this book is primarily concerned.

People of the New York-New Jersey metropolitan district normally consume about 10,000,000 quarts of milk a day. Their supply depends upon a complex distribution system which brings milk from distant dairy farms to central depots, then routes it to stores and homes. The task is performed by more than 200 milk dealers and their employes.

THE inscription "Visita Presidente Higinio Morinigo Maio 1943" superimposed on a marble pillar on a 1.20-cruzeiro pale blue air-mail stamp released by Brazil gives the clue as to why it was issued -- to commemorate the visit by President Figinio Morinigo of Paraguay to Brazil last month.

PROKOFIEFF'S Classical Symphony in D, has worn as well as most symphonies written in the last generation or two. The wit, the precision and the verve of the work, with its treatment of the honored classic style in a fresh, modern manner, retain their charm.

The part the American Friends Service Committee is playing in providing funds to keep conscientious objectors at useful nonfighting jobs was shown yesterday in its annual report. On these projects, known as Civilian Public Service, the Friends spent $363,383 during 1942, and estimated expenditures of $570,000 for 1943.

May I call attention to an omission of fact in a Washington dispatch to THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 28? I refer to the item announcing the decoration to be awarded General Bethouart for his services at Narvik in May, 1940. In this story no mention is made of the role played by the Norwegian forces in the recapture of the city.

ROSE trees have long been available for American gardens, but until recently their great individual charm and valuable landscape possibilities have been somewhat overlooked. In the writer's garden there have been rose trees ever since a visit to England in 1924 and the discovery there of a certain enchanting rose-tree path leading across an "upland lawn" to the chapel at Stoke Poges, long famous as the scene of Gray's "Elegy in a Country Churchyard."

CHUNGKING, June 5 -- Not since the battles around Hanko in 1938 have the Chinese fought with so much spirit as during the past ten days. Beginning with the recapture of the rugged mountain gateway of Yuyangkwan on May 29, the Chinese, aided by the American Air Force, urned a Japanese advance into a rout.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 287 United States soldiers wounded and of eighty missing in action in seven battle areas. It also listed 287 men held prisoners of war by Germany in Stalag 5B.

Eight years ago this department reported the discovery by Dr. Szent-Gyorgi of Szeged, Hungary, that vitamin C, in which the citrus friuts are especially rich, has no effect on scurvy unless it is accompanied by an unknown factor which he called vitamin P. This "P" reduces the fragility of the capillaries.

MADRID, June 5 (AP) -- The Spanish Government proposed today a four-point plan that it said would '"humanize" aerial bombing. Earlier the government denied charges, which it said had been made abroad, that "Spain acts in the service of another nation."

RYE, N.Y., June 5 -- A perennial winner, who has scored so many breed and group triumphs that the score has been lost, tallied her eighteenth best-in-show victory today. Champion Flornell Glamorous, a snow-white whippet, was elevated to the highest award in the first exhibition of the Mid-Hudson Kennel Club at Brookside, the estate of Mrs. Flagler Matthews.

Count Fleet achieved 21 yesterday -- twenty-one races, the number run by Man o' War in his entire career, but a figure which only seems to be a milestone for Count Fleet on his way to further greatness.

"WHITEY'S SUNDAY HORSE" (which consists of several chapters taken from the author's longer story "The Blind Colt," Holiday House ), is a genuine, spirited little tale of a boy who wants what he calls "the purtiest colt on the ranch" for a "Sunday" horse.

NEW DELHI, India, June 5 (AP) -- Medium bombers of the Tenth United States Air Force struck successfully at Japanese oil sources in Burma yesterday and also blasted a factory, an American communique said today.

McNally, chairman of the Tammany law committee, was likely to be appointed United States Attorney for the Southern New York District to succeed Matthias F. Correa when the latter resigns to take a commission in the Army.

ALMOST forgotten are the two men who first perceived northern Canada's commercial importance: Pierre Esprit Radisson and Medard Chouart, Sieur des Groseilliers. Although known too for their early explorations beyond the Great Lakes, their great achievement lay in their realization that the key to Canada's fur empire was the ocean route to Hudson Bay.

THOUGH a strict blockade of the port of Santos was maintained by the Federal government of Brazil during the revolt in the State of Sao Paulo in 1932, a Japanese ship was allowed to discharge its cargo of immigrants.

ALGIERS, June 5 -- General Charles Nogues resigned today as Resident General of French Morocco. SANTIAGO, Chile, June 5 -- Early incorporation of Argentina in the group of American nations that have broken off relations with the Axis was predicted by almost all Chilean newspapers today in analyzing the revolution yesterday that overthrew the Castillo administration.

Colleges and universities throughout the country, gearing their programs to the war effort, are planning to hold Summer sessions varying in length from six to sixteen weeks, starting this month. As never before the college campuses will remain open and busy during the traditional vacation period.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 5 (AP) -- General Arturo Rawson, the new 59-year-old President of Argentina, is a professional soldier and has devoted most of his life to the cavalry. Likewise, General Pedro P. Ramirez, co-sponsor of the Argentine coup and who will retain his post as Minister of War in the new government, is a cavalryman and former classmate of President Rawson.

DETROIT, June 5 -- In the third day of its emergency conference here, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today commissioned a committee of twenty-five members to draft a statement to the country giving the organization's views on charges of racial discrimination against Negroes in war plants and the armed services.

LONDON, June 5 -- Prime Minister Churchill returned to London today more confident than ever that victory was sure and that another mighty blow would soon be struck against the enemies in the east and in the west.

They were said to have seized twenty-one railway stations and established armed motor-boat patrols on the Danube River.

BOSTON, June 5 -- Albert F. Plock's Woodford Lad drove down the homestretch to catch H. Guy Bedwell's Sollure in the last 20 yards and go on to a nose decision today in the $5,000 added Commonwealth Handicap at Suffolk Downs before 17,123 patrons.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee reported today the Agriculture and Navy Appropriation Bills for the fiscal year beginning July 1. The committee restored appropriations for continuance of the Farm Security Administration, which the House had denied.

Harold Kimball, president of the Southern New York Fish and Game Association, has passed along a suggestion of Louis Gold-bright of White Plains to anglers for releasing the first fish caught.

KNOLLWOOD FIELD, N.C., June 5 -- A training program which employes the formerly idle time of convalescent patients has saved "more than a thousand man-hours" each day in the Army Air Forces Technical Training Command's station hospitals, according to a survey recently completed at this headquarters.

She was named The Swoose from the outline of a misshapen Walt Disney bird, half swan and half goose, which was painted on her nose with the skeptical legend, "It Flys." It did, for many thousands of miles against the enemy.

THIS book aims at teaching conversational Spanish beyond the elementary level. It deals with a trip to Mexico, a subject that has been often used. We see two travelers in the principal daily life situations. The language used is idiomatic and many expressions peculiar to Mexico are found.

Whalen, CDVO chairman, announced yesterday at City Hall.

Ben Cassidy and his gang of rustlers, posing as farmers, were stringing fences all over the Cross-J Ranch to which old Alex Jenkins had devoted his life to building up.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 5 -- The Ruhr district now offers a picture of devastation that reminds German veterans of World War I of the Flanders battlefields, according to the first detailed eyewitness account given by a returning traveler to the Stockholm newspaper Nya Daglit Allehanda.
CHICAGO, June 5 (AP) -- Brownell Combs' Miss Dogwood, one of the best 4-year-old fillies in training, turned back a strong field in today's $5,000 added Steger Handicap at Hawthorne.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 5 -- It was far-heralded "Larchmont Luck" again today when the Larchmont Yacht Club opened for the Summer season and held the second of the special regatta series out on Long Island Sound. The best breeze of the warm weather came over the low Westchester hills and the competing craft were heeled over in full racing pitch in the club's sixty-third annual early race.

Today, "A Stranger and Afraid" is not much more unlikely than any other "Inside Europe" reporting job.

Eisenhower, Allied commander in North Africa, and his land, sea and air commanders.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (U.P.) -- The most widely known military secret in the world today is that the combined American-British-French armies that ran the Axis out of Africa are about to move against the continent of Europe. DETROIT, June 5 -- Federal Judge Arthur J. Tuttle, imposing the death sentence for the third time on Max Stephan, today set July 2 as the date for his execution at the Federal Correctional Institution at Milan, Mich.

The acquisition of the Meaher Building in Mobile, Ala., for remodeling into a residential club for merchant seamen, was announced yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director of the United Seamen's Service. Randoph Burgess, general chairman of the fund's current city-wide campaign for minimum of $4,500,000 to help support 406 affiliated voluntary welfare and health agencies and hospitals.

WICHITA, Kan., June 5 -- Preparations for the transportation, marketing and storage of the 1943 Winter wheat crop will be completed at a meeting here Wednesday of the Trans-Missouri-Kansas Shippers Board at the Allis Hotel. Several hundred representatives of agriculture, industry and finance from Kansas, Missouri, Illinois, Oklahoma and Arkansas will attend.

From the time Argentina broke away from Spain in the Revolt of May 25, 1810, until last Friday the government had changed hands by revolution six times. The last overturn had been in 1930, when Jose Uriburu led the anti-democratic forces of the country in an impatient move to destroy the remaining strength of the venerable Hipolito Irigoyen.

THIS is the story of young and fearless Rob Roy Morgan, nicknamed Virginia by his companions in adventure because he hailed from the Old Dominion. In company with eleven rough and ready companions from other Southern States he rode out to California just in time to be caught in the gold rush of '49.

VETERAN readers of many Waughs will be delighted to encounter this new edition of his first novel, "Decline and Fall," originally published here fourteen years ago. It is definitely one of Evelyn Waugh's best -- together with "Vile Bodies" this reviewer's favorite of his list to date.
WARRENTON, Va. -- The Upperville Colt and Horse Show announced for June 12 has been "indefinitely postponed," owing to the gasoline shortage and the tightening of traffic restrictions.

THE magnates of the National Football League are feeling pretty glum these days, not because of the uncertainties of the coming season, but because Jimmy Conzelman has left the Chicago Cardinals to become assistant to the president and public relations counsel for the St. Louis Browns. Every one of them, deep down in his heart, wishes Jimmy well in his new job.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The official Republican party organization began this week to inch warily toward the issues which now absorb, and doubtless will continue for some years to absorb, the major attention of all thinking Americans -- the issues revolving around the war and the post-war peace.

FREEDOM of speech is guaranteed by the Bill of Rights. But even before the adoption of the Constitution, the cry of "Town meeting tonight!" accompanied by the town crier's bell, summoned the early New England colonists to open discussion of the questions that confronted them.

An engine crew employed by the Hudson River Day Line quit yesterday in a dispute with the company over interpretations made by the company of the Wages and Hours Law, but there was no interruption of the line's service to Albany.

LOS ANGELES, June 5 (AP) -- Lieutenant Louis Zamperini, national collegiate mile champion runner who almost caused an international incident by pulling down a Nazi flag in Berlin in 1936 and who expressed a desire to pay a return visit to Germany as an Army Air Forces bombardier, is reported missing in the South Pacific.

TEN years ago a traveling New Englander dined in the United States Legation in a Central American capital with a little group of citizens of his own country resident there on the errands of government, business, science, education or philanthropy.

JONATHAN followed him from the royal tent and came up to him with outstretched hands. David thought that he had never seen so frank, so fearless, so sweet a face in his life. ILYA EHRENBURG, described in part by his publisher as "for many years one of the landmarks of the Cafe Rotonde on the left bank of Paris," draws on a wealth of first-hand intimate experience and shrewd observation when he writes of "The Fall of Paris."
PRINCETON, N.J., June 5 -- Throughout the nation the political question discussed most often today is this: what are President Roosevelt's chances of winning a fourth term if he chooses to run?

ANDRE GIRAUD'S chronicles on international politics published under the signature of "Pertinax," have won him a world-wide reputation. It is a matter of common knowledge that many French statesmen and politicians consulted with him; unfortunately, most French leaders failed to profit by his advice.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 5 -- A new Argentine government was formed tonight by the military junta that had been in control of the nation's affairs since the successful revolution yesterday and General Arturo Rawson, leader of the march on Buenos Aires in the coup d'etat, became President.

Accelerated by the demands of a war of motion, intensive research is being devoted to power plants of many kinds for vehicles of widely differing sort and utility. The progressive development of horsepower output and efficiency in the conventional radial air-cooled and the liquid-cooled types of aviation engines is being supplemented by important, if still confidential, injection and supercharging devices.

The New York City Board of Education, for the first time in its history, has broadened its sphere of activity to encompass a new and highly significant program for young children. Upon the recommendation of its Committee on Instructional Affairs the board has approved a plan to establish pre-kindergarten education centers in the Fall term in specially selected academic and vocational high schools throughout New York City.

THIS is the story of Rio Rand, who "had learned early in his teens that he could make more money at rodeos and stock shows, with his genius for calf roping, target shooting and trick riding, than he ever could punching cows for "thirty per and beans," and as a result had become famous from Texas to Nevada as "Ridin' Rand of the Rio Grande."

Continued rise in production of war goods during the initial quarter of this year enabled the electrical manufacturing, building material, home and office equipment companies to report slightly better earnings than those of the corresponding quarter last year. Notwithstanding.

Republican organization leaders in New York and other Eastern States have begun to take interest in the Republican Postwar Policy Association, organized in Chicago on May 3 by representatives of a dozen Middle Western States and now being organized in States of the Atlantic seaboard.

Some of the best news of the war began to filter through censorship and secrecy to the public last week. It was news which has been long in the making; much of it was dated and the facts revealed were not conclusive; nevertheless, it was definitely cheering.

When the American forces landed in North Africa they were protected by a pall of dense white smoke that poured out of wheeled machines. Similar smoke-boxes have been installed at various strategic points on this continent. There is no reason why a dozen of them could not completely conceal a city the size of Toledo, Ohio.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A fundamental change in the Federal court system is under consideration by a House Judiciary subcommittee as a possible blow against the growing wartime problem of crime, particularly among juveniles.

FOR a long time a great many people have been rightfully distressed -- not to say indignant and outraged -- at the treatment the Negro generally receives in films. With good and sufficient reason, these persons have stoutly maintained that the usual Hollywood concept of the Negro constitutes a grave social abuse and that the tolerance of the color line in pictures is one of the bulwarks of that cruel stigma today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- A 10 per cent reduction in meat prices to be effected by a subsidy payment of $250,000,000 to $300,000,000 a year to the slaughterers was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

AN adventure with a skunk sets Private Detective Sam Ireland on the right track after he has been led astray by false clues in a Vermont murder mystery. The local police have been completely baffled, possibly because they did not happen to meet the skunk, although it is equally possible that such a meeting would have impressed them as merely something extremely unpleasant.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION IN ENGLAND, June 5 (AP) -- Captain Clark Gable, the former movie star, is making training films in England for the United States Army Air Forces, it was disclosed tonight.

LONDON, Ky., June 5 -- Ninety-nine persons active in the general election in November were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiracy to corrupt the vote and the count in the election of a United States Senator.

IN a very real sense the terrific air offensive against Germany, only now approaching its full strength, may be said to have begun on Feb. 25, 1942. On that cold gray day, when this country's fortunes in the war were at a low ebb, two men met, shook hands and began laying plans for a campaign to cripple Hitler's European fortress by bombing from the air.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 5 (U.P.) -- Two fleets of American Liberators dealt another heavy blow to Italy's tottering defenses yesterday. They dumped 125 tons of bombs on the Grottaglie airdrome near the Taranto naval base, while other American planes pounded Sicily and Pantelleria for the eighteenth day.

MOSCOW, June 5 -- In peacetime June is known in the Soviet Union as the month when all theatres close down, the schools end and those who can afford it go to the country for vacations in their "dachas." In wartime June is known as the month when the Germans try to mount their biggest offensives.

WHEN J.M. Barrie published "Sentimental Tommy" in 1895, tracing the psychological development of the artistic temperament of a Scots lad of the people, Robert Louis Stevenson thought he was the hero of the story; but that was doubtless wrong, for it has been proved, more or less incontrovertibly, that Barrie wrote from introspection -- an autobiographical study.

THIS is an intelligently conceived and honestly presented manual on a prosy lot of individuals -- spies and saboteurs. In it the reader will find little that chills the marrow and even less that is glamorous.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Face to face with the stark necessities of wartime gasoline rationing, Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price and Rationing Administrator, had to become harsh with East Coast motorists on Tuesday.

One hundred underprivileged diabetic children of this city and adjacent communities are looking forward to July 1, the opening day of Camp Nyda at Wallkill, N.Y., where they will spend a two-week vacation. The New York Diabetes Association, a group of leading specialists on diabetes, is sponsor of the camp.

FOR the first time in several months two major film location units are scheduled to leave Hollywood this week for extended production activities. The announcements by Paramount and Twentieth Century-Fox that the majority of sequences for "Frenchman's Creek" and "Happy Land" would be photographed in Northern California apparently indicate a relaxing of Pacific Coast wartime transportation restrictions, at least temporarily.

CURIOUS individuals are still mystified by some of the elegant uniforms in which women deck out. No longer will they have to remain in the dark. Just a flip of the pages of "American Women in Uniform" and they can spot whether the lady in question belongs to the Waves, the Wows, the Vias or the Wires.

POISON IVY KILLER -- Poison ivy and many other noxious weeds can be killed easily with a spray solution of a new chemical brought out by the du Pont laboratories. Known as ammonium sulfamate (not sulfate), the compound is nonpoisonous and free from fire hazard. It sterilizes the soil for a brief period only.

Leaders of forty unions in the distribution field will discuss today shortcomings in Federal administration of price control, rationing and manpower at a meeting in the Hotel Astor sponsored by the Greater New York Joint Council of the United Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Employes of America, a unit of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

THE CHICAGO TRIBUNE got out its first issue on June 10, 1847, "400 copies hand-set and printed on a hand press, in a one-room plant in the third story of a building at La Salle and Lake Streets." It has a bigger building now and a centennial rolling around, no doubt, by the time this history has been carried to 1947.

AT the "Warfair," which will open tomorrow in Pershing Square under the auspices of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office, the Victory Garden Committee will have an informative exhibit consisting of displays of insect pests, various type soils, weeds and composts.

Castillo by a stable regime that would cooperate with the other American republics in breaking diplomatic relations with the Axis and in hemispheric defense, it would complete the unity of the Americas that the United States so long has sought.

The book covers the fundamentals and summarizes important progress of the last few years. It is refreshingly up to date.

Thirteen-year-old Marjorie Kappelmann attends school in the living room of her farmhouse home at 151-17 Vleigh Road, Flushing, Queens. Three times a week Miss Sophie Cooper, a teacher assigned to handicapped children, visits the farmhouse. Miss Cooper has other children in her "class" and yesterday afternoon eighteen other pupils were guests of Marjorie at the farm.

MRS. OVERSTREET'S little book of conversational poems-in-prose packs a real wallop. And the punch is all the more effective because there has been no fanfare about it. In half a dozen monologues the poet gives us the answers to half a dozen questions -- or, better, she gives us half a dozen affirmations to half a dozen demurrers as to what it means to be an American.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. -- The imposition of transportation restrictions by the Office of Defense Transportation has caused Sullivan County hotel men to think of the coming season on a week-to-week basis. FOR more than a hundred years the people of Lucerne congregated on an open market place in Switzerland to witness the performance of a popular church play by an unknown author. In addition to the music and much acting without words there were approximately twelve thousand lines of text.

In the ile-and-stucco basement of El Chico, Benito Collada's Sheridan Square spot, a new revue co-featuring Pilar Gomez, flamenco dancer; Reinaldo Henrique, South American tenor, and Yola, pianist-singer, is to be unfolded Tuesday evening.

A proposal by the Federal Reserve Board to tighten consumer credit restrictions of Regulation W still further, by issuing amendment No. 10, meets with the general disapproval of retailers, it was learned yesterday. Copies of the suggested amendment, which would affect department stores much more seriously than installment sellers, have been distributed among retailers along with a request for their comments some time this week.

JUNE ushered in a heat wave that has turned the public mind vacationward, and neither lowered gasoline rations nor crowded trains appear to quench this annual urge to take off for some place. Travel bureaus report an upsweep in reservations of all types, and timetables in rail terminals disappear as by magic as balmy days produce the perenial itching foot.

THIS series of sixty lessons and seven review lessons is intended to serve as an introduction to a more detailed study of Latin-American countries. The plan seems to be good, the material interesting and the grammatical part introduced in a practical, easy manner.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The Office of Price Administration has recently been undergoing such a bombardment of abuse from the outside and an upheaval of factionalism on the inside as to raise a question in many minds as to the survival, intact, of this part of the Administration's program to control inflation.

Pantelleria, a tiny island eight miles long by four miles wide, sits in the Mediterranean on the route that leads from Tunisia to Italy. Located in the Mediterranean narrows, it constitutes a threat to Allied sea communications. It is forty-four miles east of Cap Bon, sixty-two miles southwest of Sicily.

Guadalcanal horror was brought to the International Building in Rockefeller Center yesterday. A colorful jungle scene made vivid the war as engineers of the First Air Force demonstrated the purpose of combat camouflage.

CINCINNATI, June 5 (AP) -- Butch Nieman, former halfback for the University of Kansas, broke up a seesaw ball game today with a ninth-inning triple that gave the Braves a 7-5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

A notable array of special prizes will be awarded next Saturday during the annual dog show of the North Westchester Kennel Club on the polo grounds of the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y. These will be offered by the show-giving organization and by the twenty breed clubs which are sponsoring their specialty shows at this exhibition.

The food industry, although generally endorsing the appointment last week of A.C. Hoffman as a deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration to succeed Dr. J.K. Galbraith, has not given up its plans for a "last-ditch" fight against the policies which, it contends, have produced utter confusion and chaos in the production and distribution of the nation's food supplies.

CHICAGO, June 5 -- The thin thread by which the Dodgers had been hanging to the National League lead was finally snapped today when they threw away a game to the Cubs, 3 -- 2, while the Cardinals beat the Phillies. The Brooks now are a half-length back of St. Louis, but the Southworth men have a two-game edge in the "lost" column.

MOSCOW, June 5 (U.P.) -- In a powerful indictment of Sweden's foreign policy, Professor Sergei Kryloff, noted Russian authority on international law, today charged the Swedes with seven specific violations of their neutrality in favor of the Axis.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 5 -- The Remington Arms Company has constructed here what is believed to be the largest enclosed, sound-proof firing range in the world for testing rifle and machine gun ammunition for the armed forces.

WITH the longest dance season in years finally at an end, attention now turns toward the Summer schedule. Wartime restrictions on travel will obviously make serious inroads upon the customary series of festivals held annually in various sections of the country.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Weeks of consideration preceded the introduction by Senator Josiah Bailey of North Carolina of the legislation that has for its objective a two-term limit for future Presidents. Both branches of Congress, but especially the Senate, were carefully tested for favorable sentiment before Mr. Bailey offered his proposal -- that Congress submit to the States an amendment to the Constitution limiting service in the Presidential office to eight years.

IN 1822 when the Bellamy family lived in a Connecticut farmhouse, timepieces of any kind were rare. Father Bellamy, very proud of the big silver watch which had been his father's and entirely satisfied with it, saw no need for a clock.

A group of five prize-winning one-act plays written by soldiers in a contest sponsored by John Golden, theatrical producer, and officials of the Army's Second Service Command area, will be presented under the general title of "The Army Play-by-Play" on the night of June 14 at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre as a benefit for the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York.

TORONTO, June 5 (AP)--The Financial Post said today that with the lifting of restrictions on the use of electric power by the newsprint industry in Quebec Province, "Canada's present rate of newsprint production can be maintained until the end of 1943, but only at the cost of eating into inventories..
THERE are two heads of government in Europe today who can lay some claim to fame as painters as well as figures in world affairs One is Winston Churchill, the other is Adolf Hitler.
LONDON, June 5 (AP) -- France's military class of 1942 was ordered mobilized "for work" by Pierre Laval today.

STEEL production today waits on the pleasure of no man. So a movie company, which in peace times might have caused a furor in a steel plant, brought little more than a lifting of curious eyebrows and a craning of interested necks when King Vidor, the director; Brian Donlevy and a crew of forty-five assorted technicians appeared at the South Chicago works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation.

POCONO MOUNTAINS, Pa. -- Laurel blossom time in the Poconos is being celebrated this year from June 8 to 26 and hundreds of visitors are expected to visit the region and enjoy this lovely mountain flower whose blossoming is continued over a three-week period.

THE Postoffice Department made available last week a description of the 5-cent commemorative which will be issued on June 22 as the first unit in an eleven-stamp series honoring European countries overrun by Axis forces.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- In a basement meeting hall of the United Mine Workers building, hung with newspaper cartoons of John L. Lewis, formal action calling off the nationwide strike of mine workers on Monday was approved yesterday.

ASKED by her husband, perhaps long-suffering, why she always insisted on using up left-overs, a New England housewife primly replied, "To ease my conscience." Her words, which were born of a moral sense peculiar to Yankees, strike a chord of sympathy in women who feel duty-bound these days to waste nothing.

President John A. Remon and Executive Secretary W.J. McManus, both of Washington, of the American Power Boat Association have summoned a meeting of the national council for, tomorrow night at the Hotel Lexington. Discussing problems that have come up during recent weeks will start at 6:30 o'clock.

LONDON, June 5 -- More than 2,000 Frenchmen in London are busily engaged in winding up the affairs of the French National Committee, which was established here just three years ago in modest quarters on the Embankment, opposite the Houses of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) -- The Senators hit in the clutches and took full advantage of Detroit lapses to defeat the Tigers, 6 to 3, today and move back into second place in the American League.

TWENTIETH Century-Fox is whipping up a super-duper screen "trailer" to herald the forthcoming "Jane Eyre." NEWS of a new enamel that dries in one hour will be welcome to householders who must do their own redecorating. This interesting paint, called Larcoloid and claimed to be foolproof, was developed by the Carpenter Morton Company. It flows easily over almost most any sort of surface -- even very large ones -- without leaving the least trace of uneven brushwork.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 5 (AP) -- Archbishop Francis J. Spellman of New York said today he was ready to set out on a new journey that would lead him all around Africa and on to India and China.

The pay-as-you-go tax, passed by the House and the Senate in the past week, now awaiting the President's signature, will be cited as the "Current Tax Payment Act of 1943." Although this title is a misnomer, the bill presents, probably the best terms upon which a compromise by the people and the Administration could be obtained at this time.

Castillo, according to latest reports, is trying to hold onto power, but his prospects seemed slim.

LONDON, June 5 (U.P.) -- The curtain is about to go up on a great Allied offensive against Europe, with the final attack orders issued and troops, invasion flotillas and planes assembled. The zero hour is undeniably at hand and only the time and place are secret.

MOSCOW, May 30 (Delayed) -- Peter Kalinin, a stocky 7-year-old orphan who until last January held the honorary rank of a Red Army lieutenant, has turned up his snub nose at a British Red Cross gift of a jersey suit and insists on wearing his miniature Red Army uniform.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 5 -- Uruguayan officials interested in mustering a strong pan-American front against the Axis expressed surprise and disappointment tonight at the personnel of General Arturo Rawson's new military regime in Argentina.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 5 -- General George C. Marshall, United States Chief of Staff, who has just taken part in a series of conferences here on future operations with Prime Minister Churchill, General Sir Alan Brooke, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, and General Dwight D. Eisenhower and his aides, declared today that the Germans had been rebuffed in two great campaigns on which they pinned their hopes for victory.

IN 1791 George Chalmers, slyly pretending friendship, wrote for profit a libel of Thomas Paine. Other self-styled biographers followed suit, but in candid hostility. Now, with his "Citizen Tom Paine," comes Howard Fast, taking his cue from Chalmers but topping him: cashing in on American ignorance of the historical Paine to present a lifelong slovenly drunkard that not even the most conscienceless of Paine's chief detractors ever conceived.

Hot weather spurred consumer demand for seasonal merchan .d.e here last week, producing brisk [retail trade in most Summer apPparel and accessory line Volume comparison with a year ago, however, suffered from the fact that '.the week cont2ined five business days agiec six in 1942 due to the emorial Day holiday.

WHETHER or not Chungking, capital of Free China, is an attractive city is not a matter of great importance. More than a million people are now living and working in the ancient city where three hundred thousand lived in the times before the government took refuge on the mountainous tongue of land where the Yangtze and Chieling merge, way back in 1937.

Bright-eyed, smiling and apparently not particularly fatigued by his overnight plane trip from New Orleans, Gunder Haegg, Swedish record-breaking distance runner, arrived yesterday and started preparations for a series of meetings with American track stars this Summer.

The doctrine of God's presence in the human soul is not a consideration of mystical theology but an everyday fact in the life of the faithful Christian, Mgr. Walter P. Kellenberg, vice chancellor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 6 -- Colonel Irving A. Lindberg, Collector General of Customs, has remitted to New York and London $500,000 in part payment of the frozen commercial debt of Nicaragua for merchandise purchased from the United States and Britain before August, 1937.

LONDON, June 6 -- The drab tone of the stock markets remains unrelieved except for the rather brighter finish to the week occasioned by President Roosevelt's firm action to end the coal strike and the unity achieved at last in French North Africa.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- An urgent demand for feed grains of all kinds developed late last week, with buyers pleading for supplies of corn, oats and barley. Corn prices continued to hold at ceiling levels, and while the Office of Price Administration has made efforts to thaw out the market, the result has been virtually nil so far.

More than two months have elapsed since H.G. Wells suggested at a London scientific meeting that news might better be disseminated by telephone (or the radio) than through the newspapers, but our American telephone companies -- alert as they are -- have done nothing about it.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The War Department announced today that the Army Air Forces had brought millions in contracts to the small business man. Although most of its contracts are for air frames, airplane engines, propellers and complete airplanes, which are not products which can be purchased from small plants, many of the smaller parts for airplanes are made by small firms, generally as subcontractors.

Too much time is being devoted to mere debate over schemes for the post-war world and too little to working out principles, the Rev. Karl M. Chworowsky declared in a sermon yesterday morning in the Flatbush Unitarian Church, Beverly Road and East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn.

The Consolidated Gas Utilities Corporation reports a net corporate income of $471,218 for the quarter ended April 30, 1943, after all taxes and charges, comparing with $337,643 in the same period of 1942. Operating revenues were $1,208,543, against $938,914.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (U.P.) -- The country's 530,000 coal miners, heeding the order of their chieftan, John L. Lewis, are returning to the pits tomorrow, while in the capital tonight there was evidence that negotiators were nearing an agreement which, it was hoped, would end the wage dispute for the duration.

The city's milk supply crisis, arising from the order of the Office of Defense Transportation for staggered deliveries to conserve gasoline, appeared to have passed yesterday as members of the Milk Drivers Union, A.F. of L., cooperated fully in enforcement of the order under the skip-a-day system for doorstep deliveries.

Six thousand children, two-thirds of whom were Jewish, representing the pupils of religious and other schools in the city, participated yesterday in a "Rally of Hope" in Madison Square Garden and united in a prayer and plea for immediate aid for the refugee children of Europe.
Twenty-nine gifts amounting to $56,598 have been received by Columbia University for research in science and work in languages, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president, announced yesterday.

The motive of John L. Lewis in threatening to renew his strike on June 20 is clear. He wishes to hold a club over the Administration to make sure that it grants a substantial wage increase. While this motive is not primarily patriotic, the country should be grateful to him.
PATERSON, N.J., June 6 -- An incident occurred here this evening that would have warmed the heart of the Mayor of New York City, he being an arch foe of bingo.

RYE, N.Y., June 6 -- Champion Nornay Saddler came back today. The smooth foxterrier who has won more best-in-show awards than any other pure-bred dog in the world again captured that coveted title when he was awarded the highest honors among 314 terriers benched in the third annual terrier exhibition of the Rye Kennel Club.

New York City is now the center of training of pilots and other personnel of the Domestic Transportation Division of the Air Transport Command, in a program that "has no counterpart in the world," it was announced yesterday by Colonel Harold R. Harris, former commercial airlines executive and test pilot, who is commanding officer of the division.

A BOMBER STATION IN NORTHWEST AFRICA, June 5 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Bombardier Richard J. Walsh of New York City, whose main mission is destruction, turned to rescue work in a raid over Northeastern Sardinia and saved the lives of his crewmates when enemy anti-aircraft fire shot the ship out of control.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday June 7 (AP) -- The Japanese dive-bombed the Allied mountain base at Wau, high in the mountains overlooking the Japanese coastal holdings in the Lae-Salamaua area, with sixteen planes yesterday, but inflicted no appreciable damage. There were no casualties.

The woman who wears a size larger than 38 is no longer the stepchild of ready-to-wear fashions. She does not have to seek out her own little tailor or dressmaker to be just as well dressed as her svelte sisters. Virtually every big store now has a special department devoted to her needs.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 6 -- Leaders of the Italian home front were attentive today to yesterday's bombing of Spezia less than an hour after the arrival in that port of four of the home fleet's more important units. According to direct reports from Italy during the day, they were the battleships Roma, Impero and Littorio and the 10,000-ton cruiser Pola.

NORFOLK, Va., June 6 -- Two American cargo ships, a tanker and an ammunition-laden freighter, collided off the United States east coast before dawn several days ago, causing terrific explosions and blazing oil slicks that took the lives of eighty-four of the 151 men aboard.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 -- A. Lewis Hutchinson, aged 11, son of a Philadelphia stock broker, was killed this evening by a bullet from a .22 caliber rifle accidentally kicked over by William Donner Roosevelt, 10-year-old grandson of the President, as it stood against a wall.

Harold R. Moskovit, State president of the Affiliated Young Democrats, announced yesterday that his organization would support five candidates for Democratic Assembly district leaders at the primary election on Aug. 10. The candidates endorsed are members of the Young Democrats. They are:

By running two miles in 9:22.6 Fred Wilt of the United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia earned the Jeremiah T. Mahoney Trophy at the annual Grover Cleveland Athletic Club track and field competition at Macombs Dam Park yesterday.

Worry, which is always highly detrimental to mankind, mounts to alarming proportions in wartime, the Rev. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Fifth Avenue, declared in his sermon yesterday on "Mastering Wartime Worrying."

LONDON, June 6 (U.P.) -- Whirlwinds, Typhoons and Spitfires of the Royal Air Force resumed attacks on German transport today, setting fire to two minesweepers in the Strait of Dover and wrecking locomotives on the Continent. At least eight locomotives were derailed or damaged on Northern French lines.

CINCINNATI, June 6 (AP) -- The Reds outlasted the Braves in a fourteen-inning struggle in the first half of a scheduled double bill today, to win, 4 to 3, before weather conditions called a halt to the second game in the first half of the first inning.

An appeal to Washington for "more coupons and less pamphlets" telling housewives how to use meat substitutes was voiced by Mayor La Guardia in his regular Sunday-broadcast from City Hall yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, June 6 -- The recent decision of the general council of the Trades Union Congress to allow the Postal Workers' Union to affiliate with it has raised almost as controversial a point in union circles as the Communist party's application for membership in the Labor party has raised in the political arm of the British labor movement.

WAYNE, Pa., June 6 -- American war production for the Army during May exceeded $1,600,000,000 and is increasing at the rate of $100,000,000 a month, Major Gen. Lucius D. Clay disclosed today in an address at the baccalaureate exercises of Valley Forge Military Academy.

Girls finishing college this year are not looking for jobs, the jobs are looking for them. Employment officers in ten Eastern colleges declared yesterday that the only obstacle to a 100 per cent placement record for outgoing classes is that some of the girls are too particular.

Speaking as guest preacher yesterday morning In the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany at York Avenue and Seventy-fourth Street, the Rev. Dr. Everett P. Smith portrayed every Christian as a "salesman" for the Lord and the church, and stressed the opportunity today to establish the rule of Jesus Christ in the hearts of men.

On the last day of the week it became known that the coal miners' strike was ended and that Lewis had yielded to the President. Notwithstanding continuance of the strike throughout the week and despite unwillingness, up to the last moment, for the Union to abandon its truculent attitude, financial markets at no time expected any other outcome.
BALTIMORE, June 6 (AP) -- The Newark Bears and the Baltimore Orioles divided an International League double-header today, with Newark taking the opener, 9 to 6, and Baltimore the nightcap, 4 to 2.

Warning that the fuel oil and anthracite coal situation might be worse next Winter than it was last year, Mayor La Guardia urged householders and industries yesterday to stock as much fuel as they could during the Summer.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period May 29 to June 4 are given in the appended tabulation:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 6 -- General Arturo Rawson's revolutionary government tonight decreed the dissolution of the Argentine Congress, and also displayed an anti-Communist character by ordering the police to suppress any Communist statements and to close down the Communist newspaper Hora.

The sudden death last week of Dr. Barbara Stoddard Burks will be keenly felt by her scientific colleagues in psychology and genetics as well as by others who have followed her interesting work in human heredity and the influence of environment.

Brig. Gen. Byron, head of the Army Exchange Service, has returned from a tour of inspection of Army Post Exchange Stores. These are opened wherever an advanced supply depot or a railhead has been established by the Army. They offer the soldier some of the old familiar goods, the "extras," the superfluities, if you like, things by use and habit become almost as necessary as all but the prime necessities.
Despite the changes caused by the gasoline shortage, fishing, both fresh and salt water, is being continued at some of the better known spots.
LONDON, June 6 (U.P.) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

JERSEY CITY, June 6 (AP) -Jersey City and Toronto divided a double-header today, with the Little Giants winning the opener, 3 to 2 in eleven innings, and the Leafs taking the nightcap, 9 to 3 in seven.

The battles around Ichang were not like any other battle ever fought in China. For the first time the Chinese armies had air support both from their fliers and our own. The result is heartening. The enemy is still retreating and the Japanese threat to Chungking seems ended for the Summer.

LOS ANGELES, June 6 -- Subdued and no longer ready to do battle, twenty-eight zoot-suiters, stripped of their garish clothing and with county jail barbers hopefully eying their flowing ducktail haircuts, languished behind bars today after a second night of battle with officers and service men.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 6 -- Vice President Wallace told the graduating class of Connecticut College today that he believed that in the prevention of a third world war "much will depend on just how we handle the German youth immediately after this war."
On May 19 the following telegram was sent to Joseph T. Sharkey, majority leader of the City Council:

Ignatius Martin Wilkinson, dean of Fordham Law School for the last twenty years, was named by Mayor La Guardia yesterday to the post of Corporation Counsel vacated by Thomas D. Thacher upon his elevation last month to the Court of Appeals.

LONDON, Monday, June 7 (AP) -- Russian pilots and gunners smashed 752 German planes from May 30 through June 5, a week of violent and massive air raids, Moscow reported early today, to make a five-week toll of 2,821 Nazi aircraft destroyed in the air and on the ground in Russia.

The presence in Algiers last week of Winston Churchill, Anthony Eden and the British and American Chiefs of Staff is interpreted as a final notice that the invasion of Europe is at hand. Certainly the Allies have done everything to advertise that this is their intention.

Stressing the growing dissatisfaction in organized labor with the government's wage and price control policies, representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations unions demanded yesterday effective action to roll back prices and relaxing of rigid prohibitions on wage readjustments.

THE Man From Down Under, M.P. Greenwood (Storky) Adams, appeared in a cloud of pipe smoke and an aura of excitement. "There's the greatest controversy raging in the Australian papers," he said. "Some one asked which of the American amateur sprinters might have been a match for Jack Donaldson, the old Australian professional.

NEW ORLEANS, June 6 -- An increase of twelve points in the parity price of cotton, a new move by the farm bloc in Congress to help raise values of that staple and bullish private crop estimates were all encouraging developments in the cotton futures market here last week, but, in face of increased hedging pressure, prices failed to move far in either direction.
AUSTIN, Nev., June 6--Fifteen bodies were removed today from the wreckage of a twin-engined Army transport plane missing since Monday which was sighted by a Civil Air Patrol pilot yesterday.

With the warning that "we now have the beginnings of a runaway" in food prices, Don D. Humphrey, Office of Price Administration economist, declared yesterday a price rise of 50 per cent in food and farm prices is possible in the next year unless the OPA price program announced late in May is made effective.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 6 -The celebration of Sweden's Flag Day was accompanied by a partial mobilization order that was read over the radio this morning. The men affected were told not to await written confirmation but to present themselves immediately.

DETROIT, June 6 (AP) -- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Automobile Workers (C.I.O.), said today that he had "absolute evidence" that a strike at the Packard Motor Car Company last week was promoted "by the Ku Klux Klan, or its successor body in Detroit.''

Clifford Hayman, whose production of "Uncle Harry" ran for a year at the Hudson, has acquired the producing rights to Lucille Prumbs' comedy about a family engaged in a munitions plant that goes by the title of "I'll Take the High Road."
LONDON, June 6 (AP)--An Admiralty communique:

New York University's 111th annual commencement program was opened yesterday afternoon with a baccalaureate service in the auditorium of the Gould Memorial Library on the University Heights campus. Attending were 1,200 faculty members, degree candidates and their parents and friends, necessitating for the first time in the university's history placement of extra seats on the lawn in front of the library.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Weather conditions in the last ten days have been the best of the season for agricultural work, generally speaking. Relatively light rainfall in the areas affected by excessive moisture recently sent farmers into the fields and great progress is reported to have been made in corn planting and other delayed work in the last few days, except in areas where the soil is still too wet for operations.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Awards of the Distinguishing Flying Cross for extraordinary achievement in the Southwest Pacific area were announced today by the War Department. Each of the recipients participated in fifty operational flight missions.
CHUNGKING, China, June 6 (U.P.) -- A communique:

MOSCOW, June 6 -- When the Red Air Force returned from Bryansk to Karachev Friday night to continue the great air war over the central Russian salients twenty-four hours after the heaviest sortie of the war fires from the previous night's raid were still burning.

The San Carlo Opera Company concluded its season with two performances given yesterday at the Center Theatre. In the afternoon Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" was presented with a cast headed by Lucille Meusel as Rosina, Eugene Conley as Almaviva and Carlo Morelli as Figaro.

In all the talk about nutrition -- the role vitamins play in our diets, the value of protein, and so forth -- little is said about the function of fat. That is why a brief bulletin on the subject in the current issue of Food and Nutrition News, which is published by the National Live Stock and Meat Board, is particularly interesting.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Reports of no improvement in the outlook for the new Winter wheat crop and prospects for a smaller yield of the Spring-planted variety than last year, combined with expectation of a material increase in the demand for that grain, turned prices of wheat upward last week on the Chicago Board of Trade.
In "the brave new world" to follow the war, women should take full responsibility in every field open to them, Lady Beveridge urged yesterday.

With nine named for the $5,000 added Queens County Handicap, the Aqueduct race meeting will begin today with the probability that attendance will be heavy because of the convenience of trains to the door. The first post is set for 1.30 P.M.

A happy smile is credited by many persons with being a greater beauty asset than flawlessly regular features. Which is all very well so long as you are equipped with pretty teeth. But now cosmetic chemistry is seeing to it that any woman may acquire a dazzling set of teeth and the charm of a brilliant smile.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Oats futures on the Chicago Board of Trade sold last week at a new peak since 1928 as the result of general buying induced by reports of a material improvement in the shipping demand and intimations that lack of transportation was slowing down deliveries of Canadian oats and barley in the East.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (U.P.) -- Representative Mary T. Norton, Democrat of New Jersey, predicts that women's place in post-war work will be meager in comparison to their share in the war.

PHILADELPHIA, June 6 (AP) -- Johnny Salveson's four-hit shut-out pitching plus his fifth-inning homer gave the Indians an even break. With the Athletics in a double-header today before 26,127 at Shibe Park.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, representing 122,741 of the country's physicians and surgeons, of whom more than a third are serving with the armed forces, will open here tomorrow its annual meeting, which will be devoted to the policies to be pursued by American medicine during the war and the years to follow.

CALCUTTA, India, June 2 (delayed) -- The Province of Bengal, where Western political ideas first found fertile ground in India, is now providing such an interesting object-lesson in the difficulties of applying parliamentary government to India that it is worth a quick survey.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 6 -- If in the course of twenty-five years the democracies have had to fight two "heart breaking wars" and wasted the opportunity presented to them by victory in the first, it was because opinion controlling democratic government was completely uneducated in foreign affairs, President Charles Seymour declared today at Yale University's 242d commencement exercises.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Daniel J. Tobin, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, in a sharp reference to John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America, said today that it was the public's right and the government's duty to demand that every man remain on his job.
LOGAN, Utah, June 6 -- De-emphasize competitive athletics because of the war?

MOSCOW, June 6 -- The 2,000,000th copy of Mark Twain's works printed in the Soviet Union since the revolution has just been issued. Mark Twain is second to Jack London in popularity here as an interpreter of life on the North American Continent.
AUSTIN, Texas, June 6 (AP)--Daniel Allen Penick, "father time" of tennis, chuckled when they told him he shouldn't go around bareheaded on the court with the thermometer registering 99 degrees.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The War Department announced today a list of 384 United States soldiers wounded in action in the North African area, including the following having next of kin in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Operating under war conditions, the airtransport services created by the Army and Navy are now averaging several hundred transatlantic flights weekly and are sketching the pattern of a world-wide development of airways that will be available for civilian air-transport needs after the war, the Office of War Information said today in making public a report on all phases of American air transport.

The New York Americans won the Duffy Cup by defeating Brookhattan, holder of the trophy, 2 to 1, at Starlight Park yesterday before 3,000 soccer fans in the windup of the series played annually among the four Metropolitan professional clubs of the American League.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 6 -- German prisoners of the Tunisian campaign are far different from the swaggering youths and supercilious officers captured in France and Flanders in 1940. The tremendous confidence in themselves and their Fuehrer, on which that attitude was based, is gone, lost somewhere in the snows of Russia and the hills of Tunisia.

The battle of the city budget raged through Sunday when Mayor La Guardia opened the cannonading with the charge that cuts made by the City Council eliminated the jobs of 188 city employes now on military leave while cutting the salaries of 329 others to $1 a year.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A decline of 7 per cent in cash dividend payments was reported by the Commerce Department today for April as compared with the same month last year. The total was $292,000,000, which was $21,000,000 less than in April, 1942.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- In an unanimous ruling that wage classifications based solely on difference in race were without validity, the War Labor Board today ordered abolition of pay differentials between white and Negro workers performing equal work.
Four new films will have local premieres this week. The program follows:
The Finnish Sunday communique, as broadcast from Finland and recorded and translated by the Federal Commucations Commission:

Hosiery shipments during April, amounting to 13,354,601 dozen pairs, showed a drop of 1.3 per cent from the 13,532,710 dozen pairs shipped by mills in April last year, according to the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers.

Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson hinted broadly last week that American offensive operations soon would be started in the Pacific, and it seems probable that the recapture of Attu is only the first step in a Summer-long series of attacks.
Mrs. Francis L.V. Hoppin, who was at Mayfair House after her return from Palm Beach, has gone to Newport for the season.

A public offering of $15,517,700 of 7 per cent subordinated income debentures of Armour Co. of Delaware is being made today at a price of 110 and interest to the date of delivery by an investment banking group of ninety firms headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co.

MOSCOW, June 6 (U.P.) -- The Red Army has captured several of the Germans' seventy-two-ton "Tiger" tanks and in prolonged tests has found defects making them extremely vulnerable to certain types of anti-tank defense, the Army organ Red Star reported officially today.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- Obscured by the return of the coal miners to work is the fact that the five-day strike at the nation's coal mines has already caused irretrievable loss of war production at some of the country's steel plants.

BOSTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Red Sox took both ends of a double-header from the White Sox today, 4 -- 3 and 3 -- 2, coming from behind in each game after losing three straight in single engagements with the Chicago team.

Retailers found it impossible to maintain adequate stocks on current-selling apparel items, but placed additional heavy commitments on Fall lines, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident-buying offices.

The three-day annual conference of the New Jersey Savings and Loan League closed Saturday in the Hotel Pennsylvania with a speech by Dr. Eugene E. Agger, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance of New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Army and Navy planes sank a Japanese destroyer, set fire to a corvette and a cargo vessel, and shot down fifteen defending Zero fighter planes and damaged three others yesterday (Solomons time) in what apparently was one of the fiercest and most successful of recent air battles in the Pacific war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 6--Allied naval and air forces continued their destruction of the defenses of Pantelleria and of shipping and airfields in Sardinia yesterday. The day began with another bombardment of Pantelleria by a British naval squadron at dawn--the fifth in seven days.

PITTSBURGH, June 6 -- The Giants ran out of Carl Hubbells today. In fact, they ran out of everything, including wind and ammunition, and suffered two thrashings at the hands of the Pirates before 21,358 enthusiasts.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Depth-charges from a Navy patrol plane shattered an enemy submarine and sent it plunging to the bottom of the Atlantic after a short engagement in which shells from the U-boat's guns riddled one wing of the plane.

NEW DELHI, India, June 6 (U.P.) -- American medimu bombers, taking advantage of a break in Burma's monsoon rains, yesterday attacked railroad installations and warehouses at Alon, sixty-five miles west of Mandalay, scoring hits on all their targets, the Tenth United States Air Force reported today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 6 -- Smoking putters in the hands of A.S. (Sandy) Brown of the home club and Frank Bedford, one-time New Jersey caddie champion, today gave the two 19-year-olds a victory in the seventh edition of the annual member-guest tournament staged by the Montclair Golf Club.

NEWARK, N.J., June 6 -- A dog, spurred by a little boy's cry of "sic 'em," today caused a stampede of five circus elephants, giving their trainers and police no end of trouble and scaring hundreds of pedestrians and some motorists along several principal streets of Newark.

CHUNGKING, China, June 6 (AP) -- Counter-attacking Chinese troops have cut off the retreat of several Japanese units on the Yangtze River front of Central China and are intensifying their mopping-up operations, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

ALGIERS, June 6 (U.P.) -- A "French Government" dominated by Generals Giraud, de Gaulle and Catroux, in posts tantamount to those of Ministers of War, Political Affairs and the Interior, appeared to be emerging tonight.
