BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 6 -- The new government headed by General Arturo Rawson as President -- whose members prepared to take the oaths of office tomorrow in culmination of their successful revolution -- made more clear today its policy of American continental collaboration and at the same time its strongly nationalist character.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices rose from 112.2 to 112.3. The rise was entirely due to increases in the agricultural indexes. The farm products index gained 0.3 per cent as a result of increases in the prices of eggs, barley, and potatoes, which were only partially offset by decreases in the prices of oranges, wheat, and cattle.

It is to be hoped that a generous attitude will be maintained in Congress toward the Civil Aeronautics Administration's War Training Service, which used to be known as the Civilian Pilot Training Program. This program has made useful for war purposes a great majority of small private planes which have not been employed on the civil air patrol.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 6 -- Old Boreas, who often frowns on or neglects sailing yachts entirely, for some reason or other, sprang to life in the kindly way he has acted so far this season and not only saved but made a success of the third Long Island Sound Summer championship series regatta, which was held today by the Larchmont Yacht Club.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- Navy communique 402:

KANSAS CITY, June 6 (AP) -Kjell Qvale of the Fairfax Naval Air Transport School, former Pacific Coast sprint champion, took the measure of the Big Six dash king, Joe Shy of Missouri, to win the 100-yard dash in the Missouri Valley A.A.U. track meet last night.

ST. LOUIS, June 6 (AP) -- Stan Musial's hitting streak was broken today after twenty-two consecutive games in an abbreviated contest between the world champion Cardinals and Philadelphia which was called after five innings with the score tied, 1 to 1.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, June 6 -Members of the subcommittee of the House Committee on Insular Affairs currently investigating Puerto Rican conditions visited the Virgin Islands yesterday. They conferred with department heads and the leaders of the two Municipal Councils concerning the economic future of the islands.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 6 -- Prime Minister Winston Churchill told Allied airmen "we had Corporal Hitler to help us" in the Tunisian campaign in one of his many impromptu speeches during his tour of the Tunisian army camps.

MOSCOW, June 6 -- The Red Army possesses more than 100,000 Partisan fighters who serve as an extremely valuable although highly secret patriotic mass, definitely collaborating with the High Command in the liberation of the country.

Warning that civilian volunteers will soon have to assume many unaccustomed tasks because of the growing shortage of manpower, James M. Landis, Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, declared yesterday that volunteer workers had become the front line of home defense against possible attack by the enemy.

An English-language broadcast from Berlin, recorded yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System in New York, implied Nazi approval of Argentina's new government and said that a "desire to intensify the anti-Communist policy" of the Argentine motivated the coup.

An all-Tchaikovsky program, with Artur Rubinstein, piano, as soloist, will be presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, on the opening night of the Stadium Concerts, June 17, at the Lewisohn Stadium.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 6 -- The war puts great emphasis on scientific training and on the products of applied science, but there need be no concern over the future of the liberal arts, Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, said at the annual commencement exercises this morning.
The more enthusiastic in a crowd of 36,111 fans at the Stadium mobbed big, good-natured Johnny Lindell yesterday, and not without reason.

Office of Price Administration regulations permitting a higher wholesale ceiling for restaurants than that governing retail butcher shops was blamed last night by Alfred Wendel, president of the New York State Association of Retail Meat Dealers, for the "present shortage of meat in New York City."

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Two weeks ago the Dodgers headed west at the top of the National League by two and one-half games. Tonight, with one game in Pittsburgh remaining on the tour, they are a half-game, or 28 percentage points, behind the first-place Cardinals as a result of losing eight of the fifteen games they have played in the West.

LONDON, June 6 -- With the greater part of the Italian Fleet being held at dispersed points to defend the Italian coast against a possible invasion, British submarines have recently been penetrating enemy defended coastal waters in daring raids that have increased the threat to Premier Mussolini's sea lines.

ALGIERS, June 6 (AP) -- General Charles de Gaulle, addressing a mass meeting of his followers today, accused Marshal Henri-Philippe Petain of being an "evangel of decadence" and asserted that "the instinct of the French people guides them to a Fourth Republic."

The Argentine revolution has been completed. A new Government has assumed control of the country's destiny. The revolution lasted only twenty-four hours and was virtually unopposed. After a show of resistance, President Ramon Castillo and his Government surrendered and resigned.

The post-war extent of the victory of the United Nations will be lieasured in proportion to our ability to discover "the art of living together," the Rev. Frank Curtis Williams declared yesterday morning in his first sermon as pastor of South Reformed Church, Fifty-fifth Street and Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn.

Like his father, Theodore, Kermit Roosevelt was a disciple of the "strenuous life." He was a big game hunter, explorer and engineer; and he was a fine soldier who, in two World Wars, fought under the Stars and Stripes and the Union Jack. Twice he chose to fight before his own country went to war.

The Port of New York should be the embarkation point for extensive overseas air services after the war, the Port of New York Authority said yesterday in response to a questionnaire circulated by the Civil Aeronautics Board seeking advice on post-war commercial aviation problems.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- Although there was a sharp increase in the movement of hogs to market late in May, there was relatively little accumulation in supplies of lard in that period owing to enlarged government purchases. Stocks of lard in cold storage here on May 31 aggregated 16,562,000 pounds, an increase of 2,575,000 during the month and compared with 13,987,000 pounds a year ago.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 6 (U.P.) -- A communique:

Manufacturers of national brands are definitely concerned over the paragraph in the revised L-85 order governing women's apparel, which calls for equitable distribution of the material produced under the order and bans discrimination in the acceptance of the order between customers, "who meet his (a manufacturer's) established prices or terms."

It was interesting to notice on May 28 on the same page of your newspaper an excellent editorial on the significance of the Canadian Government's program for health insurance for our own country and a letter which revived the most outworn arguments against a much more moderate proposal in the same direction.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) -- The Senators tightened their grip on second place in the American League today by sweeping both games of a double-header from the Tigers, 5 -- 1 and 8 -- 4, before 20,000 fans. Two rookie hurlers, Ewald Pyle and Milo Candini, were credited with the victories.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 6 -- The North Shore underwent a mock invasion today when units of the New York State Guards, about 600 strong, attempted "landings" at three points here and succeeded in breaking through the army of defenders to reach the Northern Boulevard, their objective route to a defense plant they were to "demolish."

Although the cotton market continued extremely dull last week, a steady undertone of price-fixing prevailed to counter more active liquidation and hedging. This buying support, while sufficient to retain firmness in the July position, was not strong enough, however, to hold the market at gains for the week, the net losses for the period amounting to 4 to 11 points for active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange.
LONDON, Monday, June 7 (U.P.) -- The Russian Sunday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
The Jewish Peoples Committee for united action against fascism and anti-Semitism held yesterday a meeting in the Hotel Capitol attended by 300 delegates representing 175 organizations.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 6 -Universal is planning a picture for its "horror" series which will include all the weird characters from the several subjects of this order made previously at the studio. The film, to be titled "The Chamber of Horrors," will revive the monsters from the former films "Dracula," "Frankenstein," "The Wolf Man," "The Invisible Man," "The Mummy" and "The Mad Ghoul."

While the anthracite wage conference of representatives of the United Mine Workers and operators resumed sessions at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, with no agreement likely until after an accord is reached in the bituminous parleys in progress in Washington, a survey of the coal supply situation here disclosed views ranging from "still scarce" to "the situation should clarify itself within the next few days."

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Companies proved to have dominated "independent" unions must repay to their workers the dues collected for membership in these unions under the closed shop check-off system, the Supreme Court ruled today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- In well-informed quarters here tonight judgment was reserved regarding both the government and the prospective foreign policy of General Pedro P. Ramirez in Argentina. But General Ramirez and his Cabinet were regarded as distinctly more promising than General Arturo Rawson, who had led the revolt, and the Cabinet he had tentatively formed before he handed over the power to General Ramirez today.

A public statement clarifying the War Production Board's attitude toward trade shows is expected to be made by Chairman Donald M. Nelson or one of his associates in another day or so, it was reported in the trade here yesterday.

The stock market on average suffered yesterday its worst inroads in almost two months and, although the losses generally did not go beyond a point, the weakness in some of the pivotal industrial groups accounted for the general softness.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 7 (AP) -- Arriving here from conferences in Washington with other Allied leaders, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell expressed the belief that plans laid in those talks would "satisfy all who cry out for strong, aggressive and immediate action."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The apostolic delegation early this morning announced designation of the Right Rev. Mgr. Bryan Joseph McEntegart, executive director of war relief services of the National Catholic Welfare Conference, to be Bishop of Ogdensburg, N.Y.

The same Senate that has frequently complained of Presidential "usurpation" of legislative functions undertook yesterday some usurpation of its own. It did so by giving tentative approval to the McKellar bill, which would require confirmation by the Senate of every Federal appointment carrying a salary of $4,500 or more, whether or not it is a policy-making appointment.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Harry Stuhldreher, whose Wisconsin football team handed Ohio State its only defeat last year, tonight was named head coach of the College All-Stars, who will play the Washington Redskins, champions of the National Football League, the night of Aug. 25 in Northwestern University's Dyche Stadium.
ALBANY, June 7 -- The State Emergency Food Commission reported to Governor Dewey today that the food shortage had reached a point where a change in Federal farm policies was necessary.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A complete revision in the list of industries to receive preferential treatment in the Eastern gasoline shortage area was issued today by the Office of Defense Transportation. The revised list, like the original list issued May 30, which it supplants, was certified to the ODT by the War Production Board through its Division of Stockpiling and Transportation.

As its final offering this season the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue (betweeen Eighty-ninth and Ninetieth Streets), will open to the public today an exhibition of paintings and sculpture exclusively by members, associate members and associates-elect.
LONDON, June 7 -- The stock markets here opened the week cheerfully following the return of Prime Minister Churchill from overseas.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- With the Attu campaign now a virtually closed book, action in the Pacific over the week-end consisted of renewed bombing of Japanese bases by Army and Navy fliers on both ends of the Pacific front, a Navy communique reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Leaders of the National Grange and the National Association of Retail Grocers pictured OPA policies today as leading to ruin and bankruptcy.

The General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, former deputy city controller, slowly neared a close yesterday with the defense lawyer, Louis B. Brodsky, taking five hours to sum up the evidence to the blue-ribbon jury. Judge James Garrett Wallace then adjourned the trial until today, when Assistant District Attorney Joseph A. Sarafite will sum up.

New charges of criminal violations of Office of Price Administration ceilings on rayon gray goods were filed in Federal court yesterday. The informations, drawn up by the office of United States Attorney Mathias F. Correa, named twenty-six persons and nine corporations as defendants.

Sandwiched in between a hosiery shop and a jewelry store at 100 West Fifty-seventh Street is the Vermont Maple Sugar and Syrup Company. So tiny that when four or five customers arrive at once, as they frequently do, they tread on one another's toes, it boasts almost every form of maple syrup products, from fluid to finely molded candy.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 7 -Following through on their victory over the Securities and Exchange Commission in the United States Supreme Court, the Federal Water Service Corporation, Utility Operators Company and Federal Water and Gas Corporation filed with the commission today a plan calling anew for parity treatment of certain of the officers and directors of Federal Water Service with respect to preferred stock bought since Nov. 8, 1937.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA (AP) -- Except that he has put on enough weight to be nicknamed Porky by his Australian friends, Frankie Strafaci hasn't changed much since the days when he won the national public links and New York's metropolitan amateur golf championships.

Christian E. Guenther, Swedish Foreign Minister, praised what he called "Norway's powerful resistance" in a speech yesterday, according to a Swedish broadcast recorded by the Columbia Broadcasting System in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- A 7 per cent increase in munitions output in April as compared with March was reported today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board. He added that war production in April was in "better balance than at any time since Pearl Harbor."

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Acting to bolster the Indians' reduced outfield staff, Vice President Roger Peckinpaugh tonight announced the purchase of Pat Seerey, 20-year-old fly-catcher from the Wilkes-Barre farm team of the Eastern League.

The renaissance of home sewing is monopolizing the attention of women in such numbers this season that pattern makers are chalking up new records. Before the end of 1943, manufacturers estimated yesterday, sales will reach 75,000,000, a total that will make a fitting observance of the eightieth anniversary of the industry.

Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau disclosed at his press conference here yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria held in connection with the formation of the new War Finance Committee, that June 28 has been set as the date for the offering of a new issue of $2,500, 000,000 of new medium-term government bonds.

LONDON, June 7 (U.P.) -- British warplanes resumed their attacks on enemy transportation targets in occupied France today after bad weather had grounded the Royal Air Force's giant bombers Sunday for the eighth consecutive night.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- Nearly 400 American boys who fought in bitter cold and over rugged terrain to wrest Attu from the Japanese were back on the mainland today, smiling on their cots at Letterman General Hospital in spite of frozen feet and battle wounds.

Congressional action to relieve the gasoline shortage on the Eastern seaboard was requested yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York. At the same time the regional Office of Price Administration announced that 12,329 motorists were questioned over the week-end for alleged pleasure driving.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The Senate passed and sent to conference today its greatest Naval Supply bill, carrying $24,850,427,198 in direct appropriations for new ships, tens of thousands of planes, ordnance, armor, defense installations and ever-increasing personnel, and nearly $5,000,000,000 more in contract authorizations for the fiscal year starting July 1.

The Council on Books in Wartime, in cooperation with the Office of War Information and other organizations, will celebrate a United Nations Book Week coincident with the observance of United Nations Week, beginning next Monday.
LONDON, June 7 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Following a good night's sleep, his first in more than three weeks, Gunder Haegg, the Swedish sensation, was at ease yesterday, though somewhat disappointed, by the weather, which prevented a workout. The great distance-running ace, here to show American fans the form that carried him through a series of unprecedented clockings on his home grounds, spent the day resting and at midnight departed for Hanover, N.H.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Manufacturers of the women's, children's, and infants' underwear, nightwear and negligee industry, of the country have been asked by the OPA to give their views concerning the most effective way of controlling prices for their products, it was announced today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 7 -- More proof of Germany's manpower shortage was forthcoming in reports from Norway today announcing that all members of the Todt organization, hitherto engaged on purely engineering and constructional work, have now received weapons and have to do double duty -- as artisans and soldiers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 (AP) -- Sam Byrd, former New York Yankee outfielder, who gave up baseball to become a golf professional, teamed up with his wife today to win the qualifying medal in the Philadelphia women's pro tourney that opened at the Bala Golf Club today.

The five-story multi-family building on a plot 50 by 100.1 feet at 521 West 161st Street, between Broadway and Amsterdam Avenue, was sold for a client of H.I. L. Cohen, attorneys, through Schimmer, Kerner Ferder, brokers.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 7 -- General Arturo Rawson resigned early today the Presidency of Argentina, which he had assumed Saturday night following Friday's successful military revolution, and turned over the government to General Pedro Pablo Ramirez.

PITTSBURGH, June 7 -- Round Freddy Fitzsimmons, pitching one of the better games of his long career, tonight let the Pirates down with seven hits as the Dodgers, directed by Coach Johnny Corriden in Leo Durocher's absence, beat Frankie Frisch's men, 4 -- 1, to give Fitz his second triumph of the season and 218th of his major league career.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 7 -- Paramount today completed its cast of principals for the Technicolor production, "Frenchman's Creek," with the signing of Basil Rathbone for the role of the heavy, "Rockingham." The cast and technical crew will leave Friday night for location at Albion, Calif., to photograph the pirate ship scenes.

A simulated paratroop attack on Manhattan and Staten Island at 9 A.M. next Sunday will be met by 3,000 members of the First Brigade of the New York Guard in the first mobilization manoeuvre of the combined Seventh, Ninth, Fifty-first and Sixty-ninth Regiments since the outbreak of the war.

A six-room penthouse apartment at 888 Park Avenue leased to Mrs. Edward Porter May through the Tishman Realty and Construction Company was one of the residential leases reported yesterday by brokers and agents. Other rentals follow:

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The conviction of William R. Johnson of Chicago, described by Justice Frankfurter as "gambler on a magnificent scale," and five of his associates for income tax evasion was upheld by the Supreme Court today. Johnson, often depicted as the czar of Chicago's organized gambling, was convicted in October, 1940, of attempting to defraud the government of $1,887,864 on a 1936-39 income of $3,377,615.

Four little brothers, threatened unknowingly with separation through loss of their foster home, grinned obligingly into a camera yesterday afternoon, and last night they had good prospects of finding a new home together.

The very recent address of Pope Pius XII to the members of the Sacred College of Cardinals evinces his wonderful spirituality and keen desire for peace. Unfortunately his admirable efforts "to induce the belligerents to respect the laws of humanity in aerial warfare" do not quite meet the present situation of humanity at large.

The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday, in its statement of operations covering the first three months of 1943, net profit of $6,336,098, equivalent to $1.46 a share on the 4,351,132 shares of capital stock This outstanding. compares with $4,889,233, or $1.13 a share, earned in the initial quarter of 1942.

BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- Ignoring the disapproval of his throne-makers, Willie Pep, Hartford's able holder of the New York version of the featherweight boxing championship, will make his initial defense of that disputed title in a fifteen-round bout with Boston's Sal Bartolo tomorrow night at Braves Field.

Directors of the Standard Steel Spring Company declared yesterday a stock dividend of one-twentieth share, or 5 per cent, as an initial disbursement on the concern's new stock. It is payable on July 20. A similar stock dividend for payment on Oct. 1 also was voted.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The United States Supreme Court today reaffirmed the constitutionality of legislation that imposes a 49-cent-per-bushel penalty on wheat produced in excess of AAA quotas, and either sold or consumed by the grower.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 7 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors authorized today payment of "cost of living" bonuses to 1,700 county employes for the last half of this year. In a resumption of a quarrel over the development of a county airport in Purchase the board heard charges that "fraudulent and deceitful" documents had been filed in Washington to win Army approval of the site.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 7 -- Federal agencies concerned with the wartime shipping problem were accused today by Louis Goldblatt, acting secretary-treasurer of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, of being "more concerned about protecting the privileges" of Joseph Ryan, head of the East Coast longshoremen, than "about getting an efficient job done."

Corporate earnings during the first quarter of 1943, despite substantially larger sales, were only slightly higher than for the same period a year previously and well below the corresponding three months of 1941, according to the division of industrial economics of the National Industrial Conference Board.

Broadway gets a revival of "The Student Prince" this evening, the first for the operetta since 1931. The Broadway Theatre is the place, and in the cast will be Everett Marshall, Ann Pennington, Frank Hornaday, Barbara Scully, Detmar Poppen, Nina Varela, Helene Arthur, Jesse Cimberg, Zella Russell, William Pringle and Agnes Cassidy.

Last evening at about 9:15 I came to Madison Square and started to walk south on Fifth Avenue. There seemed to be a golden glow in the sky and lower Fifth Avenue looked ablaze. For a minute I became alarmed, but, seeing and hearing no excitement, I proceeded to walk.

Wood is "doubling in brass" these days for the base metals now monopolized by the munitions of war and other essential manufacturing. In a brace of beauty accessories just reaching the market for the benefit of Russian War Relief it has been manipulated to serve both as hinge and closure, eliminating every iota of metal in both a compact and a lipstick.

A luncheon at the Waldorf-Astoria today will launch the Baseball War Bond League under the direction of the United States Treasury Department and the Baseball Writers Association. More than 1,000 persons are expected to be present and take part in the bidding in the opening drive for a billion dollars' of war bond purchases.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., June 7 (AP) -- Dr. W.H.S. Demarest, 80 years old, former president of Rutgers University and the New Brunswick Theological Seminary, was reelected president of the Board of Direction of the Reformed Church in America at the 138th annual session today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- As the main body of the 450,000 bituminous and 80,000 anthracite miners streamed back to work today following a five-day strike, the wage dispute between the Appalachian bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers appeared to be moving toward final settlement by the War Labor Board.

A tea and cocktail party will be held under the auspices of the Gramercy Park Branch of Bundles for America on Thursday in the Skyline Roof of the Gramercy Park Hotel. Proceeds will further the maintenance of merchant marine convalescent homes in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, June 7 -- The scope of Canada's war effort was outlined today by Vincent Massey at Edinburgh. The Canadian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom said that the Dominion now ranked fourth among the United Nations as a producer of supplies.

One big phase of the better world which every one wants after the war is concerned with the status of the backward nations. What of the colonial peoples in the century of the common man? American sentiment strongly resents the old snobbery which distinguished between higher and lower breeds.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Austin C. Hoffman, whose recent appointment as Acting Deputy Administrator of the Office of Price Administration was nailed by grocery and food groups, resigned today and announced that he would return to the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- As John L. Lewis's new period of truce in the coal strike begins to diminish in the calendar the expectations of close observers here are coming to be uniform. These expectations are several in number and they include the following forecasts of a forthcoming settlement:

Rapid expansion of existing television facilities and the development of television networks to make programs available over wide areas in the post-war period were predicted yesterday by David Grimes, vice president in charge of engineering for the Philco Corporation, in an address before the New York Institute of Finance at the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that a draft registrant satisfies the requirement of keeping his draft board informed of his whereabouts when he provides a chain of forwarding addresses through which he can reasonably expect to receive an induction notice in time to report for service.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, June 8 (U.P.) -- Allied attack bombers strafed and bombed enemy entrenchments on Green's hill, a few miles north of Mubo, Monday in direct support of jungle-trained infantry who have been harassing the Japanese around their New Guinea coastal base at Salamaua for the past several months.

The Rome radio said yesterday that Carlo Scorza, newly appointed secretary of the Fascist party, had "adopted disciplinary acts" against more than a score of party members, according to the Office of War Information.

DETROIT, June 7 -- Office girls at the Ford Motor Company's Highland Park plant did not like the effect of slacks on their silhouettes, so they wore dresses to work today. The company, however, did not go for the dress, and provided no work, so the girls sat idly in front of their typewriters.

Coincident with a meeting of the Canadian Newsprint Administrator with officials of the War Production Board here yesterday, paper industry sources, according to the Office of Price Administration, said Canadian newsprint manufacturers had been ordered by Dominion authorities to reduce their shipments 12 per cent.

ANNAPOLIS, June 7 -- Midshipman George Downes Prestwich of Collingswood, N.J., was announced today as the honor man of the class of midshipmen who will receive their diplomas at the Naval Academy on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Blood plasma, skillful surgery and the sulfa drugs, in that order, have resulted in the reduction of the death rate among our wounded in the North African campaign to one-sixth of the rate of the last war, Major Gen. Norman T. Kirk, newly appointed surgeon-general of the Army, disclosed here today at the annual meeting of the house of delegates of the American Medical Association.

MOSCOW, June 7 -- The effectiveness of Soviet Partisan warfare is amply attested in a recent article in the Berliner Boersen-zeitung by a Major Gen. Schultz, of the Wehrmacht, who points out not only the harassing powers of consistent and sudden night attacks by irregular bands but the enormous difficulties involved in crushing them.

When Dr. Hiram N. Vineberg, consulting gynecologist to the Mount Sinai Hospital, is honored this afternoon at a special ceremony at the hospital's Blumenthal Auditorium, Ninety-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, only half the story will be told. Guests will hear once again that he is responsible for relieving women of suffering and disablement by insisting, half a century ago, that reproductive organs be conserved in operations.

LONDON, June 7 -- London has received the shorthand notes of instructions by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels to editors of National Socialist party papers on the line they should follow to counteract the war weariness and discouragement of the German people.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the United States Army, returned here this afternoon from overseas. His return, in the opinion of some military observers here, cast cold water on reports from abroad that the American Chief of Staff would become Commander in Chief of an imminent invasion of Europe.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 7 -- Johnny Kinder, New Jersey P.G.A. champion, had the unique experience of taking the first two places and tying for fourth in a State P.G.A. pro-amateur tournament today at the Branch Brook Golf Club.

PHILADELPHIA, June 7 -- An optimistic earnings forecast for the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation was presented by its president, Justin R. Whiting, today before a trial examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission at the opening of a hearing on the proposal of the company to recapitalize on the basis of a single class of common stock.

In order to properly finance "a people's war," individuals must be persuaded to buy $18,000,000,000 in war bonds during the next seven months in addition to the $7,000, 000,000 purchased since the first of the year, Herbert E. Gaston, assistant secretary of the United States Treasury, declared yesterday at the luncheon of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association in the Pennsylvania Hotel.

CHICAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Discovery of a new double star weighing about 100 times as much as the sun, or 200 billion billion billion tons, was reported today in The Astrophysical Journal by Dr. Daniel M. Popper, instructor in astronomy at the University of Chicago.

Three years ago this week Mussolini hurried his unprepared country into war. He was in a hurry because he was afraid he would not get in in time for the division of the spoils. Whatever mixed and devious motives inspired the fateful declaration of June 10, 1940, the strongest was certainty of swift German victory.

NEW DELHI, India, June 6 (Delayed) -- One way to get home from far-away India is to get sick or wounded, but it is the way no one chooses, although it is only human to take it philosophically -- if you haven't been hit too badly.

CHUNGKING, China, June 7 -- This being the fifth day of the fifth moon of the Chinese calendar, all Chungking took a half holiday to celebrate the Dragon Boat Festival as usual. Probably most of the river men who paddled the long, lean boats did not know they were honoring the memory of the poet Ch'u Yuan, who drowned himself 2,000 years ago because none heeded his warnings against corruption in the government.

Rain and all, 13,075 persons went to Aqueduct yesterday for the opening and saw a thriller when Mrs. Payne Whitney's The Rhymer just got up to snatch the victory from Mrs. Tilyou Christopher's Kingfisher by a head in the $6,175 Queens County Handicap at a mile and a sixteenth.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Early attendance at the advance Fall and Winter apparel showings, which this year were "substituted" for the regular midseason wholesale market, today appeared larger than spokesmen cared to admit. The reason for the unusual reluctance of market officials to talk freely on opening day apparently was the unfavorable attitude of the Office of Defense Transportation toward trade gatherings this year.

In Mr. Krock's very interesting analysis of the principles for a judicious use of the method of subsidies published in THE NEW YORK TIMES, one case is missing which to many economists would seem to be perhaps the most typical one.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Mr. Roosevelt today signed legislation extending for two years Presidential authority to negotiate reciprocal trade agreements with foreign countries and, in doing so, to raise or lower existing tariff rates as much as 50 per cent.

A SOLDIER-STUDENT who prefers to remain anonymous "because repercussions are swift and severe in the A.S.T.P." offers very intelligent and enlightening comment on some remarks which were made in this space last week. At that time this observer suggested that the Army let its student-soldiers participate in intercollegiate athletics provided they have the time and the desire for it.

Plans are taking shape for a private sale of not more than $15, 000,000 of new bonds of Paramount Pictures, Inc., and possibly of a smaller amount, that, together with Treasury cash, will be applied to the retirement of $16,634,000 outstanding principal amount of 4 per cent debentures, due 1956.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., June 7 -- Mrs. Faye Brammer Binder, past president of the Federation of Women's Clubs of New York City and wife of Dr. Rudolph M. Binder, prominent author and retired Professor of Sociology of New York University, died today in her home on Eagle Road in Upper Makefield Township, Bucks County, at the age of 54.

Steel Operations The rate of steel operations has declined 1.8 points in the past two weeks at a time when a moderate increase would be normal, indicating that between 1 and 2 per cent of production has been lost for lack of furnace charges, which in turn is due to the coal strike, suspended anew yesterday.

Predicting that the third war loan drive, scheduled to start in September, would meet with even greater success than its two predecessors, Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced at a press conference here yesterday that unification of old groups into a new sales organization for the State was near completion.

Mrs. Freda S. Fineman, the first woman lawyer permitted to practice in Palestine, won yesterday her second bar admission. With a group of about eighty others, she was admitted to the New York State bar at the Appellate Division.
NEW DELHI, India, June 7 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, according to the Federal Reserve Board, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 2. Increases of 173,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $201,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted and $151,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks and a decrease of $312,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

" The Russian Story," a pictorial cavalcade of Russian history from the time of Alexander Nevsky to the present, will have its first showing at 8:30 tonight at the Stanley Theatre. Produced by Joseph Burstyn and released by Artkino Pictures, Inc., the film has an English text written by Theodore Strauss and was edited by George Freedland.

Several amendments to Inventory Control Order L-219 have now reached the stage where they are before WPB officials for action within the near future, it was learned here yesterday. Meanwhile available data indicated that the number of restricted merchants under the order thus far is well under previous estimates of around 2,000.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- President Roosevelt gave a preview of some of his ideas on the peace settlement in a brief talk at the White House today before more than 400 delegates, advisers and experts who attended the United Nations Conference on Food and Agriculture at Virginia Hot Springs.

BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- The Christian Science board of directors announced today the election of Mrs. Daisette D.S. McKenzie of Cambridge as president of the Mother Church, the First Church of Christ, Scientist, here, and, in a statement to the annual meeting, placed prayer at the top of the list of defensive-offensive weapons which free-thinking peoples are counting on to win the global war against oppression and suppression.

The most serious threat to agricultural production for 1944 that has yet developed appeared yesterday, when the War Production Board decided that it would have to delay indefinitely a new order permitting sharply increased production of farm machinery, it was learned here.
SANTIAGO, June 7 (AP) -- Quickly resolving a sudden Cabinet crisis, President Juan Antonio Rios tonight named a new group of Ministers who immediately took the oath of office.

Summonses charging criminal libel against Rex Stout, author; Dr. Frederick W. Foerster, German scholar, and Theodore H. (Fritz) Tetens, were obtained in Essex Market Court yesterday by Victor F. Ridder, publisher and editor of the New York Staats-Zeitung.

Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, City Health Commissioner, announced yesterday the appointment of Matthew A. Byrne as secretary of the Department of Health, a position paying $6,500 a year. The appointment was made on the fortieth anniversary of his service in the department.

The first food vender to be jailed for compelling a customer, through a tie-in sale, to buy unwanted vegetables in order to get supposedly scarce potatoes was sentenced yesterday in Municipal Term Court. At the same time the fiction of any current potato scarcity was further exploded by the arrival of 246 carloads of tubers, increasing to 992 cars the shipments received here in the last seven days.
LONDON, June 7 -- Today marked a milestone in the peculiar cigarette situation which for months had United States Army men asking a lot of questions and in many cases saying a lot of hard words.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 7 -- Six hundred persons attended the annual meeting here tonight of the Westchester County Republican Committee at which candidates for the November election received endorsement.

ALGIERS, June 7 -- Eleven commissioners who will govern the French Empire were named in a cabinet of fourteen appointed today by the Committee of National Liberation. But, according to an American diplomatic source, the seven-man Committee of Liberation remains the highest governing authority and those commissioners who do not belong to it have no vote.

Twenty thousand persons filled Madison Square Garden last night at a Negro freedom rally to pledge the full cooperation of the American Negro to achieve the unconditional surrender of the Axis and to cheer lustily a message from Wenwell Willkie saying that the victory of the United Nations is a sure thing.

LONDON, June 7 -- Argentine railway stocks were extremely lively on the London Stock Exchange today, following the news of political changes in Argentina. At the opening of the day's trading prices of the rails were marked up sharply, and in some cases gains were as much as 2 1/2 points, raising them to their highest levels thus far this year.

Frank J. Siclari, 35 years old, manager of the Clifton Theatre, 1034 Second Avenue, whose legal difficulties began on June 1 when Mayor La Guardia, passing the movie house, saw advertisements for a bingo game, was charged in Yorkville Court yesterday with two new violations of the Administrative Code.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., June 7 -- The Alabama Water Service Company, a subsidiary of the Federal Water and Gas Corporation, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a plan for the sale of five water properties to municipalities in Alabama.
MELBOURNE, Australia, June 7 -- At the first of three crucial labor conferences to be held within the next five weeks Prime Minister John Curtin has scored a resounding success.
CHUNGKING, China, June 7 (AP) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:
LONDON, Tuesday, June 8 (AP) -- The Russian Monday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

LONDON. June 7 -- In a long leading editorial tomorrow, The Times of London will sharply denounce as a blunder the announcement of the willingness of the general council of the Trades Union Congress to allow postal workers to affiliate with it.

CLEVELAND, June 7 (AP) -- Jimmy Bivins, who already has collected about $100,000 for eleven fights in the last year, may pocket his share of $18,000 more for giving Lloyd Marshall a shot at the "duration light-heavyweight championship" on the season's first outdoor card at Cleveland Stadium tomorrow night.

A group of 150 investment banking firms headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation began at noon yesterday public offering of 764,500 shares of stock of the Gulf Oil Corporation at $47.50 each. By the end of the afternoon orders had been received in excess of the offering.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 8 (AP) -- Strong German feeler thrusts into Soviet lines were smashed back Monday on three main sectors, the Russians reported early today, but the main action on the long front still appeared to be in the air, with Red Army and German airmen trading especially heavy blows Sunday night.

CHICAGO, June 7 -- Trading in wheat on the Board of Trade today was desultory, with no special feature to the market except unwillingness of traders to take the initiative on either side of the market. The present disposition is to wait for announcement of 1943 loan prices and for some further disposition of the question of flour price ceilings.
Yonkers, N.Y., will offer on Tuesday next a new issue of $750,000 of refunding bonds dated June 1, 1943, and due on June 1, 1949 to 1952. Bidders are to stipulate the rate of interest
BERNE, Switzerland, June 7 -- As a springboard for an Allied invasion of the Continent, Spain is coming more actively into German and neutral European speculation.

Beginning July 1, C.E. Hooper, Inc., radio rating organization, will expand its service by providing breakdown data on the number of men, women and children listening to particular programs, average number of minutes listened during each hour, and continuous ratings on nationally sponsored programs broadcast after 10:30 P.M., and, if scheduled, before 8 A.M., it was announced yesterday.

BOSTON, June 7 (AP) -- After seven unsuccessful starts this season Glen Felkner's Eric Knight today won the feature Orient Heights at Suffolk Downs by a slim nose. The M and M Stables' Dodge City was second, a half length in front of J.H. Miles's Rush Act.
WASHINGTON, June 7 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 282 United States soldiers killed in action in the North African area and four in the European area.

Service will be reduced beginning July 4 on all three IND subway lines serving Queens as part of a Board of Transportation program to effect operating economies of $500,000 a year and conserve irreplaceable rolling stock and other equipment, it became known yesterday.

No official tabulation is as yet available concerning the run of shad in the Connecticut River, but residents of the State and commercial fishermen are ready to believe that this has been the best season in years.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The government, urging full use of "all loyal and qualified workers irrespective of origin or citizenship," today simplified the procedure under which holders of airplane and "classified" contracts may obtain permission to hire aliens.

With Justice Walter P. Stacy of the Supreme Court of North Carolina presiding, an emergency board of the National Railway Panel began hearings yesterday in the Grand Central Terminal Building on the demand of five railway unions for a wage increase of 30 per cent for 400,000 railway employes.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's address to the delegates to the United Nations Food Conference, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Judge Harry Stackell sentenced eight youths in Bronx County Court yesterday to indeterminate terms in the reformatory for the rape of a 17-year-old girl on March 11 in the Bronx Opera House, a motion picture theatre. Six of the youths were convicted by a jury and two pleaded guilty during the trial.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 7 -- Willie Klein, playing his home course in better-than-par figures, captured the first and second prizes in the weekly one-day Long Island P.G.A. pro-amateur best-ball golf tournament at Wheatley Hills today.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 7 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court of Argentina recognized the Provisional Government of President Ramirez tonight soon after he and his Cabinet members took the oaths of office.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union, headed by David Dubinsky, announced yesterday the allocation from its 1943-44 war relief fund of $1,300,000 to war relief and community agencies. The fund is raised from contributions of a day's pay from the union's 315,000 members.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 7 (AP) -- General Arturo Rawson of Argentina told The Associated Press late today that the international situation was the "fundamental cause" of the military uprising in that country, which he declared was "indispensable to save the situation and rectify the isolationist situation in which we now so unjustly find ourselves."

Martin (Marty) Krompier, a former lieutenant of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, who was shot and dangerously wounded in a midtown Broadway barber shop three hours after Flegenheimer was mortally wounded by gunmen in a Newark tavern on the night of Oct 23, 1935, was arrested late yesterday in District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office as a suspected "fence" for midtown safe burglars.

A Southerner born and bred, President Frank P. Graham of the University of North Carolina wrote the War Labor Board's unanimous opinion in the case of the Southport Petroleum Company of Texas City, Texas, made public Sunday. The case was, as he said, "small but significant." The question was whether Negro laborers should receive the same pay as white laborers for the same kind of work.

High above the rooftops of Manhattan, the Women's City Club yesterday opened the doors of its new quarters at the New Weston Hotel. Square-paned glass doors they are, too, opening out on terraces where members may sun themselves.

An increase to $250,000 in the damage asked by Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, was announced yesterday as the summing up began before Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew and a jury in Dr. Davis' libel suit against the Curtis Publishing Company and Benjamin Stolberg, writer.

Yesterday Secretary Morgenthau said that the union of the New York State War Savings Staff with the State's Second Federal Reserve Victory Fund Committee under the name of the War Finance Committee for he State of New York is nearly complete. Thus Colonel Richard C. Patterson Jr., chairman of the first organization for more than two years, is able to go back to his private business.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- The gasoline ratings announced today were AA-1, most critical; A-1, very critical: A-2, critical, and A-3, important. The AA-1 rating is for trucks used in moving, for export by sea or air, supplies of the Army, Navy, Maritime Commission, and Coast Guard and lend-lease supplies.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Wool growers are girding for a battle against present and prospective controls on the civilian use of wool. They assert that American stockpiles and production can carry the country unaided until January, 1946.
CHUNGKING, China, June 7 (AP) -- A communique:

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 7 (U.P.) -- Judge Thomas W. Slick announced today that the Marion (Ind.) plant of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company and five individuals had agreed to enter pleas of nolo contendere in the government's $5,000,000 war fraud case against them.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 7 -- Formidable forces of American, British and South African bombers swept down on Pantelleria yesterday, showering it with hundreds of bombs.

" Juvenile delinquency is on the increase because we as citizens are indifferent to its causes," Frank C. Scerbo, judge of the First Judicial District Court of Morris County, N.J., declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Association of Manufacturers Representatives at ll the Hotel Pennsylvania.

CLEVELAND, June 7 -- The effective range and accuracy of the "bazooka" -- the Army's new portable rocket type anti-tank gun -- have been increased through sights developed by an American soldier in the Tunisian campaign, the Cleveland Ordnance District announced tonight.

Mayor La Guardia urged preparedness for anything that might occur in wartime, when he appealed yesterday for 250,000 more volunteers to bring the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office staff to 500,000.

CHUNGKING, China, June 7 (AP) -- United States planes attacked the Japanese all along the upper Yangtze battlefront yesterday in support of Chinese troops who continued to hurl the enemy back in one of the biggest Japanese defeats in China.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were unchanged from those of the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The week, however, had five business days against six in 1942.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (U.P.) -- The War Labor Board instructed its twelve regional boards tonight to adopt "minimum going rates" as ceilings in correcting substandards of living or gross inequities under the hold-the-line anti-inflation order.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Eastern States Congressmen seeking to determine why their section alone must have automobile pleasure driving restrictions, heard today that the ban soon may be extended to fifteen Midwestern States.

Covering of the near months, especially the December position on the New York Cotton Exchange, and switching from old-crop holdings to the new crops dominated the rather listless trading in the cotton futures market yesterday. Prices held within a tight range under slight volume, with the six active contracts closing 1 to 3 points under Saturday's final quotations.
May I offer the following suggestions as a solution to the present milk delivery crisis?

LONDON, June 7 -- Upward of eighty million dollars in gold owned by the Polish Government that for a long time stood in jeopardy of falling in to the hands of Germany, which, in her scramble for gold, obtained some $266,600,000 worth belonging to Belgium, is safe beyond the Nazis' reach, it was learned from reliable quarters in London today.

WASHINGTON, June 7 -- Reinstatement of a provision affirming the President's right to seize and operate strike-bound war industries and the inclusion of all other essentials of the original Connally bill were approved today by Senate and House conferees on the Connally-Smith strike and labor control bill.

The United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, Admiral William H. Standley, was planning no immediate resignation when I told him good-bye in a Russian airport a few days ago, but he probably will not go through another Winter.

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP) -- Proponents of legislation to require confirmation of virtually all Federal employes with salaries of more than $4,500 a year scored a 43-to-22 victory on a major test vote in the Senate today.

A new court action to restrain the city from carrying out a contract for the erection of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's Stuyvesant Town housing project was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Julius L. Goldstein, counsel for the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League.

LONDON, June 7 -- This could be one of the most depressing places on earth. It probably would be if you listened to the gloomy utterances of some Londoners who take an odd pride in their hardships. The writer took an afternoon off to saunter through a few old haunts here after five months spent in the strident atmosphere of New York and elsewhere in the United States and Canada.

The soft-coal miners have gone back to work, but the battle between John L. Lewis and the Administration is not over. Mr. Lewis has twice called a strike of his union; and he still threatens a resumption of that strike on June 20 if he does not get what he wants.

The average price of 1,469,720,887 shares of stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange at the close of business May 29 was $32.96 a share, comparing with $31.45 a share for 1,468,918,529 shares on April 30, a rise of $1.51, The Exchange announced yesterday.

A suit by a former official of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes International Union, charging that present officials were "maliciously determined" to bar him from employment in building services, was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.
LONDON, June 7 -- Herbert Morrison, Home Minister, told the Metropolitan Mayors Association today that Prime Minister Churchill's trips always worried the Cabinet.

LONDON, June 8 -- Basking modestly in what he termed "the mellow light of victory," Prime Minister Winston Churchill informed the House of Commons today that the time for a thrust across the seas against Axis Europe was "approaching."

C. Roome Parmele 3d, recent graduate from the Staten Island Day School who is awaiting his induction into the Army, triumphed twice to move a round ahead of the field in the Manhattan-Bronx junior tennis championships yesterday at the New York T.C.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Rear Admiral Ross T. McIntire, surgeon general of the Navy, said today that "a simple and effective method of making sea water safe to drink" had been perfected at the Naval Medical Research Institute, Bethesda, Md.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House, voting again today on the issue of restricting the use of President Roosevelt's $90,000,000 emergency fund, upheld restrictions added by the Senate, but with a slight relaxation. The action was by a record vote of 204 to 139.

Simplified price control at the source that will encourage civilian goods production as the effective means of combating inflation, while preserving retailers' historical trade practices, was urged as vital at this time by speakers at the opening sessions yesterday of the War Council of the American Retail Federation at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

CINCINNATI, June 8 (AP) -- John K. Westberg, a price executive of the Office of Price Administration, said today he was resigning, effective July 3, "because I was not permitted to do a fair, honest and complete job."

The annual award of the New York Music Critics' Circle was voted yesterday to Paul Creston's Symphony No. 1, Opus 20, by a majority vote. The Creston score was selected as the best of the symphonic works by American composers which had their New York premieres in the course of the season just ended.

LONDON, June 8 -- Two more historic houses have been given to the nation in trust for preservation, Sir Isaac Newton's birthplace, Woolsthorpe Manor, near Grantham, Lincolnshire, and St. John's Jerusalem in Sutton-at-Hone, Kent.

As the packing industry rushed to empty local coolers before the roll-back of meat prices scheduled by the Office of Price Administration for June 21, offerings other than pork became very few yesterday, while both Federal and city market authorities forecast that the shortage of meats here might become acute.

The New York Curb Exchange's pages, reporters and employes in the quotations department will get wage increases ranging upward from 10 per cent, it was announced yesterday by the Regional War Labor Board. The increases are retroactive to March 6. The cumulative advances will be in the pay envelopes distributed on Friday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 8 -- Led by formations of Flying Fortresses, strong forces of Allied bombers hammered Pantelleria, Italy's island sentry in the Sicilian Channel, yesterday morning and afternoon.

LOS ANGELES, June 8 (AP) -- Naval, Army and civilian authorities took stern action today to stem a wave of rioting between men of the armed services and roving bands of youths whose most conspicuous badge is the zoot suit with its ankle-hugging pants cuff and knee-length coat.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, June 9 (U.P.) -- Allied medium and heavy bombers raided Japanese shipping and air bases along a 2,500-mile arc north of Australia yesterday, scoring two damaging near misses on a 5,000-ton cargo vessel at Waingapu, on Sandalwood Island, and attacking a convoy in the Bismarck Sea.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The HK-1, giant cargo-carrying flying boat designed for Henry Kaiser by Howard Hughes on order of the War Production Board, will take to the air early next Spring, at least two months ahead of schedule.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,726, as against 592 in the preceding week and 488 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations totaled 731, which compared with fifty-three last Tuesday.

A simulated bombing of City Hall Plaza that included such realistic details as miniature bombs that made a tremendous noise without causing damage, pre-arranged "incidents" and the extinguishing of small-scale incendiaries was used yesterday by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office to show the roles that its protective services would play in the event of a real air raid here and the need for additional volunteers for these services.

Elimination of bus service on Seventh Avenue, with sharp curtailments of Sunday and night operations on longitudinal lines, was ordered yesterday by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in a letter addressed jointly to John McCarthy, president of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and its subsidiary, the New York City Omnibus Company, and to Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, representing employes of these operators.

The Treasury seems to have reverted to a practice which was prevalent in the Nineteen Twenties -- that of disclosing information piecemeal with respect to new financing. A few days ago it made known that it was to offer $2,500,000,000 of bonds due in not more than ten years.

It is to be hoped that Winston Churchill will live to write the history of the Twentieth Century War. In his review of his trip to Washington and the African front, he maintains his eminence as the greatest war commentator, and the only one who helped also to make the strategy of the two great phases of the struggle that began in 1914 and now moves toward a second grand climax.

BOSTON, June 8 -- Willie Pep's first defense of his world featherweight championship was easy. The Hartford boxer, who holds the 126-pound title by grace of the New York State Athletic Commission, fought Sal Bartolo of East Boston at Braves Field tonight and walked off with the unanimous decision at the conclusion of the fifteen rounds.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Instead of replying to the report of the New York State Emergency Food Commission, which criticized Federal food policies, Chester C. Davis, War Food Administrator, commented today:

LONDON, June 87 -- The name of Sir Samuel Hoare, British Ambassador to Madrid, as the likeliest successor to the Marquess of Linlithgow as Viceroy of India is being heard more here from close observers of the British political and diplomatic affairs.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8 (AP) -- The Bears gained ground in the International League standings tonight by winning a double-header from Montreal. They captured the opener, 8 -- 5, and took the nightcap, 8 -- 2, behind fine pitching by Southpaw Joe Page.

The final play-off in the city P.S.A.L. senior high baseball championship will be held next Tuesday, it was decided yesterday at the monthly meeting of the High School Games Committee of the P.S.A.L. at the Hotel Astor.

ALGIERS, June 8 -- The organization of a National Consultative Council to act in an advisory capacity to the Committee of National Liberation and as a sounding board for French opinion in metropolitan France, as well as in the empire, was discussed by the committee in its meeting today.

Provocative gayety typified Braagaard's Autumn hat collection shown to the press yesterday in his salon at 17 West Fifty-seventh Street. Exquisitely made bits of flattery ranged from small bretons to tiny toques all tipped forward over one eye.

Aqueduct's race meeting settled into stride yesterday with 15,420 on hand for the second program at the compact Queens County track and three $2,000 events serving as the features. The track, one of the fastest drying in the nation, was still a bit muddy from the opening day's rain, but there was good racing, including several nose finishes.

Curt Lustbader, 29 years old, who came to this country in 1938 on his release from a German concentration camp, was found guilty yesterday in Special Sessions of operating steamship ticket offices here without a license. Justices Perlman, Wieboldt and McDonald ordered him to appear for sentence next Wednesday.

A general back-to-work movement in baseball will be started today, with both the Giants and Dodgers playing at home and the Yankees engaging in an exhibition under lights at Wilmington, Del. The Giants will get their chance against the Phils at the Polo Grounds this afternoon, while the Dodgers will open against the Braves in a twilight encounter, which gets under way at 6 P.M. at Ebbets Field.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House today passed the bill of Representative Margaret Chase Smith, Republican, of Maine, allowing Waves assignments overseas, raising their maximum rank from lieutenant commander to captain and entitling them to allowances for dependents such as Navy men receive.

Add to the list of films opening this week, "Spitfire," an English-made picture produced and directed by Leslie Howard and presented in this country by Samuel Goldwyn, which will have its local premiere at the Rivoli on Saturday.

Six of "the boys" from Chicago, components of "the syndicate" which took over where Al Capone was constrained to leave off, paid a visit to Federal court here yesterday morning. All pleaded not guilty to charges of having helped extort $2,500,000 from employers and workers of the motion-picture industry.

Criticism of the Office of Price Administration and of proposals of government bureaus that interfere with the initiative of the nation's farmers in the production and marketing of essential food products was voiced yesterday at the opening of the Northeastern Farm Bureau Conference at the Hotel New Yorker.

Lieut. Col. Philip G. Cochran of the United States Army Air Corps, just back from the fighting in North Africa, sat for an interview in a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. At the age of 33 he has become a legendary figure, not so much for the Germans he shot down as the way in which he shot them up.

The $250,000 libel suit brought against the Curtis Publishing Company and Benjamin Stolberg, writer, by Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, went to the jury at 3:35 P.M. yesterday after Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew had charged the jurors that under the laws of New York State and the United States "no man has a legal right to be a Communist."
LONDON, Wednesday, June 9 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (AP) -- The successful Chinese counter-offensive which thwarted a Japanese drive toward Chungking has eliminated the danger to the great rice bowl area of Central China, an Army spokesman disclosed today as the Chinese High Command announced the complete occupation of Itu, Yangtze River port eighteen miles below Ichang.

Assistant District Attorney Joseph A. Sarafite for six hours yesterday summed up the evidence to the jury in the General Sessions trial of Milton Solomon, former Deputy City Controller. The latter is charged with having attempted an $8,000 "shakedown" from the head of a stirrup pump concern on a promise last November to kill a City Council amendment that would have deprived the company of a monopoly in sales under the war defense ordinance.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 (AP) -- The Germans, said to be counting from hour to hour on an Allied invasion of Europe, presented today their advance story of just what the first few days of assault would be like if Northern France is attacked from across the English.

Cornelius Warmerdam, the world's greatest pole vaulter, will share the spotlight with the man who is probably the world's greatest foot racer, Gunder Haegg, in the National A.A.U. track and field championships at Randalls Island on June 19 and 20.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Marketing of the largest run of salable hogs here in five months, plus the 18,000 billed directly to packers, brought total receipts today to 40,000 head, the largest number for one day in seventeen months, or since January, 1942.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The decision on if and when the New York City economy program for milk handling will be put into effect rested today with Frederick M. Vinson, newly appointed Director of the Office of Economic Stabilization.

The first recognition by the Office of Price Administration of the pleas of the food industry for relief from the "bankruptcy" profit margins fixed under the agency's rollback order of May 17, was seen by food traders yesterday following the issuance by OPA of invitations to representative wholesalers and retailers to meet with agency officials on the matter in Washington on June 15 and 16.
A West Side hotel and several apartment houses in various parts of Manhattan figured in the residential realty transactions listed yesterday.
LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Churchill's report to the House of Commons today on his war conferences in Washington and North Africa:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 8 -- The German colony here has been split over the party call to the colors of all Germans living abroad, a highly placed member now among the dissidents told your correspondent today. Thirty per cent of the German colony has refused to heed the call and has applied for Swedish citizenship because of it.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The economic weaknesses of Italy that are expected to hasten her defeat are indicated in the latest estimates reaching Washington of the food situation, the coal and labor shortages and the inflationary effects of war financing in Italy.

Chinese victories on the banks of the Yangtze below Ichang apparently will prove as important economically as they are in the military field. A Chinese Army spokesman has just announced that the famous "Rice Bowl" around Lake Tungting is now securely in Chinese hands.

Upon the recognition of man's spiritual nature by all men depends the hope of any lasting civilization and peace, declared the Most Rev. Bryan J. McEntegart, Bishop-elect of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Ogdensburg, N. Y., in an interview yesterday at the Chancery office, 477 Madison Avenue, soon after the announcement of his designation as a Bishop.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Roosevelt reported today mounting evidence that the Axis powers were making "significant preparations" to use poisonous or noxious gases, and warned that such an attack against any of the United Nations by any Axis power "will immediately be followed by the fullest possible retaliation upon munition centers, seaports and other military objectives throughout the whole extent of the territory of such Axis country."

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- A New York stockholder, declaring that the voluntary plan of recapitalization filed by the Standard Gas and Electric Company would constitute a "gross fraud" if permitted to become effective, attempted unsuccessfully today to have the Securities and Exchange Commission take steps to plunge the holding company into receivership.

PHILADELPHIA, June 8 -- Warrants were sworn out today for the arrest of officials of an investment firm which Arthur J. Spragg, chief investigator for the Pennsylvania Securities Commission, said was one of several Canadian companies in a ring of stock swindlers that had mulcted Pennsylvania investors of several thousand dollars through the sale of shares in nonexistent tin mines, aircraft plants and oil properties.

LONDON, June 8 -- Most sections of the Stock Exchange were virtually inactive today, pending further war developments. After a firm opening Argentine rails eased under profit-taking, Central Argentine being 10s lower.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Among 252 United States soldiers listed today by the War Department as prisoners of Japan are eight from New York, three from New Jersey and two from Connecticut. All enlisted men, they are, with next of kin:

New York University will celebrate its 111th annual commencement exercises at 10:30 A.M. today at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus, 181st Street and University Avenue, the Bronx. About 15,000 persons are expected to attend.
CHUNGKING, China, June 2 (Delayed) -- Almost any one can look at an American diplomat in Chungking now without having to organize a safari into the bald peaks across the Yangtze.

Three American Liberator bombers representing enemy planes roared northward 200 miles through three States from Georgetown, Del., to Westchester County, N.Y., last night in a test air raid drill in which some 12,500,000 citizens were involved.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The first move for a bonus for World War II came today when Representative Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican of New York, introduced a bill to provide an average of $300 to $400 for every member of the armed forces and of the merchant marine when the war ended.

Demanding that the "food front" be reorganized again with "drastic changes" in national policies, Herbert Hoover declared last night that only one course will clear up "this muddle of uncontrolled food prices, local famines, profiteering, black markets and stifled farm production."

Five crippled college students received last night $100 cash scholarship awards to continue their studies at local colleges at exercises held under the auspices of the Men's League in Aid of Crippled Children at the Governor Clinton Hotel, Thirty-first Street and Seventh Avenue. C. Ira Funston, president of the organization, presided.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The War Mobilization Committee, headed by James F. Byrnes, held its first meeting today with President Roosevelt, who told reporters later that he and his home front war leaders discussed a great many subjects.

The motion-picture has a vital role to play in bringing the peoples of the Allied nations closer together, Leonid Antonov, special representative of the Soviet Cinema Committee in this country, said yesterday afternoon at a preview of the picture, "The Russian Story," in the Soviet Consulate, 7 East Sixty-first Street.

A thirty-six-inch water main under Lafayette Street burst during the blackout last night, flooding Foley Square, pouring tons of water into the BMT station there, and also interrupting service on the Lexington Avenue line of the IRT at the Duane Street station.

Justin W. Dart, president of United Drug, Inc., announced yesterday that the company was considering the calling for redemption later this year of its twenty-five-year 5 per cent debentures due on March 15, 1953, now outstanding in the amount of about $30,000,000. This is the only funded debt of the company.

Our market scouts report that rhubarb is now at the peak of its season, selling for the attractive price of approximately 7 cents a pound. As a matter of fact it is one of the cheapest vegetables available, and because it is arriving from near-by gardens it is especially fresh and fine.

HAVANA, June 8 -- Closer relations of the press of the American nations, the service to be rendered to democracy and Pan-Americanism, the protection of the newspaper man, freedom of the press, war censorship and the economic problems now faced by publishers in this hemisphere were considered by the second national and Pan-American press congress today.

The committee for the annual tea dance which will be held by the Young Women's Republican Club, Inc., on Sunday in the St. Regis Roof Garden, met yesterday afternoon at the hotel. Miss Elizabeth W. Darrow heads the executive committee for the dance and Miss Trini Sarmiento is vice chairman.
LONDON, June 8 -- An appeal has been made to Prime Minister Churchill for his intervention in the rising dispute over whether civil servants are entitled to join the Trades Union Congress.

A five-story house at 8 East Sixty-first Street, officially changed hands yesterday for the duration when the key was passed over, figuratively speaking, from Mrs. Moses Taylor Pyne, its owner, to Mrs. Charles Howland Russell Jr., chairman of the New York City Women's Council of the Navy League.

LONDON, June 8 (U.P.) -- Allied and Axis reports from Europe today told of a growing feeling among Nazi occupation authorities in Belgium and Northern France that Germany is doomed to complete defeat and of continuing sabotage and violence in the Netherlands, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The mystery of the "Sphinxes" that American service men have been smoking in Britain was cleared up today by the Quartermaster Corps. They were part of a batch of cigarettes shipped abroad with the first troops to sail to England, but things are geared now, a spokesman said, so it will not happen again.
CHUNGKING, China, June 8 (AP) -- A communique:

Production of electric furnace steel set a new monthly record of 398,057 net tons in May, an increase of 15,525 tons over the previous record, made in April, and 64,857 tons more than was produced in May, 1942, the American Iron and Steel Institute announced yesterday.

The public has been repeatedly told how a part of the gold owned by the Belgian Bank of Issue, instead of being shipped to America by the Bank of France, according to the instructions they had received from the Belgian Bank, was sent to Dakar and finally delivered to the Germans by the French authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- Federal aid to the States to assure adequate health and welfare services for the children of mothers employed on essential war jobs was urged at a hearing today before the Senate Committee on Education and Labor on the proposed "War-Area Child-Care Act."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 8 -- Sonny Tufts has been lent by Paramount to RKO to play the lead opposite Olivia De Havilland in "Government Girl" in return for Maureen O'Hara. Miss O'Hara's film has not been chosen. Fred MacMurray replaced Tufts in the lead of Paramount's proposed "Standing Room Only" to make the exchange possible.

FREDERIC S. MARQUARDT would be an American "colonial" if we used that term as the British do. He was born in the Philippine Islands and spent his childhood there. After attending school and college in the United States he went back to Manila and served as an associate editor of The Philippine Free Press from 1928 until 1941.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The House today passed its Senate-amended Bolton bill to provide more nurses for military, Federal government and civilian war service through subsidized training and the establishment of a uniform nurse reserve.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Helicopters equipped with litters for the evacuation of our wounded from inaccessible spots on far-flung battlefields are nearly ready for our troops, poised to invade Axis-dominated lands, it was revealed today at the annual meeting of the house of delegates of the American Medical Association by Brig. Gen. David N.W. Grant, air surgeon, Army Air Forces.

The main lesson of the last twenty-five years is that there can be no economic security without political stability, Dr. A. Loudon, Ambassador of the Netherlands to the United States, contended last night in an address before the Economic Club of New York at the Hotel Astor.
LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Daniel Noce, amphibious-war expert of United States forces, described today well advanced preparations for invasions at any one or several European fronts.

Sir William Beveridge supplements his much-discussed Beveridge Plan, first put forward in "Social Insurance and Allied Service," with a new book, "Pillars of Society: Wartime Essays and Addresses," which Macmillan will release in an American edition early in September.

Prime Minister Churchill, long an advocate of Mediterranean strategy and of the "eccentric" (off-center) attack, announced yesterday in the House of Commons that "amphibious operations of peculiar complexity and hazard on a large scale are approaching."

Fresh water fishing has slackened considerably in Connecticut, according to semi-official surveys made during the past week. The State's Board of Fisheries and Game has completed most of the stocking program which included the Housatonic and is now concentrating solely upon streams close to population centers.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 8 (AP) -- Jersey City gained a two-to-one edge in its three-game series with the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs in a twilight game tonight, winning by 4 to 1 behind the six-hit pitching of Tom Sunkel. Sunkel, who racked up his third straight triumph, outpitched Dick Conger, who allowed 11 hits to the Little Giants.

War has changed the farmer's wife from the popular role of "butter and egg woman" to that of a real "handyman," it became evident yesterday at the opening session of the Northeastern Farm Bureau Conference, embracing eleven States.
