The regional Office of Price Administration announced yesterday that fuel oil renewal forms will be mailed out by local rationing boards next week and at the same time urged home owners to "begin filling up their tanks in July."

BOSTON, June 8 (AP) -- The largest daily double of the New England season, $1,189.20 on twenty tickets, and a slashing come-from-behind victory by Robert Robertson's Arrow Rock in the $1,700 Quincy Purse for 3-year-olds featured today's card at Suffolk Downs.

MOSCOW, June 8 -- As the present war in Russia has developed and the spontaneous resistance movement has spread in occupied areas, the Russian General Staff naturally has been able to take more and more into consideration the enormous value of the Partisan movement, which has grown and flourished.

A revival of the Lynn Root-Harry Clork comedy, "The Milky Way," will be presented this evening at the Windsor Theatre by Lucia Victor's New York Stock Company as that firm's first bargain-price offering. Joey Faye and Lila Lee are co-starred in the production, which also includes Lewis Charles, Helen Gillette, Stanley Phillips, Max Leavitt, Bert Jeter, Jerry Sylvon and Marshall Reid. The comedy has been staged by Rodney Hale.

The Baseball War Bond League started a drive yesterday for $1,000,000,000 with pledges of $123,850,000 from banks, business houses and other organizations bidding for thirty-seven Yankee, Giant and Dodger idols who were "auctioned" off to the sponsors at a luncheon at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

I hope that the attitude expressed by Harold Callender in THE TIMES of June 5 does not represent the attitude of our government. "Responsible" observers are quoted as regarding the French struggle for self-expression and self-assertion as a "French farce" to be viewed by "us" with "indulgence."

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- A large-scale Japanese bomber and fighter attack on the American-held Russell Islands two days ago was repelled by United States fighter planes, with high losses to the enemy, the Navy Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- General Henri-Honore Giraud is planning to visit the United States, according to information in French circles today. General Giraud is said to have been invited by this government and to have accepted.
The incidence of meningococcus meningitis, pneumonia and tuberculosis here declined considerably last week, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.
As an active Red Cross worker I feel compelled to express my reaction to the current attempt to unionize the American Red Cross.

While general delivery of milk was normal yesterday, in accordance with the new skip-a-day system instituted under the order of the Office of Defense Transportation for the saving of gasoline, fifty drivers of a Bronx wholesale milk distributing agency refused to deliver 74,000 quarts of institutional and other large users, despite pleas of their union leader, until their employers stopped what the strikers termed was "overloading" of trucks.

AN AMERICAN AIR BASE IN INDIA, June 6 (Delayed) -- For one day let's stop gilding the lily and writing about glory and heroes and what a pleasure it is to die for one's country or to live in godforsaken climates thousands of miles from home.
Mrs. Ogden Goelet has arrived from Chevy Chase, Md., and is at the Weylin.

To save an estimated $500,000 a year the Board of Transportation has cut off-peak subway service on the West Side IRT lines in Manhattan. It announces that on July 4 more drastic cuts will be made on the three Independent lines which serve Queens. These cuts will also affect service in Manhattan and Brooklyn between midnight and 4:30 A.M. and between 9 A.M. and 4 P.M.

RYE, N.Y., June 8 -- Ellis Knowles, 56-year-old "baby" member of the United States Seniors Golf Association, today broke all existing records for that venerable body's championships when he tripped around the Apawamis course, his home layout, in 67 strokes, five under par.

NEWARK, N.J., June 8 -- Settlement for $45,000 of a suit brought by the seven children of the late Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Murphy of Jersey City, both of whom were injured fatally last year in a bus accident, was approved here today by Federal Judge Thomas F. Meaney.

Adoption by Congress of the Connally-Smith bill outlawing strikes and placing other restrictions upon organized labor would be tantamount to the introduction of Hitlerism in this country, according to a resolution adopted by the Association of General Grievance Committees of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen, representing practically all railroads in the United States.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association held yesterday its bitterest election since it was founded more than thirty years ago and reelected Patrolman Patrick W. Harnedy to the presidency. The meeting of nearly 300 delegates took place in the Hotel Commodore amid enthusiastic shouts for opposing candidates.

Except for increased price-fixing on the scale-down, trading in the cotton futures market yesterday duplicated the preceding sessions, with liquidation and transferring of the old-crop positions to the new crops, which more than offset the covering of the near months, depressing prices moderately for the sixth consecutive day.

CHICAGO, June 8 (AP) -- Judge Sherman Minton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals questioned a Federal prosecutor today to determine whether six German-Americans convicted of treason understood what rights they were signing away when they were seized by FBI agents last Summer.

Two thirteen-room and six-bath apartments in 33 East Seventieth Street have been leased to Isaac S. Heller, attorney, and to Mrs. Eleanor P. Hunt, respectively, through the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, agents. The Hunt lease was made in conjunction with Pease Elliman, Inc., brokers.
CHICAGO, June 8 -- Butchering of sheep and hogs last month set new high records for May, but production of beef and veal continued to fall, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

THE East-West battles on the baseball front have reached the cease-firing stage and the boys will be back in their own neighborhoods for a while, some of them sadder but wiser. Saddest of them all, but no wiser for the experience, are the once high-flying Phillies and Boston Braves.

CLEVELAND, June 8 (U.P.) -- Champion Jimmy Bivins knocked out Lloyd Marshall in the thirteenth round of their fifteen-round "duration" light-heavyweight title bout tonight before 18,448 fans in Cleveland Stadium.

Grandma is much younger than people think. The reason is not that Grandma at the age of 80 will sometimes put in an afternoon rolling bandages, or that at 75 she may hold her own against the youngsters in the community barn dance.

June Week has come again at Annapolis. Today 760 midshipmen graduate and will be addressed by the Secretary of the Navy. The Naval Academy was founded by George Bancroft, President Polk's Secretary of the Navy. It is no disparagement to his writings to say that the Academy is his most enduring monument.

Robert J. McKim was elected president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation at the directors' meeting yesterday. Mr. McKim, who will take office on July 1, succeeds Oswald W. Knauth, who requested that he not be re-elected. However, he will retain connection with the company in an advisory capacity.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 8 -- At the end of the first Cabinet council of the new government of General Pedro Ramirez, late today, announcement was made of the ending of martial law, which had been declared Friday after the military revolt that ousted the regime of President Ramon S. Castillo.

Informal conferences of both groups indicated yesterday that the majority and minority lines in the City Council would hold firm tomorrow when a Democratic proposal to override Mayor La Guardia's veto of budget cuts amounting to almost $10,800,000 is put to a vote.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- President Roosevelt said today that he was preparing a fiscal program for presentation to Congress before the Summer recess which it intends to take, and reiterated his demand for more receipts from taxes and savings.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., June 8 (AP) -- The General Synod of the Reformed Church in America voted today to ask Congress to amend immigration laws to abolish what it termed "racial discrimination" and permit citizens of all "cobelligerent nations" to enter the United States on a quota basis.

The ninety-eighth annual commencement exercises of Fordham University will be held today at 4 P.M. in the university gymnasium at Fordham Road and Third Avenue, the Bronx. The Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, Auxiliary Bishop of New York, will preside and the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university, win deliver the commencement address.

Faced with a serious manpower shortage, various laundry companies in the metropolitan area have been forced to close during the last week, it was revealed yesterday as one of New Jersey's largest laundries announced that it would close on Saturday because of inability to get help.

George Eliopoulos, a Greek refugee on trial with his brother, Elias, both charged with smuggling narcotics valued at $1,000,000 into the United States in 1930, denied yesterday before Federal Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo and a jury in Brooklyn that he had conspired violate the revenue laws by importing morphine hydrochloride without registering the shipment or paying Federal taxes.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- John L. Lewis stalked angrily out of a conference with the bituminous coal operators of the Appalachian region this evening and denounced the procedure as "farcical" and "a stultification of collective bargaining."

BERNE, Switzerland, June 8 -- On the eve of entering its fourth year of war on Thursday morning, Italy today looks back with a wistful glance on a conflict which began under the auspicious sign of militaristic imperialism and territorial conquest, but which for the past five months has developed into a relentless readaptation of the real values of existing internal institutions.

Subsidies are at best highly dangerous and two-edged weapons for "combating" inflation. The subsidies already announced by the OPA for butter and meat, and planned for coffee and fresh vegetables, will, in fact, directly foster inflation.
ANKARA, Turkey, June 8 (U.P.) -- President Ismet Inonu, addressing the sixth People's Party Congress today, indicated that Turkey would continue her policy of neutrality.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The $820,000,000 Department of Agriculture supply bill for the approaching fiscal year was chosen in the Senate today as the medium for a new attempt to invalidate President Roosevelt's executive order to require the deduction of soil conservation benefit payments to farmers in the setting of ceiling prices on agricultural commodities.

HANOVER, N.H., June 8 -- After sniffing the cool, clear air and gazing at the surrounding wooded hills, Gunder Haegg, the sensational Swedish runner who has seven world records to his credit, today compared his Dartmouth training quarters favorably with his homeland.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The War Production Board liberalized its official attitude toward the wool piece goods industry today through amending its Order M-73, wiping out all wool quotas assigned for the production of blended worsted and woolen yarns and cloth for civilian use and increasing the amount of wool usable for civilian products without restriction as to wool content.

Mrs. Lytle Hull gave a supper party last night in the Perroquet Suite of the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. Hermann Irion (Yolanda Mero) in tribute to the latter's services as general manager of the New Opera Company.

LONDON, June 8 -- In a corner of the heart of London there was held this afternoon a miniature world's fair by men and women driven from their native lands by the Germans or the Japanese or who were otherwise compelled to enter the conflict.

Fuffy is going to have a chance to grow another bean in another Victory garden -- there's no doubt about that. Whether it will be on a country estate or in his own family's backyard awaits all kinds of red tape, about which Fuffy knows absolutely nothing.

Selling of moderate proportions forced yesterday a further retreat in the stock market, although the edge was taken off the worst of the inroads by a steadying movement in the afternoon. Lack of any aggressive demand produced the lightest session of the month on the Stock Exchange, but turnover still held above the million-share mark, transfers amounting to 1,077,520 shares, compared with 1,212,820 on Monday.

That current fashion shows do not depend on pre-war fabrics or designs to be successful was proved once again yesterday when six champion amateur dressmakers and their needlework were presented here. Culminating its third annual national sewing contest, the National Needlecraft Bureau gave prizes to six winners in the Sert Room of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Although he specifically avoided predictions as to what will happen in the future, and especially in the near future, Winston Churchill has nevertheless delivered a speech before the House of Commons which is and must be interpreted as a trumpet signal for the beginning of an Allied invasion of Hitler's "fortress."

LONDON, June 8 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company, Ltd., reported today for 1942 that its profit before depreciation and other items amounted to 2,303,891. After deducting depreciation, obsolescence, directors' fees, employe pension funds, income tax charges and contingencies, there was left a net profit of 410,169, compared with 256,625 in 1941.

LONDON, June 8 -- Rome and Berlin reported today that British Commandos had assaulted the tiny island of Lampedusa on Monday night and had been repulsed. Allied military and naval quarters were silent on the enemy accounts of the operation, which -- if the reports were true -- appeared to be nothing more than a minor-scale probing for bigger blows to come.

"The Student Prince" is one of the drama's perennials which most deserves the overworked adjective of hardy. Each year it is out in one form or another, wandering the long road that stretches westward across the Hudson, showing itself to the operetta festivals of Summer and the middle cities' au ditoriums in Winter.

I hasten to congratulate you on your editorial in the June 4 issue, "The Showdown at Last." The New Dealers have stacked the cards in favor of organized labor and corrupt political organizations able to "deliver the vote."

Following a period of experimentation, the War Advertising Council is ready to go ahead with its coordinated program to explain all phases of the war to the people, Chester J. LaRoche, chairman, announced yesterday. The remaining job is chiefly one of educating advertisers and media to the need for cooperating to the utmost, he said.

Three hundred colleagues and friends of Dr. Hiram N. Vineberg, consulting gynecologist to the Mount Sinai Hospital for fifty years, attended a special ceremony in his honor yesterday afternoon in the hospital's Blumenthal Auditorium, Ninety-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, June 8 -- The Pacific fleet is gradually being strengthened, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, announced yesterday in confirming that Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, Commander in Chief of the Pacific Fleet, had recently conferred on the West Coast with Admiral Ernest J. King, Chief of Naval Operations and Commander in Chief of the entire fleet.

A huge green van shuttled yesterday from the Women's Shelter, maintained by the city at 630 East Sixth Street, to the Municipal Lodging House at 438 East Twenty-fifth Street, with which it has merged. Inside the shelter, in bare, dismantled but clean rooms, the twenty-five current occupants sat waiting patiently to be transferred to their new quarters.

The majority of newspapers will have to ration advertising space if another 10 per cent cut in newsprint consumption is put into effect, it was reported yesterday at a clinic on problems of large metropolitan newspapers at the Hotel Pennsylvania, where the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association is holding a wartime conference and exhibit.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 9 (AP) -- Two Sharp river battles -- with the Germans driven across a river on the central front and repulsed at a waterway below Kharkov -- were reported by the Russians early today, while German airports and the Soviet industrial city of Gorki were pounded again in the mighty and unabated aerial war.

CHICAGO, June 8 -- Prices of wheat firmed slightly today after a small early setback. Moderate buying was stimulated by the Washington report that Congressional authority had been granted definitely to the Commodity Credit Corporation to sell 50,000,000 more bushels of wheat for feed.

The Supreme Court jury that heard the $250,000 libel action by Dr. Jerome Davis, former president of the American Federation of Teachers, failed to agree yesterday and was discharged by Justice John F. Carew twenty-four hours after the seven women and five men had received the case.

With Maj. Gen. John J. Phelan, chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission, looking on, Henry Armstrong and Sammy Angott completed their heavy training at Stillman's Gym yesterday preparatory to their ten-round meeting tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

New price ceilings for butter and eggs go into effect today, Frank C. Russell, office of price administration director for the New York district, announced yesterday. Butter prices are reduced about five cents a pound and egg prices are increased two cents a dozen.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, which concluded its annual session here today, voted to establish a council on medical service and public relations, to "streamline" medical practice in America with changing times.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 9 -- Police precautions have been taken in Italian cities, principally in the north, following reports of a plot to demonstrate tomorrow in honor of Giacomo Matteotti, Socialist slain by the Fascisti on June 10, 1924. Tomorrow also marks the third anniversary of Italy's entrance into the war.

The improvement and return to sound individual owner-operation of some 100,000 farms with an aggregate of 15,000,000 acres and a population of nearly 500,000 persons, undertaken by life insurance companies which took over the properties in the depression, is now nearing completion, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- In his first public announcement as Director of War Mobilization, former Justice James F. Byrnes disclosed today that he had taken two steps intended to bring closer together the men with the "know-how" and those with the responsibility for organizing the country for war.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 9 (AP) -- British heavy bombers set fires and blasted targets in an attack Monday night on the ferry terminus and railway sidings at the Sicilian port of Messina, the Middle East Air Command said today. Aegean shipping was attacked yesterday.

In recognition of services performed during the last year by the Columbia Broadcasting System's Latin-American network, William S. Paley, president of CBS, and Edmund A. Chester, CBS director of short-wave broadcasting, received yesterday the Carlos Manuel De Cespedes National Order of Merit, highest civilian decoration of the government of Cuba.

The Police Department, seeking to trim its motor mileage to the hard necessities of the gasoline crisis, ordered yesterday that 109 patrol cars be taken off the streets, that supervising sergeants and lieutenants use shoe leather or public transit on their rounds and that commanding officers end the practice of riding to and from their homes in departmental cars.

Dr. Charles H. Wesley, president of Wilberforce University, Wilberforce, Ohio, speaking at a luncheon yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Commodore under auspices of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, urged an enlarged program of self-help in missionary activities.
CHUNGKING, China, June 9 -- 'What is a fair estimate of monthly living costs in Chungking?" an American inquires in this sweltering bureau.

The development of more copy writers who could contribute creative ideas to the selling of newspaper advertising was urged yesterday by Ray H. McKinney, president of the American Association of Newspaper Representatives, in an address at the closing session of the wartime conference of the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LONDON, June 9 (U.P.) -- Three British prisoners of war who sought sanctuary in the Vatican after their escape from a Rome hospital and who were protected by Pope Pius XII from the Fascist police arrived in London tonight.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 9 -- A role of increased importance for the Royal Australian Air Force in the Southwest Pacific is to be expected in the coming months, it was indicated today.
MOSCOW, June 9 (AP) -- The noon communique:
DETROIT, June 9 (AP) -- The White Sox climbed into a tie for fourth place with the Tigers by defeating Detroit, 3 to 1, in the opener tonight of a five-game series.

What is happening to fishermen in other States? If there are New Yorkers who believe they are victims of discrimination, they are hereby informed that New Jersey and Connecticut anglers are not riding to the fishing grounds in cars, either.
Frances Sebel, soprano; Carlos Buhler, piano, and the Pan-American Trio will give a concert tonight at 8:30 in Steinway Hall under the auspices of the Pan-American Women's Association.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., June 9 -- Bus lines transporting commuters, workers and shoppers between suburbs and the city do not come under the provisions of the Federal Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 according to an opinion of United States District Court Judge John Bright of Middletown, N. Y., received today by Norton Lexow, attorney for Rockland Coaches, Inc., of this village.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Establishment of a system of industry advisory committees matched by labor policy committees was announced by the Office of Price Administration today. The move, according to Administrator Prentiss M. Brown, is intended to assure OPA the benefit of advice from those connected with all industries affected by price regulations.

The Columbia Pictures Corporation had a net profit of $1,032,000 for the thirty-nine-week period ended on March 27, Harry Cohn, president, reported yesterday, comparing with $942,000 in the same period a year ago. The results were after Federal income and excess profits tax provisions of $2,288,000 and $648,000, respectively.
CHUNKING, China, June 9 (AP) -- A communique:
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

BERNE, Switzerland, June 9 -- President Roosevelt's pronouncement on gas warfare calls for no new fundamental declaration by Germany, it was said in the Wilhelmstrasse today. The German position was clearly defined when the subject previously figured in international discussion and that position remains unchanged, Berlin spokesmen said.

Although the manpower shortage in the laundry industry was felt yesterday in all parts of the city as the laundries continued to stretch out the time between pickup and delivery ten days and two weeks in some cases, spokesmen for some of the large laundries said that there was no longer a shortage of bleaches and that there was an ample supply of high grade soap to assure clean, white wash.

CHICAGO, June 9 (AP) -- A.E. Kelly, secretary-treasurer of E.H. Rollins Sons, Inc., investment bankers in New York, testified today before an examiner for the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company had made profits totaling $280,000 in thirty-three months of dealings with accounts of the former Methodist Episcopal Church, South.

BUENOS AIRES, June 9 -- Up to yesterday hopes had been entertained that all the Americas would form a united front to act simultaneously and in harmony with respect to recognizing the new Argentine government. That hope suffered a set-back, however, when it became known that several South American countries had announced their intention to grant recognition.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals here was told yesterday that the status of all Austrians was involved in an action for release of one interned as a "dangerous alien enemy." A major point was whether the man, Paul Schwarzkopf, became German when a Nazi decree abolished Austrian citizenship and conferred German citizenship on Austrians.

LONDON, Thursday, June 10 -- Striking at six key German airdromes on the Eastern Front Tuesday night in its campaign to break up preparations for an enemy offensive, the Russian Air Force damaged or destroyed between 150 and 160 planes at a cost of twenty-one of its own craft, the Moscow radio reported today.

Unless manpower problems which are unduly hampering output of wool fabrics are solved without further delay, the War Production Board's action in liberalizing raw material quotas in order to stimulate civilian supply will be meaningless, Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, declared yesterday in commenting on WPB's new wool conservation order M-73.

In his recent address on the "Health Aspects of Social Security in Britain" Sir William Beveridge had much to say about health insurance. On the quality of medical care he was silent beyond asserting that his plan "makes it part of the national minimum for every British citizen to be at all times as well as science can make him."

LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- The Allied ultimatum for the unconditional surrender of Pantelleria stirred widespread speculation today that General Dwight D. Eisenhower's forces might have begun an invasion of the Italian outpost islands. Reports of such operations persisted, although there was no confirmation in official sources in London.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 9 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

Increases in food production are insufficient to meet mounting direct war needs, and further cuts in civilian consumption are inevitable, Roy F. Hendrickson, deputy administrator and food distribution director of the War Food Administration, said last night at the dinner concluding the two-day war council of the American Retail Federation at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

HONOLULU, T.H., June 9 (AP) -- Hawaii's first chaplain of Japanese ancestry to enter the armed forces is Masao Yamada, 36 years old, a Congregational minister who says "God and guns will win the war for the United Nations."

MELBOURNE, Australia -- Very many Australians, including all our leading political and business men, have moved among American formations in this country and all have been impressed by the capacity inherent in them. They are staffed by experts in all walks of life, the highest grades of business executives as well as the highest grades of sailors, soldiers, surgeons and organizers.

Headed by Don Burham of Dartmouth, I.C. 4A. champion miler indoors and outdoors, twenty-four athletes have been entered by the New York A.C. to defend its National A.A.U. senior and junior titles in the championship meet at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, June 19 and 20.

Normal service BMT subway lines servicing Brooklyn and Queens was resumed at 2:30 P.M. yesterday after emergency squads had labored for nearly fourteen hours pumping out water that flooded the City Hall station Tuesday night when a water main broke during the blackmout.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The President met with Administration and Congressional leaders on United Nations relief and rehabilitation; saw Richard K. Law, M.P.; Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, and Alvanley Johnston, president of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers; received General Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay, and met with the Pacific War Council.

Joseph Harding, a war worker, who was busy in his garden in the rear of his home at 3841 Bailey Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday, thought he had seen an apparition when an 8-month-old buck deer leaped gracefully over his backyard fence.
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Action taken last week to increase production of farm machinery to 80 per cent of the 1940 level was announced today by Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board.

"Packaged" goods available in department stores now include prefabricated structures, albeit miniature ones. Capable of being put together in twenty minutes, the makers claim, prefabricated units comprising seven pieces went on display yesterday at Bloomingdale's.
Stalled by the weather, the Giants, Dodgers and Yankees remained idle yesterday, but will make an attempt to get going today.

Miss Pauline Thompson, 45 years old, who runs a laundry and works as a domestic in Port Washington, L.I., where she owns her own home, walked into the Children's Aid Society at 105 East Twenty-second Street two days ago to get a birth certificate.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 9 (AP) -- The track experts glibly dismiss Southern California's chances of winning its ninth straight National Collegiate A.A. title this weekend, but are a little confused when it comes to naming a probable successor.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The President evidently did not consider the news of the first official government connection of Bernard M. Baruch since 1920 important enough to announce at his press conference yesterday. But to the war administration in Washington it is an event of the highest consequence.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The executive department stepped squarely into the current tax picture today when James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, said that he would take a hand "in the shaping of future tax policy."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 9 -- The refusal by the garrison of Pantelleria to surrender unconditionally to the Anglo-American forces that have been hammering it by sea and air for seventeen consecutive days has unleashed another destructive attack on the island's defenses by British cruisers and destroyers and a formidable force of Allied bombers, including Flying Fortresses.

Warren W. Oley, director of farm marketing for New Jersey, told the Northeastern Poultry Producers Cooperative, meeting yesterday at the New Yorker Hotel, that developing Federal programs have left farmer cooperatives facing a highly uncertain future, although they are so important to agriculture that in his State alone they marketed more than $16,000,000 worth of farm products in 1942.

Discontinuance of an arrangement whereby standholders in nine municipal markets have been retailing about 70,000 pounds of beef a week was announced with regret yesterday by Daniel P. Woolley, Commissioner of Markets. Because of new OPA regulations that went into effect June 1, the wholesaler who supplied the meat to the standholders can no longer afford to do so, it was explained.

Random House has set June 25 as the publication date for the late Gustavus Myers's "History of Bigotry in the United States," which the writer took seventeen years to compile. After completing the manuscript last August, he collapsed and suffered an illness that culminated in his death at the age of 70 on Dec. 9.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 -- Eleanor Powell has received at her request a release from her Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract, which still had nine months to run. She had been at the studio for eight years. Miss Powell had been mentioned for the lead in the musical, "Along Broadway," but recently Ginny Simms was assigned to the part.

LONDON, June 9 -- The methodical obliteration of Rhenish Westphalia, the industrial region comprising roughly 960 square miles with a population of 4,000,000, is now being undertaken by "those two magnificent instruments," the Royal Air Force and the United States Eighth Air Force, the Earl of Selborne, Minister of Economic Warfare, explained today. This great target has come to be known as the Ruhr.

The use of 5,000 pounds of strategically important copper in the illicit manufacture of slide fasteners, "commonly known as zippers," was charged in Federal court yesterday to Abraham Ernst, the Atlas Fastener Company, Inc., and Rex Slide Fastener Corporation.

ALBANY, June 9 -- State Controller Frank C. Moore, addressing today's session of the annual convention of the State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials, discussed changes in municipal government procedure which become effective Jan. 1.
BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Bruce S. Campbell's Barbara Childs, the 6-5 choice, scored her second straight victory for her Towson, Md., owner today at Suffolk Downs when she won the Jess Read Purse.

A concert commemorating the one hundredth anniversary of the birth of the Norwegian composer, Edvard Grieg, will be given Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall under the sponsorship of Crown Princess Martha of Norway, to aid the American Friends of Norway and Norwegian Relief, Inc.

CHUNGKING, China, June 9 (U.P.) -- The Fourteenth United States Air Force, switching its operations against the Japanese in Indo-China after helping the Chinese win their greatest victory of the war in Central China, yesterday attacked Hongai, coal mining and shipping center.

TRENTON, June 9 -- The annual convention of the New Jersey Department, Grand Army of the Republic, was held at the Hotel Hildebrecht here today with only one member present. He was William H. Perrine, 97 years old, of Plainfield, one of the four surviving veterans of the G.A.R. in this State and the only one who was able to make the trip.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 -- Fourteen newly graduated Naval Academy midshipmen married today soon after they had received their diplomas from Secretary of the Navy Knox.

AT AN ADVANCED UNITED STATES FIGHTER BASE, in North Africa, June 8 -- (Delayed) (AP) -- American airmen bombing Pantelleria today also enjoyed a rare, cloud-seat view as British naval units pounded the same target from the sea.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Military authorities, faced with a mounting disparity between the production of high-octane aviation gasoline and the estimated requirements of the United Nations for aerial warfare, are experimenting with a new chemical "additive" calculated to increase the volume output from existing plants by 20 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The Senate, by a 23-54 vote, overrode today an attempt by Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia and colleagues of the economy group to force prompt abolition of the Farm Security Administration.

Despite official comment that Tuesday night's blackout was excellent from the standpoint of civilian cooperation, city courts and the police were still busy yesterday dealing with blackout regulation violators.

Declaring that in many instances the shoe industry is still producing footwear equal in quality to prewar merchandise, the National Shoe Retailers Association yesterday asserted that this achievement should be given full recognition by the trade and consumers, and not minimized.

Concerning the recent letter from Elisha M. Friedman, may I suggest that Mr. Friedman's theories concerning holding companies and the Securities and Exchange Commission are conclusively refuted by the record of proceedings before the Securities and Exchange Commission and by experience in practice before it?

Shareholders of two investment rusts, Pacific Southern Investors, Inc., and American Capital Corporation, are to vote on a merger on June 29, according to proxy material just mailed. The companies now have net assets of about $6,800,000 and $5,800,000, respectively.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 9 -- Josiah A. Stratton, retired realty man, who, as an expressman earlier in his career, carried baggage for President Ulysses S. Grant and President James A. Garfield when they were Summer residents here, died early this morning in Monmouth Memorial Hospital of injuries suffered last night in an automobile accident.

IT was at the Baseball Writers Dinner a few years ago that Bill Klem, the Old Arbitrator, arose to make a speech. He shuffled uncomfortably for a few moments, stammered a bit and finally threw away his prepared script. Clearing his throat, he boomed, "Now I feel all right. Let's go." Thereupon he launched into an impassioned talk which must have surprised him as much as it did his listeners.

BOSTON, June 9 (AP) -- Henry L. Hansen, 22-year-old former farm twirler for the Brooklyn Dodgers, helped do the "pitching" when the Coast Guard cutter Spencer sent a Nazi submarine to the bottom of the North Atlantic.

LONDON, June 9 -- A couple of weeks ago newspapers here were predicting that an invasion of the Continent was "only hours away." Last week-end they reported that the assault on Adolf Hitler's "fortress" could be expected "at any moment."

The Chinese flag flew high yesterday at the Navy Auxiliary Training School at Hunter College in the Bronx. A special two-decker reviewing stand on the drill field boasted a plush armchair. Policemen stood guard on the roofs of the campus buildings, double shore patrols were posted at each gate.
CLEVELAND, June 9 (AP) -- The Browns blanked Cleveland, 6 to 0, today behind the two-hit pitching of towering Bob Muncrief, dropping the Indians to seventh place.

The liberal arts colleges must stop worrying about what is going to happen to them during the war and start looking forward to the post-war days when they will be of the greatest value to the nation in its history, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, said yesterday at the university's ninety-eighth annual commencement.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 308 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, North African and Southwest Pacific areas and of 403 held as prisoners of war by Italy.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 (U.P.) -- The City Council voted late today to have an ordinance drawn up which would provide a thirty-day jail sentence for the wearing of a zoot suit in Los Angeles, in an attempt to stop open warfare between service men and teen-age hoodlums which had made the reat pleat and stuff cuff the mark of the outlaw.
LONDON, June 9 -- Activity in the stock markets was checked generally today by Prime Minister Winston Churchill's reference to the approach of large-scale war operations.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 10 -- General Douglas MacArthur flew to Sydney on Tuesday and conferred twice with Prime Minister John Curtin, it was announced officially today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission temporarily silenced today Sanford L. Schamus of New York, one of its former employes, by excluding him from further participation in a hearing on the recapitalization plan of the Standard Gas and Electric Company until all the testimony had been recorded. He had opposed the plan as a stockholder.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -The War Food Administration announced today it would make loans to eligible farmers on 1943-grown wheat at rates averaging nationally $1.22 a bushel at the farm. Rates under a similar loan program last year averaged $1.14 a bushel at the farm.

Procter Gamble was the largest advertiser in 1942, according to the fourth annual edition of "Expenditures of National Advertisers in Newspapers, Magazines, Farm Journals and Chain Radio," published yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

LOS ANGELES, June 9 (AP) -- Ralph M. Gelvin, associate director of Poston, Ariz., relocation center, says 450 American-born Japanese at the camp have refused to repudiate their loyalty to the Emperor of Japan or swear allegiance to the United States.
LONDON, Thursday, June 10 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Your June 7 editorial "The Anti-Strike Bill" is rather paradoxical. After pronouncing the bill "unsatisfactory" on several counts you proceed to urge its passage, apparently on the grounds that bad legislation is preferable to none. Such reasoning is open to serious questioning.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 9 -- Details of the damage inflicted in recent raids on Italy and Sicily reveal that widespread destruction was wrought by Flying Fortresses and Wellingtons of the Northwest African Air Forces and Liberators of the Ninth United States Air Force based in the Middle East.
ST. LOUIS, June 9 -- George (Whitey) Kurowski returned to third base for the Cardinals today for the first time since May 28 and led the world champions to a 4-to-3 victory over the Pirates.

ALBANY, June 9 (AP) -- The newly organized Eastern New York Power Corporation's petition for authority to issue $27,000,000 in securities to merge with two other concerns was denied today by New York's Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt sought Congressional support today for Administration plans for the establishment of a United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to feed and clothe millions of people in the liberated countries of Europe and Asia until they are able to become self sufficient.

Seventy-five service men from near-by camps will be guests at a supper party this evening in the garden of the Soldiers and Sailors Club of New York, 283 Lexington Avenue. The guests will be the playwrights, actors and directors of "The Army Play-by-Play," the series of five one-act plays which will be produced by John Golden at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre Monday night for the benefit of the Soldiers and Sailors Club.

A doctor who practiced extensively in compensation cases testified yesterday at the resumption of the Moreland inquiry at the Bar Association Building that one of his patients received 213 injections of novocaine in less than two years. He denied, however, that he prolonged treatments or that he ran "an assembly line" practice.

By the end of this year it is the intention of the Office of Price Administration to have specific price regulations in effect for almost all branches of the apparel industries, Abraham Boykoff, in charge of pricing for that agency's women's garment section, declared last night at a meeting of the National Association of House Dress Manufacturers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The Tax Commission revealed yesterday in its final report to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia that the total of assessed valuations on real estate and special franchises subject to taxation during the coming fiscal year was $16,011,211,556. This total is $47,472,280 less than the tentative estimate made in February and $111,762,899 less than the final figure for the current fiscal year ending June 30.

Fears that the current food subsidies program is planned as a means to make the food industry a "public utility" under strict governmental control, which will be continued indefinitely, were expressed yesterday by leaders of the industry gathered at the Grocery Manufacturers of America war conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Among those who helped swell the War Dog Fund at the War Fair Booth in Pershing Square yesterday were Mrs. Clark Winter of 4 East Sixty-sixth Street, who paid a fee and enrolled her greyhound Tully Brown, a retired racer, the 4F class.

The National City Bank of New York announced yesterday that its board of directors has authorized an increase of $7,500,000 in its surplus, thus increasing its surplus account from $77,500,000 to $85,000,000. The increase resulted principally from the receipt by the bank from the City Company of New York, Inc., in dissolution, of the proceeds of the recent sale by the company, of its stock holdings in the West Indies Sugar Corporation.
NEW YORK Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Mellon Evans have arrived from Pittsburgh, and are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 9 (AP) -- Back from North Africa where the RAF's "know how" perhaps saved his life in the desert, First Lieutenant H.B. (Buddy) Rosenson of New York has met the Queen and as a result of the two incidents regards himself as no longer anti-British.

Here is a recipe for a frosted feeling on a sultry day. First take a cold shower, apply a sprinkling of powder, and put on a crisp cotton frock. Then take a stout-bristled hair brush and get every last clinging tendril of hair smoothly up on the top of your head and fasten it securely with tuck combs.

An Argentine general named Arturo Rawson heads an uprising which leads to a new Cabinet in which the Minister of War is Edelmiro and the Minister of Agriculture is Diego Mason. It is a reminder that the original English-speaking element in the southern republics of South America has counted for a great deal more than its limited numbers would suggest.

Citing the fact that within the past week the city has taken title to seventeen properties in Manhattan alone for non-payment of taxes, Russell V. Cruikshank, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in an open letter to members of the City Council, yesterday said such transfers bordered on "confiscation," under existing tax conditions.

Vincent Astor, head of the American branch of the Astor family whose boyhood ambition to follow the sea was frustrated by his financial responsibilities, has been promoted to captain in the United States Naval Reserve, it was learned from Third Naval District Headquarters, here, yesterday.

Supplies of major oil products along the Atlantic Coast declined last week to within a fraction of the low point recorded in the week of May 8, according to the report of the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- John L. Lewis broke the Central Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association away from the Appalachian Operators Negotiating Committee today and made a tentative oral agreement on all points, including the portal to portal question.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., June 9 (AP) -- Two former American League pitchers, Bob Harris of the Athletics and Tom Ferrick of the Indians, collaborated on a one-hit performance today to give the undefeated Great Lakes Naval Training Station baseball team a 4-to-0 victory over the Cubs of the National League.

Murry Guggenheim, financier and philanthropist, left a net estate of $17,887,594, of which $4,729,623 will go to the Murry and Leonie Guggenheim Foundation, an estate tax appraisal filed here yesterday showed. Gross assets in the estate, before deduction of debts and expenses, were appraised at $18,887,594.

Individual spurts of strength checked yesterday a further deterioration of values in the stock market, and the list as a whole closed irregularly higher. The recovery was crowded into the final thirty minutes of business on the Stock Exchange and was accompanied by a substantial expansion in volume which, up until that period, had been woefully light.

The six-story apartment house at 612 Ocean Avenue, running through to Nineteenth Street, in Brooklyn, has been sold by Mrs. B. Badner to a buyer represented by H. Shapiro, attorney. It is on a plot 87.6 by 251 feet and was sold subject to mortgages of $343,350, according to Frederick Zittell Sons, the brokers.

Alec Templeton, blind pianist-composer, played and sang to the tune of more than $4,000 yesterday at the Four Freedoms War Bonds Show in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, sponsored by the Treasury Department, The Saturday Evening Post and the Fifth Avenue Association.

"Gildersleeve's Bad Day," which arrives at the Palace, is today's lone film newcomer. The RKO comedy is the second in the series featuring Harold Peary, creator of the radio character. Among the supporting players are Nancy Gates, Jane Darwell, Frank Jenks and Douglas Fowley.
BOSTON, June 9 -- Paced by a pair of homers with two out in the first inning, the Red Sox took a 3-to-2 verdict over the Senators today, and Tex Hughson recorded his fifth victory of the season.

"Dean James M. Landis, National Director of the Office of Civilian Defense, said earlier this week in a radio broadcast that the tremendous importance of the men, women and children who volunteer their services on the homefront, without pay and with scant recognition, is one of the discoveries of this war," observed George S. Van Schaick, regional OCD director, yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 9 (U.P.) -- Argentina's neighbor States moved swiftly to recognize her new revolutionary government tonight, forty-eight hours after President Pedro Ramirez's official bid for closer relations with the solidly anti-Axis nations of the Western Hemisphere.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 9 (AP) -- James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, said today that Japan's fleet has been "nailed to its own bases" and that aerial bombings are beginning to "soften the fortress of Europe." However, he declared that the time of victory still is uncertain, and talk of re-conversion of manufacturing facilities to peacetime products now is "premature and dangerous."

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senate and House conferees reached agreement today on a strike and labor control bill which chairmen of both conference committees described as stronger and more likely to prevent strikes than either the original Senate or House versions.

MOSCOW, June 9 -- The Red Air Force this June, as once again the thunder of giant battles impends on the Russian plains, is almost certainly stronger, both qualitatively and quantitatively, than at any previous time in comparison with its own previous peaks and with its opponent, Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Luftwaffe.
LOS ANGELES, June 9 -- There is no question of racial discrimination involved in the zoot-suit trouble here, Mayor Bowron told State Department officials in a telephonic conversation.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- Manpower shortages will trouble banks as long as the war lasts, William H. Spencer, regional director of the War Manpower Commission, told members of the American Institute of Banking at their forty-first annual meeting today.

WICHITA, June 9 -- As a result of the steel shortage, railroads will receive only 26,000 cars this year instead of the 80,000 which were requested as necessary to meet their requirements, George H. Shafer, president of the National Association of Shippers Advisory Boards, told the Trans-Missouri-Kansas Shippers Board here today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Dr. Evaline M. Burns, Chief of the Economic Security and Health Section, National Resources Planning Board, said today that the new Wagner Social Security Bill differs from the recommendations of the NRPB, which the President sent to Congress last March.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 9 -The West End of Berlin looks more like a battlefield than a city after the devastating Royal Air Force raids, according to recent arrivals from the Reich capital.

To the surprise of a great many, but with a dash and power that brought joy to his backers, Le Havre yesterday won the Shevlin Stakes for Helen Murphy. Over a track deep in mud, the son of Pilate upset the favored Bill Sickle and Famous Victory in the mile and a sixteenth run which has been one of the stake features at Aqueduct since 1925.
William R. Brennan, president of Brennan Sloane, Inc., contractors, has been elected a director of the Federation Bank and Trust Company.

The Railroad Federal Savings and Loan Association has sold the one-family house at 1358 Gillespie Avenue, the Bronx, to Frederick Sabo, the tenant, through the Eugene J. Busher Company, which also sold for the Home Owners Loan Corporation the dwelling at 1837 Victor Street to Rocco Marino. Louis Baldini was co-broker in the latter deal.

Tuesday evening's simulated air raid had its encouraging aspects. The "raiders" were picked up and followed over Delaware, New Jersey and New York, and likewise over Southwestern Connecticut, whose population had not been led to expect this intrusion. Major Gen. Thomas A. Terry, head of the Second Service Command, said that every one, the public included, had clone "a splendid job." Mayor La Guardia also expressed satisfaction.

Effecting a just and workable peace when the war ends probably will be the most difficult task that has ever faced mankind, but this task will be lightened immeasurably if our country is willing to do away with isolationism forever, Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase declared yesterday at New York University's 111th annual commencement exercises.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Congress learned from the Selective Service System today that 89,327 government employes of military age have been deferred from draft call by 6,190 of the 6,270 local boards in the United States, on the ground that they were essential to the war effort in their positions.

The principal elements of a plan for unification of the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company and the New York, Lackawanna Western Railway Company, intended to bring about a definite settlement of pending tax litigation and future tax problems as well as a reduction in system fixed charges, were announced yesterday by Lee P. Stack, president of the New York, Lackawanna Western, at the annual meeting of its stockholders.

The New York Stock Company hopefully opened a season last evening at the Windsor, but rather unwisely chose as a first bill "The Milky Way." A comedy about the prizefight racket by Lynn Root and Harry Clork, it ran for a time in the Spring of 1934, but then it was better served by acting which managed to disguise its meager detail.

LONDON, June 9 -- President Roosevelt's strong warning to the Axis, in a statement at his press conference yesterday, that the United States would retaliate if any enemy started gas warfare, occasioned deep interest and, because of its unexpectedness, some surprise in certain British military circles here today.

Declaring that the shortages of food for human consumption and feed for livestock throughout the nation would become critical in six months under prevailing conditions in agriculture, J.A. McConnell, chairman of the Feed Industry Council, a national body, urged yesterday that the farmers "mobilize the power to have Congress act" in defense of the nation's interests in food production.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 10 (AP) -- A single Allied bomber touched off a terrific explosion at Nabire, Dutch New Guinea, yesterday, apparently hitting a munitions warehouse, the High Command announced.

Christmas, '42, was the bicentennial of Sir Isaac Newton's birth. In anticipation the Pilgrim Trust must have begun negotiations for the purchase of his birthplace. Its transfer as a gift to the nation was reported yesterday. Woolsthorp Hall or Manor is its rather pretentious name.

ALGIERS, June 9 -- The French Committee of National Liberation expects joint recognition by the American and British Governments of its status as trustee for the French people, the representative of French interests in the conduct of the war and the government of the empire.

RYE, N.Y., June 9 -- Although the soliloquy of the United States Seniors Golf Association is "to tee or not to tee, that is the question," the rains that came today to Apawamis where those venerable but never aged gentlemen are playing their annual championship failed to raise any such issue.

The last progress report of William M. Jeffers will not be read with much satisfaction by the advocates of home-grown rubber. In pre-Pearl Harbor days, when the rubber program was still nothing but hope and chaos, plans were made for the planting of guayule, cryptostegia and Russian dandelion, and for the exploitation of Latin-American rubber.

MEDIA, Pa., June 9 -- William Donner Roosevelt, 10-year-old grandson of President Roosevelt, today was ordered arraigned in Delaware County Juvenile Court on Friday by Judge Albert Dutton McDade in the fatal shooting of his playmate, A. Lewis Hutchinson, 11, last Sunday evening.

The Blackfriars Guild will conclude its season on Saturday evening, when "Moment Musical." the group's current play, closes. It had been scheduled to continue through Sunday, but is suspending a day to allow one of the players to fill a role in an out-of-town stock company.

The Italian official commentator puts it mildly when he notes that the war looks different than it did three years ago today, when Mussolini joined his Axis partner to profit by the defeat of France. Seldom has there been a more striking manifestation of historic irony and retribution than the contrast between Italy's position of June 10, 1940, and June 10. 1943.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 9 -- Benny Woodall, blond Texan named as a co-respondent in the divorce suit brought by William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey against Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey, testified today before Supreme Court Referee J. Addison Young that he was only a family friend of Mrs. Dempsey and was waiting to take a street car home when found barefooted last Nov. 22 with her in a Los Angeles apartment.

A city-wide campaign to have all merchants display new Office of War Information posters in their windows twice a month was started yesterday by the Kips Bay Boys Club Nature Boy Scout Troop 472, led by 20-year-old Seaman Anthony Darrigo, a wounded hero of the Battle of Midway.

Undoubtedly there are many women who believe that deep fat frying -- a practice virtually impossible under rationing -- is the only acceptable way of cooking soft shell crabs. The proprietor of a downtown sea food restaurant knows a more timely method, however, which requires much less shortening and which produces equally appetizing results.

CHICAGO, June 9 -- A small amount of mill buying and reports from Washington that the move to exclude benefit payments in figuring ceiling levels, were factors in lifting wheat prices slightly today on the Board of Trade here. Offerings were light, but buying was inclined to slow up even on small rallies.

Champion My Own Brucie, 8-year-old black cocker spaniel and one of the greatest specimens ever produced in this country both as a show dog and as a sire, died suddenly yesterday morning at his home in the Dungarvan Kennels in Roslyn, L.I.
Large apartments in buildings in Fifth and Park Avenues were among new leases reported yesterday by renting agents.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 9 -- Machine guns and other weapons that for the past several days had frowned from the roof and windows of the Government House were withdrawn this morning and the revolutionary troops who had occupied Buenos Aires since last Friday returned to their barracks outside the city.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 9 -American troops stationed in New Zealand have been mailing butter back to the folks at home but if they figured on circumventing ration regulations they reckoned without knowledge of the operations of the Customs Service and the Office of Price Administration.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 9 -- Despite grief over the death of her son, Major Kermit Roosevelt, Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, 81-year-old widow of the twenty-sixth President, participated today in the presentation of graduation certificates to eighteen boys of the Seamanship Training Corps of the Oyster Bay High School, the first of 125 groups to be organized in the nation among youths of high school age.

The pamphlet report of the Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, made public yesterday, showed in its consolidated balance sheet as of Dec. 31 last $17,176,175 unreimbursed expenditures and accrued fees that had not been paid under United States Government cost-plus-fixed-fee contracts.

More than 243,640,000 tons of raw materials were consumed in blast furnaces and steelmaking furnaces last year to produce 62,446,000 tons of finished rolled steel products, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The figure does not include ferro-alloys and allowing metals also used in many types of steel, the report explains.

LONDON, June 9 -- The writing of the pastoral letter defying Nazi power to deport Netherland workers to the Reich, read in all the Roman Catholic churches of the Netherlands on May 16, has impressed even the best-informed persons here on the will of the Netherlands to resist the occupying power.

BRADFORD, Pa., June 9 (AP) -Walter S. Hallanan, president of the Plymouth Oil Company and a member of the Petroleum Industry War Council, declared tonight that policies of the Office of Price Administration "are forcing small independent oil operators out of business and heading the oil industry toward the most gigantic monopoly in the history of America."
WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Former Justice James F. Byrnes, who now is Director of War Mobilization, sought today to charge off his Vice Presidential "boom" to the zeal of "my newspaper friends."

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Replying to complaints from landlords against the operation of rent control, the Office of Price Administration today issued a survey of the business record of some 40,000 rental dwellings before and after rent control to show "beyond controversy'' that landlords generally are better off under it than they were in the three-year pre-war period 1939-41.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Because the movement of iron ore on the Great Lakes is approximately 8,500,000 long tons behind last year's operations at this time, the Office of Defense Transportation broadened its permit system today to include almost every commercial vessel on the lakes.

Through a late rush of shortcovering operations under a scarcity of contracts, the cotton futures market worked yesterday in the final hour of trading from losses of 9 points to gains up to 6 points, terminating a six-day decline of values.

PEARL HARBOR, June 9 -- While Bataan and Corregidor were fighting desperately during their last days a band of Navy torpedo-men from the submarine tender Canopus braved bombs and shell fire to transport the ship's torpedoes to a tunnel in Corregidor. One of their number, a 42-year-old former cowboy from Elizabeth, Col., told the story of these heroes here today.

Frank Siclari, 35-year-old Second Avenue theatre manager who thought he had trumped Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's anti-bingo edict when he invented and advertised "Trump Bingo," found himself on the losing side when he appeared for a hearing yesterday in Yorkville Court charged with five violations of the administrative code.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. June 9 -- Seven hundred and sixty-five white-clad Naval Academy graduates heard the Secretary of the Navy, Frank Knox, state today that the initiative in the war "is all ours" and that "each day sees fresh victories" in the Atlantic theatre of war.

Two veterans of the ring wars, both aiming in the same direction, will find their paths crossing in the ring at Madison Square Garden tonight when Henry Armstrong and Sammy Angott clash in a ten-round lightweight bout. Both boxers, ex-lightweight champions, are on a comeback trail and the winner expects a chance at Bob Montgomery and the crown he recently took from Beau Jack.

The executive board of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations has adopted a "Declaration of Principles on Post-War European Jewry and Palestine,'" which it made public yesterday through its official publication, Liberal Judaism.

Diederich H. Ward was unanimously elected president of the Life Underwriters Association of the City of New Lork at a luncheon meeting yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Mr. Ward, who is with the C.B. Knight Agency of the Union Central Life Insurance Company, will assume office on July 1.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 -- Mine union officials argued tonight that hopes for peace in the Appalachian coal fields were blasted by Secretary Harold L. Ickes' decision to impose fines on participants in the June 1-7 walkout.

The scope of a study Park Commissioner Robert Moses had planned to make of post-war plans to promote the New York women's clothing industry has been limited to more "practical" dimensions, he indicated yesterday.

President Roosevelt states that the 35 billion dollar "inflationary gap" in our national income represents so potent a danger to our economic stability that steps must be taken to remedy it -- presumably through higher taxes or some form of enforced savings.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- A program designed to effect further conservation of private motor vehicles which will apply to all parts of the country as well as to all phases of the private truck industry will be announced in the near future by the Office of Defense Transportation, delegates to the annual meeting of the American Retail Coal Association were told today.

The six-story apartment house at 5420 Fifteenth Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by the 5420 Fifteenth Avenue, Inc., to an investing client of Louis M. Rogovin. The property was held at $200,000. Moses H. Hoenig represented the seller and Nathan Grossman the buyer.

The woman of leisure was berated yesterday by a spokesman for the Office of War Information. Not only was she called as "foolish looking as the hardy young man who is not fighting" but a direct plea was made that the working woman be given priority in consideration of style and design in the fashion world.

A most regrettable manifestation of the national coal controversy has been the disposition of government spokesmen to brand the miners as disloyal and to threaten them with induction into the armed service as punishment.

Muskie fishing in Chautauqua Lake may improve considerably within the next year or two. This is the principal fishing ground for muskellunge in New York State and consequently it has been receiving the attention of the Conservation Department.

LONDON, June 10 -- The Royal Air Force's part in reverse lend-lease operations included a gift to the United States of 675 planes up to March 31, it was announced tonight. The planes included many Spitfires as well as communication and training types.

CLEVELAND, June 10 (AP) --The Browns defeated the Indians, 2 to 1, at Municipal Stadium tonight. Knuckle-Baller Johnny Niggeling gave only three hits in the first seven innings, but needed relief from both George Caster and Fritz Ostermueller when Cleveland threatened in the final two frames.

From points of vantage on streets in twenty-eight sections of Brooklyn and the Long Meadow in Prospect Park more than 100,000 persons joined 85,000 Sunday-school children yesterday in marking the 114th Anniversary Day parades of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union, one of the oldest unbroken traditions in the borough.

It is news when Britons go radical and Americans set their face against change. It has happened. Salesgirls in a London department store threaten to strike against an order forbidding them to come to work barelegged.

Wilhelm A.G. Meyer, 54-year-old German army veteran and naturalized citizen of the United States, was found guilty yesterday of having given false testimony before an Army board of officers. The verdict was returned by a jury in Federal court, which deliberated only fifteen minutes over the evidence presented by John F. Sonnett, chief assistant United States attorney.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The White House announced this afternoon that President Roosevelt has signed the Pay-as-You-Go tax bill. The announcement came soon after James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, completed a two-and-a-half-hour conference with fiscal chiefs to shape a new tax and savings program for Congressional action.

Earnings of the A.O. Smith Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the quarter ended with April showed a tremendous increase over the corresponding period a year ago, reflecting the huge expansion of production on military ordnance and equipment, according to the report announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- A Swedish Foreign Office spokesman denied today Russian magazine charges that Sweden had systematically and wantonly violated neutrality in favor of Germany, but he admitted a few isolated instances where the Nazis had been aided.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, June 11 (U.P.) -- A communique:
LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as broadcast from Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 10 (AP) -- A Middle East Command communique:

Many men on the fighting fronts are worrying a lot less about their families back home because of the work being done by the Vocational Service of the Civilian Activities Division of the Army Emergency Relief at 165 Broadway.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 10 -- The Argentine Government gave its first tangible proof of its desire to comply strictly with all its international commitments by issuing a decree late this evening prohibiting the use of secret codes in international wire less communications. This action was taken in compliance with the resolution of the Rio de Janeiro Conference of 1941.

The report of the Western Union Telegraph Company for the first four months of this year, issued yesterday by A.N. Williams, president, shows a net income of $2,001,248, after all operating expenses, taxes and other charges. This was equal to $1.91 a share on the company's outstanding capital stock.

Two well-known investment houses, Y.E. Booker Co. of Washington and Keen Co. of Philadelphia, are being dissolved, according to announcements yesterday. The first firm is being absorbed by Alex. Brown Sons, which will take over its Washington office on July 1 and admit Y.E. Booker as a general partner.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 10 -- Life with William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey was a series of quarrels, with unwarranted jealousy causing the former world's champion heavyweight pugilist to resort to fisticuffs, Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey testified today before Supreme Court Referee J. Addison Young in support of her suit for a separation.
ON A COUNTRY RACE-COURSE, Somewhere in England, June 10 -- Private Victor Roedel of Spokane, Wash., was celebrating his twentieth birthday. He spoke gravely, as befitted a man of his years.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Navy must retain its power to renegotiate war contracts, the House Naval Affairs Committee was told today by James V. Forrestal, Under-Secretary of the Navy, because no fixed formula to prevent profiteering could be devised to take its place.

WATERTOWN, Mass., June 10 -- Recent advances in compounding and processing synthetic rubber mean that Americans soon will be using man-made rather than natural rubber to keep their feet dry, according to C.L. Muench, president of Hood Rubber Company, a division of B.F. Goodrich Company.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson angrily denounced today as "absolutely and completely false" and as "sinister rumors" publication by a columnist that the War Department had agreed to furnish contraceptives and prophylactic equipment to members of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps.

CHUNGKING, China, June 10 (AP) -- Reinforced Japanese detachments, making a stand after almost two solid weeks of retreat, were reported by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's High Command today to have counter-attacked Chinese forces closing upon Owchihkow, near the Yangtze eighty-five miles southeast of Ichang.

A nation-wide drive for unwanted and unplayable phonograph records will be conducted from July 3 to 31 by Records for Our Fighting Men, Inc., it was announced yesterday. The chief collecting agents will be 1,500,000 volunteers from the American Legion and the American Legion Auxiliary, who will carry on a house-to-house canvass.

"Guadalajara," a Mexican musical importation, will have its local premiere today at the World Theatre. The film, which has English dialogue titles, includes Pedro Armendariz, Chaflan, Esperanza Baur and Emma Roldan among its leading players.

Dr. Charles L. Engelsher, whose patients included many compensation cases, testified yesterday at the Moreland investigation that at least five ex-convicts had aided his practice since he began operation of the Parkchester General Hospital in the Bronx two years ago.

A call for 300 women radio assembly students was issued yesterday by Mrs. Anna Rosenberg, regional director of the War Manpower Commission. The students are needed for a "double quick" earn-as-you-learn course in the elementals of radio being given by the National Youth Administration, 145 East Thirty-second Street.
ALBANY, June 10 -- Following is the report of nutrition made to Governor Dewey by the Emergency Food Commission of the State of New York:
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Incendiary bombs rained down in the middle of Madison Square Garden last night as the Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization staged a spectacular rally in connection with its campaign to recruit 500,000 additional civilian defense workers.

FALLON, Nev., June 10 (AP) -- Sheriff R.J. Vannoy said today that Army authorities have tentatively identified the bodies of two persons found dead twenty-seven miles east of here yesterday as Second Lieutenant Ralph Fischer, 34, stationed at Gowen Field, Boise, and his wife, Marian Burke Fischer.
LONDON, Friday, June 11 (U.P.) -- A special Russian communique broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor here:

Nearly 11,000,000 service men and women have been guests of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee at its headquarters, 99 Park Avenue, or at recreational centers operated by affiliated agencies and community committees, according to the organization's first report, made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Oats and rye paced today a strong recovery in the grain markets on the Board of Trade. Local buying of oats, especially the July, in the late trade was the feature. Prices for that grain were the highest since 1920.

The Central Railroad Company of New Jersey last year earned, after taxes and fixed charges, $5,046,664 or $18.39 a share on the outstanding common stock, more than 56 per cent of which belongs to the Reading Company, according to a report issued yesterday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 10 -- Waves of American and British bombers and fighter bombers hammered the beleaguered island of Pantelleria for the eighteenth consecutive day yesterday as the Allied offensive against the Italian outpost continued.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 10 -- Prospects that new offensive blows will be struck against the Japanese by United Nations forces soon were enhanced today by an announcement that General Douglas MacArthur and Prime Minister John Curtin had met to discuss the war situation and by an optimistic statement from Mr. Curtin.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- A daily double high for the New England season was set at Suffolk Downs today for the third time in six racing days as the combination of Phil Schwartz's Cabinisi and J.H. Stotler's Cherry Crush returned $1,213.40 on eighteen $2 tickets.

TRENTON, N.J., June 10 -- The State of New Jersey today decided to continue to hold 3,242 shares of stock of the United New Jersey Railway Canal Company, valued on the State's books at $326,000, despite an offer of a profit of $516,920 if it would sell them.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 (AP) -- Charles Chaplin agreed today to pay $2,500 cash and $100 a week for the support of Joan Berry, pending trial of a suit to determine paternity of her unborn child. At the same time he explicitly denied that he was the father.

Efforts continue to draft a plan of price control on furs. A meeting of the committee of the Retail Fur Council is scheduled for today and several committees are working on the basic ideas of the control plan sponsored by the National Federation of the Fur Industry.

The cooperation between the members of the United Nations today forms a pattern that can be projected into the post-war world and used as a nucleus for the development of a system of international security, Henri Bonnet, Commissioner of Information in the newly constituted French Committee of National Liberation jointly headed by Generals Charles de Gaulle and Henri Honore Giraud, declared yesterday.

EUGENE, Ore., June 10 -- Incendiary bombs carried by free balloons have been dropped on Oregon Forest by the enemy in attempts to start fires, Lieut. Col. James W. Fraser, member of an Army party now touring logging and lumber operations in this area, disclosed today.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., June 10 -- A dimple-cheeked little girl of 3 or 4, who was unable to say where she lived or who her parents were, was taken to the Nassau County Children's Shelter in Mineola late tonight after the Fifth Precinct of the Nassau County police here had been unable to find out where she belonged.

PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) -- Jake La Motta of the Bronx jabbed out a decision tonight in ten rounds over Pittsburgh's Fritzie Zivic, the judges disagreeing and Referee Al Graybar raising Jake's hands to draw loud boos from the crowd of 10,000.

Bank clearings in the twenty-three principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $8,123,193,000, an increase of 4.6 per cent from the preceding short week and 27.3 per cent above the $6,382,502,000 volume recorded in the comparable week last year, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
PHILADELPHIA, June 10 -- The Yankees swarmed all over Jesse Flores and the Athletics in one motion at Shibe Park today as they triumphed by 8 to 2.
DETROIT, June 10 -- Office girls at the Ford Motor Company's Highland Park plant reported for work today dressed in slacks, a truce having been reached in the slacks-or-dresses controversy.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The ban on pleasure driving in the twelve Northeastern States began to show results last week in increased stocks of gasoline for the shortage area, Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior and Petroleum Administrator for War, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Unex pected candor on the part of Gen eral Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay, who is here on an offi cial visit and who held his first press conference this afternoon outside his own country, accidentally revealed the intention of the United States to recognize the new government of Argentina.

ALBANY, June 10 -- The State Emergency Food Commission submitted to Governor Dewey today a four-point nutrition program for maintaining public health and morale in the face of a necessary shift to a wartime diet lacking the usual amount of animal products.

The Nazis have met a major defeat in their efforts to destroy the Christian faith in the Third Reich, and the German churches, Protestant and Roman Catholic, are now planning methods of cooperation with religious forces in other countries to build a lasting peace when Hitlerism has been overthrown, according to a report reaching Religious News Service from an exceptionally reliable Scandinavian source.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 140 West 58th Street, between Sixth and Seventh Avenues, was sold by the Bucknell Estates, Inc., Nathan Shulman, president, to Joseph Berger through the Raymond P. Quinn Company, brokers.

Although there seem to be a sufficiency of eggs at present, the seasonal peak has passed and production is decreasing steadily. Most storage eggs are reserved for military and lend-lease purposes, and with the increased demand caused by scarcities of meat and poultry it is probable that the fresh variety will not be plentiful enough to go around.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 5 were 1 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. This followed a gain of 43 per cent in the week ended May 29 over the like week of last year.
Violation of the ban on pleasure driving may have saved Anthony J. Passera's life, it developed yesterday, but cost him a penalty of ten weeks' gasoline rations.
