The story about Spanish ships signaling to Axis U-boats the movements of Allied convoys "has been denied a million times, but you can deny it again if you want to," Juan Cardenas, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday in reply to questions as he arrived at La Guardia Field by clipper, returning from Spain.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -- The Cardinals beat the Pirates, 5 to 0, tonight with the help of two runs driven in by Pitcher Max Lanier on a second-inning single. Lanier had nine strike-outs while the world champions were working on Pirate pitchers Hank Gornicki, Fred Rescigno and Harry Shuman.

LONDON, Friday, June 11 (U.P.) -- Berlin reported today that Russian troops, in a bid to end the long stalemate on the front west of Rostov, had forced a passage of the Mius River, and reports of both sides described furious air fighting in a 450-mile stretch from Leningrad to Orel.

CAMP STEWART, Ga., June 10 (U.P.) -- Camp Stewart authorities said today that during "a riot of colored troops" last night a military policeman was killed and four other military police wounded. None of the Negroes was injured.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 375 United States soldiers missing and three killed in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A pessimistic crop report today said that prospects were less promising than at any time in the last three years, but a statement afterward by Chester C. Davis, War Food Administrator, said that total food production this year might equal the 1942 record if farmers had average weather and other breaks from now on.

JERSEY CITY, June 10 (AP) -- The Little Giants and Montreal divided a twilight double-header tonight. The Royals took the opener, 2 to 0, in eight innings. Jersey City won the nightcap, 1 to 0, behind the two-hit pitching of Rube Fischer.

LONDON, Friday, June 11 -- Gratitude for the part the United States has played in the projected establishment of a United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was expressed on all sides in the British capital yesterday. Satisfaction that something comprehensive was going to be done to aid the stricken peoples was coupled with the hope that it would be the first step by the allied powers toward the post-war program.

LOS ANGELES, June 10 -- Service men and young zoot suit wearers engaged in new outbreaks today as State investigators, under orders from Governor Earl Warren, began probing for the basic causes of a week-long series of disorders which have placed Los Angeles "out of bounds" for most Navy personnel.
Major Gen. Louis McC. Little, U.S. M.C., and Mrs. Little have arrived from Washington and are at the St. Regis.

An eight-point program for the wartime control of the food industry by government was adopted by acclamation yesterday at the closing sessions of the war food conference of the Grocery Manufacturers of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Despite the fact that next week will be income tax week, the Treasury made known late yesterday that it will make withdrawals on June 15 and 17 from government war loan accounts in commercial banks. For the Second Federal Reserve District the withdrawals will amount to $205,307,300 on each day and for the country as a whole they will amount to $422,859,500 on each day.

RYE, N.Y., June 10 -- Trouble with a round of golf such as Ellis Knowles played Tuesday when he shot a 67 in the opening round of the United States seniors' championship at Apawamis is that it leaves nothing for the future.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt received in person yesterday from Dr. Herbert Evatt, Australian Foreign Minister, an invitation to extend her travels to the Pacific area.

LONDON, June 10 -- The stock markets here were steady today and price changes were comparatively few. Gilt-edge stocks saw the 3 1/2 per cent War Loan down another 1-16 to 103 1/4, but other issues in this section were steadier. Among the home rails London, Midland Scottish was 1/8 higher at 32 3/8.

The Sugar Research Foundation, Inc., 99 Wall Street, was founded yesterday as a non-profit organization to conduct research and distribute factual information about sugar in the human diet. Joseph F. Abbott, head of the American Sugar Refining Company, is president of the group.

Between Mr. Roosevelt and his guest, General Don Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay, there is more than a formal and official relation. In 1941 Mr. Roosevelt invited the general to send his young son, stricken with infantile paralysis, to Warm Springs. The invitation was accepted.

To aid member banks of the Federal Reserve System in bolstering their dwindling excess reserves the Federal Open Market Committee, acting for the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, made net purchases of $419,232,000 of government securities in the open market in the week ended on Wednesday, it was disclosed yesterday.

Frank Siclari, 35-year-old manager of the Clifton Theater, 1034 Second Avenue, was fined $235 with an alternative of seventy-three days in jail by Magistrate Morris Rothenberg in Yorkville Court yesterday on conviction of four violations of the Administrative Code.

The gasoline shortage, as it affects municipal functions, has been mastered by all city departments, which have absorbed varying cuts adding up to a 20 per cent over-all reduction in gasoline use without dropping any essential services, it was reported yesterday by Commissioner Edwin A. Salmon, municipal petroleum administrator.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP) -- Lefty Oscar Judd of the Red Sox chalked up his sixth victory of the season against one defeat as he held the Senators to three scattered singles today and shut them out, 2 to 0.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed an increase of $419,232,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

HANOVER, N.H., June 10 -- Since he has seven world records to his credit, the training methods of Gunder Haegg, Sweden's unparalleled runner, must be thoroughly sound, but most American track authorities would be flabbergasted.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Expressing conviction that price rollbacks on food would be extended to many more commodities, members of the Senate Banking Committee opened a fight today to restrict use of subsidies to compensate for the price cuts.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- General Higinio Morinigo, president of Paraguay, who is here on an official visit, was received in both houses of Congress today and in identic addresses before the Senate and the House reaffirmed his country's pledge of solidarity with the United States and other members of the United Nations group.
One top ranking player was defeated and another had to come from behind as the junior Bronx-Manhattan tennis championship was resumed at the New York Tennis Club yesterday.

A confidential survey made by the meat packing industry has disclosed that the slaughter of beef animals at federally inspected plants is running consistently behind last year's kill despite a substantial increase in the size of herds. The decline is attributed by the industry to black market operations.

The Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce has announced that in September it will hold hearings on certain proposed amendments to the Communications Act of 1934. This is the law under which the radio industry is regulated, and the question of whether it needs amendment has gained added interest in consequence of a recent decision of the Supreme Court.

Award of a new issue of $152,000 town of Hempstead, L.I., Union Free School District No. 28 bonds, due serially from July 1, 1944 to 1956, was made yesterday to C.F. Childs Co., Inc., and Sherwood Co. The bankers bid 100.50, naming the interest rate as 2.70 per cent.

LONDON, June 10 -- The United States Eighth Air Force has doubled since March, Major Gen. Ira C. Eaker disclosed this afternoon at a press conference at his headquarters somewhere in England. By October, he predicted, it will be twice as big, adding that the monthly increment of strength ranged between 15 and 30 per cent.
HONOLULU, June 10 -Rear Admiral Charles A. Lockwood Jr., commander of the Submarine IForce of the Pacific Fleet, decoated seven officers and men today on a submarine at Pearl Harbor.

STOCKHOLM, June 10 (AP) -- Dispatches from Berlin to the Swedish press reported today that the Nazi leadership had warned the German people that the Allies might carry the air offensive to all corners of Germany "at any moment,'' while admitting that raids on West and Northwest Germany already were having an "awful" effect on morale.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 10 -- In a dramatic appeal to Dr. Arthur Seyss-Inquart, Reich Commissar for the occupied Netherlands, the United Churches of the Netherlands today demanded the cessation of sterilization of the contracting parties to so-called mixed marriages, which, it is charged, has now been put into effect by the German occupation authorities.

GREAT LAKES, Ill., June 10 (AP) -- After winning thirteen games, the Great Lakes Bluejackets suffered their first baseball loss of the season today when the Reds bagged a 6-to-4 decision before 10,000 recruits.

The 1,127 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $81,479,041,193 par value as of May 29, had a total market value of $81,048,543,830, an all-time high record. As of April 30 there were 1,129 issues, aggregating $72,811,509,943 par value which had a total market value of $71,857,596,488.

LONDON, June 10 -- A United States Army boxing team scored a 6-to-5 victory over the picked ring fighters of the British Army tonight in the interservice championship tournament before a noisy crowd of more than 10,000 soldiers and civilians. Hundreds of would-be spectators were turned away.

An application was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by Aaron Gray, former vice president of the Harris Raincoat Company, Inc., to examine Louis H. Harris, president of the company, and others, in preparation for the drawing of a complaint for recovery of sums Mr. Gray contends are due to him.

Whether invasion takes place today or tomorrow or the next day, the blasted island of Pantelleria, stubbornly held as it is by a completely isolated garrison, is no longer a rock of defense for Sicily or the road to Italy. It is an encircled ruin. The fortifications of the next stepping-stones, Sicily and Sardinia, are pulverized, and Allied sea and air forces have swept the enemy from the narrow straits between Africa and Europe.

The Four Freedoms War Bond Show, being held in the International Building, Rockefeller Center, 630 Fifth Avenue, was devoted yesterday to the Merchant Marine. The ceremonies were sponsored by the United States Treasury Department and The Saturday Evening Post.

Negotiations are in progress among groups representing holders of securities of the Missouri Pacific Railroad and other companies in the system in efforts to reach a revised compromise plan of reorganization and merger of the roads in the system, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- A 15 per cent wage increase was ordered today by the War Labor Board for about 40,000 employes of the Western Union Telegraph Company.

The Hospital Day ceremonies of the city-wide Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization recruitment drive were conducted at City Hall Plaza yesterday with more than a score of emergency ambulances and a field hospital with doctors, nurses, nurses' aides and other hospital volunteers attending.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, June 11 (AP) -- Forty tons of bombs were dropped on three airdromes at Rabaul, New Britain, yesterday by heavy Allied bombers, the High Command announced.

ALBANY, June 10 -- The Federal Government's movement toward a strong centralized authority "has been eating away at the roots of local government" and constitutes "a very real menace to the freedom of the American people," Mayor Edward J. Jeffries of Detroit said tonight at the annual dinner of the New York State Conference of Mayors and other municipal officials.

LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- Italy's occupation army of 50,000 in Corsica was reported today to be working urgently to strengthen its defenses against the dual threat of Allied invasion and action by French patriots, who were reported hiding in the mountains awaiting the signal to spring upon the Fascisti.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 10 -- Premier Mussolini, in a "regular annual shake-up" of regional directors, ousted nineteen prefects today and placed six others in new posts. As to the value of the official explanation that it was a regular annual shake-up, it will be recalled that this is the fourth widespread reorganization in the last six months and others are foreshadowed for the immediate future.

The creation of a Rachmaninoff Memorial Fund to honor the memory of Sergei Rachmaninoff, the eminent Russian composer, pianist and conductor, was announced yesterday. The fund will be devoted during the war to the relief of suffering people in Russia.

In opposing enactment of H.R. 2731, designed to expedite payment of compensation for requisitioned ships, the American Merchant Marine Institute, composed of the leading steamship companies, broke sharply with the War Shipping Administration yesterday, accusing that agency of being responsible for the present snarl whereby payment of $200,000,000 has been held up.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Riding roughshod over recommendations of the Joint Committee on Reduction of Non-Essential Federal Expenditures and the American Farm Bureau Federation that the Farm Security Administration be abolished, the Senate voted, 66 -- 12, this evening to keep that long-disputed agency functioning full blast through the coming year.
Important negotiations between the American and British Governments concerning French affairs are now in progress.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Transferring a 173-foot submarine chaser, renamed the King George II, to the government of Greece, President Roosevelt expressed today the hope that the speedy little ship would hasten the day "when liberated Greeks will again maintain their own government within the shadow of the Acropolis and the Parthenon."

The Civilian Defense Volunteer Office is making slow progress in its campaign to enroll 500,000 new members. Yet it affords a real chance for public service. It promises much hard and tedious work to all qualified persons who apply. Recruits to the City Patrol Corps are assured of two four-hour night shifts a week.

A State prison sentence of twenty years to life was imposed by Judge James Garrett Wallace in General Sessions yesterday on Alexandro Ennis, 18 years old, of 522 West 145th Street, for his part in the fatal stabbing of Sue Wong Gee in a hold-up in the laundry of the Chinese at 3468 Broadway on Dec. 17 last.

Mathias F. Correa left his post as United States Attorney here yesterday to enter the Army. Announcement of President Roosevelt's acceptance of his resignation was made at the White House and a few minutes later Howard F. Corcoran was sworn in here as Mr. Correa's successor under a temporary assignment by the judges of the Federal court.

The Very Rev. Charles I. Litzinger of the faculty of the Dominican House of Theology, Washington, D.C., has been elected prior and superior of the Dominican House of Studies there, according to an announcement yesterday from the Very Rev. Terence S. McDermott, provincial of the Dominican Fathers of St. Joseph's Province, 869 Lexington Avenue.
The British Isles are now the base for the greatest air attacks in history. They may become, in time, a base for the land invasion of the continent.

HONOLULU, June 10 -- Colonel Perry M. Smoot, Hawaii Selective Service Director, criticized today widespread requests for deferment in the next draft, June 21, and charged Hawaii with "very faulty Americanism." Colonel Smoot said:

The five-family house on a plot 65 by 145 feet at 2151 Mapes Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Dollar Savings Bank to Luigi Giarrattorio for cash above a first mortgage of $9,000. The property is assessed at $20,000. P.C. D'Onofrio was the broker.

The Police Department, which several times has sought to end cruising by taxicabs, made another attempt yesterday by amending the traffic regulations. Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine amended the regulations forbidding taxicab drivers to operate their vehicles along a street "for the purpose of soliciting passengers or searching for passengers."

LONDON, June 10 -- The Czechoslovak Government in Exile broadcast an appeal today to patriots conducting guerrilla warfare in the homeland to increase their struggles "so as to hasten the fall of the Nazi regime."

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Arne Wiprud, special assistant to the Attorney General, said today that railroad and motor carrier rate-fixing bureaus had "even greater power" than the Interstate Commerce Commission.

DETROIT, June 10 (AP) -- The White Sox hustled into the American League's third place today by landing on four pitchers for 17 hits and an 11-to-5 victory over the Tigers, their second straight in the five-game series. The Tigers, dropping their fifth successive game, slipped back to sixth place.

Elias Eliopoulos, on trial with his brother, George, in Brooklyn Federal court, told Judge Matthew T. Abruzzo and the jury yesterday that it was he who supplied the tip resulting in the seizure of the shipment of drugs that he and his brother are accused of conspiring to import into this country.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that a total wheat production of 730,524,000 bushels is indicated by June 1 conditions. That is 29 per cent less than the 981,327,000 bushels produced last year and compares with the 1932-41 ten-year average production of 738,412,000 bushels.

Greenwich House, 27 Barrow Street, a charitable community service organization, is in danger of closing, because it has not been able to take in sufficient money to meet its bills, the Village Citizens Committee to Save Greenwich House announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 -- House and Senate conferees on the strike and labor control bill approved today the text of the compromise agreed on yesterday and their chairmen voiced hope for final Congressional action tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Mexican Ambassador Francisco Castillo Najera said today that he does not expect to make a formal protest to the State Department over the Los Angeles clashes between servicemen and "zoot-suiters," in which Mexican citizens were reported to have been attacked.
LONDON, June 10 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England issued today reported an increase of 422,000 in note circulation.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The peril of runaway inflation has been heightened by the government policy of financing its deficits through sales of securities to the banks on a multi-billion-dollar scarce, Rudolf S. Hecht, former president of the American Bankers Association, said today.

The hopes of Morris Barnett, a member of the British Merchant Marine, that one day his travels would take him to New York City, thus permitting him to see his two children, evacuated from London three years ago, were realized yesterday when he greeted them at the home of Miss Mae Dillon, 1330 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 10 (AP) -- Government counsel, arguing for conviction of the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company and five of it semployes on charges of conspiracy to defraud the government through manufacture of defective material for war purposes, described the ease today as "the most obnoxious fraud ever presented to a court of the United States."

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Predictions that startling radio-radar discoveries of the war will not be adopted immediately in post-war receiving sets were made today by Paul V. Galvin, president of the Radio Manufacturers Association. Mr. Galvin, who is president of the Galvin Manufacturing Corporation of Chicago, also discussed industry war production and post-war problems in opening the war conference of the association at the Palmer House.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The addition of Mr. Baruch to the ranks of those with official and public responsibility for the conduct of the home front of the war has revived in some quarters the hope that other men of high caliber who are still more or less on the sidelines will be drafted also.

Aqueduct's biggest crowd so far during the meeting, 17,607, turned out for the races yesterday, many going down to defeat with Mrs. Payne Whitney's Corydon in the Short Grass Purse, which was captured by Hugh S. Nesbitt's Copperman.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Weakening prices for fresh fruits and vegetables brought the Bureau of Labor Statistics comprehensive index of prices in primary markets down 0.1 per cent during the first week of June. The all-commodity index dropped to 103.9 per cent of the 1926 average, slightly below the peak level of the preceding week.

MOSCOW, June 10 -- Recent enemy thrusts in the Sievsk sector and various points on the Donets front and Russian activity on the Kalinin front, which for a time produced the impression that they heralded bigger events, now seem of no more than local significance and the most important news is still from the air.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes disclosed today that he is seeking to obtain gasoline rationing powers now exercised by the Office of Price Administration. In testimony before a special Congressional gasoline committee, he made these statements:

The late improvement of Wednesday in the stock market carried over yesterday during the morning period, but demand dried up in the final hours to produce a mixed closing for the day. Although the trend was to the better side, the gains were too small to establish constructive leanings.

The social insurance recommendations of the National Resources Planning Board were characterized as inadequate, vague and falling far short of the needs of the country in a statement issued yesterday by the American Association for Social Security.

DETROIT, Mich., June 10 -- American automobile manufacturers will produce only 1942 models when they reconvert to a peacetime economy, Charles F. Kettering, vice president and research director of General Motors Corporation told the Society of Automotive Engineers today at its two-day war material meeting.

Dodd, Mead announces that a gift of three royalty awards of $500 each are to be offered for books of fiction, non-fiction and juveniles to registrants at the Fourth Annual Writers Conference to be held at Northwestern University, July 28 through 31.

LONDON, June 10 -- The selection of the Allied generalissimo to lead the invasion of Europe may very well still be an open question in the minds of the few who will make the final decision, but it would be no surprise here if General Dwight D. Eisenhower were the successful candidate.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A Navy communique today reported that a flight of Flying Fortresses, escorted by Warhawk and Lightning fighters, had bombed Japanese positions at Munda on New Georgia Island in the Central Solomons two days ago. All the Army planes returned safely.

Later historians may argue the point, but J.V.D. Carlyle, fashion editor for Men's Apparel Reporter, the trade's authority, seemed convinced yesterday that the first zoot suit on record was ordered early in February, 1940, at Frierson-McEver's in Gainesville, Ga.

Director Byrnes has asked each house of Congress to designate a committee to work with the executive branch. This is one of the most encouraging announcements to come out of Washington since our entrance into the war. Mr. Byrnes's action will accomplish several purposes.

Leo Durocher's long-awaited and loudly heralded return to short-stop won the approval of 11,077 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday when the Dodgers, with their backs to the wall, staged a ninth-inning rally that brought a 4-3 victory over the Braves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has bought the film rights to Vera Caspary's mystery novel, "Laura," which is now in its fourth printing. The studio plans to co-feature George Sanders as the detective and Laird Cregar as the columnist in the screen version.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Methods of freeing large quantities of idle construction machinery for resale are under discussion at the War Production Board. At recent meetings with representatives of the industry, WPB officials were told that many contractors who had worked on Army camp construction are holding large stocks of equipment in idleness in the expectation of further construction.

SOME of the Gentlemen of the Press are viewing tonight's Sammy Angott-Henry Armstrong battle with slightly jaundiced eyes. They regard Sammy as being a hit-and-run fighter who is not the most attractive boxer in the world to watch. He showed Willie Pep more headlocks in their last meeting than Strangler Lewis ever demonstrated against Stanislaus Zbyszko.

For the first time in its turbulent six-year history, the City Council in one of its stormiest sessions yesterday mustered enough votes to override Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia on budget cuts, restoring $3,185,446 of the total of nearly $10,800,000 in reduction that he had vetoed.

Conservation of both materials and labor as well as routine training techniques will be emphasized in the fifth annual building service employes' course that will open at Teachers College next Monday, Dr. H.H. Linn, Superintendent of Buildings and Grounds at the college in Columbia University, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -- A draft agreement for a United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration was submitted by the State Department today to the governments of all the United Nations and of the other countries associated with them in the war.

The "collective bargaining" procedure between the miners' union and the operators on the portal-to-portal issue has indeed been "farcical," though not quite in the sense that Mr. Lewis's description intended. It has been pseudo-bargaining. It has been so because the question in the back of the minds of both the operators and Mr. Lewis has been: "What wage increase will the War Labor Board grant if the bargaining negotiations fail?"

POLAND SPRING, Me., June 10 -- Miss Mary E.G. Bliss of New York, assistant executive secretary of the American Nurses Association, charged today that all the State laws governing the practice of nursing in the United States failed in the purpose for which they were enacted, that is, to protect the public and the nursing profession.

Monthly magazines continued to chalk up substantial gains in advertising linage this month, reports yesterday indicated. Linage in June issues was about 33 per cent above that of a year ago, the best increase marked up this year.
CHUNGKING, China, June 10 (AP) -- A communique:

More than two years after the Germans entered Athens, Greece still has a navy. Yesterday President Roosevelt presented an anti-submarine patrol ship, built in American shipyards, to the Greek Government in Exile. He had reason to know that it would be put to good use.

Hands that destiny had shaped to rock the cradle were firm last night on stubby billies --short clubs with lethal potentialities -- as Wave sentries wearing Shore Patrol armbands paced the ground around the Naval Training School for Women's Reserves at Hunter College.

A more flexible price policy to encourage greater output of certain farm commodities and a revision of livestock feed policies to assure a better balance in the production of livestock and livestock products were among the recommendations made yesterday at the close of a three-day session of the Northeastern Farm Bureau conference in the Hotel New Yorker.

ALGIERS, June 10 -- General Charles de Gaulle's uncompromising attitude on the reorganization of the French Army led well-informed French political sources to believe that the general, backed by Rene Massigli and Andre Philip, might force a crisis in the French Committee of National Liberation.

Louis A. Lotito, former theatrical treasurer and now managing director of the Martin Beck Theatre, announced yesterday that he would try his hand at play producing come mid-October. For his initiation into that field he has acquired Frederick Lonsdale's new play "Another Love Story."
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Bernard M. Baruch declared today that "infernal bickering has hurt the war effort and confused the public," and expressed hope that James F. Byrnes would stop it.

In the future, students of the law will have to face the problem of rethinking our most fundamental and basic legal concepts, such as the idea of national sovereignty, Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, declared last night in an address at the forty-first annual commencement of the Brooklyn Law School of St. Lawrence University.

The new pay-as-you-go tax plan will probably make law violators out of 95 per cent or more of the tax-paying population, as it will be impossible for any one but an expert to familiarize himself with all of its complexities. Among the many headaches written into this bill is the following:

Belated short-covering of the July position and price-fixing, said to be on behalf of tire companies principally, retrieved early losses in the cotton futures market yesterday and ran the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net gains of 1 to 9 points, with the spot delivery leading.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- The Treasury issued instructions to employers and employes today on how to comply with the withholding system to go into effect July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Anticipating large-scale induction of fathers of small children, the Republican House leadership translated into legislation today a drive for bigger Federal payments to dependents of enlisted men.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) -- Discussing post-war problems. W.L. Hemingway, president of the American Bankers Association, today advocated return to the gold standard and direct loans to financially disabled nations to help achieve world stability.

A slur on my republicanism, which the writer of a letter published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 6 permitted himself, hardly requires refutation. Ever since my student days my whole life has been a continuous struggle, first for the defense, then, after 1933, for the resurrection of the German Republic, as well as for democratic principles in international life.

Two men who engaged in a pistol duel with a detective and a patrolman were convicted of first degree murder last night in Kings County Court for the slaying of the detective. They are Joseph Palmer, 29 years old, of 1725 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, and Vincent Sollami, 25, of 617 East 158th Street, the Bronx.

Two games on a home-and-home basis with Pennsylvania have been scheduled for Columbia's football forces for next Fall, it was announced yesterday by Ralph Furey, director of athletics at Columbia. The coming campaign thus will mark the first time the Lions and Quakers have clashed twice in the same gridiron season.
May we congratulate you, and especially your correspondent Russell Porter, on your admirable coverage of the World Food Conference just concluded at Hot Springs, Va.?
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Distinguished Service Medal has been awarded to seven generals who lead the North African campaign.

Eleven, including Market Wise, Attention, Devil Diver, With Regards and Riverland, are entered in the seven-furlong Carter Handicap at Aqueduct today. In the opinion of officials it is the best field ever named for this stake, which carries $7,500 added.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 11 (AP) -- Mr. Crouse, a former president of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, received the James H. McGraw Medal from the association in 1940 for "a signal contribution to the advancement of the manufacturing branch of the electrical industry."

Mrs. Lester M. Wilson, vice president and treasurer of the New York Engineering Company, has leased a large suite in 171 West Fifty - seventh Street through Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hmilton, Inc. Through the same brokers Alberico Guidi rented an apartment in 596 Riverside Drive, Samuel Miller in 201 West Seventy-seventh Street and Benjamin Krasnow in 120 West Twentieth Street.

Eager to resume full-scale production of peacetime merchandise as soon after the war as possible, carpet manufacturers have requested the government to consider the advisability of building a stockpile of imported wools, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The War Department gave out today the names, with next of kin, of 186 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwestern Pacific areas.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- The largest crowd to see a morning game in the major leagues this season -8,307, of whom 5,307 paid -- turned out at 11 o'clock today for the game between the last place Cubs and Cincinnati, and the Reds cut loose a fourteen-hit attack, including Ray Mueller's first 1943 homer, to win, 7 to 4.

Twenty-six naval officers, the first graduates of the training program course at the Navy School of Military Government and Administration at Columbia University, were told that their future mission would be "to act as good-will agents of America," at graduation exercises yesterday in Earl Hall.

New bond financing locally, through public offerings, amounted to $18,017,700 this week. This compared with last week's total of 8,650,000. This week, as last week, the new financing consisted a municipal and industrial bonds.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 11 -As a result of the victory garden campaign, about 4,000,000 families in New England and Middle Atlantic States have planted vegetable gardens this year. This represents an increase in these States of about 500,000 over last year.

Taking cognizance of the difficulty faced by war contractors making camouflage nets urgently needed to keep pace with overseas shipments of rolling equipment, the War Production Board has issued individual instructions to cotton spinners to maintain the rate of carded yarn deliveries that was in effect on May 15 for such suppliers, Worth Street producers reported yesterday.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 11 -- In a simple ceremony in the Foreign Ministry at noon the United States, Great Britain, Canada and most of the States of this continent that had not done so before formally recognized the new Argentine government headed by General Pedro P. Ramirez.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 11 -- The Colombian Government is acting to stabilize the present exchange rate of 56 cents to the peso and to curb inflation and for this purpose has authorized the sale of certificates of deposit bearing interest of 3 and 4 per cent annually for a term of two years.

Howard Fast, author of "The Unvanquished" and the recent "Citizen Tom Paine," published by Duell, Sloan Pearce, has gone to Oswego, N.Y., to participate in the celebration there of United Nations Week. He will speak from the auditorium of the local high school on Monday, Flag Day.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 11 -- Blasted into ruins by hundreds of tons of bombs, the Italian island of Pantelleria, the last Axis stronghold in the Sicilian Strait, surrendered to overwhelming Allied air power this morning rather than endure another day of death and destruction under the most concentrated aerial attack in the history of warfare.
LONDON, June 11 -- Business on the stock markets was restricted today in advance of the Whitsun holiday on Monday. The fall of Pantelleria had little influence on prices.
CHUNGKING, China, June 11 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Elated by the fall of Pantelleria, the Army Air Force called a press conference today to tell how war planes made the so-called Italian Gibraltar give up before a single Allied soldier landed.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 11 (AP) -- The United States Ninth Air Force dropped 3,500,000 pounds of explosives on Axis installations in 200 missions in May, Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton, its commander, announced today.

Sergeant Young Kid McCoy of Detroit, now stationed at Mitchel Field, outpointed Johnny Jones of Pittsburgh in a hard-fought eight-round main bout at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation last night. A crowd of 4,500 saw the winner rally in the last two rounds to eke out the decision.
This department gathers from reports emanating from the markets of the city that it might be shrewd to plan on serving pork next week.

There is solid ground for encouragement in the radio broadcast made last night by the able Foreign Minister of Australia, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, on the conclusion of his present mission to the United States. Though for obvious reasons he must withhold figures, Dr. Evatt is able to report that Allied air strength in the Southwest Pacific is now being "considerably increased."

ALBANY, June 11 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of John Francis O'Connell, chief investigator in the New York County District Attorney's Office, as chairman of the State Liquor Authority at $12,000 a year.

Army and Navy groups gave a demonstration yesterday of swimming and life saving technique at the Flushing Meadow Park Amphitheater pool, under the auspices of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross and the Park Department.

In taking a stand against the present intolerable custodial system whereby the Board of Education pays lump sums of money, ranging upward to $40,000, for the care of school buildings, the Strayer survey staff has turned its searchlight on a condition that calls for considerable attention.
I read with interest the comments of a soldier-student on the Army's policy toward intercollegiate athletics that appeared in Arthur Daley's column in THE TIMES on Tuesday.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pierrepont Perry will give a luncheon for the Duchess of Windsor today in the Ritz-Carlton Garden.
LONDON, June 11 (U.P.) -- Italy canceled the production and sale of radio sets today as Allied broadcasting stations spread the news that Pantelleria had fallen.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- Essentially, the war between the Soviet Union and the European Axis is a land and air war and the conflict that takes place on the sea, though important as it affects the transportation of supplies by the opposing forces, nevertheless is on the periphery of the main battle and never has been and never could be as vital.

Mayor La Guardia, on behalf of the city, yesterday accepted a fully equipped ambulance from members of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union, Local 16, A.F. of L., at special ceremonies held at Forty-sixth Street and Eighth Avenue, directly outside the offices of the union.

Youth of the Protestant Episcopal Church will join tomorrow in a nation-wide corporate holy communion in their parish churches in observance of Whitsunday, also called Pentecost, commemorating the descent of the Holy Spirit upon the first apostles, which generally is referred to as the birthday of the Christian church.

CHICAGO, June 11 -- Wheat made today a fairly good response to the government's bullish crop figures of yesterday, but met much profit-taking and receded from the top. Continued uncertainty as to the final disposition of the question of a new ceiling price for flour offset to some extent the crop figures and the general pessimistic tenor of the June report.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Acting to insure the "hold-the-line" admonition of President Roosevelt on prices of cost-of-living items, the Office of Economic Stabilization today instructed the War Food Administartion through the Commodity Credit Corporation to absorb higher production costs of canners on their 1943 packs of green peas, snap beans, sweet corn and tomatoes.

JERSEY CITY, June 11 (AP) -Montreal took a two-to-one lead in its five-game series with Jersey City tonight, defeating the Little Giants, 2 to 1, in a twilight game behind the effective five-hit hurling of Bob Chipman.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 11 (AP) -- The official text of an ultimatum issued Tuesday to the Pantelleria garrison by Lieut. Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, Allied Northwest African Air Force Commander, which is almost identical with yesterday's final surrender note, follows:

MOSCOW, June 11 -- To the accompaniment of the most lavish and enthusiastic praise of the United States ever promulgated in the Soviet Union, the Russian people were informed today that British-Russian-American cooperation, cemented in blood, would lead to the complete smashing of the European Axis, abetted by a direct Allied assault on the Continent.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 11 -Dr. Joseph Kenrick of the home club and Harold Weeks of the Rockville Country Club won the qualifying medal with a par-breaking 72 in the third annual invitation member-guest tournament at the Hempstead G.C. today.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- Prices of hogs bounded up 5 to 10 cents a hundredweight today on light receipts. The top advanced a dime to $14.20. Cattle were steady and lambs were slightly weaker. The report of the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

STRATEGIC AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 11 -- Major Gen. James H. Doolittle, in a statement tonight, declared that the conquest of Pantelleria by air power "is definitely a landmark in the history of military aviation."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York led a field of seventeen in a poll among House Republicans concerning their present choice for the party's Presidential nomination in 1944, according to Representative Leo E. Allen of Illinois, who said that he made a check among 180 of his colleagues.

PRINCESS ANNE, M.d., June 11 (U.P.) -- Rives Matthews, 36-year-old editor of The Somerset News, stood his ground today in the controversy over alleged misuse of gasoline by a State official which has resulted in his being charged with malicious slander.

Retail trade continued notably active here this week under the stimulus of ideal shopping weather. Department stores had sales increases ranging from 30 to 35 per cent. This extremely large percentage increase, however, was due to comparison with low sales figures of last year, when volume was hit by the strike of workers of the United Parcel Service.

RICHMOND, Va., June 11 -- This week's issue of The Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office lists 577 patents granted. Chief among them were patents for a variable pitch propeller for ships, a smokeless soft coal, a new method of preparing sulfapyridine and the rat-trap for which the "world may beat a path to the door" of the inventor.

Private Fire insurance interests take the view that fire and casualty insurance carriers should not set up a reserve against war damages, according to statements made in their behalf before a committee of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners in Boston this week.

The use of gasoline for shopping trips has increased tenfold in outlying districts since grocery stores were ordered by the Office of Defense Transportation to reduce their home deliveries to two a week, according to a complaint yesterday from a Queens civic group that the gasoline conservation order "doesn't make sense."

The City Council's action in overriding Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's veto of $3,185,446 in city budget cuts for the coming fiscal year was praised yesterday by Walter Hoving, chairman of the Committee to Balance the Budget Through Sensible Economies, as bringing to an end "the one-man rule of the City of New York."
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- In the opinion of Emil Ludwig, German biographer, "Hitler will be assassinated soon by his own men."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator, took steps today toward possible remission of fines levied on 450,000 bituminous coal workers by issuing instructions to all mine managers that disputes over the collection of the fines shall be taken up under the normal union grievance machinery.

An exhibition of war art comprising 125 paintings made in the United States battle zones by nine well-known American artists will open at the National Gallery of Art in Washington on June 20. All of the paintings were commissioned by Life, the weekly magazine, and after completion of a nation-wide tour will be given to the government as part of a permanent eyewitness record of the war.

AN ADVANCED U.S. FIGHTER BASE in North Africa, June 11 (AP) -- Within an hour after Italy's fortress island of Pantelleria surrendered to the Allies today, fifty to sixty German dive-bombers attempted to smash the British landing forces, but the enemy formation was broken up by American fighter pilots flying P-38 Lightnings.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- President Roosevelt denied today that he endorsed compulsory savings at his Tuesday press conference. He explained that if he gave that impression it was because he was discussing the theory of taxation.

The New York Trust Company won yesterday from the Appellate Division a reversal of a verdict for $300,995 awarded by a Supreme Court jury against the bank in a suit by Mrs. Florence Stanton Thomson, executrix of the estate of Samuel C. Thomson, mining engineer.

A tendency on the part of the general public to label absentee women war workers "shirkers" was assailed yesterday by Dr. Josephine L. Rathbone of the Physical Education Department, Teachers College, who classified their contribution to production as "magnificent."

Testimony further linking the practice of Dr. Charles L. Engelsher and the operation of his Parkchester General Hospital in the Bronx with criminals was given yesterday at the Moreland inquiry as a police bodyguard was provided for a woman who feared to testify against an ex-convict she had accompanied to the doctor's office.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Legislation to permit five instead of six Supreme Court justices to constitute a quorum was attacked at a hearing today as "a sister act to the court packing bill," which failed of enactment six years ago.
LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and revealed by the Soviet monitor here:

WASHINGTON, June 11 (U.P.) --Cooperation of the Soviet Union with its allies during the post-war reconstruction period was promised tonight in a message from Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff to Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

Mrs. George W. Biggs Jr. entertained with a luncheon yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Garden for her sister, Mrs. Lucille G. Coldren, who will leave tomorrow for Florida. Others in the party were Mrs. De Forest Lapham, Mrs. Alden J. Cusick, Mrs. Austin F. Hancock, Mrs. David Mulligan Jr., the Misses Diedre Owens, Ann Cusick and Cindy Coldren, and Arthur E. Hinch.
J.B. Straley, Regional Manager of the Office of Emergency Management, announced yesterday that the Federal war emergency agencies will be consolidated on July 1 in the Empire State Building.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. At the Rivoli will be "Spitfire," produced and directed in England by Leslie Howard, and presented here by Samuel Goldwyn. The topical production, dealing with the accomplishments of the late R.J. Mitchell, the inventor of the British fighter plane, co-stars Mr. Howard and David Niven and is released by RKO Radio Pictures.
LONDON, June 11 -- The fall of Pantelleria is regarded here as a milestone in the development of strategy in this war for two reasons:

George and Elias Eliopoulos, brothers, were convicted in the Federal court in Brooklyn last night of violation of the revenue law in connection with the importation of morphine hydrochloride into the United States.

With apparel concerns far ahead in percentage gain, sale of leading chains and mail order companies increased 2.7 per cent in May, according to a compilation yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The rising tide of apparel volume was shown by a spurt of 23.1 per cent in women's apparel and of 26 per cent in men's wear.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The House, by a bipartisan vote of 219 to 129, adopted today a compromise version of the Strike and Labor Control Bill, but Senate efforts to complete legislative action went over until tomorrow when the debate turned to the terms of the compromise, which was developed in conference.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- A demand for a $2,000,000,000-a-year subsidy to push back living costs to levels of thirteen months ago was made today by Wiliam Grmeen, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Yesterday a new life of Laurence Sterne was reviewed and approved in this newspaper. A generation ago Doctor and Governor Cross of Yale published an authoritative biography of that curious and entertaining character. He was a queer bird even for an eighteenth-century clergyman; more like the French abbes whom he met in Paris when he was thick with Diderot and Crebillon fils.
Yesterday's Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome, and recorded by The Associated Press:

To head off the exodus of lower-paid workers in the laundry and cotton garment industries to better paying jobs in war plants, Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, announced yesterday that his organization is asking immediate wage increases and improved working conditions for 100,000 workers in the two industries in the metropolitan area, the Eastern seaboard, the South and Middle West.

The city now has an investment in transit properties of approximately $1,500,000,000. When it started operating these facilities it was agreed that they should be "self-supporting" after September, 1936 -- the time subsequently being extended to 1938-40, and finally to September, 1942.

The withholding tax, and the new pay-as-you-go provisions, are now law. The whole history of this legislation, however, reflects little credit on the Administration or on Congress. Dispute over the pay-as-you-go aspect of the bill became so heated that the withholding tax was comparatively neglected.

Despite the meat and butter shortages, the kitchen salvage of waste fats in this city reached a record of 456,000 pounds for last month, Frank D. March, city salvage director, reported yesterday. The May collection was 63,000 pounds better than April's and topped that for March, which has been the record month, by 43,000 pounds.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia appealed yesterday to women to learn how to fight fires so that they would be able to serve as volunteers in the Fire Department Auxiliary Corps in the event of an emergency. He spoke during the Fire Department's program at City Hall, held in conjunction with the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office drive for 500,000 recruits.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 11 -- Official confirmation of the loss of the first parcel of Italian territory with the fall of Pantelleria had not been forthcoming to the Italian public up to a late hour tonight, although it has been common property throughout the peninsula since shortly after noon today.

LONDON, Saturday, June 12 -- A formation of more than 200 American heavy bombers renewed the Allied aerial offensive against Western Europe yesterday by smashing at German shipyards and port installations at Wilhelmshaven and Cuxhaven.

Gone but not missed is that old inhabitant of the news columns, "complacency." A man can now read cheerful war stories for five minutes at a time without somebody leaping out of the bushes and holding up a warning hand like a traffic cop and reminding him, whatever he did, he must not go complacent.

The Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, a coordinating agency representing agencies and media, has become a member of the American Standards Association, P.G. Agnew, secretary of the association, announced yesterday.
SUMMIT, N.J., June 11 (AP) -The question of how much is two pounds of shrimp is scheduled to be argued next Thursday night before Police Judge Peter C. Triolo.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (U.P.) -Merchant marine casualties, dead and missing, during May totaled seventy-four, the Navy Department announced today, bringing merchant marine casualties from war action during the period from Sept. 27, 1941, to June 1, 1943, up to 4,629.

Beginning this Fall, all children in the New York City elementary schools are to be promoted once a year, instead of semi-annually as has been the custom in the past. Although new pupils are to be admitted in September and February, as at present, they will remain with their teachers for a full year.

Skeet and trapshooters do not expect the major events in their sport to be held this season. Already the Great Eastern skeet shoot, held annually at the Lordship grounds, Stratford, Conn., has been canceled and it is likely that the Grand American, trapshooting's blue ribbon championship at Vandalia, Ohio, and the national skeet title tournament will be abandoned for the duration.

CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) -- The girl of junior high school age is a major delinquency problem because she has been left out of the war service programs, says Mrs. Evelyn Millis Duvall, director of the Association for Family Living and a worker in family relations for fifteen years.
Hardly any sports writer would call a baseball manager of Leo Durocher's skill the worst pilot in the major's as George J. Dannenfelser Jr. did in his letter in THE TIMES last Saturday.

Because of the gasoline prohibition and the determination of racing yachtsmen to live up to it, changes have been made in the regatta schedules. With race officials sailing out to the starting line and back, there was confusion last week-end as to where the course would be.

LONDON, June 11 (AP) -- Another marked drop in German U-boat claims was made today by the German war communique, which asserted that Nazi submarines had sunk nine more Allied ships totalling 43,000 tons. This report, which was without Allied confirmation, was the only German claim of Allied ship sinkings by U-boats this month.

The letter from Professor Dewey and Miss La Follette about "Mission to Moscow" in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 16 contains misstatements, misunderstandings and misinterpretations that require more space for correction than THE TIMES could possibly give, but they will be fully dealt with elsewhere.
Arthur Daley's column in THE TIMES on Monday entitled "The World's Fastest Human" concerns a matter which has stirred men ever since the dawn of time.

The first link in a counterfeit gasoline ration coupon conspiracy, alleged to revolve sixty men who were tracked down by Secret Service agents and the Office of Price Administration, was' cracked in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday when a Corona, Queens, taxicab operator pleaded guilty before Judge Mortimer Byers to illegal purchase and possession of spurious coupons.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The Senate shunned today the responsibility for a possible "breaking of the price line," and declined, by a vote of 36 -- 37, to suspend its rules and adopt legislation concededly designed to prevent roll-backs of food costs. A two-thirds vote was required.
BOSTON, June 11 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say of the Boston wool market tomorrow:

Evening-up in the July position yesterday featured an otherwise dull session on the New York Cotton Exchange. Under thin volume active futures contracts fluctuated within an 8-point range and closed 2 to 4 points above Thursday's final prices.

CHUNGKING, China, June 11 (AP) -- New Chinese successes were reported today in fighting northeast of Ichang and northwest of Hankow, as authorities officially thanked American Army fliers for helping turn their Japanese drive on the upper Yangtze River into a rout last week.

Charges by Local 475 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America that Carl L. Norden, Inc., had deliberately caused a slowdown because of grievances against the War Labor Board and the National Labor Relations Board were flatly denied yesterday by T.H. Barth, the company's president.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 11 (U.P.) -Survivors of a torpedoed ship today told how a polite German U-boat commander sank a medium-sized United States merchant vessel and then apologized for his action.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., June 11 -- A new world record was established today when a 5 1/2-pound Pomeranian passed with high honors her tracking test, the most difficult of all the requirements in obedience work leading to the highest degree of Utility Dog. Never before had a Pomeranian, or any other toy dog, qualified for U.D.

Estimated earnings of the Atlantic Rayon Corporation for the period covering Jan. 1 to May 29 totaled $673,111, or 7.5 per cent on sales, before renegotiation liability land reserve for Federal income and excess profits taxes, Royal Little, president, reported yesterday in a statement to stockholders.
SATURDAY, June 12 (U.P.) -- The midnight communique:

An additional 20,000 men for the cutting of wood pulp is necessary to prevent an acute shortage of paper, E.W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, declared yesterday, following completion of a survey of the industry's current position.

A bill composed of the first acts of "II Trovatore," "Lucia di Lami mermoor" and "La Boheme" and the second act of "La Traviata" will be presented tonight at 8:30 by the Salmaggi Opera Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in honor of Mrs. Elvira Salmagg and her four sons who are in the United States Army.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., June 11 -The third annual amateur-pro best-ball golf championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association was won by Maurie O'Connor and Don Morano of Branch Brook with a 36-hole total of 68, 67 -- 135 over the Forest Hill course today.

Completing a special check-up of apartment houses in the city at which refuse is placed in incinerators, William J. Powell, deputy sanitation commissioner, reported yesterday that 643 apartment buildings were found with evidence that tin cans were incinerated instead of being put out for Department of Sanitation collectors.
Speculation is increasing over the probable future of religion in Russia, where a quarter century of persecution has given way under the stress of war conditions to a sort of truce.

MOBILE, Ala., June 11 (AP) -Ralph B. Chandler, publisher of The Mobile Press and Register, was fined $10 and sentenced to six hours in jail on a contempt of court charge today involving an editorial published last Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -Nick Etten, who used to do his slugging in the interest of the Phillies, supplied the impetus for a Yankee victory over the Athletics tonight at Shibe Park before a gathering of 25,229, the fourth straight triumph for Joe McCarthys band and the second in a row over the Mackmen.

Up in the Hanover hills Gunder Haegg is running daily through the forest primeval -- or a reasonable facsimile of same - and listening to the murmuring pines and the hemlocks. That's the way he likes to train, far from the maddening crowds and even the more maddening interviewers. Greta Garbo preferred solitude and so does Gunder the Wonder.

CINCINNATI, June 11 (AP) -- Cincinnati will become a major funnel through which American propaganda will be shot to the rest of the world with power sufficient "to knock any radio off the shelf anywhere," it was disclosed today with announcement that the Crosley Corporation's experimental short-wave station WLWO would install transmitters with a total power of 750,000 watts.

ALTANTIC CITY, June 11 -- The hotel men and merchants of this resort city, who one year ago viewed with considerable trepidation the occupation of their hostelries and facilities by the Army Air Forces, are experiencing similar emotions today over the probability that the Army may evacuate in the not-too-distant future the buildings it has taken over.

HAVANA, June 11 -- The Second National and Pan American Press Congress, which opened last Monday, closed tonight with a session in the House of Representatives. The delegates selected Caracas, Venezuela, as the place for next year's meeting.
Increased activity in Astoria, Queens, was reported yesterday with announcement of the sale of a large apartment building and five six-family houses.

A new alcohol process that will save the government $50,000,000 annually in war-alcohol costs and which yields an inexpensive by product enabling bakers to increase the amount of protein in bread has been discovered by government scientists, it was disclosed yesterday by Frank G. Handren, president of Park Tilford Distillers, Inc.

One would never expect in these days to have a fellow-feeling for the Chief of Police of Dortmund, Germany. The United Nations airmen have no such feeling. They are constantly dropping explosives on Dortmund, these explosives leave ruins, the ruins have to be cleared up, and sidewalk spectators gather to watch the work.

The six-story apartment building at 9524 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, containing sixty apartments has been sold to the Fortham Properties, Incorporated, through the E. H. Ludlow Company, brokers. The seller was A.B. B.B. Block.

ALGIERS, June 11 -- General Charles de Gaulle has written a letter to the National Committee of Liberation offering his resignation from the committee as a means of facilitating agreement on French Army reorganization, the problem over which the committee has been deadlocked for three days.

Angelo DeSanza, 22 years old, a lightweight pugilist known as Terry Young, was indicted yesterday on a first-degree robbery charge in the hold-up last Feb. 16 in the Manhattan Democratic Club of the Eighth Assembly District, at 138 Second Avenue.

CHUNGKING, China, June 11 -- New regulations, designed to improve the treatment of recruits in the Chinese Army, were published today by the Ministry of War. In addition to government supplies, recruits will be permitted to bring mosquito nets, blankets, uniforms, shoes and other personal articles and officers who confiscate things brought by the recruits will be severely punished.

Late this month the Boston Comic Opera Company will pay a return visit to Broadway. The troupe, which made its New York debut in January of last year, will open a season of Gilbert and Sullivan operettas at the Forty-fourth Street Theatre under the aegis of the Shuberts.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -The Navy said today that all recruit training for marine women would be transferred to Camp Le Jeune, New River, N.C., after the last class of enlisted women to be trained elsewhere enters Hunter College in New York City on Monday.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 11 -- By implication Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, admitted in Vichy today that French youths were offering resistance to compulsory labor in Germany.

OTTAWA, June 11 -- Each week Canada is launching six or more escort cargo or patrol vessel and turning out eighty airplanes, C.D. Howe, Munitions Minister, told the House of Commons this afternoon when he asked for a $3,425,000,000 appropriation for his department.

A part of Italy went out of the war yesterday when the commander of the island of Pantelleria, which is administratively linked with Trapani Province, Sicily, ordered the white flag run up. History was made in another way, for this is the first time that any island has been captured by sea and air attack alone, without a prior landing.

The lowly cotton house dress has come out of the kitchen and, consequently, retail sales have soared in the house dress departments of metropolitan stores and stores throughout the country. It's versatile today -- not static.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A rule laid down by Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board that provision for post-war reconversion of factories for civilian production should not be included in the profits allowed in war contracts was criticized at today's meeting of the House Naval Affairs Committee.

The new Government in Argentina, which has now been recognized by the United States and Britain, has taken one step away from ex-President Castillo's position of "neutrality." Under Castillo the Axis diplomatic agencies were each allowed to send out 100 words a day by wireless in code.

Persons with good homes and the desire for children were urged yesterday by Assemblyman William T. Andrews, in a broadcast over Station WNYC, to consult the child-placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

The National Lawyers Guild, of which Robert Kenny, State Attorney General of California, is president, is going to ask a three-way Federal investigation of the disorder between service men and zoot suit wearers in Los Angeles, it was stated yesterday.
The New York Stock Exchange firm of Henry Morgan Co. was dissolved yesterday.

AT A U.S. BOMBER STATION IN BRITAIN, June 11 (AP) -- For fifteen nerve-wracking minutes the crew of the Flying Fortress Rigor Mortis expected momentarily to be blown to bits as it battled frantically at an altitude of 20,000 feet, en route home from Northwest Germany today, to release a live bomb that had caught in the bomb-bay racks.

LONDON, Saturday, June 12 (U.P.) -- More than 700 Russian planes joined in gigantic attacks on German airdromes along the eastern front Thursday night and destroyed or damaged at least 150 grounded enemy planes, while the Red Air Force fighter screen downed ten, a special Soviet communique said today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- William W. Bodine resigned today as president of the United Gas Improvement Company, effective Sept. 1, and Walter E. Long, a vice president, was named to succeed him as an adjourned meeting of the board of directors declared effective the company's plan for its partial liquidation.

At noon yesterday Borough Hall, Brooklyn, was the scene of a battle for the borough riveting championship as two teams from the Sullivan Shipyards took part in a demonstration that held the attention of 3,000 spectators for ten minutes.

LONDON, June 11 -- British fishermen in the port of Fleetwood, which is the largest of its kind in this country, have gone on strike against a new schedule of maximum prices laid down by the Food Ministry. Several hundred of them have refused to go to sea and this number is expected to double over the week-end.

ALBANY, June 11 -- Governor Dewey today ordered flags on all State buildings flown at half-staff in tribute to Captain Arthur W. Brandt. Captain Brandt was succeeded as State Superintendent of Public Works several weeks ago by Charles H. Sells, Westchester County Republican.

Both sides in the current battle before the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce over the proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission undoubtedly will be pleased by statistics placed yesterday on the record.

Peonies of every color and variety, from the pure white Baron Schroeder to the solid pink Venus and the bright red Krausse, are dominating the flower scene in Manhattan this week-end, the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets reported yesterday.

Hearing on an appeal by property owners from the dismissal of their suits to restrain action on the $50,000,000 post-war Stuyvesant Town housing project was set down yesterday on the Appellate Division calendar for next Tuesday.

Huge quantities of new potatoes shipped here from the South to relieve New York City's recent potato famine have rotted in transit, it was learned yesterday, because they were shipped without refrigeration in accordance with orders of the Office of Defense Transportation.

The Giants, who haven't played a league game since they brought their disastrous Western invasion to a close last Sunday in Pittsburgh, when they lost twice, 18 -- 1 and 7 -- 0, to the Pirates, will set out today on what they hope will be a campaign of rehabilitation at the Polo Grounds.

The writer, an old-time sprinter, noticed when competing in dashes of 100 yards or more a tendency to throw his head upward or back upon nearing the tape. This automatically caused an up-and-down piston-like movement of the legs, thus retarding their forward thrust and tending to diminish th burst of speed so vitally necessary close to and at the finish.
HAVANA, June 11 -- Cuba announced officially tonight that a patrol vessel of the Cuban sub-chaser fleet had sunk an enemy submarine in battle off the Cuban north coast in the Atlantic a few days ago.

INSTITUTE, W. Va., June 11 (U.P.) -- Rubber Director William M. Jeffers said here tonight that the synthetic rubber program had reached the point where the United States was assured of enough base rubber to fill its own and Allied military needs and "at least essential civilian requirements."

LOS ANGELES, June 11 -- With Los Angeles still "out of bounds" for most sailors as a result of a week of clashes between service men and wearers of zoot suits, the Army formally entered the picture today with a sharp warning to soldiers against participation in such extra-curricular practices as chasing zoot suiters and ripping off their clothes.

ALBANY, June 11 -- The State Conference of Mayors went on record today at the final session of a three-day convention as demanding that cities and villages receive an equitable share of State-collected motor vehicle fees and gasoline taxes
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, June 12 (AP) -- The Allied Command's noon communique:

A schedule of minimum and maximum wage rates, with a spread in between depending on skills in the major occupations of the metal trades industry in the metropolitan area, will be made public in about ten days, Theodore W. Kheel, chairman of the Regional War Labor Board, said yesterday.
The collapse and quick occupation of Pantelleria, announced yesterday, may be an index of things to come.

PITTSBURGH, June 11 -- Employes at three bituminous coal pits near Windber, Pa., voted to walk out tonight in protest over orders of Harold L. Ickes, Secretary of the Interior, imposing $1 a day fine on participants in the June 1-7 stoppage.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 11 -- John G. Karaffa, cartoonist known as "Kay," died at Englewood Hospital here this morning of injuries suffered last night when he was crushed behind the steering wheel of his automobile in a collision with a truck on Bergen Boulevard, Fairview, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A special food committee, appointed by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox to investigate rumors of food waste, gave naval establishments today a virtual clean bill of health but indicated that it favored "a coordinating division with a single responsible head" to balance the country's food problem, both civilian and military.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., June 11 -- John G. Karaffa, cartoonist known as "Kay," died at Englewood Hospital here this morning of injuries suffered last night when he was crushed behind the steering wheel of his automobile in a collision with a truck on Bergen Boulevard, Fairview, N.J.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- A special food committee, appointed by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox to investigate rumors of food waste, gave naval establishments today a virtual clean bill of health but indicated that it favored "a coordinating division with a single responsible head" to balance the country's food problem, both civilian and military.

ATLANTA, June 11 (AP) -- Taylor R. Durham of Charlotte, N.C., secretary, told the Southern Hosiery Manufacturers Association here today that government control of wages and commodities are necessary to prevent inflation.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Advised by the War Department of an unauthorized strike closing a Shell Oil Company refinery near Houston, Texas, where high-octane aviation gasoline sufficient to fuel a bomber mission of 1,000 planes a day over Europe is produced every twenty-four hours, Secretary Harold L. Ickes, Solid Fuels Administrator for War, said today he would take all possible steps to bring the walkout to an end.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 11 (AP) -Pantelleria, roughly eight miles long by four wide, is a part of Trapani Province, making it politically a segment of Sicily. It is the first soil of metropolitan Italy to be taken by the Allies.
MOSCOW, June 11 -- How a Russian Guards regiment retrieved its honor has just been told in the Army newspaper Red Star.

The greatest threat to liberty and the whole world is the mass state, Sir Willmott Lewis, Washington correspondent of The London Times, declared last night, in an address at the Four Freedoms War Bond Show in the International building, 630 Fifth Avenue.

Less than two days after he was alleged to have raped a 17-year-old married girl and stabbed her sailor escort after threatening them with a bayonet, Private Edward Green, 24 years old, of an infantry unit doing guard duty in the city, was arrested, indicted by the grand jury and arraigned in Felony Court yesterday.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 11 -- New York University, strongest Eastern team to enter the meet in more than a decade, dominated qualifying trials today in the twenty-second annual National Collegiate A.A. track and field championships, and at once became favorite to end Southern California's eight-year reign in tomorrow's finals.

RYE, N.Y., June 11 -- Ellis Knowles won the United States seniors' golf championship, which was concluded today. Knowles played his two rounds at Apawamis on Tuesday and Wednesday, one a 67 for a new 18-hole senior record, and the other an 80, for a total of 147.

TRENTON, June 11 -- The State Board of Education denied today the application of a corporation known as the Essex College of Medicine and Surgery for permission to confer the degree of Doctor of Medicine on the ground the Newark school "is only a paper institution."

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Hailing the surrender to Allied forces of the Mediterranean island of Pantelleria as a portent of things to come, President Roosevelt openly invited the Italian people today to overthrow Premier Benito Mussolini and the Fascist party and to expel the Germans so that they could be restored to a respected position in the European family of nations.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) -- Attorney General Francis Biddle disclosed today that the Navy has asked withdrawal of its request for $1,748,408 for use in an oil lease transaction with the Standard Oil Company of California after President Roosevelt ordered a study of the legality of the agreement.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 -- Ingrid Bergman, on loan from David O. Selznick, will have the feminine lead, originally planned for Irene Dunne, in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer's version of Patrick Hamilton's English melodrama "Gaslight."

CAIRO, Egypt, June 11 -- Brig. Gen. Patrick J. Hurley, United States Minister to New Zealand and former Secretary of War in the Hoover Administration, received the Distinguished Flying Cross today "for meritorious achievement while participating in aerial flights in furtherance of the war effort."

Henry Armstrong solved Sammy Angott's peculiar way of fighting at Madison Square Garden last night. The veteran Negro campaigner from Los Angeles, former holder of the world featherweight, lightweight and welterweight championships simultaneously, forced matters unceasingly against his foe from Washington, Pa., through ten rounds, and by so doing earned a unanimous decision.

MOSCOW, June 11 -- In a hall decorated with the Polish national colors, emblems depicting the white eagle and past heroes of liberation movements, the Union of Polish Patriots held its first assembly last Tuesday in Moscow, according to reports printed this morning.

NEWARK, N.J., June 11 (AP) -The Bears, in hot pursuit of first place, reduced Toronto's lead to two and a half games in a twilight contest tonight by taking a 6-to-3 decision. It was the opener of a five-game series in which the lead is at stake.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 11 -- Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey testified for five hours today before Supreme Court Referee J. Addison Young in support of her claims that William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey was cruel and inhuman, unfit as a guardian of their two daughters and wrong in accusing her of intimacies with Benny Woodall and Lew Jenkins.

The stock market failed yesterday to emerge from its unsatisfactory and indecisive stage as prices drifted aimlessly and closed irregularly lower. It was the second dullest session of the last two weeks on the Stock Exchange, and few groups as such managed to end on the higher side.

The 580 West End Avenue Corporation sold the fifteen-story apartment building at that address to the Su-Be Realty Corporation, David Bisgeier, president. Assessed at $400,000, the property is at the northeast corner of Eighty-eighth Street and has several doctors' apartments on the ground floor and a penthouse of twelve rooms.

The News Print Service Bureau reported yesterday aggregate production of newsprint in North America during the first five months of this year was 18.1 per cent below that of the comparable 1942 period, a decrease of 354,232 tons.

PHILADELPHIA, June 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today a report on its investigation into the purchase by the Salta Corporation and the Ward La France Truck Corporation of the latter company's publicly owned stock "without disclosure" to the public stockholders of all details of the transactions, including the intention to liquidate the truck concern.

Thirty City College post-graduate students, candidates for the Master of Science degree in education, who were unable to meet the requirements of the School of Education before their entrance into the armed forces, have been allowed to take examinations for the degree while in Army camps or on furlough, according to Dean Esek Ray Mosher.

Federal authorities in this city forecast yesterday that the packing industry's coolers here would be empty by Monday in anticipation of the scheduled roll-back of prices on June 21. They would hazard no prediction as to the time it will take the packers to restock local refrigerators.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- Higher wage rates allowed government workers in the Greater New York area by the National Labor Relations Board and the Economic Stabilization Director, may be added to prices charged by contractors in the dress industry, the Office of Price Administration ruled today.

AN ADVANCE AMERICAN AIR BASE IN CHINA, June 10 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- American and Japanese fliers traded blows over the Central China front today and, as usual, the Yanks got the best of it, shooting down a bomber and probably destroying five other planes without suffering a loss.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, June 12 (AP) -- Heavy bombers of the Fifth Air Force struck unusually heavy blows in two directions yesterday, turning Timor's capital, Kupang, into a "mass of flames" with forty-two tons of bombs and hitting two Rabaul airdromes with more than nineteen tons in a two-hour attack.

The stock market failed yesterday to emerge from its unsatisfactory and indecisive stage as prices drifted aimlessly and closed irregularly lower. It was the second dullest session of the last two weeks on the Stock Exchange, and few groups as such managed to end on the higher side.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J. -- This semi-militarized resort faces prospects of a gradual exodus of air trainees stationed here in its major Boardwalk and side avenue hotels. The transition back to a pleasure resort is expected to result in a short-term dilemma for the hostelries which are now occupied by the air trainees.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- In his report to the President Donald M. Nelson wrote:
