ON this page are shown specimens of the handwriting of Hitler, Mussolini and Stalin. To the layman they are more or less curiosities; to the graphologist they are indices of the character of the three men. For graphology is the art of reading character through analysis of handwriting.

More than 400 Negro boys and girls have had Summer camping reservations made for them under Methodist auspices with the aid of a grant of $5,000 from the New York City Society, plus what their families give or what comes from scholarships, sponsors or special sources.

The surrender on Friday of the Italian island of Pantelleria, after nineteen days of continuous bombardment, eliminates another outpost of the Fortress of Europe and prepares the way for major operations in the Mediterranean. The little Italian island in the narrow bottleneck of the Mediterranean between Tunisia and Sicily was blasted into surrender by air power, with the subsidiary help of naval bombardment.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The third phase of the campaign to break Japan's hold on the Western Aleutians appeared today to have gotten under way with resumption of fairly heavy aerial attacks on the enemy at Kiska Island.

The Boy Scout movement represents "the very best in American boyhood," Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia declared yesterday in swearing in 500 Scouts as official dispatch bearers for the Office of War Information in a ceremony at City Hall Plaza.
WHILE insect pests so far this year have been, on the whole, less troublesome than usual, severe damage by them may still be expected.

POSTMASTER General Frank C. Walker announced last week that the five-cent stamp honoring Czechoslovakia, the second in the series of eleven to commemorate the resistance by the peoples of European countries to Nazi aggression, will be issued on July 12, with first-day sales at Washington.

The only Spar in the United States Coast Guard Port Security Command, New York, Lieutenant Thelma Meharg, has assumed charge of the command's chain of canteens, becoming the first Spar officer to be assigned to a ship's service store detail.

AT 12:01 A.M. Tuesday the radio industry begins operation under the new rules of the Federal Communications Commission. A majority of broadcasters had fought the regulations for two years, finally seeing them sustained on May 10 in a Supreme Court decision that bids fair to start a wider controversy than the rules themselves.

THE Army policy of refusing to permit its soldier-students to participate in intercollegiate athletics has come in for considerable criticism, particularly since the Navy, which has just as vital an interest in winning the war, has instituted a more broad-minded program.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- The Mount Mansfield Hotel, atop Vermont's highest peak, has announced that it will keep unblemished its record of being open every year since 1857. The opening date has been set as June 20. Regular bus connections have been arranged from Waterbury, with station wagon accommodations from Stowe to the hotel.

A four-stacker destroyer of World War I design, which was refitted and cast in a new role as a patrol plane tender, the McFarland, received the Presidential unit citation yesterday for outstanding performance in action and distinguished service to the United States in the Battle of Guadalcanal.

WHEN IS A DOOR NOT A DOOR? One of the most valuable commodities to be discovered in the average house is plain, ordinary, empty space. In those bustling districts known as "war-impacted communities" this is especially and painfully true.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The way of the economizer is harder even than that of the transgressor, as Senator Harry F. Byrd of Virginia discovered anew this week when the Senate, by a bipartisan vote of 53-25, rejected his effort to abolish the Farm Security Administration, halved its $120 millions and split the remainder between the Farm Credit Administration and the extension services of land-grant colleges.

A PHILADELPHIA Chippendale strolled-top highboy with claw-and-ball feet and a sofa in antique needlepoint of the same period are features of the sale on Tuesday, Thursday and Friday afternoons at the Parke-Benet Galleries.

BALTIMORE, June 12 (AP) -- The State Office of Price Administration revoked the personal and official gasoline ration books of J. Millard Tawes, Maryland Controller, today but gave him the right to apply for a new ration for official driving.
BOSTON, June 12 -- With a rush in the stretch, Abram S. Hewitt's Some Chance won the $5,000 added Plymouth Rock Handicap that featured today's racing card at Suffolk Downs, watched by 19,500 fans.

LOS ANGELES -- Most California tourists these days are in khaki, blue or service green. Or else they are accompanied by men in uniform. The shutdown of transportation for pleasure has far from killed the California tourist trade, because the land is full of soldiers, all anxious to see the sights of which they have heard.

New York's Summer circus, "Spangles" -- Ringling Brothers' creation to "satisfy the appetite of the circus-minded in this large area" -- began its final rehearsals yesterday at Madison Square Garden. On Wednesday night, the new circus, bedecked with a Continental flavor, will open its run in the air-conditioned Garden before a capacity assemblage of war-bond purchasers.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col. -- Despite the war, this resort at the foot of Pike's Peak expects one of its busiest Summer seasons in a decade. Ice shows, golf tournaments, horse shows, square dances, starlight concerts, art exhibitions, popular concerts are scheduled for coming weeks.

Breaking away from their former insularity, students from the four New York city colleges are now employed in war industries, government and civilian laboratories, confidential research offices and Federal bureaus in every section of the country, a survey conducted by the Board of Higher Education has disclosed.

LONDON, June 12 (AP) -- All Sicily is now within range of Allied fighter planes through the capture of Pantelleria, the Air Ministry pointed out today. Fighter craft from there can reach the western half of Sicily and Malta-based planes cover the eastern half.
Lieutenant William L.E. Sinkler, U.S.N.R., and Mrs. Sinkler of Elkins Park, Pa., are at the Ritz-Carlton.

HOLLYWOOD has several systems for making film stars. But the movie industry concedes that the soundest is by way of the ballot box. For the public likes to pick its own screen favorites. And the public seldom makes a mistake.

ABOARD the Diesel yacht Privateer, outward bound from Miami, are, in addition to the crew, four passengers, Gay Holly, Searle Weymouth, Hymie Bloche and a man who calls himself Otto Ganss. Gay is a movie actress. Searle an actor. Hymie a director and Ganss poses as Hymie's financial backer.

IN the blue dawn of Nov. 8, 1942, American soldiers swarmed across the beaches of North Africa from Cape Cantin to Algiers. At Casablanca, where fighting raged for three days, landing forces were covered by squadrons of United States Navy planes, operating from carriers cruising offshore.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 12 (AP) -- Federal Judge Thomas W. Slick ended the alleged war fraud case against the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company and five employes today by imposing fines and prison sentences, the latter to be suspended on payment of the fines.

As the fighting season of the fourth year of war in Europe approaches its solstice, the whole world waits in breathless suspense for the things that are to come. Will 1943 bring a repetition of 1918? There are some who believe so, and many more who hope so.

Formation of the Council of Languages and Literature "to prevent the elimination of classical and modern language studies from high schools and colleges" was announced yesterday by Prof. E. Adelaide Hahn, chairman of the Classics Department at Hunter College and head of the council's steering committee.

City dwellers are expected to turn in greater numbers than ever before to the beaches of the metropolitan area this second war Summer. The pleasure-driving ban, coupled with the ODT's request that vacationists stay close to home, means that the sandy shores of Coney Island in Brooklyn, the Rockaways and Jacob Riis Park in Queens and Orchard Beach in the Bronx will play host to record throngs of perspiring enthusiasts.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 12 -- Waves of Allied bombers hammered the tiny Italian island of Lampedusa into submission and surrender today, just one day after Pantelleria had capitulated to the same Allied air mastery.
AN ADVANCED ALLIED AIR BASE IN NORTH AFRICA, June 12 -- A British flier named Cohen "captured" Lampedusa single-handed today.

WHILE Eileen and her many friends continue dancing their daily million miles with service men at the Stage Door Canteen, another of the American Theatre Wing's enterprises moves quietly and unglamorously on its way.

Upon the President's signature, the compromise pay-as-you-go tax bill became law on June 10. Withholding of tax does not apply, however, to remuneration paid for services performed as members of the United States military or naval forces.

With accessories meeting excellent consumer response, retail trade continued brisk in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports.
ALGIERS, June 12 (Reuter) -- There has been no direct contact between General de Gaulle and General Giraud in the past twenty-four hours.

Labor demands a major role in post-war reconstruction to attain the two-fold objective of enduring peace and economic security for the peoples of all nations. William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, told a meeting of the American Labor Conference on International Affairs at the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon.

Earl Browder, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, introduced yesterday before a plenary session of the party's national committee a resolution approving the proposal to dissolve the Communist International and calling upon all Communists to take part in eliminating "the remnants of the bogey of communism, which continues to be a weapon against national unity and the war effort."

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) -- Four Negro boys wearing zoot trousers and "pancake" hats were attacked and badly beaten on a street corner early today by twenty-five white boys in a melee in which "several shots" were fired, Patrolmen Arthur Pancerie and Thomas O'Neil reported.

KINGSTON, N.Y. -- A survey made recently by the Ulster County Board of Supervisors and the Greene County Chamber of Commerce shows that more reservations for the Summer and early Autumn have been made in the Ulster-Greene resort region than during any other year in the last decade.

Mr. Pounds, the old-fashioned grocer, has no potatoes for us, and tells us why. His wholesaler has them, he says, and asks only the wholesale ceiling price for them, but wants to charge him $2 a bag for carrying them across the sidewalk out of the warehouse and putting them into his truck.

Using the "one and three-quarters twist," George Mugford, 17-year-old draftsman, of 4005 Seventh Avenue, Brooklyn, hurled himself and the Borough of Brooklyn yesterday to the horse-shoe pitching championship of the city at the city-wide final matches at the Parade Grounds in Brooklyn under the Park Department.

WOODED hills, cool lakes and streams and sunny beaches await the vacationist this second war Summer, but the annual two-weeks-with-pay must more than ever be coordinated with the nation's victory effort and will be affected by increasing restrictions and shortages.

STAMFORD, N.Y. -- The Rexmere Hotel and cottages plans its official opening for June 30. Advance bookins forecast an excellent season at this hostelry of forty-six years' standing. A very comprehensive plan of entertainment and activity has been devised to entertain the guests.

Newtonian space and time, the conservation of energy and Darwinian evolution were the particular patterns of nature's dynamism. These were the fixed and final reckonings charted by science in the boundless ocean of the universe. Herbert Spencer based a philosophy on these postulates and two profound and original American minds used the same categories to come to terms with European thinking and American living.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, June 13 (AP) -- A liberator damaged a 2,000-ton Japanese cargo ship yesterday off Kaimana, Dutch New Guinea, the high command announced in today's noon communique.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Two of the Navy's newest submarines, the Amberjack and Grampus, were officially listed today as lost in carrying on war patrols.

One hundred and fifty dollars in United States currency for a simple coat, $50 for a five-gallon tin of kerosene, 45 cents for a candle are "astronomical" prices that prevail in Yuanling, Hunan, China, Bishop Cuthbert M. O'Gara, head of the Passionist Missions in China, wrote recently to Father Emmanuel Trainor, mission procurator, at Union City, N.J. A tailor said his Chinese cassock even at second hand was worth $250.

The answer a good many men might make is to be found in the bill of five one-act plays to be presented tomorrow night at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre under the title of "The Army Play-by-Play."

AUGUSTA, Me. -- Maine travel conditions appear to have leveled off for the duration and one may reach Pine Tree resorts with little difficulty. Once in Maine, facilities for enjoyment of the countryside are about the same.

The consensus was that the Red Army was not first-class, that the best generals had been killed in the purges, that Soviet equipment was of questionable value.

THE Department of Agriculture has obtained from the WPB an allocation of materials sufficient for the manufacture of 125,000 new pressure cookers -- good news for home canners of Victory garden products. That makes an annual total of 275,000 -- a larger number of home cookers than has been available in any other year.

LONDON, June 12 -- The Allied governments in London issued today a series of declarations marking United Nations Day on Monday. They expressed a deep sense of mutual responsibility in winning the war and hope that the unity attained in gaining that objective would live on in the days of peace to come.

MANY ornamental bird baths are placed out in the hot sun, in the most open spot available, and remain unused. The writer decided a year ago last Summer to try an innovation and make a real pool for the birds.

ALGIERS, June 12 (AP) -- A subcommittee of the new French government is reported to have gained more ground today toward the settlement of the dispute between General Charles de Gaulle and General Henri Honore Giraud, but the two principals remain estranged.
May I comment briefly on your article "I Am an American," by Francis Biddle ?

Rowboat fishermen now form the basis of our present salt water fishing population. Left behind, when power boats moved off to more distant places, the rowboat has suddenly become the "big ship" upon which anglers must rely to get to the fishing grounds.

Lieutenant George Hyde Clarke Jr., Army Air Forces, eldest son of Mrs. S. Beach Cooke of 530 Park Avenue and Cooperstown, N.Y. and of George Hyde Clarke of Hyde Hall, Cooperstown, was killed Thursday in an accident at Weed Calif., while completing training for combat duty with the Thirty fourth Bombing Group, Seventh Squadron.

RUSSIAN War Relief, Inc., has been conducting a campaign for the past few weeks to promote an exchange of letters between American and Russian individuals who are engaged in similar artistic and professional work.

THE war has brought a boom to German bookstores. In the first World War the reaction was similar; but today the demand has taken on much more vehement forms. Recently the semi-official magazine Du Neue Literatur proudly reported that in 1941 a hundred million more books were printed than in 1940.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 -- Punishment of the guilty in crimes of violence, "regardless of what clothes they wear, whether they be zoot suits, police, Army or Navy uniforms," was demanded today by a Citizens' Committee appointed by Governor Earl Warren to investigate the Los Angeles outbreaks of the last ten days involving "zoot-suit" wearers and service men.

A roomful of moguls of the American Power Boat Association gathered for several hours at the Hotel Lexington the other night as members of the National Council and effected an organization of various boards and committes for 1943 even though motor boating will be all but impossible because of the fuel rationing.

THE Knopf Literary Fellowships for 1943 have been awarded to Mrs. Fawn Brodie of Washington, D.C., for a projected study of Joseph Smith, the Mormon prophet, and Donald W. Mitchell of Sam Houston State Teachers College, Huntsville, Texas, for his proposed history of the "new" United States Navy, from 1883 to the present time.

Six Episcopal theological seminary students will enter Bellevue Hospital Wednesday for a course lasting twelve weeks in dealing with behavior problems under joint arrangement with the hospital and the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

Aviation medicine grew out of war. Nevertheless, air fighting makes it impossible for fliers to benefit fully from medical progress, according to Dr. Henry T. Ricketts, assistant professor of medicine at the University of Chicago. In his opinion, improvements in aviation await new methods of protecting the human organism.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 12 -- A funeral mass for the victims of the June 4 revolution was celebrated this morning in the Buenos Aires Cathedral in the presence of all members of the new government and high State officials.

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Eddie Miller batted 5 for 5 today and the Reds, with the assistance of a homer by Frank McCormick and a timely single by Lonnie Frey, scored a 6-to-5 victory over the Cubs in eleven innings.

MONTICELLO -- The resorts of Sullivan and Ulster Counties have made plans for the Summer and invite the cooperation of vacationists in carrying out arrangements which are intended to reduce wartime inconvenience to a minimum.

The seventeenth annual parade and commemoration exercises by the Robert Burns Memorial Association of America was held yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park. Preceded by their bands various Scottish societies marched to the statue of Burns, where a wreath was placed by J. Noble MacLean, the president of the association.

THE New Yorker, who is buffeted in the subway, prodded with trays in the cafeteria and bored with the crowds, may profess not to understand it, but half a million people each year come into New York City for their vacations.

Food trade leaders, encouraged by the success of the Food Industry War Committee in presenting its views on current industry problems to government officials, are planning to enlarge the scope of the group's operations to include a more direct approach to the consuming public in matters affecting the wartime food situation, it was learned yesterday.

PROFESSOR FERGUSON has given us a biography of Mark Twain which sums up virtually all that is known as of 1943. I myself attempted such a summary in the centennial year, 1935, but my book was not narrative, and a prodigious amount of material has appeared since.

BOSTON, June 12 (AP) -- Washington's Milo Candini hurled his fifth victory of the season, with no losses, today as he shut out the Red Sox 1-to-0. The Senators' pitcher allowed three hits, two of them by catcher Roy Partee.

SEVERAL very fine novels have come out of the University of Michigan, under the aegis of the Avery Hopwood Award. The latest one is Ann George Leslie's "Dancing Saints." To say that it introduces a promising talent is understatement.

The following statement was made in THE TIMES MAGAZINE recently: "Only nine other American soldiers have worn the four silver stars of this rank [full general] and only three wore them in wartime." I think you will find this assertion incorrect, because the Confederate generals were "American soldiers." even though they were not in the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- In asking each House of Congress to designate a single committee through which all controversies growing out of the conduct of the war might be channeled to the Executive branch of the Federal Government, the War Mobilization Director, James F. Byrnes, struck consciously and deliberately at one of the critical problems in Washington -- the epidemic of Congressional investigations.

Should she lose this war Japan will begin to plan for another conflict, Hallett Abend, Far Eastern correspondent and observer of Japan's rise to military might, said in an address yesterday in the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, at the Four Freedoms War Bond Show, sponsored by the Treasury Department-Saturday Evening Post.

Rembrandt's "Portrait of a Young Child" will be displayed to the public for the first time at 9 A.M. tomorrow with the opening of Gimbel Brothers' new art gallery for old masters on the fifth floor of the store at Broadway and Thirty-third Street, it was announced yesterday by Frederic A. Gimbel, vice president of the store.

BY anonymous ballot and a majority the Music Critics Circle of New York has given its annual award for the best American orchestral novelty heard in New York during the season of 1942-43 to Paul Creston, for his First symphony, Opus 20.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia should refer to himself as "Big Chief Setting Bull" rather than "Big Chief Rising Cloud," Walter Hoving, chairman of the Committee to Balance the Budget Through Sensible Economies, quipped yesterday in ridiculing the Mayor's criticism of the City Council for slashing city fuel appropriations by nearly $2,000,000.

A BRIGHT little annual for a hot, dry, sunny spot is portulaca. This many-colored, low-growing Rose-moss, as it is sometimes called, may be planted to fill in a sun-baked bank or border and needs little care during its long season of bloom.

LOS ANGELES, June 12 (AP) -- Boulder and Parker Dams, vast sources of water and electric power, are in constant danger of sabotage from external sources, Norris E. James, a former official of the Japanese relocation center at Poston, Ariz., told a Dies Congressional subcommittee today.

A net operating loss of $38,842.85 was sustained by the American Kennel Club for the year 1942. The governing body of the sport of breeding and showing of thoroughbred dogs felt the impact of the first full year of all-out war, as did every other business and individual throughout the nation.
THE consensus among Long Islanders is that wartime restrictions on travel may improve the 1943 Summer season. As one old Southampton resident put it: "When they come this year, they'll stay."

CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Fred H. Clutton, secretary of the Chicago Board of Trade, notified members today that the Associate War Food Administrator had approved a proposed regulation regarding liquidation of cash corn hedged in July and September 1943 futures, and that the regulation will become effective on Monday.

THE country hotel keeper, wherever he may be, faces many problems this Summer. His difficulties have been accumulating ever since rationing and shortages began; now they press hard upon him. But he is determined to overcome all obstacles and he relies upon his clients, old and new, to take the good with the bad and see him through.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass. -- There is at least one type of craft which has not been requisitioned for wartime use, and that is the famed Swampscott dory, regarded by many as the best all-service small boat ever devised.

LONDON, June 12 -- General Draja Mikhailovitch reported today from the mountains of Yugoslavia that a force of 250,000 Yugoslavs was waiting for the invasion signal to take arms from secret hiding places in a coordinated uprising against the Axis.

MURRAY BAY, Que. -- The Manoir Richelieu and cottages at picturesque Murray Bay, in the French-Canadian Province of Quebec, will formally open for the Summer season on June 21. The American traveler can reach Murray Bay by steamer, rail and air.

WHEN a reviewer considers an author's most important book to date, it is hard not to add that it is also her best. Like the comedian who yearned to play "Hamlet," Miss du Maurier (who has no peer in melodrama) has evidently yearned to write a serious dynastic novel.

WITH BRITISH ASSAULT FORCES, Pantelleria, June 12 -- American bombers laid a pattern of ruin over this one-time Italian stronghold and British cruisers and destroyers battered the remaining defenses. Then the ground forces came ashore to take the harbor.

ALGIERS, June 12 -- Behind the facade of French unity built on the foundation of the National Committee of Liberation strong forces are in conflict and a crisis which would force the resignation of some of the committee's members could arise over any one of a number of basic questions.

TO children in the Smith household minor spills and tumbles are all in the day's growing-up. A recent report tells us. "Mrs. Smith knows that the hard bumps that really hurt need to be treated as real tragedies," but that incidental spells get from her an "over you go and up you come!" and usually, after a moment, a smile from Martin or little Ann as "up they come."

THE prospect of transportation facing the vacation traveler this Summer is not a bright one. In fact, probably never before in recent times has the problem of getting from one place to another been quite so difficult or bound up with so many restrictions.

Despite the fact that a number of Fall lines were withdrawn in the wholesale markets, the allotment method of selling is enabling producers to streamline their production with the result that many organizations will probably be able to produce a more sizable volume of goods, according to the trade report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co.

WHAT is a diplomat? According to Dr. Johnson, he is "a man sent to lie abroad for the good of his country." And indeed, for many years during the long armistice, it was customary to abuse diplomats on the ground that they were either unnecessary, or crooked, or both.

METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER will spend $250,000 to reenact the Dieppe Commando raid on its studio back lot as the action highlight of "White Cliffs of Dover," an adaptation of the popular poem by the late Alice Duet Miller.

THESE two volumes, the first written by Associate Professor of Vegetable Gardening at Rutgers University and the second by the Professor of Landscape Gardening at the Uni versity of Connecticut, are compact volumes of encyclopedic information by men who thoroughly know their subjects.

PROFESSOR NAMIER, whose studies in eighteenth-century English history will be remembered, writes here as an intelligent and devoted Zionist. The book is a compilation of essays which, however disparate their topics may be, are woven together by the theme of the "Jewish problem" in contemporary society.

NEW DELHI, India, June 12 (AP) -- American and British planes operating from Indian bases carried out a series of widespread and destructive raids yesterday on Japanese troops, military installations and rolling stock in Burma.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Anthony E. Lutkus of 175 Hoyt Street, Kearny, N.J., a bombardier in the Army Air Forces, was a member of a crew which landed a crippled B-17 Flying Fortress, loaded with bombs, by a flash of lightning, the War Department reported today.

ONE of the several differences between walking unsupported and walking with a crutch is that you may become dependent upon the crutch. There have been many cases of physically ill individuals who, having been administered drugs over long periods, become mentally ill so that nothing short of a completely revised mental attitude will return them to society.

After the Japanese occupied the East Indies in 1942 and cut off nine-tenths of the world's natural rubber supply attention was focused on Kok-Saghyz, a Russian variety of dandelion which yields a latex similar to that of the rubber tree. The important part of the plant for rubber is the rhizome or root which extends deeply into the soil.

Very clever and interesting are the "population maps" published in THE TIMES MAGAZINE of May 23, but they move me to call your attention to the very grave injus tice rendered to Long Island, a geographical area of only some 1,373 square miles, but a population area of more than 4,500,000 souls.

CHUNGKING, China, June 12 (AP) -- Chinese troops attacking the Yangtze port of Sungtze, between Ichang and Shasi, have recaptured several points south of the city after inflicting heavy casualties on the Japanese, a Chinese communique announced today.

SANTA FE, N.M. -- "Come and get it" applies this Summer not only to chuck wagon dinners but to everything else in the Southwest. "Come" puts the transportation hazard up to the visitor; "get it" invites him to share in the Summer crops of the country and rationed foods, as far as stamps will go.

A FAIR approach to this book demands careful consideration of its author's own evaluation of it: "It has served but as a tiny window, through which brief snatches of the many-faceted glory of the life history of a river were briefly portrayed, in the hope that they might suggest a greater range.

HERE is a small book which may be read as pure fantasy or as a piece of realism of an event as likely to happen as not. In either case, it is sure to divert the reader. As a professor of law, Mr. Radin propounds a real problem which after the coming armistice will have to be considered; as an author, he has done a brilliant piece of writing which is a delight to read.

THE second edition of the "Inter-American Statistical Yearbook," edited by a corps of Argentine experts and published under the auspices of the Argentine Commission of High International Studies, will undoubtedly receive as warm a welcome as the first, which appeared in 1940.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 12 -- The German mobilization of Norwegian labor has so far been a failure because only 25 per cent of the persons called up have reported for service, according to an Oslo dispatch today from the Nazi-controlled STB news agency.
This is the fourth of a series of ten articles on recent developments in expert bidding methods.

ST. LOUIS, June 12 -- The alert World Champion Cardinals took advantage of Jack Hallett's wild pitch in the sixth inning today to score a 1-to-0 triumph over Pittsburgh, their third straight in a five-game series. They play a double-header tomorrow.

A report received early this morning by THE NEW YORK TIMES, originating in a usually reliable source at Rome, said that the Fascist Grand Council had met in secret session in Rome from 10 o'clock to nearly midnight last night.
CLEVELAND, June 12 -- Virtual control of all commercial craft on the Great Lakes will pass Monday morning into the hands of the Office of Defense Transportation.

It may be difficult for a seasoned business executive to believe this, but I received yesterday two letters in the course of a heavy correspondence, which might have been dictated by the aged heads of one-man backwoods general stores instead, as is the fact, by responsible department executives of large corporations.
EVANSTON, Ill., June 12 -- Southern California, voted least likely to succeed, won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's track and field championship today for the ninth consecutive year.

UNTIL the question is answered next month concerning what effect the witholding tax will have on consumer buying, retail trade is holding to its gains over last year except in those lines which are hit either by shortages or rationing.

Great Lakes cruises will be the next best thing to ocean trips this season when the high seas are barred to the vacationist. Though the great ocean liners are out for the duration, deck sports, sunbathing and dancing supply similar relaxation aboard the lake boats.

A former leader of the Black Shirt movement in this country, who had obtained employment in an emergency government agency here handling confidential national defense matters, was one of seven enemy aliens arrested in the city this week-end, according to announcement yesterday by E.E. Conroy, special agent in charge of the local Federal Bureau of Investigation.

RALEIGH, N.C. -- More than 310,000 trout of legal length will be released in North Carolina streams during 1943, the State fisheries division of the North Carolina Board of Conservation and Development has announced.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Another tug of war between the armed services and the civilian-manned War Production Board for control of production may be in prospect, and this time it is said on reliable authority that it opens up the possibility of resignations from the WPB from Donald M. Nelson, the chairman, on down.
JERSEY CITY, June 12 (AP) -- Montreal and Jersey City split a double-header today, the Royals winning the opener, 4 to 2, in 11 innings and the Little Giants taking the 7-inning nightcap, 5 to 2.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 12 (AP) -- Argentina's new Provisional Government today dismissed six judges and two State prosecutors "marked by public opinion as lacking probity and balance," while an informed source said a man had been arrested in Buenos Aires Province on suspicion of espionage on behalf of a foreign power.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Granting approval for holding the big Chicago furniture market, the War Production Board's Office of Civilian Requirements today laid down the policy that "certain furniture markets should continue to be held."

MIAMI, Fla., June 12 -- Owners of about 200 hotels and apartment houses at Miami Beach which have been occupied by Army Air Force trainees for twenty months or more are wondering what they are going to do if, and when, the War Department terminates its leases on the properties.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- By the close of this week living costs in the United States will be up an estimated 7 per cent compared with Sept. 15, last, and will continue to rise with accelerated speed unless action by Congress and the Administration imposes rigid lines against any further give-and-take on price and wage questions.

"IS Robert Benchley a solar myth?" That is the question little knots of curious people, as well as curious knots of little people, have been asking ever since Mr. Benchley traded in his quill for an Actors Equity card and abandoned the craft of writing.

Thousands of faculty members in colleges universities throughout the country have left the classroom to enter the armed services or war industries. This has meant, in many instances, that the college professors are carrying a heavier teaching schedule than ever before.

POLAND SPRING, Me. -- Since 1793 this resort has been catering to the traveler, and this season both Mansion House and Poland Spring House are celebrating the 150th anniversary of those first days. Still to be found in the lobby of Mansion House is the tiny bar where formerly always stood a bottle of rum to revive the tired wayfarer.

THE merchant seaman has been rescued from his role of obscurity within the past year by several first-hand reports of terror, endurance and courage at sea. The stark facts of the hunt -- the submarine stalking the slow, lumbering merchant fleet need none of the artistry of fiction to supply color and climax.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -- This old village, celebrated as the home of James Fenimore Cooper and as the birthplace of baseball, will have fewer visitors this Summer to enjoy its New England-like charm. Those who are able to come can pass the Summer here contentedly, without benefit of automobiles; for the village itself is beautiful and the shimmering expanse of Lake Otsego lies at its doorstep.

FOR a former Mississippi riverman (aged 10 or so) Augustus certainly gets around the country. Having helped out the Navy up in Maine, he is, as the latest chapter of his exploits begins, Georgia-bound, where Pop aims to help build an Army camp.

A new schedule of bus service reductions today will end Sunday operation of fifteen lines in Manhattan, including three crosstown routes, and will drop five of the routes on weekdays, too, for the duration of the critical gasoline shortage, it was announced yesterday by the Fifth Avenue Coach Company and its affiliates.

Benjamin Lazrus, president and founder of the Benrus Watch Company, has been named the new chairman of the Big Brother Department of the Jewish Board of Guardians, the New York Jewish Federation's agency for dealing with delinquent and problem children, Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, president of the Jewish Board of Guardians, announced yesterday.

RYE, N.Y., June 12 -- War dogs in a thrilling exhibition of attack and defense made a spectacular feature of the annual all-breed dog show of the North Westchester Kennel Club today on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.

Moderate liquidation and hedging offset continued price-fixing by the trade in the cotton futures market yesterday, holding prices steady during the dull two-hour session. The list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange closed unchanged to 2 points below Friday's final quotations.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The War Production Board today eliminated several thousand small wholesale and retail suppliers from the inventory controls of Order L-63 by an amendment to the order. As a result all suppliers whose total inventory at cost is less than $35,000 are exempt from its provisions.

Addressing yesterday several hundred delegates of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appealed to them to defend their right to administer their own organizations free from government control and with the right to strike.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

That well-known London square which has become the United States headquarters for the eventual invasion of Western Europe has been so thoroughly Americanized that to Americans and Britishers alike it has become known as "Little America."

ALBANY, June 12 -- Governor Dewey set the State's wartime nutrition program in motion today by allocating $200,000 for the extension of home food-preservation instructions to all cites in the State. At the same time he appointed Mrs. Roger W. Straus of New York as director of the nutrition program in the metropolitan area.

IN the antic days of The Independent, when it was chopping Emerson into short lengths and feeding them to an outraged public ( which called them "neither poetry nor prose") as free verse by W.R. Nosreme the magazine reviewed a book by Theodore Roosevelt.

STOCKHOLM, June 12 -- The German radio this week has been devoting much of its home front programs to warning the Reich "intellectuals" -- Propaganda Minister Goebbels disparagingly calls them "quasi-intellectuals" -- that they had better cease their agitation "to destroy Reich unity" or they will be "ruthlessly put out of the way."

Pantelleria, first of the Italian outposts in the Meditarranean to fall to the Allies, is one of those islands which are suitable at some times of the year for dreamers and mystics, and endurable at all times by those who are content to raise olives and grapes on a few acres of volcanic soil.

ARMAND DENIS, who recently returned from another expedition into the interior of Africa, is busy assembling into a feature-length motion picture the thousands of feet of film he exposed during fourteen months in the Belgian Congo, French Equatorial Africa and Burma.

THE possibilities of Connecticut as a vacation area have been neglected by New Yorkers, who judge the worth of a vacation ha terms of distance from home rather than relaxation. This Summer, with vacationists on their honor not to travel on week-ends and not too far, Connecticut is prepared to serve as a haven, offering a wide variety of attractions a few hours from Times Square.
LONDON, June 12 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Willard F. Jones, general manager of the Marine Department of the Gulf Oil Corporation, was elected president of the American Committee of Lloyd's Register of Shipping at its biennial meeting held last week. Mr. Jones succeeds John D. Reilly, president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation.

An ingenious method of separating wet from dry grain by use of an electrical condenser has been developed by two scientists -- T.A. Oxley of the British Department of Scientific Industrial Research and F.Y. Henderson of the Imperial College of Science and Technology (London).
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Charges of political corruption flew in the Senate today.

An appeal to bathers to use special care to avoid accidents on the city beaches, which are expected to be more crowded than ever this year because of travel restrictions, was issued yesterday by Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, City Health Commissioner.

At the same time that Office of Price Administration spokesmen in Washington were reported to have predicted yesterday that the new wage subsidy for vegetable canners would be paid to only a few and that most canners would have to absorb proposed wage increases, the American Institute of Food Distribution in this city advised its 3,000 members that canners expected little relief from the subsidy and were closing plants throughout the country.

The "defense" of thirty-five critical installations in Manhattan and Staten Island will be demonstrated between 9 A.M. and noon today when 3,000 members of the First Brigade of the New York Guard mobilize to meet a simulated airborne enemy attack on the city.

SUCH are the miracles of the talking wireless that a single broadcast of "Gay Nineties," that amiable and nostalgic entertainment which adorns the WABC-Columbia network on Monday evenings, finds Joe Howard playing to more people than ever saw him in the most successful of all his theatrical seasons.

Labor's right to strike on war industry jobs has been under fire from certain sections of Congress throughout much of the nation's three-year war production effort. The question brought a crisis just before Pearl Harbor. Then strikes called by John L. Lewis's United Mine Workers -- aimed at unionizing "captive" coal mines owned by steel companies -- called forth a flood of anti-strike bills on Capitol Hill.

THE home of the Morgan horse, Vermont, is attracting more and more riders who find the wooded roads of the State to their liking. Responsible in part for this trend is the Green Mountain Horse Association, the society which has blazed many new trails (a thousand miles are already marked and charted) and sponsors pack rides into picturesque country off the beaten path.

FRAMED in the blue doorway of La Marseillaise, the French seamen's canteen at 789 Second Avenue, stood Mme. Eugene Gentil, a founder and vice president. Her blue eyes glinted merrily behind harlequin glasses as she welcomed a group of women wearing the poilu-blue uniform of the auxiliary she heads -- wives of Free French War Veterans.

The Department of Motor Vehicles of New Jersey has emphasized in striking fashion the economic cost (let alone the personal tragedy) of the 103 pedestrian traffic fatalities which occurred in that State in the first quarter of this year. The department asked agricultural experts and several important war industries in the State to apply to their products the labor which 103 workers could turn out in a year's time.

Recently my mother wrote and told me that she was sending me a copy of THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE and said that I would be very interested in it. Well, I just waited and wondered. When I received the copy and read the story on the Will boys I certainly considered the author a genius right away.

Buffeted from pillar to post and back again until it was almost too difficult for the eye to follow them, the Giants plunged still deeper into the National League's second division yesterday when, to the chagrin of 9,802 onlookers, they dropped a double-header with the Phillies at the Polo Grounds.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 12 --In a spectacular finish among three sloops, Corny Shields sent his International Class Aileen across the line first today in the special regatta that was to have been held by the Manhasset Bay Y.C. but which was taken over by the Larchmont Y.C. on request because of the gasoline prohibition.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange continued to rise last month. On May 28, the last settlement date, 647 of the 1,234 issues had short interests of 980,047 shares, against the 607 issues that had aggregate short interests of 882,376 shares at the end of April.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia shouted his defiance to "any people or any combination of people in the world to make a sustained, effective landing on any point of our shores" in a speech yesterday at a New York Guard rally at City Hall Plaza that brought down the curtain on the ten-day Civilian Defense Volunteer Office drive for 500,000 recruits.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 12 -- The Finnish playwright, Mme Hella Vuolijoki, who arranged the first contact with the Russians during the 1939-40 Winter war when the Finns had decided to sue for peace, has been arrested in Helsinki on a charge of having sheltered in her home a Soviet woman parachutist.

LONDON -- The navies of the smaller Allies fighting with the United Nations have a total of 220 vessels and nearly 27,000 officers and men operating under the flags of their respective countries. In just over one year these navies have been increased from 170 fighting ships and 15,000 officers and men to their present strength.

The House Judiciary Committee, meeting in executive session, has refused to report bills which would have permitted 107 Chinese to enter this country legally every year, allowed those legally here to become citizens, and removed certain other discriminations against Chinese students and travelers.

MEXICO CITY -- Steaks are two inches thick in Mexico these days, and about the only thing that needs to be rationed is patience while you wait for accommodations. True, those who live here have to keep their cars in the garage for one day a week to conserve rubber, but the restriction hasn't been stiff enough to keep new gasoline stations from opening up.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- The local express agent of this southwestern Cape Cod village was recently heard to inquire despairingly where all the bicycles came from. That he could do with more parking space was apparent. Station storage room usually occupied by trunks and similar impedimenta had been taken over intact by a varied collection of bikes.

ON THE PACIFIC. DEAR Ruth, are you planning to be a Wave instead of a Waac? And dear what-aman, Superman Michael, are you planning to become an admiral instead of a general? If you are, you will have to learn a lot of new ways to say the old things.

LONDON. June 12 -- Strange as it may seem, the British Government is doing everything it can by radio, leaflet and underground telegraph to discourage organized sabotage against the Nazis in Europe. In this, British are supported by United States psychological warfare experts.

With its facilities already well established in conquered North Africa, the executive committee of the United Seamen's Service has turned its attenion to the organization of facilities for officers and crews of American merchant vessels in the South Pacific area, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director of the service.

Total war demands total peace. A durable peace, in turn, is possible only when economic peace is achieved. The basis of a large part of this accord lies in orderly production and distribution of raw materials. The blueprint for peace, therefore, must include two vital details.

Gustav V. King of Sweden, born June 16, 1858; ascended the throne Dee. 8, 1907; widower, two sons, six grandchildren, seven great-grandchildren; height 6 1/2 feet; hobbies: tennis, bridge, embroidery, elk-hunting, pike-fishing. Address Royal Castle, Stockholm. Telephone, 1130-60.
CHUNGKING, China, June 12 (AP) -- A communique:

We enjoyed your "Home to Roost" article in a recent TIMES MAGAZINE, perhaps because we have lately gone hen-raising, or hen-housing. My husband built a house for twenty New Hampshire Red hens; no roosters allowed; really an old ladies' home.

Kermit Roosevelt, who died recently in Alaska, recalls memories of the slim youth who was a cherished and valuable member of his father's hunting expedition in Africa, and an important factor in the latter's exploration of the "River of Doubt" in South America.

MEMBERS alone have furnished the material that constitutes the National Academy's concluding show this season. After June 26 the galleries of this institution will be closed for the rest of the Summer.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- The general assembly of the Polish Union of Patriots, concluding a two-day meeting here today, sent messages to President Roosevelt, Premier Stalin and President Eduard Benes of Czechoslovakia.

The annual parade of the Staten Island Flag Day Association was held yesterday afternoon through Brighton and Port Richmond and was witnessed by 10,000 persons. Following the parade a sixty-foot flag pole and granite monument, a tribute to men and women serving in the war, was unveiled and dedicated in Port Richmond Park.

THE subtitle of Edmund Wilson's anthology, "The Shock of Recognition," reads: "The Development of Literature in the United States Recorded by the Men Who Made It." The book, then, is not an ordinary anthology of American literature or even of American critical writing in general.
CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The names, with next of kin, of 212 United States soldiers missing in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, North American and Southwestern Pacific areas were made public today by the War Department.
THE following is an account of a trip two youth hostelers and travel novices took on a recent three-day holiday, from which they returned declaring pedaling was lots of fun:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Asserting that the strike represented a serious blow to war production and threatened adequate supplies of aviation gasoline, Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes made public today telegrams in which he urged workers who walked out of the Houston, Texas, refinery of the Shell Oil Company, to return to their posts.

Thousands of war workers of the Sperry Gyroscope Company in Nassau County had a glimpse of China's First Lady, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, as she passed by their machines yesterday in making her first visit to an American war plant.

Although confronted with numerous war-time regulations, rising taxes and operating costs, the earnings of manufacturers of consumers' goods as a group in the first quarter of this year were well above those of the initial three months of 1942.

MICHAEL TODD, who already has a comedy and a musical show warming up on the back of his stove, is thinking of preparing another dish. He has in mind Sean O'Casey's "Purple Dust," which has been looking for an American producer since the Spring of 1940, when Eddie Dowling first evinced interest in the Irishman's comedy.

ROBERT COFFIN is a talkative fellow, a Maine man with stars in his eyes and a song on his lips. He's full of laughter, and he's full of country lore, and he's as American as the Maine woods or a peck of Katahdin potatoes.

The first steam engine of which we have any record is Hero's, a mere toy invented in Alexandria in the second century A.D. It worked on the windmill principle -- that is, steam was blown against a moving member just as wind blows against vanes.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 12 -- The Italian High Command today confirmed the fall of Pantelleria to the Allies. Its announcement quoted the British radio on the severity of the Allied attack.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Following is the text of the bill to prevent strikes as passed by Congress and sent to the President:

Five thousand boys and girls, members of the Manhattan division of the Catholic Youth Organization, filled St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning to attend a mass for the welfare of the armed forces of the United States and for "a just peace after victory."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 12 -- More than 10,000 Italian prisoners have been taken on Pantelleria, according to the first, and necessarily hasty, count. The total may be considerably larger when a more complete check has been made. It is known, however, that 3,000 prisoners are already on the way back to or have arrived on the African mainland.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, June 8 (Delayed) (AP) -- Another decoration has come through for the late Major Ken McCullar, nearly two months after his death, in further recognition of this youthful Southerner's career as one of the world's outstanding bomber pilots.

FROM Asuncion comes word that Paraguay's postal administration has authorized the printing of a single stamp, 7pesos, which will be of dual commemorative significance. It will propagandize President Higinio Morinigo's "Plan Trienal" (Three-Year Plan) and at the same time will mark the inauguration of his Presidential term beginning some weeks hence.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 12 -- The second Summer field training of the State Guard units will begin at Camp Smith here tomorrow, according to the plan of training as laid out by Major Gen. William Ottmann, commander of the New York State Guard.

RED BANK, N.J. -- Monmouth County beach resorts from Keyport to Manasquan are not looking forward to a big season -- they already have it. The season has arrived, with a great many of the Summer hotels open and tenants of a good percentage of the cottages settled in the groove of Summer housekeeping.
A CURRENT witticism of the cafes of Algiers is, "After all, the two generals are very much in harmony; they are both tall and they are both soldiers."

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 12 -- Eight African lions escaped this morning from the Gilbert Brothers Circus and two of them were loose for nearly an hour on a residential street adjoining the circus grounds, providing terror and comedy before they were rounded up by trainers and roustabouts, aided by twenty policemen and firemen armed with shot guns and axes.

The New York City Committee of the National War Fund, 57 William Street, yesterday named Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, as its chairman, it was announced by Lindsay Bradford, chairman of the organizing committee.

Older boys and girls are helped by more than financial aid from friends in America, says Edna Blue reporting on Foster Parents' Plan for War Children. "It is the friendship that the child cherishes most." This organization does its work among children of various nationalities in England.

A TOWN IN ENGLAND, June 12 -- Many of the large number of United States troops stationed in or around this community are planning to celebrate their first anniversary here next month. In the year that has passed both towns-people and soldiers have settled down to an entirely different type of relationship from that of their first few months.

THERE is plenty of excitement in this one. It has to do with fifth-column activities in a mythical Central American republic and with two young Americans, Nicholas Duane and Martha Cleves, who do not know what it is all about until the very end, but who none the less are responsible for stopping what might have been a serious threat to the entire Western Hemisphere.

EARLY blooming shrubs that have completed their flowering for the season are best pruned at this time. Not only can the bushes be shaped better if trimmed back now, but in some cases it is very important to remove old flower buds in order that the plant may conserve its energy for producing buds for next season's bloom and not set seed.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12 -- A 15-year-old high school student, said by police to have admitted that he had fatally shot another youth in a street fight between Negro and white boys in this city June 3, was arrested early today at his grandmother's home in Jersey City, where he had been hiding since the slaying.

MURDER in the Brooklyn Heights apartment of Mrs. Beulah Fitch Casey Potter Donelli Roberts, four times married, once widowed and twice divorced. The victim is the elderly butler who has been with the family ever since Beulah's name was Casey.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 12 -- Two United States Navy fliers attached to the Bermuda station were decorated this morning by Rear Admiral I.C. Sowell, commandant of the United States naval operating base, Lieutenant Joseph M. Kellam of Biscoe, N.C., receiving the Silver Star Medal and Lieutenant J.G. August A. Barthes of Biloxi, Miss., the Air Medal.

Congress apparently has had an over-dose of "administrative tribunals,'' the Securities and Exchange Commission in particular. Last week ten of the eleven members of the securities sub-committee of the House Committee on Foreign and Interstate Commerce, regardless of party, engaged in a bear-baiting party at the expense of Ganson Purcell, chairman of the SEC, and members of his staff.

LAST Sunday in this place there appeared some comment on the third annual exhibition of the Federation of Modern Painters and Sculptors, which remains current at Wildenstein's through June 26. In the course of that article it was mentioned that one of the artist-members of the federation had promised a statement calculated to disperse befuddlement (which I had freely confessed) over certain paintings.

POCONO MANOR, Pa. -- Indications are that Pocono Manor will open July 1 with a capacity guest list. Arriving guests will be met with the full beauty of the rhododendron season. For it is the time when over the estate's 3,000 acres, myriads of wild shrubs burst into full bloom.

THE best-known -- and the best -- of the few novelists who have dug for literary ore in the rich narrative field of Montana, Myron Brinig returns in "The Gambler Takes a Wife" to the State which gave him the materials of "Singermann," "Wide Open Town," "The Sun Sits in the West" and "This Man Is My Brother."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, June 13 (AP) -- The noon communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, June 12 -- Great excitement spread through France today at news of the fall of Pentelleria to the Allies, according to reports received here, and the conviction grew that active operations would soon be brought to French soil.

Yappy, the mongrel trained to bring back Harlem River scrap rubber, is missing. Last year the tiny brown-and-white dog, owned by Mrs. Angela Temple and companion on her houseboat at 1 Dyckman Street, near 196th Street, gained momentary fame when it was discovered he had brought back 500 assorted rubber objects, including thirteen tires, from the swift-flowing river for the scrap drive.

Hoping to avoid the waste of food similar to that which followed the glut of spinach on New York and Northern New Jersey markets late in May, the Northeastern Vegetable and Potato Council asked yesterday that the War Food Administration immediately set up machinery needed to take off the market the anticipated surplus that growers believed would develop in cabbage, beets, tomatoes and string beans between July 1 and 15 from Baltimore to Boston.

The chief new feature of the Vassar Summer Institute for Family and Child Care Services in War Time, which will hold its second session on the campus from July 1 to 30, will be a workshop to prepare Chinese students now in the United States for reconstruction work in China.

A Brooklyn boy who never wore the Flatbush spangles was no bargain the Dodgers in an enemy uniform at Ebbets Field yesterday. Tommy Holmes took care of all the scoring and most of the heavy hitting as the Braves beat the Dodgers, 2 -- 1, before a ladies' day crowd of 19,366.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12 -- Dr. Joseph Kenrick of the home club and Harold Weeks of the Rockville Country Club, the medalists, moved ahead to the semifinals of the member-guest best-ball golf tournament over the course of the Hempstead G.C. today.

HARRISBURG, Pa. -- This war Summer of 1943, in Pennsylvania as elsewhere, will differ in many ways from past Summers. Aimless driving or touring over the State's fine highways -- pastimes which have given pleasure to millions of motorists in peacetime -- will be among the war casualties.

LONDON, Sunday, June 13 -- The Russian Air Force, blasting advanced German airdromes for the fourth straight night, dropped 600 tons of bombs that destroyed many planes and started more than 100 fires Friday night, the Moscow radio announced early today.

A NEW army of some 2,500,000 will soon be on the move when the country's children begin their annual trek to Summer camps. Even in normal years this exodus was something to cope with; now, with a war on our hands and troops on the move.

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS. -- With the Office of Defense Transportation stressing the importance of vacationing within the borders of one's resident State there is every indication that this historic vacationland, carved out of towering, rugged mountains and studded with hundreds of crystal-clear lakes, is going to be one of the major vacation fronts for the New York State civilian war workers on furlough.

PERHAPS there is no task more difficult than the just criticism of contemporary literature. It is even more grateful to give praise where it is needed than where it is deserved, and friendship so often seduces the iron stylus of justice into a vague flourish, that she writes what seems rather like an epitaph than a criticism.

CONCORD, N.H. -- To provide relaxation and refreshment for the nation's workers is a contribution to the war effort. At least that is what many of New Hampshire's hostelers feel as they enter their second wartime Summer.

SERVICE MEN, homesick for the sight and sound of small boys and girls, are playing host today to thousands of youngsters at their USO clubhouses. In the fashion of juvenile festivities, most of the guests will turn the tables and entertain the men in uniform and be rewarded with admiration and ice cream treats.

The Army and other Federal agencies have found it so difficult to buy beef in adequate quantities that the WFA yesterday ordered slaughterers to set aside 45 per cent of their kill of steers and heifers beginning tomorrow. [1:1.]

INDICATIONS here are numerous that the latest feminine uniform will be visible soon in many parts of the country. For even as the newly passed Bolton bill was on its way to the executive offices to await the President's signature, after its passage last Tuesday, interested units were active in attempts to expedite the $65,000,000 appropriation which it envisages for establishment of a student-nurse reserve.

PRINCESS ANNE, Md., June 12 (U.P.) -- Rives Matthews, editor of The Somerset News, who is charged with criminal libel because in his weekly newspaper he accused J. Millard Tawes of violating the ban on pleasure driving, denounced today the recommendations for cancellation of a public hearing of the case.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- Navy communique 407:

LONDON, June 12 -- With the Mine Workers Federation taking the lead, the Labor party is expected to vote at its annual convention decisively once again in favor of continuing the electoral truce and thereby supporting the national government for the duration of the war.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- The German Army has been indoctrinating its soldiers with tales of the crushing effectiveness of the Mark VI Tiger tank and, according to many of the prisoners the Russians have been taking in recent weeks, it is with this monster juggernaut that Adolf Hitler plans to destroy the Red Army.

Coming with a tremendous rush in the last furlong, two horses, Devil Diver and Marriage, hammered out a nose finish on the post at Aqueduct yesterday in what many considered the best renewal of the Carter Handicap, which goes back to 1895.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A report written for the Senate Small Business Committee recommended today that old age and survivors insurance be extended to the small business man.

AS an innovation in the almost unbroken procession of newly opened group exhibitions, Karl Nierendorf has ransacked the ages and put together a show which includes ancient Etruscan and Chinese sculpture; French, German and Florentine madonnas of the Renaissance; Chinese scroll paintings; and ends with a calligraphic painting by Kandinsky, a still-life by Hofer and a water-color by the West Coast Chinese artist, Dong Kingman.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., June 12 -- Miss Caroline Katherine Badgley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Durward Badgley of South Orange, was married here this afternoon to Arthur Joseph Clark, Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of West Orange, N.J. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Communion by the rector, the Rev. Eric M. Tasman.

Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, former member of the Board of Education, who was denied reappointment by Mayor La Guardia last month after seven years' service on the board, was the guest of honor last night at a testimonial dinner held at the Hotel Astor under the sponsorship of the members of the Board of Education, the Board of Superintendents and the teaching and supervisory staffs.

CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP) -- The Browns made it three in a row over the slump-ridden Indians with a 7-6 triumph today in an eleven-inning marathon which saw the Tribe's manager Lou Boudreau catch the last two stanzas, with Pitcher Jim Bagby occupying the boss shortstop spot.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 12 (AP) -- The airfield at Reggio Calabria, Italian mainland port just across the narrow Strait of Messina from Sicily, was blasted by British heavy bombers Thursday night, a few hours before the surrender of Pantelleria, the Middle East Air Command disclosed today.

Parading six abreast, 2,400 prospective ensigns of the New York United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University marched in full dress review yesterday morning on South Field as the first event of the commencement exercises for 1,165 members of the twelfth graduating class that will end Wednesday morning when they are commissioned.
WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H. -- The resorts of this section are intent upon upholding the traditions of many years by providing as far as possible the usual facilities for health and recreation.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass. -- Despite the ban on pleasure driving and the rumors arising from Cape Cod's strategic location on the Atlantic Coast, the Cape is preparing this year to offer visitors and vacationists nearly all of the usual services and conveniences to which they have been accustomed.

Possible steps for allocation of essential textile merchandise in limited supply received major attention in retail quarters here last week. Retail executives who have had the highly complicated ramifications of the question under study have apparently come to the view that if equitable allocation is to be undertaken it should be carried out in the raw material and primary production stages.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The National Association of Real Estate Boards charged "attempted deception" to the Office of Price Administration today in connection with an OPA report that net income from rental properties had risen since rent controls went into effect.

Retail shoe sales jumped to a record for the year yesterday as thousands of shoppers crowded into midtown and neighborhood shoe stores to purchase footwear before the expiration of the No. 17 rationing coupon next Tuesday. Reports from various shoe dealers throughout the city indicated that women buyers were in the majority, but all types of shoes were being sold as fast as the clerks could get them off the shelves.

A survey of shipyards holding United States Maritime Commission contracts reveals an average accident frequency rate of 32.5 for the first quarter of this year, a decrease of 5.41 below the national average for 1942, according to figures released last week by the commission.

The people of the Netherlands, ordered by German occupation authorities to surrender their radios in a move to halt the circulation of "foul Allied propaganda," have invented clever devices to cir cumvent the decree, the Netherland newspaper Algemeen Handelsblad said in a dispatch reported yesterday to the Office of War Information.

A HOT breeze blew across Roosevelt Field, beating back the bell-bottom trousers of several women at work. They continued their checking, walking carefully around one of the Navy planes lazing on the wide stretches.

THE NBC Symphony, conducted during the Winter by Arturo Toscanini and Leopold Stokowski and during the Summer by Dr. Frank Black, is scheduled to be sponsored commercially by the General Motors Corporation.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- Numerous articles commenting on the significance and history of Pantelleria and describing the taking of that island were published prominently in today's press. The people of Moscow are discussing the Allied offensive and its prospects with more and more enthusiasm.

Fifty-three visiting professors, fourteen officials of government and private agencies, and educators from forty-six colleges and other institutions will direct work in the extended wartime curriculum at the Columbia University Summer session, Professor Harry Morgan Ayres, director, announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 12 -- More than 10,000 Jews have been killed since last October in the Brest-Litovsk district alone by special German units selected for this gruesome task, according to the Swedish-language Jewish Chronicle published in Stockholm.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- The ability of the nation's principal recreation areas to keep functioning in spite of increasing wartime restrictions is probably nowhere better illustrated than here in the the heart of the Adirondacks. Hotel men, Chamber of Commerce officials and citizens everywhere throughout the region are certain that they will have one of the busiest seasons in years.

DURING the last few decades the Russian people have lived through several abrupt changes. The industrial revolution struck the country at the turn of the century, disrupting the generation-long village economy.
THIS is a revised edition of Mrs. Robbins's book for the beginning gardener which first appeared about a year ago. The twenty-five vegetables dealt with occupy most of the book.

THIS excellent portrait of the people of Ecuador is by a man who, unlike some others who have capitalized on the growing interest in the countries of Latin America by writing a quick book on all of them, has taken the time to absorb something of the spirit of the country which he describes.

The Campbell, Wyant and Cannon Foundry Company had a net profit of $270,328 after a provision of $3,650,000 for Federal taxes on income and a refund resulting from the renegotiation of profits on war contracts in the quarter to March 31.

From the wilds of Ontario comes word that bear are so numerous there at present that they are being shot, treed, and even chased across lakes (when they don't do the chasing) by guides and hunters on the prowl for game.

Charging that once more the Office of Price Administration was seeking to put over long term reforms under the guise of emergency action, installment sellers last week went on record as opposed to parts of a proposal by that agency to regulate the carrying charges on time sales of all items covered by dollars-and-cents ceilings.

A total of 44,235 sports articles was shipped from its Geneva headquarters to war prisoners in Europe during the past year, according to information War Prisoners Aid of the Young Men's Christian Asso ciation has just received from Switzerland.
LONDON, Sunday, June 13 (AP) -- The Russian Saturday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The second quarterly installment payable on Tuesday will mark the end of an income-tax system which, for most taxpayers, was simplicity itself, compared with the system effective July 1 under the Current Tax Payment Act of 1943, which President Roosevelt made law this week.
The following events of the week are of interest to gardeners:

To facilitate handling of renegotiations in the Eastern district, where the Navy Department has been assigned jurisdiction over approximately 1,000 war contracts, a regional price adjustment board has been set up, with offices in the International Building, Radio City.

I was deeply impressed with your editorial "They Too Can Aid," in which a strong plea was made that among those who have succeeded in escaping to our shores there are 2,250 exiles who are a source of intellectual warpower which we have not yet tapped and whose services should be utilized.

May I protest against the report of your Algerian correspondent concerning the population of the French Colonial Empire? Drew Middleton, in THE TIMES of June 5, mentions "the French Empire with a population of 15,000,000."

WITH Victory gardens planted and many crops well along in growth, one of the grower's most serious problems is to keep them well protected from insects and diseases. Diseases, on the whole, are more difficult to combat, especially as by the time they become evident, it is often too late to do much about them.

THE first victim of the expert archer who figures in this book is Mrs. Lorna Russell's chauffeur, Henri. This may have been merely a demonstration shot to show how easily the archer could kill, but Brice Kent thinks otherwise.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted today to the Illinois Iowa Power Company an extension of one year, or until April 14, 1944, to comply with a "death sentence" order directing the company to sever its relationships with five subsidiaries.

MOSCOW, June 12 -- A wave of restlessness, replete with symptoms of things to come, is beginning to make itself felt all along the enormous Russian front as Spring rolls on toward Summer and fine fighting weather descends over the steppes and forest lands.

COLORED SMOKE -- With the Tunisian victory now a matter of history Brig. Gen. Alden H. Waitt tells a story of many-hued smokes that played their part in battle. A simple means of identification by planes of tanks on the ground was wanted after delighted British soldiers saw the Luftwaffe attacking German tanks that were mistaken for British.

MOBILE, June 12 -- A dangerous labor situation which seemed to have been consigned to a conspiracy of silence by government agencies and a great shipyard was exposed this week when Marvin Cox, regional director of the Office of War Information, blew an overdue blast in the direction of the Alabama Dry Dock and Shipbuilding Company.

THE gremlins have arrived full force in America, in as many versions as they (or them, according to Mr. Shapiro) have apostles. They remain, however, unmistakably, indelibly British, not only in manner and speech but in the very nature of their conception.

IT was a lucky day for young Jared Austin, shy and unwanted on his father's bleak New Hampshire hill farm, when he was apprenticed to Mr. Toppan on an April morning in 1810. Mr. Toppan was a journeyman painter, one of those wandering artists of his time who, with paint and stencils, brought life and charm to prim New England walls.

"LETTER FROM NEW GUINEA" is the record of an amazing personal adventure. There will be many such stories before the full tale of the war is told. But it is not likely that any will be marked by a more curious simplicity.

MAX WERNER is one of the few military writers who has been consistent in his thinking and writing on the war since 1939. Beginning with his "Military Strength of the Powers" in that year, through his "Battle for the World" (1941), and his "Great Offensive" (1942), he has not wavered from his early estimate of the strength and weakness of the Axis war machine and program.

The greater need during wartime for the activities of The New York Society for the Suppression of Vice to overcome conditions accompanying the war program both among the military and civilians that "are conducive to laxity in ethical standards, vicious practices and spiritual decay" was emphasized in the sixty-ninth annual report of the society made public yesterday.

BOSTON -- This year in New England the agreeable activities of the Gay Nineties' Summer season are being adapted to the tastes of 1943 visitors. And, as usual, guests will be greeted everywhere with New England's warm hospitality -- in her serene old cities, villages sheltered by wine-glass elms, rocky coasts, sandy beaches, friendly wooded mountains, crystal lakes and streams.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A small group of employes within the Bureau of the Budget has the tough job of trying to make business men like it when the government says "Information, Please"

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Harold L. Ickes as Secretary of the Interior in his role of Coordinator of Fisheries, announced today a program intended to reverse the downward trend of the nation's oyster production, which now is only half as large as fifty years ago.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- Of interest to visitors is an announcement that the Tapping Reeve House on South Street will be open to the public. It is one of the most interesting of the many old houses of Litchfield. Here, in 1777, Lafayette and Rochambeau were guests.

THE music of Mendelssohn has been regaining its reputation in recent years. Actually it never lost its stature; it merely lost favor in some circles. The public in general, however, seems to have remained faithful, blandly ignoring the patronizing theory that Mendelssohn was just an enormously gifted lightweight among composers.

CHESTER, N.Y. -- A busy season is in prospect for this resort in the Ramapo Mountains. The program includes golf, tennis, riding, swimming, fishing, lawn bowling, boating and outdoor picnic luncheons and suppers. Glenmere is a large modern hotel on a 1,600-acre estate.

MRS. FOX, whose lilies and herbs and rare plants are as well known as is the beauty of her gardens, has in this new book turned the light of her knowledge and experience on the problem of the moment -- home food production.

"IT is the holier lot," wrote Hopkins once, "to be unknown than to be known." At the time of his death in 1889 Hopkins as a poet was unknown, and his lot was the holy calling of the Jesuitical priesthood.
REGARDING your arraignment of our new Saturday night program, "The Million Dollar Band" (WEAF-NBC), thanks for leaving the door even slightly ajar in the hope that it may become an acceptable show.

Some of us used to smile when Grandmother called them "pineys," smile in imagined superior knowledge. They were peonies, of course -- huge blossoms that summoned the June bees and colored the whole garden and made sweet the dusk, and finally fell in a profligate showering of petals.

TRANSPLANTING thousands of British women and girls -- milliners, manikins, dressmakers, chorus girls and many others -- into war factories all over Britain created a difficult problem. How were they to become socially adjusted and find amusement in surroundings which were often completely strange?
