WITH this delightful bit of James Ball Naylor's humor, Professor Ralph Barton Perry begins his "Plea for an Age Movement" (reprinted by the Vanguard Press, 75 cents), one of the most whimsical, subtle essays that have appeared in many a year.

LONDON, June 12 -- The Axis lost 137 ships with a total tonnage of 433,400 during the Tunisian campaign, Prime Minister Churchill revealed today. Forty-eight were sunk by airplane attacks, forty-seven by British submarines and forty-two by surface forces.

IT was not so long ago that on the piano of almost every musical family the pink volumes of the Edition Peters were to be found with the "Lyrische Stuecke," "Norwegische Taenze," the songs and the suites of Grieg, who was born on June 15, 1843.

MISCHA ELMAN dropped in to hear a new symphony by the Czech composer, Bohuslav Martinu, last season, as played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under Serge Koussevitzky. He liked what he heard, and he promptly got in touch with the composer to ask whether Mr. Martinu could be persuaded to write a violin concerto.

The most valuable victory of Henry Armstrong's comeback campaign in the ring, the ten-round decision over Sammy Angott in the Garden Friday night, turned out to be a pretty expensive one yesterday when it was learned the veteran would be out of action for eight weeks.
LONDON, June 12 -- Despite warnings from the Minister of War Transport, thousands of Londoners headed to stations today bent on having a Whitsun holiday within the framework of wartime restrictions.

Flag Day tomorrow assumes a deeper significance than ever before, because the national emblem is now a symbol of freedom for all the oppressed peoples of the world, rabbis declared in sermons here yesterday.
Prices sagged, volume ebbed and closing prices yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange were irregularly lower, with the tone dull.

PHILADELPHIA, June 12 -- The Yankees soared to new scoring heights and touched their season's high in slugging at Shibe Park today when they swamped the Athletics for their fifth straight victory. The count was 14 to 5. In swallowing their fourth straight defeat, the Mackmen touched a new low in futility.

CHICAGO, June 12 -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here were steady today, with support including some buying for mill account and some week-end evening-up. Closing quotations were unchanged to 1/8 cent a bushel higher than yesterday.

BRADLEY BEACH, N.J. -- Despite gas rationing, this resort is playing host to an increasing number of vacationists, many of whom are attracted by the excellent railroad and bus transportation between here and New York.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The American Red Cross in the June issue of its magazine, The Courier, today explained the meaning of German and Italian prisoner-of-war camp names used by American prisoners whose letters are now reaching their relatives in this country.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- At the close of the 1940 campaign political statisticians were able to pick up their pencils and show that the change of a few votes in each of a certain number of districts might have thrown the election to Wendell L. Willkie, Republican standard bearer, rather than to Franklin D. Roosevelt.

More than half of them unable to be present because they are already in the armed forces, two thousand students will receive degrees and diplomas at City College's ninety-seventh commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium, 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Wednesday evening.

NEWARK, N.J., June 12 (AP) -- The Maple Leafs maintained a two and a half game lead in the International League race today by earning an even break with the Bears. The Leafs took the opener, 8 -- 7, but Newark came back to take the nightcap, 5 -- 4, in seven frames.
On your editorial page of June 6 you have a letter, "Real Victory Is Seen in an Assurance of Future Peace," by that brilliant thinker, Leonard W. Cronkhite. He writes:

LONDON, June 12 -- Fishermen of Milford Haven, Wales, refused to take their boats to sea today despite the entreaties of the owners and of the officials of the Transport and General Workers' Union, as well as the Ministries of Food and Labor.

An afternoon party, entitled "June Rose Fiesta," will be given on June 22 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to raise funds for the Goddard Neighborhood Center, one of the oldest and best known of New York's settlement houses, which conducts an extensive welfare program for underprivileged families.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- James F. Byrnes, who has been in recent years a member of the House of Representatives, a Senator, an associate justice of the United States Supreme Court, and Economic Stabilization Director, gave every indication this week that he would be, in fact as well as in name, Deputy President of the United States in his capacity of Director of the Office of War Mobilization.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 12 (AP) -- Alertness of a postal clerk was credited by Office of Price Administration officials today for recovery of B and C coupons worth 7,044 gallons of gasoline which they said that a Virginia woman ration board member attempted to send to her salesman-nephew in suburban Pawtucket.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- By a vote of 55 to 22 the Senate late today gave final legislative approval of the compromise strike and labor control bill which came from House and Senate conferees early this week.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- This country will spend $106,000,000,000 for war purposes in 1943, an increase of 80 per cent over 1942, Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, has reported to President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Aside from the war itself, the country's most absorbing topic today probably is food. The country as a whole is going through its first experience with food shortages and food rationing. For the first time, housewives have been standing in line for fruits and vegetables and in many instances they have carried away empty baskets.

FROM the Jungles of the Pacific and the sands of North Africa stretch lines of mercy that cross oceans and end here at home. Litter-bearers, mobile hospitals, base hospitals, general hospitals at home, hospital ships, planes that are flying hospitals -- the lines are on the ground, in the air, on the sea.

THE reason why the United States for almost fifty years has had no fixed foreign policy on which its people were united, the consequences of that condition and the means of future cure -- these are the subjects of Mr. Lippmann's valuable and clear contribution to a debate of paramount importance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 (AP) -- James A. Farley, former Postmaster General, speaking tonight under the auspices of Cambridge Lodge, No. 839, Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, said that excuse-making had no place in wartime and called on men and women in all walks of life "to shoulder loyally the sacrifices which are called for."
Despite a sharp falling off in published reports of discovery and development, scientific effort has reached a new peak, declares Industrial and Engineering Chemistry.

The owners of some 4,000 craft, which include liners, tankers, freighters, fishing boats, tugs, barges, yachts and harbor vessels are unitedly opposing the enactment of H.R. 2731, a bill designed to speed up payment for requisitioned vessels and unravel a snarl in governmental red tape, but which is preventing the owners from realizing, at present, more than 75 per cent of the moneys due them.

COSMETICS, too, have gone to war, following their users to the battlefronts of victory. They appear in the most unlikely places, they wear the most serious garb -- but they're still, thank heaven, as pleasantly feminine as before.
LONDON, June 12 (U.P.) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Several good arguments commend the Lea-Bailey bill, now under consideration by a committee of the House of Representatives. Most important, perhaps, is its concentration and control of civilian flying in Federal hands under an independent authority. In addition, the bill recognizes the need of developing air transportation and provides means for doing so.

The Vatican radio, in a broadcast recorded yesterday by the Office of War Information, called on German parents to protect their children "from the dangers threatenhag their faith" and from false slogans flourishing during a period "that knows no better than to despise and persecute everything supernatural and all the true values."

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- A loss of 10,105,000 tons in coal production in the week ended on June 5 compared with the preceding week was reported today by the Department of Interior to have resulted from the coal mine work stoppage as the United Mine Workers and the Central Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association continued in a deadlock in negotiations on the most hopeful sector of the coal controversy.

Federal authorities in Washington moved promptly yesterday to arrest the loss of huge quantities of new potatoes shipped here from the South without refrigeration in accordance with a recent order by the Interstate Commerce Commission with the approval of the Office of Defense Transportation.

In a telegram to James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, Thomas A. Murray, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, speaking for 1,500,000 organized workers, yesterday assailed the Office of Defense Transportation for displaying a "definite anti-labor policy" and for demonstrating a "cruel and callous disregard for labor's rights."
Curtailment of child welfare programs was condemned yesterday by the Rev. Fred Robert Tiffany in his morning sermon at the Richmond Hill Baptist Church, 114th Street and Ninety-first Avenue, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- United States fliers scored a 25-6 victory yesterday (Solomons time) in the second great air battle of the Russell Islands area of the Solomons within five days, the Navy announced today. Of forty or fifty Japanese fighters intercepted by Marine Corps and Army fighters, twenty-five Zeros were shot down and eight more were tallied as "probables."

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 -- Assurance of the final triumph of the Allies was the keynote of messages sent today by Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to President Roosevelt, Prime Minister Winston Churchill and Premier Joseph Stalin on the eve of United Nations Day, the United States Flag Day that was adopted last year for world-wide observance by countries opposed to the Axis.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- War's grip on the American household will tighten even more, the Office of War Information said tonight in announcing that hundreds more items used in homes would be "simplified" in 1943 by elimination of frills and style variation.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The Navy has revealed one of America's secret weapons. Our warships can go farther and hit harder because they consume up to 35 per cent less fuel than the ships of any other navy in the world.

Shopping activity reminiscent of a Christmas holiday rush marred yesterday the usual Sunday calm of the lower East Side as perspiring merchants and salesmen hurriedly fitted customers who had held their No. 17 shoe ration coupons until the last minute and were out to beat tomorrow's deadline. Coupon No. 18 becomes valid on Wednesday, continuing through Oct. 31.

LONDON, June 13 -- The "Sergeant Cohen" who in less than twenty-four hours has become something of a legendary figure here for his "capture" of Lampedusa turned out tonight to be a former tailor's cutter who lived with his sister, Mrs. Lily Collins, in the Clapton East section of London.
LONDON, Monday, June 14 (U.P.) -- A special Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

HANOVER, N.H., June 13 (AP) -- Gunder Haegg, Swedish super-runner who broke seven world records last year, tonight decided to make his American track debut in the National A.A.U.'s championship 5,000-meter event in New York next Sunday. Haegg authorized Axel Nordquist, A.A.U. representative in his small training party, to telegraph his entry.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 13 -- America's blessings have been given to this nation as a trust for the whole world, the Right Rev. Dr. Henry St. George Tucker, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, said today in the baccalaureate sermon preached for the University of Virginia's graduation.

LONDON, June 13 -- Strict control in the wholesale handling of food has given Great Britain her outstanding success on the home front in this war and provided a model for other nations to study. Two major factors have made the success possible -the willingness of the people to abide by the rationing program and the willingness of the government to spend 145 mill lion pounds sterling annually to subsidize farmers and importers.

On a brief furlough from the naval training station where he is serving, Lieutenant Donald B. Aldrich of the Chaplains Corps returned yesterday for the first time in six months to the pulpit of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street, of which he is the rector, to warn his congregation not to feel that God was on our side "just because we are winning the war."

The Children's Aid Society launched its Children's Aid Week today with a special report marking its ninetieth anniversary. The purpose of the drive is to call attention to the wartime needs of New York City's children and to promote public interest.
NEW DELHI, India, June 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 14 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Pier and rowboat fishing are being emphasized more and more in the dispatches received from resorts along our coast. Remember the days when tuna tournaments were gaining international attention and arguments ensued about the potentialities of Nova Scotia and New Jersey big game angling?

BOSTON, June 13 (AP) -- After watching four of his battery mates get a 16-5 pounding from the Senators, Tex Hughson hurled a four-hitter against them today to give the Red Sox a 7-0 shut-out in the nightcap, which was held up for more than an hour by weather.
JERSEY CITY, June 13 (AP) -- Buffalo dropped Jersey City deeper into the International League cellar by defeating the Little Giants in both ends of a dauble-header today, 4 to 3 and 3 to 0.

NEWARK, N.J., June 13 (AP) -- Toronto maintained a lead of two and one-half games in the International League today, earning an even break with the second-place Bears by winning the seven-inning nightcap, 5 to 1, after losing the opener, 6 to 0.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Until dollars-and-cents prices for a list of additional constructions of fine cotton goods are supplied, producers of these fabrics may continue to use the old ceiling prices, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations may not participate in War Labor Board decisions until the board's duties under the Connally-Smith bill are clarified, it was reported today.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Last week brought an accentuation of the discouraging features in the corn trade. There was a further dwindling of country marketings, receipts here being extremely small with a correspondingly light movement at primary points. The demand for corn is urgent, but sales are small because of the light stocks now available.

In your editorial, issue of June 8, entitled "Coal Wages: The Test Case," appears this statement: "For a month the Administration kept the dispute out of the hands of the War Labor Board. The question was then passed around like a red-hot poker from Miss Perkins to Dr. Steelman, to the President, to the War Labor Board, to Secretary Iekes, back to the board, back to the President, and so on."

The corn refining industry, producer of starches, syrups, sugars and other derivatives of American corn, widely used in industry and for food purposes, is in imminent danger of having to shut down its dozen large plants in the Middle West within the next thirty days, the Corn Industries Research Foundation warned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, June 13 -- In as odd a double-header as the fans had witnessed all season, the Pirates won the opener today, 10 to 3, then held the world champion Cardinals to a twelve-inning 4-to-4 tie in the nightcap, called on account of darkness.

" So Little Time" is the title of the new John P. Marquand novel to be published this autumn by Little, Brown. His longest novel, with more than 600 pages, its scene is New York, Connecticut, Washington and Hollywood. It is the story of an aviator in the first World War who by 1940 had became a prosperous writer and of his relations with his 19-year-old son, a student at Harvard.

W.W. Kettleberger, whose income has actually decreased, like that of millions of other people, wonders where our inflationary gap lies in hiding. The answer is simple. There are millions of war workers and government employes whose income either has gone up anywhere from 100 to 500 per cent or has come into being where it did not exist before.

War news of last week was favorable, culminating in the surrender on Friday of Italy's island fortress of Pantelleria and the lesser Island of Lampedusa. Coming as these victories did in sequel to the defeat of the coal strike, the week's developments were of a character to help financial markets -- even though the government crop report of Thursday was quite as unfavorable as had been expected.

Hot breads of the coffee-cake variety provide desserts that are in keeping with the restrictions of fat rationing. The Swedish tea ring pictured here, for example, serves eight persons and calls for only about a quarter-cup of shortening.

After the temperature reached its peak of 87 degrees late yesterday afternoon, scattered showers brought brief relief to the city's millions who had suffered from the uncomfortable combination of high temperature and high humidity.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- The War Department announced today the names of 247 United States soldiers wounded in action in North Africa, including the following with next of kin in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut:

CLEVELAND, June 13 (AP) -- Battling on the brink of the American League cellar, the Indians rallied in the tenth inning to take the nightcap of today's double-header against the Browns, 2 to 1, after losing the opening, 3 to 1, at Municipal Stadium before 13,116 fans.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
Yesterday's Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The United Press:

AT A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION IN ENGLAND, June 13 (AP) -- After crash-landing their burning, shell-riddled Flying Fortress in the English Channel, nine United States airmen won a race with death by outswimming spreading gasoline flames on the water, it was disclosed today.

Henry J. Kaiser disclosed yesterday that he had decided to establish his own personal offices in this city, from which he will supervise his vast array of interests. He said he had taken part of the third floor of the British Empire Building in Rockefeller Center for this purpose and was assembling a staff for it. His home offices have been in Oakland, Calif.

America today celebrates its customary Flag Day. But this year the day far surpasses its customary significance. First, because, in the words of President Roosevelt's proclamation, the Stars and Stripes have become a battle emblem which flies not only over its native land but also over more than 2,000,000 embattled Americans throughout the world, who have made it "a mark of hope to our Allies and of despair to our enemies."

CHICAGO, June 13 (AP) -- After downing the Cubs, 10 to 6, on a 20-hit attack in the first game of a double-header today before 28, 557, the Reds could get only seven blows from big Bill Lee and lost the afterpiece, 4 to 1.
LONDON, June 13 (AP) -- An Eighth United States Air Force communique:

MERIDEN, Conn., June 13 (AP) -- James A. Farley said today that the "obligation" of all the Allies to prevent aggression in the post-war world should allay the fears of those persons who suspect "the ultimate aims of our Russian ally."

WASHINGTON, June 13 (U.P.) -- The new flag of the four freedoms symbolic of the United Nations, flew side by side with the Stars and Stripes for the first time today at American Legion ceremonies commemorating "Old Glory's" anniversary tomorrow.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

High on top of a Fifth Avenue building sits a pink and blue penthouse. It has cloud blue walls, on which are painted pink curtains billowing in an imaginary breeze, and matching pink armchairs with petal pink footstools. Its purpose, however, is uncompromisingly practical.

RYE, N.Y., June 13 -- Champion Flornell Rare Bit of Twin Ponds, sound and solemn Welsh terrier, today won his twentieth best-in-show victory when he was placed at the top of nearly 800 contestants in the eleventh annual show of the Longshore Kennel Club. The event was held on the polo field of the Westchester Country Club.

Regardless of what happens on the Russian front or elsewhere in Europe, for weeks to come the attention of military and political leaders in London and Washington will be focused on Italy. The task of knocking Italy out of the war, which means administering the first decisive defeat to an Axis country, devolves on Great Britain and the United States.

Concerned at the failure of President Roosevelt to mention the Italian monarch in his message, in which he suggested to the Italian people that they get rid of Premier Benito Mussolini and his personal Fascist regime, anti-Fascist leaders urged him yesterday to remedy that "oversight."

LONDON, Monday, June 14 -- Two large formations of American Flying Fortress bombers shot down many German fighters and battered the U-boat bases at Bremen and Kiel yesterday in the greatest air battle ever waged by the United States Eighth Air Force.

MOSCOW, June 13 -- All Soviet organizations -- and this includes practically every farm, factory and apartment house in the land -- were ordered today to demonstrate United Nations solidarity and to honor Britain, the United States and other Allied nations by flying the Red Flag tomorrow.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (U.P.) -- Miss Ann Curtis, San Francisco swimmer, and Miss Sue Zimmerman, champion of the Multnomah Athletic Club of Portland, Ore., today set two new American women's swimming records in the Far Western meet. Multnomah scored 33 points to take the title.

" The Army Play-by-Play" will have its only presentation tonight at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre. This is said to be the only Broadway dramatic presentation ever written, acted, directed and designed by soldiers. The bill consists of five prize-winners from the soldiers' one-act playwriting contest sponsored by the Second Service Command of the United States Army and John Golden.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 13 -- Almost smothering along in a local smoky southwester, the Long Island Sound sailing fleet had fine going today in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club championship series regatta.

VERN HAUGLAND works for the Associated Press. He grew up on a ranch in Montana, where he excelled at driving a team, a skill that was of little use when he served as an AP reporter among the Mormons of Salt Lake City and among the fabulous movie luminaries of Hollywood. In Hollywood he used to be identified as the man who looked as if "he'd just arrived from Iowa."

Of all musical instruments the mandolin is perhaps the most harmless. Yet to play the mandolin in the open air in Italy has been made an offense punishable by three months of imprisonment. A dispatch brought in from Berne by The Associated Press told of this state of things.
Prince and Princess Alexandre de Caraman-Chimay have left the Pierre for Tranquillity Farms, their place in Allamuchy, N.J.

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (AP) -- Chinese troops stormed through streets strewn with Japanese corpses Friday to capture the Yangtze port of Sungtze, down river from the advanced enemy base at Ichang, the Chinese High Command said tonight in a communique.

The Citizens Budget Commission urged Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick to make an upward revision to the extent of $4,000,000 in his official estimate to the City Council of the city's share of State taxes, declaring in a letter made public yesterday that the move was justified on the basis of the tax trend.

LONDON, June 13 -- Britain's Whitsunday was a study in contrasts today. Some resort areas were crowded with travelers to an extent at least thinly suggesting pre-war days. Others, notably the east coast, had a quiet time, even compared with recent wartime but non-holiday week-ends.
Only three new films are scheduled, as of now, to open in Broadway theatres during the week. The order of arrival follows:

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -- Predictions that the newly-organized Republican post-war advisory committee will be able to agree on a basic declaration of the party's foreign policy came today from senatorial members representing varying shades of opinion on international questions.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia announced on the radio yesterday three new State-financed housing projects for New York City to be constructed after the war at a total cost of $24,627,000 and drew an immediate rebuke from Acting State Housing Commissioner Ira S. Robbins. 149th Street, Concord Avenue, 145th Street and St. Mary's Park. This project will consist of six-story buildings containing 1,040 apartments capable of housing 4,000 persons. It will cost $5,700,000.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 13 -- Sir Gerald Campbell, British Minister and Special Assistant to Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador, and Lieut. Col. Ian Ferguson McAlpin of the Black Watch, commanding officer of No. 6 Commando in Tunisia, will address the annual meeting of the Oyster Bay Committee of the British War Relief Society on Tuesday night in the Parish Hall of Christ Episcopal Church.

Police promotions and graduation exercises will take place in conjunction with the annual presentation of medals to heroes of the Police and Fire Departments, in City Hall Plaza at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning. The presentation of awards will be made by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in the presence of Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., June 13 -- Mattapan, the home of John W. Davis on Overlook Road in Lattingtown, was damaged extensively by a fire started by a bolt of lightning this evening.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (U.P.) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, said tonight that sentiment in the Senate is five to one against the general use of subsidies to finance price "roll-backs" as projected by the government.

Just when it was beginning to look as if the Giants had forgotten how to win a ball game, they stepped out at the Polo Grounds yesterday and, with Carl Hubbell holding the Phillies to seven hits, scored a 6-2 decision. There was power in the New York bats, which produced sixteen hits, including three home runs.

LONDON, Monday, June 14 -- Russian bombers pounded at key points in the bulging Orel sector of the German line over the week-end, attacking big enemy train concentrations and ammunition dumps, a special communique said today. The regular midnight bulletin reported 498 German planes had been destroyed in the past week, making a total of 3,319 planes reported destroyed in the past six weeks.

LONDON, June 13 -- Strengthening the foundations for offensive operations, the Air Ministry has created a tactical air force for all the home-based Royal Air Force, a step of far-reaching importance in the organization of the British war machine, initiated by Prime Minister Churchill some months ago.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, appealed yesterday to President Roosevelt to veto the Connally-Smith bill, which forbids strikes in government-operated plants and places other restrictions on the economic and political activities of labor unions.
Two programs appropriate to the holiday will be conducted by Morton Gould at the Stadium concerts on the July 4 week-end. Saturday night, July 3, an all-American list will be presented.

Like thin files of Colonial flintlocks bristling from the redouts of Breed's Hill, a formidable if slightly unmilitary assortment of firearms in the hands of members of the First Brigade of the New York Guard yesterday saved the city from an "air-borne, enemy attack."
WASHINGTON, June 13 (U.P.) -- Navy communique 409:

A comprehensive plan for reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric system, which has been in bankruptcy since January, 1940, was announced yesterday by the trustees in reorganization of the Associated Gas and Electric Company and the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, top holding companies of the $1,000,000,000 utilities empire once dominated by H.C. Hopson.

The steps in Army training that transform a civilian into a soldier were presented yesterday afternoon by men of the 909th Engineer Air Force Headquarters Company of the First Air Force at the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue, as part of the Treasury Department Saturday Evening Post Four Freedoms War Bond Show.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 14 (U.P.) -- Flying Fortress and Liberator bombers dropped thirty tons of bombs on Vunakanau airdrome at Rabaul Sunday in their third big raid in four days against the Japanese base, where reconnaissance disclosed the enemy had concentrated 271 aircraft.

Heinrich Himmler, chief of all German police organizations, has dispatched his right-hand man. Dr. Ernst Kaltenbrunner, to take over the direction of Rumanian police forces because of the unrest within Rumania, the British Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 112.3. The only major commodity index to change was the raw materials index, which dropped 0.2 per cent as a result of decreases in cotton, apples and hogs, which were only partially offset by increases in oranges and wheat.

LONDON, June 13 -- Describing the United States war effort in a speech today at a meeting of the British Legion, the organization of veterans of the last war, Ambassador John G. Winant said that more than two million American fighting men had been sent to the fighting zones overseas in eighteen months.

The compromise anti-strike bill adopted by Congress is a hastily put together hodge-podge. It is an illustration of what happens when a legislative body which has given no basic thought to balanced labor legislation for peacetime or for wartime acts suddenly in response to a particular crisis.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, Monday, June 14 (Reuter) -- The Allied Commander in Chief, General Dwight D. Eisenhower, issued a message today to troops on the occasion of United Nations Day.
Capt. Leighton Wood, Navy ordnance and gunnery expert, has been killed in action, it was announced yesterday. An Annapolis graduate of the class of '14, Captain Wood was 51 years old.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 13 -- Never ahead until they captured the second extra hole to cap a brilliant uphill fight for a 1-up decision, Dr. Joseph Kenrick of Hempstead and Harold Weeks of the Rockville C.C. triumphed today in the annual Hempstead Golf Club member-guest best-ball tourney.

THE Army eleven had crushed Notre Dame, 27 to 0, back in 1925. It was more of a defeat than the score would indicate. The hard-hitting cadets had given the Irish a thorough physical beating as well, smashing off the tackles, thundering through the middle and whipsawing the ends and backers-up.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- The steel industry last week showed the effects of the recent coal strike with a further drop in ingot production. This loss was due primarily to the forced banking of eleven blast furnaces in the Pittsburgh district. The last of these units resumed operations about the middle of last week.

In anticipation of further delivery tie-ups in the Fall, many of the ready-to-wear manufacturers sought to alleviate the situation by further simplification of their lines, according to a summary of last week's market activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

The twenty-first annual service of the Trinity Choir Alumni Association was held yesterday afternoon in Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street. Former members of the choir sang with the present choir.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Unless the "smart boys" of the New Deal change their ways, the civilian population will go without commercially canned fruits and vegetables next year, Representative Gerald W. Landis of Indiana, chairman of the subcommittee on fresh and processed fruits and vegetables of the Republican Congressional Food Study Committee, said today.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 13 -- A brighter outlook in the campaign against malaria in combat zones of the Southwest Pacific is reflected in a statement issued today by the Allied Headquarters spokesman.

Two powerful blows by Dixie Walker and Billy Herman near the end of a long afternoon at Ebbets Field yesterday were barely enough to give the Dodgers an even break in the double-header with the Braves before a crowd of 26,737. Brooklyn dropped the opener, 4 -- 3, and won the nightcap, 3 -- 2.
The 315th anniversary of the first church service in French held in what was then New Amsterdam was celebrated yesterday at the French Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit, 109 East Sixtieth Street.

CHICAGO, June 13 -- Prices for hogs in the livestock markets here reached last week the lowest level in several months, working down to a top of $14 a hundredweight early in the week, with receipts on Monday of 43,000 head, the largest number for any day in many weeks.

The Church Pension Fund of the Protestant Episcopal Church, in its twenty-fifth annual report made public yesterday by Bishop Cameron H. Davis, president of the fund, disclosed that at the end of 1942 it had total assets of $36,271,297 and an annual pension roll of $1,404,925.

Apropos the extensive radio and newspaper appeal for kitchen waste fats for conversion into vitally necessary glycerine, our family, reared in the country in the days of the woodash leach and soap caldron, has never wasted fats -- always converted them into kitchen or laundry soap. We now have approximately a dozen pounds on hand and don't need soap, but are not able to carry that weight to the butcher.
LONDON, June 13 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 13 -- Individual German civilians have now reached the point where they cannot stand the sight of one another, if the official German organ, Voelkischer Beobachter, is to be believed.

NEW ORLEANS, June 13 -- Uncertainties over policies on price ceilings, wages and subsidies accounted for further hesitation of cotton futures last week on the Cotton Exchange here when all options traded within a range of less than $1 a bale.

As Mayor La Guardia warned citizens of New York City that the food shortage may become critical in a few days and announced a new move to curb black market selling, representatives of 5,000 retail kosher poultry shops in the city voted last night to close next Saturday and to stay closed "unless the city, State and Federal authorities" intervene to halt illegal sales.

CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (AP) -- A "sincere demand" that Russia declare war against Japan and open a second front in Asia was made today in a special article in a Chungking newspaper by Chow Lu, member of China's supreme ruling body, the Standing Committee of the Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang.

HOLLYWOOD, June 13 -- Universal has announced plans for an emended budget musical to be produced this Fall as a Charles K. Feldman Group production under the title, "Three Cheers for the Boys." The picture, with a background of Army camp shows, is expected to follow the pattern of "Stage Door Canteen" and features stars of screen, stage and radio who have taken part in service men's entertainment. It will be directed by Eddie Sutherland.
The text of Pope Pius XII's address, as received in Washington by cable and distributed by The United Press:

LONDON, June 13 -- Although relieved by the safe return of Prime Minister Winston Churchill, whose periodical visits abroad engender nervousness concerning his personal safety, the markets remain inactive and barely steady. As one commentator said, there is a pre-invasion, pre-holiday zone which certainly is not good for business.

Flag Day, commemorating the 166th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes by Congress, will be observed in New York today, with the added incentive of paying tribute to the men and women of our armed forces on war duty throughout the world.

PHILADELPHIA, June 13 -- That five-game winning streak of the Yankees was snapped today in Shibe Park before 32,117 fans, the largest gathering to see the Athletics in action this year. Being a team that does nothing by half measures, the McCarthymen nose-dived to a double defeat.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, has disclosed a new and increasing danger to the war effort -- juvenile pranks and practical jokes which virtually amount to sabotage.

The silver jubilee of the ordination of Mgr. William R. McCann and his tenth anniversary as pastor of the St. Charles Borromeo and St. Aloysius Gonzaga parishes in Harlem were celebrated yesterday afternoon by a parade of 3,300 persons, followed by a testimonial meeting in the Golden Gate Ballroom, Lenox Avenue and 142d Street, attended by 4,000.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 13 (U.P.) -- Sgt. Sidney Cohen, 22 years old, of London, told an amazing story tonight of how he had made a forced landing on Lampedusa yesterday just in time to receive the bomb-blasted Italian island's surrender between raids.

If the call for "unconditional surrender" should be supplemented by a statement of what the United States stands for in the way of international justice and order, peace would be hastened perhaps by months, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Church Methodist at Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

The turn-back-the-clock trend in municipal transit which began last November when trolley cars were hauled from storage to replace buses on the Putnam Avenue line in Brooklyn may soon spread out, Mayor La Guardia warned yesterday, saying, "It looks now as if we'll have to sacrifice some bus service and go back to the old, dilapidated, noisy, rattling trolley cars."

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Due to delays, which most high fiscal officials of the government attribute to interdepartmental rivalry, Congress would have to pass a bill producing around $30,000,000,000 additional revenue on an annual basis in order to raise the $16,000, 000,000 more which President Roosevelt has asked for the fiscal year starting July 1.

FORT RILEY, Kan., June 10 (Delayed) -- The role of horsed cavalry in modern war has been emphasized by the Russian Army, and here in this old Army post which once stood in the heart of the Indian country the horse is still king.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 13 (AP) -- Faced with the most serious emergency in its twenty-eight-year life, the Pacific Coast Conference will meet tomorrow in an effort to adjust the 1943 college football schedule to war tempo.

With America's wheat harvest only two weeks away, much of the country's half-billion bushel 1943 wheat crop probably will be piled on the ground during the harvest rush because of a grain car shortage, officials of the Santa Fe Railway predicted yesterday.
LONDON, June 13 -- The Fleetwood fishermen's strike over the new lower maximum price for hake, a cod-like delicacy, appeared to have ended today.

From the Netherlands Information Bureau came the story yesterday of how the townswomen in tropical Surinam are prepared to defend their freedom in a corps patterned after the American Waacs. Wearing dark green uniforms combining features of American and British women's auxiliaries, 150 women of all ages have enlisted in the unit, calling themselves the Women's Auxiliary Corps.
The Athletics broke a four-game losing streak in the opener.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- An investigation in both the Senate and House of a Navy contract with the Standard Oil Company of California for the tapping of oil in Naval Oil Reserve No. 1, the Elk Hills reserve in California, seemed likely tonight.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 13 -- Addressing an audience of 25,000 workers from all parts of Italy, more particularly from the north, in the closing ceremonies attendant on his thirtieth year of episcopacy, Pope Pius XII today condemned revolution as an instrument of policy for labor and protested the "calumnious" assertions of some quarters that the Vatican had desired the war.

OSWEGO, N.Y., June 13 -- The people of Oswego put the United Nations on a home-town basis today. With prayer, pageantry and solemn resolve, they opened their churches, schools, factories and homes to visitors from many lands in a community-organized effort to get to know their country's Allies as they would new neighbors down the street.
LONDON, June 13 (U.P) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
CHUNGKING, China, June 13 (U.P.) -- A communique:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 13 -- American bombers blasted three important Sicilian airfields yesterday, wrecking a large number of almost 150 planes on the ground, as the Northwest African Air Forces, the conquerors of Pantelleria and Lampedusa, trained their bombsights on tougher targets.

DETROIT, June 13 (AP) -- The Tigers seized sole possession of the American League's third place today by taking both ends of a double-header from the White Sox, 6 to 4 and 3 to 2, before 28,197 spectators, second largest 1943 crowd at Briggs Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 5 to June 12 are given in the appended tabulation:

BERNE, Switzerland, June 13 -- France is suffering from a shortage of bread, but she must not know it -- officially. Those unable to obtain their "insufficient" daily ration must suffer in silence. Should they become too articulate, Pierre Laval's police are there, ready for action.

ALGIERS, June 13 -- A note of harsh common sense was introduced into the French political disputes today. Twenty-six Communist former Deputies, released from prison by Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud in March, issued a manifesto that was sharply critical of the delays in translating the "solemn promises" of the French Committee of National Liberation into deeds.

Price movements in the cotton futures market last week were very slight under reduced volume reflecting traders' wariness over unsettled political and legislative issues. Only the spot month, July, on the New York Cotton Exchange registered a gain for the period, other positions closing with net losses of 2 to 5 points.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 13 (AP) -- Italy lost her third island outpost in the central Mediterranean in three days when a British destroyer accepted the bloodless surrender of Linosa today.

The dome of an elaborate shrine on which a poor man lavished all his savings and the leisure time of seven years was stolen Saturday night as he was preparing to take it to the Leo House at 332 West Twenty-third Street for exhibition.

Individuals and nations alike are challenged today to forego selfish interests and plunge into a positive program of progress based on religious living, the Rav. Karl M. Chworowsky declared in a sermon yesterday morning in the Flatbush Unitarian Church at Beverly Road and East Nineteenth Street, Brooklyn.

A hundred years ago private charity was almost an unheard-of thing in this country. In most instances town and city officials administered the charity which poor laws of the day provided and which included little individual care or protection for children.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 15 (U.P.) -- The Russian Monday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

ONE of the phenomenal developments of this extraordinary baseball year has been the startling transformation of the once futile Phillies to a state far removed from futility. For a while they even were perched in that unfamiliar and unnatural resting place, the first division.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (U.P.) -- A forty-foot Army "crash boat," manned by six daring men who sailed their tiny craft far into the choppy South Atlantic, rescued the entire seventy-one-man crew of an American merchant ship torpedoed and sunk in early May, the War Department disclosed today.

Still driving onward in their counter-offensive, the Chinese announce the recapture of the important port of Sungtze on the Yangtze River. This city is down river from Ichang, the Japanese advance base from which the thrust was launched, and its recapture, together with additional Chinese successes north and south of the Yangtze, may enable the Chinese to isolate Ichang itself.

John Scheer, 18 years old, a former Staten Island high school student, alternately sneered and grinned as testimony was given against him yesterday at his General Sessions trial in the Central Park, hold-up murder of Herman Holtz, 34, a clerk, of 114 West Sixty-first Street in the early morning of last Dec. 27.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 14 (U.P.) -- Lampione, the last of the Axis outpost islands, fell to Allied naval forces yesterday.

The unprecedented shoe-buying spree that began on Friday and grew over the week-end found many retail stores in the city closing shop for varying periods yesterday afternoon and refusing to make sales. This provided breathing spells for gasping salesmen as holders of shoe ration coupon 17 descended in droves on the shops.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 14 -- Mrs. Margaret B. Clyde Kniley, 72 years old, of Ventnor, N.J., today petitioned the Chancery Court here to declare her mentally competent to handle her own affairs. Hiram Steelman, an attorney here, was appointed special master to take testimony on the petition.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Buffalo made it three in a row in its five-game series with Jersey City by defeating the Little Giants in a twilight game tonight, 8 to 7.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- In a reversal of the Gobitis decision of June, 1940, the Supreme Court held by 6 to 3 today that under the Bill of Rights public school children could not be compelled to salute the American flag if this ceremony conflicted with their religious beliefs.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 14 -- If and when the Allies land in France, chaos will be let loose. The military problem, therefore, will be complicated by the necessity of policing the country as fighting progresses, and such policing will be needed far behind the lines.

Charging that gasoline has become "a political football" in Congress while the shortage in the Eastern seaboard States has disrupted transportation, Sol A. Herzog, counsel for the Eastern States Gasoline Dealers Association, said yesterday that a special meeting of consumer and industry representatives would be held within a week to press for an immediate and thorough investigation of the situation.

A TOWN IN ENGLAND, June 14 -- Walk down the broad central thoroughfare here during the day and there will be moments when you forget there is a war going on. The gardens are particularly beautiful, and a sense of urgency seems lacking as people stroll beneath the great trees and children dart about and chatter.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, June 14 (AP) -- A deliberate attempt by a Japanese Zero pilot to cut a parachuting marine flier to pieces with his propeller was reported by Allied South Pacific headquarters today.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- American proposals for a new Lend-Lease protocol designed to increase substantially the shipments of munitions, food and other essential war materials to Soviet Russia have been handed to the Russian Government, it was learned tonight.

With the pleasure driver under a measure of control, the attention of the Office of Price Administration turned yesterday to the pleasure-boater. From the United States Coast Guard the OPA received the names of thirty persons charged with running boats from rowboats to yachts with gasoline engines, for pleasure, according to Edward L. Coffey, chief district OPA attorney.

More than 1,000,000,000 rounds of ammunition have been delivered to the armed forces by the Chrysler Corporation in less than a year and a half, according to a letter addressed to stockholders yesterday by K.T. Keller, president.

A Silver Star, two Distinguished Flying Crosses (one British) and twenty-three Purple Hearts were awarded yesterday afternoon to wounded officers and enlisted men at the Halloran General Hospital on Staten Island. The ceremonies, held on the lawn in front of the headquarters building, were attended by high-ranking officers of the hospital, patients and invited guests.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Labor Department is making post-war plans for domestic rehabilitation and reconstruction elsewhere in the world. Secretary Perkins, in testimony made public today by the House Appropriations Committee, said the work was being done by the Division of Labor Statistics.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 14 -- An official communiqu issued by the Foreign Ministry announced tonight that the decree prohibiting the use of secret codes in international wireless communications has been temporarily suspended, but will return into force again at midday on Wednesday.

A protest by the Phillies that the Cardinals had been negligent in not covering their playing field when weather interrupted a game at St. Louis on June 5 was sustained yesterday by President Ford Frick of the National League and the contest ordered completed, The Associated Press reported.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 14 -- The Allied conquest of Pantelleria was a striking victory for air power, demonstrating its mobility, the ease with which its striking power can be concentrated and the psychological effect of continuous heavy bombing on the garrison and inhabitants of the target area.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, June 14 -- Flag Day of the United Nations was celebrated throughout Brazil today, with the principal ceremony taking place in this city, bedecked with flags of the Allies.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Fathers in the armed forces serving overseas now may get, via V-mail, photographs of their offspring under 1 year old or born since they left.

WITH THE UNITED STATES SOUTH PACIFIC FLEET, June 6 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- When a United States battleship met a Japanese battleship for the first time last Nov. 14-15 off the Solomon Islands, it was the skill and coolness of the American commander that made the American victory possible.

With two out in the fifth, the bases empty and the Dodgers ahead, 3 -- 1. Dixie Walker and Augie Galan let a fly ball drop between them and, though it did not appear too damaging at the time, this gift triple by Eddie Joost helped the Braves to a 4 -- 3 victory in a twilight encounter finished in semi-darkness at Ebbets Field yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Liquidation of the National Youth Administration by next January was recommended by the House Appropriations Committee today by a vote of 17 to 16, in approving a $1,086,562,499 bill for operation of the Labor Department, the Federal Security Agency and related independent offices in the fiscal year 1944.

The Trade Union Council of the American Labor party, representing American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations unions in this city with a membership of 500,000, sent a telegram yesterday urging President Roosevelt to veto the Connally-Smith bill.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- Members of four associations of coal operators employing approximately 225,000 miners in Pennsylvania and West Virginia at meetings today agreed to waive the $1 a day fines imposed on participants in the June 1 strike.

The Japanese Domei agency, in an English-language code transmission reported early today by the Office of War Information, said that at least two main islands in the Japanese Archipelago were shaken by an earthquake on Sunday, but claimed that "no damages were reported."

WASHINGTON, June 14 (U.P.) -- The Army's high rate of rejection of men for mental and nervous reasons -- nearly 23 per cent of the total rejections -- makes the selective service director, Maj. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, wonder whether "maybe we are all unfit for modern war."

Representatives of the Laundry Workers Joint Board, an affiliate of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, a member union of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, and officials of eight employer associations of the laundry industry conferred yesterday at the union's office, 15 Union Square, on wage increase demands affecting 25,000 laundry workers in New York, Westchester and Long Island.

Declaring that the "present labyrinth of laws, regulations, agencies and bureaus is such that the average citizen is completely bewildered" Henry H. Heimann, executive manager on leave of the National Association of Credit Men, yesterday urged a return to simpler forms in legislative enactments.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision enjoining a local of the Retail Shoe Salesmen's Union from picketing a New York shoe store with placards saying it was unfair to the labor organization.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 -- The Kaiser Company, Inc., was enjoined permanently today by Federal Judge A. F. St. Sure from violating priorities regulations of the War Production Board in obtaining materials for its Richmond Shipyard 3.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Yankees got help from an unexpected quarter at Griffith Stadium today when they opened a four-game series with the second-place Senators. Ossie Bluege's boys did a pretty good job of defeating themselves and the American League pace-setters increased their margin to three games. The Yanks won by 4 to 1.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, June 15 (AP) -- The noon communique:

PANTELLERIA, June 12 (Delayed) -- Premier Mussolini personally ordered the surrender of Pantelleria in response to a report from the island that the Allied bombing was no longer endurable, it was disclosed last night at the signing of the armistice.

CLEVELAND, June 14 (AP) -- The City Council defeated tonight a resolution declaring the city's intent to purchase the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company. The measure was turned down by a 19-to-13 vote.

TEANECK, N.J., June 14 -- Mrs. Joseph J. Boyle of 539 Standish Avenue revealed today that she received a rare present on her birthday, Saturday. It was a telegram from the War Department informing her that her son, Lieut. Joseph B. Boyle, the "cocktail kid" pilot of the famous Flying Fortress "Dry Martini" who had been earlier reported lost in action, is safe in a prison camp.

Alfred Robertson won the dash to the first turn in yesterday's feature at Aqueduct and made a front race of it over the mile and a furlong of the Faireno Handicap, to bring the Brookmeade Stable's Pomayya home in front. A crowd of 16,763 came out to start the meeting off on its second week and bet a total of $1,300,837 through the machines on the eight races.

CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) -- Hog prices advanced 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds today on a steady demand. The top was up 15 cents to $14.35. Cattle trade was slower and prices around 50 cents lower, while lambs were generally 50 to 75 cents off.

LONDON, June 14 -- After some surplus fish had bee dumped into the Firth of Forth on Saturday because of Ministry of Food zoning regulations, one fisherman, Joe Croan of Newhaven and Ayr, "illegally" sent 6,000 pounds to Manchester on the ground that "this isn't the time for waste of any description."

Following recent charges that the Central Procuring Agency of the Army Engineer Corps was discriminating against most lumber dealers by buying only from mills and from specially designated stockpile yards, it was learned yesterday that these designations would be withdrawn in the East on July 10.

A special meeting of stockholders of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation has been called for July 6 to consider and act upon the exercise of an option to purchase from the Chase National Bank the controlling interest in the National Theatres Corporation for $13,000,000.

As New York City's wholesale meat markets were virtually emptied by the rollback of wholesale prices yesterday the New York City League of Women Voters urged Mayor La Guardia to create a City Food Administrator.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 14 -- The Anglo-American air attacks on western and northwestern Germany from Friday through yesterday, in the proportions of a great offensive, have caused mass evacuations from the bombed cities and towns, according to reports reaching here from Berlin today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 -- Twentieth Century-Fox have bought for $50,000 an original story, "Where Do We Go From Here," from Morrie Ryskind and Sig Herzig. It will be utilized as basis for a musical to be produced by William Perlberg.

PITTSBURGH, June 14 -- A new unit in the nation's wartime steel expansion program began production today at the Homestead works of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, where additional steel making and finishing facilities are being erected for the government's Defense Plant Corporation.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 15 (U.P.) -- Russian troops are attacking in three areas of the Eastern Front and a big scale Red Army offensive is expected soon, Germany reported today.

Maxwell Ross, former Kings County under-sheriff, was suspended from practicing law for five years by a ruling yesterday of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn. Ross, who is 46 years old and lives at 1486 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, for nearly a decade was the Democratic leader of the Twenty-third Assembly District in Brownsville.
CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (AP) -- A communique:

Emphasis on its post-war type of distribution, a trend which has been developing in recent months, is one of the features of the new trade and consumer advertising campaign which Sonora Radio and Television Corporation is breaking, according to an announcement yesterday by the company.

The American Library Association's most recent booklist, published as a supplement to its regular monthly bullein, is devoted to the United Nations. Books and pamphlets are listed with a short critique of each title. The list was prepared by the staff of the Public Library of the District of Columbia and forms part of the association's national emergency book lists.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (U.P.) -- The story of how an American destroyer led a devastating torpedo attack by three warships of this class on four Japanese cruisers in the Aleutians and played the major role in thwarting the enemy's attempt to reinforce Attu and Kiska was disclosed today by the Twelfth Naval District.

Mayor Fiorella H. La Guardia was no conflict between himself during a Sunday radio broadcast of the sites selected by the city for three proposed post-war housing projects, estimated to cost about $24,627,000. He declared also there was not conflict between himself and Ira S. Robbins, Acting State Housing Commissioner, in this connection.

Programs planned to help women cope intelligently with their current culinary difficulties were started yesterday by three department stores. At Frederick Loeser's in Brooklyn a "cooking school," so styled by the management, was opened under the aegis of Mrs. Ruth Carman.

Under a Rome date line a German Transocean Agency broadcast reveals that the production and sale of radio sets have been prohibited in Italy. It is not necessary to look far to find the reason. Mussolini becomes more and more eager to stop the ears of the Italian people as the war comes closer to their shores.
MOSCOW, June 14 -- The Red Army had at the start of this war, and still possesses, the most powerful cavalry force on earth.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today that cotton consumed during May totaled 901,608 bales of lint and 98,790 bales of linters, compared with 957,864 of lint and 131,931 of linters in May last year.

Seven members of the twelfth class of the New York United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University at a party yesterday afternoon in the New York Yacht Club, 37 West Forty-fourth Street, received swords for achievement.

NEWARK, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Fred Schmidt, making his first start of the season for Rochester after nine relief appearances, defeated Frank Hiller in a tense pitching battle to give the Red Wings a 2-to-1 victory over the Newark Bears in a twilight battle tonight.
LONDON, June 14 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Brushing aside warnings that it might be accused by the nation of making "a patronage grab" in the midst of war, the Senate, by a vote of 42 to 29, passed and sent to the House today the McKellar bill to require Presidential appointment or reappointment of an estimated 30,000 government officials and employes, and their confirmation by the Senate.

The outstanding awards for children's books -- the Newbery Medal for the best story book and the Caldecott Medal for the best picture book published in 1942 -- were presented last night at a dinner at the Hotel Roosevelt given by the Children's Library Association of the American Library Association.

A concert to commemorate the centennial of the birth of Edvard Grieg, Norwegian composer, will be presented at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8:30. Ole Windingstad will conduct members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, and with Karin Branzell, contralto, and Storm Bull, pianist, as soloists in an all-Grieg program.
The new autumn millinery silhouette as Hattie Carnegie sees it was established yesterday morning at a press showing. It is easy to wear and to look at; moreover, it has plenty of verve.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The use of substitutes for living necessities in the American household was credited today by the Office of War Information as one of the principal reasons why the household continues to function efficiently and pleasurably in the face of increasing demands on the country's war materials.

The International Petroleum Company, Ltd., Canada, reported yesterday in its statement for 1942, net earnings of $13,611,825 in United States currency, after all deductions, including $7,378,904 for depreciation, depletion and amortization and for the proportion applicable to minority interests.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Navy communique 410:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 14 -- Supreme Court Referee J. Addison Young reserved decision today on the applications of Lieut. Commdr. William Harrison (Jack) Dempsey, former heavyweight champion, for a divorce and Mrs. Hannah Williams Dempsey for a separation after Lieutenant Commander Dempsey had testified as the final witness in the trial that began a fortnight ago.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Nazis, through plunder "and the severest economic pressure and political terror" have seized every important industrial enterprise in the occupied countries of Europe and transformed Europe's economy "into an enormous industrial empire," the Office of War Information stated today in its latest report on German domination.

Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, warned bus operators yesterday that it was illegal for them to discontinue any of their routes without prior authorization from the commission. He indicated also that the commission, a State agency, would review curtailments in service made to comply with gasoline conservation orders of the Office of Defense Transportation.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Here is the vote by which the Senate passed the McKellar bill requiring confirmation of most Federal employes making more than $4,500 a year:

" The Eve of St. Mark," Maxwell Anderson's war play, will end its New York run at the Cort Theatre on June 26 -- the same date on which the Playwrights Company's other production, "The Patriots," is to leave Broadway. Opening Oct. 7 of last year, "The Eve of St. Mark" will have given 306 performances at the time of its closing.

The June 15 turnover in the money market, which really covers not only today but the balance of the week and longer, will be much larger than usual. This is due to the fact that the Treasury has called for redemption today $454,000,000 of 3 3/8 per cent bonds and $629,000,000 of 1 1/8 per cent notes.
CAIRO, June 14 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

With registrations for camps outside the city already completed, the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York announced plans yesterday for the operation of seven Summer day camps in city parks. At these centers, two of which are new this year, 2,500 girls, members and non-members, will practice camping crafts.

For the first time in six years the world championship of the Star Class of sloops will be held here in the East. Announcement was made yesterday by the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association that the title event will be held on Great South Bay off Bay Shore Aug. 24-29.

Ninety-eight graduates and students of City College will receive medals, scholarships, honors and prizes tomorrow evening at the school's ninety-seventh commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry Noble Wright, president.

The Laclede Gas Light Company, a subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation, announced yesterday amendments to its plan of recapitalization now pending before the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Missouri Public Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (U.P.) -- Signals flashed from the Hawaiian shore by a German spy four days before Japan's sneak attack on Pearl Harbor helped prepare the Japanese for that heavy blow against the United States Fleet, the Office of War Information revealed today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (U.P.) -- Melio Bettina, former light-heavyweight champion, returned to the boxing ring tonight with a freak one-round technical knockout over Lou Brooks, Wilmington Del., Negro, before 7,500 fans at the Arena.

In order to continue efficient handling of important administrative work, the Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office declared yesterday that it urgently needed typists who can volunteer daytime hours.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 15 (U.P.) -- Royal Air Force planes, tapering off from a thundering three-day Allied offensive in which Nazi Europe was rocked by a record weight of some 5,500 tons of bombs, hammered Germany's industrial Rhineland, sank or damaged six ships and scattered mines in enemy waters Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The Supreme Court has often justified Mr. Dooley's statement that it follows the election returns. It still does. Also, justices have managed frequently to find law to cover legislation carrying out their own and their group political philosophies when other justices have said no law exists.

LONDON, June 14 -- By the overwhelming vote of 2,243,000 to 374,000 the British Labor party reaffirmed today its determination to adhere to the electoral truce and to support the national intraparty, or coalition, government in war production.

HARRISON, N.Y., June 14 -- The license numbers of 400 automobiles parked over the weekend at a dog show on the grounds here of the Westchester Country Club were recorded by police and will be forwarded to gasoline-rationing officials in home communities of the motorists, Police Chief Charles W. Conner of Harrison said today.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 14 -- A 16-year-old Garden City High School sophomore, George Stuhr Jr., annexed the honors in the weekly one-day Long Island P.G.A. amateur-pro best-ball golf tournament over the Salisbury No. 4 course today.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 14 -- Airdromes at Gerbini and Catania, in eastern Sicily, were attacked yesterday by heavy bombers of the United States Army Air Forces, it was announced by the Middle East Air Command today.

If Hallock Wells Dean of Tampa, Fla, the national Father's Day Committee's choice for "typical war-worker father for 1943," were virtually "typical," Uncle Sam could take his troubled eyes off the home front and turn all his attention to the fighting.

President Roosevelt gave yesterday his most significant recognition to the leadership of Michael J. Kennedy Jr. as leader of Tammany Hall as he sent to the Senate for confirmation as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York the name of James B.M. McNally, personal friend of Mr. Kennedy and chairman of Tammany Hall's law committee.

ST. LOUIS, June 14 -- The Cooper brothers, Morton and Walker, put on a show today that led to a 5-to-3 victory for the world champion Cardinals over the Reds. In addition, Harry Walker hit safely for the twenty-first consecutive game.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 14 -- A parade marked by full military pomp, in Which the colors of thirty-four nations arrayed against the Axis were massed together, took place here this morning.

" Some (too many) of us have been reluctant, even hostile, toward accepting this responsibility [of reforming medical care] which is so eagerly desired by certain non-medical groups," said Brig. Gen. Fred W. Rankin in his address as retiring president of the American Medical Association.

Field Marshal Jan Christiaan Smuts, Prime Minister of South Africa, said yesterday that Africa's freedom from aggression "is the gift of the United Nations to us, and that gift is a call to us to fight with all our might by their side until all of them enjoy the same freedom from aggression as ourselves.

Your delightful editorial "That Man Sterne" prompts me to cite a quotation from "Tristram Shandy," which, although it was written a hundred and eighty years ago, expresses with clarity and vigor a suitable set of principles for the United Nations of our day.

Complete stoppage of the twenty-five bus lines operating on Staten Island was ordered at 9:30 o'clock last night by Harold Gibb, president of Local 726, Amalgamated Association of Street Electric Railway and Motor Coach Employes, affiliate of the AFL.

LAST autumn, well in advance of the German collapse in the pocket at Stalingrad, Max Werner called the turn in the Russo-Nazi war. Either Mr. Werner carries a rabbit's foot in every pocket and a four-leaf clover in his coat lapel or he is blessed with a keener analytical ability than most of our military commentators. I have heard supposedly well-qualified experts say that Mr. Werner gets correct results by making errors which cancel out.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- An American submarine, battling a Japanese undersea craft on the surface, sent the enemy to the bottom, the Navy disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 14 -- Economic controls set up ostensibly to further the war effort were described tonight by Gov. Edward Martin in a Flag Day speech at Independence Square as the New Deal's springboard for a "new order" to be foisted upon the nation in the coming days of peace.

SYOSSET, L.I., June 14 -- Flanked by the bodies of her two pet dogs, an Airedale and a boxer, her inseparable companions, Mrs. Dorothy Ridenour Day, wife of Henry Mason Day, New York broker, was found dead at 2:20 this afternoon in the garage of her estate on Berry Hill Road, by an employe of the family.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The appearance of a new and as yet unidentified disease, with a high mortality rate but apparently not widespread, was disclosed today by release of testimony before a House committee by Public Health Service physicians.

Yetta Weisbrod's little room was cool and filled with the fresh scent of the dewy garden when the nurse brought her breakfast at 7:30 A.M. yesterday at the Home and Hospital of the Daughters of Jacob.

LONDON, June 14 -- The Whitsun rush in reverse complicated life for thousands of British men, women and children tonight. During the day there was a lull before the storm at the main terminals, while on all roads to Ascot a record number of bicycles took fans to the track for the one-day meeting.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- Dr. Bernard F. Haley of the Office of Price Administration told a Congressional committee today that OPA has "the authority to set standards where such is necessary to control prices."

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Organized labor today began a week of concentrated fire on the Connally-Smith bill, seeking its veto by President Roosevelt. The Chief Executive received the measure from the Senate today and has ten working days, until June 25, to sign or veto it or to allow it to become law without his signature.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The drafting of fathers may be delayed a couple of months, it was indicated today, as Selective Service took steps to speed up the induction of childless men now deferred because of their occupations.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Additional votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 5 to 12 are given in the appended tabulation:

SANDS POINT, L.I., June 14 -- The Chimneys, estate of the late Mrs. Christian R. Holmes, has been lent by the Holmes Foundation as a recreation center for French sailors on leave in this area, it was made known today.

Commission-house liquidation, attributed variously to the favorable war news, coupled with continued uncertainty over the ultimate action to be taken by the Government on wages and prices, and general weakness in grains and securities, depressed cotton prices moderately yesterday, in spite of persistent price-fixing and covering in the spot delivery in the futures market.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The occupational deferment of childless men, 18 to 25 years old, in all but exceptional cases is limited to six months, and men with children are for the first time to be included on replacement schedules, under revised instructions issued today to all State headquarters and local boards by the Bureau of Selective Service of the War Manpower Commission.

In his budget message last January the President asked for the expenditure of the tremendous total of $104,000,000,000 for the fiscal year 1944, which will begin on July 1. "I believe," he said, "that we should strive to collect not less than $16,000,000,000 of additional funds by taxation, savings, or both, during the fiscal year 1944."

Directors of the Bankers Trust Company voted yesterday to transfer $25,000,000 from undivided profits to surplus, increasing the latter to $75,000,000. Capital remains unchanged at $25,000,000. The directors also voted to transfer $7,000,000 from general reserve to undivided profits.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, June 15 (AP) -- Delayed reports in today's communique told of a single Liberator, on Sunday reconnaissance over Humboldt Bay in Dutch New Guinea, discovering a 4,000-ton Japanese freighter -- a transport -- and setting it afire with two direct hits with 500-pound bombs.

The entire receipts from the world premerie of Paramount's screen version of the Ernest Hemingway novel, "For Whom the Bell Tolls," which will take place at the Rivoli Theatre on July 14, will go to the National War Fund, it was announced yesterday.

The impressive three-dimensional exhibit in Radio City presents ideas -- hideous ones -- with the realism of a dramatic demonstration. Citations from the perversive doctrines that rule in Germany and Japan bring the tale to those who stroll as they read; while raucous voices recorded in regimented Germany convince the ears.

ALBANY, June 14 -- A war-diet luncheon, dominated by the humble soy bean, was served to sixty-seven guests in the State dining room of the Executive Mansion today in an effort to convince New York's housewives that palatable and nutritious substitutes for the dwindling meat supply are available.

First Lieut. Harold J. Tannenbaum, United States Army Eighth Air Force Film Unit, who as a newsreel sound technician risked his life on an ice floe, in a tropical hurricane and in many other ways, and was a veteran of the first World War, was killed in action on April 16 in the European theatre, his wife, Mrs. Adelaide Tannenbaum of Binghamton, N.Y., announced here yesterday.
AT A REHABILITATION CENTER, Somewhere in England, June 14 -- A new link between hospitalization and the return to active duty for United States soldiers has been established here.
WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 560 United States soldiers held prisoners of war: 264 by Japan, 291 by Germany and five by Italy.

Full discussion of the plan for vast expansion of the so-called Social Security system, including its effect on hospitals, is so urgently needed that I was glad to see in your columns the other day the letter of Herman A. Gray, director of the American Association for Social Security.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) -- The general death rate in the United States last year dropped to the lowest level ever recorded.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 14 -- Headquarters in New Rochelle and North Pelham of an alleged interstate abortion ring were raided today by police and members of the staff of the Westchester County District Attorney and Sheriff. Twelve women seized in the raids were brought tonight to the prosecutor's office here and two were taken to Grasslands Hospital at Eastview.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 8, the Federal Reserve Board announced yesterday. Decreases of $290,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills and $950,000,000 in United States Government deposits, and an increase of $675,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted.

Tomorrow evening a 43-year-old Norwegian-born barge skipper for the New York Central Railroad will step out of his role as a river man long enough to put on academic cap and gown and receive a Bachelor of Science degree in psychology at City College's graduation exercises in Lewisohn Stadium.
LONDON, June 14 -- The story of the United Nations parade from Wellington Barracks to the Mall today was not so much in the marchers as in the spectators.

The New York Curb Exchange has been advised that in view of the continuance of an injunction issued by the Federal Court, Southern District of New York, it will not be possible for the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad Company to pay on July 1 the quarterly rental of 1 per cent on the capital stock of the Lackawanna Railroad Company of New Jersey unless the injunction is vacated prior to that date.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- The War Food Administration moved today to add more than 15,000,000 acres to food and feed crops next year as part of the effort to meet a situation which, a Congressional delegation warned the President, marches steadily toward the crisis stage.

John R. Longo, foe of Mayor Frank Hague, was arrested yesterday in Post-Graduate Hospital soon after he had been declared a fugitive for failure to appear for trial in Quarter Sessions Court, Jersey City, on an indictment charging him with altering his voting records.
