TRENTON, June 14 -- Nominated on March 29 by Governor Charles Edison to succeed Dr. Charles H. Elliott as State Commissioner of Education, Dr. John W. Studebaker asked today that his name by withdrawn from the Senate, where the appointment is bottled up in the Judiciary Committee.

To the strains of Sousa's "Hands Across the Sea," played by a twenty-five-piece brass band, the Salvation Army opened yesterday its fifth Red Shield Club in Manhattan. The club, occupying a five-story building at 12 West Fifty-sixth Street, will be able to serve 1,000 men of the armed forces daily, it was said.

The 166th anniversary of the adoption by Congress of the United States Flag was celebrated here yesterday in a series of programs dedicated not only to the Stars and Stripes, but to the United Nations as well.

We return to our favorite arithmetical diversions. This time it is again percentages and ratios. They are dangerous masters but very useful servants. They can shake our faith in human nature, and they can bolster our affection for the human race.

ALGIERS, June 14 -- A formula for the solution of the problem of army reorganization, which has caused a deadlock in the French Committee of National Liberation, has been presented to Gen. Charles de Gaulle by the "moderates" of the committee.

CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (AP) -- American airmen dealt fresh blows to Japanese strongholds in Northern Kiangsi Province yesterday in support of Chinese ground forces whose high command reported new gains today.

TRENTON, June 14 -- Nominated on March 29 by Governor Charles Edison to succeed Dr. Charles H. Elliott as State Commissioner of Education, Dr. John W. Studebaker asked today that his name by withdrawn from the Senate, where the appointment is bottled up in the Judiciary Committee.

To the strains of Sousa's "Hands Across the Sea," played by a twenty-five-piece brass band, the Salvation Army opened yesterday its fifth Red Shield Club in Manhattan. The club, occupying a five-story building at 12 West Fifty-sixth Street, will be able to serve 1,000 men of the armed forces daily, it was said.

The 166th anniversary of the adoption by Congress of the United States Flag was celebrated here yesterday in a series of programs dedicated not only to the Stars and Stripes, but to the United Nations as well.

We return to our favorite arithmetical diversions. This time it is again percentages and ratios. They are dangerous masters but very useful servants. They can shake our faith in human nature, and they can bolster our affection for the human race.

ALGIERS, June 14 -- A formula for the solution of the problem of army reorganization, which has caused a deadlock in the French Committee of National Liberation, has been presented to Gen. Charles de Gaulle by the "moderates" of the committee.

CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (AP) -- American airmen dealt fresh blows to Japanese strongholds in Northern Kiangsi Province yesterday in support of Chinese ground forces whose high command reported new gains today.
CHUNGKING, China, June 14 (U.P.) -- A Fourteenth United States Air Force communique:

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 14 (AP) -- Francisco Segura, South American star who swings a racket with both hands, won two matches easily today in the opening singles round of the five-day Eastern Intercollegiate tennis tournament at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Eugene R. Black, vice president of the Chase National Bank, will act as director of the Banking and Investment Division of the War Finance Committee for New York State, it was announced yesterday by W. Randolph Burgess, State chairman, who is vice chairman of the National City Bank.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- Bipartisan legislative leader urged President Roosevelt today to appoint a food "czar" and reportedly received in return a proposal that Congress provide from $1,500,000,000 to $2,000,000,000 to subsidize a rollback in prices to consumers.
It will be legal to take that scrappy member of the fresh-water tomorrow, when black-bass family fishing opens in certain parts of New York State.

WASHINGTON, June 14 -- United States submarines, attacking enemy communications lines in the waters of the Pacific and Far East, have sent twelve more Japanese vessels, including a destroyer, to the bottom, and have damaged four others, a Navy Department communique stated late today.

A heavy demand from war workers, dwindling inventories and a supply situation that threatens to become rapidly worse are currently putting the jewelry retailer in the position of selling himself out of business, according to the consensus of speakers yesterday at the war conference of the National Wholesale Jewelers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 14 -- Foreign Minister Segundo Estorni revealed today that the Holy See had been the first sufferer from last Thursday's decree prohibiting the use of secret codes in wireless messages to and from Argentina.

QUONSET, R.I., June 14 (AP) -- A pilot was critically burned and three men who were standing near by suffered minor injuries today when a plane on a routine flight crashed at the naval air station here, causing the detonation of both a bomb it carried and of a pile of explosives stored near by.

Without a word of how they fared, two more American submarines, the Amberjack and the Grampus, have reached the Port of Missing Ships. We know that brave men took them there. Both commanders wore the Navy Cross for extraordinary heroism. Both crews had made their record of enemy craft destroyed.

CHICAGO, June 14 -- The wheat market was under the shadow of the new crop movement to some extent today, with some hedging being apparent, while reports from some points in the Southwest indicated that a fair percentage of current receipts was being sold.

Acting State Housing Commissioner Ira S. Robbins indicates that Mayor La Guardia jumped the gun on Sunday when he announced three State-financed post-war housing projects: one adjoining St. Mary's Park in the Bronx; one on the East River in Astoria; and one -- the Governor Smith Houses -- down in the colorful old South Street neighborhood where Alfred E. Smith grew up.

DETROIT, June 14 (AP) -- Seymour Greenberg of Chicago, displaying his usual steadiness despite limited preparation, opened defense of his national clay courts tennis championship today by disposing of lanky Robert Kimbrell of Los Angeles in straight sets.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 (AP) -- Bulgaria, anxious to win to the pro-Axis side her traditionally pro-Russian peasant population, today undertook creation of a new twenty-man commission instructed to get the people behind the Axis war machine.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- Outfielders Ron Northey and Coaker Triplett slugged the Phillies to a two-way victory over the Braves -- 6 to 4 and 2 to 1 -- before a ladies' day crowd of 6,679 today in the first swing-shift doubleheader in the major leagues.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The President's announced opposition today to putting all units of the food program -- prices, distribution, subsidies and farm labor as well as production -- in the hands of one administrator has not dispelled hope that continued pressure in favor of that move will combine with events to effect it.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Dr. Bernard F. Haley, chief of the Office of Price Administration's textile, leather and apparel division, told a House committee today the latest rayon hosiery regulation was prepared in haste and might be altered after further research.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15 (AP) -- The Newark Bears gained ground in their drive for first place tonight by taking two overtime decisions from Rochester. They won the opener in eight innings, 1 to 0, then bagged the nightcap in ten, 3 to 2.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 15 -- Judge Thomas H. Brown in Common Pleas Court, here, took under advisement today several legal and procedural questions in the case of John R. Longo, political foe of Mayor Frank Hague, who is under technical arrest at the New York Post Graduate Hospital as a fugitive from justice.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia announced yesterday afternoon the appointment of an advisory committee from the local meat industry to seek a solution of the meat shortage and to fight the black markets.

" Coney Island," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical in Technicolor, will open this morning at the Roxy. Heading the film's cast are Betty Grable, George Montgomery and Cesar Romero, with Charles Winninger, Phil Silvers, Andrew Tombes, Matt McHugh, Carmen D'Antonio and Paul Hurst among the featured players.

Under a golden moon, in the band shell on the Mall in Central Park last night, the Grasshopper Four sang their way to top place in the Manhattan eliminations in the American Ballad and Barber Shop Quartet contest.

The stock market staged yesterday a very thin recovery, one of only fractional proportions, and then only after the list had been subjected to a fresh assault at the opening of trading. The upturn was by no means general and merely dented the break sustained by values on Monday.

The first Aviation Cadet button award in the Second Service Command was presented yesterday to Roy Andersen, 17-year-old student of the Manhattan High School of Aviation Trades, at a special student assembly in the auditorium of the Julia Richmond High School, Sixty-seventh Street and Second Avenue.

At 99 Park Avenue stands a comfortable old brownstone mansion owned by the city. Probably no other spot in the world has brought so much pleasure to our men and women in national service. It is the headquarters of the New York City Defense Recreation Committee.
TORONTO, June 15 (AP) -- About 10,000 war industry workers were on strike in Ontario and Quebec today, seeking higher wages or union recognition.
The eighty-second extraordinary session of the Japanese Diet opened yesterday to "effect a readjustment" of Japan's industrial resources for a "successful conclusion" of the war.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that the corporation law of Delaware permits the elimination of accumulated dividends on the preferred stock of a corporation through merger with a wholly owned subsidiary.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, June 16 (AP) -- The noon communique:

RYE, N.Y., June 15 -- The speedboat Miss Playland stopped operating today from its pier at Westchester County's amusement park here after the Coast Guard had reported the craft as a violator of gasoline rationing and the Office of Price Administration had ordered it off the water.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The eight officers and ninety-four men aboard the United States submarine Argonaut "accepted destruction rather than surrender."

Full Cry and Ariel Lad took the feature races yesterday at Aqueduct, where the form players among the 17,029 spectators were surprised by the one and pleased that the other should sustain their judgment. Full Cry, erstwhile sprinter, shocked those who had thought he would be no match in a mile and a sixteenth test for such as Corydon and Trierarch.

New York will wait a while longer for its first afternoon boxing show in almost twenty years. Late yesterday Mike Jacobs, promoter of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, announced that the non-title match between Private Johnny Greco of the Canadian Army and Bob Montgomery, lightweight champion, originally planned for Saturday afternoon, June 26, had been moved forward to Friday night, June 25, at the Yankee Stadium.

While the large producers in the oil industry feel generally that the Petroleum Administration for War is doing a good job, it is the consensus among them that centralized control over fuel oil and gasoline under one agency would tend to eliminate much of the present confusion, an executive of one of the major companies said yesterday.

Popular priced dress manufacturers and contractors of New York last night rallied at the Hotel Astor in support of their $100,000 War Relief Fund drive and contributed over $50,000 in the initial effort. The event was a joint campaign dinner and testimonial to Nat Boriskin, president and executive director of the United Popular Dress Manufacturers Association, for his achievements in the war effort and his loyalty to the dress industry.

CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell, commander of United States forces in China, India and Burma, returned from the Washington strategy conferences today with a declaration that the United Nations were determined to crush Japan as soon as possible.

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., June 15 -- Every infantryman in the Army is receiving special training which will make him both a potential Ranger and an assault engineer, with special emphasis on man-to-man combat and the handling of such devices as flame- throwers and high explosive charges.
CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (AP) -- A communique:

Closer coordination of the activities of the War Production Board and the Board of Economic Warfare to insure the availability of essential civilian supplies for Latin-American countries was urged by exporters yesterday at the monthly forum of the Latin-American section of the New York Board of Trade at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 15 -- Heavily laden Wellingtons of the Royal Air Force pounded Messina, an important Sicilian shipping and ferrying port on the Strait of Messina, on Sunday night.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Yankees sent seven runs cascading over the plate tonight in one inning of a game delayed fifty-five minutes by weather and buried the Senators, 9 to 5, at Griffith Stadium to widen their lead in the American League flag race to four games.

LONDON, June 15 (U.P.) -- Reports from Yugoslavia disclosed tonight that Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's Chetnik guerrillas and the Russian-supported Partisans had effected a reconciliation since the dissolution of the Comintern and were fighting side by side against German occupation forces.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., June 15 (AP) -- The Pacific Movement of the Eastern World, sponsored by Japanese and General Lee Butler and David D. Erwin, Negroes, were found guilty today of conspiracy to violate the Wartime Sedition Act and the selective service law.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, June 15 -- Up to now all sourdoughs when they got into print have automatically been labeled "old sourdoughs." The two words simply went together, like "green peas." But sourdoughs can be young and pretty and vivacious, especially since the United States Army hacked its way through the Yukon, and to prove it there is Miss Brooksie Boyd and Miss Harryette Petersen.

With both ordinary and group insurance making substantial increases, the writing of new life insurance in May was 25.1 per cent more than for May, 1942, according to the report by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents to the United States Department of Commerce.

SPARTANBURG, S.C., June 15 -- By unanimous actions the State executive committee of the Democratic party for South Carolina has refused a request of the National Democratic Committee for financial and moral support of the 1944 national campaign.

HOBOKEN, N.J., June 15 -- The "Wits," women war workers trained in the government-sponsored War Industries Training Schools of Stevens Institute, here, must have exactly that -- wits -- to do their jobs.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The President saw a group of House members seeking centralization of authority over food; also Arthur Bliss Lane, Ambassador to Colombia; Senator Josiah W. Bailey of North Carolina; Representatives of the Negro Council of Churches, and the press, and signed the Bolton Bill.

LONDON, June 15 -- The largest American Red Cross club in London -- the fourteenth in the city and the sixty-third in the Eastern theatre of operations -- will open Thursday and go into full swing Sunday with a Father's Day program expected to pit real babies against the pictures of babies.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 -- Resistance in France to departure for Germany for forced labor has reached the armed stage, according to reports from Vichy tonight. Details are lacking, but the police version alleges that the recalcitrants were "vagabond Communists and other criminals."

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Arriving here after a ten-day vacation in Michigan, Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown declined today to discuss the probable fate of Lou R. Maxon, in charge of public relations for the Office of Price Administration and reported destined to become general manager of the agency.

After studying all of the plans introduced in both branches of Congress on the subject of the post-war foreign policy of the United States, the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives decided yesterday in favor of a one-sentence resolution offered by a freshman Representative from Arkansas, Mr. Fulbright. The resolution says:

Berdette Liljehult has come up in the world. Arriving at Hunter College yesterday as an apprentice seaman, the diminutive blue-eyed blonde from Portsmouth, N.H., who stretched herself half an inch to meet the Navy five-foot requirement, grinned cheerfully.

MADRID, June 15 (U.P.) -- Reports from Vichy said today that the Allied bombardments of Sicilian and Sardinian airfields had resulted in considerable destruction of aircraft aground and in combat and the gradual withdrawal of Axis air forces to airdromes on the Italian mainland.

An investment banking group here is reported reliably to be discussing the prospect of purchasing 304,600 shares of capital stock of the New York Central Railroad Company from the Delaware Hudson Company, but the transaction is not expected until after the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court has given its approval to the D. H.'s plan of debt readjustment.
HANOVER, N.H., June 15 -- Gunder Haegg, the Swedish racing sensation, today insisted upon carrying out his daily training routine despite a painful four-inch gash on his right knee.

Despite warnings of a developing food crisis throughout the nation, New York City received yesterday additional carloads of new potatoes from the South that had rotted in transit. The shipments had been made without refrigeration in accordance with a recent order of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

MOSCOW, June 15 -- While in many armies world-famous cavalry units with long and honorable traditions have been mechanized during this war and have abandoned horses, the contrary is true of the Red Army, which has maintained the cavalry as one of its most important arms, especially in Winter.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The same government agency that is directing wartime production should also be responsible for price control, Lew Hahn, managing director of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, declared here today at the opening of the three-day wartime conference of the Controllers Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Labor won a long fight today when two of its nominees were appointed vice chairmen of the War Production Board.

Two thousand young men and women will receive degrees and diplomas tonight at City College's ninety-seventh commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Only half of them, however, will be present; the others already are in the armed forces.

Visiting buyers registered in the New York market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,536, which compared with 1,726 in the preceding week and 810 in the like period a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., June 15 (U.P.) -- Ruth L. Ruxton won a final degree of divorce in Circuit Court here today from her husband, William V.C. Ruxton, New York financier and head of the British-American Ambulance Corps.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- American submarines, already responsible for the destruction of and damage to 256 enemy ships, will henceforth cause even greater havoc, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said at a press conference today.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, June 15 (U.P.) -- President Pedro P. Ramirez declared tonight in a prepared statement that "the military revolution has not come to perpetuate itself, but to clean and restore."

This department is naturally pleased to find some recent observations on an important point in Soviet history backed up, as we see it, by a very eminent authority on Russia and a good friend of the Soviet regime.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Representative J. Hardin Peterson, Democrat, of Florida, said today that the House Public Lands Committee would make a thorough investigation of the Navy's deal with the Standard Oil Company of California by which the company received the right to drill in the Elk Hills Naval Oil Reserve.

An action for criminal libel brought by Victor F. Ridder, publisher, and editor of The New Yorker Staats-Zeitung, against Rex Stout of the Writers War Board, Dr. F.W. Foerster and T.H. Tetens was adjourned yesterday until Sept. 13 by Magistrate Robert F. Mahoney.

Reserve officers have made possible the "rapidly expanding Navy," Captain John K. Richards, U.S.N., retired, commander of the New York United States Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University, told the twelfth graduating class in a farewell address yesterday afternoon at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (U.P.) -- The Navy today published the names of 316 more Navy and Marine Corps personnel known to be held prisoners of war by the Japanese. Most of them are interned in the Philippines.
Long Island Sound fishermen report fair runs of weakfish and blackfish as well as striped bass. The bass have been taken along the Connecticut shore from Milford to Greenwich.

Fifteen hundred packages of needles, threads and notions were collected at the "Needle and Thread" party given yesterday afternoon in Town Hall by Bessie Beatty, WOR's foreign correspondent, for the benefit of the Workroom Committee of the Russian War Relief, Inc.

After admitting that he testified falsely last week, Dr. Charles L. Engelsher, whose aides included several ex-convicts, told the Moreland inquiry into compensation cases yesterday he had paid out $19,000 in 1942 to cover debts to gangsters incurred by his brother who had been executive director of the doctor's Parkchester General Hospital in the Bronx.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- "State Fair," the Phil Strong novel of the agricultural Middle West, which was a starring vehicle for the late Will Rogers in 1933, will be remade by Twentieth Century-Fox as a musical. Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, who collaborated on the stage production "Oklahoma!", will write the music and lyrics.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The Delmarva Electric Cooperative, a nonprofit corporation, asked the Securities and Exchange Commission today to delay its decision on a proposal of the United Gas Improvement Company or its subsidiaries to buy the common stock of the Eastern Shore Public Service Company of Delaware until a better bid could be made for the securities.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The rapidly increasing air might of America against Germany was revealed tonight through figures showing that in eighteen raids on the Reich this year. United States heavy bombers from Britain shot down 571 Nazi planes, with 187 others probably destroyed and 231 damaged in aerial fights, against a loss of 106 American planes.

Ewald R. Hunsicker, 21-year-old graduate of Newtown High School, who told members of the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he believed in the Nazi cause, that he would not fight for the United States and intended to return to Germany after the war, was indicted yesterday by the Federal Grand Jury in Brooklyn for failure to report for induction into the Army.

CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- The United States Gypsum Company made known today that "in keeping with good citizenship" it had rejected an order of the War Labor Board directing the company to incorporate "maintenance of union membership" and the check-off system of union dues in its contract with employes at Warren, Ohio.
CHICAGO, June 15 -- The War Meat Board said tonight the shortage of beef was so critical that Army purchasing agents were being forced to buy as little as one carcass at a time.
VALLETTA, Malta, June 15 (AP) -- A communique:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Negotiations between the Central Pennsylvania Coal Producers Association and the United Mine Workers of America over the terms of a new agreement collapsed today on the question of applying the tentative terms covering the pay for portal-to-portal time.

The growing manpower shortage has for some time been swelling want ad sections of daily newspapers, and several papers which a few years ago had discontinued classified sections or had discontinued solicitation are now reviving these departments because of the pressure of war plants seeking personnel.

Max Gordon will present "Those Endearing Young Charms," a new play by Edward Chodorov, at the Booth this evening. The cast of four players is composed of Blanche Sweet, Virginia Gilmore, Dean Harens and Zachary Scott. The play takes place in the living room of an upper West Side apartment and in a Park Avenue hotel.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

A nation-wide banking group headed by the Mellon Securities Corporation, Drexel Co. and Harris, Hall Co., Inc., was high bidder yesterday for a new issue of $22,775,000 of Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Light and Power refunding revenue bonds, due serially from 1944 to 1976.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Confeeres on the $2,600,000,000 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill for the next fiscal year today left up in the air the fate of the National Resources Planning Board, which outlined the "American Beveridge Plan," pending further instructions from the House.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 15 -- A picture of the Berlin of today is furnished by the correspondent of the Stockholm newspaper Dagens Nyheter, who says that most shops and offices are now closed, their personnel having had to report for wartime duty.
WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- Legislation to permit Waves to be sent overseas met outspoken masculine criticism today in the Senate Naval Committee.

If business conditions remained substantially the same as they now are, until later in the year, Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., said a yesterday's annual meeting of the company's stockholders, he would recommend to the board an increase in the dividend rate on the common stock.

New post-war products may revitalize specialty selling, J.J. Nance, vice president and director of sales of the Zenith Radio Corporation, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Speculation over whether President Roosevelt will sign or veto the Connally-Smith bill mounted today as Philip Murray of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the executive board of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A.F. of L., urged the President to disapprove it.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- The need for maintaining high standards of nursing education in the face of accelerated nursing school programs is one of the outstanding problems confronting the nursing profession, Miss Stella Goostray, president of the National League of Nursing Education, said at the opening of the league's fiftieth anniversary convention today.

A truck driver was burned to death in his cab, while seventeen of forty passengers in a Third Avenue trolley car and the motorman were cut or touched by flame just before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon in the Bowery between East Third and Great Jones Streets.

William L. Batt, vice chairman of the War Production Board and president of SKF Industries, Inc., was re-elected chairman of the board of the American Management Association and Alvin E. Dodd was renamed president at a meeting last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

From time immemorial Sicily has been a battleground. Phoenicians, Greeks, Carthaginians, Romans, Vandals, Normans, French and Spaniards have all in their turn invaded it. Now it awaits a new invasion.
During the night of June 4 the opponents of Admiral Georges Robert in Guadeloupe attempted to overthrow his regime.

Through friends abroad I received recently a copy of the following message from the National Organization of Greek Women, which had been smuggled out of occupied Greece. It will, I think, be of interest to many of your readers and will touch their hearts with profound sympathy.

The 20 per cent cut in bus transportation on Staten Island was modified temporarily yesterday to only 10 per cent by the Office of Defense Transportation. Restoration of 10 per cent of the service was accepted by the union, which on Monday night had called drivers on the twenty-five lines on the island on strike.

LONDON, June 15 -- Civilian air raid casualties in Britain during May were 584 persons killed and 733 injured badly enough to be hospital cases, the Ministry of Home Security reported today. Of those killed, 213 were men, 266 women and 105 children under 16 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- If you travel to other cities to visit friends, if you go home for the week-end to visit your family when you are working in a distant city, take a train trip to see the sights, attend a theatre or a race track, if you travel for pleasure alone you are doing something nonessential which will hinder movement of troops and the war effort in general.

The Japanese, not over-subtle at best, have never been distinguished for their skill as propagandists. They have never been able to recognize saturation point, even at home. The mass of the people, inured to unquestioning obedience, believe because they are told to believe. Those of better education and wider experience put tongue in cheek and act as if they believed.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 -- While Outfielder Harry Walker ran his hitting streak to twenty-two consecutive games, lanky Harry Gumbert hurled a two-hitter today as the Cardinals nipped the Reds, 3 to 1, in the only contest of a scheduled double bill.

Douglas P. Falconer, national executive director of the United Seamen's Service, announced yesterday that arrangements had been completed whereby the needs of American merchant seamen hospitalized in Nassau would be looked after by the Duke and Duchess of Windsor.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 (U.P.) -- Women in industry have mastered spot welding machines with the same proficiency they once displayed in handling vacuum cleaners, but they become flippant when kidded and less efficient when coddled.

For outstanding service to the blind, Lewis W. Rodenberg of Jacksonville, Ill., blind printer, musician and poet, received yesterday the Migel Medal, established in 1937 by M.C. Migel, president of the American Foundation for the Blind, to honor those who have aided the sightless.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 15 -- Rome reports today indicated that, following up the Fascist Directorate's nine-point program for intensification of the war effort as delivered by Party Secretary Carlo Scorza yesterday, Premier Mussolini might "answer the people" this week in a speech that might be broadcast.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 15 -- Sam Graham, Greenwich veteran, today supplanted Charles P. Burgess of Baltusrol as metropolitan senior golf champion when he negotiated the historic Garden City Golf Club course, one-time stamping grounds of the immortal Walter Travis, in 79 strokes.

Great quantities of income tax payments continued to flood in by mail here yesterday to the various offices of the Treasury Department. Persons who preferred to make their payments directly again numbered many thousands, but they did not jam the collectors' offices as they had on Monday.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The House Foreign Affairs Committee unanimously approved today a concurrent resolution which would express the sentiment of Congress, if finally approved, as "favoring the creation of appropriate international machinery with power adequate to establish and to maintain a just and lasting peace, and as favoring participation of the United States therein."

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- Declaring that "you can't satisfy everybody," Leo T. Crowley, president and chairman of the board of Standard Gas and Electric Company, testified today before the Securities and Exchange Commission that the company's voluntary plan for recapitalization was the best that could be drafted on the basis of reasonably foreseeable earnings.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia took occasion yesterday afternoon during police promotion and graduation exercises in City Hall Plaza to chide department stores for opposing his budgetary program and congratulated the City Council for not eliminating Police and Fire Department positions from the city budget.

CHUNGKING, China, June 15 (U.P.) -- The sweeping Chinese offensive against the Japanese on the Yangtze front rolled on tonight as the forces of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek recaptured Michitai, only a few miles southwest of the important enemy river base of Shasi.

The future of free lunches for 54,000 New York City school children was up to Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia yesterday, as George H. Chatfield of the Board of Education asked him to find the $35,000 needed to carry the lunch program to the end of the school year.

CHUNGKING, June 15 (U.P.) -- General Stilwell personally served Army rations to three Chinese generals accompanying him on the flight from Washington in a Douglas C-54 transport plane piloted by a veteran crew that had previously flown Gen. H.H. Arnold and Prime Minister Churchill across the Atlantic.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, New bold Morris, president of the City Council, and officials of the Board of Education were guest yesterday of Harlem public school children who presented a colorful pageant, "The History of Harlem in the auditorium of Public School 194 at 242 West 144th Street.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- President Roosevelt put his foot down today on recurrent proposals that he put all controls over food under one man and that he abandon the use of subsidies to roll back and hold down the cost of living.

Robert W. Dowling, as president of the City Investing Company, has appreciably enlarged his holdings in the Times Square district by the purchase of the southwest corner of Broadway and Forty-sixth Street, taking in the Fulton and Gaiety Theatres and a six-story office building with stores on the Broadway side.

In what probably ranked as the longest and dullest game of the season, the Giants and the Dodgers came to grips at the Polo Grounds yesterday. After pummeling each other for nearly three hours, the Giants put an end to the inter-borough affair with a ninth-inning rally that broke a tie and brought the home team a 6-5 victory.

General Higino Morinigo, President of the Republic of Paraguay, who has been making a tour of war production centers in this country, will be greeted officially at Grand Central Terminal at 8:40 A.M. today by Mayor La Guardia and a reception committee of distinguished citizens, members of the Board of Estimate and leading public officials.

SOMEWHERE ON THE COAST OF ENGLAND, Wednesday, June 16 -- The first wave of an Allied invasion probably will be swept on to the European coast by men with cocoa-smeared faces who will splash through the surf from flat-bottomed flotillas that lay down their own smoke-screens, drum out their own supporting fire and ferry men and tanks ashore through water inches deep.

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 15 (AP) -- Dr. Paul P. Boyd, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at the University of Kentucky, admitted today that he failed to answer correctly several questions in the recent educational survey and test conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES among students of thirty-six American colleges.

Development of a plastic punch of a new type and a noncritical metal die which can be produced at a saving of 75 per cent of the tooling labor required to build a similar all-metal die was revealed yesterday by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.

Charging that "collapse of our food supply system, with resultant hunger for civilians" is threatened, two thousand food retailers adopted a five-point program last might at a protest mass meeting in Manhattan Center.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, June 16 (AP) -- The largest force of Liberators to be sent against the big Japanese air base of Rabaul, New Britain -- nineteen four-engined raiders -- blasted at grounded aircraft with twenty-three tons of bombs in a two-hour raid that began Monday night and extended into yesterday.

The appointment by the New York State Board of Social Welfare of Robert T. Lansdale, director of the Institute of Welfare Research of the Community Service Society of New York, to the post of State Commissioner of Social Welfare was announced yesterday by Lawrence S. Greenbaum, chairman of the board.

The council of Actors Equity Association, at a special meeting held yesterday afternoon, resolved to join the conference board of the National Conference of Entertainment Industry for War Activities, a representative body of all branches of the amusement world set up for the purpose of pooling the industry's resources.

Today is the tenth anniversary of public housing in the United States. In commemoration of the date, the National Public Housing Conference reviewed yesterday progress in the field and published statements from President Roosevelt and other leaders in housing, labor and government forecasting expanded programs after the war.

It appears that the OPA could expend the taxpayers' money to betted advantage in connection with gasoline rationing in this area. Why not pay the corps of investigators to hit the black market at its source instead of merely being a nuisance to the general motoring public by stopping suspected pleasure drivers?

MINNEAPOLIS, June 15 (AP) -- Three of the country's largest butter-making organizations, whose members account for 75 per cent of the product, told Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard today that the government's subsidy plan for food was more inflationary than reasonable prices.

A letter sent yesterday to stockholders of Creole Petroleum Corporation and of Lago Petroleum Corporation by C.H. Lieb, president of both companies, announces that Alexander Deussen and John S. Ivy of Houston, Texas, and Louis G. Huntley of Donna, Texas, have been retained to make new appraisals of the properties for use in connection with any new proposals for a consolidation of the two companies.

Sole leather is getting scarce in Great Britain. A Board of Trade official tells the National Federation of Boot Trades Association that wooden shoes are an absolute necessity if there is to be leather enough for the shoemakers to make repairs. So the English are to wear what in ignorant English opinion of the eighteenth century was a mark of the "frog-eating" Frenchmen.

Further reverberations from THE NEW YORK TIMES American history survey were felt here yesterday when Dr. J. Martin Klotsche, Professor of History at State Teachers College, Milwaukee, and head of the 1943 seminar of the Institute of World Affairs, revealed that his college had made American history a compulsory part of its curriculum on the basis of the survey.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia disclosed last night that he is planning a judicial test of some budget reductions that he believes the City Council made illegally. He revealed, too, that he and Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick had been able to make only a "constructive certification" of the new budget before the charter deadline for certifying it expired at midnight.

The monsoon rains drenched India and Burma again yesterday, as they have been doing daily for the past three weeks, and made air operations fortuitous and hazardous and ground operations virtually impossible.

Five jurors had been chosen yesterday at the trial in General Sessions of Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, accused of participating in a $514,000 extortion conspiracy with the Lepke-Gurrah racketeer gang in the garment industry, when Judge John A. Mullen adjourned the trial until today.

Industrial uses for diamonds are expanding rapidly and will prove a vital factor in strengthening the price structure for diamonds used in jewelry after the war, Henry Jacobson of Jacobson Brothers, told the concluding session yesterday of the war conference of the National Wholesale Jewelers Association at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that it will offer for sale on July 19, through competitive bidding, a new issue of $15,400,000 of collateral trust bonds. At the same time it announced that commitments are in hand that would guarantee 3 3/4 per cent on $6,700,000 of the new issue, maturing serially in one to ten years, and 4 per cent on $8,700,000 maturing in fifteen years.

The Bache collection, lent for the Summer months, goes on view to he public today at the Metropolitan Museum. In the Spring of 1937 Jules S. Bache gave his house at 814 Fifth Avenue and the rich art collection it contained to the State of New York.
Gar Wood Industries, Inc., and its subsidiaries, excluding those in Canada, had a net profit of $588,446 for the six months ended with April this year, according to the report announced yesterday.

One hundred and fifty-three Queens College students received degrees at the college's fifth commencement exercises held at Hunter College last night. Dr. Paul Klapper, president of Queens, delivered the baccalaureate address in which he predicted important post-war changes in higher education aimed at meeting the educational needs of returning soldiers as well as high school graduates.

Sales of three large Broadway corner properties featured the news of the Manhattan real estate market yesterday. Details of the investment purchase of the tall office building at 341 Madison Avenue to William F. Chatlos, builder, which was recorded on Monday, also were revealed.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Congressional tax leaders agreed at a conference today with Henry J Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, to make every effort to pass a new tax bill with additional levies, to become effective Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- It is being urged in some quarters here that a message should be sent to the German people, similar to that which President Roosevelt conveyed to the Italians at his press conference last Friday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 15 -- Ensign Elston Wyatt, top man of the unbeaten Naval Academy tennis team that Arthur Hendrix brought to the Eastern intercollegiate championships, and Francisco (Pancho) Segura, little Ecuadorian from Miami who ranks fourth in our national list, worked their way toward semi-final crossroads today at the Montclair A.C.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Trade in wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade was extremely restricted in volume today, with little feature aside from a moderate demand from mills early in the session. Hedge pressure was light, but professional operators are keeping watch on harvest operations in the Southwest and are not inclined to follow rallies until they see how heavy the pressure of free wheat will be.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 16 (AP) -- Four new German counterattacks in the reactivated Orel region were hurled back yesterday, it was announced today by the Russians, who declared enemy troops ceased their attempts to retake lost territory at sundown after two unsuccessful days.
BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- The Athletics opened a five-game stand today by sweeping a twin bill with the Red Sox, 7 to 4, and 4 to 2.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 16 (AP) -- Forthcoming decisive battles will further strengthen the United States-Soviet collaboration, President Roosevelt told President Mikhail I. Kalinin in a message, made public today by Moscow, on the occasion of the anniversary of the United States-Russian Mutual Aid Pact.

LONDON, June 15 -- Britain closed the Syrian frontier opposite Turkey at 6 A.M. today, apparently to stop the leakage of information concerning the British Ninth and Tenth Armies in the Middle East. General A.C. Arnold, British military attache at Ankara, informed the Turkish Government officially that the Syrian frontier had been closed when he visited Riza Artunkal, Minister of National Defense.

Brig. Gen. Frank T. Hines, Administrator of Veterans' Affairs, told the annual meeting of the International College of Surgeons at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night that the National Service Life Insurance for members of our armed forces had received 10,000,000 applications for insurance totaling $70,000,000,000.

This summer, principals, assistant principals, teachers and clerks of the New York City school system must give up one week of their vacation to work. They are glad and willing for the most part to do this, but what work are they to do?

To help women who intend to can fruits and vegetables this year, home economists of the United States Department of Agriculture have prepared a list that indicates approximately how many pounds of apples or tomatoes or whatever are needed to produce one quart of canned goods.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Revision of community-wide price ceilings, granting retailers and wholesalers of grocery products "a more equitable margin of mark-up," is expected to be demanded of the Office of Price Administration tomorrow at the closing session of the two-day conference of food distributors and OPA officials.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 16 -- King George VI is visiting British forces in North Africa, it was announced today by Buckingham Palace officials.

The spirit of a defiant and unbowed Norway shone through the words and music of last night's program at Carnegie Hall observing the hundredth anniversary of the birth of Edvard Grieg. The music of Norway's beloved composer reminded listeners that here was a land whose tradition was as rich as it was sturdy.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Bolton bill to provide more nurses for military and civilian war service through subsidized training and the establishment of a uniformed nurse reserve was signed by President Roosevelt this afternoon.
CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) -- Vern Stephens, with a home run and single, and Chet Laabs, with two doubles and a single, led the Browns to a 5-to-2 victory over the White Sox before 19,052 fans tonight.

DETROIT, June 15 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Betz, national clay courts champion, got away to a flying start today in defense of her crown. Before the day's events were halted by weather, she won a 6-0 set from Miss Joanne Dunn of Des Moines, Iowa.

FIFTH UNITED STATES ARMY HEADQUARTERS, North Africa, June 15 (AP) -- Back from watching the Allied assault on Pantelleria, General Dwight D. Eisenhower came here today on an inspection tour of American troops training for future operations.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) -- The bill to require Senate confirmation of most Federal employes paid more than $4,500 a year was sent to the House Civil Service Committee today, and Representative Robert Ramspeck of Georgia, the chairman, said that group is "busily engaged" and he did not know when it could find time to consider the measure.

The Salle Santelli team of the Misses Madeline Dalton, Grace Acel, Maria Cerra and Aida Condosta won the national women's team fencing title on the strips of the Fencers Club last night by defeating the defending champion, the Fencers Club, in the final bout of a round-robin, 5 to 2.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Axis invasion fears heightened today as the Italians reported that an Allied fleet was massing near Sicily.

AT A RANGER TRAINING BASE in Scotland, May 15 ((AP) by mail) -- Well-toughened young Americans with a minimum of illusions and a maximum of courage and fortitude are coming out of the Highlands in sizable bunches these days, ready in mind and muscle to be first ashore when the war goes to Hitler's Europe.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 15 -- A recommendation that "the possibilities of emigration to the United States should be examined with special reference to the post-war period" was made today in a fifty-five-page pamphlet blueprinting the colony's post-war plans.

Moving with unusual haste under the goading of its Democratic majority, the City Council, meeting just after last midnight, empowered a special committee to make a sweeping investigation of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's administration.

In England the Labor party has had strife and strikes on numerous occasions in its past history, and it probably will have in the future. Nevertheless, it has gained maturity and an assured position in the life of the English nation.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 630 United States soldiers wounded in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Wage increases amounting to $4,200,000 a year for employes of the city's unified transit system have been approved by the Board of Transportation, John H. Delaney, the chairman, announced yesterday at City Hall, following a conference with Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 16 (U.P.) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

Helmut Leiner, veteran Nazi party member who was acquitted of treason last December in a verdict directed by Federal Judge John W. Clancy, was placed on trial in Federal court yesterday under an indictment alleging illicit trading with the enemy. The charge is based on alleged financial transactions between Leiner and Edward Kerling, one of the submarine-borne saboteurs who were executed after arriving here last June.

CHICAGO, June 15 -- Growing seriousness of the household cleanliness problem in the United States was stressed by the American Washer and Ironer Manufacturers Association in session here, which plans a poll of its members in order to learn to what extent they could again begin making home laundering equipment without interference with the war effort.

Miss Pin Pin T'an, graduate of Yenching University, China, and of Radcliffe College, stressed yesterday the importance of international cooperation in an address at a luncheon given by the National Council of Women at Sherry's.

Allied political strategy would be a more effective aid to military action if we had a clearer perception of what is going on in the heads of people inside Europe. Take France and Italy, for instance, one coming to life again under its own power after unexpected defeat at the hands of Germany, the other falling to pieces in the face of certain defeat at the hands of the Allies.
Yesterday's Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

The Book-of-the-Month Club has announced for its September selection John P. Marquand's new novel "So Little Time," to be published by Little, Brown. The dividend for August and September is "Prefaces to Peace," a combination publishing venture of Simon Schuster, Doubleday, Doran, Reynal Hitchcock and Columbia University Press.

The most prolonged shoe-buying orgy the city has ever experienced ended last night with the expiration of Ration Coupon 17, leaving clerks bordering on exhaustion and merchants worrying about replenishing their virtually depleted stocks.

With numerous uncertainties discouraging long-range activity, traders in cotton futures continued yesterday to direct their business to the near positions on the New York Cotton Exchange. Price-fixing for mills in these contracts steadied the market in the afternoon after an early sinking spell on liquidation, New Orleans selling and hedging.

ALGIERS, June 15 -- The crisis in the French Committee of National Liberation over the reorganization of the army continues. There are reports from well-informed persons that, unless it breaks in favor of General Charles de Gaulle, the Fighting French leader will resign from the committee.

Resumption of piano production even on a small scale before the war is over is extremely unlikely, William D. Mayfarth of the consumer durable-goods division, WPB, indicated yesterday at the annual meeting of the National Piano Manufacturers Association of America in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 15 -- A four-mile swim to shore by an Army fighter pilot who parachuted in to the Atlantic Ocean was disclosed by the base commander here today.

WITH THE SECOND ARMY IN TENNESSEE, June 15 (AP) -- Major Gen. William C. Lee, commander of an air-borne infantry division, was injured this morning in the crack-up of a glider in which he was landed with his troops.

BOSTON, June 15 (AP) -- A prediction that a drastic curtailment in newsprint use might be forced upon American newspapers before the end of this year was made today by Warren Morgan, assistant to the associate director of the labor production division of the War Production Board, in an address before the convention of the American Newspaper Guild.
LONDON, June 15 -- The Stock Exchange opened quietly today after the Whitsun holiday. Business in most sections was on a small scale.

Despite some blunders, the Office of Price Administration has had "extraordinary success" in combating inflation, and Congress and the executive officers of the government should not overlook this in considering the criticisms now being made of the price agency, according to a resolution adopted yesterday by the National Women's Undergarment Association.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) -- Harold L. Ickes, as Petroleum Administrator, declared today that the crude oil shortage is such that "we are rapidly passing from an exporting to an importing nation," and asserted that by the end of this year "we won't be producing enough crude in California to meet the needs for the Pacific war theater and the civilian needs in that area."

Legal objections raised by opponents of the Stuyvesant Town housing project were argued yesterday before the Appellate Division, which reserved decision. During the argument all five justices of the court joined in a series of questions concerning principally the extent of the "public purpose" in the project and the "reason for the haste" by the city in seeking a quick legal decision on a plan intended for post-war construction.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) -- An Air Ministry communique:

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, was assailed in the Senate and House today for asserting, in a speech before the convention of the American Newspaper Guild at Boston yesterday, that Washington news was being covered inadequately.

NEWARK, N.J., June 15 -- Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion, speaking here tonight, expressed the hope that the United Nations would not permit Italy to surrender, saying that a surrender would mean that the Allies would have to feed the Italians.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP) -- Breakfast in bed -- the eggs and fried scrapple as traditional in this Quaker city as the Saturday night scrub -- became a war casualty in leading hotels and clubs today.
PITTSBURGH, June 15 (AP) -- A four-run rally in the sixth today pulled the Pirates from behind, giving them a 4-2 victory over the Cubs and a tie with the Reds for third place.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 15 -- Russia never can be conquered by force of arms but only won over by friendly gestures, according to the latest Wilhelmstrasse pronouncement, as telegraphed here by the Stockholm Tidningen's Berlin correspondent.

THE Customers Always Write: Private John G. Scott, one-time St. Louis newspaper man, disagrees with one remark printed here and elaborates on some others when he writes: "Jim Conzelman never left Washington University, as he told you, 'by popular request.' He gave that school such a taste of good football the athletic council thought it was ripe for national pinnacles.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 75 by 100 feet at 3554 De Kalb Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the Farbro Realty Company, William Root, president, to Mrs. Rose Kulick through Henry Waltemade, Inc., brokers.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 16 (AP) -- Sweeping along invasion paths by night and day, the Royal Air Force heaped fresh destruction on the bomb-smashed Ruhr Valley Monday night, especially the steel and communications center of Oberhausen, to keep the June air offensive tearing at Germany's war sinews.

LONDON, June 15 -- Herbert Morrison, who as Minister of Home Security has sometimes rubbed British labor unions the wrong way, particularly by his action in issuing regulations for compulsory fire-watching by civilians without first seeking the guidance of the unions, received a sharp rebuke today when, as a delegate attending the Labor party's annual convention, he was defeated in his candidacy for the key post of the party's treasurer.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- The White Sox ended a five-game losing streak, their longest of the season, by driving Al Hollingsworth from the box in less than three innings today and defeating the Browns, 9 to 0, in the second game of a double-header.
Admiral and Mrs. Joseph Strauss have arrived from Washington and are at the St. Regis.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 16 -- Willie Pep of Hartford, recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as world featherweight champion, passed his physical examination for military service today and was sworn into the Navy.

TRENTON, N.J., June 16 (AP) -- A bill that would alter New Jersey's standard fire insurance policy, described recently by a committee of the State Bar Association as "archaic and illiberal," is being prepared for introduction in the Legislature "at an early date," Eugene E. Agger, Commissioner of the State Department of Banking and Insurance, announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The War Food Administration acted today to make feed wheat available for livestock and poultry raisers and to keep corn processing plants supplied for the production of munitions.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A House Interstate and Foreign Commerce subcommittee suggested today that Israel Moses Sieff, British chain store executive and vice chairman of the Political and Economic Planning Organization, might be impregnating the OPA with anti-American economic theories in his $10-a-day position as an OPA consultant.
DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- Led by Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles and Billy Talbert of Cincinnati, all favorites advanced today in the thirty-third national clay courts tennis championships.

An exhibition of modern Mexican printing, sponsored by the Mexican Ministry of Education, was opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street, where it will continue to September.

Premier Hideki Tojo told the Japanese people yesterday that the battles in the New Guinea area "are growing fiercer and fiercer" and warned them to expect new allied offensives in Burma and air raids on "our mainland."

CHICAGO, June 16 -- Although 1942 earnings of 368 department stores reporting to the Harvard Bureau of Business Research were the highest on record for the twenty-three years covered by these studies, the final net return after corporate income and excess profits taxes amounted to only about 3 1/2 cents out of the sales dollar, or a lower ratio than in 1941 when net sales were 12.4 per cent smaller.

Strange as it may seem, salt water fishing records are still being set. Not along our eastern seaboard, but in the British West Indies, a world record wahoo has been caught and the statistics verified by the International Game Fish Association at the American Museum of Natural History.

The last application for War Ration Book 3 was "screened" -- checked for completeness and accuracy -- last night in Office of Price Administration workrooms fat 330 Fifth Avenue, next to the Empire State Building. Five hundred volunteers arriving for the night shift were sent home at 9 o'clock, when the job of checking New York State's 4,000,000 applications, started by volunteers June 1, was pronounced finished.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Action of the House Foreign Affairs Committee in unanimously reporting a resolution in favor of post-war collaboration with other nations will be heard by the Rules Committee Monday with a plea from its sponsors for immediate House consideration.
BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- Babe Barna's debut with the Red Sox was a complete success today as he started and later scored the ninth-inning run that gave his club a 3-to-2 victory over the Athletics.

Reacting mildly to reports that Rumania is extending peace "feelers" to the United Nations, the cotton futures market sagged in late dealings yesterday to final net losses of 4 to 6 points under commission-house liquidation. The trade off-take in the near-positions on the New York Cotton Exchange was strong enough to thwart any severe downward movement.

LONDON, Thursday, June 17 (AP) -- Russia will do all in her power to aid in the "creation of a strong and independent Poland," Premier Joseph Stalin told the conference of Polish Patriots in the U.S.S.R. in a message broadcast by the Moscow radio and recorded by the Russian monitor last night.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown, counter-attacking hard against inflationists in Congress who are seeking to smash the "price line," is ready to announce the long-expected shake-up in the top flight of OPA.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 16 -- In a sudden, spectacular flight, Britain's King George VI has visited the triumphant North African battleground, talked with astonished, cheering British soldiers, and watched American troops preparing for the assault upon Europe.

The greatest shoe-buying orgy in the history of the nation has been plainly the result of rationing. Ration coupons are regarded by the public as a form of currency -- a form even harder to obtain than the ordinary kind. To let a ration coupon expire unused seems to most people like throwing away money.

A further breakdown of the meat distribution machinery in this city was threatened yesterday as the result of new limitations on deliveries by packing houses and slaughterers to their wholesale and other trade customers. Although initiated by packers, the new restrictions were declared to be a direct result of new meat-pricing regulations of the Office of Price Administration that became effective on Monday at packing houses with the start of the subsidy roll-back program.

The closing of the Turkish-Syrian frontier and official reports of the massing of troops in Syria, whether or not they herald a move in the eastern Mediterranean, fit into a pattern of Allied strategy which veils plans for a series of scattered attacks in a smoke screen of constant alarm.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- A move toward inflation may be resorted to by the Finnish Government to satisfy Agrarian party demands for increased prices for farm products, according to information reaching Stockholm through private channels.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 16 -- The Stars and Stripes, weekly newspaper published for the American armed forces in the Middle East, denounced the activities of John L. Lewis today.

BEAUMONT, Tex., June 16 -- Martial law was declared in Beaumont today in a sequel to violence between Negroes and whites which caused one fatality, injured at least eleven persons, disrupted numerous businesses and virtually shut down a shipyard.

Yesterday we heard that King George had landed in North Africa Saturday. He has been visiting and inspecting ever since. There are few harder worked persons than members of the British royal family. King George is no novice. He is a professional. The Navy was his first love.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Declaring that government departments and agencies had been grossly overstaffed and their payrolls inflated through a system which fostered ever-increasing employment, irregularities in promotions, unwarranted increases in higher-bracket salaries and a draining of the nation's manpower, the Joint (Byrd) Committee on Reduction of Nonessential Federal Expenditures called on the President and Congress today to cut personnel promptly by 300,000.

Americans must not accept an armistice until Allied armies control enemy capitals, Rear Admiral William S. Pye, president of the Naval War College at Newport, R.I., warned the 1,140 graduates in the twelfth class of the Naval Reserve Midshipmen's School at Columbia University, who were commissioned yesterday morning at final commencement ceremonies in Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Track and field stars from all sections of the country continued to stream into the city yesterday for the fifty-fifth annual National A.A.U. junior and senior championships, to be held Saturday and Sunday at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

An increasing interest in religion is disclosed in the 1942 statistical report of the Methodist Church, made public yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Thomas P. Potter, official statistician for the denomination, at the Methodist Building, 150 Fifth Avenue. The figures were based on reports from the 112 annual Methodist conferences.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The public members of the National War Labor Board conferred tonight on a report to be made to the labor and industry members tomorrow on the portal-to-portal pay question for settling the long-standing dispute involving 450,000 bituminous and 80,000 anthracite coal miners.

They went to high school together, worked in the same packing company together and were separated forever in this life only when the cruiser U.S.S. Juneau went down last November -- in battle for Guadalcanal. Now Genevieve, only sister of the five Sullivan brothers who perished with the ship, is following through on one of their last messages.

According to all signs and portents, the meat situation is becoming increasingly tight. A nationwide survey made yesterday indicated that stocks are low in several big cities, and that here in New York there are shortages of beef, lamb and veal, with somewhat larger supplies of pork.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Aerial fighting continues over the Solomons, where United States and Japanese bases are within close flying range of each other, with the American and Japanese air forces trading blows within the last few days, the Navy reported today.
AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, June 16 (AP) -- South Pacific Force headquarters announced today that 1,337 Japanese planes had been destroyed in this war theatre since last July 31.

Barker Brothers The 25-cent dividend on the common stock voted yesterday by the directors is not to be construed as a regular quarterly payment, the Barker Brothers Corporation announced yesterday. The previous dividend, 50 cents on Dec. 17, was the only payment last year.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Lefty Tommy Byrne made his second start as a Yankee pitcher tonight in Griffith Stadium before a gathering of 21,000 with catastrophic results.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Retail deliveries of any packages measuring less than 60 inches in combined length and girth or weighing less than five pounds will be prohibited after Friday under an order issued here today by the Office of Defense Transportation applying to the twelve Northeastern States comprising the Eastern gasoline shortage area.

Transfers of the regular New York Curb Exchange membership of Stanley L. Ballin to Sam A. Lewisohn, that of John J. Farrell to John Belck and that of Charles C. Wright to William E. McCabe were approved yesterday by the governors of the Curb.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 -- The subject of Argentine oils for Brazil, which Brazil would pay for with American machinery purchased from the United States, provoked caustic comments in the press today.

The people of this nation do not understand how desperate the food situation is, Mrs. Roger W. Straus, newly appointed nutrition commissioner for this area of the New York State Emergency Food Commission, declared yesterday.

With wood becoming more critical than some types of steel, it is understood that L-49 will be amended soon to release stocks of angle irons now frozen in the hands of bedding manufacturers. These angles, as well as others which could be obtained, will be used in the base of coiled springs instead of wood, it was said.

ST. LOUIS, June 16 (AP) -- A three-run outburst in the eleventh inning, sparked by Eddie Miller's double which drove in two, gave the Reds a 4-to-1 triumph over the world champion Cardinals tonight. Harry Walker's hitting streak was stopped at twenty-two consecutive games and in addition he lost the National League batting lead.
INDIANAPOLIS, June 16 -- Federal Judge Robert C. Baltzell granted today a judgment of $3,664,616 against George A. Ball of Muncie, Ind., industrialist, and the George and Frances Ball Foundation.

ALGIERS, June 16 (AP) -- Foreshadowing a possible showdown on their political differences, Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Gen. Henri - Honore Giraud tonight jointly called a full meeting of the French Committee of National Liberation and the Commissioners for 10:30 A.M. tomorrow.

MONTREAL, June 16 (Canadian Press) -- Apparent total consumption in the United States of newsprint in May amounted to 334,125 tons, which was 7,908 tons, or 2.4 per cent, higher than in the same month in 1942, the Newsprint Association of Canada reported today in a monthly survey.

The annual season of Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, opened last night on the Mall in Central Park. The concert, 1458th in the series, now in its twenty-sixth year, was attended by an audience estimated at 15,000.

Newspaper correspondents on the battlefronts have been writing a good deal recently about the morale of German prisoners. All are agreed on one thing. That arrogant sureness of early victory which distinguished all German prisoners captured at the beginning of the war has been measurably reduced.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Prices of live hogs slumped today to the lowest levels of the year, losing 10 to 20 cents a hundred pounds, while the top was down 15 cents to $14. The day's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 (AP) -- A three-run rally in the eighth inning against Rookie Fred Schmidt, who had just entered the game, enabled Newark to take the measure of Rochester tonight for the third straight time, 5 to 3.

A special Federal statutory court reserved decision yesterday on the question of approval of a plan to adjust payment of a $50,000,000 bond issue of the Delaware Hudson Railroad Corporation, which became due on May 1. Argument largely concerned the adequacy of a 10 per cent cash payment now, as contemplated by the plan, which has been approved by 80 per cent of the bondholders and the Interstate Commerce Commission.
LONDON, June 16 -- Little activity was shown today in financial circles as the market awaited fresh war news.

In view of the prospect that there will be few practicing salesmen at the end of the war, industry must prepare now to train and retrain men returning from the war and from defense work, William Rados, secretary-treasurer of the National Society of Sales Training Executives, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., June 16 -- William M. (Bill) Reekie, one of the top amateur golfers of the metropolitan district a little more than a decade ago, made his debut in New Jersey senior competition at the Glen Ridge Country Club today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (U.P.) -- The Pacific Coast Conference today liberalized its eligibility rules to permit servicemen assigned to member schools to participate in its intercollegiate athletic programs.

The Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and all subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended with April net profit of $10,917,733 after all charges, including $21,831,693 income and excess profits taxes and $1,000,000 provision for contingencies.

The Imperial Irrigation District (Calif.) Board notified bankers here yesterday that its proposed new issue of $13,815,000 of refunding bonds, scheduled for sale on June 21, has been authorized by the voters of the district at an election held on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- War bond purchases were cut sharply this month, possibly to meet the heavy second quarter tax bill which fell due yesterday. The Treasury's daily statement today showed that during the first fourteen days of this month sales of war savings bonds were $331,218,987, the lowest in the last three quarterly tax payment periods.

Yetta Weisbrod, who died peacefully last Monday in her room at the Home of the Daughters of Jacob at the age of 108, was not certain about the spelling of her native town of Yeszierzana. At times, said our news story, the brisk old lady thought it was part of Poland, and on other occasions she placed it in "the northeast corner of Austria-Hungary."
WITH THE NORTH PACIFIC FLEET, at Sea, June 8 -- Unlike Guadalcanal, for which the Japanese fought with unexpected tenacity, the Tokyo war lords apparently intend to let the Aleutians go by default.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Some observers here who are well acquainted with the members of the newly formed French Cabinet in Algiers believe that it excels in character and ability any French Cabinet in a generation. They point out that, among fourteen Ministers, only one or two could be called politicians, though most of the group have had long experience in government and especially in international affairs.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 16 (AP) -- Continued advertising was urged today by officers of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations as a means of counteracting losses of business resulting from wartime curbs on home financing.

LONDON, Thursday, June 17 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers resumed their attacks on Germany last night, the British announced today, after giving the cities of the Reich a one-night respite from attack.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Prentiss M. Brown, OPA Administrator, served notice on his former colleagues of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today that it would be "impossible" for him to implement mandates of the Price Stabilization Act without employing Federal subsidies to "roll back" agricultural prices.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- Frank words came from King Gustaf tonight when he revealed that during the present world crisis he had on several occasions felt it an absolute duty to go beyond the bounds of his constitutional authority on his own initiative by personally intervening to help the country under what he termed the difficulties of those mements.

Marking what is believed to be the first action of its kind by any trade organization, the National Knitted Outerwear Association has formed a special standing committee, known as the "Committee to Fight Inflation," which will combat inflationary tendencies in the knitted outerwear industry, stamp out black markets and rally trade support for the Office of Price Administration in meeting attacks "inspired by politics and special interests," it was made known here yesterday.

This city must take steps to induce business enterprise to come here, members of the City Planning Commission declared yesterday at a public hearing when taxpayer and civic organizations of Queens opposed modification of the zoning resolution to permit construction of industrial offices and laboratories in residential districts.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia warned President Roosevelt last night to keep "politicians and lawyers" out of the Office of Price Administration and other governmental agencies dealing with the people's food supply. He also urged Congress to support the President's program for subsidies so that the farmers can get high enough prices to induce them to produce the maximum amount and the workers in the cities can get plenty of food at reasonable prices.

For the woman who finds those "silver threads among the gold" a little less romantic in reality than in the song, science presents a comfortable compromise. Two novel cosmetics -- one a cream and one a crayon -- have been developed recently to combat the coming of the gray. Neither is a dye.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 16 -- Five important Axis airdromes in western Sicily, on which the aerial defense of that island rests, were attacked by American heavy and medium bombers yesterday in a thunderous renewal of the offensive against enemy air power in the mid-Mediterranean.

LONDON, June 16 -- Openly distrusting the British Communist party's avowals that it would conform to the Labor party's program, policy, principles and rules if admitted to the latter organization's ranks, delegates attending the Labor party's forty-second annual convention rejected today by 1,951,000 votes to 712,000 the Communists' application for affiliation with the Laborites.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Requesting an opportunity for oral argument before the War Labor Board on the WLB's panel recommendations, the Chrysler Corporation today opposed recommendations granting the check-off, union security and compulsory arbitration to the United Automobile Workers, an affiliate of the CIO.

A call for volunteers to serve as recreation aides was issued yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, Regional Office of Civilian Defense Director. With the advent of Summer, there is an increasing need for recreation aides to help staff the play centers that are a prime need for children in towns and cities.

PITTSBURGH, June 16 (AP) -- The Pirates made it two straight over the Cubs tonight, 5 to 2, driving Hiram Bithorn from the mound in the three-run first inning when Frankie Gustine doubled, Frankie Colman tripled and Jimmy Russell and Bobby Elliott singled in order.

William Flynn, 28 years old, an ex-convict, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to thirty years to life imprisonment for killing an elderly patron of a bar and grill at Park Avenue and 122d Street in a hold-up on Jan. 21, 1942.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (U.P.) -- The House passed and sent to the Senate today a $1,086,059,499 Labor and Federal Security Appropriation Bill after denying a $3,000 salary increase for Paul V. McNutt, War Manpower Director. Passage was by voice and without opposition.

The nation's supply of major oil stocks declined 1,091,000 barrels last week to 81,114,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The total for the previous week was 82,205,000 while gasoline stocks a year ago were 91,846,000 barrels.

If industry would run like the front line armed forces, with men bound together facing a common peril and sharing common sacrifices and with no personal profit motivation whatever, difficulty mentioned in your editorial of June 14, "The Anti-Strike Bill," would not arise.
