BUENOS AIRES, June 16 (U.P.) -- General Edelmiro Farrell, Minister of War in the new Argentine Government, stated today that Argentina's desire was to draw closer to "the great republic of the United States" in every way possible and that one of the fundamental motives of the June 4 revolution was the army's intention to honor strictly Argentina's international agreements.

A tougher policy than heretofore to compel owners of all buildings in the New York area except private residences to convert from fuel oil to coal-burning equipment, if possible, was indicated yesterday by the Office of Price Administration, the War Production Board and the Petroleum Administration for War as the OPA began to mail fuel oil ration renewal forms for the 1943-44 season which begins July 1.

The season's first musical comedy, "Early to Bed," opens this evening at the Broadhurst Theatre under the auspices of Richard Kollmar, who also plays a featured part in the show. Described as "a fairy tale for grown-ups only," it has book and lyrics by George Marion Jr. and music by Thomas Wright (Fats) Waller.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- With a new wing and a patched-up tail, a Flying Fortress glided down before a cheering crowd at National Airport today.
The race by shoe purchasers to beat the deadline for redemption of Ration Coupon 17 over, the retail shoe business slowed down to a walk yesterday -- to the surprise of some dealers.

LONDON, June 16 -- From the crown-tipped flagstaff atop Buckingham Palace the Queen's standard flew today with its blue and white Bowes-Lyon quarterings. It brought home to the British public that the King had flown to North Africa in the longest wartime journey ever undertaken by a British sovereign.
JERSEY CITY, June 16 (AP) -- Buffalo made a sweep of its four-game series with Jersey City tonight, winning the final game, 2 to 1, behind the six-hit pitching of Jack Tising.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 17 (AP) -- The noon communique:

The committee representing the New Orleans, Texas Mexico Railway has agreed to accept the amended plan of reorganization of the Missouri Pacific Railroad subject to certain conditions, which it will not state at this time and subject to acceptance by all other parties at interest.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 16 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox, addressing the commencement class at Northwestern University today, declared that the achievements attained by the United States in the eighteen months since Pearl Harbor "never have been equalled in human history."
LANSING, Mich., June 16 -- Liquor rationing is expected to start in Michigan soon with a limit of one quart or one-fifth gallon for each person during a four-week period.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Congress received word today that this country is putting the largest share of its military expenditures behind its air force, and a strong hint that military strategists have revised upward their estimates of what air power can do to beat the Axis to its knees.

Mrs. Ames and Teddy Atkinson remained a winning combination yesterday as the jockey brought Henry Lustig's undefeated bay filly home by three-quarters of a length in the $7,075 Astoria Stakes at Aqueduct before 16,993 race followers who sent $1,456,719 through the betting machines.

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP) -- Unshaken by a test blackout that interrupted the game for forty-five minutes, Si Johnson pitched three-hit ball tonight to handcuff the Braves as the Phillies won, 2 to 0.

Thirty-seven activities designed to provide wartime protection for children in the New York City schools were listed yesterday in a report of the Committee on Civilian Defense in the Schools, made public by James Marshall, chairman of the committee since its formation in March, 1941.

Newspapers are confronted with the likelihood of another reduction in their consumption of newsprint, and future savings must come out of the large consumers, Cranston Williams, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Association of Newspaper Classified Advertising Managers at the Hotel New Yorker.

The Dairymen's League food forum, in session yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker, heard a prediction by Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont that the nation's food production for 1943 would be 15 to 30 per cent under 1942's record output and a suggestion that New York City should take a tip from Britain, setting up an over-all authority to obtain adequate supplies and distribute them equitably.

A program to rehabilitate the finances of the city while maintaining its high standard of service without new local taxes of a type that tend to affect the city's competitive position was outlined yesterday by the Committee of Fifteen.

Two new films will arrive in midtown theatres today. The Belmont will be host at the local premiere of "The Life of Simon Bolivar," a Mexican film biography of the South American liberator, starring Julian Soler in the title role.

LONDON, Thursday, June 17 -- Russian troops have driven deep into the German defense line north of Orel and heavy fighting continues along the edge of the salient, with the Russians attacking in some sectors and the Germans counter-attacking in others, Russian and German reports revealed today.

CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Action on a proposed merger and applications for two new franchises were in the offing as developments indicated one of the most interesting sessions in the National Football League's history here Saturday and Sunday.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 16 (AP) -- Charles Chaplin, 54-year-old actor-producer, married today his fourth bride, Miss Oona O'Neill of New York. The bride, daughter of Eugene O'Neill, the playwright, is 18.

Extension of the zoological area in Bronx Park by the New York Zoological Society was promised yesterday by Fairfield Osborn, president of that organization, during an inspection tour of the exhibits by members and guests of the Park Association of New York City, Inc.

MOSCOW, June 16 -- The basic arm of Soviet military forces remains the infantry. It is still those vast numbers of riflemen on foot upon whom the burden of this Eastern war has been so largely placed. The Red Air Force, armored force, artillery, cavalry, motorized forces and seamen have all contributed their important bit.

Announcing impending debt reductions of more than $22,000,000 and implying that further retirements of securities will follow, H.F. Sinclair, president of Sinclair Oil Corporation, said yesterday that "it might be wise in times like these, and subject of course to future conditions, for corporations to reduce debt when they had resources sufficient to make this possible."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, who will administer the Student War Nurse Reserve that has just been authorized, announced the appointment this afternoon of Miss Lucille Petry as director.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 16 -- Arthur B. Horton, 49 years old, of 316 Millburn Avenue, Millburn, died this afternoon in Overlook Hospital here of burns suffered in an explosion and fire early this morning in a cottage at Beekman, N.Y., the alleged victim of his own plot to collect insurance on the structure.

At the start he was uncertain and the finish found him reeling, but Rube Fischer, a refugee from Jersey City's eighth-place club, made his debut for the Giants a winning one against the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- The Allied war of nerves continued unabated today, stinging Berlin into bragging of the security of its Balkan outposts on the Eastern Mediterranean.

Eight men, who were shown through extensive testimony to have been disloyal to the United States and devoted to Nazi Germany, were rounded up yesterday by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and interned as dangerious alien enemies.

If business men everywhere, as they do, have their mail cluttered up with all sorts of governmental publications, written by not-dry-behind-the-ear theorists, Communists and other impractical so-called experts, telling practical men how to run their business, don't complain. Just put them in the wastebasket, breathe a sigh and wonder how long this Government will, through bungling bureaucracy, continue to waste the hard-earned tax money you are paying for the purpose of conducting a war.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif, June 16 -- Universal, planning to increase its "horror" picture output, has bought the screen rights to the title of the current radio series the "Inner Sanctum Mysteries." The studio will make two pictures a year under the group title.
LONDON, Thursday, June 17 (AP) -- The Russian midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, expressed the belief today that taxpayers may find they can buy more war bonds after withholding goes into effect than before. Withholding of taxes at the source begins July 1 under the pay-as-you-go tax law.

Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States showed a further gain in May, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in its monthly survey of this market, released yesterday. The volume as of the end of May was $135,815,000, a gain of $7,465,000, but a decline of $38,091,000, compared with a year ago.

The Ringling Brothers moved into an air-conditioned Madison Square Garden last night with their continental circus, "Spangles," for a summer run. It was a lavish and picturesque spectacle, with all the atmosphere of the Big Show.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16 (AP) -- A desire of Governor John W. Bricker to keep next week's Governors' conference free from politics was described today by persons close to the Executive as a possible reason why Harrison E. Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, decided to remain away.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A bill appropriating $2,921,441,504 for expenses of eighteen civilian war agencies for the fiscal year beginning July 1 was reported to the House today by its Appropriations Committee.

After a misadventure on the road last Spring, "Those Endearing Young Charms" finally reached the Booth Theatre last evening. It would be a pleasure to report this morning that the delay had enabled Edward Chodorov to bring his play to a high point of perfection, but that unfortunately is not the case.

Although the United Nations cannot lose the war for lack of machines and men, the victory can be "frittered away in a hundred thousand controversies, concessions and compromises," Beardsley Ruml declared yesterday at the ninety-seventh commencement exercises of City College.

CHICAGO, June 16 -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade reversed itself today, turning weak in the late trade after having shown initial strength. The early buying, led by commission houses with some mill support, resulted in a fair upturn.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world, offers a partial list of free amusement and recreational activities available today.

New York hotels are rapidly converting manpower to womanpower in all jobs where the change is feasible, it was disclosed yesterday, but so far there has been no drastic curtailment of hotel service traceable to war pressure, as in other cities.

CHUNGKING, China, June 16 (U.P.) -- The Japanese again have used poison gas in China, a military spokesman charged tonight as Chinese forces claimed new successes on three fronts, including the recapture of a town south of the Yangtze River.

A ship that survived the blows of two enemy torpedoes and was temporarily abandoned by her crew "miraculously" stayed afloat and came into port under her own power for repair by the Todd Shipyards Corporation, stockholders were told yesterday by John D. Reilly, president, at their annual meeting.

The Moreland investigation disclosed yesterday that at least 1,000 physicians in the city had received kickbacks last year from private roentgenologists for referring compensation cases to the X-ray specialists.

The Julia Ellsworth Ford Foundation for Children's Literature announced yesterday that Gladys Malvern of this city had won its $1,250 prize for her book "Valiant Minstrel: The Story of Harry Lauder," to be published this autumn by Julian Messner.

The use of American Army Air Forces for the first time as a separate unit, instead of using it piecemeal as an umbrella to protect scattered ground troops, contributed greatly to Allied victory in North Africa and the Mediterranean and marks the "coming of age of United States air power," Maj. Gen. George E. Stratemeyer, Chief of the Air Staff, Army Air Forces, said yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 15 (Delayed) -- Premier Shukru Saracoglu confirmed the establishment of a Russo-Turkish rapprochement and the strengthening of relations between Ankara and Moscow in a strong speech delivered this afternoon before the final session of the Sixth Congress of the Turkish People's party.

An extraordinary misconception has got abroad concerning the provision of the Connally-Smith bill barring unions from making contributions to Federal elections. Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt apparently shares this misconception and has perhaps helped to spread it. In her syndicated column, "My Day," published on Tuesday, she wrote: "I read the anti-strike bill through yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 16 -- Reports that the executive committee of the State Democratic party refused support to the party's war chest for the 1944 campaign brought repercussions today ranging from a denial to renewed assertions that the report was substantially true.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 16 (AP) -- A communique:

PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- A plan for consolidation of the Lexington Water Power Company into the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company, with the consolidated corporation assuming all outstanding bonds, debentures, notes and accounts payable of both concerns, was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHESTER, Pa., June 16 -- Five Negro workers were shot today in a clash with guards in Yard No. 4 of the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company here. One was said to be in a serious condition.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 16 -- Lawrenceville Prep captured its first Eastern private schools tennis championship in the eleven-year history of the event without waiting until the last day by placing men in the final in both singles and doubles today at the Scarborough Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- "Not that I intend to give advice to newspaper men as to how to do their jobs," said Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information, to the American Newspaper Guild convention this week in Boston. And then he proceeded to do that very thing, concentrating on the reporters of Washington news, which, he said, "is less adequately covered than any other news in the world today."

In announcing the membership of the new War Finance Committee of New York State, which will handle all war loan drives in the future, W. Randolph Burgess, chairman of the committee, disclosed after the organization meeting of the committee yesterday afternoon at 1270 Sixth Avenue that the Third War Loan Drive will be launched throughout the nation on Sept. 9.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 16 -- In the first year of our participation in the war, 11,000,000 tons of pre-war commercial shipping was "practically destroyed" by enemy action, it was disclosed today by Charles E. Walsh Jr., director of procurement, United States Maritime Commission, at the presentation of the Maritime Commission's "M" pennant to the eight manufacturing plants of the General Cable Corporation.

NEW DELHI, India, June 16 (AP) -- RAF bombers and fighters made widespread attacks on Japanese bases and communications in Burma yesterday, ranging all the way from the Arakan front to Mandalay and inflicting extensive damage without the loss of a single plane, a British communique announced today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 16 -- The great adventure is over for Staff Sergeant Cliff Wherley, 16-year-old turret gunner, who has flown more than a hundred combat hours in a Marauder.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 14 (Delayed) -- Rumania is ready for a separate peace and surrender to the Allies, according to a high Allied diplomatic source, who has received a direct plea for an armistice through a foreign diplomatic quarter, according to information reaching the Turkish capital tonight.

At his two most recent press conferences the President has defended the Administration's plan for food subsidies on the ground that nothing better is in sight. Opposition to this plan, he told the reporters, reminded him of a story popular during the last war. It was the story about the British soldier who preferred to stay even in a poor shelter till he found a better 'ole.

Dr. A.A. Berg, consulting surgeon at Mount Sinai and Montefiore Hospitals, was chosen president-elect of the International College of Surgeons to take office as president in 1945, at the annual meeting of the college at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Office of Price Administration today announced packers' and primary distributors' ceiling prices for frozen vegetables and fruits which will mean an increase of about a cent a pound to consumers for asparagus and of between 3 and 4 cents a pound for strawberries.

Thousands of commuters in Grand Central Terminal yesterday morning witnessed the arrival of General Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay, from Chicago. The onlookers stood at attention while the Fire Department band played "The Star-Spangled Banner" and the Paraguayan national anthem.

The pre-dawn action of the City Council in ordering a broad investigation of the La Guardia Administration was assailed as a political "fishing expedition" yesterday after the first subpoenas in the inquiry had been served for the records in the recently concluded stirrup-pump trial.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- An eleven-point program intended to encourage greater food production, eliminate black markets, preserve existing distribution machinery and control inflation was presented to the OPA today by retail grocers at the close of a two-day conference with officials here on proposed regulations establishing ceiling prices for the industry.

Louis Hollander, 38 years old, organizer and president of the Theaatrical Costume Workers Union, Local 21313, American Federation of Labor, was trapped at noon yesterday by three detectives from District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office when he accepted $3,000 in an envelope in the lobby of his union's headquarters at 19 West Forty-ninth Street.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 17 (AP) -- As another report was made of a heavy bomb load dropped on a Japanese air base in the southwest Pacific, it was disclosed today that the Japanese were continuing to concentrate their planes in considerable strength at three points.

Newspaper advertising linage in fifty-two cities measured by Media Records registered a 13 per cent rise last month over May, 1942. This gain brought the increase for the five-month period to 10.3 per cent.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 16 -- Twelve days after the setting up by President Juan Antonio Rios of a "technical, non-political administrative Cabinet," Congress in a midnight session tonight, in discussing the so-called "emergency economic bill," will approach the delicate question of the powers of the executive and of Congress, which for months has delayed the bill, intended to give the President special powers to deal with conditions arising out of the war.

OTTAWA, June 16 -- Japan has taken 3,200,000 tons of raw materials every month from the occupied territories within the Great Wall of China, Mme. Chiang Kaishek told the members of the two houses of the Canadian Parliament this morning when she addressed them at a joint session.

Tax collection officials and employes were settling down yesterday to the long, hard task of processing the millions of income tax payments received over the weekend and Monday and Tuesday. But they, like everyone else in the country who employs or is employed, were getting ready also for the shift to pay-as-you-go taxation which is to take effect in two weeks.

Kings County Judge Peter J. Brancato, in sentencing two men yesterday to the electric chair, took time to eulogize Detective Joseph Miccio, whom they killed, for his outstanding heroism in the first World War. The men sentenced were Joseph Palmer, 28 years old, of 1723 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, and Vincent Sollami, 26, who never gave a home address.

The United States Department of Labor has intervened in the ten-month-old dispute between the transcription companies and the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, it was disclosed yesterday.

TOPEKA, Kan., June 16 -- The present food prospects for the American people are definitely below the potential requirements for the next year, and, in the words of both Secretary of Agriculture Claude Wickard and Food Administrator Chester Davis, "there are no hopes of reaching the 1943 production goal."

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 16 -- Trailing by 1 -- 4 on two service breaks in the second set after losing the first, Robert Wasserman of Ohio State came on to win the deciding third set at love against Edgar Buttenheim of Princeton today in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Montclair A.C.

Another slow and unexciting recovery trend prevailed yesterday in the stock market, but a slackening of interest in the afternoon shaded the best gains of the day. The further improvement was spotty, with additions generally in a fractional range except for wider gains in some high-priced issues.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Details of a gigantic propaganda campaign, ranging from distribution of American drinking cups in Africa to leaflet barrages behind enemy lines, were unfolded today by the House Appropriations Committee as it recommended a fund of $34,472,504 for operations of the Office of War Information for the next fiscal year.

IT is a bit on the warmish side to be discussing football. But the owners of the National Football League will be in session over the week-end settling their wartime policy and arranging their schedules. There is no doubt about the fact that the play-for-pay gridiron gladiators are determined to carry on.

The National Legion of Decency has lifted its ban on the motion picture "Lady of Burlesque" and has now placed the film version of the Gypsy Rose Lee novel, "G-String Murders,'' in the "Class B" or "objectionable in part" category, according to an announcement yesterday from the Roman Catholic reviewing organization.
After photographing the war in North Africa since the first American troops went ashore there last Fall, Eliot Elisofon has returned to this country with new respect for the utilitarian spade.

The Hungarian radio recently revealed that Olexa Borkanyuk, former member of the Czechoslovak Parliament from Carpatho-Russia was court-martialed and hanged for military treason and mutiny, it was disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 16 -- Five Newark children met accidental deaths within two hours tonight, setting what the local police believe to be a new local record for child fatalities within such a short period. Two children were killed in falls while playing and the three others were drowned.

Senator George D. Aiken of Vermont, a member of the Senate's Subcommittee on Food, said here yesterday that if President Roosevelt wanted "a better method" than subsidies of cutting food costs to people who could not afford to pay rising prices, he should restore the stamp plan of depression days.

Planning, purchasing and preparing of food will become increasingly important to the American housewife and her family, speakers declared yesterday afternoon at the Food Forum, held in the Hotel New Yorker. The housewife must re-educate herself along these lines to cope with the rationing system and necessary changes in food habits.

NORFOLK, Va., June 16 (AP) -- Counsel for groups interested in reorganization of the Seaboard Air Line Railway Company expressed today approval generally of a report drafted by Tazewell Taylor, special master, but voiced objections to specific points of the report.

ATLANTA, June 16 (AP) -- J. Lon Duckworth, chairman of the Georgia Democratic Executive Committee, asserted today that the group would make no effort to raise funds for the 1944 campaign unless national party leaders "quit dealing with Republicans and Willkieites in Georgia."

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The War Department gave out today the names, with next of kin, of 408 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwestern Pacific areas.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 16 (AP) -- Edward J. Penn, 23 years old, was arrested by United States authorities today as he completed the minimum of his sentence in Sing Sing Prison for attempting to extort $25,000 ransom in the Peter Levine kidnapping and murder case of 1938.

A LITTLE less than two years ago it was an almost universal opinion that the German Army would go through the Russians "like a knife through cheese." And even today one encounters skepticism about Russian staying power. A publicist recently returned from London expects the Germans to make a stab for Moscow this summer, with a "fair" chance of getting there.

New York City will supply the $35,000 necessary to continue providing free lunches for 54,000 children in the city's public schools until June 26, the Board of Education announced yesterday. The funds will be obtained by transferring money from unexpended balances in the city budget.

OTTAWA, June 16 (AP) -- Defense headquarters announced today that Private Johnny Greco of the Canadian Army, one of the most promising lightweight prospects in the ring, had been refused permission to go through with his scheduled bout against Champion Bob Montgomery on June 25 in Yankee Stadium, New York.

A few weeks ago I would have agreed with Mrs. Williams' sentiments about each of us being allowed to use his quota of gasoline in his own way. Since the pleasure driving ban is actually being enforced, however, it has become very apparent to me just how far the honor system fell short of barring nonessential driving.

BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -- The national convention of the American Newspaper Guild unanimously voiced conviction today that "Elmer Davis, as director of the Office of War Information, is one of the strongest guarantees of a free press in wartime that the nation could have."

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 16 -- Stockholm had a mild sensation today when the newspaper Nya Dagligt Allehanda announced in an extra edition that peace negotiations had been conducted recently "in a boarding house somewhere in Sweden" between Soviet representatives, among whom were Mme. Alexandra Kollontay, the Soviet Ambassador here, and high German officers.

The York Ice Machinery Corporation has developed its own labor pool and is able to handle most of its problems by transferring its own workers instead of hiring more, according to an announcement yesterday by S.E. Lauer, president.

Rosie the Riveter's toes will be less endangered by dropped wrenches and other industrial accidents after July 1, when work shoes manufactured for women under specifications set up by the American Standards Association will go on the market

LONDON, June 17 -- The time-lapse between the defeat of Germany and the defeat of Japan may be shorter than is generally supposed, Herbert B. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, told a press conference today. He said there was a possibility that there might not be any interval at all.

Although most city stores have butter on hand, according to a spokesman for the Consumers' Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, supplies are not so plentiful as they were a few weeks ago. One Manhattan authority attributes the decrease to the recent price roll-back.

Rumania crumpled early in the last war, and conditions in that unfortunate country today are worse in every respect than they were when its armies disintegrated after the collapse of Russia in 1917. Rumors of peace feelers put out by Rumanian officials certainly correspond to the realities of Rumania's position.

CHUNGKING, June 17 (U.P.) -- American fliers made a destructive attack Tuesday on Owchihkow, one of the few remaining Japanese-held centers in the rice-growing area between Lake Tungting and the Yangtze River, Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters announced today.

Although the war has created many grave problems for the world, it has at least had the beneficial effect of strengthening the unity of the nations of the Americas, General Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay, declared last night at a dinner in his honor under the auspices of the Pan-American Society at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 -- An appeal for liberalization of the immigration laws by the great democracies was voiced tonight by Thomas Mann, who said that the present restrictions imposed when there was "little need" for immigration from Europe were not adapted to "the monstrous conditions" prevailing there now.

The Council of Books in Wartime announces that a series of newsreel shorts, dramatizing scenes from important books about the war, will be produced and released this Summer under an arrangement made by the council with Film Distributors, Inc.

Now that the customary domestic help has gone into the factories, lured by higher wages, it is time for the CDVO or some civilian agency to start the enlistment of kitchen aides. The subject of food and its preparation has occupied much time on the radio and much space in the papers, but no one has yet come forward with practical suggestions for lightening the housekeeper's burden.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- Appearing as a pinch-hitter for the fourth time in the five-game series, Manager Joe Cronin belted his second and third three-run homers today as his Red Sox split a Bunker Hill Day double-header with the Athletics. Cronin's first four-bagger of the day enabled Boston to win the opener, 5 -- 4.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., June 17 -- Lawrenceville Prep, paced by Bill Ylvisaker, swept all honors in the Eastern interscholastic championships for private schools, which ended at the Scarborough Tennis Club courts today. Lawrenceville captured the singles and doubles crowns on top of the team title, which was clinched yesterday.

Plans are being made to supply the Italian people with food and other relief as soon as they are liberated from German domination, it was revealed last night by former Governor Herbert H. Lehman, Director of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations.

Immense, with a beard like a cataract and a voice like the sound of many waters, he walked the Harvard Yard like a behemoth. For more than forty years his students had the advantage of hearing not only a greatly learned man but a strong, independent and original character.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- Though described as strictly local, the fighting in a small river loop northwest of Mtsensk, recently captured by the Russians, is sharp and persistent, and the Germans clearly are anxious to regain the tactically valuable positions.

ALBANY, June 17 -- Several important amendments to the State Vehicle and Traffic Law, enacted during the 1943 legislative session, become effective July 1, Clifford J. Fletcher, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said today. He made public a summary of changes in the law.

PLEASANTON, Calif., June 17 -- Working in short spurts in water up to 108 feet deep and so cold that air hose carrying oxygen to them from the surface frequently froze, deep-sea divers among the Navy's Seabees stationed in the Aleutians have been doing amazing wartime repair and salvage jobs during the last year.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (U.P.) -- The House unanimously adopted tonight a conference committee's revised Naval appropriation bill calling for $27,637,226,198 in direct allotments and contract authorizations for new ships and naval aircraft to aid offensives in the Pacific and the Atlantic.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Maureen O'Hara; who will be lent to Paramount by RKO as part of the deal whereby the latter studio will get Sonny Tufts for "Government Girl," will be co-starred with Ray Milland in "Tomorrow's Harvest." Paramount previously had tried to borrow Ingrid Bergman for the role.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 128 United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwestern Pacific areas, and of 278 wounded in North Africa.

The appointment of Phillips R. Turnbull as regional director of the War Production Board for Region 2, which embraces metropolitan New York, to succeed John P. Maguire was announced yesterday at a press conference at WPB's headquarters in the Chanin Building. Mr. Maguire will resume active management of his business, John P. Maguire Company, textile factors, but will continue on a dollar-a-year basis as regional consultant to the WPB, at the request of Mr. Turnbull.

LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- The Rome radio reported from Bucharest today that the Rumanian authorities had issued a communique denying that Rumania was seeking a separate peace. An Ankara report yesterday said Rumania had sent out peace feelers.
The usual extra dividend of 20 cents and the regular semi-annual of 80 cents a share were voted yesterday by directors of the Continental Insurance Company.

True education, opposed to the false education of the totalitarian States, which are controlled by Fascist principles and whose god is the State," must be dominated by the religious and democratic concept that exalts the dignity of human personality,"

Curtis High of Staten Island yesterday won its first city P.S. A.L. baseball championship when it registered a 4-to-2 decision over George Washington High in the final play-off on the Washington diamond.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Yankees did it the hard way today as they bade farewell to the Senators and Griffith Stadium for a spell. Twice they blew a one-run lead, and they almost wasted a five-run inning, but with a three-run ninth-inning rally they beat Ossie Bluege's band, 9 to 8.

"Handling a street car isn't as easy as it looks," warns New York City's first group of motorwomen. Two out of the original unit of recruits go out this morning for the first time strictly "on their own."

The Manhattan Savings Bank has sold the six-story apartment building at 45 Parade Place, Brooklyn, to Joseph Klein through Philip Rapoport, broker. The building contains seventy-seven rooms and is assessed for $100,000.

STOCKHOLM, June 17 (AP) -- Prime Minister Per Albin Hansson told Parliament today that instructions for "resistance to the last" in the event of an attack on Sweden had been sent to all Swedish civilian authorities.
"Sure, I've some news! There'll be a new Police Commissioner Monday morning" --

In a brief submitted yesterday to the Office of Civilian Requirements stressing the essential nature of bathing apparel, it was pointed out by Harold Korzenik, counsel to the National :Knitted Outerwear Association, that curtailment of the manufacture of bathing suits and swim trunks would deny to the public many major recreational and health advantages and would result in greater expenditure of textile materials for recreational apparel rather than conservation.

MOSCOW, June 17 (U.P.) -- President Mikhail Kalinin, while saying that religion is a misguiding institution to be strugged against by education, has advised tolerance of religious practices among older Red Army men, such as wearing crosses in battle, it was revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Standard Oil Company of California has agreed to terminate its controversial contract with the Navy for exclusive oil-drilling rights in the naval petroleum reserve at Elk Hills, Calif., and steps will be taken to end the contract, Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, said tonight.

Herbert Morrison, the British Home Secretary, has made a thoroughly convincing statement of his reasons for distrusting the application of the British Communists for affiliation with the Labor party, of which he is one of the leaders:

A blockade will be set up tonight against the pleasure drivers who have been slipping out of town late Friday nights for week-end vacations and returning after midnight Sundays, when most of the Office of Price Administration inspectors had finished their tours of duty.

Japan's rubber-stamp Diet prepared last night to finish the only business of its three-day session -- the empty and foregone approval of eight Cabinet-prepared war bills -- after Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu had told the Japanese legislators of policies he believed would win the support of "even our enemies."
Robert C. Johnson, in 1155 Park Ave, Gresham Realty Co, agents; Samuel Jones, in 105 E 38th St; Miss Marion C. Hansen, in 47 E 72d St -- Brett, Wyckoff, Potter, Hamilton, brokers.

Since musical comedies not infrequently offer mixed blessings, "Early to Bed," which opened last evening at the Broadhurst, is long on body and short on mind. It undoubtedly has the most beautiful chorus in the land, and its costumes and designs definitely are pre-priority, but it also has one of the most tedious books on record.

"Rhythm Parade," a Monogram production, will open today at the Abbey Theatre. Featured in the film are Nils T. Granlund, Gale Storm, Robert Lowery, Cliff Nazarro, Chick Chandler, the Mills Brothers and Ted Fio Rito and his orchestra.

The Economic Stabilization Act and executive orders and directives designed to implement it were characterized yesterday as "cynical devices of rhetoric to fool the people" and keep the public in a constant state of confusion by Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, in testimony before the National Railway Panel's emergency board hearing the demand of five railway unions for wage increases of 30 per cent.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from Zalmon G. Simmons Jr. to H. Walter Mewing and from Leeds Johnson to Philip G. Volpe. On July 1 the board of governors will consider a transfer from Walter S. Buck to Beverley M. Eyre for $40, 000. Mr. Eyre will continue as a partner of Delafield Delafield.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (U.P.) -- Forty major United States aircraft manufacturers have spoken out bluntly against government interference in operation of either domestic or international commercial aviation after the war, it was disclosed tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad was authorized by the Interstate Commerce Commission today to increase fares on its downtown line between Jersey City and Hoboken, N.J., and Hudson Terminal, New York City, from 8 to 9 cents.

The huge financial turnover, due to the second quarter income tax payments and to heavy government disbursements on that date, which included the redemption of government bonds and notes as well as interest payments on government securities, resulted in wide swings in many important items in the weekly Federal Reserve statistics, released yesterday, as of Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Possibility of a jurisdictional clash between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the International Association of Machinists, which recently announced its decision to leave the American Federation of Labor, loomed today when it was reported that the 23-year-old non-aggression pact between the two national unions had been canceled.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 17 (AP) -- Turkey has recalled Behic Erkin, her Ambassador to France, in protest against strong German restrictions on his embassy in Vichy, a Turkish diplomatic source said today.

The remarks of Senator Aiken of Vermont before the Dairymen's League food forum deserve the most careful consideration. His work as a member of the Senate's subcommittee on food, he declares, has convinced him "that the total food production of the United States will probably be off 15 to 30 per cent from last year's record crops."

From the standpoint of a north and south railroad that is naturally interested in the development of industry and commerce on both sides of the Mason and Dixon line, "uniform freight rates are a pretty theory but would not be a pretty practice," according to J.L. Beven, president of the Illinois Central.

Two men accused of threatening former Assistant District Attorney Victor Hurwitz, now counsel for Local 32-B, Building Service Employes International Union, American Federation of Labor, were cleared of the charges yesterday by Magistrate Edmund Palmieri in Yorkville Court.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senators were quick to point out, after the post-war resolution by Representative Fulbright of Arkansas was adopted by the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, that the Senate alone has the power to approve or disapprove treaties. This is the constitutional fact.

LONDON, June 17 (U.P.) -- Rumania's reported peace feelers caused little surprise in well-informed Middle East quarters, advices from Cairo said today. According to these sources, Hungary and Bulgaria have prepared similar tentative feelers in hope of preserving at least part of the territory they have gained since the start of the war.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A five-year plan for increasing food production by an amount sufficient to feed 10,000,000 persons for one year is proposed by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 12 were 28 per cent above sales in the corresponding week a year ago, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed a gain of 2 per cent for the week ended June 5 when compared with the like week of last year.
A composite photograph of the stockholders, management and employes of the Todd Shipyards Corporation ought to produce a face approximately six times as attractive as that of Helen of Troy.

Former Governor Lehman brought some post-war dreams down out of the clouds in his speech in this city last night. The United States, Great Britain, Russia and China have already accepted "a draft agreement for the creation of a United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration through which the productive resources of all the nations of good-will may shortly be mobilized to bring succor to the victims of war."

PITTSBURGH, June 17 (AP) -- Ival Goodman's first homer of the season, a powerful drive that was fair by inches, scored three runs today and gave the Cubs a 3-to-2 victory over the Pirates in an abbreviated seven-inning contest.
LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

The budgetary significance to the taxpayer of huge investments in capital projects, seldom given consideration, has been pointed up sharply in recent studies of this city's finances by competent nonpartisan research groups. First there was the study of the city's debt and capital outlays of the Institute of Public Administration, prepared by Herbert S. Swan, industrial consultant and city planner.

The possibility that the government's parcel post system might be used to circumvent the Office of Defense Transportation's new ban on retail deliveries of small packages in the East created a problem yesterday for which Federal officials had no ready answer.

A breakdown in the cleaning and dyeing service for the 8,000,000 residents of the New York metropolitan area is "imminent" because manpower and machinery facilities of the industry are overworked, it was announced yesterday by the Cleaners and Dyers Board of Trade after a meeting at 223 Second Avenue at which the crisis confronting the industry was discussed.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Dr. Seymour Harris, member of the faculty of Harvard Business School, currently on leave to the Office of Price Administration as head of that war agency's export-import price control, will leave shortly for South America, where he will discuss price controls with officials of the governments of several of the nations there, it was learned today.

Helmut Leiner, who won dismissal of treason charges brought against him as a result of his association with one of the eight Nazi saboteurs who came here by submarine last June, pleaded guilty yesterday to illegal trading with the enemy.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 17 -- In the absence of any action by Premier Mussolini on Monday's nine-point memorandum from the Fascist Directorate, Party Secretary Carlo Scorza has usurped "temporary" dictatorial powers on the internal front, according to reports through private channels received here from Rome tonight.

MEXICO CITY, June 17 -- About 1,000 butchers started a riot this morning in Mexico City's market and had to be dispersed by large police forces with tear gas. Scarcity of meat was said to have been the cause of the disorder, which had no political motive.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Indicating that the conquest of Pantelleria by "concentrated air power," which proved that land objectives could be reduced by crushing air attack, had made a deep impression on Allied military leaders, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson predicted today that this type of warfare "holds great promise for the future."

Installment selling is in great danger of death-dealing blows at the hands of those who do not understand it, Nathan S. Sachs, treasurer of Sachs Quality Furniture, Inc., declared yesterday at the first annual meeting of the Retail Credit Institute of America in the Hotel McAlpin. Mr. Sachs was elected as first president of the group.

F.E. Williamson, president of the New York Central System and chairman of the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, announced after a meeting of the conference yesterday that the anticipated congestion of railroad traffic this summer would be relieved considerably if the flow of travel could be leveled out.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- The White Sox won an overtime game with the Browns today, 4 to 3. Shortstop Luke Appling doubled to send in two runs in the ninth, tying the score, and singled to tally Don Kolloway from second with the winning marker in the thirteenth inning.
Investors bought the bulk of housing properties reported sold in Manhattan yesterday.

A special bronze trophy for the runner scoring the most victories in all the races featuring Gunder Haegg during the Swedish distance star's American tour was placed in competition yesterday by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, chairman of the committee sponsoring the national A.A.U. track and field championships tomorrow and Sunday at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 16 (Delayed) -- Having visited the American Army in training for invasion of Europe and sampled American field rations on the first two days of his North African tour, King George VI of England got around yesterday to inspecting units of the combined British and American Fleet in the Mediterranean and meeting the war correspondents who covered the rout of the Axis in this theatre.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, June 18 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Universal Pictures will produce fifty-five feature films during the 1943-44 season, it was announced here yesterday coincident with the opening of the company's annual three-day sales convention at the Blackstone Hotel in Chicago. Also scheduled for release in the coming season are seven Westerns, three serials, in thirteen chapters each, sixty-seven short subjects and 104 issues of the weekly Universal newsreel.

Bank clearings of the principal cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday were slightly larger than those of the preceding week, while the year-to-year gain narrowed to the smallest recorded for any week since the week ended on March 17, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of the memorandum on the War Labor Disputes Act, presented to President Roosevelt by William Green of the AFL, Philip Murray of the CIO and David B. Robertson of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen :

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Legion of Merit has been awarded to First Lieut. Maude E. Caraway, Merrimon, N.C.; Captain Helena Clearwater, Kingston, N.Y.; First Lieut. Elizabeth A. Pesut, Indianapolis; Second Lieut. Elma L. Asson, Los Angeles, and Second Lieut. Rosalie L. Swenson, Chicago, all of the Army Nurse Corps.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- While some here hope for an official indication of the treatment to be accorded Germany after her surrender, it is generally recognized that Germany forms the major European problem and that the solution will necessarily be far more difficult and perhaps longer delayed than that of the comparatively simple Italian problem.

A stockholders' committee of the Boston Providence Railroad comprising Samuel M. Freeman of Philadelphia, William G. Creamer of Brooklyn and William P. Sheffield of Newport, R.I., has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to intervene in reorganization proceedings of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad before the U.S. District Court of Massachusetts.

LONDON, June 17 -- Royal Air Force planes attacked Cologne again last night, target of the first of the 1,000-plane raids last year, and sustained the great air offensive today with operations highlighted by a damaging attack on an Axis convoy off the Netherlands.

Production of Remington Rand, Inc., last year was at the highest rate in its history, James H. Rand Jr., president and chairman of the board, reported yesterday in the sixteenth annual statement covering the fiscal year ended with March.

Six horses, each of which could have been claimed for $6,000, went to the post in the main event at Aqueduct yesterday, but no one bothered to take any, as Air Current proved fastest in a six-furlong dash over a fast track in 1:11 4-5. Piloted by Johnny Longden, this F. L. Tyler color-bearer was considered a bargain in several paddock discussions, but he went back to the same stable.

A "Dance Overture" by Vincent Persichetti and "Introduction and Allegro" by Herbert Elwell were the winning compositions in the recent annual publication competition of the Juilliard School of Music, it was announced yesterday. The awards, granted to American composers for orchestral compositions, insure the publication of the chosen works.

The Guaranty Trust Company has sold the twelve-story business building at 160-62 East Fifty-sixth Street to Frederick Brown, the operator. The building, which is on a plot 50 by 100.5 feet, is said to have been fully occupied for the last five years and was sold through Harold M. Silverman, broker. Leading tenants of the building include Hammacher, Schlemmer Co., the Coleman Galleries and the Guildhall Galleries of London.

ALGIERS, June 17 -- Thirteen members of the French Committee of National Liberation met today under the chairmanship of Gen. Henri Honore Giraud in an effort to break the deadlock existing between Gen. Charles de Gaulle and General Giraud on army reorganization, a deadlock that has threatened the life of the committee itself.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- Premier Joseph Stalin's message yesterday to the conference of the Union of Polish Patriots in the U.S.S.R. is regarded as especially significant in that, by implication, it places his stamp of approval on the Polish Union, which is in bitter opposition to the refugee Polish Government in Exile.

Footwear selling at $7 and over has experienced a sales gain of about 25 to 40 per cent, while the call for shoes between $6 and $7 has gained 15 per cent, according to a survey of the effects of shoe rationing just completed by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Problems of food and point rationing will be solved in part for the consumer by the newly revitalized New York City Nutrition Program, it was announced yesterday by Dr. David Rutstein, executive secretary of that organization, who is also Deputy Health Commissioner.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17 -- A suit seeking treble damages of $24,838 from two partners in a wholesale produce concern on the ground they exceeded ceiling prices in selling 494,500 pounds of white potatoes from March 30 to April 30 was filed here today in the United States District Court by attorneys from the area headquarters of the Office of Price Administration.

FRANK GERVASI has followed the action of this war, political as well as military, pretty well around the world as a roving reporter for Collier's magazine. He has written vigorously of what he has seen and heard. Like other reporters, he feels that a good deal of opinion and observation which had no place in his articles should not remain hidden away in his diaries and journals.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission presented to the commission today its view that management should not be permitted to realize any benefits from purchases of securities during the pendency of a corporation reorganization as a "necessary step in the protection of the public interest and the interest of public investors."

A thorough-going inquiry into the affairs of the Department of Investigation seemed in prospect last night as the City Council committee named to investigate the La Guardia administration awaited delivery of records on all cases handled by the department since June 1, 1940.

CLEVELAND, June 17 (AP) -- Mike Rocco's fly scored Manager Lou Boudreau in the twelfth inning to give the Indians a 6-to-5 triumph over the Tigers tonight in the second game of a twilight-night double-header. Cleveland staged a ninth-inning uprising to win the opener, 3 to 2.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- The wheat market was weak today and showed but little recovery from the low spots of the day. Commission support was nearly a minus quantity at times and, with scattered local selling and small hedge sales, the tone was heavy throughout the session.

On June 7 Representative Gossett of Texas introduced in the House H.R. 2893. This bill would: (1) Repeal Chinese exclusion laws and the Immigration Treaty which preceded them; (2) Place Chinese immigration on a quota basis, giving a preference of 75 per cent of the quota (approximately 107 annually) to those Chinese born and resident in China; (3) Repeal the laws which deny Chinese the right to become citizens of the United States.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Publication of "Principles of Peace," an 894-page volume containing the peace pronouncements of five Popes in the last sixty-five years and described as "a practical guide for the peacemakers who will seek to give the world a lasting and just peace," was announced today by the Most Rev. Samuel A. Stritch, Archbishop of Chicago.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- Their four-game winning streak snapped by Manuel Salvo's four-hit pitching, which gave the Braves a 2-0 victory, the Phillies pummeled three Boston pitchers for a 7-2 triumph in the second game of a swing-shift doubleheader today before 7,379.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Navy communique 414:

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A proposed "honor system" under which retailers would agree to see that the scarce merchandise they have is distributed equitably to all customers was placed before a committee of department, specialty and chain store executives here today at a conference called by the WPB's Office of Civilian Requirements.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed a decrease of $9,509,000 in holdings of United States Government securities during the week.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- One of the most significant developments in the Red Army during its two years of violent warfare against the Axis has been the emergence of a new set of outstanding military leaders who have been tempered and proved in the furnace of battle.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., June 17 (AP) -- Pete Cawthon, assistant football coach at the University of Alabama, said today he had been named head coach of the Dodgers of the National Football League and would leave to assume his new duties immediately.

A country-wide series of regional conferences will be inaugurated on Monday by the National Association of Manufacturers to prepare post-war plans for industry, Wilfred Sykes, president of the organization, announced yesterday, He said that the group regards the conferences as of utmost importance because "the practical answers to hundreds of realistic problems formulated by our post-war committee can only be expected to come from individual enterprises and local communities."
Mr. and Mrs. Fitz Eugene Dixon have come to the Waldorf-Astoria from Elkins Park, Pa.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 17 -- Swift Mosquito bombers from Malta ranged over a wide area of Sicily and Southern Italy last night, shooting up railway and military installations, while long-range fighters from the Middle East sank three sailing vessels in an Aegean island harbor, it was announced today.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 17 (AP) -- Relaxing of State restrictions on their loans to mortgagors was urged by the State League of Savings and Loan Associations today to create incentive for "adequate maintenance" of real property.

The five-story apartment house at 2250 Grand Concourse has been sold by Berjac Realties, Inc., to Alois Dunst. The property is assessed at $70,000. Nathan Berk was the broker, George V. Grainger represented the buyer and Schiff, Dorfman, Stein Brof acted for the sellers. Title was insured by the Lawyers Title Corporation of New York.

BOSTON, June 17 -- Mrs. Hazel M. Babylon's Abbe Pierre scored his second handicap victory of the Sufolk Downs meeting today, capturing the $5,000 added Bunker Hill, at one mile, in the fastest time of the New England season, 1:37 1-5.

The strains of the bridal march rang in the ballroom of the Women's Military Service Club, once the Whitelaw Reid mansion, yesterday afternoon, giving a real flavor to the bridal showing held by Saks Fifth Avenue. The occasion was a press viewing that served as well as a rehearsal for the formal presentation that will be held on the afternoon of Saturday, June 19, for members of the club.

LONDON, June 17 -- The British Labor party, which is wholeheartedly in favor of prosecuting the war against the enemies of democracy, precipitated a vociferous chorus of indignation in the minority of its ranks today by adopting a resolution identifying the "overwhelming mass" of the German people with the spirit of Nazi aggression.

The technique of malingering on the job by men and women union workers, even after a three-day strike had been called off June 5 at the Brooks Costume Company at 1160 Sixth Avenue, was revealed yesterday by Assistant District Attorney Alexander Dreiband after Louis Hollander, who had called the strike, has been released in $5,000 bail in the Felony Court on two extortion charges.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Sir Owen Dixon, Australian Minister to the United States, reported today on his return from a trip to his homeland that the populace there apparently was reconciled to the United Nations' strategy of defeating Germany first.

Proposals that the New York Stock Exchange admit corporations as members have been defeated for the second time. The Exchange conducted a poll of the membership and found the verdict two to one against. Accordingly, the board of governors will not even be asked to act on the suggestion.
THE TIMES this morning discussed the confusion in the budget cuts and I write this letter to clarify the situation.

It is difficult to understand the varied emotions that the proposed anti-strike and other labor legislation seems to arouse. When industry was young it was quite natural to protect it from foreign competition, and high tariffs ensued. When industry grew strong enough to compete with foreign markets high tariffs became unnecessary, and they should be reduced correspondingly as industry increases in strength.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- In authoritative quarters here it was assumed that the objective of the heavy Japanese air attacks on Guadalcanal must have been one of utmost importance to the enemy and bearing directly on future developments of the war.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- Testimony about secret hoards of food stocks, some of which the witness said he thought had been traded by Japanese for whisky and chickens, was given a Dies Congressional subcommittee by Earl A. Best, a former employe of the Heart Mountain relocation center in Wyoming.

Reporting on operations for 1942, Juan T. Trippe, president of the Pan American Airways Corporation, informed stockholders yesterday that the year had been the most important financially in the fifteen-year history of the corporation, with total business in excess of $109,000,000, representing the world-wide operations of the system, both civil and military.

In selecting Robert T. Lansdale as one of its commissioners, to succeed the late Mr. Adie, the New York State Board of Social Welfare has made a fortunate choice. With a wealth of experience in private and public welfare work Mr. Lansdale can bring vision and strength to the board.

Those monetary experts of Allied nations who have participated in the initial discussions at Washington on the relative merits of the White and Keynes plans for international post-war currency adjustments have given these plans a better reception than they received from American and British commentators, in the opinion of Dr. A. Perren, former Professor of Banking and Finance at the University of Neuchatel, Switzerland, and vice president of the Swiss Government's Banking Commission.
The six-family dwelling at 347 Littleton Avenue, Newark, has been sold to Dora Sokoloff by the Falcon Building and Loan Association through Michael A. Stavitsky Co.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt's advisers, working on an anti-inflation program, are making a thorough study of that part of the British subsidy system which involves government control of the entire market for critical cost-of-living commodities.

Prizes totaling $800 in war bonds were awarded yesterday to artists who have participated in the cartoons on absenteeism contest. Many of the country's leading cartoonists submitted work for this exhibition, which is now on view at 535 Fifth Avenue.

Rabbi Irving Miller, member of the governing council of the American Jewish Congress and secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, who has returned from a three-month visit to London, said yesterday the feeling prevailed in British government and church circles as well as among representatives of exiled governments that the Jewish problem must be dealt with immediately.

BEAUMONT, Texas, June 17 (AP) Col. Sidney C. Mason, commander of State troops enforcing martial law in this city of 100,000, warned shipyard workers today to refrain from any action that would revive tension in the race situation which yesterday took two lives and injured scores.

Prof. Vladimir V. Lebedenko, one of the leading surgeons of the Soviet Union and present representative of the Russian Red Cross and Red Crescent to the United States, inspected the Red Cross Blood Donors' Center, 2 East Thirty-seventh Street, yesterday.
Storm clouds are blowing up in the South Pacific; all the signs yesterday indicated that some offensive operations were impending -- perhaps by either side.

CHICAGO, June 17 -- Seven specific suggestions to retailers for curtailing services in order to merit consideration for manpower assistance were outlined here today by Donald R. Longman, chief of the distribution branch in the WPB's Office of Civilian Requirements, at the closing session of the three-day wartime conference of the Controllers Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, charged today that Congressional criticism of his assertion that Washington news was inadequately reported was based on parts of his recent Boston speech rather than the whole.

BOSTON, June 17 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild today voted to accept a minority report calling upon the Guild to assume "responsibility for exposing actions of the press destructive to the war efofrt and opposite to the best interests of the American people."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Labor members of the War Labor Board may have to withdraw from it in view of the Connally-Smith bill's injunction against board members participating in decisions in which they are directly interested, according to a statement submitted to President Roosevelt today by Philip Murray of the Congress of Industrial Organizations; William Green of the American Federation of Labor, and David B. Robertson of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- In the most devastating single air battle yet to take place in the South Pacific, United States fliers shot down seventy-seven Japanese bombers and Zero fighters over Guadalcanal yesterday (Solomons time), with a loss of only six of their own planes, the Navy Department reported in a communique today.

LONDON, Friday, June 18 (AP) -- The Red Army was reported officially early today to have smashed repeated German efforts to regain lost positions north of Orel for the fourth straight day yesterday, but the enemy is throwing fresh troops into action in this sector, where the Germans have been expected to launch a summer offensive.

Because of the unsettled condition of the weather, the opening concert of the Stadium Concerts season, scheduled for last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, at which Mayor La Guardia was slated to dedicate the new stage, was postponed until tonight at 8:30.

In contrast to the experience a year ago when agencies were just coming to the end of a period marked by indecision on the part of advertisers, campaigns are now being approved rapidly and most of the large accounts have accepted agency schedules laid out until the end of the year.

In order to facilitate the transition to peacetime industrial operations the War Production Board should permit the construction of new plants for civilian production now, David C. Prince, vice president of the General Electric Company and chairman of the industrial advisory board of the Committee for Economic Development, suggested yesterday.
LONDON, June 17 -- Great Britain is "forging a great amphibious weapon for the future," Vice Admiral Lord Louis Mountbatten, Chief of Combined Operations, said in a speech tonight.

Dr. David J. Kaliski, director of workmen's compensation in the State and New York County Medical Societies, told the Moreland Commission yesterday that the societies were taking immediate action to eradicate the kickback system among physicians handling compensation cases.

JUDGING from the way the newspapers have been handling the story, it almost seems as if Gunder Haegg will be running a solo exhibition at the National A.A.U. track and field championships on Sunday. Gunder has captured all the space and only casual mention has been made of all the other stalwarts who will be running, jumping and heaving the hardware at Triborough Stadium.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 17 -- A Finnish Government proposal to grant farmers State subsidies on agricultural produce came before the Riksdag today and caused a rumpus between Social Democrats and Agrarians, with the latter threatening to resign from the Cabinet if the bill is not passed.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Although construction volume increased in synthetic rubber, non-ferrous metals and 100-octane gasoline industries, the total construction volume in the country decreased 2 per cent from March to April and probably continued this trend in May, the War Production Board announced today.

SUMMIT, N.J., June 17 -- The shrinking shrimp case got an airing tonight before Police Judge Peter C. Triolo, and the defendant, Harry Seltzner, operator of a fish market at 444 Springfield Avenue, was fined $25 and costs on a charge of shortweighting Mrs. James R. Boyle of 112 Ashland Road, the complainant.

When Edsel Ford died and Henry Ford had to reorganize his company's board of directors there was a good deal of discussion of changes in "the Ford Empire." Metaphors comparing a business man with a monarch have become common. But the business man is not sovereign.
Sixteen fleets of the International Star Class Yacht Racing Association have sent challenges for the world championship of the class, which will be held on Great South Bay at Bay Shore, Aug. 24-29.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, June 18 (AP) -- Forty Japanese planes raided the area of Bena Bena, ninety miles northwest of Lae, yesterday for the third straight enemy strike at that sector, the High Command announced.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Live hogs were steady to strong today with the top price unchanged at $14. Better grades of beef also ruled steady to strong, but medium quality offerings were dull Lambs were active and closed stronger. The day's reports of the live stock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 17 -- Four women arrested Monday in raids on the headquarters in New Rochelle and North Pelham of an alleged interstate abortion ring were indicted here this afternoon by a Westchester County grand jury on charges of performing illegal abortions on patients from New Jersey, Connecticut and communities of this State.

Exploiting an ancient theory of never giving a bewildered foe time to collect his wits, the amazing Giants swarmed all over the Dodgers at the Polo Grounds yesterday and made a clean sweep of the three-game series by drubbing Lippy Leo Durocher's careening pennant contenders, 8 to 5.

Price-fixing by the trade in the near positions yesterday halted a five-day losing spell in the cotton futures market. This support, the sole feature of the very dull trading, raised the list of active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange to final net gains of 6 to 8 points, the session's best prices.
LONDON, June 17 (AP) -- Note circulation increased 2,569,000 during the week ended yesterday, the Bank of England reported today.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora awarded $40,000 yesterday to former Governor Charles Poletti as a fee for services as referee in the accounting proceedings to determine the disposition of funds held by the International Committee of Bankers on Mexico.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Treasury, which a week ago was asking for $16,000,000,000 of new taxes this year, has now lowered its goal to $12,000,000,000, and does not expect that the new income taxes, relied upon to produce part of it, will become effective in 1943.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- With further rises in prices for agricultural commodities in primary markets, particularly grains, fruits and vegetables, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index again advanced 0.1 per cent during the week ended June 12.

LONDON, June 17 (U.P.) -- Italian propagandists reported today that the Allies were sending scores of invasion barges to the stepping stone island of Pantelleria and estimated that 5,000 planes, more than 1,000,000 of the best American and British troops, and more than half the British fleet were poised for action in the Mediterranean and on its North African shores.

ALGIERS, June 15 (Delayed) -- I was on the deck of an American flagship when King George VI came aboard today following a quayside inspection of the personnel of British and American naval and merchant marine units in Mediterranean waters.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- During the week ended on June 16 member bank reserve balances increased $346,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The additions to member bank reserves arose from increases of $91,000,000 in reserve bank credit and $2,000,000 in Treasury currency and decreases of $169,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve banks, $48,000,000 in money in circulation and $37,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts.
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 17 -- With play in the singles at a stand-still, the semi-finals of the doubles were held today in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Montclair A.C.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The action of the House in including in the labor-Federal security appropriation bill, passed yesterday, a provision that no part of the funds appropriated for the National Labor Relations Board "shall be used in any way in connection with a complaint case arising over an agreement between management and labor which has been in existence three months or longer without a complaint being filed," was denounced today by NLRB.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 17 -- The Marine Dining Room in the West Bathhouse, one of the most popular of the resort's restaurants, will become a clubhouse of the United Service Organizations beginning Saturday, it was announced today after a meeting of the Nassau County USO and officials of the Long Island State Park Commission.

Katharine Cornell and John C. Wilson have formed a new producing alliance for the production of Miss Cornell's next starring vehicle "Lovers and Friends," described as "a romantic drama" by Dodie Smith. Specifically, it concerns a British couple whose marriage is temporarily disrupted by a third party.

An order directing bakers to increase further the vitamin content of white bread has been prepared by the War Food Administration in consultation with the baking industry and will be officially promulgated shortly, perhaps today, it was disclosed yesterday.

An increase of 15 per cent in the number of gifts from business concerns and professional groups in the current campaign of the Greater New York Fund was reported yesterday by officials of that organization at a luncheon in the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- The successful production of alcohol for synthetic rubber and explosives from sulphite liquor, formerly a waste by-product in the manufacture of newsprint and other papers, was announced today by the Ontario Paper Company, a subsidiary of The Chicago Tribune.
LONDON, June 17 -- The tone of the stock markets here was firm today and business was slightly more active than it has been recently.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Roosevelt met with the Cabinet and talked with a group from Arkansas, including Senators Hattie W. Caraway and John L. McClellan, on flood damage to roads in the State; his visitors included Representative Henry M. Jackson, Ambassador Spruille Braden and Basil O'Connor, with Nicholas Schenck.

The John Wesley Hyatt Award of a gold medal and $1,000, given annually for outstanding achievement in the plastics industry, was presented last night at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel to Frank H. Shaw, president of the Shaw Insulator Company, Irvington, N.J., for his development of the process known as transfer molding of plastics.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- John B. Hawley Jr., manufacturer of war machinery, told the House Naval Committee today that he began preparations for war long before Pearl Harbor, but was now being penalized for his foresight through downward adjustment of his profits.

MOSCOW, Friday, June 18 (U.P.) -- War and the Working Classes, an influential Communist labor publication, in a bitter condemnation of strikes in American war industries, today attacked John L. Lewis, William L. Hutcheson and Matthew Woll as "reactionary" labor leaders who are "misleading" workers into unpatriotic, anti-war strikes.
NEW DELHI, India, June 17 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

BERNE, Switzerland, Juno 17 -- With a sudden change of tactics German propaganda in France is now spreading the idea that the awaited Allied attack on Fortress Europe might be forestalled by an assault on Britain. Private sources indicate that this possibility has been held out to Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, who is at present in Paris on one of his periodical visits from Vichy.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- If Allied forces attacking Italy dropped two-ton block buster bombs on the volcanic craters of Mount Etna, Sicily, and of Mount Vesuvius, on the Bay of Naples, there is a 1-to-3,000,000 or 4,000,000,000 chance that they would erupt, Dr. Gerald F. Loughlin, chief geologist of the Geographical Survey, said in a report to the Secretary of the Interior.
LONDON, Friday, June 18 (U.P.) -- The Russian midnight communique as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

What about ammunition next Fall? Sportsmen have been discussing that topic at some length and many heated arguments have resulted. The conclusions usually reached are much in accord with what the Alabama Department of Conservation has just endorsed in the following statement:

DETROIT June 17 (AP) -- Defending champion Seymour Greenberg of Chicago and Billy Talbert, top seeded, of Cincinnati led the unbroken advance of favorites today into the quarter-finals of the national clay courts tennis championships.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as chairman of the New York Victory Fund Committee, which is now in process of being "disestablished" in favor of the recently organized War Finance Committee, issued a communication yesterday to all members of the former committee formally announcing the resignation of Perry E. Hall as executive manager, immediately effective.

Prices for stocks again registered limited gains as the list attempted further to recoup the inroads of the Monday assault, but demand proved too light to bring a decisive trend. Business on the Stock Exchange, in fact, was the smallest in almost two months as volume dropped to 740,670 shares compared with 877,010 shares on Wednesday.
The word "closed" was entered yesterday in the Police Department's bulky dossier on Reynolds Forsbrey, a murderous little man whose name has been department legend the last three decades.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Charges that the Federal Price Control law has been interpreted and enforced primarily to control and limit profits rather than prices were placed before a House committee today, supported with documents from the so-called secret files of David Ginsburg, former general counsel of the Office of Price Administration.

NEWARK, N.J., June 17 -- A charge of murder was lodged here today against a 15-year-old boy after the police and Prosecutor William A. Wachenfeld of Essex County had held a two-hour conference to discuss the accusation in view of the suspect's age, which makes him subject to the State Juvenile Delinquency Law.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The question of a nation-wide shutdown of bituminous and anthracite coal mines on Monday hinged tonight on a decision discussed by the public members of the War Labor Board on the puzzling portal-to-portal issue.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP) -- Manager Billy Southworth of the Cardinals, who picks the spots for Pitcher Howard Krist, chose a rough one today for the tall right-hander, who was beaten, 6 to 1, by the Reds.
CHICAGO, June 17 -- Civilians will get more pork and the Army and Navy will get more beef under the War Meat Board's plans for allocating the meat supply, Harry E. Reed, board chairman, said tonight.
