Two girl psychology students, wide-eyed at the unusual experience, were the only spectators in General Sessions Court at 6:30 o'clock last night when John Scheer, 18-year-old hold-up man, was found guilty by a jury of murder in the first degree in the killing of one of his robbery victims.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- While everything possible should be done to stress "toughness" in pre-combat training of American ground troops, the present program is essentially sound, three staff officers of the Ground Forces who inspected American troops on the North African battlefront have reported to the War Department.

The critical food situation facing the nation in the next year can be relieved by the Victory gardener whose efforts this summer will determine whether food shortages will be merely uncomfortable or grave next winter, according to Paul C. Stark, president of the National Victory Garden Institute.

Details of the sales of two of the largest apartment buildings in East Orange, N.J., were revealed yesterday by Frank H. Taylor Son, Inc., brokers, who arranged the financing for both deals. Both purchases were made by "out-of-town" syndicates, one from Massachusetts and the other from New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 -- The history of the motion-picture industry from the days of the Nickleodeon will be shown in a picture to be made by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer under the title "The First Fifty Years." The film, one of the company's big undertakings of the coming year, will be produced by Dore Schary.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A serious decline in lead production is faced by the nation as a result of manpower shortages and other factors, the War Production Board announced today. The war agency gave out an optimistic statement on lead production prospects a short time ago.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 18 -- As titular chief of the nation's defense, Premier Mussolini tonight decreed the entire southern end of the Italian peninsula a "zone of operations under martial law" in an ordinance printed in the Gazzetta Ufficiale.

The six-story apartment building, with a frontage of 450 feet, at 765 Riverside Drive, corner of West 155th Street, has been sold by the Audubon Park Realty Corporation, Nathan H. Brandt, president, to Joseph Berger. It was erected by the seller and contains 397 rooms.

Retail trade continued notably active here this week, the general picture being about as favorable as in the preceding week. Department-sotre volume was estimated as running around 30 per cent above the comparative week last year.

As the Japanese House of Representatives "unanimously approved" a resolution reaffirming the "gravity" of the war situation in view of expected "fierce counter-attacks" by the Allies, the Tokyo radio reported yesterday that the Eighty-second Diet had concluded the business of its three-day special session, convoked to rubber-stamp legislation prepared by Premier Hideki Tojo's government.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Expecting a new crisis in the coal industry as a result of the War Labor Board's rejection of the miners' principal demands, leaders within the Administration today were urging that President Roosevelt sign without further delay the War Labor Disputes Bill as passed by Congress a week ago.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The dissenting opinion by the labor members of the War Labor Board in the soft coal wage dispute follows:

The Artist Associates, 138 West Fifteenth Street, will open tomorrow at 2 P.M. an exhibition and sale of selected works in exchange for war bonds and stamps. The exhibition will be open daily, including Sundays, from 2 to 6 P.M.; and, on Mondays and Thursdays until 10 P.M.

LONDON, June 18 -- The crisis of the Yugoslav Government in Exile, which came to a head yesterday with the acceptance by King Peter of the resignation of Premier Slobodan Yovanovitch and his Cabinet, will probably take several days to resolve, it was indicated today.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia helped to dedicate the new stage at the Lewisohn Stadium last night as the twenty-sixth season of outdoor concerts there opened and paid his respects to the city's department stores and to "the lousy politicians."

CHICAGO, Saturday, June 19 (AP) -- The Indians scored two runs on four singles in the fourteenth inning shortly after midnight to win a 5-to-3 duel with the White Sox. Vern Kennedy, who pitched shut-out ball after taking the mound in the seventh, was the winning pitcher.

BUENOS AIRES, June 18 -- Gen. Pedro Ramirez' government issued a decree tonight suspending Presidential elections scheduled for Sept. 5, and also banned the word "provisional" in referring to the present government.
Baseball is going to war in a big way, according to an announcement from Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis relayed to the press yesterday by President Ford Frick of the National League.

CHUNGKING, China, June 18 (U.P.) -- The Japanese slaughtered 15,000 civilians and 5,000 wounded Chinese prisoners before evacuating Nanhsien on the northwestern shore of Tungting Lake last week, the Central News Agency said today.

Today's events: Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Fritz Reiner, with Albert Spalding, violin soloist, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P.M.; Joseph Victor Laderoute, tenor, and Paul Wittgenstein, piano, in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Goldman Band, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, 8:30; "Rigoletto," Salmaggi Opera Company, Brooklyn Academy of Music, evening.

" I WISH we'd start winning again," said Bob Quinn with an unhappy shake of his head. "I've seen all the clubs in the league and I'm convinced that the Braves were in their proper place in the standings when they were in the first division. We've a far better team than most people suspect."
The executive committee of the Christian Council on Palestine at a meeting yesterday in its headquarters, 70 Fifth Avenue, voted to enlarge the committee which numbers 400.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Congress today gave the National Resources Planning Board, author of the "American Beveridge Plan" for post-war social security, until Aug. 31 to liquidate itself and allowed $50,000 for that purpose.

Christopher La Farge will receive the A.C. Benson Silver Medal today, presented on behalf of the Royal Society of Literature, for his novel in verse, "Each to the Other," published by Coward-McCann. Mr. La Farge has gone to Washington to receive the award from Lord Halifax, the British Ambassador to the United States.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 18 -- As the result of frugality on the putting greens, Frank Simonson and his partner Bert Braun, member of the almost adjoining Garden City Country Club, tied Harry Leiser and W. Neal Fulkerson of the Garden City Golf Club in the qualifying round of the Cherry Valley Club's annual member-guest tourney, each pair posting a best-ball card of 69, three under par.

Despite the growing shortage of manpower and the extra burdens placed on commercial banks by the banking of ration coupons, the nation's banks contemplate no reductions in hours, such as closing on Saturdays during the summer months.

NEW DELHI, India, Saturday, June 19 (U.P.) -- The appointment of Field Marshal Sir Archibald Wavell as Viceroy of India insures a continuation of the policy followed by his predecessor, the Marquess of Linlithgow, and may be taken as confirmation that the question of India's future status is shelved for the duration, observers said today.

Eddie Dowling, presently convalescing in his Long Island home from an illness which he describes as "nothing that a hit couldn't cure," is interested in a play by Sam F. Hoffman called "So Much for Music." Although no commitments have been consummated as yet, Mr. Dowling reports that the play may easily turn out to be his next fall production.

Net sales of the United States Industrial Alcohol Company for its fiscal year ended with March, established a new high record for the second successive year with a total volume of $29,727,966. This represents an increase of 7 per cent over the $27,746,241 net sales for the preceding year, according to the annual report issued yesterday by Glenn L. Haskell, president.

Gross revenues of $13,627,140 in May by the Erie Railroad were the largest of any month in that road's history, Robert E. Woodruff, president, said yesterday following the directors' meeting in Cleveland.

A warning to the American public against expecting "fantastic, radical, war-borne dream products to become actual realities in the immediate post-war period" was sounded yesterday by T.J. Newcomb, sales manager of the Westinghouse Electrical Appliance Division, at a meeting for newspaper and magazine writers at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A tidal wave of romance and sentimentality is inundating the bridal salons. June brides of 1943 are going in for all the trappings of ultra-feminine appeal in their wedding gowns. And the men love it. White may be traditional but it looks new and wonderful when "she" wears it.
Of the nation's total population, 50.3 per cent are church members, the highest percentage ever reported, according to the 1943 Yearbook of American Churches, published today.

NEWTON, N.J., June 18 -- The entire six-man crew of an Army medium bomber perished last night when their plane, apparently struck by lightning during a thunderstorm, fell in flames in a cornfield seven miles west of here. Identification of the six, two flying officers and four enlisted men, was withheld pending notification of the next of kin.

June bridegrooms are wearing uniforms this year. Bronzed soldiers, fresh in their summer suntan outfits; erect, self-conscious marines, and trim blue and white clad sailors, with girls by their sides, fill every available seat in the Marriage License Bureau.
LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as braodcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., a holding company which controls textile merchandising organizations, mills and finishing plants, filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration covering a proposed issue of $6,000,000 of 5 per cent cumulative preferred stock with a par value of $100 a share.

In closing, as far as we are concerned, the discussion started by Arthur Upham Pope over our criticism of the film "Mission to Moscow." may we comment upon a single point contained in the letter of Mr. Pope in your issue of June 12?

Net profit of the National Theatres Corporation and its subsidiaries for the fifty-two weeks ended on Dec. 26, 1942, amounted to $3,382,015, nearly $1,000,000 above earnings of $2,397,246 in the previous fiscal year and comparing with $2,037,178 earned in 1940, according to the proxy statement of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, which is asking stockholders to permit the borrowing of $13,000,000 to purchase 58 per cent of the National shares from the Chase National Bank.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Slightly more than a month after President Roosevelt's April 8 statement on inflation in which he declared "all items affecting the cost of living are to be brought under control," nearly 60 per cent of the average American family's budget remained the same, but food prices rose 1.7 per cent and the total cost of living for city workers increased 0.8 per cent, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins announced today.

LONDON, Saturday, June 19 (U.P.) -- Germany has ceased her costly counter-attacks north of Orel and is massing fresh reserves after losing 2,000 men killed in vain attempts to win back territory the Red Army captured there, the Russian Friday midnight communique reported today.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia warned some 10,000,000 residents of the New York metropolitan area yesterday afternoon that the long expected meat famine had arrived. In a nine-minute broadcast from City Hall over six radio stations he appealed to the public "to go very easy on the purchase of meat, particularly beef, this week and during the next week."
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In a surge of bitterness against policies of the Office of Price Administration and the Office of War Information, the House voted tonight:

Though the Lewisohn Stadium opening had to be delayed for a day, the season, when it did open last night, got off to a cheerful start. There were 14,00 paying guests in the amphitheatre. The New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra was on hand, and in fine fettle, thanks in part to the first rate leadership of Fritz Reiner.

The New York City Defense Recreation Committee, 99 Park Avenue (at Fortieth Street), through the generosity of the entertainment world offers a partial list of free amusements and recreational activities available today.
RICHMOND, Va., June 18 -- Developments in aviation and organic chemistry led the field among the 638 patents listed as issued in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office here.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 18 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, little Ecuadorian who represents the University of Miami, and Robert Wasserman of Ohio State reached the final of the Eastern Intercollegiate tennis championship today at the Montclair A.C.

There has been no serious attempt by the Office of Price Administration to control rising living costs or to curb inflation since the spring of 1942, A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, asserted yesterday when he appeared as a witness before the Emergency Board of the National Railway Panel now conducting hearings on the 30 per cent wage demand of railroad workers.
CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- The task of providing meat for the armed forces and civilians encountered fresh problems today.

ST. LOUIS, June 18 (AP) -- The Cardinals looked nothing like the 1942 world champions, for becoming which they received gold rings tonight, in losing to the Cubs. Chicago scored four runs in the seventh inning without a hit, breaking a tie, and counted again in the ninth to win, 6 to 1.

President Roosevelt has just signed a supplemental lend-lease appropriation act increasing aid to our allies by another $6,273,629,000. Simultaneously, new proposals have been submitted to the Russian Government providing for a continuation of and substantial increase in lend-lease shipments to its armies and people after the present protocol expires at the end of this month.

NEWARK, N.J., June 18 (AP) -- Buffalo scored its eighth victory in nine starts by defeating Newark tonight, 8 to 3. Rufe Gentry allowed only five safeties. He walked ten, but fanned nine and left fourteen Bears on the bases.

With many uncertainties in regard to subsidies on agricultural products and the probable size and quality of the new cotton crop still confronting traders, virtual stagnancy prevailed yesterday in the cotton futures market. Only routine trade business was promulgated on the New York Cotton Exchange as the list of active contracts closed unchanged to 2 points lower, after moving with a 5-point range throughout the listless trading.

The Bear Mountain boats and other oil-burning vessels which make train and bus connections in the vacation country will be permitted to keep running, but excursion craft which make only sightseeing or moonlight outings will be denied fuel oil, Frank C. Russell, New York district director of the Office of Price Administration, ruled yesterday.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Buying of wheat for flour mills offset today what little hedge pressure there was in the market for that grain on the Board of Trade and prices had a rather firm undertone. The support from mills stimulated some local buying and prices at the close were up 1/8 to 5/8 cent a bushel on the day.
DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- The Browns hammered three pitchers for fourteen hits good for twenty-six bases in a twilight contest tonight to take the opener of a four-game series with the Tigers, 7 to 4.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The War Labor Board decision in the soft-coal wage dispute follows:

To help solve the increasing shortage of canned fruits and vegetables in New York City, a can-your-own-food movement was launched yesterday by the Consumer Division of the Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization at the International Center of the Young Women's Christian Association, 341 East Seventeenth Street

NEWARK, N.J., June 18 (AP) -- Vice Chancellor John O. Bigelow has set June 29 as the date for argument on a move by the Canadian Mining Reporter and its editor, John H. Roberts, to throw out of court the New Jersey Attorney General's suit to restrain the trade journal from doing business in this state.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The United States turned out a total of 7,200 planes of all types in May, the War Production Board made known today. It added that the figure, a record, would be "substantially larger" for June.

WHITEHORSE, Yukon Territory, June 18 -- After months of military secrecy, a wartime Army project that rivals the Alaskan Military Highway in scope and importance, and brings the military value of that highway to full fruition, has been revealed.

An apartment of twelve rooms and five baths has been leased in 120 East End Avenue by James M. Wareham, and Harry L. Bailey, president of the Wellington Sears Company, has rented an apartment in 350 Park Avenue, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., brokers.

Interest in the stock market died down yesterday to a mere simmer as the few remaining active traders of importance narrowed their activity to the minimum. Prices turned narrowly irregular and the number of issues to alter their values were almost balanced, up and down.

The bottle barge, each one of which releases for the haulage of Navy supplies fourteen large trailer trucks which formerly made wholesale deliveries of soft drinks, has joined the commercial flotilla of New York Harbor as a result of the gasoline shortage.

LONDON, June 18 (AP) -- Reopening of the Turkish-Syrian frontier by Britain and Axis reports of large Allied troop concentrations in Syria boosted enemy worry today over the shaky "Southeastern Wall" in the Balkans, where the Germans were said to have sent strong reinforcements.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 18 (AP) -- Rochester handed Jersey City its fifth straight defeat in a twilight game tonight, 10 to 0. The Red Wings battered Bill Voiselle, Little Giant starter, for seven runs on as many hits in the first three innings and picked up eight hits and three additional runs against Bob Wells, who finished.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Chester C. Davis, War Food Administrator, has told White House advisers, it was disclosed today, that the present government food program is not working satisfactorily and is in danger of collapse unless steps are taken soon to eliminate divided authority and to allow more flexibility in price control.

Father's Day will be celebrated tomorrow in churches of the city by fathers honoring their sons rather than being honored, the day having more significance this year in religious life than heretofore because thousands of fathers have sons in the armed forces.

Fred L. Soufert, 40 years old, who stole about $50,000 in coffee tea and rice from his former employers, S.A. Schonbrunn Co. Inc., importers at 77 Water Street to operate a black market in Queens, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to a Sing Sing term of eighteen months to three years on his recent guilty plea.

As a result of this week's conferences with food wholesalers and retailers, the Office of Price Administration is likely to revive the so-called "over-all" regulation originally planned for the trade, providing a single system of percentage margins, it was reported yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which long has been the official collector of statistics on the commercial paper market throughout the country, reported yesterday that the volume of open market commercial paper outstanding at the end of May was $159,600,000.

The gravity of the situation in the laundry industry in this and neighboring areas, where many laundries have closed within the last few weeks and most of the others have curtailed services drastically because of a labor shortage, showed no signs of improvement yesterday.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 18 -- Rationing on a social basis is Vichy's latest device to meet ever-increasing complaints in France that those with slender means get very little food, according to an indication given at Paris by Agriculture Minister Max Bonnafous, it was known today.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) -- Professional football's most critical meeting and in some respects its most unusual -- opens a two-day run tomorrow with three or four owners wavering about starting the 1943 season and at least five outsiders bidding for new franchises.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown denied today that "individual officials in OPA are out to use price control to change the American system of free enterprise."

LONDON, June 18 -- Operators in Kaffir mining shares received announcements today of dividends in the Anglo-American group. Results of these, compared with December, are: Brakpan, 5/8s, against 1s; Daggafontein, 1s 2 1/2d against 1s 4 1/2d; East Daggafontein, 1 1/4s against 1s 5 1/4d; New Era, 4 1/4d, unchanged; South African Land, 2 1/2s against 3 1/8s; Springs, 6d against 9d; West Springs, 6d against 9d.

Separate investigations by the medical societies of the five boroughs into the kickback system among physicians handling compensation cases will be started within the next week, Dr. David J. Kaliski, director of workmen's compensation in the State and New York County Medical Societies, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The National War Labor Board denied today the demand of the United Mine Workers of America for an upward wage adjustment based on travel time occupied by miners in moving from the mine portal to the working face and back to the portal.

A civic group in Spokane has suggested a movement to pay formal tribute to the American mother-in-law. The thing has been done before, but the Spokane boosters have a new reason. We owe honor to the American mother-in-law because she is now taking care of the grandchildren while the father is at the front and the mother is in the defense plant.
LONDON, June 18 -- The British Labor party wound up its forty-second annual convention today with a declaration that the Atlantic Charter and the four freedoms should apply to colonies.

Four attendants of Manhattan State Hospital on Wards Island were arraigned in Homicide Court yesterday on suspicion of causing the death of a patient by violence when he became unruly last Tuesday evening and was being carried from one ward to another.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, Republican of Massachusetts, called in the Senate today for concentration upon preventing the United States from becoming a "have not" nation when peace comes.
In the winter of 1942 you published a letter of mine proposing a Rice-MacMitchell-Dodds race. Your note at the end of that letter was that it was too late in the season.

With the aim of emphasizing the ultimate unity of France and this country, French nationals gathered yesterday to celebrate the national holiday proclaimed by the French Committee of National Liberation. The ceremonies, commemorating the third anniversary of the appeal of General Charles de Gaulle to the French nation, were held at the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes, 21 West Twelfth Street.

BOSTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Wool dealers are extremely busy with grading and distribution of supplies previously sold to mills, while trading of the week has maintained the recent routine. Selling of free domestic wools to a moderate extent, some activity in consigned lots, further turnover of the popular medium scoureds and additional business in foreign cargoes before arrival are keeping the market diversified if not excited.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Diminishing stocks of whisky and gin may be stretched a little by imports of Cuban neutral spirits, although this will increase prices as much as 30 cents a quart.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 18 -- Wellington bombers of the Northwest African Air Force hammered Naples early yesterday morning and American Liberator bombers of the Middle East Command blasted the Comiso and Biscari airdromes in southern Sicily yesterday as Allied air power converged on southern Italy and Sicily.

The City Council investigation of the La Guardia administration struck its first snag yesterday when William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, ordered under subpoena to produce detailed records on all cases handled by his department since June 1, 1940, appeared with two boxes of index cards that did not meet requirements.

Father's Day tomorrow will be marked by a bond drive sponsored by the National Father's Day Committee in cooperation with the Treasury Department, with the slogan, "Thirty-three Million Fath-J ers: Buy a Billion in Bonds," the committee announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A $71,510,438,873 War Department appropriation bill for the year beginning July 1, described as the "decisive" appropriation to win the war, was reported today by the House Appropriations Committee.

SARANAC, N.Y., June 18 (AP) -- A "tremendous" potential market for housing units in the United States after the war was predicted today by Walter C. Voss, head of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's building engineering and construction department.

TORONTO, June 18 (Canadian Press) -- Mrs. Mavis Constance Tate, only woman member of the British Parliamentary delegation now visiting Canada, today warned that women may be asked after the war to relinquish the equality they have attained in the war years and return to their kitchens.

DETROIT, June 18 (AP) -- Five showdown singles matches and surprise intervention by the United States Lawn Tennis Association today stripped the thirty-third national clay court championships of all except six seeded players -- Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles and Miss Nancy Corbett of Chicago in the women's division and four men.

ALBANY, June 18 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey rejected today a request by Mayor F.H. La Guardia that he call the Legislature into special session before June 25 to give authority to New York City to impose additional taxes and avoid the necessity of an increase in the city's basic real estate tax rate.

Fritz Kuhn, leader of the German-American Bund, was ordered released on parole from State prison yesterday by the State Board of Parole after serving three and one-half years of a five-year sentence for stealing funds from his Nazi organization.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- One United States merchant ship and one landing barge were damaged, while United States personnel casualties were twenty-five killed, twenty-nine injured and twenty-two missing, afloat and ashore, in the thwarted Japanese air raid on Guadalcanal on Wednesday (Solomons time) that cost the enemy seventy-seven of 120 attacking planes, the Navy reported today.

ALBANY, June 18 -- The Court of Appeals will resentence Louis (Lepke) Buchalaer, Emmanuel Weiss and Louis Capone July 20 where the court, which recessed today until that date, returns to Albany to clear up its business for the summer recess.

Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island will become the country's track and field capital when the fifty-fifth annual national AAU championships open there today, but the American debut tomorrow of Gunder Haegg, world record-breaking distance ace from Sweden, is the scheduled highlight of the two-day carnival.

One woman was fatally burned, two others were so seriously burned that their conditions were reported as grave and another was on the critical list at Lincoln Hospital as the result of a flash-fire in the third floor of a kopak processing plant at 455 East 147th Street, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon.

Steps to put the New York Stock Exchange on a stronger financial footing were announced by the institution yesterday. The membership, by a vote of 694 to 50, has approved an amendment to the constitution which permits the board of governors to continue to collect a 1 per cent tax on the net commissions retained by members and member firms from deals on the Exchange.

A complete reorganization of Butler Brothers, designed to provide for greater development of its Ben Frankin and Federated stores, will be made effective July 15, T.B. Freeman, president, revealed yesterday. At the same time it was announced that E.H. Niehaus, New York credit manager, would become New York branch house manager.

ALGIERS, June 18 -- Today, on the third anniversary of the founding of the Fighting French movement by Gen. Charles de Gaulle definite signs pointed to the likelihood of a compromise to bring about the unity of General de Gaulle and Gen. Henri Honore Giraud.

Advices from various sources, all authoritative, have led this department to formulate menus for next week that are virtually devoid of fresh meat. In fact, a pound of pork liver, a half-pound of bacon and a tin of luncheon loaf are the only meats of any sort used in these meals, which are planned for three -- a moderately active man and woman and a school-age child.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Office of Price Administration has accepted an invitation from the Canadian Wartime Prices and Trade Board to send one or two delegates to Montreal next week "for a discussion of newsprint prices."

Yesterday's decision of the War Labor Board leaves open the possibility of direct negotiations between the coal miners and operators on the question of "portal-to-portal" wages, though the Board insists that any agreement reached in this manner must have its approval before it becomes effective.

A petition for reorganization of the Childs Company, operator of Childs restaurants in eleven States and three Canadian Provinces, was filed yesterday in Federal court here. It asked that a trustee be appointed to continue the business during reorganization under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Laws.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, June 19 (U.P.) -- Vultee Vengence dive bombers, a new addition to Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's air arm, are in action in the southwest Pacific, an Allied communique revealed today less than two weeks after Prime Minister John Curtin said he expected aerial reinforcements in this area.

Rising opposition against the Roman Catholic clergy and Christianity in general by the Nazi parties in the occupied countries was noted yesterday in European press dispatches reported to the Office of War Information.

The Yankees ran into an old problem on their return to the Stadium yesterday. His name is Cecil C. Hughson, he comes from Kyle, Tex., he is 6 feet 3 inches tall and he pitches for the Red Sox. He pitched so well that he checked the New Yorkers with four hits, issued a solitary pass, fanned nine and batted in the deciding run in his 3-to-1 triumph.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 18 -- Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, was chief speaker at the public burial services for the victims of the RAF raid on Wuppertal, which were held in the town hall on the Elberfeld today.

Tricks of the trade -- short cuts to combining housework with civilian defense activities -- help win those Civilian Defense Volunteer Organization blue stripes, the "thousand-hour volunteers" report. But many feel that it is going to take a long time to chalk up the next thousand hours.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 18 -- More than 8,000 seniors of public and parochial high schools in metropolitan New York walked wide-eyed through some of the hangars of this air base today as guests of the Army and thrilled to a mock combat and tactical demonstration staged especially for them on the parade grounds.

LONDON, June 18 (UP) -- Whirlwind, Typhoon and Mosquito planes of the Royal Air Force "maintained the regular delivery of bombs" last night, pounding air facilities, rail targets and barges in nothern France and blasting a German E-boat off the French coast, the Air Ministry announced today.

New issues of municipal bonds in the amount of $22,942,110 are scheduled for award next week, compared with this week's revised total of $25,014,000, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new municipal financing for the year to date now stands at $16,237,007.

Pure white flowers took the lead over all others yesterday for the first time this season, the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets declared. Bouvardia, often described as "imitation orange blossoms," lilies of the valley, purple-lipped white orchids, and chalk-white sweet peas were all in demand.

Eleven 3-year-olds, each to carry 110 pounds, are named for the $25,000 added Dwyer Stakes, mile and a quarter test that is expected to attract 30,000 persons to Aqueduct today. The field is so large because Count Fleet and other front rank thoroughbreds are missing from this race, which goes back to the first World War in 1918.

New York City faced the highest basic tax rate in its history -- $2.89 on every $100 of assessable real estate -- on the basis of Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick's final estimate of general fund revenues, submitted to the City Council last night in accordance with charter requirements.

Gasoline rationing as applied to fishing boats still remains the chief topic of letters in the mailbag. George Ruppert, sponsor of the coastal tournament, says that it is not necessary to have a gasoline-propelled boat to catch prize-winning fish.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Publishers of larger newspapers will be directed to reduce their consumption of newsprint by about another 5 per cent in the third quarter of this year and to reduce their inventories from a seventy-five-day to a fifty-day supply, with some regional exceptions, if recommendations made today by the Newspaper Industry Advisory Committee are accepted by the War Production Board.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 18 (AP) -- Frank Gannett, president of the Gannett Company, Inc., announced today the purchase of The Binghamton Press, 39-year-old afternoon daily founded by the late Willis Sharpe Kilmer.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes of the Department of the Interior, as Petroleum Administrator, called today for the production of 4,328,500 barrels daily of all petroleum liquids next month, a jump of 109,600 barrels daily over the quota for June.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 (AP) -- The Reds got the jump on the Pirates today as they opened a four-game series with third place at stake by taking a 1-to-0 decision in fourteen innings behind superb hurling by Ray Starr.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 18 -Vandals entered the Victory Garden here Wednesday night of Toru Matsumoto, a Japanese of strong American sympathies and trampled and slashed every seedling on the lot. By today the action had so angered village officials and club women that they replanted the lot with seedlings from their own property and some offered to send gardeners to tend it.

Many colleges have abandoned their plans for football this year because of the lack of material. They have taken the attitude that the public is not interested in seeing inferior teams composed of small boys and those rejected by the armed forces.

New bond flotations here this week were all in the tax-exempt field. The total of $23,767,000 for three issues offered to the public was the largest for any week since that ended on March 5. The total compared with $18,017,700 for one industrial and two State and municipal loans last week and with a single municipal issue of $1,792,000 in this week of 1942.

Whether or not Jehovah's Witnesses leave a mark on the religious history of the United States, they are certainly leaving one on its constitutional history. The very fact that the conduct and manners of a good many of them strike some of us as outrageous makes the test more searching.
LONDON, Saturday, June 19 (U.P.) -- The Russian midnight communique:

Herman Nadelman, 28 years old, got off yesterday in General Sessions with a suspended sentence of two and one-half to five years in Sing Sing because he had kept the promise he made last week when he pleaded guilty and returned $2,500 he had stolen from Lieut. Albert Wood of the Naval Reserve.

Because of accelerated study in professional schools and inductions into the armed services, the State Board of Regents voted yesterday at their meeting in the State Building, 80 Centre Street, to allow qualified candidates to take certain examinations before their twenty-first birthdays. These examinations lead to licensing of architect, certified shorthand reporters, engineers, land surveyors, optometrists and pharmacists. The age limit is waived only for the duration of the war.

Large numbers of young women "white collar" workers here, faced with the prospect of going without proper food to pay taxes after the 20 per cent deduction order goes into effect July 1, are abandoning poorly paid office jobs for good meals in the Waacs and Waves, or for fat pay envelopes in war production plants, it was revealed yesterday.

The Connally-Smith act or anti-strike law has been passed. In denouncing Congress, labor leaders may ease their anger, but they do not diagnose the generative source of law in a democracy -- public opinion.

BOSTON, June 18 -- The Braves treated their returning chieftain, the convalescing Casey Stengel, with a series of pyrotechnics today that almost had the good professor forgetting his broken leg, but came close to sending him back to the hospital with a case of jitters.

I have read with interest Arthur Daley's comments in THE TIMES on the War Department's refusal to allow Army trainees in the various colleges to play football. I think Mr. Daley is doing splendid work and hope he will keep it up, as I think it is of vital importance.
CHICAGO, June 18 -- A meat crisis which will bring a showdown on the Administration's food subsidy program was indicated by developments today in the livestock industry.

CHICAGO, June 18 -- Republican national committeemen and committeewomen and State chairmen and vice chairmen from seventeen midwestern States will meet here tomorrow and Sunday for informal discussions of national and postwar policies and next year's Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Senate completed Congressional action on the Naval Appropriation Bill and the Independent Office Appropriation bill, passed the Interior Department Appropriation Bill, the bill providing protection for gold and silver mines closed by wartime orders and the bill permitting release of 1,500,000,000 ounces of silver for industry, heard Senator Lodge on post-war problems and recessed at 5:04 P.M. until noon Tuesday.

Literary descriptions of the best means by which the youth of the city "can contribute most to the war effort" earned for 211 authors cash awards of from $25 to $2 in the annual city-wide essay contest sponsored by the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, June 19 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Starting in August, the Traffic Audit Bureau will issue semi-annual circulation figures for outdoor plants in cities of 25,000 population or over, replacing its former procedure of supplying complete audits of all outdoor plants once every three years, Henry M. Stevens, president of the bureau, announced yesterday.

The sudden awakening of this country to the vital importance of food as a war weapon marks the first general recognition of the central fact of this war. We have talked a lot about the home front, the production line, the morale of populations under bombs or under abnormal strains and shortages.

Rabbi Edward E. Klein, director of the B'nai B'rith Foundation at the University of California, Berkeley, Calif., for the last year and a half but until recently of this city, has been called to the Free Synagogue to take the place of Rabbi Stephen S. Wise.

LONDON, June 18 -- Field Marshal Sir Archibald P. Wavell, Commander in Chief in India, will be the new Viceroy of India, it was announced at 10 Downing Street today following approval of his appointment by the King. The communique designating Britain's ranking soldier for this high office also announced the creation of a separate East Asia command to mount an offensive against Japan, the commander of which will be named soon.

The City Council's current investigation, so hurriedly authorized in the witching hours of last Wednesday morning and so quickly centered upon Commissioner Herland's Department of Investigation, obviously differs from most of this city's historic political inquiries.

ALGIERS, June 18 (U.P.) -- The Stars and Stripes, soldiers' newspaper, devoted an entire page to letters from American soldiers in North Africa attacking John L. Lewis and other strike leaders as "un-American."

ALBANY, June 18 -- Taxing authorities in the State may put assessments on outside station equipment of the New York Telephone Company, the Court of Appeals ruled today. The decision means that about $7,000,000 additional revenue will be turned into the local treasuries for the next three years and $2,500,000 annually thereafter.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, June 18 (U.P.) -- United States fighter plane pilots who shot down seventy-seven Japanese planes in the great air battle over Guadalcanal Wednesday said today the enemy airmen apparently were the "rawest of recruits."

Fall and winter apparel is already starting to sell in retail stores in many sections, with indications that the forthcoming 20 per cent withholding tax is encouraging some consumers to make purchases while they have funds available, according to reports in the wholesale markets here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 (AP) -- Milo Candini tonight scored his sixth victory for the Senators against no defeats, but had to go eleven innings before gaining a 4-to-2 triumph over the third-place Athletics before 16,427 at Shibe Park.
Lippy Leo Durocher and Flatbush fans received their worst shock of the season at Ebbets Field yesterday from that red-hot team once known as the lowly or futile Phillies.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The United States Coast Guard cutter Escanaba sank recently while on convoy duty in the North Atlantic, following "an explosion of undetermined cause," the Navy Department announced today. All but two of her complement were lost.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- After listening to James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, in executive session today, several members of the House Agriculture Committee indicated that their enthusiasm for the Fulmer bill to create an over-all food czar had cooled considerably.
MOSCOW, June 18 -- Of all branches of the Red Army the most powerful in relation to its equivalent in the Axis forces is Marshal Nikolai N. Voronoff's artillery.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Navy Department communique 416:

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Exports from the United States during the first four months of 1943 totaled $3,438,000,000, a gain of more than 52 per cent as compared with the same period last year, an all-time high. The four months' exports, in fact, exceeded in value those for the whole years of 1938 and 1939.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The names, with next of kin, of 113 United States soldiers wounded and 140 missing in action in the Asiatic, European, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas were made public today by the War Department.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- The fact that it is the end of the third week of June and no German offensive has so far materialized in Russia has been leading to considerable speculation on the part of many foreign observers. Is the German offensive delayed, they ask, and if so, for what reason?

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A revision of the list of industries to be given preferential treatment in the Eastern gasoline shortage area, which adds some industries to the list and moves others from one priority rating to another, was announced today by the Office of Defense Transportation.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 19 -- Victory of an all-woman crew in the Atlantic sloop Teal and the handicap class triumph of the Rev. H.C. Benjamin's 42-year-old Pecusa were features in the special regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

SANFORD, Fla. -- Florida's summertime "little season" promises to be a big one at the beaches this year with the family-to-visit service-man guest playing the role of chief tourist and the service men themselves arriving from neighboring camps for week-ends in Fourth of July hordes.

AS long as the war goes on, the war is our unfinished business. This unfinished business can only be finished with decisive and total victory. The first business of every one of us is to make this purpose an accomplished fact, as efficiently and as speedily as possible. No effort can be spared, no sacrifice is too great for the winning of the humane peace to which we are committed.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Navy communique 418:

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 19 -- The Northwest African Air Force has plunged into what may well be one of the decisive aerial battles of the war -- a contest for supremacy in the sky over Sicily, Sardinia and the outer defenses of Hitler's European Fortress.

Dr. Nahum Goldmann, a member of the World Jewish Agency, outlined last night a three-point demand for the restoration of Jewish life and rights after the war. He spoke at the opening of the thirty-fourth annual convention of the Sons of Zion in the Hotel Pennsylvania to 400 delegates, representing sixteen States.

For many years only economists and bankers took an active interest in currency problems. Yet monetary changes have very powerful effects on everybody's life. Today inflation is a question second in importance only to the task of winning the war. Voters should know as much as possible about the problems involved, as the final decision rests with them.

The much confused situation in which utility holding company common stockholders find themselves today received added impetus last week as hearings got under way before the Securities and Exchange Commission on the recapitalization plan of the $1,000,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company system.

In your editorial of June 3 entitled "Home to Roost" you failed to mention Belgrade, capital of Yugoslavia, as one of the places most ruthlessly and cynically bombed, invaded and "punished" for having dared oppose the Axis plans. Without means to defend itself and not yet able to retaliate by bombing, the Yugoslav nation is still doing its pert in resistance to the four invaders its soil.

EVEN in peacetime there is a certain elemental dramatic quality about the building of a ship. Add to this the compulsion and speed of a wartime program, plus the knowledge that a crew of saboteurs has been planted in the yard and is waiting only until the most costly moment possible before they strike -- well, action is called for.
LONDON, June 19 -- The crisis besetting the Yugoslav Government in London continued today. Better prospects were seen ahead, however, after a number of consultations had been held during the day.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- A lifeboat filled with survivors of the torpedoing of a Standard Oil tanker in the South Pacific on May 18 bumped into the submarine which had fired the torpedoes, members of the tanker crew related on their arrival here.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 -- Sectional differences of opinion over whether America should play an active part in post-war world affairs are largely a figment of the imagination.

Now completing their first full year under the war program, the secondary schools of this country have made widespread revisions in their curriculum, gearing the studies to meet the requirements of the Army and Navy. Vast changes have taken place in the classroom.
Yesterday's Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

PITTSBURGH, June 19 (AP) -- The Pirates and the Reds staged their second extra inning battle in two days today, the Pirates winning, 4 to 3, after eleven innings. The Reds captured a fourteen-inning affair yesterday, 1 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- All set to pass on Monday the biggest military appropriation bill in world history, the House heard promises today that this Army outlay of $71,510,438,873 for the 1943-44 fiscal year would bring terror and ultimate defeat to the Axis.

ACADMICIANS are not generally supposed to make good composers. Yet most English composers have been connected in some capacity or other with educational institutes. Parry was principal of the Royal College of Music and Parry's "Jerusalem" is now a national "signature" anthem, sung at all meetings of town and village institutes.

Columbia University will double the usual number of classes to be offered in Japanese during the coming summer session which begins July 6, Harold G. Henderson, Professor of Japanese, announced yesterday. The amplification is in answer to requests from Army, Navy and government services for men and women trained in that language.

During the last ten days, government reports and authoritative statements have highlighted the nation's growing food shortage. The situation was further emphasized last week at the food forum arranged in New York by the Dairymen's League.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Eight of last year's ten National Football League teams elected tonight to play professional ball in the 1943 season after the club owners had approved a merger of the Pittsburgh Steelers and Philadelphia Eagles.

Indications are that Fall retail trade will start much earlier than in previous years as stores have placed fall orders early and manufacturers, foreseeing future delivery difficulties, are shipping as fast as possible, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

A NEW vaudeville show is on its way, due at the Ambassador either late in July or early in August. Masterminding the production is none other than Clifford C. Fischer, whose "Priorities of 1942" was one of the first of the variety shows of last season, when the ancient art of vaudeville had its renaissance.

NEW DELHI, India, June 19 (U.P.) -- Heavy and medium bomber formations of the Tenth United States Air Force again smashed at Japanese railroad communications and oil supply centers in Upper and Central Burma yesterday, a communique of the United States Air Force in the China-Burma-India theatre announced today.

Representatives of 5,000 retail kosher poultry dealers in Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens reaffirmed last night their decision to close their stores beginning today and to keep them closed until the black market in poultry is eliminated.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 19 -- With practically only one week left before the end of the month French opinion is wondering how far Chief of Government Pierre Laval has succeeded in delivering the goods, namely, 200,000 more French workers for German armament plants.

The American Civil Liberties Union made a formal recommendation yesterday to President Roosevelt the Department of State and the Office of War Information that restrictions that made news coverage of recent international conferences at Bermuda and Hot Springs extremely difficult be relaxed at future conclaves of this nature.
CROSSVILLE, Tenn., June 19 (AP) -- Life inside the Crossville internment camp is an easy one for more than a thousand German and Italian prisoners of war.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A daily production of 4,328,500 barrels of all petroleum liquids was certified today to the various petroleum-producing States for July by Petroleum Administrator Harold Ickes. This is an increase of 109,600 barrels daily over the certification for June.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Thomas P. Henry, president of the American Automobile Association, told Price Administrator Prentiss M. Brown in a letter today that the ban on pleasure driving should be ended permanently. "It has no place in the rationing machinery of this country," he asserted, and attempts to enforce it result in "snooping."

Is Tin Pan Alley really seeking the war song, as John Desmond reported in this magazine recently? Song writers doubt it very much. All sorts of them, including a major general, a country doctor and a playwright, have composed the song that will win the war, and yet the music publishers simply ignore them -- or so their friends inform us.

UNUSUAL both from an antiques and a news angle is the exhibition of Korean pottery at the Warren E. Cox Gallery, 6 East Thirty-ninth Street. Collectors believe that this old Korean ware, one of the rarest of antique ceramics, will become even more important when long-oppressed Korea gains its freedom with the defeat of the Japanese.

Income taxes consumed more than half of the profits of furniture stores last year, and some merchants reporting on the installment basis paid taxes totaling as much as 150 per cent of their accrual profits, the National Retail Furniture Association reported yesterday.

Declaring that the activities of the Office of Price Administration have done much to prevent a runaway inflation market in foods and other commodities, Walter Gellhorn, regional attorney for the OPA, yesterday told a conference of trade union officials that the OPA should be "strengthened and invigorated" rather than criticized.

Although the actual anniversary date is still two days off, it was on the corresponding Sunday morning in June two years ago that Adolf Hitler and his armed hordes broke forth like thieves in the night to launch their assault on Russia. At the time they thought that this assault would bring a quick end of the war and make the German "master race" the master of the earth.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican of Ohio, declared today that the people of the United States must commit themselves to the use of military force in the post-war world to suppress international aggression where an international body had found it to exist.

THE American Ballet, which was the parent organization from which the Ballet Caravan sprang, has now organized another company of chamber size, to be called the American Concert Ballet. George Balanchine is its artistic director and has choreographed several works himself.

MARGATE, June 19 (U.P.) -- Speaking of his post-war federation plan at Margate today, Capt. Harold H. Balfour said that workers in war factories and soldiers at the front were going to demand a world of organized security and that a world federation was the only answer.

EVERYWHERE -- wherever a terrace or rooftop or penthouse, small or large, may be had -- people are planning and planting gardens. A vacation-less Summer offers real possibilities to those who have a bit of space, sunny in the daytime and cool in the evening, in which to plant a few flowers, vegetables and herbs.

With the award of best in show yesterday at the Ladies Dog Club in Brookline, Mass., the first half of the dog show year in the East was completed. No more events are scheduled in this section until mid-August and many things may happen before the day of the next exhibition arrives.

LONDON, Sunday, June 20 (U.P.) -- Russian shock troops, charging from a river bridgehead won in a week-long battle north of Orel, have ripped another gap in the German defenses and advanced to new forward positions, the Red Army reported.

EISENHOWER, Alexander, Cunningham, Tedder, Spaatz, Doolittle, Montgomery, Patton, Bradley -- these men and a host of others comprise the military portrait gallery of the United Nations' leaders in North Africa. These are the men who will plan, direct and lead the next operations against Hitler's "Festung Europa" or its outposts; these are the men who conquered Tunisia and bombarded Pantelleria into surrender.

WHEN the Special Librarians Association opens its 1943 convention on Tuesday at the Hotel Pennsylvania, some 500 women and a handful of scholarly men will sit down to a three-day series of discussions guaranteed to be anything but sedate.

Many of the domestic problems confronting our Government are concerned with the rights and claims of organized labor in their divers appearances. The Government has been dealing with these problems as they came along, and the decisions reached were in most cases influenced, if not dictated, by the pressure that could be exerted, or merely threatened, by the various groups supporting or opposing the measure under discussion.

The largest aircraft carburetor plant in the world has been placed in operation in the Chicago area, producing for the Bendix Aviation Corporation aircraft injection carburetors of the most advanced design at a monthly rate running into four figures, it was announced yesterday by D.O. Thomas, manufacturing vice president.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Although half a dozen star performers were only hours out of the hospital, where they were among more than 100 employes of the Ringling Brothers, Barnum Bailey Circus who were treated for food poisoning, the show went on this afternoon just as it did last night while the stricken employes were being taken out one by one.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Miss Pauline Betz of Los Angeles, who hopes to make 1943 a grand slam year, captured the national clay courts tennis championship today by defeating her Rollins College (Fla.) pal, Miss Nancy Corbett of Chicago, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.

IF Radio Row ever had a hobby, it has one now in guessing who will be the buyer of the Blue network, which the Radio Corporation of America must sell in conformity with the FCC order. Almost hourly, specialists in vague predictions have disposed of the chain.

LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- Unofficial observers suggested today the possibility that an American general was being considered along with several British officers for Commander in Chief of the new separate East Asia military command which may take over direction of a knockout blow against Japan.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The War Department announced today that leases on 206 of 434 hotels now used by the Technical Training Command of the Army Air Forces will be canceled in the middle of July.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 19 (AP) -- The cruiser Houston slid down the ways at the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company here today. Thus was started on her way a new vessel to avenge the sinking of another warship by the same name in the Java Sea battle with the Japanese fleet a year ago.

HERE is an excellent handbook of reference for the layman who wants a reasonably comprehensive and brief survey of the navies of the world. The separate chapters on each type of ship are supplemented with 340 photographs, line drawings and diagrams of ships, their structures and their weapons.

FORT BELL, Bermuda, June 19 -- An airfield which has been literally raised from the bottom of the ocean, adding substantially to the overall acreage of Bermuda's nineteen and a half square miles, is the outstanding topographical feature of this United States Army post which has brought the Stars and Stripes flying alongside the Union Jack in one of the British Empire's oldest colonies.

NAVAL TRAINING STATION, BAINBRIDGE, Md., June 19 -- Where scarcely a year ago cows grazed and orchard bloomed here on the banks of the Susquehanna River 20,000 Navy recruits are learning to serve as fighting men of the sea.

LONDON, June 19 -- The wartime expansion of Britain's industry and military establishments has taken over more acres of farmland than have been reclaimed. The use of land is strictly controlled in this crowded little island and it has been a major problem to meet all the demands for space.

MOSCOW, Jun 19 -- The famous Peterhof Palace outside Leningrad, through whose grounds the front lines ran for almost a year, has been damaged beyond all hope of repair. All the beautiful lesser buildings in the garden, the architecture of which includes some of the best work of Rastrelli and Leblanc, are also irreparable.

ALGIERS, June 19 (AP) -- The belief that the long-standing dispute between the two French groups may be ended officially on Monday grew today after General Charles de Gaulle, General Henri-Honore Giraud and their followers had indicated increasing satisfaction over a proposed compromise plan for control over the French military forces.

THE Bridges live in the heart of the Brooklyn plain that sweeps east from Borough Hall. Here, as Thomas Bell proves in his fine, stinging novel, is "the true, the authentic Brooklyn. Here are streets without end, without number, without rememberable names.

BUENOS AIRES, via Montevideo, June 19 -- Revolutions are nothing new in Latin-American countries, though they are rarer in Argentina than in most. What is remarkable about the one that overthrew the Government on June 4 was the fact that as soon as the revolutionary movement got under way President Ramon S. Castillo found himself completely alone, shunned and abandoned even by those who had profited most from his regime.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Files of the Japanese-American Citizens League subpoenaed by the House Committee on Un-American Activities were disclosed today to contain a statement that a Japanese in this country declared publicly that President Roosevelt should be killed, that the incident was reported and that this person continued to make pro-Japanese speeches for five months last year.

CERTAINLY the forgotten Englishman during the crucial months following June, 1940, when invasion of England seemed imminent and the air blitz was on, was the British soldier. Cursed with a job which seldom showed him an enemy, forced to stand fruitless guard while civilians absorbed the punishment and the R.A.F. fought to clear the sky of raiders, the soldier of the home forces had the safest, dullest and perhaps hardest job on the island.

THE hero of this story is Bill Mason, first mate of the S.S. Fouqua, which is lying at her New York pier taking on a cargo of planes and other munitions destined for our troops in Africa. But such ships and such cargoes reach their destinations only when the enemy is unable to stop them.

The New York Stock Exchange's volume of business yesterday was only 302,930 shares, the smallest since Jan. 2, and there was little price movement. Stocks drifted narrowly and closed mixed. The market was also the third narrowest of the year, or since Jan. 9.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 19 (AP) -- Jersey City snapped its five-game losing streak today, defeating Rochester in the second game of a five-game series, 15 to 0. The Little Giants collected 16 hits, driving Starter Kemp Wicker from the mound in the second inning and continuing their attack at the expense of Lou Sakas and Manager Pepper Martin, the latter hurling the last five innings. Crip Polli gave up only four hits.

LETTERS I have received from broadcasters indicate a definite desire on the part of a good many of them to determine some method of utilizing the influence on public opinion which radio so obviously could exert.
Post-war European trade and immigration problems were discussed yesterday by the economic committee of the Pan European Conference at the New York University Faculty Club, 22 Washington Square North.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Two Midwestern sailors -- sole survivors of the sinking of the Coast Guard cutter Escanaba -- tonight told graphic stories of their rescue after a violent explosion sent the ship down in the North Atlantic with a loss of fifty-eight lives.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, June 20 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The surrender of Pantelleria and Lampedusa to attack almost wholly from the air emphasizes a fact that has been apparent through the whole African campaign now ended. That fact is that the Army air forces played a role of primary importance and that our African victory was also an air victory.

To accommodate children who must remain in the city this summer because of wartime travel restrictions, the Horace Mann-Lincoln School of Teachers College, Columbia University, 425 West 123d Street, has rearranged its youth center to cater to five different groups of youngsters, Gordon R. Mirick, principal, announced yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, June 19 (AP) -- The Germans have built well-camouflaged military towns in Jutland as anti-invasion nerve centers from which highly mobile units can be rushed to any danger point in Denmark, reliable information reaching here disclosed today.

Apropos my verses, "Flower of France," in THE TIMES of June 13, I have received letters from several readers who have wanted to know how the fleur de lis was chosen as the symbol of France, and why and when.

Charles Sparks, the general manager of Ringling Brothers' continental circus, "Spangles," had an anniversary yesterday. It was Charley's fortieth birthday as a "circus man." But with the daily fare of overseeing "my gang" at Madison Square Garden and paying his usual minute attention to the riggings, there was no time for a party.
BOSTON, June 19 -- Carl O. Hubbell continued to thread his seemingly ageless course as the Giants' mightiest man of the hour as he turned back the rambunctious Braves today, 5 to 3.

AT the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx Park, graduation exercises for the students who have successfully completed the two-year science course for professional gardeners and the two-year course in practical gardening will be held in the administration building Thursday at 8 P.M Dr. John C. Wister will be the principal speaker of the evening.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- With only 400 head of hogs on sale, no reliable test of market conditions was possible today and prices were quoted nominally unchanged. The average price of yesterday was $13.77 a hundredweight against $14.02 a week ago and $14.20 a year ago. The $13.77 figure, maintained for the last three days this week, was only 2 cents above the level at which the government has said it would support prices.

The American Army today is an army of specialists. Of every 100 inducted sixty-three are assigned to duties requiring specialized training. However, we are not getting them through the induction centers. These specially trained men must know the fundamentals of electricity, know automotive mechanics, know how to dismantle carburetors and be familiar with radios.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 19 -- Condemning bureaucracy as an evil at all times and a Frankenstein in times of war, Joao Alberto Lins de Barros, Brazilian Coordinator of Economic Mobilization, promised today that he would twist the monster's tail around its hind legs and prevent it from moving.

The critical situation in the laundry industry here, with drastic service curtailments and unpredictable deliveries on finished work, presents no health menace, Dr. Frank A. Calderone, deputy Health Commissioner, declared yesterday.

Chile has set an example which may in time be followed by other countries. The recent action of that Government in bestowing special decorations upon Michael Lerner and S. Kip Farrington Jr., big game anglers, brings reassurance that sportsmen may still be called ambassadors of good-will.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Mrs. Clyde Troutt's Take Wing, outsider at $11.80 for $2, was best in the three-horse field that contested the $5,000 added Lincoln Handicap at Hawthorne today in the closing feature of the transplanted Lincoln Fields meeting.

STOCKHOLM, June 19 (Reuter) -- The Germans are showing increasing signs of worry over Turkey's attitude. In leading Berlin circles it is feared that certain "imponderable" factors will cause Turkey to abandon her neutrality, according to a Berlin correspondent of the Stockholm Tidningen.

ALBANY, June 19 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey urged the Federal Government today to draw immediately upon petroleum reserves in the Middle West to supplement the Eastern gasoline supply, which, it is said, was running 100,000 barrels a day short of minimum needs for trucks, buses and other necessary civilian purposes.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Analysis of the Connally-Smith labor regulation bill by Federal observers tends to support the views of organized labor's spokesmen who believe that the measure will foment strikes rather than prevent them.

ALFRED GREENFIELD has been appointed conductor of the Oratorio Society of New York for the 1943-44 season, according to an announcement made by the board of directors. The works he will direct include Handel's "Messiah" and Bach's Mass in B minor.

" THE UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA," by Lewis Sowden, is not a popular book, not the story of Darkest Africa, or a fast-moving, predigested, easy-to-read compendium of the subcontinent. The title describes the book, which begins with a short history of South Africa, continues with an extremely up-to-date report on the present conditions in the Union, and ends with some interesting and quite objective speculations on the future.

SIX years ago Jules S. Bache presented his fine collection and the Fifth Avenue house in which he had assembled it to the State of New York. It was by no means an easy task, but the Yankees yesterday avenged Friday's setback by the Red Sox. Though they had to work overtime at the Stadium, they found it worthwhile as Rollie Hemsley singled sharply to left with one out and the bases crowded with Yankees in the twelfth inning.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- The veteran Roger Cramer singled home a run in the twelfth inning today to win a 4-to-3 decision from the Browns and return the Tigers to a tie for third place in the American League standings.

Many, perhaps most, see it, like Sir Norman Angell, as an urge toward the internationalization of law and order, to be effected by widening our political association at the expense of national sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Cast in a difficult, dangerous and tremendously vital role, the scope of which is virtually dictated by the Pacific war map, submarines of the United States fleet are performing an increasingly important part in the war with Japan.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- That Congress does not intend to ration its calendar was again evident when one of its members recently dumped that perennial and never-solved problem -- national representation for citizens of the District of Columbia -- on the floor of the House.

Boston University has established a War and Post-War Training Institute to prepare draft-exempt persons, mostly girls, for apprentice positions in forty-three industrial specialties. The institute, a division of the College of Business Administration, will give intensive eight, twelve and sixteen month courses.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Although many home furnishings' manufacturers in the Merchandise Mart, particularly in the floor-covering division, are heavily engaged in war work, a large majority will hold open house during the traditional summer market, according to John C. Goodall, general manager of the Mart.
MOSCOW, June 19 -- The faults that appeared in the Czarist armies during World War I have been corrected in Russia's second major conflict with the Germans.

THE history of discovery, the exploits of men who dared to venture into unknown seas in small, unseaworthy vessels, is so intrinsically romantic that even bald and meager accounts of the early voyagers have been read eagerly by young people.

LONDON, Sunday, June 20 (AP) -- The Germans made a weak attempt to raid London early today, while the Air Ministry announced that four Mosquito bombers of the Royal Air Force had pounced on eight Junkers 88s over the Bay of Biscay last night, shooting down one and damaging at least three others.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., June 19 -- Atlantic City received the War Department announcement of the impending return of leased hotels with mingled emotions of alarm, resentment and optimism.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., June 19 -- Much better equipped with various types of guns, jeeps, trucks and all other training facilities than afforded last year at the initial opening of the State Guard summer field training, nearly 1,500 guardsmen are here at Camp Smith successfully acquiring a basic knowledge of military tactics.

With a warning that the new schedule might be in effect for only ten days because of impending Congressional action, the Office of Price Administration yesterday released its new retail community cents-per-pound ceilings for meat rolled back some 10 per cent under the subsidy program.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A decision of great importance to Belmont Park and other of the country's leading race tracks was taken by the Office of Defense Transportation today when it exempted the use of urban or suburban passenger trains made up of electrically propelled, non-interchangeable equipment from its general order forbidding operation of special trains or extra sections.

IT is a pleasure to record, in the words of that completely omniscient index of information on the subject, the box office, that the 1943 season of Stadium concerts has "started with a bang." Approximately 100 per cent more orders for seats have been received for the opening performances than was the case at the same time last season.

Mrs. John T. Pratt and a group of other women of prominence are acting as a sponsoring committee for the world premiere of Paramount's motion picture, "For Whom the Bell Tolls," which will be presented on July 14 at the Rivoli Theatre as a benefit for the National War Fund, of which Winthrop Aldrich is president.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Officials of the United Mine Workers of America and spokesmen for the joint Appalachian bituminous coal conference resumed conferences today in an unexpected maneuver to compose their differences in advance of a threatened stoppage of 530,000 bituminous and anthracite operators at midnight tomorrow.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 19 -- Premier Mussolini presided this morning at a special meeting of his Cabinet, which, according to a communique, did nothing more than "examine current affairs, more particularly concerning the salaries and welfare allocations of state employes."
LONDON, June 19 -- In a speech at Hayes, Middlesex, today, Baron Winster paid tribute to the work of the British Navy and merchant fleet.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- During the course of a double-header today, the Indians accumulated fourteen runs in three innings to withstand belated challenges by the White Sox and sweep two victories, 5 to 4 and 10 to 8 in ten innings. The double triumph elevated the Tribe to a third-place tie with the Tigers.

In its drive against questionable organizations masquerading as charitable institutions, the Welfare Department announced yesterday that the Volunteers Tabernacle, Inc., of 45 Astor Place, has been restrained permanently by court order from future solicitation of funds.

THE other day Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, heiress presumptive to the British Throne, accompanied her father the King on a visit to the naval school at Pangbourne. For the King this was merely one of many official inspections he has to make in his role as supreme head of the three fighting services.

White, general secretary of the Civil Service Clerical Association, who said government workers could profitably eschew politics for the duration of the war, provided they were allowed to enter the TUC.

"An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure" should be the slogan for controlling poultry disease.

Supplementing its regular eight-week summer session and its sixteen-week summer term with a variety of special war training courses, the University of Michigan will open its second accelerated summer teaching program Monday, June 28, with an anticipated enrollment of between 6,000 and 8,000 students.

McGhee, director of the center. The courses will carry credit toward the degrees of Master of Public Administration or Master of Business Administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 19 -- A firm attitude by the Army, the Navy and Los Angeles city officials has had the effect of curbing, temporarily at least, the outbreaks involving zoot-suit wearers and members of the armed forces.

PROFESSOR CHARLES LEE LEWIS'S second and final volume of his biography of Admiral David Glasgow Farragut has more than fulfilled the expectations aroused by the first volume, which appeared two years ago.

PITTSBURGH, June 19 -- On the eve of another coal mine crisis, the third in less than two months, miners by the thousands stayed away from the pits today in scattered parts of the country's coal fields in protest against denial by the War Labor Board of pay increases for portal-to-portal travel.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Lend-lease exports of food and other agricultural products declined by $29,000,000 from March to April, according to a monthly report made public today by Edward R. Stettinius Jr., Lend-Lease Administrator.

The Third Naval District announced yesterday a second series of mass examinations for Naval Aviation Cadet candidates in metropolitan high schools beginning tomorrow. Following for a while the Oregon Trail, it branched off and, once across the Continental Divide and into Idaho, angled off to the southwest through Northern Nevada to another great divide, that of the Sierra Nevada, climbing which, it descended into the final and promised land.

Attributing the favorable labor conditions in Brazil to the special tribunals set up by that govern ment for the negotiation of labor disputes, Dr. Lourival Fontes, Brazilian delegate to the International Labor Office, declared yesterday that the resulting decisions have been beneficial to capital, labor and the government.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y. -- Trail suppers, skeet shoots and golf this week will inaugurate Summer activities at the Lake Placid Club and several hiking parties are scheduled among members of the hotel colony.

NEWARK, N.J., June 19 (AP) -- Two-hit pitching by Steve Roser in the seven-inning nightcap enabled the Bears to gain an even break in a twin bill with Buffalo today. Roser, who gave up his first hit with two out in the sixth, hung up a 3-1 victory. Newark lost in the eleventh inning of the opener, 7 to 6.

The Commerce and Industry Association declared yesterday that an analysis of the Census of Manufactures and of United States Department of Commerce reports on retail trade showed that New York City lost ground in manufacturing from 1929 to 1939 and that its percentage gain in retail trade between March, 1940, and March, 1943, was less than the national average.
