All had art training before induction, but all are working soldiers now.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, June 20 (AP) -- Allied Flying Fortresses and Liberators dropped thirty-three tons of bombs on Rabaul, New Britain, yesterday, the High Command announced in the noon communique.

ST. LOUIS, June 19 -- Morton Cooper, the Cardinals' "stop" pitcher, broke the world champions' three-game losing streak today and won his ninth victory of the season, against three defeats, by beating the Cubs, 4 to 2.

After ten years of experience more and more physicians are using injections of gold in rheumatoid or infectious types of arthritis. Though they have no value in degenerative arthritis (osteo arthritis), which commonly occurs in the later years of life, gold salts seem to inactivate infectious arthritis and to prevent further destruction in the affected joints.

JERUSALEM, June 17 (Delayed) -- One of the remarkable effects of the war on Palestine has been the amazing extent to which agricultural prosperity has developed among a formerly indigent Arab peasantry as well as among the Jewish farmers.

NEWMARKET, England, June 19 -- Miss Dorothy Paget, British-born cousin of the American sportsmen Lieut. Cols. C.V. and John Hay Whitney, dominated the English racing picture today as her colors were carried to victory in the fourth wartime Derby and the Coventry Stakes.

INDICATIONS are that custom has changed little in the matter of vacations despite appeals to the public from the Office of Defense Transportation to spread them. Summertime still remains the high favorite for holidays and travel bureaus report that practically all big hotels at near-by resorts are heavily booked for the coming months.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A stormy meeting of Senate and House conferees on the Treasury-Postoffice Department appropriations broke up today after a roar ing exchange between Senator Kenneth McKellar, Democrat, of Tennessee, and Representative Frank B. Keefe, Republican, of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- At unrevealed bases on both the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, a "Unified Invasion Force," made up of specially selected Army and Navy officers and men, is being "welded in preparation for assaults on enemy territory," the Navy Department disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Developments this week indicated that the draft of pre-Pearl Harbor fathers would be delayed at least until October, but the usual confusion over that question reigned with the continuance of conflicting official statements.

RADIO is only one section of the hugely growing field of electronics now being covered from end to end by countless technical volumes rolling off the presses of the book publishers. The output, perhaps, is great enough to tax the reviewing capacity of a dozen persons.

CHICAGO, June 19 (AP) -- Harrison Spangler, chairman of the Republican National Committee, charged today that New Deal Democrats were using the war politically by attempting to build up a conviction that "you can't beat the Commander in Chief."

Wartime conditions of scarcity and reduced sales volume have reversed the trend by which food chains have gradually been taking over an increasing share of the nation's food distribution, it was noted in trade circles last week. Normally leaders in the food retailing industry, the chain operators are now yielding their place to independent grocers, because they previously held -- namely, large turnover and low-cost operation -- have become definite liabilities.

Millions of dollars' worth of the most critical war product components, which have become surplus material as a result of cancellations of new plant construction, have been frozen by the Ordnance Department and other military buyers and frantic efforts by the oil industry to pry some of these components loose for use in the aviation gasoline and synthetic rubber program have proved fruitless, it was learned here last week.

The eighty-second extraordinary session of the Japanese Diet was formally closed yesterday with a statement from Premier Hideki Tojo urging the Japanese people to exert "unprecedented strength with higher morale" at a time when "the present war situation is truly serious."

Sweetness and light came back to Ebbets Field yesterday after five straight days in the dismal fog of defeat as the Dodgers outscored the Phillies, 7 -- 5, and snapped their longest losing streak of the campaign. However, the league-leading Cards also won and held their three-game advantage over Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- Three New York members of a United States Army Air Forces flying Fortress Bomber crew hold silver stars for gallantry for spotting a Japanese fleet of fourteen ships before the battle of Santa Cruz and downing three Japanese Zeros last October in the South Pacific area.
GUADALCANAL, June 16 (Delayed) -- I have just seen the Japanese take their worst aerial beating of the war.

OF the many experiments now being tried to achieve greater realism in forthcoming war pictures none is considered more outstanding than the efforts to be made by Twentieth Century-Fox in the filming of "Lifeboat," a story of the survivors of a torpedoed merchant ship.
Five German enemy aliens, two of them women, were arrested here during the week-end, it was announced yesterday at the local offices of the Federal' Bureau of Investigation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 19 -- A polyglot army of about 42,000 men, including Czechs, Germans, Austrians, Maltese, Berbers and Kebili tribesmen from mountain fastnesses has been mobilized for North Africa's labor front since the Allies arrived here last autumn.

LONDON, June 19 -- The Ruhr region which the Royal Air Force has been attacking with relentless intensity is only about forty miles long and forty miles wide. Its industrial area is only about two or three times that of greater Berlin.

LONDON, June 19 -- The German war potential suffered "the most shattering blow" thus far delivered in the aerial Battle of the Ruhr when Royal Air Force bombers in great strength struck at Duesseldorf, the leading commercial city of western Germany, the night of June 11, the Air Ministry said today.

OUT-OF-DOORS, at easels, little boys and girls concentrated on swoops of bright pink paint. They piled a stockade of big blocks to "play fort." Little girls scooped and rolled fistfuls of moist black earth; one and all they squealed happily going down the slide.

The curtailment of wholesale beer deliveries resulted yesterday in temporary shortages in some areas, with the result that some storekeepers were limiting sales to three large bottles to a customer. Leaders in the brewing industry said that while there was some shortage of materials, in addition to the transport problem, there was no danger of a general shortage of beer.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, June 19 -- American industry can solve its problems if we can preserve freedom of speech and freedom of the press, Frederick C. Crawford, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared here today in a speech before the Wartime Conference of the National Editorial Association.

A doctor who must have been one of the oldest members of his profession died in Norfolk, Va., the other day at the age of 95. He began practice more than seventy years ago, and to the very end he made his rounds in a horse and buggy.
LONDON, Sunday, June 20 (AP) -- The Russian Saturday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

IN "Assignment to Nowhere" Lowell Bennett has written an account of the early stages of the Tunisian campaign which is both amusing and authoritative. To those in the United States and Britain who wondered why that brigade known as "The First Amy" did not capture Tunis and Bizerte in November or December, Bennett has provided some of the answers in very readable style.

" S. Klein on the Square," specializing in sales of women's apparel on Union Square at Fourteenth Street, was doing an annual business of $14,000,000 and had 1,100 claims outstanding, from small sums to $20,000, at the death of its sole owner, Samuel Klein, on Nov. 15, it was disclosed yesterday.

DETROIT, June 19 -- Seven hundred and fifty foremen at the Willow Run bomber plant of the Ford Motor Company went on strike tonight, bringing to 3,400 the number of foremen idle at midnight at four Ford war plants. The strikers are members of the Foremen's Association of America, an independent union.

The Port of New York is justly entitled to its position of supremacy; other splendid harbors of the world may surpass it in particular aspects, but none has the combination of so many inherent possibilities -- none is so favorably situated for the creation of a magnificent system of water routes engaging in the internal, coastal and foreign trade, Eugene F. Moran, Commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, asserted yesterday.

THERE is little comforting news for East Coast motorists in the compact, factual volume, "Fightin' Oil," into which Harold L. Ickes, Sectary of the Interior and Petroleum Administrator for War, has fitted an appraisal of the nation's wartime petroleum situation.

Governor Thomas E. Dewey in a message to the annual convention of the Rabbinical Assembly of America, which will be held next week, opening tomorrow, in the Henry Hudson Hotel, declared that many members of the assembly "are bringing spiritual comfort and solace to our young men on the battlefront."

To meet the Allies' need for foodstuffs during World War I President Wilson appointed Herbert Hoover Food Administrator, thus centering supervision of all food production and distribution under one head. The former director of Belgian relief -- he disliked the title "Food Czar" -- launched a program which depended mainly upon voluntary cooperation.

BOSTON, June 19 (AP) -- Allen T. Simmons' Smart Lookin, a $700 yearling, ran her unbeaten string to three today as she scored a neck decision in the $7,500 added Betsy Ross Stakes at Suffolk Downs before 17,561 racegoers.

THERE is something about a soldier; and on the Broadway which is part of the democratic if not the fighting front, it is that he brings excitement with him. On a hot night of last July, "This Is the Army" marched into town, capturing it with no delay whatsoever and stirring up a general jubilation which has not ceased, even though the show long since has gone.

RAHWAY, N. J., June 19 -- One man was fatally injured and five others, including a sailor and a soldier, were hurt when an automobile driven by Matthew J. Daly, 30, of this city, plowed into a group of war plant workers here at 1:30 A.M. today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 19 -- Swedish military measures announced these last weeks, as well as official statements, principally this Wednesday's speech by King Gustaf on the occasion of his eighty-fifth birthday, have been reminders to the Swedes that they are not yet out of the danger of becoming involved in World War II.

IN a Spanish philatelic journal which reached New York last week is illustrated a new Hungarian series presenting portraits of notable Magyar statesmen of the past. The reproductions are so small that the inscribed names on only three in the group are legible, and one of these, honored on the one-filler, is Arpad, founder of the Hungarian homeland and first ruler of the Magyar people.

FOR a continuous supply of choicest flowers, successive plantings of marigolds may be made from now until the first of July. Later sowings may be located where early vegetables such as radishes, peas and lettuce have been pulled out of the Victory garden.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Either the President soon will give Chester C. Davis, War Food Administrator, additional authority to deal with the serious food situation or Mr. Davis plans to return to his home in St. Louis, it was learned tonight.

Collector of Internal Revenue Joseph T. Higgins has filed a $38,711 income tax lien in Federal court against Pelham G. Wodehouse, identified yesterday by his American attorney as P.G. Wodehouse, British writer, now in Germany.

THE Holdens always referred to their home as "The House" and to the head of the clan as "The Holden." As the story opens there are five male Holdens: Mattheus, Mark, Luke, John and Stephen, all brothers.

MOSCOW, June 19 -- An article in yesterday's issue of Pravda warns against drawing too optimistic a conclusion from defeatist statements by recently taken German prisoners. It is yet too early to talk about a break in the German Army's morale, the writer says because it is not yet destroyed.

While war work has brought large-scale expansion for many plants in New York City and has sustained hundreds of others lacking materials for civilian goods, new factories and business enterprises have come into the city or set up here in recent months that will continue after the war and add to the city's industry, a survey indicated yesterday.

John Desmond wrote a highly interesting article in your issue of June 6, concerning the failure of Tin Pan Alley, in its search for a national war song, to take the place of "Over There" and other robust declarations of spirit which flourished in the last World War.

A tougher training course for the feminine counterpart of the hard-hitting marines -- the Marine Corps Women's Reserve -- is indicated by the announcement that henceforth all the new recruits will be trained at-Camp LeJeune, New River, N.C., instead of at the Naval Women's Reserve training schools.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 19 -- The week just ending has witnessed a significant change in Italian internal administration the full purport of which still remains to be seen. First outward indications point to an eclipse of Premier Mussolini and his Cabinet Ministers.

The United States Maritime Service recently opened an "upgrading" school for American merchant marine deck and engineer officers on the third floor of 39 Broadway. Qualified officers are offered a 30-day course, free of charge, to prepare them for examinations for chief and second mate and first and second assistant engineer licenses.

Premier Hideki Tojo's promise last week before the Japanese Diet that the Philippines will be given independence "within the year" may be dismissed as Japanese double talk. The only independence they will get from Japan will be that enjoyed by Manchukuo and the puppet regime in China.

GLASGOW, June 19 -- Jackie Paterson, former Glasgow ship-worker, won British recognition as the world flyweight boxing champion tonight when he knocked out Peter Kane, former champion from Lancashire, in the first round of their scheduled fifteen-round fight.

WITH the photostat working overtime for publishers, those days are gone when it was something to have a score published. While I do not have actual statistics showing what country's music is being tampered with the most, it is well known that domestic publishers have fed large chunks of Soviet music to this photostat machine for the simple reason that it is so easy to take; Russian music is not copyrighted in this country.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 19 (AP) -- A communique:

In a fit of pique against Mayor La Guardia and William B. Herlands, his Commissioner of Investigation, the Democratic members of the City Council have started an investigation of the city administration, aimed in the first instance at Commissioner Herlands but with the hope that it may bring about disclosures of irregularities sufficient to be of advantage politically.

SWANZEY CENTER, N.H. -- Denman Thompson's play "The Old Homestead" will make its fifth annual appearance at the Potash Bowl, in the Monadnock region of the White Mountains, on July 9, 10 and 11. If the new regulations on the use of gasoline are still in effect on July 5 it may be given in the Keene, N.H., high school auditorium.

CORNELIA MEIGS in her thoughtfully written, carefully authentic stories has described many significant peri ods in American history. This latest story begins in 1755, just as Mr. Franklin of Philadelphia, "head postmaster for all the colonies," was planning the first western mail route on which the post riders would carry the mail and bring news to the settlements along the Susquehanna.

SEVERAL years ago Iola Fuller won an Avery Hopwood Award for her first novel. "The Locn Feather" - a tale of Mackinac Island in the great days of fur trading, and of an Indian girl, the daughter of Tecumseh, whose destiny was cast among the whites.

OTTAWA, June 19 -- The shadow of future political divisions and discussion in Canada was cast forward sharply this week in several speeches made inside and outside Parliament and in the comment on them.

The motion picture can be made a very effective means of promoting peace and good will among nations, after the war. Movies speak a universal language that can be understood equally well by Roumanian peasants and American schoolboys, and means can be found for providing suitable films and projection equipment either free or at prices that even the most backward communities can afford.

GRIZZLY MEADOWS, the finest Winter range in the country, was about to be transferred to the State and offered for lease. Before Pig Bratton came on the scene Jim Dysart's D X and various small outfits had used it in common.

THE world, in the latter half of the Seventeen Hundreds, was richer by the birth of two men who were both great physical sufferers. Powers in their different fields, arriving at the climax of their lives through different channels, they lived under the same stars and shared, though far apart, the acclaim and admiration of their fellow-men as well as being figures about whom many books have been written.

The Victory ship is a fine vessel and admittedly superior to its predecessor the Liberty, but it must be remembered that the Liberty vessels were designed to meet mass production needs for the emergency of war and in that they have succeeded admirably, H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America, said yesterday.

An honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred yesterday by Fordham University upon Gen. Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay, at a ceremony in the office of the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, Fordham University president, who presented the degree.

Weather still seemed to be playing a part last week on the 2,000-mile Russian front. The official Soviet weather forecasters, who in April warned Central Russian farmers that though the thaw was early, spring was likely to be long and fitful, with frequent rainstorms, had been proved right.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

SOMETIMES little children "get mad" at their loving parents; older boys and girls act "mean" -- even if they don't storm from the room, slamming the door., "I hate you" voices youthful protest at all ages.

Charging that war-contract renegotiation boards have been virtually swamped by the task confronting them and that the excusing of smaller contractors in order to clear the vast number of pending 1942 accounts still to reach the board would void the democratic principle of the Renegotiation Act, Lewis H. Brown, president of the Johns-Manville Corporation, asked last week that the entire problem be turned over to the Bureau of Internal Revenue for handling and settlement.

HOLLYWOOD. The story buyers -- and sellers -- of the film industry are watching with considerable interest the suit brought in Superior Court here last week by Warner Brothers against the Phil Berg-Bert Allenberg agency involving the counting of a literary chick before its actual hatching.

Fixations by the trade for Southern mills constituted the principal buying support in the cotton futures market again yesterday. On the New York Cotton Exchange active futures contracts closed mixed, 1 point lower to 2 points higher than Friday's final quotations, with the near months strongest.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia declared yesterday that Governor Dewey's denial of his request for a special session of the Legislature to empower the city to tax its way out of a threatened ten-point rise in the city's basic real estate tax rate was "politically astute but not the statemanship that I expected."

A large crowd at the Lewisohn Stadium, officially estimated at 10,000, heard Albert Spalding, violinist, give a full-bodied and virile performance of Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto last night with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, Fritz Reiner, conductor, in the second concert of the summer season.

The Italian nation is as much responsible as Premier Mussolini for Italy's part in the war, but the population has lost heart, and the time required to conquer the country will depend on what aid Germany continues to give, in the opinion of Yilma Deressa. Ethiopian Vice Minister of Finance.

Dr. George H. Chatfield, member of the Board of Education, assured more than 200 persons who attended a luncheon held in his honor yesterday afternoon on the Marine Roof of the Hotel Bossert in Brooklyn that he approved the organization of employes in the educational system and the school lunch program would be continued.
This is the fifth of a series of ten articles on the recent developments in expert bidding methods.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- At a press conference today Robert P. Patterson, Under-Secretary of War, expressed grave concern over the fact that Army production fell considerably below schedule in May and attributed a large part of the decline to "complacency and over-confidence."

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Freedom won a decisive victory in the United States this week. A small and often unpopular, even despised, religious sect -- the Jehovah's Witnesses -- won from the Supreme Court of the United States a six-to-three ruling that their children must not be required to salute the American flag or pledge allegiance to it as a prerequisite for attending public schools.

TWENTY-YEAR-OLD HELEN BRUSACK, a TWA cargo-hauler, is the first woman at La Guardia Field to joint the Marine. Sworn in June 1, she is still on the job checking baggage manifests and loading and unloading baggage, cargo and mail on TWA flights while awaiting orders to report at a North Carolina training camp.

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- Although the automobile has been shunted from the vacation scene by the tide of war, its absence has not dampened the ardor of city dwellers for a sojourn in the Adirondacks. With the season just moving into stride, fair-sized contingents are already arriving daily at the resorts by bus and train from metropolitan areas.
Mr. and Mrs. Lowell M. Clucas are expected to arrive tomorrow from Camden, S. C., at the Berkshire.

PROCESSED FOODS (Most canned vegetables, soups, fruits and fruit juices; dried beans, peas and lentils, and frozen vegetables and fruits) -- Blue stamps K, L and M in War Ration Book 2 are valid through July 7.

Retail trade continued very active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey made especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Shoe departments were jammed, Father's Day promotions met excellent response and many women's accessories met a brisk seasonal demand.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 19 -- A truck out of control careened down Richmond Hill Avenue into a group of more than 100 persons at Taylor Street late last night, killing two persons and injuring three others, one seriously, as it plunged into another vehicle and set it rolling.

AN acquaintance remarked a little sarcastically that every one whose aunt or uncle had ever been a missionary in Japan was now writing a book about the Island Empire. Pearl Harbor signalized a boom in books about our oriental enemy, and these works are of uneven value.

In discussions of the pending measure to remove the discrimination against the Chinese in our immigration and naturalization laws I have seen little or no mention of the way in which the discrimination developed.

OYSTER HARBORS, Mass. -- Golf at Oyster Harbors continues to be one of the major sports at this community where the first tee of the eighteen-hole championship golf course is right at the club door. Over the Fourth of July week-end there will be a tournament benefiting the Red Cross, with contests for both men and women and two prizes in each division.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Attacking the proposed subsidy program as a move "to further the socialization of our entire economy," the Board of Directors of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today authorized a statement congratulating the House of Representatives on its opposition to using subsidies in the price roll-back.

WERE there a dispenser of good-will on hand to appropriate some sort of annual medal for heroism in the theatre, this year's award would undoubtedly go to Miss Miriam Hopkins who, without a perceptible blink of an eyelash, became Sabina overnight.

AN ominous new anxiety has just been added to the common man's intellectual burden. The scholars are talking again about a world language, a universal tongue that everybody would use and understand. To the average fellow who has trouble enough with his own language this opens a prospect more dismal than point rationing and a new tax in the lower brackets.

LOS ANGELES, June 19 (AP) -- A Dies subcommittee investigating relocation camps said in a statement tonight that "the preponderance of testimony indicates that the administration of the Japanese relocation camps has not been satisfactory."

KENNETH SPENCER is young man who went to Hollywood a singer and emerged an actor. If the transmutation appears to be a reflection on his voice it can only be explained that there's many a cut and splice between the script and the projection room.

Retail trade here continued notably active last week, marking the second consecutive period of high percentage sale gains. Department store volume was estimated as ranging around 30 per cent over the comparative week last year.

AS a child Laurence Sterne once made a long-nosed caricature of himself and labeled it "This Is Lorence." It makes a temerarious title for a biography, but Mr. Hartley's admirable pages go far to justify it. Such a title is somewhat startling on a university press book, reinforced by an enchantingly mad jacket, a narrative of admirable sprightliness, and a critical study illuminated by most unstodgy wisdom.

Peter J. Vandenberge, secretary of the American section of the Dutch Central Transport Workers Union, an affiliate of the International Transport Workers Federation, declared yesterday that the general consensus of opinion among the workers of Great Britain is that the Allies are now on the road to decisive victory and that the war in the European theatre will end late this year.

BURLINGTON, Vt. -- Vacation weather has arrived in the Green Mountains, after a rather cold May, and guests are beginning to arrive in Vermont in spite of transportation problems. Most of them come by train or bus. Many are relatives of men in military service who are stationed at Fort Ethan Allen, in the air crew at the University of Vermont in this city, or at Norwich University, Northfield.

WOMEN in war factories need constance assurance that they have not been forgotten. Acting on this knowledge, many firms have introduced counselors for women on the production front. Called "Mrs. Anthonys" by the war workers, the counselors describe themselves as "a cross between a grandmother and an advice-to-the-lovelorn columnist."

NEWS that the Truman Committee of the Senate has requested the Army and Navy to report upon all inventories of supplies and materiel by Sept. 1 has a significance to business which can scarcely be exaggerated.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia reaffirmed his interest in "the good people of Harlem" as against those "who want to thrive on violation of the law, whether it be gambling or numbers," in awarding prizes yesterday at City Hall to seven school children from the area who were winners in an essay contest on the lives of outstanding Negroes.

AS O'Donovan and Chester Park at last found their feet clear of wire, the three Germans paid, swiftly and almost silently, for their erroneous assumptions. While they stared at the two crossing the wire, some of the commando men already across had crawled up close.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 307 United States soldiers killed and 169 wounded in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Increased hedge pressure against wheat on the Board of Trade here developed late in the session today, and that grain sold off sharply from the opening high spots. Commission-house support was not aggressive, and in the forepart of the session a little short covering caused a strong tone for a while.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 18 -- Uncensored news reaching the Social Democratic Stockholm newspaper Aftontidningen reveals that neither the Germans nor the German language are regarded with favor in Rome. The influx of refugees from bombed areas has doubled the population -- with the largest proportion of these refugees from German bombed areas.

RICHMOND, Va., June 19 -- Whatever the precise reasons behind the reported reluctance of certain Democratic committeemen in Georgia, Louisiana and South Carolina to raise funds for the national treasury of the Democratic party, there is no likelihood that any of these States will go Republican in next year's Presidential election.

LONDON, June 19 -- The German U-boat drive last month marked al new peak in the number of submarines they sent into action, Capt. Harold H. Balfour, Under-Secretary of State for Air, said today, speaking at Margate.

It has been held by the United States Supreme Court in a 5-to-4 decision that excessive depreciation deducted in income tax returns resulting in net losses may not be restored to the property account in determining the new base upon which revised rates of depreciation will be calculated (Virginian Hotel Corporation vs. Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, decided on June 7, affirming the lower court).

ANY one who succeeds in building and growing a satisfactory home place in the country swells with a tremendous pride of accomplishment which the most sumptuous penthouse in a city (a "boughten" glory) never inspires.

CAIRO, June 18 (delayed) -- Among the latest arrivals in the Middle East are the members of the Belgian Congo Brigade. Somewhere in the desert these colored warriors, with noncommissioned officers of their own kind, continue their training, practicing new types of warfare with newly issued weapons while at the same time performing the duty imposed upon the Allies in general of guarding thousands of Axis war prisoners in transient camps.

ON THE WASHINGTON WIRE -- Warm wool blankets (which may not sound so appealing now, but will certainly be appreciated during next Winter's fuel shortage) received the okay sign of the WPB last week. One hundred per cent wool coverlets (as opposed to the part-wool versions that were specified before) will keep America warm -- and production is being stepped up already.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 19 -- Firing a best-ball of 68, four under par, at Wesley Cotterell and Dr. Charles J. Robinson of Wheatley Hills, Frank Simonson and his partner, Bert Braun of the Garden City Country Club, co-medalists in the Cherry Valley Club's member-guest golf tourney, today advanced to the semi-final round of that event.

NEWS PHOTOGRAPHER FLASH CASEY is big and strong and tough, and he needs all those attributes in the case with which this story deals, for there are some very desperate characters who are determined to prevent his finding out why and by whom Rosalind Taylor was killed.

A memorial rally in honor of the 35,000 Jews killed in the Warsaw ghetto when they took up arms against the Nazis on April 17 was held last night at Carnegie Hall and was marked by speeches condemning the Nazis and praising the dead Jews for their fight against tyranny.

Much too speedy for his rivals after taking the lead at the 700-yard mark, Gilbert Dodds, divinity student representing the Boston A.A., successfully defended his senior 1,500-meter crown to feature the opening session of the two-day National A.A.U. track and field championships at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 (AP) -- Alex Carrasquel registered his seventh pitching victory of the year today although he wasn't around to see the Senators complete a 6-3 victory over the Athletics.

EDNA YOST'S book on "American Women of Science" is made up of sketches of twelve women who top the army of women who fill the country's laboratories -- many of whom are there because of what these twelve women have done.

MOSCOW, June 19 (AP) -- A new magazine, War and the Working Class, published by labor unions of Russia, declared in art article today that "it is clear that the Baltic countries are linked with our country and that they were only separated from us during the temporary weakening of Russia at the time of the civil wars."
MONTCLAIR, N.J., June 19 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura's first tennis quest of the season in the north ended in triumph today on the courts of the Montclair Athletic Club.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The toll of Japanese planes downed in the great air battle over Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands on Wednesday (Solomons time) was increased to ninety-four by later reports received by the Navy today.

IF weeds are allowed to become established along driveways or fences, in crevices between sidewalks, on tennis courts or on parking areas they detract from the appearance of the property; furthermore, they tend to act as harboring places for injurious insects.

The Office of Price Administration, in the most widespread single move against the gasoline black market here, issued orders yesterday suspending from business for the duration of the war thirty-one retail stations whose owners had admitted illegal traffic in ration coupons which were found to be counterfeit.

A 10-year-old boy was drowned in the Bronx River at 234th Street yesterday. His body was pulled out of the water by a young cyclist who then rode more than half a mile at breakneck speed to summon aid while another boy applied artificial respiration to the stricken swimmer.

Would it be possible to drop "blockbusters" into the crater of Vesuvius, Etna or Fujiyama, blow out the plug that confines gases and lava and thus bring disaster on Italy and Japan? The question came up for discussion at Cornell University for the nth time last week.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- That price appeal, despite wartime acceleration of consumer incomes, has not lost its potency as a factor influencing department store sales volume was impressed upon merchants who attended the three-day conference held here this week by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

CLEVELAND, June 19 -- The Office of Defense Transportation ended today its first week of virtual control of Great Lakes shipping without achieving its goal of having all bulk freighters operating in the ore trade. Complying with an ODT order, owners switched twelve vessels from the grain to the ore trade, but a series of accidents practically nullified this increase in the carrying capacity of the fleet.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 19 -- Thirty-nine Axis fighters were destroyed yesterday when an all-American bombing armada swept across the Mediterranean to blast shipping, port installations and airfields in Sardinia and Sicily.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The annual list of outstanding religious books of the year was made public today by the American Library Association. This list is usually released at the annual conference of the association, which was canceled this year as a result of transportation difficulties.

While housewives stoically faced New York City's worst meat famine yesterday, the War Food Administration disclosed that as part of its program to guarantee meat supplies to the armed forces and lend-lease, it had revoked or suspended scores of livestock slaughterers' permits in this Eastern twelve-State region.

Consolidation of the offices of the five County Sheriffs into that of a single City Sheriff, chosen by competitive civil service examination, has saved the city at least $404,580 in salaries in the fifteen months following Jan. 1, 1942, and restored public confidence in the integrity and efficiency of the of_ lice itself, according to a report filed with Mayor La Guardia by City Sheriff John J. McCloskey Jr. and made public yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Monday, June 21 -- The third undeclared strike in the anthracite region since April 1 was in effect at 12:01 A.M. with the expiration of the two weeks' truce between the operators and the United Mine Workers.

A memorial tablet to the first New York City fireman killed in World War I was unveiled yesterday at Fordham Road and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx. It was set in a square named after the fireman, Sgt. Charles E. Johnson, who was killed in action in the Argonne on Oct. 14, 1918.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- The White Sox, through the medium of a seven-run fourth inning, interrupted their Cleveland jinx long enough to take the opener of a double-header, 10 to 6, today, but the Indians, behind Jim Bagby's six-hit pitching, reasserted their mastery in the nightcap, 7 to 2.
LONDON, June 20 -- Without benefit of the promised real live baby, the Columbia Club, the newest and largest American Red Cross unit here, put on its special program honoring soldier-fathers today.
PITTSBURGH, Monday, June 21 -- Western Pennsylvania coal operators prepared early today for the gravest strike in the history of the industry.
PANAMA, June 20 -- A cynical view of the cooperation of some Latin-American governments was expressed by a writer using the name of Ruminahui in the Universo of Guayaquil, Ecuador, today. He wrote:

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The National Football League added new blood for the 1944 season today by accepting the Boston franchise application of Ted Collins, manager of the singer, Kate Smith, and former operator of the Long Island Indians professional squad.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Prices of oats had last week their first sizable reaction in some time on the Chicago Board of Trade, profit-taking being a factor as well as recessions in other grains. At the close of business yesterday they were down 2 7/8 to 3 1/8 cents a bushel, with July at 67 3/4; September at 65 1/2 and December at 66 1/4.

WELLESLEY, Mass., June 20 -- Commencement exercises were held this morning at Wellesley College, 314 B.A. degrees being awarded, thirteen M.A. degrees and twelve degrees of Master of Hygiene and Physical Education.

DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- The patched-up Browns, whose ace shortstop, Vern Stephens, went out of action with a back injury, left the solitude of the American League cellar today by defeating the Tigers in both ends of a double-header, 6 to 3 and 5 to 4, before 27,595 spectators.

The 1942-43 opera season dispelled the fear that the Metropolitan Opera Association might become a casualty of the war, Edward Johnson, general manager, said in his report printed in the association's "Statement on Operations" made public last night.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 -- Denmark is beginning to feel the effects of allied bombings of the Ruhr coal mines and of Reich communications.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Second Lieut. William L. MacCoy Jr., varsity baseball captain at Princeton in 1942 and son of W. Logan MacCoy, president of the Provident Trust Company, was killed yesterday in an airplane crash at Pampa, Tex., according to word received here.

In anticipation of the official approach of summer at 3:13 A.M. tomorrow, the weather yesterday gave New Yorkers a sample of the shape of things to come as temperatures rose close to 90 degrees, causing record crowds for the year to gather at near-by beaches, parks and shady places along the city's streets.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- About 20,000 persons attending the American Slav Congress rally in Kennywood Park here today, stood and unanimously approved a resolution condemning the proposed work stoppage by the United Mine Workers.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 20 -- With the growing food shortage, price inflation and post-war planning dominating their interests, Chief Executives of forty States and representatives of five others were gathering here tonight for the thirty-fifth annual meeting of the Governors Conference.

Churches must set their own houses of faith in order if they are to meet the demands and questions of the men returning from war, the Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan, the pastor, declared yesterday morning in a sermon in the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (U.P.) -- Chairman Robert Ramspeck of the House Civil Service Committee announced tonight his opposition to the Senate-approved McKellar bill requiring reappointment and Senate confirmation of all government employes earning $4,500 or more a year.

Father's Day was celebrated yesterday afternoon on the Mall in Central Park. There several hundred persons heard Newbold Morris, President of the City Council, say the "message from New York fathers to John L. Lewis is to get the men back into the mines."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 21 -- The largest force of Spitfire fighters ever to take the air in Australia smashed a Japanese attempt to raid the Darwin area on Sunday, it was revealed today. The Spitfires caught forty-eight enemy planes near Cape Gambier, thirty miles north of the town, and destroyed or damaged twenty-two of them.
LONDON, June 20 -- No news from the United States is read with more interest or more puzzlement than reports of efforts to avert a nation-wide strike of coal miners.
Sicily, the "cockpit of history," is being battered with bombs as the United Nations continue the "softening up" process preliminary to invasion.
Resuming their torrid transpontine feud with the opening clash of a six-game series at Ebbets Field yesterday, the Giants and Dodgers hit each other with practically everything at hand.

Spring recruiting for young farm workers among private schools and colleges already has reaped a good harvest for Mrs. Abbot Low Moffat, who is farm placement representative in charge of girl students for the United States Employment Service.

DETROIT, June 20 -- Officials of the United Auto Workers (CIO) said today that they had told the union's members to go through picket lines established by striking foremen of the four large Ford plants here.

Study of the transcript of hearings on the proxy rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission before the securities subcommittee of the House Committee on Interstate and Foreign Commerce uncovers many revealing things. There is, for example, the case of Milton Freeman, assistant solicitor of the SEC.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 14 to 18 are given in the appended tabulation:

The Rev. Joseph Summerville Minnis, chaplain of the State Penitentiary at Joliet, Ill., since 1932 and rector of Christ Episcopal Church there, has been appointed vicar of the Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, at Broadway and 155th Street.
Mrs. Theron Roundell Strong of the Carlyle will leave today for Asher Lodge, her summer home in Southampton, L.I.

HAROLD J. LASKI, the little British Professor of Political Science with the bushy mustache, is a respectable revolutionist. By lectures, by a swollen stream of evangelical books, by frequent letters to this and other papers and by exhorting his fellow-members of the British Labor Party he strives tirelessly to hasten the day when the world will be remade according to his own rather watery and rarefied interpretation of Marxism.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 20 -- Frank Simonson and his partner, Bert Braun of the neighboring Garden City Country Club, today capped two days of almost perfect teamwork by defeating Dr. R.M. Bowles and Frank Graven, Plandome ace, in the final round of the Cherry Valley Club's seventh annual member-guest golf tournament.

Gunder Haegg, Sweden's phenomenal world record-breaking distance runner, lived up to advance billing in his American debut at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday by gliding to a decisive triumph over nine rivals, including famed Greg Rice.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- A resolution asking that President Roosevelt put an end to discrimination against Negroes at Army camps in the South was unanimously adopted at a mass meeting of the National Negro Council and the Chicago Citizens Committee of 1,000 today in the Metropolitan Community Center.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- A complete career diplomatic service similar to the American Foreign Service under the State Department or the British career service with a system of permanent ranks and promotions has been established in the Soviet Union.

Retail furniture stores doing more than $350,000 a year spend 63.97 per cent of their advertising dollar for newspaper space, according to the tenth annual report on "Retail Furniture Store Operating Experiences and Departmental Activities for 1942," published by the National Retail Furniture Association.

An old holding in the retail furniture district of Harlem passed to new control with the purchase by Samuel Kilpatrick, operator, of the four three-story buildings on a plot 75 by 100 feet at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and 120th Street.

ALGIERS, June 20 -- The Fighting French organization of Gen. Charles de Gaulle made a dramatic gesture today to influence the decision of the Committee of National Liberation on General de Gaulle's demands for paramount military power and the reform of the French Army on his specifications.

The largest group of women engineering aides ever to be trained at Columbia University -- 105 students -- begin their duties today. With sixty colleges and twenty-five States represented, the enrollment marks a 50 per cent increase since the course began last year.

Now celebrating its tenth anniversary, the New York Adult Education Council has filled an important role in this community. During the past decade the Council has focused attention on the kind of learning that goes beyond classroom walls or that is found between the covers of a book.

LONDON, June 20 -- The British Board of Trades index of commodity prices for May based on 1930 as 100, reached a new wartime high mark of 163.3, compared with the previous record of 162.8 for April, and with 160.5 for May last year, making a total increase of 66 per cent since August, 1939.

LONDON, Monday, June 21 -- Four-motored bombers of the Royal Air Force over Saturday night heavily attacked the sprawling Schneider armament works at Le Creusot, France, 170 miles south of Paris, battering factories that had doubled in importance to the Germans since the devastation of the Ruhr by allied air fleets.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 20 -- The southern Italian ports of Reggio Calabria and San Giovanni, the eastern termini of Sicily's lifeline across the Strait of Messina, were blasted by heavy American bombers of the Middle East Air Command yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- With fair prospects for success, the Administration maneuvered backstage tonight with the aim of reversing in the Senate the setbacks encountered in the House last week by the Office of Price Administration, the Office of War Information and the program for the use of subsidies to hold down food prices.

Mayor La Guardia hinted strongly yesterday, in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall, that he would be a candidate for a fourth term in 1945 if his type of "clean, nonpartisan, nonpolitical" government should then be facing attack by the sponsors of commercialized vice, professional gambling and indecent stage performances.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that estimated corporate profits for 1942, after provision for income and excess profits taxes, were slightly higher, despite the sharp increase in taxes, than the "high level" of profits in 1941.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has petitioned the House Committee on the Merchant Marine and Fisheries to take cognizance of the fact that any action, under the proposed House Resolution 2731, that might detrimentally affect American ship-owners, necessarily, concerned and would affect the entire corelated marine industry, it was announced here yesterday by Cornelius H. Callaghan, manager of the association.

NEWARK, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- The Newark Bears and the Buffalo Bisons divided another double-header today, giving the herd the series, three games to two. Newark took the opener, 8 -- 5, and the nightcap went to Buffalo, 13 -- 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 20 -- Harry Carey will portray the late William E. Dodd, United States Ambassador to Germany, 1933-37, in the Twentieth Century-Fox picture to be based on Mr. Dodd's diary and the book "Through Embassy Eyes" written by his daughter Martha.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The War Department announced tonight the names of 115 United States soldiers killed in action. Nineteen were from New York and eleven were from New Jersey. Among those listed were the following from the metropolitan area:

PITTSBURGH, June 20 -- Raw steel output last week rebounded two and a half points to 97 1/2 per cent of rated capacity. The gain was due to the elimination of conditions brought about by the mine shutdown several weeks ago. Unless unforseen developments occur, such as another curtailment in blast furnace activity due to coal shortages, steel output this week will equal or exceed last week's.

CLEVELAND, June 20 (AP) -- Steel mill schedules continue to tighten, although various consumers are forced to modify operations because of reductions in some lines of ordnance, the magazine Steel reported today.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- Another step in bringing the Red Army formally further in line with Russian military tradition and the accepted usage of other countries was taken today with the publication of a decree by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union designating a series of silk ribbons, each representing decorations that must be worn instead of medals.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 (AP) -- The Red Sox clouted five homers today -- two of them by Jim Tabor -- to sweep a double-header from the Athletics, 7 to 3 and 6 to 5, before 22,987 at Shibe Park. The two victories put the Red Sox in fourth place in the American League while the Mackmen dropped to sixth.

Most of the buying of fall apparel was completed last week, and many retailers turned their attention once more to purchases of current selling merchandise, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
LONDON, Monday, June 21 (AP) -- The Russian Sunday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

Although the box score will testify to five errors for each side, the New York City Police Department nine made six in its annual clash with the Fire Department yesterday at the Polo Grounds and wound up on the embarrassing end of a 13 -- 3 score.

The Stadium concert conducted by Fritz Reiner last night attracted an audience of some 6,000 persons. For this third event in the current series a program of a romantic nature was offered, composed of the prelude to Wagner's "Die Meistersinger," Mendelssohn's "Italian" symphony, Strauss' "Till Eulenspiegel" and the Mussorgsky-Ravel "Pictures at an Exhibition."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 20 (AP) -- Col. Elliott Roosevelt, the President's son and the commander of the Allied aerial photography service of North Africa, said today that "the Allies stand head and shoulders above the Germans in heavy bombardment and we have the pictures to prove it."

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- The Pirates surged back into third place today on the strength of two eighth-inning outbursts which gave them both ends of a twin bill with the Reds, 5 -- 4 and 4 -- 2. A crowd of 27,392, largest of the year at Forbes Field, attended.

Led by seventy-one service men on leave from the armed forces, 1,160 graduates and 280 members of the faculty marched in academic procession at Brooklyn College's eighteenth commencement late yesterday afternoon in the campus quadrangle.

To some Americans it may seem a little odd that a letters-to-the-editor controversy should be going on in London papers in these serious times over the question whether the simplified spelling "fone" should be used for "phone."

Restoration of special trains by the Long Island Railroad to beach resorts and racetracks, under a revised order of the Office of Defense Transportation, will conserve mileage, equipment and manpower by ending the fantastic aspects of the "relief train" situation, it developed yesterday.

Gen. Higinio Morinigo, president of the Republic of Paraguay, and his official party of fifteen, attended the 12:35 o'clock mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday. They arrived in four official cars, decorated with the flags of the United States and of Paraguay, and were received at the Fifth Avenue door by Bishop John F. O'Hara, military delegate, and by Mgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of the cathedral.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 112.3 to 111.1. Sharp declines in the prices of livestock and meats were primarily responsible for the 1.0 per cent drop. In the finished goods index, the declines in meat prices were a direct result of the 10 per cent rollback in the price of meat.

BOSTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Phillies opened their Boston campaign against the Braves today by taking both ends of a double-header, winning the first game, 13 -- 7, with a ten-run seventh inning, and capturing the nightcap, 7 to 0.

WASHINGTON, Monday, June 21 -- Renewal of the nation-wide strike of 530,000 bituminous and anthracite miners became effective with the end of the fifteen-day truce last midnight, the miners and operators having failed to agree on a contract and no action to insure a continuance of work having been taken by the Government.

Bishop William T. Manning officiated yesterday morning at ordination ceremonies during a communion service in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Three laymen were ordained as deacons and two deacons were advanced into the priesthood.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Receipts of hogs here were fairly liberal last week and prices declined to a point only a little above the Federal supporting level. The top here is now around $14 a hundredweight and, at this level, there appears to be a fair demand from packers as well as some call from shippers.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 20 -Mrs. Percy Ingalls of Orange, N.J., and East Hampton is the new summer production chairman of the East Hampton branch, Hamptons Chapter, American Red Cross. Other summer residents aiding in Red Cross administration here include Mrs. Alice Robbins of Baltimore and East Hampton, Junior Red Cross chairman; Miss Rosanne Roudebush, Miss Marguerite Hoguet, Mrs. Edward H. Jewett and Miss Frances Ford.

New York University has begun a nine-week course in the Kenny method of treating infantile paralysis, Dean E. George Payne of the School of Education, disclosed yesterday. The course, which began June 2, has an enrollment of twenty pyhsical therapists who will have completed their training by August, when the disease is most prevalent.
The schedule said the Yankees were to oppose the Senators in a double-header yesterday at the Stadium, but the American League champions extended their battle lines to include the umpires.

Arturo Toscanini conducted the NBC Summer Symphony Orchestra late yesterday afternoon in the first of four special Treasury Department broadcast concerts at the NBC studios. The program was given before an audience of women in the United States armed forces and a delegation of British Wrens.

LONDON, June 20 -- Scattered throughout this country there are today a few thousand rather forlorn civilians from occupied lands in Europe who are trying to carry on their traditional jobs far from home. Most of them are earning more now than they ever dreamed possible, yet they are the first to affirm the truth of the saying that money is not everything.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- Improvement in weather conditions and a modest increase in the amount of hedge selling were the main factors last week in giving the wheat market a downward trend. General buying was slow and the attitude of the local professional element on the Chicago Board of Trade was to back away from anything that looked like selling against purchases of new wheat.

The Lighthouse, headquarters of the New York Association for the Blind, for the last thirty-one years has given the blind of all ages, races and creeds much needed summer vacations. This year the very old blind and the very young blind Nursery School children go to River Lighthouse at Cornwall-on-the-Hudson.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 21 (AP) -- British and Australian pilots in Spitfire fighters paid off an old debt to the Japanese when they smashed the air raid on Darwin Sunday.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 21 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:
CINCINNATI, June 20 (AP) -- The first of a nation-wide series of meetings to help provide jobs for returning fighters in the post-war period by providing more employers will be held here tomorrow.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 20 -- Fifty-five sailing craft had a full spread of canvas today in the regatta of the Knickerbocker Yacht Club, the fifth of the championship season. It was the largest number out this summer.

The city beaches -- Coney Island, Rockaway and Orchard Beach -- bore the brunt yesterday of police enforcement of the ban on nonessential driving, while Office of Price Administration inspectors fanned out from the metropolitan area to pick up week-end gasoline wastrels.

With political, legislative and military uncertainties dictating caution, the cotton futures market last week was very dull and price movements remained within the narrow range in which they have held since late in March. On the New York Cotton Exchange active contracts ended the week 1 point higher to 3 points lower than the final levels of the preceding week.

An apartment containing twelve rooms and five baths in 895 Park Avenue has been leased by Walter Ross through Douglas L. Elliman Co., who also rented suites in 1095 Park Avenue to Dr. Murray Last, in 1215 Fifth Avenue to Raymond G. Irvine and in 105 East Sixty-third Street to Lieut. Ralph F. Holland, U.S.N.

NEW ORLEANS, June 20 -- With directive influences lacking on either side of the market, cotton futures here drifted narrowly for the most part last week. Nothing came from Washington to change definitely the control picture. War news continued to support the more optimistic ideas that the conflict may end much sooner than hoped for not many months ago.

George Mahr, 17 years old, of 349 Westminster Road, Cedarhurst, L.I., alleged to have slain a 65-year-old watchman when caught in the act of committing a burglary in a gasoline service station and repair shop at 10-17 Beach Twenty-first Street, Far Rockaway, Queens, early yesterday, was arrested on a homicide charge later in the day.

When Margaret Stein, 16 years old, left the apartment of her mother, Mrs. Erna Stein, 34, at 32-32 Thirty-fourth Street, Astoria, Queens, to go roller-skating with friends at 7 o'clock last night it was the scene of a happy reunion between her mother and her father, William, 39, who had been estranged for three months.

THERE was nothing to it. Gunder Haegg lived up to his press notices as he toured the Triborough Stadium track like a mechanical rabbit. Maybe the Flying Fireman from Sweden has ruined his tour already. If he can administer so crushing a defeat to Greg Rice in his first outing, the only one with a chance to give him a battle of it is Count Fleet.

LONDON, June 20 -- Illustrating why the month of May was one of the best for Atlantic convoys to Britain since the closing days of 1941, officials gave out today an exciting account of a bitter five-day fight against enemy U-boats in which warships and planes from a carrier and share stations sank two submarines, probably destroyed three more and are believed to have damaged many others.

LONDON, Monday, June 21 (AP) -- A strong force of Russian bombers blasted parked German planes, hangars and stores at Bryansk and Karachev behind the Orel front Saturday night to round out a week that cost the Germans more than 276 planes, Moscow announced early today.

By this time virtually all women have at least a nodding acquaintance with the cosmetic known as liquid stockings. And yet, according to distraught reports of department store buyers and salesgirls, less than 10 per cent of the customers know how to use them.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 20 -- Reports from "conservative" Fascist circles in Rome tonight indicate that Premier Mussolini struck his first blow against the separatist movement within the party ranks during yesterday's Cabinet meeting, details of which are still tightly censored.
SIMLA, India, June 20 (U.P.) -- Indian Nationalist circles today were generally critical of the appointment of Field Marshal Sir Archibald P. Wavell as Viceroy of India.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -- The Cardinals gained a 10-to-9 decision over the Cubs today in a first game so fraught with excitement the spectators didn't mind much when the nightcap was called after five innings on account of weather with the Cubs winning, 2 to 1.

Irving Cooper announced yesterday that he had acquired the rights to "Sophie Halenczik, American," the series of articles written by Rose C. Feld for The New Yorker about a Czech woman who hires out as a domestic in a small Connecticut town.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 20 -- Vichy is said to be preparing excuses for the day of reckoning. The latest instance relates to arrests of Protestant pastors. News of this having reached the outside world, Vichy issued a denial. It asserts it has made no such arrests, that two pastors were sent to internment camps many months ago but that they had been released long ago.

Without the courage this time candidly to resume the coal strike, and unwilling to back down in public from the limb out on which he had climbed, John L. Lewis has tried to cover his operations with the smoke screen of a highly ambiguous statement which can be read several ways.

Financial markets were largely at a standstill last week and prices of stocks slightly lower; with only two million-share days, at the beginning of the week. This hesitation was wholly due to the deadlock in the coal-miners' negotiation.

First-hand reports from all the major battlefronts have been compiled for "Journalism in War," to be published by the American Council on Public Affairs. The book has been assembled by the School of Journalism of the University of Missouri, and edited by Dean Frank L. Mott of that institution.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 20 (AP) -- Reliable Allied quarters today denied rumors that Italian envoys were in Algiers or elsewhere in North Africa to sue for a separate peace.
LONDON, June 20 (U.P.) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique:...

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 20 -- The latest German propaganda station is one alleged to be a "free British sender" operating on 41.42 meters short wave, broadcasting in Swedish. So far the station has been on the air only once, on June 17.
Your editorial of June 16 entitled "Policy vs. Patronage" suggests some very interesting questions.

Mayor La Guardia disclosed in his regular Sunday broadcast yesterday that he had advised the Senate Banking and Currency Committee that the food bootlegging situation here was likely to get worse than prohibition bootlegging within a few days unless the Federal Government paid the differential, by means of subsidies, between retail ceiling prices and the cost of livestock.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The Transportation Association of America today assailed recommendations of the National Resources Planning Board that railroad transportation facilities be put under a Federal agency for reorganization and modernization after the war.

Leaders of organized labor and political labor organizations in three States -- the American Labor party of New York, the American Labor League of New Jersey and the United Labor Committee of Philadelphia -- joined yesterday in a telegram urging President Roosevelt to veto the Connally-Smith anti-strike bill on the ground that it was a conspiracy against organized labor and would impede the war program.
LONDON, June 20 (U.P.) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

The Japanese plume themselves on their scientific weather forecasting. For years they have been developing it as a war weapon. Expert meteorologists are attached to all branches of their service. Yet their two worst air disasters seem largely due to faulty weather prediction.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 20 -- Fifteen government ministers attended a conference of trade unions convened by the government for the announced purpose of providing for an exchange of views with the ministers on the industrial problems confronting the government in the war effort.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Four more air attacks on Japanese positions in the Solomon Islands were announced by the Navy today in a communique that mentioned no enemy activity in the area.

Two projects in the Office of Price Administration's double program of educating consumers and retailers on food rationing and maintaining legal price ceilings will be started here today by volunteer price panels in fifteen ration boards, according to H. Woodruff Bissell, price executive of the New York District.

WITH THE BRITISH ROYAL PARTY, in Tunisia, June 18 (Delayed) -- When King George VI visited the city of Tunis today amid scenes of enthusiastic welcome, he was wearing a long-sleeved bush-jacked instead of a shortsleeved one that he wore on previous day of his tour of Allied positions in North Africa.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- American girls serving with the Red Cross in Great Britain are healthy, happy and working hard, according to Mrs. S. Sloan Colt, whose chief job is looking after their welfare.

Brig. Gen. Paul Loeser, general manager and secretary of the Triborough Bridge Authority, announced yesterday that unless the holders of about $10,000,000 of the Authority's serial revenue bonds act promptly to give their consent to amendments to the bond resolution, it may be impossible to prevent a default in interest on Aug. 1.
THE NEW YORK TIMES printed a table of deductions from salaries for income taxes under the new law effective July 1. You note in your heading that the table is one issued by the Treasury Department.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 20 (AP) -- Laundry owners of New York City, who have been hinting at a need to shut down because of shortages, will go on a wartime footing and eliminate many frilly services.

Prime Minister Eamon de Valera of Eire was proposed yesterday as chairman of the peace conference at the end of the war by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, at the eleventh annual Feis of the United Irish Counties Association on the Fordham campus.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 20 (AP) -- Rochester gained a 3-1 edge in its four-game series with Jersey City today by taking both ends of a double-header from the Little Giants, 2 to 0 and 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Every State attained record income levels in 1942, the first full year of the nation's participation in the war, when the national income reached $114,000,000,000, Commerce Department experts report.

In the two-story, red brick building where the congregation has worshiped for eighty years, special all-day services were conducted yesterday on the 100th anniversary of the founding of Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church, Avenue B and Ninth Street.

CHUNGKING, China, June 20 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops, continuing to advance eastward along the Hutu River, south of the Yangtze in Hupeh Province, have recaptured four more localities after wiping out the Japanese garrisons, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.
Four films are scheduled to open at Broadway theatres during the week. Herewith the order of arrival:

Compared with the amounts used by men in the Army, members of the Women's Army Auxiliary Corps use 5 per cent less meat, 10 per cent fewer potatoes, 16 2-3 per cent less bread, 50 per cent less cereal and 33 1-3 per cent less canned milk, flour, sugar and lard for baking.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 20 -- Alfred Rosenberg, Reich Minister for the Eastern occupied areas, is at present touring the Ukraine, according to German reports received here today, which said his party had just inspected the districts of Dniepropetrovsk, the Crimea and Nikolaiev.

Counsel for the foreign bondholders protective committee of St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company first terminal and unifying mortgage 5 per cent bonds due 1952 has filed a brief in the Federal Court at St. Louis in support of objections to the plan of reorganization approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- It was a close shave, but the Four Harmonizers of Chicago are the new champions of barber shop harmony.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (U.P.) -- -- A slow but steady increase in the use of Negro workers in war plants has developed throughout the country during the last year, the War Manpower Commission said tonight in releasing the findings of a survey it made.

Experts see a reversal in the trend away from cereals -- a trend graphically shown by the fact that in 1900 the average consumption was 380 pounds a year as against 250 in the early Thirties. They argue that the rationing of sugar and fats and meats, not to say the shortage of other foods, is prompting people to turn to oats and wheat and such more frequently than they have in the recent past.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Northwest African Air Force came into being on Feb. 17 as a result of the Winter defeats. Lieut. Col. Philip G. Cochran, one of the most brilliant of the younger leaders in that air force, states the case in this way:

A stoppage in the anthracite field of Pennsylvania today appeared inevitable last night, according to Major W.W. Inglis of Scranton, Pa., spokesman for the hard coal operators and chairman of the joint wage conference of anthracite operators and miners.

DUBLIN, June 20 (AP) -- Irish voters will decide Tuesday in their first wartime election whether to continue Prime Minister Eamon de Valera in control of the government he has headed since 1932 or substitute a coalition rule, advocated by the Opposition leader, William T. Cosgrave.

LONDON, June 20 -- Although no extravagant hopes are being built on the present trend of the note circulation of the Bank of England, fears that another big expansion would occur duriing the Summer months have been considerably allayed recently.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 20 (U.P.) -- Swiss newspapers said tonight that 5,000 bodies reported by Axis propagandists to have been buried near Odessa were those of Rumanian Jews killed by the Rumanian secret police.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Apparently encouraged by the recent waves of voluntary plans and favorable court opinions, the Securities and Exchange Commission in its eighth annual report, made public today, told Congress that, so far as enforcement of the "death sentence" clause of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was concerned, it was, in effect, all over but the shouting.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 22 -- British Lancaster bombers, striking another damaging blow against key German war industries, roared over Friedrichshafen in the south Reich during Sunday night and early yesterday and wrecked a large factory manufacturing radio detection equipment. The raid was carried out without loss of a single one of the fast four-motored planes that carry eight tons of explosives.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A minister of "Jehovah's Witnesses" won today a Supreme Court review of his conviction on a charge of failing to report for non-military work after being classified by his draft board as a conscientious objector.

Wholesalers and retailers of blended whiskies may not advance their prices to cover the higher costs of neutral spirits as permitted in the adjustment order recently issued by the Office of Price Administraton unless such blends actually contain imported spirits, the agency warned yesterday.

When an American thinks of Russia, as all must on this second anniversary of Hitler's attack, he may have in mind a Government, an economic system or many millions of people. The Government and the economic system, if we regard them as continuous, are twenty-six years old.

LOWELL BENNETT, a South Orange, N.J., boy, joined the RAAF in Australia, but was thrown out when it was discovered that he was an American citizen. Later on, in Britain, he joined Kermit Roosevelt's International Brigade for Finland. This second attempt to reach a fighting front came to an end when the Russians and the Finns made peace.

Pan-American solidarity is great enough to destroy Axis dictatorships, to help restore peace and security abroad and to discourage foreign exploitation of any part of the Americas, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia declared yesterday in extending at City Hall an official welcome to Gen. Higinio Morinigo, President of Paraguay.

CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- The National Football League today concluded its most important meeting in history by adopting a forty-game schedule for 1943, beginning Sept. 19 with a game between the Chicago Cardinals and Lions of Detroit and ending Dec. 5.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 21 -- Marauders and Lightnings fought their way through swarming enemy fighters yesterday to batter three Sicilian airfields, the keys to the island's aerial defense, as American and British bombers concentrated on the island's air bases and its communications with Italy.

The Rabbinical Assembly of America opened its forty-third annual convention yesterday with an all-day session at the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street. Dr. Louis Finkelstein welcomed more than 200 delegates on behalf of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, and Louis A. Moss spoke for the United Synagogue of America.

Unaffected by priorities, food rationing or scarce hotel accommodations, one of the world's largest "conventions" opened here yesterday with 15,000 "delegates." It was the fourth annual American Doll Show and was held under the auspices of the American Hobby Federation in Hearns Auditorium, Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth Street.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 22 (U.P.) -- A summary of the text of a special Russian communique, recorded from the Moscow radio, follows:

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- In a critical report covering developments on the home front in the last month, the Special Military Affairs (Kilgore) Subcommittee on War Mobilization told the Senate today that there had been "a further deterioration" of the domestic war effort in that period.

AKRON, Ohio, June 21 -- A new cement that joins metals more firmly together than riveting or spot-welding and promises to have important industrial applications was announced today by P.W. Litchfield, chairman of the board of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, at the dedication of its new $1,325,000 research laboratory.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- A temporary order to distribute anthracite coal proportionate to the amount ordered through the summer months last year was announced today by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes as Solid Fuels Administrator.

Adjustment of the July position on the New York Cotton Exchange continued yesterday as the feature of otherwise dull trading in the futures market. At the close of trading the list of active contracts was unchanged to 7 points below Saturday's final quotations, with the new-crop positions weakened by hedging and liquidation.
MONTREAL, June 21 (AP) -- The Royals were outhit, 12 -- 10, tonight but managed to beat Jersey City, 7 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- There were indications here today that London and Washington might soon seek a final solution of the French conflict in North Africa, which they now agree in regarding as dominated by what are described in both capitals as the dictatorial aspirations of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

Accountings filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by trustees of the estate of William Rockefeller, who died in 1922, showed that his estate had a gross value of $62,651,368 between June 11, 1937, the date of the first accounting, and April 30, 1943.

Immediate shifting of 9,000 tank cars from other sections of the country to ease the acute gasoline shortage along the Atlantic seaboard is planned by Federal agencies, it was learned here yesterday, as War Production Chief Donald M. Nelson, in Washington, was promising relief for East Coast civilians "in the very near future."

A bar room brawl early yesterday led to the death of a would-be peacemaker, Joseph Lazarus, 39 years old, an insurance broker o 1125 Park Avenue, and the subsequent arrest of John Jackson, 27, a junior electrician in the British merchant marine, in. District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office.

Wage negotiations by representatives of the Laundry Workers Joint Board with plant operators hit a snag yesterday when the union unexpectedly presented to the employers' associations a new scale revised upward.

While major emphasis will be placed on advertising's current job of aiding the war effort at the thirty-ninth annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America which starts on Monday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, the attacks on brand names will also come up for discussion.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Disease and malnutrition have killed 300 Americans in Japanese prison camps since the fall of Bataan and Corregidor, the War Department disclosed tonight.
Gunder Haegg is going to make a serious assault on at least three of the seven world records he hung up last summer in Sweden, The Associated Press reports.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- Three persons were killed and another seriously injured in a village on the Swiss shore of Lake Constance during last night's RAF attack against Friedrichshafen, which witnesses concurred this morning in describing as "devastating."
