YSTRADGYNLAIS, Wales, June 21 -- The woman behind the bar at Tutcher's Arms, the miners' favorite pub here, had heard of the American labor leader with the ferocious eyebrows and knew all about him. "He's a big man," she said.

Marjorie Lawrence was a Bruennhilde last night who might have fired Richard Wagner's imagination. Appearing as soloist with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium under Fritz Reiner's direction, she sang the Immolation Scene from Wagner's "Goetterdaemmerung" with an imperious courage that would have gladdened the heart of a composer who created heroines, particularly the Bruennhilde of "Goetterdaemmerung," in the grand line.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Pathfinder Magazine said tonight that results of a poll which it conducted among Republican members of thirty-eight State Legislatures showed that Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York was first choice for the party's 1944 Presidential candidate on the basis of potential State-by-State electoral strength, with Governor John W. Bricker of Ohio second and Wendell L. Willkie third.

LONDON, June 21 -- New reconnaissance photographs taken by Royal Air Force planes indicate that industrial targets in the Ruhr and German cities that economically are closely linked with the Ruhr district have suffered from Allied bombing raids devastation greater than that in any other war theatre, the Air Ministry said today.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Dr. Katherine McHale, Director of the American Association of University Women, made public today a letter in which President Roosevelt endorsed the War-Area Child Care bill introduced by Senator Elbert D. Thomas, Utah Democrat, to assure adequate health and welfare services for the children of mothers employed in essential war jobs.

Participation in a draft-dodging scheme involving a $65 bribe and theft and destruction of the records of nine prospective inductees was charged yesterday to William D. Katz, 27 years old, of 1660 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn. Katz formerly was a member of Selective Service Local Board 140 and later became an advisory member, according to E. E. Conroy, local chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

ALBANY, N.Y., June 21 (AP) -- Ten of New York's public campsites, previously kept closed to encourage conformance with restrictions on pleasure driving of automobiles, will be opened through July at least, John L. Halpin, acting State Conservation Commissioner, said today.

AN ADVANCED AIR BASE IN NORTHWEST AFRICA, June 12 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Lieut. Gen. Carl Spaatz, deputy allied air commander in North Africa, told newspapermen today that, if adequate air power could be applied against the heart of a nation, no other force was necessary.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Government efforts to revoke the American citizenship of William Schneiderman, Russian-born California Communist leader, on the grounds that the privilege was fraudulently obtained were rejected by the Supreme Court in a 5-to-3 decision today.

Alexander F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, one of the five railway unions seeking a wage increase of 30 per cent in hearing before an emergency board of the National Railway Panel in the Grand Central Terminal, clashed yesterday with Jacob Aronson, counsel for the carriers.

Germans and Italians received "pep" talks yesterday from Admiral Kichisaburo Nomura of Japan, based on the premise that "the Tripartite Pact powers do not have to attack any more to win; they need only hold out in conquered positions."

ALBANY, June 21 -- Reports from managers of the State's six regional markets indicate a very serious food shortage, with the volume of produce received far below that of a year ago, C. Chester Du Mond, State Commissioner of Agriculture and director of the Emergency Food Commission, declared today.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Hundreds of store representatives in search of merchandise at the midsummer furniture and home furnishings markets checked in at the American Furniture Mart and the Merchandise Mart today, and added to more hundreds that had come a day or two earlier hoping to get choice selections.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 21 (AP) -- With the No. 1 star, Francisco Segura of the University of Miami, on the sidelines until tomorrow because of first-round bye, the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championships started today with scarcely a ripple of excitement.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Palmer Hoyt, publisher of The Morning Oregonian of Portland, took over the helm of the Office of War Information's domestic branch today and found himself in what he called "the peculiar position of a man finding the job abolished which he arrives to take."

Kenneth C. Crain, vice president of the Hospital Management Magazine, a few days ago raised the question in these columns why more people have not joined existing voluntary hospitalization insurance schemes. The answer is not, as he intimates, that Americans are too individualistic, but that these privately managed schemes are too expensive and ineffective to attract the economically informed.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 22 -- Russia made her strongest demand for a second front, as indispensable to allied victory, in a confident special communiqu today on the second anniversary of the Russo-German War.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Assurance that substantial quantities of rayon will be available this year to meet civilian needs was given here today by Frank L. Walton, Director of the Textile, Clothing and Leather Division of the War Production Board.

BOSTON, June 21 (AP) -- Although carried wide at the head of the stretch, George R. Watkins' Gondalina came on to win today's feature offering at Suffolk Downs, the Town Lyne $1,800 allowance event over a mile and a sixteenth.

JERSEY CITY, June 21 -- Salary increases affecting 1,600 teachers and other employes of the Jersey City school department were approved by the local Board of Education today following conferences with representatives of the Teachers Association of Jersey City, it was announced by Alexander D. Sullivan, president of the board.

WASHINGTON, June 21 (AP) -- Selective Service officials disclosed today that locals boards have been instructed to check closely on the work of men now asking or already granted occupational deferment as resident doctors in hospitals.

Davis, War Food Administrator, plans to resign soon unless he is given essential authority to deal effectively with the serious food situation which he was directed to improve.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The employment of children is mounting at an unprecedented rate throughout the country.

General Motors Corporation has paid off the remaining $50,000,000 of the $100,000,000 it borrowed under the Regulation V loan of $1,000,000,000 arranged with a nation-wide banking group last fall. Prompt payments by Federal contracting agencies and cash holdings of the corporation have made such borrowing virtually unnecessary, and the banks are somewhat I discouraged by the general paucity of V loan borrowing by war indus'tries,
The thirteen-story and penthouse apartment house at 1049 Park Avenue has been purchased from the Chase National Bank, as trustee, by Morton and Aaron Simon, comprising the firm of Simon Bros.

LONDON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Artillery bombardments, intensifying scouting forays and gigantic air raids continued to feature fighting on the Eastern Front tonight as the Russo-German war neared its second anniversary tomorrow.

DETROIT, June 21 -- Governor Harry F. Kelly tonight imposed his modified form of martial law on three southeastern Michigan counties, comprising the Detroit metropolitan area.

ALGIERS, June 21 -- Superficially, the disagreement among the de Gaullists, the Giraudists and the moderates continued unabated in the two-and-a-half-hour meeting of the French Committee of National Liberation today. Some commissioners believe, however, that the situation has been eased slightly and that the chances that Gen. Charles de Gaulle might break up the infant government by resigning and taking his commissioners with him have faded.

At the suggestion of the New York regional board of the War Labor Board, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms has appointed a committee to prepare a schedule of clerical salary classifications for Wall Street. Its purpose will be to devise a horizontal wage scale, based on experience rather than job or department.

William B. Falconer was reelected for his sixth term as president of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., following that firm's annual stockholders' meeting yesterday. Other officers re-elected included Charles F. Noyes, chairman; Harold S. Ford, executive vice president; Marcel S. Keene, secretary and treasurer, and George S. Haight Jr., assistant secretary.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Army Liberator heavy bombers flew far northward into the Japanese-held Gilbert Islands Friday night and attacked the enemy stronghold at Tarawa, the Navy stated today. A number of hits were scored on enemy installations.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., June 21 -- Problems brought about by wartime conditions were discussed today by the directors of the seventy-seven camps that use the facilities of the 40,000-acre Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park, in conference with Miss Ruby M. Jolliffe, camp superintendent.

A film on the techniques of canning -- and not half so dull and ponderous as it sounds -- opened a three weeks' engagement yesterday in the auditorium on the fifth floor at Gimbels. It will be shown daily at 2:30 P. M., with "repeats" on Mondays and Thursdays at 7 P. M.

"The Youngest Profession," a Metro production starring Virginia Weidler, Edward Arnold and John Carroll, which opens at the Radio City Music Hall on Thursday, is the latest addition to the week's list of film newcomers. HARVARD, Neb., June 21 (AP) -- A sixteen-year-old youth with an amazing line of legal chatter made a claim of ownership today to the municipal jail in this town of about 700, providing a headache for the town fathers.
The Manhattan Civilian Defense Volunteer Office stressed yesterday the necessity of having additional typists who can volunteer daytime hours to help handle administrative details of its work.

Coal strike news proved yesterday a deterrent to buying, and prices on the New York Stock Exchange sagged fractions to more than a point in dull trading. Business was quiet all day, with lack of buying interest rather than pressure of selling responsible for the downward trend.

EIGHTH UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS, Somewhere in England, June 21 (AP) -- Following exhaustive experiments, the Eighth Air Force announced today that all crews of American heavy bombers were to be equipped with protective armor reminiscent of that worn by knights of the Middle Ages.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- With the Administration showing no indication that it would give Chester C. Davis the additional powers he wants to handle his job as War Food Administrator, agricultural circles tonight speculated on possibilities as Mr. Davis' successors in the very likely event that he resigns.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 21 (AP) -- The Allied command has begun broadcasting appeals to the Italian people to "demonstrate for peace" and warnings to clear away from war industries and centers of communications or face death from the air.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The Army-Navy "E" production award has been given to twenty-one additional industrial plants, it was announced today.

BOSTON, June 21 -- The procedure to be followed in negotiating the termination of military contracts before their completion was outlined here today by Lieut. Col. John W. BERNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- "They [Generals Henri-Honore Giraud and Charles de Gaulle] are reconciled and they will win the war!" Stickers bearing this slogan are being displayed prominently throughout France. This is symptomatic of the situation now developing there in expectation of an Allied landing.

CINCINNATI, June 21 (AP) -- An odd sixth inning meant four runs to the Cardinals tonight and they defeated the Reds, 6 to 2, before 16,197 fans in a game that was halted by weather early in the eighth inning.

Spring became summer in the New York area at 3:13 A.M. today as the city sweltered for the third successive day with temperatures above normal and the humidity making all physical effort uncomfortable. The Weather Bureau, which had recorded a high temperature of 89 degrees at 12:30 P.M. yesterday, offered no consolation for today in its forecast of "continued warm, with moderate winds."
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 21 -- Thunderbird, the indestructible Flying Fortress, has done it again.

James J. Hines, once powerful Tammany district leader, has started an action in the Supreme Court in White Plains to require the State Parole Board to reconsider his application for release from Sing Sing prison, where he is serving a sentence of four to eight years for protecting the policy racket of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, it was disclosed yesterday.

A close race among three players, Charlie Keller of the Yankees, Dixie Walker of the Dodgers and Sid Gordon of the Giants, marks the end of the first week of the Baseball War Bond League's campaign. Financial officials of the Pennsylvania Railroad have opened discussions with the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington with respect to a proposed refunding of $28,483,000 of bonds of the Pennsylvania, Ohio Detroit Railroad Company, operated under lease by the Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- Wartime curfew regulations controlling the movements of American-born Japanese on the West Coast were unanimously sustained by the Supreme Court today as military necessities which are within the powers of Army commanders.

COLUMBUS, June 21 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey of New York threw a bombshell into the opening session of the annual Governors' Conference today when he proposed that farmers of the Midwest begin killing off their pigs and diverting their grain as much as possible to the cows and chickens of New York State.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The War Department announced today the names, with next of kin, of 156 soldiers missing in action in the European, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 21 -- The Battle of the Atlantic has lost the preferred position accorded to it in German High Command communiques during the early months of the current year, and reports from Berlin predict a further heavy slump in the sunken tonnage figures for June claimed for Grand Admiral Karl Doenitz's U-boat packs.

LONDON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Madrid dispatches reported today that eight alarms of various sorts, some possibly caused by the fear of imminent invasion, had been sounded during the past forty-eight hours in southern Italy, Sicily and Sardinia.

Lucia Victor and the New York Stock Company will offer a revival of "Boy Meets Girl," the Bella and Samuel Spewack play, this evening at the Windsor Theatre. Lefty Ken Chase, seeking a new and better life in the National League, made his bow as a Giant in the twilight at Ebbets Field yesterday and for six innings the former Red Sox southpaw got by nicely.

DETROIT, June 21 -- Federal troops in full battle regalia, with jeeps, trucks and armored cars, moved into Detroit tonight to help city police, home guards and State troops restore order in the country's worst race riots since the East St. Louis (Ill.) disturbances in the first World War.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 16: Increases of $110,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations, $200,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $726,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, and $281,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $671,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Three regional fire insurance groups have been merged to form a nation-wide trade organization called the Factory Insurance Association, with headquarters in Hartford, Conn., it was announced yesterday. The new organization will begin to function on July 1.

The stirring five-day engagement with Atlantic submarine packs reported by the British Admiralty throws new light on the progress of Allied efforts to meet the undersea menace. Repeatedly attacked, a large convoy reached port with only a small loss after the probable destruction of five of the raiding craft.

LONDON, June 21 -- Two features of the stock markets here today were a drop of 9 points in San Paulo Railroad and a further rise in diamonds.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- President Roosevelt today took note of the second anniversary tomorrow of Germany's attack on Russia by sending a message to Premier Joseph Stalin paying tribute to the "history-making exploits of the armed forces of the Soviet Union and the almost incredible sacrifices which the Russian people are so heroically making."

For many years employers clung bitterly to the position of arbitrary power over the labor market, and in their opposition to all forms of suggested reform they made themselves morally helpless to meet the flood of inept and unjust legislation which did not cure the evils in the labor market but merely interfered with the legitimate functions of the employer and helped to entrench a counter-power equally arbitrary.

MOSCOW, June 21 -- By the end of February, when the latest calculations were officially tabulated, 428,904 decorations had been awarded to the Red Army, besides those promoted to navy men, civilians, etc.

Headquarters for a Greater New York committee to handle local applications for pressure cookers has been established in the Department of Health Building, 125 Worth Street, and, beginning today, a clerk will be on hand to distribute forms to groups wishing to obtain priority for their purchase.

PHILADELPHIA, June 21 -- Forecasts that hard coal miners would be back at their jobs soon, possibly before the end of the week, came from several sources tonight as word spread in the Eastern Pennsylvania anthracite fields that an agreement had been reached raising the taken vacation pay for 85,000 miners from $20 to $25.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- With virtually all the nation's coal mines shut down for the third time in seven weeks and predictions from industrial and Government sources indicating a disastrous situation if the strike continues, the trend of Government sentiment today appeared to be that President Roosevelt would have to settle the crisis himself.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 18 per cent last week over the comparative week last year, according to the preliminary report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

A ship's purser is urgently needed, the New York University Bureau of Employment heard two weeks ago. Remembering that assistant alumni secretary Fred Halton had once been connected with a shipping company, the bureau called him.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 21 (AP) -- Miss Helen Germaine of New York, defending titleholder, advanced to the quarter-finals of the New Jersey State women's tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today when she gained a first-round default and defeated Miss Olga Kallos of Tuckahoe, N.Y., 6 -- 4, 6 -- 1, in the second round.

The vote by which the House of Representatives chopped off the domestic half of Mr. Davis' Office of War Information was cast primarily along party lines. The House Democrats voted two to one against this action, preferring to stand by Mr. Davis. But the House Republicans voted against Mr. Davis by so large a majority -- 160 to 5 -- that their point of view prevailed.

More than eighty affidavits were filed yesterday by The Associated Press with the Federal Court of the Southern District of New York in opposition to the motion made by the Government last May 25, which asked for a summary judgment in its anti-trust civil suit against the cooperative news agency.
CHICAGO, June 21 (AP) -- Arlington Park opened its 1943 racing meeting, most pretentious in Chicago's history, at Washington Park today to solve a perplexing transportation problem.

CHICAGO, June 21 -- Government requisitioning of supplies of cash corn at terminal markets is regarded by brokers as one step nearer, following announcement that elevator interests must report to the Food Distribution Administration, compliance branch, the amount of that grain they had on hand or purchased to arrive on June 19, as well as the amount sold and to whom.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- The big war production machine, which has been running at top speed for three years, was geared for a crippling slowdown tonight as first effects of the coal mine strike were felt.

Jacob Lebowitz, retail clothier, was bent over his desk about 9 A.M. yesterday, counting some $1,900 in cash and checks in the Noble Lebowitz store at 83 Stanton Street, preparatory to banking the money.

ALBANY, June 21 -- Protests against the appointment of Dr. George H. Chatfield as Queens County member of the New York City Board of Education were heard this afternoon by Dr. George D. Stoddard, State Commissioner of Education.

BOSTON, June 21 (U.P.) -- Whirl-away, 1942 winner, tops the list of thirty-five of the nation's best thoroughbreds nominated today for the ninth renewal of the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap to be run at Suffolk Downs July 5. The entries are:

Edward J. Flynn, Democratic leader of the Bronx, was elected unanimously yesterday to succeed himself as Democratic National Committeeman from New York. The action, taken by the Democratic State Committee at a special meeting at the National Democratic Club, 233 Madison Avenue, was apparently the closing act in the political play that started when Mr. Flynn became President Roosevelt's selection as special envoy to Australia last winter.

Igor Sikorsky, engineering manager of the Sikorsky Aircraft Division of United Aircraft, Inc., predicted yesterday at a meeting of the New York section of the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences in the auditorium of the Engineering Societies Building, 21 West Thirty-ninth Street that in the decade following the war hundreds of thousands of helicopter aircraft would fill the skies here, providing cheap, safe intermediate transportation.

William O'Dwyer, now a lieutenant colonel in the Army, was re-designated yesterday as a candidate for another four-year term as Kings County District Attorney by the members of the Kings County Democratic Executive Committee.

A net operating profit of $4,141,199 for the six months ended on February 27 was reported by Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and its subsidiaries in a statement of operations issued for release today.

The four-story walk-up, on a plot 90 by 93 feet, at 14 Fabyan Place, Newark, N.J., has been sold by the Avon Avenue Corporation to the 15 Fabyan Place Corporation of Newark. This property is assessed for $90,000 and has an annual rent roll of about $13,000.

An eight-point program, designed to conserve the dwindling supply of pulp and to direct it into the most needed channels, was submitted yesterday to Arthur G. Wakeman, director of the pulp and paper division of the War Production Board by the Association of Pulp Consumers, Inc., George R. Wallace, president of the organization, announced.

An agreement made on May 13 for purchase of Postal Telegraph, Inc., by the Western Union Telegraph Company was amended yesterday because of a decision by the War Labor Board on May 31 increasing the wages of Postal employes by about twice the rate of the "Little Steel" formula, it was announced jointly yesterday by A.N. Williams, president of Western Union, and William J. Deegan, head of Postal.

Traffic on the Port Washington branch of the Long Island Railroad was delayed more than an hour last night when a fire started on the railroad drawbridge over Flushing Creek, near the site of the World's Fair. The blaze was discovered at 7 P.M. and was believed to have been started by a combination of the summer heat and a spark from a train which ignited the creosoted ties in the roadbed.

COEDELY, Wales, June 22 -- Bernard Roberts crouched on the dining-room floor in front of the fireplace, like a Moslem bowing toward Mecca. The difference was that the miner's face and head were bent over a washtub while his pretty wife scrubbed his gleaming but grimy back with red soap.

Representative Walter H. Judd, a Minnesota Republican, suggested last night at a joint meeting of the New York Young Republican Club and the Young Women's Republican Club that the Republican and Democratic parties agree on a "constructive national foreign policy" in advance of next year's Presidential election campaign.

Lieut. Nelson Macy Jr., USA, and Mrs. Macy a luncheon gave yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Garden for Mrs. William A. Belden, Miss Gertrude Macy, Capt. Ralph G. Hunt and Lieut. Lewis M. Schwab, USA; John H. Perry and Wilbur Forrest.

The five members of the Senate's Special Subcommittee on War Mobilization who signed the report which was published yesterday are all Democrats. They have no reason to attempt to make political capital out of the situation which now prevails in Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Office of Price Administration will discuss with the House Banking and Currency Committee a reduction to 20 per cent from the 33 1-3 per cent cash down payment which the OPA now requires on the purchase of tenanted property, Paul A. Porter, deputy administrator in charge of rents, disclosed today.
The United States Lawn Tennis Association has come to a definite decision to hold the national amateur championships this year.
American day bombers made their first major attack yesterday upon "Happy Valley" -- the Ruhr Valley in Germany -- with losses there and in an attack at Antwerp of twenty planes.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- One of the best ideas of some of the fantastic deeds of valor being performed on this front, and of what is expected of the Red Army man by his commander, is given by a study of the qualifications for receiving the Soviet Union's new war medal, the Order of the War for the Father-land.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 22 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin defended his Labor Government today against a "no confidence" attack in Parliament by citing Australia's war record and disclosing that American planes soon would increase the strength of the Australian Air Force by 60 per cent.

Although you may look to a frosty ice-cream soda as a virtual life-saver when the thermometer soars upward of 80 degrees, your choice is not the wisest so far as cooling qualities are concerned. First of all, declares Miss Marion E. French, nutritionist for the New York City Department of Health, the soda will refresh you only temporarily, for it acquires body temperature soon after being swallowed.

The categorical method of teaching history, described as the method of putting names and dates together and expected students to rely on their memories to reassort them after the scrambling of time, was disapproved last night at a meeting of the New York Adult Education Council at the Hotel Woodstock.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Office of Price Administration announced today that it had made its grocery pricing regulations sufficiently flexible so that grocery wholesalers and retailers may apply for a reclassification of their establishments and a consequent adjustment of the price ceilings under which they operate.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 22 (AP) -- A court test of New York's anti-kickback law as applied to union work-permit practices seemed assured tonight with the indictment of Joseph S. Fay, vice president of the International Union of Operating Engineers (AFL) and five associates.

AKRON, Ohio, June 22 -- The taming of static, the major nuisance to radio listeners and radio photography, and more recently a major saboteur in radar and war communications in general, was announced today at the dedication of the new research laboratory of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company by P.W. Litchfield, chairman of Goodyear's board of directors.
LONDON, June 22 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Church attendance in outlying communities more or less inaccessible except by automobile has shown a sharp drop as a result of the gasoline shortage and the strict enforcement of the ban on so-called nonessential driving by the Office of Price Administration, a cross-section check in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester counties and northern New Jersey disclosed yesterday.

ALGIERS, June 22 -- The crisis in the French Committee of National Liberation was resolved today by a Compromise. Gen. Henri Honore Giraud will retain the command of the French armies in North Africa, as the Allies desire, while Gen. Charles de Gaulle will continue as commander of all French forces in the rest of the empire.

THE Office of War Information recently reported that the Japanese had "abolished from Japanese life" all of the Olympic sports. It is a smart move because the Sons of the Rising Sun are making preparations for when that sun sets and they relapse into their medieval ways of the last century. When a nation eliminates sports it is a certain sign of belt-tightening.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Frank Knox, Secretary of the Navy, bowing to Justice Department findings that the Navy's disputed contract with the Standard Oil Company of California giving exclusive drilling rights in the Elk Hills oil field was illegal and invalid, notified Congressional Naval Committees today that he might turn from this proposed "partnership" agreement to condemnation proceedings against the company.

The Central Conference of American Rabbis opened yesterday its fifty-fourth annual convention with a meeting of the executive board in the Hotel New Yorker. Dr. James G. Heller of Cincinnati, president of the group, which represents the Reform Rabbinate in the United States and has a membership of 500, addressed the delegates last night.

The Detroit riots have smeared a dark blot on this country's good name at the very moment when it could be of the most assistance to the enemy, and at the very point where it could be most effective. Detroit, with its vast automotive industries, is the key city in our "arsenal of democracy."

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 22 (AP) -- The Italian-born head of the Antonelli Fireworks Company, Inc., Amerigo Antonelli, and six assistants pleaded innocent today to charges of sabotage in connection with allegedly faulty manufacture of incendiary bombs and hand grenades for the United States Army.

Alexander Smallens made his first appearance this season with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night, and devoted his program to eighteenth and twentieth century compositions. The "novelty" of the evening was Aaron Copland's suite from the ballet "Rodeo," which had its first stadium performance.

Re-elected for his sixth term as chairman of the board of the National Dress Manufacturers Association, Henry Silver of Silver Dresses, Inc., yesterday urged the dress industry to anticipate its post-war problems now and to consider particularly the possibilities that will be opened for the export of American-made dresses.

"WHAT a happy, sad, busy, terrible, glorious life a minister leads!" Louis Tucker is a mister and ho has had a "royal good time" leading his. His autobiography, written in the seventy-second year of his life and entitled "Clerical Errors,"* is royally good reading, too. It is a funny, touching, dramatic book written by a man whose courage and integrity and kinetic personal force of character color every page.

LONDON, June 22 (U.P.) -- Germany is reinforcing Italy's mainland and islands, it was learned tonight. This indicated that the Axis command had decided on a strong defense there, although enemy sources warned that the Allied invasion forces might strike first at some other area of the medierranean, by-passing the Italian peninsula.

The Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the public offering of a new issue of 100,000 shares of prior preferred stock. It is understood that the underwriting group will be headed by Lehman Brothers and Hayden, Stone Co. and will include Blyth Co., Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- John L. Lewis and the United Mine Workers of America policy committee tonight called off the nationwide coal strike which began Sunday night by extending their truce with the Government until Oct. 31.

Police Commissioner Valentine denied yesterday that either he or Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell had sent out an order to all commanding officers in the Police Department to take strict precautions against any incident which might touch off race rioting in this city, but he admitted that some of his subordinates might have done so.

Once upon a time there was a newspaper editor who decided that the men in his line of business were giving a wrong slant to the news by printing it on the wrong pages. He made revolutionary changes accordingly.

Records of testimony taken by the Dies committee were placed in evidence yesterday by United States Attorney Howard F. Corcoran at the Federal court trial of Dr. Ferdinand Kertess. Kertess is accused of engineering the transportation to Germany of 183 ounces of platinum group metals, in violation of the export control laws.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- Leaders of the United Mine Workers in the soft coal fields predicted tonight that more than 500,000 idle coal diggers would quickly return to their jobs when official word reached them of their policy committee's action in calling off until Oct. 31 the industry-wide walkout.

Strikes, race riots and other outbreaks of violence do not loom large in proportion to the immense war effort of the United States. Optimists may discount the increasing signs of restlessness and dissension as inevitable consequences of pulls and strains the loose fabric of American society has never known before.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- A civil suit for damages, filed today in Federal District Court by a private citizen, alleged that Gen. Charles G. Dawes, president, and eight other officers of the City National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago conspired to defraud the United States Government of $35,331,464.

Government advertising accounts for only 9.6 per cent of the advertising space of English provincial newspapers, the bulk of which are weeklies, Leslie Bird, British representative of Meyer Both Company, reported yesterday in an analysis of thirty-seven such papers.

Despite a mild epidemic of vacation fever among their volunteers, all the city's civilian defense services will continue almost at full tilt this second wartime summer, chiefs of volunteer groups declared yesterday. Businesslike schedules have been worked out by the Civilian Defense Volunteer Office to allow hard-working aides a respite during the hot weather, with coworkers pinch-hitting for absentees until their own turns come.
PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -Tex Hughson pitched the Red Sox into a third-place tie with Cleveland tonight by twirling a five-hitter to beat the Athletics, 7 to 1, before 8,689 at Shibe Park.

Testimony purporting to show that a doctor reported a gross income for tax purposes in 1942 of only $11,436 although he allegedly collected at least $16,229 on compensation cases alone, which was only half of his practice, was brought out yesterday at the Moreland inquiry in the Bar Association Building.

While the district Office of Price Administration was penalizing the 73-year-old skipper of a Long Island charter fishing boat yesterday for taking a party into South-old Bay on June 2, Federal agencies in Washington were understood to be busy on a proposed reorganization of petroleum transportation on the Great Lakes and canal routes as part of the "relief program" now being devised to ease the East Coast gasoline shortage.

Laundry workers throughout New York State, with the exception of the New York City area were placed yesterday in the same category as persons working in essential industries in an order issued by the regional office of the War Manpower Commission.

LONDON, June 22 -- Queen Elizabeth held her first investiture this week. As deputy for the absent King she decorated more than 270 persons at a ceremony in Buckingham Palace, it was announced today. This is the first time an investiture has been held by the Queen since the days of Queen Victoria.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 22 -- Two employes of the J.D. Fowler Company, construction engineers, were sent to the hospital with serious injuries and a third man was slightly hurt as the result of rioting today at the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company's Hubbard blast furnace.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Short covering developed in the wheat market late in today's session on the Board of Trade and a rally of around 1 cent a bushel from the early low followed, resulting in the market closing at the top with net gains of 1/8 to 3/8 cent.

As the war progresses there will be more compulsion in manpower regulations, and less talk about democracy, Dr. Bryce M. Stewart, director of research of Industrial Relations Counselors, Inc., predicted yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Sheraton.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Census figures showed today nearly 4,000 centenarians in the country, but even the Census Bureau did not believe it.

LONDON, June 22 (U.P.) -- All Jews in Amsterdam have been deported by the Germans to Poland, thus completing the removal of the entire Jewish population of the Netherlands, the Aneta news agency said today.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Before a morning crowd of 3,783, Paul Derringer shut out the Pirates on seven hits today while a single by Shortstop Lenny Merullo, following a two-base error by a substitute third baseman for a 1-0 victory for the Cubs.

"Dixie," a Paramount production about Dan Emmett and his Virginia Minstrels, starring Bing Crosby and Dorothy Lamour, will open this morning at the Paramount. Featured in the Technicolor musical are Marjorie Reynolds, the late Lynne Overman, Raymond Walburn, Eddie Foy Jr. and Billy de Wolfe.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Judge Marvin Jones, president of the United Nations Food Conference at Hot Springs, Va., reported today on the sessions of the conference to the Agriculture Committee of the House.
This is what the Axis was saying about the coal strike in the United States, according to reports yesterday from Federal Communications Commission monitors.
EVANSTON, Ill., June 22 (AP) -- Francisco Segura broke into the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis scene today and gained an easy victory.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. announced today that since payment of individual income taxes was now virtually current, the sale of Treasury tax savings notes of series A had been discontinued and that the holders of any surplus of these notes would be allowed to redeem them in cash at the tax-payment value current at the time of presentation.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 23 (U.P.) -- Berlin reported today that the Russians had opened the third year of the Eastern Front war by attacking or reconnoitering in five key areas of the front, including the important Kirov sector, between Smolensk and Orel, where they were using artificial fog and were expected to attack anew.

The first van loads of household goods belonging to twenty-four families of war workers and naval officers yesterday began filling the rooms of the Clinton Hill housing development erected by the Equitable Life Insurance Society, at Clinton and Willoughby Avenues in the Brooklyn Hill section of Brooklyn.

Former Magistrate Hulon Capshaw was disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division for attempting to "obstruct the administration of justice" and for "professional misconduct." Justice Edward S. Dore concurred as to Capshaw's guilt but dissented on the punishment.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- Two seeded stars were eliminated today from the Women's New Jersey State Tennis Championships -- both in straight sets-in the quarter-final round.

AT A RED ARMY FIGHTER BASE, June 22 -- Russian pilots like the American P-39 [Airacobra] fighters, which are arriving here steadily in quantities under lend-lease and which they affectionately dub "Cobras." They employ them not only as ordinary day fighters, and occasionally as attack planes, but also for night use, although no new equipment, such as the radio locater, is installed in them, but specially trained pilots operate them.

CHICAGO, June 22 (U.P.) -- The circus world dropped its mask and lost its smile at 11 o'clock today in memory of show business' most tragic accident, in which eighty-five performers were killed a quarter of a century ago.

Expressing fear that a serious reaction similar to the one after the last war may follow in the post-war period, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia said yesterday that "our country may go wild over some slogan or epigram and that some scheming politicians may take advantage of the frayed nerves of the people and that the people might be misled" and an attempt made again to crush the masses.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 23 -- The Flying Fortresses of the United States Eighth Air Force entered the Battle of the Ruhr yesterday in great strength.

Lieut. Col. Ralph Mackenzie Kellogg died on May 23 in the North African area as the result of an airplane accident while on a mission, according to word received here yesterday. Before his death he had received the Air Medal for operational flights over enemy territory.

Flaught and Grey Wing, both bred by Walter M. Jeffords, but now running for Mrs. Ethel Jacobs and the Cedar Farm, respectively, captured the main events at Aqueduct yesterday and both ran the same kind of race.

A tall, thin man in a French Army uniform told yesterday of his experiences for sixteen months as a prisoner of the Gestapo and of his subsequent escape through North Africa. He was the Rev. Pierre Goube, former chaplain of the French Air Forces, who spoke in his native tongue at the headquarters of the Coordinating Council of the French war Relief Societies, 457 Madison Avenue.

The United States stands at the threshold of an era in which women will be in the majority, a change that holds implications of vast importance in the future of business, Frank R. Wilson, assistant to Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones, declared yesterday.

LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- While the British heavies were over Krefeld last night, RAF fighters swept out on intruder patrols over France and Belgium, attacking the airfield at Poix and hitting railway targets, the British communique reported.

The scandal of "medical kickback" fees, as brought out in the Moreland Act Investigation of the administration of the Workmen's Compensation Law, is the direct result of attempts at bureaucratic regulation of the medical profession.

A UNITED STATES BASE, Somewhere in India, June 12 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Mothers, wives and sweethearts at home were held largely responsible today for the high ratio of mental cases among American soldiers in the ChinaBurma-India theatre.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -Carmen Miranda, instead of Alice Faye, will be starred in Twentieth Century-Fox's proposed musical, "Greenwich Village." Miss Faye will take a leave of absence after her current "The Girl He Left Behind." The Miranda picture, which will deal with the Village during the prohibition era, will be produced by William Le Baron and directed by Walter Lang.

WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -- Senator Albert W. Hawkes, former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, and Republican National Chairman Harrison E. Spangler will address a Republican dinner in Pittsburgh, which Senator Guffey, Democrat, of Pennsylvania described to the Senate today as costing "$8,000 a plate."

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The report from Algiers that General Henri-Honore Giraud will remain in command of the French forces in North and West Africa, while General Charles de Gaulle will command those in other French territories, accords with the desires of this Government and of General Dwight D. Eisenhower, the allied Commander in Chief in that theatre. Those desires were made known to General de Gaulle.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, June 22 (AP) -- To the strains of "God Save the King" followed by "The Star-Spangled Banner," the Stars and Stripes were hoisted over the Eighth Air Force Support Command Headquarters here today.

LONDON, June 22 -- Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz, who was Commander in Chief of the Polish Army at the outbreak of the war, now is the leader of one of Poland's most effective underground groups, two London newspapers reported today.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- Sixty United States Army and Navy decorations have been awarded to Russian soldiers and sailors for the first time in history. Ambassador William H. Standley made the presentation at a ceremony in the Kremlin today, with Foreign Commissar Vyascheslaff M. Molotoff accepting the decorations on behalf of the Russian fighting men.

To help improve the teaching of American history in the schools and colleges of this country, a comprehensive survey in this field has been undertaken, sponsored by the American Historical Association, the Mississippi Valley Historical Association and the National Council for the Social Studies, it was learned yesterday.

A pledge that the House Committee to Investigate Restrictions on Brands Names and Newsprint will fight any attacks on trademarks and advertising, "which have served the American people well," was given yesterday by Representative Lyle H. Boren, chairman of the committee, in an address at the weekly luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.
ST. LOUIS, June 22 (AP) -- The White Sox defeated the Browns, 5 to 3, tonight. Harlond Clift hit his second home run of the year for the basement-dwelling Browns.
The downward trend in construction continued during May in the thirty-seven eastern States, as the contracts awarded amounted to only $234,426,000, according to the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 22 -- Moved by the fear that the coming of peace may turn many of their communities into areas of obsolete facilities, with millions unemployed, State Executives meeting here for the annual Governors' conference started a determined effort today to set up a system for post-war planning within their own spheres and jurisdiction.

Don Juan, claimant to the Spanish throne, has informed General Francisco Franco that he would not accept monarchial restoration under the Franco regime and called upon General Franco to establish a Spanish foreign policy of real neutrality, the United Press learns.

The four-family dwelling on a plot 30 by 100 feet at 1681 Fifty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation to Luigi Tucci through the Sullivan-Kushner Company, Inc., in cooperation with Michael J. Rizzo. The HOLC also sold through the Sullivan Kushner concern:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, June 23 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:

DUBLIN, June 22 (AP) -- Polling in Eire's general election to determine whether or not Prime Minister Eamon de Valera is to be returned to power for another five years closed tonight after one of the most peaceful voting days in the country's history.

Churches in the post-war world must stand for "economic justice" and work for peace, Dr. Walter W. Van Kirk, secretary of the Commission on International Justice and Goodwill of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, told the evening session of the annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Fifty-fourth Street and Lexington Avenue, last night.

An American admiral handed out sixty medals yesterday for "combat service." Twenty were for distinguished action at sea, the others for valor in land battles. The recipients ranged in rank from sergeant to general and from common sailor to admiral.

PASSAIC, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- One world track record was broken and an American standard was established in another event tonight at an invitation track and field meet which was featured by assaults on seldom-challenged marks.

"The Two Mrs. Carrolls," the London importation which will bring Elisabeth Bergner back to the local stage, is now scheduled to make its New York debut on Aug. 2, according to the plans of Robert Reud and Paul Czinner, the sponsors. It originally had been slated to arrive on July 19.

According to a Stockholm dispatch, Nazi authorities are alarmed by the deteriorating effect of the fortune-tellers upon national morale. Two prophets have been sentenced to jail and hard labor. Berlin is the center of these forecasters. They thrive in spite of attempts to put them out of business.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Scarcity of merchandise, loss of personnel and better alternative opportunity of employment were found by the authors of a Commerce Department survey of "Small Retail Store Mortality," which is published today, to be the outstanding reasons why small business men have been closing their stores since war began.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 -- The possibility that war production in New Jersey, one of the nation's ranking arsenals, may become virtually paralyzed was raised today by a walkout of an estimated 2,600 electrical repair and maintenance workers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which supplies power to war plants throughout the State.

After three weeks of political maneuvers between its rival factions, the French Committee of National Liberation has at last worked out a solution which is rightly dubbed a "settlement that settles nothing." Generals Giraud and de Gaulle remain commanders of their respective armies, while a committee headed by both of them has been appointed to make further efforts toward unifying all French forces at a later date.

MODELTOWN, N.Y., June 22 (AP) -- The huge Lake Ontario Ordnance Works, in operation nine months, will stop production of TNT July 31 because, its commanding officer said today, of the lack of need for its produce "due to the ever-changing requirements of the armed forces."

LONDON, June 22 -- The doughboy newspaper Stars and Stripes stirred up a red-hot controversy in at least one Army kitchen today with a suggestion to do away with potato peeling by having all spuds cooked in their jackets.

Investors yesterday were waiting for something to happen in the arenas of war or labor, and the stock market went through another dull day. Rumors that the coal strike might see an early settlement permeated Wall Street near noon and the resulting suspicion of strength wiped out-early losses and brought an irregularly higher close.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of eighty-four United States soldiers killed in action in the Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American and Southwest Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The argument by those in favor of food subsidies that they will not be inflationary in the United States because they are not in the United Kingdom has been examined by opponents of the plan and found wanting in a fundamental particular.
Summer opened its 1943 season yesterday by averaging 12 degrees above normal for the date, with a high temperature of 91 degrees, reached at 3:50 P. M.
There is a bit of encouragement in the news from Albany for those who formerly selected State campsites for their vacations.

DETROIT, June 22 -- Under orders to "load your guns and don't take anything from anybody" United States troops patrolled Detroit streets today, restoring calm to this great armament production center after twenty-four hours of racial conflict that brought death to twenty-nine persons and injuries of varying degree to at least 700 others.

Princess Margrethe of Denmark, her daughter, Princess Anne de Bourbon Parme and Mrs. Ruth Bryan Rohde, one time Minister to Denmark, were guests of honor yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Danish-American Women's Association in the Hotel Pierre.
Yesterday's German communique, a broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

Net sales of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., for its fiscal year ended with March reached a new peak of $141,046,615, representing an increase of 25 per cent from the $112,309,839 volume of the previous year, the company's annual report will disclose today.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- The second anniversary of the Nazi attack on Russia was marked by the opening of an exhibit of captured enemy arms and equipment, a sober reminder of German strength and thoroughness.

CHICAGO, June 22 -- Essential needs of retailing, after the armed forces have been supplied, should be met, according to Hughston M. McBain, president of Marshall Field Co., in order to maintain the highest possible civilian living standards consistent with the war effort. He declared today the program is an integral part of the country's war economy.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 22 -- The major realty and building needs of the armed forces in this country now have been met, with the War Department alone holding 20,000,000 acres of land and with Federal agencies listed as tenants of more than 150,000,000 square feet of space exclusive of Federal buildings and rented postoffice quarters, the National Association of Building Owners and Managers was told today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 (AP) -- The question whether the Court of Chancery of New Jersey can restrain activities by a securities dealer in Canada was raised today before Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein.

Discussions of a plan for changing delivery times on the New York Stock Exchange have reached a stage where action appears imminent. Studies by the back-office committee of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms have been under way for some weeks and have resulted in a request to Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, that its staff work out details.
LONDON, June 22 (U.P.) -- A joint British Air Ministry and American Headquarters for the European Theatre of Operations communique:

I cannot refrain from commenting upon a letter from Mrs. Williams in THE TIMES of June 14. She put a question that will take some answering, especially at a time when we are prating a bit about freedom and the democratic way of life and indulging in editorials praising the Supreme Court's ruling regarding certain religious sects' unwillingness to salute the flag.

SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 22 -- The heavy air losses that the Japanese have been suffering during the last week in the Southwest Pacific cannot fail to have an important effect on future military operations in these areas. Japan will desperately need the planes she has recently lost when the time comes for her to attempt to halt counter-offensive blows by Allied forces in the Pacific.
The Commonwealth of Massachusetts announced yesterday that it will be in the market on June 28 with $2,500,000 of notes. The issue will be dated July 13 and will be payable on June 12, 1944.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 22 -- The port of Naples, the nucleus of the Axis defenses in the mid-Mediterranean, was blasted into a sea of flaming wreckage yesterday when Flying Fortresses completed a smashing Allied "one-two" punch against the chief supply center for Sardinia and Sicily.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Hogs slumped today to a top of $13.95 a hundredweight, the lowest since last November, as expanded receipts pushed prices downward 15 to 20 cents in slow trading. The day's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

LONDON, June 22 -- Milos Bobitch, a Serb, one-time Mayor of Belgrade and most recently active in post-war reconstruction plans, was asked today by King Peter to try and form a Yugoslav Cabinet. This step came after Jovan Banjanin, Minister of Forests and Mines, had informed the King of his failure to do so.

It took the Senators nearly eight innings in the humid heat of the Yankee Stadium to find the range on Hank Borowy yesterday. Then their heavy guns, Dick Vernon and Bob Johnson, bracketed Charley Keller with a pair of triples in left field and the game belonged to the Senators, 3 to 2.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- The second anniversary of the German invasion of Russia was the occasion of comment today in the Berlin press, the conclusions being that the Bolshevist menace in Europe had been underestimated rather than exaggerated.

Close cooperation between management and labor and speeding up of completion of the industry expansion program were recognized yesterday as essential to an increased production of steel in the last half of 1943 by a meeting of steel leaders held in the Empire State Building.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 22 -- New Zealand fighter planes in the South Pacific are now inflicting losses upon the Japanese, the Air Department revealed today with the announcement that the four-day score of fighter squadrons fighting under Admiral William F. Halsey, Commander in Chief in the South Pacific, was now sixteen Japanese planes definitely destroyed.
MONTREAL, June 22 (AP) -- Montreal and Jersey City split a double-header tonight, with the Little Giants taking the opener, 4 -- 1, and the Royals the nightcap, 10 -- 1.

Charley (Lulu) Costantino, East Side featherweight, defeated Angel Aviles of Mexico in the star bout of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. A crowd of 3,600 fans paid $3,472 to witness the show. Costantino had trouble with his left-handed rival in the first three rounds, but solved Aviles' style thereafter.

CINCINNATI, June 22 (U.P.) -- The Sixth United States Circuit Court of Appeals today ordered the District Court at Detroit to proceed with the hanging of Max Stephan, Detroit restaurant operator, convicted of treason for harboring Hans Peter Krug, an escaped German flier.
LONDON, June 22 (AP) -- The Russian noon communiqu, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:
College football is being abandoned on a wholesale scale across the nation, a United Press survey disclosed last night, with the South and the East struck hardest by the gridiron blackout.

There was the makings of a first-class row in Tammany Hall last night. Feelings had been hurt, precedent trampled upon. But there was also the weather to be considered. It was hot. So the parties concerned just mopped their brows, rushed through routine business at meetings of the executive and county committees and departed for air-conditioned places.
Sir Shuldham and Lady Redfern have arrived from Government House, Ottawa, and are at the Chatham.

Children's wear buyers should fight for an increase in advertising and promotion appropriations, for a place in store meetings and a voice in store thinking and planning, Abbott Kimball, head of the advertising agency of the same name, told the Infants' and Childrens Wear Buyers Association at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,172 as against 1,536 in the preceding week and 1,070 in the similar period of last year, according to the listings in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's arrivals totaled 543 which compared with 626 last Tuesday.

Under wartime conditions and competing for space against priorities granted to passengers and express, airmail is now subject to frequent delays. The necessity for air travel for a person engaged in war missions cannot be questioned, but the importance of the mail should also be considered.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox and military observers took an unruffled view today of Russia's latest and strongest demand for a second front in Europe, while in diplomatic circles, where the Soviet statement was studied with interest, it was cautiously suggested that Russia might be speaking "for the record" to make her position extremely clear.
ABOARD A UNITED STATES SUBMARINE, in the Pacific, June 22 (U.P.) -- Lieut. Commdr. Philip H. Ross, commanding this submarine, wiped the sweat from his brow and put his eye to the periscope.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 22 -Nelson A. Rockefeller, Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs, told the Chamber of Commerce today that "cooperation among the Americas in the coordination of price controls and larger production of food and other essentials" was one answer to the problem of the trend toward higher costs of living.

Testimony that twenty-one textile finishers were forced by threats of sabotage and personal injury to pay a tribute of $1,500 a month from 1932 to 1934 opened the State's case yesterday in General Sessions against Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, arrested as a racketeer in the garment industry.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Wednesday, June 23 (U.P.) -- The largest Japanese ground force reported recently in the Mubo area of New Guinea, 130 miles above Buna, attacked allied positions along a ridge east of the village Monday and was repulsed sharply, with more than 100 casualties, it was revealed today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- As Berlin's time limit -- the end of this month -- draws nearer for the delivery of another 220,000 workers, Pierre Laval, Chief of Government, has begun a combing-out process. Hitherto youths of 21 enrolled in the Todt organization on French soil -- those working on the "Atlantic Wall" -- were exempt from service in Germany. Today it is announced that they must leave forthwith.

GUADALCANAL, June (AP) -- Without giving false hopes to the United States, the thought arises -- just how long can the Japanese take the present air-pounding in the South Pacific and still maintain a semblance of composure?

TORONTO, June 22 (AP) -- The Newark Bears climbed to within one game of first place tonight when they defeated the league-leading Toronto Maple Leafs, 6 -- 2. Frank Hiller, on the mound for Newark, limited the Leafs to seven hits while striking out eight to gain his fourth victory.

Concentrating most of their attack in one inning, the Dodgers yesterday defeated the Giants again, 7 to 4, at Ebbets Field, ran their winning streak to four straight -- their longest series of triumphs since late in May -- and cut the Cardinals' first-place lead to two games.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Senator Robert F. Wagner, Democrat, of New York, said today that he soon would introduce legislation to increase allowances for the immediate families of men of the armed forces who have children.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The overseas shipping situation has so much improved due to a combination of factors that the task of finding cargo for available ships has become more trying than finding ships for essential cargo, the War Shipping Administration said today.

In residence at the Windsor, Lucia Victor and the New York Stock Company last evening turned their attention to the Bella and Samuel Spewack "Boy Meets Girl," which was the Broadway riot in 1935. With it they had a better script than "The Milky Way," with which they opened their season, but even so, the production was somewhat removed from George Abbott's of the same name.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

Thousands of Americans paid tribute yesterday to the courage and gallantry of the Red Army and the contribution of the Soviet Union to the cause of the United Nations in meetings here and elsewhere in the nation.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP) -- Directors of the Norfolk Western Railway Company declared today a quarterly dividend of $1 a share on the adjustment preferred stock, payable on Aug. 10 to stock of record of July 22. They also declared a quarterly dividend of $2.50 a share on the common stock, payable on Sept. 10 to stock of record of Aug. 21.

BOSTON, June 22 -- In the postwar world, increased volume will be used not to increase profits but to provide employment, and the rate of profit will be determined by the degree of intelligence with which cost control is exercised, it was declared today at the annual convention of the National Association of Cost Accountants by F.F. Hoyt, vice president and controller of the Carrier Corporation, Syracuse, N.Y.

Lacking incentives for forward commitments, traders in cotton futures continued yesterday to concentrate their activity in the July position on the New York Cotton Exchange, with price fixing by the trade for Southern mills and covering in that contract offset by liquidation in advance of first-notice day, Friday.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 22 (AP) -- American heavy bombers of the Ninth United States Air Force blasted important Italian military establishments on the "toe" of Italy in daylight yesterday and shot down twenty of forty enemy fighters that challenged them, a Middle East communique said today.

EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 22 -- Almost the entire night shift of the Crocker-Wheeler Electric Manufacturing Company of Ampere, N.J., near here, went on strike at 6 P.M. today. The walkout halted production at the plant, which is engaged almost entirely on Army and Navy contracts.

NEWARK, N.J., June 22 -- Indictments charging seven Army privates with having kidnapped and robbed the Rev. Wilmont A. Green, curate of Christ Gospel Church, Atlantic City, were returned here today by the Federal grand jury.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- While American airmen continued their pounding of Japanese bases in the South Pacific, Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox today threw cold water on any supposition that the aerial attacks were a prelude to any immediate United States offensive in the South Pacific.

For the first time since last September the general death rate in New York fell below the "anticipated" figure last week, it was reported yesterday by the city Health Department. The death rate last week was 9.2 per 1,000 population, 2.4 below the previous week.

LONDON, June 22 -- Overseas railway shares strengthened today on the stock markets here. Canadian Pacific ordinary improved 3-16 to 16 1/8. San Paulo Railway ordinary stock was steadier at its overnight level of 60.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 22 -- The latest issue of Vichy's Journal Officiel to reach here contains a law signed by the Chief of State, Marshal Henri Philippe Petain, "closing the session of the Supreme Court."

Expressing concern over rumors of negotiations between Allied and Italian leaders, a group of forty-five educators, labor leaders, journalists and religious leaders issued an appeal yesterday through the Union for Democratic Action for a restatement by the Government of its demand for the "unconditional surrender of fascism."
WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) -The House agreed today to accept a Senate-approved $100,000,000 rise in the Agriculture Department's 1944 funds for soil conservation payments.

Although the railroads of the country are moving a greater volume of freight than ever, carloadings are running sharply below those of a year ago and are only slightly higher than two years ago. For the first four months of this year it is estimated that the railroads handled about 26 per cent more ton-miles of revenue freight than in the similar period of 1942, while carloadings were down about 5 1/2 per cent.

Thirty "primitive" paintings by Morris Hirshfield of Brooklyn constitute the exhibition which opens today in the ground floor galleries of the Museum of Modern Art. This is a "retrospective" exhibition including all the work Mr. Hirshfield has done in this field in the five or six years since retiring at the age of 65, after two decades or more of work in the cloak and suit business and as a slipper manufacturer.

CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- Whirlaway, all-time leading money winner, returned to the races, after a lay-off of 191 days, in Arlington Park's program at Washington Park today and finished third to his stablemate, Mar-Kell, in a one-mile tune-up for the $10,000 added Equipoise Mile Saturday. Whirlaway is one of twenty-three eligibles for the Equipoise.

Don Burke, correspondent for Time and Life magazines, just returned from six months in the Solomon Islands, will be the great today of Bullets Cerf on "Books Are Bullets," to be broadcast at 5 P.M. over WQXR. The program, a weekly feature, is sponsored by the Council on Books in Wartine.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The War Production Board has completed a survey to find sites for additional aluminum plants which will be erected to augment production if the 1944 aircraft program, as is expected, calls for increased output of heavy bombers.

School children of this city will flock to war industries and the farms, as well as office jobs and civilian employment, in unprecedented numbers this year, according to reports submitted yesterday to City Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins.
Your editorial of June 17, "The Better 'Ole," reminds me of a story Dr. Kettering told many years ago which I think is quite appropriate to the theme of your editorial:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 22 -- An indication as to where the German General Staff thinks that an invasion may come is furnished by reports received here through private channels from fairly reliable Berlin sources.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- War has sent the income of the average American from $47.92 in July, 1940, to $85.03 in April of this year, the Office of War Information reported today.

Scholarships and medal certificates were awarded yesterday afternoon by the School Art League to boys and girls from the New York City high schools at exercises in the auditorium of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue, between 103d and 104th Streets.

The City Council committee investigating the administration of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia adopted yesterday rules for the conduct of the inquiry, including one permitting the creation of subcommittees composed of one or more members empowered to hold private hearings on special phases of the investigation.

Restrictive regulations by the Office of Price Administration were held responsible for the shutdown yesterday of the world's largest starch manufacturing plant -- the Corn Products Refining Company's plant at Pekin, Ill., working largely on war contracts.

BOSTON, June 22 (AP) -- Catcher Phil Masi's second home run of the season, with Chet Ross on base in the fifth inning, gave the Braves a 7-to-6 victory over the Phillies at Braves Field today. The home run was off the Phillies' "Lefty" Jack Kraus after Ross had made a base hit.

LONDON, June 22 -- The problem of how to cease making money hand over fist now appears a major one for the chain of United States Army Post Exchanges throughout the European Theatre of Operations. Profits for the seven months ended last October amounted to about $2,000,000, five-eighths of which has been returned for the use of unit funds to buy magazines, records and other recreational equipment.
LONDON, June 22 -- Field Marshal Sir Archibald Wavell spoke his mind today on the most outstanding questions raised by his appointment as Viceroy of India.

How the New York City schools have adjusted their program to the war economy and at the same time maintained essential cultural subjects of long-range importance was described in a reviewing of the last year, made public yesterday by Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools. Dr. Wade completes his first year as Superintendent on Friday.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The Senate tomorrow will take up for decision the question of food subsidies and a House test on the issue is not far behind.

The seventeen-story loft building at 6-8 West Forty-fifth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenue, has been purchased by the 2728 Realty Corporation, represented by Roe Kramer, attorneys. The seller was the New York Savings Bank. Cuyler Co., Inc., brokers in the deal, have been appointed agents for the structure, which is assessed for $290,000.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The War Meat Board reported today that increased pork production last week as compared with a year ago almost offset the reduction in other types of meat.

Because of the failure of the Australian Government to take a long-sighted view of production in agriculture and industry while dealing with war manpower problems, the Commonwealth faces a serious food shortage, Albert Badman, a member of the Australian House of Representatives, declared here yesterday after his arrival from London.

Fire, accident and marine premiums of the Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Company, Ltd., of Liverpool, England, amounted to 10,485,290 in 1942, an increase of 475,943 over 1941, according to the annual report by P.R. England, chairman.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 23 (AP) -- The Russian Tuesday midnight communique as recorded here by the Soviet monitor:

When a government official a few days ago needed to know the exact number of Chevrolet coupes in the United States, an alert clerk in the Office of Price Administration headquarters in the Empire State Building shuffled quickly through a master file of the States, and came up with the answer.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The War Production Board has instructed manufacturers and wholesalers to set aside for sale to farm distribution outlets specifies percentages of about fifty items, largely tools and equipment, needed on farms and which are in short supply.

Though there may be a general scarcity of manpower, 13-year-old Robert Little Jr. didn't think it quite fair that he alone should make up for the labor shortage. So, on Saturday night he packed up and left the twenty-five-acre farm in North Carolina where he milked a cow at 7 every morning, took care of the vegetable garden, sold newspapers in the town and went to school.

American foreign traders in the reopening of post-war European markets can learn much by watching the example of Sweden which has had the advantage of a "ringside seat" during the war and which recognizes that it must continue to "live with" the neighboring nations, Marvin M. Lowes, assistant director of the international editions of the Readers Digest, declared yesterday.

The four-story apartment building for nine families on a plot 35 by 70 feet at 764 East 187th Street, the Bronx, has been purchased by Gerald Tranzillo through the Richard O. Califano Company, broker. Sale was for cash.

Two prisoners, who confessed to the same burglary but insisted that they did not know each other, caused detectives of the West Thirtieth Street police station to believe yesterday that perhaps they had found a double solution to the looting of $200 in apparel from a haberdashery window, at 462 Seventh Avenue last Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Rookie Leon Culberson's fourth-inning home run gave the Red Sox a 1-to-0 victory over the Athletics before 8,053 fans who sat through an hour-and-five-minute blackout at Shibe Park tonight. It was the Mackmen's sixth straight loss.

The regional War Labor Board yesterday gave approval to a general wage increase of 6.7 cents an hour for employes of the New York cleaning and dyeing industry previously agreed upon between employers and the Cleaners and Dyers Union, Local 239, an affiliate of the Amalagamated Clothing Workers, CIO.

Frank C. Moore, New York State Controller, announced yesterday that he would offer for sale on Tuesday, through competitive bidding, various blocks of New York State municipal bonds aggregating $6,493,587. These bonds are in the investment accounts of the Canal Debt Sinking Funds 9 and 12, and their sale will not constitute new financing by the State.
LONDON, June 23 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Early this week a cool, well-ordered shop opened in the middle Fifties, and immediately set about to disprove the theory that a woman must suffer in order to be beautiful. It is the contention that anything from a manicure to a permanent wave may be administered with speed, with economy and above all with comfort.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Senate fight over subsidies for consumer price roll-backs began today when the Banking and Currency Committee agreed upon a compromise under which the programs to which the Administration has committed itself would be approved and financed, but Congress then would take command.

With 16,308 in the stands, Aqueduct staged the last midweek festivities of its summer meeting yesterday with a steeplechase handicap and the Gazelle Stakes, for 3-year-old fillies, as twin features arranged by the management.

The nation's gasoline supplies last week declined 1,308,000 barrels to 79,806,000, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A year ago, they amounted to 89,693,000 barrels. Light fuel oil supplies increased 1,003,000 barrels to 33,558,000, compared with 31,477,000 a year ago, but heavy fuel oil supplies decreased 197,000 to 67,455,000, against 78,934,000 a year ago.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 23 -- Members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America employed in the Kearny and Port Newark plants of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company adopted a resolution tonight approving a thirty-day extension of a contract expiring at midnight to give the negotiation committee additional time to work out a new contract with the management.

The adoption of quality standardization in retail trade by offering commodities for sale only in standard units of weig4nt and measure and restricting series to sizes that are self-defining as to quantity of content would be advantageous to packers, dealers and the consumer, the National Bureau of Standards stated yesterday.
BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- The combination of timely hitting and effective pitching today enabled the Braves to sweep a double-header with a 1-0 shut out and a 4-3 victory in eleven innings.

With buying activity in the women's apparel markets here tapering off following the peak arrivals of buyers in the last four to six weeks, initial deliveries of fall garments are coming through better than was expected, reports yesterday indicated. However, the real test of the delivery situation, according to the consensus in both the retail and manufacturing fields, will come during the latter part of July and in August.

The Eureka Vacuum Cleaner Company announced yesterday a dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share, the same as was paid on March 29. Last year stockholders received only one dividend, 10 cents in December, the first disbursement since 1937.
Much more comfortable weather arrived in town yesterday afternoon, and if it takes temperatures in the 80s to make a heat wave, then the heat wave was over for the time being.
MONTREAL, June 23 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants defeated Montreal, 4 to 2, tonight to earn an even break in the four-game series. An eighth-inning homer by Juan Torres was the deciding blow.

DETROIT, June 23 -- Fifteen hundred foremen employed in four units of the Ford Motor Company's River Rouge plant walked out today in protest against the suspension or discharge recently of some sixty of their fellow members of the Independent Foremen's Association of America.

The flurry in Washington over the Navy's lease of its Elk Hills oil lands in California to Standard Oil naturally revived memories of the Teapot Dome scandal of twenty-one years ago. There is no evidence, however, that the two instances are comparable. The lease was executed last November with the President's approval.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 305 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Aleutian area and of 283 held prisoners of war by Italy.
