Confidence that the United States would weather the post-war period successfully, profiting by lessons learned by both private enterprise and Government, was expressed yesterday by Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution, Washington, D.C.
LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by The Associated Press:

ALGIERS, June 23 -- Every one of the thousands of persons in French North Africa interned in concentration camps, incorporated into work companies or restricted to reside in certain areas before the Allied landings last Nov. 8 has been liberated, it was announced today by the Joint Commission for Political Prisoners and Refugees.

That the Nazi High Command is hesitating to launch its expected offensive in the East there can be no doubt. But the arguments broadcast by military commentators in Berlin suggesting that the Germans can afford to remain on the defensive this year, ready to crush an attack instead of delivering one, should not fool anyone into assuming that they do not intend to make a final attempt to destroy the hitherto indestructible Red Army.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 24 -- A heavy force of Liberators smashed at Macassar, Netherland Celebes, for the first time yesterday, heavily damaging a Japanese cruiser.

The Duke of Windsor, who once was King Edward VIII of Great Britain, Emperor of India, and is now the Governor of the Bahamas, sat for a mass interview in the Carpenter Suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday. It was his forty-ninth birthday.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 23 -- British Wellingtons of the Strategic Air Force pounded Salerno, a port and railway junction thirty miles southeast of Naples, on Monday night, twelve hours after it had been heavily attacked by American Mitchell bombers.

LONDON, Thursday, June 24 -- Hundreds of giant Royal Air Force bombers crushed the Ruhr steel city of Muelheim in a moon1ight attack Tuesday night, and twin-engined bombers pounded the invasion coast late yesterday to keep the Allied aerial offensive rolling at a mighty pace.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 -- Deferring for the time being a more pointed attack on broader post-war problems, the country's Governors began a drive today to recapture for their States, with the return of peace, the powers surrendered to the Federal Government for prosecution of the war, and previously for dealing with the economic depression of the Thirties.
GUADALCANAL (AP by Mail) -- What a whale of a difference half a year can make!

PITTSBURGH, June 23 -- The back-to-work movement of the nation's 521,000 striking miners proceeded at a slow pace tonight as many locals of the United Mine Workers, with thousands of members, voted flatly against any resumption of operations without a union contract.

Cedric A. Major, general solicitor for the Lehigh Valley Railroad, has leased an apartment in 775 Park Avenue through Douglas L. Elliman Co. A six-room penthouse has been rented in 400 East Fifty-ninth Street by Major Theodore L. Deglin, according to Webb Knapp, brokers.

BOSTON, June 23 -- Speaking here today at the closing session of the annual convention of the National Association of Cost Accountants, Stanley Z. Bronner of the Bridgeport Brass Company, Bridgeport, Conn., recommended that now was the time for every industrial company to organize what he called a "special transition-period budget committee."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Economic distress in North Africa, long regarded as a danger for the Allied cause in a region that has now become a huge military base, has been greatly relieved and the territories are on the way to becoming self-sufficient, except for the industrial goods that they have always imported, according to officials in close touch with the supply administration.

The announcement by the Office of Price Administration that more liberal markups for distributors are contemplated on rice, pickles, relishes and certain canned fruits and vegetables has brought wholesale transactions in those items to a virtual standstill and current trading with retailers is on an "accommodation" basis, exclusively, it was reported in Hudson Street yesterday.

Scales and tape measures are the new tools of the girls behind the packing counters in the city's department stores. Complying with the recent regulations of the Office of Defense Transportation, the stores are measuring and weighing carefully before they promise delivery on purchases that may be just under the required limit.

DUBLIN, Thursday, June 24 (AP) -- The Farmers party, in a surprise showing in Tuesday's general election, had won seven seats in the new Dail Eireann by early today, mostly at the expense of Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's Fianna Fail party, which appeared to be experiencing a reverse.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Cyrus Eaton of Otis Co., investment bankers in Cleveland, telegraphed today to the Interstate Commerce Commission a demand that a proposed $28,000,000 refunding bond issue of the Pennsylvania Railroad be opened to competitive bidding.

A gasoline station operator, who allegedly dealt in gasoline ration coupons that had been stolen from a Chicago rationing office, was arrested yesterday at the Midtown Service Station, 1102 First Avenue, and held in $2,000 bail for the Federal grand jury on a charge of illegal possession of coupons.

I have read with keen interest the editorials in THE TIMES and the letters of Earl Browder, both touching on the abandonment by Premier Stalin of the control over Communist parties outside of Russia. Without this significant move taken by Stalin, there was little hope of the feeling of the American people for the Russian people flowing in good, free American fashion.

As motorists here showed a deep apathy about buying the new $5 Federal stickers which must be displayed on all automobiles operated after next Wednesday, the Automobile Club of New York sought action yesterday by Congress to repeal or scale down the use tax on passenger-car owners in the Eastern gasoline shortage area.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 (UP) -- Approval of President Roosevelt's plans to draft workers who strike in government-operated plants or mines was given tonight by several State Chief Executives attending the annual Governors Conference.

LONDON, June 23 -- Yugoslav intelligence reported tonight that General Draja Mikhailovitch, leader of the guerrilla forces in Yugoslavia, was safe in a Serbian mountain spot after a sensational escape from Germans who surrounded a wayside inn in Montenegro where he was holding council disguised as a peasant.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 23 -- A vast plan to rush medicines, foods and clothing into Greece and the Balkans "the very minute" that it is feasible to do so has been worked out in the Middle East office of the American Red Cross, of which Ralph Bain is director.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 23 -- Although thrice rejected as physically unfit for the Army, Leo Rosenblum, president of the Hudson County Tax Board and prominent as a leader in anti-Hague groups, has been named in a sealed indictment by the Federal grand jury in Newark for an alleged failure to appear before a Selective Service Medical Advisory Board, it was disclosed here today by his counsel, Irving Eisenberg.
LONDON, June 23 (U.P.) -- The RAF raid on Muelheim last night ended a month of the most intensive bombing ever delivered to an area the size of the valley of the Ruhr.

To be voted the "best sport" among 13,000 New York boys from Staten Island to Harlem is something. But to be handed a medal and two weeks' vacation in the country along with it has Frank Mangus, 12-year-old Staten Islander, pretty well worked up this morning.
LONDON, June 23 -- Now that Italy is being pounded as heavily as Germany itself, the troublesome issue of whether Rome is to be exempt from bombing is coming to the fore again.

The annual convention of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, in session at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street, will be asked to act today on a resolution protesting among other things "the unreasonable enforcement in many areas of the Office of Price Administration restrictions with regard to 'gas,' oil for heating purposes and bus transportation during the hours of worship."

A survey showing the extent to which office salaries in the city have increased since the beginning of 1941 was released yesterday by the local chapter of the National Office Management Association. The study, which was summarized by H.K. Marks of J.K. Lasser Co., certified public accountants, 1440 Broadway, showed substantial increases for both men and women in nearly all of the major classifications.

William Fischer, president of the Major Forwarding Company, Inc., of 15 Moore Street, charged yesterday that large amounts of cargo were being left on the docks because of governmental red tape, and particularly the quota system established last year by the Bureau of Economic Warfare and the State Department.

ALBANY, June 23 -- Thomas N. Hurd, State farm manpower director, reported to Governor Dewey and the War Council today that there has been "substantial improvement" in New York's farm labor situation, but that the problem is not yet solved.

AS Louise Randall Pierson says in her autobiography, "Roughly Speaking,"* they used to call it vivacity. But Mrs. Pierson also has punch, pep, zingo, adrenalin, and an excess of vitamin B. Her first husband left her because "living with you and those kids is like living with Fannie Brice in a den of lions." Her second husband -- a "Robin Hood in plus uours" -- was more amenable to speed, change and the utterly incalculable.

A special master will be appointed by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind to take testimony on the financial status of the Childs Company, restaurant chain, the Court decided yesterday. Officials of the corporation are opposing a request for reorganization of the concern under Chapter X of the Federal bankruptcy laws, contained in a petition filed last week by three creditors.

A woman found dead in an isolated spot off the Belt Parkway near Mill Basin in Brooklyn late Tuesday afternoon was identified yesterday by her husband, Patrolman Theodore Johnson of the Butler Street police station, as Bridget Kelly Johnson, 31 years old, mother of two children, Thomas, 9, and Lorraine, 3 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Roosevelt, criticizing the strike leadership action of the United Mine Workers of America as "intolerable," announced today his intention of asking Congress to raise the age limit for non-combat military service from 45 to 65 years in order to have available for prompt action machinery to deal with strikes in plants, mines or establishments owned by the government or in its custody.

LONDON, Thursday, June 24 (U.P.) -- Russian troops have intensiied their reconnaissance operations on the Eastern Front and the Red Air Force has heavily raided the important Pskov junction on the Riga-Staraya Russa railroad, which feeds German forces on the Lake Ilmen front, Moscow revealed today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, welcomed today the assistance of a committee named by the American Newspaper Publishers Association in the government-industry campaign to increase production of pulpwood for vital military and civilian war uses.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 23 -- A merchant seaman's penciled note of instructions on the disposal of his $5,000 insurance was admitted to probate today by Common Pleas Judge Paul D. Duffy in Orphan's Court, who said the note met the requirements of a will made by persons in the nation's war services.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Manufacture of cartons used to carry soft drinks has been prohibited by the War Production Board to save paperboard for use by the fighting forces and lend-lease and for packaging food for civilians.

Are there people who go in for collecting hotels? The thing should be not wholly impossible since we know that collectors lavish their affections on practically everything under the sun, from birds' nests to old umbrella ribs.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Joseph B. Eastman, director of Defense Transportation, said today that the problem of rail passenger movement would reach "the test" in the next three months.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Reports of improved weather and crop conditions, particularly in the Midwestern grain, livestock and dairy regions, served today to ease official apprehensions over 1943 food production prospects.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The text of President Roosevelt's statement on the coal mining situation was as follows:
LONDON, June 23 -- There is a constant accrual of evidence that no invasion of the European Continent will be undertaken until the softening-up process through air bombardment has been completed.

The Federal Trade Commission yesterday resumed hearings at 45 Broadway on its charges that the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc. violated section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act through alleged "domination and coercion" of the Eastern Milk Producers Cooperative Association, which resulted in "unfair competitive advantage" to the company.

Joan Field, American violinist, appeared as soloist last night with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium, Alexander Smallens conducting. Miss Field played the third Saint-Saens concerto in B minor and gave it a sensitive and musical reading.

CHUNGKING, China, June 23 (U.P.) -- American fliers, supporting Chinese ground operations in central China, blasted two important Japanese-held centers in the Tungting lake area on Monday and attacked enemy shipping on the Yangtze River, a communique from Lieut. Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell's headquarters said today.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 -- Fewer than 1,100 of the 46,000 diggers employed in the Pittsburgh District No. 5 area reported at the start of morning shifts, a canvass by the Western Pennsylvania Coal Operators Association showed. The figures rose somewhat with the afternoon shift.

To the Census Bureau members of the Hundred Club are objects of suspicion. In 1940, 3,679 persons told the census taker that they were 100. The Bureau and life statisticians in general are disposed to doubt some of these declarations of age. Old people are often forgetful.

Ham, bacon and other cured pork products were being dumped on wholesale markets in large quantities yesterday as packers attempted to dispose of reserves before the new Federal subsidy roll-back program is applied to pork at the packer level next week.

MOSCOW, June 23 (AP) -- Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker has been in Moscow since Sunday on a mission as the representative of Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson, it was disclosed today. He arrived at 1 P.M. Sunday in a four-engined Liberator.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The charge that a survey of the teaching of American history in schools and colleges to be undertaken by the American Historical Association and other bodies was "designed by social extremists" to divert attention from the "appalling and shocking neglect" of the subject in the school system was made yesterday by Hugh Russell Fraser, chairman of the Committee on American History.

"We are winning the war and we are winning it in the air," Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia told students of the Manhattan High School of Aviation Trades yesterday afternoon in Queensborough Playground, Fifty-ninth Street and Sutton Place, at a ceremony at which the Mayor presented a flying ambulance to the Navy, paid for by money collected by the students.

The insistence of the Japanese upon the observance of a curious customs regulation resulted in 1940 in thwarting a plan of their Nazi partner n the Axis, it was revealed yesterday at the Federal court trial of Dr. Ferdinand Kertess.

CARDIFF, Wales, June 23 -- A United States flag, flying on Saint Mary's Street here, marks what is accurately called "Little America in Wales." It is the American Merchant Seamen's Club, operated by the United Seamen's Service under the auspices of the War Shipping Administration -- and soldiers and sailors are just as welcome as the men who man the merchant vessels.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The intense air action the Eighth Air Force is carrying on against Germany and German-occupied territory in Europe is reflected in the largest list of decorations ever made at one time from any theatre by the United States Army Air Forces, the War Department announced today.

Like an echo from the remote past comes word from Vichy that Marshal Petain has dissolved the special court at Riom which was set up in February, 1942, to "establish responsibility for the war." The Nazis seem to have hoped that the trials of General Gamelin and former Premiers Blum and Daladier could by some fantastic hocus-pocus be made to reveal a pre-war conspiracy of Frenchmen against the peace of Europe.

Last week Mel Ott's Giants were riding the crest of a wave when they walloped the Dodgers three straight at the Polo Grounds. But the crest broke at Ebbets Field and yesterday the Stoneham crew was completely engulfed as the Dodgers took both ends of a double-header for their fifth straight over the Giants and their sixth consecutive triumph.
TORONTO, June 23 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs kept their lead intact tonight by defeating the Newark Bears, 7 -- 5, the Leafs making all their runs in the first two innings.

Operations of Austin, Nichols Co., Inc., distributors of beers, wines and liquor, in the fiscal year ended on April 30 resulted in a net profit of $544,991 after provision for taxes, Thomas F. McCarthy, president, reported yesterday.

Kenneth C. Crain's letter published June 15 brings to my mind the arguments that were advanced against any form of compulsory insurance before it was enacted into law. I still recall the days when, at legislative hearings, the opposition came in droves to attack old-age pensions and to claim that to pension an old man or an old woman would make wastrels and spendthrifts of them and would ruin the moral fiber of our country.

MITCHEL FIELD, L.I., June 23 -- "Enemy" bombers struck today at the nation's capital and other large cities along the East Coast from Newport News, Va., to Providence, R.I., it was disclosed here by Maj. Gen. Ralph Royce, commanding general of the First Air Force.

Evidence that an insurance carrier's superintendent of compensation claims sought to influence a doctor to submit a report on a workman's injuries favorable to the company was brought out yesterday before the Moreland investigation as the hearings in the Bar Association Building were adjourned until Fall, when they will be resumed up-State.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, June 24 (UP) -- The noon communique:

DETROIT, June 23 -- Under the careful scrutiny of 350 armed troops, the Tigers and Indians divided a double-header today at Briggs Stadium, the Tigers taking the opener, 3 to 1, on Hal Newhouser's five-hitter and the Indians winning the nightcap, 9 to 6, on Jeff Heath's eleventh-inning homer.
LONDON, Thursday, June 24 (U.P.) -- A special communique broadcast from Moscow:

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -- Sources of the Polish Government in exile reported today another outbreak of German terror in Poland and declared more than 500 men and women on the Nazi blacklist had been shot in recent weeks and at least 2,000 others whose fate was unknown had been arrested.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 23 -- Don Juan, Count of Barcelona and pretender to the throne of Spain, has reached an accord "in principle" with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime for his immediate return to Spain and accession to the throne, according to information reaching here today from his private secretary, Ramon Padilla.

Obviously concerned over the possibility of an acute shortage in paper, the War Production Board is seriously considering the advisability of including paper in the list of materials under the Controlled Materials Plan, Regulation No. 5, the provision that allows plants to extend their ratings for the purchases of operating and repair supplies, it was learned yesterday.

Fifteen battalion chiefs of the Fire Department have been ordered by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia to appear at City Hall at 10 A. M. Saturday in connection with the filling of five vacancies in the higher rank of deputy chief.

EVANSTON, Ill., June 23 -- Led by the No. 1 Player, Francisco (Pancho) Segura of the University of Miami, and the No. 2 Man, Tom Brown Jr. of California, all seeded performers advanced to tomorrow's quarter finals today in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championships.

Admiral Nomura, Japan's pre-Pearl Harbor Ambassador to Washington, offers the peoples of the Axis an assurance of victory that has at least the advantage of novelty. He says they do not have to attack any more. To win now they have only "to hold out in conquered positions."

Interest in the stock markets returned yesterday as the striking coal miners drifted back to work. Closing prices on the New York Stock Exchange showed gains of fractions to 2 points and the volume of 830,230 shares was the best in a week.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The son of an Italian-born tailor in New Jersey took his place tonight among the great American war heroes, when a Marine Corps platoon sergeant, John Basilone of Raritan, 26, one of a family of ten children, was cited for the Congressional Medal of Honor, the highest tribute this nation can bestow upon its fighting sons.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (U.P.) -- Captain Rickenbacker has made several observation tours to find out for Secretary Stimson how effectively United States air power is being applied to the task of defeating the Axis.

The second anniversary of Hitler's assault on Russia has produced new Russian pleas for a second front in Europe. Such a plea was the main point of the official Russian summary of the war, and it was reiterated by Foreign Commissar Molotoff to Admiral Standley, the American Ambassador.

MOSCOW, June 23 -- Handing United States Army and Navy decorations to Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff for award to sixty members of the Soviet fighting services, Admiral William H. Standley, the United States Ambassador, yesterday expressed the hope that a long period of peacetime cooperation would develop between the Allies now fighting together against a common enemy.

ALGIERS, June 23 -- This is the story of a French father, a forty-eight-year-old business man, who avenged the death of his son so well that today he received the Croix de Guerre from General Henri Honore Giraud for a particularly daring piece of intelligence work behind the German lines in Tunisia last winter.

LONDON, June 23 -- The port of Rotterdam, The Netherlands, has been rendered useless for large-scale shipments of iron, ore and coal essential for the proper functioning of German industry, it was learned here today. The tight blockade by sea and air has choked off one of the main arteries pumping life into the enemy's war factories.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Until the President announced that he will ask Congress to pass a work-or-be-drafted bill for strikers up to the age of 65, and was planning to invoke this curb if the coal strike continued, John L. Lewis had maintained himself as dictator to the Government of the terms on which he would permit his miners to dig coal.

A plea "to eschew all racial violence and hate and to unite in the defense of our common heritage of good-will, equality and freedom for all," was embodied in a resolution decrying recent race riots which was adopted yesterday by the Central Conference of American Rabbis in the Hotel New Yorker.

BUENOS AIRES, June 23 -- The Argentine Government has suspended for twenty-four hours the English-language newspaper The Standard, founded in 1861. The measure was taken under the state of siege regulations, which forbid any discussion of international problems, and was a consequence of an editorial printed Feb. 20 attacking a speech by German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels.

LONDON, June 23 (U.P.) -- Spanish monarchists both inside and outside Spain have been increasingly active in recent months, it was said today. There is considerable evidence that they have sought to interest the Allies in their cause, based on actual Spanish neutrality as opposed to Generalissimo Franco's attitude toward the Axis.

JOCKO CONLAN became an umpire because he broke his thumb and the first major league game in which he officiated found him, strictly speaking, not an umpire but a player. Perhaps that does not seem to make much sense, being filled with strange contradictions and paradoxes. Still it is eminently correct. Listen further, if you will.

In a cook's lexicon summer is defined as the season for salads, a culinary department that can include anything from a limp lettuce leaf garnished with three uninteresting prunes to a bowl of crisp greens redolent of herbs and shining with french dressing.

LONDON, June 23 -- Some interesting observations on how the British press met its wartime obligations were provided yesterday by Lieut. Col. John J. Astor, chairman of The Times Publishing Company, at a luncheon at the Devon-shire Club.
The Appellate Division unanimously affirmed yesterday a Supreme Court ruling denying an injunction and dismissing an action brought by two borrowers against the Household Finance Corporation.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 23 -- Although store and office buildings generally are enjoying the highest rate of occupancy in many years, recent gains are attributable largely to war influences and to government tenancy, and owners face the prospect of a decline in the period just ahead and a possible dislocation of their business after the war, leaders of the industry declared today at the convention of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

LONDON, June 23 -- Great Britain has had no general strike of coal miners such as the United States has just had to face, but Major Gwilym Lloyd George, Minister of Fuel, disclosed today during a debate in the House of Commons on the Government's efforts to step up coal production that 4 1/2 per cent of the "miners, who absent themselves from work unnecessarily, cost this country 8,000,000 tons yearly.

In a discussion of the various methods of copy testing yesterday, Dr. Henry C. Link, vice president of the Psychological Corporation, declared that no one test is superior to the others, but that each is useful for different situations. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton.
CINCINNATI, June 23 (AP) -- slow game that wore out fifteen Cardinals including three pitcher went to the Reds today, 8 to 3, square the current series.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 (AP) -- About 150 well-to-do Republicans of Western Pennsylvania met tonight in the Duquesne Club at a dinner which had been described by Senator Joseph F. Guffey, Democrat, as an "$8,000-a-plate feast of Belshazzar" and heard informal "across-the-table" talks by their party's national chairman, Harrison Spangler, and others.
ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP) -- The White Sox moved another step from the American League basement today with a 4-to-3 victory over the eighth-place Browns.

Commercial banks and trust companies in Manhattan have given the Greater New York Fund's 1943 campaign 24 1/2 per cent more than they did in 1942, Pierpont V. Davis, chairman of the finance section of the fund campaign, and Harry E. Ward, chairman of the banks and trusts division, reported yesterday to W. Randolph Burgess, campaign chairman.

An attack on "defeatists" using the "counsel of despair made by Senator Joseph H. Ball of Minnesota in a speech delivered last night before the Women's National Republican Club, 3 West Fifty-first Street, urging the adoption of the Ball-Burton-Hill-Hatch resolution now pending in the Senate.
World famous tennis players, headed by Miss Alice Marble and Miss Mary Hardwick of Great Britain, will appear in a series of exhibition matches at Fort Slocum, New Rochelle, Sunday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- Paramount has opened negotiations with Edward G. Robinson to portray Adolf Hitler in "The Hitler Gang" after the actor finishes "Tampico." The company is seeking Walter Slezak for the role of Hermann Goering.

BOSTON, June 23 (AP) -- Jim Carr's Fair Call won the second division of the Twin Lakes features at Suffolk Downs today, scoring by three lengths in 1:10 2-5, the fastest time of the New England season for six furlongs, while Mrs. Robert Campbell's Hicomb, a 13-to-1 outsider, surprised by a half a length in the first division.

Edwin Seaver is editing a collection of new American writing, novelettes, short stories, essays, reportage and poems not hitherto published in a book or national magazine. Tentatively called "Cross-Section," the book will be published early next year by L.B. Fischer.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Treasury began final preparations today for a $2,500,000,000 war loan drive to begin on Monday with conferences between Secretary Henry Morgenthau Jr. and two bankers' committees.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

All able-bodied young men and women and boys and girls from the age of 16 up should arrange to spend all or part of their vacation this year in farm service, George S. Van Schaick, Regional Di rector of the Office of Civilian Defense, urged yesterday.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- Chicago will have its annual winter furniture market next January but the opening will be deferred two weeks beyond the usual date to cut down on transportation congestion.

The practice of substituting sherbets and water ices for ice cream without adequate warning to the customer is a "nutritional fraud" and strictly illegal, Dr. Ernest L. Stebbins, city Health Commissioner, cautioned the public and the industry yesterday.

LONDON, June 6 -- A recent survey of London school children has shown that youngsters between the ages of five and seven have forgotten so many of the attributes of peacetime living that they will have a hard time adjusting themselves to normal conditions again.

ALGIERS, June 23 (AP) -- With the French armies divided between two Commanders in Chief, Giraudists indicated today that they would demand that recruiting be on a territorial basis, thus preventing the Fighting French from taking manpower in this area.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered new rates on telegraph service today between the United States and South and Central America and the West Indies which it said would save users of such service $2,500,000 a year.

A great number of ships at sea today are manned 80 per cent by reserve officers and they are doing a splendid job, Rear Admiral Monroe Kelly, new commandant of the Navy Yard in Brooklyn, told a class of 867 graduates yesterday at exercises at the Naval Training School (Indoctrination), Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.
New Hampshire's Fish and Game Department undoubtedly has had some experience with persons who are anxious to start their own "game farms" by obtaining stock from a natural source of supply.

Supreme Court Justice Robert H. Jackson asserted last night that the letter which former Chief Justice Charles E. Hughes and the late Supreme Court Justice Louis D. Brandeis sent to Senator Wheeler did more than any other one thing to turn the tide against President Roosevelt's plan to reorganize and enlarge the Supreme Court.

The vacant blockfront on the north side of Thirty-fourth Avenue, between Steinway and Forty-first Streets, Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by Frederick Brown, operator, from the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The secret of skip-bombing, one of the most deadly aerial attack techniques developed in this war, was revealed today by Army aviation authorities as a concentration of terrific protective fire power combined with perfect timing and coordinated attack.

Duke, a 3-year-old brown and white collie, turned into a "conscientious objector" yesterday when he bolted from 111 East Seventy-seventh Street, the induction center for Dogs for Defense, and went "over the hill" to Central Park, where he disappeared from view.

The Fort Worth Denver City Railway Company announced yesterday that it will spend up to $2,000,000 in purchasing the 4 1/2 per cent general mortgage bonds of its parent company, the Colorado Southern Railway Company. There is outstanding about $16,800,000 of the bonds.

The six-family house on a plot 28 by 42 feet at 41-43 Dean Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Herbert E. Cheeseman to Andrew N. Miller through Samuel Hurwitz, broker. This structure is assessed for $4,800.

The odor of frying fish permeated the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker yesterday as seven Boy Scouts, representing the seven Manhattan Scout districts, tested their culinary skill in the finals of the Fourth Annual Boy Scout Fish Cooking Contest.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Capitalizing on Claude Passeau's five-hit pitching, the Cubs defeated Pittsburgh, 4 to 1, in the first game of a double-header today, thereby winning three games in a row for the first time this season and climbing out of the cellar for the first time since May 14.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 23 -- Last in the field of forty contestants to post his score, Ralph Rotunda of Split Rock carded an 83 -- 12 -- 71 today to take the low net honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association one-day handicap tourney at the Metropolis Country Club.

TRIPOLI, June 23 (U.P.) -- King George visited here Monday and was greeted by Gen. Sir Bernard L. Montgomery, commander of the British Eighth Army, as he stepped ashore from the Fighting French launch that brought him from the cruiser Aurora.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 23 -- Willie Pep, featherweight champion, has demonstrated in scores of ring battles that he can take care of himself, and today the Navy assigned him to take care of twenty-seven fellow-inductees on an overnight trip to their "boot" training station.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- Continuation of the liquidation in wheat futures that developed yesterday was in evidence today in the early trading on the Board of Trade, but the selling soon ran its course and commission houses took the buying side when the July sold within a small fraction of a cent a bushel of the Government loan price.

Speaking at the eighty-third commencement exercises of Hunter College last night, Lieut. Commdr. Mildred H. McAfee, commanding officer of the Waves, called for an "attitude of togetherness" on the part of graduates and contemporaries alike.

CHICAGO, June 23 -- American industry could face its future with far more assurance if the government would make clear its policy regarding the disposition of its vast war plants and contracts when peace comes, Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the board of General Motors Corporation, told a group of Chicago business leaders today.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia sent to the City Council yesterday an emergency message urging that body to join with him in asking for a special session of the Legislature to authorize the city to impose new local taxes in order to stave off a substantial rise in the basic real estate tax rate.

Battered all over the Stadium, their pride ruffled by an 8-0, six-hit shut-out by Milo Candini and their grip on first place challenged, the Yankees called on Ernie Bonham to square matters against the Senators in the afterpiece of the twin bill yesterday and Jumbo answered the call.

OTTAWA, June 23 -- Out of 8,720,000 persons in Canada aged 14 years and over, 5,100,000 are in the armed services or employed at paid work, Humphrey Mitchell, Labor Minister, told the House of Commons today when asking for the appropriations for his department.

Two huge simulated palm leaves will stretch across Broadway and Seventh Avenue just north of Forty-third Street if plans for the proposed Victory Arch to be erected by the Broadway Association are approved by the city.

DETROIT, June 23 -- Detroit had quieted down today and Gov. Harry F. Kelly conferred with Brig. Gen. William E. Guthner, city and State officials on the possibility of relaxing the restrictions on civilian activities which have been in effect since late Monday, when Governor Kelly imposed his "modified martial law" as the result of race riots in which thirty-one persons were killed.

Councilman Walter R. Hart, Brooklyn Democrat, who heads the City Council committee now investigating the conduct of the present city government, charged yesterday that Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's administration was trying to "frustrate" his committee's inquiry into the affairs of the Department of Sanitation.
A number of leases for quarters in downtown buildings were among the contracts for commercial space reported yesterday by brokers.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The President saw representatives of the Hawaiian legislature, lunched with Sir Owen Dixon, Australian minister to the United States and conferred with United States military and naval chiefs.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (U.P.) -The failure of a woman juror to answer a qualifying question when the jury was empaneled last Friday, halted today the second trial of George Sylvester Viereck, 57-year-old German propagandist, charged with failing to register as an enemy agent.

The "settlement" of the soft-coal strike cannot be allowed to remain on its present basis. If the Government acquiesces in the terms laid down by John L. Lewis, an armed truce will have been declared between two sovereign powers: the Government of the United States on the one hand, and John L. Lewis on the other.

The sixteen-story apartment house at 240 West End Avenue, at West Seventy-first Street, was purchased by Samuel Knepper through Pearce Mayer and the Halford Realty Company, brokers. It contains sixteen four-room apartments and forty-eight three-room apartments and rents for about $60,000 a year.

A Department of Student Life, to administer all extracurricular student affairs at City College, to counsel undergraduates on their individual problems, and to provide a program of recreation for soldiers assigned to the school for training, has been formed under the chairmanship of Dr. John L. Bergstresser, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 23 -- President Enrique Penaranda of Bolivia arrived here this morning to extend a good neighbor's gesture and also to repay the visit that President Getulio D. Vargas made to Bolivia in 1940.

LONDON, June 23 -- The stock markets here had a more cheerful tone today as a result of the agreement of the French factions in North Africa and the return of coal miners in the United States to work.

MOSCOW, June 23 (U.P.) -- Soviet Foreign Commissar Vyacheslaff M. Molotoff was revealed today to have said on Tuesday, during an official ceremony attended by the United States Ambassador Admiral William H. Standley, that the Russian people were living in hope that the enemy soon would be hit by combined Allied blows.

"The Army Play by Play" gave a special performance for President Roosevelt last Saturday afternoon in the Library at Hyde Park, it was disclosed yesterday by the John Golden office. News of the performance of the five short plays written and acted by soldiers was withheld until the President had returned to Washington.

CHICAGO, June 23 (Canadian Press) -- J.G. Gardiner, Canada's Minister of Agriculture, said today that the 1943 wheat crop was likely to increase Canadian holdings of that grain available for international distribution to 900,000,000 bushels.

The curtain will rise at 8:40 tonight on what is announced as the second edition of "Stars on Ice" at the Center Theatre, the fourth ice spectacle to be presented at the house since 1940 -- all under the auspices of Sonja Henie and Arthur M. Wirtz.

A group of about 200 egg wholesalers voted last night at a meeting in Manhattan Center held under the auspices of the Butter and Egg Merchants Association, Inc., to cease handling eggs for the retail trade after July 3 unless the Office of Price Administration issues before that date its long-promised amendment to the egg pricing order of March 6.

As a measure of cooperation with the Federal Government to conserve gasoline and rubber, the Police Department has decided to discontinue about 100 traffic lights for the duration of the war and to have about 1,200 other lights extinguished from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M., Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director, today vetoed a general wage increase of 8 cents an hour for 1,100,000 non-operating railway employes which would have become effective today, retroactively to Feb. 1, at an annual cost of $204,000,000 to the carriers. About $85,000,000 in back pay was involved.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Blue stamps N, P and Q from ration book No. 2 will be valid for buying processed foods from July 1 to Aug. 7 inclusive, the Office of Price Administration announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Describing herself as "a great friend of Globalliances" Representative Clare Booth Luce, Republican, of Connecticut, told the House today that the United States' foreign policy should begin with "a permanent military alliance, or non-aggression pact, with Great Britain and the self-governing members of the Commonwealth."

ALBANY, June 24 -- Dr. George D. Stoddard, State Commissioner of Education, ,announced today that the Education Department was undertaking a "short and intensive survey" to determine the merits of numerous complaints that some of the recent Regents examinations were unduly difficult.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 24 -- The ninth annual championship of the Westchester Seniors Golf Association, pared in half to a one-day wartime tourney, was captured by Chares V. Benton of the Hudson River C.C. at the Westchester Hills course today.

The Ballet Theatre's "festival" of four performances at the Lewisohn Stadium got under way last night with a program of ballets which have been popular for a long time and can probably be counted on to remain so for a considerable period to come.

The President's reply to Mr. Lewis' nationalization of the coal mines, on his own say-so, is a tacit acceptance of Mr. Lewis' terms, coupled with a proposal that Congress raise the draft age in order to discourage further strikes on the part of Mr. Lewis' miners or of any other group of workers in "establishments owned by the Government, or taken possession of by the Government."

NORTH TARRYTOWNN, N.Y., June 24 -- Shorn of the "improvements" that tenants had been adding for two centuries, the 260-year-old Philipse Castle here has been restored to its original design by the Historical Society of the Tarrytowns, and will be dedicated July 4 as a permanent museum and shrine of colonial life.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 -- The backbone of revolt among Pennsylvania miners against the coal strike settlement appeared to have been broken today. Some 75,000 workers poured back into the pits and additional thousands were scheduled to return to their jobs tomorrow.

ST. PAUL, Minn., June 24 -- A program for the building-management industry designed to protect business property values and guard these investments against postwar dislocations was adopted by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers at the closing business session of its annual convention today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- In an effort to break the corn price squeeze which has cut food production and forced essential industries to close, the War Food Administration moved tonight to requisition stocks of corn at terminal market elevators.

BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- After dropping three games in a row, the Phillies battered four Braves pitchers for sixteen hits and a 12-5 victory today to square a six-game series. Si Johnson, the veteran right-hander, went the distance for the victors and was credited with his seventh victory of the season.

Mrs. Margaret O'Hanlon Fernandez, 47 years old, of 405 East Nineteenth Street, who became temporarily paralyzed and blind following her arrest last September on charges of defrauding numerous men and women under the pretext that she was heir to a $340,000,000 estate, was carried into General Sessions yesterday on a stretcher to face an indictment charging first and second-degree grand larceny.

Retail credit collections rose 6.89 per cent in May, according to the twenty-store index issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. The highest collection percentage for the month was 64.46, against 56.38, an increase of 8.08 per cent.

Little, Brown announces that Peter Masefield, correspondent in England, has been signed for a biography of the late Reginald Joseph Mitchell, the British plane designer, whose life story is told in the recent film "Spitfire." The first chapters of the book are due soon from England.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Thousands of teachers throughout the country are leaving their jobs, 106,000 in rural communities having quit last spring, according to a recent survey made by the United States Office of Education. That means one teacher in four.

The City Council failed yesterday to fix the basic real estate tax rate for 1943-44 because its finance committee, after several hours of deliberation and debate, was unable to decide whether it would go along on the $2.89 rate indicated by budgetary and assessment figures or set a rate of $2.85, based upon a theory put forth by Councilman Hugh Quinn, Queens Democrat.
TORONTO, June 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Jersey City Giants took advantage of loose play afield by Toronto to score a 5-1 victory over the league leaders tonight.

Hesitance continued yesterday to mark operations on the New York Stock Exchange, but stocks extended their gains in late trading and closed higher generally, with industrial shares exhibiting most of the strength.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of June 18 you carry a dispatch from Moscow quoting a Soviet publication, purporting to speak for the Russian workers, in which I am characterized as a "reactionary" labor leader who is "misleading" workers into "unpatriotic, anti-war strikes."

The Lehigh Coal and Navigation Company announced yesterday an interim dividend of 40 cents a share, the largest first half-year payment since 1932. The dividend, payable on July 26, involves $771,651. Last year the company paid 25 cents in July and 40 cents in December.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -The Senate Appropriations Committee voted thirteen to twelve today to liquidate the National Youth Administration, reversing a six to five recommendation of a subcommittee.

In a letter to Senator Frederick Van Nuys, chairman of the Senate judiciary committee, the judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of New York City withdrew yesterday through John G. Jackson, acting chairman, its objection to confirmation of James B.M. McNally, former chairman of the Tammany law committee, as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, June 25 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur today expressed support of the action of Major Gen. Lewis H. Brereton in handling air forces in the Philippines at the beginning of the war.

More than 75,000 volunteer airmen of the Civil Air Patrol, organized the week before Pearl Harbor, have flown more than 20,000,000 miles; have spotted more than 150 submarines for the Army, Navy and Coast Guard; have sunk some submarines themselves and have proved so useful that their organization is now an auxiliary arm of the Army Air Force, according to a comprehensive report on the CAP issued yesterday by the Office of War Information.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee restored today the cuts made by the House in the budget of the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

There is an ever-increasing need for nurses to care for our men in the armed forces. The American Red Cross is seeking 3,000 nurses a month and was able to fill less than half of that national quota in May. These facts were revealed yesterday at a meeting of the Recruiting Committee, Recruiting Station for the Army and Navy Nurse Corps, 139 East Thirty-sixth Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- In a separate but supplemental plan, the Consolidated Gas and Electric Company outlined today to the Securities and Exchange Commission further proposals to effect complete compliance with the integration and corporate simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (U.P.) -Willis S. MacLeod, the Office of Price Administration's technical operations chief, displayed armloads of clothes, shoes and textile products before a House investigating committee today in an effort to prove that "quality deterioration has arrived and must be met." Defending OPA's orders to set standards as well as prices for certain goods, he declared:

Formal completion of the organizing of a social missions committee of the United Lutheran Synod of New York was effected yesterday at the closing sessions of its annual convention at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson called attention today in his weekly war review to the "extraordinary lull" on the "long Russian front" -- a situation that is being watched with interest in diplomatic as well as military circles here.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 24 (AP) -Royal Air Force heavy bombers from Middle East bases on Tuesday night drove in over the Mediterranean to assault the Italian airdrome at Comiso in Sicily, which was left erupting with two violent explosions and many fires, and the hangar and workshops were squarely hit.

CAMP TAMIMENT, Pa., June 24 -- Declaring that the elimination of mass unemployment was the first requirement for the post-war period, Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said here tonight that it was "folly" to think that business could make the transition from full wartime employment to high peacetime employment without the cooperation of Federal, State and local governments.

SOUTHVILLE, Mass., June 24 -- The flaming wreckage of one of two Army planes which were in collision at a high altitude plummeted into the path of a passenger train today, derailing the engine and five coaches, two of which caught fire.

Persistent short-covering and price-fixing in the spot delivery, attracting commission-house and spot-firm support to the five other active contracts on the New York Cotton exchange yesterday produced the widest price movement in the futures market in more than a month and lifted the July position to its highest level in fourteen years.

RIO DE JANERIO, June 24 -Land-locked Bolivia appears to be on the threshhold of solving her principal problem -- obtaining an outlet to the sea. Brazil, in a concrete manifestation of the Good Neighbor policy, has offered her sister republic the use of the Port of Santos, 200 miles south of Rio de Janeiro.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Army has created a Specialized Training Reserve with a maximum quota of 25,000 qualified high school graduates 17 to 18 years of age receiving military scholarships for basic phase instruction at selected colleges and universities.

MOSCOW, June 24 -- The Soviet defensive system, gradually developed and amplified during the present war, has been carefully built up on one essential basis -the proper disposition and employment of strategic reserves. This principle applies to the country as a whole, to the principal fronts, to the sectors commanded by army generals, to smaller units and cities menaced with encirclement.

Dr. C.J. Blanford, administrator of the New York metropolitan milk marketing area, announced yesterday that disbursement of the largest return on record from the New York milk pool is scheduled to be completed today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board was reported today to have turned down Secretary Harold L. Ickes' request for control over gasoline and fuel oil rationing with a plan instead to create two committees on petroleum distribution.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Department of State building, adjacent to the White House, lost one of its decorative features today when twenty-nine antique brass and iron cannon captured in other wars were removed from the entrance steps and sent elsewhere.

The Ramirez Government in Argentina continues to disappoint those who had hoped that the "revolution" which deposed President Castillo meant a change in the more obnoxious Castillo policies. President Ramirez either fears public opinion or just doesn't believe in it.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade at a special meeting today failed to take any action on a request from the War Food Administration that the exchange ban trading in corn futures. Officials of the board refused to comment on their action, but it is understood they demanded that the government agency issue mandatory orders to stop trading in corn futures before they would order pit operations to cease.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24 -- Govs. Thomas E. Dewey of New York and John W. Bricker of Ohio did a masterful job here this week of mystifying those Republican leaders and other observers who had thought to use the occasion of the annual Governors' conference to observe these two 1944 Presidential possibilities in action.

The Lighthouse, headquarters of the New York Association for the Blind, is appealing this month for funds to carry on its vacation program. For thirty-seven years this organization, supported solely by voluntary contributions, has provided free vacations for the blind of our city.

WITH THE KING'S PARTY IN NORTH AFRICA (Delayed) -- In the desert outside of Tripoli during his North African trip, King George pinned the Victoria Cross, Britain's highest military award, on the tunic of a little Gurkha sergeant, who was the first Indian to receive it during this war.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -The Senate rejected 52 to 17 today a House-approved conference report on a $143,000,000 deficiency appropriations bill after sharp debate over a provision cutting off the salaries of three government employes accused of membership in subversive organizations.

IN every man there is an element of cruelty and bigotry that can be aroused by appeals to fear and self-interest if controls of religion, idealism and codes of character are once relaxed. In every nation the forces of barbarism and evil are always present. The degree to which they are controlled is perhaps the highest standard by which the measure of a man or a civilization can be taken.
The committee of educators now analyzing the study of United States history will undoubtedly improve the present methods in many ways.

LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- The Axis was reported tonight to be shortening its anti-invasion defenses, pulling back some of its island garrisons and concentrating more strength in the Balkans, apparently in expectation of a massive Allied blow from the southeast.

The City Council, by a vote of 19 to 6, overrode yesterday Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's veto of a local law designating the huge airport under construction in the Idlewild section of Queens as Maj. Gen. Alexander E. Anderson Airport.
I feel deeply that the people who call our policy of Chinese exclusion insulting and discriminatory do not understand the basis of our policy of exclusion or oriental immigration.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes declared today that he and members of his staff decided last March that the Navy Department's contract for acquiring the Elk Hills oil lands of the Standard Oil Company of California was a bad deal "from the point of view of the Government."
Patience and affection combined to establish the ownership of a tiny Pomeranian dog when the problem came up yesterday in Bay Ridge Magistrate's Court.

Furniture store sales in the Second Federal Reserve District in May were up 3 per cent from the corresponding 1942 level, while volume in this city showed a gain of 12 per cent for the period, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The House Committee of Agriculture, 18 to 8, voted today to report out a bill of its chairman, Representative Hampton P. Fulmer, Democrat of South Carolina, to give Chester C. Davis, recently appointed War Food Administrator, full power over the food industries of the country.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., June 24 -- An all-male jury, after seven and a half hours' deliberation, acquitted today Mrs. Elsie Farr, 35-year-old blond divorcee, of the charge of murder which resulted from the fatal shooting last April 6 of Patrolman Alfred Lundgren, 41, here.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 24 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister John Curtin, whose Labor government survived by the margin of one vote an Opposition motion of "no confidence," announced today that he would seek dissolution of the sixteenth Australian Parliament, probably next week, and submit the issue to the country in a general election in August.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 24 -Private hospital plans probably can survive a modified form of federalized hospital and medical insurance, but may have to be abandoned entirely if governmental control is made absolute, Louis H. Pink, president of the Associated Hospital Service of New York and former New York State Superintendent of Insurance, declared today.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Dr. Frank E. Rice, executive secretary of the Evaporated Milk Association, asserted today that "all users of evaporated milk can be assured that for the present and as far as can be seen into the future, evaporated milk supplies are adequate for family needs."

John van Allen, once head of the brokerage firm of W.G. Forrester, Inc., has been restrained from dealing in securities "within and from the State of New York," according to an announcement yesterday. Supreme Court Justice Lloyd Church signed a consent injunction late Wednesday.

Twenty-nine Jesuit deacons from New York and New Jersey were ordained to the priesthood yesterday morning at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street, by the Most Rev. Stephen J. Donahue, D.D., Auxiliary Bishop of New York.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Declaring that the food situation in the United States is such today that "action within hours, not days" is necessary to ward off a serious deficiency in supplies, Clarence Francis, president of General Foods Corporation and chairman of the Food Industries War Committee, called today for coordinating authority over all phases of the food industry in the hands of one individual, preferably the war food administrator.

A full day of hearings, at which a Secret Service agent demonstrated how counterfeit gasoline ration coupons reveal their falsity under the bluish-green light of a fluoroscope, resulted yesterday in the suspension from gasoline business for "the duration" of a Bronx service station operator, who admitted peddling coupons to other dealers, and the suspension of six other dealers for from two weeks to one year.
LONDON, June 24 -- Reports of record sales at the diamond "sights" brought a further rise today in the shares of diamond producing companies.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The war so far has cost the United States Army 63,958 casualties, including 7,523 soldiers who were killed in action or died of wounds, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson reported today. He warned that "very heavy" losses might be expected in future operations involving greater numbers of American troops.

The Office of Defense Transportation, whose agents have been quietly checking on delivery trucks on the highways, at freight terminals and elsewhere, has within the past week penalized 150 violators of its recent order restricting wholesale and retail deliveries of various commodities, it was announced yesterday by Henry C. Wall, district manager of the ODT motor transport division.

It needs no long memory to recall the time when hardly one woman was employed by a daily newspaper. There had been woman writers, correspondents, but the news room was strictly a masculine reservation. In the days before typewriters even a secretary was masculine.

LONDON, Friday, June 25 (U.P.) -- German sources reported today that a new Red Army attack had penetrated the main German lines southwest of Velikiye Luki, where the Russian line bulges out toward Latvia, but added that a counter-attack had eliminated the Soviet gain.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -The Army Air Forces during the coming fiscal year will be increased by 115,000 new airplanes, Gen. Henry H. Arnold, commanding the air forces, told the House Civil Service Committee today. This will be encompassed in a $36,000,000,000 procurement program, incuding aircraft engines, spare parts and other equipment.

PATERSON, N.J., June 24 -Moving to prevent a tie-up in the vital magnesium foundry of the Fair Lawn plant, the Wright Aeronautical Corporation discharged today 110 coremakers of the morning and afternoon shifts who walked out yesterday and did not report for work today.

The investigation of the administration of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia by a City Council committee headed by Walter R. Hart, Brooklyn Democrat, was in the name-calling stage yesterday, when Councilman Hart and William B. Herlands, Commissioner of Investigation, exchanged caustic comment.

To enable the nation's banks to bolster their reserves, the Federal open market committee acting on behalf of the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System, purchased $834,721,000 of Treasury bills during the week ended on Wednesday, it was revealed yesterday in the weekly figures.

CHUNGKING, China, June 24 (U.P.) -- More than 1,000 Japanese troops were drowned when a Japanese warship hit a Chinese mine in the Yangtze River near Tungliu, southern Anhwei Province, on June 1, the Central News Agency said today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -The War Labor Board pleaded today with counsel for the United States Gypsum Company to comply with a union maintenance order affecting its Warren, Ohio, plant, but the attorney, John E. MacLeish, said that the decision not to comply was final.

LONDON, June 24 -- Roving the Mediterranean from Gibraltar to Suez, British submarines have sent to the bottom thirteen more enemy vessels, including an armed merchant cruiser, torpedoed seven other ships and surfaced boldly to shell an enemy radio location station, the Admiralty reported tonight.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 24 (AP) -- Governor John W. Bricker came out definitely and unmistakably today for American participation in a post-war international organization to preserve peace.

A recommendation that the Government discard the 1940 census figures in allotting food, clothing, etc., inasmuch as ration-book registries provide an up-to-date record of where the population now lives, was made yesterday by Emil Brisacher, president of Brisacher, Davis Van Norden.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, New York City Controller, sold yesterday by allotment to a group of twenty-three New York City banks $33,000,000 of revenue bills on an 0.75 per cent basis. The bills are dated June 25, 1943, and will mature as follows:

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- As a result of sharp declines in prices for meats, fruits and vegetables, the Bureau of Labor Statistics' index of commodity prices in primary markets dropped by 0.5 per cent during the week ended June 19.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -Location of twelve depots handling pipe and other oil-country equipment to meet the emergency needs of wildcat operators was announced today by Ralph K. Davies, deputy petroleum administrator.

Blushing happily, his smiling face alert, 13-year-old Herbert Greenberg of Public School 93, Brooklyn, where he ranks at the top of his class with a 92 per cent average, heard Dr. John E. Wade, Superintendent of Schools, describe him yesterday as a model pupil, possessing a keen sense of humor, aptitude for hard work and a winning personality.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -A commutation of sentence from President Roosevelt apparently was Max Stephan's only hope tonight of escaping the gallows for his treason conviction.

LONDON, June 24 -- The Royal Air Force has inaugurated shuttle bombing between the British Isles and North Africa. It is a tactic that is especially valuable while the nights are so short that there is scarcely enough darkness to cover a round-trip bombing mission deep into Germany.

The Misses Audrey and Shirley Hasler gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois for their sister, Miss Marjory Hasler, whose marriage to Lieut. J.G. Blaine Ewing Jr., Army Parachute Corps, will take place on July 4 at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Paul Moss, License Commissioner, yesterday announced the suspension of the license of the Gibraltar Employment Agency, 105 West Forty-fifth Street, for alleged irregularities involving the employment in war jobs of soldiers seeking discharge from the Army on letters furnished by the agency.

A picture of far greater efficiency in the drafting of men in the present war compared with the first World War was sketched yesterday by E.E. Conroy, local chief of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. In the earlier war 474,861 men were listed as "deserters," the term equivalent to "draft delinquents" today. But in the present conflict only 171,642 delinquencies have been reported.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 24 -- Gilbert Lewy, 54-year-old senior, and George Stuhr Jr., 16 years old, teamed today to win the Long Island annual amateur best-ball golf championship, a title gained a year ago by Norman Files and Ray Torgerson of Lakeville.

More than 300 persons attended the dedication yesterday afternoon by Bishop William T. Manning of the new Chantry of the Holy Comforter at the entrance to the Chapel of Our Saviour in the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- The Allied air forces hurled 400 to 500 bombers and fighters against Adolf Hitler's "Atlantic Wall" defenses from the Netherlands to Cherbourg Peninsula by daylight today.
Yesterday's Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The Associated Press:

A couple of horses who last raced against each other in the Kentucky Derby, took the dust yesterday of a 3-year-old who stayed at home, all this in the featured Mad Play Purse at Aqueduct where 16,020 persons wagered $1,441,808.

Three men were convicted of first degree murder in Kings County Court last night. The jury returning to Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz with a verdict after three hours' deliberation held the men had killed Patrolman Leon Fox of the Coney Island precinct on Feb. 15, 1941, while the policeman was accompanying a theatre manager to a night depository of a bank.
ALBANY, June 24 -- The State Tax Commission adopted today resolutions urging the Federal Government to change its method of renegotiating war contracts to prevent heavy tax losses to the States.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of ninety-six United States soldiers killed in action in the European, Middle Eastern, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine must bear a share of the responsibility for any outbreak of race rioting in New York, the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Negro member of the City Council, declared yesterday.

LONDON, June 24 -- The Society of British Aircraft Constructors will issue a statement tomorrow outlining their hopes and fears for the post-war aviation industry. They envisage eight or ten large companies operating from this country with the blessing of the British and dominion governments in the form of a modified state aid. The society condemns the monopoly system.

Net sales of the Aviation Corporation for the six months ended with May totaled $37,780,792, or more than double the volume of $17,423,296 for the corresponding six months of last year, Victor Emanuel, president, stated in a report to stockholders issued for publication today.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor here:

Another large corn refining plant -- the Roby, Ind., plant of the American Maize-Products Company -- will close tomorrow because of the acute shortage of grain in the terminal markets, due to the fact that farmers find it more profitable to feed their corn to hogs on their own farms than to sell it for commercial use at present prices of corn.

Commercial banks with government war loan accounts were notified late yesterday by the Treasury that it would make further withdrawals from these accounts on Monday and Tuesday. For the Second Federal Reserve District these withdrawals will amount to $105,913,000 on each day, and for the nation as a whole to $220,226, 000.

The war has drastically changed newspaper reading habits in relation to both news columns and advertisements, James R. McLauchlen of the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association revealed yesterday.

William Miller Collier, former United States Ambassador to Chile, and Mrs. Collier, accompanied by Mrs. George H. Mason, have arrived from Asheville, N.C., and are at the Biltmore. They will leave Sunday to spend the summer at Crawford Notch, N.H.

Kuhn, Loeb Co. will offer publicly today a new issue of first and refunding mortgage 3 3/4 per cent bonds, Series D, of the Pennsylvania, Ohio Detroit Railroad Company in the amount of $28,483,000. The new bonds, dated July 1, 1943, and due on July 1, 1968, are priced at 101 3/4 and interest to yield 3.64 per cent to maturity.

DETROIT, June 24 -- While Detroiters, under the watchful eyes of Federal and State troops, returned to the more normal ways of life, Gov. Harry F Kelly of Michigan set in motion today an inquiry to determine the underlying social causes of the worst race riot in the history of this great industrial region.

"Aerial Gunner," a Paramount picture with Chester Morris, Richard Arlen, Jimmy Lydon, Lita Ward and Dick Purcell, will open this morning at the Rialto instead of tomorrow, as originally scheduled. The topical production was made with the cooperation of the Army Air Forces at Harlingen Aerial Gunnery School.

In a letter to George S. Counts, State chairman of the American Labor party, Representative Vito Marcantonio and Eugene P. Connolly, respectively chairman and secretary of its New York County Committee, yesterday called upon the officers of the State organization to condemn John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential space was Leonard Carey, art director of the Thompson-Koch Company, advertising agency, who leased an apartment in 16 Park Avenue through the Fred F. French Management Company, agent.

Proposals covering the establishment of a commercial standard for women's slips of woven fabrics, in accordance with specifications developed during recent months, will be submitted at an industry meeting next Wednesday at the Hotel McAlpin under the auspices of the Bureau of Standards in cooperation with the National Women's Undergarment Manufacturers Association, it was made known here yesterday.

The Central Conference of American Rabbis, in annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker, adopted yesterday the report of its committee on rabbinical pensions. The plan was submitted by Rabbi Samuel Gup of Columbus, Ohio, chairman of the joint committee on rabbinical pensions of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations and the Central Conference of American Rabbis.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt nominated Ray Atherton to be Minister to Canada; William C. Burdett to be Minister to New Zealand; Loy V. Henderson to be Minister to Iraq, and Maj. Gen. Harry C. Ingles to be chief signal officer of the Army. He had lunch with Dr. Vannevar Bush.

Australia's war effort is summed up by a member of the Commonwealth Parliament passing through town on his way home from London. He points out that Australia has 7,000,000 inhabitants and 800,000 men in her armed forces.

Predicting that a heavy volume of public financing will be required by the nation's railroads after the war, the railroad securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association in a preliminary report issued yesterday estimated that the roads must make total capital expenditures of about $1,000,000,000 annually for ten years.

Graduates of New York's schools for handicapped students received prizes yesterday for their courage and perseverance. Students of Junior High School 47, Twenty-third Street between Second and Third Avenues, topped the list.

CHICAGO, June 24 -- Each university in the Western Conference today was assured of sufficient manpower to field a representative football team this fall when Big Ten faculty representatives waived all basic eligibility requirements for the duration.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- The weekly statement of condition of the Bank of England, issued today, reported a decrease of 1,683,000 in note circulation in the week ended on Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Administration's program for rolling consumer prices back by means of subsidy payments appeared to be in danger tonight. A movement in the Senate to repeal the law under which the Office of Price Administration started the program, now applied to meats, butter and coffee, suddenly gained sufficient strength, according to a survey, to leave the outcome in doubt.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- With the announcement today by the Navy of eighty-eight casualties divided into fifty-eight dead, six wounded and twenty-four missing, the total casualties in the Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard reported to next of kin since Dec. 7, 1941, was brought up to 26,902, subdivided as follows: 7,604 dead, 4,732 wounded, 11,010 missing and 3,556 prisoners of war.

BRIDGETON, N.J., June 24 -The heads of four large South Jersey canneries said today that the failure of the Office of Price Administration to issue 1943 ceiling prices on asparagus had frozen a pack of it worth close to $4,000,000 in their sheds, tying up their warehouse space and their money, and seriously impairing their ability to handle oncoming crops, such as beans and peas and especially tomatoes.

LONDON, June 24 (Reuter) -Axis spokesmen are saying some really astonishing things in following Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels' latest line of telling all about Allied raids to work up pity for the victims.

MOSCOW, June 24 -- The June crops are far better than last year in the Soviet Union and as a result of favorable climatic conditions, including a long, moist spring, this summer's grain harvest is expected considerably to exceed its predecessor.

LONDON, Friday, June 25 (AP) Brig. Gen. Nathan Bedford Forrest, great-grandson and namesake of the famed Confederate cavalry general, was lost June 13 in one of history's greatest aerial fights during the mass American daylight attack on Kiel, Germany.

The shadow of towering Cliff Melton fell athwart the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday, with the result that Mel Ott's tottering Giants regained their balance and salvaged the finale of the six-game series, 3 -- 1.

Predicting that the current food crisis would become increasingly serious, Dean Sarah G. Blanding of Cornell University advocated yesterday a coordinated emergency program to cope with nutrition problems. She spoke at the opening meeting of the State campaign to aid families in this area at the New York State emergency food commission's metropolitan area headquarters, 247 Park Avenue.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 24 (AP) -- Manpower and materials shortages continue to cause substantial minus signs in furniture industry indices, Seidman Seidman, accountants to the industry, reported today in a monthly survey.

CINCINNATI, June 24 (AP) -- Coming back stronger after their 8-3 defeat of yesterday, the world champion Cardinals won handily from the Reds, 5 -- 1, in a morning "swing shift" game today to give Harry Gumbert his second straight victory over Bucky Walters in ten days.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- A further increase in the coffee ration to one pound every three weeks was announced today by the Office of Price Administration. For the first time since coffee rationing began, it was said, supplies had reached a normal level and imports to sustain this volume could be expected.

LONDON, June 24 -- How to learn English while commanding a fighting tank in the Eighth Army drive from El Alamein to Tripoli and winning the Distinguished Service Order on the way was made beautifully plain today by Major Henri Lereux, a Belgian, who thrice escaped from the Nazis after the fall of his country and transferred to the British forces.

Daily American food wastage of two-thirds of a pound of food a person contrasted with the Russian diet during the siege of Leningrad of four slices of black bread and one glass of water was demonstrated yesterday at the opening of the American-Soviet War Exhibit at the Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center.

The seven-story apartment house on a plot 147 by 150 feet at 514 Gramatan Avenue in the Fleetwood section of Mount Vernon, Westchester County, has been purchased by David S. Meister, operator, through Harold M. Silverman, broker.

The eleven-story and penthouse apartment building at 1061-65 Lexington Avenue, just south of St. Jean Baptiste Church at Seventy-sixth Street, has been sold by the New York Life Insurance Company to Aaron and Morton Simon of Simon Bros., operators and builders.

Frank Magnus Jr., 12 years old, of 100 Prospect Avenue, New Brighton, S.I., received the George Lane Nichols Memorial Medal yesterday afternoon for the honesty he displayed six months ago when he returned to its owner a wallet containing $372.

A War Film Library was established yesterday in the New York City Division of War Training at 299 Broadway. The library was collected by the Office of War Training of the State War Council, but will be administered by the city Division of War Training under Dr. John J. Furia, director.

Eggs are considerably less plentiful in Manhattan stores now than they were last week, and it is possible that a severe shortage will occur soon unless the Office of Price Administration puts a ceiling on ungraded eggs at wholesale.
PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP) -- The Athletics came from behind to snap a six-game losing streak and beat the Red Sex, 8 to 3, in the final game of their series today.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 24 -- Oscar Straub, Madison (N.J.) police sergeant, added a 79 to a first-round 74 for a total of 153 today at the Essex County C.C.'s west course and had the honor for at least twenty-four hours of leading the field in the first annual New Jersey State amateur open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Action to limit new installations of telegraph equipment to essential users and to recapture stand-by equipment not deemed necessary to render service was taken today by the War Production Board with the issue of Utilities Order U-6.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 24 -- Oscar Straub, Madison (N.J.) police sergeant, added a 79 to a first-round 74 for a total of 153 today at the Essex County C.C.'s west course and had the honor for at least twenty-four hours of leading the field in the first annual New Jersey State amateur open golf championship.
