WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Action to limit new installations of telegraph equipment to essential users and to recapture stand-by equipment not deemed necessary to render service was taken today by the War Production Board with the issue of Utilities Order U-6.

The vacant land on the northwest side of Steinway Street, 300 feet northeast of Winthrop Avenue, Astoria, Queens, has been purchased by the Superior Magneto Corporation from Ethel M. Cummings. It is assessed for $20,000. George J. Gross, Inc., represented the seller.

Government-financed plants for production of 255,000 tons of synthetic rubber annually, or more than a third of the output sched uled under the Government's entire program, will be in operation in Texas within the next ninety days, James J. Newman, vice president of the B.F. Goodrich Company, told a meeting of business and industrial leaders in Dallas yesterday.

DUBLIN, June 24 -- Of the 138 Dail Eireann seats, nineteen are yet to be filled in the general elections being tallied in Eire. An analysis of how these remaining seats are likely to be filled indicates that Prime Minister Eamon de Valera is not likely to receive a working majority over all the parties in the Dail Eireann, as first results promised.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Despite increased expenses and taxes, current operating earnings of insured commercial banks increased in 1942 to the highest figure on record, it was announced today by Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

LONDON, June 24 -- The rising fury of the Allied air offensive has shaken Nazi leaders into a desperate attempt to throw an "aerial Maginot Line" into the skies over the bomb-shattered areas of western Germany, according to information reaching British air circles.

War is having a sobering and constructive influence on advertising which should lead to less exaggerated claims in the future, I.A. Hirschmann, a vice president of Bloomingdale Brothers, declared last night in an address before 200 graduates of the New York Employing Printers Association's educational courses, at exercises in the Manhattan Industrial High School.

Ever since "Rebecca" was successfully presented on the London stage and later turned into a hit film with Laurence Olivier and Joan Fontaine in the leading roles, attempts have been made by local producers to offer Daphne du Maurier's dramatization of her best-selling novel.
DETROIT, June 24 (AP) -- For the first time this season the Tigers won a series from the Indians by gaining a 7-to-4 triumph in a twilight game tonight for Virgil (Fire) Trucks' seventh victory.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Roosevelt will be asked by the War Labor Board to use every possible means to enforce its directive of June 18 upon the United Mine Workers of America, even to the extent of canceling the check-off of union dues, seizing its $6,000,000 treasury and taking civil and criminal action against John L. Lewis, president of the UMW, and other union officials, it was reported today.

The action of Fred M. Vinson, the new Economic Stabilization Director, in vetoing a general wage increase of 8 cents an hour for 1,100,000 non-operating railway employes is as reassuring as it was unexpected. The increase had been recommended by a special "emergency board" appointed for the purpose.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -A war picture with an Australian background will be made by Columbia under the title "Treason." The yarn, an original by Horace McCoy, involves an Australian officer and a Japanese war prisoner. It will be produced by David Chatkin.

Bank clearings during the week ended on Wednesday were the largest in five weeks, reflecting the recent income tax payment period. The turnover for the major cities of the country came to $9,057,851,000, a gain of 5.5 per cent over the preceding week and 30.7 per cent above the $6,930,829,000 recorded last year, Dun Brad-street, Inc., reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 24 (U.P.) -- Italian secret police have arrested more than 11,000 persons in a sweep of the country in search of possible fifth columnists, advices said tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Department store sales in the week ended June 19 were 28 per cents above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight. This followed a gain of 29 per cent in the week ended June 12 when compared with the like week of 1942.
Directors of Gar Wood Industries, Inc., yesterday approved the issuance and sale to a banking group headed by Emanuel Co. of 200,000 shares of its authorized but unissued common stock.
LONDON, June 24 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

The basic suit and the basic dress have been talked about so much in fashion editorials and advertising that American women gladly have accepted them as the backlog of a versatile wardrobe. Now the basic hat, which changes its character to fit the occasion, makes its debut as a boon to the furlough bride or the woman whose war work takes her traveling in these days of limited luggage.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Eric A. Johnston, a representative of management on the Economic Stabilization Board and president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, gave a sharp warning to the American public tonight, declaring that "our country is confronted by a crisis that daily grows more menacing, and of a nature so serious that its dangers cannot be overemphasized."

EVANSTON, Ill., June 24 (AP) -Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador and the University of Miami jumped into the semi-finals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association singles tennis championships today at the Northwestern University courts.

FOR more years than the mind of man runneth not to the contrary Jake Weber has been massaging the muscles of scores of thousands of athletes. He probably has ministered to more famous performers than any trainer in the world. Technically he has been Fordham's chief muscle manipulator for the past thirty-three years. Actually, he handles whoever seeks his services, whether it be at national championships, Olympic Games or elsewhere.

MONTREAL, June 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Royals took a double-header from Newark tonight, winning by 7 -- 6 in the twelve-inning opener and then rallying with a thirteen-run outburst in one inning to capture the nightcap, 13 -- 9.

Three Class 1 steam railroads of the nation yesterday were awarded the E.H. Harriman Memorial Medals for outstanding accomplishment in railroad safety last year. The award was made at a luncheon here at the Yale Club under the auspices of the American Museum of Safety.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, June 25 (U.P.) -- Japanese troops have suffered 204 casualties since June 20 in attacks apparently designed to test Allied lines around Mubo, New Guinea, in the belief that an attack impends against their near-by bases at Salamaua and Lae, it was learned today.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to authorize the purchase of the Rhinelander Building, at 226-240 Duane Street and 2-10 William Street, for $500,000. The city plans to use the building as a repository for municipal archives. Against the purchase price will be credited the sum of $20,000, advanced by the city, as a lessee of the building, for elevator repairs.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Three veteran career diplomats were nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Ministers at important posts. They were:

The motorist who until recently was picked up first for pleasure driving and then given an opportunity to explain why the doctor had ordered the trip may now obtain from the Office of Price Administration a written legal and medical opinion as to the necessity for a trip before he steps on the starter.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (U.P.) -- Secretary Ickes, Petroleum Administrator, warned anew today that petroleum rationing in the Midwest may have to be tightened up "very suddenly" because of rapidly dwindling stocks in that area, but said no date for such action can be anticipated.
The global spotlight continued to illuminate the Middle East and Turkey yesterday as the war of nerves was extended to the eastern Mediterranean.

Columbia will produce forty-four feature films, three of them in Technicolor, for its 1943-44 program, it was announced yesterday. In addition, the studio will make two special productions, one of which will be a screen version of "The Land Is Bright," to be produced and directed by Sam Wood from the Broadway play by Edna Ferber and George S. Kaufman.
LONDON, Friday, June 25 (U.P.) -- The Russian midnight communique:
A few changes have been recorded in the Governor Edison Fishing Contest of New Jersey, but the entries are still coming in slowly.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The American people were asked by President Roosevelt today, in a letter to Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., to invest "considerably more" than 10 per cent of their incomes in the Treasury's payroll savings plan.

The main responsibility for success or failure of the gasoline rationing program lies with garage and service station owners, Ralph Masinter, Office of Price Administration hearing commissioner, declared yesterday in berating the owners of nine such establishments that were suspended from dealing in gasoline for varying periods after having been found guilty of handling counterfeit ration coupons and other irregularities.

Although his production of "Early to Bed" is hardly more than a week old on Broadway, Richard Kollmar is already talking about another project for this season. Mr. Kollmar reports that he is thinking of sponsoring, probably in the fall, an all-Negro opera based on an original play by Dorothy Hayword called "Let My People Go."

BUFFALO, June 25 (AP) -- The Treasury Department's regulation permitting buyers of war bends to name a beneficiary is valid under the Government's power to prosecute a war, Surrogate George T. Vandermeulen of Erie County ruled today.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- A British-American attempt to invade the Continent might easily decide the outcome of the war and for that reason Germany would welcome rather than dread it, Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels writes in his weekly review of the military situation in the magazine Reich.
When Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia returned from Washington yesterday he said he had obtained assurances from the National Administration of "direct action" to ease the city's acute shortage of meat.

Details of the voluntary "honor system" program, under which retailers would avoid promotion of scarce textile merchandise and manufacturers would equitably allocate their production and which was to have been announced several days ago by the Office of Civilian Requirements of the WPB, were obtained yesterday from local trade sources.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Administration's program for rolling consumer prices back with subsidies was put in further jeopardy today when the House dealt what it meant to be a knockout blow and the Senate seemed likely to follow the example tomorrow.

PEEKSKILL, N. Y., June 25 -- State Guardsmen of the Second Regiment of Troy and the Fiftysixth Regiment of Newburgh at Camp Smith here were hosts today to Governor Thomas E. Dewey, who reviewed the 1,400 guardsmen now on a ten-day training tour.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- Vichy continues to outlaw those who join Fighting France, it was disclosed today. The latest to fall under the ban are General Alphone-Joseph Georges, Commissioner Without Portfolio in Algiers, and Henri Queuille, a Minister in many French Cabinets who is now in London.

Thomas A. Murray, president of the New York State Federation of Labor, said last night that the action of Congress in overriding President Roosevelt's veto of the Connally-Smith bill was likely to "cause serious reaction detrimental to the continuance of organized labor's splendid record in essential war industry."

Congress has passed the Connally Smith bill over the President's veto and the measure is now a law. The act is hasty, ill-considered and confused measure. There are sound reasons for which-the President could have vetoed it. The provisions for strike ballots and for cooling-off periods were clearly out of place in a measure which in another part sought in effect to outlaw war-time strikes altogether.
MONTREAL, June 25 (Canadian Press) -- Newark needed an extra inning to do it but finally beat the Royals, 5-3, to go one game up on Montreal in the battle for third place in the International League.

LONDON, June 25 -- Whether by accident or direction, the edition here of The Stars and Stripes, American service paper, has had no space for news of the race riots in Detroit. Its policy is to avoid controversial subjects.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., June 25 -- New England can lose its competitive position in the manufacturing field, it was declared here today at the quarterly meeting of the New England Council, unless a successful fight is waged against current attempts to impose a uniform freight rate throughout the country east of the Rockies.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States submarine R-12 has been lost as a result of an accident which occurred during training exercises off the East Coast of the United States, the Navy Department said tonight.

Only twelve of thirty-six departments of New York department stores registered advertising linage gains last month, according to a breakdown by Media Records yesterday. Total linage declined 4.3 per cent from the corresponding 1942 month.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 25 -- During the transition from war work to home life women should concentrate on provincial and municipal government affairs, questions of health and conditions of occupation, Dr. Charlotte Whitton told Zontians in conference at the Lake Placid Club tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) --The Interstate Commerce Commission issued today a modified plan of reorganization for the Denver and Rio Grande Western Railroad Company which would increase total capitalization by $651,515 to $155,173,127.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The Dodgers were made the victims of a Roman holiday for a wildly enthusiastic crowd of 21,504 fans, who watched Bucky Harris' revivified Phillies beat them, 8-2, under the Shibe Park lights tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, June 26 (AP) -- A Beaufort bomber scored a near miss on a merchantman in a small Japanese convoy off Cape St. George yesterday, the High Command announced. Cape St. George is on the southeastern tip of New Ireland.

Arthur Curtiss James, railroad industrialist, who died June 4, 1941, left a gross estate of $37,771,613 and a net of $34,771,702, according to an appraisal filed yesterday by Louis J. Lefkowitz, Deputy State Tax Commissioner and Appraiser.

Ricardo G. Hill, Mexico's Consul General in this city, and Mrs. Hill were guests at a ball in honor of that country held last night for officers of the armed forces at the Hotel Roosevelt. Sponsored by the Daughters of the American Revolution War Service Committee of Greater New York, the fete was the third dance in the organization's series of Stars and Stripes balls.
You can tell what day of the week it is, if you stand long enough on a corner, just by watching the taxicabs go by.

LONDON, June 25 (AP) -- Premier Mussolini has ordered a wholesale purge of Fascist party members who "do not serve the country and the Fascist regime with a religious fervor," a Rome radio broadcast recorded by Reuter said today.

ALGIERS, June 25 -- King George VI has returned to England from North Africa after nearly two weeks spent in offering personal congratulations to the fighting men who wiped this continent clean of Axis power.

A secondary distribution of the remainder of the Chase National Bank's holdings in Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, comprising 665,715 shares of convertible preferred stock, or 75 per cent of the 905,082 shares outstanding, is foreshadowed by the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering an offering of these shares.

CAMDEN, N.J., June 25 (AP) -- Wilfred Forrest, former Mayor of Pine Hill, N.J., was fined $475 by Federal Judge John Boyd Avis today on a plea of guilty to charges of conspiracy and embezzlement in connection with illegal sale of gasoline ration coupons.

The steadily climbing thermometer went to 96.3 degrees at 6:15 P.M. yesterday -- the fifteenth day with no average temperature below normal -- and broke several records. It was the hottest day for nearly three years specifically since July 6, 1940, when the highest official temperature was 99 degrees. It was the hottest June 25 on record here, with the mercury 1.3 degrees higher than the 95 degrees reached on the same date in 1875.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Office of Defense Transportation today ordered all local cartage service by "for-hire" truckers to observe a 3 P.M. "curfew" in the acceptance of orders for freight pick-up, or requests for delivery, to become effective Monday.

Youngsters will still get vacations away from hot city streets this year. Despite the difficulties imposed by lack of transportation and personnel and the problems of food shortages and rationing, most of the non-profit camps are prepared for a capacity season.

The Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell, for twenty-seven years pastor of the Rutgers Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street, west of Broadway, has retired, it was announced yesterday. He has been made pastor emeritus by the congregation, with salary and with provision for his wife in the event that he should precede her in death.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 25 --Strikes were denounced here tonight by Mrs. Edward V. Rickenbacker of New York in an address at the commencement of the University Foundation and the American Theological Seminary, where she accepted an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters conferred upon her husband, who is in Moscow on a mission for the War Department.

" Many mothers, wives and dependents are not aware that the Army has special agency, shorn of red tape, equipped to render speedy confidential service when induction or sudden emergencies at home create financial problems" the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, as president of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, wrote this week to the Protestant pastors of the New York area.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 25 (U.P.) -- The Buenos Aires police, in a surprise move, have closed the headquarters of a pro-Allied Argentine women's organization and ordered a halt to the activities of other volunteer groups preparing bandages and other medical supplies for the Allied forces, reports reaching here from the Argentine capital said tonight.

LONDON, June 25 (U.P.) -- King George, returning to Britain today from his fourteen-day, 5,800-mile air trip to the Mediterranean area, conferred half an hour at the airport with Prime Minister Churchill who received a royal joshing for arriving late.

A special war bond drive conducted by the Central Trades and Labor Council of Greater New York, American Federation of Labor, resulted in total sales of $623,248, it was revealed yesterday when the council turned over a check for that amount to Nevil Ford, executive manager of the New York War Finance Committee. The drive was conducted from May 19 to June 23, and had as its goal the financing of two heavy Army bombers.
MEXICO CITY, June 25 -- Anna Seghers, anti-Nazi German author, was in a critical condition today as the result of injuries suffered when a hit-and-run driver knocked her unconscious late last night.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it would begin at 10 A.M. on Wednesday an investigation of recent curtailment of bus service by New York companies under restrictions recently imposed by the Office of Defense Transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- On one of Washington's hottest days President Roosevelt told reporters at his press conference today that the Government was going to spend about $25,000 to lay a new steam pipe connecting the White House with the State Department heating system so the reporters in the Executive Offices would not be cold next winter.
CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -- The Indians supported Southpaw Al Smith with an eight-hit attack tonight to beat the White Sox, 6 to 2, in a series opener.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A blanket increase of $4.50 a week for 4,000 inside workers in the milk industry in the New York-New Jersey area has been approved by the Director of Economic Stabilization, the War Labor Board announced today.

The recently promised extension of furloughs from two to three weeks for men newly inducted into the Army will become effective on July 1 in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, it was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Thomas A. Terry, commanding general of the Second Service Command.

A United States Army lieutenant, in a letter received here yesterday from Tunisia, declared that if John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, should appear in North Africa "he would be lynched."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Dividend payments in May at $115,- 000,000 declined 3 per cent from May, 1942, the Commerce Department reported today. This drop, however, was less than the decrease during the first four months of 1943.

The city's transit system, feeling the pinch of the manpower shortage, again has resorted to signs posted in the subways to attract applicants for jobs. Signs were posted in the Independent Line cars yesterday morning advertising for skilled and unskilled workers for subway, bus, trolley and shop work.

ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- Toughening up as they dig in to help New York farmers, city-bred boys and girls recruited for the Cadet Victory Corps soon will number about 3,000, a State education official said today.
NEW DELHI, June 25 (AP) -- A British communique:

One of your readers recently objected to my suggestion that the balk rule should be changed so that a pitcher is not penalized for an accidental slip. That critic contended that umpires would have unnecessary power if called upon to decide whether a balk is intentional or not.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- President Roosevelt said today he would not recognize or accept an Oct. 31 deadline set by the United Mine Workers for continued coal production in government-operated mines.

Tallulah Bankhead will return to the screen after an absence of more than ten years in a starring role in "Lifeboat," the forthcoming Alfred Hitchcock film at Twentieth Century-Fox, it was learned yesterday. Miss Bankhead will play the role of Mrs. Porter, a war correspondent and one of the survivors of a torpedoed American merchant ship.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Suspension of A-card coupons in the East is one of the steps being considered by the Office of Price Administration in view of the increasingly tight supplies of gasoline for civilians, officials revealed tonight.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- A check of buyers in both the Merchandise Mart and American Furniture Mart today, as the Chicago mid-summer furniture and home furnishings market rounded out its first week, revealed considerable dissatisfaction over quota discrepancies between big and small stores.

Some well-traveled sailor, surprised at finding a huge United Service Organization clubhouse on the island of Trinidad, called it the "Grand Central Terminal of the Caribbean," and the center is living up to its name, reports Miss Sally McPherson, one of its assistant directors, now at home on furlough.

LONDON, Saturday, June 26 (AP) -- A resumption of local but bitter fighting on the Kalinin front northwest of Moscow, in which the Germans were hurled from a settlement and three times beaten off as they counter-attacked, was reported early today by the Soviet command, along with sharp air activity in several areas.
ATLANTA, June 25 (AP) -- The men who run the Deep South big-time football will meet here tomorrow, and the prospect looks bleak.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

New York leads other cities in the number of its playgrounds, 694, according to the annual Recreation Year Book for 1942 published by the National Recreation Association, 315 Fourth Avenue. This national report contains detailed information on the public recreation program in almost 1,I00 communities.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 25 -- The revolt of the membership of the United Mine Workers of America against the terms of this week's strike settlement spread throughout the anthracite field today, but union leaders and other observers familiar with labor difficulties in the hard coal region maintained an optimistic view, predicting that the industry would return to normal conditions next week.

Widening of the proposed New Chambers Street to 150 feet from the Municipal Building to South Street, bisecting the proposed Governor Smith low-cost housing project, was urged yesterday by Borough President Edgar J. Nathan Jr. to the City Housing Authority.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation's proposal to pay from capital a dividend of $3 a share, or a total of $4,446,000, on its $6 preferred stock.

The four-story walkup apartment at 155-68 Summit Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by Coleman House, Inc., to the 166 Summit Corporation through the C.B. Snyder Realty Company, brokers. The property is assessed for $80,000 and is on a plot 80 by 125 feet.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Bills which Congress has enacted into law over President Roosevelt's veto since he took office number eight. They were:

WILMINGTON, Del., June 25 (AP) -- Hugh B. Monjar of Ardmore, Pa., national president of the Mantle Club, was sentenced to five years in prison and fined $49,000 today by Federal Judge Paul Leahy on charges of using the mails to defraud and violating the Securities Act of 1933.

While the recent classification of pulpwood cutting operations as essential by the War Manpower Commission may help relieve the pending critical shortage of paper, additional steps are necessary to avoid scarcities, E.W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association, declared yesterday.

ALGIERS, June 25 -- The French Committee of National Liberation moved toward the abrogation of three orders penalizing de Gaullists, Communists and French officials at a meeting today that was attended for the first time by all fourteen members of the committee.

BALTIMORE, June 25 (AP) -- The Pimlico race course filed today a bid for the best horses in training for a possible fall meeting by announcing that purse distribution would average at least $25,000 a day.

DUBLIN, June 25 -- Prime Minister Eamon de Valera's majority in the lower house of Parliament [Dail Eireann] has been wiped out, final returns from Tuesday's general election showed today, and political quarters believed that he would seek a deal with minor parties to maintain his government in power.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Secretary Knox predicted today a serious shortage of crude oil with-in a year and exhaustion in fourteen to twenty years of its presently known natural resources in the country.

The recent action of Fred M. Vinson, Economic Stabilization Director, in overruling an 8-cent-an-hour increase for non-operating railway employes "has destroyed the Railway Labor Act" and is taken as an indication that the case of the five railroad operating brotherhoods for a 30 per cent increase has "undoubtedly" been judged already, Alvanley Johnston, grand chief engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, charged yesterday.
A London firm, specializing since 1772 in the manufacture of swords, is now beating its product into something much more useful at the moment It is making suits of mail for American air men.

NEW DELHI, India, June 25 (AP) -- Seaforth Highlanders, Indian troops and native Burmese levies have fought three sharp skirmishes with Japanese forces on the Chindwin River front in northwestern Burma during the past few days, inflicting severe casualties on the enemy while suffering light losses, a British communique said today.

A pioneer in the reclamation and training of problem boys, Berkshire Industrial Farm is today serving an important role in guiding potential delinquents into paths that will make them good citizens. In its fifty-seventh annual report the school points to the record of the last year in helping 150 unfortunate boys grow and develop into good Americans.

DALLAS, Texas, June 25 -- Beauford H. Jester, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, told a House naval affairs subcommittee today that if the East Coast was cold for lack of petroleum products this winter, the Federal Government and the Federal Government alone would be responsible.

Although this is the season when fruits are usually abundant and cheap, the situation is different this year, with most kinds scarce and prohibitively high. Consequently, in planning the menus for next week for our hypothetical household of three -- a moderately active man and woman and a school-age child -- this department has used quick-frozen berries and tinned grapefruit, which seemed better selections than the fresh kinds.

The Detroit riots are a grim and powerful argument for an organized world. Here, in a modern city of a highly civilized State, law is flouted by a mob -- an aggressor nation -- and the State and city, under the Governor and the Mayor, arise as one man to demand and compel respect for the law.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 179 United States soldiers wounded and eighty-three missing in action in the Aleutian, Asiatic, European, North African, North American, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- It is considered likely here that within a short time the channeling of all Allied financial aid to the French through the new French Committee of National Liberation in North Africa, which represents both French factions, will provide a new incentive to French unity.

The world of scholarship has lost a leader and the world of aeronautics a stanch and far-seeing friend in the death of Dr. Joseph S. Ames. For more than fifty years he was associated with Johns Hopkins University in active capacities which ran the gamut from student to president.
The Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company reported yesterday for the nine months ended with May net profit of $I,452,388, subject to renegotiation, equivalent to $2.65 a share on the combined A and B stocks.

LONDON, June 25 (U.P.) -- The unescorted United States bombers, raiding northwestern Germany today, played a deadly game of hide-and-seek with Nazi fighter planes, destroying many of them in the "soupy" weather in which the attack was made.
LONDON, June 25 -- The report of the Amalgamated Anthracite Collieries, published today, shows an increased trading profit.

The queston is raised whether, in a recent discussion in this column, we succeeded in holding the scales of justice firmly. Carl L. Cannon, writing from the executive office of the War Production Board in Washington, wonders if we were quite fair to the United States Army in asking, on June 6, why our naval history has given us the greater number of famous battle sayings. Mr. Cannon writes:

New bond flotations here this week were more diversified than in the preceding period, when offerings consisted entirely of tax-exempt securities. The flotations, which aggregated $57,428,000, the largest total for any week since that ended April 2, included three municipal loans, one industrial, one public utility and the largest railroad offering since April, 1940.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 25 -- A savage surprise blow was struck at the big German airdrome of Sedes, near Salonika, Greece, yesterday by Liberator bombers of the Ninth United States Army Air Force from its Middle East base.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 25 -- After hearing a long expose from Carlo Scorza and a few words from Premier Mussolini last night, the Fascist party directorate under the presidency of the Premier met again tonight for another long meeting.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Requisitioning by the War Food Administration of an estimated 20,000,- 000 bushels of cash corn now stored in elevators -- the exact amount is not known -- threw the grain markets into a furore of excitement today.

To the speed and smothness of an Army air transport ship went the credit yesterday for possibly saving the life of 16-year-old Irwin Stuart Goldfarb of Miami, Fla., Young Goldfarb was operated on for a critical spinal injury at the Brooklyn, Jewish Hospital where his condition was reported as "good."
LONDON, Saturday, June 26 (U.P.) -- A special Russian communique:

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 25 -- Bernard N. Schwartz, a Newark fish dealer, was in the Union County jail here today and he will remain there for the next 2,879 days, or about seven years and ten months, unless he raises enough money to pay a fine for possession of undersized lobsters, or failing that, gets a reduction of the penalty from the State Fish and Game Commission.

Broad and unprecedented powers over working conditions and the training and allocation of the Japanese labor supply have been granted to the huge industrial cartels operating in five basic war industries, the Tokyo radio disclosed today.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Hi Bithorn, the Cubs' Puerto Rican right-hander, shut out the Cardinals with two hits, 6 to 0, tonight for his fourth victory over he world champions this season. A crowd of 6,620 saw the game, which was the first twilight contest ever played at Wrigley Field.

In the stands a ladies' day crowd of 4,090 sweltered. On the field our Master Melvin Ott fumed. In his exasperation, he even hit a home run in the ninth inning to match a circuit blow by Dick Bartell in the first.

The City Council voted unanimously yesterday to fix the basic real estate tax rate for 1943-44 at $2.89 to each $100 of assessed valuation. Its action, taken in conformity with the mandatory provisions of the City Charter, established the highest rate in the city's history, ten points above the $2.79 mark for 1942-43 and five points above the previous high mark of $2.84 set for 1940-41.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Voluntary all-out conservation of use of such public utilities as power, natural and manufactured gas, transportation of all types, water and fuel will be urged upon the American public next month in a coordinated advertising campaign financed by the industries involved and sponsored by Federal war agencies.

RICHMOND, Va., June 24 -- Chief among the 538 patents issued during the last week as announced in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office are two German processes having to do with hormone research and an unusual apparatus said to be able to control landings and take-offs of aircraft automatically.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The anti-strike bill, which the Senate and House passed today over President Roosevelt's veto, forbids any strike in a government-held plant.
Isn't the fact of the Detroit race riots far less important than the background causes of such bitterness in our country?

Shuffling down Forty-eighth Street a day or two ago was a company of hot and tired soldiers trying to sing. A boy in front led off with a few bars of "Dixie." Another started whistling a tune from "Oklahoma." A big fellow with a bass voice groped around among his vocal chords for the right key for "A Long, Long Trail."

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Drafting of labor or property as a solution to strikes or "a substitute for a sound national labor policy" was condemned by the board of directors of the National Association of Manufacturers at a meeting here today.

The Central Conference of American Rabbis, representing the Reform Rabbinate in the United States, in annual convention here adopted a resolution yesterday in which it declared it saw no essential incompatibility between Reform Judaism and Zionism.

Wendell L. Willkie will discuss his book, "One World," as a guest of Professor John T. Frederick today on his program "Of Men and Books," broadcast over the Columbia Broadcasting System network at 3 P.M. Mr. Willkie will be heard as part of a special United Nations program discussing books about "America and the Future."
The Writers War Board has turned thumbs down on the Warner Brothers film "Mission to Moscow," which is based on former Ambassador Joseph Davies's book of the same title, it was learned yesterday.

Even with the advent of the black bass season in New York and Connecticut next week, it is not expected that an increase in the number of anglers on lakes and ponds will be noticed, because of travel difficulties.

WASHINGTON. June 25 -- Labor will demand higher wages and a lifting of the hold-the-line order and abandonment of the Little Steel Formula unless by July 15 price control is made effective with a rollback to the Sept. 15, 1942, level with the aid of subsidies, Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, said today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Roosevelt vetoed the anti-strike bill, met with the Cabinet and held his press conference; his visitors included Representative Buell Snyder, Alvin J. Wirtz and Senators Truman and Kilgore.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 25 -- The remaining work of Parliament is expected to be finished next week, after which Prime Minister John Curtin will move for its dissolution in preparation for his general election campaign. It is believed the election will be held in August.
Three men who had run afoul of United States laws designed to protect this country against internal enemies were before the Federal court here yesterday.

ALBANY, June 25 -- Nearly 90 per cent of the State's income taxpayers paid their income taxes in full on April 15 despite the law permitting quarterly payments. Figures compiled by the Tax Department showed that 1,177,095 paid income taxes this year, with only 130,000 using the installment plan.

Much has been said about the performance of the railroads in moving the men and the stuff of war so efficiently in view of unprecedented demands, inability to increase rolling stock and serious drains upon experienced personnel. The annual award of the E.H. Harriman Memorial medals calls attention, however, to another aspect of the railroads' performance which is worthy of the highest commendation.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The new Student Nurse Reserve will be called the United States Cadet Nurse Corps, under a decision made today by the National Advisory Committee, called into conference by Paul V. McNutt, Federal Security Administrator.

ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP) -- Home runs by Vernon Stephens and Mike Chartak, each with a man on base, aided Denny Galehouse tonight in pitching his second consecutive victory over the Tigers as the Browns won the opener of a four-game series, 6 to 3.
BOSTON, June 25 -- It took the Yankees three innings at Fenway Park this evening to become accustomed to their first twilight game of the campaign.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 25 (AP) -- Eight recipients of research fellowships "designed to keep alive during the war years research and scholarship in the liberal arts" were announced today by Dr. Charles Seymour, president of Yale University.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Asked today whether Chester C. Davis had submitted his resignation as Food Administrator, President Roosevelt said no and discounted reports that Mr. Davis wants more power over food prices.
TORONTO, June 25 (AP) -- Toronto evened the series with Jersey City at one game each tonight when Nick Strincevich won, 5 to 0, giving four hits.

Pleasure driving bans and out-of-town transportation difficulties are giving New Yorkers a chance to rediscover the city. The Fourth of July will give many people three whole days to enjoy the pleasant pastime of staying home.
PITTSBURGH, June 25 -- Business activity in the Pittsburgh area has declined sharply because of the coal strike.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The text of President Roosevelt's veto message on the anti-strike bill follows:

Market Wise and Shut Out, together with eleven others, have been named for this afternoon's $30,000 Brooklyn Handicap, richest race of the Queens County Jockey Club whose summer Aqueduct meeting closes today. It looks like one of the greatest renewals of the Brooklyn, which goes back to gaslight days.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) --President Philip Murray of the Congress of Industrial Organizations said tonight that "absentee Congressmen must share the blame for a major national disaster" in the Congressional overturning of President Roosevelt's veto of the War Labor Disputes Act. He predicted that popular resentment over the Congressional action will bring about repeal of the measure.
EVANSTON, Ill., June 25 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura showed Earl Cochell today how much a fellow can improve at tennis in two years.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UP) -- The Navy Department made public today the names of seventy-five men held prisoner by the Japanese in the Philippines and in Japan.

While commission-house liquidation and hedging were depressing the distant positions in late dealings on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, continued trade covering and price fixing in the July pushed its price to the highest level of any contract since the 1928-29 season.

CAIRO, June 25 (AP) -- United States air headquarters here said today that the American Liberators that attacked the Sedes airdrome near Salonika dropped more than 125 tons of bombs. It was the first American blow at German-held Greece since September.

Donald Brown, 5 years old, of 3917 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, whose stomach was relieved of a small metal lock through the use of a magnet in the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn on Wednesday, was reported last night to have recovered sufficiently to go home today.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 25 (AP) -- Ensign John S. Arnald of Tallahassee, Fla., drew praise from survivors of a torpedoed tanker for getting his gun crew into action despite severe burns from the fire which the torpedo started.

On June 14 President Roosevelt sent to the Senate for confirmation as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York the name of James B.M. McNally. Mr. McNally is a graduate of St. John's College and Fordham Law School. For a dozen years he has been professor in St. John's Law School and Postgraduate Law School.

Retail trade here continued brisk this week, with some stores having estimated gains of up to 30 per cent over the corresponding week last year. The average increase for the city's department stores, however, will be well under that figure inasmuch as several leading establishments will be closed today which were open on the corresponding day last year.

EAST ORANGE. N.J., June 25 -- Playing two rounds in one day for the first time this year, Joseph H. Roberti, home club member, today won the first annual New Jersey State amateur open golf championship with a 36-hole total of 145.

LONDON, June 25 (AP) -- Five United States enlisted men and one officer were reported today to have been injured in a fight between American military police and Negro troops in northwest England last night.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A rebellious Congress, angered by three coal strikes and other sporadic interruptions of war production, quickly overrode President Roosevelt's veto today and enacted into law the Smith-Connally anti-strike bill requiring thirty days' notice in advance of strike votes and providing criminal penalties for those who instigate, direct or aid strikes in government-operated plants or mines.

Records which make use of singers only and do not employ any musicians have been brought under the ban of the American Federation of Musicians, it was announced yesterday by James C. Petrillo, the union's president.
Peter J. Curran, a funeral director for mor than thirty-five years and the last man in that field to discard the horse-drawn hack for the modern motor coach, died yesterday at the age of 74.

MEXICO CITY, June 25 -- A group of about 400 Mexican students held demonstrations against the United States this morning, as a protest against the recent clashes in Los Angeles between members of the American armed forces and zoot-sulters of Mexican blood.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -Michael O'Shea, the former Eddie O'Shea of Broadway, whose initial picture was "Lady of Burlesque," has been borrowed from Hunt Stromberg by Samuel Bronston to portray the name role in "Jack London," the first film in the latter producer's program for United Artists.

LONDON, Saturday, June 26 -- Fleets of United States heavy bombers pounded northwestern Germany yesterday on the heels of another town-crusher raid Thursday night by the Royal Air Force upon the Ruhr, the bomb-shattered industrial valley where 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 persons were reported evacuated to escape the mighty Allied air offensive.

Mexican Bonds An announcement by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday seems to be something more than a gentle hint to holders of Mexican Government bonds that, if they can possibly do so, they should have their bonds registered (as to non-enemy ownership) at the Pan American Trust Company before June 30.

Phillip Orlofsky, the middle-aged former manager of a cutters' union in the garment industry, toward the close of his second day of testimony yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro on the extortion indictment growing out of the Lepke-Gurrah racketeering in the industry about ten years ago, told of gifts of automobiles and diamond rings he made to protect himself from the thugs.

LOOK at it," said Casey Stengel, disgustedly, as he gave his innocent cast a savage slap. "The bones of my right leg are scattered into little pieces and they give me a cast that stretches from my hip to my ankle. It's heavy to carry around, too, and I can't bend over. That is to say, I can't bend over to pick up ordinary things.

DUBLIN, June 25 (AP) -- Mr. Cosgrave, leader of the Fine Gael, had campaigned for a coalition government of all parties. Mr. de Valera had opposed this proposal and said he would not join such a government.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) -- President William Harridge of the American League declared today that "unless there is a sharp tightening of the manpower situation," baseball team owners plan to operate next year. He also predicted that "the league as a whole" would enjoy a profitable season this year.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 25 -- Miss Betty Rosenquest of South Orange, N. J., gained the final round of the Women's New Jersey State Tennis Championship today on the courts of the Oritani Field Club.

In your editorial of June 23 on the Detroit race riot you say, "We ought to take the lid off and look squarely at this shameful thing." Merely as a mild preliminary to taking the lid off, let us look squarely at a few plain facts on the surface.
Fatal home accidents, alone among all classifications of accidental deaths, increased in New York City during 1942, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins reported yesterday.

LONDON, June 25 (U.P.) -- "Russia is methodically listing Germany's wanton expendtiure of Russian property as well as life," an informant said here today. "An awful day of reckoning is facing the Reich," he added.

Pivotal industrial issues made an impressive display of strength yesterday and the stock market responded with the widest gain for any day since March 25. Individual advances ranged from fractions to 2 points and 599 of the 895 issues traded on the New York Stock Exchange were higher, seventy-six of them at new highs for the year.

CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- The sensational Occupation, the nation's 1942 juvenile money-winning champion, successfully continued his quest for 3-year-old honors today by turning back Slide Rule, owned by W. E. Boeing, Seattle airplane manufacturer, in a sizzling stretch tussle for the $2,500 purse over seven furlongs at Washington Park.

NEWARK, N.J., June 25 -- Although Leo Rosenblum, president of the Hudson County Tax Board and an anti-Hague leader, has been thrice rejected for the Army because of high blood pressure, he must undergo a fourth examination if he wishes to avoid prosecution for allegedly violating draft regulations.

Municipal bond issues scheduled for award next week will total $13,083,687, according to the Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's revised total of $29,442,110 and with the weekly average for the year, thus far of $16,765,211. Most of next week's municipal financing will be concentrated on Tuesday and Wednesday.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- The branch of the Soviet military forces that has received the least publicity of any, either locally or abroad, is the famous NKVD [Narodni Kommissariat Vnutrenikh Del] force. NKVD stands for People Commissariat for Internal Affairs.
Picking an all-star, all-time baseball team long has been a popular diversion for fans, managers, players and writers.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Athletics made fifteen hits to defeat the Senators, 5 to 2, before 15,500 spectators tonight. Orrie Arntzen limited Washington to six blows and struck out nine batters.

I would like to refer to an incident that occurred during the final stages of the senior National A.A.U. 5,000-meter run at Randalls Island last Sunday, for the reason that I wonder how it could happen.

MOSCOW, June 25 (U.P.) -- Russia published today the findings of a State Commission charging individual acts of looting, torture and murder "against specific German officers and officials, and the official press in reporting the findings promised that Russia would exact the last ounce of vengeance from Germany.

ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) -- Don Gutteridge and Mike Kreevich, two of the weakest of the weak-batting Browns, came through with three hits apiece today to lead the way in a 6-to-3 victory over the Tigers.

The Eastern Defense Command issued yesterday a warning to vacationists and other persons to stay away from beaches and other restricted shore areas between sunset and sunrise, saying it was doing so to prevent the shooting of some innocent person by Army or Coast Guard patrols.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Dealing with one of the most delicate and potentially explosive issues in the whole war, that of discrimination, especially against Negroes, in war industry employment, the revived Fair Employment Practices Committee, headed by Mgr. Francis J. Haas of Catholic University, has been moving slowly in carrying out the mandate given it by President Roosevelt.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 26 -- Crews of six German submarines in Norway have mutinied and refused to re-embark in the underseas boats, it was reported in Norwegian circles here today.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 26 -- Assistant Attorney-General Edward G. O'Neill, special prosecutor in the State's investigation into the activities of Hudson Valley labor unions, estimated today that millions of dollars have been collected in the form of tribute from nonunion workmen employed on publicly financed works projects in the metropolitan area during the last four years.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- The Soviet High Command is forming entire Guards corps and Guards armies as the culmination of a process that has been going on since November, 1941, when this elite military class was instituted in the Soviet Union by the formation of the first Guards unit.

COMRADE of Daniel Boone, trusted scout for George Rogers Clark, a frontiersman who could certainly have licked his weight in wildcats had the necessity ever arisen, Simon Kenton was of the stuff from which our native folklore has sprung.

REVIVAL of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra seems likely. Continuance of the orchestra next fall for a regular season, following the present series of Sunday broadcasts, is indicated in word from Detroit. Efrem Kurtz, who reassembled the orchestra, now composed of virtually all of the original members of the organization conducted by the late Ossip Gabrilowitsch, is expected to become the permanent musical director.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -Army and Navy personnel were purposely cast adrift on rubber life rafts off Cape Fear, N.C., within the past week, the Navy reported today, in order to test new ideas in life saving equipment under conditions approaching those of actual war.

A SERIES of free weekly con-concerts will be presented by the Department of Parks in collaboration with the Associate Committee of the League of Composers beginning Tuesday, July 13, at 8:30 P.M., on the Mall in Central Park, and Wednesday, July 14, at the same hour, in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

Lieut. Col. William O'Dwyer, who has been endorsed for re-election as District Attorney of Kings county by the Republican, Democratic and right and left wings of the American Labor party, has declared himself in sympathy with President Roosevelt's war and post-war policies, according to a letter from him to Max Torchin, executive secretary of the Progressive Committee of the American Labor party of Kings county, made public yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 (AP) -United States District Judge Harry E. Kalodner declined today to stop a court inquiry into an offer made by Webster-Eisenlohr, Inc., of Philadelphia, cigar manufacturer, to buy up its outstanding 7 per cent preferred stock at $150 a share, $50 more than its par value.

Commenting on the recent agreement on waiting pay and living cost allowances for Dutch merchant seamen in the United Kingdom, Adrian Gips, chairman of the Netherland Shipping Committee in New York, pointed out yesterday that the allowances for Dutch seafarers were considerably larger in this country and Canada in order to help the men meet higher living costs.

ADIRONDACK MOUNTAINS -- Fishing this summer is expected to appeal especially to the enthusiast in the Adirondack playgrounds. The New York State Conservation Department has planted thousands of fish in the lakes, ponds and streams that checker this territory; and the signal to take to rod and reel will be sounded when the bass season opens on Thursday.

Following numerous conferences with committees of Congress and officials of the Treasury Department, the Controllers Institute of America has issued a forty-eight-page report to answer some of the troublesome questions confronting emplyers in connection with the withholding tax, Arthur R. Tucker, managing editor, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A new and improved program for the redistribution of idle and used equipment and machinery has been outlined by WPB officials to the used equipment and machinery industry advisory committee at a meeting here.

Westchester fresh-water anglers anticipate a good black bass season. Officially the curtain rises for the bronze backs on Thursday, but already many bass have been hooked and released by those who have been fishing for trout.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia announced yesterday the promotion of fifteen battalion chiefs of the Fire Department to the rank of deputy chief, at salaries of $6,300 a year. The fifteen appointees were named from a civil service list promulgated four years ago and scheduled to expire at midnight tomorrow.

A FOUR-STAMP series received last week from Vatican City commemorates the silver jubilee of the consecration of Eugenio Pacelli, now Pope Pius XII, as Titular Archbishop of Sardes. According to a New England dealer's advertising in the philatelic press, the stamps were released in 1943, but the publishers of the Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue have information that they appeared in 1942 and so will chronicle them under the earlier date.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Early Wynn defeated Jesse Flores in a hurling duel tonight as Washington defeated the Athletics, 4 to 1. Bob Johnson of the Senators drove a home run with a mate on base in the first inning.

Three world records for transatlantic flights have been set by American Export Airlines in its first year of operations, John E. Slater, executive vice president, disclosed yesterday at the dedication of the company's enlarged operating base at La Guardia Field.

IN this war Americans are flying to every continent and across every ocean. But many are asking, What about aviation after the war? Will American pilots find the air outside our own borders closed to them? Will the United States keep her own airlanes closed and insist that not one foreign plane should fly over our territory?

PITTSBURGH, June 26 -- Mounting signs came from the Appalachian coal fields tonight that nearly normal production might be resumed next week although the situation in Pennsylvania remained uncertain after a day which saw the closing of more mines even though anti-strike legislation has become law.

In an effort to meet the need for an additional 800 ships' officers and 3,500 skilled unlicensed seamen in the immediate future, the Atlantic coast regional office of the Recruitment and Manning Organization of the War Shipping Administration will send field representatives on a recruiting mission into five States, extending from Pennsylvania to North Carolina, beginning tomorrow.

WHEN Mr. Granby interviewed Kay in London he told her that his tropical island home offered no city diversions for her day off and that for her vacation she could go to New Zealand for a couple of months. Kay was not frightened by the prospect.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 26 -- After five months of what they called "Casablanca intimidation," Italian commentators said today that "the phase of the war of nerves is now on the eve of giving way to something we can combat: invasion."

New York's railroad and bus terminals reported yesterday that their facilities were being strained to ultimate capacity. It seemed, as they analyzed it, that children going to summer camps, wives, mothers and sweethearts going to visit soldiers and sailors in near-by concentrations, and residents fleeing the summer heat had combined to provide an enormous load.

American foreign traders, anxious to maintain their operations despite wartime controls and restricted markets, are becoming impatient over the delay in opening up private trade with North Africa, it was noted in export circles last week.

FROM THE NATION'S CAPITAL -- Allied victories in North Africa have already had a number of domestic effects. Vast supplies of cork, for example, are being released for use in wartime floor tiles. The WPB announces that this material -- almost unobtainable a year ago, and strictly restricted to war uses -- will soon arrive in quantity from Spain, Portugal and North Africa, its transportation made possible by recent military achievements.

SINCE no one expects too much of the replacement shows that while away the summer until the big names get back to work, it had to be news when Paul Whiteman and Dinah Shore, a couple of big names themselves, agreed to sit in for the Messrs.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The great bulk of the operations of the Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation in Tunisia is being conducted on a commercial rather than a direct-contribution basis, the office of its director, Herbert H. Lehman, announced today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Events of the last few days impress observers with the feeling that a labor crisis vitally affecting national unity is now moving toward a climax.

The industrial securities committee of the Investment Bankers Association of America, of which Percy M. Stewart of Kuhn, Loeb Co. is chairman, issued yesterday a special report on probable post-war conditions, asserting that new capital demands for the first three years after the war may be not less than $5,000,000,000 a year for the nation's industrial concerns.

TORONTO, June 26 (AP) -- Toronto increased its lead on the top rung of the International League ladder when it defeated the Jersey City Giants in both ends of today's double-header, 7 -- 3 and 7 -- 0.
LONDON, Sunday, June 27 (AP) -- The Russian Saturday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Plans for an exhaustive, nationwide investigation of "the growing racial antagonisms in this country" were disclosed tonight by Representative Martin Dies of Texas, chairman of the House Committee on un-American Activities.

A REVOLUTION in "sound" is going on at WOR. Not long ago assistant chief engineer Edward J. Content designed a new studio to clarify the spoken word. The general idea was to "improve" the commentators -- make their talks about world affairs more lifelike in American homes.

SINCE its introduction into the United States during the early part of the present century, the Japanese Beetle has cost the people of the eastern section of the country millions of dollars. From 1918 to the present year the cost to the Federal Government for research and control work has been $10,608,461.92, of which $1,826,963 was contributed by the States where beetles have been found.

For the third of its four scheduled programs at the Lewisohn Stadium, the Ballet Theatre last night undertook the rather ambitious project of presenting the full two-act version of "Giselle" as its major offering, with "Capriccio Espagnol" and "Three Virgins and a Devil" for companion pieces.

DON'T start to read David Master' account of the underseas exploits of British submarines if you expect an air raid warning, a feeding time for baby or a call from your rich aunt. Once you have started "Up Periscope" you will ignore every distraction as you turn page after page, muttering now and again, "Damn the cliches -- full speed ahead!"

AFTER reading the "Globalism" piece, which appeared in these columns a fortnight ago, one reader wrote in enthusiastically: "Please accept my thanks for enlivening an otherwise drab day." If the net result had been that, we might just dismiss the whole thing as a sort of larking interlude in the sterner crusade of art criticism.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- The "squeeze" for manpower in Canada has now been extended to include boys of 16 and men of 65 in the categories of those subject to compulsory transfer orders. This has been done with special emphasis on the need to supply workers in the forests and in the fishing industry, but it shows to what an extent the mobilization of manpower has been pushed for total war.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 26 -- A major factor in the Russians' morale is a feeling that they have the United States behind them in their death struggle with Nazi Germany, according to Brooklyn-born Rowena Meyer, now on her way back to New York after working for eight years in the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, June 26 -- Governor Dewey approved today a report recommending that all harness racing in New York State be conducted this year at a joint meeting at the Empire City Track, Yonkers.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 26 -- An important factor in the French political situation, one which should always be considered in any judgment of French politics, is that three years ago the French Republic collapsed in the face of superior military forces, wrecking the structure of the republic, and, what was worse, the faith of a large percentage of the French people in their government.

WITH the closing last evening of its two remaining plays, "The Eve of St. Mark" and "The Patriots," the Playwrights Company brought its fifth season to an end. As the Broadway counting house reckons such things it was a very successful season, for three tries resulted in three hits, which is an average generally unattainable.

Across Europe's skies last week, from the North Sea to the Mediterranean, Allied planes streaked by the thousands. They were lashing the Axis with the fiercest sustained air offensive the world has ever seen. The big bombers struck repeatedly in the theatre of war -- the Mediterranean -- and struck even harder at the Axis bases and production centers that serve that theatre.
A test case involving the use for tax purposes of the "last-in, first out" or "lifo" method of inventory valuation by retailers is now being prepared, it was learned here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The intensive Allied air attacks on Italy, marked this week by a kind of shuttle service between England and North Africa with four-motored planes, dropping bombs on each trip, does not necessarily imply an early invasion of Italy.

Columbia University's Institute of Arts and Sciences will sponsor a twelve-point program during the Summer session beginning July 6, Dr. Russell Potter, director, announced yesterday. Authors, journalists, statesmen and musicians will participate in the series to be given in the McMillin Academic Theatre, Broadway and 116th Street.

FOLLOWING Governor Dewey's exemption of its real property, devoted to opera and allied educational purposes, from taxation, and for the second time within a relatively short period, the Metropolitan Opera Association has issued a statement of its fiscal condition, its practical operations and artistic problems of the past and the future, which takes the public into the confidence of the organization as never before in the sixty years of its history.
LONDON, June 26 (U.P.) -- An Eighth United States Air Force communique:

For the third successive day the July contract on the New York Cotton Exchange broke into new fourteen-year high ground yesterday under the impetus of continued trade price-fixing and short-covering. Strength was apparent also in the five other active futures.
WILSON DAM, Ala., June 26 (AP) -- Here in the Muscle Shoals area of northern Alabama is the war plant that got a second chance -- and made good.

IF the same person both writes and delivers a program on the air, is he a writer or performer? That moot if esthetic point has led to a major jurisdictional row between the American Federation of Radio Artists and the Radio Writers Guild.

All experience has shown that the best of laws can be rendered useless by poor administration but even poor laws can be made to work under good leadership and administration. The same will be true of the machinery to achieve a just and durable peace. Thus, the most skillfully devised political machinery for peace will be no better than the purposes and capacities of the human beings who direct it.

THE fact that many types of garden irrigation equipment are now off the market should not deter any one from taking proper care of his garden during dry periods. Gardens received artificial watering hundreds of years before the watering devices of the modern garden were developed.

THE butterfly bush or buddleia has summer values of every kind. From July until frost the shapely, arching bushes, growing from four to eight feet tall according to the variety, display a gradation of soft, subtle colors, white, pink, orchid, lavender and purple, within the shrubbery border.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- A threat to discharge all machinists, numbering up to 3,500, who refused to work ten-hour shifts was held in abeyance today by the manage ment of the Joshua Hendy Iron Works at Sunnyvale as the Maritime Commission took a hand in a dispute which was threatening to interfere seriously with engine production for Liberty ships and Navy craft.

JOAN HARRISON is blond, pretty, 32, and English. She also has eight years of assisting Alfred Hitchcock to eat, direct, read, write and produce behind her, so she's admirably equipped to take office at Universal, hire two quiet secretaries, wear raucous yellow-and-black plaid shirts, and buckle down to work as the only woman producer in Hollywood.

Following are editorial comments of the country's newspapers on the action of Congress in overriding the President's Veto of the antistrike bill. These extracts, gathered by The Associated Press, are very strongly commendatory of the legislator's votes.

The arrest here of 167 Selective Service delinquents as part of a national round-up in which 785 men were taken in custody by Government agents and the police was announced yesterday at the local office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

LONDON, June 26 -- Bent on forcing him to quit Spain, the Germans have done everything in their power, even resorting to gunman methods, to undermine Sir Samuel Hoare, Great Britain's Ambassador to Madrid, according to a letter the envoy has sent to the Women's Auxiliary Branch of the Conservative Association in Chelsea.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, June 27 (AP) -- Twenty tons of bombs were dropped yesterday by Allied raiders on Rabaul, New Britain, where concentrations of Japanese shipping and aircraft had been reported by reconnaissance fliers, the High Command announced.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Attributing to OPA regulations the meat crisis facing the country, John A. Kotal, executive secretary of the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers, said today that the shortage was threatening the requirements of the armed forces as well as supplies for civilian consumption.

Fourteen leaders of national organizations seeking to promote interracial understanding issued a joint statement yesterday warning that "no industrial center of any size in the United States can look complacently or even objectively on what has happend in Detroit."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., June 26 -- Despite many changes of personnel in the State Guard because of the draft of 18-year-old members and the recruiting of 17-year-old youths, training results at Camp Smith have already shown much improvement over the accomplishments of last year.

Germans are making synthetic fat out of paraffin from petroleum mixed with synthetic glycerin by means of a new process of paraffin oxidation. They also are extracting the marrow from bones by a new autoclaving process. This information comes from the official journal of the British Association for the Advancement of Science.
The Detroit race riots were described as a menace to our war drive in sermons by rabbis here yesterday.

This year's Mississippi flood is one of the worst on record. Accordingly T. Kennard Thomson, a civil engineer with a large experience in river control, revives a proposal which he made years ago to spare millions anxiety and to save property worth a billion at least.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Reports were current today on the Board of Trade here that the War Food Administration will announce soon that further control will be imposed on the handling of cash corn. It is expected that fresh receipts of corn from the country will be allocated to industries and that elevator interests will not be permitted to make sales except to essential users of the grain.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Congress dealt the Administration another severe blow today through Senate approval of a bill which would end the Office of Price Administration's price rollback program for butter and beef and, in the absence of specific legislative authorization, ban future subsidy programs to hold down or roll back prices.

Post-war planning with respect to consumer credit terms developed last week into a sharp controversy between those retailers who would like to see present controls continued on a modified basis and others, who appeared to be in a majority, who want no governmental control at all after the war.

SUMMER brings fresh duties to 327 women volunteers at the New York City Defense Recreation Committee, who take turns at its 99 Park Avenue information desk. They plan to take their own outdoor sports vicariously, in order to tell the boys and girls in blue and khaki about all the facilities the city and park departments are placing at their disposal.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Praising the efficiency of Russian-American cooperation, Admiral William H. Standley, United States Ambassador here, last night expressed the hope "that the wartime cooperation now working to defeat Hitler will continue until Japan is defeated" and then added: "But at any rate, that cooperation must continue into peace; postwar cooperation is absolutely essential if we are to win the peace."
