WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees agreed today upon a compromise designed to prevent the removal from the government payroll before Jan. 1 of three officials accused of membership in subversive organizations.

Federal agents arrested sixteen enemy aliens here this week-end, it was announced yesterday, and among the prisoners was a family of five Germans living in Brooklyn, including twin daughters who were quoted as having admitted their willingness to sabotage American industry.

THE volume by Professors Lemon and Ference is a second-year text for professional or pre-professional science students and has been used as a provisional text for nearly eight years at the University of Chicago in the sophomore sequence courses.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- George H. Pabst Jr., president of the Pennsylvania, Ohio Detroit Railroad Company and vice president in charge of finance of the Pennsylvania Railroad System, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today not to permit firms "concerned only with prospective bankers' profits" to defeat a plan of the Pennsylvania System to assume obligation in respect of $28,483,000 of its subsidiary's 3 3/4 per cent first and refunding mortgage bonds, Series D.

The city heat they were fleeing was responsible for only part of the discomfort of many motorists who were halted yesterday by Office of Price Administration inspectors, who were out in strength at beaches and on the open roads to enforce the ban on nonessential driving.

OPENING two-bids of various sorts have received more publicity during the past year than any other bid in bridge. A very weak two-bid, used as a pre-emptive bid; a moderately weak two-bid, made on a strong six-card suit with little outside strength; aJ artificial two:I club bid, forcing to game, which isI designed to replace the two-bid in common use -- all these methods have won the support of various groups of experts.

THE cafe and hotel news this week, one of the busiest this season, concerns chiefly the return to the local sector of Benny Goodman, the swing clarinetist; the opening of a new club and summer show and other assorted doings. Noted in chronological order, the events are:

LONDON, Sunday, June 27 -- A large force of American heavy bombers attacked airfields and industrial targets in France by daylight yesterday, winding up the busiest week yet seen in the mighty Allied aerial offensive that has devastated the German war cradle in the Ruhr valley and woven a pattern of destruction along Adolf Hitler's coastal wall.

With the accent on engineering, City College's second full-term summer session will begin tomorrow with 4,500 students attending. Almost 70 per cent of these will be technology students, a record total.

MEXICO CITY, June 26 -- Constantine Oumansky, Russian Ambassador to Mexico, said today that when he left Moscow a few weeks ago, the Germans were massing large forces on all fronts in preparation for a summer offensive.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 26 -- Passive resistance to Vichy's orders is increasing in France, especially among the peasantry. Evasion of the law is becoming the rule rather than the exception.
" THE OTHER AMERICANS" might have been more accurately called "The Other Americas," for this is a book about places and things rather than people. Colorful romantic places and things.
MACON, Ga., June 26 (AP) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek received an honorary LL.D. from Wesleyan University today and left with present students this quotation as a rule for living:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., June 26 -- Amelia Earhart, scholarships of $500 each will be awarded by Zonta International to Mrs. Gertrude Hill Fila of Burbank, Calif., and Miss Susanna Wilson of Miami, according to the report of Mrs. Dorothy Mcsparron Arnold of New York at the Zonta convention, which ended tonight.

THIS is a book important far beyond either its length or its specific contents, although it is distinguished both for its brevity and for its unrelenting specificity. Its greatest merit is its temper or tone -- a tone clear, intelligent, imaginative and powerful.
Eight Democratic Representatives from New York City were not recorded on the vote in the House which overrode President Roosevelt's veto of the Connally-Smith anti-strike bill.

Operating almost exclusively on war contracts, the aircraft and automotive industries in the United States have jumped their production to record levels, with indications that the peak has not yet been reached. Renegotiation of contracts, taxes and higher operating costs are taking an increasingly greater proportion of revenues, however, with the result that it will be difficult for members of these groups to maintain earnings above current levels.

Fortunately for the taxpayer, most of the administrative intricacies involved in pay-as-you-go taxation will disappear after the transition period. This period should be completed by next March 15 when the final income-tax return for the calendar year 1943 is required to be filed.

INCREDIBLY, it is a scant twenty years -- remember the crystal set? -- since radio sent its first tentative bleats into our homes. More than we realize, our lives were changed thereby, our habits, our hobbies, and some of these changes Miss Morris has recorded in an unassuming novel, "The Tuckers Tune In."

THE midway point in 1943 finds the influence of the Axis short-wave broadcasters steadily waning while the United Nations' outlets prepare for the coming invasion. Compared with previous years, the "war of words" as waged by the Nazis has been a near-failure.

DALLAS, Texas, June 26 -- Texas ranges, from the coastal areas on through East Texas and across the State to the west, are teeming with cattle, yet severe shortages of beef exist not only outside Texas but also in many parts of this State.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce outlined today a nine-point program of action for itself for the coming "Chamber Year" and at the same time issued a bulletin sponsored by its committee of economic policy covering recommendations of the committee's economists on how to absorb the total American labor supply in the postwar period.

A recent Supreme Court order is of vast significance for the future of labor relations. It covered the so-called "Railroad Adjustment Board case" (Washington Terminal Company v. Boswell, et al.). The order merely stated that because of an equal division of opinion among the eight justices who sat in the case, one being disqualified, the decision of the lower court would be permitted to stand.

In camp barracks from coast to coast, aboard transports going to India or Australia, seated in tents beneath the hot New Guinea sun or the cold wind-swept Iceland villages, American soldiers can be found poring over books, solving arithmetic problems or answering American history questions.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- In spite of the importation of Mexican labor, California farmers and fruit growers must have 35,000 additional workers next month to avert big crop losses, it was estimated today by William B. Parker, executive director of the newly organized State Farm Production Council.

THE rain, slanting and silver, drove lightly across the terrace." These are the first words of Mrs. Delafield's new novel, as if in those two adjectives she were suggesting the mood of her book -- as if things were to be considered obliquely, as if they were to have the quality, say, of those very thin old spoons that must have been on the table in the big, cold house at Coombe.

Flag Day pictures in the paper disclosed a fact we hadn't noticed before. Old Glory, so gallantly streaming, is not merely the grandest flag t. hat floats, the promise of liberty and equality, the flag of the free heart's hope and home, the sign of pr/de, honor and union, and the emblem that makes tyranny tremble.

FOR such an unmilitary folk Americans have done rather well in war. They have been consistent at the business -- consistently unprepared and just as consistently victorious. They have paid exorbitant prices for success.

PROFESSOR WILSON D. WALLIS, head of the Department of Anthropology at the University of Minnesota, has written a richly documented study of the messiah as he appears in various guises across the centuries in every part of the world and every type of culture.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago, during World War I, Bruce Bairnsfather's Old Bill and Alf crouched in their Better 'Ole and did more for the cause of international relations than all the allied propagandists laid end to end.

CAIRO, Egypt, June 26 -- The personal conduct of the American soldiers and airmen stationed in and around Cairo during the past year has set a high standard, according to British Police Chiefs in the Egyptian Government service.

NATIONAL interest among philatelists in the forthcoming auction of stamps, covers and related material for the benefit of the United Service Organizations is attested by the fact that thus far more than 300 collectors and dealers in 116 cities and towns in twenty-eight States have sent contributions.

IN view of the shortage of meat and the need for good health in the nation, Victory gardeners may well take a tip from the Chinese and plant an abundance of peas and beans. Their high protein content makes them a valuable substitute for meat and they contain many essential vitamins and minerals.

SALTING, is one of the simplest means of food preservation as well as one of the cheapest. Experts advise, however, that it be used only with supplies that cannot be kept by another method, for it reduces nutritive values somewhat.

THE reading of biography is, for the layman -- like his choice of a physician -- an act of faith. In the latter instance he is able at least to evaluate to a degree the wisdom of his confidence by the state of his own health.

Despite the satisfaction which we are entitled to feel over the success of the incessant bombings of Nazi Germany, it is prudent not to forget the costs involved and, now and again, to strike a balance with regard to comparative losses in the air battles themselves.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 26 -When 20-year-old American or British bombing pilots are permitted to destroy works of art by Albrecht Duerer or Titian, it is high time for cultured Europeans to blush with shame, Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, told an audience at the opening of the seventh annual German art exhibition in Munich today.

At 3:13 last Friday afternoon from the rostrum of the Senate a message from the President was read. It was his veto of the Connally-Smith anti-strike bill. When the reading was over a motion for roll-call was made and seconded. The Senate voted 56 to 25 to override the veto.

HAMPTON, Va., June 26 -- A 25-year-old Negro artist's conception of the contribution his race has made to democracy in America was unveiled at Hampton Institute last night. It is a mural 11 by 17 feet. The artist is Charles W. White and he made formal presentation to the college of the work he had just completed on a grant from the Julius Rosenwald Fund.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Millions of America's consumers of radio equipment and related devices have some highly interesting things in store for them in the post-war period, according to plans now being formulated here by the commercial research department of the Radio Corporation of America.

EVEN the most casual observer, seeing hundreds of small gray inch-worms dangling on silken threads from branches and noticing entire trees denuded by the pest, would conclude that this was a "canker worm year."

LONDON, June 26 (U.P.) -- The Axis suffered another attack of week-end invasion nerves tonight, telling the world by radio that "the guns will open up soon" in the Mediterranean and guessing that Allied preparations for attack are completed everywhere from the Balkans to Italy and Norway.

Wall Street banks, as the second quarter of 1943 draws to a close, are demonstrating to the nation's banking industry that they can do business with virtually no excess reserves. A cushion of idle funds, however customary in former years, yields no revenue, and under present conditions idle bank funds do not help the war effort.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Francis Biddle, the Attorney General, announced today that a Federal grand jury at Indianapolis had indicted six persons, including a lieutenant colonel in the engineering corps, on charges of conspiring to overcharge the Government $190,000 on rental of equipment used in building the Hoosier ordnance plant near Charlestown, Ind.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 25 (Delayed) -- An organized underground army of more than 260,000 Serbian, as well as, it is estimated, 40,000 Communist Partisans and almost 30,000 Croat guerrillas are armed and ready to launch a full-scale revolt in Yugoslavia the moment that the signal is received from the Allied command, according to the disclosures of a Serbian air force officer who escaped from Europe this week.

A WELL-KNOWN educator remarked recently: "Since the first World War we have seen a disturbing proportion of our youth developing a lukewarm patriotism. They have been indifferent to their health, and all too frequently have revealed an aversion to hard work."

ALGIERS, June 26 -- An editorial criticizing the French Committee of National Liberation for lack of decision and not asserting French sovereignty in the face of Allied wishes was withdrawn today from Combat, the organ of the de Gaullist party in Algiers.
Corp. William L. Mackey of the Marine Corps described yesterday his encounter on Guadalcanal with "the first-string relief pitcher of the Tokyo Red Sox," a persistent Japanese grenade tosser.

I RECALL well that muddy and muggy morning in November, 1918, twenty-five years ago now, less six months, when the cannon ceased their angry roar along the battleline in France which stretched from Belfort to the sea. Six million men had died in a four years' war fought against aggression.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 26 -- Miss Helen Germaine of New York, the defending champion in the women's New Jersey State tennis championship was eliminated from the tournament in the semifinal round today at the Oritani Field Club.
NEW DELHI, India, June 26 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

HAVING marked the heroic defensive actions of American forces in the Pacific with "Wake Island" and "Bataan," Hollywood now is turning attention to pictures dealing with actual offensive operations against Japan.

WHEN Desmond Shannon drives down to Breckpool, a Summer resort on the New Jersey coast, his only task, so far as he knows, is to find Judy Mason, who has disappeared. Judy is Miss Lane's niece, and Miss Lane is Shannon's secretary.

An immediately hopeful but ultimately dismaying perspective on warfare is revealed by the Army. First, there is the skip-bomb, with the aid of which Army fliers last March sank twenty-two out of twenty-two ships in a Japanese convoy in the Bismarck Sea.

LONDON, June 26 (U.P.) -- American Flying Fortresses pounced on a Nazi convoy in the North Sea during their Friday daylight attack against northwest Germany, it was announced today. They were believed to have scored hits on fifteen to twenty ships, probably destroying some of them.

IT is a commonly accepted belief that the best place to bring up children is in a home -- preferably their own home. This does not disregard the function of the institution, which is thought to be best for some boys and girls, but it is on the foregoing premise that child placement in this country has long moved in the direction of foster care.

Devil Diver, for the Greentree Stable, yesterday captured the $33,700 Brooklyn Handicap as Aqueduct closed its Summer meeting, and thereby made alive once more the disputations and contentions which had the turf world by the ears following the Kentucky Derby of 1942 which Shut Out won.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Possible railroad entry into the aviation business on a large scale was indicated today when the Burlington Transportation Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, asked the Civil Aeronautics Administration for permission to operate helicopter or similar aircraft service in the area that it serves. The Burlington's bus company operates 8,500 highway miles in thirteen Middle Western States.

THE military mind, which, like the bureaucratic mind and some of the more glacial forms of the academic mind, distrusts departure from the traditional and stereotyped, is not required cerebral equipment of the soldier.

BAYONNE, N.J., June 26 -- Less than twenty-four hours after Congress made a law of the Smith-Connally Anti-Strike Bill over President Roosevelt's veto some 250 employes of the Bayonne plant of Best Foods, Inc., stopped work today in what the management called a strike and what the employes called a lock-out inspired by the adoption of the measure to curb strikes in plants operated by the government or plants having contracts with the government.

LONDON -- Some account has just been given of the work of a little-known branch of the Royal Navy, the sea rescue tugboats, whose job it is to steam into the Atlantic and tow bombed, torpedoed and abandoned merchant ships into the nearest British port.

CLEVELAND, June 26 -- Steel manufacturing war plants in the Great Lakes area are back in high gear and the task of building up ore stocks is growing more difficult every day, shippers disclosed today.

DURING the first World War, as officer in charge of diving operations in the Third Naval District, Frank Meier became known as the "underwater trouble shooter." In handling this job he added to an already sizable knowledge of diving and other operations that undersea salvage entails.

One of the happiest families in Queens is that of Staff Sergeant Thomas D. McMahon, 18 years old, of 112-36 207th Street, St. Albans. He was reported missing on Jan. 13. On March 1 he was reported killed in action, and was awarded the Order of the Purple Heart posthumously last May 13.

Drs. Harold Brandaleone, Elizabeth Main and J. Murray Steele (New York University), in a report to the Society for Experimental Biology and Medicine, dash the hopes of those who would restore gray hair to its natural color by taking vitamins. In only two out of nineteen gray-haired elderly men and women did a significant change of hair-color occur with intensive vitamin treatment over a period of eight consecutive months.

The Greater New York Industrial Council of the Congress of Industrial Organizations stated yesterday that a delegation of 500 labor and community consumer representatives from this city would go to Washington Tuesday to protest against Congressional action on the Connally-Smith anti-strike bill and the banning of price subsidies through the Commodity Credit Corporation.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 26 -- More than 100 Flying Fortresses, the largest formation of heavy bombers ever launched against a single target from North Africa, battled through an Axis fighter screen to blast Messina, the terminus of the main Axis supply line to Sicily, in a violent eighteen-minute raid yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Navy comunique 423:

THE record companies' practice of holding in reserve disks by outstanding artists so that the release dates can be spaced over a period of years may be a source of aggravation to those who want their favorites on records as soon as the recording sessions are completed.

Ground fighting in the South Pacific area has been virtually suspended since February, when the last of the Japanese were expelled from Guadalcanal and Papua. Now it is briskly resumed at Mubo, in New Guinea, where we have repulsed an enemy attack.

QUEBEC -- Members of the United States colony in Quebec will celebrate two holidays within the next few days, for they will join with Canadians in the fete of Dominion Day, on July 1, and three days later will celebrate the Fourth.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (U.P.) -The Nazis have thrown everything they have against United States heavy bombers over Germany but have not yet been able to inflict critical losses, Maj. Gen. Davenport Johnson said today.

Representative Emanuel Celler of New York yesterday urged members of the American Medical Women's Association not to rest upon the laurels of their victorious fight to obtain commissions for women doctors in the Army and Navy but to help women in other professions by taking up cudgels in behalf of the Equal Rights Amendment.

THE midsummer news from the Katharine Cornell-Guthrie McClintic menage is herewith presented. The producing alliance between Miss Cornell and John C. Wilson, which will bring the actress to Broadway in Dodie Smith's romantic drama, "Lovers and Friends," will work this way: Miss Cornell will handle the production end and Mr. Wilson's office will handle the operating end after the play opens.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- With strike tension eased, President Roosevelt has on his desk another difficult and complicated domestic problem: What to do about centralizing food authority?

WASHINGTON, June 26 (U.P.) -- A Senate judiciary subcommittee today unanimously approved the nomination of James B. McNally to be United States Attorney for Southern New York. The nomination was sent to the full committee for action on Monday.

WHEN the gentlemen of the House of Representatives killed the budget the other day for the Office of War Information in all its domestic activities, they put a potential quietus on a sizable wartime service of the screen.

GUSTAVUS MYERS did not live to see this book published. He died last Winter. a little worn and aged, and the libraries he had haunted most of his life missed him. He had been a tireless researcher, ever taxing his eyesight as he pored over old newspapers and documents in search of the facts of which he built his books.

Dr. K.K. Darrow broadcast over station WRUL last week some remarks on the way scientists all over the world cooperate -- a way that ought to be taken to heart by the men who will draft the new world order.

SUTTON ROYAL is a quiet little English village to which come many and varied people who would never have heard of it if there had been no war. The villagers themselves discovered new characters under the surface in each other, too.

STRIDENT isolationism made Chicago famous before Pearl Harbor. Today, eighteen months after that event, the city's mood has changed. Colonel Robert R. McCormick's recent proposal in The Chicago Tribune for "States across the sea" may have aroused only derision in the British lands which he magnanimously invited to join the union.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (U.P.) -- Congested Washington is dirty and vice-ridden and faces the danger of disastrous epidemics unless it is cleaned up, a special House subcommittee warned tonight. The committee added that half of the capital's population lived in squalid, unsanitary slums.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Calling attention to the far-reaching costs of the rioting in Detroit, Joseph D. Keenan, vice chairman of the War Production Board for labor production, urged today that management and labor in every war industry center cooperate with civic groups to correct the causes of racial strife.

HINTS for better gardening practice are especially opportune this year when every gardener must save as much time and labor as possible. Methods of easing outdoor burdens and conserving time are numerous -- most of them have been used for years by professionals and other successful gardeners -- and go a long way toward making a finished and beautiful display.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -The Senate cleared the way today for passage Monday of the $71,898,425,740 war bill and for a fight over a proposal to set aside House demands for scapping the National Youth Administration.

As a result of the war this country has witnessed a remarkable expansion in the content of workers' education. Not only does this education retain its earlier idealistic philosophy, but it has increasingly emphasized a wide variety of social, recreational and cultural activities.

The Coordinating Council of French Relief Societies, Inc., will be the beneficiary of an exhibition of drawings by Paul Cesar Helleu and John Singer Sargent, which will be opened at the council's headquarters, 457 Madison Avenue, on July 14 at an invitation preview afternoon reception.

LONDON, June 26 (U.P.) -- Russian troops, attacking with powerful tank support, have driven two armored wedges into the rim of the German salient looping around Orel, the big base midway between Moscow and Kharkov, the Berlin radio reported tonight.

ON David's tenth birthday his understanding uncle sent him an electric train with more cars and track than he had ever dreamed of. The neighborhood gang helped him set it up, and almost before anyone could say "Caboose!" the train scooted out of doors on a track that none of them had seen.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. -- Pleasant Valley Bird and Wild Flower Sanctuary, Lenox, is to hold its thirteenth annual meeting on Wednesday in a red-painted barn with original hand-hewn timbers open to the rafters. It is a museum of natural history specimens and early American furniture.

At the fifty-fifth commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, today at 4:30 P.M., the Ginzberg Jubilee Year will be started in celebration of Prof. Louis Ginzberg's seventieth birthday next November. Dr. Ginzberg, Professor of Talmud at the seminary, is a leading rabbinic scholar.

LONDON, June 26 -- Britain and the United States -- but especially Britain -- have shown a marked change in their attitude toward Generalissimo Francisco Franco's Fascist government in Spain in recent weeks. It is a steadily stiffening attitude with regard to a foreign government which, although neutral in name, is pro-Axis in fact.

PITTSBURGH, June 26 (AP) -- While the petroleum industry has performed "a real transportation miracle" in moving oil to the East coast, stocks available for civilian use are still far below safe and efficient levels, Dr. Robert E. Wilson, New York petroleum economist, said today.

TRENTON, June 26 -- Replying to recent criticism of the marked increase in the number of Federal employes since the nation's preparedness program got under way, Harry B. Mitchell, president of the United States Civil Service Commission, asserted here today that "all but a fraction" of the newly hired employes were laborers needed to man government shipyards, arsenals, air stations and other centers of war activity.

THE $70,000,000 Westchester County park system, which has served as a model for the nation since its establishment two decades ago, is now facing its greatest crisis because of a fiscal pruning contemplated by officials as a war economy.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The fate of the Office of War Information, one of the most influential of the Government emergency bureaus, is endangered, and Elmer Davis, its director, has threatened to resign if the Senate does not restore appropriation cuts, made by the House, which would wipe out the agency's activities within the United States.

DETROIT, June 26 (AP) -- A sociologist who directed an inquiry among race rioters here reported tonight that the war-induced influx of workers from the South and other sections was "almost no factor" in Monday's outbreak of fighting between Negroes and white persons.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. -- The chief problem for the vacationist who wants to visit the New Jersey coast this summer is one of transportation. If he can get there -- by train or bus -- he will find plenty of other visitors and plenty to do.

The article on "French disagreements" in THE TIMES of June 13 was written with such evident love of France and impatient desire to see that unhappy country freed and united that it disarms disagreement, and yet I find myself heartily and entirely opposed to the whole approach to the problem.

Despite high temperatures, retail trade here continued active throughout most of last week. Seasonal merchandise was in brisk demand and some early buying of fall staples was noted. Some department stores had estimated increases ranging to 30 per cent over last year.

OFF the press tomorrow come 100,000 copies of a new booklet, "Going Somewhere?" which the USO Division of the National Board of the Y.W.C.A. plans to distribute from its 600 Lexington Avenue headquarters to USO centers.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- In this vast land where there is a powerful political machine all publicity can be called official public opinion. It is far less easy to assess with confidence the true mood of the people based on deep traditions of popular prejudice, though this in turn is a more important factor in the shaping of the official attitude than is usually imagined.

LAKE CHAUTAUQUA and the institution which has grown up on its shores are perhaps not so well known to the American public as they were a generation ago, but there are still many who remember Chautauqua as a spot where recreation and the pursuit of knowledge went hand in hand.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Roosevelt received written pledges today of continued allegiance to labor's no-strike pledge from William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, and Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, as John L. Lewis of the United Mine Workers, principal target of the Smith-Connally Anti-Strike Bill which Congress passed yesterday over an Executive veto, strove to get his miners back to work.

AN inclusive exhibition of paintings by Morris Hirshfield has been imposingly installed at the Museum of Modern Art. The complete list numbers some thirty canvases executed in the Brooklyn "primitive's" familiar manner in the five or six years he has been painting since his retirement from the garment industry.

WHEN Aldous Huxley arrived in New York aboard the Normandie in the Spring of 1937 he came only to visit. Now he has taken up residence in America, the years between have developed into one of the most interesting periods of his life.

Young women of society in authentic costumes dating back to 1830 will comprise an informal reception committee tomorrow afternoon at a reception in the Sea-bury Tredwell house, 29 East Fourth Street, which is sometimes referred to as the "Old Merchant's House".

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., June 26 -- Predictions that New England industry will enjoy a period of easy competition during the period immediately following the end of the war, but may have trouble later which can be averted only by energetic post-war planning and research now, were made at the closing session of the New England Council's quarterly meeting held here today.

Eugene J. Houdry, national president of France Forever, predicted last night that the war against Germany can be won by the United Nations this year "because the German people cannot stand up under the intensity of the bombing raids they are now undergoing."

If the Waacs, Waves, Spars and other auxiliaries of women are needed to fight and win the war, the age-old barrier in the United States Power Squadrons against distaff skippers is perhaps about to be lowered. This recurring controversy flared up again recently in the last monthly meeting until September of the national governing board.

PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- Walter Kirby Higbe today hit the first home run of his half-dozen years in the National League and that blow, coming in the seventh inning off Charley Fuchs, proved the winning margin for the Dodgers. They beat the Phillies, 3 -- 2.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Six hundred and seventy-three million books and brochures are reported to have been printed during the two years of Russia's participation in the war, including 35,000 separate editions.
IT'S too bad that everything can't turn out as pleasantly in real life as it does in fiction.

The sixteenth day of the current heat wave gripped New York yesterday. Although the high mark of 94.2 degrees at 12:30 P.M. was 2.1 degrees lower than Friday's record high of the year, the average yesterday was higher.

Our American colleges are practically unanimous on the need for accelerating our educational program. The war demands have given us an all-year academic calendar. Our colleges, however, have been slow in accepting the values of acceleration within the revised calendar.

AWAY out on the edge of show business there are a number of highly profitable activities that have only the flimsiest relationship with the time-honored make-believe of theatre tradition. Excluding the new promotions that are being thought up while this is being written, these would number such common enterprises as ticket scalping, coat checking lemonade and a million-dollar business that evolves around the souvenir program.

WHEN you cross the Potomac and for the first time set foot in Pentagon, the great, concrete doughnut of a building where the War Department now lives, a strange, haunting feeling grips you. There's a tang of nostalgia in it. You have been here before, but you don't know where or when.

WITH English domestic enormously altered the war and our own being put more out of joint week by week, it is a good thing to have the picture set before us by Mr. Strong. He has arranged his selections chronologically, beginning with the almost incredible scene from "Clarissa Harlowe" in which the heavy father and the submissive mother unite to compel poor Clarissa to accept "the odious Solmes."
LONDON, June 26 -- After a week-long crisis, during which two attempts to form a Yugoslav Cabinet had failed, King Peter announced today that Milos Trifunovitch would head a new Cabinet.
ATLANTA, June 26 (AP) -- Members of the football-conscious Southeastern Conference got a green light today to continue intercollegiate athletics in the deep South -- if they can.

It seems almost incredible that running head on into a slow ball could possibly inflict such frightful damage and yet, 5,479 spectators at the Polo Grounds yesterday will attest that what Jim Tobin's tantalizing "flutter ball" did to the Giants was both a crime and a caution.

NEW DELHI, India, June 26 (U.P.) -- United States Liberator heavy bombers and Mitchell medium bombers, taking advantage of a break in the monsoon season, hammered Japanese targets in central and southern Burma Thursday and Friday, the Tenth United States Air Force announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, appealed today to a Senate Appropriations subcommittee to reject House demands for elimination of the OWI's domestic branch. He has threatened to resign if the House action is approved by the Senate.

Russia has had two inlets for lend-lease supplies. One was the winter route through the Arctic to Murmansk. The other is Russia's "Burma Road" -- a long land bridge through mountainous Iran, a fabulous land of antiquity. It connects southern Russia with the headwaters of the Persian Gulf.

THE paper chase with which this story deals is a deadly serious affair, although some of the participants do not know just how serious it is until it is nearly over. Three groups of people are involved in the chase, and two of them are up to no good.

The nation's supply of dressed meats is shrinking toward the vanishing point so rapidly that thousands of butcher shops in the Midwest as well as the East are closing and the new War Meat Board will meet in Chicago tomorrow to consider how to obtain enough meat for the armed forces.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -- The continued release of 1,000 persons weekly from Japanese relocation centers, Dies committee inquiries into operation of the camps and a Supreme Court decision this week upholding Army curfew regulations on the West Coast have brought into sharp focus the question, What shall be done from here on out with the 120,000 persons of Japanese ancestry in this country?

Special prayers were offered for the nation's leadership toward "a peace of righteousness and permanence" at a service in Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, held yesterday in conjunction with the annual convention of the Central Conference of American Rabbis, who represent the Reform Rabbinate in the United States.
" Restless railroad money" is retiring rail debt this year at a higher rate than in the first half Xof 1942, according to an article in The Exchange, publication of the New York Stock Exchange.

Leaders of European "free movements" in the United States are much concerned by the State Department's policy of "rebuffing the democrats and promoting the reactionaries" in Europe, Irwin Ross writes in the current issue of The Antioch Review, a quarterly edited by a group of faculty members at Antioch College, published yesterday.

IN "Heaven Is a Sunswept Hill" Earl Guy has written a novel with the age-old theme of a man's love for his acres. There are Sam Drindles and people like his neighbors the world over, human beings who live under the constant threat of earthquake, flood or tornado, yet think no land as dear and blessed as their own.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 26 -- If the two-score State executives who gathered here this week for the thirty-fifth annual Governors' Conference reflected the moods in their own communities -- it is certainly assumed in this space that they did -- then it must be said that the following matters are having a tremendous influence upon the thinking and action of the American people in these days:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, June 27 (AP) -- The noon communique:

ATHOUGH she loved the pink and white and green island which was her home, and in spite of a generally cheerful disposition, there were times when Jenny was a truly "vex'd Bermoothe." Not that she didn't have some justification, for at 15 it is not easy to cope with a pair of absent-minded poetic parents, a goat, a dog and a very small housekeeping budget.

The American people stand today more united in their desire for international cooperation than ever in the past. All surveys and tests of public opinion are proof of this. A recent survey by the Twentieth Century Fund came to the conclusion that what the American people want as their general post-war objectives are economic stability and national prosperity within a workable system of collective security and revived international trade.

TWO newly rearranged early American rooms at the Brooklyn Museum demonstrate how antique fabrics can enhance the beauty of old-time furniture. In these rooms -- the Irvington dining room and parlor -- the red dining-room curtains and seat covers and the golden yellow curtains in the parlor could hardly have been brighter when they were dyed over a century ago.

LONDON, Sunday, June 27 -- Premier Joseph Stalin of Russia thanked President Roosevelt for his "high estimation of the determination and bravery of the Soviet people" in a special message broadcast by the Moscow radio early today, and said that conditions had been created for the final defeat of the common enemy.

GIBBSTOWN, N.J., June 26 -- Shangri-La may be the figment of a novelist's imagination to most people, but it is a very real place to C. Joseph Rosbert, 26-year-old former ace of the "Flying Tigers" of the American Volunteer Group in China and a former resident of this South Jersey community.

Nobody has yet, thank goodness, found either means or reason to dim out the fireflies. Indeed, they seem to be more numerous and full of fire this season than ever before; but that may be only by contrast. We have become light-conscious -- or at least the OCD has done its best to make us so.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 26 -- An ice boat champion came through today in the hottest session of summer on the water. The heat not only was turned on by old man weather; it also marked the competition at the regatta of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club, the fifth special one of the season on Long Island Sound.

Hundreds of thousands of Americans saw "This Is the Army" on the stage; hundreds of thousands more will soon see it on the screen. The Army's show, with its soldier cast, has been made into a movie by Warner Brothers, and will open on July 23 in New York.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.J., June 26 -- The body of Miss Madeline Tregaskis, 29-year-old sister of Richard Tregaskis, author of the book, "Guadalcanal Diary," was found last night in her automobile in a private garage here. Her death was listed as a suicide by police, but Dr. Harvey W. Hartman, county physician, said that while the indications pointed to suicide he would not give a verdict until county detectives had completed their investigation.
On one of the hottest days of the year, 500 children danced to near exhaustion yesterday afternoon in the fourth annual Children's Folk Dancing Exhibition at Sheep Meadow, Central Park.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

Prices of stocks rose yesterday to the highest levels in three years, extending the recovery movement which had set in on Thursday. Volume of 553,500 shares on the New York Stock Exchange compared with 302,930 in the previous two-hour session and was spread over 768 issues.
The first black dress always brings with it the headline news of the fall styles. This year the new black dresses prove there are many ways of enlivening the government-prescribed slim line.

BOSTON, June 26 -- The jinx that is Cecil Huntington Hughson, called Tex for short, dogged the Yankees today. Before a ladies' day crowd of 6,797, the Red Sox submerged the American League champions, 4 to 1, and thus the willovy right-hander became the first hurler in the circuit to win nine games.

IN our far-flung system of national parks our native wild animals are protected from hunters and trappers and allowed to live, as far as possible, as they did in the days before white men came to this continent.

DETROIT, June 26 -- Were the race riots which swept Detroit this week, costing more than 30 lives and unestimated but heavy property damage inspired by Axis agents? Were they the result of a well-laid plot, carefully organized by hate-breeding groups and societies?

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass. -- There is at least one type of craft which has not been requisitioned for wartime use, and that is the famed Swampscott dory, regarded by many as the best all-service small boat ever devised.

Supplemental gasoline rations may be issued by local boards, under certain conditions, to teachers to enable them to drive home for the Summer, if they live out of town, or to permit occupational use of their automobiles during the school vacation, Frank C. Russell, district manager of the Office of Price Administration, said yesterday.

THIS one is supposed to prove that love at first sight, between a wealthy young man and a foundling girl known locally as a river rat, can bring happiness to all concerned, including the stuffy relatives on the one side and the hard-drinking pals on the other.

Capt. George Spencer of Atlanta, on duty with the British Eighth Army behind El Alamein last summer, was teaching Major Henri Lereux, a Belgian in the same service, the English language. As part of the course Captain Spencer gave Major Lereux a book to read called "Gone With the Wind."
At one point in Dr. Tucker's varied and, as he truly says, adventurous career as an Episcopal clergyman he almost became an archdeacon, which would almost certainly have led to his becoming a Bishop.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader and chairman of the executive committee of the Post-War World Council, wrote yesterday to Senator Robert R. Reynolds, chairman of the Senate Military Affairs Committee, asking to be heard in opposition to President Roosevelt's proposal for power to draft men up to 65 years of age if a measure embodying such a plan should be submitted to Congress.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. alone are producing more explosives today than were being made in the whole country at the peak of war production in 1918, according to Lammot du Pont, chairman of the board of that corporation. The company produces in one day, and every day, more explosives than it made for the Union throughout the four years of the Civil War.

CINCINNATI, June 26 (AP) -- A B-25 medium bomber, racing in from the West on June 23, circled a midwestern airport, nosed into the wind and landed, writing another chapter in the history of women in aviation, according to an announcement tonight by the Army Air Corps ferrying division headquarters here.

A Liberty ship to be launched on Wednesday morning at an East Coast shipyard will be named the Admiral H.I. Cone, a tribute by the War Shipping Administration to a man whose record of accomplishment has meant much to the development of our Merchant Marine, it was announced yesterday by the Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc.

Officials of the United Mine Workers of America who were to have conferred again here yesterday with anthracite mine operators on a new contract were understood to be remaining in the Pennsylvania hard coal region over the week-end in an effort to speed the back-to-work movement among the 83,000 anthracite miners.

A large section of the nation's population is faced with "actual disaster" from the rising tide of inflation, according to a report of a survey of consumers in all parts of the country and at different income levels made public yesterday by Consumers Union at a meeting of the organization in the New School for Social Research.

PRIVATE SCHOOLS -- Aid Credits An opportunity for high school students to make progress and earn credits during the summer is offered through the medium of seventeen New York City private schools which have been designated by the State Board of Regents.

GUNDER HAEGG, the farm boy who learned to run in the forests of Sweden, has done his stuff for an American audience. There were skeptics in the crowd that gathered last Sunday at Triborough Stadium, on Randalls Island. They wondered whether Haegg would live up to advance notices.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- After giving only four blows in eight innings, Lefty Chubby Dean yielded two runs in the ninth and the White Sox won a 3-to-2 victory over the Indians in Cleveland Stadium today.

CARE should be taken that accessories used in the garden fit into the general scheme. If, for instance, the pool is oblong, long narrow benches look better beside it than round seats. The rule of harmony holds also for color and texture.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Soviet correspondents returning from a visit to the camp where the Polish Tadeusz Kosciusko Division is in training report that the division now has a full complement of officers, noncommissioned officers and men, but that Poles continue to report for service from many parts of the Soviet Union.

WOBBIE -- A new root vegetable, the "wobbie," has been introduced in Holland -- a cross between a carrot and a beet which contains three or four times more vitamin C than either. Large areas are being planted with this new hybrid. If the reports which come from the Netherlands Press Agency in London are correct, this is the first new vegetable introduced into agriculture for a generation.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

LONDON, June 12. THE loss of Leslie Howard on his way home from Lisbon overshadows every other topic in British film circles this month. It is ten days now since the airliner was shot down over the Atlantic, and the chances of survival seem infinitely remote.
MRS. BUCK'S novels have won her literary fame. This book shows she is a great and fearless writer who will always be remembered for her efforts to make true democracy blossom in the hearts of men.

MOSCOW, June 26 -- Provided their calculations are not upset by this summer's military operations, this year will be the first since they first swept into the area in 1941 that the Germans can be expected to derive any major benefits by their occupation of the Soviet Union's richest province, the Ukraine.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Motorists in the twelve Northeastern States comprising the extreme shortage area must forego pleasure driving "for the duration of the war."

MOVING up to its test under the 20 per cent withholding tax which begins with the week, retail trade is holding its substantial gain over last year in all divisions except food and those lines where production bans are in effect.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A regular Treasury offering of $2,500,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent Treasury notes of Series A, 1947, which will be offered on Monday and have an indefinite subscription date limit except that payment must be completed by July 12, was announced today by Henry Morgenthau, Secretary of the Treasury.

ENSHIH, China, June 26 (AP) -- Japanese forces in China proper are not strong enough to begin another offensive unless they draw reinforcements from Burma, the Southwest Pacific or the northern provinces, Gen. Chen Cheng, who turned back the recent Japanese thrust toward Chungking, declared today.

ONE of the bright and shining achievements of a disturbed and unnatural season has been the persistent accomplishment of the Humphrey-Weidman organization in its cozy little Studio Theatre down in West Sixteenth Street.
EVANSTON, Ill., June 26 -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, as he had said he would be, was a better tennis player today than he was yesterday -- when he was sensational.

" The domestic scene, as you listen to the radio and read the papers today, is anything but encouraging, and one would like not to think about it, because it gives one a feeling that, as a whole, we are not really prepared for democracy."

CONEY ISLAND, America's most popular seashore resort, is enjoying a war boom. With driving and travel restricted, huge crowds are swarming to the island via the BMT. Charles Kean, president of the Chamber of Commerce, expects "a very big year."

HAVANA -- Announcement is made by Dr. Marino Lopez Blanco, Cuba's Minister of Communications, that the long-awaited anti-fifth column series, to have been issued last year but deferred because of wartime developments, will be released on July 5.

War brings to pass varied vicissitudes in the economy of nations, organizations and individuals. It has greatly influenced the sport and business of breeding and showing pure-bred dogs in competition and has necessitated numerous economies and reallignments.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Kiska, the last remaining Japanese stronghold in the Aleutian Islands since the fall of Attu, was attacked by Army heavy and medium bombers three times on Thursday afternoon, the Navy announced today.

FORT FAIRFIELD, Me., June 26 (U.P.) -- Five Army fliers and four farm workers were killed when a two-motored Army bomber on a routine flight from the Presque Isle air base plunged into a potato field today.

IF the mountains or the Maine coast are out of bounds for the family this summer, the children can still have swimming and games, and find interesting places to go and things to do around town. Aside from what goes on in the 162 recreation centers listed by the Welfare Council of New York City, here are some of the more unusual summer activities planned for boys and girls.

June, the preface to great events, is ending. Across the map of this global war, preliminary moves have been made in the several theatres; the troops and ships and planes are ready for what is to come. Another summer of crisis has started -- a summer which will decide the duration of the war and its cost to victors and to vanquished.

IF anyone doubts that the way of the bluestocking in nineteenth-century America was bleak, let him read this book. Here is the story of an idolized Vassar professor, a woman honored in and beyond her own college and her own time as a liberalizer of history teaching.

WITH the alarms of war ringing in our ears, the messianic promises of our prophets for the post-war world are calculated to fill us with grandiose expectations or to plunge us into pessimistic scepticism.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Because third-quarter supplies of steel are 26 per cent below total stated demands and a large part of this deficit is of critical importance to the war effort the War Production Board will start a "Steel for Victory" drive in Pittsburgh Thursday and Friday.

IF the radio and record companies are looking for a lively war song, they might glance at a modest little book of "Win-the-War Ballads" published recently by the Edward B. Marks Music Corporation. There are twelve "timely songs for children and everybody else" in this collection with music by Sam Morgenstern and words by Beatrice Goldsmith.

IT is obvious that years of exploration in the African jungle have not robbed Commander Gatti of either an understanding of young boys, black, or white, or a sense of humor. They both, necessarily, go hand in hand, and when combined, as here, with hair-raising jungle adventure the result is something to satisfy any boy's heart.

Shortages of merchandise for current seeing are now becoming aggravated in many lines, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co. However, stores are not losing volume because much of the fall merchandise had to be taken into stock earlier.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A record-breaking fiscal year will end for the Federal Treasury next Wednesday with receipts and expenditures apparently below the estimates submitted by President Roosevelt in his budget message of last Jan. 6.

To an extent which will surprise many people, American business is far-sightedly and courageously planning to meet its post-war problems. The change-over to peacetime economy will involve problems more vast and intricate and difficult than those solved so brilliantly during the transition to an all-out war economy.

THE figure of a woman in a faded purple dress and sunbonnet plays an important part in this story. Clara Gamadge sees it several times -- the last time just before a murder is committed. There are those who believe that Clara has seen a ghost, and there are others who consider her the victim of a hallucination.

BOSTON, June 26 (AP) -- Believe, owned by Charles F. Martin, editor of the North Attleboro Chronicle, scored a surprise triumph at Suffolk Downs today in the $5,000 added Constitution Mile for, 3-year-olds before a crowd of 16,273.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- Best Seller, at odds of 18 to 1, charged across the finish line a surprise winner today of Arlington Park's $10,000 added Equipoise Mile at Washington Park with Whirlaway, 6-to-5 favorite, struggling back in fifth place, never a factor in the race.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 424 United States soldiers held prisoners of war; 314 by Japan, 106 by Germany and four by Italy. Twenty-five of these soldiers came from New York, six from New Jersey and three from Connecticut.

WHILE Congress debated the precise phraseology of the Declaration of Independence, eliminating a sentence here, inserting a word there, Jefferson looked on, a gloomy witness to what he felt was the emasculation of his text.

MEXICO CITY, June 26 -- Vicente Lombardo Toledano, president of the Confederation of Latin-American Workers, today urged all members of that organization throughout Latin America to increase their production and to fight "the gigantic Nazi maneuvers" in the Western Hemisphere that are aiming at sowing dissension among the United Nations and sabotaging the war effort.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The President sent to Congress, in rejecting the Connally-Smith anti-strike bill, one of the best-written and best-reasoned vetoes of his tenure. He has been sustained often on weak arguments; this time both the Senate and the House overrode him on a strong one. Long-overdue chickens were coming home to roost on the President's desk.

LONDON -- Faced with a serious shortage of manpower for her war factories, Germany has launched a new method of exacting forced labor from France, according to reports reaching London. The Nazis have abandoned their former pretense of voluntary recruiting of French labor and are now "grabbing" Frenchmen indiscriminately by means of kidnappers and pressgangs.

CINCINNATI, June 26 -- Taking full advantage of Johnny Vander Meer's wildness and the general ineffectiveness of the Reds, the Pirates hammered a 9-0 victory today to strengthen their hold on third place in the National League.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Anxious over a growing shortage of teachers in rural schools, the Women's Advisory Committee of the War Manpower Commission offered a six-point program today for women's groups seeking to avert serious conditions in their school systems.

RHODE ISLAND in looking -- over the summer scene announces that its beaches are open and its famous shore dinners unharmed by rationing. Trains from New York, among them the Bay State out of Grand Central Station and the Pilgrim out of Pennsylvania Station, carry through daily to Westerly, Watch Hill and other well-known stops, where hotels are prepared to meet all guests.

Holding their breath, the awe-stricken authors reveal that the Nazis, these amazing wizards, even use such revolutionary devices as filing cabinets and a veritable morgue.

A post-war world in which the United States will finally abandon isolationism and participate in an international system of cooperation to maintain peace through lowered tariffs and other trade barriers, freer and expanding world trade, and an economy of abundance not only in this country but among all peoples, was envisaged last night in addresses by three of America's leading business men.
CALIFORNIA is still leading in the battle various sectional invaders are waging for Chicago's money. New York is second; Detroit and the Ohio River have both quit.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 26 -- Ninety percent of the Netherlanders have sabotaged the calling up for German slave labor duty, according to a Hague dispatch to the Essener National Zeitung. As a result, the Germans have resorted to the draft on military lines, first of men born between 1923 and 1924 and now in 1922.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., June 26 (AP) -- North Carolina's 1943 football schedule adds Pennsylvania, retains Fordham and omits Tulane and Duquesne.

CHICAGO, June 26 -- The Cubs, self-designated stumbling blocks in the Cardinals' path toward a second straight title, beat the world champions for the third straight time within a week and reduced the Redbirds' league lead to a half-game as they converted Paul Derringer's six-hit pitching into a 5-to-2 victory today.

At the Botanic Gardens in the Bronx and in Brooklyn the demonstration Victory gardens, now maturing their early crops, are attracting the attention of many first-year vegetable growers. Much can be learned from observing the methods used.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 26 -- The favorite, Bill Watson, husky Detroit heavyweight policeman, gained a commanding lead in quest of his second National A.A.U. decathlon championship today in the first half of the competition contested under a broiling sun at Warinanco Park Stadium.

A STUDY of Dr. George N. Shuster's interesting review of Dr. R.M. Brickner's important book "Is Germany Incurable?" shows that a mistake was somehow made before publication which led to a somewhat inaccurate and incomplete picture of the contents.

THE era of confusion and misnomers in New York turf is about to begin. Tomorrow the racing at Empire City will be held at Jamaica and next month the racing at Saratoga will take place at Belmont. This is strictly a war measure, of course, in order to enable the government agencies to save both gasoline and rubber and the betting fraternity to save shoe leather.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 26 -- Latest check of Republican rank and file sentiment on Presidential possibilities for 1944 shows Thomas E. Dewey again at the head of the list. But in the month past he has not improved his position. Actually Mr. Dewey's popularity in this period shows a falling off of 1 per cent.

THE first stamp, honoring Poland, in the series which the United States is issuing to commemorate resistance to Axis aggression in eleven European countries went on sale at Washington and Chicago simultaneously last Tuesday.

PASADENA, Calif., June 26 (AP) -- Those fanciful post-war electronic gadgets envisioned by architects of a wonderful world of tomorrow aren't probable, and some of them are hardly possible, according to Prof. W.H. Pickering of the physics departments of the California Institute of Technology.

SAID James T. Farrell, over an omelette and beer: "I'd planned a six month vacation after finishing my last Danny O'Neill volume. But I'd hardly pulled the final page out of the typewriter before I'd started a new trilogy.

Corn has been the basic American food crop since prehistoric times. Colonists learned its value from Indians, learned to eat it as hominy, mush, johnny cake, hoecake, pone. Americans planted more land to corn than to any other crop. In time corn culture centered in the upper Mississippi Valley.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 27 -- For the third time within thirty-six hours, Allied bombers swept across the Mediterranean from Africa on Friday night to heap explosives on the battered port of Messina, the main supply port of Sicily.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Requisitioning of cash corn stored in Midwest elevators by the War Food Administration, while not unexpected by the trade, threw the grain market into confusion late last week and brought about a strong upturn that more than wiped out an early break and carried September and December oats into new seasonal high ground.

A UNITED STATES BOMBER STATION, in England, June 27 (AP) -- Gunner Sgt. Clifford T. Erickson of Fond du Lac, Wis., brought the crippled Flying Fortress Dangerous Dan back from the crews' first raid against the Nazis on June 11 after the pilot and co-pilot had been wounded seriously, it was disclosed today.
LONDON, Monday, June 28 (U.P.) -- The Russian Sunday midnight communiqu, as broadcast from MOSCOW:

An Army plane circled low over the Fort Totten parade ground Friday and at the command of an officer, a training unit of some 500 men of the Anti-Aircraft Artillery Command dashed to their 40 mm. Bofors guns and in 40 seconds theoretically shot down the plane.

Churchmen who are meeting the present world situation with "easy, polite, gentlemanly expressions of religion" must display more aggressive leadership if religion is to play its true part in winning the war and preserving peace, Bishop Edwin F. Lee of the Methodist area of the Philippines and Malaya declared yesterday in a sermon in the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street.

The heat wave in the New York area entered its eighteenth day at 12:01 o'clock this morning with the Weather Bureau unable to promise any relief from a distressing combination of high temperatures and abnormal humidity.

ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- The Browns' rise to a fifth-place tie in the American League was shortlived today as Detroit sent them tumbling back to the cellar by connetting for a 9-5 triumph after the ]Browns won the first game, 6 -- 3.

An enlarged and intensified program for Jewish religious education "to meet the needs of Jewish children in America in wartime and during the post-war period" was adopted yesterday at a meeting of the board of governors of the American Association for Jewish Education in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The sun seldom sets on a day when the customer is not asked to help the merchant in some new way, and we have no doubt that Mr. Phil Cooper, president of a chain of cleaning and dyeing establishments, will get much of what he is asking for.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 27 (U.P.) -- A struggle of opposing tendencies in the new Argentine Government lies behind the contradictory acts of President Pedro P. Ramirez's Government during its first weeks in office, well informed Argentine political observers said today.

LONDON, June 27 -- The incipient revival of the stock markets reported here a week ago blossomed last week into a decided rally. Not only have prices risen but business has climbed out of the subnormal rut in which it had moved for several weeks.

Decorations for meritorious service were presented yesterday to 264 members, including ten women, of the Manhattan division of the City Patrol Corps. Maj. Gem Robert M. Danford, commandant of the corps, made the awards at a review in the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- American goods have won a major victory in economics in North Africa as well as becoming valuable fighting allies for the United Nations, E.R. Stettinius Jr., lend-lease administrator, reported today.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Prices of wheat were on the downgrade early last week on the Chicago Board of Trade, being affected by scattered liquidation and hedging pressure from the Southwest. They rallied sharply later, however, following the requisitioning of elevator stocks of corn by the Government.
The lower level of Grand Central Terminal exhibited the bedlam of a political convention yesterday during the first mass evacuation of thousands of country-starved children for summer camps.

In a caustic arraignment of the huge civilian personnel now on the Federal payroll, Senator William Langer, Republican, of North Dakota, charged yesterday that there are "three-quarters of a million young fellows of draft age now holding down swivel chair jobs instead of being in the armed services where they belong."
BERNE, Switzerland, June 27 -- The 1942 balance sheet of the German railways, just published, reflects the wartime conditions under which the system is operating.

The trustees of Tuskegee Institute voted unanimously to present its collection of Booker T. Washington's papers to the Library of Congress, Dr. F.D. Patterson, president of the institute, yesterday informed Archibald MacLeish, Librarian of Congress.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (U.P.) -- Navy communiqu 424:

BERNE, Switzerland, June 27 -- With prices on the black market rising to 1,000 francs for a chicken -- tough at that -- and 150 francs for a pack of native cigarettes, hostesses in France are inviting their friends in "concrete parties."

Boys' baseball, basketball, track, and even wrestling will be coached at many high schools next year by women physical education directors, Dr. Jay B. Nash, chairman of the department of physical education and health at New York University, predicted yesterday.
CINCINNATI, June 27 (AP) -- The Reds finally won a Sunday double-header. They did it today at the expense of the Pirates, 6 to 3 and 5 to 1, before 12,015 fans and moved from fifth to fourth.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP) -- A wave of return-to-work sentiment swept the Appalachian coal fields today, with many local union units of the United Mine Workers voting to resume operations tomorrow in the partially idle producing regions.

CLINTON, Mass., June 27 (U.P.) -- One Waac was killed and twenty other persons, mostly Waacs and soldiers from Fort Devens, were injured today when a thirty-eight-passenger bus of the Boston Maine Transportation Company and an automobile were in collision.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 27 -- Embittered by the passage of the anti-strike bill over the President's veto and by the failure of their leaders to obtain an increase in wages, thousands of hard-coal miners voted today and tonight to continue their stoppage tomorrow.

The New York City Department of Water Supply estimates that the average Manhattanite uses fourteen gallons more of water a day in June than in January. A large proportion of this increase they attribute to the warm weather pastime of taking baths.
BOSTON, June 27 -- Proof that he is shaking off his batting slump came from Joe Gordon today as the Yankees split a double-header with the Red Sex before a gathering of 33,617.

STOCKHOLM, June 27 -- Fears are being expressed here that Gunder Haegg, now in the United States, is jeoparding his amateur standing by permitting his name to be used in Swedish nation-wide commercial advertising campaigns. For several weeks his picture and name have been used in Swedish newspapers to "plug" a wrist watch, and a special make of rye bread, and by a manufacturer of ready-made clothes.

LONDON, Monday, June 28 (U.P.) -- Red Army troops, striking out again in offensive operations on the Velikiye Luki front, have captured an inhabited place and thrown back six determined German attempts to retake it, Russia reported today.

NEWARK, N.J., June 27 -- A policy established twenty-two years ago was upset today with the announcement by Mgr. Ralph J. Glover that the Associated Catholic Charities, of which he is executive director, would affiliate with Community Chests in the archdiocese, taking in Essex, Union, Hudson and Bergen Counties.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., June 27 -- In a thrilling finish that kept the result in doubt until the last foursome reported at the Wheatley Hills links, Cherry Valley today triumphed in the first of a series of interclub matches among four Long Island golf clubs.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Leaders of both major parties propose to reserve to Congress the right to reconvene during the summer recess without waiting for a call from the White House.

The public utilities in New York State have been advised by the Public Service Commission to use accumulated cash not immediately needed for capital or operating purposes to improve their financial structure through the retirement of liabilities in order that they be better able to meet the uncertainties of conditions after the war.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 27 -- Without competing in the 1,500-meter run, finale of the ten-event program, Bill Watson, Detroit heavyweight policeman, fulfilled expectations this sultry afternoon by regaining the National A.A.U. Decathlon championship at the sunbaked Warinanco Park Stadium.
LONDON, June 27 (Reuter) -- Russia believes that the invasion of Europe is near. The Red Army was told in a Moscow broadcast tonight: "The hour of reckoning is at hand."
LONDON, June 27 (U.P.) -- The Russian noon communiqu, as broadcast from Moscow:

Two years ago the Germans launched their first assault against Russia on June 22. It was beaten back at the gates of Moscow, and one explanation for its failure was that it was started too late, because Hitler's original plans had been upset by the revolt in Yugoslavia.

DETROIT, June 27 -- Counting every day without a new incident as so much gained in cooling off the race feeling which exploded into rioting a week ago tonight, Michigan and Detroit officials were preparing tonight for a final "mop up" of the disturbances which cost thirty-one lives and brought injury to several hundred more.
The Federal Government's confused and chaotic handling of the nation's food situation was assailed here yesterday by former President Herbert Hoover and Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.

Force of arms can win the war, but "winning the peace is spiritual and can be done only in God's way," Dr. Louis M. Epstein of Boston declared yesterday at the fifty-fifth annual commencement exercises of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, Broadway and 122d Street.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The Cardinals, with Danny Litwhiler's two homers supplying all the runs in the opener and his double starting the winning rally in the eighth inning of the nightcap, twice edged out the Cubs before a crowd of 37,792 today, 3 to 2 and 4 to 3, to preserve their half-game league lead over the Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- In its vote yesterday on the bill extending the life of the Commodity Credit Corporation for two more years the Senate approved continuance of payments to encourage production of vitally needed crops, for transportation and for mineral production.

Educators and laymen generally will approve the nation-wide study of the place of American history in our schools and colleges now being made by a representative committee of prominent scholars. For many months there has been a suspicion in the public mind that the schools have been neglecting to give a due emphasis to the teaching of our nation's background, growth and development.

Alfredo Gonzalez Prada, former Peruvian Minister to Great Britain and charge d'affaires at the Peruvian Embassy in Washington, jumped or fell to his death at 3:50 A.M. yesterday from his apartment on the twenty-second floor of Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 27 -- The underground in France will celebrate Bastille Day on July 14 by an intensification of sabotage and general partisan activities, according to a copy of the illegal French Communist newspaper Humanite that has found its way here.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, June 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- Four officers and six enlisted men, all of whom man the transport planes which carry men and materiel to forward positions in New Guinea, have received the Air Medal for meritorious achievement from Lieut. Gem George C. Kenney, commander of the Allies' Southwest Pacific Air Forces.
LONDON, June 27 (Reuter) -- Dr. Henry A. Wilson, Bishop of Chelmsford, spoke tonight at the great London meeting commemorating the anniversary of the German invasion of Russia.

The validity of at least seven of the promotions made by Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh on Saturday, when he advanced fifteen battalion chiefs to the rank of deputy chief, was challenged yesterday by H. Eliot Kaplan, executive secretary and counsel of the Civil Service Reform Association.

GRAND JUNCTION, Col., June 27 (AP) -- A freight train fire touched off two carloads of munitions early today, splattering shrapnel over the western end of Grand Junction and terrorizing residents awakened by explosions which jarred the city for more than four hours.

The fighting tradition and freedom-loving spirit of the people of Serbia were symbolized yesterday in a religious, patriotic ceremony at the Serbian Orthodox Procathedral of St. Sava, 15 West Twenty-fifth Street, in observance of Vido-Dan, the Serbian national day of mourning.

The Citizen Budget Commission made public yesterday a letter to the City Planning Commission, asking that body to issue to the public a statement of its fundamental plan for the development of the city as a whole after the war.

MOSCOW, June 27 -- The attitude of the Soviet Government toward the Red Army Guards units strongly indicates a desire to cultivate what could conceivably be called a military aristocracy. In the ranks of the Guards themselves a spirit of superiority prevails.

We are at war with the "un-Christian doctrine of man" as opposed to the Christian doctrine of man, Canon Thomas A. Sparks declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, of which he is the pastor.
Six houses in one street in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn have been sold by the Home Owners Loan Corporation through Slomka Brothers.

FITTSBURGH, June 27 -- Possibly foreshadowing a general work resumption, mine union locals in the Pennsylvania coal fields which had ignored previous instructions from the United Mine Workers' international policy committee voted today to return to the pits at the start of morning shifts tomorrow.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 27 -- The help that Brazil is giving to other American nations is implemented by economic understandings already concluded with Uruguay and Paraguay. An agreement with Bolivia will be signed tomorrow, and Peru is believed to be next in line.

The Ballet Theatre last night concluded its series of four performances at the Lewisohn Stadium with a bill which was made up of "Petruchka," "Spectre de la Rose," "Gala Performance" and "Princess Aurora." The first and last of these were repetitions from last week, though with important changes of cast in "Petruchka."

BERNE, Switzerland, June 27 -- Free scope is allowed to American and British "propaganda" in Spain, a Madrid dispatch to the Frankfurter Zeitung says. The correspondent charges the Spanish Government with complacently looking on without indicating a desire to interfere.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- There is nothing wrong with the way Henry Kaiser builds ships, as far as Rear Admiral Howard L. Vickery, vice chairman of the Maritime Commission, is concerned. Admiral Vickery arrived today to inspect Bay area yards.

Bombs burst again yesterday in the rock-hewn harbors and valley airfields of Sicily as they burst, less than three weeks ago, on the rugged little island of Pantelleria -- first island in world history to be conquered primarily by air bombardment without surface assault.
Yesterday's Chinese communiqu, as recorded and translated by the Federal Communications Commission from a Chungking broadcast in Mandarin to China and the South Seas:

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia warned "snake agitators" bent on starting racial trouble to stay away from New York in his weekly radio broadcast from City Hall yesterday. He served notice that he would not tolerate any oppression of minority groups and asked for the cooperation of the public in keeping New York the happiest as well as the greatest city in the world.

The advance of the July position on the New York Cotton Exchange to the highest price of any contract since the 1928-29 season last week featured trading in the cotton futures market. Price-fixing and short-covering in the spot month raised it 26 points, or $1.30 a bale, in the week, while the five other active contracts, less in demand, registered net gains of only 7 to 15 points, or 35 to 75 cents a bale.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senators and Athletics split a double-header today before 25,000 fans. Washington shut out the Mackmen, 9 to 0, in the opener. Philadelphia won the nightcap, 5 to 4, with a three-run rally in the ninth.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., June 27 -- A.F. Kammer and his son Lowrey today won the New Jersey State father-and-son golf title for the fourth time when they collaborated for an alternate stroke 76 over the Glen Ridge Country Club course.

LONDON, June 27 -- There are a number of Americans in Great Britain who, by virtue of being either in Government positions or close to official life, are well qualified as observers of the food rationing systems here and at home.

APPLETON, Wis., June 27 -- Wisconsin Republicans were told today by Representative Clare Boothe Luce of Connecticut that the only way to get rid of the New Deal was to vote President Roosevelt out of office. Mrs. Luce gave the keynote speech at the Republican State Convention in Lawrence College chapel here.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- For the third year, the alcoholic beverage industry in 1942 was the country's biggest industrial taxpayer, establishing a new record of nearly two billion dollars, as consumers purchased more such beverages than in any other year since the repeal of prohibition, the Distilled Spirits Institute reported today.

Two five-story and three-story connecting buildings at 409-13 East Forty-seventh Street, between First Avenue and the East River, have been purchased by a syndicate organized by Simon Kutner from the Sardik Food Products Corporation.

LENINGRAD, June 27 -- Leningrad, first of Russia's hero cities, stands firm today after nearly two years of German attack. It is still in the first line. Daily German shells and bombs crash down on it. But it teems with life, it is proud and confident, and it is ready to fight on to victory.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold the twelve-story apartment house at 276 Riverside Drive, southeast corner of West 100th Street, to the S.E. Riverside Drive Corporation, Alexander Eisenberg, president, for investment.
