R.B. Franken's letter in THE TIMES of June 16 reveals a faulty understanding of the purpose of the Board of Education's program of summer service for teachers. One gets the impression from the letter that the board's primary concern is to provide war-related agencies, such as selective service boards, AWVS, CDVO, hospitals, rationing boards, etc., with teacher volunteers.

THE conquerors had no respect for the treaties they imposed by force and violated them with monotonous regularity. They massacred women and children, scattered survivors, burned their towns and destroyed their means of subsistence. Proud of their superior race, insatiable for more and more land and more and more wealth, they knew well how to divide and conquer, defeating their poor armed foes one by one.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Apparently aided by better weather conditions, American fliers pressed home six attacks Friday afternoon against Kiska, the isolated Japanese stronghold in the Aleutian Islands. The Navy told of the attacks in today's communique.

Three employes of the Acme Backing Corporation in Brooklyn were ordered discharged yesterday by George J. Mintzer, impartial chairman, on charges that they had fomented a strike in a vital war plant in protest against the employment of Negro workers.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- The Berlin radio said tonight that Fritz Schmidt, regional chief of the National Socialist party in the Netherlands, had "met with a fatal accident" while on an official tour through France.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired a painting of Saint Catherine of Alexandria by the Neapolitan artist Bernardo Cavillino (1622-54), a follower of Caravaggio.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Administration's post-war aviation policy, being secretly studied by the Interdepartmental Committee on International Aviation, will probably be made public in September, when an Anglo-American conference on post-war aviation will be held here.

ON THE UPPER YANGTZE FRONT, June 20 (Delayed) -- Nearly three weeks after the Battle of West Hupeh was over a party of foreign correspondents turned up under official guidance on the crucial Shihpai battlefield with pens, notebooks, sunglasses and other warlike equipment.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- First inning scoring bursts put both games of a double-header on ice today as the Buffalo Bisons split with Jersey City.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 27 (AP) -- Rochester's hopes of reaching the first division received a severe jolt today when the Newark Bears took both ends of a double-header from the Red Wings, 4 -- 2 and 6 -- 3.

Three would-be fliers for the Royal Canadian Air Force -- Regis Stern, 10 years old; Frank Sullivan, "almost 12," and Donald Mullin, 13, all of Jersey City -- were taken into custody by police of the East Fifty-first Street station early yesterday as runaways after a railroad policeman had halted them in the Grand Central Terminal.

With eight in the featured Nepperhan Purse, and with a 1:45 post time for the first race, the transplanted Empire City race meeting will begin this afternoon at the Jamaica race course on Long Island where it will continue for twenty-four racing days.

If any additional reductions in the use of paper for magazines and newspapers develop, it is also expected in the paper field that some curbs on the use of direct mail by business may be included in the new regulations. This possibility is only being discussed at the present time and it is not believed that any formal regulation has been drawn up as yet.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 27 -- Working quietly with a few Coast Guard officers and civic leaders, Mrs. William J. Clothier of Philadelphia, now Lieutenant Clothier senior officer of women's units of the Volunteer Port Security Force of the Coast Guard Reserve, is laying the groundwork for the first units to be set up on the West Coast.

LONDON, June 27 -- British bomber fleets roared over Adolf Hitler's European fortress for the eighth consecutive night last night to batter targets in west and northwest Germany, carrying the mightiest nonstop aerial offensive of the war into its second week, it was announced today.

Noting a steady upsurge of popular interest in economic issues since the war, Harold S. Sloan, director of the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, announced yesterday in the foundation's annual report its sponsorship of an Institute on Post-War Reconstruction at New York University, which he said would enable the public to share actively in post-war planning.
Seven new films, including a French and a Mexican production, are scheduled to open during the week. The program follows:

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Increased farm consumption of oats and barley is anticipated this season owing to the prospective shortage in corn, and there was aggressive buying of both grains last week attributed to feed manufacturers. The deferred deliveries of oats sold at new seasonal highs on the Chicago Board of Trade and the July came within a small fraction of equalling the best price in fifteen years.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Weather conditions last week were the most favorable of the season for cultivating corn and harvesting winter wheat as well as promoting the rapid growth of other small grains. Farmers by working day and night have managed to catch up with cultivating corn and complete planting except in areas which suffered from excessive rains.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Trading in grain futures expanded last week, a big business on June 25 following announcement that the Government had requisitioned stocks of cash corn held in elevators and ordered trading in corn futures to cease.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- Outlawing of race persecution by international agreement was urged today at the annual convention of the Independent Order of Brith Abraham.

LONDON, June 27 (Netherlands News Agency) -- The physicians of occupied Holland have sent Reich Commissar Arthur Seyss-Inquart a strong protest against the German violation of international law in looting food from the country, thereby threatening increasing numbers with "death through hunger," it was reported today.

With most buying for fall already completed, wholesale markets were comparatively quiet last week, according to a summary of the week's activities prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Reorders were placed on many fail items, however.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (U.P.) -- The magazine American Aviation chargeed tonight that high Government officials and "certain brass hats" are using twenty-one-passenger Army transport planes in solitary and luxurious splendor for week-end trips home and to attend conferences that could be handled by telephone.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- William H. Pine and William C. Thomas have signed a new producing deal with Paramount under which they will increase their contribution to the Paramount program. Their schedule for the coming year will include three musicals and two extended-budget pictures, in addition to three war subjects in which Chester Morris and Russell Hayden will be teamed.

Neutrality was not an issue in the Irish election. The strains caused by war in an isolated and dependent country were reflected in the vote. A new Farmers' party came into being as a result of agricultural stress. Labor made considerable gains. The two leading parties, Premier de Valera's Fianna Fail and the Opposition group led by former President Cosgrave, Fine Gael, both lost support.

With Satchell Paige hurling five innings, the Kansas City Monarchs defeated the New York Cubans in the feature game of National Negro Baseball League double-header at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. A crowd of 22,000 saw the Monarchs register a 6-to-3 triumph. In the first contest the Cubans turned back the New York Black Yankees, 6 to 2.

IT is singularly unfortunate that Judge Kenesaw Mountain Landis waited almost until the last minute before setting Wednesday as the first of the two days the major leagues are contributing to war relief. Club owners have had much too short a notice to prepare elaborate programs of entertainment, to embark on grandiose promotion schemes and to make this day particularly enticing to the fans.

ABERDEEN PROVING GROUNDS, Md., June 25 (Delayed) (AP) -- The Army staged a private showing today of the training of specialists in the dramatic and dangerous business of neutralizing the sudden death latent, sometimes by intent, in unexploded bombs.

Development of a device by which the propeller pitch and engine speeds of multiengined airplane are synchronized automatically by the turn of a single knob instead of a series of four was announced yesterday by George W. Brady, chief engineer of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation propeller division at Caldwell, N.J.

Families that find themselves one book short when their allotment of War Ration Book 3 arrives by mail should wait until Aug. 1 before applying to their local rationing boards for the additional book, the regional Office of Price Administration advised yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Treasury announced today that regulations are being prepared under which all banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation may qualify as government depositaries to receive the new withholding taxes.

James M. Landis, director of the United States Office of Civilian Defense, revealed yesterday that broadening of the scope of the civilian defense War Emergency Radio Service to make it a "vastly more effective instrument of day-to-day community protection."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 28 (AP) -- A small Japanese merchantman, escorted by a destroyer, was damaged in the Solomon Sea, southwest of Buka Passage, by a Beaufort bomber that scored near misses on the merchantman and then strafed the decks of both ships from low altitude.
On July 4 the Independent Subway will eliminate several trains by increasing the headway; thus decreasing wear and tear on equipment and promoting efficiency in transportation.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Stocks of cured hog products at Western packing points are accumulating very slowly, despite an enlargement in the movement of hogs from the country due to the active demand from both the domestic trade and the Government.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 27 -- James Coggeshall, who retired in 1931 as vice president of the Continental Appraisal Company of New York, a post he had held for twelve years, died here today at the summer home of his son, James Coggeshall Jr.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP)-- The War Manpower Commission today added four cities in Group One to its areas of acute labor shortage, raising a strong probability that they would be put on the forty-eight-hour week by WMC regional directors.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., June 27 -- Volunteer pilots of the Westchester squadron of the Civil Air Patrol dived low today in three planes over the polo field "airport" at the 700-acre Felix M. Warburg estate here in a vain effort to help two companies of State Guardsmen fight off an attack by seven companies of their fellows in a war game staged by the Seventeenth Infantry.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 27 -- Lured by the prospect of earning money at an early age, pupils are leaving the schools of the country at an "alarming" rate, according to a report to the National Education Association which opened its annual convention here today.

THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 21 published a letter signed by J. Chas. Roemer, dated June 18, to which this letter comes as a reply. Mr. Roemer has drawn certain erroneous conclusions with respect to the action of the Treasury Department in connection with the newly enacted law requiring deduction and withholding of income taxes at the source on wages.

ALGIERS, June 27 (U.P.) -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle, reviewing Allied troops in Tunis today, said in one of several speeches that Europe and the democracies faced a future of blood, tears and ruins unless those guilty of starting the war were punished.

The Central Conference of American Rabbis, representing the Reform Rabbinate in the United States, closed yesterday its fifty-fourth annual convention in the Hotel New Yorker by adopting a resolution disapproving enactment of the Connally-Smith anti-strike bill by Congress over President Roosevelt's veto.
Eighteen attractions will give holiday matinees next Monday. Divided into dramas and musical offerings, the listing is arranged alphabetically:

Reports from Stockholm that crews of six German submarines in an unnamed Norwegian port have mutinied against further sea duty would be highly significant if true. Coming from such a rumor factory as Stockholm, however, they require both confirmation and elucidation before they can be accepted.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 27 -- The Rochester Transit Corporation will become a Rochester-owned utility tomorrow. Rochesterians who have been negotiating for purchase of common stock holdings of the Associated Gas and Electric Corporation, or their representatives will advance the purchase money and the actual transfer of the stock will take place with all the legal details complied with tomorrow in New York.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission denied today a motion by the Delmarva Electric Cooperative to stay for ninety days a decision on the proposed acquisition by the United Gas Improvement Company of the common stock of the Eastern Shore Public Service Company (Delaware) to give the cooperative time to evaluate the Delmarva properties and work out a plan to buy the company.

During most of the week, financial markets hardly moved. Until Friday, no day's transactions reached a million shares; on Tuesday they fell below 700,000. Markets were naturally dominated by the coal strike, but equally so by doubt over the President's action on the anti-strike bill, then at his desk for signature or veto.

In his budget message in January the President asked for the tremendous addition of $16,000,000,000 to the annual tax bill. The Pay-as-You-Go Bill passed by Congress is estimated to have added $3,000,000,000 a year to taxes. The Secretary of the Treasury is now asking for an additional $12,000,000,000.

This summer thousands of high school and college students will work on farms helping to relieve the existing shortage of labor, while at the same time receiving a valuable rural training. Many colleges, aware of the need, are encouraging their students to get into slacks or overalls.
LONDON, June 27 -- Reports circulated tonight that the Italian Fleet, carefully husbanded through the thick of the Mediterranean action, had put to sea, possibly for offensive action.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- There was little laughter among the Philly fans as the Dodgers bade them farewell today. The Brooks disappointed a crowd of 27,866 by beating the Phillies twice, 9 -- 4 and 6 -- 0, to make it three out of four in the series.
CARTERET, N.J., June 27 (AP) -- Two men were injured fatally and four others were hurt in an explosion early today at the plant of the United States Metals Refining Company.

Nap Reyes, the young man from Havana, who is seeking permanent possession of first base at the Polo Grounds, cemented relations with 17,036 Giant fans yesterday with a bang-up performance that brought Mel Ott's nine a split with the Braves.

LONDON, June 27 -- Herbert Morrison denounced today as "a typical piece of Communist wrecking tactics" the rumor that when he was defeated by Arthur Greenwood in his candidacy for the key post of treasurer of the Labor party at the organization's convention two weeks ago he was watering down genuine labor policy.
CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- Cleveland and Chicago divided a double-header today to end their series at two games apiece.

SELFRIDGE FIELD, Mich., June 27 (AP) -- The body of Second Lieut. Wilmath W. Sidat-Singh, Army flier and former Syracuse University athletic star whose plane plunged into Lake Huron May 9, was found in the lake today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 27 -- Despite an increase in over-all output last year, the net earnings of manufacturers of wood household furniture were generally lower than in 1941, according to the twenty-third annual report issued here today by the furniture statistical department of Seidman Seidman, certified public accountants.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, June 28 (U.P.) -- The noon communiqu:
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The votes of the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period June 19 to 25 are given in the appended tabulation:
Yesterday's Finnish communiqu, as broadcast domestically in Finland and reported by the Federal Communications Commission:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- With apparent agreement that the program of the Office of Price Administration to roll back food prices is dead, jockeying for position still went on tonight on the subsidy and related issues.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 27 -- A championship series regatta was sailed today without wind, and of fifty-two starting craft forty-nine finished, the trio withdrawing voluntarily. It was the scheduled event of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club of Oyster Bay, which was run by request by the Larchmont Club.

TUNIS, June 27 (AP) -- This city, battered by the Allied aerial war until its liberation last month, has started on "the road back." With "business as usual" its unofficial slogan, the overcrowded capital of Tunisia is resuming more of a normal existence.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices dropped from 111.2 to 111.1. The farm products index declined 0.2 per cent as a result of decreases in the prices of wheat, hogs, and potatoes which were only partially offset by increases in the prices of eggs, cattle and cotton.

LONDON, June 27 -- Wartime shortages have forced British housewives to experiment somewhat in their cooking, but they have done it sparingly despite efforts of the Ministry of Foods to put the best variety into Britain's diet.

HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., June 27 (U.P.) -- Forty-nine persons were injured, three of them being critically burned, when a blazing, pilotless Army P-38 pursuit plane crashed and exploded in a crowded beach area today.

Declaring that there can be no certain victory or lasting peace without Russia, former Ambassador Joseph E. Davies appealed yesterday to the American people not to allow "little things, past or future prejudices, or unbridled speech, to disrupt, becloud or endanger" the friendship between the United States and the Soviet.

Curiously enough, the products that seemed most interesting on a recent tour of city shops were alike in two respects -- they were all concentrated foods and could help ease in one way or another some current culinary predicaments.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- The full effects of last week's major coal strike on the steel industry were not completely known here last night. It is certain, however, that losses in steel production in the Pittsburgh district will be substantial this week.

"Home Front Memo" is to be the title of a new book by Carl Sandburg, to be published early in September by Harcourt, Brace. The book will give a cross-section of what Mr. Sandburg has thought, written and said in the war years, and will contain many of his magazine pieces, radio scripts, newspaper columns and short poems.

Coney, that old generic term for rabbit which is still used in the fur trade, has taken a sudden hip-pity-hop into the limelight of fashion. It is being brought out this year in smart but inexpensive fur coats, as well as taking a definite place, along with other shorthaired furs, in what promises to be an overwhelming trend toward furlined coats next Fall.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Roosevelt today signed the largest naval appropriation bill in the country's history, providing about $33,000,000,000 for the twelve months starting July 1.

LONDON, Tuesday, June 29 (U.P.) -- Axis radios reported today that the Russians had captured new bridgeheads on the German side of the Donets River and said that the Red Army was massing men in important numbers in the Velikiye Luki sector, along the Donets and in the Kuban.

AT UNITED STATES AIR FORCE HEADQUARTERS IN CHINA, June 27 (Delayed) (AP) -- The tempo of the war against Japan will be increased "within a reasonable time" in accordance with carefully prepared plans, Maj. Gen. Claire L. Chennault said today.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 28 -- In Vichy today Chief of Government Pierre Laval had a birthday. He has passed 60 years.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 28 -- Allied bombers maintained their offensive in the central and eastern Mediterranean areas as American heavy bombers pounded two German air bases in Greece yesterday and British Wellingtons assaulted Naples in a violent fifteen-minute raid on Saturday night.

A new five-year working agreement covering 35,000 workers and 1,500 employers in the cloak and suit industry was signed yesterday at a luncheon in the Hotel Astor, in the presence of Mayor La Guardia.

The recent stock market advance, encouraged to some extent by the increasing independence of Congress, was resumed yesterday despite such adverse factors as limited operation of the coal mines, the slowest rate of steel output since the start of the Battle of Britain in 1940, the lack of corn on the nation's markets and other unbalanced conditions on the price and supply fronts.
LONDON, June 28 -- Britain alone produces more aircraft than Germany can produce, Labor Minister Bevin said today at the diamond jubilee meeting of the Womens Cooperative Guild in London.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- Expanded loadings of hogs and cattle today resulted in price downturns, with hogs off 15 to 25 cents a hundred pounds and cattle about 15 cents lower. Sheep were uneven and around steady.

Fall market week opened yesterday in the millinery industry here, but buyers had already beaten the gun by placing substantial advance orders in the last two to three weeks. It was indicated, however, that the marketing event would add considerably to the volume of orders on the books of millinery manufacturers.

Ernest Frederick Lehmitz, 57 years old, a tall professorial-looking man who has been regarded as the most zealous air raid warden and the most enthusiastic victory gardener in Tompkinsville, S.I., pleaded guilty in Brooklyn yesterday to charges by the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he supplied information on troop movements, convoy sailings, armament shipments and shipbuilding to the Nazi intelligence system.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 (U.P.) -- Taking advantage of a break in the monsoon rains, American airmen struck in force yesterday against Japanese installations in central Burma and the Royal Air Force pounded enemy targets in the coastal Arkan district.

Four men and a corporation were accused of mail fraud yesterday in connection with a scheme alleged to have been carried out in the shipment to Russia of 3,072,000 .45 caliber cartridges, of which 38 per cent were found to be dangerously defective.

MEXICO CITY, June 28 -- The electoral campaign for the election of 147 Federal deputies and seven State Governors next Sunday began in real earnest in the capital today as the newspapers reported the killing of a Mexican Revolutionary party member and the wounding of eleven other people at a meeting that was held in one of the suburbs yesterday afternoon.

HOUSTON, Texas, June 28 (AP) -- By the end of this year, Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce, predicted today, the United States will have a completely integrated rubber industry, capable of meeting all essential needs, military and civilian.

The letter in THE NEW YORK TIMES by Henry J. Taylor on the Detroit race riots cannot pass unchallenged. He seems to find the chief cause of the tragic events "those conspicuous figures in our public life who have so far forgotten the first principles of human nature as to encourage and insist on rapid transformations in the lives and relationships of our colored people and our white people."
CAIRO, Egypt, June 28 (AP) -- A Ninth United States Air Force communique:

WHEN George Strickler of the National Football League official family sits down in front of a typewriter and pounds out an essay on the happenings at the stormy meeting last week-end, there is no recourse but to let George do it. Here he is carrying the ball and heading toward a sure touchdown:

DETROIT, June 28 (AP) -- Dr. Gustav Egloff, director of research for the Universal Oil Products Company, Chicago, predicted today that automobile tires of the not very distant future would have a minimum life of 100,000 miles and that the motorist, instead of buying a new set of tires for his car, might buy a new car for his tires.
I felt that you would be interested in publishing a part of a letter I have just received from one of our employes who is now in the Navy. He writes:

Enactment of the anti-strike bill over Presidential veto "can and should mark the first step in a thoroughgoing revision of the government's labor policy," the Guaranty Trust Company asserts in the current issue of the Guaranty Survey.

Among those reported yesterday as having taken new residential quarters was James F. Hallinan, vice president of Commercial Factors Corporation, who leased a penthouse at 1112 Park Avenue through Frances R. Jaffin, broker.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Eight more Japanese ships, including a destroyer, have been sunk and three damaged by United States submarines operating in waters of the Pacific and Far East. They increased to 269 the announced total of enemy ships sunk or damaged by our underwater raiders since Pearl Harbor.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The texts of the letter from Chester C. Davis to President Roosevelt and of the Chief Executive's reply in connection with the former's resignation as the Food Administrator were as follows:

The so-called decentralization plan controlling exports to Latin America is "utterly hopeless" and possibly may involve the necessity for government-to-government purchases and the elimination of the private trader, exporters asserted yesterday in a bulletin released by the Export Managers Club.
PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- A $45,000,000 bond refunding program was placed before the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Northern Indiana Public Service Company today for approval.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The new military government of Argentina has suggested sending a special mission to Washington to improve relations with the United States, it was learned tonight. It was understood that discussion of political, economic and military questions was contemplated.

Pantelleria, the island reduced by air power, was attacked for twenty days -- the last thirteen of them intensively -- by air and by sea. It had been intermittently blockaded and attacked before the final assault. Air power plainly bore the brunt of the burden of attack.

Perhaps it was fitting that an Irish-bred horse should capture the inaugural feature of the transplanted meeting of the Empire City Racing Association, which flew a green and gold banner from each of Jamaica's towers yesterday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., June 28 (AP) -- Sentiment favoring a fourth term for President Roosevelt, as expressed by Dr. Stephen S. Wise, was greeted with cheers today by delegates to the annual convention of Brith Abraham.

Referring to your article "Post-War Commerce in Europe Discussed," where you mentioned the views which I expressed to the New York University Faculty Club, I wish to make clear that I do not believe in the immediate possibility of a free trade system for all Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- A joint application providing for a reduction of $6,267,000 in the capital stock liability and a reclassification of the common stock of the Idaho Power Company was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by that company and its parent, Electric Power and Light Corporation.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- Herbert Marshall has signed a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer contract for three pictures, the first of which will be the Oscar Wilde story "The Picture of Dorian Gray." In this film, to be produced by Pandro S. Berman and directed by Albert Lewis, Mr. Marshall will portray the artist Basil Hillward.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Thirty-seven additional industrial plants have won the Army-Navy production award.

King Peter of Yugoslavia promised his people in a St. Virus Day broadcast from London yesterday that after the Allies had delivered them from the enemy he would make it possible for them "to decide on their own fate in conformity with the principles of democracy."

A mechanical brain which takes all the guesswork out of aerial gunnery and can make of an untrained youth a deadly enemy of a Zero or a Messerschmidt within three weeks was demonstrated here yesterday before a group of newspeper men and Army officers by the Sperry Corporation and the United States Army.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- A steady rise in the employment of older workers was reported today by Paul V. McNutt, chairman of the War Manpower Commission. More than one-third of the total number of persons employed in May were 45 years of age or older, he announced.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 28 -- A teacher shortage of alarming proportions, with resulting lowered standards, crowded classrooms and curtailed school services, faces this country, educators attending the annual convention of the National Education Association warned today.

Reports from Stockholm that Gunder Haegg, Sweden's great runner now in this country, had endangered his amateur status by permitting his name to be used in Swedish commercial advertising were denied yesterday in a cable received by the American-Swedish News Exchange, Inc., of this city.

Dr. Samuel Belkin, talmudic scholar and dean of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (Yeshiva) since 1941, has been elected president of Yeshiva and Yeshiva College, it was announced yesterday by Samuel Levy, former Borough President of Manhattan and chairman of the Board of Directors of Yeshiva and Yeshiva College.

A final draft of maximum price regulations to replace GMPR for the women's undergarment and nightwear industry has been adopted unanimously by the OPA price regulation committee of the National Women's Undergarment Manufacturers Association, it was made known yesterday by Mortimer J. Greenberg, president of the organization.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 28 -- Whatever the claims of Propaganda Ministries in Axis countries that home populations and those of the occupied countries are discounting an Allied invasion of the Continent as "doomed to failure," the "nerve war" has had the effect of immobilizing ninety-six German divisions, representing approximately 1,700,000 German troops, according to a broadcast from Paris today.

LONDON, June 28 -- On the Stock Exchange here today diamond shares gave way on profit taking. DeBeers issues were about 6s 3d lower at 21 21-48; Anglo-American lost sixpence at 68 shillings, but Consolidated held firm at 44s 3d.

The regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board released yesterday disclosed that factory workers' earnings rose to new peak levels in April, that the average number of hours worked weekly increased and employment declined slightly.

Persons not supporting the Civilian Defense program would be "the first to complain and whine if we were attacked," Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia declared yesterday at a City Hall ceremony in which he presented certificates of merit to owners of real estate who have provided free space for Civilian Defense activities.

Wall Street banks are preparing for a deluge of new accounts in connection with the new Federal withholding tax, effective Thursday, under which employers must turn over to the banks sums deducted from wages and salaries of employees.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Higher allowances for dependent children of men in the lower ranks of the armed forces were recommended to Congress today by the Army and Navy. A wife with one child would get $68 a month, instead of the present $62, with $11 a month for each additional child, instead of $10.

"The Vagabond King," with music by Rudolf Friml and book and lyrics by Brian Hooker and Russell Janney, will be revived this evening by Mr. Janney at the Shubert Theatre. It has not been offered on Broadway since December, 1926, when the operetta closed a run of 508 performances under Mr. Janney's auspices.
LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Assurance that the United Nations were rapidly approaching final victory and a promise that war would be carried to Japan "in a most violent and destructive way" were given by Lieut. Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, deputy chief of staff, in statements to the Senate Appropriations Committee, which recommended $71,500,000,000 for the War Department during the 1943-44 fiscal year.

United Merchants Manufacturers, Inc., textiles, had for the nine months ended with March a net income of $3,268,423 after provision of $5,634,002 for foreign income and excess profits taxes and Federal income and excess profits taxes and $500,000 reserve for contingencies, according to a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 28 (AP) --The Newark Bears made it three in a row over the Rochester Red Wings by capturing a 2-to-1 decision tonight.

TOLEDO, June 28 -- A spin-test machine, conceived and designed at Willys-Overland Motors, Inc., which simulates the action of a shell in flight, is said virtually to eliminate the possibility of "duds" reaching American gunners. The device is used in inspecting volume production of fuses for anti-aircraft shells and has reduced rejections from an original figure of 20 per cent to one-tenth of 1 per cent, states Joseph W. Frazer, president.

In THE NEW YORK TIMES today Clare Luce, speaking from Appleton, Wis., is quoted as saying that if an isolationist is or was a man who wanted to stay out of war, then she was an isolationist, and that she believes that everybody in the United States was an isolationist before Pearl Harbor.
The six-family apartment house at 135 Wilkinson Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by Rudolph G. Grief to the L.S. Holding Company through J.I. Kislak, Inc., broker.
CAIRO, Egypt, June 28 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, urged the public today to spend the July Fourth week-end at home and warned that holiday travelers might find themselves stranded at pleasure spots by lack of transportation.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission has ordered the Western Union and Postal Telegraph companies to refrain from closing or merging any of their offices without specific approval of the commission.

A comprehensive plan for recapitalization and simplification of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation system was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The plan, formulated to meet the requirements of the integration and simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act, calls for consolidation of the corporation's principal subsidiaries into a single operating electric and gas utility company and the elimination of intermediate holding companies in the system.

The "cheap and cynical fringe" of the advertising profession that is damaging advertising in the eyes of labor, consumers and the Government was attacked yesterday by Carroll B. Larrabee, president of Printers' Ink Publishing Company, in an address at the opening luncheon of the thirty-ninth annual meeting and wartime conference of the Advertising Federation of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The new protein by-product distilling process recently developed at the Park Tilford Brownesville, Pa., distillery was put into full-scale commercial operation for the first time yesterday at the company's Midway, Ky., plant, Frank G. Handren, president, announced last night.

Testimony that garment-industry racketeers had demanded $15,000 to end a strike, had accepted $7,500 after bargaining, and had later returned $3,600 because they feared investigation, came from a prosecution witness yesterday in General Sessions, at the trial of Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro on an indictment charging extortion.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Commercial interests and commission-house buying advanced rye futures today on the Board of Trade to a new fifteen-year peak before heavy profit taking was able to stem the upturn. Shorts covered freely on the way up and numerous stop-loss orders were uncovered on the bulge.

It will be a decided help toward building a better world after the war if we learn to think of that better world as a continuation and not a revolution. Excited comment on the "revolutionary" character of the Beveridge report on social security died down when a more careful reading of the text revealed Sir William Beveridge tracing back the long history of social security in Great Britain.

The slump in production through out the New York Metropolitan milkshed has started, it was learned yesterday. Already the reduction is about where it was expected to have been in August. Although production reached such a peak at the annual milk flush a month ago that thousands of cans were dumped into gutters up-State where receiving stations and manufacturing plants were swamped, manufacturing plants are now running short and are begging for milk.

MOSCOW, June 28 -- Diplomatic representatives of the Soviet Union will soon receive official formal uniforms that they will be expected to wear at all state occasions in the capitals to which they are accredited. Similar uniforms will be provided for all members of the newly established career diplomatic service who are employed at the Foreign Commissariat in Moscow.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 28 -- The Allied aerial offensive against the Ruhr is forcing the Germans to transfer much of their war production to Austria, according to a trustworthy traveler just back from Vienna. Austrian factories are already working around the clock to satisfy German war requirements and the added strain of the transfer is complicated by widespread sabotage.

Although yesterday was hot and humid, carrying on the design of the current heat wave, the temperature tapered off to a point where the day's principal distinction was that none of the longstanding Weather Bureau records was broken.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Secretary Ickes told the House Ways and Means Committee today that the Government had "no desire and no plans for the nationalization" of the coal industry and hopes to return the mines to private ownership "at the earliest possible moment."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -Overriding recommendations of the Joint (Byrd) Economic Committee and the two appropriations committees of Congress that the National Youth Administration be liquidated, the Senate by a 41-37 vote late today, adopted an amendment to the Labor-Federal Security Supply Bill to continue the agency as a "war essential" and to give it $47,800,000 for the 1943-44 fiscal year.

LONDON, June 28 -- The expected Allied land action remains a threat rather than an actuality and the weather may interrupt the relentless blows that have already pulverized so much of the Ruhr, but the air war goes on and will go on.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (U.P.) -- Carl E. Newton, president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, said tonight that his new job as director of coal mine operations for the Government will be "to get maximum production."

With "Fighting Planes for Our Fighting Forces" as its slogan, a vacation campaign among 2,000,000 school children in New York State was launched yesterday. Announcement of the plan was made by Mrs. Courtlandt D. Barnes, vice chairman of the New York War Savings Staff for the metropolitan area, from the New York Staff headquarters at 1270 Sixth Avenue.

ALBANY, June 28 -- New York's real estate tax base has shrunk $6,793,981,570, or about 20 per cent, in a decade, forcing localities to impose a higher tax rate to raise the same revenue as ten years ago, the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Office of Price Administration called off plans today to effect a 25 per cent reduction in the maximum prices of Grade B women's hosiery.

In a move to ease the crisis in the laundry industry that is threatening the family wash of 1,000,000 homes in the metropolitan area and to stem the exodus of laundry workers to higher paying jobs in other industries, a four-point program was submitted to eight employer associations yesterday by the Laundry Workers Joint Board, affiliate of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America.
LENINGRAD, June 28 -- Leningrad's own people saved the city in 1941.

Guarded references to a new and vitally important service rendered by civilian women volunteers led to the partial disclosure yesterday of confidential work carried on at the Aircraft Warning Center here.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (U.P.) -- Good fortune and good flying saved the lives of six members of a B-25 Mitchell bomber crew who crash-landed on the Greenland coast after encountering seemingly insurmountable hazards, a War Department report revealed tonight.

A Federal grand jury here indicted yesterday the National Lead Company and a subsidiary, the Titan Company, Inc., as well as E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and four individuals, on charges of participating in a world-wide conspiracy to control the production and marketing of titanium compounds.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Representative Robert A. Grant, Republican of Indiana, told the House today that newspapers "are being choked to death by the flood of Government handouts, while on the other hand these continued cuts in the supply of newsprint strike out at the jugular vein of our free press."

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28 -- Gen. Enrique Penaranda, President of land-locked Bolivia, left Brazil tonight, carrying in his pocket three trade agreements and other concessions that will extend for the duration of the war.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Small war plants have been cut into more than $1,000,000,000 worth of war contracts since establishment of the Smaller War Plants Corporation a year ago, Brig. Gen. Robert W. Johnson, chairman, reported today to Chairman Donald M. Nelson of the War Production Board.

MONTREAL, June 28 (AP) -- Newsprint Administrator Guy Z. Hoult announced today that instructions had been sent to Canadian newsprint manufacturers which, in effect, would cut July deliveries to the United States 13 per cent below the amounts ordered.

New issues of Treasury notes, while not precisely a novelty, have been infrequent. Books were opened yesterday on the new offering of $2,500,000,000, "or thereabouts," and the advance business was reported as brisk. The new four-year 1 1/2 per cent notes fill a gap in the financing structure between certificates of indebtedness and medium-term bonds, and a substantial over-subscription is to be anticipated.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- It took Miss Patty Berg three attempts to tee up her ball on the first hole today -- she was just that shaky -- but her drive screamed 220 yards down the fairway.
The six-story apartment house on a plot 44 by 103.3 feet at 128-30 West Thirteenth Street has been sold by the West Side Savings Bank to an investor through the Wood, Dolson Company, Inc., broker.

In a dispatch to this newspaper from "the Upper Yangtze front" Brooks Atkinson suggests that a new factor has appeared in the war in China. "In previous battles," he says, "the Chinese outnumbered the enemy. But this time the Chinese were outnumbered, and the fact that they turned the Japanese advance into a rout by the superiority of their fighting spirit has given the Chinese soldier refreshed and heightened confidence."

LONDON, Tuesday, June 29 -- A strong force of United States heavy bombers, striking Axis targets for the third time in four days, battered St. Nazaire and Beaumantle-Roger in France yesterday, it was officially announced early today.

LONDON, June 28 (U.P.) -- At least 400 enemy warships, supply vessels and smaller craft have been sunk or damaged by mines strewn in European waters by British ships and planes since the war began, the Admiralty and Air Ministry announced jointly tonight.

MARCELO, Brazil, June 28 (U.P) -- The last dramatic moments aboard the 8,000-ton American merchant ship East Indian, torpedoed in mid-Atlantic last year, and the agony and despair of countless days without food or water in a storm-beaten open raft were recorded by an unidentified young blond seaman whose body was found on a raft grounded near here today.

It is evident from the resignation yesterday of Chester C. Davis as War Food Administrator that the President was forced to choose between a good man and a poor policy, and that he chose the poor policy. Mr. Davis could not go along with the subsidy program which is the Administration's newest white rabbit.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- A protracted period of reconversion after the war was foreseen by Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, Federal Works Administrator, in an address today before the governing and advisory boards of the Associated General Contractors of America.

BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- Extreme outsider in the field of nine starters, Houghton P. Metcalf's Scotch Abbot scored a surprise victory in today's feature at Suffolk Downs, the $1,800 Woodland, an allowance dash for 3-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- It required unusual courage and a true sense of responsibility to a people engaged in war for Chester C. Davis, the Food Administrator, to return his commission to the President. The food situation is so grave, its implications are so alarming, as the consequence of politics, misorganization and mismanagement that candor was the obligation of a patriot to a country which is the victim.

SOUTH PACIFIC HEADQUARTERS, June 28 -- A 26-year-old fighter pilot from Pittsburgh who has been an airman since he started flying gliders at 13 was credited officially today with having shot down five Zeros and probably a sixth in the great air battle over Guadalcanal June 16.

"Best Foot Forward," Metro's Technicolored film version of the Broadway musical, will have its premiere at the Astor Theatre today. Starred in the production are Lucille Ball and William Gaxton. Harry James and his band and Virginia Weidler are among the featured players as well as Tommy Dix, Kenny Bowers, Jack Jordan, Nancy Walker, June Allyson and Gil Stratton.
NEW DELHI, India, June 28 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:
CAIRO, Egypt, June 28 -- Axis airdromes near Athens were blasted yesterday by a large formation of American Liberators, which also showered leaflets on the city itself.

Cotton prices developed yesterday moderate strength, influenced in part by the Congressional defeat of the price rollback subsidy program. On the New York Cotton Exchange final quotations were near their highs for the session and 2 to 7 points above Saturday's final prices.

The academic cap and gown -- symbol of things accomplished in the realm of learning -- added distinction to the graduation exercises yesterday at the kindergarten of the Children's Aid Society, 419 West Thirty-eight Street. In the dignified university garb, thirty-three children passed the first mile-stone in their educational careers, received their certificates and said farewell to cutting out paper dolls.

AT AN ARMORED FIGHTING SCHOOL, in England, June 28 (Reuter) -- Anglo-American invasion armies have some sensational surprises for the Germans. When they blast their way forward from Continental bridgeheads they will throw into action an array of tanks and armored cars that bristle with secrets.

America's military air power has only started the campaign that, with one frightful surprise after another, soon will shatter Axis resistance on all fronts and force an early end of the war, according to The Aircraft Year Book for 1943, edited by Howard Mingos and released today by Lanciar Publishers.

Mayor La Guardia demanded in an address broadcast last night over the WJZ Blue Network that Congress act immediately to provide subsidies to hold the line on the cost of living. Urging his hearers to wire or write their members of Congress to move to check rising food costs, the Mayor charged that "our civilian authorities are playing politics." He added:

LONDON, June 28 (AP) -- An unofficial source with underground contacts with the Continent reported today, without confirmation, that Germany had ordered fifty divisions from the Russian front to the west.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Carl Elbridge Newton, president of the Chesapeake Ohio Railway Company, will head the government organization which is being built to operate the country's seized coal mines, Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes, as Solid Fuels Administrator for War, announced today.

A considerable rise in public good-will has been experienced by the Eastern railroads since the start of their coordinated newspaper advertising campaign in October, 1942, the Bureau of Advertising, A.N.P.A., reported yesterday in the current issue of Advertising Facts.

With the end of the war the present high revenues being realized by the railroads will disappear and the carriers will be burdened with huge war-deferred maintenance costs now piling up, Dr. J. H. Parmelee, director of the Bureau of Railway Economics of the Association of American Railroads, declared yesterday.

Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores showed an increase of 7 per cent for last week in comparison with the corresponding period of last year, according to the "flash report" issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Yesterday was the eighteenth day of intolerable heats in this delirious June. The text of the weather prophets was "Continuing warm and humid." "Warm" is a word too cold by innumerable diameters. If yesterday was only "warm," so are the innards of Vesuvius and Etna; so is a burning fiery furnace; so were Othello's "steep-down gulfs of liquid fire." The whole country was like an immense flaming brazier.

If there were more musicians we would have less trouble, because the first fundamental of music is harmony, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia said yesterday when he opened the Mount Morris Music School, 1 West 123d Street, under the sponsorship of the Juvenile Welfare Council, of which Justice Stephen S. Jackson of the Children's Court is director.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Yale's golf squad of three seniors and a junior exploded a surprise team triumph in the forty-sixth National Collegiate A.A. golf tournament today in a combination medal-match 36-hole round that lasted from early morning until dusk over the Olympia Fields No. 1 course.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Allied submarines and bombers are turning the tables on the European Axis partners in the war of attrition against shipping, a type of warfare that long was considered the most serious threat to Allied victory, the Board of Economic Warfare disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Chester C. Davis, whom President Roosevelt drafted three months ago to solve the food problem, stepped out today, telling the President flatly that the program to combat inflation would not work in its present form.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 28 -- True to his word, the Rev. Fletcher D. Parker, pastor of the Immanuel Congregational Church, started his automobile toward Lake Sunapee, N.H., this afternoon. Office of Price Administration investigators handed him a summons for a hearing here Friday.

Seventeen local housing authorities in various parts of the country will open on July 6 bids on new issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $57,860,000. The issues, which range in size from $13,994,000 to $205,000, must be bid for separately.

CHUNGKING, China, June 28 (AP) -- The possibility of a fresh Japanese drive in western Hupeh, gateway to Chungking, was reported by Chinese military authorities today on the basis of intelligence information.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 (AP) -- The Pirates batted out a 7-to-1 victory tonight over the Reds, giving Rip Sewell his tenth victory of the season against two defeats. Pittsburgh tightened its hold on third place, leading Cincinnati by a game and a half.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Provisions for the restoration to a limited number of war workers in Northeastern plants of mileage allowances lost through the recent reductions in the value of B and C gasoline coupons were announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

Food is wasted all along the line. It may rot in the fields for lack of harvesters. It may spoil in retail stores -- in 1931 one authority estimated that $470,000,000 worth of perishables were thrown away each year through lack of adequate refrigeration.

TOLEDO, Ohio, June 28 -- Designers associated with the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company, here, were putting finishing touches today on a full-scale model of the "kitchen of tomorrow" as conceived by H. Creston Doner, chief designer of the company, who "threw away the book" in supervising plans for the evolution of the American kitchen from its present stage to its potential postwar uses.

The twelve-story business building on a plot 50 by 100.5 feet at 160-62 East Fifty-sixth Street, purchased last week by Frederick Brown, operator, from the Guaranty Trust Company, has been resold to a client of Vincent A. Giaquinto.
BUFFALO, N.Y., June 28 (AP) -- The Jersey Giants went one up on the Bisons in their series of six games tonight with a cheap 5-to-1 victory.
MANCHESTER, June 29 (Reuter) -- "A general attack on the Roosevelt Administration is now in full swing," said The Manchester Guardian today.

A joint appeal for candidates for the position of custodian and custodian engineer in the public schools, where there are now sixty-six vacancies, was issued yesterday by the Board of Education and the Municipal Civil Service Commission.

LONDON, June 29 -- Some small Allied governments are beginning to wonder about the intentions of the great nations, on whom they depend for liberation from the Germans. This uneasiness is a normal symptom of the approach of the day of victory and it is only natural that the machinery for the distribution of food and other forms of relief should prove a major cause of concern.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Loud wails were being let out today by Navy officers who learned over the week-end of the latest mid-war sartorial changes in officers' uniforms, recommended by the Uniform Board, approved by Admiral Ernest J. King, and "promulgated" by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox.

ALGIERS, June 28 (U.P.} -- Details !as to how the French Committee of National Liberation will function during the sojourn of General Giraud in the United States are expected to be worked out at tomorrow's plenary session.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Axis propagandists are making the most of the coal strike, the race riots in Detroit and the anti-strike legislation passed by Congress to persuade their peoples that economic weakness and social tension imperil the fighting power of the United States.
LONDON, June 28 (U.P.) -- A joint Air and Home Security Ministries communique:

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Roosevelt announced the resignation of Chester C. Davis as War Food Administrator and the appointment of Judge Marvin Jones in his stead. He signed several bills including the record Naval Appropriation Bill, the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill and the Legislative and Judiciary Appropriation Bill.
The program presented last night at the Lewisohn Stadium by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Alexander Smallens conducting, contained four "firsts," three at the Stadium and one anywhere.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Navy communique 425:

Two sentences of five to ten years each were imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Samuel Barton Sklar, 56 years old, 880 Park Place, Brooklyn, on his recent conviction by a jury in two of the thousands of frauds he is alleged to have perpetrated on business and professional folk in the last twenty-five years.

Steel production in the United States this week will be at the slowest rate since the first big Luftwaffe raids of the Battle of Britain in August, 1940, because of the lack of coal with which to make enough pig iron to maintain full operations. The lack of coal is due to the current work stoppage in the mines and to shortages resulting from two earlier strikes this year.

AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, June 28 (U.P.) -- Allied warplanes, sweeping the Allied sea lanes off eastern Australia, bombed and probably destroyed a large Japanese submarine Friday and attacked another with undisclosed results yesterday, South Pacific Headquarters announced today.

Fathers in jobs essential to the war or in civilian economy will not be released for service in the armed forces before Oct. 1, local draft boards and employers were notified yesterday by Col. Arthur V. McDermott, director of Selective Service for New York City.

DETROIT, June 28 -- Just as this city was about to settle down to normal after last week's race riots and the foremen's strike at the Ford plant, there came a threat today that it might furnish the first test for the anti-strike law which Congress passed over President Roosevelt's veto. Wiser heads seem to have prevailed, however.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 -- The South Carolina Electric and Gas Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today a plan to issue $20,000,000 face amount of first mortgage bonds, due July 1, 1973, for the purpose of refunding four bond issues that will be outstanding following the consolidation and merger of Lexington Water Power Company into South Carolina Electric and Gas.

SWAMPSCOTT, Mass., June 28 (AP) -- Mrs. John L. Whitehurst of Baltimore, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, urged club women tonight to beware of peace propagandists and not to endorse peace plans at this time.

WHEN the Pilgrims sailed into Cape Cod Bay and Plymouth harbor they thought they were exploring and colonizing a new world. Their landfall had been an accident, for they had originally set sail for "northern" Virginia. In all their words on the subject, they left their children with the distinct idea that the colonizing of Plymouth was a startling and wholly unprecedented beginning.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 23: Decreases of $609,000,000 in holdings of Treasury bills, $217,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, $315,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted, $593,000,000 in U.S. Government deposits, and $334,000,000 in deposits credited to domestic banks.

ON THE UPPER YANGTZE FRONT, June 22 (Delayed) -- Less than three weeks ago the deep gullies of this turbulent range of mountains were swarming with Japanese soldiers. The air was whinning and the earth was trembling during attacks by Japanese bombers and fighter planes.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- Whirlaway will race no more.

Your correspondents who inquire caustically how much pleasure driving can be squeezed from a gallon and a half of gasoline are naive, to say the least. Surely they must know that the great amount of pleasure driving turned up by the OPA checkers is, by itself, complete justification of the checking.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- The State Parole Board is refusing to release James J. Hines from Sing Sing solely because he is a "man of newspaper interest" who still professes his innocence of contriving to operate a policy-slip lottery of the late Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, he contended through counsel today in Supreme Court here.

PITTSBURGH, June 28 -- The back-to-work movement in the Appalachian coal field today was reflected in a 10 per cent rise in operations at the by-product coke plant of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation in Clairton.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 28 -- Henry T. Istas, blind since birth, was today named assistant city attorney by Judges John A. Maresca and Nathan Reback. It is the first such appointment has been made in the State. Mr. Istas and his "seeing eye" dog Gretchen have been a familiar sight for years.

After two weeks of competition, the second augmented by the participation of fans who by purchasing bonds were entitled to vote in the "popularity" phase of the drive, Brooklyn's Dixie Walker is setting the pace in the Baseball War Bond League, sponsored by the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America and the United States Treasury Department.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, June 29 (U.P.) -- Eighteen Japanese planes, including a new type of square-winged Zero fighter, gave the Allied base at Darwin in northwestern Australia its seventy-third attack of the war Monday and Allied defenders destroyed or probably destroyed a third of the raiding force.
LONDON, Tuesday, June 29 (U.P.) -- The Russian Monday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
GUADALCANAL, June 19 (by Mail) -- Between the Tokyo radio and Japanese bombers, the nights are not always dull here.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 29 -- A great hue and cry has been raised in Germany over the bombing by the Royal Air Force last night of Cologne, in which, the Germans say, the famous 600-year-old Cologne Cathedral was destroyed.

SOMEWHERE IN ENGLAND, June 29 (U.P.) -- Five "pick and shovel boys" of the Eighth United States Air Force were decorated today for their part in keeping the Flying Fortresses over Germany and Africa. They were the first men of the Eighth Air Force Service Command to be honored.

DETROIT, June 29 -- The only long-range solution for Detroit's race problem, as seen by officials and social workers who have watched it develop to the explosive stage, is a middle-of-the-road course in which there will be enough give-and-take on both sides to draw off the worst of the tension.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A revision of its order covering women's, girls', children's and toddlers' outer-wear garments, which increases the number of categories affected to forty-six and extends control to an all-year basis by providing a pricing formula for such fall selling prices as are higher than spring ones, was announced today by the Office of Price Administration.

Joseph B. Eastman, Director of the Office of Defense Transportation, asks the public to stay at home for the long week-end caused by the falling of the Fourth of July on Sunday. If this is not the American way of keeping a holiday, it is imperiously enforced by common sense and a knowledge of facts.

LONDON, June 29 -- Hundreds of British bombers, roaring over Europe in the tenth straight night of attacks on Germany's war industries, blasted Cologne "in great strength" last night and simultaneously attacked the northwest German port and submarine center of Hamburg.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals reversed today the treason conviction of six Chicagoans, who were found guilty by a district court here last Nov. 14 on charges of sheltering and assisting Herbert Haupt, one of eight Nazi saboteurs who were smuggled into the country a year ago from a German submarine.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -- Volo Song, 2-year-old trotting champion of 1942 and a strong favorite for this year's Hambletonian, stepped out to a rather soft straight-heat victory today in the thirty-third renewal of the Matron Stake, feature of the first program of a twenty-three-day Grand Circuit meeting at neighboring North Randall.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (U.P.) -- Promotion of 166 Marine Corps officers was announced today by Marine Corps headquarters. The list includes nine colonels, thirty-nine lieutenant colonels and 118 majors, representing forty-one States and the District of Columbia. All advancements were effective as of June 1.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Unless Vice President Henry A. Wallace submitted to the President his severe personal attack on Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones today, and received Mr. Roosevelt's approval, the publication was a flat violation of the President's order of Aug. 21, 1942, banning official critical public debate of that character.

Warner Brothers' screen version of Irving Berlin's "This Is the Army" will have its world premiere at the Hollywood Theatre on Wednesday night, July 28, it was announced yesterday. Tickets for the opening of the Technicolor picture, which was produced for Army Emergency Relief, will be on a reserved seat.

The bombing of Berlin by the Royal Air Force on March 27 left 80,000 persons homeless, and the nerves of the German people are gradually breaking under the prolonged strain of the bombings, according to a recent letter from a Swedish business man to a friend in this country.

Attacked by two muggers as he walked home through Central Park last Friday night after a visit to his wife, a maternity patient in Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, Leo Reichert, 41-year-old house painter and decorator of 159 West 103d Street, died in the hospital yesterday after an operation had failed to save his life.
Orchestral Program Includes Overture to 'Bartered Bride' and Beethoven's 'Eroica'

Service men who are refugees from Nazi-dominated countries and who have long ceased to hear from their friends and families are hearing their names at mail call these days. Forty young women, members of the Our Boys Club, not only are writing regularly but are sending small packages as well.

OTTAWA, June 29 -- An Allied assault on Axis territory in the very near future was predicted today by Malcolm MacDonald, Britain's High Commissioner to Canada, who disclosed also that U-boats had been knocked out at the rate of one a day for the past two weeks.
LONDON, June 29 (U.P.) -- An Air Ministry communique:

Capt. Frederick G. Reinicke, Director of the Port of the Third Naval District, told 500 American Women's Voluntary Service Motor Transport Service members last night that American military operations were in such fine order that by the end of 1943 enemy submarine raids would be effective only under "suicidal conditions."

Wages for the average employe will reach a new high this year and now are considerably above those paid to Canadian railroad employes performing similar work, two witnesses for the carriers testified at yesterday's hearing before the Emergency Board of the National Railway Wage Panel on the 30 per cent wage increase demanded by the railroad brotherhoods.

Mr. and Mrs. Jansen Noyes gave a farewell dinner last night in the St. Regis Roof for their son, Blancke Noyes, who is leaving soon for active duty in the United States Naval Reserve. Others in the party were Lieut. Alfred F. King, USNR, and Mrs. King; the Misses Shirley Noyes, Ruth Schwab and Elizabeth Durk: Lieut. George N. Lindsay Jr., USNR; David Lindsay and John Harper.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Navy announced today twelve casualties; two dead and ten missing. In addition, eleven men previously listed as prisoners of war now are reported dead. Another whose status was changed from prisoner of war to dead was not listed, the Navy said, because his next of kin lived in an occupied country.

The Anthracite Tri-district Scale Committee, policy-making group of the United Mine Workers of America for the anthracite fields, issued a statement here yesterday urging Pennsylvania hard coal miners to return to their jobs "in the best interests of all concerned."

MEXICO CITY, June 29 (U.P.) -- The Spanish Republican leader, Indalecio Prieto, in an open letter to the British Deputy Prime Minister, Clement R. Attlee, published in the newspaper Excelsior today, denounced any move tending to restore the monarchy in Spain.

Branch Rickey, who admitted that he had been toying with the idea for a month, announced yesterday at a surprise press conference that Charley (Chuck) Dressen had been rehired as a coach of the Dodgers.

THE Western clubs of the National League switch the scene of their operations to the Atlantic seaboard today and the Eastern clubs of the American League swing out where the West begins. But that is not the big news at the moment This is the day when the two major leagues contribute all of their receipts to the National War Fund, the all-embracing agency which handles every form of relief except the Red Cross.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia made an appeal yesterday to all New Yorkers to join, through contributions, the campaign to save Greenwich House, stating that he personally was distressed to learn that the settlement house, which has operated for more than forty years in Greenwich Village, might have to close because of financial difficulties.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- It is all a mistake about the gray shirts being mandatory for Navy officers after Oct. 1, Rear Admiral Randall Jacobs, naval personnel chief, told the House Naval Affairs Subcommittee on Uniforms today, according to Representative Leonard W. Schuetz of Illinois.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 29 -- Speaking at the summer conference of the State Federation of Women's Republican Clubs this afternoon, Mrs. Ann Scott Wilson of Huntington, W.Va., called for live party policies.

LONDON, June 29 (Reuter) -- The German radio's military commentator, Lieut. Gen Kurt Dietmar, in a broadcast talk entitled "Warfare Without Risks," said tonight that "to an ever-increasing degree the United States has become a real enemy, the heart and core of the anti-European coalition and the dominating influence in the Allied camp.

The New York War Finance Committee, headed by W. Randolph Burgess, vice chairman of the National City Bank, has virtually completed its State-wide network of regional and subcommittees in preparation for the nation-wide War Loan drive scheduled for Sept. 9, it was announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, June 29 -- Maj. Gen. Talensky, in a detailed survey of two years' campaigning on the Soviet-German front, published in the army newspaper Red Star, attributes the enemy's failure to launch a spring offensive to his being completely outmaneuvered by Premier Joseph Stalin's strategy.

Preparations are under way in the toilet goods industry for adjustments to the expected WPB order which would limit the use of glass containers from July 1 to Nov. 1 to 65 per cent of the amount used in that period in 1942. Drugs and foods, it is understood, will be exempt from the restriction.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Miss Patty Berg, medalist, after dramatically crashing into the second round of the women's Western Open today with a 5 and 3 triumph over Mrs. Opal S. Hill, is ready to face the severest test in her golf comeback tomorrow.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Accelerated receipts of hogs shoved prices of that form of livestock sharply downward today. The top was $13.80 a hundredweight, paid sparingly, and the few good and choice heavy hogs were steady at $13.75, the Department of Agriculture's proposed ceiling price. Most prices, however, were 10 to 25 cents or more lower.

THE last week in June is usually a publisher's pause for refreshment and a brief breathing spell. The spring season is over and the summer one, which used to be devoted to light, so-called "hammock reading," but which has become increasingly important in recent years, has not yet begun. It provides a welcome opportunity for harried reviewers to take up overlooked books, pushed to the back of their shelves during the literary torrents of spring.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A night bombing attack by American planes against a small group of Japanese light warships in the central Solomons was reported by the Navy Department today.

From the Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Human Nutrition and Home Economics come two new pamphlets of practical import. One is "Wartime Canning of Fruits and Vegetables," opportunely issued at a time when the interest in food preservation seldom has been so intense.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- By September more than 1,000,000 children will need some sort of supervision while their mothers work, Dr. Bess Goodykoontz, Assistant Commissioner, U.S. Office of Education, estimated today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, June 29 (AP) -- Lieut. Gen. Robert Eichelberger, speaking today before 400 American graduates of an officers' candidate school, warned them not to take the Japanese lightly because the Japanese were more implacable enemies than the Germans or the Italians.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Persisting in its policy of using subsidies to keep down prices, the Office of Price Administration has arranged to buy the entire output of industrial alcohol plants on a fixed profit basis and resell to manufacturers at the present ceiling price that part of the alcohol the War Production Board decides is needed for essential civilian use.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The War Food Administration announced today that the civilian share of pork, lamb and mutton slaughtered during the three months beginning July 1 would be larger than in the current quarters, but that the civilian allotment of beef and veal would be the same.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The War Production Board established itself today as arbiter of the use to which virtually every ton of wood pulp may be put, declaring that military and other demands for paper products "have become so insistent and the shortages of wood pulp so severe" that stern control is required.

The nine-story and penthouse apartment house at 105 West Seventy-third Street has been sold by Paul S. Hitlin, builder and operator, to an investing client of Milton M. Sittenfield, attorney, for cash above a mortgage of $178,650 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

A registration statement covering $7,000,000 of Consolidated Cigar Corporation ten-year 3 1/4 per cent sinking fund debentures due on July 1, 1953, was filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an announcement here.

Urging a more effective system to exclude possible mental patients from Selective Service, Dr. Arthur H. Ruggles, superintendent of Butler Hospital in Providence, Rhode Island, predicted yesterday that by the end of this year the nation may have 1,000,000 young men disabled because of mental disorders.

HEADQUARTERS ALASKA DEFENSE COMMAND, June 29 -- Japanese anti-aircraft positions on Kiska Island are hard hit by a new type of attack, designed to counteract the difficulties of bombing through the Aleutian overcast.
Negotiations for a refunding of $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year 5 per cent debentures of the United Drug Company, due in 1953, are in their final stage, it was learned yesterday.

The Japanese agency Domei, in a broadcast from Tokyo recorded in New York by The Associated Press yesterday, quoted Japanese military observers as asserting that Japan had completed her preparation of strategical bases from which an all-out offensive could be launched "at any moment" against Australia.

INDIANAPOLIS, June 29 -- Taking an unprecedented step, the National Education Association, at its closing sessions, sent a direct appeal to Senate leaders to pass the $300,000,000 Federal-aid bill, to prevent the closing of thousands of schools this fall.

American fliers returning from their latest raids on Messina report that harbor installations in that city have ceased virtually to exist. The waterfront looks as it did after the earthquake of 1908. Yet Italy must keep the port of Messina open if she is to hold Sicily.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A voice vote in the Senate passed and sent to conference today the $71,507,678,873 Army Appropriation Bill, said to be "the largest in the history of mankind," but outspoken misgivings accompanied speeding of the measure to enactment for the fiscal year starting tomorrow midnight.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A bill sponsored by the War Department to avoid the situation following the first World War when contractors had to wait months or years for government payments on termination of their war contracts was put in shape this afternoon by members of the House Military Affairs Committee and spokesmen of the War Department.

Domestic economic and political developments laid a chilling hand yesterday on the stock market, and although prices managed to make a half-hearted recovery in the afternoon values were irregularly lower on the day. Absence of any real demand, plus a moderate amount of profit-taking, acted as the primary factor in the day's results, with business the lightest since last Thursday and a further contraction in the number of individual issues traded.

PITTSBURGH, June 29 (AP) -- A back-to-work movement gained momentum in some sections of the nation's coal fields today, but an estimated 139,000 miners continued an unauthorized "no contract, no work" stoppage and another blast furnace -- the nation's eighteenth -- was shut down as coal supplies dwindled in war industries.

The volume of long-distance telephone calls handled by the Bell System has nearly doubled in the last two years, while during the same period the system has added 150,000 new operators to handle the increased traffic and to replace losses among the operating force, Mark R. Sullivan, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday.

LONDON, Wednesday, June 30 (U.P.) -- Berlin reported today that the Russians had broken through their lines at two places south of Staraya Russa, on the Lake Ilmen front, using flame-throwers and artificial fog in the latest of a series of attacks that extended down to the Kuban bridgehead.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- The War Meat Board appealed to hog producers today to reduce marketing temporarily because heavy receipts at terminal markets and country points in the last two weeks "far exceeded" available processing facilities and prices had been depressed to the government support level of $13.75 per 100 pounds.

"Baseball for Victory Day," with special and attractive programs offered everywhere in both major leagues, will be staged today and tonight and 100 per cent of the proceeds will be donated to the National War Fund.

NEWBURYPORT, Mass., June 29 (AP) -- Edward F. Dow, 13, youngest person ever tried for murder in Massachusetts, was sentenced to 14 to 20 years in State prison today by Judge John V. Spalding for the hammer slaying of Miss Lydia S. Cook, 72 years old, last April.

Procedural details on the new censorship system for the export of sales and other printed material, which becomes effective tomorrow, were outlined to foreign traders yesterday at a meeting at the postal censor's local offices at 215 West Twenty-fourth Street.

When "Artists and Models" goes into rehearsal Aug. 25, Jane Froman will be starred. The revue, with book by Gene Towne from an idea supplied by Lou Walters, its co-producer, will open late in September on Broadway without benefit of an out-of-town try-out.

An ex-convict who was at liberty in bail on a narcotics charge was arrested yesterday as the first suspect in the slaying of a Catholic priest on Dec. 17, 1931, by gunmen who held up a steamship ticket agency at 191 Sullivan Street.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- An amended voluntary plan for the merger of the International Utilities Corporation with the Dominion Gas and Electric Company in order to comply with the corporate simplification provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act was made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Yale University, which scored a surprise team triumph yesterday in the forty-sixth national collegiate golf tournament, advanced today into position to sweep individual honors as well.
