RICHMOND, Va., June 29 (AP) -- A collaboration committee of thirty-three white and thirty-three Negro leaders from Southern States, meeting here for a searching analysis of the principal issues involved in race relations, has agreed that some affirmative action is needed and has named a continuing committee to work out methods and practical means of approach.

ALGIERS, June 29 -- Pierre Boisson, the last of the reactionaries who governed French North and West Africa for Vichy when the Allies landed last November, has resigned his post as Governor General of French West Africa.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., June 29 (AP) -- President Thomas H. Richardson of the Eastern League today ordered four games won by the Hartford Laurels from the Springfield Rifles stricken from the standings.

One commercial bank and 121 savings institutions in New York State have been approved for membership in the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, making the roll of banks in this State protected by the Federal fund unanimous, Leo T. Crowley, chairman of the Federal agency, and Elliott V. Bell, State Superintendent of Banks, announced jointly here yesterday.

Two pending orders, an OPA rationing regulation and a WPB production regulation, occupied the attention of the annual convention of the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.
Debate continues on THE NEW YORK TIMES quiz in American history, and this department cannot refrain from making its contribution to the discussions; which, in the vulgar, is putting its oar in.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 29 (AP) -- The Independent Order of Brith Abraham ended a three-day meeting today by re-electing Herman Hoffman, a New York lawyer, as grand master and choosing Atlantic City for the 1944 convention.

Liquidation in the July position and fears that the shakeup in the War Food Administration might result in more stringent price controls brought about yesterday some nervous selling in the other deliveries on cotton market. At the close active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net losses of 9 to 16 points, with the greatest recession in the July position.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 -- Three baby pigs, trapped and roasted on a rocky South Pacific island by castaways from a torpedoed Liberty ship, were so tender that crew members devoured even the bones and hair, survivors said at Treasure Island here today.

Substantial improvement in earnings of Schenley Distillers Corporation was disclosed in the report for the nine months ended on May 31, announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors.

School is over! That is the cry that will be heard today from the throats of a million boys and girls, released from classroom routine for ten weeks. When the 3 o'clock bell rings this afternoon it will be the signal for the end of the current school term. Who among us is so old that he can't remember the last day of school and the impatience with which the "all out" signal was awaited?

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 29 (U.P.) -- Heinz Bongartz, naval correspondent for Reich Marshal Hermann Goering's Essener National Zeitung, was quoted in a Berlin dispatch today as saying that new Allied anti-submarine methods, especially the increased use of airplanes, had virtually whipped the U-boats, for the present at least.

The United States today faces a choice between subsidies on fool or ruinous inflation, Lou R. Maxon deputy administrator of the Office of Price Administration, declared here yesterday. Mr. Maxon held a press conference at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, where on the previous day he had given an off-of-the-record talk to the annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 29 -- Irked by the failure of many persons rejected for the draft to participate in home-front protective services and by the indifference of some men in older age brackets toward civilian defense, the heads of civilian protection services in the eighteen towns and twenty-one villages of Westchester County recommended unanimously today to President Roosevelt that such men be drafted by law for service as wardens and other civilian defense workers.

Net sales of the Bendix Aviation Corporation for the six months ended on March 31 amounted to $417,812,580, compared with $170,420,270 in the corresponding period a year ago, it was announced yesterday by E. R. Breech, president.

BUFFALO, June 29 (AP) -- The Most Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Burke was consecrated today as the first Auxiliary Bishop of the Buffalo Diocese and Titular Bishop of the Ancient See of Vita, in Tunisia, in the impressive service of the Roman Catholic Church.

NEWPORT, Ky., June 29 (AP) -- Norman B. Schreiber and Jerome S. Greenberg, who headed a New York and Chicago syndicate which bought the Andrews Steel Company several months ago for a reported $5,000,000, resigned as president and vice president today, directors announced.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Elmer Davis, director of the Office of War Information, who recently criticized what he said was undue prominence of Washington news concerning "bickering" among government officials, declined today to include in that category newspaper accounts of the difference of views between President Roosevelt and Chester C. Davis, who has just resigned as War Food Administrator.

BUFFALO, N.Y., June 29 (AP) -- Manager Greg Mulleavy came up with another new starting combination in an effort to snap Buffalo out of its losing lethargy tonight, but it was of no avail as Jersey City took a 3-to-2 decision to make it three straight.

In announcing the declaration of the regular quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share on the common stock, the International Business Machines Corporation explained that the meeting of directors had been held earlier than usual because of improbability of obtaining a quorum in July.

Officers of the Civil Service Reform Association met in special session yesterday but reached no decision on what action the organization would take, if any, to challenge the recent promotion of fifteen battalion chiefs to the rank of deputy chief in the Fire Department.

Manufacturers of gas appliances will have to increase their national advertising after the war or face oblivion, Arthur P. Hirose, director of market research and promotion for McCall's and the Red Book Magazines, declared yesterday befor the Association of Gas Appliance and Equipment Manufacturers in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

LONDON, June 29 (U.P.) -- Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch's Yugoslav Army has started an offensive on three fronts, and Greek guerrillas are battling strong forces of German troops in apparent belief that the Allied aerial attacks in the eastern Mediterranean foretell an early invasion, it was revealed tonight.
Two weeks ago the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives accepted a proposed concurrent resolution offered by Representative Fulbright of Arkansas. It read as follows:
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Harry James of jitterbug trumpet fame is due to be divorced in Juarez, Mexico, and has planned to be married Monday in Las Vegas, Nev., to Betty Grable.

Riots of serious proportions were reported last night to have occurred in Athens and three other Greek cities as a result of weekend American bombings during which leaflets signed by President Roosevelt, expressing the hope that the Greeks' liberation was not far off, were dropped, The Associated Press said.
A local version of the monsoon arrived in town yesterday, ending, for the time being, the eighteen-day tropic spell that had the population wondering whether this was New York or Bombay.

BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) -- The Maryland Racing Commission allotted today a twelve-day meeting to the Maryland Jockey Club to be conducted over that organization's Pimlico course from Nov. l through Nov. 13.

Neighbors noticed that when Erwin Harry De Spretter got off the 5 o'clock ferry bus at Richmond and Todt Hill Roads in Dongan Hills, S.I., Monday night, the little engineer seemed inordinately distressed.

Convinced of the legality of their own position and encouraged by the rising tide of public resentment against restrictive Office of Price Administration regulations, independent meat packers in New York City disclosed yesterday that they intended to ask the United States Department of Justice to intervene in the situation.

The State of New York sold yesterday from the investment accounts of its Canal Debt Sinking Funds 9 and 12 $6,493,587 par value of various blocks of municipal bonds for a total price of $7,884,589, or a premium of $1,391,002. The sale was by sealed competitive bids.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Because of a temporary shortage of used and recapped tires, the Office of Price Administration limited sales in the gasoline shortage area today to holders of B, C, S and T gasoline ration cards and limited replacements elsewhere to automobiles used for occupational purposes.

MOSCOW, June 29 -- The view that the German industrial machine, although unlikely to break down suddenly through shortage of any one strategic material, is grinding implacably to a standstill by reason of a combination of factors, is expressed by a Pravda writer today.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The War Department gave out today the names, with next of kin, of 1,189 United States soldiers held prisoners of war by the enemy. Of these, 932 are held by Germany, 256 by Japan and one by Italy. Among the prisoners listed today are eighty-three from New York, twenty-eight from New Jersey and seven from Connecticut, all enlisted men. They are:

Max Zerkow, who gave his address as 20 Plaza Street, Brooklyn, and said he has been in the garment business for thirty-five years, was called as a prosecution witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, ex-convict, on an indictment resulting from the racketeering of the Lepke-Gurrah gang.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- Navy communique 427:

When John L. Lewis called off his last coal strike he did so only on condition that the Government would operate the mines. Work would "automatically terminate," he announced, if Government control were vacated before Oct. 31. Since then the United States Government has strictly obeyed Mr. Lewis' terms.

The plan just filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation for over-all simplification in conformance with the provisions of the Public Utility Holding Company Act calls for a considerable amount of refunding of senior obligations, but from present indications none of this business will be ready for marketing before late this year or early 1944.

In THE TIMES of June 28 Senator Langer is quoted as saying that "the OPA alone has 2,700 lawyers, while in England they only need about seven attorneys to do the same job." This statement has been made on other occasions.

LONDON, June 29 -- In the stock markets here today interest was centered largely around Kaffir mining shares. Vlak-Fontein jumped 3s 9d to 33s 9d and Lace Prop, 1s 1d to 28s 9d. Blyvoor rose to 80s and West Uit was better at 9. Diamond shares were quiet, although Consolidated Diamonds hardened 3d to 44s 3d.

The ban on pleasure driving in the East and the present system of gasoline rationing as applied in this area by the Office of Price Administration were attacked strongly from different standpoints yesterday by Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey and a group of Mayors and other officials of cities and villages in Westchester County in New York State.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 29 -- Politicians of both parties are worried over the soldier vote in next year's election.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- Sinclair Lewis arrived here today, under contract to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, to write the screen play for a "super" Western. The picture "Storm in the West" will be based on an original story by Dore Schary, who will also produce it.

Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 949, which compared with 1,172 in the preceding week and 922 in the like period a year ago, according to the list published in THE NEW YORK TIMES. Yesterday's registrations numbered 369 as against 543 last Tuesday.

CHICAGO, June 29 -- Grain markets developed a weaker undertone today on the Board of Trade. The resignation of Chester C. Davis as Food Administrator was regarded as likely to result in a further delay in the prospective advance in the ceiling price on corn, and likewise eliminate some of the favorable measures taken recently in regard to the grain trade.
LONDON, Wednesday, June 30 (U.P.) -- A special Russian communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The President saw Representative James W. Wadsworth, New York Republican; Representative Henry D. Larcade Jr., Louisiana Democrat; the Secretary of the Interior, Harold L. Ickes; Herbert Pell, former Minister to Portugal, and Mrs. Pell, and the Secretary of War, Henry L. Stimson, and held a press conference.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- House and Senate conferees agreed tonight after a seven-hour meeting on a bill which killed the rollback subsidy program for beef, butter and coffee and in effect prohibited future subsidy programs for food without the express permission of Congress.

After a one-week drop to "anticipated" levels for the first time in nine months, the general death rate in New York City rose again last week to the higher figures that have become usual this year, Health Commissioner Ernest L. Stebbins' report yesterday showed.

Influences of traditional headgear from far-flung countries of the world are evident in the new fall hat styles. Yesterday Madame Pauline presented her attractive versions of millinery's global aspect at a special showing for the press in her salon at 6 East Fifty-third Street.

Two players gained the semifinal round of the Metropolitan championship for junior girls yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club and a third match was in the concluding set when rain interrupted the proceedings for the day.

LINDEN, N.J., June 29 -- A penny found by Leo Zelbofski, an electrical worker at the eastern aircraft division of the General Motors Corporation plant here, and attached by the finder to a Wildcat fighter plane just before it was completed, as a good luck token last Friday, started a spontaneous collection that rolled up an estimated $3,000 today for the Navy Relief Fund.

Funds have been provided by a private source for recreational programs in three Harlem schools in an effort to solve the teen-age problem by furnishing facilities for after-school activity, it was disclosed yesterday by Francis J. Brennan, assistant director of the Division of Recreational and Community Activities of the Board of Education, at the annual Ladies Day luncheon of the Kiwanis Club of Brooklyn in the Hotel Towers.

The Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, 34 Nassau Street, announced yesterday a plan for making an immediate cash payment to the beneficiary of a man killed in service without waiting for an official death certificate or letter from Washington.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Representative Albert J. Engel, Republican of Michigan, assailed private war industries today as paying "excessive wages" to unskilled workers, equaling or exceeding in some instances the pay of high-ranking Army officers.

Judge James Garrett Wallace, in sentencing a youthful hold-up murderer to a life term yesterday in General Sesions, declared the law that permits murder juries to recommend mercy for slayers, saving them from mandatory sentences to die, is "silly" and the Legislature should change it immediately.

Appearing in its slimmest size since the early years of this century, the summer Social Register now being distributed to its subscribers here and in other cities is indicative of the restrictions and changes imposed by the war on any formal directory of prominent families and individual.

LONDON, June 29 -- Half a million holiday harvesters are lending a hand with the crops in Britain this year. There has never been anything quite like it in the history of this country, which will rely on their skill and industry for the greater part of the food to be consumed during the coming winter.

With 150 youngsters as an example of his words, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, at ceremonies held yesterday afternoon at the Heckscher Ball Field in Central Park, commended their participation in sports as a certain cure for juvenile delinquency. He awarded prizes to the all-city winners of Park Department sports competitions.

Tomorrow the black bass season, with the exception of Lake George, will be extended to all New York waters. In certain areas the season already has been under way, but July 1 marks the opening for bass fishing in the greater part of the State.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 29 -- France is not exempt from the war of nerves which is being intensified each day in Europe.

Cooperative action by the Army and Navy in their procurement programs has been developed to the point where it is now possible to prevent much duplication and waste, with consequent savings in money and shipping space, Frank M. Folsom, assistant chief of the Office of Procurement and Materials, United States Navy, declared yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Sales Executives Club of New York in the Hotel Roosevelt.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29 -- Two more Canadian brokers were enjoined here today by Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein from dealing in securities in this State. They are William J. Simpson and Alexander Galbraith, both of whom maintain offices in Toronto.

Nearly 45,000 boys and girls between the ages of 12 and 18 took part in the Spring Sports Tournament which reached its climax yesterday, with the New York Community Trust furnishing $10,000 worth of prizes and the Park Department providing space and other facilities.
I am happy to agree with your contention in your editorial of June 25, "The Reply to Mr. Lewis," that the President's proposal to raise the draft age is unsatisfactory.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 29 -- Yesterday's Flying Fortress bombardment of Leghorn has devastated the center of the town and most of the port area, according to official statements from Rome received here tonight. Preliminary estimates so far list 175 persons killed and 300 seriously wounded but added that "there are many more still under the ruins."

The annual summer series of dancing under the stars in city parks will open tomorrow night on the Central Park Mall to the music of Bob Alien's orchestra, the Parks Department announced yesterday. Admission is free, and during the season a number of "name" bands, including those of Sammy Kaye, Will Osborne, Jerry Wald, Johnny McGee and Joe Venuti, will be heard.

A secondary distribution of 30,000 shares of the Gaylord Container Corporation's common stock made by Lehman Brothers and Hemphill, Noyes Co. at 3:05 P.M. yesterday was oversubscribed and the books were closed. The distributors had informed the New York Stock Exchange that they might stabilize the price to facilitate the offering.

The first native of the United States to be named by the Vatican as a bishop in Central America was consecrated in a ceremony lasting three hours yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral, when the Most Rev. Matthew Aloysius Niedhammer, a Capuchin missionary born in this city, was duly accredited as vicar apostolic of Bluefields, Nicaragua, and became titular bishop of Caloe in Asia Minor, near Ephesus.

Mickey Cohen, a second lieutenant in the City Patrol who operates an automobile body and fender repair shop at 2178 Jerome Avenue, the Bronx, got his man yesterday and earned the praises of Bronx detectives.

ALBANY, June 29 (AP) -- New York State, whose food authorities hold that the Midwest pigs consumption of grain which New York could use for milk cows and poultry is largely responsible for food shortages, is raising 53 per cent more pigs than a year ago.

ROCHESTER, June 29 (AP) -- Gerry Burmeister's single of Relief Pitcher Tom Ananicz with two out, the bases loaded and the score tied in the ninth gave Rochester a 6-5 victory over Newark tonight. It was the Red Wings' first victory over the Bears in the last seven games between the two clubs.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 (AP) -- The Japanese in Burma have accumulated large stores of railroad equipment at Thanbyuzayat to extend the line to connect with a road from the Thai capital, Bangkok, a United States communique disclosed today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 18 (AP) (by Mail) -- The United States is employing the most powerful radio transmitter in Africa to tell the people of Europe the truth about the war in a calm, matter-of-fact manner.

While reaffirming its belief in descriptive labeling of consumer products "which honestly informs the prospective buyer regarding the product offered for sale," the Advertising Federation of America yesterday went on record as unqualifiedly condemning the mandatory use of government-assigned grades on many articles of merchandise.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP} -- A warning that casualties of the war will be large and the country should be prepared for them as part of the price of victory and freedom came tonight from Elmer Davis, Director of the Office of War Information.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Gulf, Mobile Ohio Railroad Company today sought authority from the Interstate Commerce Commission to issue new securities in a refinancing program which it said would reduce its debt by $2,817,000 and save $2,125,285 in interest over a seven-year period.

Six members of the Woman's Royal Navy Service, popularly known as Wrens, who have crossed the Atlantic with troop transports, are in town. They are among the first women in this war to sail as regular crew members of a British ship.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A delegation of representatives of the Congress of Industrial Organizations from New York and New Jersey visited the White House today and called on members of Congress and other officials, urging support of various Administration proposals.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., June 29 (AP) -- A white-haired Oklahoma farm woman whose seven sons all are commissioned officers in the armed forces, is glad that they were all physically fit and able to serve their country.

Ernest (Cat) Robinson, veteran Jamaica welterweight, defeated Johnny Jones of Pittsburgh in the feature battle of eight rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. The battle was close and the decision apparently went to Robinson on the strength of a nine-count knockdown he scored with a left hook in the third.
LONDON, June 29 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Vice President Wallace today publicly accused Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which the Secretary of Commerce heads, of "obstructionist tactics" against the Board of Economic Warfare in its effort to build up stockpiles of critical and strategic war materials and drugs.

The second day of the transplanted Empire City race meeting saw a crowd of 12,099 journeying to the Jamaica track yesterday through a rainfall which broke the heat wave but held the attendance down and lowered betting enthusiasm.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 29 -- More than 100 Flying Fortresses flew a thousand miles across the Mediterranean yesterday to blast Leghorn, 200 miles north of Rome, in a nine-minute assault that was the thunderous climax...

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The tradition that it is a disgrace for a woman to work outside her home, common to many South American countries, is breaking down and with it severe class distinctions, according to Miss Mary M. Cannon, chief of the Inter-American Division of the Women's Bureau, who has just returned from a seven months' trip to Brazil, Paraguay, Peru and Ecuador.

HANOVER, N.H., June 29 (U.P.) -- Long-striding Gunder Haegg completed training at Dartmouth today as Gil Dodds, Boston divinity student, announced that he is in peak condition to extend the Swedish flash to his utmost in their meetings on a transcontinental tour.

When Karl Landsteiner received the Nobel Prize in 1930 at Stockholm he responded modestly with a bow and the comment that he would let "the master of words" speak in his behalf. "You may call me a master of the word," said Sinclair Lewis, upon whom this compliment was bestowed, "but what is he? He has been in a thousand cases the master of death."

Added impetus was given yesterday to the city nutrition program, originally set up by the Department of Health to disseminate information concerning the best use of the available food supply in terms of a well-balanced diet.

Reports from the island of Pantelleria after its surrender to air power indicate that no minefields, booby traps or anti-tank obstacles had been prepared; the spirit and quality of the men were poor and their, morale was extremely low. There had been very few casualties by our bombardment; most of the garrison and civilian population had taken refuge in the rock shelters.

Crown Publishers announce the purchase of assets and publications of Covici Friede. Several hundred trade titles are involved in the purchase. Crown Publishers said that some of the titles would be taken over and reissued under the new imprint, but a definite choice has not yet been made.
B. Kleijn Molekamp, Minister of the Netherlands in Washington, and Mrs. Molekamp are at the Ambassador.

The president of the Midget Manufacturing Company spoke here yesterday to an audience including several of the nation's leading industrialists, who listened intently as the youth swung into his talk on war production.

OTTAWA, June 29 -- Princess Margriet Francisco, infant daughter of Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, was baptized here today in St. Andrew's Church in the presence of her grandmother, Queen Wilhelmina, on her father's thirty-second birthday.

Internal auditors can be of material assistance in bringing about the equitable termination of war contracts, according to speakers at at special meeting of the Institute of Internal Auditors last night at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- William H. Davis, chairman of the War Labor Board, said today that the board's wage stabilization policy called for the prompt carrying forward of the announced policies of the Administration affecting the cost of food.

Moving to alleviate the growing feed shortage and its effects upon the production of food, representatives of 500,000 dairy and poultry farmers in thirteen northeastern States voted unanimously yesterday to oppose the payment of Government food subsidies at an emergency feed conference called jointly by the Northeastern Dairy Conference and the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council at the Hotel New Yorker.

ST. LOUIS, June 29 -- Vernon Stephens, the slugging shortstop, was rejected for military service today, giving the Browns another and unexpected opportunity to take advantage of his powerful hitting and emerge from the cellar.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Federal Trade Commission has ordered five western corporations engaged in producing and distributing commercial motion picture films used by national advertisers, a trade association they organized, and two booking agencies to cease restraining trade in the distributing of such films by entering into conspiracy.

LONDON, June 29 -- With the building up of basic stocks in the British army to a point where they are considered sufficient to meet the needs of whatever contingencies may arise, this country has developed a highly mobile system of war production that enables a quick "swing-over" from the manufacture of one type of war material to others of more urgent priority.

Indications are at hand that, in his answer to President Roosevelt's letter -- the letter that Joseph E. Davies delivered in Moscow -- Premier Joseph Stalin accepted the President's proposal for a meeting. At the same time, he avoided appointing or suggesting any definite date or place.

In Edward R. Lewis' letter which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 25, favoring Oriental exclusion, he said: "Finally, is it not clear that if this immigration question were a two-way question, this talk of insult would stop instanter? Does anyone believe that the Japanese or the Chinese would permit white common laborers, white farm laborers and mechanics to enter their countries?"

Eugene D. Kisselev, Russian Consul General, gave a reception yesterday afternoon at the Russian Consulate, 7 East Sixty-first Street, in honor of Prof. Solomon Michoels, director of the Moscow Jewish State Theatre and chairman of the Jewish Anti-Fascist Committee of the Soviet Union, and Itzik Feffer, noted Soviet Jewish poet.

JERUSALEM, June 29 -- With their former export markets still only a pleasant recollection and a pious hope for the future, Arab and Jewish citrus growers in Palestine fared badly during the past season, when the bulk of the crop was either sold at ridiculous prices or used for by-products, with the residue processed as animal feed or even buried, recalling the destruction of the unmarketable Brazilian coffee crop.

LONDON, June 29 -- A United Nations victory will strengthen the position of English as a world language, and agreement upon its adoption as the principal international auxiliary language should now be possible, it is stated in the report of the United Nations'education conference recently held here.

NEWARK, N.J., June 29 (AP) -- Workers from two big New Jersey steel companies, Crucible Steel in Harrison and John A. Roebling's Sons in Trenton, walked out today in what union officials for both locals involved termed unauthorized strikes.
NEW DELHI, India, June 29 (AP) -- A Tenth United States Air Force communique:

Rafael Rojas, one of the founders in 1937 of Colombia's first school of civil aeronautics, arrived in this city yesterday on his way to Washington, where he hopes to obtain through the Lend-Lease Administration several training ships for his country's civil aviation students.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., June 29 -- Trapped on the roof of a former roadside restaurant on Long Beach Road, here, Brother, a 6-year-old orangutan who has made a monkey out of police for the last week, was shot and killed this morning. The bullet came from the service pistol of Patrolman Lanice Ray of the Nassau County Police Department, a former Texas Ranger and one of a group of policemen who were in at the kill.

The Public Service Commission will begin a series of hearings today to determine whether bus companies in the city are living up to their certificates in eliminating certain routes and curtailing service on others in their efforts to comply with Office of Defense Transportation orders limiting mileage.

CHUNGKING, China, June 29 -- Commenting today on strikes in the United States, the moderate newspaper Ta Kung Pao says that it "hopes that the strikes will be amicably settled very soon and will not jeopardize the plan of the United Nations to crush the Axis jointly.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The first anniversary of the institution of paid Government war-risk insurance found the War Damage Corporation with total insurance liabilities exceeding $124,000,000,000 and practically no damage to pay for.
A drive to collect phonograph records for men in the armed services will be launched Saturday afternoon from 2:30 to 4:30 with a Block Dance on the Mall in Central Park.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The United States ended its fiscal year tonight with a record of expenditures of more than $76,000,000,000, receipts of more than $21,000,000,000, a gross public debt of more that $140,000,000,000 and a deficit of more than $55,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt asserted today that the danger of race riots such as occurred recently in Detroit could be materially lessened if individuals would scotch inflammatory rumors and stop unreasoning fear.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- An attempt by the War Mobilization Director, James F. Byrnes, to harmonize the differences between Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones, failed today after he had summoned them to his office for a two-hour discussion this afternoon.

Determined to go all out in their efforts to make a success of the National War Fund benefit double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the Giants and the Cardinals regaled a gathering of 15,694 with a performance that ran close to seven hours.
MOSCOW, June 30 (AP) -- The noon communique:

Seven hundred and twenty-eight prospective Navy engineers and doctors will report today at Columbia University for the opening of the Navy V-12 specialized training program. The largest center in the world for training naval officers, Columbia is the only school in this area to start the special curricula for both undergraduates and professional units.

CORONADO, Calif., June 30 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox believes the time is approaching when the United Nations can put into effect the final strategy for victory but that it may take three to four more years to crush the Axis.
Many new apartment leases in the Buchanan, at 160 East Forty-eighth Street, were reported yesterday by William Marr, resident manager, who said renewals also had been brisk there.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Chicago's summer furniture and home furnishings markets concluded their sessions with many visiting merchants still short of goods but understanding better the problems under which the industries are operating.

The 500 "founder members" of the New York committee of the National War Fund, meeting yesterday in the City Council chamber at City Hall, set up an executive committee of thirty-six to direct a campaign to raise $17,000,000 as the city's quota of the $125,000,000 sought by the national organization to finance sixteen war relief organizations.

The mid-year list of securities legal for investment by savings banks, issued yesterday by the New York State Banking Department, shows that bond issues with a par value of $151,144,000 have been added, and issues having a par value of $173,006,000 have been removed from the list.

BUFFALO, June 30 (AP) -- Ken Trinkle, pitching with only two days' rest, gained his second verdict of the series over the Bisons tonight, winning, 2 to 0, in the second half a double bill to give the Jersey Giants an even break for the evening and four out of six on the series.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- James F. Byrnes, Director of War Mobilization, announced today he has requested all procurement agencies of the government to set up boards of review to pass upon present purchase programs with the objective of balancing them with the over-all strategy of the war.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Miss Elizabeth Hicks, who won the "duration" national amateur championship in 1941, beat herself today in the women's Western open golf tournament on the nineteenth hole of her quarter-final match with Miss Dorothy Kirby.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The American republics, exclusive of the United States, presented to President Roosevelt through the governing board of the Pan American Union today a resolution commending the Good Neighbor policy.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- There are now 211 German divisions on the Soviet front and there are no signs of any withdrawal of troops westward to meet the threat of an Allied assault on the European Continent, the communist newspaper Pravda asserts in an article signed "Intelligence Officer."
LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- Invasion jitters spurred to even greater intensity by a new and heavy British volley on the nerve war front racked the bomb-buffeted peoples of Europe tonight.

The little old rural schoolhouse in Richmond Valley, a small town on the south shore of Staten Island, one of the last two-classroom schools in the city, closed its doors at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, much to the regret of the fifteen pupils, their parents and members of patriotic and civic organizations who had used the schoolhouse as a civic center for the last forty-six years.

Mme. Chiang Kai-shek is on her way back to Chungking after a seven months' visit in the United States. We hope she returns restored in health, confident of the American people's warm friendship for herself and the cause she represents, and with assurances that this friendship win soon speak eloquently in increased material aid for China.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 30 -- The opening day of play in the New Jersey State tennis singles championship saw one of the top favorites in jeopardy of defeat today at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club.

While the revised MPR 287 reflects progress in recognition of the industry's problems, efforts will be continued by the legal and legislative committee of the National Coat and Suit Board to bring about several changes previously suggested by it, it was stated yesterday by Joseph L. Dubow, chairman of the committee and executive director of the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association.

LONDON, Thursday, July 1 (U.P.) -- The Russians reported today the repulse of German attacks on the Leningrad, Smolensk and Kursk fronts and said their own troops had captured a strongly fortified German height on the Velikiye Luki front northwest of Smolensk.

The NBC Symphony, conducted during the winter season by Arturo Toscanini and Leopold Stokowski, will be sponsored commercially on a year-round basis by the General Motors Corporation, it was announced yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the corporation's board, and Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Continued disagreements between the Senate and the House blocked the attempts of Congress tonight to drive through to final enactment a half-dozen log-jammed appropriation bills, containing a total of more than $5,300,000,000 of funds required by war agencies and other governmental establishments to meet obligations of the fiscal year which starts at midnight.

LONDON, June 30 -- Announcement that the interim dividend on the ordinary stock of F.W. Woolworth Co., Ltd., would be cut from 20 to 10 per cent amazed the stock markets here today. After a temporary suspension of dealings in the issue pending confirmation of the report, the shares quickly dropped 8 1/8s to 51 1/4s, rallying later to 53 3/4s.
CHUNGKING, China, June 30 (AP) -- A communique:

The military stalemate existing in the Southwest Pacific since the conquest of Guadalcanal early in February has been broken by what is generally regarded as the beginning of a new American offensive. Combined United States forces, which presumably means Army and Navy units, have landed on Rendova Island, 170 miles northwest of Guadalcanal, and are now presumably engaged in battle with the occupying Japanese.
ROCHESTER, June 30 (AP) -- Newark gained an even split with Rochester tonight to leave town with a 4-to-2 edge in their six-game series.

J.B. Hill, president of the Louisville Nashville Railroad, warned yesterday that neither rail managers, investors nor employes could afford to "lull themselves into a position of false security" with respect to public transportation after the war.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- Conditions brightened slightly today in the coal fields, although 130,000 of the nation's 521,00 miners still were ignoring the order of June 21 by the United Mine Workers Policy Committee telling them to go back to the pits.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30 -- An increase in personal income tax rates with a reduction in exemptions will be needed the first of next year to bring spending power into line with curtailed supplies of civilian goods and to prevent inflation, Randolph E. Paul, general counsel of the Treasury Department, declared here today.

A banking group headed by Shields Co. won yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 city of Tacoma, Wash., electric revenue bonds, due $75,000 semi-annually from 1944 to 1963. The bankers bid 100 for the issue, of which $750,000 would be 4 per cents, $450,000 would be 2s and $1,800,000 would be 1 1/4s, stipulating that the bonds become callable not earlier than Jan. 1, 1954.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- The State CIO Council recommended to its affiliated unions and to the national CIO today that labor's "no-strike" pledge no longer be considered binding unless the "assurances made to labor" at the time the pledge was made were "immediately put into operation."

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- An important facility which the President did not extend to Chester C. Davis as Food Administrator has been granted to his successor -- membership on the boards of the Office of War Mobilization and the War Production Board. This will enable Marvin Jones, the new Administrator, to reach and be a continuous part of the central network of Federal controls.

LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden called upon Premier Mussolini today "to accept the unconditional surrender offered to him" and said that Britain had not approached and did not intend to approach Italy regarding the question of bombing Rome.

LONDON, Thursday, July 1 (AP) -- The Air Ministry today disclosed new details of Germany's six-engined troop-carrying Merseburg 323 plane, which fell such an easy prey to Allied fliers in the African campaign.

Detective Edward T.V. Fitzgerald, first grade, of the main office squad at Police Headquarters, bodyguard of visiting nobility and notables, who once rode in a motorcycle sidecar through Central Park with Prince Leopold of Belgium, retired at midnight last night after thirty-one years of service and today was headed for his farm at Pawling, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- "For meritorious achievement during aerial combat while engaged on a search mission," the Air Medal has been awarded Second Lieut. William J. Knapp, whose mother, Mrs. William J. Knapp Sr., resides at 30 East Forty-second Street, New York City.

Night Glow, longest price in a field of four, was an easy winner yesterday in Empire City's $5,120 feature at Jamaica when she led from start to finish of the Aphrodite Handicap to beat horses considered beyond her class.

LONDON, June 30 -- Prime Minister Churchill warned the Axis today that the Allies were preparing heavier blows on land and sea and by air from east, south and west to bring about the unconditional surrender that he and President Roosevelt de clared at Casablanca was the price of peace.

In THE TIMES of June 30 Thomas I. Emerson disputes the statement I made in New York on Sunday that "the OPA alone has 2,700 lawyers while in England they only need about seven attorneys to do the same job," and Mr. Emerson states the fact to be that both the figures are "seriously incorrect."

CLEVELAND, June 30 (AP) -- Adios, champion 2-year-old pacer of 1942, was an easy winner of the two heats that decided the twenty-first renewal of the Matron Stake Pace, feature of the Grand Circuit program at North Randall today.

Another musical hit of the Nineteen Twenties, "A Connecticut Yankee," will be revived on Broadway in September by Richard Rodgers, he announced yesterday. This will mark Mr. Rodgers' first solo attempt in the producing field; last season he served as co-producer of "By Jupiter."

CHUNGKING, China, June 30 -- A Chinese business man, who has just returned from Shanghai after a fourteen months' visit, said today that Chungking looked shabbier and living was harder, but that all his Chungking friends were convinced that China would win.

Pin-ball machines are in demand at the American Foundation for the Blind, 15 West Sixteenth Street, not for entertainment purposes or as games of chance, however. Parts of the devices are utilized in an "electric eye" guard for the protection of blind operators of electric sewing machines, which was demonstrated in the Helen Keller Room there yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The names, with next of kin, of 789 United States soldiers held prisoners of war by Japan and of eighty-six wounded in action in the Aleutian, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas were made public today by the War Department.

SHEPPERTON-ON-THE-THAMES, June 30 -- Jim Ellis is a shipyard worker from Merseyside who came all the way down from the London district with his chums the McLachlan brothers, Alex and Stan, to spend carefree holidays.

Protests by residents of the Eastchester district of the Bronx at a Public Service Commission hearing yesterday won prompt relief from a recent suspension of bus service in that community by the Surface Transportation Corporation.

A frosty cold cream for Summer appears in a hand-painted china jar inspired by those apothecary crocks still to be discovered in old-fashioned "chemists'" shops. The cream itself, according to the makers, is contrived according to a traditional druggist's formula which calls for such ingredients as lanolin and camomile and amygdalis communis -- which means almond oil.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Lieut. Col. Darryl Zanuck, now on the Army inactive list, will return to his desk at Twentieth Century-Fox on Tuesday to resume charge of production. On the same day William Goetz, his former assistant, who has been in the top production berth, opens offices in Beverly Hills of his independent company, International Pictures, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Except for severe long-standing drought conditions in the far Southwest, where some livestock is reported to have perished for lack of feed and water, weather of the last week encouraged favorable development of the nation's food and livestock feed crops.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Cubs, who have yet to be beaten by the Braves in the 1943 campaign, scored 6-2 and 5-4 victories over the Braves today as a crowd of 9,123 contributed $9,532,83 toward the war fund, with receipts still being counted.

As a heavy influx of potatoes into the local market drove prices below ceiling levels and threatened to precipitate a glut today, victory gardeners were urged yesterday by a spokesman for the regional Food Distribution Administration not to eat their own potatoes but to leave them in the ground and buy potatoes in the markets, thereby helping to relieve the oversupply.
LONDON, June 30 (U.P.) -- Prime Minister Churchill received honorary freedom of the City of London today and thus became elegible for admission to the poorhouses at Brixton, if the need ever arises.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (AP) -- The Phillies and the Pirates battled to a 3-3 stalemate in eleven innings tonight before 10,655 at a war relief game. Umpire George Barr halted the contest at the end of the eleventh under a National League rule that no night game may start an inning after 11:50 P.M.

The report of the American Cable and Radio Corporation and subsidiaries for the first three months of this year, released yesterday by John L. Merrill, chairman, shows a net income after operating expenses, taxes and other charges, of $404,230, compared with $255,001 in the March quarter a year ago.

A special meeting of stockholders of the New York Harlem Railroad Company has been called for Aug. 5 to consider the proposed issuance by the company of $7,820,000 of 100-year non-callable 4 per cent mortgage bonds which the New York Central Railroad has agreed to purchase.
LONDON, Thursday, July 1 (AP) -- The Russian Wednesday midnight communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Testifying before a Senate Agriculture Subcommittee, Joseph G. Montague named Harry Hopkins, Benjamin Cohen and Felix Frankfurter as among those he believed were most influential in "setting up policies."

It became illegal last midnight to drive a passenger or commercial automobile without displaying the 1943-44 Federal use tax stamp, which costs $5, but there were indications -- at least in the gasoline-starved East -- that there would be no immediate round-up of violators, who are subject to fines up to $25 and thirty days' imprisonment.

Although it is doubtful if the 1943 goal of fifty-seven billion quarts of milk will be produced by dairy farmers, the possibility of rationing, at least in areas where production has been maintained at good levels, is "fairly remote," according to the Milk Industry Foundation, which issued a survey of the situation yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Twelve regional and thirty-six branch offices of the Office of War Information throughout the country began closing at midnight tonight as the fiscal year ended.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Amid predictions that "they won't see enough to stick in their eye," five Senators received unofficial clearance from the Senate tonight for a trip around the globe in an Army bomber to visit American fighting forces in the battle zones and inspect their equipment.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The President signed the Treasury-Postoffice Appropriation Bill and other legislation, nominated George H. Payne for reappointment as a member of the Federal Communications Commission, met with members of the National Resources Planning Board and received callers, including Maritime Commission officials and Maritime Union members, Dr. Leo S. Rowe and members of the Pan American Union Governing Board, Under-Secretary of State Sumner Welles and Secretary of State Cordell Hull.

A moderate improvement took place in the oil supply situation on the Atlantic Coast last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The institute's index for the East Coast at the close of last week stood at 29.5, compared with 27.6 at the end of the previous week and a low point of 25.5 on May 8.

A program of French music was given last night by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, led by Alexander Smallens, at the Lewisohn Stadium. It included Milhaud's "Suite Provencale," heard for the first time at the Stadium; the Berlioz overture to "Beatrice et Benedict," Ravel's "La Valse" and Franck's Symphony in D minor.

Spurred by accelerated war production and the extremely hot weather, electric power production of the nation's electric utilities set last week an all-time peak. The amount of electrical energy distributed by the power industry, according to figures released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute, was 4,120,038,000 kilowatt-hours, an increase of one-half of 1 per cent over the preceding week and a gain of 19.2 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago.

A registration statement covering 15,000 shares of series A cumulative preferred stock and 50,000 common shares of United States Plywood Corporation is to be filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Eastman, Dillon Co. will head an underwriting group to offer the securities publicly during July.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., June 30 (AP) -- Power to decide where the next blow will be struck in the Pacific "now rests with our side, and it will continue to rest with us for the duration," Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox declared today.

Major produce distributors in the Washington Street market disclosed yesterday their fear that I proposed revisions of an Office of Price Administration regulation covering the movement of seven popular vegetables go through as interpreted to them they will either wipe out the nation's independent operators, throwing the industry with its $6,000,000,000 annual turn-over to the chain stores or force independents to become black marketers.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury today indicted Carl Guenther Boshan Orgell, 43 years old, an engineer residing on Staten Island, New York, on charges of failing to disclose that he acted in behalf of the German Foreign Office and the Nazi party when he registered with the State Department as a foreign agent.

Miss Marguerite McAdoo entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Stork Club for several young women serving with her on the junior committee for the premiere showing of the motion picture "For Whom the Bell Tolls," on the night of July 14 at the Rivoli Theatre for the benefit of the National War Fund.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., June 30 (AP) -- The revolt of anthracite miners against their union's "back-to-work" order appeared to have been broken today in District No. 1, the principal producing region, but the strikers stood firm in the other two districts of the United Mine Workers in the hard coal field.

CHUNGKING, China, June 30 (U.P.) -- Bitter fighting continued in the Hupeh-Hunan border area today as Chinese forces made new gains in their drive to oust the Japanese from their last footholds in the rice-growing region between Lake Tungting and the Yangtze River.

The 15-cent dividend declared yesterday on the common stock of the American European Securities Company is the first dividend this year. In 1942 stockholders received 25 cents in June and also in December.
NEWARK, N.J., June 30 -- The Central Railroad of New Jersey will wind up tonight forty years of operation as a subsidiary of the Reading Company.

New issues of bonds offered here in June for public subscription aggregated $110,131,000 for twenty-one flotations, the smallest amount for that month since 1932, when $105,864,000 in thirty-three issues were marketed. Last month's emissions compared with $135,089,000 for sixteen offerings the month before and with $115,699,000 for twenty-four issues in June, 1942.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, July 1 (AP) -- The noon communique:

SOMEWHERE ON LONG ISLAND, June 30 -- The first barrage balloons to guard important ground establishments in the New York metropolitan area against enemy aircraft were flown in concentric circles over a vital industrial area here today in the presence of leading Army, Navy and defense officials.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Congress, handing the Roosevelt Administration another legislative setback, today forbade use of subsidies to push down retail food prices and ordered the meat-butter price "roll back" ended by Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Navy announced today thirteen casualties, including five dead and eight missing.

Bonds called before maturity for payment in June aggregated $149,875,000, the largest amount for any month since April, 1942, when $179,888,000 was retired and the biggest total for a June since 1939, when $298,722,000 was redeemed. In the preceding month $70,222,000 in bonds were prepaid ahead of maturity and in June, 1942, $42,067,000.

Mrs. Annie K. Lamb, widow of Col. Albert E. Lamb, Brooklyn attorney, left $250,000 to the endowment fund of Yale University in memory of her husband, a member of the class of '67, according to her will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

This country's "good-neighbor" policy is doomed if the countries of the world become too strongly nationalistic following the war, Kenneth K. Boynton, president of General Electric S.A. of Mexico and affiliated companies, said yesterday in announcing that the concern has completed a new fluorescent lamp factory in Monterrey.

Government authorities were urged yesterday by William B. Craig, president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, to encourage record production of sugar during 1944 both in this country and in the Caribbean, in order to provide increased rations for civilians and to alleviate the shortage of energy-giving carbohydrates which is facing the United Nations.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 30 -- Establishment by the Government of definite and fair policies for the prompt settlement of contractors' claims, so that procedure involving a minimum of delay and dispute will be in effect at the conclusion of hostilities, is of vital importance, Samuel J. Broad, chairman of the committee on auditing procedure of the American Institute of Accountants, declared today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 30 -- Enemy reconnaissance aircraft fly over this island now and again, usually at a great height, just as they fly over many other localities in the Mediterranean theatre to find out what we are up to, what our plans are, what particular base, if any, we favor for forthcoming operations.

Impressed by our war bond campaign and its success, Senor Juan Francisco Rojas of Guayaquil, Ecuador, said yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria that he was sorry no efforts were being made to sell American war bonds in Latin-American countries.

The wildcat strike of an estimated 250 longshoremen at six piers of the United States Maritime Commission in Hoboken, N.J., went into its second day yesterday, with officials of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, and the Maritime Commission professing not to know the cause of the stoppage.

Four new films will arrive in midtown theatres this morning. "Bombardier," an RKO topical drama, will be the new attraction at Loew's Criterion. Produced with the cooperation of the Army Air Forces, the Bomber Command and the Bombardier Training Organization at Kirtland Field, Albuquerque, N.M., the film features Pat O'Brien, Randolph Scott, Anne Shirley and Eddie Albert.

The Martinique radio broadcast a statement last night by Admiral Georges Robert, Vichy's High Commissioner on the island, asserting that he had asked the United States Government to dispatch a "plenipotentiary to fix the terms for a change of French authority."

With reference to your Monday editorial on the need for better teaching of American history, you certainly touched on a subject of national interest. In spite of four courses between grade school and college and a good stiff course in government, it took a movie to remind me that Andrew Johnson was not Andrew Jackson and that an impeachment of the President is presided over by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court.

Although the volume of trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the second smallest of any month this year, it was the largest for a June in five years, or since 1938, and total transactions, for the first half of 1943, continued at the most active pace in seven years, or since 1937 for a similar period.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The National War Labor Board reaffirmed today its decision to restrict a wage increase for Akron rubber workers to three cents an hour instead of eight cents as recommended by a board panel.

A resolution favoring the proposed commercial standards for women's slips made from woven fabrics was adopted yesterday at a preliminary conference held under the National Bureau of Standards at the Hotel McAlpin. Minor changes were made in the standards as previously listed in a trade draft.

Herbert L. Matthews is a lucky man. He is able to travel and he finds good places to go to. In June he was in Srinagar, capital of Kashmir: City of Bridges, City of the Sun, Venice of the East. He has been looking at narrow lanes with their overhanging balconies, carved gateways, courtyards, the arched houses along the River Jhelum, once famous as Hydaspes.

IN March, 1935, Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, invited the air attaches of France and England to visit him in his office. There was a roar outside the Ministry as the No. 2 Nazi announced that Germany had not only decided to rearm in the air but had already accomplished the job secretly. Looking, no doubt, like a huge cat that had eaten a half-dozen canaries, Goering led his visitors to the window.

CHUNGKING, China, June 30 -- "China faces her seventh year of war in good spirits," declared Chang Ping-chun, counselor of the Executive Yuan, at the weekly government press conference this afternoon, "certainly not in a spirit of gloom or depression as depicted abroad."

A big white stucco house in a small town not so far away became home yesterday to four of the city's smallest transients. Transients they are because this was the third home that four little brothers have had in not so many more years -- with their own parents, with one set of foster parents and now with a second set.

Round golden peaches, sweet and heavy with juice, form the principal ingredient for one summer-time ice cream made by Sutter's Confections, Inc., in its subterranean kitchens at 403 Bleecker Street. When blended with cream and sugar and eggs according to the shop's own recipe the peaches produce a smooth dessert, not unlike frozen custard, that is free of fruit particles and icy granules.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (U.P.) -- The Office of Price Administration today barred air-raid wardens from the list of civilian volunteers eligible for supplemental gasoline rations and cracked down on the use of government-owned automobiles for nonessential purposes.

Heavy travel yesterday by rail from and to New York was regarded by carrier spokesmen as presaging an extremely busy Fourth of July week-end. Although the week-end had not yet begun, many persons seemed to consider that it had. Railroad men thought that some were attempting to get out of town before the peak of the outbound rush, expected to materialize on Friday.

NEWARK, N.J., June 30 -- Miss Marion Greenberg of this city, who admitted she stole $10,000 from a Bronx electrical contractor last February while he was being entertained in a New York apartment by another woman, was sentenced here today by Common Pleas Judge Richard Hartshorne of Essex County to serve four to nine years in State's prison.

Influenced by the strength in grains, the cotton futures market yesterday rallied sharply as the liquidating movement of recent days seemed to have run its course. Led by the July contract, active futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed at net gains of 8 to 18 points.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Under the system devised by Congress to keep people as nearly abreast of annual income taxes as possible, Treasury officials estimated today that employers would deduct about $500,000,000 a month from the pay of employes under the law going into effect tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission extended today until Jan. 1, 1944, the date by which fifty independent telephone companies must file statements of their proposed methods for keeping certain accounting records.

The American Committee for Protection of Foreign Born, through Carol King, its counsel, announced yesterday that it has undertaken to test in the Federal courts the Government's action in opposing the naturalization of noncitizens who are former members of the Communist party.

William F. Brunner of Rockaway Park, Queens, former Democratic President of the old Board of Aldermen, was appointed to an $1,800-a-year job by Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick on Tuesday, it was disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

YONKERS, N.Y., June 30 -- The Getty Square branch of the Putnam Division, New York Central Railroad, was discontinued tonight, with the last train leaving Yonkers without ceremony at 7:08 for the trip to the Sedgwick Avenue terminal in the Bronx.

Armour Co. of Delaware are notifying holders of their first mortgage 4 per cent bonds, Series B, due on Aug. 1, 1955, that $628,000 of the bonds has been drawn for redemption on Aug. 1 at 102 1/2. The called bonds may be presented for payment to the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago or to the Chase National Bank.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The War Manpower Commission extended to the country's laundries today the same preferential treatment in the allocation of manpower as is given to essential war industries.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Joseph G. Montague, general counsel for the Texas and Southwestern Cattle Raisers Association, put the blame for the meat shortage today on "the unofficial policymakers close to the President," thereby bringing into the open a charge which figured behind the scenes in the Congressional rejection of food subsidies and the retirement of Chester C. Davis as Food Administrator.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Representatives of the Federal Security Agency and of the Federal Works Agency disagreed today in a hearing before the Senate Committee on Public Buildings and Grounds over who should administer the $200,000,000 of additional funds which is being asked for under the Lanham act for child care during the war.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Changes in shoe rationing were announced today by the Office of Price Administration whereby baseball, track and football shoes will not require coupons for purchase beginning July 7.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The White Sox ganged up on Dutch Leonard for three runs in the first inning and knocked him off the mound as they made four more in the fifth tonight to defeat the Senators, 7 to 1, before 29,495 war fund game fans who paid $32,624.50.

People have come to look for news in Mr. Churchill's speeches. He is a great reporter in a supreme observation post while the biggest story of all time is unfolding. Once, musing over the destiny that placed him at the head of the British Government in England's "finest hour," he told a visitor that he would be remembered in history more for what he said in that hour than for what he did in it.

The Japanese-controlled Batavia radio said in a broadcast reported by the Federal Communications Commission yesterday that the United States was becoming "the laughing stock of the whole world" as a result of its domestic disputes.

Lippy Leo Durocher's Dodgers served both themselves and the National War Fund well at Ebbets Field yesterday. They ran roughshod over Mild Will McKechnie's Reds, beating them by 5 -- 0 and 11 -- 5, before a happy crowd of 26,893.

It was a memorable evening for 77-year-old James A. Hopkins last night in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Sixty-sixth Street and Park Avenue. James celebrated his forty-fifth anniversary as company servant of Company K of the Seventh Regiment.

IT should have been a gala occasion. As part of "baseball for Victory Day" the Giants faced the world champion Cardinals at the Polo Grounds yesterday with every penny of the receipts going to the National War Fund. There were pre-game and between-game flourishes. In fact there was everything at hand except the crowd.

LONDON, June 30 (AP) -- Great Britain enjoyed her sixth day without sighting an enemy plane today, while Mustangs and Typhoons shot up twenty locomotives in sweeps over Northern France to cap a record month of aerial warfare in which the Royal Air Force alone dropped at least 13,500 tons of explosives on German targets.

William Hepner, national director of Military and Naval Welfare Service, American Red Cross, and vice-chairman of the Victory Book Campaign, was elected yesterday to the chairmanship of the campaign at a meeting of its board of directors.

One of the first volunteer organizations in the field of war relief work, Bundles for Britain has a record of which it can justly be proud. It has provided through the help of willing workers clothing of all kinds for those made destitute in Britain by the devastation of war.

The employes of the maintenance of equipment department of the Pennsylvania Railroad, New York Division, donated three ambulances yesterday afternoon to the Army in memory of four fellow-workers, who lost their lives in the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Lieut. Col. William Randolph Lovelace 2d, a surgeon and an expert on the Army Air Forces high altitude equipment, made a parachute jump from 40,200 feet, the highest on record in this country, to convince himself and everybody else that the emergency oxygen equipment supplied to Army airmen is all that laboratory tests indicate.

At Pier 88, North River, beside which one of the world's biggest salvage jobs, the refloating of the former French liner Normandie, is now well under way, some 430 Navy enlisted men are undergoing a strenuous fourteen-week course which will turn most of them into salvage divers, Third Naval District headquarters revealed yesterday.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, India, June 24 (Delayed) -- Kashmir's fame and size, but above all her beauty and misery, make it necessary for those interested in India to study her.

Suzanne et Roger placed their early fall hat collection on view yesterday morning in their salon at 24 East Sixty-fourth Street. Finesse is the outstanding characteristic of their chapeaux -- they are spirited and full of coquetry. The brim line is tilted forward and sometimes set gracefully to the side to reveal the profile.
The Regional Office of Civilian Defense called attention yesterday to an outstanding exam ple of the spirit and enterprise of volunteers engaged in this city's great civilian war program.

Reporting on a nation-wide survey of the volume of demand deposits of individuals, partnerships and corporations in banks from Jan. 1, 1942, to March 15, 1943, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in the July 1 issue of its monthly review discloses that manufacturing, mining and construction companies, as a group, and insurance concerns accounted for the principal increases.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- The Red Sox and Tigers, exchanging dramatic ninth-inning home runs, played to a 3 to 3 tie in twelve innings in a twilight game tonight before 13,789 fans who paid an estimated $10,000 to the war fund.

A direct conflict between Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia and the Office of Price Administration appeared inevitable last night, after the Mayor had announced that he had approved, on his own responsibility, a plan for independent slaughterers to sell meat to the public at consumer ceiling prices through consignments to retailers, despite the OPA's objections to the plan.

Increasing shortages of solvents will probably mean further restrictions in production of protective coatings for civilian use, suppliers of raw materials indicated yesterday at a meeting of the New York Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association in the Hotel Biltmore. About 75 per cent of the coating industry's @production is currently being used in war work, it was reported.
BERNE, Switzerland, June 30 -- Despite severe censorship in France, it is becoming known generally that special food coupons are turning out to be worthless.

LONDON, June 30 -- When it comes to working together in the important business of winning the war the fact that one of two allies says "suspenders" while the other says "braces" is not very important. But the fact that one says "monkeywrench" where the other says "adjustable spanner" may be of considerable importance.

Indicating its willingness to broaden the zoning resolution so as to encourage the development of large-scale projects in the city, the City Planning Commission approved yesterday an amendment designed to permit the construction of administrative office and industrial laboratory buildings on landscaped sites in residential sections.
Sir William Beveridge has joined Lady Beveridge at the St. Regis.

CLEVELAND, June 30 -- Nick Etten got the Yankees' second swing through the West started in the right direction tonight at the Municipal Stadium, where his slugging gave the American League champions an eleven-inning victory over the Indians in a struggle that was the clubs' first contribution to the National War Fund, Inc., drive for $500,000.
WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 1 -- Combined Army and Navy forces under General Douglas MacArthur have opened the long expected offensive against the Japanese in the south and southwest Pacific.
Your editorial of June 10, "Sir Isaac's House," was interesting; but may I call attention to a lapsus pennae therein? "Christmas, 1942, was the tri (not bi) centennial of Sir Isaac Newton's birth."
Appropriately enough with the opening of the bass season this morning, a new booklet on the bass waters of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut made its appearance yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The War Labor Board urged employers and employes today to implement the labor-industry no-strike, no-lockout agreement by creating machinery for the prompt handling of grievances that may arise under collective bargaining contracts.

Endorsements of the simplified price-control plan submitted to the nation-wide fur trade by the National Federation of the Fur Industry are coming in strongly from all sections of the country, according to a statement issued yesterday by Walter H. Pringle, president of the federation.

George S. Van Schaick, who retired yesterday as director of the Office of Civilian Defense, Second Region, to return to the New York Life Insurance Company after a year of service as a dollar-a-year man, was succeeded by his deputy director, Sinclair Hatch, who before last November was senior partner of a law firm here.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, June 30 -- Bombers from Northwest Africa and the Middle East converged on the Strait of Messina on Monday night. They hammered Messina, the Sicilian terminus of the train ferry service, which is the shortest line of communication between the island and Italy and Reggio Calabria, one of the mainland ports for the ferries.

ALGIERS, June 30 (AP) -- Dissension between French military and civil authorities broke out today after reports that a newspaper at Oran had been raided last night on orders of the French naval commander there.

A strong National League All-Star squad, dominated by eight of the world champion Cardinals, was announced yesterday for the eleventh annual game with a picked team from the American League at Philadelphia Tuesday night, July 13, The Associated Press reports.

This department is one of the minority -- we have no means of knowing how big or small a minority it is -- that was not exactly carried off its feet by Representative Clare Boothe Luce's "globaloney." It is our own theory that the thing which landed Mrs. Luce's new coinage on the front pages was not the inherent merits of the word, on any level, but the fighting spirit behind it.

The advertising profession will be faced with two extremely difficult jobs in the post-war era -- selling a vastly increased quantity of merchandise and combating the sweep of State socialism by improving the performance of capitalism -- John E. Wiley, vice president of Fuller Smith Ross, declared yesterday at the concluding session of the thirty-ninth annual convention and wartime conference of the Advertising Federation of America at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

Lieut. Gen. Brehon Somerville, commanding the Army Service Forces, warned in an article made public today that a lag in production of equipment urgently needed by the Army threatens the whole strategy and tactical plans of the war.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Thursday, July 1 (AP) -- Supporting the Allied landing operations, Flying Fortresses and Liberators of Lieut. Gen. George C. Kenney's Fifth Air Force pounded the Japanese airfields at Rabaul, New Britain, in five separate sorties through the night of June 29 and the morning of the 30th while strong units of Mitchell medium bombers blasted enemy installations around Salamaua, it was announced here today.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- Grain markets soared today, rye leading the advance on the Board of Trade and closing 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday, while oats were up 1/2 to 1 1/4 cents to a new twenty-three-year peak. Wheat futures rose 1 3/4 to 2 cents.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 30 -- Duplicate sets of the new Ration Book No. 3 have been mailed by mistake to several families here by the New York headquarters of the Office of Price Administration, the White Plains ration board said this afternoon after several residents had appeared voluntarily at the board offices to surrender extra books.

Alex. Brown Sons of Baltimore has announced that Y.E. Booker has become a general partner in the firm and that the business of Y.E. Booker Co., Washington, D.C., has been combined with that of the Washington office of Alex. Brown Sons.

A move to make Fordham Road from Jerome Avenue to Webster Avenue or Fordham Plaza "the Times Square of the Bronx" was supported by Borough President James J. Lyons, the Bronx Board of Trade and the Bronx Chamber of Commerce yesterday at a hearing before the City Planning Commission.
The officially announced theory of rationing is that we must share equally among ourselves the stock of goods within this country.

New York University officials learned yesterday that 142 members of the Army Enlisted Reserve Corps, pre-medical and pre-dental students at the Washington Square College of Arts and Science and the University College of Arts and Pure Science, have been called to active duty.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 30 -- Berlin will evacuate in the Fall women and children not engaged in the war industries, according to reliable information received here today through private channels.

HARTFORD, Conn., June 30 (AP) -- Phil Terranova, Bronx featherweight making his first start since he was stopped by Chalky Wright in Madison Square Garden, knocked out Jackie Callura, N.B.A. featherweight champion from Hamilton, Ont., and Providence, R.I., tonight in the third round of a scheduled ten-round non-title bout at the Auditorium's outdoor arena.

Complaints are beginning to be heard in the export advertising field that South American media, such as newspapers and radio stations, are boosting their advertising rates sharply in order to take advantage of the increased flow of advertising dollars from American manufacturers.
LONDON, June 30 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Winston Churchill's address today in the Guildhall:

The strong support of advertising campaigns in Latin-American media given to United States exporters by governmental agencies here indicates that there is no official intention of "sovietizing" foreign trade in the post-war period, Franklin Johnston, publisher of The American Exporter, declared yesterday.
The report of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and its domestic subsidiary sales company disclosed yesterday a net profit of $548,380 for the quarter ended on March 31 last.

Bullish forces reasserted themselves with such force yesterday that prices on the stock market were pushed forward to the best levels in three years. Ignoring the internal Administration bickerings in Washington but paying close attention to further Congressional dissatisfaction with the domestic economic program, traders returned to the market in force in the afternoon.

BERNE, Switzerland, June 30 -The damage to the Cologne Cathedral in Monday night's raid is the sole topic of discussion in Berlin today and is being extravagantly propagandized. It has received greater publicity than the devastating raids on Wuppertal, which it is now acknowledged caused heavy casualties.

Sixty-six persons attending a committee meeting in Richmond, Va., do not make as dramatic a piece of news as many thousands rioting in the streets of Detroit. Yet out of committee meetings like one held in Richmond this week may come a program which will make future race riots improbable.

Current ceiling prices on green coffee are lower than the average price during the past thirty years, despite an increase of from 33 to 50 per cent in the cost of producing coffee in Latin America, Eurico Penteado, chairman of the Pan-American Coffee Bureau, declared yesterday in giving the viewpoint of the coffee producing countries in connection with a proposed rollback in prices.

We notice in your edition of June 28 a statement by the Citizens Budget Commission asking the City Planning Commission for full publicity on its $678,000,000 post-war public works program. We heartily endorse this request. At the present time very little is known by the public concerning these plans, and in our opinion it would be almost criminal if they were adopted without complete public discussion.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Two moves which may result in prohibiting one form of transportation company from engaging in traffic of another kind were made here today.
