WEST POINT, N.Y., July 1 -- Some 1,200 cadet candidates were sworn in today at the United States Military Academy, the largest plebe class in West Point history. The new cadets are registered from every State in the Union and from many outposts and battlefronts, among them Africa, Panama, Australia and Puerto Rico.

Louis Parisi, 22 years old, was sentenced yesterday in General Sessions to die in the electric chair in the week beginning Aug. 9 for shotting a fellow hold-up man, Vincent Rappa, 27, in front of a candy store at 146 Forsyth Street last July 30.

While conceding that there have been numerous instances of extravagant overbuying by the military procurement offices, Leon Henderson, former OPA Administrator and now chairman of the board of editors of the Research Institute of America, and Leo M. Cherne, executive secretary of the organization, insisted yesterday there was no oversupply of major capital equipment and "war procurement will show little, if any, let-up for the full twelve months ahead."
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:...

LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- While the British, promised that this summer would see fighting on a European front, turned eager attention to General MacArthur's offensive in the Pacific, the Axis, alone in the matter, kept up a clamor of invasion speculation.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune and critic of the Administration, was asked tonight to enter the Illinois preferential primaries in April as a Republican candidate for President.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (U.P.) -- As the government entered its new fiscal year today, its financial condition was reflected in these figures:

St. John's Guild opened its seventy-seventh season yesterday morning when its floating hospital, the Lloyd I. Seaman, left the East Twenty-second Street pier with almost 300 mothers and children aboard. The floating hospital will make daily trips, Sundays excluded, down the bay or up the Hudson, through Sept. 4.

LONDON, July 1 -- Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden highly praised the "invaluable work" of General Dwight D. Eisenhower in his address tonight before the English-Speaking Union, which celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary.

DUBLIN, July 1 -- Eamon de Valera, as leader of the largest party in the new Dail Eireann, which assembled in Leinster House this evening, was elected Premier and has announced the personnel of his government.

Rejecting a plea for an indefinite stay of action, made by the City Council committee investigating the affairs of the La Guardia administration, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to approve a supplemental agreement under which the Welfare Honor Relief Fund of the Department of Sanitation would pay the city about $112,000 for labor, materials and equipment used in the construction and improvement of Sanita Hills, the department's vacation resort at Holmes, N.Y.

LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- The weekly condition statement of the Bank of England, issued today, reported large gains which were technical in nature and reflected to some extent the end of the business half year.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Mrs. Ernest J. Lundeen, widow of the Senator from Minnesota, was a surprise witness today at the second trial of George Sylvester Viereck, alleged German propagandist charged with violating the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

Growing resentment among food retailers over the "gestapo" methods of the city's enforcement officials in enforcement of price ceiling regulations was reported in the trade yesterday. Although grocers were generally reluctant to discuss the matter for publication because of fears of reprisals from City Hall, it was estimated that nearly 2,000 retailers have been hailed before city magistrates for alleged violations of the price laws.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, a leading processor of cottonseed oil products, and its subsidiaries, reported yesterday in a statement of operations for the nine months ended on May 29 a net profit of $2,338.950.

ROCHESTER, July 1 (AP) -- Shelling two Jersey City pitchers for thirteen hits, Rochester took the opening encounter of a three-game series tonight, 11 to 4. Al Schoendienst led the Red Wings' attack with a home run and two singles. Bill Trotter went the route for the Wings.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Roosevelt sought tonight to avert a crisis in the railway industry resulting from dissatisfaction by the fifteen standard "non-operating" railway unions with the reasons advanced today by Fred M. Vinson, Director of Economic Stabilization, for disapproving a wage increase of 8 cents an hour for 1,100,000 railway men, which was recommended by an emergency fact-finding board.

LONDON, July 1 (AP) -- Ever-active Yugoslav guerrillas have smashed an effort by eight Nazi divisions to clear the way for a stand against a possible Allied invasion of the Balkans and have stripped to half its might the Prinz Eugen Division of the German Elite Guard, Yugoslav sources said today.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- An American League All-Star team, heavily laden with Yankees and Indians, was created from nominations submitted by the eight managers for the tenth annual game with the National League stars July 13 in Philadelphia's Shibe Park.
Crowds of passengers leaving and entering the city yesterday indicated a new record for week-end travel. Grand Central Terminal, particularly, did a rushing business with a further increase expected.

" The New Meet the People" is the title Henry Myers, Edward Eliscu, Jay Gorney and Danny Dare have selected for the show they will produce July 26 at the Assistance League Playhouse, Hollywood. It will later come to New York, just as the first "Meet the People," a satirical revue, did.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 1 -- Intensive training of Allied armies involving hundreds of thousands of combat troops and thousands of tanks, ships and aircraft is taking place in North Africa from Casablanca to Cairo as preparations for invasion of Europe go forward.

Gasoline and tire rationing made the trip to Coney Island a bit uncomfortable, but they could not dull the spirits of 6,675 orphans from the metropolitan area who were guests of the New York City Police Anchor Club yesterday at Steeplechase Park.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- During the week ended June 30 member bank reserve balances decreased $138,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. Reductions in member bank reserves arose from increases of $266,000,000 in money in circulation, $161,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, $90,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts and $7,000,000 in Treasury cash, offset in part by increases of $382,000,000 in Reserve Bank credit and $3,000,000 in Treasury currency.

Women today are charged with the two-fold duty of maintaining their homes and helping to turn the wheels of industry, Mrs. Alfred J. Mathebat, president of the American Legion Auxiliary, declared yesterday. She emphasized that these two factors presented a serious challenge.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, June 25 (Delayed) -- The Maharajah of Jammu and Kashmir received me for tea in his little palace.
Most New York and Brooklyn department stores had sharp percentage increases in sales during June, according to a survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Navy announced today sixteen casualties, including four dead, one wounded and eleven missing.

The Dodgers wrote their own version of "It Can't Happen Here" at Ebbets Field yesterday in dropping a 10-9, twelve-inning verdict to the Reds and blowing a golden opportunity to get into first place for the first time since they relinquished that position to the Cards on June 5.
PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- The Pirates scored a 2-1 decision in the second game of a double-header today after dropping the first game to the Phillies, 6-1.

The trustees of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, gave a buffet dinner last night in the museum's sculpture garden after an invitation preview of "Airways to Peace: An Exhibition of Geography for the Future," which will be opened to the public today.

Bank clearings for the twenty-three major cities of the country in the week ended on Wednesday totaled $8,503,080,000, a drop of 6.2 per cent from the amount recorded in the preceding week, but 17 per cent over the 1942 week, when the turnover was $7,266,432,000, according to yesterday's report of Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- The "wonderful job of production" by American industry has contributed greatly to the favorable turn of the war in the last few months, Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, today told a large group of Chicago business leaders.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- Several of the leading prelates of the Orthodox Russian Church have deserted from the organization headed by the Patriarchal incumbent, Sergius, Metropolitan of Moscow and Kolomna, whose ecclesiastical authority as the chief of the orthodox worshipers in the Soviet Union is recognized by the Soviet Government.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 1 (AP) -- Negotiations through which Stokely Brothers Co., Inc., manufacturers of food products, will acquire added working capital were outlined today by William B. Stokely Jr., president.

The matter of medical ethics discussed by Edward G. Griffin in his letter published June 23 is put in a confused status by his failure to separate ethical transgressions that are in no sense illegal from ethical violations that are also legal violations. The latter are truly for the courts to try, as any other violations of the law are tried, whether committed by professional -- legal, medical, ecclesiastical, engineering -- persons or non-professional persons.
Service on another suspended bus route in the city was partly restored yesterday at a hearing of the Public Service Commission in the State Office Building.

Seventeen-year-old Fong On-git, only Chinese in the submarine service, who was graduated sixth out of several hundred students last week at the Navy's Submarine School in New London, Conn., is now in New York as a guest of the city's Chinese-American leaders.

A banner crowd of 20,000, the season's best thus far, turned out to hear Paul Robeson in a guest appearance, at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra led by Alexander Smallens and the Collegiate Chorale directed by Robert Shaw were also on the bill, but by the end of the evening it was unmistakable that Mr. Robeson was the principal attraction.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The total domestic wheat supply for the 1943-44 crop year was estimated today by the Stanford Food Research Institute at 1,280,000,000 bushels.

Commerical banks with government war loan accounts were advised late yesterday that the Treasury will make withdrawals from these accounts on next Tuesday. For the Second Federal Reserve District the call will amount to $187,972,800, and for the nation as a whole to $392,809,900.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Women doctors are not enlisting in the Army. After having fought hard for the privilege, only four have applied for, and received, commissions as officers during the two months they have been entitled by law to apply for commissions. The Army is disappointed over their failure to volunteer.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The gasoline famine probably will spread from the East to the Midwest soon and to the Pacific Coast before the year is out, Secretary Ickes indicated today, thus forcing tighter curbs on motorists throughout the country.

The first of a summer series of outdoor dances sponsored by the Park Department and the Consolidated Edison Company opened last night on the mall at Central Park, where 500 couples swayed, shuffled and glided over the highly waxed marble floor to the strains of Bob Allen's orchestra.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, July 2 -- American forces that landed on Rendova Island have destroyed the enemy garrison, an Allied communique said today, and a headquarters spokesman said occupation of the small but important island was believed "complete."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- Joan Crawford today signed a six years' optional contract with Warners. Her first assignment is in the starring role of a film to be based on the Maritta Wolff novel, "Night Shift," which previously slated for Ann Sheridan, and postponed several times, has since undergone script revision.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Maximum prices for white potatoes and dry onions at other than retail distribution levels were set by the Office of Price Administration today. The potato prices cover sales this month, August and September, and while they give to country shippers 50 to 60 cents more a hundredweight than was allowed through June, consumers may buy at slightly less than current prices, OPA officials said.

The Rev. Dr. Alvin E. Magary of the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, at South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, who has appealed to the Office of Price Administration for review of the recent revoking by the OPA board at 123 Adelphi Street, Brooklyn, of his B gasoline ration book, has the support of the Presbytery of Brooklyn-Nassau, according to an announcement yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Herbert H. Field, executive and stated clerk of the Presbytery.

The physical assets of the United States are worth 12 trillion 23 billion dollars, or $89,000 per capita, according to an article by Secretary of the Interior Harold L. Ickes in the current issue of The American Magazine. The magazine says this is the first computation ever made of this nation's physical wealth.

Characterizing the handling of food problems, price stabilization and labor relations as confusing and controversial "to a deplorable extent," the National City Bank in its July 1 review of business and finance asserts that what is now being determined, through trial and experience, is whether substitution of overhead regulation for the impersonal direction of the price system is practical even in war.

LONDON, Friday, July 2 (AP) -- Russian troops have captured a "German height of great strategic importance" on the front northwest of Moscow and held it against twenty-three counter-attacks in which the enemy lost 600 dead, Moscow announced early today.

YONKERS, N.Y., July 1 -- Walter Moravsky, a battle-scarred veteran of the Navy at the age of 15, returned last night to his home at 436 Walnut Street here, prepared to re-enter the Longfellow Junior High School in the fall.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 1 (AP) -- In the same town where Woodrow Wilson, the father of the League of Nations, lived before he became President, the same League of Nations is making a plan for another new world.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (U.P.) -- Senate and House conferees tonight compromised on a $2,750,000 appropriation for the domestic branch of the Office of War Information. The agreement virtually assured continuance, at least on a limited basis, of the domestic branch which the House previously had voted to abolish.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 1 -- When the Cretan chapter was closed, work on the Cyprus defenses was progressing at fever pitch. Peasant men and women were employed by the thousand to aid the military in the vast projects that resulted in an intricate system of underground communications.

Three gorillas from the Belgian Congo were placed on exhibition yesterday at the Central Park Zoo in a cage adjoining the sea lion pool. They are the gift of an anonymous donor and are said to be the largest single collection of gorillas in any zoo in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- British newspapers, and doubtless the British government and public as well, are concerned over the conflicts that have arisen between Congress and the President. This concern is wholly natural. The British and the Americans are the chief partners in a desperate war, the conduct of which depends for its rate of efficiency on the home front conditions in both countries.

Brazil and Bolivia have concluded a wartime emergency agreement that gives land-locked Bolivia an outlet to the sea by providing for the establishment of a free zone in Brazil's great coffee port of Santos. A minimum of diplomatic fanfare heralded the agreement.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 1 -- American air power dealt another punishing blow to Sicily yesterday when formidable forces of heavy and medium bombers escorted by fighters blasted and scourged the port of Palermo and four key airfields where the aerial defense of the island rests.

Ruling on a protest by Mel Ott, who charged that Babe Dahlgren should have been called out for crossing the batter's box and intentionally getting hit by a pitched ball in the ninth inning of the game between the Giants and Phillies at the Polo Grounds on June 13, President Ford Frick of the National League announced yesterday that the contest had been ordered resumed as of the start of the tenth frame.

Invitations were accepted yesterday by six golfers to play with the ten-man wartime Ryder Cup team in Detroit, Aug. 7-8, against Walter Hagen's All-Stars in the fourth annual challenge series for the benefit of the Red Cross, The Associated Press reports.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- With Bill Dietrich pitching four-hit ball, the White Sox shut out Washington, 2 to 0, today to stay within a fractional percentage point of the first division. Guy Curtright, Chicago rookie, tripled to extend his hitting string to twenty-six consecutive games.

BUENOS AIRES, July 1 -- The police on June 25 suspended the activities of the Junta de la Victoria, a women's organization 50,000 strong with branches throughout Argentina for collecting funds and promoting public sentiment favoring the United Nations, because of official opposition to communism, it now appears.
BERNE, Switzerland ,July 1 -- Rome will not be declared an open city, according to an unsigned editorial in today's Popolo d'Italia, attributable by its style to Premier Mussolini.

Substantial increases in deposits in total resources and in holdings of United States Government securities characterized most of the statements of condition of Wall Street banks, as of June 30, which were made public yesterday. In many instances these figures represented the highest levels in the histories of the respective institutions.

ALGIERS, July 1 -- The French National Committee took decisive steps to liberalize the administration of French North Africa and to hasten the fusion of the armies of Generals Charles de Gaulle and Henri-Honore Giraud at a four-hour meeting today.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 1 -- Superior attack and defense tactics against U-boats brought Allied shipping losses on the seven seas during June to the lowest wartime point, according to figures released by the German Admiralty today.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Gunder Haegg was doubly surprised to-I night at the news that it was his mile record which had been ex-

Acting on complaints that a gambling house in Fort Lee, N.J., operated a shuttle service of automobiles to carry New Yorkers to and from its tables, the police and agents of the Office of Price Administration set up a cordon at the Manhattan end of George Washington Bridge last night, stopped seven limousines and gave summonses to each of the drivers charging violations of the hacking regulations.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- When the Waac ceases to be an auxiliary corps and becomes the Women's Army Corps the 67,000 women who now make up the corps will have to re-enlist into the Army.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The House insisted today on retention, with slight modification, of a provision it inserted in the Labor Department-Federal Security Agency Appropriation Bill designed to prevent the National Labor Relations Board from opening up a jurisdictional labor dispute in three Henry J. Kaiser shipyards on the West Coast.

The services of the Automobile Old Timers, whose board of directors includes Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, Ralph De Palma, Harvey S. Firestone Jr. and other motor car pioneers, were offered to National Petroleum Coordinator Harold L. Ickes yesterday by the club's president, George Conrad Diehl, to "discourage fault-finding with necessary rules and regulations" resulting from the gasoline shortage.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Sears, Roebuck Co. today began mailing 7,000,000 catalogues to its mail-order customers. The new volume is smaller in size than the two preceding editions because of the omission of many "big ticket" items forced by curtailed production.

LONDON, July 1 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that he considered it necessary that Gen. Henri Honore Giraud should remain in supreme command of the French military forces, at least for the present.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed holdings of United States Government securities to be the highest on record, having increased $454,056,000 during the week.

STOCKHOLM, July 1 -- Arne Anderson, 27-year-old school teacher, ran a mile in 4 minutes 2.6 seconds today at the Swedish National Festival track meet in Goeteborg to cut two seconds from Gunder Haegg's recognized world mark of 4:04.6.

Increasingly heavy shipments of potatoes have brought about a drop of 1 to 2 cents in price since last Friday. The quality is far better than it has been, according to a spokesman for the Consumers Service Bureau of the Department of Markets, who points out that the Virginia variety is particularly clean, large and free from decay.

ALGIERS, July 1 (AP) -- Dr. Georges Giraud, brother of Gen. Henri Honore Giraud, French Commander in Chief in North Africa, declared today as one newly escaped from occupied France that "the people of France are neither Giraudist nor de Gaullist -- they are against the Boche."

Twenty charitable institutions, churches and hospitals share $3,593,332 from the estate of Josiah Locke Webster, it was shown yesterday in the estate tax appraisal filed here. Mr. Webster, who died in Miami, Fla., on Feb. 28, 1942, was a brother of the late Charles Bertram Webster, one of the founders and a former head of R.H. Macy Co.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Creation of the Petroleum Reserves Corporation "to acquire petroleum, petroleum products and petroleum reserves outside the Continental United States" was announced today by Jesse Jones, Secretary of Commerce.

Federal revenues from alcoholic beverages for the first five months of this year totaled $607,740,292, an increase of $5,000,000 above the collections from the industry during the entire calendar year of 1939, according to a study released yesterday by Allied Liquor Industries, Inc.

IT was hot. A storm was blowing up and the clouds were already clinging to the higher peaks of Manhattan. I was reading one of the more promising books of the spring that had never been noticed in these columns and had just exclaimed while on page 66, "This is quite lovely," when the young woman reporter walked into the Books of the Times office.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 1 -- The New York State Association of Real Estate Boards called upon the Federal Government today to revise sharply its residential rent control practices in the State on a basis that would be "fair and equitable" to property owners.

Warning Office of Price Administration enforcement attorneys that the OPA was under accusation of being "un-American" and of "trying to destroy business," Chief Hearing Commissioner Harry B. Chambers declared yesterday that it would be his policy to penalize violators of the regulations but not to destroy them, as he handed down a decision to which enforcement attorneys violently objected.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS FOR SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, July 1 -- A series of advances by American forces in the Southwest Pacific, comprising an attack on the New Georgia Islands, occupation of the Trobriands and Woodlark Island and invasion of the Salamaua area through a landing on Nassau Bay, New Guinea, represents the biggest single offensive move yet made by the Allied forces in the Pacific against the Japanese.

The Office of Defense Transportation came to the defense of New York City's taxicab drivers yesterday to deny charges, which have, seeped in from New Jersey from time to time, that they were carrying vacationists to Summer resorts beyond the limits permitted for such conveyance.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Ten Army officers were nominated by the President today to the temporary rank of major general and forty-seven to the temporary rank of brigadier general.

Advertisers were urged yesterday to "put farming on the front line" by dramatizing the important role of food in total war and by acknowledging the farmer's contribution to victory. In a joint appeal by the War Advertising Council and the Department of Agriculture, advertisers were told they could help elevate farm produce to its rightful place in American thinking, on the same level of war importance with guns, planes, tanks and ships.

ONE debt American sports ever will owe Australia is the famed Australian crawl stroke which revolutionized our swimming before it gave way to the perfected six-and eight-beat crawl of the present day. Storky Adams, the Man From Down Under, dropped by the other day, surrounded by his usual wreath of pipe smoke and his usual air of enthusiasm.

Balance between dress and hat offered the major consideration of Florence Reichman's study in evolving her military line for the fall. In her own mind, and for the audience present at her showing yesterday morning, she created a picture of the woman as she will step out of her front door in her new togs.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The War Department made public today the names of 312 more American soldiers reported through the International Red Cross as having died from disease in Japanese prison camps since the fall of Bataan and Corregidor.

The United States Government ended its fiscal year on June 30 with a Treasury position that defies comparison with all previous records in the nation's history. Revenues for the year were 21 billion dollars, which is four times the immediate pre-war average. Expenditures were 76 billion, ten times the pre-war average and four times the peak year of spending in the First World War.

ABOARD U.S. FLAGSHIP OF A DESTROYER DIVISION, between Rendova Island and Munda Point, June 30 (delayed) -- An all-out American assault on the Japanese stronghold of New Georgia Island got away to a flying start at dawn this morning. The brilliantly conceived and daringly executed plan caught the Japanese flat-footed; the landing of men and materials had actually begun before the enemy shore batteries opened fire at this destroyer screen.

The General Motors Corporation is turning out tanks, planes, guns, trucks and more than 2,000 items for the armed forces at the rate of more than $10,000,000 a day, C.E. Wilson, president, announced yesterday in Detroit.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The verbal battle between Vice President Henry A. Wallace and Secretary of Commerce Jesse Jones led Senator Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, to propose today that the Senate Military Committee investigate relations between the Board of Economic Warfare and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in purchasing war materials.

The Office of Price Administration won the Battle of Long Island Sound yesterday in Federal court, whereupon the motor steamer Americana ran up a figurative white flag and ended its outlaw voyaging to Playland at Rye, N.Y.

Payment of the $12,500 salary of Assistant Superintendent of Schools Joseph M. Sheehan, whose position was cut out of the 1943-44 school budget by Mayor La Guardia last April, has been discontinued by order of Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick, it became known yesterday.

MILAN, Mich., July 1 (AP) -- Saved from death by a Presidential commutation of sentence, Max Stephan "collapsed on a chair and burst into tears" when he learned the news, a Department of Justice representative said today. The traitor kissed the hands of Cecil J. Shuttleworth, warden of the Federal Correctional Institution, when the warden told him of the order.
LONDON, July 1 -- On the stock markets today shares of F.W. Woolworth Co., Ltd., rose 1 1/4s to 55s after yesterday's rapid fall on news that the company had cut its interim dividend in half.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Prices for agricultural commodities in primary markets, particularly grains, meats and potatoes, dropped sharply during the week ended June 26, and the Bureau of Labor Statistics all-commodity index of nearly 900 series fell 0.4 per cent to 103.1, the lowest level since March.

LONDON, July 1 (U.P.) -- British-based bombers of the Royal Air Force, blasting Axis targets from Germany to Italy in the greatest month of the unparalelled air offensive, dropped a record-breaking total of more than 15,800 tons of bombs on Europe in June, a recapitulation showed today.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- Don Black of the Athletics, who shut out the Browns on one hit Memorial Day, was almost as effective for ten innings today but he weakened in the eleventh and was defeated, 2 to 1.

Six trains filled,with 1,450 youths between 17 and 19 years of age left Grand Central Terminal yesterday bound for thirteen Eastern colleges to participate in the Navy's V-12 Specialized Training Program. Another car of trainees headed for Cornell University departed from Lackawanna Terminal, Hoboken, N.J., in mid-morning.
In a continuance of the demand for loft properties investors yesterday purchased several buildings of this type in Manhattan.

Thirty-eight women volunteers who take time off from plotting the course of planes to interview applicants for similar duties are responsible for the splendid record of the Army Aircraft Warning Service. Due to their skillful screening of applicants, not a single member of the group to date has been prosecuted under the Espionage Act, which forms the basis of the oath all volunteers must take when sworn in by the Army.
Will the sportsmen help the farmers? The answer, of course, is unanimously in the affirmative.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Miss Dot Kirby of Atlanta, Ga., and Miss Patty Berg of Minneapolis shot sub-par golf at Glen Oak today to defeat their young Eastern rivals and move into the thirty-six hole championship round of the women's Western open tournament.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 1 -- Representatives of the Empire City Racing Association and of the four trotting race associations in the State unanimously agreed today, at a conference with James C. Hagerty, executive assistant to Governor Dewey, that a joint trotting meet will be held at the Empire track July 26 through Labor Day.
CLEVELAND, July 1 -- The amazing generosity of Charley Wensloff, coupled with Ken Sears' hesitancy in picking up a topped ball, stopped the Yankees today, as the Indians won 3 to 2.

The ambition of City Councilman Adam Clayton Powell Jr., to run next year for Representative in the new Congressional district in Harlem has prevented settlement of a contest for Tammany leader of the Twenty-first Assembly District, it was revealed yesterday.
It seems to me that the gasoline problem has clear-cut aspects: How much can we manufacture, how much do our fighting forces need? What is left should be equally divided among civilians.

CHUNGKING, China, July 1 (U.P.) -- The Japanese, fighting desperately to save Owchihkow, one of their last footholds in the rich Tungting Lake region, have attempted to send reinforcements to their encircled forces there, but Chinese troops intercepted the rescue column, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek's High Command announced tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hover, FBI Director, declared today that law-enforcement agencies could no longer refuse to answer "the challenge presented by crime among young men and women."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Indications here tonight were that, as a result of the offer of Admiral Georges Robert, Vichy's High Commissioner in Martinique, to negotiate "a change of French authority," that island and the others of the French Antilles, the last remaining overseas outposts of the Vichy regime, would soon join the United Nations.

BOSTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Cubs jumped into a five-run lead today but then had all they could do to preserve their seasonal mastery over the Braves by eking out a 6-5 decision. It was the seventh Cub victory over the Braves without defeat this year.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- New fuel was added today to the bullish sentiment of the Board of Trade by the announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation would purchase cash wheat at the Government's loan price from farmers who cooperated in the farm program and that the loan had been advanced 1 cent a bushel.

A Government-sponsored effort to mediate the controversy over records ended in fifteen minutes yesterday afternoon when James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, announced that the union no longer was interested in negotiating a settlement and intended to stop the transcription industry permanently.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The War Production Board's building materials division is considering the possibility of directing a proportion of hardware production to fill low-rated orders, it was announced here today. The move has been suggested in order to make more adequate provision for essential civilian needs.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Department store sales for the week ended June 26 were 19 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This followed an increase of 28 per cent for the week ended June 19, compared with the like week of 1942.

A 72-to-1 shot speeded around the Jamaica turn leading into the home stretch and winged his way for the wire, being caught only in the last stride and beaten a nose by Arnold Hanger's Dit. A field of eleven went to the post in the race, the Irish Dream purse, Empire City's highlight yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 -- Patents covering production of vitamin D, reported to have yielded royalties exceeding $7,500,000 to the University of Wisconsin Alumni Research Foundation, were held invalid today by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- New York State's plan for maternity care for the wives and infants of non-commissioned men of the armed services has been approved and cleared by the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr. proved today that the advent of pay-as-you-go taxation found the American people still with lots of money to lend to their Government by announcing that this week's offer of $2,500,000,000 of 1 1/2 per cent Treasury notes had brought in between $19,000,000,000 and $20,000,000,000 of subscriptions.

Japan, with her supply of labor and raw materials, is in a potential position to become the "most powerful nation in the world," J.B. Powell, former editor of The China Weekly Review and The China Press, Shanghai, declared yesterday.

Cotton prices yesterday advanced to new seasonal highs under aggressive buying by trade houses, New Orleans and commission houses. The new buying was influenced partly by strength in the grain markets and by developments in Washington, which indicated higher prices to some traders.

Japanese Imperial Headquarters acknowledged yesterday that American troops had landed on Rendova Island, in the Solomons, but reported that Japanese naval planes had sunk or heavily damaged six American transports, three cruisers and a destroyer.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 -- Officials of the War Production Board came to Pittsburgh today with a plea to rank-and-file iron workers and management that they exceed last year's capacity production. They were told by the United Steel workers, through their president, Philip Murray, that mill men would fill the bill if they are provided with sufficient fuel to fire their furnaces.

Random House announces that Peter Burchette, Burma and India correspondent of The London Daily Express, has been signed to write a book on the adventures of "Wingate's mob" in Burma this spring. Brigadier Wingate, with a handpicked group of British Army men, crossed the Japanese lines into Burma last February, and after four months of guerrilla fighting behind the lines, managed to cross into British-held territory in May.

City people are becoming increasingly aware of the paradox that while there is now a shortage of meat in the cities there is a surplus of meat on the farms. It is generally recognized that it is the Government's price policies that have brought about this anomalous situation.

Despite periodic profit-taking and lapses in demand, the stock market pushed forward again yesterday to new high ground under the continued stimulus of inflationary psychology and favorable war developments. Even though business at times tended to lighten, volume hit its best stride in more than two weeks with a return to the million-share tempo on the Stock Exchange, transfers there being 1,152,580 shares, compared with 942,410 on Wednesday.

Mr. Churchill was made an honorary freeman of the City of London Wednesday. This gift of the freedom of the city to distinguished visitors is known among us but accompanied with less ceremonial and with slight appreciation of the origin of the custom. In London, perhaps we may say roughly in any medieval city, while the guilds were in their prime, citizenship was prized.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The first great air battle reported in the new battle of the south and southwest Pacific resulted in the destruction of at least sixty-five out of 110 Japanese planes that attempted to interfere with the landing of United States forces at Rendova Island, the Navy reported today.

With millions of men in the armed forces becoming accustomed to slacks and shirts as outer apparel, the clothing industry is faced with a threat that will call for the injection of new designing, advertising and merchandising ideas to offset the trend when the mustering-out process comes, Ralph Schneider, president of Broadstreet's, told the sixty seventh semi-annual meeting of the International Association of Clothing Designers yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia opened up a second front in his fight against the Office of Price Administration yesterday. Accusing it of responsibility for a threatened serious shortage of eggs in this city, he appealed direct to the new Food Administrator, Marvin D. Jones, to prevent the shortage.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- It was reported here today that the Germans have launched a campaign against the Soviet Partisans on a bigger scale than any previous similar operation in occupied Russia. It is not yet known whether the new drive differs, other than in scale, from the earlier ones, which often have been intended to "blood" inexperienced troops before moving them into line.

Out of 130 Negro boys examined in a Harlem boys' club health contest, not a single case of congenital disease, only one case of acquired venereal disease and only two cases of tuberculosis were found, it was announced yesterday at the presentation of awards to the winners at the club in the Children's Aid Society's Harlem Center, 28 West 134th Street.

The right to own property, guaranteed as inalienable by the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, was defended last night by former Governor Alfred E. Smith in one of the "long talks" at the Tammany Society's celebration of the 157th anniversary of its founding and the 167th anniversary of American independence.
MOSCOW, July 1 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued the following communique:
The writer of Topics of The Times today chooses odd facts on which to base an unfavorable comparison between Australian labor policy and that of the old school tie colonial.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Tokie Slocum, a Japanese-American now employed by the War Manpower Commission, told the Dies committee today that he relayed to the Federal Bureau of Investigation a warning which he had received in November, 1941, that war was impending between Japan and the United States, but was "laughed at."

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 1 -- A large part of Naples has been smashed almost to rubble, port installations wiped out and residential areas of the great Italian seaport city are largely uninhabitable, according to a competent eyewitness, a neutral traveler who arrived in Turkey this week direct from Italy after having undergone incessant Allied bombardments.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 1 -- The top man in the 1943 tennis picture to date, Francisco (Pancho) Segura, started out in quest of another title today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- A registration statement covering $37,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1973 was today filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Utah Power and Light Company, a holding company in the Electric Bond and Share Company system.
LEESBURG, Va., July 1 (AP) -- Zev, Kentucky Derby winner in 1923 and one of the great thoroughbreds of the American turf, is dead at the age of 23.
Navy communique 429:
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The long expected and long delayed offensive in the South Pacific has started.

PRINCETON, N.J., July l -- Although President Roosevelt has been sharply criticized by many Southern political leaders and writers, his standing among the rank and file of Southern Democratic voters as a candidate for 1944 is virtually as high as among Democrats elsewhere.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) -- Tom M. Girdler, chairman, and R.J. Wysor, president, of the Republic Steel Corporation, asserted today that the Government must develop "orderly, swift procedure" enabling business to make a quick changeover to peacetime production in the post-war period.

In ordinary times people would be amazed to see top-line members of an Administration violently attacking each other; but these are not ordinary times. So unusual are today's circumstances and so great the strain on men in responsible posts that we may see things even stranger.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary Ickes said today that next Winter might find the country short of coal and that coal rationing was "still a possibility."

The Port of New York is handling almost twice the outgoing cargo of 1917-18 and its eight trunk line railroads are carrying double the freight and passengers they did in the first World War, Carl H. Henrikson Jr., regional business consultant of the United States Department of Commerce, declared in a report on transportation in the New York region which was made public here yesterday.

Thus far, judging from the official communiques, the American drive, in which all arms are participating and which is aided by the Australian air force, is proceeding "satisfactorily and successfully according to plan." Advancing along a 750-mile arc from northeast of New Guinea to the New Georgia Island group, the American forces have established beach heads on Rendova Island, from which they are now battling the enemy.

Money in circulation in the United States jumped $266,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday. This is one of the largest weekly increases in the history of the nation, although the record increase was $294,000,000 on June 2.

DETROIT, July 1 (AP) -- Ned Harris lined a pinch single to left field with the bases loaded in the ninth to break a tie and give the Tigers a 3-to-2 victory over the Red Sox in a twilight game tonight.

In selling merchandise to one another, or "up stream," as permitted under L-219 for he purpose of balancing stocks, furniture retailers must not charge more than the "out-of-pocket" cost plus charges actually paid or incurred for transportation in ordinary channels of distribution, except charges for local trucking and unloading, according to an interpretation received from the OPA by the National Retail Furniture Association.

Something has happened on the island of Martinique, where Admiral Georges Robert has been clinging stoutly to his peculiar theory of "neutrality" plus allegiance to the Vichy "government." It is time something happened, for besides immobilizing a cruiser, an airplane carrier, a mine layer, four cargo ships and six tankers for which patriotic Frenchmen could find use, the Robert regime has been an unfriendly outpost in a strategic position.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Hopes of Congress to get away this week for a summer recess were virtually abandoned today as appropriation bill snarls left three Government departments and a score of war agencies without new funds with which to start the fiscal year, which began at midnight.
LONDON, Friday, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Russian midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor here:

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- President Roosevelt late today commuted the death sentence of Max Stephan of Detroit because he regarded the penalty as too harsh for his treasonous crime of aiding Hans Peter Krug, Nazi flier, in his break from a prison camp in Canada in April, 1942.

On many fronts efforts are being made to reduce accidents of all kinds, in order to conserve manpower. Important gains in this respect have been made by the War Production Fund to Conserve Manpower, working through the National Safety Council. Now the problem is about to be tackled on another front.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Friday, July 2 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:
BERNE, Switzerland, July 1 -- National discipline and iron nerves are demanded of the German people by Dr. Joseph Goebbels in this week's issue of the magazine Reich.

Abe Frosch, Brooklyn bail bondsman, who is reported to have talked frequently to John Harlan Amen when the latter was investigating alleged official wrongdoing in Brooklyn, was arrested yesterday as the head of a Brooklyn lottery ring that was supposed to have a daily take of $1,000.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Senator Claude Pepper of Florida has introduced a bill designed to provide loans for military personnel and merchant seamen to help them in acquiring an education and job-training opportunities on their return from service.

Max Blauner, dress manufacturer here since 1929, testified yesterday as the thirteenth State witness against Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, ex-convict, on trial in General Sessions accused of extortion, that "because of fear," he had paid $44,000 to the Lepke-Gurrah gang.

The garage building on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 712 Thirty-ninth Street, in the heart of the Bush Terminal area in Brooklyn, has been sold by the Vandevoort Realty Corporation. The buyer at once leased it to the Sperry Gyroscope Company of Brooklyn for three years.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The United States and Great Britain are putting new planes into the skies over Europe faster than the enemy can shoot them down, and a "greatly worried" Axis is shifting troops around, attempting to guess where a land blow may be struck, Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson declared today at his press conference.

The National Urban League, following an investigation of the race riots in Detroit, issued a report yesterday which stated that back of the rioting were very poor and inadequate housing for a rapidly growing Negro population, discrimination in employment, and a feeling among the rank and file of Negroes that they have been "entirely neglected by the white community and by much of the Negro leadership."

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 2 -- Dr. Margaret Janeway of New York City was sworn in as a major in the Army Medical Corps yesterday after she had been discharged as a first lieutenant in the Women's Army Corps. She thus became the first woman doctor in the United States Army in the North Afircan theatre and the second in the entire Army.

While orders for motors and generators are beginning to decline sharply, the industry still has a backlog of business that will keep it operating at full capacity on the average for the next nine months to a year, according to reports this week.

LONDON, Saturday, July 3 (U.P.) -- A Berlin broadcast reported today that German forces had retreated to a new defense line in the Dorogobuzh sector, fifty miles east of Smolensk, under the impact of repeated Russian attacks.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Navy stated today that not a single ship among the "thousands" of transports and supply vessels which its new non-rigid airships have escorted has been lost while under protection of the blimps.

The Appellate Division ruled unanimously yesterday that Fire Commissioner Patrick Walsh had no right to pass over for appointment civil service eligibles who had 3-A draft classification but who were subject to reclassification in 1-A under new Selective Service regulations.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 2 (AP) -- RAF heavy bombers, in blasting sluices at Duisburg May 12 and at Oberhausen June 14, paralyzed traffic on the Rhine-Herne Canal, eyewitness reports from Germany declared today. Herne, in Westphalia, is about twenty-two miles northwest of Duisburg, which is at the junction of the Rhine and Ruhr.

A Federal Circuit Court of Appeals has decided that the sun anticipated Dr. Harry Steenbock by many hundred million years in the art of generating vitamin D in foods and organic matter. Hence the Steenbock patents which disclose a process of irradiating foods with ultraviolet lamps or artificial suns to impart anti-rachitic properties to foods are invalid.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- Claude Passeau's four-hit pitching gave the Cubs a sweep of their four-game series with the Braves today as the visitors racked up a 7-1 verdict to extend their seasonal domination over Boston to eight victories in as many games.

LONDON, July 2 -- An outstanding movement today in the stock markets here was a fresh jump of 3s 9d to 90s in Blyvoor in the Kaffir mining group, which of course was a new high level. The price of these 10s shares was 3s in 1940.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 2 (AP) -- Pinch Hitter Walter Alston's outfield fly, with one out in the tenth, scored Pinch Runner Johnny Morrow from third base with the run that gave Rochester a 1-0 victory over Jersey City tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -- Agents of the Office of Price Administration assigned to two bridges between Philadelphia and points across the Delaware River in the drive to shut off holiday pleasure driving to seashore points, said today that "up to 50 per cent" of the drivers they stopped had doctors' certificates stating that their trips were necessary for their health.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Navy Department "retreated" tonight on its recently announced regulations requiring changes in gold stripes, gold braid and the color of shirts worn by naval officers.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 2 -- The Rev, Fletcher D. Parker, pastor of Immanuel Congregational Church here, lost today the use of his clerical "C" gasoline ration coupons and his two "A" books until Oct. 1 for openly driving his automobile to his summer home at Lake Sunapee, 140 miles away, in violation of OPA rules.

Increasing prices and the growing shortage of distilled spirits have brought an increase in the number of hijackings and burglaries of liquor, and underwriters here anticipate a mounting volume of losses as the shortage becomes more severe, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Forty-eight large and medium-sized companies engaged primarily in war production have made "excessive profits" after deduction of taxes which range up to 53 per cent on the market value of their stock, Representative Albert J. Engel, Republican, of Michigan, contended in the House today.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Bank deposits in Chicago have crossed the $6,000,000,000 mark for the first time, and the long downward sweep in loans and discounts was almost halted in the second quarter of this year. These developments were disclosed today in bank statements as of June 30, issued in response to State and Federal calls.

American bombs bursting on Nazi airfields around Salonika and Athens have kindled fires that are spreading far back into the Balkans. Greek patriots rioting in the cities, and Greek and Yugoslav guerrillas massing in the mountains, accept these raids as a promise that the hoped-for Allied invasion is not far off.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Carl E. Newton, Deputy Coal Mine Administrator, completed today a series of conferences with spokesmen for the UMWA and the bituminous coal operators with a view to speeding up coal production.

CLEVELAND, July 2 -- Counsel for four stockholders in the old Union Trust Company filed today an amended petition in Common Pleas Court attacking the reorganization plan under which the Union Bank of Commerce was set up in 1938.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Three of the four Senators who sponsored a comprehensive resolution designed to put Congress on record on its post-war international policies gave notice to the Senate today that they would insist on prompt action on their proposal after the summer Congressional recess ends.

The Maryland-New York Province of the Society of Jesus, in which there were 1,700 Jesuits, was divided yesterday into the Maryland Province and the New York Province. In the former are such large institutions as Georgetown University in Washington and in the latter Fordham University.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The text of President Roosevelt's veto of the CCC-Subsidies Bill was as follows:

So the National Football League intends to operate as usual next fall. How wonderful! What a sight it will be to see the pros play while thousands of college and university stars, annually responsible for the main appeal of football, are serving their country.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The index of retail store sales in May showed an increase over April after allowance for seasonal changes, the Department of Commerce reported today. The department's seasonally adjusted index of sales of all stores was at 158, based on the 1935-39 average, and represented the highest level attained this year except for the peak months of February and March.

Possibly still in a coma as a result of Thursday's terrible twelfth inning, the Dodgers rolled over and played dead for the Reds in yesterday's twilight game at Ebbets Field before a ladies' day gathering of 9,307 fans, most of whom spent the time booing their erstwhile idols.

I read with interest Frank McCabe's letter in THE TIMES last Saturday. He gave a list of New York baseball players and expressed the belief that no other city represented in the major leagues can match it. In rebuttal I give you the Philadelphia story.

ALGIERS, July 2 -- The political situation here is quieter than it has been since the Allies first landed last autumn. Although much difficult work lies ahead of the French Committee of National Liberation, there is little chance that the group's power will be challenged by any individual or group of individuals.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The rugged life of the South Pacific does not daunt Army nurses, according to Maj. Edna Mahar, who has just returned. For two and a half months Major Mahar has been director of nurses in the South Pacific area and for ten months before that she was chief nurse at Base Section 2 in the Southwest Pacific area.
The firm name of Chandler Hovey Co. is to be changed to Mixter Co., effective on July 8, according to the New York Stock Exchange.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 2 -- There has been a move to re-establish normal diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union, the Polish Premier, Gen. Wladislaw Sikorski, announced at a press conference in Cairo today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UP) -- The special Eastern Seaboard Congressional Committee demanding an easing of gasoline restrictions in thirteen Northeastern States approved today plans to "go to the White House" in an effort to gain removal of the Eastern pleasure driving ban and bring an increase in crude oil prices.

CHUNGKING, China, July 2 (U.P.) -- Japanese reinforcements have managed to break through Chinese lines to strengthen the encircled enemy garrison at Owchihkow, in the heart of the Tungting Lake region, and fighting is in progress in the city's outskirts, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

The Army Air Force has offered the senior Girl Scout Troops of Greater New York the opportunity to help directly in this nation's war program. Volunteers are needed to man the Aircraft Warning Center of the New York Air Defense Wing, and an "alert" was sounded yesterday for 300 workers.

The stucco gambling house atop the Palisades that Jersey justice could not find yesterday, although its fame had led New York City police and Office of Price Administration agents to halt its rented limousines, was locked last night for the first time in the recent memory of residents of the neighboring small homes.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- A probable Presidential veto of the Commodity Credit Corporation bill banning payment of subsidies forecast in reports from Washington, turned the grain markets downward today on the Board of Trade.
We are getting back to the Horatio Alger feeling about the American Dream.

ALGIERS, July 2 (AP) -- The newspaper Echo d'Alger published today what it described as a joint resolution signed by ten French political groups expressing "uneasiness caused by anything that might constitute limitation of national sovereignty."

In a three-to-two decision, the Appellate Division upheld yesterday the validity of the contract approved by the Board of Estimate for the construction of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's post-war "Stuyvesant Tom" housing project.

Columbia's "Crime Doctor," starring Warner Baxter, will open this morning at the Globe Theatre. The melodrama, which is a screen version of the radio program of the same name, is the first film in a proposed series. In featured roles are Margaret Lindsay, John Litel, Ray Collins, Harold Huber, Constance Worth and Leon Ames.

It is only fair to the farmers that the public be told the facts regarding the present deplorable farm machinery condition. Farmers are lining up before machinery dealers every day, endeavoring to purchase new equipment or get their old equipment repaired.

Including note issues of seventeen local housing authorities throughout the country, new municipal financing next week will aggregate $63,383,100, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. This compares with this week's total of $14,083,687, and with the weekly average for the year to date of $16,662,076.

The charge made Thursday by spokesmen for the Army Surgeon General's Office, Washington, D.C., that women doctors are not volunteering for Army service now that the way has been opened to them by Congress, was answered yesterday by Dr. Emily Dunning Barringer, who led the women doctors in their fight for commissions.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, July 3 -- Australian jungle fighters from the interior have joined American troops at Nassau Bay on the New Guinea coast in a move threatening the southern approaches to the Japanese base at Salamaua, a communique revealed today, and the ground situation is unchanged on New Georgia Island in the central Solomons where United States troops are headed for the Munda base.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- No more than 5 to 6 per cent of the country's total fabric and yarn production will be shipped abroad this year, Frank L. Walton, head of the textile, clothing and leather division of the War Production Board, asserted today.

LONDON, July 2 (Netherland News Agency) -- The Germans have staged a secret trial in a concentration camp of Netherland Army officers and other leading Hollanders and have sentenced "a fairly large number" of them to death, the Netherlands Government in London revealed tonight.

New issues of bonds offered to the public this week declined to $3,308,000 for two municipal loans from $57,428,000 for six diversified offerings last week and from $35,575,000 in the corresponding week of 1942, when $35,000,000 represented an industrial flotation and the balance, a tax-exempt issue.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Army is sticking by its guns on intercollegiate football. There is no official ruling against soldiers in the specialized training program engaging in sports but, more important, there is no time, officers say.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) -Truett (Rip) Sewell, whose slow ball keeps National League batters guessing, won his eleventh victory of the season against two defeats today as the Pirates downed the Phillies, 2 to 1, before a ladies' day crowd of 3,667 in Shibe Park.

Reversing a Supreme Court decision, the Appellate Division invalidated yesterday under the State anti-monopoly law an agreement between Ohrbach's, Inc., and two manufacturing firms under which Ohrbach's received exclusive local right to sell garments of the manufacturers at retail and the manufacturers refused to sell to Alexander's Department Stores, Inc., in the Bronx.
It is my belief that major league managers are making a great mistake in exaggerating the potentialities of a right-handed batter against a left-handed pitcher or vice versa.

Dr. Ferdinand A. Kertess, who smuggled vital materials out of this country to his native Germany, received yesterday an opportunity to exchange $16,000 for two years of liberty. Although he is reputed to be well off, he passed up the chance, and his attorney said he was forced to do so by lack of funds.
The following warning was issued yesterday by the Greater New York Safety Council:

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- Less than ten months after it instituted "death sentence" proceedings against the Community Gas and Power Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order today directing the break-up of the holding company system.

MEXICO CITY, July 2 -- Mexican authorities today announced that extraordinary precautions were being taken all over the country to prevent disorders and bloodshed in the campaigning for the election next Sunday of 147 members of the new Chamber of Deputies and six State Governors.

The Society of Ethical Culture has sold the two-family house on a plot 25 by 100 at 2150 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, to Josephine Delillo for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $3,000, which was taken back by the seller. The Richard C. Califano Company was the broker.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -- Secretary Knox has awarded the Silver Star Medal to Captain Howard K. Goodman, U.S.M.C., 25, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Goodman of Long Beach, L.I. Captain Goodman formerly lived at 1660 Crotona Park East, New York.

Axis broadcasts, perhaps intended to cushion an announcement of the loss of further southwest Pacific territory by the Japanese, sought yesterday to minimize the importance of the United States offensive in the New Guinea-Solomons area.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS FOR THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, Saturday, July 3 -- Heavy American air bombing of the Japanese-held Vila airdrome on Kolombangara Island and thirty miles northwest of Munda has neutralized this field.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 2 -- College players were in possession of the field at the end of the quarter-final round of the New Jersey State tennis singles championship today at the Elizabeth Town and Country Club.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- Secretary Knox said here today that when he left Washington the Navy was planning to renegotiate the abrogated contract with Standard Oil Company of California for the operation and conservation of the Elk Hills oil fields in this State.

The cotton market was easier yesterday on the veto by President Roosevelt of the anti-subsidy bill. Selling at no time, however, was heavy, and in view of the recent rise in quotations the decline was considered moderate. On the New York Cotton Exchange final quotations lost 2 to 8 points, with the smallest decline in the distant months.
NOUMEA, New Caledonia, July 2 -- Fifteen months ago I was chased out of the Far East by the Japanese. Today I am on my way back, traveling with American forces in the South Pacific.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Roosevelt vetoed the bill extending the Commodity Credit Corporation and forbidding food subsidies.

Although an air of indecision hung over the stock market yesterday, primarily as a result of the approach of a lengthened weekend, the firm undertone was unaltered. Best prices were scored during the first and final hours, with the interim reserved for backing and filling movements of no particular consequence.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The feud between Vice President Wallace and Jesse H. Jones, Secretary of Commerce, was touched on informally today as Mr. Jones appeared before the House Rules Committee to testify on the need of an investigation of United State aid in developing the Canadian Shipshaw power and aluminum project.

LONDON, July 2 (U.P.) -- Asserting that the United States has nothing which compares with the British Home Guard, Brig. Gen. Dwight H. Mohr, commanding General of the Maryland State Guard, said today that he would urge the War Department to take over all State Guard programs in America, drafting for home service all men now exempt from the Army due to dependents, health, or vital war jobs.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 2 -- Italy has no choice but to stand united and to resist impending events, says an editorial in today's Giornale d'Italia of Rome, explaining again that if the country dropped out of the fighting now it would gain nothing and be transformed into a "bloody battlefield."

Today's events: American program, Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Morton Gould, Lewisohn Stadium, 8:30 P.M.; Kraeuter Trio in Victory concert, New York Public Library, 5:30; Goldman Band, Prospect Park, Brooklyn, 8:30.

District Office of Price Administration authorities rejected yesterday the proposal of a group of independent packers to sell meats at or below ceiling prices on consignment to retailers. The plan had the endorsement of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia.

Macmillan yesterday released the extraordinary story behind their publication of Earl Guy's novel "Heaven Is a Sunswept Hill," released last week. After accepting the manuscript of the book during 1942, through an agent, the publishers were curious about their unknown author.

The thirteen-story apartment building on a plot 101 by 98 feet at 884 West End Avenue, corner of 103d Street, has been sold by the New York Savings Bank to Henry Leeds through Byrne, Bowman Forshay, Inc., brokers.

From a trustworthy source comes the information that the Theatre Guild is seriously thinking of sending a company of '"Without Love," early next September, on a tour of those subscription cities which failed to see the Philip Barry play last spring. Last Wednesday

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Gunder Haegg of Gaevle, Sweden, holder of seven world distance-running records, defeated Gil Dodds of Boston by 20 yards in a special two-mile race at flood-lighted Soldier Field tonight, running the distance in 9:02.8.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 (AP) -- Everett Fagan, rookie pitcher, issued five walks in the ninth inning today and the Browns capitalized on his generosity to defeat the Athletics, 8 to 7, and move into a tie for sixth place.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 2 -- RAF Wellingtons again attacked Cagliari, principal port of southern Sardinia, Wednesday night as Allied fliers maintained their bombardment against Sardinia and Sicily.

Through the death of Martha Lincoln Draper New York City has lost one of its outstanding champions of public education. From 1910 until 1917 she served as a member of the New York Board of Education. In 1926 she was appointed to the Friedsam Commission, which established the present formula of State aid for New York, and was helpful in setting better standards for teachers' salaries.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Final figures for the 1943 fiscal year, announced today by Secretary of the Treasury Henry Morgenthau Jr., indicated that the national debt of the United States is now slightly higher than its national income. The Government closed the fiscal year on June 30 with a debt of $136,696,090,330.

The President gives as his reason for commuting the death sentence of Max Stephan his belief that the death penalty imposed by the court in this case "did not sufficiently take into account the statute which provides for the con sideration of different qualities of treason."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Roosevelt today vetoed the Commodity Credit Corporation bill into which Congress had written a ban on the use of subsidies to roll back food prices, and the House voted 154 to 228 to sustain the veto.

Aprons have definitely entered the realm of fashion -- being currently in seven times greater demand than they were before the war. When asked, for example, why the sudden appearance of half aprons all over the town, buyers answer loftily, "It's a new style trend."

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Rationing news was nearly all bad today. Higher point values were announced for beef, some cuts of veal, lamb and mutton, canned fish, catsup, chile sauce, four vegetables and five fruits.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A minimum of 3,600,000 persons must be added to the armed forces and munitions industries during the one-year period between this July and the next, the War Manpower Commission said today. The requirements, however, closely followed the estimate made last January.

One hundred and seventy five United States Marine Corps Women Reserves, the first contingent to be transferred from Hunter and Holyoke Colleges, arrived yesterday at the Marine base in New River, N.C. The lieutenants, privates and corporals left Pennsylvania Station Thursday afternoon bound for Camp LeJeune where they will train recruits.

The Nazi DNB agency yesterday quoted the newspaper Corriere della Sera of Milan as saying that bombing reprisals against the United States were "impossible" because of a lack of "cultural" targets. The wireless code transmission was reported by United States Government monitors to the Office of War Information.

Retail trade here improved sharply toward the end of the week. Estimates indicated department stores would have gains ranging up to 25 per cent over a year ago. A major factor in the large percentage increase over last year, however, was the six business days against five in 1942, when the comparative week closed with the July 4 holiday.

German prisoners of war interned in a Southern camp like to trumpet the refrain of the song of conquest they sang as they marched off to war: "Today, Germany. Tomorrow, the world." Probably they imagine they are defying somebody, or proving something, but all they really prove is that they are very far from home.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 2 -- The retirement of Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, Walker Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, and four other professors was announced today by Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the institution.

While it is not difficult to design and merchandise apparel at this time, a new and more difficult chapter in the trade's history is in the making for the post-war era, M.M. Lebensburger, former advertising manager of Kuppenheimer Clothes, Chicago, told the sixty-seventh semi-annual meeting of the international Association of Clothing Designers at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The War Department made public today the names, with next of kin, of 153 United States soldiers wounded in action in the Aleutian, European, North African and Pacific areas and of 232 held prisoners of war by the enemy, 231 by Japan and one by Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Tooru Kanazawa, an American of Japanese parentage and a private in the United States Army, told the Dies Committee today that the War Relocation Authority passed confidential documents concerning its plans to the Japanese-American Citizens League in this country.

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Strained by nearly four years of total war and hammered day and night by Allied air power, German industry has lost the production race essential to victory, although Germany still has plenty of fight left, reliable British and foreign sources indicated today.

I want to express hearty concurrence in the views of the Citizens' Budget Commission with reference to its recommendation that the City Planning Commission issue to the public a statement of its fundamental plan for the future development of the city as a whole.

The failure to educate parents to the benefits of day nurseries and school centers was cited yesterday afternoon by Helen Harris, executive secretary of the Mayor's committee on wartime care of children, as a hindrance to the development of a widespread child care program.

THE Dodgers and the Cardinals open one of those famous crucial series at Ebbets Field today with a single engagement this afternoon and a double-header tomorrow. The Flatbush Faithful, it goes without saying, will be sitting on tenterhooks, never the most comfortable perch in the world.

LENINGRAD, July 2 -- The makeshift barricades thrown up in the streets of Leningrad when the Germans stormed its gates in the Summer of 1941 have been demolished and today the city bristles with modern fortifications that promise another bloody defeat for Adolf Hitler's armies if they try again.

The hot sun, the end of school and visions of wartime duty stirred up by their teachers started two Brooklyn school chums on their way as volunteer farmers, and thus yesterday while anxious families awaited word of the boys' whereabouts the Police Missing Persons Bureau sent out an eight-State alarm for Joseph Bracht, 13 years old of 1431 Schenectady Avenue, and John Wilson Jr., 12, of 1403 Schenectady Avenue.

Among the firms reported yesterday as having leased business space was the Inter-American Airways Agency, Inc., which took quarters in the International Building, 630 Fifth Avenue. This concern represents the British West Indian Airways, Transportes Aereos Centro Americanos and Aerovias Brazil.

The discussion as to whether Vincentive is a better horse than Famous Victory will be decided today in the $25,000 added Empire City Handicap which will be the main race of seven scheduled at the Jamaica track.

Asserting that he does not want to fight the Mayor's order striking his salary from the budget, Dr. Joseph M. Sheehan, assistant superintendent, yesterday filed his application for retirement from the school system, to become effective today. Dr. Sheehan, who will be 70 on Sept. 21, would have been forced to retire by the end of the fall term.

CLEVELAND, July 2 (AP) -- Expansion of the Sherwin-Williams Company's manufacturing facilities in Mexico City, Mexico, and San Paulo, Brazil, was forecast today by George A. Martin, chairi man, who has just returned from a 16,500-mile trip'through Latin i America. The paint and varnish :concern now has plants in Cuba 'and Argentina and the proposed new units will be established as soon as conditions permit, Mr. Martin said. He estimated each would icost approximately $1,OOQ,O00.

While I must dissent from Edward R. Lewis' implied assumption that racial discrimination is either ethically or strategically justifiable, I want to note in particular an error into which Mr. Lewis appears to have fallen as a result of current misuse of the word "quota" in connection with immigration.

Net profit of the Kroger Grocery and Baking Company and its subsidiaries amounted to $2,354,859 for the twenty-four weeks ended on June 19, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by C. M. Robertson, president.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The Senators moved back within a game and a half of the league-leading Yankees today by stopping the White Sox and Rookie Guy Curtright in eleven innings, 3 to 2.
LONDON, Saturday, July 3 (U.P.) -- The midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:

DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- The veteran Tommy Bridges gained his fifth victory and fanned eleven today as the Tigers downed the Red Sox, 8 to 2, for a 2-0 edge in their series that opened with a tie game.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Miss Patty Berg effected a successful golfing comeback today, winning four of the last six holes in a sub-par rally that gave her a 1-up victory over Miss Dorothy Kirby and her second women's Western open championship in three years.

LONDON, July 2 -- Government intervention in the management of a Scottish colliery, announced today, makes the eighth such case since it was decided that drastic action would be taken wherever private ownership and control was deemed inadequate.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The Associated Press:

LONDON, Saturday, July 3 (U.P.) -- Cairo dispatches said today that all national guerrilla bands in Greece, now understood to have adequate modern armament, had agreed to regard themselves as part of the United Nations forces, giving the Allies for the first time a disciplined military body in that enemy-occupied territory.

Dublin, July 2 (AP) -- Prime Minister Emon de Valera, whose Fianna Fail party lost its eleven-year-old working majority in the Eire Parliament in the June election, hinted today he would call for another vote, probably in the fall.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -- Major Everett W. Holstrom, later one of the Tokyo fliers, was flying at the "unsafe" bombing level of 800 feet when he sighted and sank a Japanese submarine off the Oregon coast a few days after Pearl Harbor, the War Department disclosed today.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Saturday, July 3 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:

LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- United States and British Air Forces and Allied anti-aircraft units destroyed a known total of 18,031 German, Italian and Japanese planes from the start of the war to the end of June, a compilation from communiques disclosed tonight.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- Darryl Zanuck will produce a war drama with a Greek background when he returns to Twentieth Century-Fox. George Maniotes, Minister of Information for the Greek Embassy in Washington, is here as an adviser in the writing of the screen play.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 2 -There was considerable critical talk here today over an Army band concert given last night on the lawn of the Bath Club in the Strathmore and Vanderbilt Strathmore residential district and the topic was neither the program nor the musicianship.

CLEVELAND, July 2 -- The Indians made twelve runs in a single inning against the Yankees at League Park today -- more runs than the Tribe had scored in an inning over the last twenty years and more than any major league club had made this season.

As another Fourth of July comes a bit of retrospect is in order. In the second Continental Congress the first step toward the Declaration of Independence was taken on June 7. Resolutions offered by Richard Henry Lee and seconded by John Adams declared that "these united colonies are, and of right ought to be, independent States."

Because potatoes have become so plentiful this department has used them seven times in preparing the menus for next week for our hypothetical household of three -- a moderately active man and woman and a school-age child. The lowly spud, seven pounds of which are employed, appears in a salad and a soup, escalloped and mashed and hashed brown, baked and with parsley.

LONDON, Saturday, July 3 (AP) -- Royal Air Force bombers and fighters again ripped into enemy railway, supply and communications targets in France and the Low Countries yesterday and observers reported seeing another strong force of British planes, apparently including bombers, heading across the Channel last night.

Drivers of taxicabs were defended against charges of "polite racketeering" in a statement issued yesterday by the United Taxi Council, representing 90 per cent of all cab operators in Greater New York, but Police Commissioner Lewis J.
