Valentine said that while the picture drawn in published accounts "on the whole, is true," conditions "are not as bad as the article sounds."

The departure and arrival of travelers bound to and from the city for Independence Day is already the greatest in the history of the Grand Central Terminal, not only for the single day yesterday but for any holiday week-end, railroad officials declared.

BOLTON LANDING, N.Y., July 2 -- The vast home-building, industrial-production and public-improvement programs now being drawn up for the post-war period offer high hope for keeping real estate and business generally on an even keel during readjustments, the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards was informed today at its convention.
Harry Gumbert, the tall right-hander whom the Giants traded to the Cardinals some years ago, bobbed up at the Polo Grounds yesterday to make the New York club rue once more that ill-fated move.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Details of the State's plan for maternity care for wives of noncommisioned members of the armed forces, which was approved yesterday by the Children's Bureau of the National Labor Department, were announced today by Dr. Edward S. Godfrey, State Health Commissioner.
Numerous apartments were leased yesterday in buildings in Park Avenue.

THE war literature of the past six months has been almost equally divided between the narratives of personal experience and books which attempt to explore the bases for a lasting peace. Sometimes the two types of literature have been mixed together.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- More than $5,000,000,000 of operating appropriations for the new fiscal year remained tied up tonight in House and Senate deadlocks after another day of struggling for final agreements.

In the exchanges between Senator Langer and Office of Price Administration Attorney Emerson on how many lawyers the OPA has as against how few its opposite number in England employs, I am struck by Mr. Emerson's explanation that England uses "a very large number * * * upon a part-time or fee basis."

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has long been exercising the coercive powers of a dictator in his special field. He has been deciding what music the American people can and cannot hear. A few months ago he expressed a willingness to allow the makers of phonograph records to stay in business if they would pay a monetary tribute to his union for the privilege.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- The present fighting in the Southwest Pacific was characterized today by Secretary of the Navy Frank Knox as a "real offensive" by the United Nations and not merely an "island-to-island" advance on a long road to Tokyo.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Charges that the Federal Communications Commission, under the chairmanship of James Lawrence Fly, had abused its statutory powers to the detriment of the peacetime civil interests of the people and of the war effort were made at the opening hearing today of the committee appointed last January by the House of Representatives to investigate the agency.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 2 (AP) -The Bears played tag with the Bisons in both halves of a double-header tonight to gallop off with 10-to-1 and 11-to-2 decisions before 4,212 spectators.

RICHMOND, Va., July 2 -- This really is a week of gadgets as far as the 543 patents listed as issued in the Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office are concerned; gadgets and highly technical new wrinkles in already complicated machines.

Many bass fishermen on Thursday's opening day in New York came home convinced that there would be better fishing later. Scattered reports indicated that the recent hot spell had something to do with the fish going into deep water and that they are not ready for anxious anglers yet.

MOSCOW, July 2 (U.P.) -- Nikolai Malinin, Soviet writer, tonight opened Russia's first public forum on post-war problems, and at the same time sharply rebuked United Nations isolationists for demanding a definition of Allied war aims at a possible risk of extending the conflict.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Vice Admiral John Howard Hoover, commander of the Caribbean Sea frontier, will confer with Admiral Georges Robert, Vichy High Commissioner in Martinique, on Admiral Robert's suggestion that "a change of French authority" for the French Antilles be negotiated, the Navy Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (U.P.) -- The Senate Military Affairs Committee reported favorably today a bill by Senator Burton K. Wheeler, Democrat, Montana, exempting married men with children from the draft until Jan. 1.
MOSCOW, July 2 (AP) -- The Soviet Information Bureau issued this midday communique:

WITH THE AMERICAN LANDING FORCE ON RENDOVA ISLAND, June 30 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Thousands of picked American infantrymen, marines and sailors came ashore on this island today under the protection of their fleet's guns and the greatest plane concentration of the Solomons campaign.

Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday that it has arranged for $23,000,000 of new financing, of which $15,000,000 will be through bank loans and $8,000,000 through the private sale of 4 per cent serial debentures.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Donald M. Nelson, chairman of the War Production Board, reorganized today the setup for the rationing of gasoline and fuel oil to establish clear lines of responsibility for the four agencies now concerned with it and for the War Food Administration as representative of the farmers.

TOPEKA, Kan., July 2 (U.P.) -- Alfred M. Landon warned in an interview today that "the obstinancy" of President Roosevelt and "the interdepartmental pot-shotting" in Government bureaus constitute as great a threat to the war effort as absenteeism, strikes, public indifference and overconfidence.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 2 -- British-American air raids over western and northwestern Ger many cost the enemy 2,507 planes in the first six months of 1943, a German communique reported today. Most of the machines shot down were four-motored bombers, it is claimed.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- A possibility that Colonel Robert R. McCormick editor and publisher of The Chicago Tribune, bitter foe of the Roosevelt Administration and pre-Pearl Harbor isolationist, might enter the Presidential primaries of Illinois and near-by States in 1944 was being discussed today with more than ordinary seriousness.

It is indicated in Washington that the Ramirez government in Argentina will have to join the rest of the hemisphere in breaking relations with the Axis before it can receive lend-lease aid or any other special favors from this country. One would hope so. Lend-lease, under the law, is confined to those countries "whose defense the President deems vital to the defense of the United States."

Frank McCabe's selections for an all-star New York baseball squad appearing in his letter in THE TIMES last Saturday were good. To his list I would add second baseman Larry Doyle and pitchers Joe McGinnity and Art Nehf.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The Electric Bond and Share Company, the nation's largest single public utility holding company, was granted permission today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to acquire $15,000,000 of its outstanding $5 and $6 preferred stock through purchases on the New York Curb Exchange.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -Plans to feed Italians when United Nations troops occupy Italy are being drafted in Washington, with Herbert H. Lehman's Office of Relief and Rehabilitation Operations prepared to handle the job.

LONDON, Saturday, July 3 (AP) -- German propaganda resumed this morning its predictions that an Allied invasion of the Continent would begin today, with the Nazicontrolled Paris radio broadcasting that it was so sure the blow was going to fall it had sent reporters to the French coast.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) -- The U.S. Steel Corporation announced today it has restored six more blast furnaces to operation in view of increasing supplies of coal dug by an ever-growing number of miners returning to work after their third recent strike. This left but five still inactive.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- At the opening of the new year at the University of Pennsylvania today Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president, said in welcoming new students, upper classmen and members of the armed services:

Largely because of political pressure from members of Congress from the Southern States, the board of managers of the New York Cotton Exchange has approved a new contract which will be voted upon by members on July 12.

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 -- A recent trip to the United States of nine distinguished Argentine journalists has resulted in the challenge to a duel -- a duel that failed to materialize because the challenged person declined to fight.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 3 (AP) -- Vice Admiral John H. Hoover, commandant of the Tenth Naval District, has gone to Martinique to confer with Admiral Robert on the latter's offer to arrange terms for a "change of French authority," it was disclosed here tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- American shipyards in the first six months this year delivered more merchant tonnage than in all of 1942.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Senate completed Congressional action on a bill authorizing the appropriation of $10,000,000 for flood control repair work in the Midwest and on the $143,000,000 urgent deficiency bill, returned the labor-Federal security bill to conference after approving liquidation of the National Youth Administration, received a special committee report recommending centralization of control over petroleum and recessed at 5:42 P.M. until noon Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Although the first five months of 1943 saw 58,300 privately financed war family-dwelling units built, the postponement of nonessential construction until after the war has caused the accumulation of "a tremendous deferred demand" for new homes, Earle S. Draper, deputy commissioner of the Federal Housing Administration, declared today.

This afternoon, in observance of Independence Day, the historic Liberty Bell, cherished symbol of the freedom for which the United States is fighting today, will speak again to millions of listeners from the Atlantic to the Pacific coast. This announcement was made yesterday by the National Council of the Lutheran Church at its headquarters, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street.

The "Six Pillars of Peace" are clear enough so far as major aims are concerned. Forward-looking people want continuing political and economic cooperation between the United Nations and, as soon as possible, between all nations, with an international organization of some sort, flexible to change and strong enough to control armaments, to provide security against war, to gain increasing autonomy for subject peoples and progressively to win for all men religious and intellectual liberty.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -Charges of gross misconduct and abuse of trust, including an accusation of gross misuse of the United States war bond campaign, have been filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a complaint against the Investors Syndicate, the nation's largest investment company.

ALGIERS, July 3 -- The French Committee of National Liberation has decided to send an envoy to Martinique in the hope of ending the isolation of the island and winning its allegiance to the committee as the provisional government of the French Empire.

WEST POINT, N.Y., July 3 -- (AP) No site has been announced for the Army-Navy football game in the fall, but it will probably be played at West Point, Col. Lawrence (Biff) Jones, Army graduate manager of athletics, said today.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 3 -- An American Negro fighter squadron, escorting bombers yesterday over Sicily, destroyed a Focke-Wulf 190 to score the formation's first victory. General Dwight D. Eisenhower was on the air field to congratulate First Lieut. Charles Hall of Brazil, Ind., when he returned after shooting down the plane.
I SAW the war of 1975, or thereabout, beginning in the wardroom of a destroyer on patrol off the North African coast.

As a result of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's so-called "second-front" attack to compel the Office of Price Administration to fix wholesale price ceilings on un-graded eggs, butter and egg dealers of New York City announced the cancellation of their "egg holiday" yesterday afternoon when they were advised that OPA had agreed to the demanded amendment.

LONDON, July 3 -- John Brown, general secretary of the Iron and Steel Federation, told the organization today that, despite what he described as "bakers' oven" working conditions, this country's output of iron and steel ingots had reached a record figure last year.

LONDON, Sunday, July 4 (AP) -- Light bombers and fighter planes of the Royal Air Force made widespread sweeps over France, the Netherlands and Belgium yesterday, striking at Nazi objectives by daylight for the third consecutive day.

The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to approve on Tuesday several amendments to the New York Stock Exchange's rules covering special offerings, making these rules permanent instead of continuing them as temporary regulations for six-month periods, as in the past.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -Bernard M. Baruch, adviser to the Administration, has taken a hand in efforts to straighten out policy differences between the Board of Economic Warfare and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, which led to the sharp exchange between Vice President Wallace and Secretary of Commerce Jesse H. Jones.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Dog Day, owned and bred by Houghton P. Metcalf of Providence, R.I., scored by a length and a half today in the $7,500 added Myles Standish Stakes at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 19,579, covering the five furlongs in fifty-nine seconds, fastest time of the New England season.

WHEN you so severely discredit Frank Sinatra's ability as a comedian, I think you ought to remember that Frankie does not write his own material he only reads it (and pretty well too). If his jokes aren't funny (and most of Jack Benny's aren't either) blame it on his gag writer.

PROBLEMS of post-war reconstruction are being seriously and widely discussed. This is as it should be, even with the war not yet won. Rebuilding the world on the basis of a sound and just and enduring new world order is going, as we all know, to be a colossal undertaking.

THE astronomical sales figures of Wendell Willkie's "One World" have set a number of people not connected with Simon Schuster to worrying about the Simon Schuster paper allotment. The publishers explain that as they had a big year in 1942 with such monster volumes as "Mission to Moscow."

WELLESLEY, Mass., July 3 -- The Misses Chandralehka and Nayantara Pandit of Allahabad, India, nieces of Jawaharlal Nehru, have arrived in this country to study at Wellesley College. Traveling from India by way of Melbourne, the girls came to Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A new administrative dispute was dumped on the White House doorstep today when I.L. Sharfman, chairman of the Railroad Emergency Board, turned down the request of Fred M. Vinson, Stabilization Director, that the board reconsider its recommendation for an 8-cents-an-hour wage increase for non-operating railway employes.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 3 -Arthur Knapp worked the sloop Four Winds from sixth place to first in a windward thrash of two miles, acknowledged by competitors to be quite a feat in the way of sailing, in a highly spirited International class race today.

DOROTHY BAKER started "Trio" in Paris in 1930. During the course of working on this novel she came back to the United States and published "Young Man With a Horn," earned a Guggenheim Fellowship and settled down on an orange grove in California.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 3 -- American heavy bombers from the Middle East battered three airdromes in southern Italy in daylight yesterday. Twelve enemy fighters were shot down in this operation, in which three bombers were lost.

IN his preface to "American Words and Ways" the author says that the book ought to be a much needed supplement to existing grammars used to teach English to Germans. His stated purpose is to help pre-Hitler Germans and refugees understand American English and American ways -- to help them find themselves in a new country.

LIGHT novels about girls who work for air lines, military or civilian, seem to grade a bit higher in quality than the general run of romances with a war background. This one is no exception and belongs in the top row of its class.

His Old Age The enterprising United Press gave us two sideline items on the latest Churchill address which merge without much difficulty into a single pleasant effect. We are told that the freedom of the city which was bestowed on Mr. Churchill on the occasion of his Guildhall speech carries with it, among other privileges, the right of admission to the City of London poorhouses at Brixton.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 3 -- East Hampton's Village Fair, held annually since 1895 by the Village Improvement Society to raise funds for care of trees and greens here, will take place as usual on the Village Green on the afternoon of July 30. Mrs. Edward Ewen Anderson is president of the society and Mrs. Thomas Aquin Kelly is general fair chairman.

Last March General Giraud, when revoking Vichy laws promulgated by the Petain government after the conquest of France, canceled the Cremieux decree of 1871, thereby depriving some 40,000 to 50,000 Algerian Jews of their French citizenship. In reply to the protests made at the time, the State Department replied sharply in defense of the action.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Advocates of post-war international collaboration will take their views to the people this summer in a bi-partisan speaking campaign.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -- Chief of Government Pierre Laval's Police Chief, Rene Bousquet, is reported by Vichy to be in Clermont-Ferrrand "supervising intense police activities there."

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- One thing that a trip through the hard-coal region of eastern Pennsylvania brings home is that just about the most unpopular man in the country in the eyes of the anthracite miner is John L. Lewis.

LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Ponderous attempts at levity by Dr. Joseph Goebbels' propaganda machine today could not quite conceal the misgivings within Nazi Europe as the second date set by the German for an Allied invasion passed with scarcely more than the usual flow of reports from belligerent and neutral capitals.

The South Sea offensive is an answer to critics who said we were not pushing our war against Japan with sufficient vigor, just as the North African landings were an answer to the stay-at-homes who could not rest in their comfortable beds unless we had a "second front."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The special Senate committee investigating the oil situation recommended today that Secretary Ickes receive more authority as Petroleum Administrator for War at the expense of the Office of Price Administration.

THIS is a book that will send you scurrying through your vocabulary for the proper descriptive term. You will come up with "Glub!" The English language is still too poor to afford the kind of superdooper word which would express the effect of Louise Randall Pierson's hilarious, catch-as-catch-can, knock-down-and-drag-out story of her life.

IT was a simple announcement: "Pete S. Harrison and E.B. Derr will film James Fenimore Cooper's 'The Deerslayer' for Republic Pictures." To the movie-going public at large it probably had no special significance. But to the owners of some 8,000 independent movie houses meant an awful lot.
Nerves taken from corpses have been successfully transplanted to living persons by Prof. A.S. Vichnevsky, head of the surgical department of the Soviet Neurological Clinic.

BEETLE KILLER -- Some chemicals tested as Japanese beetle killers have gone to war, but an effective one tested recently and approved by the United States Department of Agriculture entomologists -- ethylene dichloride -- is still available. The investigators found that an emulsion containing 60 per cent by weight of ethylene dichloride should first be prepared.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 3 (AP) -- A Middle East air communique:

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- If distribution bottlenecks can be overcome, the country's food supply for 1943 will be adequate for a healthful diet, despite the fact that one-fourth, or more, of our total production is going to the armed services and to our Allies.

AS an innovation, the Boston Symphony Orchestra will present a series of concerts this summer devoted to music for an ensemble of chamber proportions. Each of the seven programs will be under the direction of a different conductor and will be performed in Sanders Theatre, Cambridge, on successive Sunday afternoons, beginning July 18, with repetition the next night in New England Mutual Hall, Boston.

Regardless of the failures and achievements of the National Resources Planning Board, its dissolution by Congress leaves the country without an authoritative agency qualified to deal with postwar domestic problems in a comprehensive manner.

GENERALLY speaking, it is a characteristic of radio -and a good one, too -- that the average program hurries along as if it had no great amount of time to lose; wherefore it is agreeable, by way of variety, occasionally to hear one that does not.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -Defending the contract for development of the Elk Hills petroleum reserve between the Standard Oil Company of California and the Navy Department, Ralph W. Richards, staff geologist of the Geological Survey, told the House Lands Committee today the contract was a sound conservation measure.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Despite a plea by James F. Byrnes, Director of the Office of War Mobilization, for no restrictions on funds to be used for subsidies, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee voted tonight to limit to $525,000,000 the amount which can be used to roll back or hold down prices.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -The Cubs made it five victories in a row today, beating the Phillies, 6 to 1, before 3,984 fans in a game that started at 1:30 P.M.

LONDON, Sunday, July 4 (U.P.) -- The Eighth Air Force of the United States Army announced today that 253 of its men had been decorated with medals, including eight Silver Stars for gallantry in action and one Soldier's Medal for heroism in action not involving combat with the enemy.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Now comes the housemaid with a union card.
"THE MAINE IDEA" is pretty well summed up in the pithy colloquy: "You say you want a round-trip ticket. Where to?" "Back here."
NEW DELHI, India, July 3 (AP) -- A communique:

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Sweden's "thin man," Gunder Haegg, rested in a hotel room today before leaving for the West Coast and another two-mile race with Gill Dodds, who made the great runner exert himself last night to win his second start on American soil.

When John Adams and Thomas Jefferson were both old men Adams wrote that there was not an idea in the Declaration of Independence "but what had been hackneyed in Congress for two years before." Jefferson was at first annoyed. Later he realized that Adams was right.

A WELL written, very human story of Ecuador. Chico, the 10-year-old hero, lives high up in the mountains with an old man whom he has always believed to be his grandfather and with his engaging pet, a spectacled bear named Chan.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 3 -- Church leaders of sixteen nations will discuss post-war reconstruction problems at an International Round Table to be held here from July 8 to 11 under the auspices of the Commission to Study the Basis of a Just and Durable Peace of the Federal Council of Churches in collaboration with the Canadian Council on the Church, Nation and World Order.
The weird psychiatric phenomenon of "battle dreams," in which a man may relive, night after night, a particularly terrifying battle experience, is being studied by psychiatrists in North Africa.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The Chicago-owned Calumet Farm's pair, Twilight Tear and Miss Keeneland, dominated the $35,000 Arlington Lassie Stakes for 2-year-old fillies before 17,000 at Washington Park today.

Retail trade continued active last week in the three major test markets of New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, according to the survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Brisk trade was noted in practically all main floor departments, sports wear and beach wear.

I am well aware of the toil and blood and treasure, that it will cost us to maintain this declaration, and support and defend these States. Yet through all the gloom I can see the rays of ravishing light and glory. I can see that the end is worth more than all the means, and that posterity will triumph in that day's transaction.

LONDON, July 3 -- The steady flow of news recently from the United States dealing with race riots, strikes and the tug of war between President Roosevelt and Congress has puzzled, and worried, the British people regarding the state of their western ally's affairs.

THE great increase in suburban homes and gardens in recent years where only thickets flourished before has done little to limit the abundance of rabbits, mice and moles. These creatures, with many of their natural enemies, such as skunks, foxes, owls and hawks, frightened away by man's intrusion, and with a plenitude of food supplied by backyard gardens, seem actually to thrive in close association with man.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, July 4 -Allied forces, closing in steadily on the Japanese garrison at Salamaua, have cleared the enemy from the area south of the Bitoi River delta, near the big New Guinea base, but sharp fighting continues near Komiatum, six miles to the southwest of Salamaua, Allied headquarters reported today.

"The abolition of the death penalty in all States" was asked and a protest against the execution of youths under 18 years of age was made in the annual report of the American League to Abolish Capital Punishment, Inc., issued yesterday from the headquarters of that organization at 124 Lexington Avenue.

LONDON, July 3 -- The Alice in Wonderland election in Eire settled all about whether the country was neutral inside and out for the duration -- it is. Incidentally, the voters turned in a surprise of their own by denying Premier Eamon de Valera a clear-cut margin for the power he has enjoyed a long time.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3 (AP) -Hearing on charges filed yesterday against one of the nation's largest investment groups -- Investors Syndicate, Investors Mutual, Inc., and Investors Syndicate of America -scheduled for today, was postponed today by Federal Judge Gunnar H. Nordbye until next Friday to allow attorneys for Investors Syndicate time to study the pleadings.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- Race tension in Chicago was believed to have been relieved considerably tonight when a convention of the "March on Washington" movement voted to defer, for the time-being, the projected mass appeal to the White House for redress of Negro grievances.

YACHTING has just sailed into its most difficult season since the Merrie Monarch, King Charles II, inaugurated the sport nearly 300 years ago and Samuel Pepys reported the seasick event for history. Yet the amateur skippers of Long Island Sound, foremost yachting center in the world, are beating forward doggedly against the numerous wartime restrictions.

DOMESTIC DILEMMA -- Time was when clothing bundled off to the laundry on Monday would return from its ablutions, all neatly pressed and packed, by Friday. But -- those easy and comfortable days are gone -- at least for the duration.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 (AP) -- Home runs by Stan Spence and Bob Johnson coupled with a walk, a wild pitch and a single enabled the Senators to beat the Browns, 6 to 4, tonight. The victory moved Washington into a virtual first-place tie with the Yankees, now only three percentage points ahead.
A billion pounds of protein can be recovered annually by a distillation process which has been developed by Irwin W. Tucker and Dr. A.K. Balls of the United States Department of Agriculture.

THE latest addition to the Everses' cheerful menagerie is an all-too-voluble duckling. Where others of his kind content with a simple "quack," he always tripled the comment. From sunrise to sunset he chattered -- and even in his sleep -- until his barnyard companions burst out in such noisy wrath that Chatterduck became a wiser and a much quieter duck, reserving his single quack for occasions that really mattered.

IN connection with the contemplated holiday plans of several millions of vacationists this Summer, I find myself officially constrained to request them to avoid visiting the National Parks unless they are lucky enough to live in close proximity to one of them.

CHUNGKING, China, July 3 (Reuter) -- Continued heavy fighting in the suburbs of Owchikow, one of the four strategic bases still held by Japanese forces on the south bank of the Yangtze River west of Tungting Lake, was reported in tonight's Chinese communique.

Morton Gould conducted the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at the Lewisohn Stadium last night for the first time, presenting a United Nations program. The feature of the list was Miaskowsky's Symphony No. 16 in what was announced as its first American performance.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- A joint Admiralty and Air Ministry communique:

THE web of destiny spun itself fast when they began shooting "For Whom the Bell Tolls." Diverse things happened all of a sudden. The war began, the $5,000 ceiling was clamped on movie sets, travel was stopped, there could be no junketing or shuttling back and forth from location sets to the somatic center in Hollywood.

LIEUT. COMMDR. WILLIAM DALE commands the old brig Pegasus on coast patrols and through the convoy lanes to Iceland and Norway. When the Pegasus was shelled and sunk Dale and the other survivors who managed to get away in the long-boat capture a U-boat, and using it to get to Breida Fjord (Dale had formerly been in the submarine service) they torpedo one cruiser and ram another.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Among the winners of 180 decorations for "extraordinary achievements" with the Eighth United States Army Air Force in the European theatre, announced today by the War Department, are a dozen New Yorkers, five Jerseyites and three men from Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Washington resounds these days with the din of a conflict more disturbing to many than the clangor that accompanies strife on the battlefield. It is the "Battle of Washington," accelerating in temper and growing in intensity so that the impression prevails in some quarters that feuding on the home front has become more the preoccupation of the capital than fighting on the war fronts.

TWENTY-ONE "city softies," girls fresh from New York high schools and from Queens and Hunter Colleges, who pitched in to help Long Island farmers, worked so hard during the recent torrid spell that they wrung protests from their employer, Mrs. Abbot Low Moffat, senior farm placement representative of the United States Employment Service Farm Bureau, reports pridefully.

OSSINING, July 3 -- Orders have been issued, it was learned today, directing that Emanuel Weiss, 36 years old, and Louis Capone, 46, Sing Sing deathhouse prisoners, and Louis (Lepke) Buchalter, 45, a Federal prisoner in Manhattan, be produced before the State Court of Appeals in Albany on Tuesday morning, July 20, to be resentenced to death.

The Fourth of July week-end began yesterday with a minimum of patriotic ceremonies scheduled for today and tomorrow and with a volume of travel that transportation officials believed was the greatest in the city's history.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:...

The Colonial Trust Company reported as of June 30 total deposits of $26,168,113 and total assets of $27,823,041, compared, respectively, with $24,045,524 and $25,586,340 on Dec. 31. Cash on hand and due from banks amounted to $7,261,630, against $7,112,563; holdings of United States Government securities to $12,082,812, against $10,084,391, and loans and bills purchased to $7,540,388, against $7,713,212.

PITTSBURGH, July 3 (AP) -- A picture of continuing improvement was reflected today throughout the coal fields, although in western Pennsylvania two new outbreaks left 1,100 more diggers idle and shut down a big captive pit of the Republic Steel Corporation.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -Rookie Leon Culberson turned in a home run, triple, double, single and a base on balls tonight to lead a Red Sox hitting attack that defeated the Indians, 12 to 4, in a series opener.

BEFORE 1943 is out another two million women will follow the footsteps of Josephine von Miklos into the labor force. Her book may help to prepare many of them for what they will find. By that I do not mean to say that it is a guide book. There are no "do's" or "don'ts," no advice to be found in it anywhere.

DETROIT, July 3 -- The United Automobile Workers, CIO, announced today a program of postwar objectives, including a demand for Government or municipal ownership of "monopolistic" industries and those essential to national safety.

American fighting men need the inspiration and encouragement that only a study of their own country's history can give them, Dr. Asa E. Martin of the Pennsylvania State College observed in praising military authorities for the inclusion of history in the Army's college training program.

BRILLAT-SAVARIN, were he alive today, would not be satisfied with a dinner composed like a symphony, counterpointing exotic and subtle flavors. He would insist that his meal also add up to the proper number of calories, proteins, minerals and vitamins.
The interest in furs is unusually great this season, and the launching of fall styles in coats is actually beginning a month earlier than in past years.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- The first anniversary of the end of the defense of Sevastopol falls today. On July 3, 1942, the last of the Russian rear guards were fighting on the beaches to cover the withdrawal of wounded and the garrison's remnants were forced to yield.

WOMEN have joined the fighting legions in the battle for crops waged between time and man. Ripe apples rotted and the juice of lush tomatoes flowed into the dirt last year because hands to harvest them were holding guns or piloting planes. This year women are seeing to it that the fruits of the soil do not rot.

DETERRED, perhaps, by the hot weather, New York's showplaces for art registered a sharp decline in attractions offered last week, with little new to offer, moreover, in the days immediately ahead. The summer doldrums seem definitely to have set in.

HERE is a tale of adventure, mystery and romance in the South Seas. Jim Marsden, unjustly condemned to die for a murder he did not commit, breaks jail and sets out to find the man who is really guilty. The rest of the story takes place on a remote island where devils are said to haunt a certain harbor.

THE spirit of the American dancers can be called nothing less than invincible. From the beginning the victims of a longtime conspiracy between provincialism, academicism and the commercial interests that trade upon them, they have fought and starved to create fully in terms of their own election; and now in spite of war, Congress and heat-waves, they are still brimming with energy to carry on.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 3 -- Robert Odman, 6 foot 3-inch stalwart from the University of Washington, stands between Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador and his third successive tennis championship of the season.

WRITERS of books for children are making a valiant effort to keep up with the headlines. Miss Stinedorf's "Children of North Africa" contains brief stories of Cairo, the Nubian desert, a Moroccan village, sponge fishers of Tunisia, a fisher boy of Tangier, a shepherd lad of South Algeria and a native boy of French West Africa.
CAIRO, Egypt, July 3 (Reuter) -- A Ninth United States Air Force communique:

UNLESS some producer has something rehearsing in secret there will not be a single opening on Broadway during the month of July. This perhaps is not newsworthy, for July is traditionally the dead month in the theatre.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The damage to Cologne Cathedral has received far more publicity than it deserves. To state that Cologne is one of the world's finest cathedrals is but to display one's own architectural illiteracy and complete lack of taste. No authority of first rank, or of second rank for that matter, has ever spoken well of Cologne.

IN spite of the fact that leg make-up is not completely new to the cosmetic world (the first one reputedly appeared in 1921 -- a light tan cream designed for evening wear on shoulders, arms and legs), it comes as a complete novelty to the vast majority of women.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Because he "unhesitatingly volunteered time after time to act as stretcher bearer with cool courage and utter disregard of his personal safety during the Guadalcanal battle," the Silver Star Medal has been awarded to Marine Private First Class Carlton R. Rouh of Lindenwold, N.J.

LARAMIE, Wyo., July 3 (AP) -- Infuriated ranchers sent their families to havens here today and joined law officers in a hunt for the perpetrator of three seemingly motiveless murders in the high cattle lands.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Roger D. Lapham, retiring Industry Member of the National War Labor Board, closed his desk today and left for San Francisco where he will run as an independent candidate for Mayor in the fall.

THE perennial poison ivy question comes to the fore again and recommendations for eliminating the baneful weed are the topic of all over-the-fence conversations. Aside from sodium chlorate and ammonium sulfamate, two of the most effective cures, which are at present sometimes difficult to obtain, commercial preparations and such eradicators as rock salt and crankcase oil (if any happens to be around), the latest recommended "sure cure" is borax.

PEOPLE with a prejudice against gardening usually trace their dislike to the days when they had to spend long hours on hands and knees fighting weeds, whatever the attractions elsewhere. To children this was often unjust.

LONDON, July 3 (Reuter) -- Britain's Communist party, at its first congress since the dissolution of the Communist International, is making drastic changes that carry it far from its old revolutionary character.

Jockey Johnny Longden, erstwhile pilot of Count Fleet, seems to bounce successfully from one 3-year-old winner to another, for he was up yesterday at Jamaica on Chop Chop, winner of the $28,100 Empire City Handicap in track record time.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Naval action between American and Japanese surface craft blazed out tonight (Solomons time) in the Central Solomons when a Japanese task force of three light cruisers and four destroyers attempted to shell American positions on Rendova Island, the Navy reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senate's War Investigating (Truman) Committee today called for a definition now of post-war rights of the United States to use of airfields and other military installations built by this country in all parts of the world.

Columbia University's fortyfourth summer session, which opens Tuesday, will be conducted on a wartime basis, with 10,000 military and civilian students enrolled in the regular summer and accelerated programs. For the first time in its 189-year history almost every school will offer a full term's schedule.

KNOLLWOOD FIELD, N.C., July 3 (AP) -- In a report to the nation the Army Air Forces Technical Training Command revealed today that it had turned out more than half a million ground and air combat crew technicians since it was organized two and a quarter years ago.

LONDON, July 3 -- Although most of the real fireworks are being currently provided by their brothers in arms in the Southwest Pacific, Americans in the Eastern Theatre of Operations plan to observe Independence Day in a big way.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Guy Curtright, whose twenty-six game hitting streak was ended yesterday, drove home a run in the first inning tonight to provide the first two runs in the White Sox's 6-to-4 victory over the Athletics in a twilight game before 10,577 at Comiskey Park.

Banks' excess reserves, funds which are neither invested nor lent, are going out of fashion rapidly under wartime pressure, but the public's "excess reserves," funds that are neither invested nor placed on deposit in the banks, are mounting steadily.

The arrest of nine German aliens, including a father, mother and son, was announced yesterday by E.E. Conroy, local agent in charge of the office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The arrests were made in metropolitan New York during the week-end.

As a general rule this writer is not the pushover that apparently some folks are for these shows that are packed with "name" performers for the sake of their names alone. To us it is usually depressing to see a film jammed with so many stars that each has but time to flash a samples of his wares before another is rushed on.

In the last war we heard of "shell shock," supposed to be caused by concussion. Statistics showed that many sufferers in all the armies had never been near the front lines. Thereupon it was supposed that shell shock was a subconscious attempt to escape from danger.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- July rye furnished the fireworks today on the Board of Trade, advancing 3 1/4 cents a bushel from its early low mark, going to a new seasonal high and closing at the top with a gain of 1 3/4 cents. Buying attributed to cash interests and shorts found little rye for sale when the market started upward.

On the theory that "one play is worth a dozen sermons," the 348 Congregationalist churches of New York State will each present a series of plays for children dealing with different aspects of democracy, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Harold Saxe Tuttle, Professor of Education at City College, who is the originator of the drama program.

ACCORDING to a startling theory proposed by Charlie Thomas, the success of a new play depends mainly on the man in the box office. "The box office is the vein to the show business," Charlie says. "A treasurer can make or break a producer."

A contractor who owns a row of houses in Fort Lee, N.J., was arrested yesterday and held in $2,500 bail on a charge of maintaining the gambling resort of whose existence North Jersey law officials had expressed doubt for more than twenty-four hours after New York City police and the Office of Price Administration had halted its rented limousines filled with dice players.

For several days Kiska, main base and last foothold of the enemy in the Aleutians, has been under heavy aerial bombardment. It is reasonable to believe that this is a prelude to an early effort to reoccupy the island.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- Two destroyer escorts, designed to combat the submarine menace, were launched today at the Navy Yard here, while across the Delaware River in New Jersey two fleet-service oil tankers slid down the ways of the RTC Shipbuilding Corporation, Camden.
ALGIERS, July 3 (Reuter) -- A message of greeting to President Roosevelt from Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud was released tonight. It said:

In view of the War Production Board's recent restrictions on the use of glass bottles, the liquor industry is likely to press for some kind of an adjustment of the present federal regulations under which thousands of wine and liquor bottles are smashed daily by tavern operators, it was learned yesterday.

DETROIT, July 3 -- The Yankees spent this afternoon at Briggs Stadium blowing what might ordinarily be considered comfortable leads -- and wound up blowing two vital ball games. Everything went against the American League champions in their first local struggles of the year against the Tigers -- including Nick Etten and Johnny Murphy.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 3 -- The only sergeant who ever made soldiers philosophical has been unearthed in Tunisia. His name is N.V. Jerkovich but the soldiers call him "the sad sack," after George Baker's cartoon character, and other names -- although not to his face.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 3 -- Blending their efforts nicely for a four-under-par performance, Ray F. Kilthau of Oakland and Reginald G. Narelle of North Hempstead carded a 68 today to take top honors in the qualifying round of the North Hempstead Country Club's annual member-guest best-ball golf tourney.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Casualties of the United States armed forces from the start of the war to date total 91,644, the Office of War Information reported today, divided as follows: Dead, 16,696; wounded, 21,828; missing, 31,579; prisoners of war, 21,541. The 64,621 Army casualties coral prise: Killed, 8,533; wounded, 17,094; missing, 21,046; prisoners of war. 17,948.

HERBERT JACOBY, who can always be counted upon to supply the unusual note in supper club divertisement discloses he is trying to bring here for an appearance at his Blue Angel Josephine Baker, the dusky artist from St. Louis who became the darling of the Paris pre-war music halls.

Completion of arrangements for the induction of Paducah as a member port in the Propeller Club of the United States was announced yesterday by Arthur M. Tode, honorary president of the club. Presentation of Paducah's charter will be made at a later date.
Market activities were comparatively quiet last week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company.

THERE are two schools of thought in the matter of responding to forcing two-bids. The first school holds that a two-bid is a bid designed to reach game and that the first thought in bidding should be to find the best trump suit.

Lemons on which the Office of Price Administration has fixed a retail ceiling price of 42 cents a dozen were reported yesterday to be selling at prices ranging from 10 to 15 cents apiece in some sections of New York City. In these sections housewives complained of a shortage of both lemons and limes as well as of skyrocketing prices.

The stock market adopted yesterday a cautious attitude in view of the lengthy week-end holiday, but there was still sufficient inflationary thinking to keep prices on the upper side, aided by a smattering of further investment purchases.

"THE NAVY READER," an anthology edited by Lieut. William Harrison Fetridge, United States Naval Reserve, could well be called "The Spirit of Patriotism," for every page sends forth a message to the reader -- vital authentic, bristling with one dynamic purpose -- to inform the American people of their great Navy, of which they may well be proud.

ONLY yesterday they were little boys, flocking to the science workshop and the mineral laboratory of the Brooklyn Children's Museum. Today they are off to the wars, Sid, Ira, Alec and the rest, reporting back from army camps, from Alaska and Australia, on the local flora and fauna and mineral deposits.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The National Gallery of Art here will become permanent custodian of the Index of American Design, the comprehensive pictorial record of the American tradition in arts and crafts prepared by artists of the WPA Federal Art Project during the depression of the 1930's.

"SISTER CARRIE" was finished in May, 1900. It has become one of the most historic books in modern American literature, and its widespread acceptance as an American classic marks a major victory that has been won for American letters against the Philistines.

FOR stamp dealers in New York the past week has been one of the sparsest "new issues" periods in years. The major news of importance received from abroad reached J. H. Stolow in the form of a cablegram from Beirut saying that Syria plans to issue on July 15 a six-stamp series to commemorate the holding of a medical congress.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, July 2 (AP) (Delayed) -- After pushing eastward toward the coast while under Japanese artillery fire the Australians gained positions on ridges near the Francisco River and could see the Salamaua air base.

FILMING was completed this week for Universal's "Corvette K 225," the picture being produced in collaboration with the Royal Canadian Navy. Director Richard Rosson and camera crews made six corvette voyages across the North Atlantic to obtain authentic scenes of convoy action against Nazi submarines and planes.

AT AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE, July 2 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Rough and ready marines blazed the American invasion trail into the Central Solomons, carrying out a bold expedition to New Georgia several days before the main assault forces struck.

Encouraged by the manner in which manufacturers are making shipments on early orders for major items of fall apparel, retailers believe they will be able to open the new retail season with fewer delivery handicaps than had been feared, a survey here last week indicated.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- American soldiers and Red Cross workers in Britain appeared tonight in Maxwell Anderson's play "The Eve of St. Mark." The opening was received with enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Interior Department Appropriation Bill which came from conference today, retained an amendment by Senator O'Mahoney prohibiting the use of any of the funds appropriated to maintain Jackson Hole National Monument, recently created in Wyoming by Presidential proclamation.

Those people who have been suggesting that the best way to go fishing this summer because of travel limitation, is to stay home and read a good book about the sport must have known that the International Game Fish Association was ready to issue an annual.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, June 30 (Delayed) (AP) -- Eighteen officers and men of the flight crews of transport planes have just received the Oak Leaf Cluster, in lieu of an additional award of the Air Medal, for participating in more than twenty-five operational missions.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The WPB announced today that with warehouse space getting tighter and tighter, it may become necessary to establish storage priorities to make certain that the most critical materials get the kind of protection they require.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 3 (AP) -- The Red Wings completed a sweep of their three-game series with the Jersey City Giants today, winning, 2 to 1, and moving into position to challenge the incoming Royals for a first division berth.

Mort Cooper asked Manager Billy Southworth for the pitching assignment against the Dodgers at Ebbets Field yesterday in the opener of the three-game series between the National League leaders and the second-place Brooks. Mort got it and, unhappily for 17,775 Flatbush fans, the world champion Redbirds won, 5 -- 3.

HEADQUARTERS 14TH U.S. AIR FORCE, China, July 3 -Maj. Gen. Claire N. Chennault told American airmen at this base today in an anniversary speech that "during the next year you men will fly over Japan itself many times."

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- In the first steeplechase event on record here, M.A. Cushman's Rouge Dragon outdistanced a field of six today before 15,141 at the State Fair Grounds track to win the $5,000 Bloomfield Open Hunt Handicap.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Reports from Algiers that the French Committee of National Liberation contemplates taking part in negotiations about the French Antilles and the expected arrival of General Giraud in Washington drew attention today to two French desires. One is the recognition by the Allies of the newly formed committee as a French central authority. The other is the rapid equipment of the French Army with American weapons.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 3 -President Roosevelt, Secretary Morgenthau, Senator George and others who will have to decide whether to make war-bond buying compulsory, and the corps of people who are now getting ready for the next bond drive, will find considerable significance in the results of a nation-wide survey just completed by the institute to determine how many Americans have bought bonds or stamps in 1943 -and how many have not.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 3 -That 1943 summer offensive against the Russians that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering promised for the time "when the sun again stands high in the heavens" has not materialized so far, although the summer solstice is well past and the days are rapidly shortening.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- We must maintain armed forces adequate to protect the Western Hemisphere "until war-minded generations of Axis nations have passed away," Mrs. William H. Pouch, President General of the Daughters of the American Revolution, declared today.

LONDON, Sunday, July 4(AP) -A German thrust toward Russian positions on the central front before Smolensk was frustrated yesterday by Soviet artillery and infantry units, Moscow announced early today in the regular midnight communique.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- The United States Eighth Air Force today completed its first year of operations against the European enemy -- a year in which it loosed some 15,000 tons of bombs upon the Continent and grew from a force of less than ten medium bombers into one approximately 1,000 planes strong.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Sunday, July 4 (AP) -- The noon communique:

New York University's summer program will be complete tomorrow when the School of Education, the College of Engineering and the School of Retailing begin courses for an estimated 2,000 students. The eleven other schools, colleges and divisions of the university, whose summer curricula are already in operation, have a registration of 6,111 civilian students.

The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, declared last night in an address before the Christian Endeavor Unions of the Southeastern District of New York that bureaucracies, subsidies and monopolies have no part in the democratic system and should be abolished.

The Eighth Army moved rapidly across the sands of North Africa partly because of special tires built in Britain from 4-inch models which were tested in trays of sand and which showed that a flat tread is better than a round one in the desert.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -- The League of Nations Economic Section estimates that the German public debt has multiplied sixfold since the start of the war and "would now seem to have exceeded 200,000,000,000 marks," according to a statement in the monthly statistical bulletin for June.
The long stalemate in the South Pacific was broken last week as the forces of General Douglas MacArthur and Admiral William F. Halsey began a coordinated island-stepping offensive toward Rabaul.

Bishop James T.G. Hayes of New York and a group of other Jesuit missionaries, priests and scholastics, who were captured by the Japanese in the Philippines, are interned in a civilian camp at Baguio, the former summer capital, the Jesuit Philippine Bureau, 51 East Eighty-third Street, announced yesterday.

LONDON, July 3 (U.P.) -- Reports reaching air observers today indicated that Reich Marshal Hermann Goering was concentrating at least 1,000 bombers and 1,500 fighters in Western and Southern Europe to meet an Allied invasion.

NEW DELHI, India, July 3 (AP) -- Heavy and medium American bombers flew through heavy monsoon weather to pound Japanese targets in Burma twenty-three days during June, Maj. Gen. Clayton L. Bissell said today.

Police Captain Louis Goldberg, whose crusades against gambling made him famous, got the green light yesterday from Supreme Court Justice Francis G. Hooley to look in on the swank Queens Boulevard Club in Forest Hills, Queens, as often as was necessary to assure himself there was no violation of he law.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Pressing economic problems have deepened the lassitude among the top leaders of organized labor in connection with the movement for organic unity of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

AS a writer of literate detective stories Georges Simenon ranks well up in the Grade A, or almost-as-goodas-Dorothy-Sayres class. Some of his "Maigret" stories are little short of masterpieces. The latest addition to his American works is "Havoc by Accident," a volume of two short novels which are not whodunits, but which are designed for the same trade.

The Republican Post-War Policy Association, organized to support a policy of international cooperation after the war, will hold an Eastern conference of delegates from twelve States at the Hotel Commodore on Monday, July 19.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 3 -- Federal aid to education proved to be the central theme of the 1,500 school leaders meeting here this week at the annual National Education Association convention. This was the first time in a quarter of a century that all social pomp was dropped and the business at hand stressed in the interests of wartime efficiency.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 3 -- The annual Yankee Doodle Fair of the Westport Woman's Club will be held here July 15, 16 and 17 on Jessup Green. This country fete is given annually to raise funds for the club's welfare activities, which include child health conferences and the support of dental clinics and two visiting nurses.

MOSCOW, July 3 (AP) -- Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES returned to Moscow today after a two-day visit somewhere on the Russian front, at which he inspected several hospitals in his capacity as a Red Cross delegate.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Washington's summer weather this week got its first kind word in history. It was: "The average weather conditions here do not equal in severity tropical conditions in many parts of the world in which our troops are fighting and working continuously for many days without relief."

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 3 -- Having acquired a valuable knowledge of field tactics, a general physical buildup and a fine coat of tan, 1,400 members of up-State Guard units, the Second Regiment of Troy and the Fifty-sixth Regiment of Newburgh, moved out of Camp Smith Thursday for their home armories after a highly successful ten-day training tour that earned the personal commendation of Governor Thomas E. Dewey.

Three more dog shows in the Eastern section of the country have been canceled. H. Morin de Linclays, president of the French Line, said yesterday that the French merchant marine, flying the Tricolor and manned by French crews, soon would resume service with the United Nations, carrying supplies for the armed forces.

PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., July 3 (AP) -- Seventy-five Pennsylvania soldiers wounded in the North African campaign arrived today at Valley Forge General Hospital from Halloran General Hospital, New York, and most of them had a story to tell.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Specific cents-per-dozen prices for wholesale grades of eggs for sale by producers and shippers to primary receivers, jobbers and retailers were established today by the Office of Price Administration following approval by the War Food Administration.

The appearance of Benny Goodman and his orchestra, Frank Sinatra and other leading Broadway entertainers on the Mall in Central Park yesterday afternoon started the second annual nationwide "records for our fighting men" campaign moving on all cylinders. The drive, sponsored by the American Legion, attracted more than 3,000 youngsters.

THE National Victory Garden Institute will hold a conference of national leaders on home food conservation at 598 Madison Avenue on July 13 and 14. The meetings will serve as a clearing house for the latest news from the food front.

OTTAWA, July 3 -- Of all the improvisations for total war that have been made in Canada during the past four years, the one that, in the estimation of its authors, has worked most effectively is undoubtedly the price-control system, inaugurated in December, 1941.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., July 3 -Hoosier high school youths have the greatest faith in the United States Government, according to an analysis of "The Purdue Opinion Poll for Young People" conducted by Dr. H.H. Remmers and R.L. Hobson of the Division of Educational Reference.

The Inter-Continent News, the Communist agency which supplies the Communist Daily Worker with most of its reading matter, reports from Moscow that the Soviet press is giving front page prominence to a report that the collective farmer Berdybekov, chairman of the "Karl Marx" collective farm in Pahkta Aral district of Kazakhstan, together with his family, bought war bonds to the amount of 1,037,000 rubles and paid for them in full and in cash.

THE rare Lycoris, which grows lushly in Virginia, is a native of China and Japan. It was brought from England many years ago and planted in the garden of the Governor's Palace in Williamsburg. Later it was widely distributed and it is now well known in many parts of the United States.

To eliminate the chaotic conditions now prevailing throughout the Federal Government, Washington should attempt to apply the fundamental rules of scientific management, built up by industry over a period of years, Edwin G. Booz, president of the Association of Consulting Management Engineers and senior partner of Booz, Allen Hamilton, management engineers, declared here yesterday.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 3 -- Reports reaching one diplomatic source at Istanbul today asserted that Communist partisans in Yugoslavia had agreed to an armed truce with the Italian troops of occupation in Slovenia, Dalmatia and Montenegro in exchange for promises by the Italians not to interfere with the Partisans in their fighting against the Germans, Bulgars and Hungarians elsewhere in Yugoslavia.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -The Army is reported to have agreed to turn over to civilian industry. 10 per cent of the about 130,000 students whom it sends to college for specialized training.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The names, with next of kin, of 190 United States soldiers killed in action in the North American area were made public today by the War Department. Most of these casualties occurred in the Aleutians and some include men long reported missing but now counted as dead. The War Department also gave out the names of 246 soldiers reported missing in action in the European area.

July is the high noon of the northern year, month of ripened wheat and windrowed hay, of firefly nights and corn growing so fast out in Ioway that you can hear its joints pop in the moonlight. July is hot days and sultry nights, rolling thunder and slashing rain and white-fanged lightning. Young eagles take wing in July.

EVANSTON, Ill., July 3 (AP) -Hal Davis, California's great sprinter, retains his two places on the All-America college track and field team, the only one of last year's double-event performers to do so on the 1943 team, announced today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association track rules committee.

LONDON, July 3 -- British Communists, meeting today in a party convention under the leadership of Harry Pollitt, reiterated their demands for the immediate opening of a second front and for affiliation with the Labor party. The Laborites recently rejected the Communist application for union.

FREEHOLD, N.J., July 3 -- Construction of a $12,000,000 Navy ordnance depot on 11,000 acres in Howell, Atlantic and Shrewsbury Townships will begin in three weeks and will be completed in ten months. It will take in land earmarked for construction of the Asbury Park airport. Capt. J.D. Wilson, officer in charge of the project told the Monmouth County Board of Freeholders and township representatives here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- With controversies over appropriation bills involving differences between the Administration and a bipartisan opposition still untangled, Congress failed today to meet the objective, voiced last week by leaders on both sides, that it recess today for a two-month vacation.

ONCE the stress and strain of 1943's Victory Garden is past, Victory Gardeners will be thinking in terms of 1944 and its problems -- among which fertilizer and preparation of the soil loom large. In many sections the "two area" vegetable garden has become popular.

CLEVELAND, July 3 (AP) -- His Excellency, world champion trotter of 1942, sped to a straight-heat victory in the $2,612 championship Stallion Stake, featured event of the Grand Circuit program at North Randall today. Scotland's Comet was second in each of the two heats of the Grand Circuit feature.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -Coal production in the first half of this year fell 1,729,000 tons below the 1942 period, Secretary Ickes reported today. He attributed the decrease to strikes.

THE demand for musicians in the popular field has reached the highest point in several years, thanks to a wartime boom in music and a shortage of available musicians. A survey of booking agencies in New York reveals that they are unable to fill the requests for orchestras.

Fragmentation bombs are dropped by means of specially designed rayon parachutes. The bomber skims along at a height which is often no more than fifty to seventy-five feet. If parachutes were not used a bomb at such low altitudes might endanger the plane. Rayon parachutes delay the descent for a few moments and thus allow bombers to move out of the danger zone.

The Fourth Constitutional Convention of the National Maritime Union, Committee of Industrial Organizations, will meet on Tuesday at 10 A.M. in the Manhattan Center on West Thirty-fourth Street. The sessions will continue through the week.
