Mott, attached to Hook and Ladder Company 26 in Harlem, charged yesterday that a jurisdictional dispute between American Federation of Labor unions in the printing trades was being injected into the forthcoming election of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, AFL, by incumbent officers to defeat his candidacy for trustee for Manhattan.

The refusal of the House on Friday to override the Presidential veto of the anti-subsidy measure brought heavy liquidation in the cotton futures market in the short session yesterday. At one time on the New York Cotton Exchange prices were down 14 to 22 points, but recovered near the close to finish at net losses of 8 to 9 points.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 3 -- Persistent rumors of trouble come from France tonight. They are difficult to confirm, for there are no means of free communication, not to mention the strict censorship.

LONDON, July 3 -- Wherever offensives develop in the next phase of the European fighting, one somewhere in the Mediterranean, even if it turns out to be only subsidiary to a big thrust elsewhere, appears imperative.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Treasury experts are answering many inquiries regarding the apparently large numbers of taxpayers who will pay more through withholding than they owe, with the statement that this is one of the unavoidable results of a current system of collection of taxes at the source which takes into account nontaxable income of individuals.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 3 (AP) -Although forced to retire because of a leg injury suffered in the eighth inning, Jack Tising gained credit for a brilliant shut-out victory over the Bears as Buffalo took a 6-to-0 verdict today to square the series of four games.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, July -- United States Independence Day is being marked by Rio de Janeiro with special zest this year. This morning a group of prominent Brazilians visited the American Embassy to extend congratulations through Ambassador Jefferson Caffery.

One of the latest war casualties the New York Athletic Club Yachting Department, which has rented its snug little yacht house and yacht yard at Travers Island, is making the best of the situation. It is carrying on.
ATLANTA, July 3 (AP) -- W. Allen Murphy is a 45-year-old Negro waiter at the Piedmont Driving Club. He's tall, spectacled, quietly dignified, earnest in thought and action.

Preparations are going forward for the closing on July 15 of the New York-New Jersey regional office of the Office of War Information and branch offices in Buffalo, Albany, Syracuse and Newark, Hector Perrier, regional director, said yesterday, with a consequent loss of forty-nine jobs.

OMAHA, Neb., July 3 -- Harvest days are here, reading from south to north, and with them the now chronic condition of a skilled-labor shortage. But this shortage is not being discussed, as it was a year ago, as something in the nature of a crisis or as portending a breakdown of farm production.

With the war and armament industries requiring a steadily increasing quantity of petroleum products, a real crisis in the domestic supply of oil may develop before the end of this year unless greater use is made of the huge foreign sources of supply which, because of difficulties of transportation, so far have played a comparatively minor role in the war effort.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- The opposing houses of labor have found a common meeting and working ground here in the construction of an outdoor USO-Labor outdoor canteen which will be dedicated Monday to the entertainment of service men and women.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- Despite a shortage of beef in the retail markets the American livestock man is faced with "a serious problem of over-production," Dan C. McKinney, secretary of the California Cattlemen's Association, asserted in a statement today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 -- A post-war "work-pile" plan developed by the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce as a "shock absorber" for the transition period between the end of hostilities and the return to stable peacetime business levels is attracting inquiries from all parts of the nation and from foreign countries.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the War Food Administration follows:

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recently I sent to a British friend a magazine article drawing attention to the fact that the American press did not adequately report the proceedings of Congress and contrasting this with the report of parliamentary proceedings by the press in Great Britain. The reply of my British friend seems to me to be highly interesting to American readers:

If figures were all that the country had from which to form an opinion of wartime performance, the fact that the steel industry in the first five months of 1943 produced only 210,000 tons more of finished steel products than a year before might be discouraging, particularly since ingot production was 1,320,000 tons higher for the period.

Thursday, July 1, 1943, marked for the American income taxpayer the beginning of a hectic period of transition from the old system of payment to the new pay-as-you-go method. From now until next March 15 employers, employes -- nearly anyone who has money pass through his hands -- will be concerned with a vast amount of calculation and bookkeeping.

NURSE'S AIDES are desperately needed in all civilian hospitals, as the graduate nurses are going into the armed forces at the rate of some three thousand a month; but while the need has been widely publicized, the response has been inadequate.

THE women of the United States have had a new job of price-watching cut out for them since President Roosevelt issued his famous "hold the line" order against inflation. With three-quarters of the nation's shopping done by women, much depends on them.

THIS year the vacationist is seeing to it that he has a place to stay before he leaves the family hearthstone. Gone are the days when he stepped into the family car, trusting to luck to find a pleasant night's lodging somewhere along the highway en route to other one or two-night stands.

WILL it be possible to make ice cream this summer? The question, put to several home economists by this department received an answer in the affirmative. Yes, they said, even though heavy whipping cream is no longer obtainable, you can still evolve certain frozen desserts at home, and without reliance on evaporated milk, which is rationed.

IN response to protests because Denmark had not been included among the German-held European nations receiving postal tribute, Postmaster General Frank C. Walker announced last week that "Denmark has been added to the list of overrun countries being honored" by an issue of stamps.
CHUNGKING, July 4 -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek, wife of China's Generalissimo, returned home today aboard a four-engined American transport plane, manned by an American crew.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- Equally weighted at 126 pounds, the Green-tree Stable's Shut Out and Lou Tufano's Market Wise shared the early public sentiment as possible winners of tomorrow's ninth running of the $50,000 added Massachusetts Handicap -- richest stake of the New England turf season before a crowd expected to exceed 40,000.

UNITED STATES AIR HEADQUARTERS, Solomon Islands, July 2 (Delayed) (UP) -- Latest figures available on the air fighting in the New Georgia area indicate that losses of American airmen have been less than one-fourth of the enemy's.
BERNE, Switzerland, July 4 -- July 4, 1943, found Vichy very anti-American outwardly. Inwardly, the story is different.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- An open Finnish bid for better relations with the United States, in disregard of German pressure on Finland, aroused interest in diplomatic quarters here today.
Breathes there an eighth-place club with soul so dead that never (on July 4) to itself has said: "The Braves of 1914 did it"?

LONDON, July 4 -- The twenty-eight-hour Atlantic crossing by a fully loaded glider with an eighty-four-foot wingspread has set a precedent that may be of great significance to the future of air transport, both in war and in peace.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Treasury has for some time been studying the problem of how to tax the increases in individual income due to the war. Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, asked some time ago that the possibilities for such a tax be surveyed.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN NORTH AFRICA, July 4 -- Allied bombers and fighters struck their heaviest blow against enemy air power in the mid-Mediterranean area since the fall of Pantelleria when hundreds of planes lashed eight important Axis airfields yesterday.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., July 4 -- Every pew in Christ Episcopal Church, where Theodore Roosevelt worshiped while occupying Sagamore Hill, his home near by, was filled this morning at the dedication of a new altar shrine in honor of the members of the parish serving in the armed forces.

NEW HAVEN, July 4 -- The Winchester Arms Company is supplying the Army with a new weapon, the Winchester carbine, which will deliver twenty aimed shots a minute and has an effective range of 300 yards. It fires a .30 caliber ball cartridge and has an eighteen-inch barrel.

SOMEWHERE IN NEW GUINEA, July 4 -- Gen. Douglas MacArthur arrived in New Guinea several days before the "target day" to direct the start of the new Allied offensive in the South Pacific last Wednesday, it may now be revealed.

Just as freedom "must be circumscribed for the good of the whole," independence cannot be "a selfish good held in isolation," the Rev. Dr. John C. Sehroeder, master of Calhoun College at Yale University, declared yesterday morning in a sermon in Riverside Church.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Charity is the sure winner although the first horse will draw down $46,550 tomorrow if all sixteen nominees go in the Stars and Stripes Handicap at Arlington Park's meeting at the Washington Park track.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Two training schools will be inaugurated this month by the National League of Women Voters to prepare leaders for a summer round-up to mobilize the 50,000 members of the league "for an active campaign to help the American people realize that the United States is part of the world and must cooperate with the rest of the world, now or never," the League announced tonight.

Alike in the stock market, in the bond market and in the grain markets, prices advanced rapidly last week. Stocks reached toward the week-end the highest average since May, 1940, bonds the highest since March, 1937. Rye reached at one time a higher price than any in the past fifteen years; the price of oats could not be matched in twenty-three years.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Navy communique 432:

BERNE, Switzerland, July 4 -- Premier Mussolini warned the Fascist Directorate on June 24 that Italy must win the war or be reduced to the rank of a fourth or fifth rate power, according to a text of his address issued today by Stefani.

Max Flick, who built the six-story apartment house at 3045 Godwin Terrace, adjoining the corner of 231st Street, in the Bronx, in 1940, has sold it to a client of S.W. Sollfrey, attorney. The house, which is on a plot 150 by 100 feet, contains seventy-eight apartments and is assessed at $280,000.

A prediction that there may one day be a Declaration of Interdependence by the nations of the world ushering in a world brotherhood was voiced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. F. Howard Callahan in an Independence Day sermon at the Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 -- Steel ingot output last week was off sharply, to 93 per cent of rated capacity. This was a decline of 4 points from the week before and was almost entirely due to the coal strike.

The President's veto message on Friday raised two grave problems: first, what policy Congress and the Administration should now adopt with regard to subsidies; and second, what the relationship of the President and Congress will be in dealing with the whole domestic economic problem.

CRANE, Ind., July 4 (AP) -- Neatly, row on row, 600 housing units stand waiting for occupants. In the city hall the signs "Mayor," "Fire Chief" and "Police Chief" identify offices, but the men who will fill those posts are yet to be named.
LONDON, Monday, July 5 (Reuter) -- United States forces have made an encouraging beginning in their bold venture in the Southwest Pacific, said a London Times editorial today.

Freight carloadings in the third quarter of this year are expected to be 1.5 per cent more than in the same period of 1942, according to a tabulation by the thirteen Shippers Advisory Boards. These estimates indicate that loadings of the twenty-eight principal commodities will be 9,959,651 cars in the third quarter of this year, compared with 9,814,974 in the similar period of 1942.

BOSTON, July 4 (AP) -- The Braves snapped a six-game losing streak today by winning a double-header with the Pirates. They took the opener, 3 -- 1, behind Red Barrett's four-hit pitching and blasted out a 13 -- 0 triumph for Jim Tobin in the nightcap.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.) -- Col. Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Waacs, to be known as the Wac or Women's Army Corps after Sept. 30, said tonight that every woman in uniform enabled one father to remain with his family and thereby helped preserve "the core of American civilization and culture."
Yesterday's Italian communique, as broadcast from Rome and recorded by The United Press:

DETROIT, July 4 -- Maybe the gallant crew of the Flying Fortress Memphis Belle furnished the inspiration. Perhaps the Yanks felt too close to being toppled from the American League lead. Or maybe they just got tired of being kicked around.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, July 5 -- American troops, tightening their ring around the Japanese base at Munda in the central Solomons, have landed on a third island in that area, killing 300 of the Japanese garrison and dispersing the rest, a communique revealed today.

If the vegetable pack of 1943 declines, it will not be the result of lack of tin plate, in the opinion of the magazine Steel, which reports that a backward spring, heavy floods in the Middle West and certain other developments indicate a lighter harvest than a year ago.
Yesterday's German communique, as broadcast from Berlin and recorded by The United Press:

BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP) -- With the band playing "Yankee Doodle Dandy" and 20,000 persons roaring approval, the Liberty ship George M. Cohan, named for the late showman-songwriter who was born July 4, slid smoothly into the waters of Chesapeake Bay today.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The Government will exercise almost complete domination over the marketing and distribution of corn during the July 1-Aug. 10 period as the result of a war food administration announcement which stated that farmers who sell cash corn during that period will share in any increase in the ceiling prices if such is announced prior to Oct. 31.

The New York State Labor Relations Board nnounced yesterday that it had designated Local 101 of the Tr,-port Workers Union of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, as the collective-bargaining agency for emlloyes of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, exclusive of clerlcal and supervisory personnel andl salesmen.

" Listen to the People," Stephen Vincent Benet's poem, written for radio and first heard on Independence Day two years ago, will be heard again today on the Cavalcade of America program at 8 P.M. over the National Broadcasting Company network in a special July 2 program featuring a tribute to Mr. Benet.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4 -- The medal-winning team of Ray F. Kilthau of Oakland and Reginald G. Narelle of the home club today continued along their pace-setting journey in the North Hempstead Country Club's annual member-guest best-ball golf tournament.

Bergen County Sheriff Robert S. Tipping said last night that he believed that he had found the Fairview. N.J. gambling house to which dice and card players were alleged to have been steered from the closed Fort Lee gaming establishment but that he couldn't find the Fairview police chief to question him about it.

NEW ORLEANS, July 4 (AP) -- Rangy Bob Montgomery, recognized as world lightweight champion in New York and Pennsylvania, scored a sixth-round knockout over Chicago's Al Reasoner today before 5,500 spectators. The bout ended 2 minutes and 15 seconds after the sixth began.

At least one radio commentator advocates the shooting of certain Nazis without trial. This is the Nazi method we condemn. Criminals should be convicted only after a fair trial in which they have had an opportunity to defend themselves.

Asserting that all Americans were united on winning the war, the national affairs committee of the National Republican Club issued a statement yesterday declaring that the entire world would suffer if the United States failed to maintain a sound economic position and charging that the Roosevelt Administration had sought to discourage private enterprise.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 4 (U.P.) -- Roane Waring, national commander of the American Legion, accused the Federal Government tonight of usurping State's rights and assuming a control over individual citizens "never intended by the authors of the Constitution."

It has often been said that if the American people were subjected to aerial bombing they would unite as the people of England have done. Petty quarrels there have been submerged in the magnificent fight which the British people have made to save their homeland and to rid the world of the Axis and all it stands for.

HAWAIIAN AIR DEPOT, HICKMAN FIELD, Hawaii, July 4 -- Suggestions made by pilots returned from combat for small changes in their planes were put into effect by shop workers here and the result was greater aerial losses for the Japanese, Lieut. Gen. Robert C. Richardson Jr., commander of the Hawaiian Department, said today in presenting the Army-Navy "E" for excellence to this air depot.

LONDON, July 4 -- Solemn Te Deum was sung in the Greek Cathedral in London today in honor of United States Independence Day. American soldiers and sailors of Greek origin were invited to the services by Archbishop Germanos, who presided.
DALLAS, Tex., July 4 (UP) -- Two Dallas County deputy sheriffs remained on guard last night to see for themselves whether the furniture at the T.A. Hardin home really does sail around the rooms.

JERUSALEM, July 4 -- Several hundred Russian soldiers -- the first to pass through Palestine in this war -- attracted much attention it Haifa this week-end when groups were surrounded by passersby or followed by admiring children.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 -- Susan Hayward has been borrowed from Paramount by Samuel Bronston to portray the role of Charmian, the wife of Jack London, in the film biography of the author which goes into production this coming week-end.

LARAMIE, Wyo., July 4 (AP) -- Sheriff Ed A. Wood announced that a man held by police officers in Cheyenne was identified late today by Mrs. O.W. Larson as the man who killed her companion, Mat Katmo, and then beat her after they stepped out of Katmo's car to pick flowers in a mountain camp ground last Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The War Department made public today the names of 134 United States soldiers killed in action in the Aleutian, Asiatic, European, Middle Eastern, North African, Pacific and Southwest Pacific areas.
OWA CITY, July 4 (AP) -- Slip Madigan came back to the football wars today.
LONDON, Monday, July 5 (U.P.) -- The Russian Sunday midnight communique, as broadcast from Moscow:
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Monday, July 5 (U.P.) -- The noon communique:

ARNE ANDERSSON had to wait until Gunder Haegg got out of the country to do it, but the 27-year-old school teacher from Sweden ripped off a gaudy world record 4:02.6 mile at Goeteborg last week. Don't look now, but that "impossible" four-minute mile is just around the corner.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP) -- The Browns, led by Chet Laabs, who pounded out two home runs, came to life at the plate today and downed the Senators in a doubleheader, 4 to 2 and 10 to 3. The second contest was called at the end of seven innings so the Senators could catch a train.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A "workable meat program" drawn up after conferences with representatives of all factors in the meat industry today was presented to Federal food officials by Representative of Walter C. Ploeser, Republican, of Missouri.

In its issue of June 27 THE NEW YORK TIMES published a United Press dispatch from Rio de Janeiro which contains statements that are incorrect. "Brazil is carrying out a vast program to attain economic dominance if South America.

CHUNGKING, China, July 4 (U.P.) -- Chinese troops have repulsed Japanese attacks around Kungan, southern Hupeh Province, and have hurled back reinforced enemy units at Chowchiachang, twelve miles east of Kungan, inficting more than 100 casualties on the invaders, the Chinese High Command announced tonight.

PITTSBURGH, July 4 (AP) -- Both management and union leaders looked optimistically today to the restoration of near-capacity production in the coal fields by Tuesday while a wave of work-on-Monday sentiment over the weekend indicated most of the country's 521,000 miners would work the first holiday shift in the history of the United Mine Workers.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 4 -- The German meat ration is scheduled to be reduced again this autumn, according to information received here through private channels from Berlin. It was cut early this year from 350 to 250 grams a week.

LONDON, July 4 -- The harvest will not be good in Hyde Park this season according to reports collected on the spot this afternoon from "farmers" who cultivate some of the most interesting soft in London.

Oliver Lyttelton, British Minister of Production, disclosed yesterday in a broadcast on the operations of lend-lease and reverse lend-lease that the British Commonwealth's war production exceeded that of Germany, Austria and Czechoslovakia put together.

A group of Americans formerly closely associated with the League of Nations has begun the first intensive study looking toward the utilization of the knowledge gained by League agencies, as well as the determination of the place of the League itself in any plans for a post-war world, it was announced yesterday by the League of Nations Association.

Since it is the avowed purpose of our patent law to encourage invention, the courts construed broadly the patentee's exclusive right to make, sell and use his invention -- probably more broadly than the framers of the Constitution intended. Thus the door was opened wide for questionable practices.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The possibility of British-grown potatoes appearing on American tables next winter was seen tonight in an exchange of correspondence between the lend-lease administrator, Edward R. Stettinius Jr., and Representative Raymond S. Springer, Republican, of Indiana.

The fifth of July is distinguished through the years for little except its staggering score of sunburns. On or about this day every year -- according to estimates of the Greater New York Safety Council -- the vast majority of vacation-born blisters are just beginning to make their presence felt.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Bullish sentiment predominated in the grain markets last week, as announcement that the Commodity Credit Corporation had ceased to sell cash wheat to distillers at relatively low prices, and would not sell additional grain at less than parity, furnishing the main background for a material broadening in general buying.

I was amused by your article relating the language differences which cause trouble for American and British soldiers in England. I am inclined to think that some writers on this subject -- and I have seen Dave Breger's amusing book -- rather draw the long bow in an effort to make their point.

A new method of salting vegetables has been devised by the United States Department of Agriculture working in cooperation with the North Carolina Agricultural Experiment Station. The process, which is a variation of one mentioned in this column several times, departs from the usual practice in that it uses less salt and some vinegar.

BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -- The whole Argentine democratic press gives much space to the Fourth of July, printing ample accounts of the ceremonies with which it is celebrated and also commentaries underlining its significance, especially now that the United States leads the United Nations in the war.

" We've been seeing a bit of action lately," Pvt. Daniel Soloway, 21 years old, wrote from the New Guinea area to his sister, Muriel, on June 14. "We've got a little job lined up for tonight. I hope old Tojo has a hell of a headache tomorrow morning!"
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 4 -- Vice Admiral John H. Hoover returned tonight from his conference with Admiral Georges Robert at Martinique and summed up his impressions in one word: "Favorable."

Gone are the days when only husky male swimmers were considered for lifeguard duty at beaches and pools. Both the Lexington Avenue and the West Side branches of the Young Women's Christian Association have opened their pools to Army and Navy men for afternoon and evening swims, with several girl lifeguards ready to give advice, first aid or artificial respiration, if needed.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- If the Administration wins a temporary victory on the food subsidy issue Congress probably will quit by midweek with President Roosevelt's batting average on major legislation standing well over the .500 mark.

Pennant races aren't decided by July 4, but it would be hard to convince 33,003 Flatbush fans, record crowd of the season at Ebbets Field, that the world champion Cardinals didn't eliminate the Dodgers yesterday when the Redbirds swept a double-header.
ELIZABETH, N.J., July 4 -- Once again it was Francisco (Pancho) Segura today.
NEWARK, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- The tail-end Jersey City Giants celebrated Independence Day today with a display of batting fireworks which rocked the Newark Bears for a twin defeat, 4 to 2 and 11 to 7.

The war-brought scarcity of new golf balls and the eagerness of duffers to get a ball that will give them something resembling a 100-yard drive, yesterday brought John Clancy, 47 years old, of 5724 Faraday Avenue, the Bronx, into Bronx Magistrate's Court on a charge of operating a gambling device.

NEW ORLEANS, July 4 -- More attention was paid last week on the Cotton Exchange here to the rather favorable crop reports by the Government and also by private sources. The Rio Grande Valley area reported the best progress since planting time, and in spite of general boll weevil infestation, one of the best yields in recent years may result.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 4 (AP) -- When General MacArthur went to New Guinea to take personal command of the new Allied offensive in the Southwest Pacific, it was the second time in eight months that General MacArthur had gone to the battle zone in New Guinea.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 4 (UP) -- While General MacArthur was directing the operation from his field headquarters, Prime Minister John Curtin of Australia was reported spending much of his time in Canberra studying battle reports.

Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday in urging a "100 per cent prayer effort" for a Christian peace at a solemn mass at the cathedral.
ALBANY, July 4 -- New York State, at the request of the War Department, opened today a block by block canvass to spur enlistments as Wacs and as Aviation Cadets of the Army air forces.
SOMEWHERE IN AUSTRALIA, June 29 (Delayed) (AP) -- Almost 400 young Americans wore the gold bars of second lieutenants today after having won commissions through the Officers' Candidate School.

It is symbolic and prophetic that American forces are engaged in offensive action in the Pacific as China ends her sixth year of resistance to Japanese aggression. It was July 7, 1937, that Japanese troops fired on the Chinese holding the famous Marco Polo bridge, in the suburbs of Peiping, and sounded the signal for the Sino-Japanese war.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- A material enlargement in the receipts of hogs is reflected in increasing supply of lard held in cold storage. Stocks here on Wednesday agg regated 30,392,000 pounds, a gain of 13,730,000 pounds during the last month, and compared with 23,537,000 pounds last year.

MANCHESTER, Vt., July 4 -- Upset followed upset in the annual Robert Todd Lincoln golf tournament at the Ekwanok Country Club today and when the two rounds were finished the medalist, 23-year-old J.H. Hunter of North Adams, Mass., had been reduced to the spectator ranks and the metropolitan district's representation of four, after yesterday's qualifying test, was completely wiped out.

LONDON, July 4 -- With the half-year passed and the big national savings campaign now closed, a distinct revival is taking place in the stock markets. Speculative favorites have been well to the fore, gold mining, oil and rubber shares making most of the running and gilt-edge securities staging a modest but fairly general recovery.

CAIRO, Egypt, July 4 -- In a broadcast from Cairo tonight, King George of Greece appealed to all Greeks for political unity and promised free elections for a constituent assembly convention within six months of the liberation of the country.

The Church Committee on Overseas Relief and Reconstruction, 297 Fourth Avenue, announced yesterday that $1,850,000 was sought from American Protestant churches for the year 1943-44. This amount has been approved by the committee, which represents more than twenty denominations.

Purchase of the Jewish Maternity Hospital at 270 East Broadway by the Home of the Sages of Israel, 268 East Broadway, was announced yesterday by Herman Bieler, superintendent of the home. The hospital will be remodeled, he said, to provide dormitories and private rooms for an increasing number of aged rabbis cared for by the home.
GORHAM, Me., July 4 (AP) -- Ten harness horses perished and one of the owners was burned severely early today in a spectacular fire that leveled a 110-stall stable at the Gorham raceway.

The importance of the new American offensive in the southwest Pacific is emphasized anew by the disclosure of Allied Headquarters in Australia that General Douglas MacArthur is in supreme command of all land, sea and air forces participating in it, and that he has established new headquarters in New Guinea, to be closer to the scene of operations.
While differing on subsidies, former President Herbert Hoover and Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia urged yesterday in radio broadcasts that prompt steps be taken to avert a national food crisis.

Last week the Irving Fisher index of wholesale commodity prices remained at the previous week's level of 111.1. The only major commodity index to change was the finished goods index which advanced 0.1 per cent as a result of an upward revision of the ceiling price on broadcloth.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 4 (AP) -- A speech on race relations which was to have been given by Professor Maurice R. Davie of Yale University over Station WTIC in Hartford was cancelled tonight, the station said, because of a reference in the script to Red Cross policy on Negro blood donors.

The thunder of bombs and the crackle of machine-gun fire on the far-off fighting fronts replaced the noisy rattle of the firecrackers of yesteryear as the nation celebrated the 167th anniversary of the Declaration of Independence yesterday with a grim resolve to maintain at all costs the freedom then won.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y. July 4 -- John D. Rockefeller Jr. was the principal speaker this afternoon when the Historical Society of the Tarrytowns dedicated its $500,000 restoration of Philipse Castle and Philipse Manor as a shrine, museum and society headquarters on Albany Post Road opposite the old Sleepy Hollow Church immortalized by Washington Irving.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 4 (AP) -- A Chinese laundryman of Ashland, Ky., and his wife today received the Air Medal for their son, Sgt. Charles S. Dick, a gunner in the American Army Air Forces, who is officially listed as missing in action in the European war theatre.

Germany has lost the war and Hitler's "fortress Europe" cannot be defended, according to a message prepared for the German people yesterday by the Conference of German-Speaking Social Democrats. The group met in the Rand School. 7 East Fifteenth Street.

The republics of South and Central America have surpassed the United States in resolving the vital questions of race and internationalism, the Rev. Dr. John Alexander Mackay, president of Princeton Theological Seminary, asserted yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UP) -- Potatoes have come back into their own. The Food Distribution Administration in a statement issued yesterday calculated to hearten housewives, who had become resigned to eking out rationed menus with rice and macaroni.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UP) -- American troops in the British isles have earned a reputation as "well-mannered guests," according to Brig. Gen. Lawrence H. Hedrick, former judge advocate general of United States Army forces in the European theatre.

If rate of compensation is an indication of worth, then women from 56 to 65 give the most valuable service of any age group, according to a survey of the membership of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs, Inc.
LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as broadcast from Moscow and recorded by the Soviet monitor:

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 4 (AP) -- A Berlin dispatch to the newspaper Aftonbladet reported today that a new German "general service" military branch headed by Grand Admiral Erich Raeder had been created, apparently to combat any Allied invasion.

HAVANA, July 4 -- Cuba celebrated the Fourth of July today as if it were her own national holiday. The unprecedented festivities reached a climax with a gigantic parade in honor of the United States, in which 80,000 Cubans of all walks of life and officials and members of industrial, commercial, agricultural, political, civic, cultural and patriotic organizations marched.

MARIENVILLE, Pa., July 4 -- Seven residents of Elmira, N.Y., on the way home from an outing in Niles, Ohio, were burned to death when their automobile was in collision with another machine near this community today.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 4 -- Local daily newspaper service to the people of Rhode Island will be interrupted for the first time in 114 years next Wednesday, if members of Providence Typographical Union No. 33 go on strike against the Providence Journal Company, as they voted today to do.

LONDON, July 4 (UP) -- Lieut. Col. Chesly G. Peterson of Santaquin, Utah, already a hero, formerly with the American Eagle Squadron, today received the Distinguished Service Cross for "extraordinary heroism" in single-handedly routing an attack by eight enemy planes on a bombing formation, probably downing one Axis ship and damaging another.

ALGIERS, July 4 (UP) -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower hailed British and French participation today in American Independence Day ceremonies throughout North Africa as a symbol of Allied war solidarity and termed this "a source of apprehension and terror" for the enemy.

LONDON, Monday, July 5 (AP) -- the Germans suffered 800 dead in two futile charges against an important height on the northwest front yesterday, Moscow announced early today, while the Berlin radio said Russian transport movements along the huge front had been completed and "a Soviet offensive now is to be expected almost any day."
A major change in German strategy is now occurring in Europe -- a change so fundamental that it may well affect the course and duration of the war.

Reuben Fine of Washington successfully defended the speed championship of the United States Chess Federation with a clean score of eleven victories in the second annual tournament at the Hotel Capitol last night.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- With Commissioner Robert C. Healy dissenting, the Securities and Exchange Commission granted permission to the New York Curb Exchange yesterday to extend unlisted trading privileges to the $25,000,000 of 3 3/4 per cent first mortgage bonds, Series A, due 1969, of the Central Power and Light Company and to the 4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due 1970, of the Kentucky Utilities Company.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- United States bombers resumed their pounding of Kiska Friday with eight attacks on the Japanese-held Aleutian Island and followed yesterday with another raid, the Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- James Lawrence Fly, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, charged today that Representative Edward Eugene Cox was conspiring with "the radio monopoly and Wall Street interests on the one hand and the military on the other" to "wreck" the commission.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The Phillies and the Cubs split a double-header at Shibe Park today before a crowd of 15,671 that sent the Phillies 6,552 over their last year's total home attendance for the season. Bucky Harris' team took the first game, 2 to 1, and the Cubs the second, 5 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has announced that the Consolidated Natural Gas Company, formed by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey in its effort to escape provisions of the Holding Company Act, had filed an amendment application proposing to acquire the securities of the New York State Natural Gas Corporation in exchange for its own stock.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Congress headed toward a long-deferred recess tonight, but a few important issues which promised brisk battles must be disposed of this week before the weary legislators leave for home.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (U.P.) -- City girls are "taking to the soil" and proving they can pick beans, pitch hay, or milk cows like veterans, Florence Hall, National Director of the Women's Land Army, said tonight.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, July 4 (AP) -- The first American landing boat debarked its complement of heavily armed, picked combat troops on Kiriwina Island in twenty-eight minutes in a perfectly coordinated landing operation.

A Fourth of July program devoted to contemporary American works was presented by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Morton Gould, last night at the Lewisohn Stadium. The offerings were of a predominatingly light caliber well suited to a holiday entertainment.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 4 -- A sudden welding of wind clouds that had tantalized for a time provided the best sailing of the season today on Long Island Sound. It was in the Independence Day championship regatta of the New Rochelle Yacht Club.

HEADQUARTERS OF AMPHIBIOUS FORCES in the Solomons, July 2 (Delayed), (UP) -- The transport McCawley, veteran of a score of war exploits, is gone -- sunk by Japanese planes as the price for the landing of thousands of troops and tons of equipment in the New Georgia area.
MEXICO CITY, July 4 -- The Administration party (P.R.M.) late this afternoon announced overwhelming victory in every one of Mexico's twenty-eight States.

Employers and parents were warned yesterday by Mayor Florello H. La Guardia against what he called "really alarming trends toward child labor." The warning was issued by means of a recording, made by the Mayor just before he left the city for a tour of Canada with the United States-Canadian Permanent Joint Board on Defense. It was broadcast by WNYC, the municipal radio station.
Herewith the set-up for the holiday in the Broadway theatres:

The Printing Arts Building, a sixteen-story structure at 228 East Forty-fifth Street, running through the block to Forty-fourth Street, has been sold by the 228 East Forty-fifth Street Corporation to a client of Joseph G. Abramson, attorney. It fronts 127 feet on Forty-fifth Street and was sold subject to a first mortgage of more than $1,000,000 held by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The war may "harden us physically but only God can restore us morally and spiritually," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer declared yesterday in a Fourth of July sermon at the Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, in which he called for "a rebirth of freedom and a rebirth of spirituality."

Sgt. Barney Ross, the former lightweight and welterweight champion, received the Silver Star Medal yesterday for "conspicuous gallantry and intrepidity against the enemy" with the Marines on Guadalcanal. The award was made during a "Tribute to America's Heroes" program at the studios of Radio Station WJZ.

After moving upward in the first part of last week, the cotton market turned easier in final dealings and lost a large part of its earlier gains. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week of a decline of 1 point to an advance of 14 points.

COHOES, N.Y., July 4 -- Major James J. O'Donovan of Cohoes, former military instructor at La Salle Institute, died June 30 in the Philippine Islands, where he was held prisoner by the Japanese, according to word received from the War Department by his mother, Mrs. Loula O'Donovan.

CINCINNATI, July 4 -- Ten rabbis who in normal times would have graduated next June were ordained at Hebrew Union College yesterday. They will go to pulpits of rabbis on leave as chaplains with the armed forces.

The transition of control over steel distribution from the Production Requirements Plan to the Controlled Materials Plan is now complete, as of July 1, and while some difficulties are being met in application of the new method, most steel users have followed instructions and are well covered, according to the magazine Steel.

An American "Declaration of Interdependence" of the nations of the world was proposed yesterday by Wendell L. Willkie as a sign that this country wants the creation of a world in which there is equality of opportunity for every race and every nation.

SEATTLE, July 4 (AP) -- American casualties on Attu reached the care of Pacific Coast hospitals before Japanese resistance on the island was overcome, Col. Louis Brecheman Jr., Seattle port surgeon, said today. Nearly all wounded have been brought more than 3,000 miles back to the United States.

The Service Flag and the Gold Star Flag of the New York Archdiocesan Union of Holy Name Societies were seen by the public again yesterday, Independence Day, for the first time in several months having been rehung Saturday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Royal Air Force rocked the already devastated city of Cologne for forty-five minutes last night and also pounded Hamburg. Large formations of American Flying Fortresses took over the offensive by daylight today and laid a destructive bomb pattern across three important Axis targets, Nantes, Le Mans and La Pallice in France.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- Orval Grove held the Athletics to three hits after Thornton Lee had pitched a six-hitter against them to give the White Sox twin victories, 5 to 2 and 5 to 1, before 18,020 spectators today. The double triumph moved the uprising Chicagoans into a third-place tie with Detroit, only two and one-half games behind first place.

NEW DELHI, India, July 4 (UP) -- Mitchell medium bombers of the Tenth United States Air Force made a successful attack yesterday on the Myitnge road and railway bridge south of Mandalay, Burma, which the Japanese had restored to service following damage caused in previous American raids, a communique reported today.

If the American public didn't realize that the Fourth of July week-end this year was a bad one on which to travel it wasn't because it hadn't been told. Director Joseph B. Eastman of the Office of Defense Transportation warned and urged those who could possibly stay at home to do so.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS FOR THE SOUTHWEST PACIFIC, July 4 -- The Japanese give every indica tion of putting up a stiff battle for New Georgia Island and to retain their air base there. Use of a naval task force to shell American positions on Rendova Saturday can be taken as evidence that the Japanese are prepared to risk considerable resources in an effort to hold the island.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- Trading in rye futures on the Board of Trade set a new high record last week, with a material expansion in buying attributed to distillers, cash interests and the outside public a factor. Heavy profit-taking developed on the bulge and a reaction followed, but closing trades yesterday found July rye at the highest of the season.

Active demand during the past week for all classes of wool goods is reported by the Wool Associates of the New York Cotton Exchange, Inc. However, mills have continued a cautious policy and, as a consequence, much of the effort of buyers has been devoted to the expediting of deliveries.

The extent to which subcontracting and integration of small and large businesses have spread is sharply emphasized in the statement of C.E. Wilson, president of General Motors Corporation. This prime contractor, occupied so intensively in the production of a volume of war goods which now reaches a value of some $10,000,000 a day, has a network of 19,000 different suppliers and subcontractors spreading all over the country.

Eleven graduates of metropolitan New York high schools and one boy from Albany have received scholarships to attend Fordham College, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Lawrence A. Walsh, dean. The new students, who will complete their full college course in three years under Fordham's accelerated scholastic program, will begin their studies with the entering freshman class tomorrow.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., July 5 -- Archaeologists will begin excavating here tomorrow in the old orchard of Philipse Castle, the 260-year-old shrine of Colonial life that was dedicated yesterday, in an attempt to locate the foundations of subsidiary buildings that surrounded the castle and its grist mill.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 5 -- Desertion to Sweden by German officers and soldiers in Norway has now grown to such proportions that Col. Gen. Nikolas von Falkenhorst, Commander in Chief there, has published an appeal to his troops calling on their sense of honor and duty to remain with the flag and also sharply censuring the Swedish Government for harboring this influx of deserters instead of returning them for punishment.

The play season officially starts this morning for 5,000 city boys and girls from five to fourteen years of age who will attend the 24 all-day play schools affiliated with the Play School Association.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Elmer Davis and other officals of the Office of War Information were puzzling today over the question of how far activities of the organization's domestic branch could be carried on with a total appropriation of $2,750,000 left to the agency today after the House agreed with the Senate on cutting the Senate committee recommendations of $3,561,000 down to the sum finally allowed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) -- The Cardinals and the Phillies divided a double-header before 21,067 fans at Shibe Park today. The Phillies scored a 15-to-2 victory in the opener but bowed to their old nemesis, Howie Krist, by 4 to 3 in the afterpiece.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (U.P.) -- Legislation for the draft of labor to prevent possible collapse of manpower policies appeared tonight to be headed for enactment when Congress returns from its Summer recess. It will probably have Administration backing.

Masculine or feminine, "the sailor loves the sea." And so during the national convention of the National Maritime Union that opens three-day sessions today at the Manhattan Center, 400 women of the United States Merchant Marine win submit a plea for aid in getting permission to return to their ships.

LONDON, July 5 -- Notwithstanding a 20 per cent increase in the number of passengers carried last year over 1941, there were remarkably few serious accidents on the railroads. This country had only forty-six fatalities, according to the annual report of the chief inspecting officer of the railways issued today.

Smashing all betting records for a seven-race program anywhere, the Empire City Racing Association yesterday was host at Jamaica to 41,792 persons, the biggest turf crowd ever at Jamaica or Empire City. All the profits, both on betting and admissions, went to the National War Fund.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Electric energy requirements of the principal public utility, systems of the country during May totaled 17,451,448,000 kilowatt-hours, a rise of 19.6 per cent over last year. Corresponding peak demands aggreated 33,176,937 kilowatts, up 16.7 per cent over May a year ago.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 6 (Netherlands News Agency) -- Presenting the 1942 report of the Shell Transport and Trading Company at a stockholders meeting today, the chairman, Viscount Bearsted, announced a profit of u2,893,349.

This is just a word of congratulation on the editorial "A Sentence Commuted." Our greatest peacetime problem of crime is often so little understood that your editorial, like the President's action, is encouraging.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Twenty-three manufacturers of mattresses, bedsprings and related products, known as Sealy Products, and their trade association, Sealy, Inc., 316 Broadway, New York City, have been charged by the Federal Trade Commission with maintaining a combination to restrain sales competition.

MOSCOW, July 5 -- Mikhail Kolotosoff, Georgian-born Soviet film producer, expects to be in Hollywood soon as the representative of the Soviet Film committee, which controls the production and distribution of all Soviet and foreign films here.
TORONTO, July 5 (AP) -- Gains outnumbered the losses on the Stock Exchange today and turnover was in sizable volume chiefly on the activity of some of the cheaper issues.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 5 -- Setting the pace with an individual 71, James T. Smith of the Hempstead Golf Club, paired with O.M. (Pete) Lamberson to defeat Hal Proskey and Charles B. Newman, unattached, 2 up, in the final of the North Hempstead Country Club member-guest tournament today.

DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- The Senators yielded full game today to the leading Yankees, but they protected their second-place rights by defeating the Tigers, 6 to 4, in the second half of a morningtwilight, double-header. The Tigers won the opener, 10 to 3.

ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, July 6 (U.P.) -- From Admiral Halsey's headquarters came word that United States forces now hold the islands adjacent to Rendova, which was taken in last Wednesday's opening in the South Pacific offensive.

PROVIDENCE, July 5 (AP) -- The Providence Typographical Union, Local 33, tonight reiterated its decision to strike against the three publications of the Providence Journal Company Wednesday, declaring it would not "arbitrate arbitration."

FORT GEORGE G. MEADE, Md., July 5 (AP) -- An automobile plowed through two companies of combat engineers on night maneuvers near Patapsco State Park early today, striking at least fifteen men and injuring several so severely that they may die.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- An increase of as much as 33 cents a bushel in the price of corn was recommended unanimously today by the Senate Agriculture Committee in the hope of getting on the market some of the 800,000,000 bushels held by farmers.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The White Sox and the Red Sox split before 22,487 today, the Chicagoans taking the opener, 4 to 2, when four Boston throwing errors scuttled Tex Hughson, and the Red Sox blasting Edgar Smith with a four-run fourth inning to win the second game, 6 to 1.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Gen. Henri-Honore Giraud, commander of the French armed forces in North and West Africa, who is expected here soon as a guest of the Government, will confer with the President and General George C. Marshall, Chief of Staff of the Army, according to Stephen T. Early, White House Secretary, who said today that the visit would be chiefly military.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- A movement to have a city-wide 11 P.M. curfew adopted in Philadelphia for teen-age girls and service men, which was begun Friday by the June grand jury in its final report, won the support today of the heads of the Philadelphia Federation of Women's Clubs and Allied Organizations and of the Philadelphia Home and School Council.

Engineers and business leaders are beginning to say that the new post-war age of miracles is being overdone. Invention, spurred on by the war, will of course bring us new conveniences, comforts, and even luxuries for the enhancement of life, but we are now being cautioned that these things will not come twenty-four hours after the armistice.

NUTLEY, N.J., July 5 -- The American plan of life encompassing equality and freedom for all "cannot exist in a world half free, half oppressed," Governor Charles Edison of New Jersey declared tonight at Old Home Day celebration at Park Oval where he urged that the nation resolved "to maintain the ideals of 1776."

Tomorrow six years will have passed since the Japanese loosed their aggression against the Chinese by attacking at the Marco Polo Bridge. During these six years our oldest ally, reckoned retrospectively, has given millions of lives, civilian and military, to keep her independence.
LONDON, July 5 (AP) -- The Russian noon communique, as recorded by the Soviet monitor:
ST. LOUIS, July 5 -- The Yanks took two games from the Browns before 15,357 fans today, one of them a contest that had been awarded to Luke Sewell's dashing gang.

OTTAWA, July 5 -- Prime Minister W.L. Mackenzie King retorted vigorously today in the House of Commons to the Progressive Conservative party leader, John Bracken, for having said in a speech in Toronto that the Dominion Government policy was one of "political cowardice" and that the Canadian home-defense army was "a hoax."
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- An important post was created today in the Army Air Forces for Miss Jacqueline Cochran, indicating that increased war activity for women pilots might be in prospect.
ALLIED HEADQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, July 4 (U.P.) -- The noon Allied communique:

In reappointing Dr. Harry J. Carman for a second term as a member of the Board of Higher Education, Mayor La Guardia has shown commendable wisdom and foresight. Both the school system and the city will profit by the penetrating and sympathetic understanding toward educational problems displayed by Dr. Carman.

" Natal has become a springboard to a United Nations victory and the Good Neighbor policy has taken on a new meaning," declared Dr. Belisario de Souza, Brazilian journalist, at a luncheon yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria. Twelve Brazilian publishers now completing a tour of this country were honor guests at the luncheon, which was given by Don Francesco, director radio division of the office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs.

Hundreds of thousands of pleasure-seeking New Yorkers who had spent the long holiday week-end at the shore or in the country all started for home yesterday afternoon and evening, thereby placing the heaviest burden ever known upon the railroads and bus lines serving the metropolitan area.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (U.P.) -- Gerald L.K. Smith, director of the America First party, said in a statement tonight:

MOSCOW, Tuesday, July 6 (AP) -- It is difficult yet to say with precision just what the German objective is in launching the Orel-Kursk-Belgorod area drives, but the immediate aim seems to be to cut off the Russian bulge in the German lines around the Russian-held city of Kursk.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- In another move to ease shortages of essential civilian goods, the War Production Board amended its regulations governing production of cutlery today to promote production of the most essential civilian, commercial, industrial and household uses, in addition to meeting military requirements.
LONDON, July 5 -- The markets here opened today on a cheerful note and trading showed an increase in activity.

The block-by-block canvass to spur enlistment of women in the Women's Army Corps and of 17-year-old boys as aviation cadets of the Army Air Forces is well under way in the counties of Southern New York, and estimates of its success will be reported at the end of the week, it was revealed yesterday by Third Officer Vera Johnson of the Wac recruiting office, in charge of reports for this district.

What is most important in preventing inflation is to make sure that the excess purchasing power that would otherwise remain in the hands of the civil population in wartime is siphoned off by taxes and by purchase of Government bonds out of real savings.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 5 -- Varied overhead conditions cut the fleet to thirty-seven starters today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixty-second annual regatta. At that there were full finishes, with Arthur Knapp leading the Internationals in Bill Luders' Four Winds and Phil Patton again showing the way home to the other Class S sloops with his Kandahar.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- "Torpedo Town" was an 18-hole suburban golf course only sixteen months ago.

PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Two weeks after it started the big coal strike was near an end today, officials of the United Mine Workers reported, as thousands more men returned to the pits in response to union appeals and the lure of overtime pay on the Independence Day holiday.

" I wish I could do something"; this has been my motto for several weeks now. I am not a citizen yet, but I am a whole-hearted American, 19 years old, and more or less growing up in this country, calling it nothing but home.

Realty dealing in and around Newark, N.J., is showing considerable activity this season, according to the Abeles-Stevens brokerage firm. That office announces the sale of the taxpayer structure with five stores at 68-72 Market Street for the Prudential Insurance Company of America to the Seventy Market Corporation, represented by Charles Kanter.

BERNE, Switzerland, July 5 -- Neither the German radio nor press tonight had any thing to say on the subject of the renewed German offensive on the Eastern Front in the Orel, Kursk and Belgorod sectors.

Presenting Chief of Government Pierre Laval as a "peasant" and "patriot" who was trying to save Frenchmen from themselves, German propagandists in France quoted him yesterday as appealing to Frenchmen not to take up widespread guerrilla warfare against the Germans when Europe was invaded.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Renewing a plea he made last autumn, Senator Pepper of Florida has asked Prentiss M. Brown, Federal Price Administrator, to recommend removal of Florida from Rationing District 1, embracing seventeen Eastern States, to District 2, where rationing of gasoline is less stringent than in the Eastern area.

CHICAGO, July 5 (U.P.) -- Railroad officials said today that shortage of railroad cars to move wheat from grain-producing States will become serious this week unless unloading efforts at terminals prove successful during the three-day holiday.

Taking a leaf from the Army chaplains' program of using music to stimulate the recovery of hospital patients, the Richmond Memorial Hospital, Dreyfus Foundation, announced yesterday that its operation of a similar plan had shown a marked therapeutic value.

CHUNGKING, July 5 (U.P.) -- Chinese military sources said today that German technicians had been arriving in increasing numbers in Japan to speed her aircraft and shipping production in exchange for vital raw materials transported to the Reich in large cargo submarines.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- With nearly as many strap-hangers as sitters, scores of trains and buses from seashore resorts were strained to their utmost tonight to transport some 200,000 Philadelphians back to the city.

Some time may still elapse before the heavens are darkened by swarms of aerial freight trains gliding to distant ports across the seven seas. Yet the first train from America, towed through 3,500 miles of Atlantic storms, has just unloaded its cargo in England. It was only a one-glider train.

Independent slaughterers who have offered to supply meats on consignment to retailers for sale at or below Office of Price Administration ceiling prices accepted yesterday Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia's offer to test in the courts the rejection of the packers' proposal by OPA.

JERSEY CITY, July 5 (AP) -- Jersey City and Newark divided a double-header today, the Little Giants winning the opener, 5 -- 2, with the Bears coming back to snap a three-game losing streak in the nightcap by the identical score.
LONDON, July 5 -- Col. Victor A. Cazalet was an authority on internatonal affairs, a popular member of the House of Commons and a veteran of World War I.
OTTAWA, July 5 (U.P.) -- The National War Labor Board has agreed to an interim increase in the wages paid to underground miners in the Edmonton and Carbon areas, it was announced tonight.

The dessert recipes presented here today, and tested in THE NEW YORK TIMES' kitchen, were assembled with hot weather in mind. They are cooling in effect, not too filling and, perhaps best of all, require none of that extensive cooking that can heat a "cliff dweller's" kitchen in a most uncomfortable way.

ALLIED HEADQQUARTERS IN AUSTRALIA, Tuesday, July 6 (AP) -- American fighters battled a numerically superior force of forty Japanese Zeros over newly conquered Rendova Island Monday and downed two, increasing enemy plane losses there to 157, the High Command announced today.

Announcement was made yesterday by Edmond B. Butler, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, that the architects had been selected for the six public housing projects in the post-war program of the Housing Authority.

LONDON, July 5 -- The industrial heart of Cologne has "ceased to beat" as a result of the big Royal Air Force raids the nights of June 28 and July 3, but the famous Cologne Cathedral appeared to have escaped with only "some roof damage" on the north transept, Air Ministry officials said tonight after examination of reconnaissance photographs.
NEW DELHI, India, July 5 (AP) -- Liberators of the United States Tenth Air Force bombed the jetty at Akyab and attacked the Shweli bridge in Northern Burma yesterday, a communique announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The War Department announced today the award of 190 decorations to officers and enlisted men of the United States Army Tenth Air Force operating in India. Two of the air heroes are listed as having been killed in action and one in an airplane crash.

BASEBALL'S biggest mystery of the season has been the Chicago Cubs. Long before the campaign opened the Gents Who Know Things were confiding to unwary listeners: "Don't breathe a word of this to a soul, but the Cubs are the real dark horses of the year. Watch them. They are going to sneak right past the Cards and the Brooks and win the National League pennant."

Advertising linage in eight New York newspapers registered an increase of 20 per cent in June over the like 1942 period, according to a compilation based on Media Records figures. All the papers showed gains.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Army-Navy Production Award has been given to twenty-two additional industrial plants and three war construction projects.

VALLETTA, Malta, July 5 (Reuter) -- Six members of the crew of an American Liberator that recently crashed into the sea when returning from a bombing raid on the Lecce airfield in Italy were rescued by a British mine-layer after having drifted in dinghies ninety miles off the North African coast for four and a half hours.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- President Roosevelt maintains that agencies now governing civil aviation are "working satisfactorily" and that their present status should not be disturbed.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 6 -- Germany opened a heavy offensive yesterday on a 160-mile front in the Orel, Kursk and Belgorod sector and lost 586 tanks, 203 planes and thousands of men in the first few hours of savage fighting, Russia announced today.
